title: Review/Recital; Byron Janis, 40 Years After Carnegie Hall Debut
description: Forty-five years ago, when he was 15 years old, Byron Janis made his first impression on the musical world, playing Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto with the NBC Symphony. Five years later, by then a protege of Vladimir Horowitz, the young pianist made his recital debut at Carnegie Hall and embarked on a career that has been a long roller-coaster ride of exhilarating ups and sickening downs. The recital he gave at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Carnegie event, must rank as one of the decided ups.

title: Books of The Times; Gifts That Convey Regard But Not the Obligation
description: ''People seldom read a book that is given to them,'' Samuel Johnson said. If this is true, then the solution might be to give books that people don't have to read. The books in this list, arranged according to cost, do have a word or two in them, but they are to be looked at as well as read and will instantly convey your high regard for the recipient.

title: San Diego Freeways Termed Deathtraps for Illegal Aliens
description: Freeways in southern San Diego County are increasingly becoming deathtraps for illegal aliens who try to cross them at night on their journey north, the California Highway Patrol says.

title: U.S. Should Keep Faith With the Afghan Rebels
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Consulate Firebombed In Arab Sector of Jerusalem
description: Two firebombs were thrown at the United States Consulate in predominantly Arab East Jerusalem today, four days after the United States denied the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, a visa to speak at the United Nations in New York.

title: Oppenheimer Capital LP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The partnership began operating July 9, 1987. For the period from July 9 through Oct. 31, 1987, it said it earned $3,201,000, or 40 cents a unit, on $3,360,000 in revenue. The share earnings are in units.

title: City Clerk Sentenced In Embezzling Case
description: A former part-time city clerk was sentenced yesterday to four months in prison for embezzling $170,000 from the White Plains City Court over the last 10 years.

title: As a Critic, BBC Cellist Is Smashing
description: Timothy Hugh ended his latest performance with a flourish of splintering wood when he flung a cello to the ground and jumped on it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Fenech Retains Title: Jeff Fenech, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, disposed of his American challenger, Georgie Navarro, with a knockout in the fifth round last night in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Strengthening a Frail Canterbury Stand
description: LEAD: The word canterbury refers to a small stand with several open-topped partitions and a drawer below, usually supported on short tapered, turned or rectangular legs. Said to have been named after the English cleric for whom one was made in 1806, the canterbury was designed to hold sheet music.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Michelle Pleskow has been named senior vice president/group management supervisor at Barry Blau & Partners Inc., Fairfield, Conn., a direct-response advertising agency.

title: Mexican Chief's Long List of Woes
description: Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who will be sworn in Thursday to a six-year term as Mexico's President, faces a host of grave economic problems that demand immediate action.

title: Man Who Sued Musicians Dies After Coma
description: A man who sued the rock group Judas Priest, contending that its music drove him to a suicide attempt in 1985, has died after lapsing into an unexplained coma.

title: Fossils Date Use of Fires 1 Million Years
description: Archeologists in South Africa have turned up the earliest direct evidence of the use of fire: fossilized animal bones apparently charred in ancient campfires from 1 million to 1.5 million years ago.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Off Slightly
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products in November declined slightly from a month earlier but remained nearly 8 percent above their level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Shuttle Is Poised for Launching Today
description: Despite a threat of high winds and rain, techicians pressed ahead today with the countdown for launching the space shuttle Atlantis on a secret military mission Thursday morning.

title: The Milquetoast Presidency
description: President-elect Bush won a solid mandate, but will find it difficult to govern, though not for the reason so often put forth -a recalcitrant Democratic Congress. Actually, his greatest troubles will emerge from within his own administration.

title: CUC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Q&A
description: Q. I had an addition built on my house with a four-foot-wide picture window. The sill is rotting out. Must I put in a whole new window, or could a carpenter replace the sill only?

title: Bronx Leader Salutes Embattled P.S. 53
description: The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, stood at the edge of a stage yesterday in Public School 53, whose principal was arrested on a crack-possession charge, and three times he asked the rows of students before him, ''Are we going to be drug-free?''

title: Legislator Loses 2d Bid for Seat
description: The Florida Supreme Court today rejected a lawsuit in which a longtime Democratic Congressman, Bill Chappell Jr., sought to reverse his failure to win re-election by having nearly 11,000 ballots thrown out.

title: Chinese Visit Aims to Break The Soviet Ice
description: The first working visit to Moscow by a Chinese Foreign Minister since 1956 will begin here Thursday, as the world's two largest Communist countries seek to erase the last vestiges of the bitter estrangement that has divided them for three decades.

title: District of Columbia Closer to Accepting AIDS Testing Order
description: The District of Columbia City Council is moving toward final passage of Congressionally ordered legislation that would allow insurance companies to test all applicants for health care coverage to determine if they have the AIDS virus.

title: Initial Offerings In Robins Case
description: The director of the $2.4 billion trust for victims of the Dalkon Shield birth control device made by the A.H. Robins Company yesterday announced the initial settlements that would be offered by the trust.

title: Pakistan's Elected Assembly Meets and Applauds Bhutto
description: The newly elected National Assembly convened today, returning Pakistan to democracy.

title: Life in the 30's
description: HER name is Maria. She was born on Tuesday, Nov. 22. ''Tuesday's child is full of grace,'' the nursery rhyme says. It's too soon to tell about that, although she does have remarkably pretty hands, long-fingered and oddly elegant. She was big at birth, just over nine pounds, and she came with a full head of very thick, very black hair, so that at times she appears to be wearing a bad toupee. She is our first daughter, and our third child.

title: Currents; Couture for Furniture: Fashion Designer's Upholstery
description: BARBARA MUNVES, the owner of James II, an antiques shop at 15 East 57th Street, has long been enamored of clothes by the fashion designer Koos van den Akker. His signature look - collages of fabrics - attracted her most.

title: Review/Television; At a Distance, Trying to Save Endangered Rhinos
description: Tonight's edition of ''48 Hours'' turns out to be only mildly adventurous. The report at 8 o'clock on CBS, ''48 Hours in the Rhino War,'' begins excitingly enough with a troop of Zimbabwean rangers tracking poachers from neighboring Zambia who have been killing off black rhinoceroses at a devastating rate. Twenty years ago, we learn, 70,000 rhinos lumbered around Zimbabwe, then known as Rhodesia; today, there are fewer than 4,000.

title: Review/Dance; The Forces of Nature Unleashed, but Slowly
description: Eiko and Koma, the Japanese-born choreographers and dancers, create dreamlike productions performed in hypnotic slow motion. Yet, though their dances may seem like visions, their subject matter derives from the real world about us. The forces of nature moved - sometimes serenely, sometimes ferociously - in the two works they presented Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: ENGINEER DISPUTES JET CRASH THEORY
description: A Boeing engineer testified today that the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed on takeoff here on Aug. 31 should have been able to keep flying even if, as much evidence indicates, the wing flaps were not properly extended.

title: Sailor Killed on U.S. Carrier
description: An American sailor was killed and another seriously burned on the aircraft carrier Nimitz in the northern Arabian Sea when shots were accidentally fired from one jet plane and hit another, the Pentagon said today. At least six aircraft were damaged in the resulting blaze, which occurred early today, local time, a Defense Department spokesman said. ''The fire apparently started when a gun on an A-7E aircraft fired during routine maintenance, which resulted in a round striking an A-6 aircraft, starting the fire,'' the spokesman added.

title: School Board Bill Gaining in Albany
description: Lawmakers said today they were confident that a bill to prohibit political leaders and school-district employees from serving on community school boards would be approved by the Legislature this week.

title: Israel Convicts Jewish Settler In the Killing of a Shepherd
description: An Israeli court today found an American-born immigrant guilty of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a Palestinian shepherd near a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank, Israeli radio reported.

title: ATI Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INSIDE
description: Toll in Soviet Clashes at 28

title: Chip Panel Head Named
description: President Reagan announced on Tuesday that he would name Ian M. Ross, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories, as chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors. The announcement said Mr. Reagan would appoint Mr. Ross as a member of the committee and he would be designated as chairman.

title: Drug Seizure Policy Defended
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration said today that it planned no change in procedures under which it sometimes arranges for local police officers to claim public credit for seizures of drug shipments that are brought into the United States by the agency's undercover operatives.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. announced a technology exchange agreement with the Actel Corporation, a small semiconductor company that makes computer chips that users can customize themselves. Under the agreement, Texas Instruments will make chips incorporating Actel's technology and resell Actel's computer-aided engineering system under its own name. Actel, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will gain access to Texas Instruments' manufacturing technology. Actel is expected to name John East, a former vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., as its new president on Thursday.

title: The Real Stakes In the Arafat Fiasco
description: The outcry surrounding the decision to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, which he sought in order to address the United Nations, blurs the real issues at stake for the United States. What has become an embarrassing international incident is largely a result of a new Soviet policy in the Middle East. Once again, Washington is reacting to events rather than shaping them.

title: Troops in France Ferry Strike-Bound Commuters
description: The French Government used hundreds of soldiers and military trucks today to ferry suburban commuters into Paris as transport strikes left hundreds of thousands of commuters stranded.

title: A Sun-Times Pact Snag
description: Negotiators for The Chicago Sun-Times and its newsroom employees today scheduled another round of contract negotiations after a clause on pension-fund contributions jeopardized their tentative labor pact.

title: Drexel Case: Tough Issues Block Accord
description: Difficult issues must be resolved before Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. can reach a plea-bargaining agreement with Federal prosecutors, people involved in the discussions said yesterday.

title: Texaco Guilty in Rig Case
description: Texaco Inc. today agreed to plead guilty to Federal felony charges and pay a $750,000 fine in a case stemming from a failure to test safety equipment on an offshore oil rig.

title: Harvey Berin, 90, Manufacturer Of Dresses on 7th Avenue, Is Dead
description: LEAD: Harvey Berin, a dress manufacturer on Seventh Avenue for almost 50 years, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: Currents; Open-Air Benefit On Madison
description: MADISON AVENUE will be closed to cars and buses from 66th to 72d Streets on Sunday from noon until 5 P.M., while shops open for a charitable shopping event called the Madison Avenue Christmas for Children.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Gas Pipelines From Canada Win Support
description: An administrative law judge at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission yesterday recommended the construction of two natural gas pipelines from Canada that would increase imports of Canadian gas by about 20 percent.

title: Stanhope Hotel Sold to a Japanese Concern
description: The resplendent Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, across the street from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been purchased by a Japanese real-estate and construction concern, officials said yesterday.

title: The Value of Homework
description: To The Home Section:

title: Canada Judge Orders Extradition of Man in U.S. Sex Slayings
description: A Canadian judge ordered today that a former United States marine charged in a string of sex murders in California be extradited to the United States, where he could face the death penalty if convicted.

title: For Gorbachev, Met Museum And Trump Tower Visits Due
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is tentatively scheduled to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Trump Tower during his trip to New York next week, the Soviet Mission to the United Nations said yesterday, and Donald Trump plans to show Mr. Gorbachev a swimming pool inside a $19 million apartment.

title: Authors to Read Works Of Imprisoned Writers
description: To commemorate the 40th anniversary of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, a group of American writers and playwrights is to hold a reading next Wednesday of work by writers imprisoned around the world.

title: Guggenheim Names Curator
description: Germano Celant, an Italian art critic and freelance curator internationally known for large-scale and ambitious exhibitions in Italy, France, West Germany, the United States and Canada, is joining the staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York as curator of contemporary art on Jan. 1.

title: Metro Matters; The Time Clocks, The Chancellor And Symbolism
description: Dr. Richard R. Green, the beleaguered New York City Schools Chancellor, finally can claim a modest success today. It's about time.

title: Spec's Music Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company adopted SFAS 96 during the latest first quarter, which increased earnings by $206,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Sharper Image Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Long-Distance Rate Cuts Set
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would lower its basic interstate long-distance rates by an average of 3.8 percent on Thursday, the same day that local phone costs go up by 60 cents a month.

title: Geonex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Police Training Being Revised After Cadet's Death
description: A plan to revamp the training of the state's law-enforcement officers was approved today by the Criminal Justice Training Council in the aftermath of the death of a police cadet.

title: Paris Exhibit Asks: What Is a Chateau?
description: SOME years ago I tagged along with a group of Americans who were touring the Bordeaux wine country. Doctors, lawyers and their spouses, they were members of a suburban wine club. The French, thinking these Americans were truly knowledgeable, took them from one chateau to another to see fermenting tanks, aging barrels, wine stocks and bottling lines.

title: Complaints About School Boards Pour In
description: The arrest of a Bronx school principal on a drug charge three weeks ago and the subsequent suspension of his local school board have triggered many complaints -most of them anonymous - against members of other school boards, law-enforcement officials have said.

title: E.P.A. Seeks Stiff Rules on Storm Sewers in Cities
description: Cities with a population of more than 100,000 will be required to obtain Federal permits if they want to discharge waste into storm sewers, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

title: Justice for Oliver North
description: In his Administration's dwindling days, President Reagan is pressed in two ways to spare Oliver North a trial on charges of conspiracy and cover-up in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Hijack Convoy Of U.N. Aid for Rival Rebel Area
description: The first United Nations relief convoy taking medical and agricultural supplies from Kabul to areas held by guerrilla forces was hijacked at gunpoint Saturday by a rival guerrilla group.

title: Walesa, in Debate on Unions, Urges End to Remnants of Stalinism
description: Lech Walesa, making his first appearance on Polish television in five years, declared tonight that Poland could find prosperity only by casting off the ''tail end of Stalinism.''

title: A Deadline Near, Legislators Demand New Shoreham Pact
description: Key state legislators said today that they would not support the proposed settlement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island without major changes in the deal. Their stand made approval of the agreement before Thursday's deadline appear unlikely.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 23 about a British move to block distribution of a magazine misstated the British Government's position. The magazine carries excerpts from a book by a former secret service agent, Anthony Cavendish, and the Government maintains that the book violates a lifelong obligation of confidentiality by an intelligence agent. It has not cited a violation of the Official Secrets Act. The article also misstated the book title. It is ''Inside Intelligence.''

title: Pressing Questions for Giants
description: The Giants, after their 13-12 last-minute victory over the New Orleans Saints on Sunday night, can qualify for the National Football League playoffs if they win their last three games, starting with the Phoenix Cardinals here Sunday. But they must deal with some pressing questions:

title: St. James's Club: Hollywood's Golden Era Lives
description: LEAD: THE elevator stops, and David Bowie steps out into the lobby of the St. James's Club, a luxurious hotel set in the newly renovated Sunset Towers, one of the finest examples of Art Deco architecture in Los Angeles. It is a building, and a way of life, that Los Angeles almost lost.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Industry Gets 2 New Magazines
description: Hope springs eternal among some in the advertising community for new magazines to supplement the two leaders, Adweek and Advertising Age. Ken Smikle and David J. Breznau are turning those hopes into reality.

title: Senators Ask Bush to Reject New Curb on Benefits
description: Thirty-five senators, including the entire Democratic Senate leadership, today asked President-elect Bush to repudiate proposed restrictions on the rights of the elderly and disabled to appeal Government decisions denying benefits under Social Security, Medicare and welfare.

title: Offering in U.S. From Australia
description: The Victorian Public Authorities Finance Agency of Australia is offering in the United States a $150 million issue of 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 1993 at a price of 99.70 to yield 9.547 percent via Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Filion Sets Mark
description: Herve Filion posted two victories in 10 races at Freehold (N.J.) Raceway yesterday afternoon to tie Mike Lachance's 1986 record of 770 victories in one year, and then broke the mark by winning the second race with Tim Hershey ($5.80) at Yonkers Raceway last night.

title: Review/Music; One Band's Scruffy, Sloppy, Solid Rock
description: Keith Richards's concert Tuesday at the Beacon Theater was raucous, scruffy, unkempt and often out-of-tune. It was also inspired rock and roll.

title: GROWTH RATE SLOWING IN MOST OF U.S.
description: The nation's economy is growing at a slower rate in most regions than in recent months, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Currents; The 'Magic' Behind Bergdorf's Windows
description: ALTHOUGH midtown Christmas decorations appear each season as if by magic, many require over a year of planning. Take the lush boxwood shrubs framing Bergdorf Goodman's 17 windows along Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street.

title: Pakistan Attache Is Arrested By India on Spying Charges
description: India arrested Pakistan's military attache today after catching him red-handed with a sensitive defense document, a Government spokesman said.

title: Ophthalmology: Eye Protection Urged After New Study Links Cataracts to Sun Rays
description: A study of people who work on the waters of Chesapeake Bay has provided the most definitive evidence yet that prolonged exposure to the ultraviolet radiation in sunlight increases the risk of cataracts.

title: Wrap-Up of Gifts For Home at the Holidays
description: THE holiday shopping Olympics have started. But this year, buying for the homebody is a piece of cake. Department stores and small shops are brimming with imaginative and enticing wares, both functional and frivolous.

title: U.S. Gets Deadline From U.N. on Barring Arafat
description: The General Assembly today gave the United States 24 hours to reverse a decision to bar Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, from addressing the Assembly here.

title: Study Says Drug Use Is Wide in New York
description: More than 3.5 million New York adults have used drugs at some point in their lives, a survey showed yesterday.

title: Metro Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $131,000 for the quarter and $614,000 for the 6 months.

title: Teamster Denies Tampering With Votes at Job
description: A shop steward for a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that he did not tamper with the votes of his fellow workers in the first contested election in 25 years at the local, which in the past was dominated by organized crime.

title: F.T.C. Head Asks Change
description: Insurance companies and agricultural cooperatives should be subject to the same antitrust laws as other businesses, the head of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: There Needn't Be a Fund Shortage to Restore 42d St. Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: RJR Nabisco Suitor Claims $24.88 Billion Victory
description: In one of the roughest, most confusing and dramatic finales to a takeover battle, the small but powerful buyout firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company claimed victory late last night in the contest for RJR Nabisco Inc. with a staggering offer of $24.88 billion, the largest sum ever paid for a corporation.

title: Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Hangings Now the Routine at Pretoria Prison
description: The family and friends of the condemned men trickled into the prison waiting room to spend a last hour with their loved ones. The brief encounter was the only comfort they took away, for at dawn the next morning the five men were hanged.

title: BRITAIN PLANNING NEW SECRETS LAW
description: The British Government introduced legislation today that would make unauthorized disclosure of information by a member of the security or intelligence services a prima facie criminal offense, punishable by up to two years in prison and a fine.

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings for the year- earlier periods have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Baffling Rise of Intestinal Disorder in the Young
description: Crohn's disease, a serious disorder of the intestines, appears to be increasing sharply among children, a trend that may reflect some unknown influence of Western industrial civilization, a British scientist said yesterday at a scientific symposium in Houston.

title: Currents; Anthology Of Famous Rooms
description: STEPHEN CALLOWAY'S ''Twentieth Century Decoration'' (Rizzoli, $100) is a design book in the best sense. Its author, the curator in the department of design, prints and drawings at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, charts the century's tastes with pictures and illustrations of the most famous rooms of their time.

title: 300 Miles From a K Mart, Boredom Is Enemy
description: Never mind drug smugglers and illegal aliens: for United States Customs inspectors at this outpost on the Alaska Highway, the biggest enemy is boredom.

title: Absent With Excuse
description: The Downtown Athletic Club has invited five players to attend the announcement Saturday of its Heisman Trophy winner as the nation's top college football player. Two can't make it to the party, including the favorite, Barry Sanders of Oklahoma State.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Intelligence; The Webster Watch: Director's Tenure Debated
description: Several months before the election, George Bush was telling associates that as President he intended to keep William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, as a means of re-establishing the tradition that the intelligence post was a nonpartisan job.

title: Dispute on Sprinklers Delays San Juan Hotel's Reopening
description: The Dupont Plaza Hotel, where 97 people were killed in a New Year's Eve fire in 1986, has postponed its reopening indefinitely in a dispute over installing automatic sprinklers.

title: 2 California Utilities Set To Merge
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company agreed today to merge with the parent of the Southern California Edison Company in a stock deal valued at more than $2.4 billion.

title: Diana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 15
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $408,000 from the writeoff of deferred debt issuance costs. c-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months results include non-recurring gains of $555,000 and $1,873,000, respectively, from the company's Entre Corp. unit, reflecting the reverse for the provision of an anticipated loss on a sale which did not occur.

title: Suspension for Antley
description: Chris Antley, a 22-year-old jockey who was the nation's leading rider in 1985 with 469 winning mounts, has been suspended by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, effective last Monday, for having an illegal controlled substance in his system.

title: Interco Sends Out Part of Dividends
description: Interco Inc. mailed the cash portion of the special dividends it had declared to ward off a hostile takeover. The special dividends amounted to $38.60 for each share of Interco common stock. The company said checks in the amount of $14.221 a share were being mailed to shareholders of record as of the close of business on Oct. 13, and checks for $24.379 are being sent to shareholders of record as of Nov. 22. Interco's stock closed today at $29.625 on the New York Stock Exchange after closing at $67.75 on Tuesday. Until today, the stock had been trading with ''due bills,'' which require the seller to pay the dividend amount to the buyer as soon as it is received.

title: National Technical Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Found in Laundry Room: a Stolen Masterpiece
description: An oil painting by Manet that was stolen from a Long Island museum on Sunday was recovered undamaged today after a thief who sounded remorseful called the Suffolk County police and told them where to find it.

title: The Pressure on President Salinas
description: The honeymoon is already over for Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who today takes office as President of Mexico. Per capita income is shrinking. The ruling party's grip has been shaken. And Mr. Salinas' own election in July remains disputed.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Truth Reclaimed in the Baltic
description: The best way to grasp what is happening in the Baltic republics is to go there and sense the exhilaration of peoples finally able to discuss a haunted past. For those unable to make the trip, there is ''The Captive Mind,'' by Czeslaw Milosz. It was published in 1953, after the author left Poland but long before his poetry won him a Nobel Prize.

title: SNL Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cypress Fund reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Assets represent total net assets. The company said latest fourth quarter and year investment losses were $71,798 and $21,901, respectively. The year-ago periods' investment income was $60,597, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter, and $1,109,095, or 12 cents a share, for the year.

title: Navy Overhauling an Ailing Health Care System
description: The Navy has quietly begun a major overhaul of its health care system intended to rebuild morale, treat more patients at its own hospitals and clinics and attract and train more doctors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Smithsonian's Plans For Ad History Center
description: Long ignored or reviled by scholars, advertising is taking a long leap into intellectual respectability with the Smithsonian Institution's announcement that it is establishing a Center for Advertising History at its National Museum of American History.

title: Analog Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you can find it on the spending side, God bless you.'' - Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, on reducing the budget deficit without raising taxes. [ B16:5. ]

title: Driver Says Myerson Called The Wife of Capasso 'Evil'
description: A witness testified yesterday that Bess Myerson described her companion's estranged wife as an ''evil woman'' who would get his money only ''over her dead body.''

title: Review/Dance; Canada's 'Synonym for Ballet' Has Gala on Her 20th Anniversary
description: Unlike Wayne Gretzky, Karen Kain did not defect from Canada to the United States. In apparent gratitude Tuesday night, Canadians honored their most famous ballerina with a highly unusual 20th anniversary gala, ''Celebrating Kain!''

title: Sutton Ouster Urged
description: The student newspaper at the University of Kentucky published an editorial yesterday urging that the basketball coach, Eddie Sutton, and his entire coaching staff step down at the end of the season.

title: RJR Nabisco Suitor Claims $24.88 Billion Victory
description: In one of the roughest, most confusing and dramatic finales to a takeover battle, the small but powerful buyout firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company claimed victory late last night in the contest for RJR Nabisco Inc. with a staggering offer of $24.88 billion, the largest sum ever paid for a corporation.

title: Dolphin Suspended
description: The National Football League suspended Mark Brown of the Miami Dolphins for one game yesterday as additional punishment for a late hit. Brown was ejected from the game Sunday against the Jets after hitting the quarterback Pat Ryan in the head. Brown came at Ryan with his forearms high and made contact after the quarterback had thrown the ball. Brown will miss the game Sunday against Indianapolis. (AP)

title: Fox's Blue-Collar Comedy vs. ABC's: No Contest
description: Al Bundy sells women's shoes and hates the work. He once told a customer her feet resembled ''rib roasts with nails.'' He and his spendthrift wife, Peggy, are always barking at each other. She's a miserable housewife; he's a pathetic provider. Their two teen-agers are the sort you worry more about keeping out of prison than getting into college.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Money for a Holiday Party Goes to the Neediest Instead
description: A Manhattan law firm, Breed Abbott & Morgan, decided this year to forgo the annual holiday party for its lawyers and staff and to contribute the estimated cost to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead. The company sent a gift of $15,000.

title: Oneida Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend effective Nov. 15, 1988.

title: Electricity Eases Dependence on Imported Oil; Oil-Shale Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: Sporting Life Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a tax credit of $165,000.

title: Vornado Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
A. Brad Truax, Physician, 42
description: Dr. A. Brad Truax, a physician active in advocating laws protecting people with AIDS from discrimination, died Tuesday of complications from the disease. He was 42 years old. A former Navy flight surgeon, Dr. Truax was appointed in 1983 to the Mayor's Task Force on AIDS, which became the county's advisory committee on issues relating to the disease. He was a delegate to the 1980 Democratic National Convention.

title: Volcker Warns Deficit Is Threat to Markets
description: Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the Federal budget deficits threaten to bring recurring turmoil to the stock and currency markets and ''the kind of recession that would be most difficult to handle.'' He indicated that he doubted the deficit could be controlled without raising taxes.

title: Kinder? Gentler? Not for Aliens
description: LEAD: As President-elect Bush sets out to create his vision of ''a kinder and gentler America,'' he would do well to consider proposed regulations published in October by the board of directors of the Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed agency charged with providing legal services to the poor.

title: Handmade Ornaments From Christmas Past
description: I THINK it's this whole resurgence of interest in the traditional,'' said Pat Ross, explaining why reproductions of Victorian Christmas ornaments, handmade of paper, glass, tin, fabric and silver, are so popular this year. Her shop, Sweet Nellie, carries dainty paper ornaments trimmed with lace and Santas with handpainted faces.

title: McGraw-Hill Adds Unit
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the assets of the college and school divisions of Random House Inc. for about $200 million in cash. As a result, McGraw-Hill will become one of the largest publishers of educational books.

title: Jersey's Hopes For Riverfront Are Faltering
description: One of the nation's most sweeping urban redevelopments, the transformation of 18 miles of New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront, has stumbled over what led to its original advantage - the fortunes of New York City's financial industry.

title: Structofab Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Milk Bill Backers Fail To Upset Cuomo Veto
description: The New York State Senate failed today to override Governor Cuomo's veto of a bill that would have prohibited milk dealers from using ''coercion'' to lure farmers away from a dairy cooperative.

title: Becker Regains Spark As He Beats Wilander
description: At age 21, Boris Becker understands that the road to No. 1 can be littered with double faults, misplayed groundstrokes and netted volleys. Four years ago, he was the heir apparent, an uninhibited teen-ager moving up in the top 10 like a New Yorker shouldering past pedestrians on a crowded Manhattan street. Now, he is more willing to wait his turn, learning to enjoying success and not be devastated in defeat.

title: Bogen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Chrysler Sales Milestone
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had sold its two millionth vehicle of 1988, the fourth straight year with sales of more than two million cars and trucks.

title: Child World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a gain of $2,853,000 from an accounting change. Prior year 9-month results were restated for cumulative effect on prior years to change in method of valuing inventories.

title: Poetry and Art
description: There is not much poetry in the life of a Secretary of State. To remedy that condition, the Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies purchased an illustrated volume of American verse for George P. Shultz, the departing Secretary, and his wife, Obie.

title: Gas Fumes Injure 4 At a Plant in Jersey
description: Ammonia gas in a four-story plant injured four workers and forced the removal of 200 others yesterday, a fire official said.

title: Corections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Tuesday about the American Standard account misidentified the company's previous agency. It was Calet Hirsch & Spector, not Kornhauser & Calene.

title: Transit Driver Who Miscarried Wins Bias Case
description: A New York City bus driver who suffered a miscarriage after her request to be placed on restricted duty was denied was awarded $450,000 in compensation after hearings before the New York State Division of Human Rights.

title: Losers in Maryland Gun Vote Outspent the Winners 9 to 1
description: The National Rifle Association and other opponents of Maryland's gun control law spent nearly $6.6 million, nine times as much as the law's supporters, in an unsuccessful effort to repeal the law in the election Nov. 8.

title: Departure of Football Coach Gives Columbia Another Distressing Loss
description: First there was Jim Garrett, the one-season coach who lost his temper and his job when he denounced the 1985 Columbia football team as ''drug-addicted losers.''

title: Resilient Knicks Win in Overtime
description: The Knicks bounced back tonight from Tuesday's 20-point loss to the Nuggets, but they needed a few extra bounces to do it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about the former Alice's Restaurant in Stockbridge, Mass., misidentified the police officer who arrested the singer Arlo Guthrie for littering in 1965. He was William Obanhein.

title: Home Improvement
description: REPLACING a faulty wall switch is not as difficult as it might seem. In most cases, all you will need are a screwdriver, long-nose pliers, a replacement switch and a voltage tester, which consists of a small light bulb in a plastic holder with two insulated wire probes extending from it.

title: MEXICAN LEADER TAKES OVER TODAY
description: After a tumultuous election, Carlos Salinas de Gortari will begin a six-year term as President of Mexico on Thursday publicly committed to overhauling a battered economy and transforming a discredited political system.

title: N.H.L. Notebook; Union Is Warned About Its Insurance
description: Lloyd's of London, the insurance company that holds the National Hockey League's liability policy, has warned the N.H.L. players' union that public threats by the players to harm each other physically might jeopardize the policy.

title: Dominican Ex-Chief Returns To Contest Graft Conviction
description: Former President Salvador Jorge Blanco returned here today to fight his conviction on charges of corruption and was taken to jail.

title: Royals Sign Boone
description: The Kansas City Royals announced yesterday that they have signed the 16-year veteran catcher, Bob Boone, to a one-year contract. Boone, who hit a career-high .295 for the California Angels last year, will be called upon to solidify a position that has been unsettled on the Royals for several years. Boone, 41, is the major league leader in games caught with 2,056. He has won five Gold Gloves and made four All-Star teams. He spent the past seven seasons with California. Before that, he was with the Phillies' organization.(AP)

title: Carme Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a $35,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said year-ago first quarter results are restated to reflect cumulative effect of an accounting change and to adjust income taxes provided on a quarterly basis to recognize the limitations of charitable contributions and other tax items.

title: Two Cable Operations Are on Block
description: Two companies, the Centel Corporation and Dow Jones & Company, yesterday announced plans to sell their cable holdings.

title: House of Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Nets: From Bad to Worse
description: The Nets, who lost to the Celtics by 7 points at the Meadowlands on Tuesday, were routed by the Celtics in Boston last night, 133-100. Page D27.

title: Electricity Eases Dependence on Imported Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Job Applicants
description: There is heavy competition for the job of Secretary of Health and Human Services. ''Everybody in the world is lobbying for it,'' a White House aide said of the job.

title: David Siegal, 83, Restaurant Union Leader
description: David Siegal, a labor leader in the culinary trades, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old.

title: Peter Morrison, 53, Securities-Fraud Lawyer
description: Peter H. Morrison, a lawyer who was a prosecutor and, later, a defender of people accused of securities fraud, died of colon cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: Prospect of Tower at Pentagon Worries Some Ex-Colleagues
description: Former Senator John G. Tower's strong connections to Capitol Hill have helped make him a leading candidate for Secretary of Defense in the eyes of President-elect Bush. Paradoxically, however, Mr. Tower's long legislative record is causing considerable criticism by some of his old colleagues.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. named Ron W. Forrest to the newly created post of managing director, global business development, for its insurance broking companies.

title: Secret's Out: Ryan Will Start
description: Coach Joe Walton revealed today what he had confided to his quarterbacks last Monday: Pat Ryan will start Sunday at Kansas City while Ken O'Brien will back him up.

title: Review/Theater; Brooding Look at Dismal Lives in Wilson Revival
description: ''The Rimers of Eldritch'' is a dark, brooding contemplation of a small ghostly town frozen in time and place, the mid-century in the Middle West. In this 1966 play, now being revived by the Second Stage, Lanford Wilson looks behind the ''Spoon River Anthology'' exterior in order to expose the warring frustrations in these thwarted lives and, in so doing, he prefigures the movie ''Blue Velvet.'' At the same time, ''Rimers'' has its limpid, lyrical elements, as the author, early in his career, used the art of counterpoint to illuminate the people of Eldritch, a town that is itself an entrapment.

title: Bridge
description: One of the finest tournament streaks of all time was put together at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals that ended Sunday in Nashville. In eight days Jim Cayne of Manhattan and Chuck Burger of Southfield, Mich., won the Men's Board-a-Match Teams, finished third in the Blue Ribbon Pairs and won the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1988
description: Companies

title: Abdul-Jabbar Hurt
description: A severely bruised right knee sidelined Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers, last night before a game with the Seattle Supersonics, a team doctor said.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reagan to Bar Secret Material For North's Case
description: The White House today raised a potential roadblock to the prosecution of Oliver L. North for conspiracy in the Iran-contra case, saying it intends to stop the release of secret documents Mr. North wants to use in his defense.

title: Full-Size Designers, Miniature Mansion
description: A DOLLHOUSE donated by a child and decorated by seven New York interior designers will be among the offerings at the 33d annual art and antiques auction of the Irvington Institute for Medical Research Wednesday at Sotheby's.

title: Strong Aftershock Hits China
description: A powerful aftershock shook a remote area of southwestern China today, collapsing buildings damaged in an earthquake this month in which more than 700 people died.

title: TV Notes
description: Winners and Losers

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Holland Advertising Is Acquired by Lamar
description: The Lamar Corporation has added another conquest to its small empire of outdoor advertising agencies in the South and West by buying Holland Advertising of Beaumont, Tex., a full-service agency that specializes in poster ads.

title: Archive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brazatortas Journal; In Spain, Sheep Count the Days of Southern Sun
description: A sudden wind-driven sleet storm that blew across the Valle de Alcudia on a cold day forced Jose Diaz Pizarro and Angel Vinas back into the stone hut that is home and to the comfortable warmth of the fireplace.

title: Cambridge Journal; Budding Chefs Get a Lesson on Cooking, From an Expert
description: While Julia Child, television's French chef, wiggled a raw scrod out of its skin with a deft knife stroke, 16-year-old Mark D'Ambrosio stood next to her, hacking at his slippery fish, mangling it only slightly.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Last Christmas I gave my husband a special gift that, unlike the many sweaters, shirts, pajamas and gloves of the past, he could not say he neither needed nor wanted. I gave him my pledge to cook each week for a homeless shelter run by his favorite local charity. He said it was the most thoughtful gift I'd given him in 22 years, but to my surprise, it turned out to be even more of a present to myself.

title: PHILIPPINES EXPECTED TO FILE SUIT AGAINST WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Philippines will file a suit against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a New Jersey engineering firm on Thursday, accusing them of conspiring with former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and one of his relatives to obtain a contract to build a nuclear power plant near Manila, people knowledgeable about the case said today.

title: Include Us Out
description: ''The outcome of the Palestine National Council session in Algiers produced signs that there are Palestinians who are trying to move the P.L.O. in a constructive way. That is encouraging and should continue.''

title: Malrite Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $399,000.

title: KEY RATES
Indira Gandhi Killers To Be Hanged Friday
description: Two Sikhs condemned to death in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will be hanged Friday, Indian officials said here tonight.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is tentatively offering $177 million of 1987 service contract bonds for transit facilities and commuter facilities, with a maximum yield of about 8.09 percent for an issue due in 2018. The underwriters are led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Deadlines Downplayed
description: Legal experts said yesterday that the directors of RJR Nabisco who have been weighing the gigantic bids by three competing groups have no legal obligation to abide by the deadlines they have set and to put a halt to the unusual bidding war.

title: Commercial Credit Notes Yield 9.89%
description: The Commercial Credit Company is offering $150 million of 9 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.875 to yield 9.89 percent through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: LaPOINT TAKES TIME DECIDING By JOSEPH DURSO
description: Dave LaPoint said yesterday that the Yankees were ''primary contenders'' to sign him as a free agent. But he added that 8 to 10 other teams had expressed interest, and said that he had no intention of rushing into a contract until his price rose.

title: Seals Are Blamed in Leaks at Nuclear Plant
description: Leaky seals and gaskets caused a series of plutonium leaks at the Government's Savannah River Plant near Aiken, S.C., and more leaks could occur before the problem is fixed, scientists said today.

title: Firestone Tire
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its Japanese parent, the Bridgestone Corporation, will invest about $1.5 billion in the next three years to expand and modernize Firestone's tire operations and other businesses, the companies said. The companies will invest $1.3 billion in Firestone's tire operations - $1 billion in North America and $300 million in Europe, Central and South America - and $200 million on Firestone's diversified products and Master Care automotive service units.

title: Ailing U.S. Senator Improves
description: Senator Quentin Burdick's condition has been upgraded to stable and the North Dakota Democrat could be out of intensive care in a few days, doctors said today. The Senator, 80 years old, has been hospitalized since Sunday after suffering a seizure.

title: Comfed Bancorp Chief Heads Investor Group
description: Thomas D. O'Malley, a former vice chairman of Salomon Inc., has made some varied purchases since he set up his own investment firm two years ago.

title: Centel Is Awarded Administrative Contract From G.S.A.
description: The General Services Administration yesterday awarded the Centel Corporation a disputed contract to supervise telephone companies that will build the Government's new $25 billion telecommunications system.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resolution of a dispute between Fujitsu Ltd. and the International Business Machines Corporation misstated, in some editions, the amount still owed I.B.M. and the duration of one arbitrator's review of the case.

title: Swiss Company To Buy Rockaway
description: The Rockaway Corporation, a Parsippany, N.J., maker of business machines and mailing systems, agreed to be acquired by Ascom Holding A.G., a Swiss manufacturer of postage meters, for $16 a share, or a total of about $112 million. Rockaway's shares jumped $5 yesterday, to $14.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 51.9 percent gain was by far the largest of the day.

title: Bush Tells Environmentalists He'll Listen to Them
description: President-elect Bush told a group of leading environmentalists today that he would carefully consider their recommendations for fighting pollution and protecting natural resources.

title: Deal for U.N. Rights Inquiry in Iran Crumbles
description: An attempt to send a United Nations team into Iran for an investigation of the human rights situation there collapsed today in a dispute over the wording of a General Assembly resolution criticizing the Teheran Government's record.

title: 3 Owners of Clinic In Brooklyn Guilty Of Medicaid Fraud
description: The owners of a Brooklyn medical clinic were convicted yesterday of stealing more than $16 million in what officials said was the largest single Medicaid fraud prosecuted in the United States.

title: 468 or 84 Free Agents?
description: The National Football League Management Council said today that 468 players would become unconditional free agents on Feb. 1 under a plan that club owners said they would impose if there was no other contract agreement. The players union insisted, however, that only 84 players would become unconditional free agents under the plan.

title: Jersey Senate Chief Defends Legislation For Handguns Ban
description: The State Senate president defended proposed legislation today that would ban handguns in New Jersey, while opponents vowed to fight the measure.

title: 2 Mexican Teen-Agers Held In Rio Grande Sniper Attack
description: The police have arrested two Mexican teen-agers and are seeking two others in a fatal sniper attack against people rafting on the Rio Grande.

title: Leroy Pharmacies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it completed an initial public offering of 700,000 shares on Nov. 16. It also said it currently has 1,750,000 shares outstanding and its earnings per share for all periods was based on 1,050,000 average shares.

title: Quayle Says He Won't Be Right's Link to Bush
description: Vice President-elect Dan Quayle, wooed by members of his party's right wing since the election, said today that he would not be their ''so-called spear carrier'' in the Bush administration.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * All Nippon Airways, Tokyo, said it would buy jet engines for the its Airbus A320-200 jets from a U.S.-based joint venture between General Electric Co. and Snecma of France.

title: Yields Rise In Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday, as short-term money market rates continued to increase, bolstered by Monday's rise in the prime lending rate by the major banks.

title: 28 Reported Killed in 2 Weeks in Strife in Soviet Caucasus Region
description: Soviet authorities reported that 28 people have been killed in the troubled Caucasus region in the last two weeks, while a rising flood of refugees were reported to be fleeing from ethnic violence in the area.

title: For Nussbaum, Journey To Understanding Is Slow
description: A few months ago, Hedda Nussbaum would describe her hypothetical future with a childlike simplicity: She would find a place to live in Westchester County and work again as a children's book editor.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE phrase ''children of divorce'' conjures up images of youngsters shuttling between two homes or living with only one parent. But there are other children of divorce, an often-overlooked group on whom the effects of the breakup are only beginning to be studied. They are the adult children, those whose parents divorce after as many as three or four decades of marriage.

title: Eagle Coach in Hospital
description: Buddy Ryan, the coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, was hospitalized last night after choking on a piece of meat during dinner, prompting an assistant to administer the Heimlich maneuver, a team spokesman said. Ryan was admitted to Methodist Hospital, according to a hospital nursing supervisor who said Ryan asked the hospital to withhold any additional information.(AP)

title: Big Problem Awaiting Bush: Who Pays for Savings Crisis
description: The crisis in the savings and loan industry will be a top economic priority of the Bush administration, many in Congress and at the White House realize. Resolving it, they are certain, will require vast amounts of funds - from $50 billion to $100 billion.

title: Island's Deer May Face A Roundup, Not a Rifle
description: Homeowners here on this rocky mound of woods and marshland just off the coast of Mystic have long been piqued at the pesky white-tailed deer that browse on backyard shrubbery and dart past their pickup trucks.

title: Certain Treatments Hinder Lyme Detection
description: Patients with Lyme disease who are treated with low doses of antibiotics may later develop a debilitating chronic infection that escapes detection by commonly used blood tests.

title: Transact International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The figures included the operating results of Yankee Contract Services since its acquisition in July 1987.

title: Bush and Jackson Seek Common Ground
description: President-elect Bush met with the Rev. Jesse Jackson today and, borrowing one of the civil rights leader's campaign slogans, said he shared ''common ground'' with Mr. Jackson and would seek his suggestions after moving into the Oval Office.

title: Metromedia Beeper Curbs
description: In an effort to discourage the use of paging beepers by drug dealers, Metromedia Paging Services said yesterday that it plans to charge customers $1 for each page in excess of 1,000 pages a month.

title: Canada G.D.P. Up 0.2%
description: Canada's real gross domestic product, seasonally adjusted, rose two-tenths of a percent in September after a gain of six-tenths of a percent in August, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. Consumer spending grew by 1.1 percent and the business sector maintained its recent strong pace with a 1.5 percent increase in plant and equipment spending. Real merchandise exports, however, dropped by 3.1 percent, with declines in refined petroleum, lumber, chemicals, industrial machinery and auto parts.

title: Gwendolyn Cafritz, 78, Washington Hostess
description: Gwendolyn Cafritz, a leading Washington hostess, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in the capital. She was 78 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Punta Gorda Isles Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texan Artists in Town
description: In a sense, Washingtonians are entering a period in which they can contend that the ''Guys of Texas Are Upon Us,'' what with the President-elect, his designated Secretary of State, the Speaker of the House, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and others yet to be appointed hailing from the Lone Star State.

title: Reviews/Music; Haydn and Schubert, Calmly
description: The Kodaly String Quartet, which appeared Monday night at Weill Recital Hall, is one of those central European ensembles that calls into question the stereotypical attributes of American-trained groups.

title: U.S. Opposes Raising Minimum Combat Age to 18
description: The United States is opposing efforts at a United Nations treaty-drafting conference to raise the minimum age at which soldiers can be sent into combat under international law.

title: Wicks Law: Evil or Good in School Planning?
description: For 70 years, they were three obscure New York State statutes that provoked little public interest but were of vital concern to a rare coalition of construction contractors, labor unions and upstate Republican legislators.

title: Pushing Out Engineers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tricks of Memory
description: To The Home Section:

title: COURT ORDERS FIVE DEPORTED TO CUBA
description: A Federal appeals court here refused today to block the deportation of five Cubans being held in a Federal prison. The expulsions, set for Thursday, would be the first since the 1984 immigration treaty between the United States and Cuba was suspended three years ago.

title: Turkish Trust Certificates A Part of Arms Refinancing
description: A $3.4 billion face amount of Government trust certificates issued by Turkey was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the BT Securities Corporation, a Bankers Trust unit.

title: U.S. Warned by Europe On Farm Trade Stance
description: The European Community's top trade negotiator said today that the United States was taking an ''absolutely unacceptable'' position on long-term agricultural reform in advance of critical world trade talks in Montreal next week.

title: Psychology: Nurturing Can Offset the Trauma Of Loss in Childhood, Study Says
description: The loss of a parent early in life through death or divorce does not necessarily make a person more susceptible to depression or other major problems as an adult, a new study has found. A nurturing home life can offset the trauma, the study showed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Ad Spending Up 12.3% in Third Quarter
description: Broadcast television advertising rose 12.3 percent in the third quarter from the comparable period last year, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday.

title: British in Deal With Columbia
description: British Satellite Broadcasting, which will begin broadcasting on three channels next September, announced today that it had signed a $166 million deal with Columbia Pictures Entertainment giving it exclusive rights to more than 200 movies.

title: Market Place; A New Defense In Hostile Bids
description: Conceding that ''poison pills'' are not preventing hostile takeovers, Martin Lipton has come up with a new defensive tactic for American companies that fear hostile bids. In effect, he suggests that companies bet the house that their stocks are undervalued and that the market will figure that out within a few years. They will do that by offering to buy back a large proportion of their shares if the stock price does not rise far enough in the next several years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; DDB Needham Official Gets Media Award
description: Michael White, a senior vice president at DDB Needham in Chicago, has been named the ad industry's top media director in Media & Marketing Decisions magazine's third annual Media All Stars awards.

title: Takeover Hint From Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company reiterated today that its directors had deemed Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s current $5.2 billion offer inadequate but it hinted that a higher bid from the British company might break the two-month takeover deadlock.

title: Electricity Eases Dependence on Imported Oil; Role of Alcohol Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Expected to Get Lilco Fraud Case Today
description: After hearing testimony for two months, a Federal jury is expected to begin deciding today whether the Long Island Lighting Company deceived the Public Service Commission to obtain $2.9 billion in rate increases from customers to help pay for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Vestar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Currents; Artworks to Sink Your Toes Into
description: IN past centuries, floors were more important in architecture than they are today,'' said Peter Littmann, the president of Vorwerk, a West German concern. And floors, Mr. Littmann maintains, can be spectacular, interesting, even funny.

title: France to Lift Its Visa Policy For U.S. Citizens by Year-End
description: France said today that it would lift the visa requirement for United States citizens by the end of this year.

title: Pennsylvania Sale Of Revenue Bonds
description: The Delaware County Industrial Development Authority in Pennsylvania is tentatively offering $300 million of refunding revenue bonds for a resource recovery project through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Therapeutic Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Photog Pewter the Time-Honored Way
description: WHEN Roger Withrington was 16 years old, he thought he wanted to be a printer. But one day he walked by Englefields, a pewter manufacturer near his home in the East End of London, saw a help-wanted sign and got the job.

title: Treasury Issues in Strong Rally
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged a strong, technically based rally yesterday, as market participants shrugged off a host of potentially unpleasant developments and focused instead on a Federal Reserve report that said the pace of economic activity was slowing.

title: For Corn Belt Farmers, Oat Bran Isn't That Chic
description: Shoppers around the country are sweeping oat bran off the shelves faster than grocers can restock it, mills are running full tilt and prices of products like muffins are soaring.

title: CYCLONE BATTERS BANGLADESH COAST
description: A cyclone battered coastal areas of Bangladesh and eastern India late Tuesday, killing at least 300 people and leaving a trail of devastation, officials and news reports said today.

title: SOVIET UNION ENDS YEARS OF JAMMING OF RADIO LIBERTY
description: The Soviet Union has stopped jamming Russian-language broadcasts by the American-financed Radio Liberty and two other foreign radio stations, apparently clearing Soviet airwaves of deliberate interference with foreign broadcasts for the first time since the early 1950's.

title: 184 Afghan Army Soldiers Defect to the Guerrillas
description: The ragtag group of Afghan men sat cross-legged on the bare ground in three long rows, some wearing heavy Soviet Army jackets and gray felt hats, others unshaven in dirty sweaters, turbans and sandals. They chatted in muffled undertones, then listened attentively as a guerrilla commander talked to them.

title: For Stepfathers, Trust Comes Slowly
description: SIX months after Tony Gorman, a retired social- studies teacher, married Louise Griffiths, who has three children, the youngest child asked her mother at dinner one night, ''When is Tony going home?''

title: Incomes Up Strong 1.8% In October
description: A large increase in farm subsidy payments and bonuses to automobile workers pushed Americans' personal income up 1.8 percent in October, the steepest rise in a year.

title: Review/Music; Five Easygoing Pieces
description: Gerard Schwarz focused on the more easygoing side of the contemporary literature in his Music Today program at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening. Not that the works he offered were toothless, or in any way lacking a sense of their time and place. But the five composers represented on the program addressed themselves to music for string ensembles, large and small, and they all took full advantage of the lush timbres this scoring has to offer.

title: PENTAGON SEVERS COMPUTER LINKUP
description: The Pentagon said yesterday that it had temporarily severed the connections between a nonclassifed military computer network and the nationwide academic research and corporate computer network that was jammed last month by a computer virus program.

title: Entree Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 15
Top Executive Shifts Announced by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that Kaspar V. Cassani, a vice chairman, was leaving that post and returning to Europe in anticipation of his retirement next year.

title: Comatose Woman Dies After 2 Weeks Off Feeding Tube
description: Marcia Gray, 49 years old, a comatose woman kept alive near three years by a feeding tube while her family successfully fought to stop feeding her, died today after surviving two weeks without nourishment.

title: Nets Go From Bad to Worse
description: The Nets thought they played a bad first half Tuesday night. Tonight was even worse.

title: Dow Advances 12.98 to Close at 2,114.51
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher again yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.98 points, to close at 2,114.51.

title: Greenspan Urges Shifts In Clearing
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, today called for changes in the international clearing system for securities to adapt to the globalization of the financial marketplace.

title: Tyson Foods Raises Bid for Holly Farms
description: Tyson Foods Inc. today continued its battle to acquire the Holly Farms Corporation, one of the nation's largest poultry processors, by increasing its tender offer to $54 a share in cash, from $52, for all shares outstanding.

title: Intergroup Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $49,978.

title: Judge Declines to Curb Anti-Abortion Protests
description: A state justice refused today to restrict the activities of anti-abortion demonstrators who have blocked the entrances to Buffalo-area medical clinics.

title: Talking Deals; Guide to Future In Bid for Plessey
description: When Britain's General Electric Company and West Germany's Siemens A.G. made a bid on Nov. 16 for the Plessey Company of Britain, its signifcance far outweighed the $3.1 billion price tag.

title: Pentagon Severs Computer Links
description: The Pentagon has temporarily severed the links between a nonclassified military computer network and a nationwide computer network that was jammed last month by a computer virus.

title: Yonkers Housing Advocate Held in Fake Death Threats
description: The legal secretary who was vilified by some and hailed by others after speaking out for the Yonkers desegregation plan, was arrested today and accused of painting death threats outside her apartment door.

title: Calendar: Fairs All Around The Town
description: Industrial Design, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, 212-475-3424.

title: LABOR PARTY QUITS TALKS WITH LIKUD ON BROAD COALITION
description: The Israeli Labor Party voted by a narrow margin tonight not to continue coalition negotiations with the Likud, leaving Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in a political quandary.

title: THE PROTEST OF ONE MAN
description: Tim Mayotte, who is 6 feet 3 inches tall, with dark eyebrows and dark eyes closely knit, and gentle-spoken, was saying recently that he wasn't Tina Turner and he wasn't Michael Jackson and he wasn't John McEnroe, all of which should come as a surprise to very few.

title: Greenery Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $368,000 and $817,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from early extinguishment of long-term debt net of income taxes. c-Includes a gain of $392,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Exorcising the Demon Sourdough Starter
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Eagles Drive Toward Playoffs
description: The Philadelphia Eagles can smell the playoffs and, with three more victories, they will be the National Conference East champions.

title: KEY RATES
Pentagon Acknowledges Computer Intruder
description: Pentagon officials acknowledged yesterday that the discovery of an intruder into a military computer network led to the break in the links to a civilian network earlier this week.

title: Quayle's Seat (Cont'd)
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Health and Human Services Secretary, has apparently stayed out of the process of recommending a successor for his Cabinet post. But Dr. Bowen is working hard to promote his Under Secretary, Don M. Newman, as a candidate for the Senate seat vacated with the election of Senator Dan Quayle as Vice President.

title: Economic Scene; When the Market Appears Anxious
description: IT is a Wall Street convention for analysts to interpret the market as though it were a mystical being with a collective mind of its own. One economist asserts, ''The market is suffering from anxiety over the budget deficit.'' A second insists, ''The market is not as hysterical about the deficit as some economists but is worrying about Fed policy and rising interest rates.'' And a third says, ''The market is looking beyond the budget deficit, inflation and interest rates to focus on the leveraging of American corporations and the financial system risk.'' What one actually hears, of course, is not the voice of the market, like a patient on an analyst's couch, but the voices of the anxiety-ridden analysts.

title: Review/Film; Punctured Illusions On Castro
description: ''Piece of cake for intellectuals'': that is how Rene Tavernier, a French member of PEN, describes Fidel Castro's Cuba at a conference on human rights violations that is included in ''Nobody Listened,'' a documentary by Nestor Almendros and Jorge Ulla. Mr. Tavernier discusses the appeal held by the Cuban model for ideologues who have grown disillusioned with Communist states elsewhere. ''No big power,'' he says. ''No cold monster. Castro is a friend of the intellectuals. So he pretends, and we believe him.''

title: For Sale in Canarsie: a Beloved Century-Old Cemetery
description: For the people of Canarsie, their 100-year-old cemetery in southeastern Brooklyn is an ever-present reminder of what they were, who they are and where they are going. And in that, they say, there is a kind of serenity.

title: India Expels 2 Pakistanis as Spies
description: The Indian Government expelled Pakistan's military attache and another Pakistani official today after detaining them and accusing them of spying.

title: Arrested Officer Seized In Witness Harassment
description: A New York City police officer who was arrested last July in the robbery of a bodega was arrested again Wednesday and charged with harassing a witness in that case, the police said yesterday.

title: To Honor Loved Ones, Many Contribute to Neediest Cases
description: When Rhoda and Marty Lonow of Spring Valley, N.Y., celebrated their 25th wedding anniversary with a party on Nov. 5, they suggested to relatives and friends that instead of bringing gifts, they send donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: As Salaries Go, Yanks Take the Pennant
description: The Yankees, who have not won any titles on the field for seven seasons, regained their No. 1 position in the salary standings this year, soaring to an all-time high average of $718,670 for 1988.

title: Review/Film; A Fall Guy as Antihero
description: The proudly sophomoric comedy style of the Zucker-Abrahams-Zucker writing team, responsible for ''Airplane!,'' ''Top Secret!'' and now (with Pat Proft) ''The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!,'' is funniest when it's hardest to second-guess. But this time, in a scattershot detective parody that's a spinoff of the team's television series, things are relatively sane.

title: Yanks in First Place
description: Average team salaries as computed by the Players Association.

title: Psychiatrist's Downfall Spurs Debate
description: An eminent psychiatrist's resignation in disgrace from positions at Harvard University after admitting plagiarism has provoked a wave of protest and debate among leading psychiatrists and physicians.

title: The Real Danger Of Debt
description: As President Carlos Salinas de Gortari takes office in Mexico, his country is paying out $9 billion every year in interest and debt service on its $104 billion foreign debt.

title: Jailed Sergeant Wins Lotto and Posts Bail
description: A McGuire Air Force Base staff sergeant was given a compelling reason and plenty of means to bail himself out of jail this week.

title: Koch Wants More Cutting For Budget
description: Mayor Koch, who has preached fiscal restraint all year, said yesterday that more cuts in New York City services would be needed to balance next year's budget, and he warned that he planned no new spending programs, even though he would be up for re-election.

title: Myerson's Secretary Talks About Calls to Gabel Office
description: A secretary testified yesterday that Bess Myerson did not want her own name used when the secretary left telephone messages for Justice Hortense W. Gabel.

title: Westinghouse, Jersey Firm Are Sued by the Philippines
description: The Philippines sued the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a New Jersey engineering firm today, accusing them of bribing former President Ferdinand E. Marcos to win a contract to build a nuclear power plant near Manila.

title: Curb on Social Security Appeals Is Still a Draft; The Process Is Faulty
description: To the Editor:

title: Blazing North Stars Streak Past Bruins
description: Mark Hardy scored on a 90-foot wrist shot to break a 1-1 tie in the second period tonight as the rejuvenated Minnesota North Stars beat the Boston Bruins, 4-1.

title: To Washington Mews From Memory Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Toll at 500 in Bangladesh Cyclone
description: The official death toll rose to more than 500 today after a cyclone struck a wide area of southern Bangladesh, and the authorities continued the search for thousands of people still missing.

title: Kremlin Drops Barrier to Emigration of Dissidents
description: The Soviet Union has removed a major barrier to the emigration of about 50 people who have long been denied permission to leave by notifying them that they are no longer considered to be in possession of state secrets, State Department officials said today.

title: Macmillan and Maxwell Sell Four Units to Kohlberg
description: Macmillan Inc. and the Maxwell Communications Corporation yesterday announced the sale of four subsidiaries for about $400 million, just a month Macmillan was acquired for $2.5 billion by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher .

title: Review/Theater; A Lawyer Living the Cowboy Life
description: The iconography of the western movie hero is given an unrewarding treatment in ''The Majestic Kid.'' The Mark Medoff play, which opened last night at Theater at St. Peter's Church after a number of regional theater productions, is an attempt to merge the image of the archetypal cowboy with a do-gooder of today, a liberal lawyer who wants to restore the land to its rightful Indian constituency.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Mikhail Gorbachev's political plan was approved in part by the Soviet legislature, enacting some transfer of power from the Communist Party to popularly elected legislative bodies. Page A1

title: Is RJR Worth $25 Billion?
description: Few Wall Street dramas have generated as much debate as the strenuous bidding for RJR Nabisco Inc., which culminated late Wednesday in a deal to sell the company to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $25 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a debate involving Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, misstated in some copies the last time Mr. Walesa appeared on Polish television. It was 1983.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''A CHARLES DICKENS CHRISTMAS,'' a musical with book by Robert Owens Scott, lyrics by Tom Toce and music by Douglas J. Cohen, presented by Theaterworks-USA, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Information: 677-5959. ''THE CRICKET ON THE HEARTH,'' a play directed by Kim Sharp, about two English families, a blind girl and a cricket, presented by the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, 2 P.M. Sunday and Dec. 11, at the Open Eye Theater, Henry Lindenbaum Center, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: children, $8; adults, $10. Information: 769-4143. ''DINOSAUR DAYS,'' a program with John Burstein, who will narrate adventures of Tyrone the Terrible Tyrannosaurus, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $12. Information: 427-6000. ''DR. SEUSS AS STORY AND THEATER,'' three Dr. Seuss stories will be acted out by Scott Laughead, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Queens Museum, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Flushing. Free with museum admission: children, $3; adults, $4. Information: (718) 592-2405. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a play by the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations recommended: 734-5195.

title: 100,000 Flee Ethnic Violence In the Caucasus
description: More than 100,000 people fearing further ethnic strife have fled their homes in the southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, finding shelter in dormitories, in private homes and even in a growing tent city on the shore of the Caspian Sea, Soviet officials reported today.

title: Islanders Tumble to New Low
description: The Islanders, already becoming well-established in last place in the Patrick Division, are beginning to settle at the bottom of the entire National Hockey League.

title: New Rules Issued For Garbage Barges
