description: The State Environmental Conservation Department announced new regulations yesterday for garbage barges operating in New York City that it hopes will prevent trash from washing ashore.

title: Farley Extends Bid
description: Farley Inc. has extended its $1.4 billion tender offer for West Point-Pepperell Inc. a second time. The offer was to expire at midnight on Wednesday, but the Chicago-based Farley said that it was being extended by a week, to midnight next Wednesday. Farley also said that a preliminary count showed that about 11.4 million Pepperell common shares had been tendered as of the close of business on Wednesday. The company, which makes Fruit of the Loom underwear, originally set Nov. 21 as the deadline for its $48-a-share offer for Pepperell, based in West Point, Ga.

title: O'Neill Suggests Taxes May Rise For Next Year
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he doubted he would be able to balance next year's budget without a tax increase. He also indicated that he might seek increases for this fiscal year.

title: Southwestern Bell Cancels Yellow Pages in Three Areas
description: Withdrawing from a highly competitive scene, the Southwestern Bell Corporation announced yesterday that it would no longer publish Yellow Pages telephone directories in Manhattan, Chicago and the Tampa, Fla., area.

title: Market Place; Glimmer of Cheer For Mutual Funds
description: MUTUAL FUND customers, after a year and a half of hesitance, are again buying long-term municipal bond funds, just as those bonds seem to be growing expensive relative to taxable bonds.

title: Edward S. Deevey, 73, Biologist and Ecologist
description: Prof. Edward S. Deevey Jr., a biologist and ecologist, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Alachua General Hospital in Gainesville, Fla., where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Security Pacific Buys 44 Branches
description: In a move to increase its market share in Northern California, the Security Pacific Corporation has agreed to acquire the 44 branch offices of the Central Banking System in a stock swap valued at $14.25 a share, or about $62.7 million.

title: New York City AIDS Housing Plan Is a Mirage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Book-of-the-Month Club Judges
description: Gloria Naylor, a novelist, and J. Anthony Lukas, whose book on the effects of court-ordered busing in Boston won the 1986 Pulitzer Prize, have been named judges of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

title: Tennis Council Modifies Tour
description: In response to the Association of Tennis Professional's decision to break from the Men's Tennis Council and run its own tour beginning in 1990, Marshall Happer, the council's administrator, yesterday formally unveiled an alternative format for 1990. He said he hoped this would persuade the players to change their minds and remain part of the Grand Prix circuit.

title: President Rules Out a Pardon for North
description: President Reagan today emphatically ruled out a pardon for Oliver L. North, the former White House aide indicted on charges stemming from the Iran-contra affair.

title: Mr. Deaver's Compartments
description: ''Never Again Mike Deaver'' - that was the nickname for the ethics bill President Reagan pocket-vetoed last week. It would have closed the loophole through which Mr. Reagan's close friend and former deputy chief of staff escaped prosecution for lobbying former co-workers soon after leaving the White House in 1985.

title: Losers Get Some Spoils In Fight for RJR Nabisco
description: The losers in the bidding war for RJR Nabisco Inc. will hardly walk away empty-handed.

title: Australia Warns Yugoslavia
description: Australia said today that it would close the Yugoslav Consulate and expel its staff if authorities there do not turn over a security guard who shot a teen-age demonstrator. Yugoslavia rejected the demand.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and article yesterday about an embezzlement case in White Plains incorrectly described the defendant, Mary Vaden. She is a former part-time clerical worker for the City Court.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kidder Review For Doremus
description: Doremus & Company, an Omnicom Group subsidiary, may be the odd agency out in the account review initiated yesterday by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Nigeria Said to Get Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund has approved a $650 million loan for Nigeria in return for economic reforms, monetary sources said on Wednesday.

title: Switches by Parties Tangle Israel's Political Web
description: Israel's political schematic grew even more tangled today as the religious parties split between Labor and Likud, leaving neither with enough seats to form a government.

title: Sports People; Search Continues
description: The National League is unlikely to name a new president until after baseball's winter meetings next week, Peter O'Malley, the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers and the head of the league's search committee, said yesterday after a meeting of the committee.

title: U.S. Index On Economy Rises by 0.1%
description: The Government's predictive economic index edged up one-tenth of a percent in October, the sixth straight month in which it reversed direction.

title: Radio Liberty Is Heard in Moscow
description: Radio Liberty's Russian broadcasts could be heard in Moscow today, although some Russian listeners seemed skeptical about the Soviet decision to end jamming of the American station.

title: Two Securities That Buy Time
description: Zero-coupon bonds and payment-in-kind securities, both of which are to be used in the purchase of RJR Nabisco, have won growing popularity on Wall Street in highly leveraged transactions. They allow a company to avoid cash payments for years, giving it time to improve operations or to sell assets.

title: Dining Out Guide: Latin American
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Cinco de Mayo * (April 10, 1987), 45 Tudor City Place, between 42d and 43d Streets (661-5070) - This midtown outpost of the SoHo original has a similar menu of regional Mexican dishes. Recommended entrees include enchiladas verdes and camarones en pipian, a dish combining sauteed shrimp with peppery pumpkin sauce to be rolled in warm tortillas. Entrees are $8.95 to $17.95. Hours are noon to 3 P.M. Friday and 5 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. La Fusta Diner's Journal (Jan. 15, 1988), 80-32 Baxter Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens (718-429-8222) - This popular neighborhood cafe features traditional Argentine mixed grill, parrillada, prepared at the table on a small barbecue. The grilled parrillada has marinated skirt steak, blood sausage and sweetbreads. For starters, there are empanadas and a salad of watercress and onion. La fusta means riding crop, and leather crops and horse-racing ephemera decorate the stucco walls. Entrees are $7 to $16.50. Open 4 P.M. to midnight Friday to Sunday. No credit cards. Sabor * (March 18, 1988), 20 Cornelia Street (243-9579) - Authentic Cuban cuisine is served in a pint-size Village dining room. You might start with frituras de malanga, a deep-fried Caribbean root vegetable. Other recommended dishes include ropa vieja (braised flank steak in a red sauce spiced with cinnamon and cloves), snapper in green sauce, shrimp in a sauce of coconut, curry and onion (a special), and side dishes of black beans and fried plantains. Entrees are $10.50 to $18. Open 6 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, 6 to 11 P.M. Sunday. Zarela ** (Jan. 1, 1988), 953 Second Avenue, near 51st Street (644-6740) - Antique Mexican masks decorate the downstairs dining room; upstairs, the walls are lined with banquettes covered in bright fabric. Most appetizers are recommended, including flautas (chicken-filled tacos served with guacamole) and enchiladas de mole. Among the entrees are steak fajitas and grilled pork tenderloin with ancho chilies. Entrees $8.95 to $14.95. Dinner 5 P.M. to midnightFriday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. What the stars mean, page C18.

title: Kellogg Names Top Executives
description: The Kellogg Company, the giant cereal company, named Horst W. Schroeder its president and chief operating officer yesterday, putting him firmly in line to succeed its chairman and chief executive, W.E. LaMothe, who is 62 years old. Kellogg also named Gary E. Costley, 47, as president of its U.S. Food Products division, and Charles W. Elliott, 56, as chief financial officer.

title: Simms Tests Shoulder
description: Phil Simms tested his bruised right shoulder in practice today, and the Giants' quarterback said that he felt ''O.K.'' He said that he was sure he would play Sunday against the Phoenix Cardinals unless his arm became ''really sore.''

title: Miyazawa May Resign
description: Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, told Parliament today that he was prepared to relinquish his Cabinet post because of his involvement in a stock scandal if his resignation would help the passage of a tax-revision bill.

title: GORBACHEV'S PLAN TO REALIGN POWER VOTED BY SOVIETS
description: The Soviet legislature today approved the first phase of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to redesign the political system, enacting into law a partial transfer of power from the Communist Party to popularly elected legislative bodies.

title: Restaurants
description: La Boheme

title: NBC Wins Rights to '92 Olympics
description: Despite its low ratings and negligible profits from its broadcast of the Seoul Olympics, NBC bid a surprising $401 million to win the United States television rights to the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain.

title: 3 Promotions At Dow Jones
description: Dow Jones & Company yesterday named Kenneth L. Burenga, a 44-year-old senior vice president, as general manager of the company and its flagship newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, effective Jan. 1. The promotion was announced by Warren H. Phillips, chairman of the company.

title: TV Weekend; A Graham Greene Tale
description: Consistently ranking among television's more distinguished series, the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' returns this Sunday, on CBS at 9 P.M., with the kind of production that keeps its reputation intact. The series' 158th presentation is ''The Tenth Man,'' by Graham Greene. Back in 1943, Mr. Greene did a story treatment of ''The Tenth Man'' for M-G-M. The ''property'' was forgotten by both the author and the studio until five years ago, when it was rediscovered and published. Now, adapted by Lee Langley, it has finally been made into a movie.

title: Message From Vienna
description: Well, good friend, tell me what truths you have discovered in 40 years of hunting down the murderers of the innocent.

title: Developer Convicted In Credit Union Case
description: A real-estate developer was convicted yesterday of obtaining $12.5 million in fraudulent loans from the now-defunct Hyfin Credit Union by bribing its officers with shares in his real estate holdings.

title: Baroness Pannonica de Koenigswarter, 74
description: Pannonica de Koenigswarter, a patron of jazz performers, died Wednesday of heart failure at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 74 years old.

title: Bridge
description: Europe is far ahead of North America in offering opportunities for junior players, those under age 26. These players can attend an annual camp in different parts of the continent. Most countries have junior championships, and there are several international events, including a European championship.

title: Arms Talks Post
description: Max M. Kampelman, the State Department counselor and chief negotiator with the Soviet Union on arms, has decided to return to private life, State Department officials say.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Continental Corp. agreed to sell 40 percent of its First Insurance Co. of Hawaii unit to Tokyo Marine and Fire Co., a Japanese insurance concern, for $27.5 million.

title: Cornelia Goldsmith, Health Official, 96
description: Cornelia Goldsmith, a former director of the New York City Health Department's division of day care, day camps and institutions, died of cardiac arrest on Nov. 23 in Clinton, N.Y., where she lived. She was 96 years old.

title: Charlie Rouse, 64, a Saxophonist Known for Work in Monk Quartet
description: Charlie Rouse, a tenor saxophonist and one of jazz's great individualists, died of lung cancer on Wednesday afternoon at University Hospital in Seattle. He was 64 years old.

title: Chinese and Russians Talk About Cambodia
description: China's Foreign Minister opened the first working visit to Moscow by a senior Chinese official in more than 30 years today with intensive talks about the Soviet-supported presence of Vietnamese troops in Cambodia.

title: Five Courts Join to Complete Bridgeport Collapse Accord
description: A year and a half after an unfinished Bridgeport apartment complex collapsed, killing 28 construction workers, 300 people gathered here today to put the legal case to rest in an unusual courtroom session.

title: Wife of Jersey Mayor Dies in Peru Rail Crash
description: The wives of Mayor Anthony Cucci of Jersey City and the Mayor of Cuzco, Peru, were killed when their railroad car derailed and fell off an embankment near Cuzco.

title: Disney Expansion Set; Film Output to Double
description: The Walt Disney Company, which has had a magic touch at the box office for the last few years, said today that it would nearly double its motion picture production through the creation of a new movie company, to be called Hollywood Pictures.

title: OPEC Ties For U.S. Seen
description: The United States can be expected to have more contact with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries under George Bush as President, according to the head of the Texas Railroad Commission, Kent Hance. The commission regulates oil and gas production in Texas, and before OPEC was formed it virtually controlled world oil prices. Mr. Hance, speaking

title: Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. Dies at 89; Ex-Chief of U.S. Court of Customs
description: Judge Paul P. Rao Sr., an associate judge of the United States Court of International Trade, died of a heart attack Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: White Girl Is Hit and Robbed In a Bias Attack by 24 Blacks
description: A 17-year-old white girl waiting at a bus stop in Jamaica, Queens, was taunted, beaten then and robbed by a group of 24 black youths in what the police desribed as a racially motivated incident.

title: Software Concern Agrees to a Merger
description: Teknowledge Inc. agreed to merge with the American Cimflex Corporation, a private company, in a deal that involves the exchange of stock. The value of the deal was not announced.

title: Playboy Considers Past and Future
description: Hugh Hefner stayed home, swigging Diet Pepsi in his black silk pajamas. The party went on without him, as it always has, with some 800 writers, business executives, celebrities and celebrity hangers-on gathering last night at Windows on the World for the 35th anniversary of the magazine Mr. Hefner started in the living room of his Chicago apartment.

title: 2,000 Albums for Sale
description: The Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library will offer more than 2,000 long-playing records for $1 each during a sale today and tomorrow from 1 to 4:30 P.M. The offerings will include jazz, pop, opera, orchestral and instrumental works. Proceeds from the sale are to be used for the Donnell Media Center. The branch is at 20 West 53d Street. Information: 221-7676.

title: Tiger Airline May Go Private
description: Saul P. Steinberg, Tiger International Inc.'s largest shareholder, told the company's board today that he was considering taking the air cargo carrier private by buying its stock at an unspecified premium over the market price.

title: Review/Music; Scottish Airs, Adapted for Mars
description: Sometimes, in the often gray context of new-music concerts, a piece jumps out from the background and demands attention. That happened Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, where Musical Elements performed an honorable, even laudable program before a sparse audience.

title: U.S. STUDY FAULTS NURSING HOME CARE OVER MEDICATIONS
description: More than 4,000 of the nation's 15,000 nursing homes administer drugs without regard to a physician's written orders, according to a national survey published today by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Sports People; Henderson Agrees
description: Dave Henderson, the center fielder who batted .304 with 24 home runs and 94 runs batted in for the Oakland Athletics last season, agreed yesterday to a three-year contract worth $2.8 million. Henderson, who made $450,000 last season, will receive a $300,000 signing bonus, $750,000 in 1989 and 1990 and $1 million in 1991. (AP)

title: At the> Movies
description: The Real Leslie Nielsen

title: Construction Spending Climbed 0.9% in October
description: Construction spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in October, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, with half of the gain coming in single-family homes.

title: Paralegal Status Sign: Malpractice Insurance
description: Paralegals, the nation's fastest-growing occupation, have acquired a curious symbol of their rising status: their own malpractice insurance.

title: Our Towns; Money Is Tight, But for a Pool, H.U.D. Says Yes
description: Island Park is a pleasant middle-class seashore village of 4,200. The village clerk, Walter Foster, estimates a typical house here sells for $150,000 to $200,000, with some near the water going for $400,000.

title: Jardine Matheson Unit in Vancouver
description: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., the diversified Hong Kong-based trading house, plans to establish a shipping operation in Vancouver. Dennis Hon, the managing director of the new Jardine Matheson Transport Services (Canada) Ltd., said an office was also being planned for Toronto.

title: For Which American Flag Did the South Vote?
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO'S LEADER ASKS DEBT RELIEF
description: Carlos Salinas de Gortari was sworn in as President today and immediately called for a renegotiation of Mexico's $104 billion foreign debt. He declared that a situation in which ''we are transferring abroad 5 percent of our national product each year'' is ''unacceptable and unsustainable.''

title: Unit of Eveready To Buy Cofinea
description: The Eveready Battery Company's European unit agreed to acquire Cofinea, a French company that makes the Wonder and Mazda batteries, for up to $170 million. A spokesman of Ralston Purina Inc., Eveready's parent, said Cofinea's annual sales totaled more than $200 million.

title: Bengals Close In on Bills
description: The Buffalo Bills, despite slipping to an 11-2 record after losing to the Cincinnati Bengals last Sunday, remained on top of The New York Times's pro football rankings. Cincinnati leaped from No. 4 to No. 2, as it continued to establish itself as the National Football League's most explosive offensive team.

title: 'Who's a Jew?' Hits Home
description: LEAD: For American Jews en route to the Holy Land, Israel is a state of mind beginning somewhere over the Atlantic. When I awoke outside of Rome, there was a man standing next to me in the aisle, reciting his morning prayers. Even an agnostic like me knew he was thanking God for not being a woman.

title: Review/Dance; A Butterfly Who Can Also Soar Like a Bird
description: Kuniko Kisanuki's ''Tefu Tefu 9'' looks at first very much like soul-searching of the sort New York dan=cegoers have been exposed to in recent visits by Japanese Butoh performers and companies.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'THE FOREST'S' FIRST NIGHT

title: Reviews/Film; Of Cocaine and a Clash of Loyalties
description: Watching Robert Towne's ''Tequila Sunrise'' is like being allowed into a swinging Hollywood party so chic that, to quote Neil Simon, you're the only person there you've never heard of. All of the guests are dressed to the nines, including those wearing old jeans and T-shirts, which, in fact, are designer-distressed. You don't know the host but the people are friendly. The talk is nasty, clever and funny. You're in with the in crowd.

title: Norway Raises Output, Jolting OPEC
description: Norway dealt a blow to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today by substantially increasing oil production at one of its largest new fields.

title: Reagan Debt Legacy: His Trap for Democrats?
description: The greatest achievement of President Reagan's Administration may prove to be the roughly $155 billion budget deficit he is leaving to his successor, which is nearly twice the deficit he inherited from President Carter.

title: Bush Pledges to Press for Deficit Cuts
description: President-elect Bush today told George J. Mitchell of Maine, the new Senate Democratic leader, that he would take the lead in looking for ways to reduce the budget deficit.

title: Review/Art; A Celebrated Unknown
description: Regular visitors to the Frick Collection have learned to look out for the small-scale but invariably rewarding exhibitions that are mounted from time to time in the nether region to the right of the turnstiles. Generally these are the work of the Frick's curator, Edgar Munhall, a lifelong Francophile with a good nose for an out-of-the-way but congenial subject.

title: Ethical Music
description: The Ethical Culture Ensemble - Julius Baker, flutist; Henry Schuman, oboist; Gerald Ranck, harpsichordist, and Richard Locker, cellist - are to play works by Bach, Couperin, Telemann, Handel and Quantz on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. Admission is free. Information: 874-5210.

title: NATO IS STUDYING AN AIRBORNE FORCE
description: Some European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are studying a multinational airborne strike force to ease some of the burden of the United States in defending Europe, the alliance's military chief said today.

title: INSIDE
description: School Politics Bill Passes The New York Senate approved barring political officeholders, party officials and school employees from New York City school boards. Page B3. A Money-Laundering Case A Yugoslav consul general, four other people and a Yugoslav bank's American branch were indicted on Federal money-laundering charges. Page D1. Despite disappointments in Seoul, NBC will pay $401 million for television rights to the 1992 Summer Olympic Games in Barcelona. Page D17.

title: Talks Resume in Congo on Peace Pact for Namibia
description: Negotiators from Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States have resumed talks here in an effort to wind up their tortuous discussions with a formal agreement on all details of a peace settlement in southwestern Africa.

title: West Village Chorale
description: Gwen Gould will lead the West Village Chorale in Hugo Distler's ''Christmas Story'' at the Church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields, 487 Hudson Street, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. The program also included Baroque works, performed both a cappella and with an early-instruments ensemble. Tickets are $10. Information: (718) 499-1611.

title: Jets' Baldwin Voted Most Courageous
description: Tom Baldwin, the player the Jets jokingly nicknamed Budman because of his beer-drinking, admitted yesterday he was a recovering alcoholic.

title: Books of The Times; Detectives Fighting Crime and Time
description: Saratoga Bestiary By Stephen Dobyns 256 pages. Viking. $16.95. Obedience: A David Brandstetter Mystery By Joseph Hansen 202 pages. Mysterious Press. $16.95. A Question of Murder By Eric Wright 200 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Primitive World

title: British Electric System Sale
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher submitted legislation today on a plan to end Government ownership of Britain's electrical power system, a sale three times larger than previous steps in her campaign to dispose of nationalized industries.

title: Universal Foods Gets Offer of $520 Million
description: An investor group that includes a Massachusetts industrial equipment company and a British food conglomerate said yesterday that it had offered $30.50 a share, or about $520 million, for the Universal Foods Corporation, a food manufacturer based in Milwaukee.

title: British Steel Sale Outlook
description: The British Government's sale of British Steel P.L.C., the latest privatization of a nationally owned industry, for $:2.5 billion, or $4.6 billion, looks set for success despite news media speculation that the offering may be undersubscribed, sources close to the transaction said today.

title: Salt Lake City Journal; When College Apathy Runs Amok
description: To those who believe college campuses have become hotbeds of political apathy, the University of Utah's student government replies, ''Who Cares?''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The RJR Nabisco Deal

title: School Board Eligibility Bill Passed by Senate in Albany
description: The State Senate today gave final approval to a long-stalled proposal to prohibit political officeholders, party officials and school district employees from serving on community school boards in New York City.

title: Pop/Jazz; Artists Blend Resistance And Rap
description: If a social analyst were searching for a clue to which way cultural winds were blowing, he could look at two benefits this weekend. On Sunday, Resist in Concert! - a 10-hour show featuring an immense amount of talent, from the reggae rapper Shinehead to the performance artist Karen Finley - has something definite in mind, something quintessentially American. And tomorrow night, an exceptional triple bill, featuring the rock group NRBQ, the rhythm-and-blues singers Bobby King and Terry Evans, and the blues guitarist Danny Gatton will come together at Hunter College for a benefit.

title: Sports People; Carroll to Return
description: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' 7-foot starting center, will be back in the lineup for Sunday night's home game against the Detroit Pistons. Carroll has missed the last nine games with torn ligaments in his left wrist.

title: Celebrating St. Nick on a House Tour
description: Here's one for hard-core New York chauvinists: Santa Claus is a New Yorker, and he's coming home this week.

title: Vienna Journal; Along With the Strudel, Demons That Don't Die
description: This is the season when ghosts of past glory rise early among the labyrinthine streets and faded palaces of old Vienna. The bronze emperors from bygone centuries lurk in the wintry fog, and wrought-iron street lanterns cast long shadows over the icy cobblestones. But this year the spirits of lost empire have been eclipsed by the darker shadows of a more recent past. It was 50 years since Austria was swept up in Nazi madness, and the somber anniversaries, played out against the wrenching struggle over President Kurt Waldheim's past, put an indelible mark on the old city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Leumi, Tel Aviv, named Moshe Zanbar chairman and David Friedman managing director.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Hornets 109, 76ers 107: Kelly Tripucka hit a layup with four seconds left to lift Charlotte to the victory at home last night. Philadelphia's Charles Barkley, who finished with 31 points, made a driving layup at the buzzer, but the basket was nullified when Barkley was called for a foul to end the game. Tripucka led the Hornets with 25. (AP) Hawks 127, Bullets 115: Dominique Wilkins, with 36 points, put the Hawks in front and kept them there most of the night as Atlanta won its sixth straight home game. Wilkins's 11-foot baseline jumper with 8:11 remaining in the second quarter put the Hawks ahead for good. Atlanta got 23 points from Moses Malone. John Williams led the Bullets with 30 points.(AP) Cavaliers 99, Bucks 96: Mark Price hit a go-ahead 3-pointer with 29 seconds left and Ron Harper scored 28 points as Cleveland rallied for the victory in Milwaukee. Price's shot made it 93-90 and his two free throws with 16 seconds to go gave Cleveland a 95-92 lead. The Bucks' Jay Humphries made a long jumper with 13 seconds left but Harper and Brad Daugherty made two free throws each. (AP) College Basketball Fordham 78, Hofstra 64: Andre McClendon hit all five of his 3-point shots in scoring 21 points and Joe Paterno added 20 for Fordham last night. Dan O'Sullivan had 12 points and 11 rebounds for the Rams (2-0). Carlos Dicenta had 25 points for the Flying Dutchmen (1-2), including five 3-pointers in six attempts. The Rams led by 41-23 at halftime. Hofstra got to 52-44 after a Dicenta 3-pointer with 9:44 left, but Fordham went on a 12-2 run to put the game away. (AP) B.C. 90, New Hampshire 76: Dana Barros scored 32 points, including five 3-pointers last night for Boston College. In the first half, Barros's long-range shooting helped Boston College (2-1) to a 22-14 lead with 12 minutes left. But New Hampshire fought back behind the shooting of Bob Cummins to tie at 38-38 at halftime. Doug Able scored 12 of his 15 points within the first nine minutes of the second half as the Eagles gained control at 60-51.(AP) Horse Racing Dancing Spree Rallies to Win: Dancing Spree, ridden by Julian Vazquez, rallied in the stretch and scored a four-length victory in yesterday's feature race for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Fluorescent Lou was runner-up in the field of five. Dancing Spree, the odds-on favorites, covered a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:51 1/5 and earned $17,400 for Ogden Phipps. The winner returned $3.20 for $2.(AP) Golf Sheehan and Haas Lead: Patty Sheehan and Jay Haas overcame gusty winds to shoot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday for a one-stroke lead in the J. C. Penney Classic at Largo, Fla. Sheehan, who finished second to Sherri Turner on the L.P.G.A. Tour money list this year with $326,171, and Haas, who ranked 20th on the PGA Tour season with $490,409, are the highest-ranked pair in the tournament. The brother-sister team of Larry and Laurie Rinker finished the par-72 North Course at the Bardmoor Country Club with a 66. (AP) College Football Alabama 30, Texas A&M 10: David Smith threw two short touchdown passes, and Philip Doyle kicked three field goals to establish an Alabama season record as the 20th-ranked Crimson Tide beat Texas A&M last night in Jackie Sherrill's 81st, and perhaps last, game as coach of the Aggies. The Alabama linebacker Derrick Thomas, the Butkus Award winner as the nation's top linebacker, had four sacks and recovered a fumble. Alabama, which will play Army in the Sun Bowl, improved its record to 8-3 while Texas A&M dropped to 7-5 in the game in College Station, Tex. The Aggies cut into a 10-point Alabama halftime lead on Robert Wilson's 1-yard touchdown run in the third period. But Smith hit Kevin Turner with an 8-yard pass; Doyle kicked a 30-yard field goal, and Murry Hill ran 10 yards to score in the fourth period to put the game away for Alabama. Sherrill's future at Texas A&M remains under a cloud because of a school investigation of payoff accusations by a former player, George Smith, who later recanted his statement. Bill Curry, the Alabama coach, was informed before the game that his contract would be honored through 1992. Alabama officials made the gesture as a vote of confidence to stem rumors that Curry would be dismissed. The Texas A&M-Alabama game was originally scheduled for Sept. 17, but Alabama couldn't come to College Station because of Hurricane Gilbert. (AP)

title: No Looking Back in Moscow
description: A real national legislature with clearly stipulated powers . . . unfettered debate . . . a 10-year limit on holding office . . . contested elections . . . an independent judiciary. These are among the departures in what Mikhail Gorbachev calls ''a rule-of-law state'' made possible by ''the direct involvement of the Soviet people in politics.''

title: John M. Duggan, 60, A University President
description: John M. Duggan, president of Washburn University in Topeka, died of pancreatic cancer Tuesday in a Topeka hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Curb on Social Security Appeals Is Still a Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Mafia Gang Indicted in East Side Terror
description: An organized-crime gang that authorities say terrorized an Upper East Side neighborhood through murder, extortion and loan sharking was indicted yesterday under a new antirackeetering law.

title: Sports People; Croudip Sought Aid
description: David Croudip, the defensive back for the Atlanta Falcons who died last Oct. 10 from cocaine intoxication, had sought counseling for drug abuse this year, according to a letter sent by his psychiatrist, Dr. Hedges Capers of La Jolla, Calif., to police in Gwinnett County, Georgia.

title: Sikhs Who Killed Gandhi Get Temporary Stay of Execution
description: Overruling the President, India's Supreme Court ordered a stay today on the eve of the scheduled execution of two Sikhs convicted for killing Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in October 1984.

title: '76 Prosecution in Dallas Murder Case Is Assailed
description: Twelve years after Randall Dale Adams was sentenced to death for the killing of a Dallas police officer, Mr. Adams's defense attorneys rested their case today. They are seeking to win a new trial for him.

title: Doctor Freed in Wife's Death
description: A physician charged with first-degree murder for helping to kill his terminally ill wife after she tried to kill herself was acquitted today by a jury in the Pinellas County Circuit Court.

title: Rangers Receive Lesson in Humility
description: The team bus was idling outside the Saddledome here, its destination Banff, a resort at the edge of the Rocky Mountains. Awaiting the Rangers were hot springs and saunas, peace and perhaps a little quiet.

title: Gibraltar Official Quits
description: Jay Janis, who became chairman of the Gibraltar Financial Corporation in March as part of a management overhaul aimed at stemming mounting losses, said in a statement today that he had resigned to pursue other interests, effective Dec. 31. Mr. Janis, who is 55 years old, will be succeeded as chairman by James N. Thayer, 62, who became president and chief executive of the thrift institution in March. The Beverly Hills, Calif.-based company which has $14.7 billion in assets, has begun a search for a new president and chief executive.

title: Errors That Will Live
description: ''Save that document.'' That was the word at the Office of the United States Trade Representative this week when a background paper on world trade talk was published with a misprint.

title: Death Row Appeals are Drawing Sharp Rebukes From Frustrated Federal Judges in the South
description: The case is called Bell v. Lynaugh. But it could as easily be named Jones v. Chikofsky, for the judge who wrote the opinion and the lawyer she excoriated in it.

title: U.S. Arm of Yugoslav Bank And 5 Accused of Laundering
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Yugoslav Consul General, four other people and the American branch of a large Yugoslav bank on charges of participating in a money-laundering conspiracy. They were charged with conspiring to evade American cash-reporting laws through the use of Yugoslav diplomatic channels, among other techniques.

title: New Rules Aim to Minimize Takeoff Hazards
description: A Government engineer testified today that two newly proposed rules for checking takeoff warning systems should minimize the chance of airline crashes caused by unextended wing flaps on takeoff.

title: Conversion Ban On S.R.O. Units Upheld by Court
description: A New York State appeals court yesterday upheld a New York City law that prohibits the demolition of rooms in single-room-occupancy hotels or their conversion to luxury housing or commercial space.

title: The Nabisco Battle's Key Moment
description: The key strategic moment in the battle for RJR Nabisco may have been a few days before a Nov. 18 bidding deadline when H. John Greeniaus, chief executive of the conglomerate's Nabisco Brands subsidiary, telephoned Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and said he wanted to meet.

title: Soviet Human Rights Gesture
description: In a shift, Moscow has removed a major barrier to the emigration of about 50 people who have long sought to leave the country. Page A9.

title: Will Gorbachev 'Test' Bush?
description: LEAD: Speculation abounds about why Mikhail S. Gorbachev sought a meeting with Ronald Reagan and President-elect Bush during his visit to the United States next week.

title: On Stage
description: A Season for Musicals

title: Review/Art; Shifting Image and Scale
description: Jeff Koons would rather switch than fight. If it seems in 1988 that absolutely everything can be bought and exchanged, then why not make art that proudly advertises itself as a commodity and therefore, the theory goes, focuses attention on the plight of art and avoids being violated and used? Mr. Koons's porcelain and polychrome wood chatchkes make the Sonnabend Gallery seem like a cross between F. A. O Schwarz, Bloomingdale's and Graceland.

title: G.O.P. Senators in Albany Make Long Islander Their Leader
description: Ralph J. Marino of Nassau County yesterday became the first downstate Republican in 50 years to be elected majority leader of the New York State Senate, one of the most powerful positions in state government.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Trattoria's Visual Puns

title: Bonn G.N.P. Rises 1.5%
description: The West German economy maintained strong growth in the third quarter and may experience its best annual growth since 1979, the Economics Ministry said today. Its gross national product, the total value of all goods and services produced, rose by 1.5 percent in terms of real volume in the quarter, giving a year-to-year rise of 3.4 percent. The ministry attributed the growth to buoyant domestic and foreign demand. It added that the rise in corporate investment had been especially strong.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $500 million issue of real estate investment conduit securities offered to the public by the Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: California Pier Fire Kills Man
description: A fire on an oil-soaked pier killed a man and destroyed at least 11 boats and two cars early today, the authorities said. The dead man was asleep in his boat when the fire broke out and spread to his vessel, the authorities said. At least two other people were injured in the blaze, which was brought under control by firefighters on the shore and in boats.

title: Allied, Raytheon Win Big Contract
description: Allied Signal Inc. and the Raytheon Company said they were awarded an Air Force contract potentially worth $4 billion over 15 years to upgrade its ''friend or foe'' aircraft identification system. The need for an improved system was demonstrated by the downing in July of an Iranian civilian jetliner by the Navy cruiser Vincennes in the Persian Gulf. The incident killed 290 people.

title: Contra Case Figure Believed Dead
description: A man carrying the passport of a former Israeli official linked to the Iran-contra scandal was killed in a plane crash, Government officials said today.

title: Last Echoes of Battle?
description: In the afterglow of the election, Mark Goodin, the new spokesman for the Republican National Committee, has sent a peace offering to his Democratic counterpart, Michael McCurry.

title: Finance Officer Named New President at GTE
description: Completing a yearlong management transition, the GTE Corporation yesterday elected Charles R. Lee president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: U.S. WILL PAY OHIO TO SETTLE CHARGE AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Federal Government has agreed for first time to make payments to a state to settle charges that its contractor illegally released radioactive materials from a nuclear weapon plant.

title: VITAMINS MAY CUT BIRTH DEFECT RISK
description: Women who take multivitamin pills at the time of conception have less than half the risk of having a baby with a serious neurological defect as do women who are not taking these vitamins, a new study has found.

title: Auctions
description: Head of the Class

title: HISTORY OF THE RJR NABISCO TAKEOVER
description: Following are the highlights of the most expensive takeover battle in history waged for RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco giant that is the nation's 19th-largest industrial concern. Oct. 20, 1988: An investment group led by F. Ross Johnson, Nabisco's chief executive, in partnership with the Wall Street firm Shearson Lehman Hutton, proposes a $17 billion leveraged buyout at $75 a share. Oct. 24: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, Wall Street's leader in leveraged buyouts, tops the record bid with a $20.43 billion offer. Oct. 25: Shearson and Kohlberg, Kravis consider a combined bid. Oct. 26: Competition heats up as a joint deal is rejected. Oct. 27: Salomon Brothers joins Shearson as a backer in the management-led offer. Kolhberg, Kravis begins its tender offer for $90 a share. Oct. 28: RJR Nabisco agrees to give Kolberg, Kravis confidential financial data about its operations. Nov. 1: RJR's chairman, Charles E. Hugel, said it is highly likely that the company will be sold. Stock rises $1.25, to $85 a share. Several Kohlberg, Kravis investors balk at allowing the firm to use their cash in a RJR Nabisco buyout because of a possible hostile takeover and because of RJR Nabisco's ties to South Africa. Nov. 2: The two suitors tentatively agree to join forces. Nov. 3: The agreement fails; Mr. Johnson's group raises the stakes with a $92-a-share counteroffer of $20.9 billion. Nov. 4: Forstmann Little indicates it might join the battle with a higher bid. Shearson accuses Forstmann of breach of promise. Nov. 8: RJR Nabisco discloses formal rules for its sale, indicates it might sell its food divisions on its own and sets Nov. 18 as a deadline for bids. Nov. 11: Kohlberg, Kravis extends its tender offer by 10 days, to Dec. 5. Nov. 16: Field narrows as Forstmann Little declines to enter the auction; RJR Nabisco's stock tumbles $4.50, to $84. ITT, which holds RJR Nabisco bonds, sues RJR Nabisco and Mr. Johnson over the decline in the bonds' value. Nov. 18: RJR Nabisco management and Kohlberg, Kravis deliver bids before the 5 P.M. deadline of $22.7 billion and $21.3 billion, respectively. A surprise tentative offer of $23.8 billion to $26.8 billion comes from group led by First Boston, which is aligned with the Pritzker family of Chicago. Financing for that offer is uncertain. Nov. 19: Potential buyers spend the day explaining their complex bids to the company. Nov. 20: Special committee running the auction announces a new deadline, Nov. 29., for reformulated proposals. Nov. 29: Three suitors submit final bids of more than $100 a share. Management offers $22.9 billion, Kohlberg, Kravis offers $24 billion and First Boston offers $23.38 to $26.11. Stock price jumps $1.875, to $90.875. Nov. 30: Kohlberg, Kravis claims victory for the staggering price of $24.88 billion, or $109 a share. Mr. Johnson's group char

title: With Rise of the Far Right, Apartheid Again Puts Its Worst Foot Forward
description: ''Welcome to beautiful Boksburg'' hails the sign greeting travelers at the edge of this traditional mining town.

title: Strong Winds Delay Liftoff of Space Shuttle
description: Dangerously shifting winds forced the postponement of the secret military mission of the space shuttle Atlantis today. A second launching attempt will be made Friday morning.

title: Bonds and Long-Term Notes Gain
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and long-term notes moved higher again yesterday, as market participants positioned themselves for this morning's release of critical November employment data.

title: Nils Bejerot, 67, Pioneer in Study of Drug Abuse
description: Nils Bejerot, a Swedish physician and psychiatrist who was a pioneer in the study of drug abuse in contemporary society, died of lymphoma on Tuesday at Karolinska Hospital in Stockholm. He was 67 years old and lived in Stockholm.

title: Shoreham Closing Still Uncertain As the Legislators Leave Albany
description: New York State legislators left Albany today without even voting on the proposed settlement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, giving the Long Island Lighting Company the option to operate the plant if it is licensed.

title: Council Panel Defeats Commercial-Rent Bill
description: A New York City Council committee narrowly defeated a commercial rent-control bill yesterday.

title: Sports People; New Kimball Incident
description: Bruce Kimball, the former Olympic diver who faces manslaughter charges in the deaths of two teenagers Aug. 1 in Brandon, Fla., has pleaded guilty to charges of throwing an object at a police officer after a Michigan football game last month.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the United Nations' reaction to the denial of an American visa to Yasir Arafat described the General Assembly's tenure in New York incorrectly. After establishing its headquarters in New York in 1946, the Assembly held sessions in Paris in 1948-49 and 1951-52.

title: Reviews/Film; Biker in Horse Country
description: ''Dakota'' is the sort of movie that demands an addition to the rating code - say, P12 (''Unfit for Anybody Over Puberty''). It is a finding-yourself show. Eighteen-year-old Dakota (he doesn't like to give out his first name) races away from home troubles into the Western scenery on his motorbike and finds himself on the Diamond Thoroughbred Horse Ranch in Texas. He and Molly, the rancher's nice daughter, find each other, even though she knows about horses and all he knows about is automobiles. Soon they are meeting at Enchanted Rock. Dakota also helps Molly's brave 12-year-old one-legged brother to find himself, while a deeply wise old Indian woman grinds out wisdom.

title: Harvard Awaits Appointment of New Law Dean
description: The search for a new dean at the Harvard Law School has highlighted the deep divisions in the faculty and among the students.

title: Drug Defendant Not Guilty By Reason of a Misspelling
description: A man has been acquitted of manufacturing and distributing a drug known as ''ecstasy'' because the drug's scientific name was misspelled in state law.

title: Many Bids Are Likely If Company Sells Units
description: Amid all the uncertainties surrounding the largest corporate acquisition ever, one thing that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company will not have to worry about is finding buyers interested in whatever portions of RJR Nabisco Inc.'s food business it decides to sell, analysts and food-industry executives said yesterday.

title: Hlasek Spoils Lendl's Return
description: His attempt to regain the No. 1 ranking he held for three years cannot officially begin until January, in Australia. Still, there was no better setting than Madison Square Garden for Ivan Lendl to serve notice that his era is not over, the dates to be diligently inscribed in the game's history books alongside those of Connors, Borg and McEnroe. What Lendl hoped to prove here this week is that 1988 has been an untimely interruption, not the end of his reign.

title: Bush Is Urged to Be a Leader in the Fight on AIDS
description: As Reagan Administration officials debated how to finance AIDS programs in the next budget, medical, civil rights and gay groups urged President-elect Bush today to take an aggressive role in fighting the disease.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Panel Spurs Dispute Over Alcohol Ads
description: THE advertising community and the Surgeon General's office are waging a bitter battle over a planned workshop on drunken driving that marketers and broadcasters say is biased in favor of restricting alcoholic-beverage advertising.

title: Daughter of Determination: Benazir Bhutto
description: Benazir Bhutto, chosen today to lead the first democratically elected government in Pakistan in more than a decade, is also the first woman to become Prime Minister of a modern Islamic nation.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Piano Man

title: Stifling Tears, Nussbaum Recounts Lisa's Last Days
description: Facing the man she said beat and tortured her, Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday at the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg, telling the jury that he handed her the unconscious form of Lisa Steinberg on the evening of Nov. 1, 1987, the night the prosecution says he gave the child a fatal beating.

title: One Step Forward on Schools
description: The mounting charges of corruption on New York City school boards already bear positive fruit in Albany: the Legislature has finally passed a bill to address the issue. Meanwhile, an urgently needed bill to facilitate school construction remains blocked in the Senate Republican conference, which defers dubiously to construction unions.

title: Japan Air Crash Inquiry Ends
description: The police sought criminal charges today against employees of Boeing, Japan Air Lines and the Transport Ministry after a three-year investigation into the cause of the world's worst single-plane crash. The Boeing 747 with 524 people aboard crashed into a mountain during a flight from Tokyo to Osaka on Aug. 12, 1985, killing all but four on board.

title: General Powell Getting Army's Top Command
description: Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the President's national security adviser for the last year, will be nominated for the rank of four-star general and take over the largest command in the Army early next year, the White House announced today.

title: Pepsico To Acquire Big Bottler
description: The General Cinema Corporation, one of the nation's biggest soft-drink bottlers, movie exhibitors and department-store operators, has agreed to sell its soft-drink bottling business to Pepsico Inc. for $1.5 billion, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Dow Slides 12.63 Points; Volume Falls
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 12.63 points to close at 2,101.88.

title: Chrysler Canada Sets 530 Layoffs
description: About 530 workers at a Chrysler Canada Inc. plant here will lose their jobs beginning next month shortly after the United States automobile maker closes its factory in Kenosha, Wis., a company spokesman said. The Chrysler Corporation, Chrysler Canada's parent, has said it will close the Kenosha plant on Dec. 23 and lay off more than 5,000 workers. The Ajax plant has about 2,000 employees.

title: Enough U.S. 'Televocracy'; Let's Have a Prime Minister Govern
description: To the Editor:

title: Popeye's Extends Church's Deadline
description: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., which owns Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits restaurants, has extended the deadline on its offer for Church's Fried Chicken Inc. until Dec. 16. The previous deadline had been set for midnight on Wednesday. Federal District Judge Charles Schwartz Jr. has forbiddne Popeye's to buy Church's stock until 10 business days after it discloses information upon which its bid is based.

title: Review/Photography; Urbane Images Of Alienation And Voyeurism
description: THERE are those who say the New York view of photography is parochial, self-centered and worse. These people, most often from outside the city, complain - sometimes with justification - that the art marketplace here pays insufficient attention to photography produced elsewhere.

title: Two Prerequisites the Democrats Are Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: James Neely, 52, Dies; A Research Scientist
description: James R. Neely, a physiologist and researcher, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Geisinger Medical Center in Danville, Pa. He was 52 years old and lived in Danville.

title: Punished Archbishop Of Seattle Sees the Pope
description: Pope John Paul II met today with a United States Archbishop who had been punished by the Vatican for permitting gatherings of homosexuals and for other practices to which the Vatican objects.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mess At Columbia
description: ONE of the most telling signs in the departure of Larry McElreavy as the Columbia football coach is that the players have not rushed to defend him. This lack of support tells more than the less-than-compelling defense the school gave McElreavy as he resigned on Tuesday, following unproven charges that he had been drinking and having an affair with a female staff member.

title: Article 575688 -- No Title
description: Responding to fierce competition in the long-distance telephone industry that is eroding its dominant share, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would take a $6.7 billion charge against earnings to modernize its telephone network and to eliminate 16,000 jobs.

title: Conservatives From Reagan Down Convene to Honor Kemp
description: Veterans of the Reagan Revolution gathered tonight to celebrate their victories, lament their casualties and honor one of the most stalwart insurgents ever to storm an ideological barricade.

title: David Schaps, 76, Clothing Manufacturer
description: David Schaps, a retired men's clothing manufacturer, died of lung cancer Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in East Rockaway, L.I.

title: U.S. Declines to Reverse Decision on Arafat
description: The United States today refused an appeal to reverse its decision to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: Other Presidents and Budget Reality
description: Experience is the best teacher of, among other things, Presidents. Thus when two ex-Presidents speak, a President-elect does well to listen. Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter offer sobering advice for George Bush on the budget deficit. Forget campaign promises about taxes and Social Security, they say, and ''face reality.''

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: The assets of the nation's 466 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.13 billion, to $280.64 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 136 institutional funds decreased by $389.1 million, to $73.18 billion. The assets of the 230 general-purpose funds were up by $268.6 million, to $90.25 billion. The 100 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.01 billion, to $117.22 billion, the institute said.

title: Where Audiences Participate In Improvisional Comedy
description: IN ''Everything Kills,'' the latest comic revue by the long-running improvisational troupe Chicago City Limits, the company belts out a jolly theme song that announces the multiplying deadly perils of everyday life. ''The shore was once a place for sunning/ now bathers spend more time running from sewage spills/ 'Cause everything kills'' begins one of the verses set to Cole Porter's jaunty tune for ''Anything Goes.'' Death is also found in rare steaks, coffee breaks, Tic-Tacs, Big Macs and everything else one might care to eat, drink or chew.

title: L.I. Flexes Its Muscle; Population Growth and Bipartisanship Underlie New Strength in Legislature
description: Long Island came of age politically yesterday.

title: About Real Estate; Luxury Homes and Young Families
description: Most suburban home builders are sure that the best way to sell new houses in this weak market is to make them more affordable. But that may not always be true: some builders have found unexpected market strength by taking the opposite tack.

title: Duper Skipped Two Drug Tests
description: Mark Duper's failure to appear for two drug tests last week apparently was the cause for his 30-day suspension by the National Football League, his agent said today.

title: Cuomo Guard Shifted After Mansion Theft
description: A member of Governor Cuomo's security detail has been reassigned because a burglar was able to enter the Executive Mansion living quarters on Monday while Mr. Cuomo's wife was home, Superintendent Thomas A. Constantine of the state police said Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The priority will no longer be to pay, but to return to growth.

title: Cut U.S. Troops in Korea Now
description: LEAD: During President Roh Tae Woo's recent Washington visit, President Reagan mused, off the cuff, that we might reduce our 44,000 troops in South Korea or withdraw them if tensions in the region lessened. Although that lessening has barely begun, now is the time to start small cuts in our forces and to begin lowering our military profile.

title: Devis Grebu Paintings At the French Institute
description: Thirty-two watercolors and drawings by Devis Grebu, a Rumanian-born painter, book illustrator and set designer who lives in Ossinging, N.Y., will go on display today in the gallery of the French Institute-Alliance Francaise, 22 East 60th Street. Gallery hours today are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. Information: 355-6100.

title: Official Retires At Intergroup
description: National Intergroup Inc. said yesterday that James E. Haas would retire as president, chief operating officer and a director on Jan. 1. He will be succeeded by Laurence J. Farley, chief financial officer.

title: Bank Official to Shift To Children's Finances
description: Neale S. Godfrey, president and chief operating officer of First Women's Bank, is shifting to children's banking.

title: Leading Indicators: Component Analysis
description: Components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change from Sept. to Oct. Change in sensitive materials prices Contrib. to Index: -0.18 Index of stock prices Contrib. to Index: +0.29 Money supply: M-2, adjusted for inflation Contrib. to Index: -0.13 Change in credit (business and consumer borrowing) Contrib. to Index: N.A. title: Sports People; Another Offer for Ryan
description: The Texas Rangers have offered Nolan Ryan, a free-agent pitcher, a one-year contract for more than $1 million, Tom Grieve, the Rangers general manager, said yesterday.

title: School Basketball; City Teams Return on the Air
description: It used to be a Saturday morning ritual. High school basketball games in New York City were televised in the early 1960's with Marty Glickman describing the action.

title: Dozens Are Seized in New U.S.-Italian Drug Sweep
description: Federal officials yesterday announced the arrest of 52 people around the country in the year's second major set of coordinated sweeps by the American and Italian authorities against Sicilian Mafia drug rings operating in the United States.

title: Review/Art; The Romance of Ruins
description: The world has never looked the way Hubert Robert pictured it - as an endless and eternally lush garden inhabited by workers who happily make their homes in picturesque ancient ruins. Robert imbued this fantastical place with a gentle soul, creating scenes where the past and present, the natural and manmade, the mundane and sublime, seem held in blessed equilibrium.

title: 'Yellow Rain' and Soviet Lies Don't Compare
description: To the Editor:

title: Efforts Begin to Rebuild Nabisco's Morale
description: Henry R. Kravis and another partner of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company flew to RJR Nabisco Inc.'s headquarters in Atlanta yesterday to begin rebuilding morale at the company that their investor group agreed to purchase earlier this week for $24.88 billion.

title: Patents; Device Stops Snorers Without Waking Them
description: A French inventor has developed a device to stop sleepers from snoring without waking them.

title: Lilco Will Try to Open Shoreham
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, responding to the State Legislature's failure to adopt Governor Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear plant, said today that it would no longer be bound by the accord and would press its efforts to win a license for the plant.

title: Knicks Top Dallas On Tucker's Basket
description: The road has become an unlikely haven for Knick victories. For the second time in three nights, the Knicks won a game that appeared lost in the closing minutes.

title: Weisfield's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Regal International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: After Fear-Tinged Bus Ride, Tearful and Joyous Reunion
description: The fourth-grade class at School 42 in the Caucasus Mountain city of Ordzhonikidze had finished an outing to a local printing plant Thursday afternoon when a man approached them saying he was the driver sent to take them home.

title: Plane Inspector Says Safety Directive Was Delayed
description: The chief Government inspector at Delta Air Lines said today that he did not receive a Federal directive to review the operation of takeoff warning systems until more than two months after it was issued and several days after a Delta jet crashed on takeoff here.

title: Next Step for Shoreham: Open It
description: When it came down to this week's deadline, the New York Legislature decided that Long Islanders feared high electric costs more than nuclear power. Instead of acting boldly on this new perception by turning down an agreement to decommission the Shoreham nuclear power plant and putting the $5 billion-plus facility to productive use, they left town.

title: Two Unions Renew Fight With Eastern
description: Two unions at Eastern Airlines plan to begin a new lobbying effort with Congress against the airline's management and that of its corporate parent, the Texas Air Corporation, sources close to the unions said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Mixed Program by Jupiter
description: Among New York's smaller orchestral ensembles, Jens Nygaard's Jupiter Symphony stands out for the unaffected freshness of its best performances. The programs are not generally adventurous; Monday's bill of Wagner, Ibert and Beethoven at Alice Tully Hall was typical. But the validity of the group's role in our overstuffed concert life comes from Mr. Nygaard's likable style. The Ibert ''Divertissement,'' the closest thing the program had to a novelty, gave the ideal demonstration; its delicious blend of Mozart, Mendelssohn, Poulenc and jazz, mixed in the most delicate proportions, came off superbly in this understated performance.

title: Dixon Ticonderoga Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $103,204 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $664,513 for the year.

title: Calumet Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jaffe and Apache
description: An investment group led by Jaffe Energy Inc. has agreed not to purchase more that 20 percent of the ei Corporation common stock, without the permission of the company's chairman. The Jaffe group now holds a 9.25 percent stake in the Minneapolis-based oil and gas concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Jaffe group said that it was evaluating its position in the company, although it had no definitive plans. In previous filings with the S.E.C., Jaffe had said it might seek control of Apache. The Jaffe group purchased an additional 270,984 Apache common shares on the open market between Oct. 21 and Nov. 9 for an average price per share of $7.25.

title: Libel Suits Wane, Press Study Finds
description: The steady rise in the number of libel suits filed against major news organizations, a trend that plagued newspapers and broadcasters through most of the 1980's, has suddenly abated, the Society of Professional Journalists reports.

title: Council's Recycling Bill Deserves Early Passage
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; A Bulgarian Jew Upsets His Life To Save the Faith
description: The Bulgarian built an accomplished career in physics, belonging to the national science academy and journeying to Moscow for important conferences. He wrote works like ''Electron Density in the F-2 Layer Based on Quasi-vertical Sounding of the Ionosphere.''

title: Piedmont Natural Gas Co reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Billionaire Is Giving $41 Million to Fight Cancer
description: Harold C. Simmons, a Texan with a personal fortune estimated at close to $1.5 billion, plans to donate $41 million, mainly for cancer research, to the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas.

title: Constructive Thrashing on Trade
description: Close to 100 nations assemble in Montreal next week to huff and puff at each other's trade restrictions. Their trade ministers will review the global bargaining on barriers that began two years ago in Uruguay and still has two years to run. While it may appear they're getting nowhere, the Uruguay Round is the broadest and most difficult trade negotiation ever undertaken. As long as the negotiators remain committed to eventual success, a week of threats and posturing won't hurt.

title: Warner-Lambert Nicotine Patch
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it would market a transdermal nicotine patch, a prescription developed by the Elan Corporation P.L.C. as an aid to help smokers kick the habit. Each patch application maintains 24-hour nicotine plasma levels in a smoker comparable to those that would result from cigarette smoking. Normal treatment with the nicotine patch takes six weeks, the company said.

title: Dep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $318,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Milovan Djilas on Gorbachev's Future
description: LEAD: This article is adapted from an interview in the October issue of Encounter, a journal published in London.

title: Liposome Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: The introduction to an article in Weekend on Nov. 25, about talented new performers, misidentified the year of the first ''New Faces'' show on Broadway. It was 1934.

title: Plan Is Unveiled To Fix Problems At a Hospital
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation outlined yesterday how it would correct widespread deficiencies in care at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

title: Forum Re Group (Concord) Inc (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was formerly known as the Veta Grande Companies.

title: Your Money; Ways to Reduce Tax Bill for 1988
description: There is still time to whittle tax liabilities for 1988, but taxpayers must act before the end of the year. By next year, only damage assessment will be possible.

title: Johannes Steel, 80, Commentator
description: Johannes Steel, a newspaperman and radio commentator whose career was marked by controversy over his outspoken left-wing views and his often sensational political and economic predictions, died on Wednesday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: Networks of Computers At Risk From Invaders
description: Basic security flaws similar to the ones that let intruders gain illegal entry to military computer networks in recent weeks are far more common than is generally believed, system designers and researchers say.

title: A Sad Situation In Pants
description: Needing pants, I go to Google's. The pants department is idle. Five or six people browsing, but no salesperson bustling up to ask, ''Can I help you?'' In fact, there don't seem to be any salespersons working.

title: Reasons Enjoys Bigger Role
description: In the Giants' 13-12 upset of the New Orleans Saints last Sunday night, the heroics of Lawrence Taylor, Jeff Rutledge, Stephen Baker and Paul McFadden overshadowed an exemplary performance by Gary Reasons.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 33.

title: Ban on Hazardous Crib Toys Is Sought
description: The staff of the Consumer Product Safety Commission determined last year that babies can hang themselves on crib toys, but the Federal agency did not publicize its findings, and for lack of funds, decided not to take any action for at least two years.

title: California Smog Days Rise
description: Southern Californians have suffered through one of the worst smog seasons of the decade, air quality officials say. They said ozone levels in the South Coast Air Basin surpassed Federal standards on 172 of the 184 days of the past smog season, which runs from May 1 to Oct. 31, exceeded in this decade only in 1981 and 1984.

title: Tennis Players Set Plans for New Tour
description: With the top-ranked players Mats Wilander, Boris Becker, Stefan Edberg, Andre Agassi, Tim Mayotte, Henri Leconte and Jakob Hlasek in attendance, Hamilton Jordan, chief executive officer of the Association of Tennis Professionals, yesterday formally unveiled the particulars of a tour to be run by the A.T.P. starting in 1990. For all practical purposes, this ended chances for a compromise between the players and the Men's Tennis Council, which runs the existing Grand Prix circuit.

title: Lisa's Staring Said to Lead To Beating
description: Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday that Joel B. Steinberg told her he had ''knocked Lisa down and she didn't want to get up'' just hours after Lisa Steinberg was fatally injured.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ametek Inc., a diversified manufacturing concern, said it had completed the spinoff of several units into a newly formed company, Ketema Inc. Ametek shareholders will receive one share of Ketema stock for every 10 Ametek shares owned.

title: Japanese to Buy A Milacron Unit
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. announced it planned to sell its semiconductor materials subsidiary to a Japanese company that manufactures components for the semiconductor industry. Cincinnati Milacron, a Cincinnati-based manufacturer, declined to disclose the price that the Osaka Titanium Company Ltd. would pay for the subsidiary, Cincinnati Milacron Semiconductor Materials Inc.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 112, Celtics 84: Ron Harper scored 23 points and Brad Daugherty matched his career high with 17 rebounds last night as Cleveland, off to its best start in 12 years, beat Boston in Richfield, Ohio. The margin equaled Cleveland's largest ever against the Celtics. The Cavaliers also beat Boston by 28 points in March 1977.

title: Factories' Orders Show Gain of 1.6%
description: Orders to the nation's factories increased 1.6 percent in October, driven by a surge in spending for military equipment.

title: SNL Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Thursday, Dec. 1, editions.

Velcro Industries NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $1,048,000 related to discontinuance of manufacturing operations in the Netherlands. c-After a non-recurring gain of $3,503,000.

title: Vertex Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
Patents; New Sweeteners Developed by Coke
description: The Coca-Cola Company won patent approval this week for a new class of sweeteners that are as much as 1,900 times as sweet as sugar.

title: The Seamy Reality of 'Adoption, Not Abortion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tektronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
Water Emergency Is Declared
description: The only source of drinking water in this eastern Kentucky town ran dry this week, prompting Gov. Wallace Wilkinson to declare a state of emergency that authorizes the National Guard to ship water in from other areas. The Governor's executive order, dated Wednesday, cited the ''considerable hardship and health hazard'' that occurred when the water level dropped over the weekend. The system serves about 1,000 people.

title: MINOR VIOLATIONS OF ARMS PACT SEEN
description: The Reagan Administration today charged the Soviet Union with five minor violations of the new treaty to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land. But it said all the infractions had been corrected or were being resolved.

title: First Georgia Holding reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Arc International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Boxing Notebook; Tyson-Bruno Bout Still Seems Far Off
description: Not long ago, Seth Abraham of Home Box Office was optimistic about Mike Tyson's imminent return to the prize ring.

title: Seagate Job Cuts
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the world's largest maker of hard disk drives for small computers, said it had laid off 1,000 employees in a move that cuts its domestic work force by 20 percent. The domestic layoff followed the company's recent announcement that it was reducing its Singapore work force by 800 employees. A Merrill Lynch analyst, James Stone, said the cutbacks had resulted from Seagate's decision to increase capacity over the last few years in expectation of a greater market for its products.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Sanders in Absentia Heisman Trophy winners are supposed to need national television exposure, and Barry Sanders didn't have it. Heisman Trophy winners are supposed to be seniors, and Barry Sanders is only a junior. Heisman Trophy winners are supposed to come from national powerhouses, and Barry Sanders's Oklahoma State team was no better than third in the Big Eight Conference. The Heisman Trophy is supposed to be coveted and Barry Sanders professes not to even want it all that much. So who will win the Heisman Trophy when the announcement is made tonight at the Downtown Athletic Club? Probably Barry Sanders - and he won't even be on hand to accept it. The Oklahoma State tailback will be preparing for a game in Tokyo against Texas Tech. CBS, however, has set up a special satellite link by which Sanders is expected to speak to the news media from his hotel.(AP)

title: Jazz Orchestra
description: Toshiko Akiyoshi, pianist and composer, is to lead the New York Jazz Orchestra, featuring Lew Tabackin on saxophone and flute, tonight and tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M., and there is to be a midnight set tonight; $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: Man Killed in Mexican Crash Is Indeed Iran-Contra Figure
description: The Israeli Embassy, confirming that the man killed in a plane crash on Wednesday was Amiram Nir, a figure in the Iran-contra scandal, said today that Mr. Nir was not on ''any official business'' in Mexico.

title: Duper Appeals
description: Mark Duper of the Miami Dolphins appealed his season-ending drug-related suspension to the National Football League yesterday and was told a decision will be made after his case is discussed with Commissioner Pete Rozelle. Duper, who was suspended Wednesday for 30 days for violating the league's substance-abuse policy, met with the league vice president and counsel, Jay Moyer, for two hours. Dan Bakst, the wide receiver's agent, said Thursday that Duper was suspended apparently because he failed to appear for two drug tests last week. The two-time Pro Bowl player tested positive early this season, Bakst said. Duper disputed the result but agreed to random tests three times a week. The league considers failure to show to be a positive test. (AP)

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $2,903,529 from disposal of a warehouse business. c-Includes a tax credit of $300,000.

title: New York Jobless Rate Rises; Jersey Figure Remains Steady
description: The unemployment rate in New York State climbed slightly last month, and New Jersey figures remained steady, the Federal Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Can Sound of Silence Play in Japan?
description: In Japan, when people have something to say, they turn to the loudspeaker.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
description: The latest 12 months is after a provision of $54 million to provide for potential uncollectibility of certain power sales to Gulf States Utilities Co. The year-ago 12 months included an after-tax charge of $229 million to cover a construction cost over-run at the company's Vogtle nuclear plant.

title: Selfix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the increase was largely the result of the sale of plastic shutter products by Shutters Inc., a manufacturer of exterior shutters acquired in February 1988.

title: How Gentification Broke My Nose
description: It was 8:30 P.M. on a Friday night in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Four young black males attacked three young white males on their way to the subway station at the intersection of Seventh and Flatbush Avenues. Two of the whites were basically unharmed, while one of the whites suffered a severely broken nose. I was the one with the broken nose.

title: Pay $170,000, Police Chief Told
description: A Federal jury has ordered Police Chief Daryl Gates of Los Angeles to pay $170,000 personally to a man whose nose was broken by police officers who ransacked his house looking for a weapon used in a gang slaying.

title: Analogic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter included a gain of $4,600,000 from sale of Medical Electronic Laboratories Inc.

title: Panel Finds 'Serious Errors' In Paper on Gene Experiment
description: A panel of experts has concluded that an important scientific paper, whose authors include a Nobel Laureate, Dr. David Baltimore, contained ''serious errors of misstatement and omission'' but no evidence of fraud, according to a draft report of its findings.

title: 12,913,582 to 1, but Oh That Irresistible 1
description: Rebecca Ebere of Brooklyn looked at her watch and sighed. She had been standing in a lottery ticket line for 30 minutes yesterday and still could not see the ticket agent.

title: Final Test Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Opera; 'Amahl,' With Visitors and Livestock
description: ''Amahl and the Night Visitors,'' now 37 years old, clings to the holiday season with amazing tenacity. Gian Carlo Menotti wrote it for television in 1951, and its performance has become as much an American December tradition as the Mormon Tabernacle Choir singing carols or ''All I want for Christmas is my two front teeth.''

title: U.S. Bars Some Soviet Jews And Armenians as Refugees
description: In a major change, the United States has begun rejecting applications from some Soviet Jews and other Soviet citizens who want to come to this country as refugees.

title: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $9,235,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. c-After a loss on the early extinguishment of debt of $6,027,000.
