Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about the artist Francois-Marius Granet misstated the location of the Musee Granet in one of two references. It is in Aix-en-Provence.

title: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The company said that in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.94, it consolidated the financial statements of its wholly owned finance, insurance and real estate subsidiaries with its manufacturing operations, beginning with the July 1988 quarter. It also said all intercompany transactions have been eliminated and prior year financial statements have been restated to conform to the current year's presentation.

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Article 804088 -- No Title
description: A leader of an internationally renowned family of silversmiths and jewelers lost a reported $500,000 worth of jewelry belonging to his wife when the couple checked into a Fifth Avenue hotel Thursday, the police said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; Art Hodes, 84, Plays On
description: At the age of 84, Art Hodes is still playing the blues with easy authority. At the Fortune Garden Pavilion on Tuesday evening, that sense of authority was tinged with a mellow warmth, particularly when he was dealing with such classics as ''Chimes Blues'' and ''St. Louis Blues'' or anything that evolves into boogie-woogie.

title: Revolt by 400 Argentine Troops Quelled
description: Rebellious Argentine soldiers took control of an infantry school outside the capital today and tried to seize a prison where senior officers convicted of human rights abuses are being held.

title: Joseph W. Fischbach, Consultant, 71
description: Joseph W. Fischbach, president of Fischbach-McCoach Associates, a management consulting company, died of lung cancer Nov. 24 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Jump in Interest Rates Tied to Job Report
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday after the Government announced an increase in November employment that was much larger than expected.

title: Zenith Proxy Action Ended
description: Brookhurst Partners yesterday called off the proxy solicitation against the Zenith Electronics Corporation that it started in October. Brookhurst owns more than 6 percent of Zenith's common stock.

title: Memories Part of Gifts To Neediest
description: Elsie Mildred Garten was a ''loyal, born and bred New Yorker'' who loved New York City, appreciated its advantages and contributed faithfully to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, her sister, Muriel Kathryn Garten of Yonkers, said.

title: Review/Dance; As Usual, It's Toys 1, Mice 0
description: Mice, toys, snowflakes and candy canes have taken over the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet opened its annual winter engagement of ''The Nutcracker'' on Thursday night. Did the wicked mice win this time in their battle with the toys? Of course not. The mice never win in ''Nutcracker.''

title: In Shoreham Standoff, a Serious Defeat for Cuomo
description: By refusing to approve Governor Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant by Thursday's deadline, the New York State Legislature has deliberately engineered what is probably Governor Cuomo's most significant political defeat since he took office six years ago.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Rises
description: Japan said today that its unadjusted current account surplus for October rose by more than 10 percent from the period a year earlier, to $7.41 billion. It was the first increase since December 1987.

title: When It Counts, Nets Can't Deliver
description: The Nets are in a downward slide, desperately looking for something to cling to.

title: Anti-Apartheid Editor Freed With Restrictions
description: The editor of a prominent anti-apartheid newspaper financed by the Roman Catholic Church was conditionally freed from prison today after being held without charges for two years.

title: Culp Inc Qtr. to Oct 29 reports earnings for 1988
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $315,000 for the quarter and $675,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and included a gain of $927,000, or 21 cents a share, on the sale of Culp Industrial fabrics division.

title: Review/Dance; Bujones, Canada's Guest, Offers a Playful Prince
description: Fernando Bujones has pursued a freelance career since 1985. One result is that, to his detriment and ours, a great American dancer is rarely seen as part of a bona fide production in an established classical company.

title: Three New Members for Arts and Letters Academy
description: The composer John Cage, the writer Mary McCarthy and the painter Jasper Johns were elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters at the organization's annual meeting Friday at its Upper Manhattan headquarters. The three artists were chosen by other members of the Academy, which is a part of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Youth
description: An off-duty police officer shot and wounded a 15-year-old boy who pointed a revolver at him last night in a Brooklyn clothing store, the police said.

title: Break-in Ends in Kidnapping
description: A New Jersey man was charged with burglary, kidnapping and assault yesterday after he broke into a woman's house, chased her down the street at gunpoint and forced her into a passing car in the town of Westfield, N.J., the police there said.

Kaypro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
Presents You Don't Even Need To Wrap
description: The gift certificate, that standby of the harried or indecisive holiday shopper, is turning up everywhere.

title: Nutmeg Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Ian Keldoulis Is Wed To Olivia King Canter
description: Olivia King Canter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman M. Canter of Fairfield, Conn., was married in Santa Fe, N.M., yesterday to Ian Keldoulis, a son of Dr. Theo Keldoulis of Sydney, Australia, and Helen Sutherland of Edinburgh. Lily Gonzalez, a town justice of Santa Fe, performed the ceremony at the Town Hall.

title: Texas Judge Says He'll Urge New Trial in 1976 Murder
description: A State district judge today recommended a new trial for a man convicted of murdering a Dallas police officer in 1976 and said he believed a jury would find the man not guilty.

title: Patents; Toothbrush Developed For the Handicapped
description: Youti Kuo of Penfield, N.Y., has developed a toothbrush for the physically handicapped that dispenses its own toothpaste and requires only one hand to operate.

title: Biotech Plight: A Cash Shortage
description: After investing billions of dollars and dreaming for years about creating pharmaceutical products that would change daily life, the biotechnology industry is running out of cash.

title: Film Festival That Lost Its Star Film
description: What is the director of a film festival to do when he loses his opening night film and film maker five days before the festival begins?

title: The Wonder of Africa Tempered by Sadness
description: African Madness By Alex Shoumatoff 202 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Zapata Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U S Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income and included gains of $16,042,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes. The latest 9 months included one- time charges equal to 7 cents a share relating to the closing of six superstores in the second quarter and other non-recurring items. The year-ago 9 months included gains of 16 cents a share from the sale of a menswear and shoe manufacturing unit. Year-ago 9-month figures have been restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Telecredit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Aifs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results for its first quarter ending Dec. 31 will include a non-recurring gain of about $864,000 as the result of the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Chinese and Soviets Say They Will Hold '89 Summit Meeting
description: The Chinese Foreign Minister met today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and the two sides said afterward that there would be a Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in the first half of next year.

title: Seton Hall Is Twice As Good
description: John Morton scored 22 points and Seton Hall went on a 15-0 second-half spurt tonight to defeat Central Connecticut State, 82-41, in the first round of the Seton Hall Tip-off tournament.

title: Islanders Aching for Victory
description: First there was a curfew, then a discretionary bed check, and next came an early morning practice in which every able-bodied Islander player except the goaltenders and an already haggard Ken Morrow was forced through a punishing practice that emphasized wind sprints before finesse.

title: Suave Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring expense of about $300,000 incurred in connection with its October 1987 self tender offer and related class-action litigation. c-Net income

title: A.T.&T.: Not the Only One
description: Millions of callers who use the American Telephone and Telegraph Company found their long-distance service disrupted for several hours last month when a construction crew accidentally severed a fiber-optic communication cable in New Jersey. What most did not realize is that they could have placed their calls through another long-distance carrier - MCI or U S Sprint - simply by dialing a five-digit access number.

title: Wells Fargo Broker
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it would open a full-service brokerage, Wells Fargo Securities Inc., on Jan. 1. Wells Fargo Securities will be staffed with 12 brokers in San Francisco and eight in Los Angeles, Wells Fargo's banking unit said. It said the brokerage house would provide investment advice and buy and sell recommendations to clients on a variety of securities. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, received approval for the brokerage unit in September. It is the first California bank to offer such a service through its subsidiary. Two banks in North Carolina offer similar services, Wells Fargo said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in Currents in The Home Section on Thursday about a line of wall-to-wall carpeting by 11 architects and artists gave an incorrect address for Furniture of the 20th Century. The correct address is 227 West 17th Street in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a brief article on Thursday about plans to execute the convicted killers of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India misstated the date of her assassination. It was Oct. 31, 1984.

title: Capasso Cursed About His Wife, A Witness Says
description: Carl A. Capasso screamed ''a lot of curse words'' when his estranged wife, Nancy, barred him from their Fifth Avenue apartment, a witness testified yesterday in the Bess Myerson trial.

title: Two Emigre Artists Invited To Give Moscow Concerts
description: The pianist Bella Davidovich and her son, Dmitri Sitkovetsky, both Soviet emigres, are to play three concerts in Moscow in December.

title: Reviews/Music; A Birthday Celebration Of Intricacy
description: Since its founding in 1971, the New York new-music group Speculum Musicae has been closely linked with the music of Elliott Carter. Thus, of all the Carter 80th-birthday tributes taking place this fall (the actual birthday is Dec. 11), that presented Thursday night at the Merkin Concert Hall by Speculum probably drew the most distinguished audience of Carter-admirers.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Cars Thieves Like
description: Buying a particular automobile may be a matter of personal choice. But if the model you favor is also preferred by car thieves, the choice can mean higher insurance costs. There were 1.3 million vehicles thefts reported in 1987, according to Government statistics, for an estimated loss of about $6 billion, and the rate has been increasing this year. The list of vehicles at high risk varies by insurer and area. These are the models with the highest theft rate in the nation in 1987 as compiled by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Vehicle Type/Model Thefts Per 1,000 Manufactured Pontiac Firebird 30.14 Chevrolet Camaro 26.02 Chevrolet Monte Carlo 20.28 Toyota MR2 19.25 Buick Regal 14.7 Mitsubishi Starion 14.7 Ferrari Mondial 13.60 Mitsubishi Mirage 12.80 Pontiac Fiero 12.68 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme 11.73 (Source: National Automobile Theft Bureau)

title: Shuttle With Spy Craft Lifts Off As Winds Ease With Minutes Left
description: The space shuttle Atlantis, swiftly taking advantage of a lull in the menacing high-altitude winds, rocketed into orbit today on a military mission to deploy a secret reconnaissance satellite.

title: Wally Berger, 83, Dies; Baseball Star in '30's
description: Wally Berger, the Boston Braves outfielder who hit 38 home runs as a rookie in 1930 to establish a major league record that stood for 57 years, died of a stroke Wednesday in Redondo Beach, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: New Soviet Commission To Aid Ethnic Refugees
description: The Soviet Government today announced formation of a special commission to deal with the refugee problem in the southern republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia and to give material aid to the strife-torn area.

title: New York Owes Head Start Workers a Pension
description: To the Editor:

title: American Business Computrs reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: France Ends Oil Embargo As Iran-Europe Ties Grow
description: France announced today that it was lifting its 16-month embargo against the purchase of Iranian oil by French companies, in the latest manifestation of growing trade ties between Iran and Western Europe.

title: Inconclusive Croudip Finding
description: A Gwinnett County coroner's jury today ruled that it could not be determined whether the cocaine-related death of the Atlanta Falcons defensive back David Croudip was a result of foul play or an accident.

title: Quanex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses on the extinguishment of debt of $2,345,000 and $4,720,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a tax credit of $256,000. c-Includes tax credits of $582,000 for the quarter and $2,158,000 for the year.

title: Soviets Study U.S. Alcoholism Treatment By CRAIG WOLFF
description: The five Soviet doctors listened with their ''hearts and minds'' at an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting when a young woman described her dependence on lunchtime martinis to get through the day.

title: Patents; Running on Water
description: Mere mortals may not be able to walk on water, but a New York inventor won patent approval this week for fins that will let them run. The fins fit on the feet, and each fin has a wide flap that extends out along thin wire spokes. The fins are wide enough to keep an adult afloat for the time it takes to make one running step.

title: Mitchell Seeks Major Policy Debates in Senate
description: George J. Mitchell, the new Senate Democratic leader, says that his ''fondest hope'' is to find a way to schedule formal major policy debates on the Senate floor.

title: Banker's Note Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest third quarter included a charge of $55,000 related to expenses involved in closing four unprofitable locations.

title: Farm House Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 15
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6 months included non-recurring income of $555,000 and $1,873,000, respectively, from the reversal of provisions for anticipated losses on a sale which did not occur, and the 6 months also included a non-recurring charge of $9,112,000 representing the loss incurrerd on the disposition of an investment in Diana Corp. The company said the latest 6 months also included non-recurring charges of $441,000 representing writeoff of deferred debt issuance costs, and $3,625,000 representing dilution of prior ownership interest in Diana Corp.

title: Unocal in Venture
description: The Unocal Corporation signed a previously announced agreement with Venezuela's national oil company to form a joint venture, transferring Unocal's Chicago refinery and related assets to it. Los Angeles-based Unocal expects to gain more than $500 million if the equal joint venture is completed, the energy company said. The deal is conditioned on acceptable agreements being reached on the joint venture and crude oil supply issues between Unocal and Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. affiliates. The assets to be transferred include Unocal's 147,000-barrels-a-day refinery near Lemont, Ill.; 14 terminals and more than 100 service stations, as well as an oil blending and packaging plant and contracts with a network of 190 marketers in 12 Midwest states. The venture will continue to manufacture and market Unocal's 76 branded products in this market, Unocal said.

title: Review/Concert; Lutoslawski and the Sound of Music
description: Apparently the word is filtering through to contemporary composers that the formally ingenious, arrogantly ugly music that has been mediocrity's passport to academic respectability since World War II may have outlived even that ephemeral usefulness.

title: Yanks, LaPoint Agree on Terms
description: The Yankees have taken another step toward bolstering their shaky pitching staff, reaching agreement with Dave LaPoint on a three-year contract worth about $2.5 million, a source familiar with the deal said last night.

title: A Victory for Careless Police
description: Promoters of tougher law enforcement might praise the Supreme Court's ruling that it's constitutional to convict a defendant even though police have carelessly lost evidence that could prove his innocence. A close look at the case makes clear that the ruling needlessly rewards police negligence and may render society less safe.

title: Gelman Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $240,000 from an accounting change.

title: 'Who Is a Jew?' Debate in Israel Attracts Leading Figures of U.S. Judaism
description: An elderly man rose last month at the annual convention of the Council of Jewish Federations and spoke in a voice heavy with emotion.

title: JOB GROWTH RISES ALONG WITH RATE OF UNEMPLOYMENT
description: The Labor Department reported today that more than 450,000 new jobs were generated in November, a striking performance that indicated the economy is maintaining its vigorous rebound from a summer lull.

title: Alvin B. Lebar, Lawyer, 66
description: Alvin B. Lebar, a lawyer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Perth Amboy, N.J.

title: Dollar Drops Unexpectedly In Spite of Strong Job Data
description: The foreign exchange market was contrary yesterday, driving the dollar down despite an employment report that normally would have been expected to lift it.

title: Texaco Canada
description: Texaco Canada Inc. declared a special cash dividend of $6.50 (Canadian) a share on its outstanding common shares. The dividend is payable Feb. 1 to shareholders of record Jan. 19. Texaco Canada said the special dividend, totaling $785 million, is intended to make it easier to sell the company. Texaco Inc., which owns 78 percent of Texaco Canada, has said it will sell its interest in the Canadian subsidiary.

title: Songs and Guitar
description: Doc Watson and Eric Andersen, guitarists and singers, are to perform at 8:30 and 11:30 tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $13.

title: Triton Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $25,488,000 and $28,665,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $33,530,000 for the quarter and $34,226,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $6,029,000 for the quarter and $13,689,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $2,961,000 and $8,404,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: New-Home Sales Post 3.5% Gain
description: New-home sales in October jumped to the highest level since February 1987, the Government said today, surprising analysts who have been expecting that this year's rising interest rates would dampen sales.

title: Blood Bank Loses Suit Over AIDS Virus Tainting
description: This city's largest blood bank has become the first in the nation to be successfully sued for negligently providing blood tainted with the AIDS virus to a patient who subsequently developed acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: U.N. VOTES TO MOVE SESSION TO GENEVA
description: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to move its current session to Geneva later this month so that Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, can address it.

title: 34 U.S. Marks Allowed
description: The records committee of The Athletic Congress, the national governing body of track and field in the United States, has accepted 34 American records and rejected six other record applications. The committee accepted 21 men's marks and 13 women's records set during the 1988 season. Among those accepted were the world marks of 10.49 seconds for the women's 100-meter dash and 21.34 for 200 meters by Florence Griffith Joyner; the 43.29 for the men's 400 by Butch Reynolds, and the 7.291 points in the heptathlon by Jackie Joyner-Kersee. Among the applications rejected was the time of 7 minutes 18.67 seconds achieved by Arkansas in the 3,200-meter relay of the 1987 National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor championships, because not all the team members were American citizens. . . . Bill Moultrie of Howard University and Gary Winckler of Illinois were named coaches of the United States track and field teams for the 1989 World Indoor Championships. Moultrie will be the men's coach and Winckler will coach the women for the March 3-5 meet at Budapest. (AP)

title: A Vote For Fergie
description: Few pitchers have endured like Ferguson Arthur Jenkins, the strapping 6-foot-5-inch Canadian with the sizzling fastball, the capacity to labor like a milk horse, and with the luck of the Titanic.

title: Hanukkah's Tale of Hope Heartens Young Patients
description: A little boy who had no hair hugged a corduroy pillow shaped like a rabbit as if he would never let go. A dark-eyed girl with a Mickey Mouse nightgown and Mickey Mouse slippers twirled her intravenous cord around her Mickey Mouse jewelry box. A little boy pulled his robe gingerly over his bandaged shoulder and sighed.

title: Bhutto Pledges Aid to Women, Students and Labor
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was sworn into office today, announced a Government program tonight that promised an end to restrictions on women's rights, labor unions, students and the press.

title: Ex-Owner of Concrete Plant Sues New York
description: The previous owner of a concrete plant subsidized by New York City filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday charging city officials and the current owners of the plant with fraud and breach of contract.

title: Mid-State Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The prior year figures do not reflect the acquisition of First Federal Savings and Loan of Brooksville, acquired during the latest fiscal year.

title: Nodaway Valley Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52..

title: Meridian Diagnostics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bridge; Arkansas brothers who won Swiss Team title may be today's top sibling partnership.
description: For some reason, sibling partnerships seldom make a mark on the tournament scene. In the 50's, the brothers Ernst and Fritz Goudsmit were regular members of the Dutch international team. Even stronger were the British twins Robert Sharples and the late James Sharples.

title: Article 747388 -- No Title
description: The antiquities market moved into high gear yesterday as new price levels were reached in the sale at Sotheby's of ancient Greek, Roman and Egyptian art. Major works were bought at record prices by a number of buyers, including Edward H. Merrin, a New York dealer who has been backed since early November by a publicly traded investment company, Canal Capital Corporation, in which the financier and collector Asher B. Edelman has a majority holding.

title: Final Race Today For Mack Lobell
description: Mack Lobell, history's fastest trotter and the only American one to earn more than $2 million in his career, will race for the last time Saturday night when he competes in the $100,000 Frederick Van Lennep Trot at Pompano Park.

title: Patents; Two New Variations On Bowling
description: The number of serious bowlers has been declining in recent years, so the Brunswick Bowling and Billiards Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of pin-setting equipment, is thinking up new variations on the old game.

title: Legal Experts to Debate Brawley-Case Issues
description: Legal experts from around New York State will debate the Tawana Brawley case in a forum open to the public on Monday at 6 P.M. at the Helmsley Hotel on East 42d Street.

title: MHI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Car Sales Incentives Seem Likely
description: The nation's swelling inventory of 2.3 million unsold new cars may be put on sale at substantial discounts in the next few weeks, industry analysts say.

title: Coping: With Pets at Holiday Time
description: To pay or not to pay $20 for a shapely 1.7-ounce bottle of La Pooch perfume? That's only one of the decisions faced by pet owners at holiday time. Temptations, extravagances and risks are inherent in sharing the Christmas spirit, including the weighty matter of whether to get someone a pet as a gift.

title: National Securities Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
AM International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,980,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6 Five hijackers in the Soviet Union seized a bus full of schoolchildren, exchanged their hostages for a plane and more than $3 million in ransom, then flew to Tel Aviv and surrendered to Israeli authorities. Page 1 The U.N. General Assembly voted to move its current session to Geneva later this month so that Yasir Arafat can address it. Mr. Arafat has been denied entry to the United States. 1 Soviets citizens have been denied refugee status in the United States because they could not demonstrate ''a well-founded fear of persecution,'' Federal officials said. 1 A Chinese-Soviet summit meeting will take place in the first half of next year, the two sides announced after a meeting between the Chinese Foreign Minister and Mikhail Gorbachev in Moscow. 1 A massacre of Guatemalan peasants last week in which 22 civilians were tortured and strangled to death was carried out by leftist guerrillas, villagers said. A leading guerrilla group denied the charge. 3 South Africa released the editor of a prominent anti-apartheid newspaper after holding him without charges for two years. But the authorities immediately put the journalist, Zwelakhe Sisulu, under tough new restrictions. 4 American Jews have visited Israel in great numbers and with surprising spontaneity in the month since the Israeli elections. They are fighting an effort by Orthodox Jewish parties to amend Israel's Law of Return. 6 The White House charged the Soviets with five minor violations of the new accord to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles but said all the infractions have been corrected or are being resolved. 5 France said it will end an embargo against the purchase of Iranian oil by French companies in the latest manifestation of growing trade ties between Iran and Western Europe. 35 National 8-12, 28, 52 More than 450,000 jobs were created in November, indicating a strong economy. Because the number of people looking for work also increased, the unemployment rate edged up a tenth of a point. 1 Unemployment in New York State climbed slightly in November, to a rate of 4.6 percent, while New Jersey's rate remained at 3.9 percent, the Government reported. 12 The space shuttle Atlantis launched into orbit on a mission to deploy a reconnaisance satellite after swiftly taking advantage of a lull in the menacing high-altitude winds. 1 President-elect Bush will review his options and strategies for tackling the Federal deficit in a meeting with his senior advisers on Sunday, Mr. Bush's aides said. 10 News analysis: A Bush-Dukakis meeting completed a week in which the President-elect has reached out to political opponents of both parties to establish a theme of conciliation. 10 Investment for biotechnology is becoming scarce after billions of dollars have been directed to the hope of creating revolutionary products. Experts say the shortfall comes at a time of critical need. 35 George Mitchell's ''fondest hope'' as the new Senate Majority Leader, he said, is to find a way to schedule formal major policy debates on the Senate floor that would evoke the drama of a parliamentary body. 10 An air safety directive to review takeoff warning systems was not received by the chief Federal inspector for Delta Air Lines until more than two months after it was issued and several days after a Delta jet crash, the inspector said. 28 Ohio has the first claim to resources the Federal Government has devoted to repairing environmental damage at nuclear weapon plants, state environmental officials asserted. 8 Basic flaws in computer security similar to the one that let a rogue program jam a nationwide computer network are far more common than is generally believed, system designers say. 8 Serum from healthy AIDS carriers that had been injected into patients ill with AIDS apparently cleared the virus from the patients' blood, two studies have found. They do not show whether the treatment can prolong lives. 9 A blood bank in San Francisco has become the first such repository in the nation to be successfully sued for providing blood tainted with the AIDS virus to a patient who later developed the disease. 9 New-home sales jumped in October to the highest level since February 1987, the Government said, surprising analysts who have been expecting the rise in interest rates this year to dampen sales. 35 Having agreed to buy RJR Nabisco, Henry R. Kravis and another partner of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company flew to RJR Nabisco's headquarters in Atlanta to begin rebuilding morale. 35 Regional 29-32 Lilco said it was no longer bound to Governor Cuomo's plan to close the Shoreham nuclear plant, which the New York State Legislature has not adopted. The utility filed for an emergency rate increase. 1 News analysis: The State Legislature in New York has engineered what is probably Governor Cuomo's greatest defeat in Albany by refusing to approve his plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant. 32 Joel Steinberg told Hedda Nussbaum hours after Lisa Steinberg had been fatally injured that he had ''knocked Lisa down and she didn't want to get up,'' Ms. Nussbaum said at the Steinberg trial. 29 Asbestos in New York City can be found in about two-thirds of all buildings, said a study issued by Mayor Koch, who proposed new laws to remove or contain the potentially disease-causing fibers. 29 People hoping to win the state lottery in New York have spent more than $12 million a day on Lotto tickets since Thursday, their eyes on the $45 million jackpot in tonight's drawing. It is the largest in the state's history. 29 American treatments for alcoholism have been studied by five Soviet doctors on a visit to the United States. They are searching for more successful ways to treat the disease in the Soviet Union. 29 Neediest Cases 30

title: SKETCHES OF 5 ON THE SHUTTLE MISSION
description: For the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, a secret mission for the Defense Department, the space agency chose only astronauts who are in the military. Here are sketches of the five astronauts aboard the Atlantis. Robert L. Gibson Mission Commander

title: Guatemala Massacre Laid to Rebels
description: Villagers here say guerrillas were responsible for a massacre last week in which 22 unarmed peasants were tortured and strangled.

title: For Most Americans, Canada Is Just a Blur
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Parody of a Skyjacking' Ends Peacefully in Israel
description: Five Soviet hijackers seized a bus full of schoolchildren, exchanged their hostages for a cargo plane and more than $3 million in ransom, then flew here today and surrendered to Israeli authorities.

title: INSIDE
description: Biotechnology Companies: Feeling the Pinch

title: Henley Spinoff Gets an Offer
description: The Henley Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it had received a takeover offer of $80 a share, or $208 million, from New Hampshire Oak Inc., a holding company controlled by top executives of Henley Group Inc.

title: Optical Specialties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McGraw-Hill World News Will Close at End of Month
description: McGraw-Hill World News, a worldwide reporting network that supplies business news articles to the magazines, newsletters and wire services owned by McGraw-Hill Inc., will be dissolved at the end of this month, executives of the publishing conglomerate said yesterday.

title: Study Finds Prevalence Of Asbestos
description: About two-thirds of all the buildings in New York City contain some form of asbestos, said a scientific study issued yesterday by Mayor Koch, who proposed new laws and regulations intended to remove or contain the potentially disease-causing fibers.

title: N.C.A.A. Soccer; Spotlight on Defense in Semifinals
description: Vivid proof that defense is what wins in soccer is exemplified by the four teams in today's semifinals in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Rales Group Seeking Interco's Ethan Allen
description: An investment group led by the Washington investors Steven M. Rales and his brother Mitchell P. Rales has formally expressed its interest in beginning negotiations with Interco Inc. to acquire the company's furniture division, Ethan Allen Inc.

title: Linda Schaller Is Wed To Steven P. Schwartz
description: The marriage of Linda Lee Schaller and Steven Paul Schwartz took place yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's home in New York. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: President-Elect Reaches Out to Heal Election Wounds in Distinctive Style
description: President-elect Bush's meeting today with Michael S. Dukakis completed a week in which he reached out to political opponents in both parties to establish a theme of conciliation after a bruising campaign.

title: In the Ultimate Test, the System Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiley, John & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Oversight on Jail Contract
description: A $34 million contract to build a new five-story jail lacked one major item: doors. Omitted from the contract was $1.5 million for 195 electronic sliding glass cell doors and other furnishings, city officials said Thursday. Michael Berg, the sheriff's director of jails and prisons, said the cell doors would be purchased out of a $2 million contingency fund established to pay for costs in excess of the contract.

title: A J Ross Logistics Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pregnancy Is No Bar To Law Partnerships
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.L.U. Continues Struggle of the Framers
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Bright, 87, Dies; A Writer for Children
description: Robert Bright, an author and illustrator of children's books, died of cancer on Nov. 21 at his home in San Francisco. He was 87 years old.

title: 2 Top South Africans Arrive Early for Talks
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister, alluding to difficulties in overcoming the last obstacle to a peace settlement in southern Africa, arrived here today to lend his weight to the newest round of negotiations involving Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States.

title: Dow Declines 9.60 Points, to 2,092.28
description: LEAD: The stock market declined yesterday after the Labor Department released its employment figure for November, but traders said the stock pullback was surprisingly modest.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It's there - and it's big.'' - Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, on the increase in jobs.

title: Donald E. Keyhoe, 91, Exponent of U.F.O.'s
description: Donald Edward Keoeoe, a retired Marine Corps major who espoused the belief that there were unidentified flying objects from outer space, died of pneumonia and cardiac arrest Tuesday at the Life Care Center in New Market, Va. He was 91 years old and lived in Luray, Va.

title: Village Super Market Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 22
Prab Robots Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Lebanon Letter Urges Swiss To Cooperate With Captors
description: A letter apparently from a Swiss Red Cross worker kidnapped last month was made public today. It calls on the Swiss Government to cooperate with the kidnappers ''to save my life.''

title: Galileo Electro-Optics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Ohio Stakes Nuclear Cleanup Claim
description: Environmental officials in Ohio asserted yesterday that they had staked the first claim on the meager resources the Federal Government has devoted to repairing environmental damage at nuclear weapon plants.

title: 6 Ask Dismissal of Case on Fighting in Nicaragua
description: Six men accused of leading armed attacks in Nicaragua in violation of United States law urged a judge today to dismiss the charges on the ground that this country has been waging a de facto war against the Nicaraguan Government.

title: I.B.M. Gift To Colleges
description: In an effort to increase the pool of workers in computer-integrated manufacturing, the International Business Machines Corporation plans to give up to $25 million to help American colleges establish training and demonstration centers.

title: Army vs. Navy: The Strategy Is Hardly a Secret
description: Because both teams run, run and run some more from wishbone offenses and seldom throw a pass, they have few secrets to keep from one another. Will the Army-Navy game this afternoon at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia therefore be predictable, or even a little dull?

title: Price of Hughes Acquisition Is Being Disputed by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had begun arbitration proceedings with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute to determine if a partial refund is warranted of the $5.2 billion it paid to acquire the Hughes Aircraft Company.

title: Serum From Virus Carriers Found to Help AIDS Patients
description: Injected serum from healthy carriers of the AIDS virus apparently cleared the virus from the blood of patients who were ill with AIDS, two recent studies have found. But the studies did not establish whether this experimental treatment can prolong the lives of AIDS patients, and scientists urged caution in interpreting the results.

title: Bush Is Planning a Session To Review Deficit Strategy
description: President-elect Bush, under pressure from Congress to take the lead in tackling the Federal deficit, will review options and strategy for the first time at a meeting Sunday with his senior advisers, Mr. Bush's aides said today.

title: New York Principals: A Tale
description: This is a tale of two principals in the New York City school system. One of them, Matthew

title: Lendl Defeats Agassi
description: The first set was a lot like playing against the wind, with Ivan Lendl making little headway against a tennis gust with streaked blond hair. Everything Lendl hit appeared to come back twice as hard, with Andre Agassi playing each point briskly, as if he were trying to prevent Lendl from catching his breath.

title: Meyer, Fred Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
Jail for Wings' Klima
description: A judge ordered the Detroit Red Wings forward Petr Klima to spend yesterday afternoon in jail after Klima pleaded guilty to violating the terms of his probation with a second drunken-driving arrest.

title: HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: Sometime in the beginning of December - the exact hour may vary - an irrepressible urge overcomes the civilized world. Quite suddenly, people are transformed into hosts. Even the most urbane, cool-headed sophisticates find themselves threading strings of popcorn and cranberries, humming Christmas carols and plying people with stacks of presents and plates heaped with food. The season begins its softening dance.

title: Rewards Are Slim In Sailboat Series
description: The first year of professional sailboat racing in the United States has brought with it both hope and doubt for its future survival.

title: School Shuts for Disease
description: A private alternative elementary school closed today to let an outbreak of whooping cough run its course after parents balked at subjecting their children to immunization or antibiotic treatment. The teachers council voted to shut the Rudolf Steiner School until Jan. 4, said a faculty spokesman. He said the state Department of Public Health had threatened to allow only those students and teachers taking antibiotics to attend classes, and so few agreed that it would have been impossible for the school to operate.

title: WHAT'S INANNA? MODEM? SKA? A QUIZ FOR THE WINTER SOLSTICE
description: Once upon a time, argues E. D. Hirsch Jr. in his 1987 book, ''Cultural Literacy,'' when schools and colleges offered a standard curriculum, there existed a great shared body of knowledge. Mourning the end of those days, Mr. Hirsch offered in their memory some 5,000 terms - passwords to savviness: book titles, authors, dates, scientific concepts, sayings, historical events.

title: Proof of Baby Switch Is Cited
description: A lawyer for a couple who believe that a 10-year-old Sarasota girl is their daughter said Friday that he has medical records to support the assertion.

title: AIDS Victim Writes for His Children
description: When Bill Vincent realized he would probably die before his children were grown, he started searching for a way to remain a part of their lives.

title: Bhutto Plans Amnesty and No Change in Afghanistan Policy
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto announced an amnesty for political and other prisoners today and pledged to maintain Pakistan's policy toward Afghanistan.

title: Barbara Lane Married To Thomas Astbury Jr.
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Barbara Anne Lane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Lane of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Astbury Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Astbury of Trenton. The Rev. James J. Fischer, the president of Regis High School in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our asphalt shingle roof has dark streaks of mildew on it, even though there are no overhanging trees that keep it shaded. When we had mildew on the siding, we scrubbed it off with a mixture of bleach and water. If we use this method on the roof, will this loosen the little granules on the shingles, and is there anything we can do to prevent the mildew from returning?

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Springfield, Mass.;
New Homes In Old Styles
description: LEAD: A LOCAL real estate agent is helping to revive an inner-city neighborhood where he was brought up by building new homes in 19th-century styles.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: On the eve of photography's 150th anniversary, this year's crop of photography books has a fin de siecle air. Overall, there is a sense of reflectivity and limited ambition, as if photographers and book publishers alike have pulled in their horns in advance of the millennium. No blockbuster monographs of modernist masters are in evidence. And one can see in four of the books discussed below - Bernd and Hilla Becher's ''Water Towers,'' Lynne Cohen's ''Occupied Territory,'' George Tice's ''Hometowns'' and ''American Classroom: The Photographs of Catherine Wagner'' - an emptying out of human presence.

title: An Infamous Anniversary for Topical Collectors
description: THE speech by Franklin Delano Roosevelt began like this:

title: A Musical Theme Binds Together an Exhibition of 40 Works
description: SIGMUND R. BALKA doesn't come on as a Renaissance man but he is, nevertheless, general counsel to Krasdale Foods, president of the Graphic Arts Council of New York and eminence grise at the Bronx Museum's satellite gallery in the Krasdale Building.

title: Islanders' Losing Streak at 7
description: The effort was there, the goals were not. A 4-2 loss in Pittsburgh tonight capped a disastrous three-game trip for the Islanders and extended their losing streak to seven games.

title: Pattern-Book Architecture: Revolution in Building
description: LEAD: F you think you have spotted a house identical to your own, or one nearly so, it could be more than coincidence. The genealogy of many American homes, old and new, can be traced to an antecedent in a pattern book rather than a commissioned-to-order architect's blueprint.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey

West Orange $245,000 104 Lessing Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; central air-conditioning, garage, den, fireplace; taxes $5,212. OTHER AREAS Ridgefield, Conn. $422,000 128 Sleepy Hollow Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceilings, hot tub, 2.1 acres; taxes $3,429. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. $500,000 3 Floral Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 73-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, playroom, workshop; taxes $7,032. Patchogue, L.I. $139,000 25 Roland Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new ranch; basement, dining room; eat-in kitchen; estimated taxes $2,500.

title: Ithaca Moves To Final By 62-28
description: Paul Parker ran for five touchdowns today as Ithaca soared to a 62-28 victory over Ferrum in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinal game.

title: Giving the Look Of a Changing Guard
description: The totems of shifting power are everywhere. At the Palm Restaurant downtown, the owners are getting ready for what they call ''the changing of the guard'' - when they remove the caricatures of Ronald and Nancy Reagan in the center of the dining room and replace them with ones of George and Barbara Bush. Meanwhile, color portraits of several in Mr. Bush's inner circle have already gone up. Mr. Fuller, Frederick M. Bush, Lee Atwater, Richard N. Bond and Edward M. Rogers Jr. smile down on diners and, often, on themselves.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Our Shakespeare

title: Review/Cabaret; A Campy Showgirl Sendup
description: One would have to look far and wide to find a show that packs as much campy show-business esoterica into one hour as John Epperson's ''I Could Go on Lip-Synching.''

title: Artist, Reciter Try a Collaboration
description: LEAD: YEARS ago, when they first met and began admiring each other's work, the storyteller Heather Forest and the artist Susan Gaber thought ''it would be neat'' to work together Ms. Forest recalled.

title: Flowers ProgramIs a Matter of Pride
description: LEAD: IT was a chilly fall morning when the head gardeners of this city's Flowers Blocks program gathered for the last meeting of the season while their marigolds, begonias and impatiens wilted with the onset of the first frost. The group shared impressions, stories and a certain degree of amusement about the success of the community's beautification project, which no one believed could work.

title: DATA BANK: December 4, 1988
Ailey: Dancing the Dream
description: ARTIST AND HUMANIST ROLLED into one, Alvin Ailey has been the great anomaly of American dance for the last 30 years. At a time when nearly all the arts turned toward abstraction, not to speak of inaccessibility via trendy minimalist and conceptualist currents, Mr. Ailey insisted on celebrating the human spirit. Communication with the widest audience possible was his goal, harmony was his ideal.

title: Correction
description: An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies last Sunday about Marian P. Welch, editor of two John Birch Society publications, described the namesake of the society incorrectly. Capt. John Birch, a missionary in China before World War II, served in the war as an intelligence officer. He was killed by Chinese Communists on Aug. 25, 1945, 10 days after V-J Day.

title: TRAILBLAZERS OF THE NEW HIGH FINANCE
description: ON THE MORNING OF OCT. 19, 1987, A CAUTIOUS, SOBER GENTLEMAN named Stanley A. Seneker arrived at the 12th floor of Glass House, Ford Motor Company's world headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., to assume his new duties as chief financial officer. The events of the day, he recalls with typical understatement, came as ''quite a surprise.'' At 9 o'clock that morning, the Ford pension funds, one of Seneker's primary responsibilities, had been worth $15 billion. By day's end, after a $500 billion firestorm in the equity markets, Stanley Seneker discovered that he had presided over the loss of $2 billion in his pension funds during his first seven hours on the job. ''It was quite a trying day,'' he says.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VERSIONS OF CHEKHOV A few years ago John Houseman's Acting Company invited 12 well-known playwrights to adapt some of Chekhov's short stories into one-act plays. ''Seven of them responded,'' said Tom Zingarelli, the director of the Fairfield University Players's production of the results, to be performed Monday Saturday at the University Playhouse.

title: Let the Buyers Beware of 'Gorby Gridlock'
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will address the United Nations this week, have lunch with President Reagan and President-elect Bush, tour a city swathed in Christmas glitter and hopelessly snarl traffic and block shoppers.

title: Fighting Erosion, One Grain of Sand
description: MY house fronts on Long Island Sound. It sits like a yellow-and-white-clad matron at least 30 feet back from the water's edge of a half- moon-shaped cove.

title: Helping a Hamlet
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Newington, Conn. $140,000 221 Main Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, patio; taxes $1,457. Ridgefield, Conn. $422,000 128 Sleepy Hollow Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceilings, hot tub, 2.1 acres; taxes $3,429. Southington, Conn. $143,000 68 Raynor Street 3-bedroom, 1 bath, 80-year-old colonial; new siding and roof, dining room, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,257. Croton-On-Hudson, N.Y. $360,000 32 Westminster Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; fireplace, c/a, central vacuum, 2 decks, 2-car garage; taxes $5,053. OTHER AREAS Toms River, N.J. $87,900 918 Hardenbrook Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, full basement, corner lot; taxes $917. West Orange, N.J. $245,000 104 Lessing Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; garage, c/a, den, fireplace; taxes $5,212. Lindenhurst, L.I. $126,000 121 North Clinton Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, dining room, fireplace, basement, walk to railroad station and schools; taxes $1,600.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Joe Jackson Turnabout
description: Like a pot a feu that stews all winter on the back burner, the question of Shoeless Joe Jackson's guilt in the 1919 Black Sox scandal is a fixture of the Hot Stove League, the chit chat circuit that keeps baseball folk all asimmer from the World Series to spring training.

title: Sherrye Henry Jr. And John Garrett Are Wed on L.I.
description: Sherrye Patton Henry Jr., a daughter of Sherrye Patton Henry of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and E. William Henry of Washington, was married yesterday to John Raymond Garrett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wiley C. Garrett of Blountstown, Fla. The Rev. Robert F. Capon performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: THE HOW-TO'S OF HOWDY-DO'S
description: ARE CONVENTIONS TRULY a nightmare? Do you have trouble knowing how to talk to strangers at business receptions? Susan RoAne, a lecturer and writer based in San Francisco, has your number. In her forthcoming book - ''How to Work a Room: A Guide to Successfully Managing the Mingling'' - she identifies the potential benefits of good mingling (the chance to build up your image, and your Rolodex) and provides a variety of strategies for the inhibited.

title: A Town Shares Ways to Handle Alzheimer's
description: Victoria Kennedy, a third grader, told her classmates in a quiet voice how her grandmother looked at wedding pictures and could not remember the names of her own family members.

title: Their Muse Is Malcolm X
description: WHEN THE SAXOPHONIST Steve Coleman performs with M-BASE, a 16-member avant-garde jazz collective, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival on Friday and Saturday, he'll be playing close to home.

title: Rickie Singer, Lawyer, Marries James Peaslee
description: Rickie L. J. Singer and James M. Peaslee, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the New York home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Blum. Justice Bentley Kassal of the State Supreme Court Appellate Division in Manhattan, and Rabbi Burt Siegel officiated.

title: The P.L.O. Has Proved That It Will Negotiate
description: To the Editor:

title: Stretching the Budget for the First House
description: BEFORE the night was over and their wedding guests started to leave, Agatha and Robert Martino went through the customary receiving line at their reception. Relatives and friends wished them good luck and handed Aggie envelopes that she stuffed into a white satin sack.

title: Steel Cocoon Heralds Municipal Building Face Lift
description: The bureaucratic center of New York City is disappearing beneath a labyrinth of tubes, nets and catwalks and will not fully emerge again until 1993. But the scaffolding creeping 580 feet up the Municipal Building on Centre Street in lower Manhattan will stop short of obscuring ''Civic Fame,'' the 25-foot gilded statue that stands on top.

title: Syracuse Dominates Pitt, 24-7
description: Syracuse relied on Pitt's reputation as relentless pursuers on defense and used it against the Panthers for a 24-7 rout today in the Carrier Dome.

title: Stepping Down
description: A graduate student at the University of Rochester found a notable lack of originality in some of the published papers of Dr. Shervert H. Frazier, an eminent psychiatrist. The student, Paul Scatena, last summer brought his concerns to the attention of officials at Harvard Medical School, where Dr. Frazier was a professor and head of one of Harvard's principal teaching hospitals. Last week, Harvard released a letter in which the dean of the medical school said an investigating committee had found evidence of plagiarism in four papers that Dr. Frazier published between 1966 and 1975. The letter also said that Dr. Frazier, a former president of the American College of Psychiatrists, had resigned from his posts at Harvard.

title: Infra Dig
description: To the Editor:

title: The Party Line Isn't So Straight Anymore
description: AS Senate Democrats elected their new majority leader last week, they did so on an optimistic note: If they were still out of power in the White House, they were far from powerless in Washington. Paradoxically, one reason the Democrats had anything at all to celebrate as a party was that among the voters back home, party labels are meaning less and less.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: The New Good-Time Blues: More Fireworks, Less Fire
description: THERE'S ONE IN EVERY college town, sometimes two or three. Larger municipalities support even more, and New York has at least a dozen. They call themselves blues bands, and the musicians are usually white; they sport slouch or porkpie hats, sunglasses, banged-up vintage guitars and sometimes vintage zoot suits with harmonicas in the pockets. Mustaches and suspenders are optional. The good ones work regularly, on a circuit of bars, college dances and private parties; they know how to make a joint jump.

title: About Cars; Nissan's 240SX Passes the Test of Critics
description: Dick Fehr is standing there shivering, watching over his new pets. And he is wondering.

title: Teacher Assaulted; Student's Brother Held
description: A teacher was struck and knocked unconscious at his Bronx school Friday by the brother of a student whom the teacher had punished for chronic tardiness by locking away her coat, the police said yesterday.

title: TALKING: Employees; Avoiding Personnel Minefields
description: THE growth of protective personnel legislation in the last decade and the increasing number of challenges based on allegations of wrongful dismissal or unlawful labor practices has made the hiring, handling and dismissal of employees a legal minefield.

title: INSIDE
description: Hijackers Return to Russia

title: Sun Ra and Band
description: The keyboardist Sun Ra is to lead his Arkestra band tonight at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Can Nissan Stage a U.S. Comeback?
description: In the 1970's, when Japanese auto companies were making their big push into the American market with inexpensive, reliable little cars and trucks, Datsun was out in front with the leaders.

title: Books for Women Who Read About Men - Too Much
description: Looking for love in bookstores has been a boon to the publishing industry. In the past several years, cash registers have jingled with the sale of such best sellers as ''Women Who Love Too Much,'' ''Women Men Love, Women Men Leave,'' and ''Men Who Hate Women and the Women Who Love Them.''

title: Lasorda's Balk
description: Just about a month after he was the toast of the baseball world, you could look it up: The restaurant Tommy Lasorda owns in South Pasadena, Calif., was shut down for five days after being hit with 43 health-code violations, including what one inspector called ''one of the worst rat infestations I've seen.''

title: Central American Countries to Revive Peace Effort
description: After three days of negotiations here, the Presidents of five Central American countries have agreed to hold a regional summit meeting next month in an effort to revive a Central American peace effort that has been stalled for nearly a year.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: DICKENS DECOR

title: Alyson Flournoy, Professor, Weds
description: Alyson Craig Flournoy, an assistant professor of law at the University of Florida at Gainesville, and John Clifford Schaible, a lawyer with Neighborhood Legal Services in Washington, were married yesterday in the chapel at the Our Lady of Princeton guest house in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Edward Dougherty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Indiana Routed Again, 101-79
description: At another time, the Big Four Classic would have been a showdown between four of the most powerful college basketball programs in this region: Indiana and Notre Dame from in state, Louisville and Kentucky from across the Ohio River.

title: Amtrak Adopts Fare System Of Airlines
description: Amtrak will begin using the same kind of computerized fare-setting system as airlines some time next year, which will mean new, possibly lower fares and constantly varying numbers of seats at different prices.

title:
THEATER;
Jerome Robbins Gets a Little Help From His Friends
description: LEAD: CLAIRE DE LOONE (SINGING): Ya got me, baby, ya got me! (ba-bumbum-bum) (while clapping hands over head and stamping feet) Ya got my extensive knowledge of anatomy . . . (while outlining undulating body with rippling hands) Ya got my who-o-o-ole interest in mankind of every breed (while extending arms in generous gesture of giving)

title: Pace's Law Dean is Stepping Down
description: LEAD: AFTER leading the Pace University School of Law for half of its existence, Dean Janet A. Johnson will step down at the end of this academic year.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Nov. 19 MANHATTAN Chelsea $122,000 77 Seventh Avenue (15th St.) (Vermeer) 550-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer; maintenance $445, includes gas and electricity, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) Greenwich Village $1.06 million 393 Bleecker Street 2-family, 4-story town house; dining room in upper duplex; large kitchen in lower duplex; 4 bedrooms, 2 baths in each; 3 fireplaces, common garden; 20- by 40-ft. lot; taxes $5,841 (Broker: William B. QUEENS Queens Village $164,000 90-09 212th Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial: dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; 36- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $777 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Sunnyside $290,000 50-10 48th Street 2-family, attached brick house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 1 bedroom, dining room in other; large kitchen in each; finished basement, new roof, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $507 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Grymes Hill $325,000 210 Longview Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 75- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Pearl Foreman Real Estate) New Springville $245,000 66 Freedom Avenue 2-family, detached, raised-ranch; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining room in primary unit; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in other; large kitchens in both; in-ground pool, 1-car garage, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,400 (Broker: Weichert Realtors)
