The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: With a Knack for Knits
description: JOAN VASS has expanded her range since she introduced hand-knitted caps and scarves 11 years ago: she now shows jump suits, evening dresses and daytime suits in silk, wool and linen. But the knits still have a special cachet. They include midriff-baring pullovers, cardigans with a Chanel look, simple tank tops and sweaters and dresses with ruffled edges.

title: A Mansion Marks its Return to Glory
description: LEAD: A MAN'S house should be his castle, LeGrand Lockwood reasoned. So when Mr. Lockwood, a New York investment banker and one of America's first millionaires, decided in 1862 to build a country retreat in his home town of Norwalk, Conn., the result was a veritable palace. The nearly $2 million project was the most sumptuous private home built in

title: CACTUS AND HATHAWAY MEN
description: In looking ahead to the Giants' schedule not long ago, Phil Simms spoke of having to play ''St. Louis.'' He meant Phoenix, but he's not alone. Out of habit many pro football people still refer to ''St. Louis,'' which the Cardinals deserted earlier this year, just as many still refer to ''Oakland'' even though the Raiders abandoned that area for Los Angeles before the 1982 season.

title: Carson Deserves The 'Group Hug'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TEARING APART EASTERN AIRLINES
description: As an aviation writer and pilot, I was amused at your use of the word ''tarmac'' in a picture caption accompanying the article on Eastern Airlines.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
International Show Will Open on Saturday
description: LEAD: FOREIGN and ancient coins will be in the spotlight next weekend, when dealers and collectors gather for the 17th annual New York International Numismatic Convention. The show will open Saturday and continue through Monday, at the Sheraton Centre Hotel on Seventh Avenue between 52nd and 53rd streets.

title: The Primary Problem; How to Choose the V.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Crews Chosen for 4 Shuttle Flights
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has announced four crews for future missions of the space shuttle, including the shuttle's first black commander and a number of space rookies.

title: Hoist by a PAC Petard
description: Last year, Senate Republicans filibustered to block campaign finance reform. Their reward was renewed Democratic control of the House and Senate on Election Day. Why should Republicans continue to block reform?

title: Jazz That Flies Beyond The Pigeonholes
description: SINCE THE 1960'S, THE WORD jazz has put in some overtime. The music's original impulses have spread, as surely as a river entering a broad delta, into different styles and movements Unfortunately, the kinds of jazz musicians who have reached the status of public figure have never reflected jazz's breadth. They have been limited to a few predictable cliches - the elder statesman, the young turk, the novelty act. As a result, most of jazz's significant musicians are left out in the cold.

title: University's Chandelier Reappears in City Library
description: Brown University has asked the police to find out how a turn-of-the-century chandelier that disappeared from the school in the late 1970's has reappeared in the newly renovated Providence Public Library.

title: A Holiday Date With Bachelor No.3
description: LEAD: LIKE many holiday shoppers, Linda Kline of Vernon was not sure what to give her sister this year. But in a moment of spontaneity she decided on an unusual gift: dinner and a show with Jim Cassidy of Scotch Plains at the Tropicana in Atlantic City.

title:
ART;
Poles of Expression: Formal and Emotional
description: LEAD: JOAN SNYDER'S paintings speak with two voices: one that expresses itself in terms of art and another that talks of the human condition.

title: NOBODY TOLD A BAD JOKE BETTER
description: FLYWHEEL, SHYSTER, AND FLYWHEEL The Marx Brothers' Lost Radio Show. Edited by Michael Barson. 330 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $9.95.

title: I.O.C. May Study Drug Use of Weight Lifters
description: The twinkle of Christmas lights and a recent dusting of snow have added cheer to the usual charm of Austria's capital city, particularly within the old central district, where Mozart concerts are a way of life and trolley cars remain the most popular mode of public transportation.

title: Gilroy's 'Roses' Revived
description: REMEMBER ''Studio One,'' ''Playhouse 90,'' ''The U.S. Steel Hour'' and ''Omnibus''? Those were among the leading live 1950's television dramas - yes, live. On such shows - indeed, on all of them -the playwright Frank D. Gilroy paid his dues as a writer, before making his mark on Broadway with ''The Subject Was Roses,'' the play that won virtually all the important prizes, the Pulitzer included, during the 1964-65 theater season.

title: Bed and Breakfast
description: To the Editor: My husband and I were most intrigued by your article about London B & B's, having just had a wonderful experience with one of these places.

title: A SAMPLING OF EXPEDITIONS TO AFRICA
description: Andrew Fentiman, owner of Safari Consultants of London, arranges old-style safaris. ''A safari is an adventure,'' he says. ''It is not traveling in a caravan of minibuses.'' A luxury tour or custom-made safari, which is admittedly expensive, is one way to avoid Africa's burgeoning tourist circuit. Groups are smaller and private tented camps featured. (Since tents accommodate two, only a limited number of singles are usually allowed.) The place to start is with a safari packager, who will either provide a preplanned tour or arrange a safari tailored to the guests' desires. Packagers, usually through on-site outfitters, make arrangements for equipment, porters, charter aircraft and so on.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Demand for Industrial Condos Growing
description: LEAD: RESPONDING to a demand from small companies to buy rather than lease space, developers are building or renovating from old structures an increasing number of industrial condominiums in the heart of the Meadowlands, which includes parts of 14 communities in Hudson and Bergen Counties.

title: Union Vote Could Change Tradition
description: When Ray Carney says it takes courage to run for president of Local 560 of the teamsters here, that may be more than the usual campaign rhetoric. After all, the last man to campaign against the leadership was beaten and garroted with piano wire.

title: The Nuclear Plant That Refuses to Die
description: IN the latest cliffhanging chapter of ''The Perils of Shoreham,'' the New York Legislature adjourns without voting on a pact under which the state would buy the nuclear power station for $1 and scrap it. The Long Island Lighting Company, which is not quite ready to run the plant anyway, says it will still accept the deal if the Legislature will. The Legislature promises to come back a week from Monday, but there is no assurance it will like the bargain any better then. Many members complain that the rate increases it involves will be too expensive for Long Islanders.

title:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS;
GUESTS WITHOUT SUFFERING
description: LEAD: Americans have never had more to cook with and never had less inclination to cook. To the novice, exotic fruits and imported vinegars are not labor-saving devices. It takes a professional like Moira Hodgson to eye the modern marketplace and declare that cooking, and thus entertaining, has never been easier.

title: A Gift of Hope When Cold and Hunger Are Life's Constant Companions; A Hand Reaches Out To Brooklyn's Poor
description: With more than 2,000,000 people, Brooklyn is a borough of promising growth, but also a borough scarred by poverty. Major efforts are succeeding in attracting new business and industry. But large numbers of the unemployed remain dependent and despairing.

title: Review/Pop; A Neville Brother Goes Solo
description: In New Orleans during the mid-70's, when the Neville Brothers band rose out of the ashes of the Meters, Ivan Neville, then a teen-ager, had a featured spot amid his older relatives. His songs were always anomalies, the low points of the show; uninspired mainstream pop, they stood in sharp relief to the traditionalism of his family's music.

title: Wagner Reclaims The Championship
description: Ever since they were forced to forfeit eight victories last year and were not allowed to defend their Public Schools Athletic League football championship of two years ago, Susan Wagner High School of Staten Island has been on a mission.

title: Correction
description: A listing of cruises on Oct. 30 misstated the final port of call in Europe for Polish Ocean Lines freighters making trans-Atlantic crossings. It is now Bremerhaven, West Germany, not Gdynia, Poland.

title: BACK WHEN A WABBIT WAS A WABBIT
description: THAT'S ALL FOLKS! The Art of Warner Bros. Animation. By Steve Schneider. Foreword by Ray Bradbury. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: A Donald Hutter Book/ Henry Holt & Company. $39.95.

title: A Computer Project Links Students with Soviet Partners
description: TWO Westchester high schools are among the 12 in the state chosen for an electronic exchange program with 12 schools in the Soviet Union. Sponsored by a private Westchester-based foundation and the State Education Department, the three-year telecommunications project is the first of its kind to be established between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: 911 Report for County Board Recommends Decentralized System
description: LEAD: AT its meeting tomorrow, the County Board of Legislators is expected to take a major step toward bringing an ''enhanced'' emergency telephone system - which has come to be referred to as E-911 - within reach of every Westchester household. The enhancements include such capabilities as displaying callers' telephone numbers and automatic routing of calls to responding agencies.

title: Gorbachev's Advance Men Meet the Press
description: Glasnost was on everyone's lips when a panel of distinguished Russians held a news conference here today to talk about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United Nations and New York.

title: Show of Table Art Reflects Growth Of Crafts World
description: LEAD: ''THE main objective of the show is to try to remind the public that fine crafts can also be fine art and that it can be both functional and displayable,'' said Ruth Raible, a curator for ''Table Art: A Step Beyond'' at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson.

title:
DINING OUT;
Consistency in Spanish-Portuguese Fare
description: LEAD: IN looking over a 1982 review in this space of Tony Da Caneca in Newark's Portuguese area, it is intriguing to see how much remains the same. Tucked in among the row houses in a corner of the Ironbound section, this is one of the best of the Spanish-Portuguese restaurants. It has been attractively done over since our last visit.

title: Should Steroid Use by Atheletes Be Allowed
description: Probably not, because of the ever mounting medical evidence that steroids cause severe long term physical maladies. But in a society that condones team doctors injecting injured players with cortisone and other pain numbing potions, which surely cause as much damage as steroids, one needs to look at the greater question of ''What price victory?''

title: Pakistan Is Sure of Its Leader, Less Sure of Her Plans
description: THEY danced in the streets of Lahore, Karachi and Rawalpindi last week when Benazir Bhutto became Prime Minister of Pakistan.

title: Review/Pop; Patti Austin In Low-Key Double Bill
description: A singer whose velvety alto and cool refinement have made her one of the most sought-after New York studio voices, Patti Austin has yet to earn the kind of mass acclaim that her talents would seem to merit. Watching her on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall, where she appeared on a double bill with the jazz-fusion keyboardist David Benoit, one wondered whether Ms. Austin's impeccable technique and taste might in fact have hampered her career. She never screams and shouts or indulges in throat-catching histrionics. Her clear, smooth delivery lacks the signifying quirks that make a voice instantly and indelibly recognizable.

title: Soviets to Allow U.S. Citizens to Send More Goods
description: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to allow private citizens in the United States to send copies of the Bible and Talmud, as well as personal computers and videotape recorders, among other items, to friends and relatives in the Soviet Union, according to Soviet officials and a businessman who signed a contract yesterday with the Soviet trade delegation in New York.

title: Arab in the West Bank Slain by Israeli Troops
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian youth in the occupied West Bank today when demonstrators objected to a search and arrest operation, the army said.

title: When Playing Santa, Avoid the Red Ink
description: Inviting displays of holiday gifts in every store window and mall can tempt even the most level-headed of shoppers to throw caution to the winds and spend more than they had planned. The financial challenge of the holidays is to buy the most suitable gifts for everyone on your list without regretting those purchases when the bills start rolling in next month.

title: Lisbet M. Nilson, A Writer, Marries
description: Lisbet Margareta Nilson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bengt R. Nilson of Greenwich, Conn., Colrain, Mass., and Vaxholm, Sweden, was married yesterday to Mark Calvin Ashida, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Ashida of San Diego. The Rev. James A. Robinson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Church in Brewster, Mass.

title: Tower Still Waits To Hear From Friend
description: In the category of ''they also serve who only stand and wait,'' John G. Tower is still waiting to hear if his old friend, Mr. Bush, has lined up enough tough managers for Defense Department slots to make dubious Bush advisers more comfortable about the naming of Mr. Tower as Defense Secretary.

title: A.T.&.T to Sponsor 3 Dance Companies
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has chosen three dance companies to participate in its 1988-89 ''A.T.&T. Dance Tour'' program, which helps subsidize domestic touring by dance troupes. The companies are the David Gordon-Pick Up Company of Manhattan, which was awarded $35,000; the Chicago-based Hubbard Street Dance Company, $40,000, and the Margaret Jenkins Dance Company, in San Francisco, $25,000.

title: Japanese Design: A Western View
description: LEAD: TWO American women, one from Armonk and the other from New Canaan, Conn., who went to Japan when their husbands were transferred there to work, are the authors of a book that since its publication in Japan a year ago is in its fifth printing and has been described by its publisher as an unexpected best seller there.

title: THE MARKET GIVES ROMANCE A BOOST
description: THE STOCKBROKER was working his way through piles of sell orders, that morning of Oct. 20, 1987, when the telephone rang. It was Tisch calling, with a request to buy $300,000 in blue-chip stocks. The move was very much in keeping with the contrarian strategies of Laurence A. Tisch, C.E.O. of the Loews Corporation and CBS, but the voice on the phone belonged to his daughter-in-law, Susan H. Tisch.

title: Review/Music; Blomstedt Leads 20th-Century Bill
description: The San Francisco Symphony is in sound hands and good condition, to judge by its Carnegie Hall concert under Herbert Blomstedt Friday evening. It seems to face no great problems beyond those that are the birthright of today's symphony orchestra, chief among these being a certain risk of uninterestingness. In an all-20th-century bill - one contemporary work and two by old masters - the orchestra displayed an all-around strength of staffing, a level of discipline and a quality of sound that ranged from satisfactory to very good. The concert was precisely the sum of those parts: satisfactory to very good, not exciting.

title: Is Bonsai Becoming a National Art?
description: JERALD STOWELL finds that it cures headaches and backaches. ''All the stress of my everyday life just disappears when I do it,'' said Mr. Stowell, an assistant professor of occupational therapy at Harcum Junior College in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: 5 BODIES PROMPT HUNT FOR A SLAYER
description: The skeletal remains of five people have been found along two highways here in southeastern Massachusetts, prompting concern that one killer might be responsible.

title: Should Steroid Use by Atheletes Be Allowed
description: Unless you are directly involved, the steroid issue is as interesting as a mollusk on a retired submarine.

title: Miss Stanton Has Wedding
description: At the Georgetown Presbyterian Church in Washington, Elizabeth Ann Stanton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Stanton of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph Howard Santarlasci Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Santarlasci of Paoli, Pa. The Rev. C. C. Campbell Gillon performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Gillis, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Elizabeth Ann Gillis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Gillis of Dover, Mass., and Sanibel, Fla., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to John Louis Dotson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dotson Jr. of Boulder, Colo. The Rev. Jeffrey H. Walker performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: Moscow And Havana Still Can't Differ Much
description: WHEN Mikhail S. Gorbachev meets with Fidel Castro next weekend in Havana, the two are expected to do their best to make the visit, the first to Cuba by a Soviet leader in nearly 15 years, a bear-hugging celebration of Soviet-Cuban ties.

title:
The View From: The Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum;
Marking Christmas and a Return to Glory
description: LEAD: a MAN'S house should be his castle, LeGrand Lockwood reasoned. So when Mr. Lockwood, a New York investment banker and one of America's first millionaires, decided in 1862 to build a country retreat in his hometown of Norwalk, it would hardly have been a simple cottage.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Co-op Conversions Produce Affordables
description: LEAD: WHILE there is concern that rental housing, already in short supply, is being rapidly depleted, people who want to own a home are finding that the growing number of co-op conversions on the Island is creating relatively affordable housing - a commodity that new construction can seldom provide without subsidies.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Babylon $1.5 million 199 Peninsula Drive 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; 1 bayfront acre, boat slip, 450 feet of bulkheading; taxes $18,000. Great River $1.1 million 265 Great River Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old ranch; sauna, gym, 3.6 waterfront acres with boat slip; taxes $12,700. Lindenhurst $126,000 121 North Clinton Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, dining room, fireplace, basement, walk to railroad station and schools; taxes $1,600. Patchogue $139,000 25 Roland Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new ranch; basement, dining room, eat-in kitchen; estimated taxes $2,500. Westbury $337,000 41 Butler Street 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 68-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, professional office, maid's quarters; taxes $6,100. West Islip $655,000 4 Davidson Lane West 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; bay view, boat slip; taxes $8,500. OTHER AREAS Newington, Conn. $140,000 221 Main Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, patio; taxes $1,457. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. $500,000 3 Floral Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 73-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, playroom, workshop; taxes $7,032. Springfield, N.J. $189,500 72 Fieldstone Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; living-room fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $2,828.

title: Choices and Value Abound In the Middle Price Range
description: THE ANCIENT GREEKS extolled the golden mean - the idea of moderation and appropriate measure. An expression of this thoughtful attitude can be found in audio equipment at the mid-price level. Such sound gear is neither hampered by stringency in regard to cost, nor inflated by hubris of engineering ambition. In consequence, good value is often found in this price class, and what follows is a brief survey of outstanding designs in this group.

title: THE PALOMINO IS A FLIRT
description: RUCKUS RODEO By Red Grooms. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Harry N. Abrams.

title: 'The Laws Are Not Well-Enforced
description: LAST month Edith G. Prague was re-elected to a fourth term as a state representative from northeastern Connecticut. In the past, Mrs. Prague has sponsored legislation to raise the drinking age and to strengthen penalties for drunken drivers.

title: 2d Sailor in Nimitz Fire Dies
description: A second sailor has died of injuries suffered in an explosion and fire on the aircraft carrier Nimitz, officials said today.

title: A SKI RESORT IN THE SAHDOW OF MT. RAINIER
description: Crystal Mountain, high in the Cascades southeast of Seattle, is well known to tourists from Japan and western Canada who choose to vacation in Washington State rather than travel farther east to resorts in the Rockies.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I declare emphatically and with conviction that the interests of Mexicans are above the interest of creditors. '' Carlos Salinas de Gortari, President of Mexico, speaking about foreign debt in his inaugural address.

title: TEARING APART EASTERN AIRLINES
description: Your article on Eastern Airlines served to emphasize how little regard companies have for their employees, especially long-term ones. Is it any wonder that employees no longer have any company loyalty? How can they, when they must live every day wondering when they will be made expendable in order to line someone else's pocket? ELIZABETH MULLEN Washington, Conn.

title: WHY THIS TREK COST $3,890
description: Mouths went agape and eyes bugged out when I told friends about my recent African mountaineering trek. Unfortunately, it was not my rhapsodic accounts of the moonlit snows of Kilimanjaro or dawn at 15,000 feet on Mount Kenya that so astonished them. No, it was the cost of the trip - a 19-day expedition run by Mountain Travel, the oldest and largest adventure travel company in the United States. One friend's reaction was typical: ''Are you kidding? You paid $200 a day to sleep on the ground and eat porridge?''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the engagement of Hilary Joy Frankel and Carl Loeb Kempner Jr. referred incorrectly to the bride's maternal grandmother. She is Mrs. Paul Christenfeld, not ''the late.''

title: Iran Group Going to Moscow To Plan Economic Ventures
description: Iran, which has expressed interest in improved ties with the Soviet Union, is sending a high-level delegation to Moscow on Sunday, the Iranian news agency reported.

title: Sarah Bower Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hamilton Bower of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Palmer Bower, to Paul Herbert Maenner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robertson Maenner of Omaha. A May wedding is planned. Miss Bower, a graduate of Brown University, is a marketing associate with World Book in Chicago. Mr. Maenner, a graduate of Northwestern University, is an assistant vice president of Landauer Associates, a real-estate firm in Chicago.

title: A GLORIOUS DECADENCE NORTH OF LONDON
description: We first stumbled across Highgate Cemetery in an accidental way, as the culmination of a serendipitous walk across Hampstead Heath. Except for the Heath itself, a very pleasant place, this part of north London is not very promising in tourist attractions.

title: A Painter Finally Gets His Due
description: A TYPICAL roundup of major New Jersey artists inevitably includes Richard Anuskiewicz and George Segal and just as inevitably omits Hughie Lee-Smith. Meanwhile, in the larger world, there are painters half Mr. Lee-Smith's age - 73 - and half as gifted who have long since had retrospectives. So it is a pleasure to report that Mr. Lee-Smith, who teaches at the Art Students League, is finally getting his due at the State Museum here.

title: The Drug Czar's Mission
description: A recent ''Our Towns'' column in The Times by Michael Winerip vividly portrayed a Jersey City minister's frustration with drug dealing. ''Louise Miller, 65, one of his most respected members . . . said a dealer who lives in her building had roughed her up and slashed her tires. She was afraid to go out. 'I have to go for my dialysis appointment,' she [ said ] . . . 'What do I do?' ''

title: Democratic Shadow Cabinet Nearing Oblivion
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders Heisman Trophy Winner
description: Barry Sanders, the Oklahoma State tailback who was rejected by most coaches as too small to play in a big-time backfield, was the overwhelming winner yesterday of the Heisman Trophy as the best player in college football this year.

title: 77 Held in Abortion Protest
description: Seventy-seven people were arrested today for blocking a Planned Parenthood clinic while singing Christmas carols and hymns. About 100 other people marched in front of the clinic, the Elizabeth Campbell Center, carrying signs reading ''Rescue in progress'' and ''Warning: Killing babies may be hazardous to your soul.''

title:
DINING OUT;
In Elmsford, Just a Bit of Haute
description: LEAD: GAULIN'S has occupied this corner spot on Main Street for so long that surely it deserves landmark status. Enjoying its 37th year, this popular restaurant attracts a clientele from the surrounding community, diners who want just a bit of haute with unpretentious, moderately priced cuisine. And Gaulin's fills the bill, listing on its menu popular roasts and other familiar dishes but updating them just a tad, keeping the nouvelle style at several arms' length.

title: Kathe Kramer Married To Reid Scott Chase
description: Kathe Kramer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Kramer of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., and Reid Scott Chase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Chase of East Hills, L.I., and New York, were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi David H. Lincoln.

title:
Social Events;
Season in Full Swing
description: LEAD: Harlem Anniversary

title: Like Having Another Set of Eyes
description: Pausing at a critical moment in the operation, when the slightest slip could have devastating results, the surgeon monitors the patient's vital signs as they scroll across a corner of the computer screen. ''Show me the latest sequence of CT scans,'' he asks, and the technician at the computer on the other side of the operating room types in the appropriate commands. A series of high-resolution images of the patient's cranium flashes across the screen, revealing the location and size of the tumor.

title: New York Court of Appeals Rejects Waste Law Challenge
description: New York State's highest court has turned aside a recycling company's challenge to state hazardous waste disposal laws, saying the challenge would have created an ''intolerable loophole'' in the regulations.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1988
description: There are nine nonfiction books and seven volumes of fiction on the 1988 list of best books of the year, chosen by the editors of The Book Review from among those reviewed here since last year's Christmas issue.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-33

title: Beneath A Bridge Lie Mystery, Fear
description: MY 7-year-old son, two of his friends, and I were on an evening walk to the little black bridge not far from our home.

title: Health Plans: Choices Grow in County
description: AS the new year approaches, employees in the county are being asked by their companies to take another look at their health insurance coverage and to choose among various options.

title: Boom in Spain Darkened by Political Clouds
description: As Spain's economy glides along at boom levels, fueled by foreign investments and growing consumer demand, political clouds continue to build and undermine the stability touted by the Socialist Government.

title: A New Face in Grover's Corners
description: THORNTON WILDER, IN HIS 1957 preface to ''Three Plays'':

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf 2 Teams Share Lead: Mike Hulbert and Lori Garbacz, a last-minute pairing, and the veteran duo of Larry Mize and Martha Nause shared the lead after three rounds of the $800,000 J. C. Penney Classic yesterday in Largo, Fla. Garbacz, who replaced injured Val Skinner, and Hulbert combined for a seven-under-par 65 over the par-72 Bardmoor Country Club course. They were at 15-under 201 with Mize and Nause, who have competed together for six years and teamed up for a 67. Two other teams, Mike Sullivan-Sally Little and John Huston-Amy Benz, were a stroke back. Four other teams were two shots off the pace, including the second-round leaders, Donna White amd Morris Hatalsky, who shot 71.(AP) Irwin Leads in Australia: Hale Irwin, twice the United States champion, shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday and opened a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the $1.25 million Australian Bicentennial Classic in Melbourne. Going into the final round, closest to Irwin's 54-hole score of 201 were a fellow American, Ben Crenshaw, and Brett Ogle and Rodger Davis, both Australians. Ogle shot a 66 in the third round with seven birdies and a single bogey, and Davis had a 68 and Crenshaw a 70 on the Royal Melbourne course. An American, Fred Couples, was another shot back at 204 after a third-round 69. If Irwin can hold the lead, his winner's purse of $430,000 would be more than he has earned in any one of his 21 seasons on the PGA Tour.(AP) Allem and Green Tied: A South African, Fulton Allem, shot a six-under-par 66 to climb from fifth place into a tie for the lead with an American, Ken Green, after three rounds of the Million Dollar Challenge in Sun City, South Africa. Allem, a first year pro, and Green had 54-hole scores of 209, and shared a two-stroke lead in the eight-man invitation event that offers golf's richest prize. Green shot a 70. The defending champion, Ian Woosnam of Wales, had a 69 and was two shots behind the co-leaders. Chip Beck of the United States had a run of four birdies from the 14th hole to tie a South African, David Frost, for fourth place at 212.(AP) Boxing Moorer Remains Unbeaten: Michael Moorer of Monessen, Pa., stopped Ramzi Hassan of San Diego at 2:37 of the fifth round to win the World Boxing Council Continental Americas light-heavyweight championship yesterday in Brook Park, Ohio. Moorer is 12-0 with 12 knockouts since turning professional last March. Hassan, 25-5, was the first boxer to take Moorer beyond four rounds as a professional.(AP) Horse Racing Notebook Has Nice Finish: Notebook, the odds-on favorite, took the lead nearing the stretch and then held on to win by a neck in the $85,650 Joe Palmer Stakes for New York State-bred 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct. Scottish Monk was runner-up in the field of seven, finishing 5 1/4 lengths ahead of Fourstardave. The victory was the third in nine starts this year for Notebook, who went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 3/5 to earn $51,390 for Eugene V. Klein. Notebook returned $3.40, $2.40 and $2.10 for $2 across the board.(AP) Figure Skating Mills Is First: Jessica Mills of the United States won the ladies' event in the junior world figure skating championships in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, last night. The 14-year-old from Chicago beat Junko Yaginuma of Japan. Surya Bonaly of France was third. Finishing sixth was Jennifer Leng of the United States.(AP) Bowling Ferraro Wins Title: Dave Ferraro of Kingston, N.Y., took advantage of two missed spares by Walter Ray Williams Jr. of Stockton, Calif., to capture the Professional Bowlers Association $135,000 Budweiser Touring Players Championship, 212-195, in Taylor, Mich. The victory was Ferraro's second this year and fourth of his career. He finished the year fourth on the Professional Bowlers' Association earnings list with $150,395. Williams earned his championship berth against Ferraro by downing Roger Bowker of Ocala, Fla., 179-178 in the semifinal. Brian Voss of Seattle finished fourth after opening the round with a 236-195 victory over Philip Ringener, then losing to Bowker 195-184. (AP) Horse Show Best and Gem Twist Triumph: Greg Best of Flemington N.J., rode Gem Twist to victory in the $30,000 invitational jumping competiton, the second phase of the Michelob American Grand Prix Association championships, at the Florida State Fairgrounds Exposition Center in Tampa, Fla., on Friday night. Best and Gem Twist, the horse that he rode to the team silver medal for the United States Equestrian Team at the Seoul Olympics, put in the only clear round in a five-horse jumpoff. Best's Olympic teammate, Anne Kursinski, rode Starman to second place with two knockdowns in the jumpoff for eight faults. Tennis Novotna Takes Tourney: Fifth-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia outplayed compatriot Jana Pospisilova, 7-5, 6-4, to win the $100,000 Southern Cross Classic women's tournament in Adelaide, Australia. Novotna, 20, ranked 45th in the world, broke the 18-year-old Pospisilova in the 10th game of the second set to take the match.(AP)

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Princeton
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH its scale is intimate and its look elegant - tall trees frame neighborhoods of neat shingled houses and 19th-century estates - this 1.76-square-mile central New Jersey borough of more than 12,000 residents has the energy and bustle of a city.

title: Gasoline Station Of Historic Note
description: NOT too often does a gasoline station make the National Register of Historic Places. But one in Yonkers on the Saw Mill River Parkway was deemed eligible by the New York State Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.

title: Last Minute Chores For the Home Turf
description: USE outdoor wiring and fasten it securely to trees for holiday lights. Prune hollies, yews, spruces and other evergreens and use the trimmings to make decorations. Check coldframes to be sure they are secure. Lightly water pots containing hardy bulbs that were potted for forcing into bloom indoors during the cold winter months, January and February. Keep Busy

title: Charlotte M. Harris Marries
description: Charlotte Mary Harris, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Basil Harris of Manchester, Vt., was married there yesterday to John Helm Roach Jr., the son of Margery M. Roach of Marlow, N.H., and Mr. Roach of Queretaro, Mexico. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Joseph J. Lagor.

title: Prospects; Mexico's Stumbling Steps
description: Mexico's new President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, was sworn into office on Thursday. After his inauguration, Mr. Salinas said the payments Mexico makes on its $104 billion foreign debt are unacceptable. He explained that Mexico's priority will not be to pay its debt, but to return to growth. Is Mexico's economy ready to grow? Richard E. Feinberg Vice president, Overseas Development Council.

title: Practical Traveler; What U.S. Pays for Trips
description: Like most travelers who work out a budget before their trip, the Federal Government calculates the cost of travel in various places for employees on official business - everyone from State Department couriers to White House staff members. The result is compiled in a monthly publication, ''Maximum Travel Per Diem Allowances for Foreign Areas,'' listing a daily rate for lodging and meals in about 1,000 cities.

title: The Case for a High-Estrogen President
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
'Modern Israel' Show
description: LEAD: IN spite of their unquestionably strong nationalistic loyalties, most Israeli artists are quick to insist on the internationalism of their creative outlook. Indeed, a number have either worked or studied in major foreign art capitals.

title: Actors Workshop Stresses Flexibility
description: LEAD: IT'S called a black box stage. In the world of the theater, that loosely translates into a flexible seating and stage arrangement, used to create a particular environment for the audience. This can be an arena or a center, thrust or proscenium stage.

title: Miss Flynn Weds In Massachusetts
description: The wedding of Geraldine Greenway Flynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Flynn of South Hamilton, Mass., to Trevor Allen Gowdy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis E. Gowdy of Wellesley Hills, Mass., took place yesterday at the First Parish Congregational Church in Manchester, Mass. The Rev. John Hughes, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. Guy Morrison, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Bush Is Urged to Take Active Role in Mideast
description: Experts on the Middle East, including a senior foreign policy adviser to President-elect Bush, say the next administration must move swiftly to show its interest in promoting Arab-Israeli peace through active American diplomacy.

title: STRIKE UP THE CHOIR!
description: I read Stephen Jay Gould's article ''Strike Up the Choir!'' (Nov. 6) with great interest and greater nostalgia. It brought back memories of my participation in the New York All-City High School Chorus from 1936 to 1939, when we were 400-students strong.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Building Bonuses for Public Amenities
description: LAST month, a four-year-old art gallery in Marlborough opened a branch in downtown Hartford where it had no decorating costs and will pay no rent. It is the first beneficiary of a city zoning ordinance passed in 1984 that gives developers of commercial buildings extra square footage in return for providing space for public use.

title: At Kentucky, Basketball Sags Under Weighty Problems
description: Eddie Sutton walked briskly down the hallway that leads from his office at Memorial Coliseum to the coaches locker room. His head lowered as if in deep contemplation, Sutton was oblivious at first to a reporter who had come up behind him, until the reporter called his name.

title: NINE SHRINES TO THE OFFBEAT IN ROME
description: They are sometimes more than a little time-consuming to find, and their opening and closing hours are as mysterious and erratic as the Roman weather in spring. Nevertheless, the less-publicized, out-of-the-way museums of Rome can provide the persistent visitor with such exquisite novelties as chandeliers made from monks' bones, locks of hair from the great Romantic poets and handprints from the souls in purgatory.

title: George Glasser Weds Alexandra de Trenck
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Alexandra de Trenck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles de Trenck of Scottsdale, Ariz., and George Glasser, the son of Mrs. C. A. Cameron of Harrison, N.Y., were married yesterday by the Rev. Charles A. Amstein.

title: A Novice Builder Puts It in Writing
description: LEAD: SOON after Stephen Taylor and his family moved into their new house nestled in almost four acres of East Hampton woods, he realized that he could not write at home.

title: HER NIBS
description: HERE SHE COMES, STROLLING down the pier, chatting in rat-a-tat-tat French of her horses and dogs and husbands. Blonde and petite, trim and relaxed, casually chic in electric blue, 56-year-old Francine Gomez seems just another sun-worshipper on September holiday in the resort town of La Grande Motte, nestled by the Mediterranean on the outskirts of Montpellier.

title:
FOCUS: Pittsburgh's Airport;
20 Years Later, a New Terminal Rises
description: LEAD: TWENTY years after it was originally conceived, construction of Greater Pittsburgh International Airport's midfield terminal has begun. The $550 million project is one of only a handful of completely new airport terminals being built nationwide.

title: 'My Fair Lady' in Elmsford
description: IN more than 14 years, An Evening Dinner Theater produced 77 musicals, and not one of them was ''My Fair Lady.''

title: Mary Beth Donnelly to Wed
description: Mary Elizabeth Donnelly and Steven Albert Westlake plan to marry Feb. 11. Mr. and Mrs. John P. Donnelly of Binghamton, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Donald E. Westlake of New York, the novelist, and Nedra Henderson of Binghamton. The future bride, known as Mary Beth, is a scenic carpenter with the Tri-Cities Opera in Binghamton. She attended the State University at Binghamton, of which her fiance, a writer, is a graduate.

title: Kimberly A. Hartman to Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Catherine Hartman of Alexandria, Va., and Pierre Hartman of Silver Spring, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Ann Hartman, to Paul Eric Teske, a son of Jean Teske of Fishkill, N.Y., and the late Emil Teske. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Nussbaum Testimony Is Called a Risk
description: The decision to call Hedda Nussbaum to the stand in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg was necessary and correct, but a risk nonetheless, legal experts said yesterday.

title: LAWYER PRESSING INSURANCE BATTLE
description: Harvey Rosenfield is still fighting his war.

title:
MUSIC;
A Bit of 'Luck' for Wayne Orchestra
description: LEAD: IT seems fitting that the Wayne Chamber Orchestra, whose conductor, Murray Colosimo, is an ardent supporter of American composers, will open its 1988-89 season not only with a work by Elliott Carter, but also with a performance of it on the composer's 80th birthday next Sunday.

title: Pearl Harbor: A Peaceful Sunday Is
description: IT was a cold but bright Sunday in early winter, I remember, when I unlocked and opened Houghton's Drug Store in a little farming town in northwest Missouri. It was almost 1 P.M. Church was over, and I had had a quick sandwich at home.

title: Susan Murphy to Wed J. N. Whitman in April
description: Susan Saxton Murphy and John Newcom Whitman, a son of Patricia M. Whitman of Stamford, Conn., and Bruce N. Whitman of Greenwich, Conn., plan to marry in April, the mother of the future bride, Elayne J. Murphy of Brockton, Mass., has announced.

title: At American Joe's Bar he Twists Are Political
description: American Joe Miedusiewski could be one of the young professionals who have been lured in recent years to East Baltimore by inexpensive housing and safe streets.

title: U.S. Tells Farmers to Prepare Data to Avoid Foreclosures
description: Federal officials have offered 1,551 farmers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut a chance to reorganize their debts to the Farmers Home Administration before facing foreclosure notices and losing their farms.

title: Tell it Straight to Gorbachev
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's decision to go to New York this week to talk with the outgoing and incoming U.S. Presidents is a powerful signal of how much he wants to make sure of continuing improvement in Soviet-American relations.

title: Three New Members for Arts and Letters Academy
description: The composer John Cage, the writer Mary McCarthy and the painter Jasper Johns were elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters at the organization's annual meeting Friday at its Upper Manhattan headquarters. The three artists were chosen by other members of the Academy, which is a part of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: Bed and Breakfast
description: To the Editor: The articles ''Hawaii's Short-Sleeve Plumage'' and ''London's Crop of Choice B & B's'' (Travel, Oct. 16) can be used together while visiting London. Tremendous bargains on classic aloha shirts can be had at the American classic clothes stores along King's Road in Chelsea and North End Road in Fulham (the latest gentrified area in London), both in southwest London, right around the corner from Parsons Green and Kensington. RICK SASSE Governors Island, N.Y.

title: INVESTING IN AN ABSENCE OF CIVILIZATION
description: It is 6 o'clock in the morning in East Africa. The sky outside your tent is not quite light, but the birds have already begun tuning up, all together, as though a conductor had waved a baton. The sky turns a faint pearl, and though you hear no footsteps, there is the smooth discreet sound of a tent zipper. Your guardian-of-the-tent steps inside with a tray. ''Tea,'' he announces politely.

title: A Christmas Non-Tie
description: With a happy heart, a New Yorker whose brother-in-law admires her taste went shopping at a famous store. He wanted a tie to go with his new greenish tweed jacket.

title: Beijing Wary On Soviet Tie; Increased but Limited Contact Is Forseen
description: With a Chinese-Soviet summit meeting next year all but certain, the Chinese seem to expect not just an end to nearly three decades of quarrels but also the emergence of a broad network of commercial, diplomatic and academic links.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: PATRICIA MATSON remembers the incident very well, but considering the trauma of it all, she's fuzzy about the details. One thing she knows for sure - her mother stood transfixed, not quite able to believe her eyes. It isn't every day that you walk into a room and see your child brushing the dog's teeth with her own toothbrush.

title: STRIKE UP THE CHOIR!
description: This year is the 20th anniversary of my first year with the All-City High School Chorus. By my time, Dr. Wilhousky had retired. He had been replaced by John Motley, who instilled in us a love of quality, a sense that perfection was attainable, and the virtue of patience.

title: Who Is 'Old'? Agencies Struggle With Definitions
description: LEAD: AS older adults lead longer and more active lives and as the frail elderly population continues to swell on the Island, officials of public and private agencies are struggling to define ''old'' and trying to decide whom within this diverse group to address first and with what services.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL' Charles Dickens's ''Christmas Carol,'' an annual tradition at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, will open next Sunday and run through Christmas Eve.

title: Ms. Zimmerman, Banker, to Wed David Marc Weil
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Zimmerman of New York of the engagement of their daughter Susan Hollis Zimmerman to David Marc Weil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weil of Andover, Mass. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Spray-Can Painting
description: FOR painting or applying other finish to small or detailed items such as furniture, outdoor equipment and decorative hardware, no method is quicker or easier than spraying with an aerosol finish, the type available in pressurized cans.

title: JUDGE HOLDS F.B.I. MISUSED U.S. JURY
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation misused a Federal grand jury to retaliate against a Hispanic agent who filed a lawsuit against the bureau charging discrimination.

title: Philadelphia Inquiry Blames Inspection Department in Fires
description: A grand jury said Thursday that mismanagement in the city's Department of Licenses and Inspections was responsible for at least six fires since 1984 that caused more than $23 million in damage and killed two people.

title: GATEWAY IN BEIRUT CLOSED TO TRAFFIC
description: The only road linking the Christian and Muslim halves of Beirut was closed today in what appears to be an economic war between the two rival governments that have been struggling for power here for the last 10 weeks.

title: Polly Martin Wed To Marc Schaefer
description: The marriage of Polly Day Martin and Marc Kingsley Schaefer took place yesterday in New York at the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. John Bryson, stepfather and mother of the bride. The Rev. Beatrice Blair, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: On Ethics, Reagan Finally Did Right
description: By vetoing the so-called Ethics Bill, President Reagan finally did something that merited applause. Instead, he was denounced reflexively by many liberals and editorial board guardians of the Constitution who should have known better. Overlooked in their condemnation were two fundamental facts that should have, but did not, guide Congress in crafting this legislation and where the President was on solid ground.

title: John Parke Young, a Monetary Expert, 93
description: John Parke Young, an authority on the international monetary system and longtime advocate of a single world currency, died Tuesday at age 93.

title: Girl Scout Initiative Wins Award
description: THEY still wear green and they still win merit badges, but Girl Scouts in Westchester are changing. Last week, the Girl Scouts of Westchester-Putnam won the Westchester Youth Services Excellence Award, a $10,000 unrestricted gift, for their efforts to bring Scouting to low-income girls in Peekskill.

title: Democrats Make a Point By Picking Mitchell
description: CONGRESSIONAL leadership races rarely command center stage in national politics.

title: Jacqueline Meyer Weds M. I. Gold
description: Jacqueline Meyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Meyer of Beechhurst, Queens, was married last night to Martin I. Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gold of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: Shipwreck Salvors Snubbed by Peers
description: Off the shores of this outer Cape Cod town, a team of researchers and treasure hunters are digging up relics from a pirate ship that may shed light on the 18th-century world and its seafaring outlaws.

title: Redmen Eke Out a Victory
description: Jayson Williams, the leading scorer for St. John's, came down with food poisoning before the game against Hawaii last night and was unable to play. As he watched the game in a sweat suit, Williams may not have been the only one on the Redmen bench with a queasy feeling.

title: Which Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: 19th-Century China Shows Danger of Soviet Restructuring Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A recital today by Tatiana Troyanos and James Levine, listed on page 33A of Arts and Leisure, Section 2, has been cancelled because Miss Troyanos is ill. The recital will be rescheduled.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Home-Care Workshops
description: LEAD: Caring at home for a family member who is ill can be a terrible burden to face alone, particularly if the illness is Alzheimer's disease. But some care- givers are reluctant to hire professional help. Home health aides, they fear, might disrupt already-established routines, or act surly or, in the worst scenario, actually harm the sick person.

title: Players That Don't Strut
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: New Jersey; Wayne Valley Routs Ramapo
description: Unbeaten Wayne Valley scored on six of its first seven possessions and rolled to a 49-10 victory over Ramapo yesterday in the North Jersey, Section 1, Group 3 championship in Franklin Lakes. The fullback, John Klosek, rushed for 116 yards on 14 carries, including first-half touchdown runs of 4 and 15 yards.

title: NEW STUMBLING BLOCK IN SOUTHWEST AFRICA TALKS
description: Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States failed tonight to approve an agreement they had been expected to sign leading to a comprehensive peace settlement in southwestern Africa.

title: Critics Circle Nominate The 25 Best Books of 1988
description: ''A Bright Shining Lie'' by Neil Sheehan and ''Paris Trout'' by Pete Dexter, which last week won the National Book Awards for nonfiction and fiction respectively, are among the 25 books nominated by the National Book Critics Circle as the most distinguished books of 1988.

title: The Benefits of Unemployment
description: IT took me two months to muster the courage to file for unemployment benefits. A friend told me how her unemployment benefits had enabled her to continue her graduate studies while she searched for a job, and I thought that perhaps I too deserved to put in my claim.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
What It All Boils Down To
description: LEAD: ''DOUBLE, double toil and trouble; fire, burn; and, cauldron, bubble,'' said Shakespeare's witches, who no doubt were inaugurating the fall cooking season. It begins with Thanksgiving preparations and ends when you write at the top of your New Year's resolution list, ''Lose 20 pounds. By Jan. 15.''

title: Q and A
description: Choosing a Tour Question: After years of vacationing solo, in countries where we could communicate, we are contemplating joining a tour in countries like China or Indonesia whose languages we cannot speak. How do we pick a tour organizer? Is there a consumers' report that rates tour operators? Or are we left to make a selection based on glossy brochures and the salesmanship of travel agents? - L. N., Ridgefield, Conn. Answer: Any serious and reliable attempt at rating the quality of tour companies would be extremely expensive and soon become out of date. In this diverse market, hundreds of operators appeal to all kinds of interests.

title: Correction
description: An obituary Nov. 20 of Marc Stone, a public relations executive, misstated the date of his death and the place of his birth. He died Friday, Nov. 18; he was born in Richmond, Ind., and was reared in Haddonfield, N.J.

title: A New Push For Quebec's Independence
description: Among the Canadian politicians who celebrated the voters' endorsement of Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States, a common view was that the agreement would eventually make Canada stronger as a nation.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our asphalt shingle roof has dark streaks of mildew on it, even though there are no overhanging trees that keep it shaded. When we had mildew on the siding, we scrubbed it off with a mixture of bleach and water. If we use this method on the roof, will this loosen the little granules on the shingles, and is there anything we can do to prevent the mildew from returning?

title: Garfield's Picture, To Teach a Lesson
description: Even though the President-elect is rarely around, there is tight security at the Federal office building on Connecticut Avenue downtown where the transition headquarters is located. All visitors must go through a metal detector, a computerized I.D. check and several layers of guards.

title: Body Shop
description: EVANGELINE CALVIN TELLS A story about a man who was new in Portland, Ore., and didn't know about her business. Driving through town one night, he looked up and spotted a beautiful woman, completely undressed, standing in a lighted window. Smitten - or maybe just curious - he returned the next day. ''He was disappointed,'' Ms. Calvin says.

title: Living on Love - and Marketing It, Too
description: From mistletoe to Miss Lonelyhearts, romance has always been a good business, and not even the hard-driving 1980's have been impervious to love. While marriage rates continue to decline, the number of couples living together has increased by one million since the start of the decade, to 2.6 million households early this year, according to the Census Bureau. And the rate of divorce, which had risen steadily in the 1970's, appears to have leveled off.

title: For Japan's Working Women, a Slow Recognition
description: On Japanese television, there are, by and large, two kinds of women. The happy ones wear frilly aprons and sing while they iron. The troubled ones work as nurses or secretaries but neglect their children and spend time in bars, consorting with men who want to take advantage of them.

title: Seven Are Charged With Sale Of Powerful Synthetic Drug
description: Seven people have been arrested on charges of manufacturing and distributing a synthetic drug that produces a euphoria like that of heroin but is hundreds of times more powerful, the police said.

title: Should Steroid Use by Atheletes Be Allowed
description: This is how it was meant to be: man or woman against nature. Brawn and brains against the brute. Since Milo started to lift the calf, one man did it himself, and to him goes the glory and satisfaction of a deed well done.

title: Deborah Alovis Weds Dr. Michael Newman
description: Deborah Lynn Alovis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Alovis of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., and Scottsdale, Ariz., and Dr. Michael Glenn Newman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Newman of Great Neck, L.I., were married last evening at Singers Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Jerome Davidson, assisted by Cantor David Rosenzweig, performed the ceremony.

title: HYMN TO HEMS
description: THE FASHION CONSPIRACY A Remarkable Journey Through the Empires of Fashion. By Nicholas Coleridge. Illustrated. 323 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Murder Begets Grief and an Effort to Curb Murders
description: The last article Lionel Harris wrote for the newspaper at Calvin Coolidge High School was about the killings in his city.

title: Nola Beldegreen Weds
description: Nola Beth Beldegreen, a daughter of Joane Archer of Wayne, Pa., and the late Robert Alan Beldegreen, was married last evening to Stephen Laurence Klein, the son of Elsie Klein of Wilmington, Del., and the late Manuel Klein. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated at the Lotos Club in New York. The bride, a graduate of Rutgers University, is the travel advertising manager for Gourmet magazine in New York. Mr. Klein, a graduate of the University of Delaware, is the Massachusetts manager in Boston for Vintners International, a producer of California and New York wines.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 4, 1988
description: NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS *4*(In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates) Sep. 88 Sep. 87 Change Starts 1,449 1,679 -14% Completions 1,523 1,591 -4% Sales 659 644 2% *3*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.75 10.64 10.93 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.32 8.25 8.05 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.51 10.43 10.72 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.15 8.14 8.04 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.62 10.56 10.86 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.57 8.55 8.08 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 11.06 11.22 11.56 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.53 8.45 8.32 Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.71 8.55 7.02 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.11 9.11 8.86 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Storage Buildings; Windfall Profits Inspiring Moving Days
description: MOVING and storage companies buy warehouses in low-budget locations for storage capacity, not redevelopment potential. But when surroundings improve, the warehouses often become far more valuable as real estate deals than as storage centers.

title: THE NATION: No Pardon, Perhaps No Trial; In Iran-Contra Prosecution, The Perils of Thinking Big
description: WHEN the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, met privately with the Congressional Iran-contra panels last year, several committee members advised him to limit the indictment he was working on to comparatively narrow crimes such as lying to Congress.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: IN 1962, in response to the dwindling number of players who came to Darien on Sunday mornings for a casual game of touch football, Frank Fay, Henry Egan, Tony Good and Roy Makowsky formed the Inter-City Touch Football League. ''We decided the one way to guarantee a game every Sunday was to form a league,'' Mr.

title: Golden Delivery
description: The next time you lose something in the mail, the man to contact is Bud Tyler, a representative of the consumer-affairs division of the Postal Service in Washington. Just tell him you want the same treatment he gave Mary T. Meagher after the Postal Service lost two of the three gold medals she won in swimming at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.

title: The Golem - As Medieval Hero, Frankenstein Monster and Proto-Computer
description: A GOLEM IS AN ARTIFICIAL man. In Jewish mystical tradition the idea of creating such a man goes back to Talmudic times (the word itself, which occurs only once in the Bible, in the Psalms, means ''unformed substance''). The legend of the golem flourished in the Middle Ages, attracted the attention of Christian scholars in the Renaissance, and found its way into German literature during the Romantic period; around the end of the 19th century it began firing the imagination of visual artists, and in recent years it has enjoyed renewed popularity as an artistic theme.

title: 'Messiah' As Played By Handel
description: HANDEL'S ''Messiah,'' which has enjoyed continuous performances and stylistic tamperings since its creation in 1742, will receive an authentic Baroque period performance by the Fairfield Period Music Academy on Friday, next Sunday and Dec. 16 in three locations in Connecticut.

title: Review/Theater; 'Angalak,' Or, Inuit High Jinks
description: If all ghosts were as good-natured as the three that supply most of the action in Walt Vail's ''Angalak,'' who would not want to be haunted? To be sure, the one who in life was Ivik, the favorite husband of the title character, is a bit stiff in his ghostly existence as a caribou. But the two others, also sometime husbands of Angalak (at the same time, it turns out) - Tilgut, a hunter turned after death into an affectionate bear, and Niutuk, a shaman whose soul inhabits a flamboyant bird - are high spirits indeed.

title: Teaching Reform: Shared Hopes, Sharp Differences.
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER school superintendents, school board members and teachers union leaders say they are hopeful that proposed reforms designed to upgrade the status of teachers will soon be put into effect statewide.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Dead Starring Anjelica Huston, Donal McCann, Helena Carroll, Cathleen Delany, Dan O'Herlihy, Donal Donnelly, Marie Kean. Directed by John Huston. 1987. Vestron Video. 82 minutes. $89.98. Closed captioned. Rated PG. Contains some strong language.

title: Anti-Shoreham Groups Plan Legislative Campaign
description: Representatives of groups that have fought the Shoreham nuclear power plant for more than a decade met yesterday to begin pressuring Long Island legislators to change their minds and back Governor Cuomo's plan to close the plant.

title: Kristin Farrish Engaged
description: Kristin Farrish and Gale Howard Shaw 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw Jr. of Stowe, Vt., plan to marry in September, the future bride's parents, Gail Farrish of Boston and Edgartown, Mass., and Dr. Grover Farrish of Hyannis and Nantucket, Mass., have announced.

title: Hospitals Overwhelmed as Poor In New York City Search for Care
description: The AIDS epidemic that health-care experts said would overwhelm New York City hospitals has clearly taken its toll and will continue to do so. So has a nursing shortage, a shortage of beds and the rise in drug abusers seeking treatment.

title: THE SPY WHO SAVED ME - A THRILLER STARRING JOHN LE CARRE
description: As with first love, most book publishers vividly can recall the circumstances of their first big success. I still remember the very low point I had reached in my short career more than a quarter-century ago before the miracle happened. Defying all the standard odds, a book I acquired from London as a result of my very first trip there - a grimly realistic thriller by an unknown British writer - was to blossom into the smash best seller of the publishing year, thereby dumbfounding both its author and his publisher.

title: Review/Pop; Ruben Blades's Salsa
description: In Latin music, Ruben Blades has staked out a territory all his own, where salsa, jazz, politics and literature meet and meld. His group, Son del Solar (formerly Seis del Solar) mixes Latin percussion with the advanced harmonies and electric keyboards of a jazz-fusion band; his songs, in Spanish, tell politically informed stories, invoke childhood memories of his native Panama or set Gabriel Garcia Marquez's plots to music. What could be an intellectual exercise turns out to be catchy, propulsive and good-natured, especially when Mr. Blades delivers his songs in person.

title: Sliding Devils Anger Coach
description: With John MacLean and Patrik Sundstrom the only players scoring with any consistency, it's no wonder the Devils are without a victory in their last seven games.

title: THE NATION: An Accounting; The Environment's Gains and Losses
description: ''I am an environmentalist,'' Vice President Bush declared during the Presidential campaign.

title: Postmark Vietnam
description: LISA MARIE PRESLEY, ELVIS'S DAUGHTER, was married last October. I pointed this out to my husband, Dave, as he read the newspaper at our kitchen table. Walking by, I saw Lisa Marie's name and picture on the celebrity page. I put my finger on the photo of Lisa and her new husband. ''What does that remind you of?'' Dave looked at the picture, and then at me, and said, ''Nothing. It doesn't remind me of anything. Is it supposed to?'' That's Elvis's daughter,'' I said. ''And her bridegroom. Doesn't that make you think of her parents' wedding? In the spring of '67? Don't you remember the newspaper picture of Elvis and Priscilla cutting their wedding cake?''

title: SPEAKING ILL OF THE DEAD
description: As the author of biographies of two modern iconoclasts (''To All Gentleness: William Carlos Williams, The Doctor Poet'' and ''Man Ray: American Artist''), I am moved to respond to James Atlas's provocative Nov. 6 essay ''Speaking Ill of the Dead.''

title: He DancesAnd Taps On Clogs
description: LEAD: A FUNNY thing happened to Ira Bernstein on his way to becoming a veterinarian; he discovered clog dancing.

title: A GREED FOR THE WORK
description: IN 1959, A YEAR OF LOFTY TAIL FINS AND boundless optimism, the editors of Life magazine proclaimed that American civilization was on the brink of becoming ''freer and bolder than the Greek, more just and powerful than the Roman, wiser than the Confucian . . . saner than the French, more responsible than the Victorian and happier than all of them together.''

title: Olympia Dukakis on Many Stages
description: LEAD: OLYMPIA DUKAKIS wasn't in the mood for small talk. Her role in a provocative tragicomedy was both stimulating and exhausting, and she was immersed in research for an experimental production she was creating.

title: A YANK GETS TO MAKE HIS OWN BRITISH MOVIE
description: IN A DISUSED MENTAL HOSPITAL preserved from demolition because of its architectural interest, on the gentrified banks of London's Regent's Canal, in the side streets, doorways, parks and living rooms of once-middle-class districts of northwest London now housing a population so diverse that everything from electioneering pamphlets to advertisements for job vacancies are printed in five languages - the dream project of the American film director Randal Kleiser has taken shape.

title: Retired U.S. Official Convicted of Bribery
description: A retired General Services Administration official was convicted Friday of receiving $24,185 in bribes to provide inside information to two businessmen who were found guilty of conspiracy.

title: Joseph P. Scordato and Karen A. Wendell Marry
description: Karen A. Wendell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Henry Wendell Jr. of Punta Gorda, Fla., and Joseph P. Scordato, the son of Joseph C. Scordato of Valley Cottage, N.Y., and Patricia A. Nickerson of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: Diverting PINS From the Court Process
description: In dealing with as complex an issue as PINS [ ''Emancipation Age: Should It Rise to 18?'' Oct. 2 ] , information can easily become garbled.

title: A New Tune at the Chamber Music Society
description: IN POLITICS, DEMOCRATIC TRADITION dictates that when the chief of state leaves office his cabinet resigns en masse to allow the heir to power complete freedom in choosing his associates. That makes sense. His closest aides, after all, will be important factors in his success or failure. No leader can be better than those who serve under him. In musical organizations, however, such sweeping changes of personnel have not been possible of late, the time having passed when an incoming music director like Artur Rodzinski might walk into a rehearsal and fire as many orchestra members as he could lay eyes on. There are artistic arguments to be made for such periodic housecleanings, of course, but increased strength of music unions over the last quarter-century or so have rendered most of them moot. In major orchestras, change by attrition is now the only way to go.

title: 'Adopting' Lakes And Other Water
description: WITH funds running dry and pollution problems increasing, many state environmental agencies are turning to citizen volunteers for help in policing and improving their water resources.

title: A RED-HOT MARKET IN VINTAGE CARS
description: ON THE PASTURE-SIZED LAWN OF A VERY SIZABLE house in the horse country of Mendham, N. J., a surrealistic sight: dozens and dozens of low, perfect Ferraris - of various vintages, but almost all of them red - sit row upon row. The occasion is the fall meeting of the Ferrari Club of America, and it is an occasion. Prosperous-looking men in meticulously casual attire, their female companions in tow, stroll among the rakish cars with admiring glances. Yet these days Ferraris and other collectible cars are prized not merely as objects of esthetic contemplation. They are hot investments, the focus of an ever-spiraling market in which prices can jump 50 percent in the space of six months.

title: 2 Mexican Arrivals in Stamford
description: IN less than a year, the number of Mexican restaurants in Stamford has gone from zero to two. And they could not be more disparate.

title: FOR DIRECTORS, A SOFT LANDING
description: WHEN A RAIDER STRIKES, pity not the corporate director; he may have a golden parachute.

title: Walker Ponders Quitting, or Moving On
description: Even though Wesley Walker is catching passes once again, the season has upset him so much he says he is thinking of quitting football after this campaign.

title: Law Clerk Is Engaged To Valerie K. Feigen
description: The engagement of Valerie Kim Feigen to Steven Eisman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Eisman of New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Feigen of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Why Everyone Knew About the Secret Shuttle Mission
description: NOT all secrets can be kept all that secret. The Defense Department was reminded of this in the days before Friday's launching of the space shuttle Atlantis. The payload tucked away in the shuttle's cargo bay was classified top secret. But everyone, it seemed, had a good idea of what it was.

title: Barkley Leads 76ers Past Pacers
description: Charles Barkley scored 31 points, including 9 in a fourth-quarter rally, to lift the Philadelphia 76ers to a 107-100 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: Boston Hotel Workers Gain a Housing Fund
description: Unionized hotel workers here have won a novel provision in their new three-year contract that would establish a fund financed by hotel owners to help low-income workers buy housing.

title: Bed and Breakfast
description: To the Editor: Donald Goddard's generally useful article on London's B & B's is marred by an uncritical enthusiasm that conflicts with my experience. I have visited London at least a dozen times, most recently in June, and have always rejected mediocre, expensive hotels for bed and breakfast accommodations. Still, there are inconveniences, most having to do with location.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Randolph, Me.; Rail Line Goes Back to Nature
description: TWO miles of the former Kennebec Central Railroad right of way, which connected Randolph with Chelsea five miles away, has been cleared for a six-foot-wide nature trail for hikers in summer and cross-country skiers in winter.

title: THEY CAN GET IT FOR YOU WHOLESALE
description: LIKE A GIANT MATCHBOX LYING ON its side, the warehouse in Burbank stretches long, low and white toward the rough foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains. It stands in a neighborhood of body shops and small factories, its identity announced only by a small, red-lettered sign: Price Club.

title: Gambling by Teen-Agers Stirs Concern
description: LEAD: LAST July, after the hot-line number of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey was posted on lottery machines statewide, the first caller responding to the stickers and seeking help was a 15-year-old boy, says Arnold Wexler, the council's executive director.

title: SERVING ON DAD'S COURT
description: MY FATHER AND I FIRST started playing tennis together in 1967, when I was 7 years old. As those who have followed his career in the electric shaver business may know, Victor Kiam is an intense competitor. Even then, he played to win. So did I. But the results were always the same: match to Dad.

title: The Day New York Stopped
description: Consider next Wednesday, Dec. 7, 1988. It's not likely to be as famous as its 1941 predecessor, the day of Pearl Harbor. Still, it may live on in a lesser infamy. Wednesday promises to be a day for the Guinness Book of Gridlock.

title: A Gift of Hope When Cold and Hunger Are Life's Constant Companiions; Small Acts Can Raise People From Despair
description: Sometimes, just a little goes a long way.

title: Argentine President Orders Troops to End Revolt
description: President Raul Alfonsin ordered the use of force tonight to end a two-day Argentine Army rebellion.

title: Holiday Fare For Youngsters? Scout Around
description: QUICK, MOMS AND DADS, WHEN did you first see ''The Year the Grinch Stole Christmas'' and how old were you? The television perennial made its debut in 1966 and is part of a festival of holiday viewing at the Museum of Broadcasting from Dec. 13 through Christmas Eve. The retrospective includes other prize memory ornaments, such as ''Kukla, Fran and Ollie'' from 1979 and ''John Denver and the Muppets'' from the same year, and underscores the point that really outstanding holiday fare is rare. While the networks have consistently invested in substantial quantities of holiday programming for family viewing, the dross is replayed as often as the gold.

title: Of Ruble Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepping Into Jeopardy
description: Another politician might be daunted by the prospect of spending 20 years in prison and paying fines of $17.3 million, but for Salvador Jorge Blanco, a former President of the Dominican Republic, the larger issue is honor. Mr. Jorge Blanco, whom Dominican courts convicted in absentia on corruption charges last month, returned home last week to try to reopen the case. The former President, who came to the United States in 1987 after being charged back home, said those ''totally false'' allegations had been trumped up by political opponents to keep him from running for President again. For now, he said, ''My first obligation is to defend myself. I am an honest person.'' Upon landing in the Dominican Republic, he was arrested pending court action.

title: Alexandra Gittes, Actress, Weds M. Edward Napier
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York, Alexandra Elizabeth Gittes was married yesterday to M. Edward Napier by the Rev. Charles S. Temple.

A monumental (1,064 pages) account, centered on the life and work of Martin Luther King Jr., of the nation in one of its most painful and critical passages, the rise of the civil rights movement. CHEKHOV: A Spirit Set Free, by V. S. Pritchett. (Random House, $17.95.) This graceful, imaginative literary biography by the distinguished British short-story writer and critic argues persuasively that Chekhov is best approached through his short fiction rather than his theatrical works. THESE THINGS HAPPEN, by Marian Thurm. (Poseidon, $15.95.) The characters in Ms. Thurm's second collection of short stories, a compendium of modern alternatives to the nuclear family, never know when love will arrive - or when it will depart. KISSES OF THE ENEMY, by Rodney Hall. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A scary dystopia of the 1990's, in which the Central Intelligence Agency compasses the subversion of Australia; by an Australian novelist not nearly well enough known here. BEHIND THE WALL: A Journey Through China, by Colin Thubron. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) A BOMB IN THE BRAIN: A Heroic Tale of Science, Surgery, and Survival, by Steve Fishman. (Scribners, $19.95.) A candid and harrowing personal tale by a young writer who suffered a brain hemorrhage and neurosurgery with imperfect results. TO URANIA, by Joseph Brodsky. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) New verse, dense and rich, by the Nobel laureate and Russian emigre, a poet whose work enjoys a gaiety of allusion and display of learning rarely risked by his contemporaries.

title: RJR Nabisco: The Winner Is...
description: The price for RJR Nabisco was $24.88 billion, and the winning bidder was Kohblerg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm. The $109-a-share offer was accepted by a special committee of RJR Nabisco board after a frenzied round of bidding between Kohlberg, Kravis and a group led by RJR Nabisco's top executives. The management group bitterly complained that it had made a better offer - one it valued at $25.42 billion - but that it had been cheated by an unfair bidding process. The group hinted it might try to challenge the outcome. The deal will involve enormous debt, and Kolhlberg, Kravis executives said that to help pay off the loans they hoped to raise as much as $6 billion in the next few years by selling some RJR Nabisco food businesses. For shareholders, the Kohlberg, Kravis offer is about double the $55 that the shares were selling for before the takeover battle began. But the shares traded in the low $90's during the week, indicating some uneasiness with the record deal that may take months to complete. *

title: POISON GAS TRACES ARE FOUND IN IRAQ
description: A British laboratory has found traces of mustard gas in soil samples taken from Iraqi Kurdistan, lending credence to allegations that Iraq has been using chemical weapons in a drive to debilitate its Kurdish population.

title: Stuck in the Middle Of a 'Soft Market'
description: IN November 1987, my husband and I began a voyage of discovery. On the way, we discovered our unlimited capacity for rejection, disappointment and depression. Since our trip began, we found that selling a house, especially one in which we've lived for 25 years, can be psychologically and physically demanding and debilitating. On our journey, we developed a new vocabulary that included terms like multiple listing service, right of first refusal, time-of-the-essence clauses, open house and creative financing.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: MANAGEMENT BY STRESS;
Behind the Scenes at Nummi Motors
description: LEAD: The General Motors-Toyota assembly plant in Fremont, Calif., has probably been the site of more pilgrimages by eager managers than any other factory in the United States.
