description: Jacalyn F. Barnett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Fischer of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Ronald Alan Ruden, a son of Arthur Ruden of Garden City, L.I., and the late Jeannette Ruden. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony at the Lycee Francais in New York.

title: Gorbachev Gets A Chance to Size Up the New Man
description: IT won't be a real summit conference, they're saying in Washington, more a get-together to mark the changing of the guard, when President Reagan and President-elect Bush meet Wednesday in New York City with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: 'Daughters': Dip in the Gene Pool
description: AS we see in the BayWay Arts production of John Morgan-Evans's ''Daughters,'' food is not the only topic of a kitchen conversation.

title: Orosco Signs With Indians
description: Jesse Orosco, the free-agent relief pitcher who was on World Series championship teams with the Mets in 1986 and the Dodgers this year, has signed a two-year contract with the Cleveland Indians worth $2,975,000, making him the highest-paid pitcher on the staff.

title: Getting a Lift In the Elevator
description: Along with Mr. Untermeyer, Robert M. Teeter and Craig L. Fuller, the chairmen of Mr. Bush's transition office, are the most popular men in town.

title: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE
description: Congratulations to Mark Hunter on having found the right person (About Men, ''Vive la Difference,'' Nov. 13). Surely, he owes American women no apology or explanation for marrying outside his own country. But his personal good luck should create no occasion for bad-thing American feminists. If, at times, we have had to move away from conventional manners, it has been in state legislatures, the halls of Congress and the offices of university presidents and corporate boards of directors. It has been in the fight to have the real doors opened.

title: Drug-Test Plan Approved
description: An out-of-competition testing program fully supported by the athletes was unanimously approved today by The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field. The sweeping approval came at the general session on the final day of T.A.C.'s six-day convention and was heartily applauded by the athletes, who had proposed such a resolution at a meeting late Thursday night.

title: The Primary Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Criticized On Jet Downing
description: An international aviation panel has concluded that major mistakes by the Navy in preparing for aerial combat contributed to the downing of an Iranian airliner in July. The panel said the Navy had taken inadequate precautions for keeping civilian aircraft away from combat operations. Article, page 3.

title: A LOWLY FISH GOES UPSCALE
description: IN THE MISSISSIPPI DELTA, THE livin' has never been all that easy -even when the fish were jumpin'. In the nation's poorest state, many a hungry family relied on a regular diet of catfish from the muddy pond down the road. The big, ugly, bottom-feeding fish might have an earthy flavor but, once cleaned, dredged in cornmeal and deep-fried, it made for a tasty meal. Best of all, it was free.

title: A Few Fans Spoil Image
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The wave of dismay and frustration will crystallize anti-American sentiments.'' - Assad Abdul-Rahman, of the Palestinian National Council, on the denial of a visa to Yasir Arafat. [ 30:1. ]

title: Sarah Houghton Is a Bride
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, Sarah Richardson Houghton, a daughter of Ruth West Houghton of New York and Representative Amory Houghton Jr. of Corning, N.Y., was married last evening to Mark William Grayson, a son of Suzanne M. Rowins of Hancock, Calif., and Thomas D. Grayson of Fairfax, Va.

title: Calgary
description: Not everyone will want to spend $82 for a 63-second ride down a bobsled run, but bobsled rides, with qualified driver and brakeman, are just some of the offerings at Canada Olympic Park in Calgary.

title: This Traditional 'Aida' Focuses On Real People
description: SONJA FRISELL, THE DIRECTOR of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's ''Aida,'' is quietly emphatic about staging operas along traditional lines. ''I tend to think a composer chose a setting for a definite reason,'' she said. ''And I'm convinced that one can make an operatic evening, set in the period the composer designated, seem alive and telling to a modern audience. I don't think transplanting the story is the key to that. I think relevancy is conveyed to the audience through the type and style of acting, and that's what we're working on.

title: CLASSICS? BAH, HUMBUG: A SYMPOSIUM
description: The sentimentality of Christmas sometimes brings out the Scrooge in each of us, and this year we asked the participants in our Christmas symposium to play literary Scrooge and tell us about the classics that make them most grouchy. The literary pantheon has always had fluid membership, and when our Scrooges revealed who they thought should be evicted from its halls, it became evident that nobody is guaranteed eternal tenure. Henry James was the clear winner for most Scroogy mentions - perhaps an inverse compliment of a kind. In any case, he would have understood that one person's sacred cow may well be another's favorite bete noire, and that nothing is more bracing than a draft of strong opinion. Herein we offer a few, for an invigorating season. Erica Jong Author of ''Serenissima: A Novel of Venice.'' Hail to thee, blithe Spirit! Bird thou never wert.

title: If RJR Nabisco Can Do It, Why Can't I?
description: I HAVE KNOWN STEVE K. FOR ALMOST 20 years. We were in law school together and then worked at the Federal Trade Commission for about one year. Our paths drifted apart, though, when I moved to Los Angeles and he moved to New York to work at an investment bank. I had heard that he lost his job for arguing with a computer about a trade and had drifted into genteel poverty as an advertising account manager. But when I got on an American Airlines flight from New York to Los Angeles last week, there, seated right next to me in business class, was a beaming, radiant, prosperous Steve K. He had on a smashing tiny dot suit from Polo, a $90 tie from Hermes and what had to be $300 tasseled loafers from Gucci. In short, he looked as if he had Michael Eisner's money and Ralph Lauren's sense of style and Ronald Reagan's optimism.

title: GRIPPED BY GOLD FEVER
description: THE SLEEPY TOWN OF ELKO, Nev., used to erupt once a year when local ranchers drove their cattle to the railhead, and cowboys, their wallets crammed with cash, headed for the casinos and brothels on and around Idaho Street. Today, in Elko, whose population has swelled from 8,000 to 16,000 since 1980, it's sort of like that all year round.

title: Reviews/Music; An Ex-Prodigy Returns to the Piano
description: It would be no bad thing if the passionless correct piano-competition winners everybody complains about had to spend an evening listening to Richard Gresko, or someone like him, play the piano. Mr. Gresko, who gave a recital on Nov. 26 at Merkin Concert Hall, had something of a child-prodigy career in the 1950's and was a student of Rosina Lhevinne, but he has not been active on the professional concert circuit in recent years; instead, he has composed and edited film music, written about electronics, reviewed records and the like.

title: FRANCHISEES FIGHT BACK
description: Ever since the Pillsbury Corporation proposed spinning off its Burger King chain into a debt-laden company to help thwart a takeover attempt by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the chain's franchisees have been collectively rebelling. That they own 85 percent of the chain's stores - at an average value of $1 million each - has certainly put a bite into their complaints.

title: Show, Don't Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: World Aviation Panel Faults U.S. Navy on Downing of Iran Air
description: A report by an international panel of aviation experts has concluded that a series of mistakes by the United States Navy in preparing for aerial combat in the Persian Gulf contributed to the shooting down of an Iranian airliner in the summer, with the loss of all 290 people aboard.

title: Judge Bars Challenges To Iran-Contra Charges
description: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell on Friday rejected Oliver L. North's remaining challenges to charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by diverting to the Nicaraguan rebels some of the profits from arms sales to Iran..

title:
INVESTING;
Clearing Skies Ahead for Airlines?
description: LEAD: Airline stocks are rising, along with air fares. This rise in stock prices has come on the heels of announcements two weeks ago by leading carriers that some discount fares were being eliminated and other fares would be raised.

title: Margaret Mee Dies; Amazon Artist Was 79
description: Margaret Mee, a botanical artist and explorer of Amazonian rain forests, died in a car accident, her family said Friday.

title: Review/Dance; Chaos, Anarchy, Art And 4 Hurtling Bodies
description: Wooden planks, tire tubes and bodies flew through the air and careered across the floor on Thursday at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, where Yvonne Meier is presenting ''The Bodysnatcher'' through Sunday. Chaos and anarchy reigned, filtered through Ms. Meier's well-honed sense of creative order. And it was chaos exquisitely rendered by Ms. Meier and four equally strong and fearless movers with quietly vivid stage presences.

title: Keeping Alive Memory of Dukakis
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Mr. Bush may have had a ''good discussion'' in a spirit of ''good will'' Friday, as the President-elect put it. But the competitive edge has not completely faded. In the transition press office sits a platform, which moves up and down to adjust to varying heights, labeled: ''The Mike Dukakis Memorial Podium.''

title:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS;
HE EDITS BEST WHO EDITS LEAST ALL THINGS, ESPECIALLY MINE
description: LEAD: A trove of James Thurber's unpublished papers lay in varying states of order in cardboard boxes for more than 20 years after his death in 1961. While going through the great humorist's stories, sketches and musings, Michael J. Rosen, who is editing a collection of Thurber's works, discovered an unpublished piece entitled by Thurber ''The Theory and Practice of Criticizing the Criticism of the Editing of New Yorker Articles (With a Lighted Candle for Wolcott Gibbs).

title: River Deltas Are Searched for 3,000 Missing in Bangladesh Cyclone
description: Searchers traveled the river deltas and channels of southern Bangladesh today looking for more than 3,000 people reported missing after a cyclone that killed at least 1,300 people.

title: Army Triumphs, But Not Easily
description: Army beat Navy as expected today in the 89th game between the service academies, but the Cadets had no easy time in a 20-15 victory.

title:
GARDENING;
Selecting Holiday Trees and Greens
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS decorations are appearing in the stores, and most of us will soon be planning the holiday decorations for our own homes. Christmas tree lots will be opening, too, While it is gratifying to know that the era of the aluminum Christmas tree has passed, alas, artificial trees are still with us.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Minneapolis;
Good Riddance To a Bad Block
description: LEAD: THIS city has demolished a row of buildings so linked in the public's mind with vice and violence that it threatened plans to revitalize the area as an entertainment district.

title: Review/Rock; Bobby Previte Leads A Fusionist Quartet
description: On the last tune of his set at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night, the composer and drummer Bobby Previte set his two guitarists battling. Looping and fierce metallic melodies snarled away at each other, only to smooth out into a country-styled riff, then into rock power chords. Mr. Previte's group played with the exuberant power of the best rock bands, as it had during much of the show, Mr. Previte has long been a central figure in many of the downtown scene's most important groups - Elliot Sharp's Carbon, John Zorn's various groups, Wayne Horvitz's President - so it's not much of a surprise to find elements of those groups in his band. Like President, Mr. Previte's group - featuring Jerome Harris on bass and guitar, Allan Jaffe on guitar, Steve Gaboury on keyboards - works an area heavily influenced by pop and instrumental music from the 70's. And like President, his group strikes an uneasy balance between easily digestible music and harder to assimilate sounds.

title: The Big Snore
description: SNORING STORIES are a woman's preserve. To see a man at a dinner party - upright, shirt and tie, a wine glass held delicately to his lips -reduced by a snoring story to a slack-jawed monster of darkness is to know the very nature of female revenge.

title: Gorbachev Impressing The Skeptical Emigres
description: On the crowded sidewalks of Brighton Beach, where shoppers speaking Russian trawl expectantly through the stores as if they were still in the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is getting some unlikely praise in the days before he arrives in New York.

title: Throw Out the Lifeline: Remember to Help the Neediest Cases; A Woman, Battered, Stands Up
description: Wanda A. did not leave her boyfriend after he shot at her and missed. She did not leave him when he tore their apartment to shreds and forced her to have sex with him. It was only after he threatened to beat her with a baseball bat last summer that she took their two children and walked out.

title: The Presidio
description: To the Editor: In the interesting article on the San Francisco Presidio (Travel, Oct. 16), there were a couple of minor errors.

title: My Husband - Their Hostage
description: LEAD: Along with other Americans, I am relieved by the end of the carnage in the Persian Gulf. I am proud of the role played by our elected representatives, and our men and women in uniform, in bringing about an end to the fighting and Teheran's acceptance of United Nations Security Council Resolution 598.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY HANUKKAH Activities marking Hanukkah, the Feast of Lights, are in full gear on the Island. For example, the Suffolk Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 74 Hauppauge Road, Commack, and the South Shore Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 25 Castleton Court, Oceanside, will hold their celebrations, complete with the usual latke noshing, entertainment and crafts workshops, at 1 P.M. today. Call 462-9800 or 766-4341, respectively, for ticket information. Also today, the American Chamber Ensemble plays ''A Hanukkah Celebration'' at the Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor.

title: 2 Killed and 13 Hurt in Blast In Town in Southern Zambia
description: Two people have been killed and 13 others wounded in a car-bomb blast in the southern Zambian town of Livingstone, Zambian authorities said today.

title: For Greek Ruling Party, the Plays Still Sting
description: One scene in the play shows an elderly politician frolicking with a young woman, while another has beggars in the street lamenting Greece's worsening economic plight and the political scandals rocking the country. Yet another has dancers inviting the audience to join in refrains calling on the Government to go.

title: Classical Bronzes Speak of More Than Art
description: ''THE GODS DELIGHT'' AT THE Cleveland Museum of Art is drawing a large, rapt and silent public, every one of whom moves through the show as a free spirit. (There is no Acoustiguide). Quite clearly, every visitor is spellbound by a vision of human beauty, human nature and the human potential that is definitive and in no need of amendment.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TEARING APART EASTERN AIRLINES
description: Your article implied that Eastern airlines might become profitable if its long-term employees would grant concessions. What you should have asked is why Frank Lorenzo cannot make Continental Airlines profitable. After declaring bankruptcy to eliminate Continental Airlines' unions, he had among the lowest labor costs in the industry. But management fees and the upstreaming of cash and assets to Jet Capital will never permit either Eastern or Continental to become profitable. PAUL E. LOUBRIS Revere, Pa.

title: Federal Inspection of Airline Reveals No Major Problems
description: Continental Airlines has received good marks in an inspection by the Federal Aviation Administration, which says an agency team was impressed with the performance of the airline's pilots and found no serious management flaws.

title: Colorized Camelot
description: In keeping with France's tradition of protecting artists' rights, a three-judge court in Paris has banned a colorized version of John Huston's ''The Asphalt Jungle'' from television. The court cited the director's comment on the colorization of ''The Maltese Falcon,'' another Huston classic: ''I shot it in black and white the same way a sculptor chooses between clay, bronze or marble.'' While the French judges' authority doesn't equate with American practice, one can't help but admire their good taste.

title: Nintendo Scores Big
description: When 13-year-old Peter Gambardella of Staten Island drifts off to sleep these days, he's not counting sheep but battling with Mini Bosses, Zoomers and Rippers, and perfecting his plan to destroy the dread Mother Brain.

title: Old Swimming Hole in Suffolk Is Center of Dispute
description: LEAD: A SWIMMING hole in Noyack is not what it used to be ever since the Town of Southampton banned bathing at Trout Pond, where two youths suffered broken necks after swinging out on ropes hung from trees, jumping into the water and hitting submerged debris.

title: Sports of The Times; The Tutor From the Majors
description: Like a weary cowboy coming in off the range to sleep under a dry roof, Jack Aker is coming off the baseball circuit for the first time in 30 years.

title: Back in Moscow, the Party Is Giving and Taking Away
description: WITH Mikhail S. Gorbachev poised to depart on a three-nation trip that begins Tuesday in New York City, the Soviet Union last week was experiencing a turbulent passage across the uncharted boundary between tyranny and tolerance.

title: MEAGDEALER FOR THE ROTHSCHILDS
description: MIDWAY THROUGH THE AFTERNOON OF SEPT. 26, ROBERT S PIRIE, PRESIDENT of Rothschild Inc., waits anxiously in the salmon-colored dining room opposite his office at 1 Rockefeller Plaza. The dishes have been cleared away but the banker, having lunched on turbot quenelles, partridge and tarte tatin, washed down with the house wine (Chateau Lafite-Rothschild '79), remains at the table, sipping claret and puffing on his third Davidoff cigar of the last hour.

title:
GARDENING;
Selecting Holiday Trees and Greens
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS decorations are appearing in the stores, and most of us will soon be planning the holiday decorations for our own homes. Christmas tree lots will be opening, too, While it is gratifying to know that the era of the aluminum Christmas tree has passed, alas, artificial trees are still with us.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our asphalt shingle roof has dark streaks of mildew on it, even though there are no overhanging trees that keep it shaded. When we had mildew on the siding, we scrubbed it off with a mixture of bleach and water. If we use this method on the roof, will this loosen the little granules on the shingles, and is there anything we can do to prevent the mildew from returning?

title: Drugs Crowding State's Prison for Women
description: THIS year about 4,000 women in Connecticut will have spent time in prison on narcotics convictions, almost double the number of last year and four times the number who were imprisoned only five years ago.

title: Kremlin Acts on Ethnic Strife
description: Kremlin officials beefed up security at airports and power plants in the republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia today and scrambled to aid 100,000 refugees who have fled their homes in fear of ethnic violence, Soviet news organizations reported.

title: Dreadful Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Weehawken Project; Condos on a Pier
description: Town houses line a pier on the western shore of the Hudson River, each affording a Circle Line-level view of Manhattan, and ferry boats whisk their business-suited owners across the water to work. This is not the fuzzy vision of an urban planner, but the reality John Tedesco is creating in Weehawken, N.J. On a concrete pier 132 feet wide and jutting 980 feet beyond dry land, Mr. Tedesco, chairman of the Coastal Group, has started to build the 245 condominiums of Riva Pointe.

title: Library to Get New Home
description: LEAD: THE Clifton Public Library, already one of the better libraries in northern New Jersey, will be moving to a new computerized facility that will make it one of the best of its kind in the state.

title: Lucian Freud: The Unblinking Eye
description: LUCIAN FREUD HAS BECOME a figure of popular myth, an artist poised between the underworld and the aristocracy, a kind of slumming Faust who prowls lowlife pubs and eats woodcock for breakfast.

title: Business Classes Lagging
description: LEAD: CONCERNED by a sharp decline in the number of students signing up for business education courses at the high school level - up to 60 percent in one year - 60 department chairmen are drafting a letter to the state's Board of Regents, asking it to reassess some portions of the Regents Action Plan.

title: STREETSCAPES: Hammerstein's Wildflower; A Queens Memorial to a Musical May Get Company
description: ARTHUR HAMMERSTEIN memorialized his 1923 theater hit ''Wildflower'' with his 1924 waterfront estate in Beechhurst, Queens, to which he gave the same name.

title: FOOD & WINE
description: Like any well-chosen guest, a book about food or drink should be thoughtfully selected. Whether the cook's taste is exotic or home-style, highly technical or rather haphazard, there are outstanding choices this season, ranging from lavish oversize volumes to stocking stuffers. *

title: POSTINGS: A Tale of 2 Towns; The Watch Ends for Those Vast Estates
description: Practically all the land in the Towns of North Salem and Southeast, N.Y., was once owned by a few families - 1,000 acres here, an entire ridge there. Then the subdivisions began; spreads became estates, which became yards. Last year, when Leon and Lillian Linder sold their property spanning the border of the two towns and Westchester and Putnam Counties, it consisted of a paltry 272 acres. Its division will continue. The new owners, Gotham Organization and Sloan House, will split the property in two stages. Approved by the towns is the carving out of two estates of 10 and 30 acres. The remaining 232 acres would be divided into 49 country lots that follow natural divisions rather than a superimposed grid. The developers will build on some of the lots, which will range from 3 to 30 acres, and sell others with deed restrictions on the size and style of the houses. Approval of the second subdivision will take 18 months, but should not be difficult since the property is zoned for up to 125 homes, said Myles R. Itkin, a Sloan principal.

title: For Art Class in Milford, Apples, Oranges and Nudes
description: LIKE Picasso, Rembrandt and Gauguin, art students in an adult education class in Milford will soon use nude models for their paintings.

title: Want to meet a Mate? Spend More Time at Work
description: Love and work may be the most important components of a person's life, but until recently most corporations have required that employees keep them separate. Now, as more women are in the work force, particularly in the managerial ranks, and people spend more hours in the office, the workplace becomes one of the likeliest places to make a match. Accordingly, employers are becoming more tolerant of office romance and even marriage, particularly if one partner does not oversee the other's work or expense account.

title: A Seafood Heritage, Home at Last>
description: THE long, fruitless search for the super little seafood restaurant is over. Elliot's Seafood Eatery in Lake Ronkonkoma is a find. Good, inexpensive seafood like that at Elliot's should be Long Island's heritage, not a rarity.

title: NEW JERSEY OPINIONIn Lieu of Flowers, Please Send Chocolates
description: IT was a race to the grave. Big Jim and Mary were dying - he of heart disease, she of cancer. The two cousins had grown up on opposite sides of the street. Now, on opposite sides of the Hudson, they were engaged in a macabre pas de mort.

title: UPWARDLY MOBILE
description: THE STEEP GRANITE WALL OF PYWIACK Dome, an 800-foot-high chunk of rock in Yosemite National Park, glitters in the afternoon sun. I am 150 feet up its sheer face, thin air beneath my heels, supporting my weight with clenched toes within my thin climbing shoes on ''ledges'' of rock not much wider than a saltshaker. My hands grip nearly nonexistent convexities. If I slip, the nylon safety rope will catch me up after three to five feet . But even a fall of that distance would mean sliding and scraping down hard, coarse rock before the jarring halt - sort of equivalent to being worked over by a power sander, then slammed against a wall.

title: Ellen B. Hale To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Hale of Altanta of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Bradley Hale, to Raymond Allen Jones 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. The couple plan to marry next month.

title: Peter W. Dickson Weds Miss Shea
description: At St. Elizabeth of Hungary Roman Catholic Church in New York, Mary Kathleen Shea, a daughter of Mrs. William R. Kesler of Danville, Ill., and the late John Keating Shea, was married yesterday to Peter William Dickson, a son of Mrs. William A. Dickson Jr. of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dickson. The Rev. Robert O'Connor and the Rev. Susan C. Harriss, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Contests, Winners And Choirs
description: AMONG the more ambitious projects sponsored by Performers of Connecticut is their annual Young Artists Competition. This year the auditions are for piano, woodwind and brass soloists between 18 and 30 years old and not yet under professional management. Some remarkable talents have been discovered over the 15 years that the contests have been held, and you can sit in on the selection process since the finals are open to the public without charge, starting at 2:30 this afternoon at Ives Hall on the Danbury campus of Western Connecticut State University (227-8998).

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Crystal Ball Ignites Fire

title: Fiction With Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 SOVIET HIJACKERS ARE SHIPPED HOME
description: The five Soviet citizens involved in the hijacking of an Aeroflot plane to Israel on Friday were sent back to the Soviet Union today in two Soviet planes.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Randolph, Me.; Rail Line Goes Back to Nature
description: TWO miles of the former Kennebec Central Railroad right of way, which connected Randolph with Chelsea five miles away, has been cleared for a six-foot-wide nature trail for hikers in summer and cross-country skiers in winter.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our asphalt shingle roof has dark streaks of mildew on it, even though there are no overhanging trees that keep it shaded. When we had mildew on the siding, we scrubbed it off with a mixture of bleach and water. If we use this method on the roof, will this loosen the little granules on the shingles, and is there anything we can do to prevent the mildew from returning?

title: Easing Musical Practice
description: PRACTICE, practice. Every good music student does it, but how many enjoy it? Practicing is lonely, frustrating and sometimes painful, many say. Yet the conscientious persevere, and this, according to the violinist and teacher Burton Kaplan, is not always a beneficial thing.

title: Finding a Parking Space Could Drive You Crazy
description: BRIAN used to ride to work with me. As he approached the car on this particular morning, I noticed that he was limping. ''What happened?'' I asked. ''Skinned my knee,'' he replied shortly, evidently not wishing to discuss it. ''How did you do it?'' I asked, ignoring his right to privacy. ''Saving a parking space.'' ''How come?'' I persisted. ''I flung myself down in the street,'' he said in a matter-of-fact voice.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 27 about Turtle Bay Gardens misidentified its north and south borders. They are 49th and 48th Streets, respectively.

title: Judi Robin Brenner to Wed
description: Judi Robin Brenner's engagement to Alan David Kaplan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Kaplan of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Brenner of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Venezuelans Voting Today For President
description: After a long and tedious campaign marked by mud-slinging, nationalist posturing and minimal discussion of substantive issues, Venezuelans vote Sunday in presidential elections in which the outcome is apparently not in doubt.

title: TRAVEL
description: After a mental journey of a thousand pages, I begin to see my world through the eyes of a diary-keeping traveler. In search of authenticity, I mingle with the people and experience New York life by taking a subway ($1 U.S.). Maps have been torn from the station walls. Each car displays a different destination. No one seems to understand my language. There are few seats in this egalitarian system. Exhausted, I sleep well that night on a large comfortable bed elaborately provided with sheets and pillows. Wealthy Americans, morbidly preoccupied with privacy, sleep only one or two to a chamber. In the morning, after a meal of ground grain, flaked and mixed with milk, I enter a small paneled room. After I push one of a series of numbered buttons, the room descends to street level. According to New York custom, the people boarding the little room do not speak. At the entrance to their building, however, they exchange invocations, designed to bring good luck to the day, with the guards. I follow some of them into the park, which is leafy and full of men and women engaged in all kinds of ritual athletics. Strange, very long vehicles with darkened windows roll along the roads. As the people who live on the benches begin to wake up, I approach a circle of young men who are exchanging money for small glass vials. I reflect that people are the same everywhere.

title: DEATH GANG LINKED TO PERU'S RULERS
description: Extremists within Peru's ruling party are sponsoring a paramilitary group that has claimed credit for death threats, bombings and at least two murders over the past four months, according to well-placed Peruvian politicians.

title: GARDENING
description: Now that the chores of autumn are done and the winter is at hand, it is a time for armchair gardening and catching up on horticultural reading. It is a time of lull, just before nursery catalogues begin to pour into our mailboxes early next year. Among the current books on gardening, here are four with high merit, although each one will appeal to a different kind of audience. *

title: Illegal Dumping in Vermont
description: The president of a Connecticut demolition company has pleaded no contest to charges of operating two illegal landfills in Vermont. The case is the Vermont attorney general's first prosecution against a private company operating an illegal landfill, which is a felony environmental offense, Deputy Attorney General Brian Burgess said Thursday. Gene R. Capozziello, president of Connecticut Building and Wrecking Company Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., entered the plea agreement with the state Wednesday.

title: Outdoors; AMERICAN WOMAN AT THE SUMMIT
description: When Stacy Allison reached the summit of Mount Everest recently, emerging in 50-mile-an-hour wind that blew her hat away, she grabbed the brass ring of American climbing. She became the first woman from the United States to stand on the roof of the world, which in the past several years had become one of the most sought-after goals in the sport.

title: Giving High-Tech Companies An Edge in Washington
description: NEW JERSEY has become the first state to hire a Washington insider to help small high-technology companies win Federal friends and influence Government grant makers.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
1,100 Cheerleaders
description: LEAD: This week, 1,100 girls will experience the excitement of having thousands of spectators cheer them as they perform their sport -cheerleading. The 40th annual Westchester County Cheerleading Festival will take place at the County Center in White Plains on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: Waste Tracking: U.S. Looks to State
description: THE Environmental Protection Agency is modeling a Federal system to monitor medical wastes after an emergency program New Jersey implemented three months ago.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Fugitive (Cont'd)
description: The roller coaster ride through the judicial system goes on and on for Joseph Patrick Thomas Doherty, an Irish Republican Army fugitive. Months ago, he was ordered deported to Britain, where he is wanted for the killing of a soldier.

title: Review/Ballet; 'Nutcracker' Cavalier Performed by a Finn
description: After importing Danish-trained male dancers into its ranks for a decade, the New York City Ballet has recently recruited a 27-year-old dancer from Finland, Jukka Aromaa.

title: Troops in Argentina End Rebellion
description: President Raul Alfonsin said tonight that a three-day rebellion by about 400 soldiers had been brought to an end without any concessions on the part of the Government.

title: Treasury Sales Limited to Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market and center on today's regular auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Letter: On Chemical Warfare; Looking for Control, Not Proof of Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Are Beaten By Flyers Again
description: December has been a time when the Devils have traditionally struggled, but this year they experienced a slump earlier than usual.

title: A New Outland Trophy
description: Ron Yary, winner of the 1967 Outland Trophy as that season's best college interior lineman, received the huge wall plaque at a dinner for University of Southern California athletes. Following his words of thanks, he placed the heavy, 2-foot-by-3-foot wooden and bronze trophy behind the dais and sat down to await the end of the ceremony.

title: Outdoors: Knives And Their Nature
description: WHEN I was a lad steeping myself in James Fenimore Cooper's tales of early America, I wanted a sheath knife almost as much as a bicycle. And when I finally got one, I sometimes wore it on my belt to grade school.

title: Broker Tied to Fraud Case
description: American court documents have reported a link between Blinder, Robinson & Company, the biggest penny stockbroker in the United States, and principal figures in a $500 million international securities fraud.

title: Maxwell Introduces Europe Daily
description: Robert Maxwell introduced a 12-page test issue of The European, his daily newspaper, on Friday.

title: Americans and Russians Consider Their Future
description: ''This is the room where our Founding Fathers signed the documents that gave us freedom,'' the tour guide at Independence Hall said.

title: Review/Pop; Many Faces of Judy Collins
description: Since breaking out of the folk mold in 1966 with her eclectic album ''In My Life,'' Judy Collins has embraced just about every significant American vernacular style except for pop-soul music. By placing quality theater, folk, Tin Pan Alley, rock, and art songs side by side on record and in concert, all are treated as carrying the same artistic weight.

title: A Factory-Built Answer To Housing's High Cost
description: In an attempt to fill a need for affordable urban housing, community groups and local officials around the country are turning to factory-built housing in the hope of creating instant neighborhoods on vacant city land.

title: Raising Attila the Hun
description: LEAD: You can tell it's Christmas when an endless stream of toy advertisements pours forth from the TV. My young son becomes more agitated with each station break. The ads are strictly segregated by sex: guns and monsters for boys, wigs and make-up for girls. Ever see a pre-schooler in lipstick and mascara like Betty Boop?

title: B.P. Offshore Oil Find
description: The British Petroleum Company and its partners in the Wytch Farm oilfield have made a substantial offshore find just off the English Channel port of Poole, B.P. said Friday. The well is the first of a three-well project expected to be completed by March 1989. The flow rate was restricted during testing to 1,000 barrels a day because of limited oil storage facilities aboard the rig, the company said. The Wytch Farm oilfield, also in Dorset, has recoverable oil reserves of 230 million barrels. Its reserves could top 300 million barrels with the new find and the possible similar finds from the other wells, analysts said.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Mexico has agreed to reduce its oil exports to 1.3 million barrels a day, from 1.35 million, to help the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries hold down production and raise prices. Mexico is not an OPEC member. The Government said oil generated $4.7 billion between January and August, slightly more than half that earned by non-oil exports.

title: Chernobyl Aide Asks A Soviet-U.S. Reactor
description: An official of the Chernobyl nuclear plant has suggested that the Soviet Union and the United States join in building a nuclear reactor, to help forestall accidents like the partial meltdown at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania in 1979 and the explosion and fire at Chernobyl in 1986.

title: New Haven Symphony Ends 2-Month Strike
description: The New Haven Symphony musicians ended a two-month strike today after they approved a new three-year contract by a vote of 37 to 3.

title: Reviews/Television; 'Pillar of Fire,' One History of Israel
description: A very effectively presented Zionist view of Israel's history begins today on CUNY-TV. ''Pillar of Fire,'' a 19-part series produced in Israel, was made available to City University Television by the World Zionist Organization. The first episode, which can be seen on the cable channel at 9 A.M. and 1, 5 and 9 P.M., starts with the Dreyfus case, which sparked Theodor Herzl's dream of a Jewish homeland toward the close of the 19th century, and goes forward to the British capture of Jerusalem in World War I. The tone is inspirational but, despite the auspices, not tendentious.

title: Farm Issue Is Clouding Trade Talks
description: A dispute over the extent to which the governments of the world's leading food exporters should cut aid to farmers is clouding a global effort here this week to reduce obstacles to trade.

title: Macey Weiss Married To Mitchell Haberman
description: Macey Daren Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin P. Weiss of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Mitchell Joseph Haberman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Haberman of New York and Westhampton, L.I. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Stanhope Hotel in New York.

title: F.D.A. Extends Methadone Experiment in Harlem
description: An experimental clinic in Harlem that issues daily doses of methadone to heroin addicts but does not offer the array of social services also mandated by Federal regulations has received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to continue operating.

title: League of Cities Exhorting Bush Over the Deficit
description: Representatives of about 16,000 of the nation's cities and towns added their voices today to the clamor for a reduction in the Federal budget deficit.

title: Greenburgh Has 6 Villages
description: Distinguishing between town and village is already complicated in the Town of Greenburgh, a Westchester County community with 80,000 people in 31 square miles. Greenburgh has six incorporated villages, where 42,700 of its residents live, and in many cases they are better known than the town itself: Hastings-on-Hudson, Dobbs Ferry, Irvington, Ardsley, Tarrytown and Elmsford.

title: MAJOR FIGHT SEEN ON BOMB REACTORS PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: A bruising battle is shaping up in Congress and among military experts over the Department of Energy's plan to build two costly new reactors in different states as an urgent first step toward revitalizing the nation's capability to produce nuclear weapons.

title: Bridge
description: A New Jersey player visited the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Nashville during Thanksgiving week and had a double reason to be satisfied with his trip.

title: Jewish Settler Sentenced for Killing Shepherd
description: A Jewish settler from the occupied West Bank was sentenced to five years in prison today for killing an Arab shepherd who had brought his sheep to graze on land near the Jewish community in May.

title: School Boards Found Failing To Meet Goals
description: When a middle-aged man was arrested on a Harlem street last month on charges of buying two vials of crack, there was no reason to believe that this would lead to a broad reassessment of New York City's system of decentralized school administration.

title: OPEC Output Up Last Month
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped an estimated 22.55 million barrels of crude oil a day last month, compared with 21.7 million barrels in October, a survey released Friday showed.

title: Oilers Overpower Rangers by 10-6
description: The unidentified Ranger climbed into the cab outside the team's hotel tonight and was off to the Northlands Coliseum. He relaxed in the back, the driver recalled, and casually predicted the Rangers would beat the Oilers, 4-2. The cabdriver laughed. The Ranger laughed back. The Oilers, as they have for much of the latter part of this decade in the league, laughed last. And hardest.

title: S.E.C. Doing A Bond Study
description: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission had undertaken a general review of disclosure statements for corporate bond offerings to explore whether additional rules should be issued to protect investors.

title: Kennedy Center Honors 5 in the Performing Arts
description: The worlds of entertainment and politics merged tonight as five artists were saluted and celebrated, first by President Reagan at a White House reception, then with a performance at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Bronx Juries: a Defense Dream, a Prosecution Nightmare
description: ''The testimony of a police officer,'' Judge Robert L. Cohen recently cautioned the potential jurors assembled in New York State Supreme Court, Part 39, the Bronx, ''should not be arbitrarily accepted.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Shunned Again
description: In his final months as director of Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, Gerald Austin felt shunned as the candidate relied more and more on Ronald Brown, his convention manager.

title: Cheapskates and Child Support
description: That it will help the children of single-parent families is reason enough for the New York Senate to pass a child support standards bill. Now there's another reason: a new Federal law that requires all states to have mandatory guidelines in place by October 1989.

title: Hall County Journal; Town Revives a Hospital and Itself
description: The news around these parts - headline-making, coffeeshop-chattering kind of news - is that the hospital is still open.

title: Malka Friedman Weds Michael van Bemmelen
description: The wedding of Malka M. Friedman, a daughter of Alice Friedman of Brooklyn and the late Adolph Friedman, to Michael van Bemmelen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Struick van Bemmelen of The Hague, took place last evening at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Jacob Kret officiated.

title: Lincoln Home Guides Sought
description: Tourism has increased so much at Lincoln's home that people are turned away. ''We've had to turn away school kids who came to see the Lincoln home,'' said Representative Richard Durbin. He and Senator Paul Simon say $67,000 is needed for more guides. The home Lincoln bought in 1844 was closed in 1987 for restoration and since it reopened in June it has had an 85 percent increase in visitors over 1986.

title: Can America Face Up to Fiscal Self-Deception?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld's Rules of Ego
description: ''Don't play President - you're not. The Constitution provides for only one President. Don't forget it.'' That warning appears in the last essay in the ''American Agenda'' - a series of policy recommendations to President-elect Bush from scholars and public figures, including Presidents Ford and Carter. The essay, called Rumsfeld's Rules, is a list of about 100 pointers to future White House aides from Donald Rumsfeld, who was President Ford's chief of staff.

title: Goggles Cited in Copter Crashes
description: Night-vision goggles designed for ground troops and not for flight were used by 62 military pilots whose helicopters crashed in the last decade, killing 134 servicemen, a newspaper reported today.

title: Fitness; Your Heart Disease Profile
description: HERE we are in the midst of the holiday season, a time of high fat and low exercise. So as a public service, a heart-disease risk factor test seems in order.

title: If This Be Treason, Why Wasn't I Tried?
description: On Nov. 18, Tom Manthata and three leaders of the United Democratic Front, a coalition of anti-apartheid organizations, were convicted of treason in Pretoria. I was a patron of the U.D.F. in its early years; I was named in the trial as an unindicted co-conspirator and I followed the evidence as closely as I could. If these four men have committed treason, then I have committed treason and should face charges as well.

title: Rangers Earn Their Holiday In a Top Spot
description: THIS tiny town, just inside the rugged edge of the Canadian Rockies, was originally established as a way station along the country's expanding railroad. In a short time, hot springs were discovered nearby and the town quickly evolved into a popular mountain spa.

title: Tax Watch; Hidden Ways To Gain Revenue
description: WASHINGTON tax experts today do not see higher tax rates in the near future - in stark contrast to widespread predictions during the recent campaign that the yawning Federal budget deficit made tax increases inevitable. But neither do they see any other comprehensive solution to the deficit problem.

title: Oakley Gains Some Respect With Knicks
description: WHEN the need arises for someone big, strong and quick, to pressure the inbounds pass, the Knicks usually call for Charles Oakley.

title: War on Drugs Held Burdening Justice
description: The war on drugs is overwhelming a criminal justice system whose greatest problem is a lack of resources, not the legal protections afforded to criminal suspects, a two-year study by the American Bar Association has concluded.

title: Lebanon: Land of 2, and No, Leaders
description: When two generals, each calling himself the army's commander, presided over two rival military parades marking Lebanon's Independence Day late last month, it was taken as further evidence that the rift between Lebanon's two governments and its two armies has deepened.

title: Mayor Back in Jersey City After Wife Is Killed in Peru
description: Anthony Cucci, the Mayor of Jersey City, returned home yesterday from a goodwill journey to Peru where his wife was killed when their train was derailed, apparently by saboteurs, near Cuzco, the sister city of Jersey City.

title: RED CROSS OPENS SUDAN RELIEF DRIVE
description: After almost a year of negotiations and the death by starvation of thousands of southern Sudanese, the International Committee of the Red Cross began airlifting food into two famine-stricken southern Sudanese towns today.

title: Chemical Herbicides Contain Only the Seeds of Profit; Indonesian Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Mile
description: In 1980, Ronald Monroe, aged 34, was sentenced to death in Louisiana for the stabbing murder of Lenora Collins, his next-door neighbor, three years earlier.

title: Ogilvy Wins a Mystery And $2 Million in Bottles
description: The Thompson Medical Company has selected Ogilvy & Mather over Saatchi & Saatchi to handle a new product, whose name and purpose neither agency nor client will divulge. The budget is $10 million. Thompson manufactures a range of over-the-counter products, notably Dexatrim and Aspercreme.

title: From Memory to Page, Or How Pete Dexter Wrote a Prize Winner
description: America's reading public will never have a chance to savor perhaps the best part of ''Paris Trout,'' the novel by Pete Dexter that won the 1988 National Book Award for fiction Tuesday night. Sixty days' work - ''I reckon about 110 pages,'' he said -were instantly and perpetually digested by his word processor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Ms. vanden Heuvel Is Wed
description: Katrina vanden Heuvel, a daughter of Jean Stein and William J. vanden Heuvel, both of New York, was married at her mother's home yesterday to Stephen Frand Cohen, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cohen of Owensboro, Ky., and Hollywood, Fla. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., a Presbyterian minister and the former senior minister of the Riverside Church in New York, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Inauguration; Capital Prepares (and Braces) for a 90-Hour Party
description: At inauguration time, Washington throws a 90-hour party. People from all over the country flock in to celebrate the empowering of a new President with concerts, galas, pageants, parades and solemn ceremony.

title: S.E.C. Study Links Bad Acquisitions to Later Takeovers
description: A new study of the corporate takeover boom in the 1980's has concluded that it had its origins, in part, in American corporations' attempts since the 1960's to diversify through acquisitions. The study contends that many takeovers are simply attempts to undo acquisition strategies that failed.

title: Seoul Leader Shuffles Cabinet
description: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea replaced most of his Cabinet today in his latest effort to separate himself from his disgraced predecessor, former President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: Farley Move On Pepperell
description: Farley Inc. said Friday that it would ask shareholders of textile giant West Point-Pepperell Inc. to hold a special meeting to consider Farley's $1.4 billion tender offer to acquire Pepperell.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Moonlighting' Time

title: Cambodians Look Abroad For a Future
description: With negotiations toward a Cambodian settlement stalled in two forums, the parties involved are waiting with some trepidation for the fallout from high-level Chinese-Soviet talks that ended in Moscow late Saturday.

title: 6 Contractors Say Navy Favors I.B.M. in Bidding
description: Six major computer service companies have accused the Navy of unfair bidding procedures that result in the award of almost every large-scale data processing contract to the same manufacturer - the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Gorbachev's Grand Plan: Is It Real or a Pipe Dream?
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev first visited the United States one year ago this week, the biggest question in most Western minds was whether he was the reformer he claimed to be, or simply a totalitarian with style.

title: Redskins Knock Eagles Out of First
description: The Washington Redskins knocked the Philadelphia Eagles out of their first-place tie with the Giants today on a 44-yard field goal with just 1 second left in the game.

title: Giants Are Trying for a Remake of Gatorade
description: AS improbable as it might seem for a National Football League team, the Giants won a doubleheader yesterday. And if they win their last two games against the Kansas City Chiefs and the Jets, they will qualify for the Super Bowl XXIII playoffs as the National Conference East champions.

title: Islander Loss Prompts Mixed Reactions
description: For the first time in weeks, sounds of life emanated along with the steam from the shower room as the Islanders refreshed themselves after a 4-2 loss to the surging Penguins Saturday night.

title: Chemical Herbicides Contain Only the Seeds of Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Spoils of War' to Close
description: ''Spoils of War,'' the Michael Weller play about a divided family living in the Eisenhower era, is to close Saturday at the Music Box Theater. The play, which stars Kate Nelligan and Jeffrey De Munn, will have had 36 regular performances and 14 previews.

title: China, Seeking More Efficiency, Looks to a Stock Market System
description: In its most ambitious financial experiment, China's Government is planning to turn the state-owned companies that dominate its economy into enterprises that issue stock.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday New-Car Sales Nov. Productivity 3d Qtr. Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Credit Oct. Thursday None Friday Wholesale Trade Nov.

title: Silicone Implants: No Cause for Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: A SOVIET ATTACK SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: The Soviet Union is highly unlikely to mount a surprise attack on NATO forces in Europe, despite fears of Western military leaders about a Pearl Harbor-type strike, a Congressional study said today.

title: John Upton Terrell, Author, 87
description: John Upton Terrell, the author of more than 40 books and a historian of the Old West, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 87 years old. A Chicago native, Mr. Terrell spent time as a youth on his uncle's ranch in Montana. When he was a teen-ager, he ran away from home to become a cowboy, and got work as a ranch hand. He later wrote for The San Francisco Chronicle and United Press and covered World War II for Newsweek.

title: Starrett City Decision Showed Race Bias Can Never Be 'Benign'
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 11 Miners Killed in Hungary
description: An explosion ripped through a coal mine near Budapest today, killing 11 miners and injuring 28, the Hungarian radio reported. Rescue workers pulled out the victims from the mine near the town of Dorog, between Budapest and Komarom, the broadcast said. Four of the injured miners were reported in serious condition from burn wounds.

title: Metro Matters; Policy Remedy: Unfettered Work For New Yorkers
description: When a mayoral Commission on the Year 2000 peppered largely optimistic predictions with some disturbing caveats last year, it called its forecast ''New York Ascendant.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Who was the first major league player to be on a pennant-winning team 10 times?

title: Gift Ideas for the Active Sportsman
description: FINDING the right holiday gift for family or friends can be as simple as knowing what sports they like. Match a piece of equipment to their interest and, bingo, your shopping is complete.

title: The New Republic Selects a New Publisher
description: The New Republic magazine has named Joan Stapleton as its publisher. Miss Stapleton, who is 35 years old, succeeds Jeffrey Dearth, 37, who will continue as president of the New Republic Inc., the parent company. He will concentrate on such projects as books and start-up magazines, the company said.

title: Male-Female Missile Crews Pass Test
description: After a yearlong trial, the Air Force has decided to make permanent a policy of assigning crews of one woman and one man on 24-hour duty in underground control rooms for intercontinental nuclear missiles.

title: Rome Journal; In the Italian Courtroom, Justice v. Father Time
description: It was really nothing more than a bump on the head, the judge was saying, and yet the case has dragged on for nearly a decade.

title: Recalling Year of the Banging Shoe
description: A joke about Tolstoy. A suspected bomb that turned out to be mostly apple pie. A line of harbor workers shouting, ''Go home, red butcher!''

title: Next Leader of Wyatt Built Up Boston Office
description: The Wyatt Company has named Michael H. Davis, who built up one of the benefit and compensation consulting firm's largest offices, to be its next president and chief executive.

title: Soviet General Warns On Unrest in Caucasus
description: The military commander of Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, warned today that force may be used to contain unrest there.

title: No Accord Broken on Arafat, Shultz Says
description: The United States did not violate the agreement under which it serves as host country to the United Nations when it barred the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, from entering the country to address the General Assembly, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: Lilco Wins Either Way
description: At first glance, the battle in Albany over the Shoreham nuclear power plant looks like a game of ''chicken'' between Governor Cuomo and the New York State Legislature. Each is threatening dire consequences if the other does not change position on the Governor's plan to scuttle the reactor.

title: Miss Williams Weds Fred Vandenberg
description: Marjorie Lynn Williams, the daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Davis of Cold Spring, N.Y., and Thomas O. Williams of Portland, Me., was married yesterday to Fred John Vandenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heiman Vandenberg of New York and Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: Mfanafuthi Makatini, 58, A.N.C. Aide, Dies
description: Mfanafuthi Makatini, a ranking member of the African National Congress and its former observer at the United Nations, died Saturday after a brief illness, the South African black nationalist organization announced.

title: Crack Dealers Returning to Streets That Narcotics Units Swept Clean
description: Less than two weeks after New York City's first Tactical Narcotics Team withdrew from a drug-plagued neighborhood in southeast Queens, crack dealers and their customers have begun reappearing in growing numbers on street corners, in parks and even a schoolyard in South Jamaica, residents, local officials and police officers have said.

title: 12 Tickets Are Winners In Record Lotto Jackpot
description: The odds of hitting the record $45 million New York State Lotto jackpot may be almost infinite, but the chances are practically zero that none of the 12 winning ticket holders selected late Saturday will claim their $3.75 million shares of the prize today.

title: PRETORIA WALKOUT CLOUDS PROSPECTS FOR AFRICA ACCORD
description: The abrupt departure Saturday night of South Africa from talks on peace in southwestern Africa appeared today to have thrown into doubt the readiness of the Government of President P. W. Botha to commit itself to a withdrawal from Namibia in exchange for a promised Cuban pullout from Angola.

title: Haunted By a Vienna Summit Meeting
description: Floating over the New York ''non-summit'' meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Ronald Reagan and George Bush this week will be the ghost of another get-acquainted superpower session: The Khruschev-Kennedy summit meeting in Vienna, in which many miscalculations were made.

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Political Talks Descend Into Near Chaos Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir failed to meet the first deadline for forming a new government, and his effort appears to be floundering. But he said that he will ask President Chaim Herzog for a 21-day deadline extension. Page A3. Housing Problem Tackled Cities are looking at the use of factory-built houses to quickly turn vacant lots into neighborhoods for low-income families. Page A16. A Movement to Secede An effort to create a village in Greenburgh, N.Y., that could bar housing units for the homeless has prompted charges of racism. Page B1. Lendl and Becker Gain Final Boris Becker and Ivan Lendl will meet in the final match of the Nabisco Masters. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: Raiders Edge Broncos to Stay in Race
description: You might find Greg Townsend in the Los Angeles Raiders' locker room before practice puffing on a cigarette or in solitude after drills, mulling over his day's work. The 6-foot-3-inch, 250-pound Townsend is a big man with a big smile who likes to be left alone.

title: Big Misstep for Next Mission Lamented as Atlantis Flies On
description: The space shuttle Atlantis continued circling Earth today on its secret military mission as officials here assessed the effect of a rocket worker's accident on plans for the next shuttle flight in February.

title: Bid to Bank Stirs Suspicion in France
description: ''What would people say in the United States if the Federal Reserve bought 10 percent of Chase Manhattan?'' asked an indignant Michel Thibout, an official of Societe Generale, France's third-largest commercial bank.

title: First Boston's Merger Plan
description: The First Boston Corporation, one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, has sent shareholders the details of its merger agreement with its London-based sister company, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston.

title: Quake Was Centered At Faults' Intersection
description: The earthquake that jolted Southern California early Saturday was centered at the intersection of two faults, one of which caused a deadly aftershock more than a year ago, a seismologist said today.

title: Books of The Times; For Junior Bibliophiles, 10 Favorites of the Year
description: The quality of children's picture books this year was higher than ever before. It was particularly difficult to pick out 10 that stood apart from the rest. Three books were especially hard to exclude: THE FISHERMAN'S TALE, story by Emily Whittle, pictures by Jeri Burdick (Green Tiger Press, $10.95) didn't quite make the list because its beautiful pastel sketches seemed slightly too abstract for children. DINOSAUR BOB AND HIS ADVENTURES WITH THE FAMILY LAZARDO, by William Joyce (Harper & Row, $12.95), for all the wit and originality of its illustrations, conveyed the message that a sports hero can live above the law. IRA SAYS GOODBYE, by Bernard Waber (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95) struck me as a shade too psychologically didactic, despite the pathos with which it dramatizes the trauma of two friends having to separate.

title: Renewed Outlook for Singletary
description: HE was the youngest of 10 children, always listening, tirelessly scrutinizing his elders while building a blueprint for what was right and what was wrong. And like his siblings, Mike Singletary failed gym in grade school. His father was a minister; to him, wearing shorts was a sin.

title: U.S. WILL RESPOND ON GULF DOWNING
description: The United States will respond on Monday to the International Civil Aviation Organization's findings on the downing of an Iranian civilian jetliner by a Navy ship in the Persian Gulf in July, Government officials said today.

title: Sundstrand's Head Retiring; President Is Named to Post
description: Evans W. Erikson, chairman and chief executive of the Sundstrand Corporation of Rockford, Ill., is going to retire on Dec. 31.

title: Nabisco Battle Redefines Directors' Role
description: F. Ross Johnson, the chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc., had always treated his board of directors well and had racked up a string of impressive profits for the company. So he expected the directors' blessing when he told them over dinner on Oct. 19 that he wanted to stage a $17 billion buyout of the food and tobacco conglomerate.

title: Soccer Title to Indiana
description: Sean Shapert's penalty-kick goal with 10 minutes 6 seconds to play in the first half gave Indiana a 1-0 victory over Howard University today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer championship.

title: A Third Stint at Top For Interim RJR Chief
description: As a result of the winning $25 billion bid by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for RJR Nabisco Inc., J. Paul Sticht, the avuncular executive who guided the company through a period of rapid diversification in the late 1970's and early 1980's, is set to serve a third stint as chairman and chief executive.

title: Actors Extol Underwear In Maidenform's Ads
description: The actor Christopher Reeve will join his professional colleagues Corbin Bernsen, Michael York and Omar Sharif in extolling women's underwear in the newest stage of Maidenform Inc.'s year-old television and print campaign, scheduled to begin in February.

title: Becker And Lendl In Final
description: They are meeting in the final again, although under somewhat different circumstances. When Ivan Lendl played Boris Becker for the two Nabisco Masters titles in 1986, he was the undisputed No. 1 player in the world, thought of as an interim champion but in the process of establishing his own era in tennis. Becker was the crown prince, a crowd-pleasing teen-ager with a big serve, bigger smile and two Wimbledon championships already to his credit.

title: Alexandra Bowie Weds D. C. Richman
description: The marriage of Alexandra Susan Bowie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Bowie of New York, to Daniel Charles Richman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richman of New York, took place yesterday at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn. Rabbi Margaret Wenig performed the ceremony.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT A dispute over farm subsidies threatens the progress of broad talks on world trade. The chief antagonists are the United States, with about 2.5 million farmers, and the European Community, with nearly 12 million. Ministers from 96 countries are meeting in Montreal in a review of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. [ Page D1. ] China's state-owned companies would issue stock under plans approved by the Communist Party. Proponents say such a move would force companies to be more efficient. [ A1. ] The purchase of a stake in Societe Generale has touched off a political storm in France. Opponents of the deal fear that Socialists hope to regain control of the nation's third-largest bank, which was privatized last year by the Conservative Government. [ D6. ] A U.S. attempt to straighten out Liberia's finances may be failing. A team of American experts seems ready to come home. [ D6. ] British Steel ranks among the world's lowest-cost steel producers, just a few years after suffering huge losses and acquiring a reputation for gross inefficiency. Shares of the newly privatized company begin trading today. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Congress is preparing to scrutinize leveraged buyouts in inquiries that could result in legislative restrictions. [ D1. ] A study concludes that many takeovers are attempts to undo failed acquisition strategies. [ D2. ] The economy continued to grow at a robust rate last month, although more slowly than in October, according to a report by purchasing managers. Employment grew faster than it has in 11 months. [ D1. ] Six computer service companies accused the Navy of unfair bidding procedures that favored I.B.M. in contract awards. [ B8. ] COMPANIES F. Ross Johnson made several critical mistakes in his attempt to buy out RJR Nabisco, underestimating the independence of his board and inadvertently inviting higher offers. The company's outside directors ultimately adopted a skeptical attitude toward management while showing regard for the benefits of employees. [ A1. ] Drexel Burnham told employees that the criminal charges that are expected against it will include obstruction of justice. Settlement talks to avert an indictment are at a ''crucial stage,'' the firm said. [ D1. ] Court documents have reported a link between Blinder, Robinson and figures in an international securities fraud. [ D8. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Book sales have been sluggish this fall, and publishers are entering the holiday season without ''must buy'' books. [ D10. ] The new issue of Business Week includes a 60-page supplement featuring works from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. [ D10. ] Robert Maxwell introduced a test issue of a newspaper, The European, that he said would promote Continental unity. [ D10. ] November's television ratings showed an industry in upheaval. The networks' audience continued to decline even as overall viewership increased. Television. [ D10. ] Schering-Plough has finished a nine-month agency review involving four products. Advertising. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Edison Price's factory has managed to survive in Manhattan. The company, which designs and makes special lighting fixtures, has benefited from a long-term lease. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Experts do not see higher tax rates in the near future, but an increase in ''hidden taxes'' may be inevitable. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Several large companies are said to plan to ask stockholders to exchange some of their shares for a package of securities that could help enhance common stock value. Market Place. [ D8. ] The Fed will almost certainly raise its discount rate, experts say, but the timing of such a move is unclear. Credit Markets. [ D9. ]

title: Former Leader Is Elected President of Venezuela
description: Carlos Andres Perez, a Social Democrat who served as President in the late 1970's, swept to victory today in his nation's presidential election, according to early returns and television projections. Mr. Perez's victory, over Eduardo Fernandez of the leading Christian Democratic party, Copei, and 22 other candidates of smaller parties, had been widely expected.

title: An Industry's Transformation
description: The newly privatized British Steel P.L.C., whose shares begin trading Monday, is probably the most striking example of the transformation of British industry under the Government of Margaret Thatcher during the 1980's.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Joe's Tammie Edges Tropicop: Joe's Tammie, ridden by Eddie Maple, pulled away from Tropicop in the final yards yesterday and posted a half-length victory in the $87,900 Iroquois Stakes for New York-bred fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Joe's Tammie was clocked in 1:40 2/5 for the mile on the fast track. The winner paid $6.20, $3.20 and $2.80 for $2 across the board as the second choice.(AP) GOLF Davis Wins in Playoff: A 5-foot par putt on the second sudden-death playoff hole yesterday gave Rodger Davis of Australia a dramatic victory over Fred Couples in the $1.25 million Bicentennial Classic tournament in Melbourne, Australia. The 37-year-old Davis earned the richest prize in Australian golf history, $430,000, and the biggest check of his career. He had a final round of four-under-par 68 to finish at 17-under-par 271. Couples pulled into a tie with a 67 on his final round. Both players parred the first playoff hole, but Davis sank his par putt on the second sudden-death hole after Couples had a bogey. (AP) Victory for Huston and Benz: John Huston and Amy Benz birdied the 18th hole to win the $800,000 J. C. Penney Classic by two strokes yesterday at the Bardmoor Country Club in Largo, Fla. Larry Mize and Martha Nause were second. The event pairs men's and women's pros for combined and alternate-shot competition. Huston and Benz had a 67 over the par-72 North course for 19-under-par 269. It was the first victory for Huston, a PGA Tour rookie, and Benz, a six-year L.P.G.A. competitor. They shared $160,000. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Syracuse 106, Louisiana Tech 98: Derrick Coleman scored 6 of his 23 points in overtime yesterday as Syracuse, after blowing a 23-point lead, won the 12th annual Carrier Classic in Syracuse. The Louisiana Tech forward Byron Newton sent the game into overtime with a 3-point shot as time expired. The Orangemen (7-0) had hit their first 11 shots, racing to a 24-5 lead, and appeared headed for another easy game. (AP) HARNESS RACING Final Victory for Mack Lobell: Mack Lobell, the greatest trotter in the sport's history, ended his career by winning a $100,000 race in Pompano Beach, Fla., Saturday night and bringing his winnings to more than $2.6 million. Mack Lobell finished with a career record of 40 victories, 5 second-place finishes and 4 third-place finishes in 55 starts. Retiring to stud, Mack Lobell will be sent to Alvesta, Sweden this week.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Edwards Wins 2 Events: Felicia Edwards, an 18-year-old senior at New Dorp High School on Staten Island, was a double winner yesterday in an all-comers track meet sponsored by the Metropolitan Athletics Congress at the Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck, N.J. Edwards, who does not run for her high school but represents the Starlet Track Club of Staten Island, finished first in the 600-yard run in 1 minute 27.1 seconds and in the 300 meters at 41.5 seconds. Another double winner in the women's events was Marge DeMarrais, a former Princeton runner. She won the mile in 5:01.9 and the 1,000 meters in 3:00.6.

title: People
description: * Bernie Dolan and Frank Joyce have been named senior vice presidents and, respectively, treasurer and controller at Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.

title: Gary Busey, Actor, Is Badly Hurt in Crash
description: The actor Gary Busey suffered severe head injuries after losing control of his motorcycle today, the authorities said.

title: Mission to Liberia Evidently Fails
description: Armed with a contract and brimming with self-confidence, a team of 17 American financial experts arrived here last year with a mission that at first seemed deceptively simple: clean up the finances of this small West African nation to prevent further waste, mismanagement and fraud.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Elizabeth Arden Inc., a unit of Faberge Inc. that distributes and makes beauty products and fragrances, named Peter K. Felberbaum president of the newly formed Elizabeth Arden licensing division.

title: Fewer Jobless in Japan
description: Japan's seasonally adjusted umemployment rate fell to 2.4 percent in October from September's 2.5 percent, the Government said Friday.

title: Two Leading Literary Agents Form Partnership
description: Two of the nation's most influential literary agents, Morton Janklow and Lynn Nesbit, have formed a partnership. The new agency, Janklow & Nesbit Associates, becomes effective Jan. 2.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Waived Ed Olwine and Chuck Cary, pitchers, for the purpose of giving them their unconditional release. BALTIMORE (AL) - Traded Eddie Murray, first baseman, to the Los Angeles Dodgers, for Ken Howell and Brian Holton, pitchers, and Juan Bell, shortstop. Appointed George (Birdie) Tebbetts major league and farm system scout, Gordon Goldsberry major league and free-agent scout, and Gary Nickels Midwest scouting cordinator. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Rick Mahler, pitcher, to a two-year contract. Appointed Brad Del Barba assistant director of player development and scouting, and Dan Lunetta traveling secretary. HOUSTON (NL) - Acquired Mark Portugal, pitcher, from the Minnesota Twins for a player to be named later. BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Signed Clinton Wheeler, guard. FOOTBALL MIAMI (AFC) - Activated David Frye, linebacker, from injured reserve. HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Sent Kerry Huffman, defenseman; Mark Freer, center, and Glen Seabrooke, left wing, to Hershey of the American Hockey League. WINNIPEG (NHL) - Appointed Mike Smith general manager.

title: New York Cultural Leaders Protest Budget Cut
description: Leaders of some of the 65 New York City cultural institutions that have just learned that the city will cut the amount of money it had promised them, plan to counterattack this week to try to reverse the decision.

title: Name Changes
description: For professional and college sports teams looking to associate themselves with aggression, there have been few better nicknames than the Indians. For so long the perception of the American Indian, whether fair or unfair, was one of a warrior with a relentless spirit, a character teams want to be associated with.

title: A Role Model For Darts Players
description: EVER walk into a bar and dominate the dart board the way Minnesota Fats used to control the pool table? Ever wonder if there was a way to make money from playing darts? Stop wondering because there is.

title: Market Place; A Plan to Divide Stock Into 3 Parts
description: THE latest plan in corporate reorganizations, to be announced soon by several large companies, involves persuading stockholders to sell back their shares for an ''unbundled stock unit,'' a package of securities that could help to convince investors that the shares are undervalued.

title: Simon Says He'll Run Again For Senate but Not President
description: Senator Paul Simon said today that he expected all his Presidential primary campaign debts to be paid off by early January and that he would probably sit out the 1992 Presidential campaign.

title: Advocates for Homeless Say New Law on U.S. Property Is Ignored
description: Advocates for the homeless are fighting the Federal Government's interpretation of a year-old law intended to benefit the homeless.

title: Ketchum And Messner Get Schering
description: THE Schering-Plough Corporation has finished its nine-month, four-product agency review, assigning Ocuclear, an over-the-counter eye drop, to Ketchum/Hicks & Greist, and Drixoral, a cold product, to Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, Schmetterer.

title: Winner of Heisman Runs Into Record Book
description: Just hours after being awarded the Heisman Trophy, Barry Sanders showed why he had won it as he led Oklahoma State to a 45-42 victory over Texas Tech here.

title: Hold the Alcohol
description: In an era of increasingly unruly fan behavior, Sullivan Stadium in Foxboro, Mass., achieved the dubious distinction in the early 1980's of leading the National Football League in arrests and overall rowdiness. The highpoint for rowdyism occurred in a nationally televised Monday night game in October 1980 when more than 100 spectators were arrested.

title: Dodgers Complete Trade for Murray
description: After one false start and a series of snags, including one on a hotel elevator that lasted 45 minutes, the Baltimore Orioles traded Eddie Murray, their power-hitting first baseman, to the Los Angeles Dodgers today for two pitchers and a 20-year-old shortstop.

title: Pictures for an Exhibition
description: Mikhail Gorbachev loosened the gags on his people and thereby created something radically novel in the Soviet Union: public opinion. He now has to do something equally revolutionary - feed it. And that is just what he's doing on the grand tour that brings him to New York tomorrow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just wish I were not so tired so I could celebrate.'' - President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina, at the end of a three-day military rebellion. [ A3:1. ]

title: NO COVERT ACCORD, U.S. PANELS INSIST
