description: Congressional intelligence committee officials denied knowledge today of a reported 1985 agreement between the United States and Israel to conduct covert antiterrorism operations abroad, and said the House and Senate should have been notified under Federal law if such an accord existed.

title: Johnny Paychek, Boxer, 74
description: Johnny Paychek, who once fought Joe Louis for the world heavyweight championship, died Saturday. He was 74 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fiction as History
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has warmly endorsed the theme of a new novel, ''Patterns of Abuse - A Novel of Politics and Power,'' to be published early next year by Wynwood Press of New York.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Drexel Describes Probable Charges
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has told its employees that the criminal charges expected to be filed against the securities firm will include obstruction of justice and that the settlement talks to avert an indictment have reached a ''crucial stage.''

title: Congress Is Moving Closer To Acting on Buyout Curbs
description: Prompted by the nearly $25 billion deal that will soon put RJR Nabisco Inc. into new hands, Congress is preparing to scrutinize leveraged buyouts and various related issues, senior members and staff aides say. The inquiries could result in legislative curbs against such activities.

title: Even With 'Remembrance,' A Ratings Month to Forget
description: THE numbers from November, one of the strangest ''sweep'' periods on record, are in, and while at first glance they confirm the status quo, just below the surface there is evidence of a television universe in a state of upheaval.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Bringing Light (and Fixtures) to the World
description: Just a block from the luxurious apartment houses on Sutton Place is a former icehouse that is now a factory in a city where others have found it so impractical to operate.

title: Shamir Seeks More Time to Form Cabinet
description: As his last day to form a new government drew to a close, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he would ask President Chaim Herzog on Monday for an extension of several days.

title: Giants in Command All the Way, 44-7
description: It was just like old times today. In the final minute of a victory on an chilly, blustery afternoon, Harry Carson dumped icy Gatorade on Coach Bill Parcells, who loved it. Moments later, for the benefit of the photographers who missed it, Carson did it again.

title: Cathy Barton Married To Steven Cahn Zales
description: Cathy Susan Barton, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Barton of Weston, Conn., and Steven Cahn Zales, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Zales of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz.

title: Surging Vikings Swarm Over Saints
description: Carl Lee and Jesse Solomon returned interceptions for touchdowns and Minnesota extended its string of not allowing a touchdown to 17 quarters today as the Vikings routed the New Orleans Saints, 45-3.

title: Purchasers Say Growth Is Still Robust
description: The growth rate of the nation's economy remained robust in November, though slightly lower than in October, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, to be released today.

title: A Chilly Autumn for the Book Industry
description: October and November are usually robust months for the book industry, but that was not true this year. ''From what we hear out there, things were awfully sluggish,'' said Lawrence Hughes, chairman of the Hearst Trade Books Group. To add to the potential woes of publishers and booksellers, there appears to be no one ''must buy'' book for gift givers as the industry enters its most important three sales weeks of the year, publishers say.

title: Reread His Lips
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Exploring 1947 Work By Carter
description: The current celebrations of Elliott Carter's 80th birthday are not only showcases for his recent thinking; they go back in time to the music Mr. Carter wrote well over a generation ago. These retrospectives are providing a singular service for listeners baffled by Carterian density. The New York Chamber Symphony, for example, played the complete ballet score of ''The Minotaur'' at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night. Mr. Carter wrote the music in 1947 to a scenario conceived in collaboration with George Balanchine. In it, an introductory scene depicts the mating of Pasiphae and the White Bull. A second scene moves ahead in years to the slaying of the Minotaur (their offspring) by Theseus in the Labyrinth.

title: Bush the Impish Vetoes the Imperial
description: George Bush ordered some buttered popcorn. Dan Quayle ordered some with extra butter.

title: Omnicom Division Buys Schechter Group
description: Diversified Agency Services, the Omnicom Group division that encompasses 19 specialty communications companies, has bought the Schechter Group, a New York design consultant. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition of Schechter, an 11-year-old, 35-person shop, comes less than a month after Omnicom's incoming president, Bruce Crawford, mildly criticized the composition and operation of Diversified, calling it a ''grab-bag.''

title: Time and the Chiefs Catch Up With Jets
description: The Jets could finally squeeze nothing more from their season today after holding on as playoff contenders until time ran out with 22 players chasing the ball.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 4, 1988: MONDAY Cincinnati Bell Standard Prods Harnischfeger Inds United Indl Corp Jamesway Corp Unocal Corp Rykoff Sexton Inc TUESDAY Alaska Air Gp Pep Boys American Stores So West Gas Corp Browning Ferris Inds Witco Corp Chyron Corp WEDNESDAY Corning Glass Works Peoples Energy Corp Deere & Co Portland Gen Corp Desoto Inc Premier Indl Corp Fieldcrest Cannon Inc Service Corp Intl Handleman Co Del Stanhome Inc Louisville G&E Co Starrett L S Co Masco Corp Times Mirror Corp Neiman-Marcus Gp USF&G Corp Pacific Scientific Corp THURSDAY Centel Corp Natl Fuel Gas Co NJ Flight Saftey Intl Inc Raymond James Fincl Hancock Fabrics Trinity Industries FRIDAY Helmerich & Payne Necro Inc

title: Pistons Stretch Nets' Losing Streak to 4
description: Joe Barry Carroll's 10-game absence ended tonight. But the Nets' frustration didn't.

title: Chemical Herbicides Contain Only the Seeds of Profit; No to Genes
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Cutters Zero In on Agriculture Programs
description: The Reagan Administration has seized on the $50.7 billion budget of the Department of Agriculture as a candidate for substantial cuts in the 1990 budget, according to officials at the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Review/Theater; 'Peg O' My Heart' Revived As Period Piece Set in 1930
description: First of all, without any defensiveness at all, it must be said that ''Peg O' My Heart,'' the 1912 comedy by J. Hartley Manners in revival at the Equity Library Theater, remains good fun even 75 years later.

title: Texas After the Oil Collapse: Back, if Not Quite Swaggering
description: For the first time since the bottom fell out of its economy three years ago, Texas is envisioning the brave new world beyond the oil bust that cost the state its financial independence and a sizable chunk of its self-esteem.

title: Neighbors Try to Secede Over Housing Plan
description: When town officials endorsed a plan to build housing for the homeless on county land here, neighbors of the site got out their maps and began drawing a new village: their village.

title: Rostropovich Cancels Two Recitals
description: Mstislav Rostropovich has canceled two performances at Carnegie Hall because of scheduling conflicts. His Jan. 20 recital will not be rescheduled, but subscribers who have tickets for that night have been offered the Feb. 26 recital by the pianist Maurizio Pollini in exchange.

title: Sharing With Neediest Replaces Gift Giving
description: There will be no Christmas cards this year from Alice L. Claing of Port Washington, N.Y. She writes that she is happy to have reached a decision not to take part in this ''commercial version of Christmas.''

title: Business Week's Work of Art
description: Business Week cast an admiring eye at the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in putting together a 60-page glossy advertising supplement in its Dec. 5 issue.

title: Review/Theater; The Way Thornton Wilder Said We Were
description: Thornton Wilder wasn't bashful about revealing his own high opinion of ''Our Town.'' Late in Act I, the play's narrator, the ubiquitous Stage Manager, tells the audience that he will leave the script in the cornerstone of a new bank, so that people ''a thousand years from now'' can see ''the way we were: in our growing up and in our marrying and in our living and in our dying.'' Let other writers worry about whether their work will survive the season; Wilder had his eye on a millennium.

title: Reviews/Television; An NBC Comedy, in a Family Way
description: This season of television babies continues to gurgle shamelessly. Clearly inspired by the ''Baby Boom'' school of dramaturgy, tonight's ''Maybe Baby'' movie - on Channel 4 at 9 - offers still another hot-shot career woman who suddenly decides that it is time to become a mommy. Janet Kovalcik's script pushes all the predictable buttons. But the executive producers, Perry Lafferty and Frank von Zerneck, were clever enough to fill the lead roles with two of today's best comic actors: Jane Curtin and Dabney Coleman.

title: Illinois Seniors Give Trip Money to Ill Boy
description: The 60 seniors at Altamont High School are forgoing a class trip to donate the money toward a bone marrow transplant for a 6-year-old leukemia victim.

title: Rate Rise: Only Question Is When
description: The Federal Reserve Board is virtually certain to raise an important interest rate soon, credit market analysts said. The major question confronting market participants is: when will the central bank choose to make its move?

title: 6 Die on Illegal Voyage
description: A boat carrying 53 people from the Dominican Republic trying to enter Puerto Rico capsized, killing 6 and leaving 5 missing, the Coast Guard said today. Its rescue center in San Juan said the boat capsized Saturday halfway between the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico.

title: Kirk to Quit Top Democratic Party Job
description: Paul G. Kirk Jr. announced today that he would not seek another term as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, setting off a potentially divisive battle over who will lead the party for the next four years.

title: Bubba Smith To Be Honored
description: Charles (Bubba) Smith, once an all-America football player and now a movie actor, listened to the brief speeches extolling the values of playing football and then made one himself. Later he said: ''That guy from Nebraska was right. Everything begins with football, the discipline and the work. Then you go on from there.'' The occasion was a luncheon yesterday at the ''21'' Club, an annual affair for 11 current scholar-athletes and 11 stars of the past who have had successful lives after football and have recently been elected to the College Football Hall of Fame. All are to be honored tonight at the National Football Foundation awards dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria. Smith, a devastating defensive lineman at Michigan State in the mid-1960's and later with the Baltimore Colts, is one of the inductees. So is Forrest Behm, ''the guy from Nebraska'' who for 39 years held management positions with Corning Glass.

title: Erly Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Martin Marietta Job
description: The Pentagon awarded a $347 million contract to the Martin Marietta Corporation for experimental work on lasers for the Strategic Defense Initiative anti-missile defense program. The 30-month contract is for work on the third phase of the so-called Zenith Star program, a seven-year plan to determine whether space-based lasers could be used to destroy attacking nuclear missiles in flight. The contract work awarded today is to form a blueprint for a space experiment now scheduled for the spring of 1994. The Lockheed Corporation and TRW Inc. are Martin Marietta's principal subcontractors in the program.

title: Review/Dance; Of 1789 and Other Revolutions
description: Yves Musard, a French-born choreographer, has revolution on his mind: the French Revolution of 1789. On Saturday night at the Dia Art Foundation, he offered ''The Man Who Believed He Could Move,'' a 45-minute solo that will be part of Mr. Musard's ''Va,'' a tribute to the French Revolution that is to have its premiere next year.

title: Zayre Plans A Complex Restructuring
description: The Zayre Corporation, which sold its 392 discount stores to Ames Department Stores Inc. in October, announced a complex restructuring yesterday in which it will both spin off its subsidiaries and repurchase shares in them. It also said it would declare a special cash dividend.

title: Treasury Prices Rise in Quiet Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in very slow trading yesterday as bargain-hunting traders bought securities that had been pushed down in Friday's big selloff.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Weigh Putting Limits on Damage Awards
description: With multimillion-dollar jury awards for punitive damages becoming increasingly common, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution places any limits on the amount of such damages that a jury may assess.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 6 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Rare Turtles Wash Up on Southern Coast
description: Carcasses of Kemp's ridley turtles, an endangered species, have been washing ashore in south Georgia and north Florida this fall in larger numbers than normal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Darwin raised the possibility of a continuity in mental development from animals to human beings. And it certainly looks as though he was right.'' - Dr. Edward A. Wasserman of the University of Iowa, discussing the pigeon mind. [ C1:1. ]

title: James Clair Shaw, 74, Admiral and Historian
description: James Clair Shaw, a retired rear admiral and naval historian, died Sunday at his home in Bellows Falls, Vt. He was 74 years old and before a recent illness had been New England director of the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Gophers and Ecosystem
description: Pocket gophers and their tunnels have long been the bane of homeowners and golf-course attendants. Now studies have shown that the underground rodents also profoundly affect the local ecosystem, altering the numbers, distribution and health of both plants and animals.

title: Jaguar Stock Up; Rumor Is Denied
description: The price of Jaguar P.L.C. shares jumped today on market rumors that Volkswagen A.G. or another company was building a stake in the British luxury car maker. At Volkswagen's headquarters in Wolfsburg, West Germany, a spokesman dismissed the rumor as ''pure speculation.'' Jaguar said it knew of no bid. Jaguar shares rose in hectic trading to close at $:2.7475 ($5.135), 11.25 pence (21 cents) above Friday's close, with almost four million shares changing hands.

title: Arafat Is Reportedly to Meet With U.S. Jews in Stockholm
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is to meet a group of prominent American Jews here on Tuesday, a Swedish Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Ends Bulk of Case in Myerson Trial
description: Federal prosecutors finished the bulk of their case in the Bess Myerson trial yesterday, having presented 34 witnesses who provided extensive circumstantial evidence and gossip.

title: Sallie Mae, in 2 Sales, Offers Notes Totaling $750 Million
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced two debt sales totaling three-quarters of a billion dollars in short- and medium-term securities.

title: Richton International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Applied Materials Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Police Plan to Maintain Stress on Drug Dealers
description: Although a 118-member Tactical Narcotics Team has been withdrawn from South Jamaica, the Queens narcotics command will continue to operate in the area ''for an indefinite period,'' the police said yesterday.

title: Late-November Vehicle Sales Up
description: Amid growing concern about rising inventories, the seven domestic automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new American-made cars and light trucks in the last 10 days of November were up by 3.6 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: Pacific Inland Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Pacific Inland attributed the loss in the latest 9 months to the $1,349,000 loan loss provision it recorded in the second quarter.

title: Metro Datelines; 'Silver Gun Robber' Is Held in 15 Holdups
description: A 28-year-old man was arrested Sunday as the ''silver gun robber'' responsible for 15 holdups last month on the East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: 4 Big Companies Set New Stock Unit Plans
description: Four major corporations said yesterday that they planned to buy back as much as $5.6 billion of stock in a new type of corporate reorganization. The shares will be purchased for what are known as ''unbundled stock units,'' packages of securities that include bonds and two new securities whose value will be based on the company's dividends and share prices.

title: Brisk Platinum Demand Seen Keeping Prices Up
description: After last week's sharp climb in the price of platinum on world markets, industry analysts and executives are predicting that robust demand will keep platinum supplies tight enough for prices to continue increasing for some time.

title: TV Mustn't Reinforce Myths About AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Notes
description: Because of the visit this week of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, some streets in New York City will be closed intermittently as Mr. Gorbachev and his motorcade pass. Following are the areas and times that traffic is likely to be most affected. Today 3 P.M.-5 P.M.: Grand Central Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway in Queens; 57th to 125th Streets, from Fifth Avenue to East River in Manhattan. Tomorrow 8 A.M.-9 P.M.: 67th Street to Battery Park, from Hudson to East Rivers. Thursday 9 A.M.-5 P.M.: 86th to 23d Streets, from Hudson to East Rivers. Friday 8 A.M.-10 A.M.: 57th to 125th Streets, from Fifth Avenue to East River in Manhattan; Grand Central Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway in Queens.

title: America and Research Roulette
description: This country pioneered television, VCR's and computer chips. But in 1986 America imported more high-tech products than it sold abroad. High-definition television will be the next major advance in consumer electronics but Japanese and European companies are poised to divide the vast American market between them.

title: Architect of No. 1 Defense May Move Ahead
description: Floyd Peters, the Minnesota Vikings' defensive coordinator, glances at his boss and finds similarities.

title: Pinter's Plays Following Him Out of Enigma and Into Politics
description: For many years, Harold Pinter paralleled in his personal life the enigmatic quality of his plays. In recent years, however, he has become more of a public figure, making political statements and, through PEN and Amnesty International, becoming an advocate of human rights and an outspoken opponent of suppression. Now the politicization of Harold Pinter is making itself increasingly evident in his art.

title: Reviews/Dance; From Rilke to the Rolling Stones, 8 Expressions
description: Eight works were on display in the Choreographers Showcase on Sunday afternoon at the Robert Yohn Dance Loft. Most were very brief sketches. But some of them possessed strong, clear choreographic lines.

title: Care for Players Going Beyond the Taped Ankle
description: Dr. Frank Gardner, the Knicks' team psychologist, accompanied the club on its recent four-game, six-day road trip. A team psychologist? The National Basketball Association has come a long way since the days when it was considered too costly for trainers to travel with teams, when players did their own taping and the only time they saw the team doctor was ''when we were really hurt,'' as Rod Thorn, the league's vice president of operations, put it.

title: Ex-Intelsat Official Jailed
description: A former top executive of Intelsat was sentenced today to 16 months to 4 years in prison for his role in a $4.8 million kickback scheme involving construction of the satellite consortium's headquarters.

title: Flight International Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $47,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S. Denies Israel Terrorism Pact
description: The White House denied today that the Reagan Administration had an agreement with the Israeli Government to conduct joint covert antiterrorism operations abroad.

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle to Land Today Officials said the shuttle Atlantics would end its secret military mission today with a landing in the California desert. Science Teims, page C5. Becker Defeats Lendl In a final that ran 4 hours 42 minutes, Borris Becker ended Ivan Lendl's 3-year reign as Masters tennis cham-pion, 5-7, 7-6, 3-6, 6-2, 7-6. Page B19.

title: NCH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Home National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share figures are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: New E.P.A. Weapon In Toxic Waste War: Funds for Novel Ideas
description: LEAD: THE Environmental Protection Agency has for the first time provided funds to private companies and research centers to help develop exotic, still unproved new technologies for cleansing hazardous wastes and cleaning up abandoned waste sites.

title: Venezuelan And Winner: Carlos Andres Perez
description: When Carlos Andres Perez stepped down as President of Venezuela in early 1979 at the age of 56, his main problem was how to keep busy over the next 10 years without seeming too obviously to be preparing a new bid for office.

title: Once Again, Winfield Subject of Trade Talk
description: When George Steinbrenner wanted to trade Dave Winfield earlier this year, Lou Piniella, then the Yankees' general manager, talked him out of it. Now the Yankees are trying once again to trade their run-producing right fielder.

title: 60 Are Feared Dead In Panic at a School In Cameroon Capital
description: A false alarm that a secondary school was about to collapse caused a panic today, and at least 60 students were killed when they jumped out of windows or were trampled to death, hospital officials said.

title: Boston U. Plan to Run Schools Facing Delay
description: Questions about the legality of Boston University's proposal to run the troubled schools of Chelsea, Mass., may delay the plan for the first such takeover of a public school system by a private university.

title: Unusual Freeway Monument Seen as Los Angeles Symbol
description: New York has the Statue of Liberty. St. Louis has the Gateway Arch. And by 1992, if the required $33 million can be raised in private donations and city planning agencies approve, Los Angeles will have ''The Steel Cloud,'' an unconventional monument meant to symbolize the city and its ethnic diversity.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Murdoch Magazine Hires Arnell/Bickford
description: Arnell/Bickford Associates was caught in a splendid little war between Conde Nast Publications and Murdoch Magazines and decided to switch sides. The agency has been named to create consumer and trade advertising for Mirabella, the magazine for mature women that Murdoch will introduce in the spring. The agency, which once produced a series of books on art and architecture, will use its design experience as well, consulting on logotype and cover designs for the new magazine.

title: Guide to a War That Lost Its Way
description: Nineteen years ago, Phill Coleman enlisted in the Army with enthusiasm and went to Vietnam. There, one of his duties was burying closet-size communications stations in the jungle for soldiers who were stranded.

title: 11 Universities Chosen In Technology Initiative
description: The National Science Foundation today designated 11 universities to serve as Science and Technology Centers, which are intended to link university, government and industry scientists and engineers in large-scale basic research that can quickly be put to practical use.

title: Review/Theater; Who Was That Chicken?
description: The air is thick with metaphor in ''The Promise'' by Jose Rivera. Two garishly painted actresses lurk on either side of the stage and occasionally take symbolic action in the play. A fighting chicken (played by an actress) is confined in a coop and lays an egg in the shape of a pyramid. The central character, a Patchogue, L. I. paterfamilias named Guzman (Jaime Sanchez), never grows old because he has a watch that goes backward. Time ticks very slowly in ''The Promise.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Turning Away Customers
description: Czechoslovakia imposed stiff curbs and penalties on Christmas shoppers from Poland, East Germany, Hungary and the Soviet Union. Page D1.

title: John Maher, 48, Dies; Helped Drug Addicts
description: John Maher, a former drug addict who gained national prominence by starting a successful drug and alcohol rehabilitation program in San Francisco, died in his sleep Friday at his mother's home in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and had suffered several heart attacks recently.

title: Rare Virus Tied to Nerve Disorders
description: A VIRUS that is considered a potential threat to the nation's blood supply because it causes cancer in humans, may also be an important cause of serious nervous-system disorders, scientists say.

title: Namibia-Angola Talks 'On Track,' U.S. Says
description: The State Department said today that the United States-mediated effort to achieve the withdrawal of foreign forces from southwestern Africa ''remains on track'' despite the failure of to reach an agreement last week.

title: For Growth, Cut Butter Not Guns
description: We are told that the Bush administration plans a comprehensive review of the defense program. That is good. A comprehensive review is needed, for many reasons. But we are also told that any decisions about the defense program will have to be consistent with no increase in real defense expenditures, for budgetary reasons. That is folly. This folly is generally accepted because hardly anyone is looking at the real costs of defense. Instead, almost everyone starts and ends by looking at the budget, concluding that an increase in defense expenditures cannot be squeezed within it.

title: Yugoslav Region Again Rebuffs 2 Albanians
description: The Communist Party in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province decided today against reinstating two ousted ethnic Albanian leaders who were blamed by Belgrade for being soft on separatists.

title: Encore Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $160,000 for the quarter and $633,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Noted and Not-So-Noted Relive Pearl Harbor Day
description: Printed across a looseleaf binder are the words ''Dec. 7, 1941.''

title: D & N Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., a computer retailer, to Tycer Fultz Bellack, Palo Alto, Calif., an operating unit of BBDO North America, with an estimated $5 million budget.

title: Verdict Could Derail Lilco's Progress
description: The Federal jury decision today against the Long Island Lighting Company has the potential to knock the utility off both paths it is pursuing to end the controversy surrounding the Shoreham nuclear power plant, analysts and government officials said.

title: Nir's Fatal Mexico Visit Called a Business Trip
description: A former Israeli official involved in the Iran-contra affair who was killed in a plane crash in Mexico last week was in the country in connection with a private business deal to buy avocados, Mexican and Israeli authorities said today. They said he was not here as a representative of the Israeli Government.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the $45 million New York lottery drawing misstated requirements for the second-, third- and fourth-place prizes.

title: Review/Piano; A Prize Winner's Chopin
description: Emily White, the pianist who won first prize at the October auditions of the Chopin Foundation Council of Greater New York, was presented by that organization in her New York debut recital - a Chopin program -on Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Key I.B.M. Manager Jumps to Xerox
description: The International Business Machines Corporation executive who has served as a lightning rod for criticism of the company's personal computer marketing strategy resigned yesterday to head product planning, development and manufacturing at the Xerox Corporation.

title: Trump's Tower Power
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's schedule for his trip to New York, released yesterday, included a surprising omission: As the result of a change of plan, the Soviet leader will not visit Trump Tower after all.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $692.9 million loss on Transborder claims. Fiscal 1987 figures are restated. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Materials Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2,012,000 for the quarter and $2,777,000 for the year. c-Net loss The operating net for the latest fourth quarter included a $3.7 million gain from the sale of an option on land.

title: REAGAN AND BUSH DISCUSS GORBACHEV
description: President-elect Bush and President Reagan today discussed their New York encounter with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as the United States and Soviet Union moved toward the meeting with differing expectations.

title: Chances of Better Soviet Trade Ties Rise
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the easing of some United States restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union seems possible, even to longtime American opponents of such a change.

title: Jury Finds Lilco Guilty of Fraud In Rate Hearings Over Shoreham
description: A Federal jury yesterday found that the Long Island Lighting Company and its former president deceived New York State in obtaining rate increases to help pay for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, making the utility liable for $22.8 million in damages.

title: U.N. Panel Weighs Next Step On U.S. Downing of Iran Jet
description: The 33-nation governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization failed today to reach a decision on its next step in the investigation of the downing of an Iranian airliner by the United States Navy. The aviation organization is the United Nations agency charged with regulating international civil aviation.

title: Market Place; Has Freddie Mac Moved Too High?
description: AFTER years of selling mortgage-backed securities to investors in the bond market, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, is now busy selling the virtues of its preferred stock to equity investors.

title: Optimistic Giants Use Caution
description: Two weeks ago, the Giants had a 7-5 record and were tied with the Philadelphia Eagles for their division lead. But the Eagles had the tie-breaker edge and seemed headed for the playoffs, and the Giants might have been headed nowhere.

title: Who's on Third? It's Cal Ripken Jr.
description: The trade by the Baltimore Orioles that sent Eddie Murray, their slugging first baseman, to the Los Angeles Dodgers may also make a third baseman of Cal Ripken Jr., who has been Baltimore's regular shortstop since 1982. As part of the deal, the Dodgers are sending the Orioles Juan Bell, a 20-year-old shortstop who has attracted rave reviews. ''A brilliant shortstop,'' said Roland Hemond, the Baltimore general manager. ''Defensively, Bell is ready to play in the majors right now,'' said Manager Frank Robinson. Ripken has said that he is quite willing to switch to third base. ''Whatever I can do for the team, I'll do,'' he said.(AP)

title: Method Detects Tumor Growth Far Sooner
description: A NEW computer-assisted way to look at brain scans is enabling researchers to determine whether tumors are changing in size much sooner than was previously possible.

title: KEY RATES
Petrolite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GAF to Keep WNCN-FM
description: WNCN-FM, the nation's largest classical radio station in size of audience, will remain under the ownership of the GAF Broadcasting Corporation, the New York State Court of Appeals has decided.

title: Heinz, H J Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
Chess
description: The Banco Concepcion International Tournament, a double-round quadrangular competition held in September in Vina del Mar, Chile, was won by Ljubomir Ljubojevic. The Yugoslav grandmaster won three games, drew two and lost one for a 4-2 score.

title: Ueberroth Finds Detractor In Discussion of Progress
description: In his fifth and final report as commissioner of baseball, Peter Ueberroth painted a rosy picture on economics, drugs and race relations today as he opened the sport's 87th winter business meeting. But he conceded that baseball ''must make more progress'' in hiring blacks as managers and general managers in the major leagues, and he was sharply criticized by Henry Aaron for the low level of jobs filled so far by blacks.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Do people perspire when they swim? And why is an air temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit uncomfortably warm, when this is a normal internal body temperature? A. The body may sweat during swimming, with the moisture dissipating unnoticed in the water, according to Carl V. Gisolfi, an exercise physiologist in the department of exercise science at the University of Iowa in Iowa City.

title: Mills-Jennings Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Gasoline Prices Below $1
description: The average price of gasoline has dropped to less than $1 a gallon for the first time since early July after a fall of almost half a cent in the last two weeks. The Lundberg Survey of 12,000 gas stations nationwide showed that the average retail price of gasoline was 99.61 cents last Friday, the industry analyst Trilby Lundberg said. The average retail price includes all grades of self- and full-service gasoline, taxes and cash and credit sales. On Friday, the average price at self-service pumps for regular unleaded gasoline was 89.8 cents a gallon, $1.05 for premium unleaded and 86.8 cents for regular leaded.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a reported 1985 agreement between the United States and Israel to conduct covert anti-terrorism operations abroad misstated comments by Congressional intelligence committee officials. They denied knowledge of the reported agreement; they did not say such an agreement did not exist.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Iran Sends Special Envoy to Beirut To Mediate Among Muslim Rivals
description: Iran has sent a special envoy here to mediate a conflict among Lebanon's Shiite Muslims as tension remains high between the two rival Shiite factions, Amal and the Party of God.

title: Tower Gets Bush Reassurance
description: President-elect Bush sought today to reassure former Senator John G. Tower of Texas that he was still the leading candidate to become Secretary of Defense, but that a final decision would await the selection of a group of top officials to run the Pentagon.

title: Oil Prices Down on Fears OPEC Will Not Cut Output
description: Crude oil prices fell yesterday, amid fears that the production quota recently adopted by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would not hold.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a diagram in Science Times on Nov. 29 about glutamate, a chemical involved in transmitting impulses between neurons in the brain, described the transmission process incorrectly. Dendrites, long projections of the neurons, receive the impulses. Other projections, axons, transmit the impulses. Information is carried into the receiving cells by ions.

title: Atlantic Permanent Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTH AFRICA JAILS A DRAFT RESISTER
description: An 18-year-old pacifist from an affluent white Johannesburg suburb was sentenced today to six years in prison for refusing conscription into the South African Army.

title: Careers; A Sideways Approach to A Better Job
description: WHEN there is little chance of promotion, a middle manager's best move might be sideward - the way a football player, blocked at the line of scrimmage, moves laterally to seek an opening.

title: Talking Business; with Czernek of Zenith Data Systems; Growth Picture In Laptop Field
description: The laptop computer market is growing dramatically. The International Business Machines Corporation acknowledged last week that it would not bring out a laptop product this year, and analysts said new battery-powered entries from Compaq, Zenith Data Systems, Toshiba and NEC might have intimidated the world's largest computer maker. Andrew Czernek, vice president for product marketing at the Zenith Data Systems Corporation in Glenview, Ill., said that technological development was moving rapidly in the field.

title: Computer Chip From Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company today announced the development of a computer chip that it said would vastly improve the quality of electronically generated photographs.

title: Patterns
description: Moschino's Notoriety

title: Navistar International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $23 million gain on settlement of prior year's tax audits for the quarter, and the year included a $14.8 million loss from discontinued operations. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $112.9 million on debt extinguishment.

title: Canadian Imperial Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $450 million from a provision for transborder losses. The year-ago periods have been restated to reflect changes in accounting for loan loss provisions. The results are in Canadian dollars. The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Texas Center Says Gift Will Aid Cancer Studies
description: The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center said that a gift of $41 million would allow it to greatly expand its cancer-related research.

title: Islanders and Larson Reach an Agreement
description: Reed Larson, a 32-year-old free-agent defenseman who has played in the National Hockey League for more than a dozen seasons, yesterday came to terms with the Islanders. Bill Torrey, the Islander president and general manager, said that Larson would practice with the team immediately. Contract details were not revealed. Larson was released by the Oilers Nov. 26.(AP)

title: Fearful and Angry Floridians Erect Street Barriers to Crime
description: After leveling off in the middle part of the decade, crime is rising sharply in parts of the Miami-Fort Lauderdale area, and some residents are so fearful and so fed up that they are barricading their neighborhood streets to keep criminals out.

title: Competition Can Make Auto Insurance Affordable; The 'No Fault' Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Agency Affirms Its Stand On Research on Fetal Tissue
description: A special advisory committee of the National Institutes of Health today made formal its finding that it is ''acceptable'' for the Federal Government to back medical research that involves transplanting tissue from intentionally aborted fetal tissue.

title: Daley Entering Chicago Contest For Mayoralty
description: In the most wide-open mayoral race here in many years, Richard M. Daley, the Cook County State's Attorney, joined the crowded field of candidates today and called for an end to the racial bitterness that marks this city's politics.

title: Gift Ideas From Disks To Modems
description: STUMPED for a holiday gift for your favorite computer user?

title: Icahn Linked To Talks on A Texaco Bid
description: Oil industry experts said yesterday that Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, might become part of a major new takeover battle for Texacok Inc.

title: Kuba Put The Fizz in The Masters
description: ''Ku-ba! Ku-ba!'' came chants from pockets of the crowd in Madison Square Garden Sunday afternoon. These were lyrical loyalists - growing, it seemed, with each match here - for the young Swiss tennis player Jakob Hlasek, struggling now to keep abreast of Boris Becker in their semifinal scrap in the Nabisco Masters tournament.

title: 2 Die in Tokyo Train Crash
description: A commuter train whose driver apparently missed a stop signal slammed into the back of another train in Tokyo today, killing two people and injuring 97, the police and railway authorities said. The police said the exact cause of the collision was not known.

title: Review/Music; Monks Add a Dash of Minimalist-Jazz-New Age Spice
description: The Gyuto Tantric Choir represents a Buddhist tradition that was founded in Tibet in the 15th century, and which has seen hard times in recent decades. When the Chinese invaded Tibet in 1950, the Tantric Buddhists' temples and artifacts were confiscated, and the monks who survived the invasion and subsequent purges fled to northern India.

title: Ortega Cancels Visit To U.N., Protesting Travel Curbs by U.S.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua canceled a trip to the United Nations today, saying the United States had placed unacceptable restrictions on his travel and on the size of his party.

title: Navy to Honor TWA Attendant
description: Ulrike Derickson, the TWA flight attendant who protected American passengers from Arab gunmen in a June 1985 hijacking, is to receive the Navy's highest civilian award, the Navy Distinguished Public Service Award, at the Pentagon on Tuesday, the service said today.

title: Cato Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9-month earnings include losses of $2,659,000 and $3,354,000, respectively, relating to restructuring expenses and discontinued operations.

title: Survey Finds Native Plants in Imminent Peril
description: Hundreds of native American plant species are in such imminent danger that they may vanish in the next five years, according to a major new report based on the findings of more than 90 botanists and horticulturalists.

title: HE ARRIVES TODAY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is due in New York today, may use his visit to mount an assault on United States trade restrictions and to offer a new proposal to reduce conventional weapons in Europe, American officials said yesterday.

title: License Sought For Proleukin
description: The Cetus Corporation said today that it had submitted a product license application to the Food and Drug Administration for approval of Proleukin interleukin-2 as a treatment for kidney cancer.

title: Steady Growth In Jobs Is Seen
description: Economic growth is likely to continue unabated into the new year, according to a survey released Sunday.

title: Bakker and Ex-Aide Are Charged With Defrauding Donors to PTL
description: Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, and a former top aide were indicted today on Federal charges of defrauding as many as 150,000 contributors and diverting more than $4 million for their personal use. Two other ministry figures were charged with income tax evasion.

title: The Prisoner of Perm
description: The prisoner from Perm enters the apartment in Moscow, still dressed in the shabby black and gray uniform he has worn for 10 years and one month. The cloth name tag on the jacket, so detested by political prisoners, is ripped off; only the threads show.

title: POLYGAMISTS LOSE AN ADOPTION PLEA
description: An adoption petition filed by a polygamous couple seeking custody of six motherless children was dismissed today, but the judge stayed his decision to give the couple a chance to appeal.

title: Hofmann Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $82,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 6 months.

title: Dalkon Trust Fills Vacancy
description: A Fordham University law professor was named yesterday to fill one of the three vacancies on the five-member $2.3 billion Dalkon Shield Trust.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Clients for Filler Space
description: Yellow Spots, an organization established in the fall to sell filler space in regional Yellow Pages directories to national advertisers, has its first clients: the Sears Discover Card and Budget Car and Truck Rental. The two charter clients will participate in January as part of research in four test markets in New York, California and Maine. Subsequently, the medium's effectiveness will be studied by an independent research agency.

title: Ingles Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Pepperell Attrition
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. is offering more than 800 employees early retirement in an effort to trim the company, which has grown through the acquisition of two competitors. The company said the program was not connected to its efforts to thwart a $1.4 billion takeover attempt by Farley Inc. of Chicago. Pepperell, based in West Point, Ga., has 41,000 employees and is the nation's largest publicly held textile company.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; Twilight for the 'Day One' Loyalists
description: They came to the White House eight years ago full of idealism and fierce devotion to Ronald Reagan. They are leaving now, devotion intact, but with their idealism a little shredded and with relief at leaving the pressures and conflicts behind.

title: First United Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Beyond Pork
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato justly takes pride in being New York's pork barrel Senator - a lawmaker who is not above making a few well-placed calls to see that his state receives its fair share of Federal dollars. But in helping to secure a $425,000 Housing and Urban Development grant for his hometown, Mr. D'Amato crossed the line between pork and poor taste.

title: Packages for Writing
description: WORD processing, which used to be called writing, is what most of us think of first when we are adding a personal computer to our lives. Selecting the right program can be a puzzle, though.

title: Lucky 13 Claim Share of $45 Million Jackpot
description: A bride and bridegroom in a newly arranged marriage, nine co-workers at a bank and two longtime friends were the first winners to step forward and claim shares in a $45.6 million lottery drawn Saturday evening.

title: ARGENTINE REBELS ARE SAID TO YIELD
description: The leader of the Argentine Army rebellion surrendered tonight, turning over command of an arsenal he and about 500 followers used as a base during their uprising, news reports said.

title: Physicians Insurance Company of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $2,333,284 and $5,252,013 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included losses of $110,794 and $2,810,628 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Williamson Resigns
description: Eddie Williamson, the head football coach at Virginia Military Institute for the last four years, resigned yesterday. His team was 2-9 this season and was 10-33-1 over all under him. He had one year remaining on his five-year contract.(AP)

title: Dallas Minister Held Liable in Attack on Wife
description: Relatives of the comatose wife of a former minister were awarded $16 million in damages from the husband today after a woman testified that he and she had been longtime lovers.

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $18,111,000 from the retirement of debt. c-After tax credits of $1.9 million for the quarter and $9.9 million for the year.

title: Highlights and High Spirits As Meetings Come to End
description: The International Olympic Committee's final meetings of 1988 began today with many senior officials almost giddy with satisfaction and relief.

title: A New Post of Chairman Is Created by Fiat USA
description: Furio M. Colombo, 58, has been named to the newly created post of chairman of Fiat USA Inc. and Vittorio C. Vellano, 42, has been named president. They have been, respectively, president and executive vice president.

title: Eli Lilly to Buy Concern
description: Eli Lilly & Company agreed last week to purchase a leading developer and manufacturer of catheter systems for the treatment of cardiovascular disease. The company, called Devices for Vascular Intervention Inc., is based in Redwood City, Calif. It manufactures catheter systems that treat cardiovascular disease by cutting, capturing and removing vascular plaque from diseased blood vessels. Lilly will pay about $50 million with the potential for up to another $150 million in contingency payments in the next five years.

title: NASA Says Shuttle Will Land in Desert Today
description: The secret military mission of the space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to end Tuesday with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California, space officials announced today.

title: Where Gucci and Other Big Names Are Up to Half Off
description: Malls may have replaced town squares as suburban social centers, but shoppers have proved they are willing to forgo the glitz for bare-bones retailing when the bargain is the thing. And there are few places where shopping occurs with such purity and exuberance as here at the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: 2 HELD IN DEATHS AT NURSING HOME
description: Two women who had been nurse's aides at a nursing home here were arrested and arraigned on murder charges today in connection with the deaths of two of its patients.

title: Bridge
description: At the World Team Olympiad last month in Venice, Denmark won the women's team title, and its open team tied for fifth. But two small twists from the gods in the quarterfinals could have reversed those results.

title: Brookfield Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Radioactive Steam Was Released Last Year at Plant Near Frankfurt
description: Government officials today reported an incident at an atomic power plant near Frankfurt last year in which radioactive steam was released into the atmosphere.

title: S.E.C. Acts On Amster
description: Amster & Company and two of its senior officers were charged today in Federal court in Manhattan with making false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission before the private New York-based arbitrage firm began a proxy contest for control of the Graphic Scanning Corporation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Rival Suitors For Nabisco Abandon Bid
description: The rival suitors for RJR Nabisco Inc. announced yesterday that they were no longer pursuing a bid for the consumer products company, ending speculation that they might mount a counteroffer or formally oppose the winning bid.

title: Olympic Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The bank said implementation of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement 91, the new accounting standard for loan fee income, lowered this year's third quarter pre-tax income by about $110,000.

title: Central Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Big Faults Found Deep Under Los Angeles
description: In a finding that may unsettle the nerves of millions of Southern Californians, geologists have discovered two major faults deep below some of the most densely developed parts of the Los Angeles metropolitan area.

title: Braves' Pick Is Familiar
description: Because they finished in last place last season, the Atlanta Braves had the first selection in the draft of unprotected minor league talent here at the winter meetings and they used it to pick a player from one of their own farm teams.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Martell Cognac Goes to DDB
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons has chosen DDB Needham to develop a marketing strategy and advertising for Martell cognac, which it acquired in February for $920 million after a bidding war with Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. Consumers in the United

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $19.4 million from the sale of its downtown headquarters block and an additional $2.2 million in pre-tax net gains, mostley related to securities transactions. These gains were reduced by loan loss provisions of $5.9 million and $3.7 million in writedowns on real estate. c-After a charge of $2,327,000.

title: Nations Agree to Cut Tariffs On 3d-World Tropical Items
description: The United States and other major trading nations agreed today to cut tariffs and other import barriers on bananas, tea, coffee and myriad other tropical products from the third world.

title: Costume Show: Victorian Elegance
description: Queen Victoria presides over the new exhibition at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, establishing an aura of indomitable elegance. The restrained richness of the clothes will come as a surprise to viewers accustomed to the flashier displays of past shows based on styles from Hollywood, Russia, India or Yves Saint Laurent. The theatrical genius of Diana Vreeland, a consultant to the museum until last year, gave her presentations the impact of a Broadway musical.

title: New Bellevue Director Quits
description: Citing family problems, the executive director of the Bellevue Hospital Center resigned yesterday after working two weeks.

title: Foundations Are Generous Donors to Neediest Cases Fund
description: In memory of a philanthropist, Jacob Merrill Kaplan, who died last year at the age of 95, the J. M. Kaplan Fund of Manhattan sent $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Towbin to Stay With Shearson
description: A. Robert Towbin, the investment banker, has decided to stay on with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and not join his colleague Thomas I. Unterberg in setting up a new firm.

title: Kentucky May Seek Extension on Inquiry
description: The interim athletic director at the University of Kentucky thinks that any action by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in connection with allegations about the Wildcats' basketball program will not take place until next spring. Joe Burch, who had been a deputy general counsel before replacing Cliff Hagan, said the university's response to N.C.A.A. allegations against the program, in addition to other procedural steps, would delay any final action by the N.C.A.A. He said the university was still preparing its responses to 18 allegations and might not have them finished by the association's deadline of next Monday. (AP)

title: American Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $713,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Republic Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $70,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Algeria Factory Blast Kills 18
description: A gas leak caused an explosion today at a date factory in eastern Algeria, killing 18 people and injuring eight, Government officials said. The factory is in Tolga, a village near Biskra, 240 miles southeast of Algiers, the officials said. The injured were taken to hospitals in Biskra and Constantine, they said. The officials said a gas leak caused the explosion but did not elaborate. They said the Ministry of the Interior had ordered an investigation of the incident.

title: House Democrats Vow Social Security Watch
description: House Democrats today pledged close scrutiny of Administration efforts to restrict Social Security appeals, and they hailed the demise of proposed rules that would have made it harder to appeal a decision denying benefits.

title: Raisa Gorbachev Gets Place of Honor
description: Who should be seated to the right of Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the Secretary General of the United Nations, at her luncheon tomorrow? Raisa Gorbachev or Nancy Reagan? United Nations protocol is avoiding the guest-of-honor issue by describing the event as ''a luncheon on the occasion of the visit of Mrs. Raisa Gorbachev to the United Nations.'' But the First Lady of the Soviet Union will occupy the place of honor to the hostess's right.

title: Note Sales Set By Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has scheduled two offerings tomorrow of interest-bearing short-term notes totaling $1.5 billion.

title: Datamarine International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Anti-Drug Campaign's Shortcoming
description: RESEARCH sponsored by the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America shows that the huge effort to use public-service ads to discourage narcotics use has had an effect on college students, young children and adults. A fourth group, teen-agers 13 through 17, has experienced the fewest attitudinal shifts, the report found.

title: Enough Charm And Intimidation
description: Every new President vows to improve relations with the press, and every four years they seem to get worse.

title: Israeli Reportedly Kills A Palestinian Girl, 12
description: A 12-year-old Palestinian girl was shot and killed today by an Israeli soldier in the occupied Gaza Strip, witnesses and hospital officials said.

title: Lorin Maazel, Fit as a Fiddle, Conducts 12 1/2 Hours of Beethoven
description: Lorin Maazel, music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony and the Orchestre National de France, on Sunday became the first person to conduct all nine Beethoven symphonies in a single day when he led three different orchestras in a musical marathon at London's Royal Festival Hall.

title: U.S. General Dies in Jet Crash
description: Maj. Gen. Winfield Scott Harpe, commander of the United States 16th Air Force, based in Spain, was killed yesterday while piloting a fighter bomber that crashed during a routine training mission, air force officials said.

title: Rykoff-Sexton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bonn's Record Surplus
description: West Germany registered record monthly exports and imports in October, official figures released today showed. The Federal Statistics Office said West Germany exported 53.18 billion marks ($30.91 billion) worth of goods and drew in imports worth 42.62 billion marks ($24.78 billion).

title: Valley Federal Savings & Loan Association reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Valley Federal converted to a stock savings bank effective July 22, 1987; therefore, per share earnings for the period ended Sept. 30, 1987 is computed based on earnings from July 22 to Sept. 30 of that year.

title: Six Teen-agers Die in Oregon As Car Collides With a Truck
description: Six teen-agers on their way to a party were killed when their compact car swerved in front of a pickup truck and was crushed, the police said.

title: Preferred Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bank of Montreal reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After provisions of $12 million for the quarter and $765 million for the year for losses on transborder claims. c-Net loss The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page capsule summary yesterday about Sunday's Israeli political developments misstated them in some copies. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he would ask for an extension of his deadline for forming a governing coalition; he had not already made the request. The request was made and granted yesterday, and is reported today on page A11.

title: Brandywine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Entwistle Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLORADO A-PLANT WILL NOT REOPEN FOR TWO MONTHS
description: The reopening of the nation's only industrial plant capable of processing plutonium for nuclear warheads will be delayed at least two months while the Government tries to clean up decades of accumulated plutonium dust.

title: Soviet-Cuban Trade Up
description: Trade between the Soviet Union and Cuba grew tenfold over the last 15 years to reach more than $9 billion in 1987, the official Prensa Latina press agency said today. The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is scheduled to arrive here Friday for a three-day official visit, and trade relations between the two nations are expected to be high on the agenda of his talks with Fidel Castro. Quoting official statistics, Prensa Latina said trade in 1987 totaled $9.36 billion, 10 times more than in 1972, when Cuba joined the Communist-bloc trade group, Comecon.

title: Poison Gas, Poisoned Treaties
description: In calling the use of poison gas in the Iran-Iraq war an ''ominous terror'' that has jeopardized the ''moral and legal strictures that have held these weapons in check since World War I,'' President Reagan understated the point.

title: HAITI'S NEW CHIEF FOSTERING DOUBTS
description: More than two months after Gen. Prosper Avril came to power with a promise of leading Haiti to democracy, many people here are beginning to question whether he intends to deliver.

title: Mustang Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: With No Pass Rush, There Are No Playoffs for the Jets
description: Under a gray sky, three ravens perched ominously atop the screen behind one of the goal posts at the Jets' practice field.

title: Hotly, Britons Fight to Save Welfare State
description: The welfare state has not lost its appeal to the British public, judging by reactions to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's most recent attempts to whittle it down.

title: Tiny Electronic 'Noses' Promise Speedy Sensing
description: A NEW generation of sensors that combine chemical and biological materials with electronics is under development to detect diseases in the body, toxic materials in the environment and contaminants in industrial processes.

title: Parties Name House Leaders and Goals
description: House Republicans today served notice on their Democratic colleagues that they would make ethics and campaign finance major issues in the 101st Congress, setting the stage for what may be another year of partisan confrontation over the leadership of Speaker Jim Wright.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambrit Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., a maker and distributor of ice cream bars, appointed Andrew McNaughton director emeritus and Brian E. Carley president and chief executive of its subsidiary Popsicle Industries Ltd., Burlington, Ontario.

title: Arthur Veltman, 52, A Developer in Texas
description: Arthur P. Veltman Jr., a Texas restaurateur and real estate developer, died Saturday at Baptist Medical Center, San Antonio. He was 52 years old and lived in San Antonio. He died of lymphatic cancer, said Dr. Luis Cisneros. With his partner, Bob Buchanan, Mr. Veltman opened Kangaroo Court restaurant and pub on River Walk in 1968, the first new restaurant in the San Antonio area in years. Others followed, helping to convert the bank of the San Antonio River into one of the state's top tourist attractions. His company also bought an office building and several other restaurants in the river area.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Aid to the Aiders
description: The Peace Corps is receiving some unexpected support from Band Aid, the emergency relief group set up by British rock musicians in 1984 to raise funds for alleviating famine in Africa. The Band Aid Foundation has donated $48,429 for improvement of water supplies in rural Chad.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 Mikhail Gorbachev may propose a reduction of conventional weapons in Europe and urge a reduction in United States trade restrictions during his visit to New York this week, American officials said. Page A1

title: Evidence of Atmosphere on Pluto
description: OBSERVATIONS of a star as it passed behind Pluto, the outermost planet in the solar system, have confirmed that despite its small size the planet has an atmosphere.

title: EAB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The provision for loan losses in the latest periods totaled $750,000 for the quarter and $3,750,000 for the 9 months, compared with $4.5 million and $19.5 million for the same year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Angeion Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: Exchanges Begin Fight Over Proposed Product
description: A legal battle is brewing between some of the nation's stock and and futures exchanges over a recently proposed trading instrument, and some officials believe the dispute could result in a jurisdictional fight among Federal regulators.

title: Wallowing in Misery
description: The Nussbaum Show is brilliant television. The camera cuts to the accused's face, expressionless behind thick glasses, then back to the chief witness against him - a woman whose nose appears to have no bridge and whose eyes no longer match. In the hallway, the lawyers deliver a running commentary on the trial. Meanwhile the anchors deliver a running commentary on the lawyers. On WCBS, which broadcast the show in its entirety yesterday, one of the anchors is a lawyer. While Hedda Nussbaum testifies, the ratings are going through the roof.

title: Becker Wins Masters, Beating Lendl in 5 Sets
description: He walked toward Ivan Lendl with the West German flag draped over his shoulder, a gift from a fan who had raced on the court after Boris Becker's winning backhand toppled wearily over the net. Wimbledon made him an overnight sensation and a national hero in 1985, but last night the Nabisco Masters might have given Becker the impetus he needed to finally challenge for No. 1.

title: Human Rights Movement's Foot Soldiers Gather in Manhattan
description: A few dozen largely unknown men and women who routinely - and often at great peril - monitor violations of human rights in their native lands are gathering in New York this week to celebrate the 10th anniversary of Human Rights Watch, an American organization that seeks to diminish such abuses by focusing attention on them.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Grand Met Extends Its Bid for Pillsbury
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. extended for the sixth time its $60-a-share takeover bid for the Pillsbury Company and said that about 88 percent of Pillsbury's outstanding shares had been tendered. The British conglomerate's offer of $5.23 billion is now scheduled to expire at midnight Friday.

title: Dali, Making Gains, Promises to Paint Again
description: Salvador Dali was moved out of the intensive care ward today and later told King Juan Carlos he would paint again.

title: BFS Bankorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,045,000. The year-ago periods' per share earnings are unavailable because the company converted to stock ownership on May 11, 1988. The latest year's per share earnings were since May 11, 1988. The fiscal 1988 results included one- time securities gains of $2.5 million mostly from the sale of Freddie Mac preferred stock. The fiscal 1987 results included one- time gains of $1,552,581 from the sale of mortgage-backed and investment securities and $2,672,797 from the sale of the company headquarters building in lower Manhattan.

title: Productivity At Factories Rises by 5.2%
description: The nation's manufacturers improved their productivity at an annual rate of more than 5 percent in the third quarter, but other businesses had more difficulty in keeping increases in their labor costs below the rate of inflation.

title: To Honor New York's Korean War Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Businesses to Be Split By Kaufman & Broad
description: In a bid to end investor confusion over its two business lines, Kaufman & Broad Inc. said today that it would restructure into two separate entities by distributing its 91.6 percent stake in its fast-growing home-building subsidiary to its shareholders.

title: Burndy Takes Bid From Framatome
description: The Burndy Corporation agreed to be acquired by Framatome & Company of Paris for $26 a share, or about $326 million. Shares in Burndy, a Norwalk-based maker of electronic and electrical connecting devices, soared $7.375, to $25, on the New York Stock Exchange. The 41.8 percent rise was the day's largest on the Big Board.

title: Centennial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holyfield Is Aiming to Take a Shot at Tyson
description: When last seen in a prize ring, Mike Tyson was calmly walking away from the crumpled figure of Michael Spinks, whom he had dismantled in 91 seconds.

title: 2 Will Share Literary Post At I.C.M.
description: Marvin Josephson, the head of International Creative Management, yesterday appointed Esther Newberg and Amanda Urban the joint heads of the agency's literary department.

title: Suit Challenges Chemical Arms Program as Unsafe
description: An environmental group today filed a suit that accuses the Defense Department of providing inadequate safeguards in its chemical weapons program. It asked a Federal court to halt the entire program, including production of the first new chemical bomb since the 1960's, and to order exhaustive environmental studies.

title: Urban League Gets New Chief For New York
description: Donald L. Polk, a 53-year old former educator and social worker who was most recently head of the Urban League of Eastern Massachusetts in Boston, took over yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the New York Urban League.

title: Review/Music; Americana, From Gould to Carter
description: If America has not become the melting pot it once advertised itself to be, it is still a wonder of diversity. It would be hard to imagine, for example, four more indigenous yet totally different pieces than those played by the American Composers Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Review/Television; Early Days of Rhythm-and-Blues
description: ''They danced, even if they had the blues. That's what it was all about.'' The speaker is the singer Ruth Brown, as she recalls the development of black rhythm-and-blues music in the 1940's and 1950's, a development that evolved into rock-and-roll. She can be seen tonight at 10:35 on Channel 13 in ''That Rhythm, Those Blues,'' an hourlong documentary produced by George T. Nierenberg (''Say Amen, Somebody''). It is being presented as part of ''The American Experience'' series.

title: Prague Shuts Door on East Bloc Shoppers
description: Comrade Scrooge showed up here several weeks early.

title: Pennview Savings 3d qtr or yr reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $104,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago per share figures are unavailable because the bank converted to stock ownership in September 1987.

title: Competition Can Make Auto Insurance Affordable
description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Apple' Of Gorbachev's Eye
description: LEAD: The visit of Mikhail Gorbachev to our city is fraught with sweet irony. The General Secretary's itinerary is claimed in the usual places by the usual suspects to be a calculated series of encounters with individuals and institutions exemplifying a system that works (ours) as against one that does not (his).

title: Joseph C. Nugent Sr., 85, Stockbroker, Dies
description: Joseph C. Nugent Sr., a retired New York stockbroker and emeritus member of the board of trustees of Marymount Manhattan College, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: On Searches, Trust the Experts
description: The exclusionary rule, upheld by the Supreme Court, bars the use of improperly seized evidence in criminal trials. As frustration with crime has grown, so has the volume of calls to overturn the rule. But now an impressive group refutes those calls - police and prosecutors who must deal with the exclusionary rule every day.

title: Mainstream Medicine Joins Growing Debate About Drug Approval
description: A FORMER head of the Food and Drug Administration has startled some in medicine by raising fundamental questions about the agency's hallowed scientific procedures for licensing new drugs against fatal diseases.

title: Diamond Shamrock
description: Diamond Shamrock R.&M. Inc. signed a definitive agreement to buy 80 Tenneco service station-convenience stores from F. Philip Handy, a Winter Park, Fla., financier, for an undisclosed price. Mr. Handy bought the service stations, which are in Texas and Colorado, less than two months ago as part of a 448-station package for which he paid Tenneco about $170 million.

title: Everex Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Germans Open Trial on Thefts From Nazi Archive
description: The first trial to come out of investigations into the theft of thousands of Nazi-era documents from an American-controlled archive opened in West Berlin today, and officials said more charges could be made soon.

title: Ellard Stars As Rams Beat Bears
description: Mike Ditka had said his Chicago Bears would play tonight as if they had radar in place for No. 80, Henry Ellard, the Los Angeles Rams' sneaky receiver.

title: TV Coverage Of Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's arrival at Kennedy International Airport, scheduled for 3 P.M. today, will be broadcast live by ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN, the Cable News Network. PBS (Channel 13 in New York) will report on the Soviet leader's visit on the MacNeil/Lehrer ''Newshour'' at 8 P.M.

title: Terminal Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest year results were affected primarily by non- recurring expenses in the third quarter related to the company's management restructuring, the relocation of its facilities, and the disposition and writedown of certain assets.

title: Aid for Retired Catholic Clergy
description: Roman Catholic churches will take up a special collection this weekend for nuns and priests in retirement. Most religious communities cannot afford the cost of caring for elderly religious because the number of young clergymen and clergywomen providing financial support is dwindling, church officials said.

title: Metro Datelines; Explosion Burns 3 At Transit Yard
description: An explosion yesterday in an electrical panel at the Transit Authority's 207th Street yard near 10th Avenue in upper Manhattan burned a contractor and two authority employees.

title: Elway Dismissed As Stanford Coach
description: Jack Elway, the Stanford football coach, was dismissed yesterday after five years in the post.The Cardinal finished this season with a 3-6-2 overall record and 1-5-2 in the Pacific-10 Conference. Elway compiled a 25-29-2 record at Stanford. He was head coach at San Jose State for five years and at California State-Northridge for three years before going to Stanford.

title: Actor Is in Stable Condition
description: The actor Gary Busey, who campaigned against a law requiring that motorcyclists wear helmets, was better today but still in critical condition with brain injuries suffered in a motorcycle accident on Sunday.

title: Review/Television; 'We Shall Overcome'
description: You can't help being touched and inspired by ''We Shall Overcome,'' the history of the anthem of the civil-rights movement, although after 90 minutes of hearing the song reiterated in all its variations and renditions, you may be ready to hum something, anything else.

title: Troops Clear Protesters In Azerbaijani Square
description: Soviet troops used force Sunday to clear crowds from the central square in Baku, and protesters were massing elsewhere in the Azerbaijani capital today, an official said.

title: Steel Importers Seek To Phase Out Quotas
description: An association of steel importers pitted itself against the nation's major steelmakers yesterday, calling for the Government to modify the program that limits steel imports.

title: Hart Fund-Raiser Sentenced For Making Illegal Donations
description: A video promoter from Newport Beach, Calif., who pleaded guilty to illegally donating money to Gary Hart's Presidential campaign, was given a three-year suspended sentence today and fined $60,000 by a Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles.

title: Fewer Oil Rigs in Action
description: The number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas fell by 6 last week, to 905, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the rig count was 1,152.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Designing a Memorial
description: The next memorial to rise in Washington will honor the women who have served, and will serve, in the nation's military. A design competition will be announced Thursday.

title: Beijing, Wooing Taipei, Plays Its Trump: The Chiang Card
description: China is wooing Taiwan in many ways, but the most startling bouquets are found in this rural hamlet miles from nowhere in eastern China.

title: Reviews/Dance; Asian Choreography in 2 Sensibilities
description: Four countries and two sensibilities were represented in ''Wu-Shen'' (''Dance Spirit''), a program of traditional and contemporary dance by Asian choreographers on Saturday night at the New York University Education Theater. But a shared sense of concentration and focus distinguished the choreography and performing.

title: Review/Music; Premiere of Carter Oboe Piece
description: The San Francisco Symphony and its director, Herbert Blomstedt, ended their weekend visit to New York with a program of works by Handel, Elliott Carter and Brahms on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall. In the older music, Mr. Blomstedt conducted with clarity and a sense of unswerving interpretive drive, and he seemed undaunted by the rapidly changing textures of Mr. Carter's Oboe Concerto, which had its New York premiere.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., agreed to buy the European exhaust system businesses of TI Group P.L.C. of London for about $204 million, including the assumption of debt.

title: BankAtlantic Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included $6,630,000 provision for possible loan losses, compared with $450,000 for the year-ago period.

title: CMS Advertising reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Rises By 31.48, To 2,123.76
description: LEAD: The stock market rallied strongly yesterday, led primarily by blue-chip issues.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Shot After Game In Bronx High School
