description: Three spectators at a high-school basketball game in the South Bronx were shot yesterday when two youths quarreled after the game and one pulled out a gun and fired several bullets at the other, the police reported.

title: Transplanted Nepalese Rhinos Breed
description: Tiny footprints recently led wildlife officials to a baby rhinoceros, the first calf born to a herd transplanted to this swampy area from another part of Nepal to preserve them.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Book Notes column on Wednesday about the Feminist Press misstated the year that it moved to the City University of New York. The year was 1985.

title: Our Towns; Thirty Seconds Over Marlboro, An Aerial Din
description: For days, Robert Kaplan kept a log of aircraft flying over his home. ''What's that?'' he said, jumping from his kitchen chair and running out the front door. A helicopter was passing overhead. The microwave said 11:45. On the kitchen table were eight legal-size pages, both sides filled with times and dates.

title: United Nations Journal; Acres of Paper, and a World of Good Intentions
description: For six weeks hundreds of diplomats have been shut away in subterranean committee rooms fighting over the scores of resolutions that the General Assembly will approve as its session draws to a close.

title: Savings Unit Action Urged
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that he would like to see all money-losing savings and loan institutions closed in the coming year to ease pressure on healthy institutions.

title: Soviet-Afghan Rebel Talks Adjourned
description: The Soviet Union and the Afghan guerrilla alliance based in Pakistan ended the first round of high-level meetings in the Saudi resort Taif today with expressions of satisfaction but no announcement of results, reports reaching here said.

title: Longtime Bookseller Forced Out by Rent
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Southern Federal Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said fourth quarter earnings were negatively impacted by several non-recurring transactions, involving mainly reversals of previously accrued interest income of about $700,000 related to certain commercial and commercial real estate loans. Also involved were expenses of about $400,000 associated with the early payoff of certain borrowings and the loss of about $525,000 from the sale of mortgage backed securities. The company said included in latest year net loss was an addition to the reserve for loan losses of about $7.5 million.

title: Books of The Times; A French Aristocrat With Timeless Ideas
description: Tocqueville A Biography By Andre Jardin Translated from the French by Lydia Davis with Robert Hemenway. 550 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $35.

title: Littlefield Adams & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Included losses of $184,000 for the quarter and $626,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Allied-Signal Chooses Auto Unit President
description: John W. Day was named president yesterday of Allied-Signal Automotive, a major automotive supplier with such brand names as Bendix, Fram, Autolite and Garrett in an industry that expects growth to accelerate in the next few years.

title: Americana Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $589,000 and a provision for estimated loss on disposal of mortgage banking operations of $1.1 million. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $921,000. d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $548,000. The per share figures for the year- ago 9 months were not available; the company went public in February 1987.

title: British Steel Chief Helps In Changing an Image
description: The chairman of British Steel P.L.C., which started trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, has been acclaimed in Britain for transforming a money-losing concern into an efficient steel producer.

title: Metro Datelines; Wife and 2 Men Held In S.I. Man's Death
description: A 43-year-old Staten Island woman and two young men were accused Sunday of killing her 73-year-old husband, who was beaten and suffocated last week in a staged robbery, the police reported.

title: Japan Vehicle Sales Up
description: Japanese vehicle sales for November rose 15.9 percent from a year earlier, to 446,404 vehicles, marking the 19th consecutive month of yearly gains and a record for the month, according to the Japan Automobile Dealers Association. Last month, cars sales rose 16 percent, trucks increased 15.8 percent and buses jumped 18.3 percent over November 1987. The latest sales included 11,228 imported vehicles, up 43.8 percent from a year earlier. Domestic sales from January to November totaled 3.27 million cars, up 13.6 percent from a year earlier; 1.27 million trucks, up 18.1 percent, and 22,052 buses, up 7.2 percent.

title: Fannie Mae Selling Sinking Fund Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $700 million of sinking fund debentures due in 1998 through securities dealers led by the agency. It is the first time Fannie Mae has offered 10-year debentures that include sinking fund payments.

title: Conflict Over First Boston Merger
description: The previously announced merger agreement between the First Boston Corporation and its London-based affiliate, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston, was done at a significantly lower price than an outside investment bank had originally termed fair for shareholders, according to First Boston's just-released proxy statement.

title: EFFORTS BY SHAMIR GET AN EXTENSION
description: President Chaim Herzog today granted Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir another three weeks to form a government as leaders of Labor and Likud angrily said they were closing the door on any further discussions of a coalition including the two large parties.

title: Liquid Formula Diet Can Be Hazardous to Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Starpointe Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1987 per share earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in 1988.

title: Sir David Trench, Diplomat, 73
description: Sir David Clive Crosbie Trench, a former Governor of Hong Kong, died Sunday at his home in Shillingstone, England. He was 73 years old. The cause of death was not announced.

title: By Design; Chic but Comfortable
description: Now is the season when many women find themselves facing a long, festive evening after an equally long day on the job. Naturally, they intend to have a great time, and, of course, they want to look fabulous. The trick is to figure out how tired feet can twinkle for the evening hours.

title: Citizens Savings Bank (Ithaa, NY) FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $700,000 to establish an allowance for real estate losses, a pre-tax charge of $266,000 for an accounting change and a non-recurring gain of $281,000 from a loan recovery. c-After tax credits of $362,000 for the quarter and $1,305,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' net from operations included a pre-tax gain on security sales of $426,000. The per share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 15, 1988 to shareholders of record Sept. 30.

title: Valhi Will Sell Sugar Business
description: Valhi Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its beet sugar business, the Amalgamated Sugar Company of Ogden, Utah, to an undisclosed foreign group.

title: How Do You Tell a Chair from a Cat? Scientists Say You Could Ask a Pigeon
description: THE humble pigeon, scarcely noticed as it pecks a livelihood from its sidewalk environment, may have more in common with human thinkers than generally realized.

title: Cellular Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trump Stores Report Denied
description: Neither Donald J. Trump nor Alexander's Inc. has serious plans to convert any Alexander's department stores to luxury stores under the Trump name, Robin L. Farkas, chairman and chief executive of Alexander's, said yesterday.

title: Transit Agency Puts Emphasis On Its Stations
description: After several years of improving buses and subway cars and tracks, the Transit Authority will turn its attention next year to a long-neglected area -the subway station.

title: Liquid Formula Diet Can Be Hazardous to Heart; Fat Was Beautiful
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Thrown By Steinberg, Witness Says
description: Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday that she saw Joel B. Steinberg repeatedly shake Lisa Steinberg and throw her down a few weeks before Lisa died from blows the prosecution said were inflicted by Mr. Steinberg.

title: Cubs Trade Palmeiro for Williams of Rangers
description: Jim Frey, the Chicago Cubs' general manager, thought he might have to trade Shawon Dunston, his good young shortstop, to get the closing relief pitcher he desperately wanted. But today Frey acquired that pitcher, Mitch Williams, and retained Dunston.

title: The Luncheon Guests
description: Marcela Perez de Cuellar Raisa Gorbachev Natalya Belonogov, wife of Aleksandr M. Belonogov, Soviet delegate to the United Nations Svetlana Maksimov, wife of the Byelorussian delegate, Lev I. Maksimov Dina Udovenko, wife of the Ukrainian delegate, Gennadi I. Udovenko Liana Dubinin, wife of Yuri V. Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States Nancy Reagan Barbara Bush Helena Shultz, wife of Secretary of State George P. Shultz Matilda Cuomo, wife of the Governor Elizabeth Moynihan, wife of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. Maria Pia Fanfani, an official in the Italian Committee for the Red Cross and wife of former Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani. Brooke Astor, the philanthropist Estee Lauder, the cosmetics manufacturer Aileen Mehle, who writes a gossip column for The New York Post under the name Suzy Barbara Walters, journalist for ABC News Marietta Tree, chairwoman of the Citizens Committee for New York City Carol Sulzberger, wife of Arthur O. Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times Drue Heinz, the philanthropist Cecile Zilkha, chairwoman of special events for the Metropolitan Opera Anne de Caputo, wife of Foreign Minister Dante Caputo of Argentina, President of the General Assembly Zoya Safronchuk, wife of Vasily Safronchuk, the Soviet Under Secretary General to the United Nations Secretariat Marie Reed, wife of Joseph V. Reed, the American Under Secretary General to the United Nations Secretariat Atia Teymour, wife of Aly Teymour, the United Nations chief of protocol.

title: Mini-Vans: From Fad to Fixture
description: The roomy mini-van is turning out to be a fixture on the automotive scene, not just a passing fancy.

title: Seven Oaks International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago figures have been restated.

title: Harvard Relying on Potent Offense
description: Not only is Harvard way out in front in the ECAC Hockey League, but the Crimson also has four of the top five scorers in Allen Bourbeau, Lane MacDonald, C. J. Young and Peter Ciavaglia.

title: EATING WELL
description: IN 1987, thousands of people in Pennsylvania and Delaware came down with gastrointestinal illness because of contamination in commercially prepared ice. The same year, three people in the Tampa, Fla., area were hospitalized with botulism from tainted coleslaw. This fall, 29 junior high school students in Minnesota became ill after eating precooked beef patties.

title: Cuomo Says Tax Increases Are Probable
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that his plan to close the state's budget gap would probably include tax increases as well as spending cuts.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about people who have worked at the White House since President Reagan took office misidentified one who decided to remain in Washington after the deaths of her fiance and her mother in California. The woman is Elaine Crispen, not Karen Fuller.

title: No Distant Relatives
description: To The Living Section:

title: Jackson Sparks Knicks' Overtime Surge
description: The Knicks defeated the Denver Nuggets, 124-123, in overtime last night when Mark Jackson, unproductive most of the game, found his shooting touch late in the fourth quarter and Michael Adams, unstoppable all game, missed his only free throw in seven attempts with no time remaining.

title: Jonathan Larsen Named Editor of Village Voice
description: Jonathan Z. Larsen, a 48-year-old magazine writer and editor, will become editor-in-chief of The Village Voice on Jan. 3, the publisher of the weekly newspaper announced yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Contract Voted At Sun-Times
description: Editorial employees of The Chicago Sun-Times have voted overwhelmingly to accept a three-year contract, ending a six-month dispute with the management of the city's second-largest newspaper.

title: Cobb Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said most of the latest quarter loss was attributed to the London Mine venture, which was in its first full quarter of operations.

title: Mets' Shopping List Is Long But They Come Up Short
description: The Mets pursued trade talks on half a dozen fronts today and made their first formal offer to get Dale Murphy from the Atlanta Braves. But they reported that the Braves were still asking too many players in return, and said ''nothing is imminent.''

title: For Jack McKeon, the Padres' Manager, Engineering Trades Is Hardly a Big Deal
description: The boldest, keenest, hottest trader in the ancient art of swapping baseball players these days is Jack McKeon, the manager of the San Diego Padres.

title: Knob Noster Journal; Bomber Means Boom for Base Town
description: There's gold, legend has it, buried in one of those round-topped hills above this small Midwestern town with the curious name, and several people have spent a lot of time looking for it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are living in a world which is going through some very crucial changes, and all nations have their own concerns, their own interests. We shall we sharing our concerns and our interests in analyzing and thinking over the current situation.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:6. ]

title: Students Chip In for a Gift for Santa Claus
description: Santa Claus will be getting a gift this Christmas.

title: Giuliani Is Said To Be Weighing Race for Mayor
description: United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani has told New York City Republican leaders through intermediaries that he may be interested in running for mayor.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Business People column yesterday about Fiat USA described the company's chairmanship incorrectly. There was a previous chairman, Francesco Gallo; he remains a director.

title: W. E. Potter, 83, Army Engineer
description: William E. Potter, an engineer who was a governor of the Panama Canal Zone and a builder of Walt Disney World, died of heart failure Monday at the Orlando (Fla.) Regional Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Orlando.

title: Wallace Computer Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Classic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $58,000.

title: NHD Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Enforcing S.R.O. Law
description: To the Editor:

title: General Parametrics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Prosecution Puts Limit on Evidence It Plans to Introduce Against North
description: The attorneys prosecuting Oliver L. North have pared back the scope of their conspiracy case against him, saying in documents made public today that they no longer contend that Mr. North used the profits from United States arms sales to Iran for any illegal purpose except a ''secret war'' in Central America.

title: MCI to Cut Rates
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, announced a 3.9 percent reduction in its basic interstate rates and a 4.1 percent reduction in its per-minute usage rates for the MCI Card, effective Jan. 1. MCI said its customers' long-distance bills would decrease by about $160 million. The new rates result from a decrease in the access charges MCI pays to local telephone companies.

title: Deere & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $69.3 million from tax credits and tax accounting rule changes. c-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
13 Hurt When Prisoners Riot in Puerto Ric
description: Hundreds of inmates rioted when a gang war broke out at a Puerto Rico penitentiary today, and prisoners took the warden hostage and set fire to a prison wing before surrendering.

title: 'Geraldo' Show to Move to Channel 2 Next Fall
description: In a move that it hopes will boost late-afternoon ratings, Channel 2 has purchased ''Geraldo,'' the often contentious talk show run by Geraldo Rivera, for showing in the 4 P.M. slot.

title: Review/Film; Choreographers Speak
description: Michael Blackwood's ''Retracing Steps'' doesn't have an official rating, but it ought to carry a warning. The new documentary, which opens today for a week's run at Film Forum 1 with ''Beehive,'' a giddily delightful short movie by Frank Moore and Jim Self, contains a good deal of verbiage that may make reasonably sophisticated viewers over 40 feel very old and cynical.

title: Alpine International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $445,000.

title: A Town Lightens Up
description: Residents taking part in a study aimed at reducing heart disease have lost more than 4,000 pounds and cut their cholesterol levels by nearly 5 percent in the program's first six months, researchers say.

title: Education; Lessons
description: Richard Nixon successfully ran for President in 1968 with a ''secret plan'' to end the war in Vietnam. George Bush did so this year with an almost equally vague pledge to be ''the education President.''

title: Working Ego to Ego, 6 Chefs Dish Up a Formal Dinner for 60
description: Never mind that the waters off Maine were too rough to harvest the sea urchins for the the second course, or that the air shipment of 35 ducks for the fifth course barely arrived in time: serious cooking was going on here. And when the chefs are the likes of Paul Bocuse, Gaston Lenotre, Pierre Troisgros, Michel Lorain, Michel Rostang and Jacques Maximin - well, what are a few slip-ups?

title: British to Resume Flights to Teheran
description: British Airways P.L.C. said it would restart flights to Teheran after the resumption of full diplomatic relations between Britain and Iran. A British Airways spokeswoman said the carrier would offer service twice a week via Cyprus. The airline stopped flights to Iran in 1985 after Iraqi air attacks on Teheran. Other major airlines also suspended flights because the Iranian authorities could not guarantee the safety of civilian airlines flying into Iranian airspace.

title: Right Way to Apply Capital Gains Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE REPLACE LEADER OF TIBET
description: China has dismissed the Communist Party leader in Tibet and tightened security to prevent monks from staging new anti-Chinese protests, Westerners in the autonomous region said today.

title: Computer May Help Boxing Judges
description: The international federation for amateur boxing is considering radical changes designed to eliminate subjectivity in scoring and reduce the number of knockouts and knockdowns.

title: Frazier Leads Penn To Upset of Villanova
description: Walt Frazier III scored 25 points and Jerry Simon and Scott Schewe made crucial free throws in the final minute as Penn upset Villanova, 71-70, tonight.

title: Trump Considers Spending $2 Million on Anti-Koch Drive
description: Donald J. Trump, builder and arch-antagonist of Mayor Koch, said yesterday that he is prepared to spend $2 million of his own money on anti-Koch television commercials in next year's mayoral race.

title: CML Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Manpower Head Quits A Year After Takeover
description: Blue Arrow P.L.C. announced yesterday that Mitchell S. Fromstein had resigned as president and chief executive of Manpower Inc., the Milwaukee-based temporary services company. The British employment services concern bought Manpower a year ago for $1.3 billion.

title: FEROCIOUS STORMS AND DROUGHT SEEN
description: A warming of the planet resulting from pollution of the atmosphere will make drought much more frequent and storms much fiercer, new data presented today at a conference on climate change indicate.

title: Doctors to Look at Hazards in Making Arms
description: Physicians from an international peace group said today that they were forming a commission to assess the public health hazards posed by the production of nuclear weapons.

title: Boeing Challenged by Its Backlog
description: By most measures, 1988 has been an excellent year for the Boeing Company. The giant aerospace concern has racked up record sales and has a huge backlog of orders. But in meeting the strong demand for its aircraft, Boeing faces several daunting challenges, including touchy labor negotiations, shrinking profit margins and the enormous difficulties of adding capacity on the world's largest production lines.

title: London Journal; If Not to the Manner Born, Then to the Money
description: With his mane of silver hair, his education at Oxford and Cambridge, his conservative views about privilege and duty and stewardship, Peregrine Worsthorne might be an elegant throwback to a bygone aristocratic era.

title: Winfield? Anyone Want Winfield?
description: The Dave Winfield intrigue grew today as the Yankees and the Chicago Cubs discussed a trade involving as many as half a dozen major players.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: December 7, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Article 678788 -- No Title
description: Relatives of the comatose wife of a former minister were awarded $16 million in damages from the husband on Monday after a woman testified that he and she had been longtime lovers.

title: Education; Colleges Debating Aid in Rhodes Competition
description: As hundreds of college seniors compete this week for Rhodes Scholarships, some of the nation's universities are examining whether they should help their students compete for the prizes.

title: The Pop Life
description: Salute to the Gershwins

title: Rangers Rebound in Final Period and Beat Canucks, 5-3
description: Tony Granato won a faceoff midway through the third period and fed Michel Petit, who scored to put Rangers ahead to stay tonight in a 5-3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Thornton F. Bradshaw Dies at 71; Led RCA Until Purchase by G.E.
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, a leader in American business who became the last chairman of RCA and made his mark in broadcasting by helping to restore NBC to first place among the three major television networks, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He suffered a stroke Monday. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Store Chain Names Chief
description: Directors of the American Stores Company today elected Jonathan L. Scott as chief executive of the nation's largest food and drug retailer, succeeding L. S. Skaggs Jr., who will remain as the chairman through 1992. The shift has been anticipated since September, when Mr. Skaggs, who is 65 years old, announced plans to narrow his operating duties at the 1,900-store company. There had been some speculation that John M. Lillie, the chairman of Lucky Stores Inc., was a candidate for the job.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Wrangler apparel to the Martin Agency, Richmond, with a budget in the ballpark of $10 million.

title: Rumors Outpace Changes Under New Yorker's Editor
description: It has been a strange initiation for Robert A. Gottlieb. Not long ago, for instance, he found himself fielding calls from reporters chasing yet another rumor that he had resigned as editor of The New Yorker. He couldn't understand its origin until a bit of detective work traced it to a friend who had been telling people (correctly) that Mr. Gottlieb had resigned from the board of the New York City Ballet. Somewhere along the gossip transmission line, The New Yorker was substituted for the ballet.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Digital Review, Boston, will change from a monthly to a weekly, effective Jan. 9.

title: U.S. Warns Doctors Against Agreements On Fixing of Prices
description: The Justice Department issued a stern warning to the nation's doctors today that they are under surveillance for evidence of price fixing and other violations of the antitrust laws. The department said grand jury investigations of possible antitrust violations by doctors were under way in three cities.

title: Carolyn Bean Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company did not release third quarter sales figures.

title: 93 Linked to Drug Rings Are Indicted, F.B.I. Says
description: A yearlong undercover operation involving hundreds of law officers and several state and Federal agencies has led to the indictment of 93 people associated with the two leading Colombian drug rings on charges of importing cocaine, marijuana and heroin into the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today.

title: Morgan Grenfell Cuts Market Operations
description: In a move that raised fears of further large-scale dismissals in the London securities industry, Morgan Grenfell closed most of its stock market and bond trading operations today and laid off 450 people.

title: Study Criticizes Closing of System To Safeguard New York
description: The Coast Guard's system for preventing ship collisions in New York Harbor has been shut down since last July, with little regard for the effect on safety, a Congressional study made public today said.

title: Education; Liberal Education's Place in Profit-Driven World
description: The focus of American economic activity has switched from creating useful products to creating profit-making deals, and American educators must help correct this situation through a greater emphasis on the liberal arts, the president of Vassar College told 200 educators and business leaders yesterday.

title: BYPRODUCTS OF THE BOMB: POLLUTION AND THE WEAPON FACTORIES
description: Environmental contamination problems described in the Energy Department report released yesterday. Feed Materials Production Center: Fernald, Ohio Two silos are filled with 390,000 cubic feet of radioactive wastes that emit deadly radon gas. The plant has also released more than 300,000 pounds of uranium oxide and has contaminated drinking water wells. The Hanford Reservation: Near Richland, Wash. Liquid radioactive and toxic wastes were dumped in trenches from the time the plant opened in 1944 until the early 1980's. The wastes have contaminated large underground reservoirs used for drinking water and irrigation. Idaho National Engineering Laboratory: Near Idaho Falls The plant, which reprocesses nuclear fuel and operates experimental reactors, has discharged radioactive and toxic wastes into unlined waste lagoons. From there the waste has leached into the Snake River Aquifer, a giant underground reservoir. The Kansas City Plant: Kansas City, Mo. The plant, which produces electronic components for weapons, has contaminated soil and sewer lines with PCB's by discharging the cancer-causing chemicals into pits. The plant also released 240 tons of toxic chemicals into the atmosphere. Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory: Livermore, Calif. One of the principal national weapon laboratories. The site has leached toxic contamination from other operations into the ground water. The contamination is expected to migrate to nearby residential communties dependent on ground water. Los Alamos National Laboratory: Los Alamos, N. M. Test firings of high explosives have contaminated the test area with uranium. Chemicals and radioactive particles have been found on the site. Mound Facility: Miamisburg, Ohio Waste pits at the site, which manufactures high explosives and plutonium components for satellites, are believed to be leaching toxic chemicals into soil. Officials are concerned about plutonium leaching into ground water. Nevada Test Site: Near Las Vegas The site is where nuclear weapons were tested above ground until 1961 and below ground since then. About 75 square miles of the site is thoroughly contaminated with radioactive materials from these tests, including plutonium, cesium and strontium. Pantex Facility: Amarillo, Tex. Thousands of gallons of toxic solvents from the plant, the final assembly point for nuclear warheads, were discharged into a giant unlined waste pit from 1954 to 1980. The chemicals are believed to be leaking into the Ogallala Aquifer, the primary drinking water source for Amarillo. Pinellas Plant: Largo, Fla. The plant produces mechanical components for weapons. Underground storage tanks containing chemical compounds are believed to be leaking. Portsmouth Uranium Enrichment Complex: Piketon, Ohio Roughly 36 pounds of cancer-causing and toxic hexavalent chromium used in the process of enriching uranium for reactor fuel, is being released to the atmosphere daily through the plant's cooling towers. Rocky Flats Plant: Near Golden, Colo. The plant, which processes plutonium for weapons, is leaking volatile, cancer-causing organic chemicals into underground water north of Denver. Soil around the site is contaminated with plutonium at elevated levels. Sandia National Laboratories: Albquerque, N.M., Livermore, Calif., and north of Las Vegas. Miles of desert near the Nevada site are contaminated with hazardous materials used at the laboratories since the early 1940's. Underground storage tanks have leaked. Open lagoons are receiving contaminated wastes and may be leaking. Savannah River Plant: Near Aiken, S.C. The plant, which produces radioactive tritium and plutonium for nuclear weapons, has released millions of curies of tritium gas into the atmosphere from accidents. A primary aquifer in the area has been contaminated with solvents. Y-12 Plant: Oak Ridge, Tenn. The plant fabricates weapon components. It has polluted streams with mercury. A pond at the plant containing arsenic, boron and sulfate is leaking into surface streams. Crops and livestock may be contaminated by poisonous releases into the atmosphere.

title: Nets' Lack of Offense Has Reed Concerned
description: The Nets keep telling themselves things cannot get any worse. But they are.

title: Bush's Selections for the United Nations, the C.I.A. and Top Economic Posts; William Hedgcock Webster, Director of Central Intelligence
description: In deciding to keep William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence, President-elect Bush has moved toward resuming the tradition that the post should not change hands with the election of a new President.

title: Peres Again Asks Party to Consider Likud Talks
description: One day after saying he was resigned to entering the opposition, Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, today called a meeting of the party's central committee to vote on reopening talks on forming a coalition with the Likud party.

title: William Griffith Dies; Ballet Teacher Was 60
description: William Dunbar Griffith, a noted ballet teacher, died on Nov. 12 at the Cleveland Clinic. He was 60 years old.

title: Israeli Detention Camp for Arabs Called Inhumane by Rights Group
description: An international legal group that monitors human rights asserted in a report today that the Israeli Army's Ketziot detention center for Palestinians was ''crowded and inhumane'' and a violation of the Fourth Geneva Convention.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Soviets Taking a New Look at the U.N.
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address to the General Assembly Wednesday will symbolize the transformation in Moscow's relations with the United Nations in the Gorbachev years.

title: Small Town Has Sequel To Its 'Trial of Century'
description: It was called ''the trial of the century'' here in Columbia County. A shy 17-year-old computer wizard, Wyley Gates, admitted to shooting his father, his father's girlfriend, his brother and a 3-year-old cousin. A jury then acquitted the youth of murder charges, citing shoddy police work and a coerced confession.

title: Military Chief See Dangers in Pentagon Cuts
description: President-elect Bush should not accept the conventional wisdom that ''political realities'' dictate Pentagon budget cuts, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Paul Schulman has been named executive vice president at Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Verdict Imperils Lilco's Financial Health
description: The Long Island Lighting Company's financial health has already been harmed by a jury's verdict that Lilco committed fraud in obtaining two rate increases, Lilco executives and Wall Street analysts said today.

title: Review/Opera; Marilyn Horne as Carmen
description: Marilyn Horne returned to the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night as Carmen and gave an often excellent performance marked by a peculiar duality of instinct. Even in uninspiring surroundings like those prevailing here, she never falls to the level of musical routine, but shapes her phrases with a rare elegance, purposefulness, care and true musicality. Without the collaboration of a good director, though, her dramatic instincts can lead her into overstatement and gaucherie.

title: Minister Guilty in Slaying
description: A Vicksburg minister charged with murdering his girlfriend just hours before preaching a sermon pleaded guilty Monday to the reduced charge of manslaughter. The plea bargain was reached the day before the minister, Rev. Jonathon Hamlin, was scheduled to be tried for shooting to death his 24-year-old girlfriend, Lula Sims, on July 3. He is to be sentenced Jan. 6.

title: Koch Proposes Charging Rent For Shelter Beds
description: Mayor Koch, noting that some of the sheltered homeless receive modest incomes, is proposing that the city charge those who can afford it for living in municipal shelters.

title: Argentine Uprising Tied to Economics
description: President Raul Alfonsin expressed sympathy today for some of the concerns of army officers who rebelled in recent days, and he partly blamed Argentina's economic crisis for the uprising.

title: An Idea in the Gloom
description: The Middle East does not have a very high priority on the agenda as Soviet and American leaders meet to advance their relations. That is partly because it is such an intractable issue, involving so many other nations, and partly because the improved international climate has reduced the risk that the Middle East will provoke a major war.

title: BHUTTO REVERSES PRESIDENTIAL MOVE
description: The Pakistani Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today announced unexpectedly that her party was fielding a retired general as its candidate for President, then withdrew his nomination hours later.

title: Will Donald Now Become A Big Wheel?
description: What do you call a bicycle race that meanders down the Hudson Valley, risks its life with the crackheads, cutthroats, red-light-jumpers, highwaymen and lunatics of New York City, then heads out to Pennsylvania, Virginia, Maryland and Delaware before finishing in the philanthropic heart of Atlantic City?

title: Papandreou's Old Woes and New Indiscretion
description: As the leaders of most of Western Europe gathered here over the weekend, attention was focused on the host, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, and his political troubles.

title: Boston Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Japanese Economy Surges at 9.3% Rate as Exports Rise
description: Japan's economy grew at an annual rate of 9.3 percent in the third quarter, the Government reported today. This expansion, following the second quarter's 3.3 percent growth rate, was bolstered by heavy spending by consumers and manufacturers and a surge in exports.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New York Ad Guide
description: ''N.Y. Gold,'' a 528-page hard-cover guide to New York advertising talent, includes listings ranging from illustrators and photo suppliers to costumers and commercial location scouts. The directory, issued for the second consecutive year, concentrates on visual services, hence the green eye adorning its otherwise black cover. Music houses, however, are also cited. Six thousand copies are available, for $49.95 each, at art supply shops and some bookstores, as well as through Watson-Guptill Publication Inc. in the United States and Rotovision S.A. worldwide.

title: Treasury Prices Post Sharp Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged their biggest one-day rally in more than three months yesterday on the heels of strong foreign buying, favorable technical factors and reports that Mikhail S. Gorbachev may propose a sharp reduction in Soviet military forces.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Athena Gold Corp., Reno, appointed Kenneth H. Wright president and a director. Michael Baybak, the chairman, had filled the post of president on an interim basis.

title: Review/Television; Special Offer: The Clio Candidates
description: Television commercials. They have given birth to a new form of movie, one that must be constructed as a series of mini-climaxes leading to a commercial break every 10 or 15 minutes. They have triggered a boom in muting and fast-forward devices. They send most of the nation every night to the bathroom or the refrigerator with alarming frequency. They make watching anything serious virtually impossible. And they are in trouble, as more and more viewers discover the joys of being entertained via video cassette.

title: Ex-Worker at Arms Site Is Held in Bribery
description: A former chemist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, the top-secret nuclear weapon research center near San Francisco, has been arrested in Arizona after disappearing from the laboratory and being indicted on bribery charges.

title: A Reward: A Car for a Car
description: A 70-year-old retired librarian whose car was firebombed last month, perhaps by drug dealers, got a replacement for it at a block party given for her by neighbors, the police, politicians and community leaders.

title: Nussbaum Admits Inaction in Sex Abuse
description: Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday that 2-year-old Lisa Steinberg showed clear signs of sexual abuse in 1983, but that she did nothing about it.

title: Retiree, Angered Over Greed, Gives to Neediest Cases Fund
description: A retiree who lives on a modest income on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Selma R. Rubin, says she could not enjoy what she has without thinking of those ''thousands of less fortunate than myself.''

title: Bankruptcy Filing By Rusty Jones
description: Rusty Jones Inc. has filed for protection from creditors in United States Bankruptcy Court here, saying that its car-rustproofing business had deteriorated as American automobile makers extended their warranties against rust. The filing Monday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code seeks time for the Chicago-based company to reorganize.

title: House Banking Panel Selects a Chairman
description: Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, was elected chairman of the House Banking Committee by a large margin today, succeeding the Rhode Island Democrat Fernand J. St Germain, who was not re-elected to Congress.

title: Ecology & Environment reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Japan Claims Supercomputer Lead
description: American and Japanese manufacturers have been vying for years to dominate the growing supercomputer industry, and they have traditionally relied on the speed of their machines to assert superiority. The lead has frequently seesawed in the arcane world of gigaflops and floating-point calculations.

title: S-K-I Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Rostenkowski Suggests Rise In Gasoline Tax to Cut Deficit
description: The House's top tax legislator said today that he had little doubt the Government would have to raise taxes to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Bush's Selections for the United Nations, the C.I.A. and Top Economic Posts; Carla Anderson Hills, Special Trade Representative
description: Carla Hills, designated today as the United States special trade representative, like many other selections of President-elect Bush, is a familiar face in the capital, a well-known Washington lawyer who held high posts in the Ford Administration.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Police Aren't So Blase Toward This Visitor
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's jet hadn't been on the ground at Kennedy International Airport for more than five minutes yesterday afternoon before the New York City Police Department had its first problem: several motorists, evidently fed up with having to wait behind roadblocks set up near the airport, had begun driving around them.

title: George D. Shaw, 57, Track and Field Star
description: George D. Shaw, the captain of the track and field team at Columbia University in 1953, whose school indoor long-jump and outdoor triple-jump records still stand, died Monday of a heart attack while jogging in Van Cortlandt Park, not far from his home in the Inwood section of Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Skateboarders Are Outlawed In 6-Block Business District
description: The Board of Alderman approved Monday an ordinance banning skateboarding in the six-block business district. The vote was 11 to 2.

title: August Howard, 78, Organizer Of a Society for Polar Explorers
description: August Howard, founder of the American Polar Society and the editor of a newsletter for polar explorers and researchers, died of heart disease Sunday. He was 78 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $113 million special provision for losses on divestitures. The company said it has sold or discontinued 19 health maintenance organizations in the first 9 months of this year.

title: Brazil and India Fight New Copyright Rules
description: Representatives of Brazil and India said today that a need to make advanced technology more widely available to combat hunger and disease was behind their reluctance to accept rules to protect patents, copyrights and other intellectual property.

title: The Polo Pasta Myth
description: To The Living Section:

title: A Pony Stops a Train on L.I.
description: The Long Island Rail Road's 5:05 A.M. train from Montauk to Jamaica was delayed two hours today when a pony took a canter on a railroad bridge near Amagansett and got a leg stuck in an opening on the track, the police said. While the train idled behind the pony, a veterinarian tranquilized the animal, and five people then lifted it and carried it from the bridge.

title: Israeli Arabs Linked to Blast
description: The police today arrested 13 Israeli Arabs, including two soldiers, who are suspected of belonging to a faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization and carrying out a hand grenade attack in the northern port of Haifa last summer that maimed an 8-year-old boy.

title: 3 More Killed in Soviet Ethnic Protest
description: Three people were killed and 44 wounded Monday in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, in rioting that followed the forcible early-morning disperal of a mass rally on a central square, the military commander of the city said today.

title: G.O.P. Mayoral Candidate Would Help New York
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: TELL me what you drink, mon vieux, and I'll tell you who you are. The French weekly Le Nouvel Observateur didn't put it in exactly those words, but it came out recently with a survey of wine drinking in France that offers some fascinating insights into wine drinking habits in the most famous of all the wine-consuming nations.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: AT this time of year, no matter how cranky and Scrooge-like we may feel, most of us entertain - at least a little. The cocktail party is often the easiest solution to the no-time syndrome, since it avoids the trials of a full-fledged dinner. Using a microwave oven can also help.

title: Horn & Hardart Co. reports earnings for 13wk to Sept 24
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $700,000 for the quarter and $2,031,000 for the 39 weeks. The latest periods included a restructuring charge of $18.3 million.

title: Qintex Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a $648,000 tax credit. c-Net loss The year-ago quarter included only the operations of Hal Roach Studios Inc., the predecessor of the company.

title: Healthwatch Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Gannett Plans Job Succession
description: John J. Curley, president and chief executive of the Gannett Company, will assume the additional title of chairman when Allen H. Neuharth retires from that post on March 31, the company said yesterday.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates declined for the first time in more than a month at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at a rate of 9.0267 percent, down from 9.112 percent last week. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.873 percent, down from 8.9735 percent the previous week. Citicorp said that at next week's auction it would take bids for the same amount on the 91-day and 182-day paper.

title: Continental Airlines Gets A New Chief
description: The Texas Air Corporation said today that it had named D. Joseph Corr, former president of Trans World Airlines, as chairman and chief executive of its Continental Airlines subsidiary.

title: Scapegoat's Self-Sacrifice
description: To The Living Section:

title: From the 'Underground,' $151 Million in Taxes
description: A two-year effort to ferret out New York City's ''underground economy'' and catch tax evaders has brought in $151 million in revenue, the Koch administration reported yesterday.

title: White Plains Adding More Office Space
description: YET another large office building, Ten Bank Street, is emerging among the concrete canyons of White Plains. Ten years of urban renewal, improved transportation and the movement of offices out of Manhattan have combined to produce a small boom in the city's commercial real estate market.

title: Home Cooking, When Home's On the Range
description: THE view from the dining room - four hay bales arranged in a semicircle on a patch of rangeland - extends 60 miles west, past mesas and buttes to Mount Taylor, one of the Navajos' sacred mountains. We are on the 200,000-acre Alamo Ranch, a working cattle ranch 35 miles from downtown Albuquerque. Out here, the quiet almost hurts your ears. The chuck wagon casts a shadow over a fire pit, where Ed Parsons and Gerald Schell check and stir pots on a grill. During the week, the two are coat-and-tie business executives in Albuquerque. On weekends and other spare days, they and their wives - Anne Parsons, a nurse, and Robbie Schell, an office manager - live a culinary fantasy.

title: Sanders Credited With 75 More Yards
description: A statistical revision yesterday gave Barry Sanders of Oklahoma State, the Heisman trophy winner, 75 more rushing yards in his record-setting effort against Texas Tech last Sunday in Tokyo, National Collegiate Athletic Association officials said. In Oklahoma State's 45-42 victory, Sanders was originally credited with 257 yards rushing on 42 carries, a performance that gave him 2,553 yards and broke Marcus Allen's season-rushing record of 2,342 yards set at Southern Cal in 1981. But a review of the game videotape yesterday revealed that two running plays were actually laterals and were incorrectly credited as pass receptions by Sanders. The revision gives Sanders 332 yards rushing on 44 carries, the junior tailback's fourth 300-yard-plus game of the season. His rushing record is now 2,628 yards.(AP)

title: Warning on Youths' Drinking
description: Consumption of alcohol remains widespread among young people, who ''continue to drink and drive with alarming frequency,'' the National Commission Against Drunk Driving, a private organization, said today. The commission, in a report on teen-age drinking, called on parents to do more to keep alcohol from children. But it also concluded that advertising policies contribute to the drinking problem among youths and that legislation to regulate advertising may be needed if the alcoholic beverage industry does not act.

title: Sent Away, A Man Dies On the Street
description: To the night security guard at the Carl's Jr. fast-food restaurant in the heart of the Tenderloin District, the man was apparently one of many people who come in reeking of alcohol, pass out and are taken outside to sober up. For the most part, people walk right past them or, when necessary, step over them.

title: F.D.I.C. Urged as Sole Bank Insurer
description: A lobbying group for the savings and loan industry proposed yesterday that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation be the only insurance agency for both banks and savings institutions.

title: TV Cameras Capture a Trial That Enthralls the Viewers
description: One year after the New York State Legislature began an 18-month experiment allowing television cameras in the courtroom, a trial has found a place in New York City living rooms.

title: Dow Climbs 25.60, to 2,149.36, in Late Rally
description: Stock prices climbed strongly yesterday in a late rally spurred by a steep rise in bond prices.

title: 3 Die in Azerbaijan Rioting
description: Three people died and 44 were wounded in Baku, Azerbaijan's capital, as ethnic unrest continued in the southern Soviet Union. Page A3.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Kennedy Is Beaten
description: The power of a political dynasty is apparently no match for the institutional power of the House of Representatives, as Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the Massachusetts Democrat, learned yesterday when he lost his bid for a seat on the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Bridge
description: Brisbane, Australia, is more than 8,000 miles from New York City, but for two bridge players that seems to be a short distance to commute. During the Labor Day weekend, at the Bicentennial Tournament in Brisbane, a local player, Margaret Millar, and Phillip Alder of Manhattan formed a first-time partnership in the open pairs championship. They placed second, behind the star Australian partnership of Jim and Norma Borin but ahead of many world and national champions from several parts of the world.

title: Standard Brands Paint Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $454,000. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $255,000 and $840,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Childbirth Technology Is Not Natural; Joy of Maternal Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Inco 'Poison Pill' Tested in Canada
description: ''POISON PILLS'' were invented in the United States, a fact that may or may not make Americans proud. Now shareholders, and judges, will decide whether the anti-takeover device is fit for export to Canada.

title: Bangladesh Needs Commitment, Not Better Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Reverses $1.6 Million Award in AIDS Case
description: A Federal district judge has reversed a jury award of $1.6 million to a man who said he contracted AIDS from a hemophilia drug, saying the jurors may have relied more on their emotions than the facts.

title: How to Defuse The Buyout Bomb
description: THE battle for RJR Nabisco's $25 billion snack and tobacco empire is over, but the political struggle to deter other leveraged buyouts that leave corporations buried under mountains of debt is just beginning. Spurred on by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, a Congressional Who's Who including Lloyd Bensten, Bob Dole and Dan Rostenkowski is casting about for a tax-based fix.

title: WIDE THREAT SEEN IN CONTAMINATION AT NUCLEAR UNITS
description: Pollution from nuclear weapon plants in Ohio and Texas and from two national laboratories in Northern California pose serious threats to public health, according to a report released today by the Department of Energy.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; U.S. Is Faulted in Denying Benefits to Lung-Diseased Miners
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Federal Government had improperly denied benefits to tens of thousands of coal miners who developed symptoms of black lung disease in the 1970's.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Fashion page in some copies yesterday with an article about an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art misidentified the woman standing at the left in the center photograph. She was Nancy Brinker.

title: Drexel Aide Said to Reach Agreement
description: A principal defendant in civil proceedings against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has reached an agreement to cooperate with the Government in exchange for leniency, a lawyer in the case said last night.

title: Peru Envoy Slain in Bolivia
description: The naval attache at the Peruvian Embassy was shot dead in La Paz today, the police said. Witnesses said the attache, Juan Vega LLona, was shot at point-blank range by a woman as he walked along a central city street. A note left on the body said the killing was carried out by the Workers Revolutionary Movement, a previously unknown group, the police said.

title: Education; A School For Arts Matures In Miami
description: ''In just one year our school grew from infancy to adolescence,'' said Daniel Lewis, who is a dancer, choreographer and teacher at the New World School of the Arts here. ''It was a rough experience, but we did acquire a sense of purpose and confidence in our skills to train young people for professional careers in the arts.''

title: Upshaw to Japan
description: Willie Upshaw, the Cleveland Indians' starting first baseman last season and a regular with Toronto for six years before that, agreed to a two-year contract with the Daiei Hawks of the Japanese League yesterday. Upshaw, 31 years old, batted .245 with 11 home runs and 50 runs batted in for Cleveland. His contract with Daiei is worth about $2.5 million.(AP)

title: Bush's Selections for the United Nations, the C.I.A. and Top Economic Posts; Michael Jay Boskin, Chairman, Council of Economic Advisers
description: Michael Jay Boskin, a widely respected, quite eclectic conservative scholar at Stanford, has written gently but critically of the Reagan Administration's economic policies.

title: Hadco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included $554,000 from the recovery of an account receivable previously written off.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; And in London, an Abbey Visit?
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may go to Westminster Abbey next Tuesday during his visit to London to place a wreath on the tomb of the Unknown Warrior, next to the memorial plaque for Sir Winston Churchill, according to British officials planning the Soviet leader's program.

title: Storehouse Stake By Edelman Group
description: Investors believed to be associates of the New York businessman Asher B. Edelman hold 20 million shares, or slightly less than 5 percent, of Storehouse P.L.C., its financial advisers said. Storehouse, which owns the Conran's home-furnishing stores in the United States, said that Smith New Court, Carl Marks Inc. in New York had confirmed the purchase of 20 million shares for several companies and individuals believed to be associated with Mr. Edelman.

title: A Warning From Argentina
description: Without civilian support, military revolts generally end the way Argentina's did this week, with the isolated rebels bowing to constitutional authority. Argentina has now withstood three such half-baked uprisings in less than two years.

title: FGIC Acquisition Plan Is Set by G.E. Capital
description: The FGIC Corporation, an insurer of municipal bonds, said yesterday that the General Electric Capital Corporation had agreed to buy an additional 28 percent of the company for $22.50 a share and had proposed to pay its remaining shareholders the same price to take over the rest of the company.

title: Swiss Envoy in Beirut Urges His Compatriots to Go Home
description: Ambassador Dino Sciolli of Switzerland today urged the estimated 200 Swiss nationals in Lebanon to leave the country because of the Nov. 17 abduction of a Swiss Red Cross worker.

title: Xylogics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $715,000.

title: Alexander's Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 22
description: b-Net loss The previously reported contract for the sale of the company's lease rights and closing of its Milford, Conn. store was consummated on Aug. 1, 1988. The company has recorded the approximately $17 million pre-tax gain from this transaction in the latest quarter, when the transaction closed. Sales represent net sales, which included leased departments.

title: U.S. Commander Killed in Spain
description: The commander of United States Air Force operations in the Mediterranean was killed Monday when the F-16 jet fighter he was flying crashed during a training mission, the Air Force said today.

title: Award to Stephens
description: John Stephens, the standout running back of the New England Patriots, was awarded the first Gale Sayers Humanitarian Citation yesterday. Stephens was the choice of a committee headed by Sayers, the Hall of Fame running back who starred for the Chicago Bears. The award is given to the National Football League rookie demonstrating the most outstanding commitment of time and effort toward a personally designated charitable organization, which in Stephens's case is the Roxbury (Mass.) Comprehensive Community Health Center.(AP)

title: 8 Turkish Soldiers Killed
description: Suspected Kurdish guerrillas killed an army lieutenant, two noncommissioned officers and five soldiers in a daylong battle in southeast Siirt Province, the Anatolia News Agency reported today. It was not immediately clear if any guerrillas were slain in the clash that started Monday morning.

title: Goodyear's President Chosen as Next Chief
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company yesterday elected Tom H. Barrett to succeed Robert E. Mercer as chief executive. Mr. Barrett, who is 58 years old, has worked at the Akron, Ohio, company for 35 years, serving as president since 1982.

title: Livermore Lab Computers Target of Intruder
description: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories said yesterday that five computers at the research center had been the target of an intruder who used a nationwide computer research network to illegally enter the machines and tamper with files.

title: Panel Is Said to Find Flaw in Fusion Research
description: A secret Government panel has concluded that the energy needed to achieve small-scale nuclear fusion is much greater than most scientists in the field believe, according to a letter from a dissident physicist to the president of the University of California.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Academy Is Born
description: A number of the nation's leading experts on Social Security have created a national academy to promote education and research on social insurance, a subject they consider widely misunderstood. The 122 founding members of the National Academy of Social Insurance include former Cabinet Secretaries for health, former Commissioners of Social Security and economists, historians, lawyers, political scientists, public administrators, actuaries, social workers and sociologists.

title: Challenge to Robins Plan
description: A lawyer for Dalkon Shield claimants said today that the process by which the A. H. Robins Company's bankruptcy plan was approved effectively disenfranchised women with the largest injury claims.

title: Editor Quits At American Banker
description: William E. Zimmerman, the editor of American Banker, resigned yesterday after 26 years with the newspaper to concentrate on a book publishing business that so far has produced three titles, all his own.

title: Hershiser Honored
description: Orel Hershiser, the ace pitcher of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was named Major League Player of the Year yesterday by The Sporting News. Hershiser won the National League Cy Young Award with a 23-8 record, 2.26 earned run average and a record 59-inning consecutive scoreless streak. He was also the World Series m.v.p.(AP)

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Manhattan Goes Gorbachev, From Fish to Oreo Cookies
description: In the front window of the Citarella Fish store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Fernando Lara was positioning seafood on a sheet of ice so that it looked like an American flag and a Soviet flag.

title: Council Calls for End to Free-Needles Plan
description: The New York City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve a nonbinding resolution calling on the Koch administration to abandon its pilot needle-exchange program intended to reduce the spread of AIDS.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Protect the $12 Trillion
description: What, according to Congressional estimates, will the 1989 budget deficit be:

title: Joyful Black Sheep
description: To The Living Section:

title: Judge Rejects Accord on a Hospital's Taxes
description: A New York State judge, criticizing the State Tax Department, has refused to allow a hospital in Harlem to settle a $16.2 million overdue tax bill by paying $250,000.

title: Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $800 million special provision for losses on lesser developed country lending. Year-earlier figures are restated to reflect accounting changes. The Royal Bank of Canada's results included the consolidation of RBC Dominion Securities, which was acquired in March. The bank added $360 million to its general provision for possible losses on loans to a designated group of 38 countries. The reserve stands at $2.3 billion, or 45 percent of the bank's total related exposure, which is the maximum allowed. Specific provisions of $390 million were also made for potential credit losses related to corporate and consumer lending. This is a decrease of $510 million from 1987. The results are in Canadian funds. The bank is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Bangladesh Needs Commitment, Not Better Image; No Poets' Haven Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Artworks From the Forbidden City
description: An exhibition of 76 ancient and modern Chinese masterworks from the Palace Museum of the Forbidden City in Beijing is to tour five museums for 10 months next year to celebrate the 10th anniversary of resumed relations between China and the United States. Only five of the paintings have ever been outside China and none have been seen before in this country.

title: Company Briefs
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. may raise its dividend next year for the first time since the Bell breakup in 1984, analysts said.

title: Charles Saxon, 68, a Cartoonist For 92 Covers of The New Yorker
description: Charles Saxon, a cartoonist whose elegant drawings deftly deflated the pomposities of the corporate board room and the suburban country club, died of heart failure yesterday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford, Conn. He was 68 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Abul Abbas's Other Remarks
description: LEAD: If any one factor led Secretary of State George P. Shultz to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, we have learned from subsequent news reports, it was Mr. Shultz's outrage over remarks made by Abul Abbas at the recent session of the Palestine National Council in Algiers. Mr. Abbas, a member of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, during which an elderly American tourist, Leon

title: Thousands March on Belgrade Parliament
description: Thousands of workers marched on Parliament today in heavy rain to protest plummeting living standards as a new wave of labor unrest swept the country.

title: Northern Telecom Plan
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., a supplier of digital telecommunications systems, said yesterday that it planned to establish a $200 million provision in the fourth quarter to cover a restructuring that will include closing some plants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an auction of antiquities at Sotheby's misstated the age of a Roman marble head that sold for $132,000. It was dated between A.D. 253 and A.D. 268.

title: Detroit Papers Tell of Layoffs
description: In apparently the first response to the new Federal law on factory closings, the two major Detroit newspapers said today that they had notified their employees on Monday that some would lose their jobs. An executive of The Detroit

title: GREECE DISREGARDS A DEAL WITH ITALY
description: The Greek Government today broke an agreement with Italy to extradite a Palestinian sought in connection with an attack on a synagogue in Rome in 1982. The Government instead deported the Palestinian to ''a country of his choice,'' reportedly Libya.

title: Rangers Obtain Franco From Indians in Four-Player Trade
description: Faced with a downward spiral instead of the expected upward trend, the Texas Rangers continued infusing themselves with hitting today, acquiring Julio Franco from the Cleveland Indians.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Today's Schedule
description: 10 A.M.: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives at the United Nations to meet with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Dante Caputo, President of the General Assembly. 11 A.M.: Mr. Gorbachev addresses the General Assembly. 1 P.M.: Luncheon on Governors Island in New York Harbor for Mr. Gorbachev, President Reagan and President-elect Bush. 1:15 P.M.: Mr. Perez de Cuellar's wife, Marcela, is hostess of a luncheon at her Sutton Place townhouse near the United Nations for about two dozen women, including Raisa Gorbachev, Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush. 2:45 P.M.: Mrs. Gorbachev visits the Estee Lauder cosmetics house on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street. About 4 P.M.: The Gorbachevs visit the World Trade Center, tour the financial district, Broadway and the Times Square area by car, then return to the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street. 6:30 P.M.: Reception in the North Lounge of the United Nations. TV COVERAGE ABC, NBC, CBS and Cable News Network plan to carry Mr. Gorbachev's United Nations address live, then continue with live coverage of arrivals and departures from the luncheon on Governors Island. The Gorbachev speech will also be carried live by many public-television stations, including Channel 13 in New York; it will be rebroadcast at 8 P.M. by C-SPAN, the Cable and Satellite Public Affairs Network. Reports on the day's events will be carried on the ABC News program ''Nightline'' and on a special CBS News program, both at 11:30 P.M.

title: Mr. Bush's Practical Choices
description: President-elect Bush continues to put together a team of moderate Republicans who can work in harmony with a Democratic Congress. His choices so far, including the appointments announced yesterday, suggest a healthy preference for non-ideological, practical people.

title: Gold Medal to Frank
description: Clint Frank, who won the Heisman Trophy in 1937 as a standout halfback at Yale and was elected to the College Football Hall of Fame in 1955, received the National Football Foundation's Gold Medal, the organization's highest award, last night at a dinner in Manhattan. Tonight, the Football Writers Association of America will present the Outland Trophy to the nation's top lineman. The three finalists are Tony Mandarich of Michigan State, an offensive tackle, Mark Stepnoski of Pitt, an offensive guard, and Tracy Rocker of Auburn, a defensive tackle.(AP)

title: Islanders Grow Careless and Lose 8th in Row
description: The losing streak that has engulfed them for the last seven games retreated for two periods and then, like a bad memory, overtook them again.

title: Scribner Book Store, 75, Will Close Next Month
description: The handsome Scribner Book Store on Fifth Avenue - a symbol of literary continuity since 1913 and part of the only landmark building in New York City originally designed to house a bookstore -will close on Jan. 22.

title: African Development Bank In $200 Million Debt Offering
description: The African Development Bank is offering a total of $200 million in subordinated debt through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. According to underwriters, it is the first time the African Development Bank or any development bank has issued subordinated debt.

title: Cray Nears Goal
description: Cray Research Inc. said it had received orders for 50 supercomputers through Nov. 30 and was confident that it would meet or exceed its goal of 55 orders for the year, John F. Carlson, its chief financial officer, said at a technology conference here. He added that the Minneapolis-based company had installed 36 machines in the first nine months of the year and another 11 in October and November.

title: Childbirth Technology Is Not Natural
description: To the Editor:

title: Education; About Education
description: Revolutions can succeed only if there is enough dissatisfaction with things as they are and if there is a banner around which to rally. A growing number of education experts say both of these prerequisites are in place for a revolution in testing in America.

title: Much Ado Over a Plagiarist
description: LEAD: How about that audacious nabbing and collaring the other day, in the pages of The New York Times, of Dr. Shervert H. Frazier by the redoubtable plagiarism police of the Harvard Medical School. Actually, not merely in the pages of The Times but in fact beginning right there on the front page - the ever-august page 1 -flanked by accounts of civil unrest in the Soviet Union (''Tension Called High in Armenia, With 1,400 Arrests''), the apparently imminent collapse of several Latin American economies (''Latins Want Bush to Help on Debt''), and various solemn narratives of OP

title: Transcript of Bush's Remarks at News Conference in Capital
description: Following is a transcript of portions of President-elect Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable Network News and ABC Radio News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Brazil Women Find Fertility May Cost Jobs
description: A young woman received an unusual proposal the other day: a company offered her a job in their mail department if she could show a doctor's certificate stating that she had been sterilized. Apparently she was not alone.

title: Shearson Fined $25,000 On Reported Stock Scheme
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. was disciplined yesterday by the self-regulatory body that oversees the over-the-counter market. The Wall Street firm was accused of failing to detect a stock manipulation scheme undertaken by three of its employees.

title: Reputed Members of Drug Gang Are Indicted
description: The reputed boss and five other reported members of the Vigilantes, a gang that controlled crack street sales in parts of Harlem for 14 years, were indicted on Federal racketeering charges yesterday.

title: SHUTTLE LANDING ENDS 4-DAY MISSION
description: After completing a secret four-day mission, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this afternoon.

title: Island Bastion With a History
description: Governors Island, where the Soviet and American leaders will meet today, is a secluded military preserve of 173 acres in New York Harbor just below the southern tip of Manhattan. But it has little in common with the borough besides a history that goes back to the Indians, to whom it was Pagganck. The Dutch, who bought it in 1637, knew it as Nooten Eylandt (Nutten Island).

title: Group Pays $70 Million For Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles were sold today by the family of Edward Bennett Williams for $70 million to a group headed by Eli S. Jacobs, a Wall Street investor.

title: Vehicles That Brave the Urban Wilds
description: THE four-wheel-drive utility vehicle has come into its own. What started out as a Spartan bush-buggy has quickly turned into an urban land ark for the affluent, suitable for fording a city's construction ditches while carrying passengers, groceries and the family hound.

title: Big Investors Voice Concern On 'Unbundled Stock Units'
description: Institutional investors and Wall Street analysts expressed concern yesterday that the tax ramifications of a new type of corporate reorganization could lead to increased scrutiny by Congress of the laws involving such transactions.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE term Florentine in French cooking refers to dishes that combine spinach and a cheese sauce, most often a Mornay sauce. Curiously, it has little relation to the Italian equivalent, alla fiorentina, which refers to recipes typical of the region of Florence, few of which include spinach.

title: Rockwell Sale To BTR Unit
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that BTR Dunlop Inc., a unit of a British company, had agreed to pay $437.5 million for its measurement and flow-control division, winning a bidding contest that began in September.

title: Automedix Sciences Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said it has not yet realized any revenues for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30 because it is in a development stage.

title: Helping Shoppers Buy on Principle
description: IN an age of high-fiber and macrobiotic diets, shopping for groceries has become a ritual of the healthy style of life. If the publishers of a new consumer guide are successful, a visit to the supermarket will soon be good for the soul as well as the body.

title: Sun Oil Now in Bottles
description: The Sun Refining and Marketing Company is bowing to consumer desires and ending sale of motor oil in one-quart cans. Sunoco brand oil in quart sizes will now be available only in resealable plastic bottles.

title: Bush's Selections for the United Nations, the C.I.A. and Top Economic Posts; Robert Adam Mosbacher Sr., Commerce Secretary
description: Despite the drop in oil prices, which has flung hundreds of Texas wildcatters toward financial ruin, Robert A. Mosbacher Sr. is still considered by his colleagues to be one of the wealthier, smarter and more sophisticated members of the group. His fortune, estimated by associates at more than $200 million, remains largely intact.

title: Book Notes
description: Bombeck Next Books

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Invitation to Gorbachev
description: That full-page, Russian-language ad in The New York Times today, on page B11, invites the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to visit the Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, Schmetterer advertising agency. The ad was prompted by a suggestion in The Washington Post on Monday that Mr. Gorbachev visit the shop to get a feel for the real New York. In the ad's third to last paragraph, the agency notes that the Soviet leader was the star of a commercial it did this fall for Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign, entitling him to residuals. ''So drop by,'' reads the ad. ''The vodka's on ice. The caviar's ready. And the check's been drawn.''

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Lands in California After a Four-Day Mission With a quick drop from the north, two sonic booms and an unusual landing pattern, Atlantis touched down safely at Edwards Air Force Base.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; On Speeches and Fees
description: In a brief conversation with reporters, Nancy Reagan was discussing her plans upon departing the White House on Jan. 20. Among other projects, she said, she planned to do some public speaking.

title: Review/Philharmonic; Mendelssohn and Tchaikovsky Play the Apollo
description: The New York Philharmonic has been playing an annual concert in Harlem since 1980, when it paid its first visit to the Abyssinian Baptist Church. Last year, the orchestra moved its Harlem concerts to the Apollo Theater, and on Monday night Zubin Mehta and his players returned to that famous hall to perform music of Schubert, Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky, Puccini and Bizet.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; GORBACHEV BEGINS U.S. VISIT; URGES 'GREATER DYNAMISM' IN RELATIONS WITH AMERICA
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in New York yesterday on a visit intended to showcase a more benign Soviet foreign policy and set an agenda for dealings with the Bush administration.

title: When the Package Is Part of the Pleasure
description: IF you know a person's passion - that nothing is more seductive than the perfect teaspoon of caviar or the richest chocolate truffle - then it is easy to choose a food gift. Sometimes, however, you are stumped. The object of your beneficence already has the requisite mustards, and you do not want to buy something perishable that will have to be consumed in the midst of this season of satiety.

title: The Seven Who Dreamed
description: When I was a lad, my classmates were Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts and Company, not to mention Nabisco and RJR. I mention only their last names because that's how you've heard of them since they got involved in the famous leveraged buyout.

title: Kelly, a Deal Maker, Forms An Alliance With Salomon
description: Donald P. Kelly, the deal maker who helped engineer the $8.2 billion leveraged buyout of the Beatrice Companies in 1986, today announced a formal alliance between his investment firm, D. P. Kelly & Associates L.P. and Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, some streets in New York City will be closed intermittently this week as the motorcade passes. Following are the areas likely to be most affected. Today 8 A.M.-9 P.M.: 67th Street to Battery Park from Hudson to East Rivers. Tomorrow All day: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules are suspended. Other regulations remain in effect. 9 A.M.-5 P.M.: 86th to 23d Streets, from Hudson to East Rivers. Friday 8 A.M.-10 A.M.: 57th to 125th Streets from Fifth Avenue to East River in Manhattan; Grand Central Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway in Queens.

title: Texscan Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The impact of interest expense, which increased more than 25 times over a year earlier and reflected the third full quarter of expenses on the debt which Texscan Corp. incurred as part of its restructuring during its reorganization, was the primary factor which held net income down.
