Interest expense for the latest quarter was $483,000, compared with $19,000 a year ago and for the 6 months interest expense totaled $978,000 versus $39,000 a year earlier.

title: Unabated Rise in AIDS Seen for New York
description: New York State health officials have extended their AIDS projections to show an unabated increase in cases and deaths for the next five years that would require a huge expansion in services costing billions of dollars.

title: Chicago's Restaurant of the Starsa Is 50
description: LEAD: WALLY BABYCH, who retired as maitre d'hotel of the Pump Room here, donned a black dinner jacket and smiled broadly as he sipped Champagne in the same room where he had served it to Marilyn Monroe, John Wayne, Lana Turner and Clark Gable. The Pump Room, Chicago's most famous restaurant and celebrity haunt, was celebrating its 50th anniversary.

title: Career Concluded
description: Barry's brother, Byron Sanders, also a running back, will not return to the Northwestern football team next fall, making him eligible for the 1989 National Football League draft in April. Sanders, a senior who could have played college football for one more year, rushed for 1,062 yards in the 1988 season to become the third Wildcat in history to run for more than 1,000 yards in a season. He concluded his two-year Wildcat career with 1,840 rushing yards, placing him fourth on Northwestern's career list.(AP)

title: Books of The Times; Earthly Views of Life After Death
description: Heaven: A History By Colleen McDannell and Bernhard Lang 410 pages. Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: New Marketing Director Named by Burger King
description: Seeking to reverse a slide in its market share and to calm angry franchisees, the Burger King Corporation named a new marketing director yesterday.

title: Treating Waste 5,000 Feet Down
description: If a wet waste material, like sewage sludge, is mixed with oxygen and placed under high pressure, it undergoes a process that chemists call wet oxidation. The sludge, whose disposal is becoming a burden to more and more municipal sewage plants, is converted to relatively clean water and sterile ash.

title: Review/Music; Tunes Toying With Cliches
description: There were a lot of contradictions on stage during the show of Alva Rogers, the singer and performance artist, at the Knitting Factory on Friday night. Irony and straightforwardness, humor and seriousness, cliches and new ideas all clashed, setting off sparks of meaning.

title: Psicor reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is a Sunday evening and Sheryn Goldenhersh is walking up Broadway in search of a 24-hour cash machine. On 71st Street she spots an ATM/NYCE sign in a bank window. Approaching the entrance, Ms. Goldenhersh sees a woman inside. Her face is pressed to the glass and she is knocking frantically on the pane in an attempt to get someone's attention.

title: Into a Foreign Country, Gang Territory
description: The sheriff's deputies were filling me in about the gangs. We were riding around in their car in the dark of night through the heart of L.A.'s gang turf, just southeast of Los Angeles International Airport. I'd left home just a half-hour before and here I was in an unmarked patrol car in a different country.

title: USX Stock Jumps on F.T.C. Action
description: The stock of the USX Corporation rose today after it was announced that the New York financier Carl C. Icahn had received Federal clearance to increase his 11.4 percent stake in the steel and oil giant.

title: Kabul Hauls Its Marxism Up to the Attic
description: The assistant dean at Kabul University was embarrassed. He wished the visitor hadn't noticed the file cabinet in the corner of his office.

title: Bush's Selections for the United Nations, the C.I.A. and Top Economic Posts; Thomas Reeve Pickering, U.S. Representative to the United Nations
description: Thomas R. Pickering, President-elect Bush's choice to become the next United States representative to the United Nations, has served as a troubleshooter in a series of sensitive diplomatic posts.

title: Defense Calls 5 In Myerson Case Before Resting
description: Defense lawyers in the Bess Myerson trial presented five witnesses and some financial records yesterday, then rested their case without calling any of the defendants to testify.

title: Genesee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviet Musicians Join Western Label
description: BMG Classics, a division of the Bertlesmann Music Group of Munich, West Germany, which has owned the RCA record label since 1986, announced recording agreements yesterday with a group of Soviet performers - the first signed directly to a Western record label in recent years. In the past, recordings of Soviet artists for Melodiya, the Government-owned Soviet recording company, were licensed for release in the West, but BMG is to record the performers under its own auspices, in the Soviet Union and in the West.

title: Federal Court Rejects Law on Guard Training
description: A United States appellate court ruled today that a Federal law stripping governors of control over training missions by their states' National Guard is unconstitutional. The challenge to the law was the second this year.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Not Used to Being Upstaged, White House Strikes Back
description: Worried that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will seize the public relations initiative during his stay in New York, the White House opened a quiet counteroffensive today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: ARAFAT IN SWEDEN MEETS 5 U.S. JEWS
description: Yasir Arafat flew to Sweden today and met with five American Jews to discuss the prospects for peace in the Middle East.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketing By Hospital Is a Success
description: ALTHOUGH Americans spent almost $195 billion on hospital care last year, 9 percent more than in 1986, hospitals are finding themselves increasingly in the red. But Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia finished this fiscal year in the pink, thanks in part to a strong dose of marketing savvy administered by Robert B. Kimmel.

title: Netair International Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Small Rise in Copper Prices Belies Worldwide Shortage
description: Copper prices continued to inch up yesterday, but market analysts said the small gains on the Commodity Exchange in New York masked a critical global shortage of the metal for immediate delivery. The spot December Comex copper delivery closed up 0.45 cent a pound, at $1.5125.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * We Care About New York, a nonprofit group against litter and graffiti in New York, introduces 30- and 60-second TV spots, ''Rats,'' by Della Femina, McNamee WCRS; David Lynch (''Blue Velvet'')was the director.

title: Great Western's Name On Los Angeles Forum
description: The Great Western Bank, the nation's third-largest savings institution, has signed a deal that will put its name and even its colors on the Forum, the home of the Los Angeles Lakers and the Los Angeles Kings. That type of advertising arrangement is becoming more prevalent among corporate sports sponsors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Revenue Rises For Radio Ads
description: Radio advertising revenue for 1988 increased 7.4 percent, to $7.83 billion, over last year, according to an analysis by the Radio Advertising Bureau.

title: New York State Certificates
description: New York State, through the Commissioner of General Services of the executive department, is tentatively offering $90 million of certificates of participation through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: FILLS 4 MORE POSTS; Mosbacher, Hills and Boskin Join President-Elect's Economic Team
description: President-elect Bush announced today that William H. Webster would remain as Director of Central Intelligence, saying that the need for ''continuity'' was crucial in successfully carrying out the mission of the nation's intelligence agencies.

title: A Worthy Wine That Gets No Respect
description: The birds and the bees devoured a fifth of Robert Pecota's muscat crop in the Napa Valley of California this fall. That means fewer cases of his Muscato di Andrea will be made. His 14-year-old daughter Andrea, for whom it was named, always asks, ''How's my wine, Dad?'' And he always says, ''Fine.'' Unlike most muscat wines, it always sells like hot cakes.

title: About New York; Loving Hearts Help Disabled Watch the Strong
description: Tess Hyman - an 84-year-old woman who barely knows what a touchdown is despite attending hundreds of football games - stood at a gate to Giants Stadium last Sunday squinting into an icy wind. An unlikely setting for a love story.

title: The Culinary Mystery of Nesselrode Pie
description: ''NESSELRODE? I know it exists in classical cooking,'' said Andre Soltner, chef and owner of Lutece, one of New York's oldest and most famous French restaurants. ''I think there is a game dish a la Nesselrode.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Slim Spread From France

title: The Composer Who Energizes the Erick Hawkins Dancers
description: Erick Hawkins is tall, lean and austere. A man who has adhered to his own uncompromising choreographic style for more than 50 years, he is given to extremes of poeticism and practicality, but seldom takes the middle ground. Lucia Dlugoszewski is small, round and breathlessly voluble, given equally to laughter and tears as she talks of Mr. Hawkins's work and of her own music, which has gained her distinction as a highly original avant-garde composer.

title: Gooden's Reward
description: Dwight Gooden, whose probation stemming from a fight two years ago with the police in Tampa, Fla., was terminated last month, has cleared another legal hurdle that from a practical standpoint means little. Florida law permits judges to wipe the slate clean for defendants with no prior criminal record, and Circuit Judge John P. Griffin did just that, ordering the police to return booking photographs and fingerprints as well as seal any record of arrest on charges stemming from the melee, to which the Mets' pitcher pleaded no contest. Gooden was placed on three years' probation and had completed almost two years of the term when Griffin granted early termination last month. According to Gooden's attorney, Ronald Cacciatore, the sealed record ''doesn't accomplish the same thing that it would for someone who nobody knew was charged with a crime.''(AP)

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Policy; Behind Scenes, Plot and Counterplot
description: As recounted by Constantine Menges, the character assassination and duplicity practiced by senior foreign policy officials of the Reagan Administration over the last eight years was enough to make a Borgia blush.

title: C. P. Buckley, Lawyer And Bank Official, 86
description: Charles P. Buckley Jr., a lawyer who was active in Long Island affairs, died Monday at his home in Baldwin, L.I., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Times Buys a Golf Magazine
description: The New York Times Company yesterday announced the acquisition of Golf World, which will be the company's fifth golfing magazine.

title: At Least 13 Injured as Inmates Riot in Puerto Rico
description: Some 400 rioting inmates seized control of a maximum-security prison 50 miles south of San Juan on Tuesday, took the warden hostage and then surrendered after seven hours.

title: Bridge
description: The youngest player to win a regional title in eight years, and the second-youngest of all time, is Shawn Samuel of Locust Valley, L.I., 12 years old. On Oct. 23, he won the Flight B Knockout Teams title in Stamford, Conn., playing with his father, Dr. Russell Samuel, and Alice and Jack Lahoud of Newport, R.I. He repeated the feat two weeks later in Cromwell, Conn., again paired with his father but with different teammates, Jeff and Linda Rothstein of Manhattan.

title: First-Hand Advice On Vice Presidency
description: Meanwhile, Vice President-elect Dan Quayle is planning a 10-day Christmas vacation in Vail, Colo., where he is expected to concentrate on skiing. Mr. Quayle has embarked on a series of seminars on the job of the Vice President, meeting with several who have held that position to hear accounts of what to expect.

title: Sununu and Teeter Differing on Access
description: The most intriguing personnel decision confronting President-elect Bush thus far involves not who should fill Cabinet slots but who will serve as leaders of his White House staff.

title: Home for Christmas, Then on to Texas
description: Mr. Bush will continue Mr. Reagan's practice of remaining in Washington for Christmas to allow his staff and Secret Service agents to celebrate the holiday with their families. The day after Christmas, the card-carrying member of the National Rifle Association heads to Beeville, Tex., a town of 14,574 people near Corpus Christi, to shoot turkeys. Mr. Bush will stay on the ranch of Will Farish, a wealthy businessman with holdings in oil who breeds prize horses. Mr. Bush vacationed at Mr. Farish's Florida home near Delray Beach after the election.

title: America Isn't Giving Its Scientists Their Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Humphrey In-Law Convicted Of Bank and Insurance Fraud
description: The son-in-law of Hubert H. Humphrey was found guilty today of eight counts of mail fraud and one of bank fraud. He faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count.

title: Bank Merger Approved
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation has received approval from the Federal Reserve Board for its merger with the Horizon Bancorp of Morristown, N.J. In an unusual departure, however, one Fed governor, Wayne D. Angell, dissented from the decision, reached last Friday, on the ground that Chemical would first need to raise ''significant additional capital'' to assure that its ability to serve as a source of strength to its banking affiliates would not be materially diminished by the acquisition. In granting approval, the Fed emphasized Chemical's commitment to supplement its capital by issuing $150 million of subordinated debt.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Excerpts From Speech to U.N. on Major Soviet Military Cuts
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to the General Assembly today, as issued in translation by the Soviet Mission: The Limits of Power

title: Thousands Feared Dead in Soviet Caucasus Quake
description: One of the worst earthquakes in Soviet history left a wake of devastation along the Soviet-Turkish border Wednesday, with thousands reported dead in three southern Soviet republics.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
An Embattled UTL Elects Top Executive
description: LEAD: The UTL Corporation, the military electronics company whose founder and chief executive, C. C. Lee, stepped down earlier this year after a Defense Department investigation, said yesterday that it had elected Gifford K. Johnson chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Community Fears In Takeover Bids
description: THERE has been much talk in the financial community of a coming wave of utility mergers. But if that is in the offing, dispelling community unrest may well become as pivotal a factor as settling the financial details.

title: Charter One Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,070,000. c-Includes tax credits of $815,000 and $1,768,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a FHLB prepayment penalty of $1,492,000. Share earnings are not available for the cumulative periods and year-ago quarter because the company went public in January 1988.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have noticed a musty odor in the room where there is a pull-down ladder leading to my attic. Although there is no odor in the attic, I discovered that the roof stringers and the ridge pole have mold on them. The attic has several vents and one window. What do you suggest I do?

title: School Officials Being Ousted Over Funds
description: An East Harlem school district superintendent and a school board member were ordered dismissed yesterday after a report accused them and other officials of using a secret school fund to pay personal expenses.

title: 'Icarus' With Puppets
description: The Bread and Puppet theater version of ''Icarus,'' based on the Pieter Bruegel painting ''Landscape With the Fall of Icarus,'' is to be presented by the Arts at St. Ann's, 157 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, beginning today. The company uses live actors as well as puppets, masks, dance and found objects, with music played on classical and improvised instruments. Performances are nightly at 8 o'clock, through Dec. 18. Tickets: $10. Information: (718) 834-8794.

title: Close to Home
description: IF I close my eyes I can still see her: an old woman in a worn black coat collared with a length of mangy orange fur. She was leaning on a cane, her body so bent it resembled an inverted L, and she was moving as awkwardly as a child who's just learned to walk.

title: Tapping the Collection Of a Wallpaper Fanatic
description: ''I CAN sense it; I know when it's around,'' said Suzanne Lipschutz, the owner of the Secondhand Rose shop in Greenwich Village. A fanatic about wallpaper from the 1930's to the 60's, she has been collecting and selling it for almost 20 years. With an inventory of more than 50,000 rolls, Ms. Lipschutz thinks she has ''the biggest collection in the world, I'm sure.''

title: ITALIANS CRITICIZE ATHENS ON TERROR
description: The Italian Government expressed unhappiness today over Greece's move to break an extradition agreement with Italy and deport to a third country a Palestinian who was wanted here in connection with a fatal grenade attack on a Rome synagogue six years ago.

title: Florida Rock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,507,000 from an accounting change.

title: Africans Find Freeing News Isn't So Easy
description: The worst riots in 25 years were shaking Algeria in October. Yet for days, editors at the Pan African News Agency waited here for their Algerian member agency to file a report.

title: Building on Gorbachev's Cuts in Europe
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's bold proposal to withdraw 50,000 troops and 5,000 tanks from three East European countries is a welcome step toward the ultimate goal of drastically reducing the risk of war in Europe. Taken together, this action and Mr. Gorbachev's proposals to cut total Soviet manpower by 500,000 and to restructure his forces in a defensive posture, will reduce East

title: Tyson Bid Rejected By Holly Farms
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said its board had rejected Tyson Foods Inc.'s sweetened cash offer of $54 a share, or $1 billion, as inadequate, maintaining that its proposed merger with Conagra Inc. is superior. It also rejected a higher Tyson offer of stock and cash for the same reason.

title: 'Christmas Vespers'
description: The Central City Chorus is to perform Monteverdi's ''Christmas Vespers'' at 7 P.M. Sunday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street. Charles Pilling is to conduct the performance, which will use Denis Stevens's reconstructed edition, scored for double choir, seven soloists, strings, trombones and organ continuo. Gwendolyn Toth is to be the organist, with members of the New York Sackbut Ensemble in accompaniment. Admission is $10. Information: 838-0808.

title: Pentagon Will Name a Team To Counter Computer Viruses
description: The Pentagon has announced it will establish a communications center and an emergency team of computer experts to respond to virus attacks on its computer networks.

title: 3d Transplant Is Unionized
description: The Diamond-Star Motors Corporation today became the third Japanese-managed American auto company to recognize the United Automobile Workers union as the collective bargaining representative of its hourly employees.

title: Bausch & Lomb In Dental Entry
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Dental Research Corporation, a privately held manufacturer of dental plaque removers, for $133 million.

title: Wilton Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $514,000.

title: U.S. Breaks Up International Accord on Prohibiting Child Soldiers
description: The United States blocked a compromise at United Nations-sponsored negotiations today that would have required countries to ''endeavor to prevent'' children between 15 and 18 years of age from being sent into combat.

title: O'Neill Is Touched By Offer on Ireland
description: Mr. Bush has been reaching out to people of various ideological and political stripes and made the ultimate gesture of reconcilation recently. At a private meeting, he offered former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. the post of United States Ambassador to Ireland, according to Sheila Tate, Mr. Bush's transition press spokesman. Mrs. Tate said that Mr. Bush felt that Mr. O'Neill would have been ''wonderful'' in the post, now held by Margaret Heckler.

title: Of Miracles and Men
description: In a post-mortem of the Presidential campaign, Robert J. Murray, a senior adviser on national security affairs to Michael S. Dukakis, concluded that there were only two ways the Massachusetts Governor could have won: the miraculous solution or the practical solution.

title: The Gropius House: Renovating A Modern Classic
description: The house that Walter Gropius built and the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities restored for its 50th birthday this fall is at once a modern icon, the youngest antiquity in the society's collection, and ''a nightmare'' that raised one of the hottest questions in the preservation field today: What becomes a legend most?

title: New Housing Fulfills Pledge By Koch in '86
description: ''Newly rehabbed apartments for rent,'' said the advertisements in several New York newspapers in recent weeks. While the ads themselves are routine, they represent an unusual fulfillment of a government promise.

title: Florida Rock & Tank Lines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Children Respond to Plight of Young Neediest
description: A group of third graders from Public School 11 in Manhattan performed household chores and sold trinkets to their neighbors in the last school year to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Circle K Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,506,000, or 10 cents a share fully diluted, from the sale of the company's sparkle ice subsidiary. c-Includes a gain of $8,198,000, or 7 cents a share fully diluted, from the sale of half of the company's United Kingdom subsidiary. d-Includes a credit of $5.5 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Table for Three, With Talk Of Bygones and Best Hopes
description: On a bright, breezy day in the middle of New York Harbor, President Reagan paid a sentimental farewell to Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday and expressed the hope that the Soviet leader and President-elect Bush will continue the improvement in Soviet-American relations that has become a hallmark of the Reagan Presidency.

title: Officials Take New Steps In Drug-Testing Effort
description: International Olympic officials, still groping for solutions to problems of drug use, continued their quest today with new initiatives designed to strengthen their campaign.

title: Abortion Protesters, Still Silent, Are Freed
description: Four abortion protesters have been released after more than 100 days in jail, despite their continued refusal to reveal their names.

title: JEWISH SPOKESMEN DIVIDED ON ARAFAT
description: Officials of American Jewish organizations fell into two camps yesterday as they tried to assess Yasir Arafat's statements in Stockholm apparently accepting Israel's existence and denouncing terrorism.

title: Head of Allis-Chalmers Is Looking to the Future
description: John T. Grigsby Jr. yesterday was named the chairman and chief executive of the Allis-Chalmers Corporation, once a respected name in the American business lexicon. Now Allis-Chalmers, after bankruptcy proceedings, has precious little left besides its name.

title: Thor Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Competitive Squeeze Seen Leading To More Medical Antitrust Cases
description: More competition among profit-seeking providers of medical care may lead to increasing cases of price fixing and other antitrust violations, say law-enforcement officials and experts in health care.

title: Seagram Co.  Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes equity in unremitted earnings of DuPont Co. of 51 cents and $2.36 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes equity in unremitted earnings of DuPont Co. of 54 cents and $1.68 in the quarter and 9 months, respecitvely. All figures are in U.S. dollars. The company said net income for the third quarter was slightly lower than last year due to amortization of goodwill and interest expense related to the acquisition of Martell and Tropicana.

title: Morgro Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Statement by Arafat and Jews
description: Following is the text of a joint declaration issued today by a delegation of American Jews and a delegation led by Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, as presented by Foreign Minister Sten Andersson of Sweden:

title: MILITARY FOCUSING ON FAMILY NEEDS
description: Lieut. Col. Wayne Crowder had this message for his Navy and Marine audience: ''The days of the attitude of 'if we wanted you to have a family, we would have issued you one' are over.''

title: Group That Preserves Monuments Honors One: Paley
description: The Municipal Art Society has as its mandate the preservation of New York City's monuments. So it was fitting that last night it should have bestowed its president's medal on William S. Paley, the 87-year-old chairman of CBS.

title: Europe Bloc vs. Spain
description: The European Community said today that it had started legal proceedings against Spain for failing to open its tobacco industry to outside competition. In a statement, the European Community's Executive Commission said Spain should have set quotas for the importing of tobacco from the 11 other member states as soon as the country joined the community in 1986. But it said such measures had not been taken. Under the terms of Spain's entry, the Government was due to end the country's tobacco monopoly by Dec. 31, 1991.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Profit Climbs Again
description: Saatchi & Saatchi said yesterday that its pretax profit in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 was $244.3 million, up 11 percent from a year earlier. The after-tax profit rose 7.9 percent, to $132.9 million.

title: FB&T Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9-month share net are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Sept. 10, 1988.

title: Classic Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $58,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Waste Dumping That U.S. Banned Went On at Its Own Atom Plants
description: Extensive environmental damage at Federal nuclear weapon plants is largely a result of crude waste disposal practices that were banned in the private sector a decade ago.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Soviet Star Is a Smash In Broadway Showing
description: With his uncanny knack for a dramatic entrance, Mikhail Gorbachev ordered the driver of his limousine to screech to a halt on Broadway in front of the Winter Garden Theater where the musical ''Cats'' is playing. Standing beneath the huge Coca-Cola neon advertisement with his smiling wife, Raisa, the Soviet leader raised his arms in a victory clench, like ''Rocky.''

title: Standout in the Land of Catalogues
description: In the crowded field of catalogue retailing, Lands' End continues to grow, helped by its folksy approach to selling, devotion to service and deft use of computers.

title: Currents; Design From the Ground Up
description: ART and music are the most common enrichment subjects for elementary-school students, but the New York Foundation for the Arts wants to make architecture just as accessible. Since 1972, the foundation has provided money so that architects, poets, painters and dancers could teach students throughout the state, usually for 10 to 45 days. But Community School District 6 in Harlem has received a grant allowing Moji Baratloo, a partner in Balch Baratloo Architects in Manhattan, to develop and teach a curriculum lasting much longer: 120 days.

title: Sudan Aid Convoy Attacked
description: Rebels in a southern jungle have repeatedly ambushed a truck convoy carrying food and medicine to famine victims, and one truck hit a rebel land mine, killing seven people, a United Nations official said today.

title: James Ray, 57, Actor in Movies, TV and in Shakespearean Roles
description: James Ray, an actor in theater, television and films who appeared in productions of the New York Shakespeare Festival and the American Shakespeare Festival, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old.

title: TV Notes
description: A Life of Callas

title: Pentech International Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Roy Orbison, 52, a Singer Famed For Plaintive Pop Anthems, Dies
description: Roy Orbison, the singer and songwriter whose best work brought introspection and yearning to rock-and-roll, died of a heart attack Tuesday night while visiting his mother in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 52 years old and lived in Malibu, Calif.

title: Richardson Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: HEALTH: Occupational Health; As Complaints Grow, Doctors Seek Data on Repetitive Motion Injuries
description: As more and more workers report injuries from repetitive motions on the job, Federal agencies are stepping up efforts to assess the prevalence of such injuries, suggest ways to prevent them and fine industries that do not protect workers.

title: A Ritual Forms the Stuff of Literature
description: In these mild winter days, when Cairo stirs under a smoggy dawn, Naguib Mahfouz, the Egyptian writer who won this year's Nobel Prize in Literature, does what he always does. He rises with the city and walks.

title:
BASKETBALL: AUSTRALIAN IN THE BIG EAST;
Seton Hall Goes Far to Get a Star
description: LEAD: If there were a Red Auerbach Award for wondrous personnel moves, this year's winner might be John Carroll, an assistant coach at Seton Hall University.

title: The P.L.O. Inches Forward
description: In a statement issued jointly in Stockholm yesterday with a delegation of dovish American Jews, the Palestine Liberation Organization seems to have crept closer to accepting Israel's right to exist. Just how far the P.L.O. has moved is hard to tell. But the statement appears to inch beyond the Palestine National Council's declaration issued after its recent meeting in Algiers. It does so by affirming the need for a two-state solution and says the P.L.O. would accept the existence of Israel if the Palestinians could establish their own state.

title: Dollar Surges After Speech by Gorbachev
description: Aided by currency traders' enthusiastic reaction to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's troop-reduction announcement, the beleaguered dollar rallied sharply yesterday and posted its largest one-day rise since its steep decline began this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about nominations for the National Book Critics Circle Awards gave incorrect titles for three books, misidentified an author and omitted the name of an editor. John Hollander's book of criticism is titled ''Melodious Guile.'' Nelson George's book of criticism is ''The Death of Rhythm & Blues.''

title: The Heat Loses No. 14
description: The Miami Heat, ahead by 11 points in the fourth quarter, lost to the Sacramento Kings by 96-94 tonight for the expansion team's 14th consecutive defeat without a victory.

title: Xtra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,099,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,204,000 and $2,796,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Mets Send Backman to Twins for Pitchers
description: The Mets made a move to whittle their surplus of infielders today, but also lost one of the durable and dashing figures of their recent history, when they traded Wally Backman to the Minnesota Twins for three minor league pitchers.

title: Tribute to a 19th-Century Taste Maker
description: TO the average design watcher who has a vague idea that Ogden Codman was a Newport dandy and the co-author with Edith Wharton of ''The Decoration of Houses,'' the exhibition that opened yesterday at the National Academy of Design in New York will come as an enlightening surprise.

title: GORBACHEV PLEDGES MAJOR TROOP CUTBACK, THEN ENDS TRIP, CITING VAST SOVIET QUAKE
description: In an audacious bid to seize the initiative in East-West relations, Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced at the United Nations yesterday that the Soviet Union would sharply cut its military forces.

title: Japanese Police Raid Seller of Gas to Soviets
description: Japanese police searched the offices of a medium-size chemical company today, along with the homes of its top executives, after accusing the company of selling a specialized gas to the Soviet Union that could be used in missile guidance systems.

title: Columbia Trustees Name New Provost
description: Dr. Jonathan R. Cole, a sociologist known for his studies of women in science, has been appointed provost by the trustees of Columbia University.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; This Time, Moscow Leaves the Flair Out In Covering Leader
description: Soviet television viewers saw a complete broadcast Wednesday night of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address to the United Nations General Assembly and reports of his meetings with President Reagan and President-elect Bush.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Includes net of $462,000 generated from the sale of assets and technology. The company said year-to-date earnings include a preliminary business interruption insurance claim of $200,000.

title: Robert Wilson's Papers on View
description: Robert Wilson, the creator of avant-garde theater works like ''Einstein on the Beach,'' ''The Civil Wars'' and ''The Forest,'' has donated 10,000 of his scripts, drawings, notes, photographs and other papers to Columbia University. Many of these items will go on view today in the university's Rare Book and Manuscript Library, in Butler Library, Broadway and 116th Street.

title: Lilco's Racketeering Verdict Prompts Rethinking of Plans
description: Reverberations from a Federal jury verdict that the Long Island Lighting Company lied to obtain two rate increases continued to echo through Albany and Long Island today as Governor Cuomo and several Long Island legislators began to map their new strategies.

title: October Consumer Debt Rose at 6.5% Pace
description: American consumers increased their debt burden at a 6.5 percent annual rate in October, after taking out almost no new credit in September, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Mall Planned For Moscow
description: The Triple Five Corporation, the Canadian company that developed the world's largest shopping center in West Edmonton, Alberta, said yesterday that it planned to develop a $1.5 billion mall in Moscow.

title: Granite CO-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Theater; Mining Old Plays and Films for Nostalgic Laughs
description: Through the first four scenes of Greg Zittel's ''Fighting Light,'' laughter builds as Mr. Zittel mines some familiar American plays and 1930's and 40's films for ridiculous lines and situations. But suddenly the good humor disappears, which is especially exasperating because the director, Matthew Penn, and his cast have obviously worked hard on this production at the RAPP Arts Center in the East Village.

title: Kennedy Endorses Ex-Aide
description: Ronald H. Brown's candidacy to succeed Paul G. Kirk Jr. as Democratic national chairman received a major lift today as Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts issued an ''enthusiastic'' endorsement of his friend and former aide.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Concessions by Gorbachev Are Seen on Aid to Afghans
description: In appealing today for a suspension of military supplies to all sides in Afghanistan, Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to have embraced a position he rejected last spring, when the Soviet Union thought the Afghan Government was stronger than it has turned out to be.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Models Reach For the Sky At Early Age
description: DEEP within Manhattan's ''photo district,'' a commercial casting session is about to take place for a product so secret that the advertising agency demands anonymity. The would-be models are apprehensive; some are even crying. But Jade Albert, the photographer, is ready. Lights, camera, toddle!

title: Stephen Petronio Roars Into Choreographic Gear
description: Stephen Petronio's dances are not for slowpokes. He makes his casts hurtle their way through turbulent choreography in which many types of movement are combined, so that gestural references to Judy Garland may merge with a pose inspired by Ronald Reagan.

title: An Elaboration of Beads In Bold and Subtle Hues
description: LEAD: Stringing beads is an activity that many summer campers are forced to attempt. Rarely, however, do the finished projects approach anything one would be likely to wear. A show at the Merrin Gallery, however, features strung glass-bead jewelry that is elegant and eloquent.

title: Reagan Looks West
description: Ronald Reagan, soon to ride off into a Presidential sunset, has long had a soft spot for steeds, so it comes as no surprise that he has expressed interest in a project aimed at commemorating the role of horses in the settlement of the American West.

title: ODDS SAID TO FAVOR COCAINE SMUGGLERS
description: The Commandant of the Coast Guard says American law-enforcement agencies are stopping only an estimated 5 to 7 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States because they lack enough detection equipment.

title: Kitty Dukakis Plans Book on the Campaign
description: Simon & Schuster plans to publish a book by Kitty Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: Niagara Mohawk reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of disallowed Nine Mile Two costs of $77,900,000. c-Net loss and includes a writeoff of disallowed Nine Mile Two costs of $775,100,000. All share figures are after payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Currents; A Window Full of Windows
description: MOST stores' holiday windows feature an American vision of Christmas: Santas surrounded by reindeer and radiant children. But Marimekko, which specializes in Finnish textiles and clothing, has chosen to pay homage to its own heritage.

title: At 100, Hamilton Fish Has Plenty of Kick
description: It was a confrontation involving two former friends from two old New York State families - and it echoed all across the country by radio, half a century ago.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aero Services International Inc., Teterboro, N.J., said Trenk Development Corp. had made an offer to acquire the company for a combination of cash and securities. Trenk has a lawsuit pending against Aero over the voting power of the company.

title: AIDS Groups Protest Series Episode
description: Any new television series hoping to survive wants to attract attention. But how much attention is too much? The producers of ''Midnight Caller,'' an acclaimed and already disputed new series from Lorimar and NBC, will find out on Tuesday, when a provocative episode about AIDS is scheduled to be shown.

title: Groundwater Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Latest second quarter earnings reflect a charge of $223,000 to write off the unamortized cost of certain intangible assets related to the acquisition of Blackhawk Environmental Services.

title: Biathlon Competition on Long Island
description: If you are so disposed, it is not too late to take part in a warmer-weather version of the ski-and-shoot winter biathlon Sunday at Mitchel Park in Uniondale, L.I. Open to anyone 12 years old and up, this event involves running and rifle marksmanship.

title: Review/Theater; Neighbor as Nemesis
description: Dennis McIntyre's excoriating new play, ''National Anthems,'' at the Long Wharf Theater, is an assault on traditional American values. The playwright looks into the world of a prototypical yuppie couple (Tom Berenger and Mary McDonnell) in a well-to-do suburb of Detroit and finds that their apparent rise is actually a holding pattern. In an instant, they may crash. The catalyst for this realization is a neighbor who stops by late at night to introduce himself after the couple's housewarming party is over.

title: Currents; James Dean and Some Other Historical Objects
description: THE Municipal Art Society's fourth annual City Spirit Bazaar opens today, gathering under one roof holiday gifts from 13 of the city's museums and historical societies.

title: President and Congress
description: One of George Bush's main themes since the election, a wise one, has been his intention to consult and respect Congress. It is wise, as past Presidents have learned and relearned, because our divided system of government can founder on suspicion and hostility between the branches.

title: New York Pianist Wins Monk Jazz Competition
description: Ted Rosenthal, a 29-year-old pianist from New York City, has won the first prize in the second annual Thelonious Monk International Jazz award of $10,000, is the largest in jazz. Mr. Rosenthal was chosen from more than 400 applicants from all over the world who submitted cassettes of their playing. The judges, all jazz pianists, were Tommy Flanagan, Sir Roland Hanna, Barry Harris and Roger Kellaway. Mr. Rosenthal has bachelor's and master's degrees from the Manhattan School of Music.

title: Conner Helps Out
description: Dennis Conner, who skippered the United States to victory in this year's America's Cup races against New Zealand, is in Leningrad to assist the Soviet Union in its bid to enter the next race. According to The Daily Mail of London, Conner is advising the Russians on their preparations for the 1991 race off San Diego harbor. On Sept. 30, four Soviet yachting clubs grouped under the flag of the Estonian Trade Association to enter the race. Their bid to enter, however, was hampered by a ruling last month that traditional 12-Meter yachts would be replaced by a new 75-foot class. Because of that, they discarded three months' work and will seek advice from Conner on building the new yachts and in raising funds. (AP)

title: Mr. Shultz Understands the Politics of Arafat; Grasp at Algiers
description: To the Editor:

title: North's Lawyers Say They Will Not Need Cables From C.I.A.
description: Lawyers for Oliver L. North, continuing legal fencing over the use of secret documents in the former White House aide's forthcoming trial, today dropped plans to use 10,000 pages of classified cables on Nicaragua as evidence in his defense.

title: James Patrick Garvey, Executive, 77
description: James Patrick Garvey, a former corporate vice president of Burlington Industries, died of cancer Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Yields Post Rise in Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up again for the week ended yesterday, and experts said it appeared that the rise would continue for the rest of the year.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Allen Group Inc., Melville, L.I., which makes automobile accessories, elected Philip W. Colburn, president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman.

title: California High Court to Hear Insurance Suit
description: The California Supreme Court said today that it would hear the insurance industry's lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a voter-initiated ballot measure that would lead to a sweeping overhaul of the state's insurance laws.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Cuomo's Wife Is Contesting Father's Will
description: A dispute over the $13.7 million estate of Governor Cuomo's father-in-law has family members feuding in Nassau County Surrogate's Court.

title: U.S. Issues Fall on Profit Taking
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds retreated in active, nervous trading yesterday as market participants took profits after Tuesday's strong rally.

title: LaRouche Prosecution Rests
description: Federal prosecutors completed their case today against Lyndon H. LaRouche, the political extremist, on charges of conspiring to commit tax fraud and taking part in a fund-raising scheme involving more than $30 million. Mr. LaRouche was reportedly sick at his Leesburg, Va., estate but was expected in Court on Thursday, when his lawyers begin presenting their case. A defense attorney, Odin Anderson, said he had about 50 prospective witnesses and that Mr. LaRouche would probably testify.

title: Kathleen M. Kane, Judge, 87
description: Kathleen M. Kane, the first female judge of the Nassau County District Court, died of complications Tuesday after undergoing surgery at St. Joseph's Hospital in Tampa, Fla. She was 87 years old and lived in Tampa.

title: Develcon Electronics reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $459,000 special charge.

title: Roundup in Paraguay
description: The police arrested about 20 opposition leaders to prevent them from staging a human rights march through Asuncion next Saturday to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the U.N. Declaration of Human Rights, a church official said today. The Government of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner banned the march on Monday.

title: Flow Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Coca-Cola Tested in Florida Poisoning of 3
description: The authorities tested eight bottles of Coca-Cola today for traces of a banned rat killer blamed for poisoning three members of a family here, one of whom was comatose.

title: Willis IS Suspended
description: The Atlanta Hawks have indefinitely suspended Kevin Willis, an injured forward who has a cracked bone in his foot. Willis missed team functions and rehabilitation therapy. ''The last straw was tonight when he missed the entire game,'' said Stan Kasten, the president and general manager of the Hawks after his team beat the Sacramento Kings Tuesday night. ''He was here before the game and decided to leave before the game,'' said Kasten. ''He was warned that if he was late for this game, he would be suspended.'' Kasten said Willis would be suspended without pay. (AP)

title: 2 Police Officers Admit Robbing Drug Dealers
description: Two Orange, N.J., police officers pleaded guilty today in Federal court to robbing drug dealers while moonlighting as security guards for the city's housing authority.

title: The Gorbachev Visit
description: Gorbachev's U.N. Surprise: Soviet Arms Cuts Gorbachev Plan: Over the next two years reduce Soviet armed forces by 500,000. Mr. Gorbachev did not say which forces would be reduced. The Soviet Union has about 5.1 million troops all over the world, including 1.5 million that are used for railroad work, construction civil defense and other purposes. Current Warsaw Pact forces: Total active ground forces from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains: 2.1 million, Current NATO forces: Total U.S. troops worldwide: 2.2 million. Total NATO active ground forces from the Atlantic to the Urals: 2.34 million. Gorbachev Plan: Soviet Union would withdraw by 1991 six tank divisions from East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary and disband them. Total reduction: 5,000 tanks and 50,000 men from these countries. The Soviet Union has about 10,000 tanks in Eastern Europe. Current Warsaw Pact forces: 26 tank divisions outside the Soviet Union in Warsaw Pact countries, of which 14 are Soviet. Current NATO forces: 14 1/3 tank divisions, of which 2 1/3 are U.S. Gorbachev Plan: Also, Soviet forces in the European part of the Soviet Union would be cut by 5,000 tanks, and total Soviet forces from the Atlantic to the Urals would be reduced by 8,500 artillery systems and 800 combat aircraft. NATO estimates are that there are 37,000 soviet tanks in this area, not including a small number of stored tanks. The Soviets have 33,000 artillery weapons in the Warsaw Pact and 6,050 combat aircraft, according to NATO estimates. Current Warsaw Pact forces: Equipment deployed: 51,500 Artillery systems of 100mm or more: 43,400 Combat aircraft: 8,250 Current NATO forces: Equipment deployed: Tanks: 16,424 Artillery systems: About 14,458 Combat aircraft: 3,997 (Sources: American Defense specialists, International Institute for Strategic Studies, NATO)

title: Jets Give Walton a Contract Extension
description: The fourth-place Jets announced today that they had given Coach Joe Walton a multiyear contract extension. They would not say how long the extension is for but it is believed to go through 1991.

title: Western Officials Term Troop Cuts Significant
description: Western officials yesterday welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to cut Soviet forces as an important step toward constraining Moscow's ability to attack Western Europe.

title: The Back-Seat Driver, Circa 1991
description: Within two or three years, drivers in London's famous traffic snarls could get some much-needed help. A European-designed system called Autoguide will enable motorists to let a tinny-voiced central computer in their dashboards guide them quickly around jams to their destinations. New Yorkers trapped in ''Gorby gridlock'' might well have wished for Autoguide today.

title: Fears of a 'Short Squeeze' Push Copper Contracts Up
description: Copper prices surged yesterday on the possibility that traders who had sold short might not be able to deliver the metal against the expiring December contract on the Commodity Exchange in New York. If so, the shorts, who anticipated a decline in prices, may have to pay dearly to buy out of their December contracts, which expire on Dec. 30.

title: Coach Resigns
description: After five losing seasons and several National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations that contributed to a two-year probation for the football program, Coach Dave Currey of the University of Cincinnati resigned yesterday. Currey had a 19-45 record in five seasons, including a 3-8 mark this year. Last month the N.C.A.A. imposed sanctions for violating rules regarding athletic scholarships, financial aid and recruiting in football and men's basketball.(AP)

title: California Bars Degrees at Creationist School
description: California's top education official said today that the state had barred the Institute for Creation Research from granting masters' degrees in science. The institute, a fundamentalist Christian school that had offered degrees for teaching biology, geology, astrogeophysics and science, is opposed to the teaching of evolution.

title: Abuse Reports From Nussbaum Are Questioned
description: Testimony by Hedda Nussbaum that Lisa Steinberg was sexually abused when she was 2 years old has been thrown into doubt by the prosecution in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg.

title: Service for Bradshaw
description: A memorial for Thornton F. Bradshaw, former chairman of RCA and the Atlantic Richfield Company, who died Tuesday, will be held Saturday at 11 A.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street.

title: Cranston Aide in Line
description: Not all jobs in the Bush Administration will go to Republicans. Before the election, the Democrats who control Congress made sure of that.

title: Mandela Moved to House at Prison Farm
description: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's most prominent prisoner, was quietly transferred tonight from a clinic outside Cape Town to a house on a prison farm about 50 miles away, the Government said.

title: Top Communist In U.S. Is Taking 'Fever' in Stride
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived at Kennedy International Airport Tuesday, his American counterpart as general secretary of the Communist Party wasn't there to greet him.

title: Warrant Issued
description: An arrest warrant was issued yesterday for the former champion, Lupe Aquino, after he failed to show at a hearing on manslaughter charges, but promoters in Detroit said he was still expected there for a title fight tonight. Municipal Court Judge Rosemary Shumsky issued the bench warrant with $100,000 bail attached after the 25-year-old Aquino missed his scheduled preliminary hearing in West Los Angeles Municipal Court. Aquino, a native of Mexico who lives in Santa Paula, Calif., faces two counts each of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving stemming from an Aug. 14 accident in which two passengers in the car he was driving died. Aquino faces John David Jackson of Detroit in a battle for the World Boxing Organization junior middleweight crown. (AP)

title: Nicaragua Releases Last of the July Protesters
description: A judge today ordered the release of the 10 remaining prisoners jailed for taking part in an anti-Government protest five months ago in the Nicaraguan town of Nandaime.

title: Torchmark's Plea On Insurer Denied
description: A Federal judge refused to intervene in the Torchmark Corporation's hostile takeover battle for the Kansas City Life Insurance Company by rejecting a request for a preliminary injunction. The decision was seen as a major setback for Torchmark, although a lawyer for the Birmingham, Ala., concern said it would pursue bringing its offer of $47.50 a share, or approximately $347 million, to Kansas City Life's stockholders.

title: Broker's Suit Against S.E.C.
description: Blinder, Robinson & Company, a Denver-based broker in penny stocks that is under investigation by Federal authorities, has filed a lawsuit with the Supreme Court to challenge the constitutionality of the enforcement powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Garden State Toll Rise Urged
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority yesterday proposed a 10-cent increase in Garden State Parkway tolls.

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Review/Television; In New York With Gorbachevs and 45 Vehicles
description: Although it was Mikhail S. Gorbachev's first visit to New York, television treated it as a Second Coming.

title: Gambler, Showman, Statesman
description: Perhaps not since Woodrow Wilson presented his Fourteen Points in 1918 or since Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill promulgated the Atlantic Charter in 1941 has a world figure demonstrated the vision Mikhail Gorbachev displayed yesterday at the United Nations.

title: Personal Health
description: A New York woman with an early and highly curable breast cancer refused surgery or any conventional therapy. Instead, she tried to cure herself with a macrobiotic diet of grains, beans, raw vegetables, seaweed, weak tea, fruits and seeds. In six months her tumor had spread and in two years she was dead.

title: Bankers Trust Presentation
description: The Bankers Trust Company, in a display of openness, yesterday invited securities analysts, large institutional investors and members of the press to a presentation on its leveraged buyout loan portfolio.

title: Chancellor Backs Opening Magnet Schools
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green said yesterday that he supported adopting a policy that would admit students to ''magnet'' programs in schools of their choice, regardless of what admission of those students would do to the racial balance of each school.

title: Troop-Cut Plan Bolsters Dollar
description: The dollar was bolstered as traders reacted enthusiastically to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement about a planned troop reduction.

title: INSIDE
description: Roy Orbison Is Dead

title: Sun-Blocking Chemical Is Linked to Allergies
description: A chemical used in many high-protection sun-blocking lotion sometimes causes allergic reactions, a new study indicates.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Sports Pages on Tuesday about the International Olympic Committee meetings described them incorrectly. The article was about the opening day of the meetings, not the final day.

title: William Barry Leavens Jr., Executive, 84
description: William Barry Leavens Jr., a retired business executive and inventor, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Trump Says Shuttle Is Losing Share
description: The Eastern Airlines shuttle is rapidly losing market share to Pan American World Airways and Donald J. Trump, who is buying the shuttle, warned today that that it could go out of business unless he quickly gained control and revamped its operations.

title: RJR Nabisco Explains Its Choice
description: The RJR Nabisco board indicated yesterday that fear of disrupting the bidding process was among the many reasons it chose a deal with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company over a management group's ''substantially equivalent'' offer.

title: 29 AIRLINES FINED IN SECURITY CHECKS
description: The Transportation Department said today that it had fined 29 airlines a total of $1.6 million for failing to detect simulated weapons in tests of airport security.

title: Dinkins 'Seriously' Considers Entering the Race for Mayor
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan yesterday came as close to announcing his candidacy for mayor as he could without formally declaring.

title: A New Portfolio Protection Idea
description: PORTFOLIO insurance was a phenomenon of the mid-1980's. The idea seized the imagination of institutional investors, who saw in it a way to stay fully invested in stocks while assuring that losses would be kept to a minimum. Then came Oct. 19, 1987, and portfolio insurance lost its luster. Selling by those seeking to implement portfolio insurance played a major role in the crash.

title: Hospital Says Rules Reduced Caesarean Rate
description: Requiring doctors to get second opinions and a few other basic rules reduced the percentage of Caesarean births at a Chicago hospital to half the national rate, a report says. The strategy could save more than $1 billion if applied everywhere, the program's developers assert in this week's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: KEY RATES
ARAFAT SAYS P.L.O. ACCEPTED ISRAEL
description: Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization accepted the existence of the state of Israel. His statement, which he presented as a milestone, was immediately dismissed in Israel and greeted coldly by the United States.

title: Safest Reactor Is Closing Because It Rarely Runs
description: A nuclear reactor that seems safer than others in use in the United States will be abandoned in 18 months because it cannot be made to run reliably, its owners have announced.

title: Mr. Shultz Understands the Politics of Arafat; A Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Teamsters Elect Slate Linked to Mob
description: After more than two years of Federal control aimed at eliminating mob influence within Local 560 of the teamsters, the rank and file has voted to return management of their union to associates of the convicted racketeer Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano.

title: Freshmen Help St. John's To Fifth Straight Victory
description: Despite the tradition and the numbers, Fordham seemed to have its best chance in recent memory to end St. John's dominance in their 80-year rivalry.

title: Auto Loans Back Citibank Securities
description: Citibank is offering $606 million of automobile-loan certificates due Jan. 15, 1994. The certificates have a 7.25 percent coupon and are priced at 96.24 to yield 9.69 percent.

title: DUKAKIS IS FORCED TO REVISE BUDGET
description: Michael S. Dukakis, acknowledging that the state faces a $471 million budget deficit in the current fiscal year, today outlined an eagerly awaited savings package that appears to avoid severe austerity measures.

title: San Francisco Journal; Storing Up Myths About Ourselves
description: Even knowing that heroes are hard to find, it's still a bit of a jolt to learn that the people here at the Museum of Modern Mythology contend that Bibendum, the Michelin Tire Man, may be of more relevance today than Prometheus.

title: Mr. Shultz Understands the Politics of Arafat; A Deaf Ear
description: To the Editor:

title: Islamabad Journal; At Dawning of Bhutto Age, the Torpid City Stirs
description: The days are brisk with an autumn chill and crackling with political electricity now in this capital city better known in the past for its generally somnolent, almost mournful air.

title: Article 047488 -- No Title
description: When a former Dallas minister was ordered to pay $16 million on Monday for the lifetime care of his wife, who is in a coma after a strangling attack in which the minister has been a suspect, it was one more chapter in a bizarre story that has kept Dallas riveted and confused for more than 18 months.

title: Rocker Wins the Outland
description: Tracy Rocker, the defensive tackle from Auburn, was certain Tony Mandarich, the Michigan State giant, would be the one. ''After all, he's famous,'' said Rocker. ''He even got some votes for the Heisman Trophy.''

title: New York City Bond Offering
description: New York City is tentatively offering $400 million of general obligation bonds at various prices for a maximum yield of about 8 percent for securities due 2008 through 2018. It is the city's second long-term borrowing in the current fiscal year. Underwriters led by Merrill

title: 'Thin Blue Line' Aftermath: New Trial Is Possible
description: ''Venue,'' said Errol Morris, looking up from his ham sandwich at the Texas Bar-B-Que down the street from the Dallas County Courthouse. ''I love that word. The V word.''

title: Mr. Shultz Understands the Politics of Arafat
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gorbachev Visit; Another Obstacle Falls: Nancy Reagan and Raisa Gorbachev Get Chummy
description: The luncheon party was supposed to be the last encounter between Raisa Gorbachev and Nancy Reagan, the final chapter in a frosty relationship that has been tested in Geneva, Washington and Moscow and withstood all other warming trends in United States-Soviet relations.

title: Quake Shakes Alaska Area
description: A moderate earthquake shook the Cook Inlet area early Tuesday but there were no reports of damage or injuries, the Tsunami Warning Center said. The quake had a preliminary magnitude of 5.0 on the Richter scale that measures the severity of earthquakes, the center said. The quake was centered about 50 miles west of Homer.

title: U.S. Wheat Sale Subsidy
description: The United States resumed large-scale wheat subsidies today, offering China subsidies on sales of a million metric tons of wheat, the Agriculture Department announced. It was the largest offer since India was offered a million tons in October. United States farm groups and grain traders had been anxious about a lack of American export subsidies, especially since completion of a long-term grain purchase pact in November between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Currents; Two Avenues, Two Separate Worlds
description: LAZY SUSAN, the Japanese-owned housewares store at Third Avenue and 62d Street, has branched out and gone upscale. Its sister store, LS Collection, at 765 Madison Avenue (65th Street), has the same owners, Yoshikazu and Masahiko Kasuga of Tokyo, but little else is the same.

title: Apple Computer Official To Take 5-Month Leave
description: Deborah A. Coleman, the former manufacturing chief who rose to become the chief financial officer and vice president of Apple Computer Inc., said yesterday that she would take a five-month leave of absence because of health and personal considerations.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Transition; Circle of Senior Aides Helps Bush Fill Top Posts
description: As President-elect Bush huddled with his most senior advisers last week, the discussion moved to the appointment of John G. Tower as the Secretary of Defense.

title: Infants More at Risk In Poor Rural Areas, New Study Indicates
description: Infants born in poor rural areas are a third more likely to die before the first birthday than those born in other areas in the nation, a study issued today by a public interest lobby contends.

title: Metro Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring pretax gains of $69,000 and $518,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes non-recurring pretax gains of $770,000 for the quarter, and the year includes tax benefits of $2,047,000. Prior-year net from operations includes non-recurring pretax gains of $4,007,000. The bank reported no per share figures because it converted Nov. 4, 1988.

title: Home Improvement
description: MARBLE surfaces, in addition to being beautiful, are extremely durable and versatile. However, they require modest care to protect them from stains, scratches and loss of luster.

title: What, Get A's While Watching TV?
description: There is no scientific evidence that homework done by children while they watch television is poorer than homework done in silence, two psychologists have asserted.

title: Dance Benefit for Amnesty
description: Six dance companies and soloists from the United States and Canada are to perform in a benefit for Amnesty International at 7:30 P.M. Dec. 19 at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eigth Avenue, at 19th Street. The performers are to include Pilobolus, ISO, the David Parsons Company and La La La Human Steps, with solo dancing by Margie Gillis and by Alan Boeding, who will dnace with his sculpture. Tickets or the performance alone are $75; for the performance and a dinner afterward at the Man Ray Bistro, $150, $250 and $500. Information: 633-4211.

title: Firstier Financial Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $290,000 from sale of servicing assets of Firstier Mortgage Co. for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a non-recurring gain of $5.4 million in the second quarter relating to the same transaction.

title: Valhi Unit's Buyer Is Bristar of Britain
description: Bristar, the food division of S&W Berisford P.L.C., said that it is the company that signed a tentative agreement to acquire the Amalgamated Sugar Company from Valhi Inc. Valhi, based in Dallas, disclosed Monday that an agreement had been reached with a foreign group, but it did not identify the prospective buyer. Valhi said the sale would bring it an after-tax gain of $185 million. The sale must be approved by the boards of Bristar and Valhi.

title: Rangers Sign Ryan; $2 Million Guaranteed
description: Nolan Ryan, who has more strikeouts and million-dollar seasons than anyone else in baseball history, today signed a contract with the Texas Rangers that guarantees him $2 million for one year.

title: A Good Way to Fight Drugs and AIDS
description: The apparent success of a new methadone drug treatment program in Harlem offers a glimmer of hope for the war on drugs and a strong ray for the war on AIDS. It deserves broad attention in Albany and the nation.

title: America Isn't Giving Its Scientists Their Dur; Early to College
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Monday about children's picture books misidentified a Grimm fairy tale illustrated by Maurice Sendak. It is ''Dear Mili.''

title: Bonneville Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sentences Given for Pollution
description: A New York company has been fined and four of its supervisors have been given jail terms for releasing asbestos into the air while demolishing the Kaiser steel plant in Fontana. Federal District Judge A. Andrew Hauk on Monday fined the defunct Cuyahoga Wrecking Company of Great Neck, L.I., $250,000 for violating the Federal Clean Air Act. Leonard Capizzi of Buffalo was given 18 months in prison, Chester Reiss of Bayonne, N.J., and Robert Torok of Buffalo, six-month terms, and James Abbajay of Oakwood, Tex., two months.

title: 25 Named to Advise On Housing Plan
description: Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko appointed a 25-member advisory committee yesterday to help the comply with a housing-desegregation order from a Federal court.

title: Reviews/Theater; Portrait of the Author in the Guise of a Character
description: Charles Dickens's ''Christmas Carol'' is one of those stories that has become so ingrained in our culture that we tend to view it as a myth unconnected to the author's own life. But should that really be the case? ''A Charles Dickens Christmas,'' a one-act family musical presented by Theaterworks/USA at the Promenade Theater, takes some of the basic biographical facts of Dickens's life and imagines how the author might have woven them into the story as we know it. As the show opens, Dickens (Warren Kelley) is presented as a harried, Scrooge-like figure, indifferent to Christmas, rushing to meet deadlines, and barely able to squelch his fury at a financially exploitative father (Trip Plymale) and a threatening taskmaster of a publisher (Don Stephenson).

title: U.S., Europe Still Split at GATT Talks
description: The United States and the European Community failed again today to bridge their differences over farm policy, raising the possibility that global trade talks here would end in disarray.

title: F.A.A. and Airlines to Meet On Easing Traffic at O'Hare
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would meet with the major airlines that serve O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to set schedules to reduce congestion.

title: A Virtue of Necessity
description: Mikhail Gorbachev understands this rule of political survival:

title: Currents; Half-Sour in Beverly Hills
description: WHEN the Beverly Hills branch of the Carnegie Deli opens next spring at 300 Beverly Drive, Californians and transcontinental commuters can eat authentic pastrami and half-sour pickles in a fantasy version of the New York delicatessen.

title: Nicaragua Currency
description: Facing raging inflation, Nicaragua's Government issued a new 10,000-cordoba currency note today. The value of the new bill, the largest in circulation, was put at the equivalent of $2.86 on the legal exchange market and $2.38 on the black market.

title: Study Says Women Still Do Most Housework
description: American women still do most of the cooking, laundering and housecleaning, but men have increased their share of such household chores as pet care, gardening and dealing with bills, a study shows.

title: Two Teachers Assailed After Racial Remarks
description: More than 50 faculty members and students have filed a complaint against two University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh professors who used phrases with racial connotations in a Faculty Senate debate.

title: Shula Says He Tried To Help His Players
description: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' coach, said yesterday he did all he could in 1986 to end Mark Duper's associations with convicted drug dealers. Sports Illustrated magazine reported in its Dec. 12 issue that Shula and the team owner, Joe Robbie, were told more than two years ago about photographs of Duper with a Miami cocaine dealer, Nelson Aguilar, and other dealers. ''The league and team officials apparently did little to stop Duper's association with the dealers,'' the magazine said. The National Football League last week suspended Duper for 30 days for violating the league's substance abuse policy. ''I was very disturbed,'' Shula said, ''by the implication that I was aware of alleged drug use or consorting with drug dealers and didn't do anything about it. As soon as I was aware of the photographs that were taken of two of our ballplayers with two convicted drug dealers, I immediately made the league security department aware of this and called the ballplayers in. I talked to them about having their pictures taken with these convicted drug dealers. And that was the extent of what I could do.'' Duper was warned to stay away from Aguilar after a photo surfaced showing the two men and a former Dolphin, Nat Moore, the team's security consultant, Stuart Weinstein, said. (AP)

title: Briefs
description: Debt

title: News Summary
description: International A3-21 The Soviet Union will cut its military, Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the United Nations and, hours later, said he would cut short his visit to the United States to return to Moscow because of a severe earthquake in Soviet Armenia. Page A1 The decision to cut Soviet forces was welcomed by Western officials as an important step toward constraining Moscow's capability to launch an attack on Western Europe. A1 An earthquake in the Soviet Union killed ''many people,'' devastating a mountainous section of western Armenia where the republic's second-largest city lies, officials said. A1 Mr. Gorbachev's Manhattan drive from Wall Street to Bloomingdale's was, as they say on the street where he stopped, a tour de force and a magical evening. Thousands lined Broadway. A19 At the Soviet-American meeting between the nation's leaders, the theme was continuity. President Reagan looked back on his past relations with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and George Bush symbolized the future. A17 Motorcade of surprises and quick stops A21 The Baltic republic of Estonia reaffirmed its recent decision that it had the right to veto Soviet law, underscoring its intention to seek increased sovereignty from Moscow despite Kremlin objections. A15 Yasir Arafat recognized Israel on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization. His statement was dismissed in Israel and greeted coldly by the State Department. A1 The Central Bank in Lebanon, the only government authority standing between the country and insolvency, is now in danger of becoming the latest victim of a worsening national strife after being hit by a grenade. A13 ''A new African information order'' is still considered the pressing need among African journalists, after five years' experience in the news agency business. They still criticize the West's information ''colonization'' of Africa. A3 Nicaragua releases last of July protesters it held A6 National A23-33, B18-25 Years of environmental abuses at Federal nuclear weapon plants have been revealed by an Energy Department study. The practices would have been illegal at nongovernment plants. A1 A proposal to build a new reactor at the Savannah River Plant was opposed by environmental officials and citizens in South Carolina who said the Dept. of Energy could not be trusted to perform the job safely. B18 Safest U.S. reactor is closing because it seldom runs B18 In the White House transition, the President-elect wants to keep Robert M. Teeter, a top campaign strategist and poll-taker, in a role that would be acceptable to Mr. Teeter and John Sununu. B20 In a bizarre case in Dallas, a former minister was ordered to pay $16 million for the lifetime care of his wife, who is in a coma after a strangling attack in which the minister has been a suspect. But questions remain. A24 More competition among doctors and for-profit medical-care providers may lead to increasing cases of price fixing and other antitrust violations, say law-enforcement officials and health-care authorities. A24 Odds reported in favor of cocaine smugglersqbe,a01:be,a01:23 Storehouse of the myths we love to shop for A24 Military trying to ease dependents' problems A29 Ex-F.B.I. agent jailed in teamster trial A31 29 Airlines fined for lax security at airports B21 Hospital says a few basic rules reduced its Caesarean rate B25 Washington Talk B22 Select group helps Bush fill top posts Regional B1-17 School officials sollicited money for a secret fund that was used to pay personal expenses, according to a report on an East Harlem school released by the Board of Education. B1 The role of the Board of Estimate was evaluated by the United States Supreme Court in a case that could determine the future structure of New York City's government. B1 Teamsters Local 560 has voted to return management of the union to associates of a convicted racketeer after more than two years of Federal control aimed at eliminating mob influence. B1 At 100, Hamilton Fish is going strong, recalling his years in Congress and battles with President Franklin D. Roosevelt. ''Now I don't hate Roosevelt,'' he said, ''but frankly I despise him.'' B1 The public health system is in danger of collapse in New York City, a group of senior doctors from the city's municipal hospitals said in an effort to focus attention on the fiscal health of the hospital system. B3 340 apartments have been rebuilt in 16 abandoned, city-owned buildings in Brooklyn and the Bronx, fulfilling part of a 10-year housing plan announced by the Koch administration in 1986. B2 A group of teen-agers returned $2,000 in cash and 14 credit cards that they found on a Manhattan street. In response, the owner decided to set up a scholarship fund at their school. B4 Nussbaum's sex-abuse testimony is doubted B3 Jury convictes 18-year-old of conspriacy in murder. B8. Dinkins ''seriously'' considers joining race for mayor B10. Neediest Cases B14

title: William Hill, 78, Dies; Management Adviser
description: William Edwin Hill, an international management consultant, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Freud's Influence
description: Sigmund Freud's influence on contemporary writers is to be the theme of a program Friday at 8 o'clock at the West side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Peter Gay, William Matthews, Cynthia Macdonald and Patrick Mahoney, a psychoanalyst, will read excerpts from their work. Tickets are available at the door; suggested contribution is $8. Information: 787-6557.

title: Islanders Dismiss Simpson As Arbour Comes Back
description: The moribund Islanders, crippled by their 7-18-2 record and paralyzed by an eight-game losing streak that has taken on a life of its own, chose the classic healing approach and dimissed Coach Terry Simpson today.

title: Bush's Choice for U.N. Carried Contra Appeal
description: Thomas R. Pickering, who is President-elect Bush's choice as Ambassador to the United Nations, played a brief role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Afghan Official Says Major Goal In Talks With Rebels Is Cease-Fire
description: A Vice President of Afghanistan said today that for his Government a lasting cease-fire was the most important goal in the negotiations between the Soviet Union and the Afghan guerrilla alliance based in Pakistan.

title: Exit of Soviet General Tied to Discord on Cuts
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision to make substantial reductions in the Soviet armed forces may have caused a highly unusual rift between the Soviet leader and the chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, according to American officials.

title: ESTONIA REAFFIRMS SOVEREIGNTY CLAIM
