description: The Baltic republic of Estonia today reaffirmed its recent assertion that it had the right to veto Soviet law, underscoring its intention to seek increased autonomy from Moscow despite Kremlin objections.

title: Change in Meet
description: The Vitalis-Meadowlands invitational track and field meet, scheduled for Feb. 10, will be conducted by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, it was announced today. The United States Olympic Committee ran the previous 19 meets but withdrew its involvement after last year's event.

title: Oil Reserve Is Rated Vulnerable to Terrorists
description: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve, this country's first line of defense against a foreign oil embargo, is vulnerable to a terrorist attack, Congressional investigators and Energy Department officials told a House subcommittee hearing today.

title: HEALTH: Doctors and Patients; A Surprisingly Painless Procedure: Asking the Surgeon 'How Much?'
description: Many patients might think it impossible to question doctors about their prices, but the New York City unit of the Carpenters Union Benefit Fund has found the task quite easy.

title: Shultz Is Cool to Arafat Remarks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reacted coolly yesterday to the comments in Stockholm by Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Soviets Approve Visit By Trotsky's Grandson
description: The grandson of Leon Trotsky said Tuesday that he had been given permission to visit the Soviet Union for the first time in 57 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Ethics Panel Reviews Status Of Inquiry on House Speaker
description: The House ethics committee met today and discussed its investigation of the House Speaker, Jim Wright.

title: Texas Utility Faces Claim
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company disclosed today that the Southern Company had asked a Federal court in Texas to force Gulf States to pay it an estimated $1.1 billion to settle a contract dispute between the two utility holding companies.

title: BANK OF LEBANON NOW A WAR TARGET
description: The central bank, the only government authority standing between Lebanon and insolvency, is in danger of becoming the latest victim of a worsening national strife.

title: U.S. Project To A.T.&T. And Sprint
description: After more than a year of delays that have cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars, the General Services Administration yesterday awarded the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the U S Sprint Communications Company contracts to replace the Government's antiquated telephone system. The contracts could be worth as much as $25 billion.

title: Superem Court Hears Arguments For and Against Estimate Board
description: The United States Supreme Court today heard sharply varying descriptions of the role of the New York City Board of Estimate as the justices considered a case that could determine the future structure of the city's government.

title: Jean Harris Makes Plea for Clemency
description: After serving more than seven years in prison for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, author of the best-selling ''Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet,'' Jean S. Harris is again asking Governor Cuomo to grant her clemency.

title: Review/Theater; Jeanette and Nelson, Together Again
description: The idea has charm: an affectionate evocation of Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy, the stars who made millions for M-G-M in the 1930's playing eternally young lovers in operettas. The show could kid them a little, but mainly it would provide an occasion for a soprano and a baritone all got up in period costumes to deliver everybody's favorites from such movies as ''Naughty Marietta,'' ''New Moon'' and ''Rose Marie'' sung in a gazebo, on a settee, before a screen decorated with a large heart. ''When I'm calling you/Ooh ooh ooh - ooh ooh!''

title: Officer Is Shot in Narcotics Raid And 6 Suspects Are Held in Bronx
description: A 28-year-old New York City police officer working with the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration was shot and seriously wounded yesterday in a narcotics raid in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Dow Adds 4.27 for 3d Gain in a Row
description: The stock market moved higher for the third straight session yesterday, but the current rally showed signs of slowing down.

title: Nuclear Reactor Plan Meets Strong Opposition in South Carolina
description: A proposal to build a new $3.6 billion nuclear weapon reactor at the Savannah River Plant near here was greeted today by opposition from state environmental officials, local elected leaders and private citizens who said the Department of Energy could not be trusted to perform the job safely.

title: Devils Finally Win as MacLean Scores 3 Goals
description: The Devils did several things tonight that were reminiscent of their play in last spring's playoffs and the result was their first victory in nine games.

title: Review/Music; Quartet Opts for the Gritty Over the Pretty
description: The Alexander String Quartet played with more passion than precision at its Tuesday evening concert at the 92d Street Y. But if there were lapses of intonation and tone, the ensemble's energy and its unusual coloration consistently held one's interest.

title: Westinghouse to Sell Unimation to Staubli
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Unimation robot and automation business to Staubli International A.G. of Zurich.

title: Books of The Times; Personal Relationships In a Cultural Rebellion
description: New York 1913 The Armory Show and the Paterson Strike Pageant By Martin Green Illustrated. 325 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Review/Dance; A Touch of Zen in Hawkins Premiere
description: The chaste and the sensuous meet on common ground in Erick Hawkins's choreography. So attuned are we to his celebration of nature - and the human body - that it is easy to overlook the firm and complex formal underpinnings of his dances.

title: Firstfed Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $487,000 gain from the sale of FHLMC preferred stock. Firstfed said it reported 1988 results on a new basis of accounting for loan origination fees without restating results for 1987. It said third quarter net was reduced by $789,000, or 11 cents a share, and 9-month net was reduced by $2,156,000, or 31 cents a share, due to the required change in accounting.

title: Rockwell to Buy Eaton's AIL Unit
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had agreed in principle to buy the Eaton Corporation's AIL subsidiary, which makes electronic countermeasures for the military. The terms have not been set, but the purchase price, which is subject to a review of AIL's business, will be at book value, the companies said.

title: Yankees Woo Hawkins After Trade Talks Fail
description: The Yankees were one of the first teams to leave the winter meetings today, departing in midafternoon without the pitcher they came here seeking.

title: Investing Fraud Case in London
description: The British financier Peter Clowes, whose Barlow Clowes investment group collapsed in May, was charged today with theft and conspiracy to steal more than $:22.5 million, or $41.5 million.

title: No New 'Phoros'
description: LEAD: The international money markets seem to have mastered lip reading.They know what

title: Man, 18, Guilty Of Conspiracy In '86 Murders
description: An 18-year-old, accused of helping plot the shooting deaths of his friend's father and brother, was convicted today of conspiracy and criminal facilitation but acquitted of murder.

title: John H. Geisse, 96, Aeronautical Inventor
description: John H. Geisse, a World War I aviator and aeronautical inventor, died of heart failure Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Indianaoplis. He was 96 years old and lived in Indianapolis.

title: No Smoking for Press
description: Although one of the stereotypes attached to reporters is the perpetual cigarette dangling from the lips or the cigar clenched between the teeth, the nonsmokers are a big enough majority in the Congressional press galleries these days that smoking restrictions are to go into effect there on Jan. 3. The reporters committee that oversees the Senate and House press galleries voted last week to bar smoking in the galleries, on the third floor of the Capitol, ''unless the individual wishing to smoke purchases and uses a smokeless ashtray/air-purifying device.''

title: Sears Is Extending Extra Credit
description: In its first such action nationally, Sears, Roebuck & Company has granted billions in added credit to 10 million Sears credit-card holders in an effort to increase holiday sales and clear out merchandise.

title: He Really Does Windows
description: SHE stands in a signature red suit, looking out the White House window at the Capitol, two American Airlines tickets held behind her back. Around her are stacks of books on astrology, some old movie stills, a papier-mache King Charles spaniel and a gaggle of geese a-laying.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Irwin Simms has become chairman and chief executive and Lee R. Lippman has become president and chief operating officer at Ketchum/Mandabach & Simms, a unit of Ketchum Communications.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan's trade surplus shrank to $1.15 billion in November from $1.21 billion in October and $1.51 billion in November 1987, the Government reported today.

title: 30 M.P.H. for Motorcade, 0 M.P.H. for the Rest of the Drivers
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's motorcade whizzed through Manhattan at 25 to 30 miles an hour yesterday. But for thousands of other motorists, driving was no less nasty, brutish or short than usual.

title: Indicted Securities Firm Says It Will Liquidate
description: Princeton/Newport Partners L.P., the New Jersey investment partnership whose top officers were charged in August with criminal racketeering, will liquidate because of the charges, lawyers for two of the defendants said yesterday.

title: NUCLEAR UNITS GET TIGHTER SECURITY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is imposing new regulations designed to strengthen protection against terrorist attacks at plants handling material that is capable of being used in nuclear weapons.

title: Service Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $21,200,000 aftertax charge related primarily to the discontinuance of casket assembly operations at five of the company's facilities. c-Net income

title: Review/Dance; Rituals Of Complex Relations
description: Susan Marshall took a brave and adventurous chance when she created a full-evening dance, her first, for the Next Wave Festival debut of Susan Marshall and Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But then Ms. Marshall has been following her own drummer for the five years she has been presenting dance in New York City, intently exploring and commenting on human relationships well before that was fashionable, and doing so with eloquence and humor.

title: 2 Cult Leaders Guilty In College Loan Case
description: Two leaders of the cult-like Circle of Friends were convicted today in a scheme to fraudulently obtain government-backed college loans with no plans of repaying them.

title: Icahn and Partner Buying Texaco Stock, Experts Say
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, and an unidentified partner have begun buying stock in Texaco Inc. as part of a proxy attempt to unseat James W. Kinnear as president and chief executive of the nation's third-largest oil company, oil industry officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error, a letter to the editor in The Living Section yesterday rendered a word incorrectly in referring to Marco Polo. The writer said Polo found that the Chinese (not the Christians) ate macaroni.

title: Doctors Should Have to Disclose Vested Interests in Care Facilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Parent & Child
description: FOR a growing number of working adults, the daily commute to the office is done without leaving home. Inexpensive personal computers, photocopiers and facsimile machines allow a much broader range of corporate employees and entrepreneurs to work out of a spare bedroom or a corner of the basement or dining room. For slightly more than half of these workers, there are children in the house or in the office for at least part of the workday.

title: Giants' Investment for the Future Pays Off in the Present
description: In the National Football League draft in April, the Giants wanted offensive-line help and a backup cornerback. So they took Eric Moore of Indiana, a big offensive tackle, on the first round; John (Jumbo) Elliott, a bigger offensive tackle from Michigan, on the second round and Sheldon White, a cornerback from Miami of Ohio, on the third round.

title: Van Buren Parallels
description: President-elect Bush this week celebrated his most memorable blooper as a candidate by throwing a party for 90-odd reporters who covered his every move during the campaign.

title: LDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.5 million from an accounting change.

title: Owners Setting Labor Strategy
description: Baseball's 26 club owners closed their winter meetings today with a three-hour preview of their labor negotiations and a possible strike by the players in 1990, and said they had unanimously agreed on a strategy.

title: Freddie Mac's First Sale Of 3- and 6-Month Notes
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is offering interest-bearing short-term notes in two parts totaling $1.5 billion.

title: Beyond Holly: Fragrant and Floral Ways to Deck the Halls
description: ALL is not lost if you have yet to find time to add a festive touch to your home for the holidays. Florists, geared to the challenge of a last-minute rush, are well supplied with berried branches and fragrant boughs and swags. It is always best to order early, but the following shops said they expected to be able to deliver the special trimmings listed below up to the 11th hour.

title: Virco Manufacturing Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are based on weighted average shares outstanding, 2,773,357 in 1988 and 1987, and are adjusted for a 10-percent stock dividend issued July 1, 1988.

title: Black Memorabilia: The Pride and the Pain
description: A GROWING number of blacks who once considered mammy dolls and other black memorabilia racist propaganda say they are now collecting these materials as a reminder of a period in American history that many consider painful and ugly.

title: Reagan News Session Scheduled for 8 P.M.
description: Presiden tReagan's White House news conference, scheduled for 8 o'clock tonight, will be covered live by ABCCBS,NBC, the Cable News Network and C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network. It will also be carried by public-television stations in many areas, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: Tenneco Stock Off
description: The stock price of Tenneco Inc. fell yesterday after one of its subsidiaries, the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, reported polychlorinated biphenyl contamination along its New England pipeline. The price of a Tenneco share closed 50 cents lower, at $49, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said Tuesday that it had found evidence of the hazardous waste pollution at 48 of 70 compressor stations along 14,000 miles of a natural gas pipeline that links south Texas to New England. Tenneco estimated the cleanup cost at $20 million to $30 million and said it was studying the problem.

title: Cuts in Culture Funds Are Target of a Protest
description: Leaders of New York cultural institutions have called for a demonstration this afternoon at City Hall to protest Mayor Koch's order to cut $2.5 million from the $74 million that the city's Department of Cultural Affairs gives to arts institutions.

title: For $2,000, Fast Lesson In Honesty
description: In the cosmic order of things, it doesn't rank with superpower summits or global economic developments.

title: U.S. Permits Airlines to Act On Easing Delays at O'Hare
description: The Transportation Department acted today to permit airlines using O'Hare International Airport to jointly propose schedule changes that might ease flight delays in and out of Chicago.

title: Calendar: Christmas at the Metropolitan
description: America and France, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; 212-879-5500.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we score any points, we can do it only together. If we try to score points alone, nothing good will happen.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A17:2. ]

title: New York Health Care Failure Charged
description: In an unusual outcry, a group of senior doctors from New York City's municipal hospitals said yesterday that the public health system is under such severe stress that it is in imminent danger of collapse.

title: Arab Economic Council Takes Egypt Back Into Membership
description: Egypt was unanimously voted back into the Council of Arab Economic Unity today, nine years after it wasexpelled for signing the Camp David treaty with Israel.

title: A Deliberate Pace On Filling Cabinet
description: Mr. Bush's Cabinet selection process has moved into a second stage in which, with the exception of Secretary of Defense, where John G. Tower remains the favorite, there are no clear front-runners. Thus, a narrowing process is under way, creating a much slower pace in terms of announcements and giving an impression of delay.

title: Will a $150 Super Team Please Rise
description: If old-timers keep wondering what ever happened to the good 5-cent cigar, young-timers must be wondering what ever happened to the good $50 Super Bowl ticket.

title: Cocaine Hoard Found in Plane
description: A maintenance worker found 154 pounds of cocaine above a ceiling panel in the restroom of an empty Pan Am plane on Tuesday, an airline spokeswoman said. The drugs were discovered about 45 minutes after the plane arrived here from Miami from Los Angeles. The Drug Enforcement Administration searched the plane, found no more cocaine and returned it to the airline this morning.

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Jailed in Teamster Trial
description: A man who was dismissed as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for lying has been jailed for refusing to testify against two officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who are charged with embezzlement and racketeering.

title: AS ISRAEL SEES IT, ANOTHER DECEPTION
description: Israel's leaders today dismissed the statement in which Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, apparently accepted Israel's existence.

title: Review/Television; Holmes, Hounds and Haunted Halls
description: The moors in Devonshire, spooky Dartmoor Hall, the apparent pawprints of an enormous dog, a corpse evidently dead of fright: we are back once again, of course, in Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's ''Hound of the Baskervilles.'' It's a hardy property, filmed in 1939 with Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce as Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson, and in 1959 with Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee. A 1972 television movie, starring Stewart Granger and William Shatner, was dreadful. A 1977 spoof was even worse, despite the participation of Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, who played not only Dr. Watson but also Holmes's mother.

title: USX Expects Gain
description: The chairman of the USX Corporation, the giant steel and energy company, said yesterday that he expects operating income for 1989 to exceed the results for this year. In a news conference in New York, David M. Roderick said that he expects USX to generate more than $1 billion in cash after its dividend payout and capital expenditures this year.

title: Terrence L. Smith Dies; Mystery Writer Was 46
description: Terrence Lore Smith, an author of mystery novels, died Wednesday in a traffic accident. He was 46 years old and lived in Woodland Park, Colo.

title: U.S. to Ease Backlog In Soviet Emigration, But Draws Criticism
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to ease the bottleneck on Soviet emigration to the United States, but some Congressional critics and American Jewish groups said the steps were inadequate.

title: ANTI-TERROR UNIT TO TALK STRATEGY
description: The interior ministers of the 12-member European Community, as well as senior American officials, convened in Athens today to discuss coordination of anti-terrorism measures against a background of recent major confrontations between five of the participating countries.

title: Checkups for Reagans Today At Bethesda Naval Hospital
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will go to Bethesda Naval Hospital on Friday for their annual cancer recovery checkups, the White House announced today.

title: Silent-Film Rarities
description: ''Fanfan la Tulipe'' and ''L'Atre'' (''Tillers of the Soil''), two silent-film rarities recently restored by the Cinematheque Francaise in Paris, are to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art this weekend. ''Fanfan'' - which became a star vehicle for Gerard Philipe in 1952 - is an eight-episode swashbuckler about a young soldier from Normandy; it will be shown two episodes at a time, today at 3 and 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 2:30 and 5:30. ''L'Atre,'' the story of two farmers and their love for the girl who was raised within their family, will be shown on Sunday at 2:30 and 5:30 P.M. Both films are to be shown with French intertitles and English voice-over; they are included in the museum admission fee of $6 ($3.50 for students; $3 for the elderly). Information: 708-9400.

title: Torrey's Pick More Than Nostalgia Trip
description: It was nine days ago that a traveler watched the New York Islanders trudge through the St. Louis airport. They looked worse than tired from the early wake-up call, worse than somebody might with a hangover. They looked whipped.

title: Zen Arts Sale
description: A historic Korean tea bowl, a scroll by the Zen Master Hakuin, an ancient vase and a 13th-century standing Buddha are among the objects that will be on sale at a Zen arts sale and exhibition, tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the New York Zendo, 223 East 67th Street. Information: 861-3333.

title: Aquino Arrested
description: Lupe Aquino lost a junior middleweight title fight and his freedom last night as the police in Detroit arrested him on vehicular manslaughter charges at ringside following the bout. Aquino showed up for the fight despite an arrest warrant issued after he missed a California court appearance on two counts of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving. He lost to John David Jackson when he failed answer the bell in the eighth round. Aquino was to be held until a bail hearing Friday morning. (AP)

title: Gorbachev's Journey; DIPLOMATIC GAINS CLAIMED BY WEST
description: Western diplomats claimed a victory over the Soviet Union here today, saying they had stripped a major Soviet initiative of practical significance after a three-year struggle.

title: Edward J. Quinn, Banker, 77
description: Edward J. Quinn, a retired banking executive, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Gorbachev's Journey; NATO Seeks Deeper Cuts From Soviets
description: NATO moved today to take the spotlight away from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, by proposing much deeper reductions in Soviet tanks and other conventional weapons than he announced on Wednesday.

title: Bond Offering Set By Connecticut
description: Connecticut is tentatively offering $100 million in general obligation capital appreciation bonds for a college savings plan through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

title: Soviet Troop Cuts Allay NATO Worries
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to reduce Soviet military forces in East Germany addressed head on NATO's concern that the Soviet Union could launch a surprise attack into West Germany during a time of crisis. American and other

title: Miami Loves N.B.A.'s Worst Team
description: When the Miami Heat played its first home game last month, Bill Kenchon brought along champagne and a cake in anticipation of the new basketball team's first victory.

title: Washington Finds Drug War Is Hardest at Home
description: In the last two years, the Washington police have made more than 44,000 arrests on narcotics charges in what is probably the most aggressive and well-publicized drive against drugs in the country.

title: Market Place; Question Marks About MGM/UA
description: AFTER six months of aborted restructuring plans, management defections and turmoil in its creative ranks, some semblance of calm has returned to the MGM/UA Communications Company. But in the eyes of Wall Street the motion picture and television studio's direction and prospects are more uncertain than ever.

title:
About Real Estate;
L.I. Rentals for Low-Income Elderly
description: LEAD: More than 1,600 people have applied to live in a a complex of 287 rental apartments for elderly people of low or moderate income that is being built in Smithtown, L.I.

title: Review/Film; Long-Lost Twin Brothers: Beauty and the Beast
description: The reports that Arnold Schwarzenegger has a gift for comedy, based on isolated double-entendres he has delivered in such films as ''Red Heat'' and ''The Terminator,'' turn out to have been premature.

title: Changes for Chiefs
description: Jack Steadman resigned yesterday as president of the Kansas City Chiefs, effective at the end of the season. Lamar Hunt, the owner, said Jim Schaaf, the general manager, would also not return next year.

title: Salomon to Shift $1.1 Billion to Its U.S. Operations
description: Salomon Inc. announced yesterday that it planned to shift $1.1 billion from a unit in Switzerland to its American operations, a move that would result in a $150 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings.

title: U.S. PLANE CRASHES INTO GERMAN CITY
description: A United States Air Force warplane plowed into a residential area of a West German city today, demolishing apartment buildings and leaving at least 4 people dead and 40 injured.

title: Addenda
description: * Edwin Bird Wilson has acquired Hirsch-Elliott, a recruitment and business-to-business ad agency.

title: Hurco Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS A Federal grand jury indicted a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on charges of insider trading. Robert A. Rough was accused of leaking confidential information on interest-rate policy. He resigned from the Fed in 1984. [ Page A1. ] S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman pleaded guilty to engaging in an illegal insider-trading scheme. Mr. Ruderman formerly broadcast the daily stock market radio reports of Business Week magazine. [ D5. ] Stock prices fell for the first time this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average pulling back by 11.92 points, to close yesterday at 2,141.71. Traders suggested that investors were looking ahead to next week, when a slew of economic reports will be released. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in slow trading. Yields on some short- and intermediate-term notes rose above bond yields. [ D13. ] The dollar retreated in calmer trading. [ D14. ] The price of copper soared to a record of $1.6325 a pound on the Comex, eclipsing the previous high of $1.60 on Nov. 24. [ D14. ] THE ECONOMY A G.S.A. appeals panel ruled that the Navy had violated Federal procurement laws in writing unfair specifications for a major computer contract that would apparently favor I.B.M. [ D1. ] Dividing the Government's telephone system into two parts could cost taxpayers about $1 billion in the next four years but should provide long-term benefits, experts said. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL The deadlock over agricultural policies continued at the GATT talks in Montreal and threatened to interfere with an agreement for cutting barriers in services. [ D1. ] Japan's Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa resigned, weakened by his implication in a stock trading scandal. [ A5. ] Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented Congress and President-elect Bush with an opportunity to break military spending's lock on the budget, politicians and economists say. [ A20. ] The proposed reduction of Soviet troops is unlikely to provide short-term benefits for the financial markets, Wall Street analysts said. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Competitors of A.T.& T. are likely to object to the company's proposals to provide promotional discounts for business customers, communications industry analysts said. [ D6. ] A New York State appellate court affirmed a ruling blocking Warner's acquisition of Lorimar. [ D1. ] Eastern Air Lines could soon face a cash shortage because it has been rapidly losing traffic from business travelers. [ D1. ] Salomon will shift $1.1 billion to its U.S. operations from a unit in Switzerland and take a $150 million charge against fourth-quarter profits to pay taxes on the move. [ D6. ] Thomas J. McElligott resigned from Fallon McElligott, the Minneapolis advertising agency he helped to found. [ D17. ] A Federal judge halted proceedings against the Hunt brothers by the Commodities Futures Trading Commission. [ D5. ] Fujitsu America will build an $80 million plant outside Dallas, filling a need for a more central location in the U.S. [ D4. ] The Justice Department will sue TBG, a New York-based manufacturing concern, seeking to block its proposed $127 million acquisition of Chase Brass and Copper. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS To cut military spending, Washington must make tough budget decisions. For Moscow, the problem is not just budgetary but how to change its inefficient system. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] A semblance of calm has returned to MGM/UA Communications, but in the eyes of Wall Street the studio's direction and prospects are more uncertain than ever. Market Place. [ D6. ] Tracy-Locke acquired Altschiller Reitzfeld in a move intended to improve its creative reputation. Advertising. [ D17. ]

title: Chairman Appointed In Succession at Alcan
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., the Montreal-based aluminum giant, said yesterday that it had named David Morton, president and chief operating officer, to succeed David M. Culver as chairman and chief executive.

title: Site 2 Journal; For These Huddled Masses, Only Warped Lives
description: Ten years after the Vietnamese invaded Cambodia, nearly 300,000 Cambodians still linger in camps like this one along the Thai-Cambodian border, unable to go home, unable to go to another country, unable to consider the basic decisions adults make about their lives.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'Let the K.G.B. Take My Picture!'
description: Dazed Americans have just been brushed by the kinetic political force of Mikhail Gorbachev. But how contagious is his uninhibited example? Are Soviet windows really opening? Go to Leningrad and the Baltic cities for a visit and you'll feel the breeze.

title: Court to Hear Arguments In Bond Case
description: The Washington State Supreme Court agreed today to hear new arguments in a civil case in which the state is accused of fraud and negligence by holders of the defaulted bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: Whalers Rally in 3d Period as Rangers Stumble Again
description: The long and winding road trip that crisscrossed the continent had taken its toll on the Rangers. Their lead in the Patrick Division had evaporated like a highway mirage and players had been left by the wayside in varying states of disrepair.

title: Editors' Note
description: A few articles yesterday about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's New York visit carried outdated references to his further travels, even in copies that reported his sudden decision to return to the Soviet Union. Such references occurred in a front-page article that mentioned Mr. Gorbachev's visit to Britain and in the TV Notes column, which discussed his planned trip to Cuba.

title: TALKS WITH LIKUD PLANNED BY LABOR
description: By a wide margin, the Labor Party's Central Committee voted tonight to resume coalition negotiations with the Likud party. The move came a week after the Labor party bureau, a smaller executive committee, narrowly voted to cut off the negotiations.

title: Chiefs Are a Scary Obstacle in Giants' Path to Playoffs
description: In 1986, the Giants beat the Washington Redskins in a crucial game in the 14th week of the season. They finished with handy victories over the St. Louis Cardinals and the Green Bay Packers, two teams with losing records, and went on to win Super Bowl XXI.

title: Co-founder of McFallon Ad Agency Quits
description: Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis, one of the nation's top small advertising agencies, has lost its creative director and co-founder.

title: South Korea's High-Tech Miracle
description: Earlier this year in a drab-looking building 25 miles from Seoul, the Samsung Corporation began mass-producing what most of the American electronics industry has abandoned: one-megabit chips, computer memory devices storing more than a million pieces of data.

title: Rising - Slowly - to Gorbachev's Challenge
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech to the United Nations, in its announcement of a dramatic reduction and redirection of Soviet conventional forces, is an event of high importance, and the first response of our own Government is excellent: President Reagan heartily approves and President-elect Bush agrees with him.

title: Runaway Juries and the High Court
description: Is there a constitutional right to be free from excessive damages in a civil lawsuit? Determined to find out, the Supreme Court has agreed to hear a company's argument that runaway jury verdicts violate the Eighth Amendment. The question, fascinating and increasingly germane to a litigious America, amply deserves airing.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Of Mundane Duties
description: While administrative assistants, those trusted lieutenants to members of Congress, have important responsibilities bearing on Federal policy and legislation, they are sometimes called upon to perform more mundane duties, like chauffeuring their bosses and their families to airports or cocktail parties.

title: Auctions
description: Stickley Family Items

title: Menorah Ruling: Little New Light
description: A Federal judge in Vermont has ruled that a 16-foot menorah may be displayed in City Hall Park in Burlington for the Jewish observance of Hanukkah, adding to the nationwide confusion surrounding the question of when religious symbols are permissible on public property.

title: Review/Opera; 'William Tell,' a Rarity, Is the Talk of the Towns
description: Riccardo Muti's choice of ''William Tell,'' one of the most important operas in both the French and Italian traditions but one of the most problematic, made the opening night of La Scala Wednesday even more of an event than it usually is in this city, where opera is still taken very seriously. In the afternoon, a recording of the Rossini opera blared from the loudspeakers of a department store. Advance coverage filled four pages in Corriere della Sera, the city's major newspaper. The ticket office of the opera house was deserted, as posters declared in several languages: ''All performances of 'William Tell' are completely sold out in all sections.'' The opera is front-page news all over Italy.

title: Ms. Carter, Executive, Marries Jeffrey Starr
description: Carolyn Carter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carter of Wheaton, Ill., and Jeffrey Starr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Starr of Walpole, Mass., were married yesterday in the Tillman Chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. Judge Theodore R. Kupferman of the New York State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe Marks 30th With Gala at City Center
description: The program listed him as William Cosby and he spent most of the evening as a compere in orange tights with torso bare, stocking cap on his head - a dancer, he noted, more aspiring than perspiring.

title: Dining Out Guide: Festive
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. The Nice

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Yasir Arafat's meeting with a delegation of American Jews misidentified the man at the right. He was Stanley Sheinbaum, a member of the American delegation, not Foreign Minister Sten Andersson of Sweden.

title: Instrument Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $961,000 for both the quarter and year, and a tax charge of $30,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,720,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $1,200,000 and $4,670,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a loss on discontinued operations and their disposal of $1,236,000 and a $1,502,000 loss on early extinguishment of debt. The company said the latest year includes a $1,800,000 gain on termination of a pension plan. The company also said the share earnings were reduced by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Economic Scene; Gorbachev Move: West's Response
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV's speech before the United Nations, pledging a cutback of Soviet armed forces and redeployment of troops and tanks from Eastern Europe, lifted spirits on Wall Street as stocks and the dollar went up. The exuberance stemmed from the assumption that the Soviet leader had cleared the way for the United States to reduce its military spending. That would shrink the overall budget deficit and permit Mr. Bush to keep his campaign promise not to raise taxes.

title: Knicks Find the Mark With 11 3-Point Field Goals, an N.B.A. Record
description: The Knicks set a National Basketball Association record for 3-point field goals last night and needed all of them to defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 113-109, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Yorkers' reactions to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit described a scene at the New York Stock Exchange incorrectly in some copies. When it became clear that the man ringing the closing bell was not Mr. Gorbachev but Gordon Brooks, a floor partner, the cheers from the floor grew louder; they did not stop.

title: Navy Broke Bid Rules, Panel Finds
description: A General Services Administration appeals panel ruled yesterday that the Navy had violated Federal procurement laws in writing unfair specifications for a major computer contract that appear to favor the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the election of officers by Teamster Local 560 in New Jersey misidentified a former United States Attorney for New Jersey. He is W. Hunt Dumont.

title: 5 Indicted in Steroid Case
description: Two companies and five people were indicted today on charges of manufacturing and distributing more than $1 million worth of steroids to individuals, including athletes, in several states.

title: Ulanhu, 82, a Mongol Who Rose To High Posts in Beijing, Is Dead
description: Ulanhu, a former deputy chairman of the Chinese National People's Congress who fought for Mongolian rights during his long political career, died today, the official New China News Agency said. He was 82 years old.

title: Why Hedda Nussbaum Fascinates: Most Can Identify
description: Hedda Nussbaum, it seemed, was everywhere in New York this week. And everywhere, people were drawn to her story. Why are we so fascinated? Quite simply, people wonder what separates her from them. Her very ordinariness, experts in human behavior say, is the attraction, a reminder that even a life with all the trimmings of stability can slide into disarray.

title: Furor Among Laureates Is Stuff of Peace Prizes
description: Two competing dinners for past American winners of the Nobel Prize, one in New York, one in Washington, will be held Friday night, and the acrimony is sharp enough to suggest that anyone who could mediate the dispute might qualify for one of the peace prizes.

title: Corrections $61#YES#
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article about catalogue retailing misstated the number of catalogues mailed by L. L. Bean in its 1988 fiscal year. The number is 85 million, not 8.5 million.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; A judge-maker learns what it is to win support, to be nominated and then to lose.
description: Few lawyers knew more about how judges are made than Stuart Summit. For 12 years, he helped two Mayors of New York select judicial appointees, and then he spent 9 more combing through candidates for the state's highest court.

title: Review/Opera; Stravinsky and Busoni By Students
description: When the Metropolitan Opera revived Stravinsky's first opera, ''Le Rossignol,'' in 1981, it followed the tradition established by Diaghilev at the premiere in 1914, with dancers miming the leading roles and singers relegated to the orchestra pit. The visual effects achieved this way may well be wonderful, but when the characters do their own singing ''Le Rossignol'' can take on the feel of the genuine opera that the composer originally intended it to be.

title: A Broken Leg That Led to City Hall
description: A twist of fate, or more precisely a broken leg, placed Stanley Edward Grayson on a relatively straight but steep career path to law, then to government. Yesterday, Mayor Koch named him Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.

title: Guilty Plea Is Entered In Business Week Case
description: S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, who formerly broadcast the daily stock market radio reports of Business Week magazine, pleaded guilty yesterday to engaging in an illegal insider-trading scheme.

title: Verdict is Split in Gander Crash Inquiry
description: Almost three years after 248 United States soldiers died in an air crash in Newfoundland, Canadian investigators went public today with an internal dispute over whether the crash was caused by ice or by an explosion.

title: Veeco Instruments Inc reports earnings for
Presidents News Conference on Foriegn and Domestic Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Short-Term Rates Continue Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in slow trading yesterday.

title: Turnaround Specialist Joins MacDonald & Co.
description: Frank T. Alfieri, a chief financial officer but never a chief in his corporate career, is now in the investment banking business and has been named chairman of MacDonald & Company, a small financial consulting firm.

title: Illegal Abortions Grow Into African Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Connelly, Actor, 47
description: Christopher Connelly, who starred in the television series ''Peyton Place'' and ''Paper Moon,'' died Wednesday of cancer. He was 47 years old.

title: To Revive Schools, Dump Bureaucrats
description: LEAD: If New York and other cities are to save their staggering public schools, they must first kill off their central educational bureaucracies.

title: Trade Talks Fail to Reach Accord
description: Major nations failed to reach agreement late last night on plans to revamp the world trading system and are considering a proposal to freeze what progress they have made in some areas for a four-month period.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEY RATES
Rumor of LSD-Tainted Tattoos Called Hoax
description: Taken in by a hoax, parents, school officials and doctors in New Jersey are warning children about what they have been led to believe is a new insidious drug hazard. But there is apparently no such threat, officials said.

title: NATO Proposes Arms Cut
description: NATO moved to take the spotlight away from Mikhail S. Gorbachev by proposing much deeper cuts in Soviet tanks and other arms than he had announced Wednesday. Page A19.

title: NAVY IS RELAXING GULF PROTECTION
description: The Navy is further relaxing protection of Persian Gulf shipping, no longer requiring warships to keep oil tankers in sight and permitting its ships in and near the gulf to steam farther from their stations for shore leave and resupply, Administration officials said today.

title: Soderstrom and Levine
description: The soprano Elisabeth Soderstrom and James Levine, the pianist and music director of the Metropolitan Opera, are to give a joint recital at 8 P.M. Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. The program is to include works by Stenhammar, Dubuque, Weckerlin, Tchaikovsky, Kilpinen, Grieg, Bartok, Previn, Canteloube, Mussorgsky, Haydn, Mahler and Schubert. Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: South Africa Sentences 4 Dissidents
description: A Pretoria judge today sentenced four South African blacks prominent in the domestic campaign against apartheid to prison terms ranging from 6 to 12 years for treason, formally ending one of the longest political trials in South Africa's history.

title: Infant Diarrhea Kills Hundreds Yearly in U.S.
description: Diarrhea, an easily treated illness not thought to be a major cause of death in the United States or other developed countries, kills hundreds of infants in the United States each year, most in the South, according to a study by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: American Passage Marketing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $255,000 for the quarter and $571,000 for the year, and the year also includes a loss from the settlement of a lawsuit of $1,362,000 and a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $229,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $329,000 and $562,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Fiscal 1988 net from continuing operations includes a pretax expense of $1,348,000 for a terminated merger.

title: Aegon Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. U.S. dollars equivalents are at the exchange rate of $1 equal Dfl 1.978 prevailing at Sept. 30, 1988 for both 1988 and 1987 periods.

title: Big Changes For Subways Are to Begin
description: Major changes in New York City's mass transit system - including the opening of the first new subway stations in 20 years -will begin this Sunday, affecting every borough except Staten Island and 14 of the 19 subway lines named for letters of the alphabet.

title: Review/Film; An Alien Who's Cute And Curvy
description: In ''My Stepmother Is an Alien,'' Kim Basinger plays a creature from another galaxy who is sent to Earth to sweet-talk a scientist into revealing secrets that will save her planet. The alien, called Celeste, is supposed to be an outstandingly brilliant individual who is well qualified for the task at hand. Her methods: cooking elaborate meals for the scientist, going to bed with him and wowing him with her delightfully birdbrained manner. When this doesn't do the trick, Celeste consults with three male elders from her planet, who recommend she turn on even more charm.

title: Oneita Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures are pro forma. The net income and share earnings for all periods have been restated and include an adjustment for income taxes, which is the estimated federal income tax provision, as adjusted for other pro forma items, which would have been recorded by Oneita on a separate return basis. The company is a subsidiary of Instrument Systems Corp. As a result of an intitial stock offering in July, the company will be required to file a separate federal income tax return.

title: Japan's Finance Minister Resigns in Stock Scandal
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa resigned today, the first senior politician to fall victim to a widening stock scandal.

title: Paul Heitner, 49, Dies; Leading Bridge Player
description: Paul Heitner, one of Canada's leading contract-bridge players, died of heart failure early Thursday. He was 49 years old and lived in Brampton, Ontario.

title: Review/Music; Jimmy Heath's Brand of Be-Bop
description: Like many of the other members of his generation, the be-bop tenor saxophonist and composer Jimmy Heath has become immensely sophisticated, and hardly restrained by the rules of his esthetic background. His show on Tuesday night, at a new club on 59th Street, Via Mia, was overflowing with both the rigors of be-bop and the experimental bravery of the rest of modern jazz history.

title: Police Leave Queens House Where Drug Witness Lived
description: Teams of New York City police sentries, assigned to guard an empty house in southeast Queens where a witness in a drug case once lived, were quietly withdrawn this week after nine months of serving a largely symbolic function in the crack-plagued neighborhood, the authorities said yesterday.

title: In Legal Aid Chicken Coop, the Fox Is King
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Record in Korea
description: South Korean automobile production today surpassed the one million mark in a single year for the first time. The nation's auto makers said production since the start of the year totaled 1,000,660. The tally is expected to reach 1.09 million vehicles by the end of the year, compared with 979,739 in 1987, they said.

title: U.S. Will Challenge Chase Brass Takeover
description: In one of its infrequent antitrust actions, the Justice Department said yesterday that it had advised TBG Inc., a New York-based manufacturing concern, that it intended to file a civil suit to block its proposed $127 million acquisition of the Chase Brass and Copper Company.

title: Gorbachev's Journey; Gorbachev Plan Seen Helping Deficit
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has presented Congress and President-elect Bush with a bolt-from-the-blue opportunity to break the lock of military spending on the Federal budget, many politicians and economists say.

title: I.R.A. Blast at Army Housing
description: A car bomb planted by the I.R.A. exploded at a British Army housing project today and an army spokesman said two people were treated for shock. The Irish Republican Army telephoned a warning about 30 minutes before the blast near the married soldiers' quarters in Lisburn, the army's Northern Ireland headquarters, about six miles south of Belfast. The spokesman said a policeman and a soldier treated for shock were the only casualties.

title: 4 Shootings in 4 Nights Terrify L.I. Town
description: Tonight, as the police here were trying to discern a pattern in three shootings on three successive nights within about one square mile here, a fourth man was shot in the same area.

title: Purdue Strikes Early to Top Connecticut
description: Steve Sheffler scored 15 of his 21 points in the first half tonight and Purdue went on to an 88-73 victory over Connecticut.

title: EAC Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,100,000. c-Net loss d-Includes net of $107,000 for the quarter and a loss of $932,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations.

title: Justice Brennan Enters Hospital in Bethesda
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the United States Supreme Court was hospitalized today for treatment of pneumonia.

title: Review/Concert; Korean Musicians in Benefit
description: With industry and intelligence, the Korea Music Foundation works hard to support emerging careers in New York. Its chosen musicians for a benefit concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night - both of them established artists - were an excellent advertisement for such efforts.

title: Atwood Oceanics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
For Afghans, Surviving to 5 Is Tough Task
description: In one of the world's poorest countries, where billions have been spent, mainly by the Soviet Union and the United States, to make war for nine years, the total international spending for humanitarian aid is less than $10 million a year.

title: The Bomb on Mr. Bush's Desk
description: Among the more pressing problems President-elect Bush will inherit from his predecessor next month, after the $148 billion budget deficit and the $50-to-100-billion savings and loan crisis, is a nuclear issue. America has at present lost its capacity to make tritium, an essential ingredient of nuclear weapons.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, a unit of Grey Advertising, has completed print and television ads for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York.

title: Over Protest From Nurses' Group, A.M.A. Will Train Hospital Aides
description: Despite objections from the nursing profession and some doctors, the American Medical Association is going ahead with plans to train a new type of hospital worker who would provide bedside care.

title: Israeli Aircraft Raid Targets Near Beirut
description: Israeli warplanes attacked guerrilla bases in the hills overlooking the coastal town of Naameh south of here early today, the police said.

title: Last Chance For Thomas To Rebound
description: It is a familiar boxing story: the battle-worn former champion trying for his last chance at glory by proving his mettle against the best contender moving hard through the ranks.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Forget the Deficit; a Real Crisis Is Looming: Raises
description: When the members of Congress, who had been paying themselves $6 for each day they met, voted in 1816 to increase their salaries to $1,500 a year, the public outcry was so great the pay raise was repealed the next year.

title: Gorbachev's Journey; Pressing Rock Masses Mark Center of Quake
description: The earthquake that caused catastrophic destruction in Soviet Armenia on Wednesday occurred in a zone where several great plates of the earth's surface converge, with occasionally devastating consequences.

title: Changes in Subway Service
description: The F, L, and M lines are unaffected by the transit changes. A. Begins express service in Brooklyn from Hoyt-Schermerhorn Street to Euclid Avenue from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.; previous express ran only at rush hours. B. Resumes regular route, interrupted in 1986, from 168th Street in Manhattan to Coney Island, Brooklyn, on the Avenue of the Americas instead of Broadway in Manhattan. C. Operates from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. instead of just rush hours. During midday, however, it will terminate at 145th Street in Manhattan. D. Resumes old Avenue of the Americas route between Bronx and Brooklyn 24 hours a day. K. Service ends. C line replaces it. N. Will use the Montague Street tunnel and will no longer use the Manhattan Bridge in off-peak hours. More trains to be put in service to compensate for elimination of Broadway express service in Manhattan. Q. Shifts from Broadway to Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, running rush hours from 57th Street to Brighton Beach, express. E. Terminates in Queens at Jamaica Center instead of 179th Street. J, Z. Continues past 121st Street, its old terminus in Queens, to Jamaica Center. Also begins skip-stop express service inbound to Manhattan A.M. and outbound P.M. The new Z trains will run simultaneously, making alternate skip stops with the J. R. Continues past its old terminus at Continental Avenue in Queens to 179th Street.

title: Tracy-Locke Acquires Altschiller
description: IN a move intended to improve its creative reputation and give it a needed outpost in New York, Tracy-Locke, the Dallas-based subsidiary of the Omnicom Group, yesterday acquired Altschiller Reitzfeld, a small agency with impeccable creative credentials.

title: Holidays for Children: A Multiple-Choice List
description: THIS year's holiday revelries for children feature brightly painted puppets, giant teddy bears and big silly cartons that can sing and dance. There are fearsome-looking pirates who sing sweetly and even a tiny cricket that helps people to enjoy this festive season.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Pylon Reunited

title: Tribute to a 1908 Durant in the Auto's Future
description: Most schoolchildren here know who founded the Ford Motor Company, and nearly everybody has heard of Walter P. Chrysler, but does anyone recall who started General Motors, was its first chief executive and twice managed to blunder away control of the company?

title: New Account for Chalk
description: Chalk & Partners has received a big boost from British Knights athletic footwear, a division of Jack Schwartz Shoes Inc. that sells $90 million of sneakers a year. Howard W. Chalk, president of the agency, said the account would bill $6 million annually and would include consumer advertising in television, radio and print as well as trade advertising and promotions. The account brings the agency's billings to $18 million. When he founded his shop two years ago at the age of 64, Mr. Chalk said his goal was to have $25 million in billings within three years. He is ahead of schedule.

title: DOCTOR IS ACCUSED OF 'IMMORAL' TESTS
description: Agynecologist performed experimental surgery on women for two decades without their knowledge, the State Medical Board said today, as it charged him with gross immorality and other violations of professional ethics.

title: Air Panel Delays Censure of U.S.
description: Turning back demands for an immediate censure of the United States, the governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization has ordered a report on the shooting down of an Iranian airliner sent to an internal commission for review.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about nominations for the National Book Critics Circle Awards included an erroneous title issued by the organization for a collection of short stories by Raymond Carver. The book is ''Where I'm Calling From.''

title: Books of The Times; Digging Into the Kirov Assassination
description: Stalin and the Kirov Murder By Robert Conquest 164 pages. Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: What Happened to Dad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Flyers Muscle Past Penguins
description: Pelle Eklund scored two goals as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated Pittsburgh, 4-3, in a penalty-filled game tonight.

title: Edward M. Benton, Lawyer, 82
description: Edward M. Benton, a lawyer and counsel to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wells Fargo's Banking Bids
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the San Francisco-based banking company, is seeking to buy a small bank in California and possibly a large one in Texas.

title: Objections to A.T.&T. Sales Plan Likely
description: Competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are likely to object to its proposals to provide promotional discounts for business customers, communiciations industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Leaders of the Year
description: The safety Mark Blazek, who led the University of Nebraska in tackles and interceptions, was honored yesterday as the Toyota/CBS Leader of the Year. The senior is a co-captain and has a 3.96 grade-point average in social-science education.

title: Nets Change Lineup
description: The Nets, who have lost 12 of their 19 games and the last 5 in a row, are making another change in their starting lineup. Lester Conner will replace John Bagley at point guard for the game tonight in Charlotte, N.C., against the Hornets. Coach Willis Reed said the change had been prompted by Bagley's recent shooting slump, as well as Conner's strong play off the bench.

title: On Stage
description: Kathleen Turner in 'Cat'

title: Meredith Monk
description: The composer, pianist and vocalist Meredith Monk and the pianist Nurit Tilles are to give the world premiere of their collaborative work, ''Fayum Music,'' at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The program also includes several works of Ms. Monk's, among them selections from her ''Do Be You'' recording, and music from her film ''Ellis Island.'' Tickets are $15 to $25. Information: 840-2824.

title: Amrep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,500,000 from an accounting change.

title: VISIT TO NEW YORK IS CUT A DAY SHORT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev left New York for Moscow yesterday, cutting short a triumphant diplomatic mission to deal with the aftermath of an earthquake reported to have killed tens of thousands in Soviet Armenia.

title: NATO Statement on Arms Control
description: Following are excerpts from the arms control statement issued today by NATO Foreign Ministers:

title: Gorbachev's Journey; For East Bloc, Possible Economic Relief
description: The decision by the Soviet Union to cut its conventional weapons carries the possibility of considerable economic relief for some parts of Eastern Europe, but also of accelerated political change.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Pivotal Role

title: People
description: * Donald Buckley has been named Eastern director of advertising and publicity for Warner Brothers Inc.

title: General Host Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $12,200,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary loss of $1,650,000. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $607,000 for the quarter and $65,329,000 for the 9 months. The company said the loss from discontinued operations in the latest third quarter represents a provision resulting from a November 1988 decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the tenth circuit upholding a 1987 judgment against the company and a subsidiary in a 1977 saltwater pollution lawsuit.

title: Review/Art; Morley's Careful Frenzy
description: Malcolm Morley's paintings in recent years have had a headlong, all-risking quality. This is owed in part to his readiness to go way over the top with the paint, apparently heedless of whether the image gets momentarily lost. This effect is intensified by the dive-bomber's perspective that he often uses.

title: Going to the Country to Choose a Tree
description: Back in 1901, W. V. McGalliard planted 25,000 Norway spruce seedlings on his farm just outside Trenton. Six years later, when they had grown large enough to be Christmas trees, he sold them for $1 apiece to people who came to choose their own trees for the holiday.

title: A Resignation At Genentech
description: Dr. Ralph Snyderman, senior vice president of medical research and development for Genentech Inc., will leave in the spring to become chancellor for health affairs and dean of the School of Medicine at Duke University. Dr. Snyderman, who came to

title: Gorbachev's Journey; Out of Grief, Seeking Trust Of Armenians
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's task is now to reforge out of grief and urgent necessity Armenia's lost trust in Moscow.

title: DIOCESE IN SEATTLE COULD REGAIN RULE
description: Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen says a talk with Vatican officials left him hopeful that the Seattle Roman Catholic Archdiocese would soon be operating normally.

title: Pillsbury Wins Insurance Ruling
description: A jury found that the Pillsbury Company sustained nearly $50 million in losses from 1984 to 1986 because of publicity on its use of a pesticide, Pillsbury said. The Hennepin County District Court jury's decision is the result of claims by Pillsbury against five insurance companies, in which Pillsbury sought restitution for its losses. The case involves a $150 million policy issued by the National Union Fire Insurance Company, the Royal Indemnity Company, the Employers Mutual Casualty Company, the Home Insurance Company and the Federal Insurance Company.

title: Review/Film; An Isle of Danger in 'Troma's War'
description: Troma Inc. has by now made a number of films (like ''Squeeze Play,'' ''The Toxic Avenger'' and ''Surf Nazis Must Die'') without compromising its amateur status in the slightest. So sex, gore, bathroom jokes, putrescence and idiot humor remain the hallmarks of the Troma style. In ''Troma's War,'' the balance has shifted slightly to favor burning stuntmen and gruesome (if cheesily unconvincing) makeup effects, but the sensibility remains the same. It's hard to imagine who, other than Troma relatives and Troma friends, makes up the audience for these things.

title: Addmaster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Falls 11.92 Points; Volume Off
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell for the first time this week, as the Dow Jones industrial average pulled back by 11.92 points to close yesterday at 2,141.71.

title: Yanks Sign Hawkins To $3.6 Million Pact
description: Continuing a spending spree not seen since 1982, the Yankees today exceeded the next highest offer by $1.6 million and signed Andy Hawkins, a free-agent pitcher, to a three-year contract for $3.6 million.

title: Eastern Air's Head Cites Cash Problem
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. could soon face a cash shortage because it has been rapidly losing traffic from business travelers in recent months, the company's president said today.

title: Farley Extends Bid for Pepperell
description: Farley Inc. extended its $1.4 billion unsolicited tender offer for West Point-Pepperell Inc. until midnight next Wednesday. Farley's $48-a-share offer for the Georgia-based textiles maker had previously been scheduled to expire on Wednesday. This is the third extension of the offer.

title: Gorbachev's Journey; Ideals According to Gorbachev: A Call for Tolerance and the End of Force
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda decided to title the speech ''To Put an End to the Era of Wars and Confrontations,'' but it was, in fact, ''The World According to Gorbachev.''

title: Cushman Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $52,000 gain on forgiveness of accounts payable and a $150,000 tax credit. c-Net loss and after a $142,000 gain on termination of a pension plan.

title: Double Honor
description: One day after being voted the winner of the Outland Trophy, Tracy Rocker, an Auburn defensive tackle, received the Lombardi Award last night as the top offensive or defensive lineman in balloting by 227 college football coaches, sports writers and sportscasters. Rocker beat out the linebackers Broderick Thomas of Nebraska and Derrick Thomas of Alabama and the defensive tackle Mark Messner of Michigan. (AP)

title: TOLL PUT IN TENS OF THOUSANDS FROM QUAKE IN SOVIET ARMENIA; GORBACHEV FLIES HOME FROM U.S.
description: A devastating earthquake that struck Soviet Armenia on Wednesday killed tens of thousands of people, Soviet and Armenian officials said today. They described the quake as the worst in the region in more than 80 years and one of the worst in Soviet history.

title: MICE IN AIDS STUDY KILLED IN ACCIDENT
description: The only colony of mice genetically altered to carry genes of the AIDS virus in every cell was all but wiped out over the weekend, apparently when power was turned off for maintenance work at the National Institutes of Health.

title: After a Year, Palestinians Call Uprising Stagnant
description: As the Palestinian uprising begins its second year today, its leaders acknowledge that the revolt has grown stagnant, running more on inertia than new ideas.

title: Ruling Against Warner Merger Is Upheld
description: Warner Communications Inc., the records, film and publishing company, has encountered another legal setback to its $1.2 billion acquisition of Lorimar Telepictures Inc.

title: Article 277088 -- No Title
description: The Boston Water and Sewer Commission has tentatively priced $57.9 million in general revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 7.65 percent for an issue due in 2006, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Interco to Close 2 Shoe Factories
description: Interco Inc. said its Florsheim Shoe Company division would close plants in Paducah, Ky., and Hermann, Mo., early next year. The plants employ 650 workers. The closings will save more than $2 million a year, Interco said.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding are retroactively restated to give effect to the 5 percent stock dividend declared on Sept. 15, 1988. The increase in net income resulted primarily from improved profit margins.

title: People Magazine Offer
description: People magazine is celebrating its 15th year by offering advertisers a bonus ad in any of the magazine's regional or demographic editions if they buy space in its special, March 6 anniversary edition, which closes Jan. 15. Advertisers running a national four-color or black-and-white ad or an insert will receive an equivalent ad sometime during 1989 that could reach up to 15 million readers.

title: Gifts for Neediest Cases Are A Holiday Tradition for Many
description: Every day during the eight-day festival of Hanukkah, Rosalyn and Patricia Gebhart of Manhattan have sent a check for $18 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Those donations represent gifts to certain friends and relatives.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable figures for the year-ago first quarter are not available as the company changed its fiscal year-end from Feb. 29 to June 30.

title: Shares Sold In Continental
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had sold 50 million shares of the Continental Illinois Corporation to an underwriting syndicate, a move that will raise $250 million and help offset the $4 billion committed in the 1984 rescue of the Chicago-based bank.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY THE HOLLYWOOD GOSPEL

title: TV Weekend; A Biography of Callas
description: In ''Maria Callas: An Operatic Biography,'' the legendary soprano has been given the kind of treatment she demands. The British documentary is adoring, critical, gossipy and bitchy - perfectly suited to the heightened emotion normally associated with grand opera.

title: Our Towns; Recyling Splits The Junkmen From the Boys
description: For most of his 76 years, Michael Lobosco was known as a - how to put this discreetly? ''Junkman,'' said Mr. Lobosco. Yes, that's it. His father started the family business 60 years ago, riding the streets on a wagon, collecting rags and paper. Yet today no one would dare call R. Lobosco & Sons junkmen. ''Recycling,'' said Mr. Lobosco, clearly enjoying the sound of it. ''It's a new name for us.''

title: Wary Optimism Greets Plan on Soviet Troops
description: The proposed realignment and reduction of Soviet troops in Europe and Asia is unlikely to provide short-term benefits for the financial markets, Wall Street strategists and analysts said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Court Upsets Murder Conviction
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today reversed the conviction of a murder suspect, ruling that a Mercer County Superior Court erred in the selection of the jury that sentenced James Edwards Williams to death in 1984.

title: Accounts
description: * Benihana, a Japanese restaurant chain, to Romann & Tannenholz, with a $3.5 million budget.

title: The Big Winners in the Free-Agent Market
description: The biggest contracts signed by free agents this off season (where there is a second total, it includes a nonguaranteed option year). Nolan Ryan, Rangers 1 year, $2 million (2 years, $3.2 million): $200,000 signing bonus, $1.6 million salary, option $1.4 million or $200,000 buyout. Bruce Hurst, Padres 3 years, $5.25 million: $400,000 signing bonus, salaries of $1.6 million, $1.5 million, $1.75 million. Steve Sax, Yankees 3 years, $4 million: $500,000 signing bonus, salaries of $1.1 million, $900,000, $1.5 million. Mike Moore, Athletics 3 years, $3.95 million: $500,000 signing bonus, salaries of $1,025,000, $1,025,000, $1.4 million. Scott Fletcher, Rangers 3 years, $3.9 million (4 years, $4.7 million): salaries of $1.2 million, $1 million, $1.3 million, option $1.2 million or $400,000 buyout. Andy Hawkins, Yankees 3 years, $3.6 million: $400,000 signing bonus, salaries of $800,000, $1 million, $1.4 million. Mike Marshall, Dodgers 3 years, $3.5 million: $300,000 signing bonus, salaries of $1 million, $1 million, $1.2 million. Dave Henderson, Athletics 3 years, $2.8 million: $300,000 signing bonus, salaries of $750,000, $750,000, $1 million. Tom Niedenfuer, Mariners 2 years, $1.75 million (3 years, $2.6 million): salaries of $800,000, $800,000, option $1 million or $150,000 buyout. Option year becomes vested if he pitches in 50 games in 1990. Jeffrey Leonard, Mariners 2 years, $1.75 million (3 years, $2.6 million): salaries of $800,000, $800,000, option $1 million or $150,000 buyout. Option year becomes vested if he has 550 plate appearances in 1990. Dave LaPoint, Yankees 3 years, $2,575,000: salaries of $825,000, $850,000, $900,000. Jesse Orosco, Indians 2 years, $1,675,000 (3 years, $2,525,000): $50,000 signing bonus, salaries of $800,000, $825,000, option $850,000. Option year becomes vested if he pitches in 53 games in either year or in 95 games both years. Bob Walk, Pirates 3 years, $2.5 million: salaries of $800,000, $850,000, $850,000. Tom Herr, Phillies 2 years, $1.65 million: salaries of $825,000, $825,000. Rick Mahler, Reds 2 years, $1.58 million: salaries of $790,000, $790,000.

title: Federal Express Eurobond Issue
description: Federal Express Finance P.L.C. is issuing $:75 million, or about $138.1 million, in 12 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. It features an investor ''event risk'' put option.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boston Consulting Group, Boston, which is engaged in business strategy consulting, named as senior vice presidents Rudyard L. Istvan and Burkhard F. Wittek.

title: Developer in Talks To Buy 2 Retailers
description: Kevin F. Donohoe, a Philadelphia real-estate developer, is the final bidder for the Woodward & Lothrop department stores in Washington and the John Wanamaker stores in Philadelphia, according to retail and real-estate executives. The two retail chains were put up for sale by the Taubman Investment Company, controlled by A. Alfred Taubman.

title: Antismoking Effort
description: Antismoking Educational Services is calling on elementary, junior high and high school students to participate in the New York City Antismoking Ad Contest. Prizes totaling $60,000 will be awarded to winners and their schools. The deadline is March 31. Information may be obtained by calling 269-3843 or writing to Antismoking Educational Services, c/o Joe Cherner, 375 South End Avenue, Suite 32F, New York, N.Y. 10280.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airco, Murray Hill, N.J., the U.S. gases business of the BOC Group of Britain, agreed to buy the Industrial Gases and Carbon Dioxide divisions of Amerigas Inc., a subsidiary of UGI Corp., for about $171.5 million.

title: E.P.A. RECORD SET IN POLLUTION CASES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it took a record number of enforcement actions last year against violators of pollution laws.

title: Athletes' Pact On Drug Tests
description: East Germany, which finished second in medals won at the Summer Olympics, is seeking to join the agreement on drug testing of athletes reached last month between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Fails to Carry Out Law To Improve Nursing Homes
description: The Reagan Administration has failed to carry out a 1987 law intended to improve care and treatment in the nation's 15,000 nursing homes, and instead is working on standards that appear to be far weaker than those Congress wanted.

title: Homeless Kept at Motel Too Long, Judge Rules
description: A Putnam County motel is being improperly used as long-term housing for 75 homeless people from Westchester County, an administrative law judge has ruled. The decision could affect the way Westchester houses many of its 4,300 homeless people.

title: Big Euramerica Harvest From a Little Town
description: In Pennsylvania Dutch country, the town of New Holland has delivered two completely unrelated accounts to Euramerica Advertising, an Ogilvy Group subsidiary.

title: Agriculture Chief to Join Petroleum Institute
description: The State Agriculture Commissioner, Donald Butcher, announced his resignation today, saying he was joining the Petroleum Institute of America, a Washington-based lobbying group.

title: Russ Togs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,103,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,290,000. b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $572,000 and $963,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Place for Ideas
description: When Congress is in session, a group of 38 Republican Congressmen meets every Wednesday at 5 P.M. to exchange ideas in a casual setting. They call themselves the House Wednesday Group.

title: 2 Ways to Reduce Arms
description: NATO Proposal * Reduce the number of NATO and Warsaw Pact tanks to 40,000 in Europe, a reduction of about half. * Limit each country in the two alliances to 12,000 tanks in Europe. This would require the Soviet Union to eliminate 25,000 tanks. Gorbachev Plan * Reduce Soviet armed forces by 500,000 worldwide over the next two years. The Soviet Union has a total of about 5.1 million troops all over the world, including 1.5 million noncombat troops. * Withdraw six tank divisions from East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary and disband them by 1991. This would be a reduction of 50,000 men and 5,000 of the 10,000 Soviet tanks in Eastern Europe. * In the European part of the Soviet Union, 5,000 tanks would be cut. * Of the total Soviet forces from the Atlantic to the Urals, 800 combat aircraft and 8,500 artillery systems would be cut. The proposed tank reductions would affect 10,000 of an estimated 37,000 tanks in this region. The Soviets have 33,000 artillery weapons in the Warsaw Pact and 6,050 combat aircraft, according to NATO estimates.

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1988. Year-ago revenue was restated to give effect to the consolidation of Montana Refining Co., a limited partnership which was previously accounted for using the equity method.

title: Concord Computing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Says Plane on an Aid Mission In Sahara Was Downed by Missile
description: Two planes used by a United States Government relief agency came under missile attack over Mauritania today, and one plane was shot down, the State Department said. It was unclear who had fired the missiles.

title: Unwed Father Given Custody Despite Adoption
description: In a decision emblematic of the expanding parental rights of fathers, the Surrogate's Court in Manhattan has awarded custody of a 7-month-old girl to her unwed father even though the child's mother had given her up for adoption at birth.

title: Another Loss at Maxicare
