description: In the year since a man who had been dismissed from an airline job smuggled a pistol aboard a jet to kill his former boss, causing a crash that killed 43 people, the nation's airports have upgraded their security checks for all airline employees, including pilots.

title: YONKERS PHILHARMONIC OPENS
description: FOR 25 years, the Yonkers Philharmonic has been giving the gift of music. Founded and originally directed by the late Pasquale Pistone, the orchestra was designed to offer fine music to the community without charge, a mission that now continues under the musical direction of Jerome Sala and the sponsorship of the Yonkers Bureau of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: BONN ENTHUSIASTIC ABOUT SOVIET CUTS
description: Perhaps nowhere was Mikhail S. Gorbachev's pledge to cut his armies more warmly greeted than in West Germany, although the reaction was tinged with some anxiety over what impact the initiative might have on Bonn's internal and foreign politics.

title: POSTING: Town Houses on the Block; Ossining Auction
description: The bicycle race did not quite work out for Kathy Americo and her husband, Sal. Oh, it was smashing success for Ossining and a grand celebration of the village's 175th anniversary that drew 75 racers on a hot July afternoon. But the Americos's prize offers of discounts on two of the 82 Liberty Knoll town houses - 70 built, the rest under construction or planned - were ignored by the winners.

title: TV'S TORMENTED MASTER
description: Many thanks to Alex Ward for his sensitive, affecting profile of England's innovative television writer, Dennis Potter (''TV's Tormented Master,'' Nov. 13).

title: HITLER AND THE BOMB
description: It is true, as Mr. Bundy indicates, that the German chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann were the first to recognize the presence of barium in uranium that had been bombarded with neutrons. But Hahn and Strassmann did not themselves understand how the barium was formed. It was the Austrian physicist Lise Meitner, working through the December 1938 holidays with her nephew Otto Frisch, who first realized that Hahn and Strassmann's uranium nuclei had split, or fissioned, to produce barium. The discovery of nuclear fission involved related efforts by a number of scientists. But if there was a single instant when fission was actually discovered, it was when Lise Meitner, on a walk with her nephew in the Swedish countryside, sketched a picture of a uranium nucleus splitting into two parts. Shortly thereafter, Meitner and Frisch first used the word ''fission'' in their paper ''Disintegration of Uranium by Neutrons: A New Type of Nuclear Reaction.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: In Defense, as if Any Were Needed, of Beckett; All Maturity Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: A Generation of Hard Knocks Recalled
description: The recent piano recital by Byron Janis, marking the 40th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut, brought to mind F. Scott Fitzgerald's wry observation in ''The Last Tycoon'' that there are no second acts in American lives. A literal-minded person might argue with Fitzgerald about exactly at what age the curtain comes down on the first act of an American life, but let's not quibble. The idea is clear enough: early promise and late disappointment, if not tragedy, somehow are woven into the native fabric.

title: Boiling Point
description: To the Editor:

title: London Terrace
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Therapy Helps Former Psychiatric Patients to Open Up
description: BEATE BECKER, a registered dance therapist, uses analogy to explain her profession. Movement is a powerful memory-rouser, she said - ''like the sense of smell, it takes you right back'' to the past.

title: Artist's Tree Trimming In Smithsonian Exhibit
description: LEAD: >TRIMMING a tree in a local Christmas festival was all Betsey Kimball Dempsey of Weston had in mind when she created her miniature carousel horses. Instead they, and her other handcrafted menagerie, will adorn a holiday theme tree in the 12th annual ''Trees of Christmas'' exhibition beginning Dec.

title: The World Debates How to Trade a Food Supply in Jeopardy
description: IN the United States, grain stockpiles are down 135 million tons from their record high in 1986, largely because of last summer's drought. In the rest of the world, grain stocks have fallen an additional 50 million tons, creating what some see as a precarious balance between the world's supply of food and the demand for it.

title: Man Freed in Officer's Slaying
description: A man arrested in the shooting death of a police officer in Manhattan on Oct. 18 has been released because prosecutors had too little evidence to indict him. Antonio Mena, 25 years old, of 14 Marcy Place in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, had been held since his arrest three days after Officer Michael Buczek was slain at 161st Street and Broadway as he and his partner tried to question two men.

title: Set Guidelines for Export Market Share
description: Optical fiber for data and telecommunications transmission, a ''target industry'' in Japan, became the focus of trade negotiations in the early 1980's. That is when American officials objected to the continued closure of the Japanese market to the American companies that invented the product. As a result of these negotiations, the market was formally opened. Nippon Telegraph and Telephone tested American products and found them superior to what is produced in Japan.

title: U.S. DETECTING GAIN ON STEROID ABUSE
description: The investigation of the illegal manufacturing and selling of steroids that the Department of Justice opened in 1985 is beginning to pay significant dividends, Federal officials say.

title: 2 ARE SAID TO DIE IN TIBET PROTESTS
description: Chinese troops opened fire on a small group of pro-independence demonstrators in Tibet today, killing at least two and wounding others, including a Dutch tourist, according to reports reaching Beijing.

title: INDIA: ALWAYS INVENTING ITSELF
description: IN AMERICAN living in India is a passenger on a turbulent voyage, never certain if the country is moving forward into a more prosperous, enlightened future or disintegrating under pressures of hatred and violence. During three-and-a-half years of covering India, I wrote often of floods, earthquakes and other calamities: a ferry capsizing, a train plunging into a river, the suffering left by a poisonous chemical leak that killed thousands. I wrote of Hindus being hauled off a bus and massacred, of the bloody aftermath of a Prime Minister's assassination.

title: THE GOOD FORTUNES OF PAT SAJAK
description: PAT SAJAK HAD JUST BOUGHT a new convertible. Not a fancy foreign model, but a Chrysler Le Baron. Or was it a Pontiac? He wasn't sure. The point was, driving to work with the top down, he was, well, out there. Exposed. People might recognize him: Hey, Pat! And Sajak, though he is seen by 40 million people a day as the host of the game show ''Wheel of Fortune,'' is by nature a private man. ''Actually, the word I would use is 'secretive,' '' he says.

title: SOME TRUE TALES OF CAMPAIGN CASH
description: In unusually candid remarks, the leading fund-raisers for this year's two major Presidential nominees amicably sought to top each other Friday in citing the tens of millions of dollars their parties collected from private sources to help their candidates.

title: Deirdre M. Feeney Weds Brian Gregory McGowan
description: At Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Conn., Deirdre Margaret Feeney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Feeney of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Gregory McGowan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. McGowan of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Philip Coleman performed the ceremony. Mrs. McGowan, a graduate of Boston College, is a manager of corporate human resources with the American Express Company in New York. Her father is an advertising sales executive for the National Geographic Traveler magazine in New York. Mr. McGowan, an assistant vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert, graduated from St. John's University and received an M.B.A. from New York University. His father is a vice president of Citibank in New York.

title: The Case For Burning
description: FROM CODY, WYO., THE ROAD west to Yellowstone National Park follows the North Fork of the Shoshone River. Despite faltering rain in recent weeks - it was late October, and a fine fall morning, with the crowns of the last green cottonwoods turning to gold - a sign at the edge of the Shoshone National Forest read ''FIRE DANGER.'' Of the national forests that surround Yellowstone - Shoshone and Bridger-Teton, to the east and south, in Wyoming; Gallatin, to the north, in Montana, and Targhee, to the west, in Idaho (map on page 122) - the Shoshone was burned as much as any in the great fires of last summer. But there was no sign of the Clover-Mist fire that in late August escaped eastward from Yellowstone - one of eight great fires that made up what Yellowstone officials called ''the most significant political, ecological and economic event in the park's 116-year history.''

title: Christina Babarovic Wed to Paul Turci
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., Christina Maria Babarovic, the daughter of Gretchen Zahm Babarovic of Larchmont, N.Y., and John Anthony Babarovic of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Matthew Turci, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Turci of Dover, Mass. The Rev. Nancy Roth, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Stewart Sandberg, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Squabble Over Cuomo's Legal Fees Drags On
description: A civil trial in Brooklyn involving Governor Cuomo and the distribution of $6 million in legal fees is bogged down after nine months of courtroom bitterness with one side now demanding a mistrial. The nine-year-old dispute stems from fees that were obtained by Mr. Cuomo's law firm after he left to join state government in 1975.

title: Making Last Days Count, Through Hospice Care
description: A MARINO is living on borrowed time. According to all medical reports, the 71-year-old Mrs. Marino, who has liver cancer, should not have lived this long, said her husband, Vincent.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CHINESE PORCELAIN

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
In Affirmative Action, a Question of Truth in Labeling
description: LEAD: IF a blue-eyed, blond man had a black great-grandmother, does he qualify for an affirmative action plan? In job preferences, what does, or should, ''Hispanic'' mean?

title: HAIR TODAY
description: The fashion pendulum is swinging again. Last year, many young women combined formal gowns with loose, tousled - read messy - hair. This year, the favored style for evening is perfectly neat - precise buns, demure chignons and ladylike French twists.

description: For a 17-year-old Soviet emigre and confirmed news addict, these have been heady days. Georgi P. followed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 36-hour blitz of New York City closely on television and in the newspapers.

title: A Hawk Is Recruited In The War On Pollution

title:
ART;
Works on Paper From Across Nation
description: LEAD: FOR the last 18 years, the Firehouse Gallery of Nassau Community College in Garden City has been host to an annual exhibition of works on paper. Until now, the show's scope has been regional, but this year its horizons have been broadened to encompass the entire country.

title: Artists cRate Set Pieces for Picture Books
description: TO demonstrate how she works, Eileen Doolittle, a commercial artist, occassionally gets out her Hot Wheels Collector's case, unloads a few toy cars and parks them on a canvas depicting a bright green countryside.

title: Small-Scale Sculpture on View in New Britain
description: THE New Britain Museum of American Art, at 56 Lexington Street, is usually the only cultural attraction on the block. But now, it has a rival in the house opposite, which has metamorphosed into a spectacle that would make any kitsch assemblages by a fashionable contemporary artist seem Bauhaus by comparison.

title: Milk Drivers Ratify Contract
description: The membership of the union that represents milk truck drivers and dairy employees in New York City voted by a 5-to-1 ratio yesterday to accept a new three-year contract, said Willie Whelan, president of the union, Teamsters Local 584. He said salary and benefits for the union's 2,000 workers will increase by 13 percent during the first year of the pact, and 11 percent in each of the last two years. The milk dealers' lawyer, Richard Nanness, said the agreement ''will result in more milk companies going out of business,'' The Associated Press reported.

title: County Law on Contractors is Made Permanent
description: LEAD: A STATUTE that requires certain home-improvement contractors to obtain a license before they do business in the county has been made a permanent law.

title: Turning Weapons Into Pledges
description: AFTER officiating at two funerals of people killed by guns, the Rev. Marshall Gourley, pastor of Our Lady of Guadalupe Roman Catholic Church in Denver, appealed to his parishioners to turn their guns over to him for destruction by the police and to sign pledges intended to curb the carrying of firearms.

title: srael
description: To the Editor: Upon reading the article on Safed, the artist colony nestled in the mountains of northern Israel (Travel, Aug. 7), I happily packed it along with my travel guide.

title: American Relief Planes Sent
description: Three planes left with supplies for Armenia in the first American Government relief effort accepted by Moscow since the 1940's. Page 16.

title: Cable, Bellcows and Sparkplugs
description: For all those Yankee fans who thought that George Steinbrenner had suddenly reverted to his previous philosophy of free spending for free agents, think again. Sooner or later, all those millions the principal owner assured Steve Sax, Andy Hawkins and Dave LaPoint will be on your cable-television bill.

title: 'I CAN'T STAND YOUR BOOKS': A WRITER GOES HOME
description: A friend of mine who is intensely interested in the fulfillment of immigrant fantasies recently asked me if my family was proud of me. I was able to say with perfect frankness that they were not, that, except for my mother, one cousin and one aunt, they considered me an embarrassment or a lost soul. This led me to wonder about the connections among my family's reaction to me, the place of the writer in the Irish-American community and the faintness of the Irish-American voice in the world of letters.

title: Hunters Find More Than Deer
description: Deer hunters found more than whitetails in the woods this season, the authorities said. Hunters found the body of Mark Branch, the suspect in the killing of a Greenfield Community College student, said Police Chief David McCarthy of Greenfield. They also found a helicopter that crashed last week over southwest Massachusetts. Deer hunting season began Nov. 28 and ended Wednesday.

title: Ariane 4 Rocket Makes First Commercial Flight
description: Western Europe's Ariane 4 rocket lifted off on its first commercial mission tonight carrying two telecommunications satellites.

title: THE GREAT OAKLAND EARTHQUAKE
description: THE LETTERS OF JACK LONDON Volume One: 1896-1905. Volume Two: 1906-1912. Volume Three: 1913-1916. Edited by Earle Labor, Robert C. Leitz 3d and I. Milo Shepard. Illustrated. 1,657 pp. Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press. $139.50; slipcase edition, $185. AMERICAN DREAMERS Charmian and Jack London. By Clarice Stasz. Illustrated. 362 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: Young Delight Old At Concert
description: LEAD: IN this season of giving, commercialism took a back seat recently when young students from the Thurnauer School of Music in Tenafly offered the gift of music to elderly residents of a nursing home here.

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.;
Goat Island Going Condo

description: Thousands of Czechoslovaks gathered here today to mark the 40th anniversary of the universal declaration of human rights.

description: WHEN Theodore Roosevelt described his Oyster Bay home atop Sagamore Hill, he wrote rapturously:

title: ORDINARY PEOPLE WITH BAD LUCK
description: THE COMMON INTEREST How Our Social-Welfare Policies Don't Work, and What We Can Do About Them. By Leslie W. Dunbar. 233 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: HISPANIC PARENTS MOBILIZE IN BOSTON
description: Accusing the Boston schools of ''a pattern of neglect,'' a group of parents has mobilized to press officials to give special attention to Hispanic students not in bilingual education programs.

title: Marjorie Van de Stouwe Weds a Fellow Physician
description: Dr. Marjorie Jean Van de Stouwe, an internist at the New York University Medical Center, and Dr. Scott Jay Ratner, director of the intensive-care units of the Allen Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married yesterday at the Sans Souci restaurant in Sea Cliff, L.I. Jean S. Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union, officiated.

title: CEMETERY'S PLANS CAUSE SOME ANGER
description: Plans to build stores on part of the Jewish Waldheim Cemetery here have upset relatives of some of the dead, but two Orthodox rabbis who toured the construction site said the stores would not be built on grave sites.

title: Shopper's World; In Thailand, Faking Art Is an Art in Itself
description: ''First you wear down the sharp angles, maybe chip them a little. Then you soak it in sulfuric acid, to give the stone some nice pits. Finally you put the piece in another kind of acid that makes it darker, older looking. Some people also bury it for a while, but that's not really necessary except for buyers who feel safer with a little dirt.''

title: In Town Reynolds Built, Fear for Jobs
description: In this town where the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company was born in 1875, factory workers, office workers and managers had bought stock in Reynolds over decades for as little as $5 a share. Suddenly they were wealthy beyond their dreams, at least on paper.

title: 'A GLEE IN CONNCTING THINGS'
description: NEW YORK 1913 The Armory Show and the Paterson Strike Pageant. By Martin Green. Illustrated. 325 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Pregnancy Aloft
description: To the Editor: ''Is There a Doctor in the Cabin?'' (Practical Traveler, Oct. 9) overlooked the possibility of a common occurence that presents itself on extended flights - the pregnant woman who is at or near term and goes into labor. I was involved in such an incident soon after takeoff on a trip from New York to California.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: ISSEY MIYAKE. Photographs by Irving Penn. Edited by Nicholas Callaway. (New York Graphic Society, $40 until Dec. 31; $50 thereafter.) Issey Miyake makes clothes that free body and spirit. Just a shadow of womanly shape is revealed inside an airy cocoon of fabric. An origami of pale pleats enfolds the figure, not as its designer dictates, but as the wearer chooses. Mr. Miyake, born in Hiroshima, came to Paris from Japan in 1968, the year of student revolt. He became - although he would deny it - the head of a warrior army of designers who were to challenge Western conventions of sexuality, of femininity, of what was appropriate in dress. Now, 20 years later, Irving Penn celebrates Mr. Miyake, in photographs that have the sculptural quality of the clothes themselves. These can be odd: breasts swelling out of a silicone bustier above inflated polyurethane pants. Or they can be classic: a ploughed furrow of pleats as a shirttail to a black dinner suit. The textures of this most tactile of designers - his gauzy open-weave linen scarf or unfinished bamboo hat like nesting chopsticks - come over with striking clarity. Fabric is the medium of Issey Miyake's fashion message. Mr. Penn portrays the felted fronds of acid-treated wool and the luminous transparence of a coat in chemically treated paper. ''There are no boundaries for what can be fabric,'' says the designer in one of the succint comments that go with each picture. Mr. Miyake's roots are in the natural world. A dress of glistening, pleated waves is inspired by seaweed; a coat knitted in ribbed stripes of shell pink, sand and sky blue is worked with fishing-line thread to create its rounded conch shape. The outfits are photographed on Japanese women and yet they have a universal quality. ''My generation in Japan lived in limbo,'' says Issey Miyake. ''We dreamed between two worlds.''

title: U.S. Survey Faults Standards in Nursing Homes
description: Nursing homes in New York State far exceed average national standards for health care, but large percentages of the nursing homes in New Jersey and Connecticut provide less than adequate care, a survey published by the Federal Department of Health and Human Services has found.

title: Sports of The Times; Ambassadors to the Real World
description: The Kansas City Chiefs were shouting ''Go for it'' last Sunday with the ball a few inches from the end zone and two seconds left against the Jets.

title: Arafat Calls on Palestinians To Escalate Year-Old Revolt
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization's chairman, today called on Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories to escalate their year-old uprising.

title: Headliners; Stocking Up
description: As some on Wall Street tell it, all that stands between Carl C. Icahn and his next $1 billion is James W. Kinnear. But now it appears that Mr. Icahn has begun moving Mr. Kinnear out of the way. Mr. Icahn, a well-known corporate raider who is chairman of Trans World Airlines, owns 14.8 percent of Texaco Inc., which could be worth about $1 billion more than it cost if Texaco were put on the auction block. Mr. Kinnear, the chairman of Texaco, blocked Mr. Icahn's attempt to do that last summer. A flurry of activity in Texaco stock last week prompted speculation that Mr. Icahn had found a partner who was attempting to help him accumulate 25 percent of the shares. At that point, Mr. Kinnear could be ousted in a proxy fight and a for-sale sign could go up at Texaco.

title: The Call Goes Out for Holiday Volunteers
description: LEAD: THE concept is not new: helping a charity or someone in need during the holidays. But this year, with some needs particularly acute, many charitable groups and social-service agencies say they are hoping that in the middle of holiday preparations for families and friends, county residents will also reach out to the less fortunate.

title: Giving Puss The Boot
description: IT took a while for the National Association of Real Estate Appraisers in Scottsdale, Ariz., to get wind of it, but when the group learned that one of its 20,000 members had four legs, it ejected him and sued.

title: Decentralization of Schools Provides Painful Lessons
description: IN 1970, after bitter controversy and racial confrontation, the New York City school system was decentralized in an attempt to give community residents -particularly parents - a greater voice in determining what pupils learned, and from whom.

title: Loss of Forests: Not So 'Slight'
description: The Nov. 6 article ''Woods: Total Loss Is 'Slight' '' may have left many readers with the impression that deforestation is no more than a minor or local problem in New Jersey. The preliminary figures on aggregate woodland area highlighted in the article obscured the fact that many mature forests are in serious jeopardy.

title: Pacemaker Engineer Gets One
description: Norman Roth, who helped develop one of the first heart pacemakers 30 years ago when he was a young engineer, has had one of the devices installed in his own chest, doctors said Friday. Mr. Roth, 57 years old, received the device at St. Joseph's Hospital after his heart began beating irregularly. Pacemakers stimulate the muscles of the heart with electric signals.

title: Martha Scott Taylor Plans to Wed Joseph Theodor Josephson in June
description: The engagement of Martha Scott Taylor to Joseph TheodorJosephson, the son of Ingrid B. Josephson and Marvin Josephson, both of New York, has been made known by her parents, Marion McFarland Taylor of Summit, N.J., and Arthur R. Taylor of Salisbury, Conn. The couple plan a June wedding.

description: An independent fire-safety inspection of the New York City subway system has found signficant weaknesses in Transit Authority equipment, training, communications and overall emergency preparedness.

title: Soweto Will Halt Eviction and Forgive Back Rent

GARDENING;

The prunings of yews, one of the most useful and relatively trouble-free evergreen shrubs, are commonly used in such arrangements since they will not shed needles even when dried out.

John Wightman performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Westfield.

title: Senator Burdick Discharged From Hospital After 2 Weeks
description: Senator Quentin N. Burdick of North Dakota is recovering from treatment for seizures and his doctor says the 80-year-old lawmaker will be ready to go back to work when Congress convenes next month.

THE VIEW FROM: THE CONNECTICUT TROLLEY MUSEUM;
Preserving the Spirit of Trolley Years

In their heyday, there were more than 2,400 electric street cars in Connecticut alone. But in July 1941, its charm dimmed by the growing popularity of buses powered by the internal combustion engine, Trolley 65, the last street car in

title: Review/Dance; Erich Hawkins Troupe Celebrates Its Composer
description: Dances by Erick Hawkins tend to be celebrations, meditative and small-scaled, of the human body and soul and the universe they inhabit. But the Erick Hawkins Dance Company had something else to celebrate on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. It was Lucia Dlugoszewski night, an event that paid homage to the composer and her long and fruitful association with Mr. Hawkins.

But that was before the assorted municipal scandals, the AIDS and crack crises, thousands of highly visible homeless people, heightened racial tensions and pervasive crime. Now the polls show him with a favorable rating of only about half that 1985 mark.

title: Headliners; Accentuating the Positive
description: If the name of Chiang Kai-shek is less reviled in China these days, it has perhaps less to do with revisionism than with pragmatism. The Chinese, who still hope for the day that Taiwan is reunited with the mainland, have recently taken a more tolerant view of Chiang, who died in 1975, allowing homage to be paid Beijing's old Nationalist enemy, at least in his hometown of Xikou. There, Chiang is remembered less as an oppressor of leftists than as a builder of roads and schools. And tourists from Taiwan are being encouraged to visit his restored estate as much for the hard currency they bring as for the goodwill they are presumed to take back. ''Whatever else he was, Chiang Kai-shek was a giant,'' a local official in Xikou said recently. ''And after all, every town wants its sons to become famous.''

title: Musical 'Barnum': 3-Ring Showman
description: BACK around 1875, the circus impresario P.T. Barnum planned to make Port Jefferson the permanent home for his ''Greatest Show on Earth.'' Apparently, however, Barnum was not well thought of in that Long Island community.

title: U.N. CHIEF WARNS OF COSTS OF PEACE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations accepted the 1988 Nobel Peace Prize today on behalf of the organization's 10,500 peacekeeping soldiers, but he warned that their operations were in jeopardy because of the failure of the United States and other governments to pay their full share of the cost.

title:

title: UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
description: IT ALL BEGAN ROUTINELY ENOUGH. WHEN THE SURGEON examined the lump in my breast, he was ''99 percent certain it's benign.'' But he suggested I have it out to be sure. The anesthetic was a shot of Novocain, so throughout the procedure I listened to the nurses and doctor banter about sports and the weather. What could have been more ordinary?

title: Fuse Boxes And Circuit Breakers

title: Cold Weather Ahead

Haledon $155,000 45 Coma Court 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $2,991. Livingston $300,000 14 Hickory Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; c/a, deck, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,704. Orange $99,000 267 Ivy Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, finished basement; taxes $1,948. Pompton Plains $295,000 5 Abby Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 1-year-old contemporary; c/a, formal dining room, finished basement; taxes $6,828. OTHER AREAS Katonah, N.Y. $290,000 8 Oak Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old ranch; fireplace, dining room, full basement, 1.5 acres; taxes $3,646. West Hartford, Conn. $113,000 16 Hillcrest Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; c/a, close to bus and shopping; taxes $1,464. Brookhaven, L.I. $162,500 15 Wedgewood Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,600.

title: Drug Testers Deserve Thanks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PINS: Law Should Protect Youths' Future
description: I read the article [ ''Emancipation Age,'' Oct. 2 ] with hope.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BANK THEFT;
STEALING MILLIONS WITH PUSH-BUTTON EASE
description: LEAD: The electronic robbery of the Union Bank of Switzerland and the $70 million wire fraud attempted last May against the First National Bank of Chicago have created a ''very, very strong fear'' among bankers that existing security procedures are insufficient to thwart such frauds, said Mr. Holsborg, of U.B

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Three Carriers Offer Discounts For Elderly

title: Explorations In the Realms Of Innovation
description: The Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has waited until its halfway mark this season to present its first dance events, a change from its official beginnings in 1983 when it was clearly dance dominated.

title: Parts of South Africa Airliner Recovered in Indian Ocean
description: Salvage workers said today that they had recovered the first pieces of a South African airliner that crashed into the Indian Ocean more than a year ago, killing all 160 people aboard.

title: Hudson Indian Artifacts Emerge at Putnam Dig
description: A condominium development will be built, now that archeologists have finished excavating a startling find, the remains of an Indian transit camp dating from at least 3000 B.C.

title: TEARING APART EASTERN AIRLINES
description: It seems to me that the caption writer for your article on Eastern Airlines has gone too far (''Tearing Apart Eastern Airlines,'' by William Stockton, Nov. 6). Charles Bryan, leader of the machinists at Eastern, is characterized as the ''militant head'' of the union, and the members themselves are characterized as ''militant machinists,'' in a picture showing them wearing color-coordinated T-shirts, as a form of protest. Where I come from, ''militant'' means violent, or, at least, lawless. Nothing in the article supports that implication, and fashion statements hardly qualify. After all, was Frank Lorenzo characterized as a ''militant capitalist'' for his sharp practices? R. ALTA CHARO Washington

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE CANTERBURY TALES A Selection. By Geoffrey Chaucer. Retold by Selina Hastings. Illustrated by Reg Cartwright. 77 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95. (Ages 12 and up) CANTERBURY TALESBy Geoffrey Chaucer. Selected, translated, and adapted by Barbara Cohen. Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. 87 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $17.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Keep South African Sports in Isolation
description: SPORTS have played a significant role in South Africa's search to gain international respectability for apartheid. Bringing American athletes like Carol Cady (''Why I Decided to Go to South Africa,'' The Times, Nov. 6) to the country is part of that search. The campaign to exclude South Africa from international sports is significant because it affects one of the major outlets for the aggrandizement of white supremacy.

title: British and P.L.O. Officials Hold Talks
description: A British Government minister met with an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization Friday for the first time in more than five years.

title: What It Means to Be An Alcoholic's Child
description: Thank you so much for the article ''Shattered Spirits: Growing Up With Alcoholism'' [ Nov. 13 ] . My thanks, also, to the anonymous author for her honest and open sharing of such personal and painful feelings, and of such poignant memories.

title: Iona College and Seton Move Toward a ''Marriage''
description: TWO of Westchester's leading educational institutions, Iona College and Elizabeth Seton College, are moving to consolidate in what Brother John G. Driscoll, the Iona president, said is ''not a rescue operation, but a marriage.''

title: Protection for Tenants With Pets
description: IN an effort to protect county pet owners from retaliatory evictions, the Westchester Board of Legislators unanimously adopted a law last week that limits the conditions under which landlords may force out tenants who own animals.

title: Susan N. DiSesa, Publicity Agent, Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in New Haven, Susan Nicola DiSesa, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph D. DiSesa of New Haven and the late Mr. DiSesa, was married yesterday to William Emerson Sheeline, a son of Paul C. Sheeline of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and the late Harriet Moffat Sheeline. The Rev. James J. Cronin performed the ceremony.

title: Schussing the Tricky Ski-Condo Trails
description: FIND a satisfied ski condominium owner these days and chances are he is either a recent purchaser or someone who somehow managed to traverse a real estate minefield that has claimed the savings of many resort condominium owners.

title: Facing The Facts About Cambodia
description: AS the outlines of an international settlement for Cambodia start to become clear, accelerated by the Chinese-Soviet talks last week in Moscow, there is suddenly a swell of anguished murmuring about the Khmer Rouge.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Cluster Housing Gives Builders an Edge
description: LEAD: BUILDERS say a state statute permitting municipalities to modify zoning rules if a developer agrees to cluster his houses is helping to hold down development costs by as much as $5,000 a unit.

title: INSIDE
description: Soweto Council Agrees To Forgive Back Rent

title: Paraguay Breaks Up a Human Rights Rally
description: The police attacked hundreds of people with electric prods and rubber batons today to prevent them from holding a march to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. [ Rally organizers said that more than 5,000 police were used to break up the march and that 72 people were arrested and 10 were wounded, Reuters reported. ] Among those reported injured were Rafaela Guanes de Laino, the wife of an arrested opposition leader, Domingo Laino; and Ilde Silvero, director of the Roman Catholic weekly publication Sendero.

title: I.R.S. Is Investigating Finances of 26 TV Ministries
description: The Internal Revenue Service is conducting an investigation of 26 television evangelists, agency officials said Friday.

title: 'Roots: The Gift' Is a Repackaging Of Few Surprises
description: Here's the way David Wolper, the producer, tells the story. One day he realized that there has never been a black Christmas story. So, he called Alex Haley, the author of ''Roots'' and consultant to Mr. Wolper's 1976 television production of ''Roots,'' still the most successful mini-series ever presented on American television. Yes, said Mr. Haley, he just happened to have an idea for such a story. As a matter of fact, Mr. Haley was working on a short, now published book called ''A Different Kind of Christmas,'' all about a white college student who, in the 1880's, gets involved in an underground-railway plan to help runaway slaves.

title: U.S. Teams Rush to Aid Victims of the Calamity
description: Four planes, including two Air Force cargo aircraft, were loaded today with tons of medical supplies and teams of rescue workers, doctors and a Government task force to start a public and private relief effort for victims of the shattering earthquake in Armenia.

title: The Christmas Rose
description: It's been a funny fall in New York, what with warm weather alternating with chill and sweaters alternating with down coats. On some Greenwich Village houses, petunias are still spilling healthily from window boxes that would normally be bare by now, and more than one naked street tree is still circled by marigolds.

title: Christopher's Croc?
description: FIVE CENTURIES AGO, DURING his famed first visit to the New World, Christopher Columbus came across an unfamiliar reptile in the shallows of what is now Crooked Island, in the Bahamas. His journal entry for Oct. 21, 1492, written in Spanish, reads in part, in translation, as follows: ''Thus, walking around one of these lakes, I saw a serpent, which we killed. . . . When it saw us, it threw itself into the lake and we followed it in, because it was not very deep, until with lances we killed it. It is seven palmos'' -about six feet - ''in length. I believe there are many similar ones in these lakes.''

title: ISRAELI ARMY KILLS TWO PALESTINIANS
description: Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian teen-ager during a demonstration in the occupied Gaza Strip today, and guards at a military jail in Gaza killed a Palestinian prisoner, the army said.

title: Lou Boda, Sports Broadcaster, 60
description: Lou Boda, a sports broadcaster on radio and television for more than 35 years before he retired last July, died Friday night after a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Dr. Lucy Ashley To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Dr. Lucy Pope Ashley to Dr. Philip Charles Sheils, a son of Mrs. Paul J. Sheils of Birmingham, Mich., and the late Mr. Sheils, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles A. Ashley of Cooperstown, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Day's Work for Shadow Traffic
description: ROUTE 80 is bumper to bumper from Parsippany to Wayne. The New Jersey Turnpike is packed, the Lincoln Tunnel is tied in knots, and the George Washington Bridge is an aerial parking lot. So what is the best way to get into Manhattan? Only Shadow knows.

title: Christmas Is Not My Holiday
description: EVERY year it doesn't happen. And every year it starts not happening just a little bit earlier. It used to wait for Thanksgiving, but then it moved closer and closer up until it came around Halloween. Now it starts even before pumpkins and skeletons dot the landscape. If we aren't careful, one day we may find ourselves shopping for back-to-school notebooks and shoes in stores that are decked out in red and green.

title: Hirohito's Bleeding Worsens; Condition Is Called Unstable
description: Emperor Hirohito received a series of transfusions today to control his internal bleeding and his condition remained unstable, said a palace spokeman. [ Reuters quoted the Emperor's doctors as saying that Hirohito was nearly comatose and close to suffering kidney failure. The news agency said Hirohito was not responding to questions from his physicians. ] Doctors said the 87-year-old monarch hemorrhaged heavily Friday and early today and they extracted blood from his upper digestive tract through a tube, the Imperial Household Agency spokesman, Kenji Maeda, said.

title: Avis Tsuya Wed In Massachusetts
description: Avis Kikue Tsuya, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Tsuya of Honolulu, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to David Philip Bruni, the son of Mary Elizabeth Blakeslee of Lewiston, N.Y., and the late Dr. Saverio N. Bruni. Bishop Paul Dahl of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: On Wisconson?
description: The University of Wisconsin presented nearly 4,000 diplomas to graduates in May, but it took six months for anyone to notice that the state's name was misspelled. ''It's amazing that something like this could happen,'' said Rosa Johnson, supervisor of degree summary and verification at the Madison campus. The error is in the lower right corner under the signature of Donna Shalala. It reads: ''Chancellor, University of Wisconson-Madison.'' The company that made the diplomas said it would replace them.

title: A Cottage That Kept a Piece Of My Heart
description: WHEN we left the house in Oakland - a retreat on a ridge 1,500 feet above that fabled bay, with spacious decks and majestic views of San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Pacific - we thought we'd never again live in a place so exotic or so beautiful. We were wrong.

title: Shearson's Financial Alchemy
description: For years, it has been the corporate raiders and the leveraged buyout masters who have captured most of the attention in the financial arena. Suddenly, though, other kinds of financial innovators are in the limelight.

title: Sydney Food
description: To the Editor: One of the highlights of a recent trip to Australia was taking the half-hour ferry trip from Sydney to Manley and seeking out the French restaurant mentioned in ''What's Doing in Sydney'' (Travel, Nov. 1, 1987). Because I had misplaced the article, I relied on a Sydney guidebook to help remember the restaurant's name.

title: Talks in South Africa Disturb U.S. Senators
description: Two Democratic Senators from the United States said today that they were deeply disappointed by a meeting this week with President P. W. Botha and warned that his attitude could provoke tougher American economic sanctions.

title: Freeholder? Just What Is That?
description: IN all 21 counties of New Jersey last month, the machine ballots in the election booths contained a box entitled ''Electors of President and Vice President of the United States,'' another with the name ''Member of the United States Senate'' and another with the words ''Member of the House of Representatives.'' To the right was a box enclosing the words ''Member of the Board of Chosen Freeholders.''

title: Mother Is Guilty in Sex Case
description: A woman has pleaded guilty to three counts of cruelty to children for taking pictures of her husband sexually assaulting her three children in 1984 and 1985. Family Court Judge Jeremiah S. Jeremiah Jr. gave Kathleen Shatney, 33 years old, a three-year suspended sentence and three years' supervised probation. The children's stepfather, Louis E. Shatney, 48, has already been convicted of sexual assault and child molestation and sentenced to life plus 30 years in prison. The children, now 9, 10 and 14, have been adopted by their grandparents and live out of state.

title: News and Propaganda
description: To the Editor:

title: Yorkville Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Junk that Glitters
description: LEAD: Investors venturing into the high-yield municipal market need steady nerves. Many issues are small, and trading is limited. But the diligent can discover attractive investments, analysts say. In such areas as health care and retirement villages, analysts look for good balance sheets and market positions.

title: Review/Opera; An Eclectic Offenbach 'Orpheus'
description: A handful of coincidental productions may not signal a revival, but there does seem to be more Offenbach than usual in the air this season. Following closely on the premiere of a new edition of ''Tales of Hoffmann'' in Los Angeles and Opera at the Academy's ''Vie Parisienne'' in Brooklyn, the Village Light Opera Group has weighed in with ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' in a production that has its last performance at 2 P.M. today at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street.

title: DEER AT FACTORY PROVE TOO FERTILE
description: A rapidly growing population of white-tailed deer at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's Chambers Works has become a problem for company officials, who want to cut back on the herd but don't want to fire a shot.

title: Blind New Yorkers Find Little Understanding in Their Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Rights Treaty Finished, but Debate Isn't
description: Negotiators from about 80 countries this week completed a treaty on the rights of the child.

title: Asking for A New World, He Leaves Bush Tough Choices
description: IN just over an hour at the rostrum of the United Nations General Assembly, the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, presented President-elect Bush with what may be the greatest challenge in Soviet-American relations since the Cuban missile crisis: an invitation to make fundamental changes in the relationship into which the superpowers have settled over four decades of cold war, confrontation and uneasy detente.

title: O'Brien Lifts Jets In Upset
description: In this season of parity, the Jets demonstrated today how close they came to being a playoff-caliber team.

title: 2's Company, Seven's a Crowd
description: ALICE and Angelo Cangialosi of Lake Ronkonkoma hope to take their children to see Santa Claus. ''We'll try,'' Mrs. Cangialosi said. ''If we do, we'll probably go to the Smith Haven Mall.'' The problem with seeing Santa, Mrs. Cangialosi said, is that besides maneuvering the triplet stroller and the double stroller through the Christmas retail rush, ''the babies tend to draw a crowd.'' That's because the 14-month-old Cangialosi children are a crowd.

title: Correction
description: An item in the Q & A column on Nov. 20 about cut-rate air fares to Rio de Janeiro misstated the telephone number for Tourlite International, a discount broker. The number is 212-599-2727.

title: RESCUE IS SLOWING
description: Shadowed by scenes of devastation and sorrow, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today toured areas of Armenia destroyed by an earthquake that the Government said has left at least 45,000 dead, 12,000 injured and 500,000 homeless.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 25 Years Later; Catholics Still Seek The Poetry Of the Mass
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago this month the Roman Catholic Church made one of the biggest gambles in its history, and scholars and church leaders are still assessing what was won and lost. On December 4, 1963, the world's Catholic bishops, in the first document published by the Second Vatican Council, mandated a thoroughgoing reform of the Catholic liturgy, which had remained virtually unchanged for 400 years. Priests no longer addressed God silently at Mass with their backs to the faithful but faced the congregation across the altar. Latin was abandoned for the people's own language. The laity took an active part in the rituals through responses, congregational singing, processions and other gestures.

title: Catastrophic Insurance Burdens the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN JUAN
description: In Puerto Rico, McDonald's, Wendy's and Burger King compete with lechoneras - fast-food restaurants specializing in highly seasoned roast pork and other local delicacies. In the discos, the disk jockeys play about as much rock as they do salsa and merengue. (The trick to dancing to Latin rhythms is to sway the hips without moving the shoulders.) The language is Spanish, but so many Puerto Ricans are bilingual that visitors hoping to try their Spanish are often frustrated by Puerto Ricans more eager to practice their English.

title:
GARDENING;
A Recycler's Guide to Seed Growing
description: LEAD: FOR winter-weary gardeners, there is nothing more therapeutic than planting seeds. In response to the planting urge, seed catalogues, which will start to arrive soon, shrewdly feature such aids to propagation as miniature greenhouses - clear plastic domes that fit over flower pots and rectangular trays of different sizes with matching transparent tops.

title: The Medium Is Doing Better Than the Message
description: The French composer Olivier Messiaen, celebrating his 80thbirthday this week, has not been lacking for recognition. He is generally counted as one of the great composers of this century, and his works are performed widely and often. Last season alone, Mr. Messiaen himself was in New York twice for major performances of his music: Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic devoted an entire program to the massive, Dionysiac ''Turangalila,'' and the French Institute inaugurated its new Florence Gould Hall with Kent Nagano conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke's in ''From the Canyons to the Stars,'' a piece inspired by the natural wonders of the United States. In response to his music, Utah named one of its peaks ''Mount Messiaen.''

title: 2 Brothers Killed in Shooting
description: Two brothers were killed and their mother and a teen-age girl were wounded yesterday when a man who had gone to the family's Brooklyn apartment looking for his missing daughter began shooting, the police said.

title: What Stands Out In the N.F.L. This Year?
description: The failure of the ''in the grasp and control rule'' to protect the quarterback.

title: ISLAMIC MILITANCY AGAIN ROILS EGYPT
description: Egyptian riot policemen took up positions in the Ein Shams suburb of Cairo today as part of a new crackdown on Islamic fundamentalists. A high-ranking Government security agent was stabbed to death late last week as the campaign went on.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: KENNEDY LEGACY

title: A Farm Family Stubbornly Refuses to Quit Land
description: LEAD: A FIRE that destroyed their retail market, repeated bids by developers to buy them out and the worst drought in years will not budge them from their land, say the owners of the last remaining working farm in this southern New Jersey community.

title: A RHINOCEROS AMONG THE GAZELLES
description: BIRD The Making of an American Sports Legend. By Lee Daniel Levine. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $17.95.

title: THE WORLDSihanouk: Symbol of a Nation
description: PRINCE NORODOM SIHANOUK, now 65 years old, is having the rare privilege in world politics of a second wind. Crowned King of Cambodia as a teenager 47 years ago during Japanese occupation, he assumed power as Prime Minister in 1952, was instrumental in French decolonization and, a few years later, renounced the throne and began serving as a monopolistic sort of democrat, mistrusted by Washington as a ''neutralist,'' until he was overthrown in a 1970 coup.

title:
MUSIC;
Music of the Season Fills the Air
description: LEAD: HANDEL'S ''Messiah'' will dominate the holiday musical scene in several guises, from informal community sing-ins, like those in Floral Park, Huntington and East Hampton, to more lavish productions with professional soloists, chamber orchestras and conductors.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 11, 1988
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Oct. 88 Sep. 88 Oct. 87 New York 4,492 4,174 4,656 New Jersey 3,810 3,631 5,264 Connecticut 1,512 1,598 2,028 *4*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *3*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.78 10.75 10.89 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.39 8.32 7.99 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.58 10.51 10.73 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.22 8.15 8.02 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.71 10.62 10.91 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.60 8.57 8.02 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 11.23 11.06 11.42 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.55 8.53 8.22 Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.75 8.71 7.02 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.11 9.11 8.80 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: Hypertension? Relax
description: ILLNESS IS THE BIG STICK - IT gets your attention.'' The words were spoken by my physician as he talked to me about my blood pressure. He had just discovered it was alarmingly high. And these words kept coming back as I sat meditating months later in the crisp stillness of a sugar pine forest near Prescott, Ariz., where I had come to study with a visiting Burmese teacher. The blood pressure was the big stick that had sent me there.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am planning to install insulating board between my steam radiators and the outside walls immediately behind them. I am considering using either half-inch-thick foam insulating panels faced on both sides with aluminum foil, or quarter-inch-thick plywood or particle board faced on one side with aluminum foil. Can you tell me if the foam boards pose a fire or smoke hazard, and which type of board you would recommend?

title: Rich the Treasure
description: To the Editor;

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Dec. 4 about the Riva Pointe development in Jersey City identified its designers by a former name. The firm now is called Gruzen Samton Steinglass.

title: AT YOUR MOTHER'S KNEE
description: BLACK SHEEP AND KISSING COUSINS How Our Family Stories Shape Us. By Elizabeth Stone. 254 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: Psychedelic Drug Called Ecstasy Gains Popularity in Manhattan Nightclubs
description: A psychedelic drug nicknamed ecstasy, invented in laboratories in the 1970's and outlawed in 1985, is enjoying a vogue in nightclubs in downtown Manhattan, where it is attracting a young and arty following and even sparking a wave of ecstacy theme parties, T-shirts and music.

title: Sax Signing A Yankee Coup
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Exhibit Tells Bittersweet History of Vienna's Jews
description: With a sober disdain for its traditional image as a city of wine, waltzes and whipped cream, Vienna has brought to New York an exhibition that depicts candidly the often doleful 700-year history of its Jewish community.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: In the Pink
description: To the Editor:
