The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 4 1 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 5 36 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A HARD ROAD TO GLORY: A History of the African-American Athlete, by Arthur R. Ashe Jr. with Kip Branch, Ocania Chalk and Francis Harris. (Amistad/Warner, Volume One: 1619-1918, $29.95; Volume Two: 1919-1945, $39.95; Volume Three: Since 1946, $39.95.) A sport-by-sport narrative history, with extensive reference sections, that turns previously undocumented stories into fact. NO IDLE HANDS: The Social History of American Knitting, by Anne L. Macdonald. (Ballantine, $19.95.) A historian (and lifelong knitter) surveys the transformations in women's roles through the changes - and constancy - of their handiwork. PARTING THE WATERS: America in the King Years 1954-63, by Taylor Branch. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A monumental (1,064 pages) account, centered on the life and work of Martin Luther King Jr., of the nation in one of its most painful and critical passages, the rise of the civil rights movement. CHEKHOV: A Spirit Set Free, by V. S. Pritchett. (Random House, $17.95.) This graceful, imaginative literary biography by the distinguished British short-story writer and critic argues that Chekhov is best approached through his short fiction. THESE THINGS HAPPEN, by Marian Thurm. (Poseidon, $15.95.) The characters in Ms. Thurm's second collection of short stories never know when love will arrive - or when it will depart. KISSES OF THE ENEMY, by Rodney Hall. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A scary dystopia of the 1990's, in which the Central Intelligence Agency compasses the subversion of Australia; by an Australian novelist not nearly well enough known here. BEHIND THE WALL: A Journey Through China, by Colin Thubron. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) Lyricism and melancholy, humorous misunderstandings and confrontations with otherness in a witty and sometimes cynical itinerary of China's accessible regions.

title: Trees and Menorahs: They Don't Have to Clash
description: ''HOW come we don't have a Christmas tree like my friend Mary?'' 7-year-old Sarah asked her mother. ''She has a really neat tree that they decorate with colored lights and glass ornaments. Then they put presents under it, and everybody gets lots and lots of presents. So how come we don't?''

title: Near End of a Season of Pain, The Giants Are Feeling Super
description: Last Wednesday, Ahmad Rashad, the former wide receiver and now an NBC television commentator, arrived at Giants Stadium with a camera crew.

title: Mary Sweeney Weds Dr. Clement A. Price
description: At Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Newark, Mary Sue Sweeney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweeney of Mount Lebanon, Pa., and Dr. Clement Alexander Price, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Price of Washington, were married yesterday by the Rev. Michael du Plessis.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'AMAHL' IN ENGLEWOOD Gian Carlo Menotti's classic Christmas opera, ''Amahl and the Night Visitors,''' will be presented Saturday evening at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood.

title: A Misdiagnosed Deaf Man's Ordeal
description: Joe McNulty flicked a chest pass and broke into a graceful sprint down the basketball court in a practice drill. A defender played him closely, denying Mr. McNulty the 20-footer he can shoot with precision, so he pointed to an open man.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Helping Buyers; Pension Fund Widens Housing Role
description: IT took Angela Battaglia four months to sell 44 unbuilt houses in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn this fall. Now that she has sold them, Leslie Lerner and Michael Dubb, principals in the Beechwood Organization, based in New Hyde Park, L.I., will build them.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Urban Design in Western Europe'' by Wolfgang Braunfels (University of Chicago Press) on Nov. 6 misstated the price of the book. It is $49.95.

title: Computer Invader Urged to Contact Target
description: A computer expert who has breached low-level security at a top Federal weapons laboratory about 10 times in the past week is being urged by officials to contact the laboratory so they can find out what he wants.

title: A Life Very Rich in Giving
description: THE box - property of my law client, the Estate of Tony D (as we'll call him)- rested on a bare white table at the East Orange Veterans' Hospital. It was an ordinary-looking cardboard box, but its contents were not ordinary. Inside lay tiny odd-shaped devices and delicate pulleys designed to respond to the mouth and tongue of a man paralyzed below the neck, bearing silent witness to a nearly motionless life.

title:
NATIONAL NOTBOOK: Fitchburg, Wis.;
Variety Spices Seminole Ridge
description: LEAD: ABOUT 20 builders have completed 60 homes in a variety of styles - Georgian, Victorian, colonial, contemporary and others - in a year-old project called Seminole Ridge in this southwestern suburb of Madison, the state capital.

title: Eagles Stay in Race
description: The ball has bounced and fluttered so unpredictably this season for the Philadelphia Eagles and the Phoenix Cardinals that no one here this afternoon was surprised over the puzzling twists their second meeting offered. Philadelphia won, 23-17, and left thankful that somehow the National Conference East title remains in its grasp.

title: Cuomo Orders State Agency To Fight Lilco Rate Increase
description: Governor Cuomo ordered a state consumer agency today to petition the Public Service Commission to reject the Long Island Lighting Company's request for a $97.7 million rate increase.

title: NAVIGATING THE STRAITS OF OEDIPUS
description: THE PSYCHOANALYTIC THEORY OF MALE HOMOSEXUALITY By Kenneth Lewes. 301 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: THE NATION: Critics Say It's No Cigarette; Pardon Me - Can I Bum a Nicotine Delivery System?
description: IF a tobacco-filled object is the same size, shape and weight as a cigarette; if it is sold at cigarette counters in packs of 20; if its package contains the familiar Surgeon General's health warnings, and if it is lighted on one end and smoke is drawn through a filter on the other, then is it a cigarette?

title: Pet Buyers' Baedecker: Making Sure It's the Right Choice
description: LEAD: PETS can be a wonderful holiday present if they are chosen to match the recipient's life style, say experts in the pet care field. With careful planning and research, they say, anyone can find the right combination.

title: What Is Role Of Academics?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Home, Sweet Collapsible Home

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: A MIRACLE has happened. A fairy godmother has waved her magic wand, or a good jinni has popped out of a lamp and presto! In the midst of one of the year's most frenzied months, you have an unexpected day off. There is only one stipulation to this day - it cannot be used for Christmas shopping - because both the godmother and the jinni know that that would be a waste. They are well aware that the shopping, with or without a free day, is going to get done.

title: At the Met, 9,000 Objects in 40 Straight Lines
description: In a memorable cinematic image from a film about Jorge Luis Borges, the writer wanders through what seems like miles of library stacks in his native Buenos Aires. So great is his pleasure as he contemplates these corridors of books that one senses the abundance and potential of his surroundings. An experience not unlike thisawaits the public along the crystalline corridors of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's new Henry R. Luce Center for the Study of American Art, which opens next Wednesday. Arrayed on shelves on both sides of more than 40 parallel floor-to-ceiling glass showcases, most of them 27 feet long, are not books but a visual feast of the almost 9,000 objects of American fine and decorative art, from the 17th to the early 20th century, that have previously been kept in storage.

title: ADVISER TO LEADER OF GREECE RESIGNS
description: The chief legal adviser to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou resigned today and a senior banking executive was arrested in a deepening political and financial scandal.

title: Pope Sends His Condolences And $100,000 to Armenians
description: Pope John Paul II today offered his condolences and sent $100,000 in assistance to victims of the earthquake in the Soviet republic of Armenia.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: REEL ART: Great Posters From the Golden Age of the Silver Screen. By Stephen Rebello and Richard Allen. (Abbeville Press, $75.) This handsome volume is encyclopedic in intent (and almost so in weight). What started as a minor need in the business of entertainment grew into an art form that became a major part of outdoor advertising, namely the 24-sheet: a poster 24 feet long.

title: Sweet the Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Exposure Meters
description: WHEN photography was invented, exposure meters didn't exist. Those who pioneered the new medium simply uncapped their lenses until the exposure felt right. By trial and error, they learned to judge how much light was enough.

title: Review/Opera; Americans Hold Sway In London 'Rigoletto'
description: The conquest of Europe's opera houses by American singers has been a topic of much discussion on both sides of the Atlantic in recent seasons. A century ago, the struggle was for Americans to be taken seriously in a European art form; today, they dominate the rosters at home and abroad.

title: Evelyn Day to Marry An Artist in January
description: The engagement of Evelyn Morris Day to David Paul Lasry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James E. Lasry of La Jolla, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Day 3d of New York. The couple plan to marry Jan. 7.

title: Pinon Nuts
description: To the Editor: Susan Benner's article about pine nuts (Travel, Nov. 6) recalled a trip we took to the north rim of the Grand Canyon during the middle of October 1986, just before that facility closed down for the winter.

title:
MUSIC;
A Tough Time for Music Directors
description: LEAD: DESPITE the solemn and serene nature of some of the music performed during the Christmas season, as well as the joyous and exuberant sounds of many Christmas carols, the life of a church's music director during this month is filled with stress.

title: Fear Corrodes Faith at Atomic Plants
description: In the work bays of the nuclear bomb plant here, just off the lonely highway east of Amarillo, small groups of workers gather and ask one another questions filled with fear.

title: Moving Out is Hard to Do
description: A FRIEND of mine compares changing homes to childbirth; insisting that the memory of the pain fades with the years. Perhaps I am still experiencing post-moving depression, because every detail of our last move remains clear.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am planning to install insulating board between my steam radiators and the outside walls immediately behind them. I am considering using either half-inch-thick foam insulating panels faced on both sides with aluminum foil, or quarter-inch-thick plywood or particle board faced on one side with aluminum foil. Can you tell me if the foam boards pose a fire or smoke hazard, and which type of board you would recommend?

title: Nets Shake Six-Game Slump
description: It wasn't pretty, and it certainly wasn't easy, but the Nets' six-game losing streak is over.

title: The Heat Remains Cold
description: The Miami Heat lost its 16th straight game tonight, setting a National Basketball Association record for most defeats at the start of a season. Michael Jordan's 38 points fueled the Chicago Bulls to a 111-88 victory.

title: Video-Game Mania: Passing Phase or Permanent Addiction?
description: WHERE did we go wrong? How could this have happened to us? Didn't we, with Nancy Reagan's help, instill enough responsibility and respect for the right family values to avoid such a catastrophe? Why couldn't he Just Say No?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am planning to install insulating board between my steam radiators and the outside walls immediately behind them. I am considering using either half-inch-thick foam insulating panels faced on both sides with aluminum foil, or quarter-inch-thick plywood or particle board faced on one side with aluminum foil. Can you tell me if the foam boards pose a fire or smoke hazard, and which type of board you would recommend?

title: NATIONAL NOTBOOK: York, Ontario; Riverfront Units At Modest Cost
description: FINAL approval for the redevelopment of 32 acres on the Humber River in York, a city of 135,000 on the northwest border of Toronto, promises to add much-needed moderately priced housing to the region.

title: Design Conspiracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoker Causes Hospital Fire
description: A lung cancer patient who lit a cigarette while inhaling pure oxygen caused a fire Friday that burned him and forced evacuation of patients at University Medical Center. The patient, George Stickler, 59 years old, suffered second-degree burns on his back, the authorities said. Eleven other patients on the same floor were evacuated before hospital personnel extinguished the blaze. Damage was estimated at $3,000.

title: Farming Together Holds the Land Together
description: FOR nearly as long as Barbara and John Wilkens can remember, people have been trying to buy their 180-acre farm here. There have been those looking for a home for the United Nations and those hoping to create a Westchester Levittown, and even county officials trying to condemn the property for a golf course.

title: America Is 'Fully Employed,' But Some Still Need Jobs
description: NOT so long ago, 4 percent unemployment was considered more or less normal. Then by the late 1970's, many economists began maintaining that full employment - by their definition, the point at which the economy is providing as many jobs as can reasonably be expected - corresponded to an unemployment rate of 6 percent. And after the recession of 1981 and 1982, members of the Reagan Administration suggested that a 6.5 percent rate was acceptable.

title: Ellen Unterberg Engaged to Wed Andrew Celli Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Susan Unterberg and Thomas Unterberg, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter Ellen Rose Unterberg to Andrew George Celli Jr., a son of Judge and Mrs. Celli of Rochester.

title: GREAT-AUNT PRUDENCE AND OTHER GHOSTS
description: THE WRONG-HANDED MAN By Lawrence Millman. 104 pp. Columbia: University of Missouri Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: Assimilation Is Not Just Mimicry
description: The essay titled ''Foreign Children: Hoping to Fit In'' (Opinion page, Nov. 6) about a World War II immigrant's experience struck a familiar chord but a very different conclusion with me. I, too, am a first-generation American. I breakfasted on a Swiss-import muesili when my classmates ate Frosted Flakes. I wore sensible tights when my peers wore nylons and high heels. I spoke English, but this still did not stop my classmates from telling me to ''go back to England.''

title: A Corker of a Salesman
description: A couple of famous cork sniffers showed up -Andre Tchelistcheff, for example, and Maynard Amerine and Tom Selfridge - but the rest were salesmen and they had come to honor one of their own. Legh F. Knowles, chairman of Beaulieu Vineyard and one of the best wine salesmen of them all, was packing it in.

title: Big-Screen Television Fights the Fuzzy Image
description: Whenever people buy a new television set, they tend to pick a larger screen size than they had before. This may account for the fact that sets with 26- or 27-inch screens (measured diagonally) are now gaining a greater share of the market despite their higher cost.

title:
INVESTING;
Beware of Municipal Junk Bonds
description: LEAD: Municipal junk bonds have held considerable allure because of their tax-free high yields and because their government connections have made them seem somewhat safer than their more famous cousins, corporate junk bonds. But many investment managers and analysts say the prices of municipals with below-investment-grade ratings or no ratings, have reached unrealistic heights - in other words, their yields do not adequately reflect their risks.

title: Two Weddings in Archer Family Are Planned
description: Sheila Ann Archer and Edward A. Bugniazet 3d plan to marry in April. Tara Anne Sexton and Miss Archer's brother, George H. Archer Jr., are planning a wedding next September.

title: Hispanics Getting Additional Services
description: LEAD: WITH the increasing visibility of Hispanic-owned businesses mirroring the growth of Long Island's Hispanic community in general, services geared to members of that community are also on the rise.

title: A Christmas Appeal: The Neediest Cases, 1988
description: For the mother of a severely retarded adult daughter, and for other families in need whose stories are told today, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund offers dignity and support. Articles, page 66.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 11, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 4 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 6 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 4 2 SILVER ANGEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A kidnapped Englishwoman finds romance in a pasha's harem. 5 6 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 6 2 THE MASK, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.50.) The horrors that befall a couple after they adopt an attractive teen-ager. 7 12 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 8 9 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 9 17 WAR AND REMEMBRANCE, by Herman Wouk. (Pocket, $5.95.) The Henry family from Pearl Harbor to the surrender of Germany and Japan. 10 10 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 11 7 GLITTERING IMAGES, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Sex, love, self-analysis, forgiveness and reverence in English clerical circles. 12 1 THE FINAL NEXUS, by Gene DeWeese. (Pocket, $3.95.) A new ''Star Trek'' novel. 13 10 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 14 20 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 15 5 SEARCH THE SHADOWS, by Barbara Michaels. (Berkley, $4.50.) A young woman's quest for the truth about her parentage threatens her life. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 7 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 2 2 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Bantam, $4.95.) The television star muses on life at 50. 3 3 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 4 29 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 5 26 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 268 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 17 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race's struggle for identity, seen through many centuries of mythology. 8 19 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) A discussion of what ''every American needs to know.'' 9 * 19 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 10 31 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 7 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 3, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $10.95.) A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 2 11 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 2 SEPARATED AT BIRTH? by the editors of Spy. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $6.95.) Humorous juxtapositions of celebrities' pictures. 4 13 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 5 1 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Q and A
description: Is It a Condo or a Co-op?

title: Celebrating the Arts
description: Orchestral Benefit

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GIG, by James D. Houston. (Creative Arts Book Company, $8.95.) For Roy Ambrose, a middle-aged jazz musician, one gig seems pretty much like the next. But on Saturdays - especially with a full moon in the sky - he knows that the evening is bound to be wild. This novel about a night at a California roadhouse is a ''sparkling tour de force'' and ''continually intriguing,'' Martin Levin said in The Book Review in 1969. HITCHCOCK AND SELZNICK: The Rich and Strange Collaboration of Alfred Hitchcock and David O. Selznick in Hollywood, by Leonard J. Leff. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $11.95.) In a battle of enormous egos, the producer David O. Selznick and the director Alfred Hitchcock collaborated on ''Rebecca,'' ''Spellbound,'' ''Notorious'' and, finally, ''The Paradine Case.'' The last film was a disaster and the stormy partnership ended, but Hitchcock came away from the experience a more mature artist, Leonard J. Leff believes. Earlier this year our reviewer, Stephen Harvey, said this book is ''an absorbing dual portrait of professional equals whose clash of wills brought out the best in each of them even if the cost, in the end, proved more than either was willing to pay.'' CAFE NEVO, by Barbara Rogan. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) During the war in Lebanon, a Tel Aviv bistro becomes a meeting place where an odd collection of writers and artists try to sort out their entangled lives. Last year our reviewer, Robin Finn, said the most interesting character is the proprietor, Emmanuel Sternholz, an old man whose wife and child died in the Holocaust and who ''realizes that thanks to the Mecca that is his cafe, life has its core after all.'' BROADWAY BABIES: The People Who Made the American Musical, by Ethan Mordden. (Oxford University, $7.95.) This history of the American musical is a bit too breezy, Julius Novick said here in 1984, but it ''provides many acute, defining observations. . . . A keen, hyper-nervous mind can be seen in operation throughout.'' WHITE PALACE, by Glenn Savan. (Bantam, $4.50.) A young, up-and-coming advertising man has an affair with a middle-aged waitress. ''Mr. Savan writes skillfully about sex, as he does about most subjects,'' Meg Wolitzer said here last year. ''The author is convincing in creating the opposing worlds of Max and Nora - one ordered and sane, the other frenzied and anarchic.'' CAESARS OF THE WILDERNESS. Company of Adventurers: Volume II, by Peter C. Newman. (Penguin, $8.95.) At the peak of its power, the Hudson's Bay Company controlled an area 10 times the size of the Holy Roman Empire. The second volume of this history of the North American fur monopoly is ''a lively record of several generations of white men who did some quite astounding things,'' Joan Barfoot said here last year. REUBEN, by John Edgar Wideman. (Penguin, $7.95.) From his office in an abandoned trailer in the Pittsburgh ghetto called Homewood, Reuben, a black lawyer, tries to make sense of his clients' chaotic lives. Last year one reviewer called the book ''a work full of unfulfilled promises, deceptions, and rage - but one fueled by high-octane dialogue and explosive characterizations.'' HEARTS AND MINDS: A Personal Chronicle of Race in America, by Harry S. Ashmore. (Seven Locks, $14.95.) As editor of The Arkansas Gazette, Harry S. Ashmore won a Pulitzer Prize for his editorials supporting integration in Little Rock. ''The courage, care and candor that marked Mr. Ashmore's opposition to segregation and segregationists are still with him, qualities that make his book a valuable historical analysis of the last half-century of America's struggle with the racial issue,'' Claude Sitton said here in 1982. BABY HOUSTON, by June Arnold. (Texas Monthly, $8.95.) In a posthumously published fictional memoir, the feminist author June Arnold wrote about Baby, a self-centered, somewhat hysterical widow who lived early this century in the upper echelons of Houston society. ''The adoration that evidently prompted this autobiographical novel tends to depreciate the importance of [ its ] flaws,'' Eve Ottenberg Stone said here last year. ''We are in the arena of emotion, of real life, and of all its claims over those of fiction.'' ADAM & EVE AND THE CITY: Selected Nonfiction, by Francine du Plessix Gray. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Among the essays in this collection, the profiles of the monk-philosopher Thomas Merton and the fashion commissar Coco Chanel are timeless, Jonathan Alter said here last year. While he complained that some of the author's comments on American mainstream culture were haughty and disdainful, he praised ''her extraordinarily graceful writing style and exquisite literary and cultural sensibilities.'' THE SOURCE OF LIGHT, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A young poet is called back to North Carolina from a self-imposed European exile when his father dies. In 1981, Joyce Carol Oates called Reynolds Price's 10th book ''a somber, rather beautifully muted work,'' with ''a hero who is, in his very uncertainty, absolutely convincing.'' GOVERNING THE HEARTH: Law and the Family in Nineteenth-Century America, by Michael Grossberg. (University of North Carolina, $12.95.) By tracing the 19th-century roots of legal policies on marriage, adoption, abortion and other subjects, Michael Grossberg shows how legal history has helped shape the American family. In 1986 our reviewer, Isabel Marcus, called this ''an interesting and informative volume.''

title: What Stands Out In the N.F.L. This Year?
description: One word says it all: mediocrity. KEN MONTGOMERY Herndon, Va.

title: In Coma Five Months, Woman Has Baby Boy
description: A woman who has been in a coma for more than five months gave birth to a healthy boy by Caesarean section after labor was induced in a rarely used procedure, officials said today.

title: What is a Jew for?
description: Some people here are turning to anguished and profound questions as they watch with dismay, even disgust, the cynical haggling to form a new government. These are questions that haven't been asked for a long time. The very existence of Israel seemed answer enough.

title: Kiss of Life for a Dog
description: Patricia Lopes, who owns a pet grooming store, says she does not mind kissing dogs but would rather not perform mouth-to-mouth resuscitation again. She said she had just finished bathing and clipping the toenails of Escape, a 13-year-old retired greyhound racer, when the dog collapsed Dec. 2. When she could find no pulse, she said she assumed the dog had had a heart attack and began cardiopulmonary resuscitation. ''After a few minutes,'' she said, ''I heard a cough and then a gurgle.'' The dog, owned by Roger Roy of Acushnet, is now recovering at home.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Finn M. W. Caspersen; Keeping the Peddie School's Aims Alive
description: IT has been five years since Walter H. Annenberg, the founder of TV Guide and former Ambassador to Britain, presented the Peddie School in Hightstown with $12 million, the largest single gift ever made to an independent American secondary school. Once known primarily for its facilities and 200 acres of beautifully landscaped ground, Peddie has come to symbolize the importance of alumni giving to a secondary school.

title: Deregulation Has Gone Too Far, Many Tell the New Administration
description: President-elect Bush faces growing Congressional and public pressure to revitalize the Federal regulatory machinery, which as the Reagan Administration's apostle of deregulation he himself partly dismantled.

title: FLIGHTS OF FANCY
description: If there are baby eels or fresh flageolets in the market, chances are they'll wind up in Thomas Keller's skillet at Rakel in New York. What makes Keller notable in a city that's well populated with talented cooks are his daring flights from the ordinary. A few of the items on his menu even verge on the bizarre. There are duck hearts and cock's combs, white kidneys and lamb sweetbreads, sauteed monkfish set over a lentil stew, as well as a cappuccino of wild mushrooms and sabayon turned into a tart shell. He may work on a budget cut of meat or a chicken thigh until it is as rich and lustrous as a tender confit. ''I'm amazed at how eager my customers are to order these things,'' he says.

title: Albany Notes; School Board Pay May Be Trimmed
description: It hasn't been an easy year for the New York City Board of Education. The city's school system has been accused of being mismanaged, ineffective and, most recently, corrupt. To top it off, the Legislature voted during the summer to cut off per-diem payments to the members of the central board, led by Robert F. Wagner Jr. This week it appeared, however, that the board members would receive a reprieve. Their salaries are to be cut back, but not eliminated.

title: Local Charities
description: To the Editor:

title: New Finding on Child Abuse
description: THE state's Division of Youth and Family Services says it is still not sure why reports of child abuse, which have generally increased substantially in the last five years, drop each year between Thanksgiving and the end of January, but it is convinced that such cases are underreported during the holidays.

title: 'Let's Start Talking'
description: When a party to international conflict moderates its hostile words, diplomacy tests how meaningful the change is. You talk. You explore. You negotiate.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Cape Cod Cranberry Cure

title: Miss Flocco, Sculptor, Weds
description: Grace Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Debra Anne Flocco, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Flocco of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and William Van Orden Gnichtel Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gnichtel of Madison, N.J., and Tannersville, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher A. Brown performed the ceremony.

title: MAKING A RUN FOR IT
description: LAST RAMPAGE The Escape of Gary Tison. By James W. Clarke. Illustrated. 320 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: A Barbados Synagogue Is Reborn
description: One of the Western Hemisphere's oldest synagogues is an unprepossessing building of buff-colored coral stone and mortar tucked away on a side street in Barbados's capital, Bridgetown, and surrounded by the centuries-old graves of the island's Jewish settlers.

title: Martian Invasions
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Gunas Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Gunas Jr. of East Falmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Pamela Gunas to Jeffrey James Crampton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Crampton of Saratoga, Calif. Miss Gunas, who graduated cum laude from Smith College, is an account officer at the New York branch of Commerzbank. Her fiance, an associate at the Prudential Capital Corporation in Newark, graduated from Yale University. They plan to marry in June.

title: It's Black, And Basically, It's Back
description: OCCASIONALLY there is a stunning dress in a deep stained-glass color, or with lavish embroideries, that really catches your eye and holds it. But the number that has set the tone at the toniest of this season's formal gatherings - whether it be a dress, a pants suit or a strapless jump suit in silk, wool crepe or velvet - is invariably black and has long and simple lines.

title: After the Revolution, What?
description: ''This is hard work,'' Wendy Wasserstein says. Her new play, ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' opens tonight at Playwrights Horizons, and most of her time the last couple of months has been spent at the theater, first in rehearsals and then in previews. ''My mother tells me I shouldn't work so hard. I'm a girl, my mother says, and girls shouldn't work so hard.''

title: My Kind of First Lady
description: LEAD: One thing that I, a Dukakis voter, am sure to love about the Bush White House is Barbara Bush as First Lady.

title: It's Time to Curb the Courts
description: After the longest-running trial in America's history, a jury in Belleville, Ill., last year awarded one dollar to each of 65 plaintiffs as nominal damages for alleged personal injuries in a case involving one of my company's products - orthochlorophenol crude - which is used to make wood preservatives. Then, in a burst of tortured reasoning, the jury awarded $16 million in punitive damages to the plaintiffs.

title:
DANCE;
Pilobolus, Unruly as Ever, Pulls Together Anew
description: LEAD: Pilobolus Dance Theater tends to rub the New York dance establishment the wrong way. Structurally, it has never resembled other modern-dance companies, a fact that makes some observers uncomfortable. The 18-year-old troupe is a collective, currently run by five artistic directors - the founder dancers/choreographers, minus one - working with six performers.

title: Let's Stay as We Are, Teaneck Residents Say
description: From the steps of Town Hall, the skyscrapers of Manhattan in the distance are a daily reminder of what residents here say they do not want Teaneck to become.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. $755,000 11 Middle Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 57-year-old colonial; screened porch, fireplace, formal dining room; taxes $8,557. Katonah, N.Y. $290,000 8 Oak Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old ranch; fireplace, dining room, full basement, 1.5 acres; taxes $3,646. Scarsdale, N.Y. $828,000 33 Tompkins Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Tudor; 2 fireplaces, library, pegged oak floors, walk to train; taxes $12,110. Farmington, Conn. $268,000 65 Oakridge 3-bedroom, 2-bath new colonial; skylights, hardwood floors, 0.5 acre; taxes not available. Stamford, Conn. $435,000 67 East Huntington Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; large center hallway, canopied terrace, 1.5 acres; taxes $4,137. West Hartford, Conn. $113,000 16 Hillcrest Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; c/a, close to bus and shopping; taxes $1,464. OTHER AREAS Brookhaven, L.I. $162,500 15 Wedgewood Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,600. Commack, L.I. $179,000 21 Laurinda Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 1-car garage, pool; taxes $3,100. Franklin Lakes, N.J. $215,000 954 Pines Terrace 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; patio, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $1,712.

title: When 'Ye Olde Inn' Looks Can Deceive
description: THE Locust Valley Inn looks like its name. Its English Tudor architecture is a reflection of this affluent North Shore community. Stucco and half-timbered walls, a large stone fireplace and twinkling carriage lights spell ''ye olde inn.''

title: Hospitals' Services Imperiled
description: LEAD: ABOUT 50 percent of Long Island's hospitals operated in the red this year, mainly because Federal and state reimbursement rates lagged far behind the hospitals' increased costs.

title: Artists Seek Function for Design
description: LEAD: IN colonial days, the cabinetmaker was the coveted furniture designer. Today, in contrast to technological sameness, some artists are carving out a niche, again creating unique furniture that is considered both functional and art worthy.

title: Leftist Causes? Rock Seconds Those Emotions
description: Is there an inherent leftist political bias, or even component, to rock-and-roll? The issue came to mind recently when Richard Taruskin, a musicologist writing in The New Republiccalled into question similar assumptions about classical-music modernists of earlier in the century by citing right-wing opinions of various sorts held by such icons as Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Webern.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am planning to install insulating board between my steam radiators and the outside walls immediately behind them. I am considering using either half-inch-thick foam insulating panels faced on both sides with aluminum foil, or quarter-inch-thick plywood or particle board faced on one side with aluminum foil. Can you tell me if the foam boards pose a fire or smoke hazard, and which type of board you would recommend?

title: Knicks Surge Past Kings
description: The Sacramento Kings brought a 3-13 record into last night's game against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. The only poorer mark in the National Basketball Association belonged to the Miami Heat, the expansion team that is still looking for its first victory of the season.

title: When Conducting Calls Attention to Itself
description: Schubert never heard of conductors, at least the kind who bear that job description today. The ones he knew were simpler folk. They beat time, managed tempo changes and otherwise kept out of the way. The days of the musical auteur were not quite yet at hand.

title: Filipinos Still Wary When It Comes to Marcos
description: News that Ferdinand E. Marcos had been hospitalized in Hawaii with heart problems was greeted in Manila today with a joke that illustrates the lingering pain with which his presidency is remembered.

title: Exanding Limits For the Disabled
description: WHILE Bernice Goldberg can't see the pastel baby blanket she is weaving for a friend, she can touch it. ''I know I am creating something,'' she said recently, while working on a large loom in the crafts center of the Rye Association for the Handicapped, ''because as I go along, I feel it progressing, and this gives me a sense of satisfaction.''

title: To Marrakesh, With Love And Indecision
description: It reached a point before our family decided where we would go on a one-week vacation that I had accumulated so many travel folders, guidebooks, air fares, flight times and magazine articles that if there were a travel trivia game show I would have won the car or the safari or whatever they would give away on a show like that. I also had made so many airline reservations I was practically at the level where the conversation would go, ''T.W.A. Debby speaking. How may I help you?'' ''It's Avery.'' ''Oh, hi, Avery. What flight would you like to cancel today?''

title: Columbia Places a Help-Wanted Ad
description: Each day the mail brings more resumes and letters from those wanting to be Columbia's football coach. Al Paul, the director of athletics, is not surprised.

title: Review/Music; Grand Opera Symphony
description: It was hard to make much sense of Thursday evening's concert at Alice Tully Hall. Vincent La Selva conducted an orchestra called the New York Grand Opera Symphony in familiar repertory by Rossini, Gluck, Beethoven and Brahms; Gabriella Tucci sang soprano arias by Rossini and Mozart.

title: Kissing Customs
description: I returned not long ago from from a three-year assignment in Poland, where men kiss the hands of women as a matter of course when they meet. When I first arrived in Warsaw, I did not think this was such a great idea. At the time I thought of myself as a democratic kid from the streets of New York, and the notion of bending over and brushing my lips over the back of a woman's hand struck me as offensively feudal and hopelessly effete. Each time some perfectly fine woman offered me the back of her hand to kiss, I stammered my apology, saying something like, ''Gosh, no offense intended, but where I come from we don't carry on like this, and while I respect you enormously, can't we make do with a simple handshake?''

title: Valhalla Lab Specializes in New Forensic Test
description: LEAD: THE police in Sandpoint, Idaho, a logging town near the Canadian border, were stymied. They had identified a suspect in the rape last year of a schoolteacher who was attacked in her home at 2 A.M. But the victim was legally blind and could not identify her attacker.

title: Article 310888 -- No Title
description: THE MARCOS DYNASTY By Sterling Seagrave. Illustrated. 485 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CLOSING THE TRADE GAP;
To Cure the Deficit, Bring Back Barter
description: LEAD: Since 1985, the Treasury Department's devaluation formula to increase exports has slashed the price of the dollar nearly in half. But the devaluation experiment failed and imports are still rising as exports fall back.

title: State Court Holds Kentucky Can Be Liable in '77 Club Fire
description: The Kentucky Court of Appeals has ordered hearings on damage claims against the state in the fire at the Beverly Hills Supper Club that killed 165 people in 1977.

title: ''We've Got To Stop Pollution Now''
description: LAST summer's heat wave and erratic rainfall patterns focused attention on the ''greenhouse effect'' that some scientists predict will happen as a result of burning fossil fuels. In response, Lisa Newton, the director of applied ethics and environmental studies programs at Fairfield University, says it is imperative that state and Federal governments design economic incentives that would make mass transportation and alternative forms of energy more attractive.

title: In the Midst of Silence, Carl Davis Speaks
description: Silence is golden, granny always said. But for Carl Davis silents are golden, in a long profitable line stretching from Abel Gance's epic ''Napoleon,'' by way of ''Broken Blossoms,'' ''The Thief of Bagdad'' and ''The Eagle,'' to ''The Big Parade,'' ''Greed'' and ''Intolerance.''

title: Uncle Sam's Bank?
description: To The Editor:

title: The Pageant Papers: A Teacher's Checklist
description: HAND program to secretary on time this year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Deregulation seems to be one of those things where the political costs are higher than the payoffs.'' - William A. Niskanen, formerly on the Council of Economic Advisers. [ 60:2. ]

title: Boardwalk Fire Guts Shut Amusement Park
description: An abandoned amusement park and a row of seaside businesses in Atlantic City were destroyed yesterday in a four-alarm fire that raged for more than eight hours, Fire Department officials said. No injuries were reported. The fire, at the Steeple Chase Pier amusement park on the Boardwalk, raged 75 feet from the Resorts International Casino Hotel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-31

title: The Caribbean Under Sail On One's Own
description: Bareboating - sailing a chartered craft yourself - is the sailor's ideal, when the master and the craft, the wind and the sea is all there is; joined to the sea and yet alone, the boater accepts the rhythm of nature.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: THE BASEBALL HALL OF FAME 50th ANNIVERSARY BOOK. Edited by Gerald Astor. (Prentice Hall, $40.) This is a wonderful survey of the sport, with unusual pictures and essays by grand sportwriters including Robert Lipsyte, George Vecsey, Robert Creamer and Roger Kahn. For me the historical sections are almost the most interesting.

title:
WINTER IN THE SUN;
A Taste of Puerto Rico At Its Country Inns
description: LEAD: Once upon a Sunday not so long ago, I came across Raul Julia, smiling, seated in a four-color ad between a tropical veranda and the deep blue sea, and inviting me to ''Discover the Paradores of Puerto Rico - a beautiful escape from civilization.'' Right away I called ''a Puerto Rico Travel Expert'' in New York.

title: Prospects; An Almost Green Christmas
description: So far this season, Christmas sales figures are mixed. The weekend after Thanksgiving, which kicks off the buying season, saw retail sales soar. But the following week the momentum subsided. Four experts give their sales outlooks for the buying season. Rosalind Wells President, Wells & Associates and chief economist, National Retail Merchants Association.

title: Costly Components Offer Some Subtle Musical Joys
description: It's not just the rich who buy fancy sound gear. Surveys show that most blue-chip components are owned by listeners in income brackets that raise suspicion that they skipped lunch for years in order to buy the stuff. They are a special breed of customer. Their passion for music is simply too strong to let them balk at the price.

title: Sherri Mushnick Married To William B. Rosenberg
description: At the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in East Rockaway, L.I., Sherri Beth Mushnick and William Bruce Rosenberg were married last evening by Rabbi Stanley Platek.

title: A Good Lesson From Lou Holtz
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan N. Greenberg to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Greenberg of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Nancy Greenberg to Stewart Andrew Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Fisher of East Brunswick, N.J. Miss Greenberg, a pediatric nurse practitioner at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, and her fiance, a senior financial analyst in the treasurer's office of the General Motors Corporation in New York, plan to marry in August.

title: A SEASON THAT HAS SEEN RECORDS TOPPLED DAILY
description: Masterpieces that are also rarities proved just as magical for the collectors and dealers spending money on French furniture, Chinesebronzes and American Indian artifacts at antiques auctions oover the last month as they were earlier in sales of paintings by Picasso and Jasper Johns.

title: A Close Match
description: AN episode in ''Right Through the Pack'', the classic work by Robert Darvas and Norman de Vere Hart, concerns a player who was too brilliant. Playing in a hopeless seven no-trump contract he contrived a complicated squeeze to avert a two-trick defeat.

title: Judgeship Elections: Voters Were the Losers
description: The story entitled ''Democrats Losing Out on Judgeships'' (Nov. 20) leads the reader to believe that Long Island's judiciary is being decimated because incumbent judges sometimes lose their re-election bids. The article particularly bemoans the departure from the bench of Victor J. Orgera who, having been defeated in a bid for election to Suffolk's County Court, is preparing for the return to private life.

title: Belinda Getler Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Getler of Alexandria, Va., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Belinda Getler, to Pascal Norman Levinsohn, a son of Rita Levinsohn of Wellington, Fla., and the late Philip Levinsohn. The couple plan an April wedding.

title:
GARDENING;
Turning Prunings Into Seasonal Beauty
description: LEAD: WITH the right accessories and a bit of imagination, decorative holiday arrangements can be easily created from the prunings of evergreens combined with other materials from the garden. The prunings of yews, one of the most useful and relatively trouble-free evergreen shrubs, are commonly used in such arrangements since they will not shed needles even when dried out.

title: Owners Revive Memories of Pre-Collusion Days
description: As Yogi Berra might have said, it's deja vu again.

title: A Miles Davis Collection With Only Half the Story
description: No one would have an easy time summing up Miles Davis's career in a five-LP/four-cassette/four-CD package like ''Miles Davis: The Columbia Years 1955-1985'' (Columbia C5X45000). In 30 years and nearly 50 albums before he left Columbia for Warner Bros., Mr. Davis was one of the most restless, experimental thinkers in American music. Where most musicians are likely to find a style and refine it, the 62-year-old Mr. Davis has continually changed his ensembles, his repertory and the kind of trumpet solos he wants to play; every three or four years, he'd be up to something new. And Columbia Records has the archives to prove it.

title: In Ghana, The Leader At Full Sail
description: The man who rules Ghana, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings was giving the kind of restless, messianic performance that once earned him the nickname ''Junior Jesus.'' Prying open a can of instant coffee with a presidential spoon, he was not a head of state in need of caffeine.

title: On the Road With Hoffman and Cruise
description: They couldn't seem less alike, the two men sitting side by side at the counter of the trendy retro-1950's Pink Cadillac Cafe in West Hollywood. Charlie, the younger one, wears a modish dark sports jacket, a collar-buttoned but tieless white shirt, and a targeted extrovert gaze as he reads 11 pancake options - from buckwheat to beernut to blueberry - off a wall menu. Raymond, who may be 20 years older, not quite soigne in his gray suit and dark tie, his weary eyes seeming to look inward, says he just wants ''pancakes.'' '' 'Course,'' Charlie says. '' 'Course, the maple syrup is supposed to be on the table before the pancakes,'' Raymond states in his flat voice.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THIS month is the 201st anniversary of New Jersey's ratification of the United States Constitution on Dec. 18, 1787. As every schoolchild knows (or used to know, before ''social studies'' were substituted for history in school), this was an era when great leaders grappled with great issues.

title: Fare of the Country; Saturday Staple In Brazil: Manioc
description: Visitors to Brazil are likely to have their first taste of manioc, perhaps the most unique ingredient in the Brazilian kitchen, on a Saturday night when they order feijoada, the country's national dish. Served as a condiment in the form of raw or toasted flour, the manioc is spooned onto the variedmeats, rice, beans and greens that make up this tasty dish.

title: Hawaii: The Names Are Entrancing, the Designs Unique
description: IF ever a country needed a postal system, it was the Kingdom of Hawaii of 140 years ago. The archipelago, stretching over 1,600 miles of mid-Pacific, was a major staging area for the growing shipping trade between Asia and North America. Mail was the only means of communication.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FILM AND DEBATE

title: Trimming Back the Office Gift List
description: This holiday season, gift-giving at the office is being shaped by uncertainty over the economy and reverberations from last year's stock market crash. Santas in the executive suite are still giving gifts to colleagues, secretaries and clients, but budgets are down, experts say.

title:
DINING OUT;
Cuisine With a Basque Touch in Dover
description: LEAD: THE game of jai alai originated in the Basque region of Spain in the 17th century. It is somewhat like handball, but a basketlike scoop is fastened to the arm and is used to catch and propel the ball. Jai-Alai is also the name of a restaurant in Dover, in Morris County, owned by Basque-born Ignacio Cenicacelaya.

title: Holly Bowen Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Bowen of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Leigh Bowen, to David Thorndike Foster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Foster 3d of Manchester, Mass.

title: Flaws In the Old Masters
description: THERE is plenty of inspiration to be gleaned from the opening strategies of the 19th century, but there are dangers too.

title: Amy Fontaine and Ahmet Kok Marry
description: Amy Bienvenue Fontaine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fontaine of Grymes Hill, S.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Ahmet Mete Kok, a son of Ethem R. Kok of Stapleton, S.I., and Huriye Nesrin Olcmen of Istanbul, Turkey. Judge M. Holt Meyer of the Family Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: A New Emphasis on Dressing for Work
description: IS there a growing tendency to subtly - or not so subtly - enforce specific codes of dress in the workplace? Consider the following:

title: New Director for Tass
description: Leonid P. Kravchenko, First Deputy Chairman of the State Television and Radio Committee for the last three years, has been appointed head of the official press agency Tass, the agency said Friday. Mr. Kravchenko, 50 years old, was editor in chief of the building industry newspaper Stroitelnaya Gazeta from 1975 to 1980 and later chief editor of the trade union daily Trud, Tass said. He replaces Sergei A. Losev, who died in October.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: THE HOME PLANET. Edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) This selection of photographs of Earth taken from space by men and machines, and annotated by those who have been in space, is not a coffee-table book. It is a photographic psalmbook, a biblical recitation as though the optic nerve of mankind were beholding the immense seedbed from which all cognizance sprang.

title: Home Release by Prisons Under Attack
description: IN June, a 24-year-old man slashed a female employee of a New Haven grocery with a razor in an attempted holdup a month after being given community release from a prison term. He had served 12 days of a less-than-one-year term.

title: House Genealogies Traced in Katonah
description: LEAD: NATHANIEL HUGGINS 3d hasn't had much time this year for such mundane chores as cleaning the gutters. More esoteric tasks, including making hundreds of shingles out of gummed wrapping paper and creating stained-glass windows out of acetate, are a different story.

title: Lisbeth Diringer To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Owen I. Diringer of Freeport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisbeth Marcie Diringer, to Lee Gordon Dunst, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Dunst of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Seton Hall Victory Ends an Old Jinx
description: Seton Hall ended seven years of frustration and a 75-year St. John's home-court jinx last night. The Pirates, who over the past year have turned into serious Big East contenders, defeated St. John's, 74-63.

title: Classic Face
description: There were 6,300 contestants nationwide and the regional winners were all in their 30's - all but one. Yvette Finkelstein of New Rochelle, a 47-year-old mother of three, sailed past the competition to win the 1988 Dove 30-Plus model search.

title: Granite Art: It Isn't Just Tombstones
description: Jerry Williams left art school to make his living as a stone carver, chiseling finely wrought images of the Virgin Mary and the saints into slabs of Barre gray granite to be used as cemetery headstones throughout the country.

title: Mothers Denounce Surrogate Parenting at Hearing
description: In the first public hearing on a bill that would outlaw surrogacy for profit in New York State, surrogate mothers last week denounced the practice as ''baby selling.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Nov. 6 about Post Office Square Park in Boston misidentified its designer. It is the Halvorson Company of Boston.

title: Burma's Unrest and Weather Help Opium Flourish
description: With the best opium growing conditions in many years occurring as the Burmese Army is preoccupied with political dissent, the flow of Southeast Asian opium and heroin to the rest of the world may increase by as much as 20 percent over last year, Western diplomats warn.

title: CRIME
description: God bless the police-procedural mystery. It makes heroes of decent cops, gives us the night vision to see our own cities and doesn't spit on honest work.

title: The Teapot's the Thing This Season
description: WHAT has four wheels and pours? The answer, of course, is a teapot shaped like a chariot. On exhibit at the Lee Sclar Gallery, 14 South Street, Morristown, this teapot is among many interpretations of a classic object that, as predictably as tinsel, are appearing this season in craft shops and galleries.

title: Massachusetts Port City Fighting Heroin Problem
description: This historic fishing port with its trawlers and luxury yachts, fish processing plants and cliffside mansions has spent the last decade in a frustrating battle against a rising tide of heroin addiction.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: A HOBBY that began three years ago when a Woodbury couple bought 10 domesticated deer from a farm in New York has grown into a business.

title: Free Camp Fair
description: Parents and potential campers can start planning next summer's choice at a free camp fair from noon to 4 P.M. today at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue. Directors of 25 camps accredited by the American Camping Association will be on hand. Most of the camps are private, sleep-away places with early registration dates, but information will be provided as well about day camps run by nonprofit agencies, and camps for children with special interests and needs. Brochures will be available. Information: 427-6000, extension 179.

title: Protesters Fight Savagely With the Police in Seoul
description: Protesters demanding the ouster of President Roh Tae Woo battled riot policemen with rocks and firebombs in the center of Seoul today after having been blocked from marching to the presidential palace.

title: Mim Stokes, an Investment Broker, Is Wed to Buck Brown, a Reporter
description: At the Idlewild Presbyterian Church in Memphis, Miriam Dean Stokes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Stokes Jr. of Memphis, was married yesterday to Francis Cabell Brown 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown Jr. of New York. The Rev. Louise Lawson performed the ceremony. She was assisted by the Rev. Thomas D. Kirk, a Roman Catholic priest. Elizabeth Edmondson Stokes was her sister's maid of honor and Timothy Patrick Sullivan was the best man.

title: What Ails a Nursing Home Empire
description: Like the residents at many of its nursing homes, Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest nursing-home chain, is in poor health. The company, with 1,003 nursing homes, is burdened by a reputation for poor care and suffocating under more than $1 billion in debt accumulated during a seven-year acquisition spree.

title: Sakharov Meets Walesa at Paris Ceremony
description: Andrei D. Sakharov and Lech Walesa met for the first time today, but the two studiously avoided saying anything that might suggest they were laying the groundwork for a human rights alliance in Communist Eastern Europe.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: TREASURES OF THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY. By Marshall B. Davidson with Bernard McTigue. (Abrams, $60.) The New York Public Library is the only great cultural building in the city which is still open free to the public. ''Treasures of the New York Public Library'' shows not only the glorious building itself but a sampling of all that it contains.

title: Ferry Leads Duke With 58
description: Danny Ferry broke a 37-year-old school record by scoring 58 points tonight as Duke won its closest game of the season, 117-102, over Miami.

title: BEIJING AUTHORITY BEING CHALLENGED BY LOCAL POWERS
description: Nearly four decades after China's Communist Party abolished local feifdoms and united China under a strong central Government, the country is again facing a serious challenge from regions that compete with each other and ignore commands from Beijing.

title: Review/Jazz; Reverberations of Benny Goodman
description: Walt Levinsky, who has played two engagements at Michael's Pub with his Great American Swing Band, re-creating the arrangements of such swing-era favorites as Benny Goodman, Count Basie, Harry James and Duke Ellington, is back at the East 55th Street restaurant all this month with a variation on the same theme. This time he is leading a sextet that is drawing on the style and repertory of Benny Goodman's small groups.

title: THE WORLD'S RICHEST MUSEUM
description: I enjoyed Michael Kimmelman's article about what the J. Paul Getty Museum, in Malibu, Calif., is up to (''The World's Richest Museum,'' Oct. 23). My observation about the reported attacks by Thomas Hoving (the editor in chief of Connoisseur magazine) on the Getty is that it's hooey. What appears to be an attack is a well conceived campaign to reap the Getty the maximum of publicity. The Getty's director, John Walsh, and his old boss and mentor, Thomas Hoving, are doing a little soft-shoe number. The art world is hugely entertained, and the Getty gets the exposure.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S CHILDREN
description: FOR MANY - BUT NOT all - of the people who live in it, Mrs. Thatcher's Britain feels today like a rich and booming society. In the London stores, money flows freely. In the clubs and pubs, so does the lager and the champagne -even more so now that Britain's once strict licensing laws have been relaxed. True, down by the Embankment of the river Thames, beggars work the commuting crowds and homeless young people sleep under the bridges, huddled in cardboard packaging. But downriver a sparkling new skyline shines - the post-modern high-rise towers of the thriving City of London, the banking and business quarter. The famous Square Mile - England's Wall Street - is an area of glass fantasy these days, and every building has its tree-filled atrium and its crystal elevators. Spreading out over the poorlands of the East End and onto the old docklands, once the heart of British imperial sea trade, it is the core of a new empire, now based on invisible transactions, electronic impulses, video display unit screens, fax machines and, above everything else, the new enterprise spirit.

title: POSTING: In the 'Village'; Urban Suburbia
description: Confronted by a difficult building site in a quintessentially urban setting, the developer of 117 Seventh Avenue South has found a distinctly suburban solution. Five duplex condominiums will be arranged like town houses around a landscaped courtyard 20 feet above the street, which residents will reach by an elevator. Below, 15,000 square feet of retail and restaurant space will fill two floors and a basement. In addition to the five duplexes, a single-level unit will have an entrance from the third-floor corridor that leads to the courtyard and a sixth duplex will have its own elevator landing on the fourth floor and reach into a penthouse turret. The red-brick structure, designed by the Liebman Melting Partnership, will be accented by granite footings, a cast-stone cornice and bow windows. The one - and two-bedroom units will have 800 to 1,200 square feet of space.

title: What They're Wearing
description: She seemed all but smothered in her petal-layered Ungaro, but Anne Bass wasn't letting a few excess yards of fabric cramp her style. Nor were lots of other women seen this past year on the dance floor at gala parties all over town. Not one was tripped up by a swirling skirt, sweeping train or triple-tiered ball gown. Proving, as Kenneth Jay Lane notes, that ''the dress does not the dancer make.'' The jewelry designer, who has partnered his share of fashionable women, admits that ''I've seen skirts you can't get close to.'' But things change, and already yesterday's pouf skirt and other wide-bodied looks have begun to be overtaken by leaner styles. Still, not everyone is giving up on fullness. Carolyne Roehm, for one, the designer and socialite, likes the romance of a wide skirt. ''It makes me feel feminine,'' she says. Downtown, where voguing is the rage (the dance is a series of stylized movements that recall 1960's fashion photographs), club personalities like Nell Campbell equate femininity with sultriness. ''I like dancing in high heels and a tight frock,'' says Ms. Campbell. ''But the dress has to move. If it doesn't give, how can I?''

title: Wall Township Journal; Allenwood Finds Its Humor Tested by Closed Bridge
description: ALLENWOOD, a historic and pastoral southwest corner of Wall Township in Monmouth County, is a quiet place, mostly, and better known for the good humor of its people than for political controversy.

title: The Appeal of a British Bill of Rights
description: IF they had occurred in the United States, measures taken by the Government in recent weeks to deal with violence and terrorism in Northern Ireland and revise the Official Secrets Act would have provoked a major confrontation with the Supreme Court or required a constitutional convention.

title: The Sweet Season
description: The happiest, and tastiest, holiday art show in town is at the American Craft Museum. ''The Confectioner's Art'' includes a portrait of Miss Liberty done, pointillist style, in jelly beans and another of The Lone Ranger done in sprinkles. There is a 12th-century Spanish tapestry made of chocolate and a modern assemblage contrived of licorice sticks. An elegant armchair is inlaid with gum drops and a Maison Carree has pillars of peppermint sticks along with a frieze of Life Savers.

title: Town Bids Farewell To Its Penny Meters
description: LEAD: THE 160 penny parking meters were lined up in rows on the gymnasium floor like the battlefield casualties they were - tagged with numbers, their scrapes on display - as the crowd milled about, speaking in hushed tones.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: The Greatest Risk Of All

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
A Fifth of County Property Is Tax Exempt
description: LEAD: FOR some in Westchester, many of the best things life, such as municipal services, are free, often to the economic detriment of local communities.

title: BEYOND 'E.T.' AND 'CINDERELLA': CHILDREN'S CASSETTES
description: Chemical changes occur in the brain of a person who becomes a parent, particularly in those areas that govern matters of taste. What once made the skin crawl is now worthwhile entertainment, fun for the whole family. Before my son was born, for instance, someone gave us a tape of Raffi singing folk songs for children and we listened for only a few minutes before deciding our friends had taken leave of their senses. These days, Raffi might as well be Mick Jagger.

title: 2nd Jail for Drunken Drivers
description: THE second state prison for convicted drunken drivers opened last week with the dedication of the Eddy D.W.I. Unit in Middletown.

title: THE WORLD: Bargaining and Bickering; Israelis Find Their Electoral Politics Work Against Their Votes
description: PEEL away the bargaining, the bickering and the almost daily convulsions of Israel's tortured negotiations on forming a government, and you are left with one stark fact: It seems likely that hardly any of the 2.3 million Israelis who cast ballots on Nov. 1 will get the government they had wanted.

title: 'Wiseguy' Recruits Some Stylish Acting Support
description: There is no obvious reason to anyone except Jerry Lewis why a show-business superstar would want to work outdoors on a wet, winter night when he could be making people laugh in a warm, dry nightclub.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Bad Read
description: LEAD: What's the very worst, absolutely most awful, totally terrible book you've ever read?

title:
Tales of Despair, Sorrow and Need Recounted by Agencies Aided by Fund;
United Jewish Appeal Leads Help Network
description: LEAD: The financial experts and politicians say we are in an era of prosperity. Income is up, unemployment is down and things are better than ever, they say.

title: Dr. Lorie Zimmerman To Marry in February
description: Dr. Lorie Beth Zimmerman, a senior resident in internal medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, and Scott Richard Benson, a financial analyst with A.T.&T. in Murray Hill, N.J., plan to be married Feb. 12.

title: Couple Slashed on IRT Train In Attack Classified as Racial
description: By The Associated Press

title: A Fighting Building
description: To the Editor:

title: STREETSCAPES: The Century Association Clubhouse; Richardson's Lost Work Discovered Housing a Travel Agency on East 15th
description: THE all-male Century Association has been in the news recently because of its decision to admit women as members to its 1889 clubhouse at 7 West 43d Street. But there is news of a different sort about the venerable club: Its earlier clubhouse on East 15th Street, thought to have been demolished, is not only still around, but also seems likely to be a hitherto undiscovered work by H. H. Richardson, one of the greatest American architects.

title: BOOSTERISMO
description: LEAD: AMERICAN PROGRESS The Growth of the Transport, Tourist, and Information Industries in the Nineteenth-Century West Seen Through the Life and Times of George A. Crofutt, Pioneer and Publicist of the Transcontinental Age. By J. Valerie Fifer. Illustrated. 472 pp. Chester, Conn.: The Globe Pequot Press.

title: Europe Talks Focus on Terrorist Extradition
description: Interior and justice ministers of the European Community meeting in Athens agreed today that common European legislation on extradition was necessary to combat ''the continuing threat from international terrorism.''

title: THE WORLD: Gorbachev's New York; The Tourist Who Attracted Tourists
description: THE motorcades that shuttled Mikhail S. Gorbachev were not quite triumphal, yet at times as they raced across Manhattan, he seemed to be taking a victory lap, perhaps as the world's most spontaneous Communist, or as the man who was doing more than anyone else to bring street smarts to world affairs. Such claims can best be authenticated, at least for short periods, in New York.

title: TRITIUM GAP CALLED PATH TO ARMS CUTS
description: An idea to use shrinking levels of a nuclear bomb fuel to reduce superpower weapons provoked debate Friday among weapon experts at a conference called by a private group promoting the concept.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: IDEALIZED VISIONS

title:
FOCUS;
High Road, Low Road - It's All Prime Real Estate
description: LEAD: When the Australian Prime Minister, Japanese Foreign Minister, Philippine Minister of Commerce and other foreign dignitaries showed up here for the dedication of the Washington State Convention and Trade Center this fall, officials stood with them above the city's busiest freeway at rush hour - and the guests expressed praise and admiration.

title: Reagan Praises Soviet Cuts But Still Sees Big Disparity
description: President Reagan said today that he welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promises of military cutbacks, but he said that even if they were made, the Warsaw Pact would retain a large advantage over the NATO alliance.

title: Q and A; D'Oyly Carte
description: Question: We are Gilbert & Sullivan fans, are going to London Christmas week and hear that the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company has re-formed and is performing again. But we have been unable to find out how to get tickets. - T. G. B., Troy, N.Y. Answer: Visitors to London this Christmas can see some Gilbert & Sullivan but not with the New D'Oyly Carte. The English National Opera is presenting Jonathan Miller's radical production of ''The Mikado,'' which substitutes a British hotel between the wars for the Orient, at the Coliseum Theater (London 836 3161) on St. Martin's Lane. Performance dates are Dec. 15, 19, 21, 23 and 30. There are two shows in January.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 27 about computerized customer service misstated the cost of a New Image computer consultation at Macy's Glemby Beauty Salon. Customers pay $30, of which $20 can be applied to any Glemby hair service.

title: TAKING A BACK SEAT
description: That they have been deemed universally uncomfortable doesn't seem to matter. Indeed, hall chairs -those funny wooden seats first made for the great halls of English houses - are being voraciously collected by decorators and Anglophiles alike. Renowned architects, the likes of William Kent, Robert Adam and Sir John Soane, made them for the buildings they designed. And such formidable cabinetmakers as Thomas Chippendale produced them, too.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Amherst, Mass.;
Affordability On a Farm
description: LEAD: JUDY RIVARD and her husband, Robert, got a hearty welcome from town officials when they proposed to build Misty Meadows, a 41-unit project that includes 16 apartments that the town and state are helping make affordable to first-time buyers.

title: Article 310088 -- No Title
description: THE ELEPHANT AND MY JEWISH PROBLEM Selected Stories and Journals, 1957-1987. By Hugh Nissenson. 211 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: Seminar on Nobel Winner
description: Najib Mahfouz, the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature, is to be the subject of a free lecture by Mona N. Mikhail, an associate professor of Arabic Literature at New York University, on Thursday at 6 P.M. at the Hagop Kevorkian Center of New York University, 50 Washington Square South. Selected writings by the Egyptian author will be read in Arabic and in English. Information: 998-8877.

title: HITLER AND THE BOMB
description: In his article ''Hitler and the Bomb'' (Nov. 13), McGeorge Bundy speculates on what might have happened if any inquiry or exploration had come to Werner Heisenberg from the Allies about the possibility, during the war, of scientists' limiting research on nuclear matters so as to prevent their countries from building a bomb.

title: Study Calls for 2 Closures
description: The Department of Energy has given the White House a classified study calling for closing two atomic weapons plants in Ohio and Colorado and urging the Government to spend billions of dollars to clean up 15 other laboratories and production plants in the nuclear weapons industry, Federal officials said today.

title: Abandoned Cars Stir Action
description: LEAD: AS the demand for scrap metal steadily declines, the number of abandoned vehicles littering Long Island's roadways has increased, forcing many towns to enforce stiffer penalties against those convicted of dumping their cars.

title: Hospitals Facing Threats to Financial Health
description: LEAD: ALONG with uncertainty about the state's Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, New Jersey hospitals face a number of other changes and unresolved issues at year's end that could have major effects on their financial health in 1989. Among the issues are these:
