title:
DINING OUT;
Pasta Dishes Spotlighted in Pelham
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the county already seems well-stocked with restaurants serving Italian food, when a new place as good as Via Emilia comes along there is always room for one more. That is not to say that Via Emilia is perfect; rather it is young and full of potential. Right now, however, for dependable pasta dishes and chicken nicely turned out and for personal, charming service, one need not look beyond this neat neighborhood dining spot.

title: REAGAN'S JUDGES
description: PACKING THE COURTS The Conservative Campaign to Rewrite the Constitution. By Herman Schwartz. 242 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: Harvey Hospitalized
description: Hospital officials released no details, but Doug Harvey, the 63-year-old former hockey star, was admitted to Montreal General Hospital Friday. Harvey, who won the Norris Trophy seven times as the top defenseman in the National Hockey League, was described as very sick by one hospital employee, but the nature of his illness was not disclosed and hospital officials would not describe his condition yesterday. Harvey, who played 13 seasons with the Montreal Canadiens before being sold to the Rangers in 1960, played three seasons in New York. After playing with the Detroit Red Wings and the St. Louis Blues he retired in 1969 and since then has worked as a scout for the Canadiens. (AP)

title: The Framers' Intent
description: To the Editor:

title: An Invitation the West Can't Ignore
description: What a startling scene: New York police clear Broadway for a visiting Soviet leader's hurtling motorcade while a giant sign flashes a hammer and sickle in lights and welcoming citizens chant, ''Gorby! Gorby!'' Five years ago, the only way one could have imagined such a scene is if there had been a war, won by the other side.

title: Tartans: A Brief History
description: STYLES come and go, but tartans have been popular for two centuries.

title: 92 Guerrillas and 8 Soldiers Said to Die in Clash in Chad
description: Ninety-two rebels and 8 Chadian Government soldiers have been killed in a clash, Chad's Foreign Ministry said.

title: The Day Curbs Came to St. James
description: ON occasion there are signs and wonders. On certain select days there will be a burst of revelation or an atypical light above.

title: Soto Retires
description: He once was one of baseball's top right-handed pitchers, but yesterday in the Dominican Republic, Mario Soto was saying that his career was over because of an ailing shoulder. ''I must admit that I will definitely not recover, that it looks like my shoulder will not get better,'' Soto told El Caribe, a daily newspaper in his hometown of Santo Domingo.

title: NBC's Surprising Olympic Win 1992 Games for a record $401 million.
description: When NBC submitted a record bid earlier this month to win the rights to the 1992 Summer Olympics, it took the television industry by surprise and even gave some of its own executives reason to pause. After all, the network was still licking its wounds over its reported losses covering the Seoul Olympics just a few months before.

title: Companies Simplify Gift-Giving Abroad
description: WHILE most people wrestle with the problem of what to buy an aunt or uncle for Christmas, Lydia V. Klatsky buys gifts for people she has never met in countries she has never visited.

title: The Darker Shores of Thornton Wilder
description: In 1956, on a ship crossing the Atlantic to meet Samuel Beckett for the first time, Alan Schneider found himself sitting at the captain's table with Thornton Wilder. As Mr. Schneider recalled in his autobiography, Wilder had seen both the French and German productions of ''Waiting for Godot,'' felt he knew exactly what the play was about and proceeded to give Mr. Schneider a line-by-line analysis. At Wilder's recommendation, Mr. Schneider had just been hired to direct the first American production of ''Godot,'' and he listened intently, as Wilder told him that the play was an existential work about ''the nullity of experience in relation to the search for an absolute.''

title: Review/Dance; Demonstrating Ailey's Choreographic Versatility
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is an admirably eclectic company with a repertory of works by many choreographers. Yet it should never be forgotten that one of the most talented of those choreographers is Alvin Ailey himself. The company acknowledged the skill and versatility of its director on Thursday night by dancing four of his finest creations at the City Center.

title: 'DREAMGIRLS STAGED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: RATHER than go for an unreasonable facsimile of ''Dreamgirls,'' the ultimate high-tech musical, the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport has settled for a more sensible, if not, as it turns out, satisfactory solution to the show's technological demands.

title: Now, Boutiques for the Fashion-Conscious Toddler
description: LEAD: ALMOST overnight, a new retail phenomenon has emerged, mostly in Fairfield County. It is the shop selling imported and designer clothing for children, referred to by some as the ''kiddie boutique.''

title: THE REGION: The Steinberg Case and Trends in Abuse; Sometimes the Law Is Helpless as a Child
description: EXPERTS on child abuse have more than the obvious reasons to be sorry about the Lisa Steinberg case. Appalled like everyone else by the well-aired story of her death, they are also afraid it will increase demands for vigilance by a system that is under too many demands already.

title:
During this Season of Sharing, Help the Neediest Cases Fund;
Tending Retarded Daughter Overwhelms a Bronx Mother
description: LEAD: This frail, talkative woman dreams of a time when she will be free to leave her Bronx apartment in the evening, just to eat at a restaurant or go to the movies. But for now she is a prisoner in her own home, burdened by a 22-year-old daughter who does not know how to use a fork, a washcloth or the toilet.

title: Golf in Ski Suits
description: After experimenting with the idea last winter, the County Parks Department has decided to offer year-round golf by keeping the 18-hole Saxon Woods course in Scarsdale open through Feb. 12 and reopening the Dunwoodie course in Yonkers the following day.

title: Theaters Planning an Exchange with Soviets
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT'S theater community will be well represented when planning for a United States-Soviet cultural exchange resumes tomorrow at the home of the late novelist Boris Pasternak outside of Moscow.

title: Holyfield Still Lacks Power
description: Had he been just another heavyweight going against Pinklon Thomas, Evander Holyfield would have earned raves for his demolition of the former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion Friday night.

title: Wendy Meyers Wed To Jeffrey S. Strauss
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Wendy Bari Meyers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Meyers of New York and Goshen, Conn., was married last evening to Jeffrey Spencer Strauss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Strauss of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Klein performed the ceremony.

title: Chief Is Held Hostage With Fake Derringer
description: A prisoner being taken to a mental hospital Wednesday night used pieces of beef jerky shaped like a gun muzzle to hold a police chief hostage for about 40 minutes, the authorities said.

title: Pilots in Rome Strike for Day
description: A 24-hour strike by Alitalia pilots caused the cancellation today of 80 percent of the flights to and from Leonardo da Vinci Airport outside Rome, the airline said. The strike, over delays in negotiating new contracts, did not affect other Italian fields. The nation's air-traffic controllers have called three days of strikes this coming Wednesday through Friday.

title: Rangers' Hard Trip Concludes With Tie
description: The game, an exhausting, physically expensive 1-1 draw with the Bruins, was in every sense emblematic of the road trip it concluded. More a matter of survival than anything else, it ended today with one more Ranger lost to an injury and those uninjured humbled, if not embarrassed, and chagrined, if not crushed.

title: Randolph Finds a Job With Dodgers
description: Willie Randolph, the second baseman the Yankees cast off after 13 years, reached agreement with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday on a two-year contract worth about $1.75 million.

title: Moscow: End the Cold War
description: Everyone was waiting for this shoe to drop. For nearly a year, analysts had been speculating about when Mikhail S. Gorbachev would announce a dramatic Soviet troop cut and just how big it would be. Now we know. Yet officials in Washington seemed to be caught off guard. They promised to give the Soviet proposal ''serious scrutiny.'' They welcomed it as a ''constructive sign.'' They went gone to Brussels and had a ''full discussion'' with our NATO allies.

title: Latin Debt Crisis a Legacy of Reagan Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggle for Custody Of Children's Faith Becomes Nightmare
description: A judge here has threatened to jail a Roman Catholic woman for taking her two daughters to church, turning an already bitter custody battle into a struggle that evokes the worst nightmares of interfaith marriage.

title: POSTING: Carteret Milestone; A 190-Acre Complex
description: The demolition of the tallest smokestack in the East was a celebration of sorts for the developers of Port Carteret, marking crucial steps toward completion of the $180 million industrial seaport complex on the New Jersey bank of the Arthur Kill.

title: Youthspeak
description: IF YOU THINK PC stands for personal computer, what do you think non-PC means? Anything that is not a PC? Students these days, while familiar with high technology, are using the term PC as an abbreviation for politically correct; non-PC for its opposite. The term has a leftist connotation and, more likely than not, is used by those who believe the university works hand in glove with the capitalist establishment.

title: Reporter's Notebook Personalities in Spotlight On and Off Stand at the Myerson Trial
description: All the witnesses have come and gone, but Bess Myerson remains the star of her trial, a criminal case recalling the story of her life as a beauty queen who became a public official and stumbled into a scandal.

title: Victim of AIDS Wins $3.9 Million Lawsuit
description: A man who said he contracted AIDS from a blood transfusion in a 1985 heart operation was awarded $3.9 million Friday by a jury that found a blood center negligent for not screening donors.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BANK THEFT;
High-Tech Heists and Credit Card Capers
description: LEAD: William Francis ''Willie'' Sutton Jr.'s oft-repeated reason for robbing banks was ''because that's where the money is.'' Armed with a bagful of disguises, an acetylene torch and a getaway car, the infamous robber hit nearly 100 banks in his career to net an estimated $2 million.

title: Has the Way to the American Dream Become a Rut?
description: I ALMOST bought a condominium just the other day. Seized by a blind compulsion, I reeled from my apartment with a newspaper folded under my arm, bids dancing in my brain and the future tucked in the hip pocket where I carried my checkbook.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
An Inaugural Medal for Bush
description: LEAD: AN unusual medal will be issued to commemorate George Bush's inauguration as the 41st President of the United States. It was designed by Mico Kaufman of North Tewksbury, Mass., one of the nation's leading medallic artists.

title: F.D.U. Game Is Broken Up
description: A slam dunk by Nova Madison of Fairleigh Dickinson-Madison shattered the backboard and forced a suspension of the Division III basketball game between F.D.U.-Madison and Muhlenberg with 9 minutes 23 seconds left in the first half today.

title: Dr. von Kreuter Is to Be Married
description: Dr. Betsy Frances von Kreuter, a research associate in pathology, and Dr. Juan Carlos Felix, a fellow in obstetric and gynecologic pathology, both at the Cornell Medical College, plan to be married Feb. 25, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alan von Kreuter of Darien, Conn., have announced. Dr. Felix is a son of Dr. Juan Jose Felix of Guaynabo, P.R., and Mrs. Arturo Diaz of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The former International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, Buddy McGirt, has been stricken with the flu and has withdrawn from a bout against Martin Quiroz scheduled for Thursday at the Felt Forum. . . . Y. A. Tittle, the former Giants quarterback, and Sid Luckman, the former Chicago Bears quarterback, have been named to receive Walter Camp Distinguished American of the Year awards. Don Nehlen, coach of undefeated West Virginia, was named Walter Camp Coach of the Year. (AP)

title: Annie Dillard, Writer, Weds
description: Annie Dillard, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of ''Pilgrim at Tinker Creek,'' and Robert D. Richardson Jr., author of ''Henry Thoreau: A Life of the Mind,'' were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Concord, Mass. The Rev. Gary Smith performed the ceremony.

title: It's Tit for Tat in the Albany Schoolyard
description: TO those on the sidelines, watching Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature deal with each other is often like watching a playground fight: First one is on top and the other has a bloody nose; a few minutes later the positions are reversed.

title: No Headline
description: There were only six customers aboard Precision Air Line's evening flight from Islip as the small plane joined the queue over Logan International Airport after a 60-minute hop from Long Island to Boston.

title: Ms. Francis Wed To John DeLade
description: At the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., Lynn Ann Francis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Francis of Short Hills, was married yesterday to John Emil DeLade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil DeLade of Kinnelon, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Kenyan J. Wildrick performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John R. Ryan.

title: SPANISH PREMIER FACES STRIKE TEST
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez faces the biggest threat to his six-year-old Government on Wednesday, the prospect of the first general strike in Spain since 1934.

title: Ithaca Tops Central of Iowa in Stagg
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., Dec. 10 (AP) -

title: Alison Hubbard to Marry
description: Alison Crist Hubbard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Hubbard of Summit, N.J., and Leo Hayden Daley Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daley of Winchester, Mass., plan to marry in June, her parents have announced. Miss Hubbard, a graduate of Lynchburg College, is an admninistrative assistant at Warwick Advertising in New York. Mr. Daley, who graduated from Phillips Academy and Middlebury College, is an associate at Hawthorne Associates, pension-fund managers in Boston.

title: Betsy Anne Doyle to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Doyle of River Edge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Betsy Anne Doyle to Michael Greene, a son of Judge and Mrs. Joseph F. Greene of Haddonfield, N.J. Ms. Doyle, a commercial lending officer at Marine Midland Bank in New York, graduated from Lehigh University. Her father is a sales manager at Croyden Furniture in New York and is a former mayor of River Edge. Mr. Greene, who graduated from Holy Cross College, is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University. His father is a judge of the New Jersey State Superior Court in Camden.

title: In Moscow Mourning, a Call for Unity
description: Flags all around the city hung at half staff today, many tied to their poles with black bands. Movie theaters usually bustling with weekend customers were silent and their lights dark.

title: For Stranded Jews, 'When' Is Now 'If'
description: All across the main square of this seaside town 22 miles west of Rome, the language is Russian.

title: Koch Budget: Election-Year Strategy
description: Election-year budgets, like old-fashioned American cars, often come fully loaded. Instead of chrome-plated extras, new programs and initiatives are meant to appease special interests and shore up constituencies.

title: ON THE RED SEA, ISRAEL'S ANSWER TO KEY WEST
description: Eilat is to Israel what Key West is to the United States - a hot, lazy, bohemian and (to be honest) tawdry little resort town at the nation's southern tip, physically and emotionally far removed from the commotion to the north.

title: A Caring Adviser for a Caring Cast
description: LEAD: THE cast members had just finished a run-through of Act I, Scene 2, and, after a nod toward Macey Levin, their director, they turned expectantly to Stephen Ferranti.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BANK THEFT;
FILL OUT AN APPLICATION AND BECOME A CROOK
description: LEAD: One recent Friday afternoon, an alert teller in a New York bank noticed that the name on a customer's credit card matched a name on a watch list. The teller delayed the customer while an officer notified the United States Secret Service.

title: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE
description: I'm sure there are American women who enjoy the French penchant for la difference, but I've never met one.

title: Headliners; Facing Judgment
description: In his long fall from grace, Jim Bakker has hit a new low point. Mr. Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry who was defrocked last year after he admitted committing adultery, was indicted along with a former aide last week on charges that they diverted more than $4 million in church funds for their personal use. The indictment said Mr. Bakker and Richard Dortch defrauded as many as 150,000 viewers of ''The PTL Club'' by soliciting contributions that were not used for the intended purpose. The money went instead for bonuses ranging from $740,000 to $1,055,000 a year for Mr. Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, who was not indicted, and totaled $550,000 for Mr. Dortch. Mr. Bakker's lawyer said, ''My client is disappointed, but not surprised.''

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: AN ISLAND GARDEN. By Celia Thaxter. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) This handsome slipcased edition is a faithful reproduction of the original issue, dated 1894, complete with Childe Hassam's sumptuous illustrations. A popular poet, Celia Thaxter is remembered now as an inspired gardener. The patch of stony ground she cultivated on Appledore, one of the Isles of Shoals off the coast of Portsmouth, N.H., where her family operated a resort hotel, was only 50 feet long by 15 feet wide, and yet she made a universe of it, rich with color and fragrance and bird song.

title: Getting '1,000 Airplanes' Off the Ground and on the Road
description: ''When I write a piece,'' said David Henry Hwang, the 31-year-old playwright whose ''M. Butterfly'' won the Tony for best play last season, ''I want something that holds my interest from moment to moment. And that, for me, involves a kind of total theater, which takes into account the things I believe are done better on stage than in other media. So a lot of my work involves either dance or live musicians.''

title: Miss Sulger to Wed Gilduin Blanchard
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Alden H. Sulger Jr. of Green wich, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter Jennifer Remington Sulger to Gilduin Marie-Jean Blanchard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Blanchard of Paris. A May wedding is planned.

title: Charges Against Doctor Bring Ire and Questions
description: Relief, shame and anger were being expressed today in this central Ohio city where for 22 years Dr. James C. Burt performed what experts say was crude experimentation on hundreds of women without their consent.

title: What Stands Out In the N.F.L. This Year?
description: Although I am a rabid N.F.L. fan, I don't believe there is anything memorable about the current season. Parity and the lack of quality are the catchwords. The season is still too long, and there is still too much Astroturf. Therefore, injuries continue to play a big part in the game, but the owners don't seem to care.

title: Testing the Tester
description: Park Jong Sei, the director of drug testing for the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, said he was outraged to discover that he was target of a secret test administered by Olympic officials. Along with the athletes' urine samples, the officials submitted three drug-laced samples to Park's lab to see if he was doing his job properly. Park, who discovered the drugs, said he learned about the test when he asked the officials why no action was taken against the athletes who had submitted the three tainted samples.

title: Officials at Odds Over Rat Control in Boston
description: City and state officials are engaged in a battle over plans to control a potentially pesky problem, rodents that experts say will emerge when the city begins a decade-long excavation and reconstruction project.

title: ,2>An Expanding Paper Trail Is Burdening Court Clerks
description: MUNICIPAL court clerks across the state are becoming increasingly frustrated by a morass of administrative filing requirements mandated by recent legislation. They say the requirements have taxed an already overburdened court system to the breaking point.

title: In Defense, as if Any Were Needed, of Beckett
description: To the Editor:

title: An Easier Way to Recycle is Tried
description: LEAD: CAN paper, metal, glass and plastic all coexist comfortably in a single household recycling container without having to go their own separate ways into different disposal bins?

title: FIERCE WINDS CALM AND FLAMES EASE
description: The dry, blustery Santa Ana wind subsided today after driving flames that destroyed or damaged more than 60 houses, but firefighters said dry hillside brush will remain a fire threat until it rains.

title: Yorkville Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Baroque To New, On Flute
description: Ransom Wilson, the flutist who in recent years has devoted as much time to conducting as to playing his instrument, gave a recital of Baroque and contemporary flute music at Town Hall on Wednesday. He did not sound as if he had been neglecting his instrument: his technique was solid, his coloration amply varied, and his programming inventive. Mr. Wilson also enjoyed the benefit of two excellent collaborators - the harpsichordist John Gibbons and the pianist Christopher O'Riley.

title: U.S. Stops Penalizing Welfare Clients for Loans
description: Six weeks after a Federal district judge called the policy ''unconscionable,'' the Reagan Administration has reversed a five-year-old directive and will no longer count loans as income in determining the level of welfare payments.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Fanwood Battles Mt. Laurel Razing Order
description: LEAD: A RULING by the State Council on Affordable Housing that permits the razing of single-family homes to make room for high-density projects for low- and moderate-income families has drawn objections from state and local officials and led to an appeal to the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Deborah Witsell Is Married on L.I.
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., Deborah Towne Witsell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Witsell Jr. of Locust Valley, was married yesterday to Glenn Donald Vivian, a son of Mrs. Donald Gordon Vivian of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Vivian. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Kearns, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
ART;
Printmakers' Show In Holiday Colors
description: LEAD: WHEN a group art exhibition is organized by Long Island's well-established printmakers' cooperative, the Graphic Eye Gallery in Port Washington, it becomes an opportunity to survey a range of styles and techniques and a chance to see the latest work by a number of artists with solid reputations in the local art community.

title: In Defense, as if Any Were Needed, of Beckett; Challenge to Superstars
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cable TV, A Free Rein Raises Prices
description: For an increasing number of Americans, television is coming to mean cable television, with its wide assortment of channels and programming. But at the same time they are finding the cost of cable service is rising substantially as the industry takes advantage of its freedom to raise rates and its relative lack of competition.

title: Practical Traveler; Air Fare Deals Are Still Around But Hard to Find
description: The good news: Despite the recent major tightening of the airline fare structure there are still a limited number of low fares available for those who must travel on short notice.

title: Hospital Care for Indigent Approaching Crossroads
description: LEAD: A 47-YEAR-OLD man was admitted to East Orange General Hospital through the emergency room. He had pneumonia and severe anemia and tested positive for exposure to the AIDS virus. Seven specialists took part in his treatment, which included three bone marrow tests, a lymph node biopsy, four blood transfusions and several rounds of expensive antibiotics.

title: Doctors and Price Fixing
description: 'Engaging in conduct that clearly harms the interest of America's health-care consumers and thus violates the antitrust laws can have serious consequences. Such conduct can be hazardous to your personal freedom - you can go to jail.' - Charles F. Rule, Assistant Attorney General warning the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association that the Justice Department is investigating doctors for price fixing.

title: THE 'SEPIA' STRUGGLE
description: THE DEATH OF RHYTHM & BLUES By Nelson George. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: WHALES. By Jacques-Yves Cousteau and Yves Paccalet. (Abrams, $49.50.) ''Let our imagination transport us high above our planet. Earth spins below us; only the vast oceans that gird the continents and islands seem to be alive.'' The Comte de Lacepede's epigraph provides the opening words of ''Whales,'' an impressive new book by Jacques-Yves Cousteau and Yves Paccalet.

title: U.S. Navy Captain Charged In Failure to Save Refugees
description: A United States Navy captain faces court-martial on charges of failing to rescue a group of Vietnamese boat people in June. Some of the refugees later said members of the group had cannibalized others in their 37 days at sea.

title: Polisario Says It Downed U.S. Jet
description: The Polisario rebel movement said today that it shot down an American civilian plane on Thursday in the belief that the plane was a Moroccan military jet. The group expressed its regrets.

title: Penguins Tie Devils On Late Lemieux Goals
description: Mario Lemieux scored the last two goals of the game 39 seconds apart in the third period and earned a 4-4 tie for the Penguins against the Devils tonight at the Civic Arena.

title: A Contribution To Stereotyping?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DOTTIIE'S JOKES ARE ON HER DAUGHTERS
description: THIS IS YOUR LIFE By Meg Wolitzer. 263 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: February Bridal For Kara Glover
description: Kara Glover and John Philip Billhardt 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Billhardt of New Canaan, Conn., plan to marry in February, the future bride's parents, Karolyn S. Glover of Traverse City, Mich., and Ronald K. Glover of New York have announced.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Somewhere down the line I'm not going to have anything to buy. '' Donald J. Trump, telling a court that the Eastern air shuttle, which he is trying to buy, is losing business rapidly.

title: Under the Tree, The Laughs Are Scarce
description: Film comedies used to be easier to identify than they are today.

title: Carter Calls for Mediation Unit
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said tonight that he has held preliminary discussions with a number of international leaders to discuss the formation of an organization aimed at mediating civil wars around the world.

title: MEMORIES AND UNHOLY JOYS
description: LEAD: NATIONAL COLD STORAGE COMPANY New and Selected Poems. By Harvey Shapiro. 93 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $12.95.

title: Let Jean Harris Seek Parole
description: ''You are a brilliant woman'' Judge Russell Leggett said to Jean Harris on March 21, 1981, ''and I ask that recognition be given to that in prison, where you could be most useful by bringing some light into those other women's lives.'' Then he sentenced Mrs. Harris to 15 years to life for the murder of her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower.

title: Anthony M. Moos, 75, Developer of Fuel Cells
description: Anthony Manuel Moos, a chemist who developed the fuel-cell system used in the Apollo space project, died Friday at a nursing home in Middletown, R.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Portsmouth, R.I.

title: Indian Airline Hampered by Strikes and Shortages
description: With the tourist season about to reach its peak in India, the country's domestic carrier, Indian Airlines, has been flying in disarray for weeks because of strikes and shortages of aircraft.

title: Maryland Site Offers Hope for Crippling Condition
description: Inside a wing of St. Joseph Hospital here is a world in miniature where sufferers of skeletal dysplasia, a dwarfing condition, find medical treatment and understanding.

title: Saudi Arabia Shifts to More Active Foreign Policy
description: By playing host last week to peace talks between the Soviet Union and the Afghan guerrillas, Saudi Arabia gave one more indication that it wants to abandon its traditionally passive foreign policy stance in favor of one that is more assertive, more likely to give it the image it covets as the world's leading Islamic nation.

title: The Growth of Car Phones is Busy, Busy
description: MORE people than ever are driving and talking. About two million Americans, 35,000 in Connecticut, own one or more cellular telephones, and industry officials expect the numbers to triple or quadruple by 1990.

title: POSTING: The Cos Cob Solution?; A Winning Design for Affordability
description: Two New York City architects who ignored zoning limits in Greenwich, Conn., were rewarded for it last week. A $2,500 prize was given to Jennifer Deanne Fier and Warren Temple Smith as winners of an affordable housing design competition sponsored by the Regional Plan Association, the Town of Greenwich, the Connecticut Housing Department and others. The challenge of conceiving housing for the nine-acre site of the Cos Cob power plant on the Mianus River drew 50 entries - including one from Glen Hodef, the 14-year-old son of a Westport architect - and a variety of solutions.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
The Trade Talks Fizzle in Montreal
description: LEAD: The Montreal trade talks ended in a deadlock after a week in which there was considerable bickering among the delegates from 96 nations. Farm trade proved to be the biggest obstacle, with the United States sticking to its position that governments must end ''market-distorting'' subsidies of their farmers and the European Community insisting that such a move was politically impossible.

title: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE
description: As a woman, perhaps 10 years older than Mark Hunter, I applaud, in almost all aspects, his perception of the differences, not only between men and women, but between the way American society and other cultures operate in respect to the sexes (''Vive la Difference,'' About Men, Nov. 13).

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Nov. 26 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $210,000 1326 Madison Avenue (93d St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; den, high-ceilings, hardwood floors, original moldings and details; maintenance $662, 41% tax-deductible (Broker: Wallack Management) Greenwich Village $295,000 30 East Ninth Street (Lafayette) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, windowed dining area, 4 walk-in closets; maintenance $1,060, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Baker R.E. Inc.) Upper East Side $1.1 million 114 East 72d Street 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room, 3 walk-in closets; maintenance $2,432, 42% tax-deductible (Broker: S.W. Bird) Upper East Side $1.25 million 1070 Park Avenue (88th St.) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, fireplace, southern exposure; maintenance $1,500, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) West Side $295,000 255 West End Avenue (71st St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled kitchen, partial Hudson River view; maintenance $680, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) BRONX Gun Hill Road Area $165,000 939 Duncan Stret 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 18- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $896 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) Wakefield $130,000 3711 Rombout Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN Carroll Gardens $380,000 572 Henry Street 3-family, 4-story, mixed-use building; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit on the upper three floors; 760-sq.-ft. of commercial space on the first floor; full basement, 20- by 87-ft. lot; taxes $3,330 (Broker: Markgraf Group) Kings Highway Area $59,400 1862 East 14th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; large kitchen, new windows, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $368, 53% tax-deductible (Broker: Dwork & Korn) QUEENS Elmhurst $85,000 86-15 Broadway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, large kitchen, terrace, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $380, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Forest Hills Gardens $710,000 50 Wendover Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached, brick, center-hall colonial; dining room, large kitchen, basement, patio, garden, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,967 (Broker: Terrace Realty) Jackson Heights $240,000 24-20 93d Street 2-family, attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, large kitchen, balcony in primary unit, 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath in each; finished basement, 1-car garage, 21- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,500 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Port Richmond Center $193,000 690 Port Richmond Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each unit; full basement, 32- by 99-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: RE-MAX Preferred Realty) Westerleigh $205,000 19 Elmira Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, den, sun porch, detached 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: George K. Wonica)

title: Miss VanderKloot Weds an Executive
description: Kathryn Alicia VanderKloot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic J. VanderKloot of Warwick, N.Y., was married yesterday in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., to Richard Alden Perkins Jr., the son of Mrs. William F. Prehn of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Perkins. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey and the Rev. Richardson W. Schell, the headmaster of the Kent School, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church.

title: WHEN RUSSIAN ATISTS TOOK CENTER STAGE
description: Among recent contributions to the social and cultural history of the first half of our century, none is more engrossing or more poignant than ''Russian and Soviet Theater: 1905-1932,'' by Konstantin Rudnitsky, published by Harry N. Abrams, at $75. It has a great subject - the long moment during which, war and revolution notwithstanding, the theater throughout Russia was the locus of deep feeling, vehement aspiration and the will to consummate once and for all a marriage between art and the stage.

title: Technical Schools Study A Merger in Connecticut
description: A severe drop in enrollment among Connecticut's five technical colleges may be solved through a merger with the 12-campus, two-year regional community college system, a consultant's report says.

title: James Watkins Wed To Lauren Trownsell
description: Lauren Lee Trownsell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Trownsell of Madison, Conn., was married in Nashville yesterday to James Raymond Watkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Watkins of Cincinnati. The Rev. Randall Boone performed the ceremony at the Harpeth Presbyterian Church.

title: Monument Meant as Bridge Creates a Gulf Instead
description: How to define this metropolis that fills the vast basin between the San Gabriel Mountains and the Pacific Ocean? Can anything be constructed to typify and glorify this throbbing urban machine of movie studios, aerospace factories, roaring freeways, gang wars, immigrants, glistening beaches and glamour?

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: VISIONS UNDER THE TREE
description: LEAD: SPORTS PEOPLE. By Frank Deford. Photographs by Walter Iooss Jr. (Abrams, $35.) There is a haunting quality about Walter Iooss Jr.'s photographs of professional athletes in action. Even in victory (over Chris Evert at Wimbledon in the final, 1978), Martina Navratilova is shown slumped in a chair as if in defeat.

title: Vermonter Left Boxes Of Republican History
description: When Consuelo Northrop Bailey died in 1976, she left behind 40 years of Republican political history in boxes.

title: Collective Farms Out of Style in Peru
description: Concepcion Escalante well remembers his emotions the day the villagers were first allowed into the elegant mansion on the hill. It was June 29, 1970, and the hacienda of Villa Hermosa had just been expropriated in the name of the people.

title: WHY CAN'T A ROBOT BE MORE LIKE A MAN?
description: WHY IS MONNETT HANVEY Soldo following a robot down the hall, yelling, ''Straight! Straight!''?

title: Getting Electricity From a Volcano
description: HAWAII depends almost entirely on imported oil for fuel and badly needs another energy source, but the question before the state's Supreme Court was: Would geothermal power development of Kilauea Volcano hamper worship of the legendary volcano goddess Pele?

title: At Home in the Caribbean
description: Prices for groceries on Barbados, Guadeloupe and the other islands of Te Caribbean are often comparable to or higher than those in the supermarkets of New York. But vacationers who head for the Caribbean in winter and rent a hotel room or suite with kitchen or kitchenette or condominium still have the financial edge. Those cereals, sandwiches and steak are going to cost a lot more when served by a waiter at most of the islands' resorts. Many of the islands have to import and pay duty on many food items, although the shopper should find good local fish as well as bananas, pineapples and papayas. (Cattle ranches as well as supplies of local vegetables and fruit help keep food costs down in the Dominican Republic.) To some visitors, preparing meals runs counter to the notion of avacation. For others, the housekeeping unit offers some compelling advantages, in addition to economy: freedom to come and go without having to sit in restaurants or the hotel dining room three times a day, greater privacy, the opportunity to fix simple snacks and a more relaxed atmosphere for children. Groups of friends often prefer to share costs in a condominium.

title: Islanders' Comeback Falls Short
description: Two losses ago, when the losing streak grew too unwieldy at eight games, the Islanders reached back to their heritage and returned Al Arbour, the coach who connected them with four championships, to the bench.

title: Bomb Producers Torn by Doubts
description: The safety and environmental problems that threaten to stall the production of bombs in the United States could become a crisis for military strategy and for the future of nuclear energy.

title: Stacey Denis to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Denis of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stacey J. Denis, to Mitchell D. Hollander, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert M. Hollander of New York and River Vale, N.J. Miss Denis, a pension consultant with Alan T. Nahoum Inc. in New York, graduated from the American University. Mr. Hollander, a certified public accountant, graduated from Lehigh University and is a student at the Brooklyn Law School.

title: ORANGE COUNTY: TOMORROWLAND - WALL TO WALL
description: There is no better place to think about the American landscape and what it is turning into than here, in Orange County, where brand-new suburbs sprawl across the land with such intensity that Los Angeles, by comparison, seems almost an old-fashioned, traditional city. Irvine is a world of condominiums and freeways, of shopping malls and office towers, in which everything looks as if it had been finished last month or will be finished next month, and what is old is what was built five years ago.

title: A Student Weds Karin P. Radasch
description: The wedding of Karin Paige Radasch, the daughter of Judith C. Radasch of New York and Michael A. Radasch of Somerville, Mass., to Jeffrey Mills Maddox, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Maddox of Cherry Hills Village, Colo., took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 2 about Jewish feminists praying at the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem misattributed a statement protesting the act. The statement, ''A woman carrying a Torah is like a pig at the Wailing Wall,'' was made by an unidentified bystander, not by Rabbi Meir Yehuda Getz, who is in charge of the site.

title: Trial Nears in Religion Suit by Indian Inmates
description: A simple, domelike structure used by Plains Indians in ancient worship rites is the issue in a long-running battle over religion that has pitted tribal leaders against Utah State Prison officials.

title: Tales of Despair, Sorrow and Need Recounted by Agencies Aided by Fund; Helping Thousands On Brink of Poverty
description: Last year's stock market crash brought home to many New Yorkers the unpleasant reminder that financial stability can indeed be fragile.

title: What Stands Out In the N.F.L. This Year?
description: What stands out this year is that no particular team stands out as the runaway favorite. In '85, the Bears seemed the obvious eventual winner midway through the season, and in '86 and '87, there were really only four or five teams potentially Super Bowl-bound. But this year in the N.F.C., although the Bears seem slightly favored, it wouldn't be surprising at all to see the Vikings, the Saints, the Rams, the 49ers or the Giants win.

title: In Albany, Shoreham Confusion
description: LEAD: IT has been the nature of the Shoreham story to top itself repeatedly. What appears briefly to be the denoument is superseded and cast in another light by what happens next.

title:
GARDENING;
Turning Prunings Into Seasonal Beauty
description: LEAD: WITH the right accessories and a bit of imagination, decorative holiday arrangements can be easily created from the prunings of evergreens combined with other materials from the garden. The prunings of yews, one of the most useful and relatively trouble-free evergreen shrubs, are commonly used in such arrangements since they will not shed needles even when dried out.

title: Fearful That Chaos Will Come, Afghans Scramble to Flee Kabul
description: In a city that fears the future, the privileged few, those who have the money for an air ticket, are looking for ways out. Their hopes have been reduced to getting a place on one of five flights a week, all heavily overbooked, to New Delhi.

title: Conference Examines Options in Public Housing
description: LEAD: WHEN Peter A. Smith, executive director of the Yonkers Municipal Public Housing Authority, spoke about poor conditions at the city's public housing projects during a recent conference at Manhattanville College here, no one disagreed with him.

title: ,2>Hispanic Business Community Feels Growing Pride and Stength
description: LEAD: ALEJANDRO SALAS, born in Texas of Mexican descent, is president of a Smithtown-based company that does electronic engineering design and development for aerospace companies.

title: Student Concert in Rye to Benefit Homeless
description: FIRST there was ''Live Aid,'' then ''Farm Aid,'' ''Amnesty International'' and ''Human Rights Now.''

title: County Is Checking Rock Slopes by Roads
description: LEAD: WORK is under way to determine whether 11 rock slopes along county highways pose a threat to motorists.

title: Dr. Risa Bergstein Is Married on L.I.
description: At Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., Dr. Risa Bergstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Bergstein of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Greg Ribicove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ribicove of Floral Park, Queens. Rabbi Kenneth Hain performed the ceremony.

title: A Disk Jockey Challenges an Oil Company
description: A leading disk jockey here has been urging his listeners to boycott Shell Oil products and cut up the company's credit cards to protest its parent's involvement in South Africa.

title: Lawrence A. Wien, 83, Is Dead; Lawyer Gave Millions to Charity
description: Lawrence Arthur Wien, lawyer, realtor and philanthropist who donated millions of dollars to education and the arts, died of prostate cancer Saturday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 83 years old and had additional homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Walesa, In Paris, Says West Is Lacking in Spiritual Values
description: Lech Walesa, in Paris on his first trip outside Poland in seven years, said today that people in the West seem to be lacking in spiritual values.

title: Widower's Struggle Inspires Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Melvyn Griffen's struggle to hold his family together after his wife died of cancer three years ago has inspired a number of contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Sink or Swim? Tipsy Goddesses Decide
description: NEW YORK -- The history of the theater is dotted with musical shows the sneering multitudes proclaimed would never open.

title: Jet Spirits Rise for Giants
description: Finally, a coach who says this isn't just another game.

title: John Canning of Post, 56, Dies in Mexico
description: John Canning, a managing editor of the New York Post since 1980, died suddenly yesterday while on vacation in Ixtapa, Mexico. He was 56 years old and lived in Guttenberg, N.J.

title: Campaign Finance: Smell No Evil
description: At a recent conference in Arizona, a member of the Federal Election Commission, Lee Ann Elliott, said she had seen no evidence of abuse in the millions of dollars of private funds that flowed into the publicly financed Presidential campaigns of George Bush and Michael Dukakis from labor unions, corporations and rich individuals.

title: Teachers Complain of Lack of Parent Support
description: The nation's public school teachers say they are not getting enough support from parents, and most report finding child abuse, poor health, bad nutrition and other problems among the children in their classrooms, according to a survey released today.

title: Freer Trade: Not Yet, Maybe Later
description: Although everyone went home empty-handed from a weeklong conference here to promote freer trade, global bargaining has begun that could mean more open markets in future years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McCann-Erickson Unit Names New President
description: John J. Dooner Jr. has been named president of McCann-Erickson North America. Mr. Dooner, 40 years old, who has been president and general manager of McCann-Erickson New York, succeeds John J. McNamara, who continues as president of McCann-Erickson Worldwide.

title: Dan Rostenkowski's Courage
description: Undaunted by all the Texans with commanding positions in the next administration and the new Congress, Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, advocates raising taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel. He's both brave and wise to do so.

title: United Air Restores A Discount
description: In the first significant modification of the industry's recent round of fare increases, United Airlines Inc. on Saturday resumed offering a seven-day advance-purchase discount fare.But the new fares are significantly higher than the discount fares that were offered before the increases took effect last month.

title: Sports World Specials; Letters of Advice
description: ''Dear Larry:''

title: A Calm Morris Runs Wild
description: The swirling gusts redirected airborne footballs inside Giants Stadium. The wind-chill factor was well beneath reasonable. An offensive line was creating enough spaces in the Kansas City Chief defense for Joe Morris of the Giants to excel.

title: Richard Castellano Is Dead at 55; An Actor of Stage, Screen and TV
description: Richard Castellano, a character actor noted for his portrayals of Italian-Americans, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in North Bergen, N.J.. He was 55 years old.

title: St Germain 'Presence'
description: A month after losing his campaign for re-election, Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the House Banking Committee, is in the process of setting up a Washington lobbying office.

title: Woman Dies in Fire and Ex-Tenant Is Held
description: A dispute between an evicted tenant and a landlord appears to have been the motive behind an arson fire that killed one woman and left 90 people homeless Saturday night, the authorities said today.

title: Investor Shakes a Newspaper's Ivory Tower
description: The St. Petersburg Times, one of the most independent and aggressive newspapers in the country, should be savoring its successes this year against its cross-bay rival, The Tampa Tribune, and congratulating itself on a move into a stylish new headquarters.

title: Toy Guns Are Serious
description: Congress, no tiger on controlling access to real guns, now appears equally timid about curbing realistic toy look-alikes, a growing law enforcement problem. Last year, New York City police confiscated 1,416 toy guns in criminal incidents, a remarkable increase of 80 percent since 1983. In one recent California case, a police officer who mistook a toy revolver for the real thing shot the retarded child brandishing it.

title: 185 More Cuban Exiles Arrive
description: One hundred and eighty-five Cuban exiles arrived here from Spain Saturday under a special arrangement under which they have been given private sponsors and are declared ineligible for aid from the United States Government.

title: Expansion of Universe Brings Scientists Together
description: Scientists who meld knowledge about the tiniest particles of matter and energy with theories about the structure of the universe met here this weekend and outlined a coordinated international strategy for answering the major outstanding questions about the nature of the cosmos.

title: In Oslo, Blessings for 733 Who Kept the Peace
description: The 733 United Nations soldiers who have died keeping the peace in troubled places were remembered today in the ancient cathedral of this Scandinavian capital.

title: Yes, Investigate Charities But Don't Stop Giving
description: To the Editor:

title: AMID THE RUBBLE, ARMENIANS EXPRESS RAGE AT GORBACHEV
description: In the midst of a huge international earthquake-rescue effort, the ethnic grievances of Soviet Armenians burst out anew today.

title: 2 From Jersey Die in Crash; Police Cite Drunken Driving
description: A suburban Philadelphia man was charged with homicide by vehicle while intoxicated and other offenses after a fiery accident that left two New Jersey residents dead, the authorities said today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday, about People magazine, misstated terms of an offer being extended to advertisers who buy space in a special anniversary issue. They will be offered equivalent advertisements in one of three geographic editions or in the demographic edition of the magazine.

title: HELP FOR VICTIMS POURS INTO REGION
description: From Los Angeles and New York, from Argentina and Cuba, from Britain, Scandinavia, Israel and Japan, people around the world have sent food, medical supplies and rescue equipment to victims of the earthquake in Soviet Armenia.

title: China Says One Monk Was Killed During Clash With Police in Tibet
description: China said tonight that one Buddhist monk was killed and 13 people were wounded Saturday when the police fired ''warning shots'' during a clash with pro-independence demonstrators in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.

title: Court Ruling in Bond Case
description: The Washington State Supreme Court agreed last week to hear new arguments in a civil case in which the state is accused of fraud and negligence by holders of the defaulted bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System. The court provided no details in its order, and no date was set for arguments in the class action.

title: Only 1 Vote Counts And Walton Has It
description: Turn on a radio talk show and one hears more anti-Joe Walton comments than rousing endorsements.

title: Curbs in Benefits Seen Despite Pledge by Bush
description: Social Security and Medicare benefits paid to wealthy retired people are becoming an important target in the debate over reducing the Federal budget deficit.

title: Review/Concert; Festive Note From the Pops
description: The red and green lighting that bathed the back wall of Carnegie Hall's stage on Saturday afternoon made the place garish rather than Christmasy (perhaps a wreath would have made a more striking effect). But there was no denying the festive atmosphere when Skitch Henderson led the New York Pops and the Dallas Symphony Orchestra Chorus in a holiday program that was also the opening of the orchestra's series.

title: A 'Sleeping Giant' Goes Global
description: In an imposing pink baroque building in the center of Munich, Europe's biggest electronics company has been hatching global plans that include making deeper inroads into the all-important American market.

title: 'Legends of St. Nicholas'
description: Anonymous 4, a vocal quartet that specializes in Medieval music, is to present ''Legends of St. Nicholas: Songs and Stories of the Saint Who Became Father Christmas'' at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street, Saturday evening at 8 and 10 P.M. The singers - Ruth Cunningham, Marsha Genensky, Susan Hellauer and Johanna Rose - are to perform works composed in the 11th through 14th centuries. Tickets are $10. Information: 219-3739.

title: Review/Dance; Images of a Previous Life
description: Muna Tseng took an unexpected route in ''Post Revolutionary Girl,'' a new solo performed on Friday evening at the Mulberry Street Theater, 70 Mulberry Street, a welcome new performing space in Chinatown. Instead of a confessional portrait, Miss Tseng chose to present images from her life and responses to them in a meditative, delicate style that suggested the influence of Tristan Tzara's musings, quoted in the program notes, on art as prayer.

title: New Pride for Palestinian-Americans
description: It has been a year since the uprising, the intifada, broke out in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Today Palestinian-Americans who live in suburban Long Island gathered in St. John's Orthodox Church here to commemorate the more than 285 Palestinians who have died and the uprising itself, which has given them a new sense of identity and pride.

title: U.S. and Soviet Groups Joining for Quality of Life
description: Following Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for international cooperation in solving global environmental problems, American conservation groups have let it be known here that they are ready to assist on environmental projects in the Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture in some copies on Saturday, showing two hockey players fighting, carried an incorrect caption. The picture showed Ken Daneyko of the Devils, at left, and Greg Gilbert of the Islanders exchanging punches at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; DDB Legend To Pursue New Career
description: HELMUT KRONE surveyed his art studio, a loft in the SoHo section of Manhattan with a paint-spattered tarp covering its wood floors and large canvases hanging on the walls, and confessed that he was frightened.

title: Paris Journal; Is America Perfect? (Is the Tongue in the Cheek?)
description: Since de Tocqueville, French thinkers have been fascinated with America. But when it comes to mysterious paradox and lyrical complexity, no French intellectual matches Jean Baudrillard in contemplating the New World.

title: Workers' Substance Abuse Is Increasing, Survey Says
description: Executives and Federal officials say the use of cocaine and crack is growing rapidly among workers, significantly compounding the effects of drug and alcohol abuse, which cost business more than $100 billion a year.

title: Yuri Lyubimov Dismissed From 'Ring'
description: A backstage battle at the Royal Opera House has led to the dismissal of the exiled Soviet director Yuri Lyubimov.

title: Nancy Freidman Weds
description: Nancy Sue Friedman and Arnold S. Paster were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Southampton, L.I., by Rabbi Jacob J. Hecht, who was assisted by Cantor Josef Germaine. The bride, the daughter of Mrs. A. Karl Friedman of Laguna Hills, Calif., and the late Dr. Friedman, is a real-estate saleswoman at M. J. Raynes in New York. Mr. Paster, a son of Mrs. Herman Paster of St. Paul and the late Mr. Paster, owns Peconic Bay Realty in Southampton. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Teamster Vote Is Still Good News
description: Teamsters Local 560 in New Jersey counted the ballots last week after its first free, fair and vigorously contested election in a quarter-century. The results disappointed those who had hoped for new leadership after two years under a Federal trustee. A slate loyal to the corrupt old regime handily defeated two others that promised reform.

title: INTERNATIONAL REPORT
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who took office on Dec. 2 promising a better life for Pakistanis, has inherited an economic situation she describes as horrendous and a Government that she says is virtually bankrupt.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Blackstone-Perella Pair Co-Chairmen at Wickes
description: LEAD: The leveraged buyout of Wickes Companies for $538.9 million by the Blackstone Group and Wasserstein, Perella & Company pairs officials from both investment boutiques as co-chairmen of the joint venture.

title: Max Frankel, Editor, Wed To Joyce Purnick, Journalist
description: Joyce Purnick, the daughter of Jack Purnick of New York and the late Charlotte Leah Purnick, was married yesterday to Max Frankel, the son of Jacob and Mary Frankel, also of New York. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Review/Dance; 'McShann': A Tribute From Ailey
description: It would be easy to see ''Opus McShann'' as simply a new dance homage by Alvin Ailey to a distinguished jazz musician - in this case the 72-year-old blues pianist and composer Jay McShann.

title: Ford's Savings-Unit Plan Raises Concern in Congress
description: Attempts by the Ford Motor Company to acquire a group of insolvent savings and loan institutions from the Government are stirring concerns in Congress even before any of the proposed transactions have been announced.

title: A New Dawn for Driesell on the Basketball Floor
description: IT is 6 A.M., but a thick veil of darkness still hangs over the central Shenandoah Valley. At a truckstop along Route 11, blinking red lights on rows of rumbling 18-wheelers dot the night while their drivers shiver through an early morning chill.

title: Southern Africa Talks Seen Resuming Today
description: Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States are expected to resume their efforts Monday to conclude a long-awaited political settlement in southwestern Africa.

title: To Armenians In New York, A Bitter Grief
description: Stricken with grief over the devastating earthquake in their homeland, Armenian-Americans jammed St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral in Manhattan yesterday, offering their prayers as well as clothing and money for the relief effort.

title: Body Found in River Linked to 7 Murders
description: A body found in the Sacramento River nearly three years ago has been linked to the case of Dorothea Montalvo, the Sacramento landlady suspected in the deaths of seven people whose bodies were found buried around her rooming house.

title: Gretzky or Lemieux: Who's the Best?
description: MARIO LEMIEUX is bigger, stronger, taller, younger, and even has curlier hair, but none of that makes Wayne Gretzky particularly nervous.

title: Ending the Bloodletting in U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Over the last generation, the fiercest bloodletting in American politics has been over the very foreign policy issues that were, in theory, supposed to be above partisan politics: China, Vietnam, arms control, Soviet-American relations, hostage questions and contra aid. While the debate was sometimes constructive, only in moments of great crisis did the nation find the unity that gives us our greatest strength.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: Adventist Development and Relief International, 6840 Eastern Avenue NW, Washington D.C. 20012. American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. American Jewish World Service, 729 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116. American Red Cross, 431 18th Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20006. American Red Cross in Greater New York, P.O. Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10164-0037. Americares Foundation, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. Armenian Assembly of America, 122 C Street NW, No.350, Washington D.C. 20001. Armenian Earthquake Fund, c/o Diocese of the Armenian Church of America, 630 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Armenian General Benevolent Union, 585 Saddle River Road, Saddle Brook, N.J. 07662. Armenian Missionary Association of America, 140 Forest Avenue, Paramus, N.J. 07652. Armenian Prelacy, 138 East 39th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. Armenian Relief Society of North America, 80 Bigelow Avenue, Watertown, Mass. 02172. CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Catholic Medical Mission Board, 10 W. 17th Street, New York, N.Y.10011. Church World Service, Armenian Earthquake Response, 476 Riverside Drive, New York, N.Y. 10115-0050.
