Lutheran World Relief, 360 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10010. Mennonite Central Committee, 21 South 12th Street, Akron, Pa. 17501. Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross, 264 Old Country Road, Mineola, N.Y. 11501. Operation California/U.S.A., 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. Save the Children, 48 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, N.Y. 10580. World Relief, P.O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. World Vision, Box 0, Pasadena, Calif. 91109.

title: Anthony Moos, 75, Developer of Fuel Cells
description: Anthony Manuel Moos, a chemist who developed the fuel-cell system used in the Apollo space project, died Friday at a nursing home in Middletown, R.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Portsmouth, R.I.

title: New Airliners Make Experts Ask: How Advanced Is Too Advanced?
description: A new European airliner, soon to be certified for service in the United States, uses advanced automatic systems so extensively that pilots can almost become observers if they choose, watching computers fly the airplane more than flying it themselves.

title: At Least 52 Killed in Mexico City In Fireworks Explosion and Blaze
description: Illegal fireworks on sale at a popular street market exploded today, setting off a chain reaction and fire that killed at least 51 people and injured at least 80.

title: Sports World Specials; Corrected Vision
description: Goaltenders are expected routinely to stop pucks that travel at speeds of 90 miles an hour. Larry Dyck, a Minnesota North Star prospect, has always done just that. However, up until this year, Dyck has done so with the use of only one eye.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about mini-vans misstated Chrysler's production. The company produced 178,000 Caravans and 172,000 Voyagers through the first 10 months of this year.

title: Mayor Begins Chicago Race
description: Mayor Eugene Sawyer, an alderman elevated to the city's top job after the death of Harold Washington, Chicago's first black mayor, launched his campaign to retain the post today.

title: San Francisco Journal; Help for 'Street Kids' When Nobody Cares
description: The boy was new to the Larkin Street Youth Center, but not new to the streets.

title: One Found Slain After Man, 70, Frees 3 Hostages and Surrenders
description: A 70-year-old man armed with a shotgun held two women and a child hostage inside a house for almost four hours yesterday after apparently killing one man and wounding two police officers in New Rochelle, N.Y., the authorities said.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants-Jets Private 'Playoff'
description: AT last, in their 19th season as National Football League lodge brothers, the Giants and the Jets will collide Sunday in a regular-season game with something at stake other than what Weeb Ewbank always described as the ''bragging rights'' to the New York area.

title: New President at Wiley
description: John Wiley & Sons, the publishing company, has named Ruth R. McMullin, its executive vice president and chief operating officer, to succeed Andrew H. Neilly Jr. as president and chief executive next April 30. Mr. Neilly, an employee of Wiley since 1947, will turn 65 years old this month. Mrs. McMullin, 46 years old, joined Aviation Week in 1962. She later became an editor and business manager at Doubleday and then manager of Natural History Press, a joint venture of Doubleday and the Museum of Natural History. She has also held various positions at General Electric.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly described the operations that Northern Telecom Ltd. will close as part of a corporate restructuring. The only plants that will close are a transmission operation in Aylmer, Quebec, and network support service operations in Concord, N.H.

title: Inverted Yield Pattern Persists
description: The conditions that have produced higher yields on short- to intermediate-term securities than on long-term bonds are likely to continue for at least a few months, credit market analysts say. This unusual situation, known as an ''inverted yield curve,'' last occurred in 1982.

title: Books of The Times; A Novelist's Magic-Realist Vision of Australia
description: Kisses of the Enemy By Rodney Hall 622 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Review/Music; Beyond the Minimal
description: Continuum, a new-music series in its 23d season, is known for its retrospectives focusing on genres within contemporary composition. Usually, these are as comprehensive and logically ordered as a single evening's offering can be, and they tend to eschew familiar works in favor of rarely heard ones.

title: They'll Still Be Able to Play the Palace
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Czechoslovakia Wins: Helena Sukova and Radka Zrubakova, both unbeaten throughout the week, led Czechoslovakia to a 2-1 victory over the top-seeded Soviet Union yesterday in the final of the Federation Cup tournament in Melbourne, Australia. Zrubakova, a 17-year-old rookie, defeated Larissa Savchenko, 6-1, 7-6, in the opening singles. Sukova then topped the world's seventh-ranked player, Natalya Zvereva, 6-3, 6-4, to clinch the title for the Czechoslovaks. Savchenko and Zvereva later combined to score a 7-6, 7-5 doubles victory over Jana Novotna and Jana Pospislova. Czechoslovakia, which was seeded fourth, scored its fourth Federation Cup victory in six years.(AP) Victory for Leach and Pugh: Rick Leach and Jim Pugh of the United States capped a memorable first season as full-time partners by winning the Masters doubles title in London yesterday with a 6-4, 6-3, 2-6, 6-0 victory over Sergio Casal and Emilio Sanchez of Spain.(AP) McEnroe Tops Lendl: John McEnroe defeated Ivan Lendl, 7-5,6-2, yesterday in the final of the Michelin Challenge exhibition in Inglewood, Calif. McEnroe earned $100,000. Lendl earned $60,000.(AP) Golf World Cup Title for U.S.: Ben Crenshaw sank a par-saving, 4-foot putt on the final hole yesterday, clinching an American victory in the World Cup tournament in Melbourne. Crenshaw and his teammate, Mark McCumber, gave the United States its 17th World Cup victory, finishing at 16 under par on the 6,985-yard, par-72 Royal Melbourne course. They won $88,000 from the total purse of $880,000, and Crenshaw got an extra $46,000 for finishing first with a 13-under-par total. Crenshaw finished a shot ahead of Jet Ozaki of Japan. (AP) Title to Levi and Burns: Wayne Levi sank a 38-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole yesterday and he and George Burns passed the defending champions, Mike Hulbert and Bob Tway, to win the PGA Chrysler team championship. Starting seven strokes off the lead, Levi and Burns shot a 13-under-par 59 over the 7,085-yard Cypress course at the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club in West Palm Beach, Fla.(AP) Horse Racing High Brite Coasts: Favored High Brite, with Angel Cordero Jr. aboard, posted a four-length victory in the $58,400 Gravesend Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. King's Swan was runner-up in the field of six, a neck ahead of Matter of Honor. High Brite, who led all the way, went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 3/5. He earned $35,040 for Joseph Allen and returned $3.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Skiing Tomba Triumphs: Alberto Tomba of Italy returned to the site of his first ski race yesterday and won the first race of his World Cup season before a huge crowd of fans. The 21-year-old double Olympic gold medalist had a winning time of 1 minute 41.19 seconds at Madonna di Campiglio, Italy. The victory came before 20,000 fans, one of the largest ever to see a ski race in Italy. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg was second.(AP)

title: Business and the Law; A Difficult Choice Confronts Drexel
description: FOR executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the choice they face in the Government's criminal investigation - to settle or fight criminal charges - could hardly be more difficult.

title: Debate on 'Who Is a Jew?' Stirs Deeper Waters; The Road to Unity
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Recital; Guitarist Performs Mozart
description: Manuel Barrueco's guitar recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night began with a glitch when the programs didn't arrive from the printer. An enthusiastic deputy announced the selections on the artist's behalf, and from then on everything was smooth sailing, marred by hardly so much as a missed note. Mr. Barrueco is an engaging, musical player whose technique is secure enough to get out of the way and allow him to be perceived most of all as a stylist.

title: Student Pilot Takes Early Solo, Landing Safely but in Trouble
description: A New Jersey teen-ager with only two hours of flying instruction got lost during an unauthorized solo flight this weekend, but managed to land safely at Newark International Airport early yesterday morning where he was talked down by a veteran pilot.

title: Crime Gangs Exercise Vast Power in Hong Kong
description: Yan Sui Kuen was only 10 years old when, in a secret midnight ceremony on a Hong Kong rooftop, he swore eternal allegiance to a triad, one of the colony's infamous organized crime gangs.

title: Stunned Islanders Fight Off Despair
description: The Islanders, who seem to have forgotten how to win, are not asking for forgiveness.

title: Afghan Peace Could Herald War of Sexes
description: Masooma Esmatee Wardak said that as a woman she was not afraid of the day when the Islamic conservatives who are now in exile in Pakistan or Iran come back to Afghanistan.

title: Trains to Airports Are Called Essential
description: Direct rail access to the area's three major airports is essential to curing traffic congestion and keeping the economy competitive, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

title: Pack Up Your Rod and Reel
description: Finding a good fishing hole sometimes requires more than a drive in the car. Remote areas tend to offer better fishing, but hiking in the woods can be a nuisance if you're carrying a rod and reel.

title: Bonn Economics Chief Supports Looser Reins
description: Helmut Haussmann, a 45-year-old official of the Free Democratic Party and an advocate of its free-market policies, was sworn in on Friday in Bonn as West Germany's new Economics Minister.

title: Jamaica (Note: Not South Jamaica) Mounts a Revival
description: Pounding and drilling, construction workers are putting the finishing touches on the new 11-story Federal office building at Jamaica Avenue and Parsons Boulevard, the bustling commercial core of Jamaica, Queens.

title: Surging Giants Move a Step Closer to Division Title
description: On a cold, windy, nasty day, the Giants started strong and finished strong today and beat the Kansas City Chiefs, 28-12.

title: Grand Met Raises Its Bid For Pillsbury
description: The battle for control of the Pillsbury Company by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. grew more intense yesterday, as a flurry of meetings between executives of the companies produced formal and informal offers to sweeten the bid, the companies said.

title: Market Place; Expanded Roles In Selling Loans
description: WITH two financings in the past month totaling more than $1.3 billion backed by car and credit card loans, Citibank has served notice to Wall Street that it intends to take a major role in the growing business of packaging loan receivables and selling them as securities.

title: Bridge
description: Most bridge clubs are ''open,'' permitting anyone to play without question of membership, and even membership clubs sometimes admit nonmembers. The Cavendish, at 105 East 73d Street, arguably the world's most famous bridge club, welcomes visitors to duplicate games each week, at 12:45 P.M. Mondays and 7:30 P.M. Fridays. The diagramed deal was played in a Monday game, with game director Morton Kaplan in the North seat, paired with Cavendish Secretary Tom Snow.

title: So Feared in the N.H.L. That He's Loved in Harlem
description: At 6 A.M. yesterday, on the coldest morning of the season, an 11-year-old boy named Manny De La Cruz awakened in his family's apartment in East Harlem.

title: Sports World Specials; Hitting the Big Time
description: You have a basketball conference with no identity. Your conference has a name that is long and confusing, and even when you abbreviate it people shake their heads. You need exposure and your only hope is national television. What do you do?

title: School's Dance of the Century 'Was a Blast'
description: Although it took a Federal judge's intervention to produce the first high school dance in this century-old Ozarks town, the students needed a little encouragement to do the rest Saturday.

title: Making Sense of the New Skiwear
description: SKI clothing comes with a library of tags that spell out the marvels of the fabrics used on the inside, outside and in between. All the design claims may overwhelm the potential buyer. A little knowledge goes a long way in helping to sort through the thicket of fabrics and high-tech surprises.

title: Man Held in Killing Of Pair of Brothers
description: A 48-year-old man was charged yesterday with killing two brothers and seriously wounding their mother and a teen-age girl, the police said.

title: Hijacker Diverts TWA Plane
description: A Trans World Airlines flight from San Juan to Miami with 128 people on board was diverted to Grand Turk island today after a man told the crew he had a bomb and wanted to go to Havana, a spokesman said.

title: Heat Sets Loss Record
description: The expansion Miami Heat played its 16th game Saturday night and lost for the 16th time, setting a National Basketball Association record for most defeats at the start of a season.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales ... Nov. Wednesday Merchandise Trade ... Oct. Capacity Utilization ... Nov. Industrial Production ... Nov. Thursday None Friday Housing Starts ... Nov. Producer Prices ... Nov.

title: Tennis Notebook; Players Get Set for Season of Transition
description: The new tennis season will begin in less than a month, allowing players just enough time to take a deep breath and restring their racquets. In the men's game, 1989 will be noteworthy because it is a lame-duck year for Nabisco, the tour sponsor, and most likely, the Men's Tennis Council, the game's governing body.

title: A Real-Life Karate Kid Sequel in Jersey
description: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ is only 9 years old, but his life story already reads like a movie script. To defend himself from larger kindergarten students, he took up karate four years ago. Today, no one picks on Jonathan. Schwartz, who appeared in a martial-arts exhibition at Nassau Coliseum yesterday, is a two-time international and national champion in the discipline of tang soo do and is the youngest competitor in the country with a black belt, the ultimate achievement in karate. Despite the acclaim, Jonathan wants to help erase the notion that karate is a weapon to be used in an aggressive manner.

title: Mexican Leader Vows Action Against Drugs
description: Mexico's new President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has promised a visiting committee from the United States House of Representatives that his Government will intensify its war against drugs with new efforts that will ''make life miserable for drug traffickers,'' members of the delegation say.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; G.M. Yellow Pages Job Is Awarded to D.M.B.&B.
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles is one of the few agencies that specializes in buying Yellow Pages advertising. That's a primary reason it beat out two other General Motors agencies to win the auto giant's factory and dealer Yellow Pages advertising account, with a budget reportedly in the $20 million range.

title: Reply to Gorbachev
description: The timing of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call last week for a volunteer international Peace Corps to revitalize Afghanistan was just right for the Coalition for National Service, a private nonprofit organization based in Washington.

title: Let Small Business Mind Its Own Business
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hall of Fame Entrants
description: Three more names will be added to the Advertising Hall of Fame. They are Sidney R. Bernstein, chairman of the executive committee at Crain Communications and the editor of Advertising Age from 1938-58; the late Robert V. Goldstein, who served as vice president of advertising at Procter & Gamble, and Ray A. Kroc, the founder of the McDonald's restaurant chain. The three were selected from a field of 44 nominations and their names will formally be inducted into the hall on March 28.

title: Sharp Eyes, Quiet Competence
description: For seven years, New York City has benefited from Alair Townsend's considerable gifts of financial acumen, persistence and quiet diplomacy. Now, to City Hall's regret, she leaves to become publisher of Crain's New York Business. Her successor as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development is Stanley Grayson, who comes well qualified by his work as Finance Commissioner.

title: All Aboard. . .Somewhere. . .for Subway Changes!
description: Dozens of people stood on subway platforms yesterday waiting for trains that never came. Others sought to get off at stations where the trains no longer stopped.

title: Metro Matters; When Journalists Telling the News Also Shape It
description: Colleagues call him ''the county leader,'' and they're only half-joking. Critics call him worse, and mean it.

title: 32 Americans Selected For Rhodes Scholarship
description: A doctoral candidate who entered college at the age of 12 and a New Yorker who has worked in social services programs while attending college were among the 32 men and women named today as American Rhodes Scholars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Buyback Offer By Ammirati
description: The senior partners of Ammirati & Puris have held talks with Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership, the company that acquired the agency last year, about buying it back.

title: Why We Shouldn't Reject Alien Farm Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Smiling Bakker Preaches Hope in Time of Travail
description: Delivering his first Sunday sermon since he was indicted six days ago, Jim Bakker today emphasized a message of hope, faith and the evilness of the opponent.

title: Review/Concert; LaGuardia Hall's Opening, Starring the Familiar
description: Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts finally has the concert hall it has been waiting for. The inaugural concert on Friday evening presented this space on Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street, behind Lincoln Center, to the school itself and to the city's musical life.

title: Bushes Enter a Glare, Warily but Unblinking
description: Just as Amy Carter once talked over nuclear war with her father, the President, so Dorothy Bush LeBlond offers advice to her father on matters of importance.

title: Soviet Relief Plane Crashes, Killing 78
description: A Soviet military transport plane crashed today on a rescue mission in the earthquake-devastated region of Armenia, adding 78 deaths to the swelling list of casualties, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: 20 Palestinians Are Wounded In Gaza Clashes With Israelis
description: Palestinians protesting the killing of two youths shut down the Gaza Strip in a general strike today, and hospital officials said Israeli troops had wounded 20 people in clashes.

title: Emily and George Ponder 'Our Town'
description: In the final act of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town,'' after Emily Gibbs has died in childbirth, left the cemetery and gone back for a day to visit Grover's Corners, N.H., she delivers a line that for 50 years has moved audiences to tears: ''Do any human beings ever realize life while they live it every, every minute?''

title: Reporter's Notebook; Shedding Light on Art History's Musty Esoterica
description: Since it began in the mid-19th century, the discipline of art history has been a low-profile pursuit. The scholarly research and writing that art historians do are seen in catalogues, essays, lectures and exhibitions. But although there have been occasional stars, like John Ruskin and Bernard Berenson, for the most part this musty museum-and-library-oriented profession lacks glamour. To the public, it seems a business of endless fussing over dates and attributions and finding the flaw in the angel's wing that proves the painting wasn't done by Fra Filippo Lippi after all.

title: Experts Warn of U.S. Lag In Vital Chip Technology
description: Electronics executives and scientists are warning that the Japanese are rapidly pulling ahead of the United States in development of a crucial new X-ray technology that will be used to manufacture computer chips in the mid-1990's.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks on Israeli Coalition The Labor and Likud parties entered talks on resuming a national unity government, with both sides saying they hoped for a quick end to the political deadlock. Page A3. A Discount Fare Returns United Airlines is offering seven-day advance-purchase discount fares again, but discounts are smaller than those eliminated last month. Page D1. Take the A Train (Maybe) Confusion reigned on the first day of an ambitious plan to reroute New York City subway trains for better service. Page B1. Fate of the Universe One model of the universe, shown schematically below, suggests it will expand forever at the current rate.

title: Pamela Rose Is Married To Dr. Michael S. Easton
description: Pamela Rose, the managing director of Rose Associates, a commercial real-estate concern in Chicago, and Dr. Michael Scott Easton, a resident psychiatrist at the Illinois State Psychiatric Institute in Chicago, were married there yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel. Rabbi Geoffrey D. Botnick officiated.

title: U.S. SPENT BILLIONS ON ATOM PROJECTS THAT HAVE FAILED
description: The United States spent billions of dollars in the last two decades on complex military and civilian energy projects that failed to work as promised.

title: TV Notes
description: News as Entertainment

title: Debate on 'Who Is a Jew?' Stirs Deeper Waters
description: To the Editor:

title: After Reagan, Military Shows New Muscles but Old Aches
description: After a military buildup that cost the nation $2 trillion, President-elect Bush will inherit armed forces that are better educated, better trained and generally better armed than when Ronald Reagan won the White House in 1980.

title: Kodak Blood Analyzer
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has developed a blood analyzer that works in zero-gravity conditions for use aboard the United States space station scheduled to go into orbit in 1995. Company officials said the analyzer, which does not use liquid chemicals, will allow medical personnel on the ground to evaluate illnesses and other conditions of the crew.

title: Robin Friedman Wed To Dr. K. S. Ehrensall
description: The marriage of Robin Lisa Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin S. Friedman of Hillside, N.J., to Dr. Kenneth Steven Ehrensall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Ehrensall of Boca Raton, Fla., took place yesterday in Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel.

title: Rozier and Oilers Trounce Bengals, 41-6
description: Mike Rozier scored on runs of 13, 15 and 3 yards, leading the Houston Oilers to a 41-6 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals today and keeping alive hopes of their first American Football Conference Central Division title.

title: 9 German Jews Quit Council
description: Nine members of the German Jewish Council's executive board resigned today after an embezzlement scandal earlier this year involving funds for Nazi victims, the leader of the council, Heinz Galinski, said.

title: Investigators Say They're Ready to Topple New Mafia Chiefs
description: Three years ago on Friday, a gray-haired, grandfatherly looking man was slain in a salvo of gunfire on a midtown Manhattan street in an assassination that signaled a period of rapid disintegration for the five Mafia families in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Auto Racing; The Education of a Champion
description: Bill Elliott, this season's Nascar champion, has experienced both sides of a close championship race, beating Rusty Wallace by 24 points for this year's title and losing to Darrell Waltrip in 1985 by 101.

title: Review/Dance; From the Madcap to the Somber in 5 New Works
description: The five new works presented by the Movingsound choreographers' collaborative at St. Mark's Church on Thursday evening covered a wide range of topics, styles and moods, from an appropriately somber look at the Great Potato Famine in Ireland in the mid-19th century to a madcap evocation of the moon that was the highlight of the evening.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Family Feuds That Are Right Out of a Novel
description: WITH publishing empires adding houses, divisions or imprints, the kind of frenzied rivalry for books and authors that used to be fought mainly with outsiders is now just as often occurring within publishing empires like Random House Inc., Bantam Doubleday Dell, Simon & Schuster Inc., Viking Penguin and Macmillan Inc. And this kind of competition is likely to intensify as the publishing industry becomes more concentrated and the battle for the ''big book'' grows.

title: Winning Games, Influencing People
description: The date was Nov. 23. The Knicks had just beaten the Pistons, 133-111, on the road. Chuck Daly, the Pistons' coach, upset that his experienced and talented team was rattled by the press, said of the Knicks, ''I think this club is good enough to win the Atlantic Division.''

title: Review/Theater; A Modern-Day Heffalump in Search of Herself
description: Deep into ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' Wendy Wasserstein's enlightening portrait of her generation, the title character makes a speech to her high school alumnae at a ''Women, Where Are We Going?'' luncheon. In the speech, a tour de force for the author, Heidi vividly describes an aerobics class that proved to be an epiphany. While exercising, she was surrounded by an Inferno of ''power women'' both young and old. With sudden intuition, she realized that as a child of the 1960's - as a woman subjected to judgment by men and as a humanist trying to position herself among feminists - she is stranded, and no one is about to rescue her.

title: Staten Island: In a Seceding State of Mind
description: Theresa Grey would like to take a bite out of the Big Apple. A 60.9-square-mile bite, to be exact. ''I dislike New York,'' she said. No, it is not as singable as ''I Love New York.'' But like Mrs. Grey, a clerk in a coin-operated laundry on Staten Island, many Staten Islanders do not consider New York something to sing about. They think Staten Island should secede from New York City -all 60.9 square miles, from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge all the way west to Tottenville.

title: Investors Expect a New Surge in Takeover Bids
description: Investors are anticipating a new burst of takeover attempts by corporations and financial firms.

title: Good School Design Makes Educational Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Color Me Tainted
description: Does a political background taint a journalist? Is the Republic's need for independent media criticism endangered by a new breed of androgenous analyst called the Washington Insider, those publicists and journalists leaping the barrier between participant and observer?

title: Pro-Solidarity Riot in Gdansk
description: Youths chanting slogans in support of the outlawed union Solidarity smashed the windows of a local police station in Gdansk with stones today, witnesses said. As many as 200 of the youths, most between 14 and 18, began throwing stones at the three-story building after a line of riot policemen had been withdrawn. The windows of at least two police vehicles were also shattered.

title: Labor and Likud Resume Formal Talks
description: The Labor and Likud parties began formal talks today on forming a coalition government, and among Labor's demands was that a new government change the nation's electoral system so that negotiations like those of the last few weeks will not be not repeated.

title: Bears Clinch Title By Edging Lions
description: The Chicago Bears used their home-field edge today to gain the home-field advantage in the playoffs.

title: Montana Is on Target As 49ers Win
description: Nearly everyone here today expected a nip-and-tuck scrap, because the winner would be one victory shy of the National Conference West Division title.

title: Review/Television; For the Holidays, Family and Romance
description: Two new Christmas dramas are being offered this evening. It's the ''new'' that makes them special. Television budgets make the most of recycling old Christmas shows under the heading of classics. Some of the retreads have been around for 15 or 20 years. But then again, nostalgia soaked in sentimentality is the very essence of the season. The traditional carols can always give us a goosebump or two.

title: Texas Air Faces Test In Bargaining Ruling
description: A small and obscure agency here has completed taking testimony in a case that could have serious consequences for the airline empire built by Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Janice Patt Marries
description: Janice Audrey Patt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Patt of Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Abraham Michael Obuchowski, the son of Miriam Obuchowski of Belle Harbor, Queens, and the late Itzhak Obuchowski. Rabbi Allan Blaine officiated at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. The bride is a psychotherapist at Greenwich House in New York. Dr. Obuchowski is a co-director of the Hudson Radiology Center in Bayonne, N.J., and a staff radiologist at the Jersey City Medical Center.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BNH Bancshares Inc., New Haven, and its Bank of New Haven subsidiary accepted the resignation of Joseph V. Ciaburri as president and chief executive of the company and the bank, effective Dec. 31.

title: GAF Trial to Test U.S. Evidence in Insider Cases
description: The GAF stock manipulation trial, which begins today with jury selection in Federal District Court in Manhattan,represents the first test of evidence that the Government has obtained from Boyd L. Jefferies.

title: Outdoors: A Tennessee Deer Hunt
description: TRUDGING up a hardwood ridge in pre-dawn darkness, I soon found the tree stand that my host, Wilson Burton, Jr., had allotted me for my first morning of deer hunting in Tennessee.

title: Treasury Focuses on Bill Sales This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills and followed on Thursday by the one-year Treasury bill auction.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Balancing the Equation Of Fat and Exercise
description: SEVERAL years ago, J. P. Flatt, a professor of biochemistry at the University of Massachusetts Medical School in Worcester, put a laboratory mouse in a cage with an exercise wheel and gave the mouse access to as much food as it cared to eat. In return for this cushy life style, the mouse had to submit to daily metabolic measurements.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've been working here solidly for all five days. In that time we've brought out 23 people alive. I don't want to talk about how many bodies - but there were 280 people in this building.'' - Anton Sukisikanyan, a crane operator in Leninakan, U.S.S.R. [ A1:5. ]

title: Coolidge, Carter, Bush, Reagan . . .
description: Now that the election and the ensuing discussion and recrimination are pleasantly in the past, there is satisfaction, no doubt, in finding one matter on which all observers are agreed: The 1988 Presidential campaign set a new low in banality extending to unimaginative bad taste.

title: Ceausescu, Cultural Vandal
description: LEAD: The President of Rumania, Nicolae Ceausescu, is playing God with his country's architectural heritage. His disastrous policy of ultimately demolishing 6,000 to 7,000 villages in the countryside and destroying the historic centers of 45 towns and razing old neighborhoods in Bucharest is well under way.

title: 3 Lawsuits Question Permits To New York Sewer Plants
description: Two environmental groups and an agency responsible for safeguarding water quality have sued to try to force New York State to hold hearings on operating permits recently issued to New York City's sewage treatment plants.

title: World, We Are Here
description: The next time troubles threaten in the Philippines or Pakistan and the urge to help is strong, you can suit up and say ''Lafayette, we are here'' in Manila or Islamabad and stand a chance of being welcome, says Representative Stephen Solarz, Democrat of New York, At a lunch in Mr. Solarz' honor last year, President Corazon Aquino thanked him for his work on the House Foreign Affairs Committee on behalf of the ''Filipino struggle for freedom'' and addressed him as ''the Lafayette of the Philippine revolution.''

title: Debate on 'Who Is a Jew?' Stirs Deeper Waters; Israelism, Not Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * The Soviet Union has proposed financial regulations intended to let businesses deal directly with foreign partners, make the ruble exchange rate more realistic and lower barriers to starting joint ventures. The rules, stated in a resolution adopted last week by the Council of Ministers, call for state enterprises and the Soviet cooperative movement to make direct foreign transactions by April. Several thousand cooperatives, ranging from those making household goods to restaurants, sprang up after laws supporting them were passed this year. Such transactions will be carried out on the basis of ''authentic foreign currency self-repayment,'' and Moscow will not be responsible for the groups' debts, the text said. The regulations will progressively end Moscow's current fixing of the ruble. As of Jan. 1, 1990, the ruble will initially be fixed at half its present value against convertible currencies for export-import transactions. A new exchange rate is to be set a year later. As for joint ventures, the document proposed to end Moscow's insistence on retaining a 51 percent interest but gave no effective dates.

title: Study Finds 40 Years of Flaws In Buying for Armed Forces
description: For 40 years, successive panels of industrial and business leaders have repeatedly found many flaws in the way the Defense Department buys weapons, but few officials or political leaders have done anything about it, the House Armed Services Committee asserted today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 The grievances of Soviet Armenians burst out anew with protesters clashing with army troops in the midst of an international rescue effort. Mikhail Gorbachev lashed out at protest leaders. Page A1

title: Dr. Paul Feldman, Dentist, Weds Perri Beth Koggan
description: The marriage of Perri Beth Koggan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Koggan of South Orange, N.J., to Dr. Paul Robert Feldman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Feldman of Livingston, N.J., took place yesterday at the Greenbrook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman officiated.

title: The Gorbachev Spell; Americans Warm to 'the Human Side' Shown by Soviet Leader on His Visit
description: From his eloquent speech at the United Nations on Wednesday morning to his return to a grief-stricken country two days later, Mikhail S. Gorbachev captivated American audiences last week in a way that no other Communist and few Western figures have ever done.

title: Drug Arrests Are Crowding Local Prisons
description: Since last winter, about 70 inmates in the Bergen County Jail Annex have slept on the gym floor each night because the jail has twice the number of inmates it can house.

title: NBC Planning to Revise Affiliate Compensation
description: General managers of more than 200 television stations affiliated with NBC were told last week to expect a major revision in the way they are compensated for staying with the network.

title: Condemn the Eyesores Of Roosevelt Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Speed Search for Homeless Shelters
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Administration to speed up the process of determining whether surplus Government property can be used to shelter the nation's homeless.

title: Justices Permit Agency Opinions in Private Suits
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that opinions and conclusions in reports of Government agencies may be admitted as evidence in private lawsuits if the reports are ''trustworthy'' and the conclusions are based on factual investigations.

title: SCS-Compute Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
For Reagans, a Season Of Many Last Times
description: These days are full of last times for President and Mrs. Reagan, and their eighth Christmas season at the White House is one of them. Nancy Reagan says that while the holiday, with its festive traditions, evokes unique memories, this one is also a time for looking ahead.

title: How to Increase New York City Housing Stock
description: To the Editor:

title: Parrying and Jabbing, Koch Hits 64
description: Mayor Koch spent his 64th birthday yesterday denouncing his critics, accusing political foes of deceit, attacking columnists and reporters, defending the talent and integrity of his administration and thanking God that he had been granted such a ''wonderful life.''

title: Gandalf Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income The company said results were hurt by a lengthy Bell Canada strike. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: INSIDE
description: Two commuter trains collided near a junction in the southern part of the city, and a third train plowed into the wreckage. Page A3. Swiss Government Scandal The first woman in the Swiss Cabinet resigned after admitting she told her husband that his company was the focus of a police inquiry. Page A3. Baseball's Richest Players The number of major league players earning $2 million or more reached 12 in 1988, with 62 making $1 million or more. Page B19. 3 van Goghs Stolen Three paintings by van Gogh, including a version of ''The Potato Eaters,'' were stolen from a Dutch museum last night. Page A12.

title: Big Contract For Bechtel
description: The Energy Department last week awarded Bechtel Group Inc. a 10-year contract valued at up to $1 billion to develop a system for safe, permanent disposal of radioactive nuclear waste and spent fuel.

title: Taiwan Braces for an Export Crisis
description: Signals from Washington that the United States will put pressure on Taiwan to revalue its currency upward are causing fears here of sharp reductions in exports. Worries of impending economic crisis are prompting businesses to close factories and lay off workers.

title: MICHIGAN BEGINS ABORTION FUND BAN
description: A ban approved by the state's voters on Medicaid payments for abortions took effect today, and Michigan women with unwanted pregnancies and little money were faced with searching for alternatives to the public money.

title: Topics of The Times; Soft Socialist Money
description: Prague has moved against Polish Christmas shoppers who flock across the Czechoslovak frontier to snap up consumer bargains with their overvalued Polish currency. Prague also worries about retail raids by East Germans, whose currency is worth more when exchanged for Czech crowns. And the East Germans have had to discourage Polish shoppers who cross the frontier and empty stores of consumer goods like TV sets.

title: Designatronics Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The prior year share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend declared in September 1988 and 1987.

title: G.M. Plans First Profit-Sharing Payout Since '85
description: Hailing improvements in its domestic automotive business, the General Motors Corporation told 450,000 salaried and hourly workers today that profit-sharing payments typically amounting to about $200 each would be paid for 1988.

title: Forest City Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of properties of $1,784,000. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $526,000 and a loss of $95,000 on the sale of properties. d-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $445,000, a gain from an accounting adjustment of $9,187,000, and a gain on the sale of properties of $13,000.

title: Texas Executes Man; 2d Is Spared
description: A man who murdered a restaurateur as his wife watched was executed by injection early to day, hours after the Supreme Court spared a second convict from the same fate.

title: Pall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Figures for 1987 have been restated to reflect the acquisition of RAI Research Corp. on Sept. 30, 1988, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners are taught, usually in their first lesson, that they should attempt three no-trump whenever the combined hands have 26 high-card points. But that is a normal value, and particular deals can stray considerably from that standard.

title: An Editorial Director For Time Inc.
description: Richard B. Stolley, the founding editor of People magazine, will assume the job of editorial director of the 22 magazines at Time Inc. next month, succeeding Ray Cave, who was forced out of the position last month, the company announced.

title: Amnesty Reports Wave of Executions in Iran
description: The Iranian authorities have executed hundreds and perhaps thousands of people since June in the largest wave of political executions in Iran since 1980, Amnesty International charged today.

title: The Philharmonic to Visit Wyoming
description: The New York Philharmonic is to visit Jackson Hole, Wyo., in July for a two-week residency under the auspices of the Grand Teton Music Festival, and perform four concerts in its 750-seat wooden theater, the orchestra announced yesterday.

title: Unisys Planning Decentralization
description: The Unisys Corporation said it planned to decentralize its management and split the corporate focus into product marketing and development groups. The reorganization means that fewer executives will report to the company's chairman and chief executive, W. Michael Blumenthal.

title: Argentine Military to Get Raises
description: Trying to restore discipline in the army a week after the end of a mutiny, the Government has decided to give members of the military raises of 20 percent and bonuses of $115, officials said today.

title: Mayor of Mexico City Tours Market Where Blast Killed 62
description: An enraged crowd, demanding justice, followed the new Mayor of Mexico City today on an inspection trip through a charred marketplace where 62 people died and 83 were injured in an explosion and blaze last night apparently caused by illegal fireworks.

title: Latin American Plea for Debt Relief
description: Finance ministers of seven leading Latin American nations drafted a set of proposals today to be presented to the United States and other industrial nations on ways of reducing Latin America's foreign debt.

title: Cows and the Climate
description: The average cow belches up to 400 liters of methane a day, a situation that worsens the global greenhouse effect and ought to be curbed, a Colorado State University scientist says.

title: Charter Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a one-time administrative charge of $895,000.

title: Sentence in Steroid Case
description: David Jenkins, the former British track star, was sentenced today to seven years in Federal prison and fined $75,000 for his role in an international steroid-smuggling ring.

title: Electro-Catheter Corp reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Guide to Software Maze
description: ANYBODY with an appropriate machine and a desire to save money can profit from ''Alfred Glossbrenner's Master Guide to Free Software for IBM's and Compatible Computers,'' the 14th book by the indefatigable researcher and writer.

title: An Inauguration Snag?
description: If Irving Schlaifer has his way, there could be a taxi strike in Washington just as the Bush inauguration festivities begin next month.

title: Retail Sales Fall 0.5% in Britain
description: The volume of Britain's retail sales dropped five-tenths of a percent last month, indicating that a consumer spending boom is beginning to slow.

title: By Design; Sweet Nothings for the Shoulders
description: Whether small enough to tuck around a neckline or large enough to snuggle into, a scarf or a shawl is one of the most flattering of all accessories. No matter how you drape, fold or clutch it, a scarf flatters the face and figure. It is also one of the fastest ways to give a fresh twist to something you already own.

title: Central Sprinkler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Banks' Net At Record $5.9 Billion
description: The nation's commercial banking industry reported a record $5.9 billion in third-quarter profits, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today. But the agency's chairman warned that the volume of bad loans had increased and that bank involvement in leveraged buyouts should be carefully monitored.

title: Amcast Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 96.

title: Gap Found In Averting Workplace Diseases
description: Most family doctors are inadequately trained to recognize and treat illness that stems from unhealthy environments at home or work, a National Academy of Sciences panel said today.

title: Wish List fo an ElectroniC Christmas
description: IF money were no object this Christmas, our letter to Santa might start with a request for a Next Computer System from Next Inc.

title: Italian Scholar's 2d Novel: Instant Pop Icon
description: Nothing may succeed like success in the United States, but life for Italians is more complicated, Umberto Eco was saying.

title: Despite Promise in AIDS Cases, Drug Faces Testing Hurdle
description: THE Food and Drug Administration has decided to place new restrictions on a drug widely used to fight blindness in AIDS patients until its benefits are proved in a controlled study.

title: Quayle Shows He Has Learned How to Be No. 2
description: Vice President-elect Dan Quayle today held his first news conference since the election and demonstrated that he has learned well from George Bush how to handle himself as an appropriately deferential No. 2.

description: Lacroix Ascendancy Stalls

title: Kinder-Care Group Buys Kysor Stake
description: An investment group led by Kinder-Care Inc. has purchased an 8.8 percent stake in the Kysor Industrial Corporation and said it might try to seek control of the refrigeration equipment and truck part manufacturer based in Cadillac, Mich. Kinder-Care, based in Montgomery, Ala., operates day-care centers.

title: Addendum
description: * Venture magazine will raise its ad rates 7.5 percent with the February issue.

title: Liberace's Mansion Sold
description: Liberace's mansion, once valued at $2.8 million, has been sold at auction for $325,000 to two fans of the flamboyant pianist. James

title: Ad Spending Pace for '89 Seen Slowing
description: FOR the first time since 1975, advertiser spending will not keep pace in 1989 with the increase in the gross national product, Robert E. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann Erickson, predicted yesterday.

title: Scientists Eye Ancient African Plant As Better Source of Pulp for Paper
description: NEWSPAPERS would be brighter, tougher, easier on the eyes and less likely to yellow or leave ink on the hands if they were printed on paper made from an ancient African plant that is on the verge of commercial production in the American South.

title: Soviets Allow Solzhenitsyn To Be Praised
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, branded an unpublishable heretic two weeks ago by a top Soviet ideologist, was praised as a visionary here in officially tolerated celebrations of his 70th birthday.

title: Nikko Acquires 20% of Blackstone Group
description: The Blackstone Group, a New York investment banking firm specializing in mergers and acquisitions, has tightened its link with Nikko Securities Inc., the third-largest securities firm in Japan, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: In a First, the Kremlin Allows Foreigners to See Labor Camp
description: For the first time the Government has permitted foreigners to visit a labor camp near here where Soviet citizens who challenged the Government have been incarcerated.

title: Robert T. Wieringa, Executive, 65
description: Robert T. Wieringa, a business executive and former president of the Warner-Lambert Company, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Saturday at his home on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 65 years old.

title: Plan for Row Houses, Praised Nationally, Debated at Home
description: It is New York's most celebrated affordable housing program of the 1980's. Congress and the Reagan Administration have created a new Federal program modeled on it. Yet, despite its national reputation, the Nehemiah plan - which has revived parts of the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn - faces an uncertain future in New York City.

title: Review/Dance; Experiments in Energy
description: Stephen Petronio belongs to a handful of new modern-dance choreographers who have attracted attention largely through the overtly physical quality of their movement.

title: First Woman in Swiss Cabinet Quits; Husband Is Scrutinized
description: The first woman to serve in Switzerland's Cabinet said today that she was resigning after admitting that she had advised her husband of a money-laundering investigation involving his company.

title: Swedes Report On AIDS Drug
description: SWEDISH scientists said yesterday they have found a new drug that is highly effective against the AIDS virus in laboratory and animal tests.

title: New York's Deficit - Of Political Will
description: Albany's leadership vacuum continues: New York's State Senate still prefers to deny the existence of a budget crisis, while Governor Cuomo offers a half-baked emergency plan that would merely defer much of the problem. Legislators reconvening today owe the financial markets, and the voters, more reassurance.

title: Visitors at Soviet Embassy: 'We Share Your Sorrow'
description: At the Soviet Embassy here, just past the Government brochures on changes in the machine tool industry and the philosophy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, there sits a condolence book. Over the last few days, since the earthquake in Soviet Armenia, Americans meek and mighty have signed its pages.

title: Curator Leaving Philadelphia Museum
description: The curator Mark Rosenthal, whose widely acclaimed traveling exhibitions on Jasper Johns and Anselm Kiefer have established him as one of the museum stars of his generation, has resigned as Muriel and Philip Berman Curator of 20th-Century Art at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, effective Jan. 31.

title: Bush Is Second-Guessed on Tower Delay
description: President-elect Bush's delay in picking a Defense Secretary and filling other top positions in the new administration, after a fast start, is prompting intense second-guessing here about Mr. Bush's selection process.

title: Orangemen in Fight
description: Derrick Coleman, a junior forward on the Syracuse basketball team, and two football players, Deval Glover and Chris Ingram, were among the main combatants in a fight at Syracuse's Schine Student Center early Sunday morning, according to the Syracuse city police.

title: Walther H. Feldmann, Executive, 90
description: Walther H. Feldmann, former president and chairman of the Worthington Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial equipment in Harrison, N.J., died yesterday of complications from a stroke at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 90 years old.

Armenian Relief Society of North America, 80 Bigelow Avenue, Watertown, Mass. 02172. CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Catholic Medical Mission Board, 10 W. 17th Street, New York, N.Y.10011. Church World Service, Armenian Earthquake Response, P.O. BOX 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Direct Relief International, P.O. Box 30820, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93130-0820. Fair Lawn Jewish Community Council, 10-10 Norma Avenue, Fair Lawn, N.J. 07410. Lutheran World Relief, 360 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10010. Mennonite Central Committee, 21 South 12th Street, Akron, Pa. 17501. Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross, 264 Old Country Road, Mineola, N.Y. 11501. Operation California/U.S.A., 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. Save the Children, 48 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. Temple Beth-El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, NJ 07304 U.S. Committee for UNICEF, 331 East 38th Street, N.Y., New York, 10016. Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, N.Y. 10580. World Relief, P.O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. World Vision, Box 0, Pasadena, Calif. 91109.

title: Sketch of Peasant Life
description: ''The Potato Eaters,'' one of 92 van Goghs in the Kroller-Muller National Museum in Otterlo, is the second sketch for the 1885 painting that is one of the most beloved of van Gogh's works and the synthesis of his Dutch realism. The sketch is 28 by 36 inches, roughly two-thirds the size of the painting. It is less detailed and the figures are blockier, but everything in the painting is essentially in place.

title: Dust Particles' Long Journey Puzzles Experts
description: GIANT dust particles, blown thousands of miles across the Pacific Ocean in apparent defiance of known atmospheric processes, are confounding meteorologists and oceanographers.

title: As Economy Grew Since '83, Closings and Layoffs Took 9.7 Million Jobs
description: Despite the longest peacetime economic expansion in the nation's history, nearly 10 million Americans lost their jobs to plant closings and layoffs from 1983 to 1988, Government figures show.

title: Lebanese Group Says It Will Kill a U.S. Hostage
description: The kidnappers of a United States Marine officer said today that they have decided to kill him as a spy and in retaliation for Israeli attacks in Lebanon.

title: Chock Full O' Nuts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an unrealized gain on marketable equity securities of $178,000. c-Net loss and included an unrealized loss on marketable equity securities of $1,947,000.

title: Researchers Find Fungi Rid Soil of a Contaminant
description: SCIENTISTS in California have found a way to use natural fungi in the soil to remove toxic selenium from the state's Kesterson National Wildlife Refuge and from farms throughout the western United States where selenium contamination appears to be a growing threat.

title: More Oil Rigs in Action
description: The number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas increased by 17 last week, to 922, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count was 1,181.

title: Way Cleared for N.R.C. Vote on Shoreham
description: The staff of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission cleared the way last night for the full five-member commission to consider a commercial operating permit for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: 2 Unilever Units Plan Media Buying Division
description: A new consolidated media buying operation is planned by Thomas J. Lipton Inc. and the Lever Brothers Company, both units of Unilever U.S. The new operation, L & L Media Inc., will be headed by Bruce Hoenig, 48 years old, and will represent the business units of Lipton, Lever/Shedd's Foods and Lever household products in buying all national broadcast advertising.

title: James R. Smothers Jr., Educator, Is Dead at 68
description: James Roy Smothers Jr., a college administrator and director of educational services for the United Negro College Fund, died of cardiac arrest Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Computer 'Gangs' Stake Out Turf
description: Gang warfare has broken out in the computer industry. Hardly a month seems to pass without some group of companies banding together to champion one particular way of building computers or software and, more often than not, to thwart another group with a different proposal.

title: Review/Recital; Soderstrom and Levine
description: Those of us who love song tend these days to flock to the concerts of a shrinking group of senior singers in whose work we find the sensibility, the blend of comprehension and intuitive generosity, and the sophisticated interest in repertory to make the recital of 20 or so concert songs an engrossing experience. These singers are getting older, but they keep singing and we are happy to keep going to hear them, because there is nothing quite like the evenings they give. Elisabeth Soderstrom is one of the special group; her concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night drew the usual public and gave the usual satisfaction.

title: Bass Said to Alter Plan For American Savings
description: Racing to meet a Dec. 31 deadline, the Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth has agreed to a significant change in the terms of its acquisition of American Savings and Loan, the nation's largest insolvent savings and loan association, industry experts said last night.

title: At Shuttered Newark Museum, Dreams of an Autumn Awakening
description: They're dreamers in Newark. The grounds of the Newark Museum are scarred with freshly torn earth. Most of the artworks - many of them acknowledged masterpieces - have been in storage for more than a year. And the closest the freshly plastered galleries come to looking like a museum is where the curators have taped to the wall a photocopy of a Tibetan Buddha or of an African mask or of a John Singleton Copley portrait to indicate where the real things might be placed when the museum reopens next November.

title: Disney Concert Hall Design Selected
description: Frank O. Gehry, widely regarded as one of the most individualistic and innovative architects in the world, was chosen yesterday as designer of the planned Walt Disney Concert Hall, a 2,500-seat home for the Los Angeles Philharmonic. The announcement was made in Los Angeles by Frederick M. Nicholas, chairman of the Walt Disney Concert Hall Committee, which selected the proposal submitted by Frank O. Gehry and Associates of Venice, Calif., from among four designs by internationally-known architects.

title: Alico Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The company said the $6.9 million increase in net earnings included a gain of $3.5 million from operations and $3.4 million from the cumulative effect of required accounting changes for the current and previous years.

title: Time for Compromise on Farm Trade
description: Global negotiations to reduce trade barriers are threatened by a deadlock on farm policy between the United States and the European Community. A potent bloc of Latin American nations refuses to make any deals on non-farm trade until the farm issue is settled. In a striking reversal, the third world may force reforms on the industrial powers. That would be good for all.

title: In Bitter Cold, Some of Homeless Resist Shelters They Often Fear
description: With bone-warping cold enveloping the Northeast and the Midwest, the urban homeless are suddenly faced with a life-or-death decision: where to go for the night.

title: Giant Atom Smasher Encounters Vexing Technical Obstacles
description: SCIENTISTS investigating how to build the biggest and most expensive scientific instrument of all time - a $4.4 billion atom smasher 53 miles in circumference - have encountered vexing problems making the machine's 55-foot-long superconducting magnets, thousands of which are to be strung together like pearls on a string.

title: San Jose Journal; Nobel Notwithstanding, at Home the Cheers Die
description: The best foreign minister in this country's history, many people here complain, has never had that title. He is President Oscar Arias Sanchez.

title: Transition Watch; For Bentsen, The Race Continues
description: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Vice President-elect, has been trying without success to bury the hatchet with his Democratic rival in the Presidential campaign, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.

title: Bhutto Wins Vote of Confidence
description: Acting President Ghulam Ishaq Khan easily won a five-year presidential term today and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto scored a victory in her first parliamentary vote of confidence.

title: American Gas Producers Fight Plan for Pipelines
description: Natural gas producers in the West and Southwest objected today to a proposal permitting the construction of pipelines from Canada to Long Island and Massachusetts, arguing that gas producers in Canada would have an unfair pricing advantage.

title: Layden Quit And It Was Not a Joke
description: You've heard of the caramel test, of course. It was the test Frank Layden said he gave to prospects while he was the basketball coach at Niagara University.

title: U.S. Rocket Hits Indian Ship Accidentally, Killing Crewman
description: A crewman on an Indian merchant ship was killed today when the ship was struck by a practice missile launched from a Navy jet during an exercise northwest of the island of Kauai, the Navy said.

title: Police Still Seeking a Suspect in L.I. Shooting Spree
description: Police investigators said today that they still had no motive or suspects in the shootings of four people in four nights within a mile radius here last week.

title: Federal Home Banks Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks plans to announce today the interest rates for a six-part offering totaling $5 billion.

title: In-Car Breath Tests Planned
description: People convicted of drunken driving might soon have to take breath tests to start their cars, under a bill Governor Cuomo signed today. The legislation allows courts to order interlocks, at drivers' expense, as part of probation for people convicted of felonies or misdemeanors in which driving while intoxicated is an ''essential element.''

title: Chicago Official Quits Race and Backs Daley
description: Edward Burke, the alderman once considered the strongest white candidate for mayor, quit the race today and gave his support to a fellow Democrat, Richard M. Daley.

title: Relics Hint at a Chinese Alphabet
description: Mysterious signs on wine jugs and other ancient objects have led archaeologists to hypothesize that China once had an alphabet, it was reported today.

title: Runner Disqualified
description: More than a month after he supposedly became the first runner from Brooklyn to cross the finish line and the second runner from the metropolitan area to complete the New York City Marathon, John Silva, 30 years old, was disqualified yesterday on grounds he did not run the entire course. The disqualification will cost Silva $1,100 in prize money.

title: Kentucky Shows Text of Most Allegations
description: Dwane Casey, a University of Kentucky assistant coach, is mentioned in seven allegations of wrongdoing brought against the university's basketall program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Higher Bid From Grand Met Pushes Pillsbury Shares Up
description: The share price of the Pillsbury Company surged today as investors responded to a new, higher offer for the company and as it became increasingly likely that Pillsbury would yield to its determined suitor, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Penril Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 Soviet rescues have been hampered by disorganization, Soviet newspapers and television asserted. Hope was fading for thousands of Armenians believed to be trapped by last week's earthquake. Page A1 Foreigners visited a labor camp in Soviet Union near Perm for the first time and met Soviet citizens who have been detained for challenging the Government. A1

title: Blood Test in Space
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has developed a blood analyzer that works in weightlessness for use aboard the United States space station scheduled to go into orbit in 1995.

title: Review/Television; A&E Salutes the Sultan of Swat
description: The main pleasures of ''Babe Ruth'' are the clips of the famous Yankees of the 1920's, when the Babe was breaking all the records. The hourlong documentary on the Arts & Entertainment cable network tonight at 8 and midnight takes us briskly through George Herman Ruth's life, from the orphanage where he first played what he would later call ''the only real game'' to his start in 1914 with the Baltimore Orioles, to his transformation from prodigious pitcher to sensational slugger.

title: Vincent H. Rendich, Importer, 85
description: Vincent H. Rendich, an importer of men's clothing, died of a heart attack Sunday at the United Hospital Medical Center in Portchester, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Dow Ends Down 3.91 After a Late Selloff
description: LEAD: The stock market failed to hold early gains yesterday as a late selloff left the Dow Jones industrial average with a small loss.

title: New York City Could Miss Presidential Tally
description: A spokesman for the State Board of Elections said today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's apparent victory in the state might be threatened because New York City election officials have not completed their official count. Based on unofficial figures, New York was one of the 10 states and the District of Columbia that Mr. Dukakis carried.

title: Transition Watch; The Campaign Ends On a Personal Note
description: There is already one lesson, it seems, that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has learned from his campaign with George Bush.

title: Lousiana Housing Agency Prices Mortgage Bonds
description: The Louisiana Housing Finance Agency yesterday tentatively priced a $94.2 million issue of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 3/8 percent for an issue due 2020 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The bonds are collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association securities.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for a series of economic reports to be released over the balance of the week.

title: Borman's Receives Offer From A.& P.
description: Borman's Inc., which owns a chain of 80 grocery stores in the Detroit metropolitan area, said that it had received a $27-a-share takeover bid from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Borman's owns the Farmer Jack supermarket chain, but it has been losing money recently. The offer values Borman's common stock at $75.9 million.

title: Plight of the Homeless Stirs Donors to the Neediest Cases
description: Mary Hays of Manhattan, writing ''as a New Yorker by choice, rather than birth,'' sent $1,500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the request that her contribution go toward feeding and housing the homeless in New York City, whom she called ''the city's most vulnerable citizens.''

title: More Revlon for Tarlow
description: Revlon Inc. has been good to Richard J. Tarlow. First its Max Factor division drew him out of retirement on Shelter Island to start up Tarlow Advertising. Then it gave him the Jean Nate and Jontue accounts. Now the cosmetics company's Almay subsidiary has handed him a group of products to advertise. Among the accounts are Almay's new hyopallergenic shampoo and hypoallergenic fragrance, its deodorant products and the Stress line of facial and body products.

title: For the Knicks, Leading Division Is a Rare Feat
description: The Knicks are in first place in the Atlantic Division. It's a strange occurrence, considering that in the 43-year history of the franchise they have only four divisional championships and two National Basketball Association titles - in 1970 and 1973. If the Knicks win the division, it would be their first divisional title since the 1970-71 season. They finished second in 1973.

title: In Deep Russia, the Camp at the End of the Road
description: Sometimes, the snow swirls low across the road drifting in from the forests. The world is pine and white prairie, entirely. It is like traveling through one of those gentle dreams of cloud.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A. T. Cross Co., Lincoln, R.I., a maker of pens, named Charles H. Sellman chief financial officer. He replaces John E. Buckley, who will focus on the company's Mark Cross and Manetti-Farrow divisions.

title: Sondra Ordover Dies; Paperback Editor, 59
description: Sondra T. Ordover, a longtime editor and publisher of paperback books, died of a brain tumor Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Transition Watch; The Patrician Look Is Now in Style
description: After years of having friends, relatives and her husband's political aides suggest, often not so delicately, that she dye her hair and perk up her wardrobe, Barbara Bush may have the last laugh.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS ASK CUT IN LIBERIA AID
description: In what will be an early test of human-rights policy under the Bush Administration, American and Liberian rights campaigners say they plan to seek restrictions on American aid to Liberia, America's oldest and closest ally in Africa.

title: Researchers Say a Hormone in the Blood Drastically Cuts Cholesterol
description: SCIENTISTS in California have made the surprising discovery that a hormone produced by blood cells dramatically lowers the level of cholesterol in the human body.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie signed a $350 million agreement to supply three wide-bodied A300-600R planes to the United Arab Emirates carrier, Emirates Airlines.

title: Koch Prepares Group To Aid Armenia Effort
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was prepared to send a nine-member rescue team to Armenia to help in efforts to find survivors trapped in the rubble in the earthquake last week.

title: Review/Television; Father Coughlin, 'The Radio Priest'
description: Long before the televangelists, there was an enormously popular radio personality named the Rev. Charles Coughlin. He is profiled on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight on ''An American Experience'' in a presentation called ''The Radio Priest.'' The producer is Irv Drasnin, whose distinguished documentary career covers extended periods at CBS News and PBS's ''Frontline.''

title: 3 van Gogh Paintings Are Stolen From a Dutch National Museum
description: Three paintings by Vincent van Gogh, including a version of his renowned early work ''The Potato Eaters,'' were stolen from the Kroller-Muller National Museum here tonight, the police said.

title: 3 Countries Expected to Sign Angola-Namibia Pact Today
description: Officials from Angola, Cuba and South Africa are expected to sign a preliminary agreement on Tuesday providing for a political settlement in southwestern Africa, the State Department said today.

title: Intelligent Business Comunications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and included a charge of $150,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Information Science Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,174,300 for the quarter and $1,512,100 for the 6 months.

title: Our Towns; Exercising Their Rights To Free Screech
description: Layton Welcher has his driving students announce what's happening on the road around them so they will stay alert. ''Well, I'm on the Meadowbrook Parkway heading north in the center lane,'' Annette Tharrington announced the other day. ''I'm doing 55. People are passing me on the left, people are passing on the right. There's a car right on my tail. I don't care. I'm not going to let this bother me. I'm not doing 70 like everyone else. I'm learning.''

title: Crime Fatalities Rise With Gun Availability
description: To the Editor:

title: Sherrill Quits Post at Texas A&M
description: Jackie Sherrill, the Texas A&M head football coach and athletic director, who was accused by a former player of paying ''hush'' money during an National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation, resigned tonight.

title: Financial Report
description: Following are 1988 baseball incomes for players who were on major league rosters or on the disabled list Aug. 31. Figures, obtained from management and player sources, include base salary, pro-rated share of signing bonus, other guaranteed money (such as payment for trade) and bonuses earned during the season and for post-season awards. In some cases, parts of salaries that were deferred without interest were discounted to reflect present-day value. Asterisks indicate that the player made more than the minimum of $62,500 but was paid the balance by team that released him during the season. Here is the total income those players had: Quisenberry $2,288,843; Soto $1,450,000; McWilliams $1,005,000; Larry Parrish $860,000; Griffey $750,000; Sundberg $650,000; Trevino $562,500; McClure $500,000; Morrison $427,500; Buckner $400,000; Bosley $400,000; Balboni $350,000; Cerone $300,000; Royster $275,000.

title: Senate to Study Buyouts
description: The Senate Finance Committee today announced three days of hearings on leveraged buyouts and the general increase in corporate debt.

title: Woman Charges Tyson With Assault
description: Detectives in Manhattan are investigating a complaint filed against Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, by a 24-year-old woman who charged the boxer harassed and assaulted her early Saturday morning at Bentley's Disco, 25 East 40th Street.

title: Contras in Post-Reagan Era: Are They a Thing of the Past?
description: Seven years after Nicaraguan exiles and the Central Intelligence Agency began fighting to overthrow Sandinista rule, the contra war is at a low ebb, and it is not clear whether and how the Bush administration can revive it.

title: Executive of Ski Maker To Head Diversification
description: Rossignol S.A., the world's top manufacturer of alpine skis, has named Jean-Marc Forneri, 29, to the No. 2 position of managing director.

title: Marino's 4 Scoring Passes Spark Dolphins
description: Dan Marino passed for 404 yards, including a 46-yard bomb to Fred Banks in the final minute that set up the winning touchdown, as Miami ended a five-game losing streak by beating Cleveland, 38-31, tonight.

title: Jets' Door Revolves; O'Brien Enters
description: After being benched for four weeks, Ken O'Brien has been called back to start at quarterback for the Jets next Sunday against the Giants.

title: Lewis R. Stewart, Dentist, 90
description: Lewis R. Stewart, a former dentist whose patients included President Herbert Hoover and Supreme Court Justice John Harlan, died of a heart attack Dec. 2 at his home in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 90 years old.

title: Genentech Set to Take $25 Million Charge
description: Continuing to suffer from lower than expected sales of its key product, Genentech Inc. said today that it would take a $25 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter because of excess inventory.

title: P.L.O. Is Urged to Go Easy in Geneva
description: European countries are pressing the Palestine Liberation Organization and its Arab allies to moderate plans to seek United Nations recognition of an independent Palestinian state, diplomats said today.

title: Magna International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Earl Dodge Osborn Is Dead at 95; Founded Aircraft Manufacturer
description: Earl Dodge Osborn, founder and director emeritus of the EDO Corporation, an aircraft manufacturer in College Point, Queens, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 95 years old.

title: The Newest In Place
description: The place to be seen at the State Department these days is not the well-appointed diplomatic dining room, but the lowly, ground-floor cafeteria, which boasts an unglamorous view of a concrete courtyard.

title: Labatt, John Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Japan Surprised as Trade Surplus Soars
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus soared a larger-than-expected 37.9 percent in November from a year earlier, and the nation's surplus with the United States has begun to widen again for the first time since December 1987, Japanese officials said today.

title: Boston Five Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an addition to loan loss reserves of $5.2 million and a gain of $3.2 million from the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. participating preferred stock. c-Net income d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,500,000.

title: Iowa Student Loan Offering
description: The Iowa Student Loan Liquidity Corporation is tentatively offering $67.3 million of student loan revenue bonds through underwriters led by the Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation.

title: Steel Output Declines
description: Steel production fell to 1.814 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 2.4 percent from the previous week's 1.858 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 84.6 percent of capacity during the week, down from 86.7 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 93.873 million net tons, up 13.7 percent from the 82.547 million net tons in the previous year. Production so far this year has used 88.9 percent of capacity, up from 78.1 percent a year earlier.

title: Gallbladder Operation Performed on Brennan
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court underwent gallbladder surgery today and was reported to be in satisfactory condition.

title: Careers; Continuing Education For Farmers
description: DECLINING asset values and commodity prices in recent years have put many farmers in a financial bind, so much so that two years ago the Farm Credit Corporation began an educational program for farmers called ''Business Management in Agriculture.''

title: Difficulties Reported In Deploying Satellite
description: THE solar panels on the secret spy satellite launched by the shuttle Atlantis failed to swing open the first time ground controllers commanded them to, and Air Force officials briefly feared the mission might fail, an industry magazine has reported.

title: Population and Prosperity Often Grow Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; 2 Views of New York, Old and New, Both Skewed
