description: Ms. Faux Pas A Non Guide to Glitterati Manners By Joan Kron Illustrated by Michael Witte. 86 pages. Parvenu Press. $19.88. Christopher Morley's New York By Christopher Morley Illustrated by Walter Jack Duncan. 379 pages. Fordham University Press. $19.95.

title: Mexico Sets End To Controls
description: In his first major economic policy decision since taking office Dec. 1, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico announced tonight that he is ending the freeze on wages, prices and the exchange rate that has been in effect here for the last year.

title: Democrats Dare Not Deny Jackson
description: LEAD: The presence of the Rev.

title: TREASURE HUNTER WINS RIGHT TO SHIP
description: The treasure hunter excavating the only pirate wreck known to have been found in the Western Hemisphere has complete title to the wreck and all objects he retrieves, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: Nagendra Singh, Judge At the World Court, 74
description: Judge Nagendra Singh of the International Court of Justice died Sunday of a heart attack, a court spokesman said. He was 74 years old. Judge Singh, an Indian, joined the World Court in 1973 and was its presiding judge between 1985 and February 1988. The court, based in The Hague, was set up by the United Nations in 1946 to settle disputes among states.

title: Doctors Implant Frozen Fetal Cells
description: Doctors at the Yale medical school have implanted fetal cells in the brain of a woman with Parkinson's disease after first freezing the cells and testing their viability. Researchers say that the additional steps could improve the effectiveness of the experimental treatment.

title: Indians Confer With President And Top Aides
description: President Reagan, who drew criticism after saying at the Moscow summit meeting in the late spring that the United States Government had ''humored'' American Indians by permitting them to live on reservations, met today with 16 Indians at the White House.

title: Business and Health; Acknowledging Substance Abuse
description: AFTER years of staying aloof when drugs and alcohol abuse were being debated, many senior executives have been increasingly willing to acknowledge major problems with substance abuse in their organizations.

title: A Cancer Crusade Prompts Second Thoughts
description: THE philanthropist Armand Hammer's ambitious plan to raise a billion dollars for cancer research is provoking a mixed response among some leading health officials, lawmakers and cancer researchers.

title: Iran Cuts Carpet Prices
description: Iran cut the price of new hand-woven carpets by 30 percent Sunday in an attempt to increase exports and reduce smuggling, Teheran television reported. The television, monitored in Nicosia, said the decision had been taken by an official committee that sets the price of exports. A customs report in November said Iran's exports of non-oil goods, including carpets, fell by a quarter, to $399 million, in the first half of the Iranian fiscal year that began March 21, compared with the comparable period in 1987.

title: Baseball Salaries Are Reaching The Upper Deck
description: The number of players earning $2 million or more doubled in the past year, according to a study of major league salaries for 1988.

title: Father Kills Children, Then Takes Own Life
description: A father shot and killed his two young children over the weekend before turning the gun on himself and taking his own life, the police said yesterday.

title: Trak Auto Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S., Trying to Protect Owl, To Limit Northwest Logging
description: The National Forest Service formally announced today that it would bar logging in certain parts of national forests in Oregon and Washington to expand protection for the spotted owl.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Shifts Stance On School Bill
description: Eliminating a major obstacle to creating a new school-construction agency for New York City, the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. chapter told state officials today that it would no longer oppose the bill.

title: No Flash, Just Success: Honors for 6 Who Help People
description: In New York, where success is often equal parts hyperbole and hustle, six city employees are being honored for getting great things done, quietly.

title: Polyplastex United Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales represent net sales. The company said results of operations are unaudited interim figures based, in part, on estimates and may be affected by year-end adjustments.

title: Alone in the Crowd
description: Stephen Lowey was the odd man in at a recent orientation program for spouses of newly elected members of Congress. Mr. Lowey, the husband of Nita M. Lowey, a Democratic Congresswoman-elect from Westchester County, N.Y., joined 23 wives of newly elected legislators at get-acquainted sessions arranged by the Congressional Club, a group for spouses of members of Congress.

title: Giants' Recipe for Playoffs: A Victory or a Tie on Sunday
description: It can be feast or famine or maybe just fast food for the Giants.

title: Michigan (9-0) Cruises Past Eastern Michigan
description: Second-ranked Michigan won its ninth consecutive game as Sean Higgins scored 18 points tonight to lead the Wolverines to an 80-57 victory over Eastern Michigan.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Randy Bush, outfielder, accepted salary arbitration offer. Signed Roy Smith and Gary Wayne, pitchers, to one-year contracts. COLLEGES TEXAS A&M - Announced the resignation of Jackie Sherrill, head football coach and athletic director. Named John David Crow athletic director and R. C. Slocum head football coach. FOOTBALL PHOENIX (NFC) - Signed Mark McDonald, guard. HOCKEY DEVILS (NHL) - Acquired Tommy Albelin, defenseman, from the Quebec Nordiques for future considerations. RANGERS (NHL) - Traded Igor Liba, right wing; Todd Elik, center, and Michael Boyce, forward, to Los Angeles for Dean Kennedy and Denis Larocque, defenseman.

title: 3 Die as Police Cars Collide
description: Two police cars racing to a call collided behind a downtown police station today, killing three officers and injuring a fourth, the authorities said. None of the officers were identified. The four were responding to a call for backup assistance when their cruisers collided at 3:45 A.M. behind the Central Division police station.

title: Hickok Electrical Instrument Co reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $374,000 for the latest year and $203,000 for 1987.

title: Even Safer Reactors Imperil Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Bioplasty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $89,860 from discontinued operations.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does the Earth tilt approximately 23 degrees on its axis?

title: Dorothy Jordan, 82; Entered Movies in '29
description: Dorothy Jordan, a movie actress who began a short and successful career in talking pictures in 1929, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 82 years old and lived in Coronado, Calif.

title: Job Losses Put at 10 Million
description: Despite the longest peacetime economic expansion in the nation's history, nearly 10 million Americans lost their jobs to plant closings and layoffs from 1983 to 1988, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

title: Old West's Centennial Effort: Hail Indians (and Custer, Too)
description: As six Western states prepare to celebrate their centennials in 1989 and 1990, official historians are having much more trouble telling the story of how the West was won than they did the first time around.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The commercial banking industry reported a record $5.9 billion in third-quarter profits. But the F.D.I.C.'s chairman warned that the volume of bad loans had increased and that bank involvement in leveraged buyouts should be carefully monitored. [ Page D1. ] Industry experts said the Robert M. Bass Group had agreed to a significant change in the terms of its deal for the nation's largest insolvent savings and loan. [ D22. ] Natural gas producers in the West and Southwest objected to a proposal permitting the construction of pipelines from Canada to Long Island and Massachusetts, arguing that gas producers in Canada would have an unfair pricing advantage. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan's merchandise trade surplus soared 37.9 percent in November from a year earlier, and its surplus with the U.S. has begun to widen for the first time since December 1987. Japan's Ministry of Finance now fears new trade tensions. [ D1. ] Mexico's new President will lift the freeze on wages, prices and exchange rates put in place a year ago. Instead, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari will begin a slow, steady devaluation of the peso and allow ''moderate adjustments in wages.'' [ D7. ] Seven Latin nations drafted proposals on reducing their debt. [ D7. ] The Soviet Union's plans to devalue the ruble by 50 percent over two years for trading purposes, announced on Friday, should be welcomed as a first step toward making the country's currency convertible, several experts said. [ D6. ] Taiwan is fearful that the U.S. will press for a higher value for the New Taiwan dollar. That could sharply reduce exports. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Pillsbury's shares surged as investors responded to a higher offer for the company and as it became increasingly likely that Pillsbury would yield to Grand Metropolitan. With more than 3.1 million shares trading, the stock gained $3.875, to $62.125. [ D1. ] Blackstone Group has tightened its link with Nikko Securities, the third-largest securities firm in Japan. Nikko has invested $100 million in Blackstone, giving it a 20 percent share. [ D1. ] Two corporate raiders hold a 12.5 percent stake in Pennwalt, the chemical company, and said they would pay stockholders $100 a share, or $698 million, for the rest of the company. [ D5. ] G.M. will make profit-sharing payments of an average of $200 to 450,000 salaried and hourly workers. The payments will be the first by G.M. since 1985. [ D5. ] Church's Fried Chicken began closing 112 of its 1,096 fast-food outlets and will write off up to $27 million. [ D4. ] Richard B. Stolley will become editorial director of Time Inc.'s 22 magazines, succeeding Ray Cave. [ D21. ] MARKETS The stock market failed to hold early gains as a late selloff left the Dow Jones industrial average with a small loss. The Dow ended down 3.91 points at 2,139.58. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light trading ahead of economic reports. [ D14. ] The dollar strengthened marginally in extremely slow trading. [ D17. ] Record cold temperatures in the Northeast pushed crude oil prices above $16 a barrel for the first time since August. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Many senior executives are increasingly willing to acknowledge major problems with substance abuse in their organizations, and a number of recent surveys show that the problems are serious. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Third-world loans are weak in the secondary market, but the stocks of banks that hold such loans are strong. Market Place. [ D8. ] Advertiser spending will not rise as quickly next year, said Robert E. Coen of McCann Erickson. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: The Earthquake, Everywhere
description: ''At the beginning, there was nothing - no cranes, no cutting gear, no lights, nothing . . . just 60 people standing up there and yelling at each other.'' The volunteer rescue worker was describing the scene in Leninakan, one of the cities ravaged by last week's earthquake, but he might have been talking about sudden disaster anywhere.

title: Wellington Leisure Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
It's Time to Get Serious About Holiday Fun
description: The party clothes women are shopping for this holiday season differ dramatically from the short, puffy, frilly confections they scooped up last year. Retailers say that, though the range of styles is fairly extensive, two types are selling particularly well: severely tailored suits with either skirts or trousers, and soft chiffon dresses, often in glowing colors.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Canadiens 3, Bruins 1: Guy Carbonneau set up goals by Bob Gainey and Larry Robinson as the Canadiens extended their unbeaten streak to nine games last night in Montreal. The Canadiens, who moved to 12 points ahead of Boston atop the Adams Division, have won six and tied three in the streak. Shayne Corson was the other Montreal scorer.(AP) Flames 4, Maple Leafs 4: Joel Otto's eighth goal of the season with 2 minutes 45 seconds remaining in the third period lifted Calgary into a tie with Toronto, which ended a six-game losing streak on home ice. Colin Patterson snapped a wrist shot off a faceoff and Otto tipped the puck during its flight. Al Secord scored two goals and Derek Laxdal and Dave Reid had one each for Toronto. (AP) HORSE RACING Lyphard's Ridge Surges: Lyphard's Ridge, ridden by Eddie Maple, stalked pace-setting Dr. Carrington in the stretch and outlasted him for a 1 1/2-length victory in the $41,000 Ancient Title Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Dr. Carrington finished second in the field of seven. Lyphard's Ridge covered the mile and one-sixteenth on the fast track in 1:43 3/5 for his first victory in four starts this year. He returned $6.60 for $2 to win.(AP) N.B.A. Jazz 110, Heat 94: Karl Malone scored 33 points, including 13 consecutive free throws, and Utah, playing at home, extended Miami's losing streak to 17 games.(AP)

title: AEP Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Anne Seymour, 79, Stage Actress Known for Work in Radio Drama
description: Anne Seymour, a stage, film and television actress who also performed in more than 5,000 radio programs, died of respiratory failure Thursday at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles. She was 79 years old and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: Chevron to Sell Irving Oil Stake
description: Chevron said yesterday that it would take a write-down of more than $100 million in the fourth quarter on the sale of its 48.9 percent interest in Irving Oil Ltd. of St. John, New Brunswick, a refining and marketing company.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Anthony Provanzano, 71, Ex-Teamster Chief, Dies
description: Anthony Provenzano, a reported organized-crime leader who was ousted a decade ago as the teamsters' boss of northern New Jersey, died of a heart attack yesterday in a hospital near a prison in Lompoc, Calif., where he was serving 20 years for racketeering. He was 71 years old.

title: Shift at Control Data Spurs a Resignation
description: The Control Data Corporation yesterday named a new president and vice chairman and announced that another top executive would leave in a management realignment.

title: Topics of The Times; Lost Literary Refuge
description: News that Scribner Book Store will close its doors forever next month casts a pall over Fifth Avenue's holiday glow. For 75 years, Scribner's at 48th Street has been home to book lovers, browsers and all who seek a moment's refuge from the roar of midtown Manhattan.

title: Noise Is Called a Threat to Sea Life
description: NOISE generated by human activity is seriously endangering fish and such oceanic mammals as seals and whales, according to Arthur A. Myrberg Jr., a marine biologist at the University of Miami.

title: F.B.I. Questions Cuban Exile After a Hijacking Effort Fails
description: A Cuban exile who tried to hijack a commercial airliner to Cuba was questioned today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seeking to learn his motive, officials said.

title: Erwin S. Gelsey Dead; Screenwriter Was 88
description: Erwin S. Gelsey, a prominent Hollywood screenwriter whose credits included ''Flying Down to Rio,'' the 1933 hit musical that starred Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, died yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Chip Ratio Improves
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded slightly after a seven-month slide, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported decreased shipments but had a small increase in orders, a trade group reported today.

title: Sharing a Gift
description: Recently, the group Senate Wives gave Barbara Bush a farewell and thank-you lunch for presiding for eight years at the group's functions. In appreciation, they presented her with an $8,000 watch from Tiffany's.

title: Kustom Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $55,000. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $62,000 and $114,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $640,000 for both periods and the year included a tax credit of $106,000. d-Net loss

title: Rangers Can't Halt Kings' Barrage
description: The Rangers were a crumpled lot after being whisked to and fro across their own rink last night by the Los Angeles Kings.

title: 50-Off Stores Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $137,000 and $200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a tax credit of $9,000. In the year-ago 9-months preferred dividend requirements exceeded both operating and final income figures.

title: Cucci Will Announce Plans for Re-election
description: Mayor Anthony R. Cucci, who survived a train wreck Dec. 1 in Peru that killed his wife, will seek a second four-year term, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: Packers Only Add to the Playoff Confusion
description: Let's see . . . .

title: Review/Television; A 'Caller' Episode, On AIDS
description: In one crucial sense, tonight's debated episode of ''Midnight Caller'' -on NBC at 10 - is decidedly a step in the right direction. Dealing with AIDS, the program at least ventures into the homosexual community that was hit first and, until recently, hardest by the disease. With one or two exceptions, most television dramas on the subject convey the impression that AIDS is something children pick up through tainted blood transfusion.

title: Nussbaum Testifies to Not Hearing Noise
description: Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday that she heard nothing on the night the prosecution says Joel B. Steinberg struck the blows that killed Lisa Steinberg four days later.

title: Population and Prosperity Often Grow Together; Cutting Back
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH IS REBUFFED ON MOST DEMANDS
description: The Federal judge in the Iran-contra case today rejected the bulk of Oliver L. North's demand to use 30,000 pages of secret documents as evidence in his defense, accusing Mr. North of making the request in a calculated effort to ''frustrate the prosecution.''

title: Obsessive Disorder: Secret Toll Is Found
description: WHEN James was 3 years old, he began a strange habit: whenever he crossed the street, he would walk in circles around the manhole covers. In kindergarten, he would sit for hours drawing circles on pieces of paper. At the age of 8, he would stand up and sit down 17 times before finally sitting in a chair, and would go back and forth through a door 17 times before finally exiting.

title: Daimler-Benz Negotiations
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it might back out of a plan to buy a stake in the state-owned aerospace group Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. because of the Government's financial demands.

title: Chess
description: The 19th year of the Computer Chess Championships of the Association for Computing Machinery saw a tie for first place between Deep Thought, a program by Feng-Hsuing Hsu, a graduate student at Carnegie-Mellon Institute, and Fidelity Chess Challenger X, a speeded-up version of the commercially available program.

title: Pay-O-Matic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents total operating revenue.

title: Congress Street Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After gains from the sale of real estate of $66,000. c-Net loss and after a gain on the sale of real estate of $81,000. d-After gains of $185,000 on real estate sales. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect adoption of FASB No. 96 for income taxes. The company said it had negative revenue for the year-ago quarter of $1,974,000, attributable to the company's decision to writeoff its investment in ECNP, a partnership that owned 50 percent of the Radisson Walthall Hotel, to record its pro rata amount of a loan that each partner guaranteed and the company's equity in the Parkway Cos.' loss for the quarter ended June 30, 1987.

title: Cold Temperatures Push Crude Oil Prices Above $16
description: Record cold temperatures in the Northeast yesterday pushed crude oil prices above $16 a barrel for the first time since August.

title: Swiss, as Usual, Are Prepared
description: In preparation for Yasir Arafat's visit on Tuesday, Geneva officials have turned the European headquarters of the United Nations from a quiet and bucolic workplace for 3,000 international civil servants to an impenetrable stronghold.

title: Epitaph for a Cycle
description: Say this for Ronald Reagan, as his eight years in the White House near their end: He was one of the few Presidents to take office with a definite program, then to achieve most of it.

title: Novel Source for an Expensive Sugar
description: AGRICULTURAL scientists have found bacteria in the digestive tracts of cattle that make a nonnutritive sugar that is extremely expensive to produce artificially. The sugar was previously not thought to occur in nature at all.

title: Canadian Trade-Pact Foes Brace for Fight
description: Opposition leaders gathered for the formal opening of Parliament vowed today to fight the Government's plan to win speedy parliamentary approval of Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States. Their stand appeared to set up a bruising parliamentary battle over the agreement, which was the focus of last month's general election.

title: Market Place; A Dual Perception Of 3d-World Debt
description: IN Mexico the new President says his nation must get debt relief. Yesterday the finance ministers of seven Latin American nations said reducing their debt burden was ''a matter of urgency.''

title: Transition Watch; A Citizenship Test For Job Applicants
description: If you are the sort who sometimes sits out elections, for reasons of political principle or personal convenience, don't bother applying for a job in the Bush administration.

title: Fighter Too Heavy
description: Tomas Molinares of Colombia, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, has renounced his title and does not intend to go through with his scheduled defense Feb. 4 in Las Vegas, Nev., against Mark Breland, the Bogota daily El Tiemp reported yesterday. Molinares was quoted as saying he has had trouble keeping his weight down.(AP)

title: 36 Are Killed as Commuter Trains Crash in London
description: A crowded commuter train tore into the back of one stopped ahead of it in south London this morning, killing at least 36 people, the authorities said. The wreckage was then struck by an empty train coming the other way.

title: Belgian Giant Expects a Loss
description: Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest holding company, today forecast a loss of 500 million to 2 billion Belgian francs - $13.5 million to $54 million - this year because of restructuring costs.

title: Nine Quit German Jewish Panel Over Scandal
description: Nearly half the directors of the Central Council of Jews in Germany have resigned amid continuing repercussions from the reported embezzlement of millions in reparations by the council's president, who died in January.

title: Church's Is Closing 112 Outlets
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said today that it had begun closing 112 of its 1,096 company-owned fast-food outlets and would write off between $22 million and $27 million in the 1988 fiscal year as a result of shutting these unprofitable stores. The stores being closed are in 20 states and lost a total of $7.4 million in the last 12 months, a company spokesman said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Gorbachev declared there are no political prisoners anymore.

title: SOVIET PRESS CALLS THE RESCUE EFFORT BUNGLED AND INEPT
description: As hope faded for victims still trapped under the debris of last week's earthquake in Armenia, Soviet newspapers and television asserted today that rescue efforts were hampered by poor preparedness and disorganization.

title: Rules on Drinking Water Not Enforced, Study Says
description: The Federal and state governments are failing to enforce health standards for drinking water used by hotels, schools and others not linked to municipal water systems, according to an internal Government report made available today.

title: No Bail for Suspect In Fatal Shooting
description: A retired sanitation worker was ordered held without bail yesterday on charges of killing a man and wounding two police officers in a 3 1/2-hour standoff Sunday at a rooming house.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation plans to sell $150 million of floating-rate extendible notes with interest to Dec. 20, 1990, accruing at a rate of about 80-hundredths of a percentage point more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.The exentible notes mature on Dec. 20, 1992, with an initial maturity of two years. Beginning on Dec. 20, 1990, investors will have the option to put the notes back to the company at a price of par. Security Pacific said that it would also have the option to call the notes.

title: Hallmark Cards Picks Leo Burnett
description: Hallmark Cards, which has bounced from agency to agency since leaving Foote, Cone & Belding in 1982, has landed at the Leo Burnett Company. The account is reportedly worth $35 million to $40 million in annual billings.

title: Atlantic Express Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Murray Chris-Craft Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Murray Chris-Craft boat companies yesterday filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. The filing in a Federal court in Tampa was caused by ''severe managerial and operational inefficiencies and problems inherited by the previous management,'' the company said in a statement.

title: Forests for Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Devalue Ruble Is Given Qualified Praise
description: The Soviet Union's plans to devalue the ruble by 50 percent during the next two years for trade purposes, announced on Friday, should be welcomed as a first step toward making the country's currency convertible, several economists, analysts and executives said yesterday.

title: Davis Water & Waste Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New Plan Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a $44,000 loss on the sale of securities and property. c-Included a $176,000 gain on the sale of securities and property.

title: NCF Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a $2,800,000 gain from sales of servicing rights.

title: Loudon S. Wainwright, Columnist, Dead at 63
description: Loudon Snowden Wainwright, a longtime columnist for Life magazine, a former assistant managing editor of Life and the author of ''The Great American Magazine,'' a history of Life, died of colon cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Joseph Reichler, 73, Authority on Baseball
description: Joseph Lawrence Reichler, a member of the sportswriters section of the Baseball Hall of Fame since 1980 and the editor of ''The Baseball Encyclopedia,'' died of cancer yesterday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: Air Forces Temporarily Halt Some Flights Over Germany
description: The air forces of the United States, West Germany, Britain and Canada today suspended fighter-aircraft training in West Germany until Jan. 2, the Defense Department announced.

title: Varity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $9.4 million and $23.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included writeoffs of investment in Massey Combines Corp. of $8.7 million and $17.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss The latest periods also included tax provisions of $9.9 million for the quarter and $24.2 million for the 9 months. The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Government Action Urged to Ease Nurse Shortage
description: A Federal commission today urged Government intervention to ease a ''pervasive'' shortage of registered nurses that has led to the temporary closing of hospital emergency rooms and intensive care units and to the canceling of elective surgery.

title: Pennwalt Is Offered $100 a Share
description: After six months of hostile takeover maneuvers, two corporate raiders said yesterday that they owned a million shares of the Pennwalt Corporation, or 12.5 percent, and would pay stockholders $100 a share, or $698 million, for the rest of the chemical company, based in Philadelphia.

title: Justices Uphold N.C.A.A.'s Right To Demand Suspension of Coach
description: The Supreme Court today lifted a legal cloud from the National Collegiate Athletic Association's control of college sports. It ruled that the N.C.A.A. did not violate Jerry Tarkanian's constitutional rights when it ordered the University of Nevada-Las Vegas to suspend him from his job as basketball coach for recruiting violations.

title: Sharpton's Landlord Moves to Evict Him
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's landlord, who successfully sued him for nonpayment of rent in June, began eviction proceedings against him yesterday, contending that Mr. Sharpton was again in arrears.

title: Eventual Succession Is Seen In Changes at Alco Standard
description: The Alco Standard Corporation, a company that grew big by acquiring smaller family businesses, yesterday named Richard C. Gozon president, putting him in line for the top post.

title: KEY RATES
Chicago Journal; Troupe Whose Stage Is the World of Gangs
description: The students at the high school assembly in suburban Hillside relished the skit on stage: two young men wearing gang colors jeering at another youth who wanted to read a poem he had written.

title: Donald Schwartz, 58, Lawyer and Professor
description: Donald E. Schwartz, a lawyer, author and professor of corporate and securities law at Georgetown University, died of cancer Saturday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 58 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Spectra Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dorothy de Rothschild, 93, Supporter of Israel
description: Dorothy de Rothschild, a philanthropist, died Saturday at her home in London after a brief illness. She was 93 years old.

title: Highland Superstores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $5,685,000.

title: Aid Pours In For Victims In a Far Land
description: Stamping his feet from the cold, Michael Vettis pushed through the door of the Armenian community center here and pulled $10 from his wallet, a donation, he said, to aid earthquake victims in Soviet Armenia.

title: G.M. to Correct Slow Rebates
description: Some buyers of trucks made by the General Motors Corporation have waited up to six months for rebates because of problems with the company that is administering the rebate program, G.M. said today.

title: An Interfaith Campaign To Remember the Needy
description: ''For God's sake, do something'' is the theme of a new interfaith advertising effort to raise awareness of homelessness, hunger and child abuse in the United States. Endorsing it are Catholic Charities, the Council of Jewish Federations and Lutheran Social Services. Print ads, as well as television and radio spots featuring voice-overs by the actor Martin Sheen, are scheduled to begin appearing in early January.

title: Harvey Group Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-After tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $375,000 for the 39 weeks. c-Net loss and after a tax charge of $38,000. d-After a tax credit of $111,000.

title: Gwynn Re-signs
description: Tony Gwynn, a three-time National League batting champion, signed a contract extension yesterday with the San Diego Padres that will pay him $2 million in 1991. The deal also includes an option for 1992 that would pay $2 million. Gwynn, 28, was signed through the 1989 and 1990 seasons at $1 million a year before agreeing to the extension. According to Gwynn, the club holds the option for the 1992 season but must decide whether it would exercise it by the end of the 1990 season. There is a $200,000 buyout clause. Gwynn won his third batting title in 1988.(AP)

title: U.S. Says Myerson Tried to Buy Justice
description: A Federal prosecutor yesterday portrayed Bess Myerson as a corrupt official who preyed on the weakness of former Justice Hortense W. Gabel to try to help Ms. Myerson's companion, Carl A. Capasso, in his bitter divorce.

title: Skiing Electrons On a Fast Path
description: In developing electronic components, speed is all. Supercomputers get much of their power from the speed with which their circuits can switch on and off. Bipolar transistors, the staple of high-speed elecronic systems, normally can switch on and off about 12 billion times a second.

title: Sports Peopls; 3 Vikings Arrested
description: The rash of arrests of Minnesota Viking players, mainly on charges involving intoxication, continued early yesterday when Anthony Carter, Carl Lee and Darryl Harris were arrested after 1 A.M. following an altercation outside a nightclub in Minneapolis, described by the police as ''a continuing offense observed by officers.'' Also arrested was Lee's wife, Donna, on a disorderly conduct charge. The same offense was laid to her husband, a defensive back, and Carter, a wide receiver. Harris, a running back, was charged with obstructing the legal process. (AP)

title: Thieves of 3 van Goghs Elude the Dutch Police
description: The police searched with dogs and helicopters today but found no clues to the theft of three works by Vincent van Gogh, including a version of his famous ''Potato Eaters.''

title: No Fuddy-Duddies
description: To The Living Section:

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Medford, Ore.
description: LEAD: FOR years now in Medford, Ore., Jane Watson Hopping has been the person to telephone for advice when jams are not setting or pickles are not pickling quite right. She is known locally as the ''pioneer lady'' (a sobriquet courtesy of local schoolchildren), for all her arcane knowledge of how things were done on the farm and in the kitchen before electricity and processed food.

title: New Schools? See Senator Anderson
description: After weeks of negotiations, there's a wonderful breakthrough: the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. has finally agreed to support legislation creating a school construction agency for New York City schools. Will the breakthrough mean anything? That's in the hands of the Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson.

title: F.C.C.'s Rule on Ownership Is Relaxed but Not Dropped
description: The Federal Communications Commission plans to examine on a ''case-by-case basis'' requests to waive its rule prohibiting direct ownership, operation or control of both a radio station and a television station in the same market.

title: Adele Scott Saul, Trustee, 101
description: Adele Scott Saul, the first woman in Philadelphia to run for Congress, died Dec. 6 at her former home in Rose Valley, Pa. She was 101 years old and lived in Key West, Fla.

title: New Atlantic Cable Makes More Calls Possible
description: The first fiber-optic telephone cable across the Atlantic goes into service today, vastly increasing the number of calls that can be placed to Europe at one time.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Peace on Earth. . .
description: . . .and a rocket launcher in a pear tree.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Sorry, No Number
description: A Fairfield, Conn., company that cranks out population data reports that one in four Americans has an unlisted phone. What's more, the phenomenon is spreading.

title: Parliamentary System Better for Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Nu-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $4,241,000 from purchase of debentures. c-Net loss

title: Barkley Ejected as Bucks Defeat 76ers, 109-91
description: Jack Sikma scored 26 points and Ricky Pierce added 19 tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 109-91.

title: FORMER U.S. AIDE TELLS OF LAROUCHE
description: A onetime aide to William P. Clark, the former national security adviser, testified today that he recalled meeting with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. or his supporters on numerous occasions in 1982 and 1983 to discuss issues they considered to be of national importance.

title: Kitchen Bookshelf; Year of the Italians Produces Some Stars
description: SUDDENLY, around the beginning of last summer, for reasons that were never quite clear, 1988 became the year of the Italians. Cookbook publishers responded enthusiastically (where, one wonders, were all those manuscripts hiding?), if uncritically. The result is the current class of books - an uneven group with a few obvious stars and a number of disappointments.

title: Federated Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income Sales represent net sales, which included leased department sales. In reporting these results on a comparable division basis, the company restated last year's operations to include the five retained department store divisions: Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's, Burdines, Lazarus, and Rich's, including Goldsmith's.

title: E.P.A. Finds Pesticides in Water of 38 States
description: Underground water has been contaminated by pesticides in parts of at least 38 states, the Environmental Protection Agency said today In an interim report noting that many areas remain to be sampled, the E.P.A. said the pollution was caused in 26 states by 46 different pesticides used on farms. It said 28 additional chemicals, from unknown sources, were sources in the 12 other states.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LETTER from a dog walker:

title: London Art Dealer Is Criticized For Museum Accord Gone Sour
description: A venerable London art dealer has been widely criticized in international art circles for acquiring a valuable German Renaissance painting that Britain's National Gallery had commissioned it to buy and for subsequently rejecting the museum's offer for the work.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Nussbaum says She Lied to Help Steinberg
description: Hedda Nussbaum testified yesterday that she lied to the police last year about Lisa Steinberg's injuries to provide a ''cover story'' for Joel B. Steinberg, her former lover who is charged with beating to death the 6-year-old child they raised.

title: Excerpts From Arafat's Address to General Assembly Offering Peace Plan
description: Following are excerpts from the address today by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, to the United Nations General Assembly. The text, translated from the Arabic, was provided by the P.L.O.

title: For Those Who Need Something to Talk To?
description: When Lyn Conlan's personal problems began interfering with her job at the U.S.T. corporate headquarters here, she met with the newest therapist in the company's employee assistance program: a computer nicknamed Dr. Bob.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: The Gitane Sound

title: Max Block, 86, Editor And an Accountant
description: Max Block, a nationally recognized accountant and former managing editor of The CPA Journal, died of heart failure Monday at the Del Rey Beach Community Hospital in Florida. He was 86 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: PRESIDENT BITTER ABOUT THE DEFICIT
description: Summing up the domestic achievements of his Administration, President Reagan today angrily blamed an ''iron triangle'' of Congressmen, lobbyists and journalists for the huge deficits that accumulated in his Presidency.

title: Who Uses the Shelters And Some of the Whys
description: As with the human beings they represent, statistics trying to pinpoint who is homeless and why are difficult to pin down and often tricky to analyze.

title: November Retail Sales Rose by a Strong 1.1%
description: Retail sales posted a strong gain for the second consecutive month, the Government said today.

title: Sports People; Dooley to Step Down
description: Vince Dooley will reportedly step down as football coach at Georgia but will remain as athletic director for an unspecified period. The Athens Daily News, in today's issue, said the 56-year-old Dooley, who has coached at Georgia for 25 seasons and has 200 victories, was expected to tell his players of his decision at a team meeting today and would hold a news conference later to make it public. But the sports-information director, Claude Felton said there had not been a Dooley news conference scheduled for today. The Marietta Daily Journal, in today's issue, cited unidentified sources as saying George Haffner, the offensive coordinator, will be named interim coach through the spring and will be considered as permanent coach. The team reconvenes today in preparation for its game against Michigan State in the Gator Bowl Jan. 1. (AP)

title: Construction Site Yields 1860's Chinese Artifacts
description: At a bank construction site in downtown San Francisco, archeologists and art historians today displayed thousands of newfound artifacts from a Gold Rush settlement in Chinatown.

title: REHEARING SOUGHT ON CURB ON MILITIA
description: A Federal appeals court's ruling that the Government cannot send National Guard units outside the country without the consent of their governors is being challenged by the Defense Department.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Position Filled By Ad Council
description: Robert D. Schultz will be supervising the Advertising Council's 36 national public-service campaigns. Mr. Schultz, 33, will hold the new post of vice president of campaign administration at the nonprofit organization, which creates advertising programs on social issues.

title: MAI Basic's Bid In Legal Snag
description: A Federal judge issued an injunction blocking MAI Basic Four Inc.'s hostile $970 million bid for Prime Computer Inc. but immediately suspended the order pending an appeal. After oral arguments United States District Judge A. David Mazzone said last Friday that he would issue the injunction and then stay it, and he detailed his reasoning today in the written order.

title: Change in Public Broadcasting Sought
description: The Working Group for Public Broadcasting yesterday announced a campaign to replace the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which distributes Government money through the Public Broadcasting Service, with an independent body with no ties to Congress or the Administration.

title: Five-Minute AIDS Test Is Approved by F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a test for antibodies to the AIDS virus that takes only five minutes and can be performed without sophisticated equipment.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Capitals 4, Nordiques 1: Mike Gartner and Bengt Gustafsson each had a goal and an assist last night as the visiting Capitals moved into a three-way tie for first place in the Patrick Division. The Capitals have won 10 and tied 3 of their last 15 games to draw even with the Rangers and Pittsburgh at 34 points. Gartner and Gustafsson both scored their eighth goals in the first period. Steven Leach and Kelly Miller added second-period scores, while Gaetan Duchesne was the only scorer for Quebec. The Nordiques (10-20-2) have lost eight of their last 11 games and are in last place in the Adams Division. Washington (15-12-4) dominated the first period, outshooting the Nordiques by 14-3 and taking a 2-0 edge. Gartner opened the scoring at 11 minutes 44 seconds when he redirected a ararp-angle shot by Scott Stevens, a defenseman. Gartner had an excellent chance four minutes later, however, he was robbed by Mario Gosselin, the Quebec goaltender, from point-blank range. But the puck came back to Gustafsson, who failed on his first try from the side of the net, then managed to score on his own rebound. ''The big thing with us is that we're playing as a team, and we're not giving the other teams too many chances,'' said Bryan Murray, the Capitals' coach. ''That's what it takes to win.'' (AP) Red Wings 5, North Stars 4: Paul MacLean scored his second goal of the game on a power play with 3:06 left in the third period last night to lead Detroit to a home victory. After Bob Brooke and Bob Probert traded goals midway through the third period, Brooke was penalized for roughing Gerard Gallant at 16:28. A fight between the two ensued and Brooke was assessed an additional two-minute penalty. Steve Yzerman fed a pass behind the Minnesota net to Probert, who slid the puck in front, where MacLean jabbed it past Kari Takko, the Minnesota goaltender, for his 17th goal. The Red Wings then killed a penalty to Jim Pavese to ensure their third straight victory. Minnesota trailed, 2-0, before the game was eight minutes old on goals 1:08 apart by MacLean, also on a power play, and Pavese. But the North Stars rallied on Curt Giles's goal midway through the opening period and Basil McRae's seventh of the season 6:59 into the second to tie it. Detroit reclaimed the lead midway through the period on Dave Barr's 11th goal. The game drew 19,709 fans, marking the 80th straight time the Red Wings have drawn more than 19,000.(AP)

title: XL-Datacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results included a one- time charge of $1.6 million reflecting elimination of investment tax credits.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Circle Publisher Adds Title of President
description: Charles H. Townsend, the publisher of Family Circle, has been promoted to president of the magazine from senior vice president, The New York Times Company Magazine Group announced yesterday. Several other Family Circle executives also received new titles.

title: Rostropovich to Play For Armenian Relief
description: The Russian-born cellist Mstislav Rostropovich will give his first solo recital in Britain in 20 years on Friday at a benefit appearance for the victims of the earthquake in Armenia.

title: First Fidelity Sees Loss and 2 Officers Quit
description: In a stunning reversal at a well-regarded regional bank-holding company, the First Fidelity Bancorporation said last night that it would lose $145 million to $190 million in the current quarter because of bad loans and that its chief executive and a vice chairman had resigned.

title: No French Hens
description: My Christmas shopping took practically no time at all. I did the job at Christmas Hell, a gigantic two-story building containing 273 stores (including four department stores), 5 Santa Clauses, 8 movies and 14 restaurants.

title: Corrections
description: An article from The Associated Press on Monday about the winners of Rhodes scholarships misidentified the college attended by a recipient, Jay C. Rubenstein. It is Carleton College.

title: Pepperidge Farm Faces Penalty
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration today proposed fining Pepperidge Farm Inc. nearly $1.4 million for exposing workers to dangerous working conditions at a plant in Downingtown, Pa.

title: Rooney, Pace Is Disciplined
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers announced yesterday that it had taken disciplinary action against Rooney, Pace Inc. and several individuals at the defunct firm.

title: About New York; Politics, Books, Bogey and Beer: 60 Years at a Bar
description: Simone de Beauvoir, writing in 1948: ''In Bedford Street is the only place in New York where you can read and work through the day, and talk through the night, without arousing curiosity or criticism: Chamby's.''

title: Arafat's Partner In Peace: Moscow
description: LEAD: President-elect George Bush will soon face the critical question of whether Moscow should be a partner in Middle East peacemaking.

title: Inquiry in Syracuse Incident
description: The Onondaga County district attorney's office is investigating a complaint involving Syracuse University athletes who, according to a student, kicked in the front door of his home Sunday morning in an apparent extension of a campus incident that took place late Saturday night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Agency's Conflict: Big vs. Bold
description: No agency signified advertising's emergence from the creatively moribund 1970's more than Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis, whose audacious work for Rolling Stone magazine, the Episcopal Church and others won it the envious recognition of Madison Avenue and enough clients to build its billings to $130 million in only seven years.

title: Books of The Times; Pound's Inexorable Mix Of Politics and Poetry
description: A Serious Character The Life of Ezra Pound By Humphrey Carpenter 1,005 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $40.

title: Skiing Benefits at Eastern Resorts
description: Put the statistics on paper and the Adirondacks, the Green and the White Mountains are small compared with the Rockies. But add up some of the lift-ticket deals offered in the East and then the figures look more impressive.

title: Copper Prices Keep Falling Despite Tight World Supply
description: Despite a tight global supply of copper, prices continued to plunge yesterday.

title: O'Neill Will Seek Increases in Taxes
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill will seek tax increases and cuts in programs to make up for an expected shortfall of $882 million in the Connecticut budget next year, the State Budget Director said yesterday.

title: 14 Accused in Food-Stamp Plot
description: Fourteen people, including eight New York City employees, were accused yesterday of running a $250,000 scheme to traffic in stolen food stamps.

title: Citicorp Paper Rates Up Again
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper rose yesterday for the fifth time in six weeks.

title: The P.L.O.: Only the Music's Better
description: The State Department reacted just right to Yasir Arafat's long-awaited U.N. speech yesterday. The department's statement justifiably praised the P.L.O. chairman for his ''overall tone'' and for ''some movement'' on the details. But it sensibly went on to say that Mr. Arafat still failed to go far enough in accepting Israel's right to exist and renouncing terrorism inside as well as outside Israeli borders. ''These issues must be addressed clearly, squarely, without ambiguity,'' said the Department's spokesman.

title: Food-Vendor Rules to Everybody's Taste Take Awhile to Prepare; No Pedestrian Obstacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'The Sky Is Falling'
description: What the United States Naval Observatory calls one of the most spectacular meteor showers of the year, the Geminids, peaked last night and, if anybody saw anything ''really spectacular,'' the Smithsonian Institution would like to hear about it.

title: Collectors Who Savor Wine Right Down to the Label
description: PLASTIC-COVERED binders containing 40,000 wine labels fill two large bookcases in the home of Burt Wuttken and his wife, Marnie. ''It's better than stamp collecting,'' he said. ''Besides, who ever heard of drinking a letter?''

title: Lazard Moving Money Funds
description: Lazard Freres & Company has agreed to transfer its money market mutual funds with assets of about $1.5 billion to Scudder, Stevens & Clark, Inc., the investment management concern.

title: Hawkins Has No Qualms About Pitching for Yanks
description: Andy Hawkins, the newest Yankee millionaire, made his debut in Yankee Stadium yesterday on a cold and snowy afternoon after six seasons in sunny San Diego. But he said that he was not troubled by the wintry climate that often chills relations between the Yankees and George Steinbrenner in the summertime.

title: Controversy Again as Sherrill Leaves Aggies
description: Jackie Sherrill was hired as the athletic director and football coach at Texas A&M in 1982 amid a barrage of controversy and was given the mission of turning the long-suffering Aggies into winners.

title: Japan Spurs Research and Development
description: To the Editor:

title: Voice Names Publisher
description: Sally J. Cohen, a former investment banker and advertising director, was appointed publisher of The Village Voice yesterday, said David Schneiderman, the former publisher of the paper and the president of Stern Publications Inc., the Voice's parent company.

title: It Wasn't Funny
description: To The Living Section:

title: 2 ISRAELIS KILLED NEAR SETTLEMENT
description: A Palestinian shepherd killed a Jewish settler in the occupied West Bank today and then shot and killed an Israeli soldier with a gun seized from the settler, the army said. The Palestinian was then shot to death by another soldier.

title: Bowne & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Shamir Rejects Arafat 'Double Talk'
description: Apparently speaking on behalf of both major factions in the Israeli Government, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today called Yasir Arafat's offer of peace talks with Israel nothing more than deceptive ''double talk'' intended to ''create an impression of moderation.''

title: Allied Stores Corp reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Included equity in net loss of affiliated companies of $11,729,000 for the quarter and $30,725,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $330 million on the sale of Brooks Brothers. c-Net loss The year-ago periods ended Oct. 3 and were restated. Revenue represents total revenue, including net sales, which included leased department sales, and revenue of real estate operations. The company changed its fiscal year-end, effective Jan. 30, 1988, from a fiscal year ending on the Saturday closest to Dec. 31, to a fiscal year ending on the Saturday closest to Jan. 31. As a result of this change and the disposition of a significant number of operating subsidiaries and real estate properties throughout the fiscal year ended Jan. 2, 1988, as well as the sale of Brooks Brothers on April 29, 1988, the results of operations are generally not comparable between this year and last year.

title: Savings Industry Loss Is Cut to $1.6 Billion
description: Losses at the nation's savings and loan associations moderated significantly in the third quarter, but the industry still recorded a huge deficit of $1.6 billion in the July-to-September period, Federal regulators said today.

title: Morton and Greene Pace 8-0 Seton Hall
description: There are three banners perched in Walsh Gymnasium representing Big East indoor track and field championships by Seton Hall. The banners are tucked in the corner of the gym and are hardly noticeable.

title: Boston U. Aids Those With Learning Disability
description: In what it hopes will become a model program for colleges around the country, Boston University is setting up a special office to help students with learning disabilities who attend its 16 schools and colleges.

title: Marking the Dual Legacy of Robert Moses
description: ''Unfortunately, he will have a double epitaph: 'He was the man who built New York' and 'He was the man who strangled Red Hook and killed substantial parts of the Bronx.' ''

title: Panel Urges Large Pay Increases For Congress and High Officials
description: A Presidential commission recommended today that the salaries of top Federal officials be increased at least 50 percent and that members of Congress give up speaking fees and restrict travel paid for by private interest groups.

title: JAPAN QUAKE AID IS SLOW TO ARRIVE
description: Japan, a world leader in earthquake preparedness, sent its first emergency supplies to Soviet Armenia today, days after most other countries mobilized quake relief efforts.

title: Peters, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: Rep. Bill Nichols, 70; Led Pentagon Inquiry
description: Representative Bill Nichols, Democrat of Alabama, who led a Congressional investigation into prices paid by the Pentagon for spare parts, was pronounced dead at Capitol Hill Hospital today after suffering a heart attack in his office. He was 70 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Hero Retires
description: While many of the Army's generals and the Navy's admirals served in the Vietnam War, the colonels and captains who were the junior officers then are beginning to retire after careers of 20 to 30 years.

title: Chicago Gets Law Overhauling the City's Public Schools
description: A decentralization bill mandating top-to-bottom changes in how Chicago's schools are run was signed into law Monday by Gov. James R. Thompson.

title: 3 JUDGES EXCLUDE AIDS DEFENDANTS
description: The decisions by three Alabama district judges to require AIDS-infected defendants to enter their guilty pleas and receive their sentences by telephone have touched off a debate over whether the judges are jeopardizing the right to a fair trial.

title: A Festive Menu Even a Cook Can Love
description: THE family feast at Christmas remains one of the most anticipated and exuberant meals of the year, as it was in 18th-century England.

title: Berry at a Low, Injurywise and Otherwise
description: Walter Berry's less-than-sweet season took another sour turn yesterday.

title: Icahn Has 15.8% Stake In Texaco
description: Sending out a strong signal that he may be preparing for a proxy fight to unseat Texaco Inc.'s top executives, Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., disclosed yesterday that he now owned 38.7 million Texaco shares, or 15.8 percent of the nation's third-largest oil producer.

title: 21 Die in Mozambique Blast
description: Twenty-one people have been killed and 10 wounded by a landmine explosion in the Mozambique province of Sofala, the official news agency reported today.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons; College students seeking financial aid confront a crazy quilt of sources.
description: Borrowing for college has a long tradition. As far back as 1807, when yearly tuition at Dartmouth College was $20, all but six of the 39 seniors who graduated owed the college money. Their notes ranged from 40 cents to $98.07.

title: A Reversal for I.B.M.
description: The computer maker sold its Rolm subsidiary, backing away from its dream of integrating computers and telecommunications. Page D1.

title: Luria, L & Son Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of about $357,000, or 6 cents a share, from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Tennessee Agency In $75 Million Issue
description: The Tennessee Housing Development Agency is offering $75 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Review/Film; A Way With Wealthy Women
description: Lawrence Jamieson (Michael Caine) is a haberdasher's dream, the sort of man who could make Oleg Cassini look like a panhandler. Lawrence wears clothes well, has a gourmet's palate, impeccable manners and lives in splendor on the French Riviera in a magnificent villa overlooking the sea.

title: Rival Eastern Leagues Trying Togetherness
description: The concept may be good, but its time has apparently not yet arrived.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The PLO will seek a comprehensive settlement among the parties concerned in the Arab-Israeli conflict, including the state of Palestine, Israel and other neighbors, within the framework of the international conference for peace in the Middle East on the basis of Resolutions 242 and 338 and so as to guarantee equality and the balance of interests, especially our people's rights in freedom, national independence, and respect the right to exist in peace and security for all.'' - Yasir Arafat. [ A12:5. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Yasir Arafat called on Israel to open negotiations with the P.L.O. for peace in the Middle East. But during a U.N. address in Geneva, he failed to meet conditions set by Washington for dealing with the P.L.O. Page A1

title: N.F.L. Union Proposes Free-Agency System
description: The National Football League Players Association today released a proposal for ending its two-season-old labor dispute with the league. The proposal includes a free-agency system similar to the ones used by major league baseball and the National Basketball Association.

title: Last-Minute Rally Pushes Dow Up by 3.91
description: A modest last-minute rally pushed blue-chip stock prices higher yesterday, although the overall market closed mixed.

title: Alford Is Dropped
description: The Dallas Mavericks activated a forward, Roy Tarpley, from the injured list yesterday and waived the second-year guard, Steve Alford. Tarpley missed 14 games with a left knee injury. He underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair the torn cartilage. He won the league's sixth-man award last season with his work off the bench. Alford, a two-time all-American at Indiana, was a second-round draft choice in 1987. (AP)

title: Norman Charles, 53, Head of Street Ministry
description: The Rev. Norman Charles, a minister of the United Methodist Church and founder of the Theater of Renewal, a street ministry, died of complications of diabetes Dec. 7 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: San Francisco
description: ''CHEAP AND NUTRITIOUS'' is more than the title of a cookbook. It is a series of classes on preparing wholesome, economical meals, many of which require little or no equipment.

title: Broad Bilingual Aid Plan Settles Segregation Suit
description: With a Federal court's approval, the public schools of Lowell, Mass., are starting one of the nation's most far-reaching programs of instruction and special services for students and parents whose first language is not English.

title: Africans Find Italy's Doors Swinging Shut
description: For the last week, a boatload of African emigrants have sailed futilely from one Italian port to another in search of a temporary haven and a permanent future.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Larry Kopald has been named executive vice president and executive creative director, at Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Milsteins Give $25 Million To a Hospital
description: Presbyterian Hospital has received a $25 million gift from the Milstein Family Foundation, whose members have a long personal involvement in supporting medical institutions. The gift from Seymour and Paul Milstein and their sister, Gloria Milstein Flanzer, is the largest single contribution received by Presbyterian Hospital in its 120-year history.

title: European Charter Signed
description: At what was billed as the first summit meeting of European business leaders, the heads of the leading European industry associations today signed a 16-point charter, the Common Declaration of European Businesses, that called for speeding up the process of deregulation to help Europe compete more effectively when many of its trade barriers are lowered at the end of 1992.

title: Shipyards Nearer Than Gdansk Are Closing
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; One Man's Restless Life
description: As so many German films have done in the last 20 years, Uwe Schrader's ''Sierra Leone'' practically dares you to like it. Its hero, Fred, who has returned to West Germany after working for three years in Africa, is self-centered, shallow and boorish. He is the kind of man who never bothered to call or write his wife all the time he was gone yet seems genuinely surprised that she is not glad to see him again. He had, after all, kept sending her checks.

title: Heico Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $441,000, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of a former manufacturing facility. The share earnings for all periods are adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split which will be payable Jan. 31 to shareholders of record Jan. 3.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bath Iron Works, Bath, Me., was awarded a Navy contract worth $610.1 million to build three Aegis destroyers, and the Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries received a $466.5 million contract for two of the guided missile destroyers.

title: Subaru of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Irish Deny British Bid to Extradite Priest Suspected of Aiding I.R.A.
description: Ireland today rejected a British request for the extradition of a Roman Catholic priest whom Britain suspects of providing funds and arms to the Irish Republican Army.

title: A Widow's Might Defeats the Louvre
description: A widow has beaten the Louvre in a 20-year legal battle over a 17th-century painting that the museum acquired 1n 1968 for $366 and that the widow sold for $1.4 million at an auction Monday night.

title: Weight Lifting; A Great Weight Is Lifted From Turkey's Little Hero
description: There was a reception in his honor at a Manhattan pub Monday night, red and white balloons hanging from the ceiling, guests and dignitaries eager to clasp his hand. It was in a similar setting, two years ago yesterday, that the weight lifter Naim Suleymanoglu made the biggest decision of his life, at a party following the world championships in Melbourne, Australia. He was 18 years old then, born and raised in Bulgaria but part of an oppressed Turkish minority in that country.

title: North Carolina Fugitive Held After Upstate Crash Into Bus
description: Timothy Jacobs, a fugitive who has been sought on 14 kidnapping charges stemming from a newspaper takeover here, was arrested today near Oneida, N.Y., after a high-speed police chase that ended when his automobile crashed into the back of an empty schoolbus, the authorities said.

title: Business, Too, Sends Dollars For Neediest
description: Wishing to share some of its good fortune this year, a new international merger and acquisition advisory firm and merchant bank sent a gift of $25,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 210 Waterfowl Hunters Charged After U.S. Inquiry Into Poaching
description: A three-year undercover investigation of suspected poaching by professional waterfowl hunters, in which Federal agents hunted in duck blinds along the Gulf Coast of Texas, was capped today with charges against 210 people.

title: New Gift Wraps: Gloss, Glitter and Ease
description: THE biggest surprise under the Christmas tree this season may be the gift wrap. New wraps and trims make choosing a presentation as dizzying as selecting a gift.

title: Suffolk Acts on Drug Dealers
description: The Suffolk County Legislature unanimously approved a bill today that would allow the county to seek court orders to seize houses or apartments where drugs are being sold or manufactured and to evict their occupants.

title: Super Valu Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: Trouble in Bombay: Thugs and Gang Killings
description: When several heavily armed men in three cars recently trailed and then killed five members of a rival gang on a highway near here, they drew attention to the increasing violence that marks the growth of organized crime in India's wealthiest and most vibrant city.

title: D.H. Blair Picks Doctor As Director of Finance
description: Dr. Lindsay Rosenwald, perhaps an exception to the Wall Street truism that doctors make bad investors, has been named managing director of corporate finance at D. H. Blair & Company, a Wall Street firm.

title: Pay the Price of Good Government
description: A Federal commission yesterday took the first steps toward substantial and much needed pay increases for about 2,500 top Federal officials - and toward ending the corrupting honorariums or ''speaking fees'' that buy influence in Washington.

title: Jay Jacobs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Acustar Job Cuts
description: The Chrysler Corporation's Acustar Inc. subsidiary said it would lay off 500 workers at Detroit Trim, one of four Acustar plants that the United Automobile Workers union agreed to allow Chrysler to close under a labor contract. The workers' last day will be Dec. 23.

title: Professionals Barred From Certain Trades
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today barred professionals from trading in an electronic system in the over-the-counter market meant to assist small investors.

title: Isco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
ARAFAT, IN GENEVA, CALLS ON ISRAELIS TO JOIN IN TALKS
description: Yasir Arafat called on Israel today to open negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization on peace in the Middle East. But he did not meet the conditions set by the United States for dealing with the P.L.O.

title: U.S. Says Arafat's Speech Fails to Meet 3 Conditions
description: The United States said today that Yasir Arafat's speech to the United Nations included some positive elements but was ambiguous on key points and did not meet American conditions for engaging in talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES RISES FOR 2 TAXES
description: Saying that New York State will need to raise at least $700 million in new revenues over the next year, Governor Cuomo today proposed an immediate increase in taxes on cigarettes and alcohol to help close the state's budget gap.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: America West Airlines Inc. ordered 15 of Boeing's 737-300 jetliners and 10 of the 757 commercial jets in a deal worth about $800 million. The carrier, based in Phoenix, also took options for 10 more 737-300's and 15 other 757's. The airline will receive the initial 25 planes over a three-year period beginning in 1992. Michael J. Conway, president of America West, said money for the new planes would come from company earnings, proceeds from selling currently owned aircraft and financing.

title: Foraging Bridges Language Barrier
description: MICHEL BRAS, the chef and owner of the Michelin two-star restaurant in central France that bears his name, had no time to notice the plants growing in Central Park when he ran in the New York City Marathon last month. But several days later, nose to the ground, he and his wife, Ginette, went looking for edible plants in the park with Steve Brill, a naturalist for the city's Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Ice Cream That's French

title: On TV's 'One on One,' Ideologies Grapple
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Soviet Panel Formed to Study Ecology
description: The national science academies of the United States and the Soviet Union, warning that the earth's ''ecological security'' is now endangered, announced today the formation of a joint Committee on Global Ecology Concerns.

title: Best Products Co Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 29
description: The company said in November approximately 97.2 percent of the company's common stock was acquired by an affiliate of Adler & Shaykin, a private investment firm that specializes in leverage buyouts. The results of operations for the third quarter and first 9 months of fiscal 1988 do not include any acquisition-related expenses. Such expenses, which total approximately $32 million to date, will be reflected in the results of the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988.

title: Iraq Abandons Syria Pipeline
description: Iraq has announced it is abandoning a pipeline that once carried one-third of its crude oil to the Mediterranean coast through Syria.

title: Homeless: What New York Can't Do
description: With thousands of homeless men and women sleeping nightly on streets and subways and in bus and rail stations, New York City officials say they lack the means to coax or compel them to move to city shelters or to accept other help.

title: Careercom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split which took place during the fiscal year.

title: Text of the U.S. Statement
description: Following is a transcript of the statement today by Charles E. Redman, the State Department spokesman, on the speech to the United Nations by Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization:

title: Drug Habits We Can't Afford
description: Never in 20 years in public life have I witnessed anything quite as disheartening as our feeble response to the illegal drug epidemic. News of the ravages of drugs is omnipresent. In the Steinberg case, for example, there have been widely reported allegations that cocaine was free-based the night Lisa Steinberg died. Tragically, in three-quarters of child abuse cases one or both parents is addicted to illegal drugs.

title: American Century Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Appleton, Wis.
description: TIM O'CONNELL says with some pride that his new restaurant is the only one of its kind in the Middle West, an assertion difficult to contest. Mr. O'Connell's restaurant, Mongo's, specializes in Mongolian barbecue - tasty dishes made with meat, fish and vegetables flavored with oils, wines and sauces and stir-fried on a large circular grill.

title: Murderer Executed After a Leaky Lethal Injection
description: A man who murdered an immigrant restaurateur as the man's wife watched was put to death by injection early today in an execution delayed when a tube from an intravenous needle began to leak.

title: Rescue Effort Straining Soviet Economy
description: With the national economy beginning to be strained by a diversion of resources to Armenia, frantic rescue efforts continued there today to free people still pinned beneath the rubble from the devastating earthquake last week.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PERHAPS two of the most universally popular foods in this country today are chicken and pasta. With this in mind, I have been dabbling with recipes that combine the two. One combination I particularly like was inspired by my good friend Edward Giobbi, a painter and the author of two Italian cookbooks (''Italian Family Cooking,'' Random House, 1971 and ''Eat Right, Eat Well the Italian Way,'' Alfred A. Knopf, 1985).

title: INSIDE
description: Atom Plant Debate Grows An advisory committee said that the Energy Department's safety plan for reopening a nuclear weapons reactor was inadequate. Page A20. Soviet Pledge on Radars Moscow has told Washington it will destroy old transportable radars that the United States says violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. Page A19. What Price Clothing? As prices soar, women's clothing manufacturers are trying to contain costs by streamlining production and reducing profit margins. Page C1. Awash in Red Ink Losses at the nation's savings and loans eased, but the industry still recorded a deficit of $1.6 billion in the third quarter of the year. Page D1.

title: KEY RATES
Namibia and Angola: A Tangled Past
description: 1884The Germans colonize South-West Africa, a mineral-producing and mostly desert territory with a long Atlantic coastline. 1915South Africa invades; Germany gives up the territory. 1920The League of Nations gives South Africa a mandate to administer the territory. 1946A United Nations trusteeship replaces the mandate; South Africa rejects the change. 1966The South-West Africa People's Organization begins a guerrilla war to gain independence for the territory. The United Nations strips South Africa of its trusteeship rights. 1968The United Nations renames the territory Namibia. 1971The International Court of Justice rules that the South African presence is illegal. 1973The United Nations General Assembly calls the South-West Africa People's Organization the ''sole authentic representative of the Namibian people.'' 1974United Nations resolutions demand a South African withdrawal and the transfer of power to the Namibian people, with United Nations assistance. 1975Angola becomes independent from Portugal. Cuban troops are sent to Angola at the request of the Angolan Government, led by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. 1978The United Nations Security Council approves Resolution 435, which calls for a cease-fire in the Namibian war, United Nations-sponsored elections and a peacekeeping force in Namibia. Pretoria holds elections in Namibia, but they are boycotted by the South-West Africa People's Organization; the elections are not recognized internationally. 1982Pretoria says that for Namibia to gain freedom, Cuban troops must leave Angola. 1983In December, South Africa launches a major operation against Namibian guerrillas in Angola. Pretoria offers a 30-day cease-fire; it is rejected. 1984In January, South Africa says it will pull troops from from southern Angola. In February, Angola and South Africa form a commission to monitor the pullback. The agreement bars the Namibian rebels and the Cuban troops from moving into the vacated areas. The insurgents reject the conditions.

title: All Types of Schools Find Common Goals
description: Rabbi Harvey Silberstein and Frank R. Petruzielo both work in the same field, education, and in the same city, Miami.

title: David Gordon's Tales, in Movement, of the U.S.
description: David Gordon once observed that there is a lot in a little, and the noted experimentalist choreographer's dances have tended to be microcosmic. But in ''United States,'' which opens tonight for a four-performance run at the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Gordon has taken on an entire country, in dances that aim to evoke the character of some of its states and regions.

title: Ennis Business Forms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Board Games of High Finance Mirror Reality
description: ''DO Not Pass Go,'' the Waterloo of many a Monopoly player, has found its 1980's equivent in ''Black Friday,'' the downfall of the investors-for-the-moment in the game Stocks & Bonds. A real-life vocabulary now sets the rules for what Ian McDermott, who buys games for F.A.O. Schwarz, the toy stores, calls the ''serious games'' that have brought the simple pleasures of Monopoly into the junk-bond age.

title: Western Publishing Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Chip Concern to Sell Scanners Unit to STC
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Datachecker Systems division, which makes electronic scanners for supermarket checkout lines, to a division of STC P.L.C., a large British communications and computer company, for $90 million.

title: Capital's Council Backed in Dispute With U.S.
description: A Federal judge ruled here today that Congress could not force the District of Columbia to make discrimination against homosexuals legal.

title: South African Chosen As a Rhodes Scholar
