description: Isaac Shongwe's formal education began 15 years ago in a dingy two-room schoolhouse for blacks in South Africa. It will continue next fall in the Gothic halls of Oxford University in England, where Mr. Shongwe will be a Rhodes scholar.

title: Lift Time Limits for Depreciation Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Venture For Law Firm
description: Lawyers at the Washington firm Arnold & Porter said yesterday that its consulting affiliate had agreed in principle to establish a joint venture with a Soviet consulting cooperative that is affiliated with the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations.

title: Kellogg Cutback on Oil
description: The Kellogg Company said Monday that it had stopped using tropical oils in its Cracklin' Oat Bran cereal, eliminating saturated fat for consumers who buy the cereal for cholesterol-lowering bran. Joseph Stewart, senior vice president for Kellogg's corporate affairs, said the new product will be on grocery shelves within three months.

title: Pirates and Parker Arrive at Settlement
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates announced yesterday the settlement of a lawsuit against Dave Parker, the Oakland Athletics outfielder, involving Parker's admitted use of cocaine for a period of about 7 of the 10 years he played in Pittsburgh (1973-83). The settlement avoided a trial that had threatened to drag into a courtroom some of baseball's most familiar names. In April 1986, after Parker had testified at the drug trial of one of his cocaine suppliers that his use of that drug contributed to his playing slump early in the 1980's, the Pirates filed a Federal court lawsuit against him, seeking to void the contract signed in 1979 under which the Pirates were obligated to make deferred payments of approximately $5.3 million. The lawsuit was scheduled to go to trial in United States District Court in Pittsburgh on Feb. 6, 1989. Rick Cerrone, a spokesman for the Pirates, said the terms of the out-of-court settlement would be kept confidential by mutual agreement. In the breach-of-contract suit, the Pirates charged that Parker was a heavy cocaine user for nearly five years and that his drug use reduced him to an overweight, injury-prone player ''overpaid for the drug-impaired performances'' under the 1979 contract. Parker's attorneys contended that the Pirates knew about Parker's cocaine use. Parker, as a free agent after the 1983 season, rejected an offer from the Pirates and signed with Cincinnati.(AP)

title: Home Loan Banks' Bond Offering Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks is offering a total of $5 billion worth of bonds in seven issues through various securities dealers. All the bonds are priced at par.

title: Clashes on a Polish Anniversary
description: Hundreds of demonstrators clashed with riot policemen in Warsaw today on the seventh anniversary of the martial-law crackdown of 1981.

title: Real Estate; Industrial Rents Rise In Newark
description: JUST a few years ago space in many of the industrial buildings along Frelinghuysen Avenue, an old manufacturing district in Newark's South Ward, went begging. Few companies seemed interested in leasing space there, and some tenants in the aging structures wanted to leave.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Included a loss of $1,042,000 on debt restructuring for both periods, and tax credits of $1,339,000 and $2,667,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included gains of $631,000 and $1,229,000 on debt restructuring for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $593,000 and $1,973,000 for the same periods, respectively. Latest 9-month results included a $1,255,000 non-recurring gain on the sale of property, compared with same year-ago period gain of $1,565,000. Preferred dividend requirements totaled $660,000 for the latest quarter, compared with a rebate of $173,000 from over-accrual of funds for year- ago period. For the latest 9 months, preferred dividend requirements totaled $1,569,000 against $285,000 for year- ago period.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; . . .And Good Will?
description: Maybe there is something to be grateful for this season, after all. In his annual Christmas card John M. Snyder, an active member of the capital's gun lobby, has eschewed his previous habit of showing Santa Claus armed with a pistol or brandishing a machine gun.

title: Offer for Plessey To Be Reviewed
description: The European Community will examine the joint bid for the Plessey Company, a British electronics concern, by two rivals, the General Electric Company P.L.C. and Siemens A.G. of Germany, after a formal complaint by Plessey, a community spokesman said. The spokesman said that Plessey's complaint focused on a breach of European Community antitrust rules by Siemens and G.E.C. in making the joint bid of $:1.7 billion, which amounts to $3.1 billion.

title: David T. Marvel Sr., Executive, 81
description: David T. Marvel Sr., a former corporate vice president of the Olin Corporation, died of cancer Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Lewes, Del.

title: Kent State Journal; Terrible Event Echoes in Dispute on How to Remember It
description: It has been more than 18 years since Alan Canfora was shot in the wrist after Ohio National Guardsmen were called to quell antiwar demonstrators at Kent State University. Now 39 years old, his hair a bit shorter, he remains a regular presence on campus, a reminder of the four students who were shot dead and the nine who were wounded on May 4, 1970.

title: Review/Television; Bridging 2 Cultures Via Satellite
description: Several years ago, Marlo Thomas picked up some Emmy Awards with her family special called ''Free to Be . . . You and Me.'' Tonight at 8 o'clock on ABC, Ms. Thomas is back with ''Free to Be . . . A Family.'' The family is this instance is one of nations and different cultures, those of the United States and the Soviet Union. Prime-time entertainment has arrived in the territory of the political thaw.

title: Boy Dies After Medics Leave
description: Paramedics called to treat an asthmatic 9-year-old boy left a city housing development when their ambulance was pelted by eggs and returned with the police too late to save the boy, the authorities said today.

title: Two Officers At Salomon Said to Quit
description: Salomon Brothers has lost two more important members of its old management team with the resignations of William J. Voute, a respected vice chairman at the Wall Street firm, and William N. Wight, a managing director in charge of corporate bond trading, people close to the firm said yesterday.

title: More Wheat for China
description: Exporters have sold China an additional 400,000 metric tons of American wheat at subsidized prices for shipment in January and February, the Agriculture Department said today. Melvin E. Sims, general sales manager for its Foreign Agricultural Service, said the deal was part of an authorized sale of one million tons announced last Wednesday under the Export Enhancement Program.

title: Tyson Foods-Holly
description: An attorney for Tyson Foods Inc. told the Delaware Chancery Court that directors of the Holly Farms Corporation had not pursued their stockholders' right to the best price. Tyson asserts that Holly Farm's board was influenced by Holly Farms' managers who are unfriendly to Tyson. Holly Farms, based in Memphis, has rejected two takeover offers from Tyson, which is the nation's top poultry producer. Holly Farm's board said last week that it would proceed with a proposed merger with Conagra Inc. Both deals are valued at about $1 billion.

title: Bridge
description: At the bridge table, though no longer the classroom, it is common for teachers to beat students. The converse is rare, but it happened on the diagramed deal from the Men's Board-a-Match Team Championship, played Nov. 21 during the Fall Nationals in Nashville.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE saga of American wine in France is long and undistinguished. Back in the early part of the 19th century, Nicholas Longworth's Ohio sparkling Catawba was said to have stirred up a little interest here and, if you can believe the archives, American wines would now and then win a medal at some exposition or fair over here.

title: Kremlin Says It Is Dismantling 2 Disputed Radars
description: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it is destroying several old transportable radars that Washington says violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Church's Talks With Suitor Fail
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said today that it had tried unsuccessfully to settle its differences with A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., which owns Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits restaurants. Copeland has been waging a hostile takeover campaign for Church's.

title: Fashion Faces Reality: Contain Costs or Else
description: IN an effort to contain rising prices and to improve lagging sales, manufacturers of women's clothing are re-examining the way they do business. ''Prices are going up astronomically,'' said Jon Levy, president of St. Gillian, a clothing manufacturer, voicing the concern of the fashion and retail industries. ''The question is what are we going to do about it?''

title: Food-Vendor Rules to Everybody's Taste Take Awhile to Prepare
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia C. Duncomb, Lawyer, 74
description: Virginia C. Duncomb, a lawyer who had been associated with the Legal Aid Society, died of a heart attack Sunday at her home in Lido Beach, L.I. She was 74 years old.

title: Tomato Fans Go the Extra Miles
description: FOR most people, the taste of a real tomato is just a memory, as distant and sweet as last summer's sun. Yet at this time of year, it is demoralizing to buy those hard, tasteless things that supermarkets call tomatoes.

title: Lonrho Loses Bid To Block Bond
description: The British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. failed in its legal bid to ward off a possible takeover by freezing 95 million of its shares held by the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond. Lonrho, whose interests include mining, newspapers and hotels, had asked the High Court for an interim freeze preventing any transfer of the shares owned by Mr. Bond and blocking any voting rights or dividend payments.

title: Text of the Pact on Settling The Southern Africa Conflict
description: Following is the text of the accord signed today in Brazzaville, Congo, by South Africa, Cuba and Angola, as distributed by the South African Press Association:

title: Current-Account Trade Gap Shrinks
description: The deficit in American commercial and other transactions with the rest of the world declined from July through September to the lowest quarterly level in three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Armenia Cry: The Orphans Must Remain
description: With all the victims still not identified after last week's earthquake, Armenians in the stricken republic and in Moscow say they are frantically trying to prevent orphaned children from being adopted by non-Armenian families.

title: Life of a Mouse
description: To The Living Section:

title: Devils' Unbeaten Run Reaches Four Games
description: The Devils survived a lethargic third period, in which they took a season-low two shots, and posted their third victory in the last four games.

title: Rev. Donald Campion, 67, Dies; Writer and Ex-Editor of America
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald R. Campion, a Jesuit priest, author and former editor of the national Catholic weekly magazine America, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at the Murray-Weigel Hall Health Care Center at Fordham University. He was 67 years old and lived at Fordham.

title: Christmas Dinner Is a Time For Chefs to Strut Their Stuff
description: LIKE most of us, chefs consider the traditions of Thanksgiving sacrosanct. If they have eaten turkey since childhood they continue to eat it, even if they don't like turkey. Christmas, however, is an opportunity for many of them to show off.

title: Recognition Equipment Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a $4 million reserve for severance costs related to the company's international operations, a $2 million reserve for obsolete equipment, a $1 million reserve related to a lawsuit, a tax credit of $114,000, and a charge of $3,578,000 to reflect a change in accounting for spare parts. c-Net income and included a tax credit of $2,600,000. The company said fourth-quarter results are not available because it must restate its prior quarters to reflect the accounting change.

title: Review/Film; A Bittersweet View of the Gay Life
description: The climactic confrontation between Arnold Beckoff (Harvey Fierstein) and his mother (Anne Bancroft) at the end of ''Torch Song Trilogy'' isn't really as drastic as it appears. Though mother and son argue bitterly about their clash in values, in fact they aren't very far apart. Yes, the mother would like to see her son settle down and lead a so-called normal life, but then so would he. The fact that Arnold makes a living as a drag queen (under names like ''Virginia Hamn'') has done nothing to make him any less conventional than his nagging Jewish mother.

title: Sanders Adds Prize
description: Barry Sanders, the Heisman Trophy winner as the best college player in the nation this year, added another trophy to his collection yesterday. The Oklahoma State running back was named the winner of the 52d annual Maxwell Award. Sanders had nearly four times as many first-place votes and nearly twice as many total points as Rodney Peete of Southern Cal, the runner-up.(AP)

title: Damon Creations Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income The company said the two periods are not comparable because of the merger on March 28, 1988, of Enro Holding Corp. with and into Damon Creations Inc. The surviving corporation retained the name Damon Creations Inc. The results shown for the period ending Oct. 1, 1988, include the results of the company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Enro Shirt Co.; whereas the results for the period ended Oct. 2, 1987 included only the results of Enro Holding Corp. and, at the time, its wholly owned subsidiary, the Enro Shirt Co. Sales represent net sales.

title: I.B.M. to Sell Rolm to Siemens
description: In a tacit admission that its $1.5 billion thrust into the telecommunications industry has stalled, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Rolm manufacturing and development operations to Siemens A.G. of West Germany.

title: Book Notes
description: Worldwide Literature

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Television and Communications Corp., Stamford, Conn., a cable television operator, elected James P. Cottingham executive vice president.

World Relief, P. O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. World Vision, Box 0, Pasadena, Calif. 91109.

title: Bonn Journal; A Very German Storm: Dust Settles and Unsettles
description: In the month since the Speaker of Parliament stepped down over a blunt speech he delivered about Hitler, the incident has touched off a national debate about the phobias and taboos that restrict discussion of the Nazi past.

title: Economic Scene; That Disturbing Deal on Steel
description: FOR Henry of Navarre, sometime Protestant and candidate for the throne of France in 1593, ''Paris was well worth a mass.'' For George of Kennebunkport, sometime free trader and candidate for the Oval Office in 1988, Pittsburgh apparently was worth a steel quota.

title: Japan's Plan For Economy
description: Japan today formally adopted a program to open its markets to imports to reduce its huge trade surplus.

title: Judge Orders PTL Assets Sold for $65 Million
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today ordered the assets of the PTL television ministry sold to a Toronto real estate developer for $65 million.

title: 2 More Deaths Tied by Police To Bitter Cold
description: Two men have died on the streets of New York City as a result of bitter cold in the Northeast since the weekend, according to the City Medical Examiner's office.

title: Prepared Foods Without 'Bad' Fats
description: A CRUSADE begun by consumer groups and health professionals to force manufacturers to replace the highly saturated fats in their products is having an effect. Almost daily, companies are switching from coconut, palm and palm kernel oils, as well as lard and beef tallow, to vegetable oils that are low in saturated fat and high in either polyunsaturated fat or monounsaturated fat.

title: U.S. Flies the Last Cruise Missiles Out of Belgium
description: As a United States Air Force C-141 with eight cruise missiles aboard roared from the base runway here, Belgium today became the first country to be cleared of intermediate-range nuclear weapons under the treaty concluded with the Soviet Union a year ago.

title: Charles Sallee, 63, Leader in Textile Union
description: Charles H. Sallee, the secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, died Monday at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, Mo., after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and St. Louis.

title: N.T.T. Chairman Is Said to Quit
description: The chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Hisashi Shinto, reportedly resigned today after prosecutors found that he had received nearly $80,000 in Japan's widening stock scandal.

title: Tyson-Bruno Fight Stays in Legal Tangle
description: For the last couple of months, the main obstacle to a Mike Tyson-Frank Bruno fight has been the role of Don King in Tyson's boxing future.

title: Toll Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Thorkil Host, 92, Danish Shipping Figure
description: Thorkil Host, a major figure in the Danish shipping industry in World War II, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Retreat
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to a report that suggests consumer activity remains strong in the fourth quarter.

title: Bush Agenda at Capitol Will Be Limited at First
description: President-elect Bush, facing a solidly Democratic Congress, sees the success of his administration in dealing with Capitol Hill as largely dependent on avoiding an early, protracted fight over the deficit, his aides say.

title: A Card That 'Sees' User's Veins
description: Because someone stole Joe Rice's credit cards, future shoppers may be asked to hold out their hands for a ''vein reading'' rather than signing a credit card purchase.

title: Federal Express Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a gain of $18.1 million, or 35 cents a share, from cumulative effect on fiscal years prior to 1989 of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page one on Monday about tensions in Soviet Armenia misstated in one passage the reasons for a clash between Armenians and Soviet troops. The protesters demanded the release of jailed Armenian nationalist leaders and the lifting of a curfew; the protest did not stem from mistrust of earthquake relief efforts.

title: Advance Circuits Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $380,000. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $234,000.

title: Toll in London Crash Revised to 33 Deaths
description: The police tonight put the death toll at 33 in Monday's rail disaster, the worst in two decades in this country.

title: Mediq Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses of $3,731,000 and $8,926,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively, and gains of $467,000 and $3,916,000 for the same periods, respectively, mostly from the redemption of debentures. c-Included a loss of $3,584,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and included a loss of $3,167,000 from discontinued operations and non-recurring credits of $3,423,000. Fiscal 1988 results include a non- recurring charge of $4,956,000 on the acquisition by Copelco Financial Services Group Inc. of substantially all of its common stock not held by Mediq, and the writeoff of goodwill of $9,257,000 related to the acquisition of two business activities.

title: Bhagwan's Former Secretary Freed From Jail and Deported
description: Ma Anand Sheela, the former secretary to Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the Indian guru, was released from prison in California today and deported to West Germany.

title: Knicks Are Powered By All Parts of Lineup
description: Recently, it has been said that the Detroit Pistons' second unit could possibly make the N.B.A. playoffs. That's how good it is. Given the way the Knicks played last night in their 121-100 rout of the Nets, the same thing could perhaps be said about them.

title: Washington Talk: Military Aircraft; Stealth Sheds Secrets, but Its Cost Stays Hidden
description: After a decade of nearly total secrecy, the Air Force has been slowly removing some of the wraps from the Stealth bomber in compromises driven by practical and political necessities. But it has still not answered the crucial question of the plane's cost.

title: Ulrich Finsterwalder, 90, a Bridge Designer
description: Ulrich Finsterwalder, a widely known West German bridge designer, died Dec. 5 in a Munich hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Munich.

title: Graphic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest periods' figures included results from Baum Printing House Inc. and Mercury Printing Co., both acquired in September. b-Net loss

title: Some in Pentagon Fear Effects of Lag in Picking Defense Chief
description: The delay in announcing a new Secretary of Defense has put many of the Pentagon's political appointees in limbo and will give the eventual nominee a late start in preparing for important policy decisions, Pentagon officials and sources close to the transition to a Bush administration say.

title: Bronx Teacher Seized As a Buyer of Heroin
description: A fourth-grade teacher at a public school in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx was arrested yesterday after police officers saw him buy heroin and cocaine at a known drug-selling location, officials said.

title: U.S. Plan to Restart Reactor Is Unsafe, Expert Panel Says
description: The Energy Department's plan for restarting a crippled reactor at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina overlooked crucial safeguards needed to make the nation's largest nuclear weapons plant operate safely, the department's principal scientific advisory committee said today.

title: National Gallery Gains 8 Contemporary Works
description: The National Gallery of Art announced today that it had acquired eight pieces of 20th-century art, including five paintings by Barnett Newman.

title: U.S. Tightening Rules on Asylum For Nicaraguans
description: Immigration officials said today that they were planning an aggressive new program to identify and deport citizens of Nicaragua and other Central American countries who had entered the United States illegally and could not demonstrate ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' in their homelands.

title: Review/Music; Mother and Son, in Recital
description: The pianist Bella Davidovich and the violinst Dmitry Sitkovetsky, who is also Miss Davidovich's son, devoted the first half of their Sunday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall to sonatas by Beethoven and Schumann and rounded out the program with the Chausson Concert in D, for which they were joined by the Cleveland Quartet.

title: Albany Weighs Agency to Build New Classrooms
description: Only two weeks after he called the legislation ''dead in its current form,'' the State Senate majority leader today said he was ''hopeful'' that a bill to create an authority to oversee construction of New York City schools could be passed this week.

title: Bush Makes Agriculture Post Choice
description: President-elect Bush has decided to offer the position of Secretary of Agriculture to Clayton K. Yeutter, now the United States Trade Representative, Bush transition officials said today.

title: Nabisco Chief's Wife Sold Stock
description: Laurie Johnson, the wife of F. Ross Johnson, the chairman of RJR Nabisco Inc., has sold 60,000 RJR Nabisco common shares in the open market for $5.4 million. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Citicorp's Ambac Unit Completing Transition
description: H. Russell Fraser, one of the pioneers in the business of insuring municipal bonds, is stepping down as president and chief executive of Ambac Inc., completing a transition that began when Citicorp bought the company three years ago.

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $1 million from the settlement of litigation for the quarter and 39 weeks, tax credits of $556,000 and $597,000 for the same periods, respectively; the 39 weeks also included a gain of $106,000 from an accounting change. c-After tax credits of $461,000 for the quarter and $934,000 for the 39 weeks.

title: The Gang That Hijacked Patrick Ewing
description: Recently, in a city 2,080 miles from New York, I had access to a television with all those wonderful cable buttons. I worked my way through recent movies, Spanish soap operas, weather stations, swap-'n'-shop, a Neil Diamond concert with incredibly bad acoustics, Ralph Emery chatting away in Nashville, and news, most of it bad.

title: East Harlem Schools Official Is Suspended by Local Board
description: An East Harlem schools superintendent, accused of using school funds for personal expenses, was suspended for 60 days without pay by his local school board last night.

title: Review/Theater; An Enemy of the People, With Personal Problems
description: Although ''Rosmersholm'' begins on a summer evening, it is a wintry drama with a foreboding landscape of characters. Watching Sarah Pia Anderson's compelling revival at La Mama Annex, one can readily see why Sigmund Freud and August Strindberg were so drawn to the play. Ms. Anderson, who is English, gives us a ''Rosmersholm'' that reveals its psychological undercurrents, so essential if we are to understand one of Ibsen's most difficult and problematic works.

title: Biomet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results included the contribution of Biomet's unit, Electro-Biology Inc., acquired during the second quarter of fiscal 1988.

title: The Words People Play
description: There are two games in the Middle East conflict. One is deadly.

title: Market Place; Shift in Strategy At Wells Fargo
description: LONG a favorite of banking analysts, Wells Fargo & Company has acquired a reputation for pursuing no business that does not benefit shareholders, usually sooner rather than later. With that in mind, analysts are sanguine about the San Francisco-based bank's latest moves, which include sending a team to Dallas to evaluate making a bid for Mcorp and making an unsolicited offer to acquire Southwest Bancorp of Vista, Calif.

title: Sale Is Expected Soon For National Enquirer
description: The trustees for the estate of Generoso P. Pope Jr., who died on Oct. 2, said yesterday that The National Enquirer and Weekly World News would be sold as quickly as possible.

title: Some of Bush's Advisers Challenged Budget Plan
description: On Aug. 11, four days before the Republican National Convention, with his campaign sagging in the polls, George Bush's stable of eight private economists gathered around a table here with senior campaign officials for a confidential daylong review of economic issues.

title: Substantive Agreement Concluded On Angola and a Free Namibia
description: After months of negotiation, Angola, Cuba and South Africa today concluded an agreement on independence for Namibia and the withdrawal of all Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Where Arab and Jew Work Together
description: Dr. Tarek Hassan Shawkat and Shmuel Reznikovich seem unlikely collaborators. One is a 30-year-old Muslim physician from Egypt and the other is a 33-year-old Orthodox Jew from Israel studying hospital administration.

title: Vatican Reaches Out to Russian Orthodox Church
description: In recent weeks the Vatican has substantially increased its material assistance to the Russian Orthodox Church, hoping to exploit changes in the Soviet Union that have expanded religious freedoms, senior Vatican officials say.

title: Statement by Arafat On Peace in Mideast
description: Following is a transcript of the statement made by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, at a news conference today, as recorded by Reuters:

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows Again As Imports Fall
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed modestly in October to $10.3 billion, as imports declined twice as much as exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Yields Post Gains Again
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds posted gains for the week ended yesterday. But as in recent weeks, the gains were focused on short-term rates.

title: Judgment of Solomon
description: Dr. Elizabeth Morgan is a leading plastic surgeon in Washington. Or was. For the last 16 months she has been a prisoner in the District of Columbia jail.

title: Uses Grow for Video Alterations
description: The ability to alter a video image -to place a beard on a face that is really cleanshaven or plant shrubs in front of a house that has none - was once so difficult that only the television networks and Hollywood studios could afford it.

title: Group Begins Bid For Champion
description: A group led by the New York brokerage Walsh Greenwood & Company has begun an unsolicited offer of $55 a share, or about $148 million, for the shares of Champion Products Inc. that it does not own. The offer was made by Phonicam Inc., which conditioned its bid on the purchase of at least 1.33 million shares, costing about $73.15 million. Walsh Greenwood already controls 21.5 percent of Champion's outstanding shares, and the minimum purchase would give it majority control.

title: News by First Fidelity Sends Shares Plunging
description: Shares of the First Fidelity Bancorporation lost nearly a quarter of their value yesterday after the company's announcement that it expected to post a loss of $145 million to $190 million for the current quarter because of bad loans and that several top officers had resigned or been dismissed.

title: Marking a Landmark
description: Today is the 10th anniversary of a landmark in recent United States diplomatic history - President Carter's decision to ''normalize'' relations with China by inaugurating full diplomatic relations. President Reagan marked the event a day early. He and President-elect Bush met with Han Xu, China's Ambassador to the United States.

title: Giant-Jet Cultural Exchange
description: Hurrying along a midtown Manhattan sidewalk, they bumped heads stooping to pick up an NFL Films video that had dropped out of somebody else's Christmas shopping bag. One was wearing a blue overcoat with a blue suit and a blue-and-red tie. The other had on a green cap, a green parka and green sweat pants. After their collision, each tried to claim the video by stepping on it. One with a tasseled black loafer, the other with a green-striped sneaker. But in the confusion, they shattered it.

title: Easing a Child's Pain: Hospitals Adapt Designs to Accommodate Families
description: Timothy John Richmond is just 11 years old, but he has already been hospitalized more than 50 times for cystic fibrosis. While such a record would be grueling even for an adult, it is especially trying for a child separated from his family at a vulnerable age.

title: Koch Urges Cuomo to Name Panel To Investigate School Corruption
description: Mayor Koch, saying he now believes corruption is almost certainly rampant throughout the city's school system, called on Governor Cuomo yesterday to create an independent investigative panel similar to the Knapp Commission, which exposed widespread corruption in the Police Department in the early 1970's.

title: Shelton Jones Cut
description: The Golden State Warriors yesterday waived the rookie forward Shelton Jones, who had played in only two games since being acquired Nov. 22 from San Antonio in a trade for Jerome Whitehead.

title: State Control Board Lifts Hiring Freeze in Yonkers
description: A state board today suspended a citywide hiring freeze that it had imposed in August when Yonkers faced bankrupting fines for blocking a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Savings Plan By Perelman
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the New York financier, is close to gaining control of a group of troubled Texas savings and loan associations that Federal regulators are trying to recapitalize, sources familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Seven Million Strike and Cripple Spain
description: A one-day strike brought commerce, industry and transportation throughout Spain to a standstill today, underscoring widespread dissatisfaction with the economic policies of the Socialist Government.

title: Washington and Yanks Go Down to Wire
description: The Yankees have splurged on free agents this off season, committing a total of more than $10 million to three players, but their reluctance to spend on one of their own free agents may cost them the services of Claudell Washington.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Perry Lieber, 83, Dies; Aided Howard Hughes
description: Perry Lieber, a publicity agent who was a longtime confidant of Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, died here of cancer Monday. He was 83 years old.

title: 4 Jersey City Officers Arraigned on Drug Charges
description: Four police officers, including a narcotics sergeant, were arraigned today, along with an investigator in the Hudson County Prosecutor's office, on charges that they had conspired to distribute cocaine.

title: Massacres Are Jolting Colombia
description: When a score of gunmen entered the northern town of Segovia one evening last month and began firing indiscriminately at passers-by, killing 43 people, it was just one of 20 massacres to have convulsed Colombia this year.

title: Squirrels Enjoy a Temporary Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Low Turnout Traced To Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Dooley Resigns as Georgia Coach
description: Vince Dooley resigned as the football coach at the University of Georgia today after 25 years in which he transformed the team from an also-ran to a traditional power.

title: Anchorage Journal; Center for Performing Arts Is Off to a Sour Start
description: The Alaska Center for the Performing Arts is celebrating its gala opening on Thursday in a manner befitting its three fitful years under construction.

title: Avant-Garde Computing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. AGREES TO TALKS WITH P.L.O., SAYING ARAFAT ACCEPTS ISRAEL AND RENOUNCES ALL TERRORISM
description: President Reagan today authorized the start of a ''substantive dialogue'' with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which he said had finally met the American conditions for direct talks after more than a decade.

title: Shutdowns Of Campuses Considered
description: New York State officials are discussing a retrenchment of the State University and City University systems that may include the closing of several campuses, officials of both systems said.

title: Swedes Arrest Suspect in Palme Assassination
description: The police arrested a suspect today in the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986. News reports described him as a convicted killer with a long criminal record.

title: Namibia: Peace After Failure
description: LEAD: Around the world, the Angolan-Namibian pact is being greeted as a triumph of Reagan Administration policy.

title: KEY RATES
Currents; Measuring in an Instant
description: IT'S just the sort of gadget that could prove irresistible to anyone involved in measuring rooms, whether shopping for a co-op or in the middle of redecorating. Sonin instruments are battery-operated tape cassette look-alikes that electronically measure distances up to 30, 60, 150 or 250 feet.

title: Chase Names Official To Public Finance Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, expanding its public finance activities, has named Thomas De Rogatis to head its municipal trading, sales and distribution operations.

title: 200 Inmates Escape and 2 Die In Blast at a Sri Lanka Prison
description: Bombs believed to have been set by anti-Government militants ripped open a wall of a suburban prison, allowing more than 200 convicts to escape, authorities said today. Two prisoners were killed by guards.

title: TV Notes
description: CBS Juggles Schedule

title: Mark Goldstaub, 37, Press Agent in the Arts
description: Mark Goldstaub, a press agent for many performing-arts organizations, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 37 years old.

title: Brynmor John, Legislator, 54
description: Brynmor John, a Welsh legislator who served in the Labor Governments of Harold Wilson and James Callaghan during an 18-year career in the House of Commons, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Father-Son Conflict Played for Laughs
description: At 35, Buddy Apple is still subject to the iron whim of his father, a wealthy St. Louis contractor and real-estate entrepreneur. He is busily working his way up in the family business while hoping to be a screenwriter. Jerry Mayer's ''Almost Perfect'' (at the Hudson Guild Theater) is a comedy about the awakening of Buddy, or, in the words of the play, the making of a mensch. As such, it is only mildly engaging and it is short on originality.

title: Reviews/Television; A View of the Vatican
description: Don't let tonight's promise by ''48 Hours'' of a ''behind the scenes'' look at the Vatican raise your expectations too high. Although, as the correspondents keep reminding us, we are allowed glimpses of areas off limits to most tourists, the hour does not carry us very deeply into the workings of the city-state or the spirit of the papacy of John Paul II.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The results for the year-ago quarter were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Nets Shock Lakers in Overtime
description: If only the Nets could have more games like tonight's effort.

title: Article 792688 -- No Title
description: The typescript of Orson Welles's ''War of the Worlds,'' broadcast over CBS Radio on Halloween night in 1938, was auctioned yesterday for $143,000 at Sotheby's. The buyer was not identified. Howard Koch's 46-page adaptation of a story by H. G. Wells shocked hundreds of thousands of listeners who tuned in to the Mercury Theater presentation. The price paid was more than four times Sotheby's expectations, and is believed to be a record at auction for a radio script.

title: Jersey After Kean: Problems Persist
description: As more than a dozen politicians gird for a tumultuous race for Governor next year, New Jerseyans are beginning to contemplate what life will be like after Thomas H. Kean, whose buoyant smile, patrician's diction and unabashed boosterism have come to personify New Jersey in resurgence.

title: Chiron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Burma Leader Vows to Hold Vote But Will Not Say When
description: Burma's military leader, Gen. Saw Maung, today reaffirmed his commitment to multiparty elections but declined to say when they would be held.

title: Change Proposed In Toll Increase
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is recommending that its tolls be raised 50 cents in July rather than two 25-cent increases, next month and in two years.

title: Chicago Stripped of Immunity In Suits Over Airport Noises
description: A Federal court ruled Tuesday that the city can be sued for damages traced to noise from O'Hare International Airport, and the decision was hailed today as a breakthrough in efforts to reduce the din in suburban communities.

title: Missing Bank Officer Found; Apparent Kidnapping Victim
description: A bank officer who was reported missing a month ago after she withdrew a ''substantial amount of money'' was found, naked and hysterical, outside a closed pizza parlor early today, the police said.

title: HANOI TO RETURN MORE U.S. REMAINS
description: The Pentagon announced today that Vietnam intends to turn over to the United States what could be the largest single group of remains of American servicemen missing from the Vietnam War.

title: Found at Last: A Truly Black Flower
description: PEOPLE can be as gullible about plants as about anything else, and the history of horticulture is filled with lore that is no less fascinating for being false.

title: Service in New York for Armenian Victims
description: Armenians from the New York metropolitan region joined members of the clergy, community leaders and government representatives at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan last night in an emotional prayer service for the victims of the Armenian earthquake.

title: Derailment Forces Evacuation
description: Two derailed railroad cars leaking liquid propane forced the evacuation of some 100 residents today and closed a major highway and rail routes about 10 miles east of Flagstaff.

title: Robert Pelletreau: Longtime Mideast Figure
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz picked Robert H. Pelletreau Jr. as the sole authorized contact between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization, it was not the first time the 26-year Foreign Service veteran had been tapped for a highly sensitive mission.

title: Bridge
description: The tournament finale of 1988 for metropolitan area players, the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regional, begins tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue. This is the schedule: Tomorrow - Men's Pairs, Women's Pairs, Senior Pairs, 2 and 8 P.M.; Knockout Teams, 8 P.M. Saturday - 49er Pairs and Newcomer Pairs, 1 P.M.; Open Pairs, 1 and 7:30 P.M.; 49er Pairs and Newcomer Pairs, 7:30 P.M. Sunday - 49er Swiss Teams, 12:30 P.M.;

title: United Education & Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $6,486,000 and $5,470,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included net from discontinued operations of $533,000 and $1,263,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Bishop Found Guilty In Abortion Protest
description: A Roman Catholic bishop and another man were convicted yesterday of disorderly conduct for their refusals to comply with police orders June 11 at an anti-abortion protest.

title: Kasler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Music; Mixed Program by Boehm Quintette
description: The Boehm Quintette celebrated its 20th anniversary Sunday night at Weill Recital Hall with an inventive and well-played program. There was Mozart in transcription - a ''humanized'' wind version of his F-minor Fantasy for mechanical clock. As arranged by Wolfgang Sebastian Meyer, it remains a rich piece, one that transcends its medium and loses little definition with infusions of flesh and blood.

title: Review/Music; Lincoln Center Chamber Group Plays Schuller
description: The coming change of roster at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has been in the news recently and has been attended by a certain amount of acrimony. But as the best artists always do, those who are staying, those who are going and the fellow who sent some of them on their way all sat down together in civilized musical discourse Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Huffman Koos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: West Virginians Are Out $200 Million
description: It looked like a good deal to the investors: a return of 12 to 14 percent on their money when just about everybody else was lucky to get 8 percent.

title: Vietnam Devaluation
description: Vietnam announced today that it was devaluing its currency, the dong, to 2,800 to the dollar. The dong, which had been artificially held at 368 to the dollar by the Government, had already been devalued to 2,600 in the last few weeks without any formal announcement.

title: At China Hilton, Subject Was Butter
description: A staff member at the new five-star Hilton International Hotel was officially detained and made to apologize publicly after slapping a guest. Sanitation inspectors imposed fines on the hotel for dirt in its kitchen. And the hotel got into a battle over butter with the Shanghai Tourism Bureau.

title: Boiler Failures Force Pupils Out of Classrooms in Bronx
description: Scores of pupils have been forced out of their classrooms in a Bronx elementary school by boiler failures, a situation that is representative of the crumbling, outmoded and inefficient school buildings in the city, officials said yesterday.

title: 'Right of All Parties' Accepted by Arafat
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said Wednesday that he accepted ''the right of all parties concerned in the Middle East conflict to exist in peace and security.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. We recently moved into a year-old house that apparently has a problem with the hot-water pipes. When we turn on the hot water in the upstairs bathroom, it takes from 45 to 100 seconds for hot water to come out of the faucet; meanwhile, we are wasting all that water. Can you suggest how this problem can be solved?

title: Currents; An All-American Look In a High-Tech Setting
description: THE initials may be the same, but the emphasis at Lillian August is as all-American as Laura Ashley is British. Recently, the Lillian August flagship store opened at 17 Main Street, in Westport, Conn., stocked with wall coverings, linens, crafts and clothing that had been available only by mail order.

title: Agency for Building Schools
description: Governor Cuomo and legislators say they have agreed on a bill for an authority to oversee construction of New York City schools. Page B19.

title: Milken's Departure Said to Be Considered
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael R. Milken, the head of its ''junk bond'' department, have decided that Mr. Milken will leave the firm if his presence stands in the way of a settlement of the expected criminal charges against the investment house, people at Drexel and close to Mr. Milken said yesterday.

title: Teacher in Drug Case Gets Support at School
description: Ramon Diaz was the kind of teacher parents dream about. They say he was kind and caring and devoted to the poor children who filled his fourth-grade classes at Public School 5 in the Bronx.

title: CARDINAL TESTIFIES IN SUIT BY PRIEST
description: James Cardinal Hickey, the Archbishop of Washington, was the first witness today in a trial that promises to raise delicate questions of a professor's claims to academic freedom versus a church-affiliated university's claims to religious freedom.

title: At Long Last, Heat Win First
description: The Miami Heat won their first game ever in the National Basketball Association tonight. The expansion team ended a record 17-game losing streak by beating the Los Angeles Clippers, 89-88, behind Pat Cummings and Jon Sundvold.

title: Regulation By the States Is Debated
description: A REPRESENTATIVE of the National Association of Attorneys General walked into a den of angry advertisers yesterday and defended his organization's efforts to regulate national marketing practices, saying it ''does not have a chilling effect on honest advertising.''

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Drop
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved lower yesterday, with the bulk of the losses recorded among long-term issues.

title: Patron Wins Case Against Bar
description: A jury awarded $1.25 million to a bar patron who was burned and disfigured by an out-of-control flaming rum drink. The verdict against Danny's Bar was in addition to the $250,000 Charles McCarthy received in a settlement with Seagram Company Limited. A bartender was making Mr. McCarthy the rum drink when flames from the glass ignited a bottle of Seagram's rum.

title: 'Lawrence of Arabia' The Way It Should Be
description: Stephen Spielberg was musing about ''Lawrence of Arabia'' yesterday before a news conference in Manhattan at which the American Film Institute and Columbia Pictures announced a multimillion-dollar restoration and re-release of the 1962 Sir David Lean film, which won seven Oscars.

title: Dart Group Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss on the repurchase of debentures of $108,000 and a tax credit of $2,826,000. c-Net loss and included losses on the repurchase of debentures of $281,000 for the quarter and $650,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months included results of Jumbo Food Stores Inc., consolidated for the period June 30 to Oct. 31.

title: Fateful Mideast Turn
description: The United States' decision to open ''a substantive dialogue'' with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which was announced tonight by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, constitutes a notable turn - and quite possibly a historic one - in the nation's foreign policy.

title: Career Officer Looks to His Next Post: the U.N.
description: The Foreign Service is uniquely American. Career diplomats with no experience in the private sector are sent abroad to defend free enterprise; they promote freedom of expression while suppressing their own opinions and, no matter how fast they rise, they cannot expect to reach the top. No career diplomat has ever been appointed Secretary of State.

title: Youth Convicted of Murder; Jury Splits on Death Penalty
description: A teen-ager was convicted today of killing a state lawmaker and the judge in the case sentenced him to life in prison after a jury could not decide whether he should die in the electric chair.

title: Currents; When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Steelcase Business Equipment chair by Frank Lloyd Wright, for S. C. Johnson & Son Inc., late 1930's. B. Brueton Industries Moon chair designed by Stanley Jay Friedman, 1988.

title: Close to Home
description: IT was a year ago almost to this day, and my daughter and I were heading uptown. There was a green corduroy jumper marked down at Macy's, and since her profession, though noble, is ill paid she wanted another eye on the purchase. This is not a woman who drops $40 lightly.

title: Ads Warning Drug Dealers
description: Emanuel P. Popolizio, chairman of New York City's Public Housing Authority, plays Eliot Ness in a new series of public service advertisements that warn drug dealers, ''Stay the hell out of public housing, or we'll nail you.''

title: A Billion-Dollar Bid By CBS Wins Rights To Baseball Games
description: CBS won the auction to televise major league baseball yesterday with a bid that will pay the 26 teams nearly $1.1 billion for four years starting in 1990.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe's Creatures
description: Things sizzled and seethed after a cool start on Saturday afternoon at City Center, when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented a program of dances by Ulysses Dove, Elisa Monte and Mr. Ailey.

title: Topps Company reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: U.S. Vetoes Resolution Deploring Israeli Raid
description: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have ''strongly deplored'' the Israeli attack against Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon last Friday.

title: Belfast Journal; Where They Go to School to Learn Not to Hate
description: Standing as symbols of change in a minefield of sectarian hatred is a dangerous proposition for the students and faculty of Hazelwood College.

title: Motel 6 Purchase
description: Motel 6 Inc., which operates a chain of economy motels, said it would acquire the 49 motels of Sixpence Inns of America Inc. for about $200 million. Motel 6 said it would finance the deal with cash on hand and $40 million raised through the sale of partnerships.

title: Text of Koch Letter to Cuomo Seeking Inquiry on Schools
description: Over the past weeks the faith of New Yorkers in their public school system has been severely tested by a series of revelations and allegations about corrupt practices of certain community school board officials and administrators. According to reports from local law-enforcement officials, a number of community school boards are now under investigation regarding possible criminal activities.

title: Malone Becomes A Major Force
description: Karl Malone was called the Mailman at Louisiana Tech because he delivered, but now in the National Basketball Association, Malone is known as the power forward because he is.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Pop Life column yesterday misidentified the club where Sonny Bono is playing a four-day engagement. It is the Bottom Line, not the Village Gate.

title: Injunction Lifted On Bid for Polaroid
description: Shamrock Holdings, the investor group that is pursuing the Polaroid Corporation, said a Federal District Court in Delaware had lifted a preliminary injunction against its hostile tender offer of $42 a share, or $2.6 billion. Shamrock began its bid in September, and the offer has been tied up in legal wrangling since then.

title: Parent & Child
description: HAROLD MOE is not sure why his children treated their allowances so differently. When his daughter, Kari, was 5 years old, she would dutifully take one of the three dollars she received and put it in a savings account. She spent the remainder on books. His son, Rolf, was a different story.

title: System Software Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Reflected an accounting change which added $300,000, or 6 cents a share, in the first quarter.

title: Texas Air Halts Some Dividends
description: Citing higher losses at its two subsidiaries, the Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it would not declare quarterly dividend payments of about $5.2 million on its four outstanding issues of preferred stock.

title: Bronx Zoo Manager To Run Rye Playland
description: The general manager of the Bronx Zoo was named yesterday to be the new director of the Rye Playland Amusement Park, which has been plagued by scandals over the last year.

title: Taylor Is an All-Star but Carson Is Not
description: Of the 41 National Conference players named today to play in the Pro Bowl, the only Giant was Lawrence Taylor at outside linebacker. He became the first player to be chosen by players and coaches for the post-season all-star game in each of his first eight seasons.

title: Pretoria Jails More Militants
description: A justice of South Africa's Supreme Court today sentenced a guerrilla commander in the African National Congress and nine other men to prison terms of 2 to 15 years for grenade and mine attacks. Four of the men were given suspended sentences. All of the convicted men are of mixed race.

title: Calmat Sets Sale
description: The Calmat Company, a leading cement maker, said it had agreed to sell nearly all its income-producing real estate to the Shidler Group, a Honolulu-based realty concern, for $112 million. The deal includes two million square feet of Calmat's office parks and industrial buildings in Los Angeles, San Diego and Phoenix.

title: Court Case Links Aquino Allies to Bomb-Making
description: Documents filed in Federal District Court here link three Philippine officials allied with President Corazon C. Aquino to bomb-making and interstate transportation of weapons in the early 1980's.

title: Expert on Farm Issues: Clayton Keith Yeutter
description: Ever since graduating from the University of Nebraska in 1952 and being honored as the Outstanding Animal Husbandry Graduate in the Nation, Clayton K. Yeutter has had a yen to be Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the dismantling of the Cityspire dome in Manhattan misstated the history and status of the building. The building is 11 feet taller than allowed by a special zoning permit. The dome is being disassembled under an agreement between the developer and the Koch Administration because its construction violated an earlier agreement to stop work on top of the building until the zoning matter was resolved. A resolution has tentatively been reached, subject to approval by the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.

title: Stull Is Named Missouri Coach
description: Bob Stull, credited with reviving Texas-El Paso's dismal football program in three seasons, was hired today to pull Missouri out of a string of five straight losing seasons. The 43-year-old Stull was given a five-year contract at a base salary of $85,000 a year.

title: Neutrogena Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for 1987 reflected a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Jan. 15, 1988. Sales represent net sales.

title: Italian Chemical Merger Advances
description: The Italian chemical giant Montedison S.p.A. approved a plan to merge most of its chemical activities with those of the state energy group Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi. The decision completes a significant reorganization of Italy's chemical industry intended to create a company with sufficient size to compete in international markets.

title: By Tradition, Families Help The Neediest
description: Every year for the last 60, Hortense M. Hirsch of Manhattan has sent a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of her son, John Walter Hirsch, who died at the age of 3 in 1917.

title: Lawsuit Filed in Death of Chicago Boy
description: The mother of a 9-year-old boy, who died Monday after paramedics refused to enter a South Side public housing project where they said their ambulance was pelted with stones and eggs, today filed a $60 million suit against the Chicago Fire Department.

title: Record for Wheat Seen
description: World wheat production could reach a record 550 million metric tons in the 1989-90 season, the International Wheat Council said today. This would be five million tons more than expected consumption and would allow a rebuilding of world stocks, said the council, the leading forecasting body for wheat. Stocks built up during the glut of the mid-1980's are being depleted this season because of the sharp drop in 1988-89 wheat production caused by drought in the United States and Canada. World production for 1988-89 is now forecast at 500 million tons, 13 million below the previous season's figure.

title: B.P. May Sell Mining Interests
description: The British Petroleum Company said it might sell its huge mineral interests to the RTZ Corporation, a British-based international mining group. B.P. said it was negotiating ''on an exclusive basis'' to sell B.P.'s mineral interests. The discussions do not include BP Canada.

title: Right of All Parties Accepted by Arafat
description: GENEVA--Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said Wednesday that he accepted ''the right of all parties concerned in the Middle East conflict to exist in peace and security.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Alpine Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,301,000 for the quarter and $1,762,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $132,000 and $126,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results have been reclassified to reflect the discontinuance of American Trim Products Inc. and Precision Products Inc.

title: A 'Checkmates' Producer Is in Prison for Shooting
description: A co-producer of the Broadway play ''Checkmates'' is serving a 28-year-to-life sentence for attempted murder and has been indicted by the United States Attorney's office in Los Angeles on charges of being part of an international cocaine ring.

title: Democrats' Contest Widens and Takes Twist
description: The contest for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee expanded today and took a strange twist.

title:
Talking Deals;
Chicken Business Attracts Big Bids
description: LEAD: OVERSHADOWED but not to be overlooked in the recent wave of takeover bids are the two battles involving America's powerful taste for chicken. Tyson Foods Inc. wants to dominate the chicken supply business by acquiring the Holly Farms Corporation. And Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits wants to become the nation's second largest fast-food chicken chain by acquiring Church's Fried Chicken

title: Personal Health
description: This is the season that puts millions of digestive tracts to the acid test. Combine overwork and the holiday rush with rich food and drink, an ever-tightening waistband and perhaps overindulgence in coffee to help keep you going and you've set the stage for acid indigestion.

title: 5-Year-Old Brooklyn Girl Dies
description: A five-year-old Brooklyn girl who officials said appeared to have been physically abused, died last night after she was found unconscious in her mother's apartment, the police said.

title: Agenda for the Next Social Sceurity Generation; Share the Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Chief Quits At Nippon Telegraph
description: The chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation resigned today as evidence emerged that he had secretly received about $80,000 from a company seeking favors from the communications giant.

title: Dentists Welcome Plaque Fighters Despite Scarcity of Data on Benefits
description: New dental products intended to combat plaque and tartar buildup are gaining acceptance from the public and professionals, but information on the effectiveness of many such products remains scarce, experts say.

title: Pact Reported on New School Agency
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders said today that they had broken a yearlong stalemate and agreed on a bill to create an authority to oversee construction of New York City schools.

title: 3 ARABS DEPORTED FROM GAZA STRIP
description: Three Palestinians were deported from the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip to the Bekaa today, the police said, bringing to 36 the number of deportees sent to Lebanon in a year.

title: Squirrels Enjoy a Temporary Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawrence Goldberger, Executive, 53
description: Lawrence Goldberger, the president of Garden State Brickface and Stucco, of Roselle, N.J., died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan after emergency surgery for an aneurysm. He was 53 years old and lived in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Reviews/Television; Inspector Morse Is Back on 'Mystery'
description: Now that Sherlock Holmes has completed his stint for the season, Chief Inspector Morse is coming back to public television's ''Mystery'' for several weeks. Played by John Thaw, Morse - he never uses a first name - lives in present-day Oxford. A middle-aged bachelor, he is an expert on ales served at the local pubs. He is an opera buff, and his car of choice is a spiffy red Jaguar with a first-rate audio system for his classical tapes. Berlioz is a favorite. In an adaptation by Julian Mitchell from the stories of Colin Dexter, Morse can be seen - tonight at 9 on Channels 21 and 31, Saturday at 10 on Channel 13 - in a two-parter titled ''The Wolvercote Tongue.'' Alastair Reid is the director, Kenny McBain the producer and Ted Childs the executive producer for Zenith Productions. And Mr. Thaw's Morse is, of course, the best reason for watching.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Lou Gorman, general manager, to a four-year contract extension, effective Feb. 1. Assigned Zach Crouch; John Trautwein; Dan Gabriele; John Leister and Josias Manzanillo, pitcher, outright to Pawtucket of the International League. CHICAGO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Domingo Ramos, infielder. BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Waived Shelton Jones, forward. COLLEGES ARIZONA - Announced that Mark Georgeson, freshman center, will transfer to Pepperdine for the spring semester. GEORGIA - Announced the resignation of Vince Dooley, football coach, effective Jan. 2. MISSOURI - Named Bob Stull football coach. FOOTBALL CLEVELAND (AFC) - Signed Steve Slayden, quarterback. Placed Charles Buchanan, defensive end, on injured reserve. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Placed Tony Elliott, nose tackle, on injured reserve. Signed Jon Dumbauld, defensive lineman.

title: North Carolina Fugitive Held After Upstate Crash Into Bus
description: Timothy Jacobs, a fugitive who has been sought on 14 kidnapping charges stemming from a takeover of a newspaper office here, was arrested Tuesday near Oneida, N.Y., after a high-speed police chase that ended when his automobile crashed into the back of an empty schoolbus, the authorities said.

title: Calendar: Holiday Festivities
description: 19th-Century Seaport, South Street Seaport Museum Visitors' Center, Water Street at Fulton Street; 212-669-9416.

title: On Being First Lady
description: Nancy Reagan says that she has no advice to offer Barbara Bush on the tribulations of being the First Lady, although she suggested that it was considerably more difficult than being Second Lady, an experience that Mrs. Bush has gone through for eight years as the wife of the Vice President.

title: Catharine O'Brien, 95, Ex-College Official
description: Sister Catharine Marie O'Brien, a former chief executive of the College of Mount St. Vincent, died Tuesday at the Convent of Mary the Queen in Yonkers, where she lived. She was 95 years old.

title: Andrew Young Backs Move On Meeting With the P.L.O.
description: Mayor Andrew Young, who was forced more than nine years ago to resign as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations for meeting with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today applauded the American decision to initiate contacts with the P.L.O. He said he only regretted the bloodshed that had occurred because ''people were not ready for this before now.''

title: Text of Reagan Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan on American relations with the Palestine Liberation Organization, as issued tonight by the White House:

title: After Fall From Power, an Assemblyman Resigns
description: Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, a Nassau Democrat who plummeted from power after he unsuccessfully sought the Assembly Speaker post, resigned his Assembly seat yesterday, less than two months after he had been re-elected and two weeks before he was to begin his new term.

title: Books of The Times; A Nuclear Pragmatist Offers Hope
description: Danger and Survival Choices About the Bomb in the First Fifty Years By McGeorge Bundy 735 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Setting Price of a Barrel Isn't Oil Blackmail
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Rejected on House Destroyed in Bombing
description: A Federal district judge refused today to stop the city from selling a house rebuilt on property where the police attacked the radical group Move three years ago, killing 11 of its members.

title: Moreland Act of 1907: Governors' Strong Suit
description: The Moreland Act, a 1907 state law that is the basis of Mayor Koch's call for a state investigation of the Community School Boards, was born of a Governor's frustrated attempts to remove a recalcitrant Insurance Superintendent.

title: ISRAELIS EXPRESS SHOCK AND DISMAY
description: The American decision to initiate a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization met with surprise and dismay from Israeli envoys tonight.

title: Gorman Rewarded
description: Lou Gorman, who has helped the Boston Red Sox to an American League pennant and an East Division championship in five years as general manager, was rewarded yesterday with a four-year contract extension beginning on Feb. 1.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Long March Is Still Ahead For Women
description: Only a few women who are political leaders rule tens of millions of people, and so names like Thatcher and Bhutto resonate as symbols as well as surnames. But who has heard of Gu?

title: Value Line Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included capital gains of $105,000 for the quarter and capital losses of $108,000 for the 6 months. c-Included capital gains of $995,000 and $920,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Justice Dept. Rules Job Safety Law Fails To Shield Employers
description: Employers whose workers are killed or injured on the job can be prosecuted for murder, manslaughter or assault under state laws and cannot seek refuge under Federal laws on workplace safety, the Justice Department said in an opinion made public today.

title: Not Quite Sisters, but More Than Friends
description: LEAD: WHEN Merna was 9 years old and first heard she was getting a Big Sister she was very excited. ''I thought it meant a sister to live with,'' said Merna, now a 14-year-old eighth grader. ''Then suddenly I met this big lady. 'That's my sister?' I said. 'She could be my mother.' That probably wasn't the best thing to say but she liked me anyway.

title: Changes at Wolfensohn
description: James D. Wolfensohn Inc., a Wall Street investment banking firm, said yesterday that it had reorganized as a partnership and named four partners who have been senior investment bankers at the firm. They are Jeffrey A. Goldstein, Glen S. Lewy, Stuart W. Ray and Elliott K. Slade 3d. James D. Wolfensohn remains president and chief executive and Paul A. Volcker chairman. Alexander M. White, a senior investment banker, announced his plans to retire in mid-1989, the firm said.

title: Lawsuit Settled For Metrotech; Work Is to Start
description: The developers of the huge Metrotech project in downtown Brooklyn said yesterday that they had reached an out-of-court settlement with a group of business people and neighborhood residents who were trying to block the project. They said demolition would begin next week.

title: BUSH SAYS TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS MUST BE DELAYED
description: President-elect Bush said today that there was ''no way'' his administration could meet the mid-February starting date set by the Reagan Administration for resuming strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. trade deficit narrowed modestly in October to $10.3 billion, as imports declined twice as much as exports. The $400 million improvement, though about as expected, was far less than in September, and economists were divided on its significance. [ Page A1. ] Business inventories in October rose at the slowest rate in five months, while sales surged a strong 1.2 percent. [ D22. ] Industry is using more of its capacity than at any time in nine years. [ D22. ] Sales of cars and light trucks fell 10.6 percent in the first 10 days of December from the comparable period last year. [ D22. ] COMPANIES CBS won the rights to televise major league baseball, paying $1 billion for four years starting in 1990. It will broadcast the World Series, the All-Star Game, the league playoffs and 12 regular-season games. NBC said it had been outbid by a substantial margin. [ A1. ] Michael R. Milken will leave Drexel Burnham Lambert as part of any plea-bargaining deal the firm reaches with the Government. That understanding reflects the Government's insistence that Mr. Milken leave. [ D1. ] R. H. Macy is grappling with uncertain sales, pressure to cut prices and the costs of its acquisition of two California fashion retailers. It reported a $19 million loss in its latest quarter. [ D1. ] Shares of First Fidelity lost nearly a quarter of their value after the banking company's announcement that it expected to post a loss of $145 million to $190 million for the current quarter because of bad loans and that two top officers had resigned. [ D2. ] Texas Air will not declare quarterly dividend payments of about $5.2 million on four outstanding issues of preferred stock, citing higher losses at its Continental and Eastern units. [ D5. ] Barry J. Minkow was found guilty of 57 counts of securities fraud and conspirary charges stemming from the collapse of his ZZZZ Best carpet-cleaning company. [ D13. ] Donald J. Trump holds a substantial stake in Caesars World and MCA but is unlikely to try to take over either company, people close to him said. Caesars stock price climbed on the news. [ D5. ] A jury in Texas found Tenneco liable for $600 million in damages in a contract dispute. Tenneco will appeal. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL The chairman of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone resigned amid evidence that he had secretly received about $80,000 from a company seeking favors from the communications giant. [ D1. ] MARKETS The stock market sold off in relatively listless trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 9.24 points, to 2,134.25. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower, with the bulk of the losses recorded among long-term issues. [ D15. ] The dollar declined after the trade report for October showed little improvement over September, as traders speculated about the effect of interest-rate increases in Europe. [ D16. ] Energy futures prices surged on the New York Merc after Norway said it would reduce its daily oil output by 7.5 percent. [ D16. ] The Birr, Wilson brokerage in San Francisco abruptly shut, blaming poor market conditions. [ D23. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds in the recent week. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS America's taste for chicken is behind two takeover battles: Tyson's pursuit of Holly Farms, and Popeye's bid to acquire Church's. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Companies may have to mark down ''unbundled stock units'' to persuade investors to accept them. Market Place. [ D8. ] State attorneys general and the advertising industry are at odds over increased activity by state officials. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: 4 MEN ARE ACCUSED OF ELECTION FRAUD
description: Four local businessmen have been indicted for a scheme to aid the 1986 re-election campaign of Senator Alan Cranston, the United States Attorney here announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Tuesday about the Stephen Petronio company reversed the meaning of a sentence by omitting the word ''not.'' The sentence should have read, ''Surely Mr. Petronio does not aim to have his own work erased.''

title: Krelitz Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Museum Memorializes Life in Tenements
description: LEAD: IN the dard abandoned rooms of a Lower East Side tenement, the narrow hallways, small rooms and crude one-toilet cubicles off the halls evoke a grim, enclosed world. But layers of peeling wallpaper depicting countryside scenes yield brittle hints of a brighter world.

title: 2 Policemen Are Indicted In Park Melee
description: Two police officers have been indicted on assault charges for kicking a man during a wild police confrontation with hundreds of people in Tompkins Square Park on the Lower East Side last August, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: New Thompson Office
description: J. Walter Thompson will open a small office in Minneapolis to service its 45th Ford Dealer Association account, the Twin Cities District, which covers dealers in Minnesota, Iowa, North Dakota and South Dakota. (Twenty-two Ford Dealer Associations still park their accounts elsewhere.) Thompson estimates the account for the Twin Cities District Ford Dealers Association will bill $5 million a year. Creative work will come out of the agency's Detroit office, as does most of the deale

title: Crocker's Triumph, Reagan's Loss
description: After years of false starts, the Reagan Administration has achieved a diplomatic triumph in southern Africa. Angola, Cuba and South Africa have at last negotiated an agreement providing independence for Namibia and a phased withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola.

title: San Jose Interested
description: A group in San Jose, Calif., officially began a campaign yesterday to bring an expansion team to the San Francisco Bay area. The group, N.H.L. Hockey San Jose, said that the downtown arena scheduled to open in 1992 and the Bay Area's population of 5.5 million made it a strong contender.

title: G.M. Buyback
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would repurchase up to 2.75 million shares of its class E stock, whose earnings are based on the performance of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, its Dallas-based subsidiary. G.M. said it was buying the shares on behalf of E.D.S., which needed them to finance its employees' benefit plans.

title: Leading Soviet Jew to Be Allowed to Leave
description: Yuli M. Kosharovsky, a radio electronics engineer who represented Soviet Jews in a meeting with President Reagan in Moscow last spring, has been granted permission by the Soviet authorities to emigrate to Israel, an official of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry said here today.
