title: Youth Held in Thefts From Queens Banks
description: A 17-year-old was arrested after a predawn bank burglary yesterday, and the police said he was part of a gang that had been stealing coins from as many as 40 banks in Queens.

title: Review/Music; Echo Handbell Ringers
description: Handbell ringing is perceived -when it is perceived at all by busy, secular urbanites - as an Anglo-American phenomenon. In the 19th century, teams of handbell ringers, playing sentimentalized standards and specially composed numbers, proliferated in England, and soon spread to the United States. The practice persists, often sponsored by churches; indeed, every spring there is a handbell-ringing festival at the Riverside Church, in which hundreds of earnest ringers, observed by their equally earnest audiences, fill the vast space with chiming sonorities.

title: Softech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $230,000, or 6 cents a shae, for a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: In Geneva, Arab Joy and Exultation
description: The American decision to begin a ''sustantative dialogue'' with the Palestine Liberation Organization was greeted with joy early today by several Arab foreign ministers and senior Palestinian officials here, who said it opened the way to resolve the 40-year-old Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Israel Expresses Shock
description: Israeli officials who learned of the American decision on talks with the P.L.O. early today said they were shocked and disappointed.

title: Fire Ants to Make Building Of Atom Smasher No Picnic
description: Researchers who hope to study the secrets of nature at the Government's planned $4.4 billion atom smasher may first need protection from a venomous ant with a penchant for munching its way through underground cables.

title: PUBLIC PLAN ASKED ON ATOMIC CLEANUP
description: A group of Democratic and Republican lawmakers joined by 18 citizens' groups urged the Energy Department today to conduct a comprehensive public review of its plans for modernizing and cleaning up the nation's crippled atomic arms industry.

title: ADC Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lilco Tastes RICO Justice
description: The 1970 Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Or-ganizations Act, known as RICO, comes under fresh attack whenever it results in huge civil damages for fraud. The most recent case in point: the $22.8 million award against the Long Island Lighting Company. RICO may need reforming - but not because of injustice to Lilco.

title: Cucos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $1,028,917 from an accounting change.

title: Cuba and Angola Are Said to Agree on U.N. Force
description: Cuba and Angola have agreed to the creation of an unarmed United Nations observer force to monitor the withdrawal of Cuban troops from the African country, a United Nations official said today.

title: Mitchell Energy & Developent Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $20,594,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income Results for the first two quarters of the latest year are restated as a result of an accounting change.

title: William F. Soskin, Psychologist, 72
description: William F. Soskin, a research psychologist who founded Project Community, a nationally recognized rehabilitation program for adolescent drug addicts at the University of California at Berkeley, died of lung cancer Dec. 2 at Stanford University Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Berkeley.

title: Bush Aides Seek Talks By Group of 7
description: President-elect Bush's economic team wants to have a seven-nation meeting ''early in the new year'' to set goals for the dollar and to coordinate economic policies, Treasury officials said today.

title: CALIFORNIA FACES TEACHER SHORTAGE
description: California schools are suffering from a severe shortage of bilingual teachers, leaving many districts unable to find enough qualified teachers to keep up with the sharply rising number of pupils who know little or no English.

title: One Dark Polish Undercurrent Stirs Another
description: The Poles relish their legends - when they are not being tormented by them. So a curious mixture of homage and horror emerged in Warsaw last week when several hundred invited guests gathered for the first Polish screening of a film that describes the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest by policemen. The screening was sponsored by Hybrydy, a Warsaw film club specializing in films that may not receive regular distribution.

title: Put Another Thousand In . . . .
description: WHAT, after all, can you buy for $8,000 this Christmas? A car, perhaps, but then you have to park it. A terrific computer system, yes, but with that you get social isolation. For about 40 people this year, the answer to the $8,000 question has been a 1,000-pound nickelodeon, shipped from Shakopee, Minn., a small city south of Minneapolis.

title: Right of All Parties Accepted by Arafat
description: GENEVA--Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said Wednesday that he accepted "the right of all parties concerned in the Middle East conflict to exist in peace and security.''

title: Currents; A Noisy Approach To Fighting AIDS
description: BLOW the Whistle'' on AIDS is a new campaign involving museums and galleries across the nation. People can buy a sterling silver or gold-plated whistle designed by Gerald Benney, an English silversmith, to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research (Amfar).

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Decline by 10.6%
description: The seven domestic automobile makers reported today that sales fell 10.6 percent in the first 10 days of December from the comparable period last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Presidential commission's recommendations for salary increases for top Federal officials misstated, in some copies, the recommendation for cabinet-level officers. It was for an increase to $155,000 a year, not $175,000.

title: Currents; For One Englishman, Difficult Art Is Good Art
description: AFTER seeing his work, people tend to ask Simon Moore, an English glassmaker, why he makes his life so difficult. ''I enjoy making a piece of glass that's complicated,'' said the 29-year-old, who is a partner in Glass Works, a London-based company, with Steven Newell and Catherine Hough.

title: 8,600 U.S. WORKERS FACE DRUG TESTING
description: About 8,600 employees of the Department of Health and Human Services will be subject to random drug testing under a plan announced today by Dr. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of the department.

title: Transcript of Bush's Remarks on Domestic and Foreign Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President-elect Bush's remarks and some of Clayton Y. Yeutter's remarks at a news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News: OPENING STATEMENTS

title: Legislative Snag Costs New York Thousands a Day in Sewage Aid
description: New York is losing tens of thousands of dollars a day because the State Legislature cannot agree on a measure to let the state obtain Federal funds for sewage treatment, state environmental officials say.

title: Holtz Is Named Coach of the Year
description: Lou Holtz, who guided Notre Dame to an 11-0 record and the No. 1 ranking, was named last night as the winner of the Bryant Award, given annually to the nation's top college football coach.

title: Metro Matters; 22 Degrees, A Chevrolet Bed And No Embers
description: Baltazar Morales pointed to the empty bottle of Cool Breeze, 18 percent alcohol and orange flavored, that marked the spot where Daniel Betford Burgos died.

title: 10 Years Later, Cleveland Is in Financial Health
description: Ten years after Cleveland became the first major city since the Depression to go into default, the city has slowly regained its financial credibility.

title: Congress Will Bar Honorariums as Soon as Pay Rises, Wright Says
description: The Speaker of the House, Representative Jim Wright of Texas, said today that Congress would bar its members from receiving virtually all honorariums and speaking fees on ''the day after'' they receive a pay increase.

title: Back to Levine, Huntley
description: Management Science America Inc., an Atlanta-based manufacturer of software for mainframe computers, has returned to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver after an absence of two years. The client, which advertises primarily in print, billed $5 million when it was at Levine in 1984-85, and agency executives said they assumed it would not be less this time around. Tucker Wayne & Company in Atlanta had the account in the interim.

title: N.C.A.A. Sees Right of Its Way in Ruling
description: For the last 12 years, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has sought recognition from the courts as a private entity answerable primarily to itself.

title: Believe It or Not, This Is About Dust
description: LEAD: Over in Cologne, West Germany, there is a fellow named Joachim Ronneper who collects dust. His lodgings, apparently, are literally stockpiled with it. The stuff is sealed in plastic packets, and his ambition is to exhibit it, in all its grimy varieties, in a European museum. This seems reasonable enough, for it all came from museums in the first place.

title: Conrail Names New Chairman
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said yesterday that its board had formally elected Richard D. Sanborn, president and chief operating officer, to the additonal posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: Few Women Attain Top Positions on Faculties
description: While more American women have become physicians in recent years, and more have become medical teachers, women still lag in winning top positions in medical education, a new report has found.

title: President Named Chief At Budget Rent-A-Car
description: The Budget Rent-A-Car Corporation, the nation's No. 3 car rental company, yesterday named its president, Clifton E. Haley, to the additonal posts of chairman and chief executive.

title: Cunningham Is Named to Start in Pro Bowl
description: The National Football League made a major symbolic shift in the Pro Bowl voting announced yesterday.

title: Fewer Guns and More Butter? Hungary Asks
description: As Hungarians contemplate Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for troop cuts in Eastern Europe, they appear to be hoping that fewer guns will mean more butter.

title: Whitman Bid For Kent Food
description: The Whitman Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the Orval Kent Food Company, a supplier of fresh salad products to markets, delicatessens and restaurants, for $212 million, including the assumption of debt.

title: Penn Traffic Co reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Included the writeoff of acquisition financing costs of $6.6 million (net of income tax benefit) in conjunction with the P&C Foods Inc. acquisition in August 1988. c-Net income The latest periods included the results of P&C Foods since Aug. 6, 1988.

title: Soviets Plan Quake Evacuation But the Survivors Seem Unwilling
description: One week after the mountains convulsed here in an earthquake of heartbreaking dimensions, the authorities laid plans today for a vast and probably forced evacuation of survivors who show little willingness to leave.

title: Bonn Defense Aide Resigns In Split Involving U.S. Crash
description: West Germany's No. 2 Defense Ministry official said today that he was resigning because of a dispute with the Defense Minister over a decision to suspend military training flights after the crash of an American attack jet.

title: Poor, Pregnant - and Dead
description: A 23-year-old Brazilian woman showed up at a Rio de Janeiro public hospital recently bleeding from a perforated uterus. Like many Latin American women, she had undergone a clandestine abortion. She died 24 hours later, of a massive infection.

title: Barnwell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Louisville Cleared
description: Donald Swain, the president of the University of Louisville, was notified on Monday by a National Collegiate Athletic Association official that the N.C.A.A. will not investigate a newspaper report that Tony Kimbro, a junior swingman, received grades that were higher than he merited during his senior year at Seneca High School in Louisville. The letter, from David Berst, the N.C.A.A.'s assistant executive director, read in part, ''Based on information you submitted, it does not appear that action on the matter is warranted by the N.C.A.A.'' Louisville started its own investigation of Kimbro's senior-year grades after an article appeared in The Courier-Journal Sept. 18. In the article, teachers said they felt pressured to give Kimbro A's or B's and quoted two who said they gave him undeservedly high grades. There were no charges against Kimbro or Louisville. In its report to the N.C.A.A., Louisville said the allegations were not credible and affirmed Kimbro's eligibility. The N.C.A.A. said that when former teachers and administrators at the school were interviewed, they all said they had no knowledge of academic favoritism for Kimbro or improper influence exerted on his grades.(AP)

title: POLL FINDS A DROP IN DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: A poll shows fewer Americans admit that they drink and drive today than three years ago, and the National Safety Council is attributing part of the decrease to a fear of being arrested.

title: Election Panel Certifies New York for Dukakis
description: The State Board of Elections has declared Governor Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts the winner of last month's Presidential election in New York, a spokesman for the board said today.

Operation California/U.S.A., 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Save the Children, 48 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn. 06880. Temple Beth-El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, N.J. 07304 U.S. Committee for Unicef, 331 East 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, N.Y. 10580. World Relief, P. O. Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. World Vision, Box 0, Pasadena, Calif. 91109. Apostolic Exarchate for the Armenian Catholics, 110 East 12th Street, New York, N.Y.10003

title: CBS Buying Radio Stations
description: CBS Inc. said today that it would buy two radio stations here.

title: Macy's, Loaded With Debt, Loses $19 Million in Quarter
description: A privately held company for the last two years, R. H. Macy & Company is grappling with uncertain sales, pressure to cut prices and the costs of a recent acquisition of two California fashion retailers.

title: Cavco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Capacity Use Highest In Nine Years
description: The nation's industry is using more of its capacity than at any time in nine years, the Government said today, heightening concerns that the economy will overheat and inflation accelerate.

title: How Bush Sees Quayle's Role
description: President-elect Bush today specified the role that he sees for Dan Quayle, the man who will occupy the job Mr. Bush held for the eight years.

title: Syracuse Sets Marks In Runaway Victory
description: Matt Roe tied his team record with six 3-point baskets and scored 24 points as Syracuse routed United States International, 135-93, tonight.

title: Stuart Symington, 4-Term Senator Who Ran for President, Dies at 87
description: Former Senator Stuart Symington, a Missouri Democrat who twice sought the Democratic Presidential nomination and was the first Secretary of the Air Force, died early yesterday at his home in New Canaan. He was 87 years old and had lived in retirement there since 1978.

title: Reviews/Music; A Piano Debut by Helen Lin
description: Helen Lin, a Taiwanese pianist who completed her studies at the Manhattan School of Music, made her New York debut at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon and impressed one as a player with well-formed interpretive ideas, supported by a strong but not infallible technique.

title: Nigerian Plane Crash Kills 9
description: A Nigerian cargo plane carrying flowers to Europe crashed early today near the ancient city of Luxor, killing all eight crew members and a villager, the police said. They said the plane was flying from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, to Brussels.

title: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
McDonnell Order
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had placed an order with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for jet aircraft worth up to $700 million. The company said it had placed firm orders for five MD-11 jets and had options to order another two. It said deliveries would start in the spring of 1992 and run through 1994.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, said J. Richard Kelso, chairman of its East Ohio Gas Co. subsidiary, would be replaced as president by Russell R. Gifford, effective Jan. 1.

title: Capasso Lawyer Says Prosecutors Abused Powers
description: With a combination of ridicule and blistering criticism, the lawyer for Carl A. Capasso in the Bess Myerson bribery trial accused prosecutors yesterday of abusing their power by relying on evidence supplied by people who, he said, would have failed in vaudeville.

title: Larry Davis Faces Sentencing Today
description: Larry Davis will be sentenced today on six counts of criminal possession of a weapon. The courtroom climax will be watched as closely by those who inhabit the grim streets of the South Bronx as by those who inhabit the city's highest offices.

title: Prague Plans to Stop Jamming of Broadcasts
description: Czechoslovakia plans to end its jamming of broadcasts by Radio Free Europe, the state press agency said today.

title: Collecting the Eighties: Stash the Swatch; Keep the Kettle
description: THE turnaround time for revivals is shrinking with each passing year. So compressed has the time frame become that it probably will not be long before artifacts from the 1980's will be considered collectible and historic. People will look back wistfully at the age of Ronald Reagan, oat bran muffins and the VCR.

title: Rangers Hand Islanders 11th Straight Loss
description: The Rangers didn't score many goals last night, but the Islanders hardly scored any, and that made all the difference.

title: Trump Plans to Build Caesars World Stake
description: Donald J. Trump owns a substantial amount of stock in both Caesars World Inc. and MCA Inc. but is unlikely to try to take over either company, people close to the New York real estate developer said yesterday.

title: Topics of The Times; The Gulag, Then and Now
description: A week ago, Soviet officials warily allowed A. M. Rosenthal and Philip Taubman of The Times and an American human rights monitor to visit Perm 35, a labor camp in the Urals. This seems to be the first time Western journalists have been permitted a glimpse of a Soviet penal colony for political offenders.

title: 2 Boys Held in Crack Case
description: Two boys, 10 and 13 years old, have been charged in Dorchester District Court with operating a sidewalk business peddling crack. They were arrested Friday.

title: Enzo Biochem Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $420,000 on the extinguishment of debt. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect an adjustment made in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988.

title: Herbert (Toubo) Rhoad, Singer, 44
description: Herbert (Toubo) Rhoad, a singer with the Persuasions, an a cappella group, died after a stroke last Thursday in Sacramento, Calif. He was 44 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Red-Light Runners Target of New Bill
description: The Legislature approved a bill yesterday that could clear New York City's use of electronic devices to snare drivers who run red lights. A yearlong test of the equipment has been inconclusive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19 The U.S. will talk with the P.L.O., President Reagan said. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said the American Ambassador in Tunisia will be ''the only authorized channel'' in the search for peace. Page A1

title: Education Chief Affirms Finding On Dual System
description: The State Education Commissioner, Dr. Thomas Sobol, said today that he agreed with the recent conclusions of a state task force that New York has two distinct school systems, one that is white and affluent and another that is poor and largely black and Hispanic.

title: San Francisco Brokerage Closes Its Doors Abruptly
description: Birr, Wilson & Company, a 30-year-old securities firm based here, abruptly ceased business operations last Friday and instructed personnel to seek employment elsewhere. The company, which employed 155 people in seven offices, said it closed because of poor stock market conditions.

title: Worthington Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago periods are restated.

title: COMPANIES IGNORE MEN'S HEALTH RISK
description: A study of 198 large chemical and electronics companies in Massachusetts has found that nearly one in five restrict women's work options on the ground of potential risk to their reproductive health but most ignored the reproductive hazards faced by men.

title: Customs Fraud Is Admitted
description: A Mount Kisco cheese importer, the Westland Cheese Company, and its general manager pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Customs Service of duty payments on imported cheese over a two-year period. The general manager, Jan Kos, 35 years old, of Mount Kisco, faces up to two years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The company could be fined $400,000.

title: Rural County Offers Land To Get People
description: A declining population has led a county in northern Minnesota to try a modern version of the nation's old homestead policy: anyone can claim up to 40 acres of land if the person builds a house and lives in it for 10 years.

title: Dow Falls 9.24 on Economic Uncertainty
description: LEAD: The stock market sold off in relatively listless trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 9.24 points to close at 2,134.25.

title: Dismissal in New Zealand
description: Prime Minister David Lange has dismissed his Finance Minister, a friend who had turned into a political foe, in a dispute over how fast the country should continue overhauling its economy, which had been tightly regulated.

title: Tenneco Found Liable for Over $600 Million in Damages
description: A state court jury in Wharton County, Tex., today found Tenneco Inc. liable for damages of more than $600 million in a gas contract dispute.

title: 3 Shot in New Orleans Post Office
description: A postal employee drew a shotgun at the main post office Wednesday night, wounded three people and remained in the building, possibly with hostages, the authorities said.

title: COLLEGE AID GROUP REPORTS SUCCESS
description: A study of the first comprehensive program that used private funds to help public school students graduate from high school and attend college has found that those who got significant help graduated from college at rates 60 percent above the national average.

title: Core Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Agenda for the Next Social Security Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: Transcript of Shultz's Remarks on United States' Stance Regarding P.L.O.
description: Following is a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Market Place; Price Markdown For New Units?
description: THE companies trying to issue ''unbundled stock units'' to the public may have to mark down the price to persuade investors to accept them, officials involved in marketing the securities acknowledged yesterday. They added that sales efforts for the new securities were being broadened in an effort to draw in more retail investors.

title: Dollar Falls as Trade Deficit Shows Little Improvement
description: The dollar declined yesterday after the October trade deficit report showed little improvement over September and as traders speculated about the impact of interest rate increases in Europe.

title: Review/Dance; Clashes of the Sexes
description: And now the Sex Pistols of dance, or just about. DV8 Physical Theater, a British troupe that made its United States debut Tuesday night in the Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, may be more stylized than the notorious English rock group of the 1970's, but it is equally impolite about its own society.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., said its Allied-Signal Aerospace unit had received a $36 million subcontract from Boeing Aerospace for work on a NASA space station.

title: Taking Metalwork Into a Modern Age
description: JAMES GARVEY has red hair, wire-rimmed glasses and jet-black finger tips. Mr. Garvey, who helped repair the structural grid work inside the Statue of Liberty in 1985, works with architects and designers and others to create custom pieces out of steel, brass and copper.

title: Maxwell to Sell 3 Macmillan Units
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who recently acquired Macmillan Inc., said he would sell Macmillan's remaining nonpublishing businesses, a move that was expected. Gumps, the venerable San Francisco specialty store, is among the three businesses put on the block. The other two are Katharine Gibbs Schools, a secretarial school, and Technical Schools, which offers career training programs.

title: Roadway Motor Plazas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Squirrels Enjoy a Temporary Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Clark Consolidated Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'Priority,' Not Threat
description: The letter to President-elect Bush seemed to have the echo of heavy artillery booming between the lines. It was from Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, who is chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, and it was intended, the Senator said, ''to advise you of a serious problem which must be resolved quickly.''

title: Co-op and Condo Buyers, Beware of Hazardous Conditions
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Ballet; 2 Debuts in 'Nutcracker'
description: The role of the Sugarplum Fairy's Cavalier in ''The Nutcracker'' is a small one. He does little more than appear in a pas de deux. Yet when good dancers are cast as the Cavalier, they can show off the ballerina portraying the Sugarplum Fairy as well as command attention with their own stage presence.

title: Pilots' Strike Curbs Alitalia
description: Alitalia canceled 28 national and 6 international flights today because of a strike by pilots. The pilots said they would strike for two hours today, Thursday and Friday to protest lack of progress in talks between union representatives and the state-run airline.

title: Review/Theater; In London, Taking Williams Seriously
description: In death, Tennessee Williams is more often regarded by the American theater as a tragic icon than as a playwright worthy of further artistic investigation. The reverse is true in London, where the Williams canon, neglected by the major companies during the writer's lifetime, is suddenly being rediscovered.

title: To the Young, Landmarks Aren't Relics
description: Three winning essays about the importance of New York City landmarks, selected from almost 750 entries by high-school students, add fresh voices to the perennial debate over what constitutes wise and humane urban development.

title: Topics of The Times; Containing Killer Oils
description: In response to consumer concern about cholesterol, many food manufacturers are switching from highly saturated coconut and palm oils to vegetable oils that are low in saturated fats. That is to be applauded. But it doesn't obviate the need for more stringent food labeling rules.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-After a gain of $199.1 million from discontinued operations. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $5.4 million for the quarter and $1.7 million for the 6 months.

title: 30th Anniversary of a Chicago School Disaster
description: In the 30 years since a fire at Our Lady of the Angels elementary school killed 92 children and three teachers, the school has been rebuilt and stronger safety measures are in effect at schools around the country.

title: Gillette Plans Campaign For Atra Plus Razors
description: The Gillette Company's North Atlantic Shaving division, Boston, has pumped $70 million into a yearlong global effort by the international staff at BBDO, New York, to promote the Atra Plus shaving system, a traditional cartridge razor that has been upstaged in recent years by disposable ones.

title: Control Data Plans Sale
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it planned to sell its Scientific Information Services business to the Power Computing Company. No price was disclosed. The unit markets time-sharing services to engineering, scientific and utility customers. Power Computing supplies computing services to the electric-power industry and to engineering and financial companies. It is a unit of McDermott International Inc.

title: Review/Music; Duo in 20th-Century Bill
description: Barbara Krakauer, a violinist, and Nancy Garniez, a pianist, are members of the Alaria Chamber Ensemble and also perform together as a duo. On Monday evening they made their joint New York debut at Town Hall, offering an inventive program devoted mostly to 20th-century music.

title: The Three Yesses
description: In the end, our unrelenting pressure paid off.

title: Inventory Rise Slows; Sales Surge
description: In another sign of a robust economy, business inventories in October rose at the slowest rate in five months, while sales surged a strong 1.2 percent.

title: AAR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ACT ON HOMELESS, GROUP URGES BUSH
description: With President-elect Bush preparing to take office in the dead of winter, several conservatives urged him today to make homelessness an immediate priority.

title: Lawrence Adler, 57, Australian Who Rose From Poverty to Riches
description: Lawrence Adler, an East European refugee who rose from office cleaner to become one of Australia's richest men, died on Tuesday. He was 57 years old.

title: JG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income

title: Tiger Discloses It May Get Offer
description: Tiger International Inc. said it had been approached by a party interested in acquiring the air cargo transportation company. Tiger did not identify the party. It said it had scheduled a special meeting of its board for Thursday to consider any offer that might be made.

title: Founder of ZZZZ Best Is Convicted
description: Barry J. Minkow, who founded the ZZZZ Best carpet-cleaning company as a teen-ager, was found guilty today on all 57 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy charges stemming from the collapse of his business in 1987.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I repeat for the record that we totally and absolutely renounce all forms of terrorism, including individual, group and state terrorism.'' - Yasir Arafat. [ A19:5. ]

title: Nigeria Air Cuts Jobs
description: Nigeria Airways has dismissed 3,000 workers, a third of the work force, in an effort to keep the bankrupt airline operating. Police surrounded the state airline's headquarters today to prevent attacks. Earlier this year the airline sharply reduced its overseas flights after accidents grounded some aircraft and two planes were seized for nonpayment of debts.

title: Shaklee Opposes Jacobs Stake
description: The Shaklee Corporation, concerned that the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs controls a 6.4 percent stake, said it would strengthen its shareholder rights plan.

title: Home Improvement
description: WALLBOARD, also called plasterboard, dry wall and Sheetrock, is by far the most commonly used material for interior walls and ceilings. It is also an excellent material for remodeling, one that can be used to build partition walls and room dividers, cover openings in existing walls and hide deteriorated surfaces.

title: Nordson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Personality Photos
description: Opening tonight at the One Club: a show of portraits of ad-industry personalities by Reuven Kopitchinski, a 33-year-old Israeli-born photographer. The 30 photographs include those of Phil Dusenberry, chairman of BBDO, New York; Jamie Seltzer, creative director of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, New York, and Helayne Spivak, Ammirati & Puris's award-winning writer. The show will remain at the One Club's gallery at 3 West 18th Street from Dec. 16 to Dec. 23, and again from Jan. 3 to Jan. 20.

title: NATO's Tactical Missiles: Updating Set Back
description: Last week's announcement at the United Nations by Mikhail S. Gorbachev of cuts in the Soviet armed forces dims the prospects for early modernization of NATO's short-range tactical nuclear weapons.

title: U.S. Jews Are Wary on Washington's Move to Talk to P.L.O.
description: Leaders of several major American Jewish organizations took a wary view yesterday of the decision by the United States to pursue a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization and urged negotiators to compel Yasir Arafat to back his statement on Israel's right to exist with more binding actions.

title: Reactor Unit Is Removed From Plant
description: Contractors dismantling the nation's first commercial nuclear power plant hoisted the plant's reactor vessel from its underground site here today in preparation for its 7,800-mile journey to a Federal dump in Hanford, Wash.

title: Budget Office Seeks Military Health Care Fees
description: The Office of Management and Budget is promoting a plan to begin charging military dependents and retirees fees for health care, an idea Congress banned two years ago when it was first proposed.

title: Lemieux Gets Lead From Absent Gretzky
description: Mario Lemieux scored two goals and had two assists to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 5-4 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Kings, who played without Wayne Gretzky.

title: INSIDE
description: Nationwide Strike in Spain Most of the labor force observed a one-day strike, underscoring discontent over the Socialist Government's economic policies. Page A3. Two Police Officers Indicted Aided by a videotape, a grand jury in Manhattan charged two officers with assault in the Tompkins Square Park melee last August. Page B1. Stuart Symington Dies The former Senator from Missouri, who twice sought the Democratic Presidential nomination, died at the age of 87. Page D26. A Symbolic Shift in N.F.L. For the first time in the history of the Pro Bowl, a black quarterback, Randall Cunningham of Philadelphia, was chosen to start. Page D27.

title: Reagan, Clearing Desk, Remembers College
description: A piece of flooring from the Oval Office, a commemorative jellybean jar, scores of autographed books and other White House memorabilia are piling up at Ronald Reagan's alma mater, Eureka College.

title: Any Coffee Table Would Be Uplifted
description: IT is understood, especially at this time of year, that glossy books on design and decoration make superior gifts. If the recipients are living in splendor, a book about the more splendiferous will add luster to their rooms. If the household is on the casual side, the right book will at least upgrade the coffee-table area.

title: Ford's Catalytic Converter Eliminates Use of Platinum
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had developed a catalytic converter that does not use platinum, but it declined to identify the new catalyst used in the anti-pollution device.

title: Shell Beach Journal; Delta Fishermen Watch As Man Eats at Marshes
description: As usual, the town topic in this small fishing village on Bayou Yscloskey 15 miles southeast of New Orleans is the marsh monster, ''Mr. G.O.,'' who eats marshes for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

title: Beepers Banned in Schools
description: The City Council unanimously approved an ordinance banning beepers in all public and private schools Wednesday, a move that educators say they hope will curb drug sales and prostitution.

title: Larry Davis Gets 5 to 15 Years For Conviction on Weapons
description: Larry Davis was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison for illegal weapons possession at the end of a tumultuous day of high drama in and around the Bronx County Courthouse.

title: Group Set to Buy Film Giant Pathe
description: A French investment group with ties to the American film maker Cannon Group Inc. is ready to take control of the French film company Pathe-Cinema in a deal valued at about $157 million.

title: Swedes Order Palme Suspect Held
description: A prosecutor ordered a 41-year-old Swede held in custody today in the slaying of Prime Minister Olof Palme, raising hopes for a solution to a mystery that has traumatized Sweden for nearly three years.

title: Quebec's French-Only Sign Law Voided
description: The Canadian Supreme Court today struck down a key provision in an 11-year-old Quebec law prohibiting the posting of signs in any language but French.

title: Price Lifts Cavaliers Over Pistons, 119-98
description: In a game matching two of the National Basketball Association's premier point guards, Mark Price was the clear winner.

title: As Hope Dies, Quake Rescuers Pull Out
description: Fatigued and increasingly despairing of finding survivors, hundreds of foreign rescue workers have begun withdrawing from northwest Armenia's earthquake zone to make way for Soviet demolition teams.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday, about the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, described new appointments incorrectly. J. Richard Kelso was named chairman of the company's East Ohio Gas Company subsidiary. Mr. Kelso will remain as chief executive and will be succeeded as president on Jan. 1 by Russell R. Gifford. Mr. Gifford was also named chief operating officer.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary yesterday about Sister Catharine Marie O'Brien, former president of the College of Mount St. Vincent, characterized the colleg incorrectly. Formerly a women's college, it has been coeducationsl since 1974.

title: A Public Piece of the Deal
description: Leveraged buyouts may be good or bad for American business but they are a windfall for the Securities and Exchange Commission. It reaped $7 million from the RJR Nabisco deal alone.

title: Report Finds Flaws in Fire Planning But Backs Policies as Basically Sound
description: Government investigators have upheld Federal firefighting policies as basically sound in the first detailed review of the policies since forest fires devastated Yellowstone National Park and other parts of the West.

title: Islanders Start Well but Wilt as Losing Streak Reaches 12
description: Coach Al Arbour began mopping his brow, which has grown more furrowed with each game, in the second period.

title: Greece, Haven for Terrorists
description: LEAD: Once again, the unprincipled men who run the Government of Greece are consorting with terrorists.

title: South Texans Fear an Influx of Aliens
description: A new immigration service policy threatens to burden South Texas with thousands of new Central American aliens, overwhelming public services in an impoverished area that can not care for the aliens already there.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ROBERT MOSES CENTENNIAL

title: INSIDE
description: Delicate Weapons Balance Picking an Energy Secretary has emerged as one of the most sensitive appointments facing President-elect Bush. News analysis, page A24. The Inflation Debate The Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates will go a long way toward setting the stage for more growth or a recession. News analysis, page D1. James Brown Sentenced The singer James Brown was sentenced to six years in prison for failing to stop in a car chase that stretched over two states. Page A28. Quebec Law Overturned The Canadian Supreme Court struck down an 11-year-old Quebec law prohibiting the posting of signs in any language but French. Page A3.

title: Singer James Brown Receives 6-Year Sentence in Car Chase
description: The soul singer James Brown was sentenced to six years in prison today for failing to stop for the police in a two-state automobile chase.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 459 money market mutual funds increased by $1.72 billion, to $281.22 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 136 institutional funds increased by $1.43 billion, to $73.3 billion. The assets of the 230 general-purpose funds were up by $170.1 million, to $90.06 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased by $117.7 million, to $117.86 billion, the institute said.

title: Machine Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Vernitron Proposes To Buy a Larger Rival
description: The Vernitron Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy the larger Kollmorgen Corporation, which also makes electromechanical components, for $20 a share in cash, or about $206 million.

title: Washington Scientific Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
Robert E. Urquhart, 87, Is Dead; Led British 'Bridge Too Far' Battle
description: Maj. Gen. Robert E. Urquhart, the British commander at the heroic but ill-fated Battle of Arnhem who tried to capture a bridge over the Rhine River, died Tuesday, his family said today. He was 87 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Swiss Unit of Y.&R. Merges With Advico
description: Advico, the fourth-largest ad agency in Switzerland, and Young & Rubicam Zurich, Y.&R.'s Swiss unit, have merged. Advico-Young & Rubicam will have total billings of $110 million, making the new entity the largest shop in Switzerland, according to Y.&R. Initially, a majority position will be held by Advico, which was founded in 1941. Young & Rubicam said it plans to take on a majority position eventually.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: General Instrument Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Arabs Welcome a U.S.-P.L.O. Dialogue
description: Officials and commentators in many parts of the Arab world responded warmly today to the United States decision to open a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, but said it was only a start in the longer process of securing Middle East peace.

title: New York Acts to Allow 'Poison Pills'
description: The State Legislature today made takeovers of New York corporations much more difficult by allowing companies to issue shareholder rights plans most commonly known as ''poison pills.''

title: Echlin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Albany Selects The 4 Campuses It Plans to Close
description: The City University School of Law, an academically troubled institution that won national acclaim for its innovative curriculum when it opened in 1982, is one of four campuses being considered for closing because of state budget pressures, education officials and legislative aides said yesterday.

title: A Solidarity-Warsaw Meeting Is Said to Be 'Close at Hand'
description: Lech Walesa said today that Solidarity and the Communist Government were close to opening formal talks on Poland's future.

title: U.N. Ends Its Session in Geneva, Approving 2 Mideast Resolutions
description: The United Nations General Assembly ended a three-day session here tonight by adopting two significant resolutions on the Middle East, with only the United States and Israel opposed.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Yomo Toro's Cuatro

title: Johnson Wax Goes Outside the Family
description: Samuel C. Johnson, family leader of the big and privately held Johnson Wax, has relinquished the post of chief executive to someone not in the family, Raymond F. Farley.

title: Osicom Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Valley Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Game A Week Helps
description: Pardon the nostalgia, but I am going to miss the Game of the Week when it passes after next season. I doubt very much that CBS will call its product the Game of Every Other Week.

title: Bergen Brunswig Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $606,000.

title: Major Jewish Group In U.S. Backs Shultz
description: The major umbrella organization of American Jews said yesterday that it would not fight the decision of the Reagan Administration to enter into talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Home Shopping Network reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 15
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $4.7 million from the repurchase of $20.3 million of the company's 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2002.

title: About Real Estate; A Sluggish Market Slows Sales at Stamford Project
description: An eerie stillness pervades Cambridge Court, a neo-Victorian development of 24 clapboard town houses and apartments completed in September in downtown Stamford, Conn.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Brown & Root Continues Changing of the Guard
description: LEAD: Brown & Root, a major international engineering and construction company, has elected W. Bernard Pieper president and chief operating officer.

title: David Stech, Art Director, 72
description: David Stech, a former associate art director of Life magazine, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Cape May Point, N.J. He was 73 years old and also had a home in Armonk, N.Y.

title: Sweden Chalks Up Points For Role as Go-Between
description: Sweden's active foreign policy is the reason this small but outspoken Scandanavian nation is sometimes called the world's leading exporter of unsolicited advice.

title: McRae Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Scheib (Earl) Inc.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: On Stage
description: 'Run for Your Wife'

title: Israel Leaders Unhappy; A Blunder, Shamir Says
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today called the United States decision to talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization a dangerous ''blunder'' that ''will not help us, not help the United States and not help the peace process.''

title: Pageantry to Help Celebrate a Glorious Day
description: Listed here are some of the Christmas operas, plays, celebrations and pageants planned in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Today CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The Ninth Annual Winter Consort Winter Solstice Whole Earth Christmas Celebration, featuring the Paul Winter Consort; Paul Winter, soprano saxophonist; Paul Halley, keyboardist and pipe organist; Glen Velez and Ted Moore, percussionists; Eugene Friesen, cellist; Rhonda Larson, flutist; Russ Landau, bassist. 8 P.M. Also tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. Tickets, $18 and $25. Information: 316-7540. CHURCH OF ST. LUKE-IN-THE-FIELDS (Episcopal), 497 Hudson Street. Caroling Walk through the scenic West Village, beginning at the St. Luke's School dining room (behind the church) and ending there with hot refreshments and more singing. Sponsored by West Village Chorale. 7 P.M. Information: (718) 499-6313. GREEN OASIS COMMUNITY GARDENS, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. ''Nutcracker Street,'' adapted in part from the story by E. T. A. Hoffmann; the Manhattan Performing Ensemble; music by Bah Swindler and the Humbugs; a benefit for the Scholarship Theater Enrichment Program for Children. 9 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission, $15. Information: 477-5288. HAYDEN PLANETARIUM, the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street, ''Sky Show: The Star of Christmas''; exploration of the skies of the first Christmas and what is was that led the Wise Men to Bethlehem; through Jan. 2; Monday through Friday at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M.; Saturday at 11 A.M. and Saturday and Sunday on the hour from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission, $3.75 ($2.75 for students and the elderly, $2 for children). Information: 769-5920. NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. ''Celebrating the Holidays in Old New York''; 19th-century customs, including holiday rituals, home entertaining and winter sports are presented with photographs, prints, greeting cards, toys and sleighs. Through Feb. 18. Tuesdays-Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Closed Sundays and Mondays. Admission, $2 ($1.50 for the elderly, $1 for children). Information: 873-3400. NEW YORK UNIVERSITY THEATER, 35 West Fourth Street. Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors'' is paired with the world premiere of Stephen Nye's ''Favorite Night,'' the story ofthree sisters who discover the true meaning of the season. 8 P.M. Also tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. Tickets, $10 ($8 for students and the elderly, $6 for children). Information: 998-5278. RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL, Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street, ''The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' featuring the Rockettes and the classic ''Living Nativity.'' Through Jan. 4. Tickets, $26 and $29. Information: 757-3100. SYMPHONY SPACE, Broadway at 95th Street. ''Christmas Revels,'' a masque of traditional and ritual dances, processionals, carols and drama in celebration of the winter solstice; David Moss and the Mimos Mummers, the Greenwich Morris Men, the Dorset Dancers; 8 P.M. Also tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M., and Sunday at 2 and 7 P.M. Tickets, $10 to $20 (children half price). Information: 864-5400. WASHINGTON SQUARE CHURCH (United Methodist), 135 West Fourth Street. ''Christmas With Nana and Friends''; exotic rhythms and melodic improvisations inspired by the folk, popular and sacred music of Africa, Brazil and North America. Nana Vasconcelos and Cyro Baptista, percussionists; Teese Gohl, keyboardist; Sergio Brandao, bassist. 8 P.M. Tickets, $12. Information: 206-1050. Tomorrow AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Winter celebrations. ''To Life, to Light: A Hanukkah Celebration,'' with Judith Goldsmith; ''Christmas Eve in Poland,'' with Adele Zydel and Lorraine Bobruk; ''Seven Principles of Kwanzaa,'' with Quassia Tukufu. Several performances between 1 and 4:30 P.M. Information: 873-4225. CHRIST CHURCH UNITED METHODIST, Park Avenue at 60th Street. Russo's ''Shepherds' Christmas.'' New York Art Theater Institute. Jon Swan, librettist; Donald T. Sanders, director; Paul C. Echols, music director. 6 and 8 P.M. Tickets, $20 ($12 for children under 12 and the elderly). Information: 836-3036. NEW YORK OPEN CENTER, 83 Spring Street. ''Legends of St. Nicholas: Songs and Stories of the Saint Who Became Father Christmas''; music from the 11th through the 14th centuries; poems, legends, and a Medieval miracle play; the Anonymous Four, women's vocal quartet. 8 and 10 P.M. Tickets, $10. Information: 219-3739. THE TRIPLEX, 199 Chambers Street. ''A Puerto Rican Christmas Celebration,'' a blend of Latin rhythms by Yomo Toro. Traditional jibaro (mountain string band) Christmas songs; African-derived bomba and plena. Yomo Toro on cuatro (10-string miniature guitar), Orlando Silva on drums, Ruben Figueroa on bass guitar, Kali Rivera on percussion, Louis Kahn on violin, Angel Cabrera on bongos, Luis Santiago on congas, and Dalia Chevre, vocalist. 8 P.M. Tickets: $12 and $15. Information: 206-1050. Sunday DONNELL LIBRARY CENTER, 20 West 53d Street. ''From Broadway With Love''; traditional Christmas music, operetta selections and Broadway show tunes; Paul Trueblood, pianist; Michael Maguire, vocalist; Jean Marie Browne and her All Girl Symphonette; Jack Lee, conductor. 2:30 P.M. Information: 621-0618. WINTER GARDEN, WORLD FINANCIAL CENTER, West Street in Battery Park City. Works by Vivaldi and Bach; familiar Christmas and Hanukkah songs; traditional folk songs; the Manhattan Marimba Quartet. 1 and 3 P.M. Information: 945-0505. Dec.21 BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene section. Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors''; Brooklyn Philharmonic and Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera, featuring Adam Plotch, Victoria Livengood, Douglas Perry, Stephan Kirchgraber and S. Ray Jacobs; Constantine Kitsopoulos, conductor. 10:30 A.M., noon, and 7 P.M. Also Dec. 22, same times. Tickets, $15. Information: (718) 643-7775. Dec.22 THE CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. ''The Pageant of the Holy Squash,'' a procession and performance featuring Barbara T. Smith, a performance artist. The pageant will begin in the Bronx at 3 P.M., at Fashion Moda, 2803 Third Avenue, at 149th Street, and will make its way to the cathedral in Manhattan. A ceremony will be held in the stone-cutting yard at 5:30. Information: 585-0135. CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY (Episcopal), 316 East 88th Street. ''The Father of the Child'', a one-act Christmas opera by Seymour Barab; the Heliotrope Group featuring Bert Lindsey, Mark Peters, Richard Holmes and Kathleen Silloway. 4 P.M. Tickets, $5. Information: 722-4643. TRINITY CHURCH (Episcopal), Broadway and Fulton Street. Program of Medieval Christmas carols and dances from England, Spain, France and Germany; ''Standpipe,'' ensemble of Medieval instruments; Carol Wilson, soprano. 12:10 P.M. Information: 602-0760. Christmas Eve CENTRAL PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH Park Avenue at 64h Street. A ''Blessing of the Animals'' church service will take place; people may bring their pets to have them blessed from 6 to 7 P.M. The service will be informal and will include caroling. Information: 838-0808.

title: Now Hear This, Journalists
description: President-elect Bush told the press corps today that he would ban reporters' shouted questions at White House photography sessions after he becomes President.

title: Bills Climb Into Top Spot
description: The Buffalo Bills (12-3) leaped from No. 4 to No. 1 this week in The New York Times's computer ranking of National Football League teams. Buffalo broke a two-game losing streak with a 37-21 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders on Sunday.

title: Cuomo Denies Koch's Request for School Inquiry
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday rejected Mayor Koch's request for a state commission to investigate corruption in the city's school system. Mr. Koch later asked the Corporation Counsel to determine how his administration might conduct its own inquiry.

title: Beaman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $24,227 and $91,824 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MCA Suspends Executive Named in Corruption Case
description: Eugene F. Giaquinto, a senior executive at MCA Inc., was suspended today after his name appeared in sworn statements that were unsealed in San Francisco as part of a Justice Department inquiry into corruption of employee benefit plans.

title: S.A.S. Buys 24.9% Of British Carrier
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System has bought 24.9 percent of Britain's second-largest airline group, scoring another victory in its global expansion drive. S.A.S. paid $:25 million, or about $46 million, for the stake in the Airlines of Britain Holdings Group, which owns British Midland Airways Ltd., Manx Airlines, Loganair and London City Airways.

title: The School Builders
description: It's a remarkable victory for New York City schoolchildren. A school construction reform bill, declared dead just two weeks ago, yesterday passed the State Legislature and now awaits Governor Cuomo's signature. It was resurrected with the help of dedicated New Yorkers willing to focus on a practical idea: that education begins with a decent physical setting.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Ambassador in Tunisia Makes Fast P.L.O. Contact
description: The diplomat designated as the sole American liaison with the Palestine Liberation Organization moved swiftly today to establish contact with the group and schedule formal talks.

title: Review/Music; A Mixing of Media From Philip Glass
description: There are two main collaborators behind ''1,000 Airplanes on the Roof,'' an avant-garde, mixed-media piece of crossover musical theater that opened Wednesday night at the Beacon Theater for a run through Tuesday. But the third partner neatly steals the show.

title: Down and Out in Capital
description: They spend their days and evenings near buildings where the nation's most critical decisions are made, but their lives are radically different from those who work there.

title: Casual Male reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''PETER AND THE WOLF'' AND ''THE FROG PRINCE,'' #1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Puppetwors, 287 Third Avenue at Carroll Street, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. ''BABES IN TOYLAND,'' the Victor Herbert operetta performed by the Light Opera of Manhattan, 2 P.M. Wednesdays, 8 P.M. Wednesdays through Saturdays, and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, through Jan. 8. Playhouse 91, 316 East 91st Street. Tickets: $17.50 and $20; children, students and the elderly, $12. Information: 831-2000. ''ONCE A YEAR ON CHRISTMAS EVE,'' a musical about an enchanted forest where presents grow on trees, performed by child actors, 7:30 P.M. Fridays, 2 and 4 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at Tada Theater, 120 West 28th Street. Tickets: $5; adults, $6. Information: 627-1732. ''TALES FOR A CHRISTMAS EVE,'' a program adapted and directed by Peter Royston, including stories by O. Henry, and Dylan Thomas, 8 P.M. today, tomorrow and Sunday, and 3 P.M. Sunday, at the Westside Repertory Theater, 252 West 81st Street. Admission: children, $5; others, $10, with a discount for the elderly and students. Information: 874-7290.

Pacificare Health Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Technical Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $61,110 and $227,700 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $32,000.

title: Wavetek Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary gains of $634,000 and $824,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Talks on Verifying Nuclear-Test Treaty Fall Short
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have failed to resolve their differences over how to monitor an unratified 1974 treaty that limits the size of underground nuclear explosions, the White House announced today.

title: Mrs. Fields's French Deal
description: Rather than invest further in its European operations, the troubled American cookie maker Mrs. Fields' Inc. has licensed the French food concern Midial S.A. to sell and distribute its products throughout the 12 countries of the European Community.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Children's Ad Group Forms Business Panel
description: The Children's Advertising Review Unit, the division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus that studies and, with industry compliance, regulates ads directed at children, has announced the formation of a business advisory committee.

title: CSP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LTX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Economic Scene; A Cautious Fed On a Tightwire
description: THE new trade statistics, showing only a slight easing of the deficit to $10.35 billion in October from $10.65 billion in September, combined with the Federal Reserve's report that industrial production grew by a hefty half of 1 percent in November, disappointed the markets this week. The worry is that the economy is moving so fast that the Fed will have to tighten credit, to head off higher inflation and keep the dollar from falling -and that the Fed's tightening could put the economy into a recession before 1989 is over.

title: Utah Power & Light reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $43,741,076 from the December l986 provision for a coal mining operations refund.

title: Everyone but Taylor Says No Trade Was Requested
description: The latest chapter in the Lawrence Taylor story drew angry responses today from the Giants' coach, their general manager, one of Taylor's agents and Taylor himself.

title: ARGENTINE REBEL LINKED TO NORIEGA
description: Public allegations are circulating here that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, aided in the clandestine return to Argentina of the colonel who led a rebellion in the army two weeks ago.

title: Why Someone Pays $2,295 for a Sweater
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $197,000 for the quarter and 9 months; the quarter was after a loss of $127,000 and the 9 months was after income of $75,000, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss of $72,000 for the quarter and income of $291,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Review/Dance; Gordon's 'United States'
description: The unusual aspect of ''United States,'' the new work that David Gordon presented Wednesday night in the Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is tied to its behind-the-scenes genesis.

title: SALVADOR REBELS STEP UP TERRORISM
description: Trying to demonstrate their power in the face of declining international support, Salvadoran rebels have increased their use of terrorism and escalated a pre-election offensive.

title: U.S. SETS AGENDA FOR ITS DIALOGUE WITH PALESTINIANS
description: The United States said today that when it begins its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization it will discuss arrangements for opening peace talks on the Middle East.

title: Now, Cut Off Aid to Liberia
description: American credibility is not usually enhanced by retreats. Yet Washington's reluctant decision to withdraw a team of financial advisers from Liberia a year early could send a strong signal to others who would shamelessly abuse American aid.

title: Jersey and SUNY Centers to Study The AIDS Virus in Heterosexuals
description: Amid warnings that the transmission of the AIDS virus among heterosexuals solely through sexual contact appears to be increasing, a five-year federally financed study of heterosexuals and AIDS was announced here today.

title: LDB Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $14,353,000.

title: Rales Brothers Sell Their Interco Stake
description: The Washington investors Stephen M. Rales and Mitchell P. Rales have sold their 8.7 percent stake in Interco Inc., ending their five-month quest to acquire the St. Louis-based company. The brothers made an estimated profit of more than $60 million on the sale, based on figures contained in previous Securities and Exchange Commission filings. The Raleses ended a $2.6 billion hostile bid for Interco last month only after the company, which makes such products as Ethan Allen furniture and Converse shoes, announced a distribution of a special $76-a-share dividend.

title: Nature's Bounty reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $121,460. There are no comparable year-ago figures because the company changed to a September year from a calendar year.

title: Bush Is Reported to Select Kemp To Head the Housing Department
description: President-elect Bush has chosen Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, a proponent of the aggressive use of public-private partnerships to rebuild inner cities, as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Bush transition officials and other Republicans said today.

title: Spelling (Aaron) Productions (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring income of $3.5 million from American Broadcasting Co., a unit of Capital Cities/ ABC Inc., as part of the modification and extension of the company's agreement with ABC.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have not retreated one inch from our position of guaranteeing the safety of Israel.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: Spartech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: All data have been restated to reflect the change in accounting for income taxes as prescribed by Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96 issued in December 1987. All 1987 per share data have been restated to give effect to the company's 5 percent stock dividend distributed in March 1988.

title: TV's Wave Of the Future
description: LEAD: ''How's your nose?''

description: b-Net income Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the fiscal 1988 adoption and retroactive application of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a distribution and specialty manufacturing concern, elected Richard C. Gozon president.

title: Major U.S. Jewish Group Says It Won't Fight U.S. Decision to Talk With the P.L.O.
description: In an unusual difference of opinion with the Israeli Government, the major umbrella organization of American Jews said yesterday that it would not fight the decision of the Reagan Administration to open talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Commonwealth Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Slips 1.25 Points in Listless Trading
description: The stock market's listless trading continued yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.25 points to close at 2,133.00.

title: Prism Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $12,000 and $108,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After tax credits of $122,000 and $228,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Buell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Review/Violin; Anne-Sophie Mutter in New York Recital Debut
description: Obviously not out to gain an easy victory, Anne-Sophie Mutter faced the music squarely in her first New York recital. The German violinist, whose career has been promoted by such estimable judges of musical ability as Herbert von Karajan and Mstislav Rostropovich, chose four of the most familiar pieces in her instrument's repertory for her Carnegie Hall program on Wednesday evening. She played all of them with disarming ease and well-groomed technique, finding few technical terrors even in Ravel's gaudily difficult ''Tzigane.'' Hers is a large talent, no doubt about it, even if one still in search of a clear musical personality.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Pryor Coming Back: Aaron Pryor took the first step in his comeback bid with a third-round knockout of Herminio Morales last night in Rochester. The knockout came at 1 minute 33 seconds into the round, when Pryor (37-1) landed a combination to Morales's head.

title: Watsco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Latest periods included results of Dunhill Pensonell System Inc. acquired in May 1988.

title: U.S. Raises Sugar Quota 17%; Action Called Insufficient
description: Chiefly reflecting a decline in domestic sugar production caused by last summer's drought, the Reagan Administration today announced a 17 percent increase in the amount of sugar the United States may import in 1989.

title: McLain Sentenced
description: Denny McLain, baseball's last 30-game winner, was sentenced yesterday in Tampa, Fla., to time served and probation on racketeering and drug convictions.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Celebrating Goodman

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Optioned Terry Wells, pitcher; Mike Simms, first baseman, and Bert Hunter and Cameron Drew, outfielders, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Lenny Webster, catcher; Frank Valdez, infielder, and Jimmy Williams, pitcher. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Signed Roger Craig, manager, to a two-year contract extension through 1991. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Signed Kevin Gamble, guard. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Waived Pete Myers, forward. Activated Ben Coleman, forward, from injured list. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended Bob Probert, Detroit Red Wings forward, for three games for hitting Allan Bester, Toronto goaltender, in a game Dec. 10. DETROIT (NHL) - Recalled Sam St. Laurent, goaltender, from Adirondack of the American Hockey League. HARTFORD (NHL) - Recalled Mark Reeds, right wing, from Binghamton of the American Hockey League. COLLEGES LOUISVILLE - Reinstated Keith Williams, guard, to the basketball team. MARIST - Announced it will move to the East Coast Conference from the Northeast Conference, beginning in the 1990-91 season. MIAMI, OHIO - Appointed R. C. Johnson athletic director. MISSISSIPPI STATE - Appointed Bill Clay assistant football coach.

title: Review/Film; Brotherly Love, of Sorts
description: When Charlie Babbitt (Tom Cruise), a fast-talking automobile salesman in Los Angeles, returns to Cincinnati for his father's funeral, he finds that he has inherited a pocket watch and a 1949 Buick Roadmaster convertible. The pocket watch and Roadmaster are in mint condition, and Charlie had been estranged from his father for years, but still he is disappointed.

title: Market Place; 'Asbestos Bomb' Takeover Defense
description: TO the list of takeover defenses, add the ''asbestos bomb.'' It will not work for everyone, but for the Fibreboard Corporation, it appears likely to fend off a corporate liquidator.

title: Waterman Rift: A Tearful Farewell
description: The chief executive of Waterman S.A., Francine Gomez, is about to resign from the pen company that has been part of her family for three generations because she sharply disagrees with the Gillette Company's marketing plans.

title: Our Towns; This Homeowner Thinks R.P.M.'s, Not Square Feet
description: With the press of a button, Richard Foster can make the world spin faster. Or slower. Or in reverse. Or back and forth. ''People ask me to do it all the time,'' he says.

title: Mallard Coach Co.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The latest quarter comprises of 13 weeks. The company was not public until March 1988.

title: Taxi Inspector Is Beaten by Cabby, Apparently in a Summons Dispute
description: A New York City taxi inspector was beaten with a baseball bat yesterday at La Guardia Airport after being surrounded by a group of cabdrivers who were apparently angry over a summons issued minutes earlier, officials said.

title: Review/Art; Some New Acquisitions At the Modern Museum
description: With Anselm Kiefer, in painting (through Jan. 3), and Richard Diebenkorn, in drawing (through Jan. 10), the Museum of Modern Art could hardly have a stronger program through the holiday season. But it would be a pity if visitors were to hurry, head down like runaway bison, in those two directions alone. To the left, as you walk into the Diebenkorn galleries, there is a small show drawn from the museum's acquisitions of the past few years. It gives us a sample, here and there, of activities that are fundamental to the museum's mission but that do not always attract much public attention. And to the right of the main entrance at street level, there is the latest in the distinguished and inventive series of small exhibitions by younger or less-well-known artists, directed by Linda Shearer, curator in the museum's department of painting and sculpture, Individual acquisitions by the score come into the museum every year, but with rare exceptions they take their place in the ranks with minimal stir. Where they accrue to the departments of drawings, or of photography, they will most often be seen only from time to time or on special application. If they enter the design collection, considerations of space play their part. A second helicopter, for instance, would not be seen every day.

title: Britain Acts To Cut Debt
description: At a time when the United States Treasury issues billions of dollars of bonds each year to finance the Federal debt, the Bank of England said on Wednesday that it would hold a ''reverse auction'' in 1989 to buy up Government debt.

title: Patronage and Profit in Schools: A Tale of a Bronx District Board
description: Members of a school board systematically turned a Bronx district into an enterprise for patronage and profit by trading jobs for political favors, seeking payoffs, putting relatives on the payroll and allowing school supplies to be looted, according to board members, school workers and secret records obtained by The New York Times.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 When U.S.-P.L.O talks begin, the United States said, it will discuss arrangements for opening peace talks in the Middle East and will urge the P.L.O. to uphold a renunciation of terrorism. Page A1

title: He's No Clyde, But Who Is?
description: The captain of the University of Pennsylvania basketball team may be leading his team in scoring, assists and minutes played this season, but he said a friend put all that in perspective not long ago when he told him, ''You're the only Division I player who can't whup his old man.''

title: Was Plagiarism-Case Professor Treated Fairly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; Medieval 'Shepherds' Christmas'
description: ''The Shepherds' Christmas,'' an hourlong chamber opera by William Russo based on the medieval ''Second Shepherds' Play,'' was introduced locally by the New York Art Theater Institute at Christ Church United Methodist Saturday night. The story is of sheep thievery perpetrated by the whimsical villain Mak (part devil and part poor man with a family to feed), who hides his booty in a cradle while his wife pretends to have just given birth. The three victimized shepherds find their lost lamb when they insist on giving a present to the newborn child, and punish Mak by tossing him in a blanket. The tale ends with the annunciation of the Christ child's birth to the same shepherds.

title: The College Vote
description: On Monday, the Electoral College will convene around the country to vote for the President and Vice President. It is a process administered by the Office of the Federal Register, a department of the National Archives. The requirements of this arcane procedure, under the Constitution, make it understandable why the Federal Register is involved:

title: WD-40 Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $224,000 from the settlement of litigation.

description: The decrease in net income is largely attributed to the writeoff of a customer's accounts receivable balance of $467,724 as a result of involuntary bankruptcy filed against such customer as reported in the second quarter of the company's current fiscal year.
