description: b-Net loss

title: Toshiba Unit Spurs Export
description: The Toshiba Machine Company of Japan is shipping millions of dollars of goods to the United States in the time it is taking the White House to write rules needed to enforce a ban on the goods, American officials said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., signed a letter to buy the olefin carpet fiber business of Hercules Inc. The price was not disclosed.

title: Mother Seized In Slaying Of 5-Year-Old
description: The mother of a 5-year-old girl and the mother's companion were charged yesterday with second-degree murder after the child, who was found beaten, sexually abused and near death in the couple's Brooklyn apartment, died Wednesday night at a hospital.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the main front-page article yesterday about the American decision to begin contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization described the terms of United Nations Security Council Resolution 242 incorrectly in some editions. The resolution, approved in 1967, calls for ''withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict''; it does not say ''all territories.''

title: Autoinfo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $44,160 and $138,001 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Mr. Bush's Signals
description: President-elect Bush has hit the ground limping.

title: Royalpar Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mars Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a one-time restructuring charge of $4,292,447. c-Included a provision of $700,000 for store closings for the quarter, and the 9 months included a loss from discontinued operations of $350,000. The 1988 sales figures excluded apparel sales, execept for license fees. Sales figures for all periods excluded leased departments.

title: Dollar Ends Session Higher On Outlook for Higher Rates
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, bolstered by the expectation of higher interest rates in the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Milton Bradley U.K. to Griffin Bacal, with a budget of about $8 million.

title: Pier I Imports Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: For Sri Lanka, an Agonizing Election
description: On Monday this small country, trapped for years in cycles of ethnic violence, faces what many describe as its most crucial election.

title: Glad, Not Grateful
description: It was a little embarrassing to watch from Moscow while Mikhail Gorbachev was greeted in New York with such boisterous enthusiasm. Something like being at a party sober and seeing other guests who hardly know each other hug, slap backs and make too much noise about how they ought to get together real soon.

title: One Inquiry Absolves Empire Blue Cross
description: An inquiry into accusations of lavish spending on perquisites and pensions at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest health insurance company, has found no evidence of wrongdoing by the company's officers, the board of directors said yesterday.

title: Review/Art; Ingres Show at the Met
description: ''I am a history painter. I am not a portraitist,'' Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres customarily insisted. Still for many years it was by painting and drawing the portraits of wealthy Englishmen and other tourists who passed through Rome that the French artist supported himself. Ingres equated fulfilling these commissions with serving a kind of penance, but they remain among his most admirable creations: perhaps no one else has ever drawn a face with such elan or painted silk dresses and jewelry in such chillingly scrupulous fashion.

title: The Inflation Debate
description: The drums were beating more loudly than usual this week, mostly on Wall Street, for higher interest rates to head off inflation. At the same time, the Federal Reserve's top officials were meeting in Washington to decide whether the inflation threat was exaggerated or real.

title: Charges Reduced
description: Reggie Rogers, the Detroit Lions defensive end, was ordered yesterday to stand trial on reduced charges of negligent homicide in a traffic accident Oct. 20 in Pontiac, Mich., in which three teen-agers died.

title: Introductions All Around as Sax Visits Stadium
description: The Yankees unveiled Steve Sax yesterday as one of their three new free-agent imports. Sax was standing in the Yankee Club at the Stadium, posing in his new Yankee cap and uniform No. 6, and telling everybody that he had no qualms about switching from Tommy Lasorda's hugging family to George Steinbrenner's sniping family, when with outrageous timing, into the room walked Dave Winfield, the main pressure point in the painful relations at Yankee Stadium.

title: Platinum Prices Off Sharply After Report by Ford Motor
description: Platinum prices posted the second-largest intraday decline on record yesterday after the Ford Motor Company said it had developed an catalytic converter for cars and trucks that does not require use of the metal.

title: Telephone Specialists reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Was Plagiarism-Case Professor Treated Fairly?; Different Standards?
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Janitor's Body Found
description: The badly decomposed body of a 23-year-old assistant custodian was found yesterday on a cot behind a boiler in the basement of a public school in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: 3D Departments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
MacLean's 3 Goals Do Trick For Devils
description: The Devils are beginning to show signs of improvement after the horrendous streak of eight games without a victory. Although they fell behind by two goals tonight to a hungry Toronto team, they rallied for a 6-3 triumph over the Maple Leafs at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Browns Need a Lift From Injured Kosar
description: Pardon Marty Schottenheimer for blinking twice, but this looks much too familiar, much too painful. In a season marked by an early rash of quarterback injuries, many of the teams that remain in playoff contention are led by quarterbacks who recuperated quickly enough. Schottenheimer's Browns were among those teams. They lost Bernie Kosar in the season opener with an injured elbow, but he returned to lead them back.

title: Emanuel London, 95, Retired Ad Executive
description: Emanuel London, an advertising executive and an innovator in the field, died of anemia Tuesday at his home in South Orange, N.J. He was 95 years old.

title: Tax Money to Aid Savings Banks Is Seen as Item in Reagan Budget
description: For the first time, the Reagan Administration has agreed that taxpayers' money is needed to deal with the savings and loan crisis, industry officials close to the Administration said today.

title: Balancing Act on Energy; Next Secretary Will Face Bitter Dispute On Balancing Safety and Security Needs
description: The job of Energy Secretary, first consigned by President Reagan to a dentist who was directed to dismantle the department, has now emerged as one of the most sensitive appointments facing President-elect Bush.

title: Smasher's First Toll
description: The Department of Energy has sent to its supporters and critics around the country 17,000 copies of a 23-volume report, which weighs more than 20 pounds, describing the effect on the environment expected from its projected $5 billion superconducting super collider.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about American Jewish reaction to the prospect of American contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization misidentified the president of the American Jewish Congress. He is Robert K. Lifton.

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits equal to 4 cents a share and 13 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits equal to 1 cent a share and 2 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: HANOI TURNS OVER THE REMAINS OF 38
description: Vietnam gave a United States military team 38 sets of remains today. They are believed to be those of American servicemen, a United States spokesman said. It was the largest single group of remains returned to the United States since the Vietnam War ended.

title: Lawyer Terms Myerson Aliases Eccentric Ploy
description: Bess Myerson was guilty of strange and eccentric behavior, but not a crime, when she called former Justice Hortense W. Gabel's office using aliases like Mrs. Robinson and Mrs. Goodman, Ms. Myerson's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Antonioni Memorabilia Showing at S.I. Museum
description: Nine abstract photo paintings by Michelangelo Antonioni, as well as posters, a lobby card, photographs and location shots from the Italian film maker's career, are on display at the museum of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, in St. George. The exhibition, which Mr. Antonioni has titled ''Enchanted Mountains,'' originated with a series of color tests he made for his first color film, ''The Red Desert,'' in 1964. The display is to remain in place through Jan. 29. A retrospective of Mr. Antonioni's films is to begin on Jan. 8 at the museum.

title: Cubic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pop/Jazz; The Sound Downtown Loses a Voice
description: Wayne Horvitz's two-night stand at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight and tomorrow is a farewell concert of sorts. Mr. Horvitz, a seminal figure on the downtown scene, one of its finest composers and keyboardists, is relocating to Seattle for all the obvious reasons: he and Robin Holcomb, the composer, to whom he is married, are looking for a healthy environment and affordable housing.

title: George Mann Shellhase, Artist, 93
description: George Mann Shellhase, an artist and illustrator in the 1940's, 50's and 60's, died Monday in a nursing home in Ocean Ridge, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: Interactive Technologies Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Some Antiques Stores With New Addresses
description: DURING this holiday season, collectors trying to visit their favorite antiques shops may find empty stores. Many dealers have changed their addresses from downtown to uptown, from the Upper East Side to midtown. They have left warehouses for lofts, hotel suites for galleries.

title: Quebec Coach, 39, Quits After Learning of Tumor
description: Ron Lapointe wanted no suggestions of Hollywood melodrama.

title: Killearn Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
British Introduce Bill to End Ulster Job Bias
description: The British Government introduced legislation today to correct job discrimination against the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.

title: Inca Farmers Read the Secrets of Roots and Soil
description: To the Editor:

title: Bar offers arbitrators' cool heads for lawyers fighting lawyers, but most prefer hot blood
description: It is one of the many soap opera-like stories coming out of Wall Street these days, replete with jealousy, treachery and betrayal.

title: Special Days Noted by Aid To Neediest
description: Today Stephanie Schwartz celebrates a very important event, her 16th birthday.

title: 2 Write-Offs Are Planned
description: The Washington Post Company and Knight-Ridder Inc. both announced yesterday that they would take multimillion-dollar charges against their fourth-quarter earnings.

title: The P.L.O.: From Birth Through Terrorism to Dialogue With the U.S.
description: 1964The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed at an Arab League meeting in Cairo. 1965Yasir Arafat forms the guerrilla group Al Fatah. 1967In the war from June 5 to 11, Israel captures the West Bank from Jordan, the Gaza Strip from Egypt and the Golan Heights from Syria.

title: Times Co. Sees Brief Decline
description: Walter E. Mattson, the president of The New York Times Company, told analysts yesterday that the company expected its results in the first quarter of 1989 to be weaker than those in the corresponding 1988 quarter but that earnings for the entire year should increase.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; School Days Approaching For Lintas
description: STARTING in January, Lintas:

title: Amre Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $250,000 from the cumulative effect of a tax reduction due to the adoption of FASB No. 96. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: At the Movies
description: The 2 Bette Midlers

title: Lear Siegler Seating In 2-Part Offering
description: The Lear Siegler Seating Corporation is offering $220 million of debt in two parts through Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Review/Dance; Pilobolus Moving To Shock
description: Pilobolus was its usual acrobatic and ingenious self when it opened a four-week engagement Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Also as usual, it was grotesque, naughty and even faintly nasty.

title: The Secret Effort on Arafat: Go-Betweens Seize Moment
description: It was early afternoon on Wednesday, and Sweden's secret efforts to get Yasir Arafat to meet American conditions for a dialogue with the United States had reached the critical point.

title: Palestinians See Uprising Continuing, Perhaps Less Violently
description: Convinced that the Palestinian uprising was a catalyst for the American decision to hold talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian leaders expressed confidence today that the rebellion would continue. But some suggested that it might be less violent now.

title: Auctions
description: Streisand's Bid

title: Supreme Equipment & SysFtems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $45,000.

title: 4 Cuban Refugees Deported
description: The Justice Department said today that four Cuban refugees in prison for committing crimes in this country were being deported. The destination of the Cubans, who were among 125,000 exiles who arrived in the Mariel boatlift in 1980, is Havana.

title: Newmark & Lewis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said 1987 results were restated to reflect certain year-end adjustments.

title: TV Weekend; A Life on the Links
description: On the heels of the spate of baseball movies this past year, cable television is turning to a different sport. Would you believe golf? It seems that golf is becoming the sport of choice among yuppies, who find it a convenient vehicle for socializing with their bosses, Home Box Office has found. At any rate, Dan Jenkins has updated a novel he wrote in 1974 and, with Bobby Roth as his co-writer, has turned ''Dead Solid Perfect'' into a movie for HBO. It is having its premiere at 8 P.M. Sunday.

title: The Court That Helps to Pull Europe Together
description: In the capital of this tiny duchy, justice is not only blind; it is multilingual. As the European Court of Justice, the European Community's judiciary branch, copes with nine official languages, it may sometimes stammer, but it has managed to speak with one clear voice in helping to unite Europe.

title: Vatican Payroll Is Stolen
description: Two youths on motorbikes blocked a Vatican car near St. Peter's Square today, smashed the back window and made off with a payroll of nearly $300,000 in cash and checks, the police said.

title: Tri-R Systems Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * United Cerebral Palsy national advertising to Osborn & Associates, Portland, Ore.

title: Sale of Palm Beach
description: Crystal Brands Inc. has acquired Palm Beach Inc., which produces men's and women's apparel, for $300 million from an investment group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners, which took Palm Beach private in 1985. The price includes the favorable refinancing of $205 million in outstanding indebtedness of Palm Beach, which produces clothing under such brand names as Evan-Picone, Gant and John Weitz. Palm Beach had sales of $404.5 million in 1987.

title: Systematics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
American Theater Wing Aids 2 Dozen Groups
description: More than $30,000 in grants and scholarships was awarded yesterday by the American Theater Wing to more than 20 theatrical organizations.

title: Music for Rejoicing Greatly
description: FOR music lovers, Christmas is an especially bountiful time, not only because the city's churches and concert halls are hives of almost incessant musical activity, but also because the season has a musical literature all its own. With one major exception - Handel's ''Messiah,'' which was composed as an Easter work and is performed on that holiday, too - most of the music we hear at this time of the year goes back on the shelf in January, not to be heard again until December. Even if we hear the same works every year (carols, for instance), their absence the other 11 months brings to them an odd blend of freshness and nostalgia.

title: India's Lower House Passes a Bill Giving the Vote to 18-Year-Olds
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi pushed a Constitutional amendment through the lower house of Parliament today that would lower the voting age from 21 years to 18, extending voting rights to 50 million more people.

title: U.S. Note and Bond Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in slow trading yesterday, despite a clear signal from the Federal Reserve Board that it has tightened credit conditions another notch.

title: EUROPEANS PRAISE U.S. MOVE ON P.L.O.
description: The American decision to open talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization was welcomed today by Western European governments, which expressed hope that direct talks between the P.L.O. and Israel, and eventually an international Middle East peace conference, would follow.

title: Legislature Votes New York City School Construction Agency
description: The State Legislature today approved a measure creating a new school construction authority for New York City, relieving the growing pressure on the Legislature to respond to the city's school crisis.

title: Restaurants
description: From outside, the squat brick building on Greenwich Street in far west SoHo has all the charm of a muffler repair shop. Inside, though, it is as hip as a '57 Chevy convertible. This former diner has been converted (only slightly) to a stylishly tacky nightspot called Canal Bar where restive downtowners try out their latest vintage clothes and hair colors. The service is about as frenzied as you would expect at such a place, yet the food is better.

title: Crystal Mysteries
description: Whether there is or is not a Santa Claus is a matter of personal predilection, but there has been no choice about another seasonal proposition: no two snowflakes are alike. How many parents have been pleased to astonish their children with that assertion of crystalline infinity?

title: Skyline Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of properties of $495,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: 'Accidental Tourist' Wins Film Critics' Circle Award
description: ''The Accidental Tourist,'' the screen adaptation of the novel by Anne Tyler in which a lonely, methodical man rediscovers his capacity for love, was voted the best film of 1988 by the New York Film Critics' Circle. Like each of the group's choices, in a year when no film won more than a single award, it was a far from unanimous one.

title: Sun City Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income

title: Sprint Reduces Business Rates
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company said Wednesday that it would reduce interstate rates for business products, including WATS and 800 services, by an average of 3.6 percent on Jan. 5.

title: Smith Barney Lays Off 120
description: Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said yesterday that it had laid off 120 of its staff, the latest in a series of reductions at the securities firm.

title: Hallwood Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Brendle's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Castro Tells Group From Congress He Wants to Assist in Drug Fight
description: Fidel Castro, who has been accused by the United States of abetting drug traffickers, told a visiting Congressional delegation this week that Cuba wanted to begin joint efforts with the United States to halt the flow of drugs, the chairman of the delegation reported today.

title: Good News Is That Price of Concrete Is Down
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net income and included tax credits of $80,000 and $143,700 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

Precision Aerotech reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Wide Management Split Seen at First Fidelity
description: The turmoil at the First Fidelity Bancorporation continued yesterday as the split between its headquarters in Newark and Philadelphia widened, with top executives in Philadelphia beginning to openly discuss leaving the company, people close to First Fidelity said.

title: Ambrit Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 9-month results included a $7.1 million pre-tax gain relating to the first quarter settlement of Ambrit's litigation with Kraft Inc. Year-ago 9-month results included a $2,015,000 provision for dividends on its now retired preferred stock.

title: Wiltek Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tyson-Bruno Fight Is Scheduled Again
description: For the time being, it's official: Mike Tyson will defend his world heavyweight championship Feb. 25 against Frank Bruno of Britain at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel. That was the formal announcement yesterday at a news conference in Los Angeles.

title: Steinberg Judge Hurt in Bicycle Crash
description: Acting Justice Harold J. Rothwax, the presiding judge at the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg, suffered two broken wrists when the bicycle he was riding to court yesterday morning was sideswiped by a passing automoble and he was thrown to the pavement at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 34th Street.

title: U.S. Panel and Party Aides Take Up '88 Spending
description: Officials of the Democratic and Republican parties told the Federal Election Commission today that the problem of unregulated raising of millions of dollars in the Presidential race was one of perception.

title: Student Suits Defended
description: A committee of legal and academic authorities has unanimously concluded that the University of Oregon law school's environmental law clinic did not stray from its proper role when it challenged the state's powerful timber industry.

title: Shanghai Journal; The Dowager of Chinese Cities Tries a Face Lift
description: In the days before Communist rule, Shanghai captured all that was glorious and rotten about China: the splendid colonial architecture, the meticulous tailors, the cornucopia of goods from all over the world; but also the emaciated rickshaw pullers, the thousands of young women sold into prostitution, the labor organizers roasted alive in the furnaces of steam locomotives.

title: Celtics Sign Gamble
description: Kevin Gamble, the leading scorer in the Continental Basketball Association, was signed yesterday by Boston to take the roster spot of Larry Bird, who is injured.

title: Bonn Lifts Key Rate Half-Point
description: In an attempt to curb inflationary pressures, West Germany's central bank raised an important interest rate today and announced plans to curb money supply growth next year.

title: Shaer Shoe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is tentatively offering $100 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 8.06 percent for an issue due in 2023, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The securities firm, a subsidiary of the American Express Company, won the financing in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: TLC Is Said to Be In Talks on a Sale
description: The TLC Group, the investment group headed by the New York financier Reginald F. Lewis, is holding talks with three parties interested in acquiring the Beatrice International Company's 75 percent stake in a Hong Kong food operation. Among the suitors are Nestle S.A., the Swiss food company, and two other leading international food concerns, parties close to the talks said.

title: Telco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Micron Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
Goodmark Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
North Hill Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: Earnings On Chips Are Mixed
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a second-quarter loss, which it attributed to weak sales in its semiconductor group.

title: Webster Clothes reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income

title: Group Asks F.D.A. To Drop Approval Of 2 New Condoms
description: A public-interest health group said today that it had petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to withdraw marketing clearance for two new types of condoms because neither had been tested for effectiveness in preventing pregnancy or protecting against disease.

title: Commission Staff Suggests Denial of Higher Lilco Rates
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company be denied its request for a 5.4 percent emergency rate increase.

title: Court Upholds Malpractice Rate Cap
description: New York State's efforts to contain the soaring costs of medical malpractice insurance - costs that a few years ago were forcing doctors to limit their practices or leave the state - were upheld yesterday by the state's highest court.

title: 11 New York State Hospitals Have High Mortality Rates, U.S. Says
description: Eleven of New York State's 270 hospitals had mortality rates in 1987 significantly higher than the national average, according to a Federal study of Medicare patients.

title: Ex-Fed Aide Enters Plea
description: Robert A. Rough, a former member of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, pleaded not guilty today to a Federal indictment accusing him of leaking confidential information on interest rate policy.

title: TAC Suspends 7 More
description: The Athletics Congress suspended seven athletes today for competing in South Africa earlier this year. They included Tom Petranoff, the former world record holder in the javelin, and Milan Stewart, 1982 National Collegiate Athletic Association hurdles champion.

title: Books of The Times; Absinthe: Bitter Muse, Seductive Destroyer
description: Absinthe History in a Bottle By Barnaby Conrad 3d 160 pages. Illustrated. Chronicle Books. $29.95.

title: Equipment Maker Gets Prospect Bid
description: The Prospect Group, a New York investment company, said it was prepared to offer $12.75 a share for all shares outstanding of Recognition Equipment Inc., a postal equipment maker whose top executives have been indicted in a Federal procurement scandal. Prospect already owns more than 1.4 million shares, or about 14.1 percent.

title: As Drug Trade Rises in Hartford, So Does Violent Crime
description: On a recent Monday night in the North End of the city, a couple getting ready for bed were surprised by a man who had just left the apartment next door in a rage over a drug dispute. A struggle followed, and the intruder was killed with his own knife.

title: Landmarkers Find Ally At Scribner Bookstore
description: To the Editor:

title: A Calendar of Music Events for the Holiday Season
description: Eve CALVARY CHURCH (Episcopal), Park Avenue South at 21st Street. Vocal chamber music by Hampton, with soloists; David Higgs and Harry Huff, organists. At 8 P.M. Information: 473-2877. CARNEGIE HALL, 57th Street and 7th Avenue. Program to be announced; Marilyn Horne and Frederica von Stade, mezzo-sopranos; Samuel Ramey, bass; Martin Katz, pianist. At 8 P.M. Concert tickets, $20 to $100. Patron tickets (Champagne reception with the artists), $200. Information: 247-7800. MARBLE COLLEGIATE CHURCH (Reformed Church in America), Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. Walters's ''The Gate of the Year''; Praetorius's ''Now Is the Old Year Passed Away''; Darke's ''Collegium Regale Service''; Tournemire's ''Communion Mystique, Op. 55''; Bach's Chorale prelude ''In Dir Ist Freude''; Kevin Walters, director. At 11 P.M. Information: 686-2770. RIVERSIDE CHURCH (Interdenominational), 490 Riverside Drive, at 122d Street. Carillon recital. At 10:15 P.M.; Bingham's ''Bells of Riverside''; Bach-Fox's ''Now Thank We All Our God; Franck's Choral in E major; Manz's ''God of Grace and God of Glory''; Bach's ''Ein Feste Burg Ist Unser Gott''; Lefebure-Wely's ''Sortie''; Vierne's ''Carillon de Westminster''. At 10:45 P.M.; Watchnight service. At 11:30 P.M. John Walker, organist. Information: 222-5900. ST. JEAN BAPTISTE CHURCH (Roman Catholic), Lexington Avenue and 76th Street. Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons''; Charpentier's Te Deum; the Amor Artis Chamber Choir; Anne Tedards, soprano; Theodore Sperling and Jeffrey Dooley, countertenors; Peter Terry, tenor; Glenn Billingsley, bass; the Amor Artis Orchestra; Yuval Waldman, violin soloist; Johannes Somary, conductor. At 8 P.M. Tickets, $20. Information: 772-9408. THE CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Works by Bach, Mozart and Bernstein; the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra; Odetta, guest soloist; Lukas Foss and Michael Barrett, conductors. At 7:30 P.M. Information: 662-2133. New Year's Day CHRIST AND ST. STEPHEN'S CHURCH (Episcopal), 120 West 69th Street. Handel's ''In Nomine Jesu''; Cabena's ''Introit for the New Year''; Bach's ''In Thee Is Gladness''; Beth Melcher, organist; Robert J. Russell, director. At 11 A.M. Information: 787-2755. CHURCH OF ST. MARY THE VIRGIN (Episcopal), 145 West 46th Street. Gounod's Mass in C; Shaw's ''Coventry Carol.'' Kyler Brown, director. At 11 A.M. Information: 869-5830. CHURCH OF THE HOLY APOSTLES (Episcopal), 296 Ninth Avenue, at 28th Street. Walton's ''What Cheer'' and Britten's ''A New Year Carol.'' Charles F. A. Senor 3d, organist; Frank Santo, director. At 11 A.M. Information: 807-6799. ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S CHURCH (Episcopal), Park Avenue at 50th Street. Choral music by Mathias and Schubert. Organ music by Bach and Dupre. At 11 A.M.; A Christmas festival of lessons and carols; traditional choral music for the twelve days of Christmas sung by St. Bartholomew's Choir and congregation. At 3 P.M. James Litton, organist and choirmaster. Information: 751-1616. ST. THOMAS CHURCH (Episcopal), Fifth Avenue and 53d Street. Byrd's Mass for Three Voices and ''Ecce Adventi''; anonymous 13th-century Alleluia: Post Partum. At 11 A.M.; Works by Morley, Batten and Whyte. At 4 P.M. Gerre Hancock, organist and choirmaster. Information: 757-7013.

title: Eagle Clothes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,566,000 from the early extinguishment of debt of $913,000 net of applicable income taxes of $609,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $44,000 from the recognition of a tax benefit from net operating loss carryforward.

title: Clabir Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest 9-month results included a gain of about $4.9 million on the sale of London real estate and a gain of about $7,055,000 for a favorable settlement of long-standing litigation with Kraft Inc.

title: Review/Art; From Alien to Familiar
description: No matter how substantial they may be individually, when two museum exhibitions lock into dialogue with each other, they often add up to something much greater than the sum of their parts. The ensuing give and take can form a kind of private symposium in the viewer's mind and can make the New York museum world seem an even richer place than usual.

title: Corrections
description: A list of 1985 National Basketball Association draftees in Sports Pages yesterday misidentified the college from which Joe Kleine was selected. He finished his collegiate career at Arkansas after playing his freshman season at Notre Dame.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Johnnie Walker Red Ad Takes Novel Approach
description: Smith/Greenland appears to be breaking new ground with its ad for Johnnie Walker Red, scheduled to run in USA Today next Tuesday.

title: MOSCOW APPOINTS TOP ARMY OFFICER
description: A little-known colonel general who has been described as a ''rising star'' was appointed Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces today, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: An Uneven Transition For Irving
description: When the Bank of New York Corporation finally succeeded in acquiring the Irving Trust Company after a bitter, yearlong struggle, many Irving executives and directors questioned whether enough good will existed to insure a smooth integration of the two banks.

title: Judge Refuses to Free Mother Who Hid Girl
description: Warning that ''the coercion has only just begun,'' a judge today ordered Dr. Elizabeth Morgan to remain in a city jail indefinitely for refusing to bring her 6-year-old daughter out of hiding for parental visits with her father.

title: Charles Schlein, 89, Painter and Sculptor
description: Charles Schlein, a painter and sculptor, died of oral cancer at his home in Los Angeles on Dec. 6. He was 89 years old.

title: Asset-Backed Securities Offered by Maryland Bank
description: Maryland Bank N.A. is offering $500 million of asset-backed securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The securities are backed by Mastercard and Visa credit card receivables and have an estimated average life of four years.

title: Dining Out Guide: Open on Christmas
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only Christmas hours are given.< Darbar ** (Sept. 5, 1986), 44 West 56th Street (432-7227) - When the calendar reads Dec. 25 and cooking a Christmas goose is not on your agenda, here are some restaurants open on Christmas Day. Darbar is a consistently rewarding and moderately priced midtown restaurant. The refined Mogul cuisine of northern India is served in a multilevel room decorated in vivid colors. Appetizers include all the little fritters familiar to fans of Indian food (filled with vegetables, chicken or shrimp), served with tamarind and mint sauces. Recommended entrees are reshmi kebab, spiced chicken roasted on skewers in the tandoor; boti kebab, which is marinated lamb, and gosht vindaloo, a spicy lamb stew. There are also vegetarian dishes and wonderful Indian fried and baked breads. Appetizers are $5.95 to $13.95, entrees $8.75 to $21.95. Open 5:30 to 10 P.M. David K's ** (Jan. 15, 1988), 1115 Third Avenue, at 59th Street (371-9090) - David K's has a contemporary cool look with its glass wall facing Third Avenue, spacious wicker chairs and fine china and silver tableware. The menu is low in fats and oils, and frying is kept to a minimum. Among the recommended appetizers are jumping shrimp cooked in the shell with scallions and garlic Chinese noodles tossed with ginger sauce and lobster pieces, and shredded beef with crisp rice noodles in a mustard-peanut dressing. Good entrees are the Peking chicken served with whole-wheat pancakes and scallions ($28.50, serving two to four diners); braised sea bass; pork with cashews, leeks and hot peppers, and lobster in lemon sauce. Dinner appetizers are $4.50 to $12.50, entrees $13.50 to $18.50. Open 5 to 11 P.M. Omen ** (Oct. 18, 1985), 113 Thompson Street (925-8923) - This charming SoHo restaurant, designed to resemble a Japanese country inn, is named for its signature dish. Lanterns hang from the timbered ceiling, and striking calligraphy graces the walls. Omen is a seaweed-broth-based dish that combines artfully arranged vegetables (radish, lotus root, broccoli, spinach, scallions) with wheat noodles. Very fresh sashimi is available, but not sushi. Some of the menu choices are raw tuna with Japanese yam crowned with a quail egg; avocado and shrimp with miso sauce, and boned, marinated chicken dishes. Prix fixe menu at $23; a la carte $5 to $19. Open 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Rosa Mexicano ** (Aug. 1, 1986), 1063 First Avenue, at 58th Street (753-7407) - For the holiday, Rosa Mexicano's front dining room is strung with papel picado, red and green paper garlands that are traditional Mexican decorations. The more restrained back room has rose stucco walls, mauve banquettes and a stone fountain filled with colorful flowers. Recommended are the pomegranate margaritas and appetizers of freshly prepared guacamole, and tortillas with shredded pork and chilies. Grilled entrees, cooked over stone briquettes, include shell steak with sauteed poblano chilies and piquant grilled chicken. Appetizers are $6.50 to $9, entrees $13 to $20. Open 4 to 10 P.M. Sign of the Dove *** (March 27, 1987), 1110 Third Avenue, at 65th Street (861-8080) -Skylights, graceful brick arches and generously spaced tables enhance the romantic appeal of Sign of the Dove; for Christmas, the rooms will be decorated with pine trees and wreaths. A special holiday menu is offered prix fixe at $60 and includes choices of appetizers and entrees, a cheese course, dessert and coffee. Among the appetizers are pumpkin ravioli with fricassee of mushrooms and a casserole of oysters and lobster in fennel-cream sauce. Entrees include smoked ham glazed with Sauternes, grilled salmon in a Moroccan-style marinade, and medallions of veal with wild rice, braised endive and chanterelles. There will be a choice of six desserts. Open 2 to 8 P.M. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: Girding for Bid to Count Homeless
description: Under the cover of darkness, Government agents will be dispatched across America to abandoned buildings, street corners and emergency shelters on what many say is an impossible mission: to count the homeless.

title: Nichols (S.E.) Inc.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes gain on sale of realty in 1988 relating to the closed Lancaster store of approximately $1,200,000 ($700,000 net of taxes), and other income in 1987 of approximately $130,000 ($100,000 net of taxes).

title: Diner's Journal
description: Star Fish Grill

title: Listening to Arafat, Looking for Peace
description: The bewildering Middle East diplomatic gyrations have now brought a stunning breakthrough -direct contacts between the Palestine Liberation Organization and the United States. The prospects for peace are both frightening and heady.

title: Death Rates Found Excessive at 188 Hospitals
description: The Government today published its third annual report on mortality rates for Medicare patients at nearly 6,000 hospitals, including 188 where deaths exceeded Federal predictions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * WPP Group P.L.C. has acquired for an undisclosed sum HLS Corp., Lyndhurst, N.J., a $13.6 million marketing and communications company specializing in health care.

title: Frequency Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Emanuel Ax to Perform
description: Emanuel Ax is to be the guest of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in the first of this season's Cushion Concerts at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, at 6 P.M. tomorrow. The program includes the Franck Violin Sonata, Mozart's String Quintet in G minor (K. 516) and Faure's Piano Quartet No. 1 in C minor (Op. 15). The program is also to be performed at Alice Tully Hall at 5 P.M. Sunday. Tickets for tomorrow's concert are $10 at the door. Tickets for the Sunday performance are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $76,000 and $241,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $201,000 for the quarter and $796,000 for the 9 months.

title: A Soviet Film
description: ''My Friend Ivan Lapshin,'' a film by the Soviet director Aleksei Gherman based on stories by his father, Yuri, will be shown today through Thursday at the Collective for Living Cinema, 41 White Street, three blocks south of Canal Street. The film is set in a remote village in 1937, and recalls people and events from the narrator's childhood. Screenings are today through Sunday at 8 P.M. and Monday through Thursday at 7 P.M. Admission: $5. Information: 925-2111.

title: Davis Cup Draw
description: When the Davis Cup final opens in Goteborg, Sweden, today, Mats Wilander of the host country, the world's top-ranked men's player, will face Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, according to the draw held yesterday. Stefan Edberg, the Wimbledon champion, will play West Germany's top player, Boris Becker, in the second singles of the three-of-five-match series. Edberg will team with Anders Jarryd against Becker and Eric Jelen in doubles tomorrow.(AP)

title: DOCTOR INCENTIVES ON COSTS ASSAILED
description: The General Accounting Office has issued a report criticizing health maintenance organizations that give financial incentives to doctors to hold down the costs of treating Medicare patients, suggesting that this could encourage physicians to provide poorer care.

title: Vari-Care reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Knicks Rally to Nip Jazz for Fifth Straight Victory
description: After shooting only 38 percent in the first period and falling behind by 15 points 77 seconds into the second quarter, the Knicks threw all their weapons at the Utah Jazz last night: the press, the trap and the 3-point shot.

title: Review/Film; A House Divided In Spain
description: ''The House of Bernarda Alba'' begins with the funeral of a man who surely wielded little influence, since his widow, Bernarda Alba (Irene Gutierrez Caba), is such a formidable tyrant. Feared by her five daughters, hated by her servants, Bernarda Alba rules her household with an iron hand.

title: Measurex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Beauticontrol Cosmetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Art; The Ambiguous Golem
description: ''Golem! Danger, Deliverance and Art'' is the kind of exhibition with which the Jewish Museum wants to be identified. It tackles a rich theme with a complex political, cultural and artistic history. Using as a model the multi-disciplinary exhibitions that were so prominent in the 1970's, it presents the material in a studious, crowded and ultimately convincing manner.

title: The Governor Offers Koch A Few (?) Words of Advice
description: He didn't ask for it, but Mayor Koch received some advice from Governor Cuomo yesterday on whether to run for re-election, couched in typical Cuomoese.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Wednesday about ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'' misidentified the actress who plays an Oklahoma millionaire. She is Meagen Fay, not Dana Ivey.

title: United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Colin Wheeler has been named managing director at Griffin Bacal for Britain.

title: Audio Video Affiliates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The 1987 9-month period included a pre-tax gain of $1,032,000, or an after- tax gain of 4 cents a share, from the sale of Audio-Video's share in Cyclops Corp.

title: Case Against Palme Suspect Advances
description: A Stockholm court ordered the police today to hold a 41-year-old Swede for two weeks to give prosecutors time to assemble their case and charge the suspect with killing Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: New York's Job Training Emergency
description: Mayor Koch's Commission on Black New Yorkers sounds an urgent alarm: New York faces an emergency in preparing young people for the work force, especially young minority people. The city can no longer afford to neglect the problem.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Lawyers' Final Salvos Fired at Myerson Trial
description: On the final day of arguments in the Bess Myerson bribery trial, lawyers for both sides vied yesterday for the sympathies of the jurors who will decide whether the career that began with the glitter of the Miss America crown will end with the disgrace of a criminal conviction.

title: 'Casablanca' Piano Eludes Donald Trump
description: Donald Trump lost out to a Japanese trading company in fierce bidding yesterday for the upright piano used in the Paris flashback scene in the film ''Casablanca.''

title: Producer Prices Show 0.3% Rise; Fears of a Stronger Inflation Ease
description: In another largely reassuring report on inflation, the Government said today that prices received by producers for finished goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the same as the average for the three preceding months.

title: Fed Policy Makers Leaned Toward Interest-Rate Rise
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve, fearing that a moderation in the economy's growth rate might have been temporary, decided at their November meeting to lean toward higher interest rates, according to minutes of that session released today.

title: Review/Theater; A 'Phaedra' From Britain's India
description: In ''Phaedra Britannica,'' Tony Harrison gives a 19th-century British imperial setting to the ancient tale of Phaedra's uncontrollable desire for her stepson, Hippolytus. Labeling his play ''after Jean Racine'' (in his dramatization, Racine, of course, followed both Euripides and Seneca), Mr. Harrison transposes the story from Greece to India in the time of the Raj.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7, 28 The first formal U.S.-P.L.O talks were held in Carthage, Tunisia, two days after the United States dropped its 13-year ban on contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Page 1 Four Palestinians were shot dead by Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank as clashes broke out at a funeral. The death toll was the highest since last April. 6 Syria and Iran were unhappy with the Palestine Liberation Organization's meeting with the United States. Official newspapers in Damascus rejected the talks, and one said Middle East peace ''should be taken by force.'' 6 The structural defects in Armenia that contributed to the recent earthquake's devastation are widespread in most countries. But engineers have developed methods for reinforcing buildings that might have saved many lives. 1 Soviets will not begin bulldozing cities destroyed by last week's earthquake. They said they would continue to search the wreckage until every body is accounted for and every trapped survivor found. 3 President Reagan accused Congress of exceeding its proper authority and intruding into his prerogatives as chief diplomat and military commander. 7 China's position on Cambodia regarding a diplomatic settlement is coming closer to that of Hun Sen, the Prime Minister of the Vietnamese-backed Government said at a news conference. 28 A British Cabinet minister resigned after causing a storm by asserting two weeks ago that most British eggs were infected with dangerous salmonella bacteria. 5 A Swiss official was freed in Lebanon a month after he was seized in the southern port of Sidon by unidentified gunmen. Meanwhile, other gunmen in southern Lebanon kidnapped three Irish peacekeeping soldiers. 7 The suspected killer of Olof Palme was ordered held for two weeks to give prosecutors time to assemble their case and charge the suspect. The move appears to be the furthest advance in the hunt for the assassin. 3 National 8-12, 32 George Bush named John G. Tower, a former Texas Senator with strong ties to the defense industry, as Defense Secretary, saying that he was ''totally satisfied'' with the F.B.I.'s check into the candidate's background. 1 Man in the news: John G. Tower, President-elect Bush's nominee for Secretary of Defense, provoked questions that have dogged the former Texas Senator since he was first mentioned as a candidate for the job. 1 Three Governors demanded expensive environmental cleanups as their price for allowing a nuclear weapons plant to stay open. Their demands came at a meeting in Salt Lake City with the Department of Energy. 1 In a reassuring report on inflation, the Labor Department said prices received by American producers for finished goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the same as the average for the three preceding months. 1 The role of an informer, in this case the former teamster president, Jackie Presser, is at the heart of the racketeering and embezzlement case against two of Mr. Presser's former associates. 32 Chicago raids aimed at gangs and other criminal elements in Chicago housing projects have violated the civil rights of tenants, the American Civil Liberties Union alleged. 8 Unofficial diplomacy in Texas is becoming ever more common between El Paso and Ciudad Juarez, cities that in many ways function as one, their houses 50 feet apart although they lie on opposite sides of a border. 8 An 18-year-old murderer in Dallas was given a more lenient sentence because the homosexual men he shot to death were ''cruising the streets picking up teen-age boys,'' the judge said. 8 The savings and loan situation has created tension within the Government on how to address the crisis through the budgetary process. The consensus is that taxpayer funds will be required. 35 Mother whose newborn was drug addict faces felony charge 9 Prosecutor selected to try North 11 Air Force raises estimate of Stealth bomber cost 12 Regional 29-32 News analysis: Homeless people are whose responsibility? Every interest group and every layer of government points a finger at someone else for both the general problem and the specific conditions of shelters. 1 A new residence for the homeless on the Lower East Side, the Cube, is believed to be the first of its kind in the nation and a dream come true for families who have spent years living in abandoned buildings or welfare hotels. 29 Grumman Corp. will cut 2,500 jobs on Long Island by the end of 1989, laying off 1,800 workers and eliminating 700 other positions through attrition, the company announced. 1 The state budget gap increased slightly when the Legislature returned to Albany, ostensibly to shrink it. Lawmakers approved 5 percent pay raises for 15,000 management level state bureaucrats. 29 Teachers have written to Santa requesting classroom supplies that the school system's $5.7 billion budget does not provide. The letters are on display at the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. 29 Plans for Trump Centre in Paramus, a 40-acre mall-hotel-office complex of bronze and marble, ponds and parks, has set off an uproar among residents. 29 As a badly beaten boy recovered, authorities said they were trying to determine whether they had missed any early warning signs that could have saved the life of his 5-year-old half sister. 31 In the Joel Steinberg trial, the defense lawyer, Ira D. London, said he would not enter a formal insanity defense on the ground that it would allow the prosecution to use it ''to poison the jury's mind about Joel.'' 31 In their closing statements, lawyers in the Bess Myserson trial vied for the sympathies of the jurors who will decide whether the career that began with the glitter of the Miss America crown will end in disgrace. 31 Talks are set in Lilco case 30 Neediest Cases 33

title: U.S. Concludes Teamster Fraud Case
description: The Justice Department, which has admitted that Jackie Presser was an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation while he was president of the teamsters' union, is vigorously insisting in a criminal trial that there were limits on what he was allowed to do in that role.

title: Off-Court Problems
description: The off-court problems that dogged David Thompson, the former scoring star at North Carolina State, during his pro career with Denver and Seattle are still troubling him now that he is off the court for good. Thompson has been director of community relations this season with the Charlotte Hornets, who confirmed yesterday that the former forward had entered a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Van Nuys, Calif., for 30 to 60 days.

title: Student With Pistol Kills One Teacher And Injures Another
description: A student shot two teachers today, killing one and critically wounding another, and began firing on a classroom full of students but his gun jammed before any students were hit, the police said.

title: Shouting Match at District 12 Meeting
description: A public meeting of Community School Board District 12 dissolved into a chaotic shouting match last night, as board members angrily defended themselves against accusations that they had lied and misused district funds.

title: Bush Seen as Near to Naming 2 for Deficit Panel
description: Gov. Henry L. Bellmon of Oklahoma, a Republican, and Thomas L. Ashley, a former Democratic Representative from Ohio, have emerged as the front-runners for appointment by President-elect Bush to the Government's commission on reducing the deficit, a leading Republican official said today.

title: Construction Of Housing at 7-Month High
description: Housing construction reached its highest level in seven months in November, providing further evidence of a robust economy.

title: Gerald Broderick, 52, Advertising Official
description: Gerald T. Broderick, president and chief executive officer of Arnold & Company, a Boston advertising agency, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 52 years old.

title: Political Action Group Seeks Faster Development of AIDS Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Leading U.S. Arab Is Denied Entry to Israel
description: The president of the Arab-American Anti-Discrimination Committee, an American citizen, was barred from entering Israel today despite efforts by United States Embassy officials on his behalf.

title: Sohn Plans to Retire
description: Kurt Sohn came off the Fordham campus to make it as a role player for eight seasons with the Jets. Now, at the age of 31, he plans to retire after the Jets-Giants game tomorrow.

title: Cambodia Chief Sees Rift With China Easing
description: Hun Sen, Prime Minister of the Vietnamese-backed Government here, said today that China's position on settlement of the Cambodian issue was coming closer to his own.

title: 2 Found Guilty of Collecting Millions to Aid 'Love Angels'
description: A Federal jury today convicted a man and a woman of bilking thousands of men out of $4.5 million with false stories of a garden paradise inhabited by nude ''love angels.''

title: No Adoring Viennese Millions for Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Views of Tomorrow's Showdown at Meadowlands; Why Jets Will Win
description: The Jets a December team? Strange as it seems, they are getting better these days, and are peaking just in time for their last game of the season. Too bad for them there's no also-ran bowl, or a 20-game season.

title: Review/Music; Pinnock Leads New York Forces in 'Messiah'
description: The two biggest stars of London's early-music world, Trevor Pinnock and Christopher Hogwood, are conducting Handel's ''Messiah'' in New York this month. Mr. Hogwood is to arrive Thursday for an Avery Fisher Hall performance with the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston, an early-instruments band. Mr. Pinnock offered his version Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall with the Orchestra of St. Luke's - which plays on modern instruments - and the New York Choral Artists.

title: Grand Met Acquiring Betting Outlet Chain
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate embroiled in a battle to take over the Pillsbury Company in the United States, said today that it had agreed to purchase the William Hill chain of bookmakers for $:331 million, or about $600 million, in cash.

title: Meat Export Dispute
description: European foreign ministers next week will refine their retaliatory plans if a trade war breaks out over a scheduled ban on hormone-treated meat from the United States, officials said today. The ministers of the European Community will discuss the dispute on Monday in Brussels, said a spokeswoman for the 12-nation trading bloc. The community plans to ban for health reasons all meat from animals treated with growth hormones effective Jan. 1. About $170 million of American meat exports would be affected, and Washington has threatened to take retaliatory action.

title: Democrat Selected as Leader Of Federal Election Agency
description: The Federal Election Commission selected Danny L. McDonald today as its chairman for 1989.

title: Federal Express to Buy Flying Tiger
description: In an ambitious bid to become a global air freight carrier, Federal Express Inc. agreed today to pay $880 million to buy Tiger International Inc., parent of the Flying Tiger Line, the world's largest air cargo carrier.

title: Chicago's Housing Raids Challenged
description: A series of surprise raids to sweep gangs and other criminal elements from the city's troubled public housing projects has resulted in widespread violations of the civil rights of tenants and their guests, the American Civil Liberties Union charged today.

title: Legislature, Tackling Gap, Just Widens It
description: The State Legislature returned here this week, ostensibly to reduce the state's budget gap, but instead ended up increasing it. Before leaving town Thursday night, lawmakers unanimously approved pay raises for 15,000 management-level state bureaucrats - at a cost of about $36 million for the coming year.

title: Mother Who Gives Birth to Drug Addict Faces Felony Charge
description: A woman whose son was born addicted to cocaine was charged today with child abuse and delivery of the drug to her baby, a felony drug charge that prosecutors say has never been used against a new mother.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Nov. 25, about Mirabella magazine, misstated the ownership of Elle magazine. It is owned by Hachette Publications, not by Rupert Murdoch.

title: Yields Little Changed on Treasury Issues
description: Yields on Treasury notes and bonds were essentially unchanged yesterday as most market participants withdrew to the sidelines in anticipation of a rise in the Federal Reserve's discount rate.

title: Nail Solvent Fells Boys
description: A boy under 2 years of age was found dead and a boy 2 years old nearly died after swallowing solvent used to remove artificial fingernails, two doctors reported today in an article in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Dr. E. Martin Caravati of the University of Utah and Dr. Toby L. Litovitz of Georgetown University Hospital, Washington, D.C., wrote that the solvent, SuperNail Nail Off, made by American International Industries of North Hollywood, Calif., contains acetonitrile, which slowly converts to cyanide in the body.

title: Israeli Troops Kill 4 Palestinians As Clashes Break Out at Funeral
description: Four Palestinians were shot dead by Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank today as clashes broke out at the funeral of a fifth man who died of shooting wounds sustained last month.

title: New Music
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet and soloists will present the New York premieres of three works commissioned by the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival at 8 o'clock tonight at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The ensemble will perform Ned Rorem's ''Scenes From Childhood,'' Stephen Paulus's ''Letters From Colette'' and Tobias Picker's ''New Memories.'' The quartet will be joined by the soprano Evelyn Lear; Mr. Rorem and Ursula Oppens on piano; Allan Vogel on oboe; Robert Routch on horn, and Gordon Gottlieb on percussion. Tickets: $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: Houston Is Placed on Probation
description: The University of Houston football program, about to complete its most successful season since 1979, was placed on three years' probation today and barred from bowl appearances for two years.

title: BUSH NAMES TOWER TO PENTAGON POST, ENDING LONG DELAY
description: President-elect Bush named John G. Tower, a former Texas Senator with strong ties to the military industry, as Secretary of Defense today, saying that he was ''totally satisfied'' with the check into the candidate's personal and professional background.

title: Ford Acquires 2 Savings Units
description: Federal regulators said today that they were providing $118.3 million in assistance to a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company to rescue two Michigan savings institutions.

title: Qaddafi Is Brewing Up Trouble for Bush
description: LEAD: Muammar el Qaddafi, that inveterate master of mischief, has done it again. He has acquired the capacity to wreak havoc against adversaries in the Middle East and adjacent regions. Chemical weapons and intermediate-range missiles are transforming Libya into a potential regional superpower.

title: Long Knives Banned in Tibet
description: In an effort to reduce violent crime in Lhasa, Tibet's capital, officials have outlawed the long knives that many residents wear at their hips, a newspaper reported today. The Chinese-language Ta Kung Pao said many people in Lhasa have used the weapons in murders, robberies, rapes and burglaries. So far this year, 25 people have been killed and 34 injured in 56 criminal cases involving the long knives, the newspaper reported.

title: 3 Are Wounded in Bombings At Sri Lankan Election Rally
description: Two bombs exploded today at a campaign rally of Sri Lanka's principal opposition leader. The police said that the candidate, former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike, was unhurt, but that three of her supporters were critically injured.

title: The Losing Fighter Deal With Japan
description: An American negotiating team trying to sell F-16 fighters to Japan was defeated last month and is now in Tokyo to receive its second humiliation.

title: Nordiques Appoint Perron Head Coach
description: Despite coaching the team with the second-best record in the National Hockey League regular season, Jean Perron was dropped last spring by the Montreal Canadiens, only three years after winning the Stanley Cup in his rookie season. Yesterday, the Quebec Nordiques, Montreal's archrival, appointed Perron as head coach under somewhat frantic circumstances.

title: Only a Price Cut Gave Samurai a Push
description: The jury is still out on whether the Suzuki Samurai, which has a tendency to roll over, will survive the controversy over its safety. But one thing is clear: 18,500 people were willing to risk buying the vehicle when the manufacturer cut the price by $2,000.

title: Dollar Up While Gold Rises In U.S. After Drop Abroad
description: By The Associated Press

title: Why Forgive Debt?
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Instruments' New Transistor
description: Texas Instruments, the company that developed the computer chip 30 years ago, says it has produced a tiny new super transistor that could lead to a new generation of more powerful, less expensive computer chips. The new circuit, called a quantum tunneling transistor, is only one-hundredth the size of a conventional semiconductor circuit and is 1,000 times faster. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, called the transistor a milestone, saying that it proves that chip makers can overcome physical limitations imposed by conventional semiconductor technology.

title: Jovanovich Leaving Post At Harcourt
description: William Jovanovich, the chief executive of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. for 34 years, plans to relinquish that position at the end of this month but will continue as chairman of the company's board and executive committee.

title: Alcohol Tax Rise Urged
description: A workshop on drunken driving convened by Surgeon General C. Everett Koop called today for tax increases and advertising restrictions on alcohol to discourage consumption.

title: Patents; Guiding Amateur Inventors HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Those who think that amateur inventors are an endangered species may want to contemplate George Spector. An engineer who works out of an office on Broadway in New York, Mr. Spector has for the last 25 years made a career of helping tinkerers transform vague inspirations into patentable inventions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday about possible cutbacks at the State University and City University systems in New York reported the status of some campuses incorrectly.

title: V.A. to Raise Loan Rates
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it was raising its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 10.5 percent.

title: Responsibility Is Widespread, but the Role Of the Koch Administration Is Problematic
description: When New Yorkers step around the recumbent bodies of homeless people in the streets and wonder who or what is responsible for the wrenching problem, they are confronting a long list of candidates and causes.

title: Coors Workers Reject Teamsters
description: Brewery workers at the Adolph Coors Company, who have not been members of a union for a decade, have voted against joining the teamsters' union.

title: Man Found Guilty for Fatal Kick Outside Bar
description: A Manhattan man was convicted yesterday of criminally negligent homicide for kicking to death a 24-year-old man outside a bar on the Upper West Side last winter.

title: Reagan Faults Congress On Foreign Policy Role
description: Reviewing his foreign-policy record, President Reagan accused Congress today of exceeding its proper authority and intruding into his prerogatives as chief diplomat and military commander.

title: Air Force Raises Cost Estimate of Stealth Bombers to $68.1 Billion
description: After months of putting off an announcement of the increased cost of the Stealth bomber, the Air Force acknowledged today that the plan to build a fleet of the new warplanes would cost 16 percent more than previous estimates, or $68.1 billion.

title: Fatal Delays in Armenian Relief
description: Every major natural disaster calls forth inspired and admirable enterprise in the nation affected and from the world community. But the Soviet Union is a country in transition between management by central fiat and management by local initiative, and in the case of the Armenian earthquake, virtually all the authorities appear to have failed to cope, and certainly failed in obvious and vital areas of preparation.

title: Reviews/Music; Belgian Violinist in Debut
description: Michael Guttman, a Belgian violinist who completed his studies at Juilliard, made his New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, with Simone Guttman (his mother), as his capable accompanist at the piano.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've not only been screened, I've been sifted.'' - Former Senator John G. Tower. [ 1:4. ]

title: 'Nutcracker' Libel Ruling Reversed by Appeal Court
description: The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court has reversed a libel decision against Shana Alexander and Doubleday & Company because, the court found, comments about a psychologist in a book written by Ms. Alexander were the opinions of her sources.

title: What Crumbling Infrastructure?
description: LEAD: Contrary to fashionable belief, America is not falling apart. While reports of crumbling public facilities and mounting repair and renewal costs have been a staple of the 1980s, the character of our streets, bridges, water and sewer systems is not bleak or perilous. The failure of one piece of the infrastructure, such as New York's Williamsburg Bridge, tells little about other bridges or infrastructure in New York State, and even less about other parts of the country.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Figaro' Among Towering Columns
description: It takes a certain kind of genius to transform ''Nozze di Figaro,'' perhaps the liveliest comedy of manners ever set to music, into a swollen, bloodless parody of a grand opera. The late Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, whose production of Mozart's work returned to the Metropolitan Opera stage on Thursday night for the first time this season, had that peculiar talent.

title: Cineplex Odeon
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation, the Toronto-based movie theater owner, said it had agreed to sell its Film House Group subsidiary to a joint venture that is 51 percent owned by Film House and 49 percent by Rank Organization P.L.C. Both Film House and Rank are motion picture processors. Under the agreement, Rank will pay $53.5 million to Film House and $20 million to Cineplex. Rank will have a one-year option to acquire the remaining 51 percent of Film House for about $76.5 million.

title: Miller Is Ineligible
description: Kenny Miller, who led the nation with a 13.6 rebounding average last season, has been declared academically ineligible for the rest of the season, Loyola of Chicago announced yesterday. The 6-foot-9-inch center from Chicago was ineligible for the first semester because of poor grades. ''Kenny has always been a free spirit and he'll survive,'' said Gene Sullivan, coach of the Ramblers (2-3). ''I just hope he gets his priorities in order so that he can live up to his great potential.''(AP)

title: Bridge; An energetic bridge administrator ends a term and passes the baton to her successor.
description: The hardest-working bridge administrator in New York City is going to take things a little easier in 1989.

title: Golden Nugget In Caesars Tie
description: Golden Nugget Inc., the Las Vegas-based hotel and casino company headed by Stephen A. Wynn, has purchased a 6.4 percent stake in Caesars World Inc.

title: For 22 Homeless Families, Answer to a Child's Prayer
description: Olga Villa was having a restless night a few months ago in the Lower East Side shelter that she and her three children called home. Something awakened her, and she sat up in bed to see her 8-year-old daughter, Jennifer, praying for a new house for Christmas.

title: Special Gift for Loved Ones: Donation to Neediest Cases
description: Kim M. Saffer of Spring Lake, N.J., wrote that she was ''at wits' end'' deciding upon a Christmas present for her parents, who ''seem to have everything they want or need.''

title: New Age Babble
description: The company providing our cable-television service has just accessed me with a print communication, or, as the old-timers used to say, ''sent me a letter.''

title: Lawyer Rejects Defense Of Insanity for Steinberg
description: The defense lawyer in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that he would not introduce a formal insanity defense on the ground that it would allow the prosecution to use it ''to poison the jury's mind about Joel.''

title: Kuwait Has 3 Years To Cut B.P. Stake
description: The British Government said it would allow Kuwait up to three years to reduce its holding in the British Petroleum Company to 9.9 percent from 21.68 percent. The period represents a compromise between the five years sought by the Kuwait Investment Office, which is the London-based investment arm of the Kuwaiti Government, and the one year originally recommended by the British Monopolies and Mergers Commission, which said a larger holding by Kuwait ''might be expected to operate against the public interest.''

title: Your Money; Christmas Gifts That Pay Off
description: With the Christmas gifts so closely followed by January's bills, presents that enhance a family's cash flow can be particularly welcome. And there is an array available, including books, software and videotapes.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: News for Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 21 about the 900th anniversary of the University of Bologna compared its longevity with that of other universities incorrectly.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan Faults Congress

title: Fed Approves Bank Rules
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved, by a vote of 6 to 0, new capital guidelines intended to push banks into safer investments.

title: For the U.N., a Pro
description: Presidents have often used the United Nations as a highly visible but safe place to send large egos. A cabinet seat has usually been awarded to the chief delegate, a practice followed by no other country. George Bush, who once held the job himself, has wisely broken with tradition. His choice is a seasoned professional, Thomas Pickering, who would be a subordinate and not a colleague of the Secretary of State.

title: Soviets Say Rescue Won't Be Halted
description: Apparently responding to resistance from survivors, Soviet officials said today that they had reversed their decision to begin bulldozing cities destroyed by last week's earthquake. They said they would continue to search the wreckage until every body is accounted for and every trapped survivor found.

title: Seton Hall Cruises Past Fordham
description: Not long ago, Seton Hall would lose to teams like Fordham in its home gymnasium in South Orange, N.J. Those were the days when rumors had the Pirates ready to be ousted from the Big East. Those were the days when rumors had P. J. Carlesimo, the Seton Hall coach, ready to be ousted from his job.

title: What Was Reinforced
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Views of Tomorrow's Showdown at Meadowlands; Why Giants Will Win
description: The debates all week about the Giants-Jets game Sunday have made it sound as if the Jets have a real chance to win. They have a chance, but not much.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Snarls of Wire
description: LEAD: The components that make up an audio-video system make popular holiday gifts. But remember that connecting wires come with them, and they are never things of beauty. If your gift list includes extra speakers to provide ''surround sound,'' you'll be giving people even more wires than they already have.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'Shards,' a New Work for the Ailey Company
description: In addition to creating his own dances and staging pieces by distinguished modern-dance choreographers, Alvin Ailey has taken risks over the years by encouraging choreographic newcomers. By commissioning works from them for his Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he has introduced talented but comparatively little-known choreographers to a wider public.

title: Review/Music; Bounce and Pop of 30's
description: Mack Gordon and Harry Revel, the Hollywood songwriting team affectionately saluted in a new cabaret revue, ''With My Eyes Wide Open,'' created a slew of tuneful ditties that bubbled up in such 1930's Hollywood movies as ''Wake Up and Live,'' ''Paris in Spring'' and ''Love in Bloom.''

title: White House Tensions Rise On Aid for Savings Industry
description: As the Government faces the hard fact that the savings and loan crisis will require taxpayer funds, there is significant tension within the Reagan Administration on how to address the problem through the budgetary process.

title: Movies Look Abroad for Profits
description: Until a few years ago, American movie studios aimed most of their films at customers from Buffalo to San Diego, although there have always been some movies that worked well abroad. The James Bond movies routinely grossed $50 million to $60 million in the United States and considerably more overseas. Violent action films crossed cultural barriers without a snag, but most other movies failed to score with foreign audiences, who understood a punch better than a punch line.

title: Mexicans Need Results From New President
description: To the Editor:

title: Contamination Report Erred
description: The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service now says it erred in announcing three months ago that a large wildlife refuge proposed for New Orleans was contaminated with mercury.

title: Quake-Proof Buildings: Many Lands Take a Risk
description: Engineers have developed methods for reinforcing buildings that might have saved many of the lives lost last week in the Armenian earthquake. But the structural defects that contributed to the Armenian disaster are widespread in most countries and cannot be eliminated in time to prevent future catastrophes, experts agree.

title: Gaining Ground in the A.F.C.
description: In a season dominated by more glamorous teammates who throw the ball, a pair of rookie running backs have helped transform their teams.

title: Reunion for Klima
description: Petr Klima, the 24-year-old Detroit Red Wing forward who defected from Czechoslovakia in 1985, was reunited yesterday with his parents at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. The Klimas were frustrated for several years over the refusal of Czechoslovak authorities to issue visas for the visit while stories of their son's run-ins with the law and hockey opponents filtered back to Czechoslovakia.

title: Patents; Anti-Skid Device
description: UC Systems A/S, a Norwegian company, has won patent approval for an anti-skid device that coats automobile tires with an adhesive liquid when a driver encounters slippery roads. A reservoir of the liquid, which is not specified by the patent, is in the front of the car and is connected by hoses to nozzles over each wheel. An air compressor can be activated from the driver's seat to pump the liquid onto the tires when needed.

title: Nets Go Dry And Are Left In the Dust
description: For six minutes tonight, the Nets' offense vanished. By the time it reappeared, the Philadelphia 76ers were long gone.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: John Goodwin Tower; Military Expert for Pentagon
description: The announcement of the choice of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense was only minutes old when reporters began peppering President-elect Bush with the questions that have dogged former Senator Tower since he was first mentioned as a candidate for the job he has sought for many years.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Tunis yesterday about the American move to make contact with the Palestine Liberation Organization misidentified the P.L.O. aide who was killed in Tunisia in April. He was known as Abu Jihad; his given name was Khalil al-Wazir.

title: Texas Judge Eases Sentence For Killer of 2 Homosexuals
description: A judge here has said he gave an 18-year-old murderer a more lenient sentence than prosecutors had sought because the two victims were homosexual and, the judge said, they would not have been killed ''if they hadn't been cruising the streets picking up teen-age boys.''

title: Grumman to Reduce Its L.I. Work Force By 2,500 Employees
description: The Grumman Corporation, which has slashed its Long Island work force by nearly 15 percent in the last two years, said today that it would cut 2,500 more jobs on the Island by the end of 1989.

title: Vietnam Veteran on Walsh's Staff Is Selected as Prosecutor of North
