The problem has been that the only way to get the information from all those papers into the computer was through keyboard entry. That is changing.

title: Odd Numbers
description: STAND AND DELIVER Starring Edward James Olmos (in photo), Rosana De Soto, Lou Diamond Phillips, Andy Garcia. Directed by Ramon Menendez. 1988. Warner Home Video. 102 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated PG. Contains some profanity.

title: It's a One-Woman Show at an Airport in Vermont
description: Bennington County Airport has no air traffic controllers, car rental agents or baggage handlers. But it does have Janeen Pratt.

title: Out of the Cabinet
description: In Switzerland, where women were not granted the right to vote in national elections until 1971, Elisabeth Kopp has been a pioneer. She was the first woman to enter the seven-person Swiss Executive, known as the Federal Cabinet, in 1984. A recent poll named her the most popular Cabinet member, and under the country's rotating executive system, she was to become Vice President in February and President in 1990. But last week the 52-year-old Mrs. Kopp resigned as the Minister of Justice and the Police. The reason: She had advised her husband, Hans, to resign from a company that was later disclosed to be involved in a money-laundering investigation. Attributing her resignation to ''unbearable pressure,'' Mrs. Kopp said, ''I wouldn't like one to think that I could have committed or tolerated wrongdoing.''

title: Lilco Line Stymied By Shelter Island
description: LEAD: MOST of the work on the Long Island Lighting Company's 17-mile transmission line, to run from Southold across Peconic Bay to East Hampton, has been completed, except for a four-mile section proposed for Shelter Island.

title: An Update on Jamaica: Services Intact if Frayed
description: A TRIP to Jamaica after Hurricane Gilbert struck Sept. 12 and shortly before the tourist influx began in mid-December found the island eager and just about ready for what it hoped would be a busy season.

title: Deborah Zuckert Plans To Marry Ira Jay Levy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Owen M. Zuckert of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ellen Zuckert, to Ira Jay Levy, the son of Maurice Levy and Gloria Levy, both of Brooklyn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Reviews/Music; Rock Singer's Yuppie Image
description: The growing popularity of Melissa Etheridge, a Kansas-born rock performer who is now based in Los Angeles, suggests that the vogue for female rockers who strut around in Spandex tights and shiny leather may be waning.

title: The N.C.A.A. Gets a Boost in Court
description: Last Monday, the Supreme Court enhanced the legal position of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in a ruling involving Jerry Tarkanian, the University of Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach. The court ruled that the N.C.A.A. did not violate Tarkanian's constitutional rights when it ordered U.N.L.V. to suspend him as coach because of recruiting violations.

title: Miss Jeffers Married To Frederick Rackmil
description: At All Souls Unitarian Church in New York, Alisandra B. Jeffers, a daughter of Alexander Jeffers of Maidenhead, England, and Beverly Jeffers of New York, was married yesterday to Frederick David Rackmil, the son of Betty Rackmil of Boston and the late Harry Rackmil. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard officiated. Melissa Knox and Richard W. Barber were the maid of honor and best man.

title: The Stained-Glass Wonders of York
description: TO ask how we should look at a great cathedral is a question that could arise only in the modern age. To all in the medieval age of faith, when the great buildings were raised, cathedrals were holy books written in stone and stained glass, symbolic visions of the world from the Creation to the end of time when Christ would return to judge both the quick and the dead. In no two cathedrals is the story told exactly the same way, which allows us to learn something of how men and women six or eight hundred years ago saw the world, and interpreted the Word. Since they were built over centuries, by many different artists and architects, cathedrals have all the quirks and crotchety failings of human beings, and something of the national character of the countries from which they sprung.

title:
ART;
Classical Mood, Timeless Themes
description: LEAD: THERE is a classicism in the photographs of Claus Mroczynski that immediately engages attention. It is classicism defined, in part, by extraordinary craftsmanship, the ability to discover new relationships between black, white and gray tones, and by universal subject matter.

title: Editorial Advice
description: The last time Denny McLain came up for sentencing before Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich she gave him 23 years. So the two-time Cy Young Award winner was in an understandably accommodating mood last week after he returned to Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla., for resentencing on the same racketeering and cocaine trafficking charges. Judge Kovachevich sentenced him to five years' probation plus the 29 months he had already served.

title: NONFICTION
description: CHILD STAR: An Autobiography. By Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) Born with a quick mind, an uncanny ability to memorize and mimic and a facile readiness to adjust to any situation, Shirley Temple became the biggest child star of all time. She was blessed with a sturdy self-confidence that allowed her to give unsolicited advice on how to handle the press even to Eleanor Roosevelt. She survived an assassination attempt by a woman who believed that the child star had stolen her daughter's soul, as well as multiple threats of kidnapping. Mrs. Black mentions these incidents in ''Child Star,'' an account of her first 26 years, with no more or less emphasis than she tells of the onset of her first menstruation or the loss of her front teeth. The beautiful child with dimples and corkscrew curls is as cute in this book as she was on the screen and as unreal as her celluloid characters. Where is Mrs. Black's outrage at the ''black box,'' a torture tool used by the studio for obstreperous child stars, which consisted of a soundproofed, unventilated container fitted with a large block of ice that provided a wet floor on which to stand or a freezing stool on which to sit? Where is her anger at the attempted rapes by George Jessel and David O. Selznick? Where is her resentment toward her first husband Jack Agar's persistent brutish behavior and drunken Hollywood indiscretions? Mrs. Black tells her story, but she does not seem to feel it. The people in her early life are presented one-dimensionally, with the exception of ''Uncle

title: My name Is Yon Yonson
description: LEAD: MY NAME is Yon Yonson, I come from Wisconsin, I work in a lumber mill there. When I walk down the street, all the people I meet, they say, ''Tell us what your name is.'' I say: My name is Yon Yonson, I come from Wisconsin, I work in a lumber mill there. When I walk down the street, all the people I meet, they say, ''Tell us what your name is.

title: Hofstra Falls to Clemson By 77-63
description: Elden Campbell scored 19 points, 12 in the second half, leading four double-figure scorers as Clemson defeated Hofstra, 77-63, today for its third straight victory.

title: U.S. Offers New Plan on Soviet Political Prisoners
description: The United States has sent Moscow a new plan for dealing with the long-disputed problem of Soviet political prisoners. Washington hopes the proposal will lead to a speedy conclusion of East-West talks in Vienna on human rights and security issues, Administration officials said today.

title: Prospects; A Winning Play for CBS
description: Last week, the baseball commissioner, Peter V. Ueberroth, announced that CBS had won the rights to nationally televise 12 baseball games a year plus the World Series, All-Star Games and league playoffs. The agreement extends for four years and covers all 26 major league teams. The remaining games will be auctioned to cable television. CBS - the network with the lowest viewer ratings - bid $1.1 billion, a record amount. Four experts discuss the deal. Hal Katz Executive vice president, Vitt Media International Inc.

title: Mix of Holidays andd History
description: LEAD: THE bears come out at Christmas here.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Concrete or Steel?; The Variables That Dictate the Kind of Construction
description: THE tapered office tower that Tishman Speyer Properties completed a few weeks ago in downtown Chicago looks as if it could fit just as easily into downtown Manhattan. But beneath its cloak of limestone, the 38-story NBC Tower on the Chicago River has a rugged body of reinforced concrete - and Tishman Speyer never would have built it that way in Manhattan.

title: The Dwarf Lisianthus Promises To Be Popular
description: In the Southwest, it's just a weed. But elsewhere, lisianthus is the darling of many who know it as a cut flower that lasts for 10 days or even more.

title: A la Carte: Eschewing Foolery
description: REVELRY rules the roost on New Year's Eve, but there are those who value fine dining more than noise-making. Many of Long Island's best restaurants are planning spectacular memory-making feasts for those who want to eschew the crowds, drunks, horns and funny hats.

title: An Adult Finds Monopoly as Infuriating Today as It Was Before Lease-Purchase
description: I PLAYED my first game of Monopoly as a teen-ager in the early 1950's. I probably played my last game of Monopoly in the late 50's, until last week.

title: SLOW HORSES, JAPANESE BETTORS
description: Steven Crist, in his fascinating article on Japanese horse racing, writes that Japan has been unable to produce world-class horses (''In Japan, the Quinella Is King,'' Nov. 20.) The article portrays the Japanese bettors as emotionless, stoic.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY. By Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) Any list of trivia yields up some general truths, and the insightful reader will glean much from ''Legends, Lies, and Cherished Myths of American History.'' Richard Shenkman, a co-author of ''One Night Stands With American History,'' has cobbled together 17 brief chapters to set us straight on such topics as discoverers and inventors, the good old days, education, art and other subjects both serious and light.

title: Once Again, Labor Problems Threaten to Overshadow Game
description: Forget free agent, forget balk, forget cork, forget live ball or dead ball. The baseball word to focus on now and for the next 16 months is ''lockout.'' Or, if you prefer the verb form, ''lock out.''

title: Reviews/Theater; Fire Island Philosophizing On a Midsummer's Eve
description: John Glines's romantic farce ''On Tina Tuna Walk'' is the kind of play that stands or falls on its ability to scatter enough epigrams so that one senses an acute wit manipulating its frivolous goings-on. In the play, set at Fire Island Pines on Midsummer's Eve, most of the best lines are given to Eddie (Eddie Cobb), the campiest denizen of an affluent gay household in which champagne flows day and night and lobster salad is available by the bucket.

title: POSTINGS: School Conversion; Lesson in Change
description: How to convert a high school into a lower school? It has a lot to do with plumbing: lower water fountains; lower toilets and sinks; add toilets. Such is the practical learning taking place at the Calhoun School as it converts a former Baldwin League School building at 160 West 74th Street for its preschool, kindergarten and first grade. Calhoun's lower school is currently housed in its building at 433 West End Avenue, which also has grades two through twelve.

title: East End Assays Assessment
description: LEAD: AS the result of a unanimous decision in late October by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court that held that an Atlantic Beach practice of reassessing houses at market value at resale was unconstitutional, the Towns of Southampton and East Hampton may be forced to reassess all private homes because of similar practices.

title: PINS: PARENTS FEEL OVERWHELMED
description: I am an administrator for a child-care agency working with troubled adolescents and families.

title: 'A Christmas Carol' True to Form
description: WHO's to tally the diverse and often perverse stage versions and screen variations of Charles Dickens's ''Christmas Carol''? In this theatergoer's peregrenations during recent seasons, such regional theater novelties as a contemporary morality musical called ''Ebenezer!,'' wherein the title character was a Wall Street trader, and a conventional musical comedy, ''A Christmas Carol,'' with a score by Michel Legrand and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick, have come up.

title: Trawler Catches Nazi Plane
description: Two Norwegians trawling for shrimps in the North Sea caught a World War II German Messerschmitt fighter plane, the national news agency reported today. The agency, quoting a report in the daily Stavanger Aftenblad, said the fishermen were about 340 miles south of Oslo on Thursday when their trawl got stuck. ''In the trawl was a ME-109 fighter which must have rested on the seabed for more than 40 years,'' the report said.

title: Japan, Hoping but Wary, Will Talk With Soviets
description: Japan usually puts economic gains before ideology. But it makes an exception in its relations with the Soviet Union, and that will be apparent when Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, arrives here Sunday on his first visit in nearly three years - a visit awaited here with equal doses of hope and suspicion.

title: Holiday Activities Abound for Children Throughout the State
description: LEAD: ANYONE who doubts that the holidays are for children need only take a look at goings-on throughout the state over the next few weeks. Yuletide activities, from a train or trolley ride with Santa to toy exhibits, sleigh rides, carol-sings and holiday concerts, abound.

title: Competence Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Vital Signs
description: To the Editor:

title: America Seen Through Alien Eyes
description: Since the late 1950's, American directors have roamed the world, mostly mindlessly in search of pretty scenery; but only recently have European directors been working in this country in any numbers.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Fighting for a 'Sensitive' Brentwood Tract
description: LEAD: A RESOLUTION introduced in the Suffolk County Legislature earlier this month seeking $1.5 million to buy a 38.5-acre tract in Brentwood has raised the question whether it is more important to save a parcel of land identified as environmentally significant, or to let it be developed for housing.

title: Reviews/Jazz; Sir Roland Hanna and a Longtime Friend
description: In keeping with the holiday season, the quartet that Sir Roland Hanna assembled at Via Mia last week played a kind of joyful jazz that is a rarity in the workaday commercial music world.

title: Jodi Brenner Engaged
description: An April wedding is planned by Jodi Robin Brenner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Brenner of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Westhampton, L.I., and Alan David Kaplan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Kaplan of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: ORTEGA PREPARES PEACE BID TO U.S.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra says his Government is preparing a peace proposal that will be presented to the Bush Administration ''when the moment is right.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: West Germans Clinch Title, 3-0
description: Boris Becker and Eric Jelen teamed to win a tense three-hour doubles match over Sweden today to clinch West Germany's first Davis Cup championship.

title: A Japan-North Korea Dispute Takes a New Turn
description: In the latest twist in a bizarre, five-year hostage standoff, Japan has decided to grant residency to a North Korean soldier who has been in detention since trying to defect here in 1983.

title: Independent Publishers
description: To the Editor:

title: Further Signs Of a Surge
description: Numbers poured in from Washington, many indicating a resurgence in the economy's growth and heightening the possibility that the Federal Reserve would further tighten credit by raising the discount rate. Already, the Fed funds rate - the rate at which banks lend to one another - has inched up.

title: Sara J. Brown and Ira Drescher Marry in Florida
description: Sara Jane Brown, a daughter of Beryl F. Goldstein of Hollywood, Fla., and the late Nathan W. Goldstein, was married in Hollywood last evening to Ira Drescher, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Drescher of New York. Rabbi Robert Frazin performed the ceremony at the home of Drs. Robert J. and Diane P. Blank.

title: WITHOUT TOP HAT
description: LEAD: FRED ASTAIRE His Friends Talk. By Sarah Giles. Illustrated. 210 pp. New York: Doubleday. $30.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: In ''Journey East From Ankara'' (Travel, Nov. 6), James Blachowicz has done a disservice to the almost two million Armenians who died at the turn of the century in Turkey's genocide against the Armenians. Mr. Blachowicz writes of ''the systematic displacement of Armenians by Turks''; displacement is hardly the accurate term. The Turkish genocide against the Armenians involved torture and mass killings of men, women and children whose only crime was that they were Armenians. To refer to this tragedy as a displacement is a kind of Orwellian doublespeak. HAIG BOSMAJIAN Seattle James Blachowicz replies: I appreciate the concern of Mr. Bosmajian. The term ''systematic displacement'' is an unfortunate euphemism. I did not discuss in detail this event nor did I examine any of the historical or political relations among Turks, Russians, Armenians, Kurds, Greeks and others, not only because such issues were not the focus of the article but also because more space would have been required to do them justice. I believe readers of The New York Times are generally aware of the tragedies visited on the Armenian people, especially in the events of 1915. It was not my intention to minimize the significance of these facts in any way.

title: Justice Brennan Goes Home From Hospital
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. was released from the hospital today, less than a week after surgery to remove his gallbladder, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said.

title: THE NAMELESS WOMEN OF THE WORLD
description: JOAN MAKES HISTORY By Kate Grenville. 279 pp. Latham, N.Y.: British American Publishing. $17.95.

title: Shelby Wyckoff To Wed June 17
description: Shelby Lawrence Wyckoff and Andrew Garrison Binger plan to be married June 17, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Randolph Wyckoff 3d of Buffalo, have announced. Mr. Binger is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Garrison Binger of Plainfield, N.H., and Little Compton, R.I.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Getting There is Half the Aggravation
description: LEAD: WHOEVER said, ''Getting there is half the fun'' never met my husband.

title: Link Between AIDS And Drug Abuse Is Studied in State
description: WHAT scientists do not yet know about the spread of AIDS through heterosexual relations they will probably learn in New Jersey, epidemiologists say.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lebanon, N.H.;
Medical Center Powers Growth
description: LEAD: THE construction of Dartmouth-Hitchcock Memorial Center, a 1.2-million-square-foot hospital and medical school, is powering a spurt of growth in the 19-town Upper Valley Region in New Hampshire's northwest corner.

title: Smart Team
description: When it comes to selecting academic all-America football teams, the emphasis is distinctly on academics. But this year's team, selected by college sports information directors for the GTE Company, has one bona fide football star. He is Mark Stepnoski, the University of Pittsburgh offensive lineman who was one of the three finalists for the Outland Trophy.

title: High on the Five
description: MARTIN VAN BU-ren could not have been as hip as George Bush makes him out to be. Speaking of his selection as his party's Presidential candidate, Bush said to The Associated Press and to a crowd in Huntington, Ind.: ''I just couldn't help but think that old Martin Van Buren was up there giving me the high-five sign.''

title: POSTINGS: Good Neighbor Policy; Clinton Park
description: For as long as Hell's Kitchen Park on 10th Avenue has provided a bit of open space for residents of what once was Hell's Kitchen and now is Clinton, the vacant lot next to the park at 448 West 48th Street looked tantalizingly available for more recreational elbow-room. But the city never bought the privately owned parcel. Instead, the overgrown lot only helped to isolate the park: With no one looking over their shoulders, drug dealers took over the handball courts, the floor-hockey rink and the benches, pushing even the homeless aside.

title: Reviews/Music; Violin, Piano And Schubert
description: It speaks well of performing artists when relatively low-key material brings out their best qualities. Joseph Swensen and Jeffrey Kahane, for example, played an evening of Schubert for violin and piano that achieved high levels of communication through modest means.

title: The Star Performer
description: ONE of the best-known personalities on the North American bridge scene was the late Paul Heitner. He was an enthusiast who made many contributions to the game.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: THE NATIVITYIllustrated by Julie Vivas. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Bias Seen in AIDS Studies
description: An AIDS organization has charged that trials for experimental drugs at three medical schools in New York City have excluded the poor, members of minority groups and women, and praised one of the schools for taking remedial steps.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Colors

title: EVERYTHING IN THE BALANCE
description: LEAD: DANGER AND SURVIVAL Choices About the Bomb in the First Fifty Years. By McGeorge Bundy. 735 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: U.N. TELLS OF GAINS ON RIGHTS IN CUBA
description: A United Nations investigation into human rights violations in Cuba, demanded by the Reagan Administration this year, has concluded that such abuses have declined, diplomats and officials say.

title:
ART;
Modern Day Folk Art in Bridgeport
description: LEAD: THE current exhibit at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport, ''American Folk Art of the 20th Century,'' provides the warm assurance that there is an art form that seems never to change. Recent folk art is much the same as its counterparts from the last century.

title: Bars on the 'Strip' Focus of Complaints
description: LEAD: T is midnight but there is plenty of activity on North Avenue. Young people are walking back and forth between several bars, from which rock music is blaring. The police cruise by every few minutes to keep an eye on things.

title: Bronx Schools Inquiry Influenced Vote in Albany
description: A year after Governor Cuomo summoned education and political leaders to a top-level meeting on New York City's public schools, the State Legislature has grudgingly approved three of the five proposals that Mr. Cuomo and others agreed to support during the session.

title: The Drawbacks Of Recognition
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Frank Palma;
Recapturing America's Pastime
description: LEAD: FRANK PALMA, a 51-year-old executive recruiter for the Goodrich & Sherwood Company, has been passionate about baseball since his childhood in a ''magical place called Bensonhurst,'' when he would go to see the Brooklyn Dodgers at every opportunity.

title: Handicapped
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor Deported By Lesotho
description: The authorities today deported an editor who was detained for six weeks after his weekly newspaper began publishing articles on Government corruption in this mountain kingdom surrounded by South Africa. The security police took South African-born Johnny Maseko, the 29-year-old editor of The Mirror, from a cell to a flight for Nairobi, Kenya.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DAVY CHADWICK. By James Buchan. (Atheneum, $16.95.) The apparent kidnapping of 5-year-old Davy Chadwick from his parents' isolated household in southern Italy is the pivotal event in this slim and suspenseful work by James Buchan, whose first novel, ''A Parish of Rich Women,'' won Britain's Whitbread Prize.

title: Leadership, Not Defiance, On Housing
description: THE United States Supreme Court recently upheld a decision that Huntington had to go ahead with the construction of 162 units of affordable housing around the corner from where I live in East Northport.

title:
My No 
[
star
]
 Restaurants
description: LEAD: It's no secret that I spend quite a bit of my time thumbing my nose at the ever-growing crowd of pretentious foodies, ambitious chefs and tiresome critics.

title: Warsaw Pact Ministers Meet
description: Warsaw Pact defense ministers gathered in Sofia today for their first joint meeting since Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, announced sweeping cuts in troops and equipment in Eastern Europe. The official Bulgarian press agency said the ministers of the seven-member Communist defense alliance had arrived in Sofia for the meeting chaired by the Commander in Chief, Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov of the Soviet Union. Although Moscow's allies have publicly supported the Soviet move, diplomats in the region said some Eastern-bloc military leaders might have reservations.

title: Gentile Preacher in Temple Pulpit
description: LEAD: KAREN BUZZELL, an Episcopal seminary student, can remember the hush that fell over the synagogue last year when she appeared on the bema, or platform at which the Scripture is read.

title: FREUD'S PATHOGRAPHY
description: James Atlas credits Joyce Carol Oates with the discovery of ''a new literary genre, pathography,'' in his article ''Speaking Ill of the Dead'' (Nov. 6). Actually, it was Sigmund Freud, although he describes the reaction of readers far differently from the way that Mr. Atlas and Ms. Oates do.

title: THE WORLD: Adjusting to Moscow's Disarmament Plans; For Soviets, Military Cuts May Not Feed The Economy
description: A WEEK before Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised to cut Soviet armed forces by about 10 percent, Soviet television audiences were treated to a broadcast with the unlikely name of ''Soap, Sausages and Soldiers' Boots.''

title: U.S. Is Seeking Its Prisoners of a War's Panic
description: The job Congress assigned the Justice Department was to find the names and addresses of 60,000 Japanese-Americans interned by the Government in World War II.

title: Tut, Tut
description: LIKE A LOT OF PEOPLE, JIM Onan first got interested in pyramids in the 1960's, because of their alleged mystical powers. ''A couple of universities did studies,'' he says. ''You know, if you put milk inside of a pyramid it would turn into yogurt.'' Somehow, his discovery to the contrary didn't deter his fascination. And thousands of visitors to his home in Wadsworth, Ill., have shared it. Onan, who runs his own contracting firm, began building a 24-carat, gold-plated, 54-foot-high pyramid for his family in 1977. They moved in six years ago.

title: Reviews/Music; Pianist Plays Chopin Etudes
description: Even in this world overflowing with hyperpolished conservatory graduates, it is not every week that a young pianist sits down to offer a whole book of the Chopin etudes in recital. MyungHee Chung played the Op. 10 series at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, putting her command of the basics of 19th-century keyboard virtuosity up for comprehensive inspection and emerging honorably from the trial.

title: Another Puzzling Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Post-Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE THE GLAMOUR MACHINE
description: PRIVATE VIEW Inside Baryshnikov's American Ballet Theatre. By John Fraser. Photographs by Eve Arnold. Illustrated. 259 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $30; after Dec. 31, $35.

title: Many Have Watched Climbing Monkeys
description: To the Editor:

title: Hampton Favorites Go Into a Cookbook
description: LEAD: YOU can't always tell a book - or a cookbook - by its title. For example, take ''You Can't Be Too Rich or Too Thin - Favorite Recipes from the Hamptons,'' a cookbook that Southampton Hospital has just published.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 'ART AS A VERB'

title: Volunteers Help Elderly Stay Home
description: LEAD: JOSEPHINE WASSON spends an hour and a half each week with Marian Murray, a 94-year-old resident of Tarrytown whom Mrs. Wasson calls ''a dear person.'' As a volunteer with the Senior Community Coalition, Mrs. Wasson helps Miss Murray in a variety of ways, such as shopping and letter writing. Right now she is addressing her Christmas cards.

title: PINS: PARENTS FEEL OVERWHELMED
description: As I understand it, a child 16 or older cannot be forced to live at home or attend counseling or therapy regardless of where or how the child is living. Yet, the parents are financially responsible for it until said child reaches 21. The lobbying group Parents on the Move would like to see this ''independent'' age raised from 16 to 18 and the ''financially responsible'' age changed from 21 to 18.

title: Sylvester, Singer and Entertainer, Dies at 42
description: Sylvester, the gay entertainer whose falsetto voice and drag costumes propelled him to international fame, at the height of the disco dance popularity, died Friday of complications of AIDS. He was 42 years old. Known as ''the Queen of Disco'' here in the late 1970's, Sylvester delighted audiences of every race and sexual persuasion with his funky, spiritual style singing in his nightclub routine in which he wore exotic costumes.

title: Submarine Is Commissioned
description: Howard Baker, the former White House Chief of Staff, today hailed the nuclear-powered submarine Tennessee as a ''great vessel in a dangerous time,'' while about 50 anti-nuclear demonstrators protested the commissioning. The police reported no arrests at the commissioning, at the Naval Underwater Systems Center.

title: A Lesson in Unselfish Giving
description: MY sister knows someone who makes fishing flies from lint, so she is saving the build-up from her clothes dryer and plans to give him a box of lint for Christmas. It's the thought that counts, she says.

title: Barry Champlain, Sculptured by Stone
description: The making of every film breeds a few good stories. Some are told at parties, some to your wife after the lights are out and some never told at all. The making of ''Talk Radio,'' the film opening Wednesday at the Beekman, was for me a shuttle-rocket ride from the littered pavements of downtown New York City to the fast and shiny highways of the New Hollywood. As I met with producers, conferenced on stories and attended bi-coastal casting sessions, I was like Oliver Stone's protagonist in ''Platoon'': a wide-eyed boy entering a battle zone, self-conscious of my every move.

title: Reviews/Music; Musical Jokes and Dialogue By Amsterdam String Trio
description: After hearing the Amsterdam String Trio, a Dutch ensemble that blends jazz improvisation and experimental noise into a classical format, one was left asking the same questions that occur during multi-format concerts by the Kronos Quartet: Why is it that musical humor, when expressed by a chamber string group, still seems fraught with gravity? Is it that one has been conditioned to associate string music with a mood of high solemnity? Or is there an intrinsically cerebral tug in the textures of such music?

title: Help For Students: Business Mentors
description: LESLIE CARLOS, 11 years old, is no shrinking violet. So Glen LeBlanc and Dan LaMorte are not entirely surprised at the sixth grader's description of himself in a form he filled out for his language-arts class at West Rocks Middle School in Norwalk.

title: The Omnipotent Ruler Of the Collegiate Athletic Industry
description: A FEW years ago, William S. Banowsky, then the president of the University of Oklahoma, gave his opinion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The university had just filed suit against the N.C.A.A. over televison rights, and Dr. Banowsky showed some trepidation.

title: China Should Attack Its Currency Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Remsen to Wed
description: Mrs. Charles G. Miller of Greenwich, Conn., and Frederick D. Remsen of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Story Remsen to Nigel Joseph Shepard Jaquiss, a son of Mrs. Donald B. G. Jaquiss of Lenox, Mass., and the late Dr. Jaquiss. Miss Remsen, a teacher at the Nightingale-Bamford School in New York, and her fiance, an oil trader at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, both graduated from Dartmouth College. The future bride received a master's degree in education from Lesley College. The couple plan to marry in March.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 27 about buying shoes in Florence misidentified one shop. The shop, on the Via Cerretani, is Girlardini.

title: Justice Delayed, Slightly
description: Amid all the glare of publicity on the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg, the Greenwich Village lawyer accused of beating 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg to death, the presiding judge, Harold J. Rothwax, an acting State Supreme Court Justice, has insisted on keeping courtroom nonsense and delays to a minimum. Last week, Justice Rothwax inadvertently delayed the trial himself. Riding his bicycle to court, as usual, he was sideswiped by a hit-and-run automobile on Fifth Avenue and thrown to the pavement, breaking both wrists. Just a few hours after being treated at a hospital, the 58-year-old Justice, his arms in two white plaster casts, belatedly took the bench and explained, ''We have good days, we have bad days.

title: A PAIN IN THE NECK
description: Your article mentions that manipulation of the neck has been associated with transient neurological symptoms and even stroke. This is an extremely delicate area, in which a complex network of blood vessels and nerves pass through foramina, spaces between two bony areas in the neck. These foramina often are narrowed in the elderly. Thus, hyperextension of the neck with certain activities, such as changing a light bulb while standing on a ladder, can lead to dizziness and even fatal trauma secondary to falls. Such tasks should be avoided by elderly people. WILLIBALD NAGLER, M.D. GALE PUGLIESE, M.D. Department of Rehabilitation Medicine The New York Hospital- Cornell Medical Center New York, N.Y.

title: Jennings Has Inside View
description: Dave Jennings, who has punted for both the Giants and the Jets, has a favorite for their game today. ''I'm rooting for the Celtics,'' he said. Jennings is finishing his first season as the Jets' color radio broadcaster. For most of the 1970's and 1980's, he was part of the New York scene as a punter: from 1974 to 1984 with the Giants, and from 1985 through 1987 for the Jets.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES GUIDE TO RESTAURANTS IN NEW YORK CITY: Revised and Expanded. By Bryan Miller. (Times Books, Paper, $12.95.) With its new handy pocket-size format (and a pullout map that includes thumbnail reviews of more than 200 restaurants) this revised and expanded guide promises fulfillment in all directions. Bryan Miller, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, has expanded his best-dishes and special-categories listings among the more than 300 restaurants he reviews and rates, so that if you want the city's best sorbet and in a romantic setting, you'll know where to go. Among other categories are brunch, live music, wine, dining with children. Seven neighborhood maps.

title: Diva Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: Babe Pratt, 72, a Former Ranger And Hall of Fame Member, Dies
description: Walter (Babe) Pratt, one of hockey's first scoring defensemen and a member of the sport's Hall of Fame, died of a heart attack he suffered Friday night while attending a National Hockey League game. He was 72 years old.

title: From Soviet Quake, Echoes Widen
description: Last Tuesday rescue leaders from a half dozen countries convened in the green army tent that is now Spitak's Communist Party headquarters for a tense diplomatic faceoff in the middle of the most staggering misery any of them had ever seen.

title: Catherine Clarke to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Clarke Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and Weekapaug, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Sherman Clarke to William Sidney Sondheim, the son of Mrs. Rollin H. Teare of Old Greenwich, Conn., and James Sondheim of Easton, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Manual or Automatic?
description: NOW that automatic focusing has found its way into the ranks of professional SLRs, the time has come to look at what its real advantages are. And, while we're at it, let's survey its limitations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS JAZZ A ''Giant Xmas Jam'' is to be held by Jazz Resources at the Village Bistro in Elmsford from 8 P.M. Wednesday ''until everybody goes home,'' said Dr. Lyn Christie, director of the informal collection of jazz musicians.

title: Theater Reviews: A Different Opinion
description: I strongly feel that you are doing the New Jersey area a disservice by using Alvin Klein as a theater critic. I have cringed through many a review of fine plays and productions given by the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, that Mr. Klein reviewed negatively. He has an uncanny talent for missing the essence of a creation. He focuses on the crumbs and bypasses the delectable feast.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Brooklyn Man, Deaf at Birth, Finds Validation on the Job
description: Weekday mornings a young man named Henry I. steps off the subway from Flatbush and walks to a brick warehouse in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Reviews/Music; Trio's Pianist Goes Solo
description: Daniel Epstein, most often heard in New York as the pianist of the Raphael Trio, reminded keyboard watchers at Weill Recital Hall Friday night that he is also a satisfying interpreter of the solo literature. Like many good chamber players, he seems to lack the intensity of assertion that marks a musician for a virtuoso's career, but this does not at all mean that he plays without personal expression. He drew a modest-sized but knowledgeable audience and offered it thoughtful, well-developed interpretations.

title: Quarterbacks Need Help
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Attack on a Taxi Inspector Highlights Cabbies' Tensions
description: A baseball-bat attack last week on a New York City taxi inspector has crystallized tensions in the taxi business and created a powerful symbol of lawlessness that some industry officials fear could be used to justify a crackdown by regulators.

title: Mayor Stirs Loud Debate With Anti-Noise Stance
description: An anti-noise crusade by the Mayor of Burlington has led to a loud debate over the relationship between elected officials and the courts.

title: The Tough New Cutbacks in Child Care
description: Tucked into the Family Support Act of 1988, signed by President Reagan two months ago, are several sleeper provisions with dramatic implications for some working parents who have been receiving tax benefits for child care expenses. The provisions will drastically curtail - and in many cases altogether eliminate - the chance to claim both the dependent care tax credit and the tax exclusion for dependent care assistance provided by the parents' employers.

title: Budgeting For Europe's Ski Trails; Austria, Switzerland and Italy
description: THE decline of the dollar has had a sobering effect on the European ski resorts fearful of losing their cherished American clientele. Many resorts, particularly in Austria and Switzerland (but not in France), have been especially cautious about raising rates. The increases used to reach 10 percent and more, at least for hotels. Lech, one of Austria's leading ski areas, proudly points out that in the last three years, price increases have remained under 3 percent, and Arosa, Switzerland, reports a rise of only one percent in hotel rates this season over last. (Lift ticket prices were raised 5 1/2 percent but it was the first increase in three years.) Some resorts have raised rates on both lifts and hotels this winter by up to 5 percent. However, rates for lifts and hotels in most leading Alpine resorts continue to undercut those of major ski resorts in the United States. So despite the weaker dollar, a European ski vacation will cost about as much as one in the United States that involves air fare.

title: Blast Of Shotgun Kills Girl, 9
description: A 9-year-old girl wrapping Christmas presents was killed when her younger brother picked up a shotgun and the weapon accidentally discharged, the authorities said. Amorita I. Arias was wrapping the presents on a bed at their home about 5:30 P.M. Thursday when her 7-year-old brother came into the room and picked up the 12-gauge shotgun, said Terry Wilson, the Lewis County coroner. ''Whether he bumped it or actually pulled the trigger, I don't know,'' Mr. Wilson said.

title: What South Africa Gets for the Continent's Last Colony
description: SOUTH Africa's decision to give up control of Namibia, the last colony in Africa, is in many ways the result of the kind of compromise often proposed for the Middle East - a barter of land for peace and international acceptance.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Triceratops Don't Cuddle

title: Post-Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: FATHERS OF INVENTION: Ronald L. Gallatin and E. Philip Jones; Giving Birth To 'Unbundled' Stock
description: At Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., it was dubbed ''The Manhattan Project'' - a reference to the supersecret efforts by American scientists to create the atom bomb. And the analogy was not totally inappropriate, at least when it came to the mystery involved. For nearly 11 months, a team of Shearson bankers worked in strict secrecy to create a financial instrument they say could change the structure of public ownership of corporations.

title: Youth's Success Lies in Skateboards
description: FOUR years ago, Chip Degan of Newton, who is now 19 years old, learned to ride a skateboard while vacationing in California. He envisioned his teen-age friends back home in hilly Sussex County taking up the sport, too.

title: Foundation's New Chief Challenges Stereotypes
description: Lorie A. Slutsky was 23 years old and fresh out of graduate school when she began working at New York Community Trust, one of the country's leading foundations.

title: Review/Music; A Saxophonist's Ascetic Sounds
description: The six pieces played by the saxophonist and composer Jon Gibson at Experimental Intermedia on Tuesday night shared a gentleness that seemed, at first, self-explanatory. But as the concert progressed, it became clear that behind the small, flowerlike figures he quietly drew out of his wind instruments lay a rhythmic tension that made even his longer pieces take on the strength of detail.

title: London
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 7 Travel Advisory included information about Good Show! - the London theater advisory service developed by Jean Knox (151 Park Place, Point Richmond, Calif. 94801; 415-236-5126) - and I'm writing to tell you and your readers what a valuable service it is. I have used it three times, each time as a bon voyage gift for friends traveling to London.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'We the People'
description: LEAD: STILL frantically searching for that last-minute Christmas gift?

title: 'Mystery' for Children
description: ''The Mystery of Things,'' a new exhibition at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, is intended to promote object literacy among young visitors. Through a series of clues and puzzles, children learn the significance of objects and develop reasoning skills. More than 300 objects from the museum's permanent collection - including Akuaba dolls from Ghana, a coffee cup made from a steer horn and musical instruments - fill the nooks and crannies of a 1,700-square-foot gallery in this hands-on learning center. The museum is at 145 Brooklyn Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. Hours are Saturdays, Sundays and school holidays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Monday, Wednesdays Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 5 P.M. Admission is $2. Information: (718) 735-4400.

title: Reviews/Dance; An Italian Troupe of Proselytizers
description: Teatrodanza Contemporanea di Roma has been a pioneering modern-dance troupe in Italy, a country not known for its abiding interest in that art form. But the company performing its New York debut on Dec. 10 at the 14th Street Dance Center of the Emanu-El Midtown Y did not have the haggard and truculent look one might expect of proselytizers at the barricades.

title: Nancy Baum to Wed Jeffrey Lipsitz; Louis Baum to Marry Miss Strasser
description: Nancy Hedwig Baum and Jeffrey Adam Lipsitz, graduates of Union College, plan to marry next April. Miss Baum's brother Louis Victor Baum and Kathleen Ann Strasser are planning a June wedding.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: LEAD: MOST bullion-type coins feature gold or silver but platinum is emerging as a more visible and perhaps viable alternative. Within the last few months, Australia and Canada have introduced platinum bullion coins.

title: Reviews/Dance; Diversity of Styles In Deja Vu Program
description: A varied repertory and a forceful performing style were among the virtues of the Deja Vu Dance Theater, which appeared Friday night at the Triplex of Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: New &Noteworthy;
description: LEAD: THE DOCTOR OF DESIRE, by Allen Wheelis. (Norton, $8.95.) A psychiatrist who believes that ''sex is our tie to the world, the source of meaning'' becomes obsessed with a young female patient who reminds him of an erotic painting by Gustav Klimt. Last year our reviewer, Bettina L. Knapp, said this novel, which was written by a psychiatrist, is ''an engrossing epic journey through the thoughts and yearnings of a modern-day Faust.

title: Question Of the Week; How Do You Feel About Baseball on Cable TV?
description: I love it. The only thing better than a game a night would be two games a night.

title: Question Of the Week; How Do You Feel About Baseball on Cable TV?
description: I can very easily live with radio broadasts. I might mention that when I did watch baseball games on television I did so without sound because I understand baseball well enough so that I do not have to be told what I am seeing.

title: Finast Supermarkets Fined for Mislabeling
description: The Finast supermarket chain was fined $10,000 after pleading no contest to charges that it defrauded customers at its Main Street store in Bridgeport by mislabeling meat and other items sold by weight.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Therapy Aids In a Struggle Against Fear
description: Making a phone call, doing the laundry, walking through a crowd or driving a car make Theresa D.'s heart race, her legs stiffen and her mind ring with worry.

title: Post-Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for The Shades Of Stalag 17B
description: I WAS afraid to go back. I wanted to go, but would I travel 4,600 miles and find no trace of Stalag 17B, the P.O.W. camp west of Vienna where I had spent a year of my life? No trace of the cottage north of the Danube where, in the last weeks of World War II, with the S.S. fanned out - shooting first, asking questions later - Victor and Josefine Gutmann risked their lives to give me food and an escape route to Switzerland? No trace of where the Gutmanns now lay buried?

title: Canada Begins Final Battle Over Trade Pact
description: Faced with last-ditch opposition in Parliament, the Government has set a punishing debate schedule to force through legislation ratifying Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States before the Jan. 1 deadline.

title: For Help In Search
description: LEAD: AS the demand for child care increases, the nanny business booms.

title: Political Notes; Dinkins and His Advisers Consider Campaign Costs
description: How much money would it take to defeat Mayor Koch?

title: Q and A
description: Litigating Shareholders

title: With Lasting Doubts, India Fosters Hopes of Better Ties to China
description: MORE than half a century ago and two decades before he became India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru had a dream. Friendship between China and India, he told a conference of anti-colonial parties in 1927, would form the core of a new pan-Asianism, a base on which to build a new order in the East.

title: 2 Germanys' Political Divide Is Being Blurred by Glasnost
description: On which side of the Berlin Wall can you find German editions of Pravda or Moscow News at almost any kiosk? On which side is it hard to find any Soviet publication, in any language?

title: Reviews/Theater; Don Juan In His Own Language
description: Was there ever a ladies' man like Don Juan? In these enlightened times, one rather hopes not after seeing his villainies enacted in his mother tongue at Repertorio Espanol. This versatile company is now staging ''Don Juan Tenorio,'' Jose Zorrilla's 1844 drama. There is something special in the interpretation of Don Juan in this Spanish presentation. It catches the sense of this macho man, a hero despite his monstrous seductions and slayings and his life as a profligate and profaner.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALL THE WRONG PLACES: Adrift in the Politics of the Pacific Rim. By James Fenton. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $7.95.) James Fenton is part journalist, part Indiana Jones. He has been reporting from the front lines of the major upheavals in the Pacific Rim over the past 15 years, and in ''All the Wrong Places'' he has brilliantly captured the pathos, humor, tragedy, hope and desperation he wit-nessed.

title: Eating to Hunt
description: My father used to be an unabashed hunter who lived for deer season. Every fall, he and my two brothers would raid the kitchen before their overnight forays and pack enough food for a Marine division. While they drove off happily, I always wondered if the thrill of the sport wasn't really in bagging a deer at all, but more in boxing up all those goodies to gorge on by themselves out in the hills.

title: Sounds of the Season: 'Amahl' and Handel
description: ''MARTHA KING as the mother is extremely good,'' said the review in The New York Times of the original 1963 NBC production of Gian Carlo Menotti's Christmas opera, ''Amahl and the Night Visitors.'' Now, almost exactly 25 years later, Miss King is preparing to revisit ''Amahl,'' this time in Southport.

title: Connecticut Prisons Crowded
description: In a pessimistic assessment of problems facing Connecticut's prison system, officials say the state's prisons are among the most crowded in the nation and the ''worst is yet to come.''

title: In Competitions, the Fun Is Being Called for Jury Duty
description: There they sit, the jurors of any international musical competition, wrapped in ineffable dignity, presenting an impassive front as talented young musicians play their hearts out for them. The jurors, like the contestants, have come from all over the world for the occasion, and it will be up to them to decide who will be the figure named for possible fame and fortune.

title: Keep Racism Out of the School Of Medicine
description: CHARGES of racism and racial discrimination are endangering the quality and future of New Jersey's medical school. For more than a year a few black Newark politicians have been conducting a campaign to insinuate themselves into the hiring and promotional practices of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and its Newark-based New Jersey Medical School, Questionnaires are sent frequently to the university management, meetings are called and hearings conducted.

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE WORLD: The Semantics of Diplomacy; Getting Arafat to Say the Magic Words
description: YASIR ARAFAT and the Palestine Liberation Organization traveled a long road before finding the precise words that would satisfy the United States's criteria for opening a dialogue. The words changed only a little along this road. But taken together they produced a statement last week that Secretary of State George P. Shultz found explicit enough on three crucial matters: terrorism, key United Nations resolutions and acceptance of Israel.

title: Mazda Has All the Trimmings About Cars
description: When I was a kid, we optioned our cars the way we wanted them. That meant going to the Pep Boys - Manny, Moe and Jack - or to Western Auto or to some such store for parts.

title: Many Yield to the Lure of Risky Business
description: THOUGH the prospects are no better than grim - many more new businesses fail than succeed - new entrepreneurs continue to take the big risk, offering everything from unbaked muffin dough to semiconductor chips.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Fresh Meadows
description: LEAD: FRESH MEADOWS, a neighborhood whose heart is a 3,287-unit self-contained apartment complex, lies in the midst of Queens's residential sprawl. The complex - also called Fresh Meadows - was once hailed by the urbanologist Lewis Mumford as ''perhaps the most positive and exhilarating example of large-scale planning in the country.

title: New Rule: Keep Legs on Board at Night
description: A common sight in sailboat racing is the crew lined up on the windward rail like ducks in a row. But a new rule in offshore racing now makes it illegal to dangle legs overboard at night.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have improved the outside of my house by installing clear cedar shingles. Now I am confused as to how they should be finished. Should I use a paint or a stain, and what type (paint or stain) should I use?

title: Making Peace Instead of War
description: The Nov. 13 Opinion page article by Joseph B. Ryan entitled ''Reflections on War: A Topic for Playtime?'' was noted with more than ordinary interest.

title: 'School For Wives' Is More Than Farce
description: THE ideal wife is dutiful and dumb. That is among the ''maxims of marriage,'' according to the middle-aged Arnolphe, who is training the beautiful young Agnes to be his ''unaccomplished wife'' by keeping her in seclusion.

title: Philadelphia School Has Sponsors With Badges
description: ''Agua! Agua!'' children shout in the largely Hispanic West Kensington section of the city. They are not asking for water. The word is a code to warn drug dealers and buyers that the police, who drive marine-blue and white cars, are coming.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT THE WARREN COMMISSION
description: David Belin states that ''. . . the conclusions of the autopsy physicians who testified before the Warren Commission have been supported by every panel of physicians that has examined the materials . . .'' including ''the panel appointed by the House Select Committee on Assassinations in 1978. . . .'' I was a member of the forensic-pathology panel appointed by that committee and testified before the full Congressional committee in 1978. I expressed strong disagreement with the Warren Commission report, especially with regard to the so-called ''single bullet theory.'' CYRIL H. WECHT, M.D., J.D. Past President American Academy of Forensic Sciences Pittsburgh

title: Woman Dies of Injuries In Crash of Ambulance
description: One person has died of injuries suffered in an ambulance crash Friday that injured eight and that officials attributed to a de-icing chemical put on the recently paved road.

title: Miss Fixx Weds T. J. Gumina Jr.
description: Elizabeth Anne Fixx, the daughter of Mary Durling Fixx of Oberlin, Ohio, and the late James F. Fixx, was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Gumina Jr., the son of Mr. Gumina of East Brunswick, N.J., and Dolores Kinder of Mystic Isles, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Philip L. Culbertson performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Oberlin.

title: Working for Honor
description: ''I won't claim that I liked school,'' Isaac Shongwe said last weekend, ''but I hated the position I was in.'' Not so now. The 26-year-old black South African has become a member of an elite within an elite, one of the few of his race from his country to hold one of the Rhodes Scholarships, created in 1903 by the British colonial administrator of that name to prepare Anglo-Saxon men to lead the Western world. At the age of 12, two years after his mother died, Mr. Shongwe enrolled himself in a two-room secondary school for blacks, to work his way out of manual labor; he will enter Oxford University for two years of study this fall. ''Disregarding what Cecil Rhodes stood for, I think the scholarship is a great honor,'' he said. ''More of us have to work hard for education.''

title: Army Base Splits On Smoking Ban
description: THE commander of the Army base here has proposed the first basewide ban on indoor smoking at a United States military installation. But representatives of the 3,500 civilian employees at the base say they will fight to keep their right to smoke indoors in designated areas.

title: 'A Lot of These Affairs Are Never Revealed'
description: FOR three decades, Frederick Humphrey, a professor of family studies at the University of Connecticut and a marriage and family counselor, has studied extramarital affairs and counseled people who are having them.

title: Inside
description: Foreign Affairs Transition

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN DIAMONDS;
TRYING TO GET MEN TO SPARKLE LIKE WOMEN
description: LEAD: The Japanese, long at the forefront of industrial technology, may also become trend setters in matters of the heart. N. W. Ayer, the advertising agency that represents DeBeers Mining Ltd., is now promoting the notion of women giving diamonds to the man in their life.

title: For Indian Business, a Force to Reckon With
description: In India's most prosperous and heavily built-up industrial region, the name Dutta Samant can strike fear in the hearts of company owners and managers.

title: Making the List:A Wish Is Still a Wish
description: EVERY year he asks me for a Christmas wish list and every year I give him one. For the last 11 years, I have started the list with the present I would most like to receive; every year it is ignored as ''not a valid Christmas present.'' The gift? A bird feeder installed at my dining room window.

title: Guilty Plea in Missouri Deaths
description: A man convicted of murder after a head was found buried in his backyard has admitted killing five other men and agreed to plead guilty, according to a report published today.

title: Baker Seeking Peace With Congress
description: James A. Baker 3d is making a slow, methodical, unobtrusive transition to his job as the next Secretary of State, but he has already indicated that he is much more willing than his predecessors to accept a large role for Congress in shaping foreign policy.

title:
ART;
>A Broad OverviewOf Recent Folk Art
description: LEAD: THE current exhibition at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry here, ''American Folk Art of the 20th Century,'' provides the warm assurance that there is an art form that seems never to change. Recent folk art is much the same as its counterparts from the last century.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Bearing Musical Tidings of Comfort and Joy
description: LEAD: The season's festive air, so often conceived in culinary terms, also has a most rewarding counterpart in musical fare, and this year's crop of recordings redolent of Christmas provides something for every palate.

title: DATA BANK: December 18, 1988

FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
In Provence, the Heady Perfume of Sweet Muscat
description: LEAD: IN 1859, the Provencal poet Frederic Mistral wrote these lines in his romantic work ''Mireio'': Lou bon Muscat de Baumo E lou Ferigoulet Alor se chourlo a lal gargato.

title: STREETSCAPES: Park Avenue; A Grand Residential Boulevard or Just Monotony Lane?
description: THERE are two ways for a commissioner at the Landmarks Preservation Commission to look at Park Avenue - as the grandest residential boulevard in Manhattan or as a waste of time, with a monotonous collection of similar buildings and constant window replacements and air-conditioner installations.

title: Salvager Is Exploring Harbor For Boston Tea Party's Crates
description: Exactly 215 years after revolutionary patriots dumped 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor to protest colonial tyranny, an explorer today began an effort to retrieve the chests.

title: The Characters Dont' Know From Adam
description: Larry Gelbart's view of this moment in American history is not bright. ''I don't think I know just how precarious our position is,'' he said, mentioning environment perils, the danger of atomic war and what he feels is a dearth of decent leadership. ''It's like you're on the Titanic and run out on the bridge, look up and see Daffy Duck at the wheel,'' he said.

title: Miss Juster Wed To Kevin Hudson
description: At the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y., Kristine LaChance Juster, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Waring Juster of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Kevin Walter Hudson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hudson of Baltimore, were married yesterday by the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller.

title: POSTINGS: Jamaica Revival; New Offices
description: When civic leaders of Jamaica, Queens, speak of a revival of their venerable business district, they point to the Social Security Administration building, which will be ready for its 2,700 office workers next month, and the three newly opened Archer Avenue subway stations. But the Federal Government paid for one and a public authority spent the money for the other. Except for the conversion of the old Gertz department store into offices and a mall, private investment has lagged.

title: A Slight Increase in Confidence
description: At least judging by one measure, individual investors' confidence in the stock market appears to be staging something of a comeback.

title: Black Ranger Shies From Publicity Over Race
description: The first black to become a Texas Ranger says he is happy to be a role model but looks forward to the day when he gets attention not because of his race but because of the cases he solves.

title: On Abuse of Cyclists By Some Motorists
description: Although I do own an automobile, I spend a great deal of time bicycling on the roads of northern Westchester. Lately, I have become very concerned about the lack of respect some motorists display toward me and my fellow bicyclists.

title: Hoyas Win 6th; Smith Scores 37
description: Alonzo Mourning made his national television debut this afternoon, but while the freshman center demonstrated why he is so highly regarded, it was Charles Smith, Georgetown's senior guard, who saved the day.

title: Cynthia Parzych Is Wed
description: Cynthia Mary Elizabeth Parzych, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Parzych of New Britain, Conn., and John Anthony Aldren Turner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Turner of Heyshott, Sussex, England, were married yesterday in the chapel of Trinity College in Hartford. The Rev. Allan Tull, the Episcopal chaplain at Trinity, performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Trinity, is president of Cynthia Parzych Publishing Inc., book publishers in New York. Her husband is the sales director for BLA Publishing, a book publisher in East Grinstead, Sussex, England.

title: Reviews/Music; Mehta Shows Off Brass, Winds and Percussion
description: It's holiday for strings time at the current New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, which will receive its fourth and final installment Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. Zubin Mehta has selected two pieces that showcase his winds, brass and percussion. Except for the lone Orin O'Brien, sawing away on her double bass to support the Mozart Wind Serenade No. 10 in B flat (K. 361), there is nary a string to be seen.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Times Magazine on Dec. 4 about the New York City Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, misidentified the building where he held an executive retreat in October. It was the Continental Insurance building, not Continental Bank.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;
Sharing Profits To Buy a Home
description: LEAD: A BANK and a developer have joined forces to make condominiums in two projects planned here affordable to buyers whose income is too low to qualify for conventional home loans.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PIGEONS ON THE GRASS. By Wolfgang Koeppen. Translated by David Ward. (Holmes & Meier, $24.95.) After almost 40 years, it is a pleasure to have an English translation of this postwar classic, particularly one so faithful to the content and tone of the original. Though less popular than Gunter Grass or Heinrich Boll, Wolfgang Koeppen is among the most important modern German writers.

title: Nets Hold Off Rally To Defeat Pacers
description: The Nets have struggled this season, but things could be worse. Just ask the Indiana Pacers.

title: Lasansky's Printmaking Virtuosity on Display in Purchase
description: FOR a printmaker of Mauricio Lasansky's stature and age, 15 images make a niggardly retrospective. But the show, which remains at the State University's Neuberger Museum in Purchase for the winter season, is a kind of trial run - not for the 74-year-old artist but for its curator, Roxanne Sexauer, who is an master's degree candidate in the university's department of visual arts. It comes with the written blessing of another prominent printmaker, Antonio Frasconi, who is a distinguished professor in the department and who, like Mr. Lasansky, was born in Buenos Aires.

title: Amy Goldenberg to Wed Robert Leitner, a Dentist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Goldenberg of Bayside, Queens, and Boynton Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Michelle Goldenberg, to Dr. Robert D. Leitner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Leitner of Brooklyn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week; How Do You Feel About Baseball on Cable TV?
description: Living in the Bronx, I feel left out. BOB LEVINSON The Bronx

title: Pamela Jane Whiteside Is Married
description: Lieut. (j.g.) Pamela Jane Whiteside, U.S.N., and Lieut. Lewis Paul James 3d, U.S.N., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Wilmette, Ill. The Rev. Wallace Moore performed the ceremony.

title: Wall St. on the Danube
description: One of the best-selling board games in Hungary these days is Capitaly, a version of Monopoly, the object of which is, of course, to amass the most property and capital at the expense of other players. Now, Hungary, long something of a hothouse for free-market experiments in the Communist world, is about to play Capitaly for real - and with capitalists, no less.

title: A Dragonish Display in New Haven
description: Bug-eyed dragons emblazoned on the Chinese ceramics exhibited at the Yale University Art Gallery are bound to spark more fantasy than fear in viewers. For the winged, horned reptiles whipping energetically around beach-ball-sized jars, breathing fire as they stretch clawed paws on basins and raging, fangs bared, on the center of great platters, are propitious symbols - not docile, but seemingly well disposed to all.

title: Prepare Desserts Ahead for the Holidays
description: HOLIDAY desserts that can be prepared in advance are a boon to the host or hostess. Most desserts made with caramel fall into this category. If they have to be molded, they must be allowed to set and are often best chilled overnight.

title: Ruth Falcon Is Wed To Douglas W. Meyer
description: The marriage of Ruth Ann Falcon, an operatic soprano, to Douglas W. Meyer, a management consultant at the First Manhattan Consulting Group in New York, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Paul L. Langstreth, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Dangerous Leap of STEPHEN FREARS
description: ONE MORNING LAST month, as London savored a rare Indian summer, Stephen Frears boarded a jet at Heathrow Airport for Los Angeles. With him were three cardboard boxes containing 12 reels of film. They were evidence that the British film director had won, or so it seemed, a race to turn a 200-year-old French novel of sex, love, corruption of innocence and other diversions of the ancien regime into Hollywood gold.

title: A May Wedding For Ms. Eskilson
description: Announcement has been made by Arlene Eskilson and John Eskilson, both of Evanston, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Christine Talbot Eskilson, to Russell Erik Sergeant, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Russell L. Sergeant of Groton Long Point, Conn., and Newfane, Vt. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: BUSH TEAM TO SEEK CHANGE IN MILITARY
description: With the naming of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, President-elect Bush has completed the selection of a national security team that will seek major changes in American military policy, transition officials said today.

title: Court Ordered 1986 Investigation Of Family of Slain 5-Year-Old Girl
description: Two years ago, a judge in Brooklyn Family Court ordered Special Services for Children to investigate the home where a 5-year-old girl was beaten to death this week, a court spokesman said yesterday.

title: SOUTHERNERS JUST THE SAME
description: KISSING COUSINS A Memory. By Hortense Calisher. 118 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95.

title: 'School for Wives;' Miliere Farce in Fairfield
description: IN Moliere's ''School for Wives,'' the ideal wife is dutiful and dumb. That is among the ''maxims of marriage,'' according to the middle-aged Arnolphe, who is training the beautiful young Agnes to be his ''unaccomplished wife'' by keeping her in seclusion.

title: Grit and Grace in Naples
description: NAPLES is a city about survival. Like Don Ignazio in the Giuseppe Marotta story ''The Gold of Naples,'' Naples has ''the capacity of getting up again after every fall, a remote, hereditary, intelligent, superior patience.'' These qualities have been necessary to survive the vicissitudes of 25 centuries in the shadow of a volcano.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FIRST ACTS: A Memoir. By B. L. Reid. (University of Georgia, $16.95.) B. L. Reid, a professor emeritus of English at Mount Holyoke College and the winner of the 1969 Pulitzer Prize for biography for ''The Man From New York: John Quinn and His Friends,'' has written a fascinating account of what it was like to grow up in a ''shabby-genteel'' Southern family in the years from the Great Depression to the end of World War II.

title: Blood, Alienation and Chauvinism Accompany Sri Lankans to Polls
description: Dharshanie is only 22. Her brother is a soldier. But that does not dampen the fire in her that turned her against one of Asia's oldest and most resilient democracies.

title: Reviews/Music; A 'Messiah' in Korean Forms a Cultural Bridge
description: The performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' Monday night at Carnegie Hall was probably of more sociological than musical interest, although it had its musical moments. This was a ''Messiah'' unlike any other this season for one simple reason: it was sung in Korean.

title: Reviews/Music; Earth and Nature Help To Shape Foss Concert
description: The Meet the Moderns concert presented by Lukas Foss and members of the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Wednesday evening at Cooper Union was called ''Music From the Planet Earth'' - not the most limiting or descriptive of titles. But as it turned out, the title had a double meaning. On one hand, it suggested the international flavor of the program, which included music by American, British, Greek, Italian and Japanese composers. On the other, it referred to the fact that most of the pieces were in some ways evocations of, or inspired by, nature.

title: 'Healthy' Institutions Are Hurting, Too
description: The basic facts about Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation-insured savings and loan associations are clear. Rounded off, the numbers at the end of 1988 will be as follows: 3,100 associations with $1.3 trillion in assets, of which 500 associations with $125 billion in assets are insolvent; another 500 associations with $175 billion in assets would also be insolvent if intangible assets - ''good will'' and the F.S.L.I.C's assurances - are not counted.

title: Donna M. Eisemann To Wed in February
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Eisemann of Lindenhurst, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Marie Eisemann to Dr. Wilson Crone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seth Crone of Charleston, S.C. The couple plan to marry in February.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have improved the outside of my house by installing clear cedar shingles. Now I am confused as to how they should be finished. Should I use a paint or a stain, and what type (paint or stain) should I use?

title: Reviews/Dance; 5 Women From Asheville
description: Wall St. Dance Works is a company of five women from Asheville, N.C., whose spirit is evident from the title they chose for their New York debut on Friday at the Cunningham Studio. The program of eight new and recent pieces was called ''Dance You Haven't Already Seen,'' which was stretching the point a little. But it was, nonetheless, a mostly pleasant evening of work performed by dancers who are easy and bright movers.

title: Seeing the Light in Chartres
description: IT looms through a fog above the flat farmland known as the Beauce, this Cathedral of Chartres, looking impossibly big, bigger than anything built by man, as I drive my car west on Route N10. Isolated and improbable on its hilltop, the mass of stone looks like a whale on a beach, or like the Ark on the first day after the flood waters receded. When I come close and park my car, the Ark shrinks to half its size.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ROMANTIC. By Aram Saroyan. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) An intelligent post-1960's male with an honest eye for his own inner workings and his era's social manners could write a male coming-of-middle-age novel with wit, poignancy and substance. He might choose to include (in addition to the ordinary sorrow of aging), the period's generational ricochet from idealism to careerism; its dizzying sexual practices, sexual roles, sexual politics; even its simple priorities.

title: For 'Earnfare Hotel' To Help Homeless
description: I read with interest your article, ''Village Says It Needs Help if It Is to Help the Homeless'' [ Nov. 27 ] . And, I agree that the county of Westchester hasn't treated Elmsford fairly. I'd like to make the following suggestions:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Big, but Not Lethargic, Eyes

title: Looming Cuts in Education Alarm Officials
description: EDUCATION Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi spent much of last week in meetings with legislators and state budget officials as the state's fiscal troubles began to threaten teacher salaries and local school aid.

title: States March Into The Breach
description: The Reagan Administration has done its best to fulfill its promise to get the Federal Government out of corporate America's life, but as it has done so, the states have rushed to fill the void. Especially in the past two years, the states have become activists in a broad variety of areas, like antitrust, consumer protection and the environment.

title: Last Summer's Soviet-U.S. Prison Visits
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CRACK FOUND IN CLOSED REACTOR AT SAVANNAH RIVER
description: The company managing three closed military nuclear reactors in South Carolina notified the Government early today that a crack had developed in one reactor's cooling system.

title: Fair-Weather Feathered Friends
description: SOMETIME around mid-September my gaze is directed skyward toward the migratory birds. As they merge into formation for their flight south I feel a sort of melancholy. I'll miss those warm-blooded feathered creatures, some of whom spent the entire spring and summer months nesting in my yard and dining on the designer bird seed I use in the feeder.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CABAL. By Clive Barker. (Poseidon, $18.95.) ''Cabal,'' the latest book from the English horror writer Clive Barker, contains a new novella and four short stories reprinted from a British collection. Together, they demonstrate why the gleefully gory Mr. Barker is at the top of his genre. Endlessly inventive, he takes familiar themes a step or two farther, twisting them into new angles.

title: Bush Is Said to Be Upset by News Leaks
description: President-elect Bush, hoping to set a tone for his administration, is determined to use public expressions of outrage and private threats of reprisals to battle leaks to journalists, senior aides said today.

title: Robert Sinkoff Is Married to Anna M. Azzariti
description: Anna M. Azzariti and Robert Sinkoff were married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York by Rabbi Deborah Hirsch. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Enrico Serranti of West Islip, L.I., and Rome, and Dr. George M. Azzariti of Alpine, N.J., and a stepdaughter of Mrs. Azzariti. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sinkoff of East Patchoque, L.I., and Pompano, Fla.

title: Rosanne, a Real Jersey Champion
description: The Oct. 30 article ''Farmer Is Reviving a Jersey Breed,'' about my farm in Washington, N.J., was excellent.

title: Kathleen Connor And John Del Col To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Connor of Stamford, Conn., and John's Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Ann Connor to John Virgilio Del Col, a son of Peter Del Col of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and LaVonne Del Col of Chappaqua, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: KEEP THINKERS IN THEIR PLACE
description: THE CONQUEST OF POLITICS Liberal Philosophy in Democratic Times. By Benjamin Barber. 220 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $25.

title: Father Inspires Dancing Daughter
description: LEAD: WHEN Tamara Telberg was a child, she would go into the darkroom with her father, Val Telberg, and watch him work.

title: NEVER UNDERESTIMATE A MISOGYNIST
description: LEAD: A HISTORY OF THEIR OWN Women in Europe From Prehistory to the Present. Volume Two. By Bonnie S. Anderson and Judith P. Zinsser. Illustrated. 572 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.50.

title: ON BEHALF OF PUTTERERS
description: LEAD: THE WAY THINGS WORK By David Macaulay. Illustrated. 384 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: Are You Listening, Santa? The Wish List for Grown-Ups
description: I KNOW the holiday season is upon us by the number of gift catalogues I receive daily. Even still, I can't seem to find the things I really want. If anyone out there is listening, here's a list of items I'd love to receive.

title: Kathy Graff Plans to Wed Benjamin Kline in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Robert Graff of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathy Susan Graff to Benjamin Joseph Kline, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Kline of St. Petersburg, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: LIVING ON BORROWED IMPORTANCE
description: LEAD: NIGHT STUDIO A Memoir of Philip Guston. By Musa Mayer. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
