title: Post-Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Health Panel Approves Newark Hospital for Children
description: State health officials have given preliminary approval to plans by United Hospitals Medical Center of Newark to build New Jersey's first free-standing, full-service children's hospital.

title: Lilco and Customers in Talks on Suit
description: Representatives of the Long Island Lighting Company and several of its customers began discussions yesterday aimed at reaching a settlement in Suffolk County's racketeering suit against the utility.

title: Detroit Drug Empire Showed All the Traits of Big Business
description: An upstart company in Detroit became a giant in its market by identifying a hot growth industry, shoring up its manufacturing and sales divisions, setting up strict quality control and advertising discount prices.

title: THE NATION: The Federal Safety Net; Bank Failures Set Records; The Insured Public Is Calm
description: WHEN L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, held a press conference last week on the banking industry's record profits for the third quarter, another bit of information was disclosed almost as an aside: that 1988 would see another record -for bank failures.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT THE WARREN COMMISSION
description: I do not subscribe to any particular conspiracy theory, nor are my doubts fueled by ''speculations'' of ''sensationalists.'' I do not doubt Oswald's participation, only his independence. Some of the theories that have been advanced are clearly nonsense. On others, I reserve opinion. The so-called Mafia theory is intriguing, but hardly proven. I would point out, though, that Mr. Belin's reasoning that Jack Ruby would not have attempted a hit where he was ''surrounded by police'' is unrealistic. When, after Oswald's arrest, would this condition not have pertained?

title: Hunting of Deer Begins
description: LEAD: ''THIS is like shooting animals in a petting zoo,'' said Mark Kirshner, a resident of Fire Island who jogs the back trails from the Sunken Forest to the lighthouse, areas that are now open to deer hunting.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: Books have long been considered a staple of holiday gift-giving.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-29

title: Sheila M. Mullaney Becomes the Bride Of Paul Andrew Rippe, an Executive
description: Sheila McMorrow Mullaney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mullaney Jr. of Westfield, N.J., and Montego Bay, Jamaica, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York to Paul Andrew Rippe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Demuth Rippe, also of Westfield. The Rev. Michael Desmond performed the ceremony.

title: When Erick Hawkins Sets Out to Enlighten
description: A mental clearing, refreshing as a spring shower, comes from the best of Erick Hawkins. His dances are the most uncluttered around, and his dancers, this season, have performed with a polished precision that makes it easier than ever to appreciate the clarity of movement so special to Hawkins choreography.

title: 3 Officials of L.I. Construction Union Are Indicted
description: Charging that the largest construction union on Long Island has been controlled by the Mafia for more than 20 years, Federal prosecutors have obtained racketeering indictments against the union's three principal officials.

title: FOCUS: Downtowns; A Plan to Revive Retailing in the Loop
description: MARSHALL FIELD'S, the nation's second largest department store after Macy's Herald Square in New York City, has unveiled the first phase of a five-year, $110 million renovation that it hopes will complete a decade-long transformation of State Street from a declining retail district to a vibrant mixed-use area.

title: From Russia With Perestroika: Caution
description: AT about the same time Mikhail S. Gorbachev was addressing the United Nations in Manhattan, John G. Swanhaus Jr. of Pepsico was speaking about doing business with the Soviet Union at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains. Mr. Swanhaus was one of seven experts at a conference of the World Trade Club of Westchester on doing business in the Soviet Union.

title: Affordability
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Play AM
description: To the Editor:

title: Simple and Safe Continues to Sell Best
description: Fourteen months after the stock market crash, individual investors overwhelmingly prefer investments that they believe are simple, safe and predictable, financial executives say. But there is one big exception: Many investors are snapping up shares of ''junk bond'' funds - apparently feeling the high returns are worth the risks.

title: THE NATION: The View From America's Stranded Public Schools; Gangs and Drugs: Denver Feels the Pull of Poverty
description: A NEW subject has been added to the training of Denver public-school teachers: the study of gang behavior. A few years ago, teachers here said, the notion would have seemed preposterous. But the rise in gangs and the problems they cause illustrates the changed nature of the classroom in Denver.

title: Soviets and Afghans Discuss Prisoner Swap
description: Afghan guerrillas and Soviet diplomats met here today for a second round of talks on a prisoner exchange in Afghanistan, the rebels said.

title: Companies Help Employees Buy Homes
description: EMPLOYERS in regions where housing is particularly costly, like northeastern New Jersey, are finding it in their interest to help rank-and-file employees buy homes, according to housing authorities.

title: Islanders End the Embarrassment
description: The two teams came to the game dressed in each other's morale tonight.

title: First Steps are Taken Toward Estuary Center
description: LEAD: THE approaching new year may bring a new chapter to the long and often bitter saga of the Croton Point landfill.

title: THE NATION: The View From America's Stranded Public Schools; Out of Patience: Detroiters Say No to More Taxes
description: THE people of Detroit have been willing to spend money on their public schools in the past, approving 9 out of 10 property tax increases in the last decade. But they have lately changed their minds. In November, for example, voters agreed to renew an existing school tax but rejected a proposal to increase the tax and a proposal for a bond issue to pay off the schools' accumulated debt of nearly $70 million.

title: Patricia J. Netter To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Netter of the New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Jane Netter to William McAlpin Shiland Jr., a son of the late Harriet Manice Shiland of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Shiland of Locust Valley, L.I., and New York. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping Holiday Gifts Alive and Healthy
description: LEAD: THE increasing popularity of plants makes it certain that many will be given as holiday gifts again this year. Flowering poinsettia and amaryllis help brighten the season, and green plants are appreciated as gifts for both home and office. But often overlooked is the fact that plants are living entities and have requirements that must be met if they are to survive.

title: Ruling Deals Blow To Drug Gear Sales
description: LEAD: RAIDS by the United States Customs Service on a Hauppauge company that it said was selling drug paraphernalia have drawn national attention because of the Constitutional issues they raised, law enforcement and legal officials say.

title: BEER, GUNS AND NIETZSCHE
description: THE FOOL'S PROGRESS An Honest Novel. By Edward Abbey. 485 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Rocky Flats: Death Inc.
description: LEAD: The appalling safety record of the nuclear weapons industry nationwide and the threat it has posed to public health - a story that has been unfolding for weeks - is old news to those of us in Colorado who have monitored the Rocky Flats plant, near Denver, for years.

title: Corrections
description: An article about Hong Kong on Nov. 6 misstated the cost of a three-night package at the Holiday Inn Harbour View. The price of a room for two is $103 for one night, not three nights.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN DIAMONDS;
A Blaze of Gems for a Cold Winter's Night
description: LEAD: Diamonds are not only forever, they are also for Christmas. December is far and away the biggest month for diamond sales: in 1987, more than 40 percent of all diamonds were sold in December and about a quarter of all engagement rings are purchased for the holiday season. Why are diamonds so popular at Christmas?

title: DRUG TEST POLICY CAUGHT IN SNAGS
description: More than two years after President Reagan proposed widespread drug testing in the Government, some obstacles to the program have crumbled. But it still faces stiff legal challenges, and Congress has restricted its scope.

title: ARMENIANS WARM TO SOVIET PREMIER
description: In the tragedy of the earthquake that shattered northwest Armenia, Prime minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov has emerged as the Kremlin's main figure of compassion, using authority that would ordinarily be exercised by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Question Of the Week; How Do You Feel About Baseball on Cable TV?
description: Granting cable television networks more exclusive contracts to broadcast games would make the games less accessible to the public. Isn't it bad enough that you can't compete with the corporations for a decent seat at the stadium? RACHEL DENBER New York

title: Torture Said to Rise in Philippine Drive on Rebels
description: Torture cases in the Philippines have increased as the Government has stepped up its fight against Communist insurgents, Amnesty International said in a report this week.

title: Question Of the Week; How Do You Feel About Baseball on Cable TV?
description: Baseball on cable television stinks. Living in Brooklyn and not having cable, it's understandable that I'd be upset.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Government, First Hand
description: LEAD: When George Bush is inaugurated on Jan. 20, 23 students from Woodlands High School will be there. The group will also attend a special inaugural ball for young people, sit in on Congressional proceedings, and meet with politicians during a weeklong stay in the capital.

title: U.S. Drops Out of Copter Pricing Suit
description: The Government has decided to withdraw from a lawsuit alleging that the Hughes Helicopter Company overcharged the Army by as much as $175 million in developing the Apache helicopter, the Justice Department announced Friday.

title: Patriot Hopes Diminish
description: Sammy Winder ran for two touchdowns and Tony Dorsett rushed for another today, powering the Denver Broncos to a 21-10 victory over New England and damaging the Patriots' playoff hopes. The Denver victory clinched a wild-card playoff berth for the Houston Oilers.

title: Report Finds Fewer Jobs for High School Dropouts
description: Wanted: Floor sweeper.

title: Miss Wormwood Weds M. W. Atkins
description: Juliann Marie Wormwood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Bertan Wormwood of Manchester, N.H., and Michael William Atkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Atkins of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday at Olde Farms in Grantham, N.H. Justice of the Peace Kathryn Osgood of Grantham performed the ceremony.

title: When a Mother's Nonsmoking Example Is Not Enough
description: I THOUGHT that once I quit, that would be the end of it. Beyond physical withdrawal, however, the process took much emotional time and energy just to get going, to get over the first hurdle. Quitting smoking, like any other addiction, is a lifelong commitment, but it was one I had decided to make.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Choreography of Mayhem By the Bill Cratty Company
description: Bill Cratty must delight in making dances. The two new works his Bill Cratty Dance Theater presented Thursday night at St. Mark's Church were filled with unusual steps. The quirkier they looked, the better he appeared to like them. But if they revealed Mr. Cratty to be endlessly inventive, they also suggested that he may find it difficult to edit his creations.

title: Curb on Hunting Urged After Shooting in Maine
description: Karen Wood went to the backyard of her house at the edge of dense woods in this northern Maine town one afternoon last month, apparently to ask hunters to back off from the area around her property. She never had the chance.

title: Correction
description: A report in the New Jersey Guide column of the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday about Montclair State College's ''Messiah'' Sing-In gave an incorrect time supplied by the college. The event will take place today at 3 P.M. in St. Peter's Church, 261 Roseland Avenue, Essex Fells.

title: The Great First-Day Cover Controversy
description: FOR a collector of modern first-day covers, every day is 30 days long and most American towns turn out to be Merrifield, Va.

title: A Swedish Everyman Trapped in a False Eden
description: Max Von Sydow knew he wanted to be in ''Pelle the Conqueror'' by the time he had read just 25 pages of the screenplay. The script was a page-turner, he recalled, but more important was the character he was being asked to play, that of an ordinary individual who, in the course of the story, displays the full range of human emotion - the kind of role, he says, that comes his way too rarely in Hollywood.

title:
THE REGION;
For Black New Yorkers, a Bleak Picture Is Put Into Words
description: LEAD: TO those who are its subjects, the report of Mayor Koch's Commission on Black New Yorkers came not as a revelation but as a redundancy.

title: A PAIN IN THE NECK
description: With only one serious neurological injury in tens of millions of manipulations, it would seem that chiropractors have the safest treatment for neck and back problems. This is demonstrated by the fact that chiropractors pay one-tenth the premiums for malpractice coverage that neurologists do.

title: Shoreham: Ratepayers Enter the Fray
description: LEAD: IN 20 years of fighting over the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Long Island groups and organizations on all sides of the issue have come, gone and even stayed.

title: Paul Hughes Jr. Wed in Delaware To Miss Williams
description: Elizabeth Chandler Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Henderson Williams of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Paul Russell Hughes Jr., the son of Mrs. Hughes of Washington and the late Mr. Hughes. The Rev. David Sheehan Jr. performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church, Hillcrest.

title: Subduing the Lion Killers
description: AS DUSK APPROACH-ed, thick gray clouds hung over Nairobi, Kenya, like a heavy canopy, and the air had a damp mid-winter chill. Standing in three inches of reddish-purple onion skins, several women from the ancient nomadic Masai tribe, with clean-shaven heads and long beaded earrings, shivered as they drew their red cotton shawls more snugly over their bare shoulders.

title: Coping When the Best Defense Is Long Johns
description: When Bart Starr snatched the snap and lunged into the end zone with 13 seconds left, he clinched that classic Green Bay Packers 21-17 victory over the Dallas Cowboys that is regarded as one of the greatest games in National Football League history.

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Children's Aid Society Stretches Its Capacity
description: More. That has been the watchword for the Children's Aid Society throughout 1988. We have stretched our capacity to the limit, yet there are still more children who need to be helped, provided for and even rescued. More families who need our services and who turn to us when things go bad: a child who runs away, an infant who gets sick, a family that is burned out of its home.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The decision to open official U.S. talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization lets President-elect George Bush off the hook. It opens the way for a new phase of American diplomacy in the Middle East, and a badly needed overall review of U.S. policy and concerns.

title: Budgeting For Europe's Ski Trial; In and About France's Peaks
description: IF anyone in the French ski resorts is putting a brake on prices to help American visitors parting with a weaker dollar, the evidence is hard to find. Prices have been rising steadily at a rate of 5 or 6 percent a year and increases look about the same this season, even though France's general inflation rate has been only about 3 percent in 1988. Resort operators say the reason for climbing costs is the substantial investment made in recent years to improve equipment and facilities. Most snow resorts in the French Alps now offer access to the terrain of three or more other centers.

title: PINS: Parents Feel Overwhelmed
description: People must be made aware of the situation that presently exists with regard to rebellious teen-agers or, worse yet, those on drugs. Parents all too often are being victimized by their sons and daughters because of the present laws.

title: Officer Shoots Himself in Leg
description: A New York City police officer accidentally shot himself in the leg last night while adjusting his gunbelt in a patrol car, the police said. The officer, Thomas Weil, is assigned to the 77th Precinct in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. He was adjusting his belt while sitting at the intersection of Rochester and Atlantic Avenues when the gun went off, firing a bullet into his left calf, a police spokesman, Sgt. Maurice Howard, said. He was in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital.

title: We've Become a Nation of Very Busy People
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Meeting Social Needs Of Staten Islanders
description: For 69 years, since World War I, Staten Island Family Service Inc. has provided continuous service to the social needs of Staten Islanders. As the oldest nonsectarian social agency on Staten Island, it has continued its mandate of preserving the worth of the individual and strengthening the family unit. This task becomes more difficult each year because of the nature of the social problems presented and the need for ever-increasing financial resources.

title: A Time to Rally The Spirit
description: MY MOTHER-IN-LAW is 85, or so we think.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 18, 1988
POSTINGS: Hamden Restoration; Trust on the Move
description: The Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation will move its headquarters from New Haven upland to Hamden, and the change will serve a number of purposes besides upgrading the nonprofit group from a renter to an owner.

title: ART VIEW
description: In any honor roll of the genuine, unspoiled, time-tested collectors of the last 100 years, a place should be reserved for Henri Vever (1854-1942), a third-generation Parisian jeweler whose holdings of Persian and Indian art are now the pride of the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, a recently arrived adjunct of the Smithsonian Institution, in Washington. Anyone who wishes to check this out should go forthwith to the Sackler Gallery, where 160 paintings, manuscripts, calligraphies and bookbindings from the Vever collection will be on view through April 30 in an exhibition called ''A Jeweler's Eye: Islamic Arts of the Book From the Vever Collection.''

title: AN APPETITE FOR POWER
description: LEAD: FASTING GIRLS The Emergence of Anorexia Nervosa as a Modern Disease. By Joan Jacobs Brumberg. Illustrated. 366 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: THE INSTINCTIVE 'WE'
description: TWO-PART INVENTION The Story of a Marriage. By Madeleine L'Engle. 232 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: The author of CONTROL (Zebra, $19.95) is Jack Anderson -the Jack Anderson, the investigative reporter whose column is syndicated across the country. This is his first novel, and it is written from the heart even if it is not written in the stylish sort of prose that might win him another Pulitzer.

title: Daughter Strolls Through a Garden of Metaphorical Delights
description: IN Bristol, Va., the flower gardens are gone to weeds, the bachelor's buttons, the roses and the sweet william choked out by vines and nettle and jimson. But the purple cockscomb and the blue asters rise defiantly above the tangle and the touch-me-nots seed themselves generously when I press the ripe pods.

title: Collusion Is Over, but Excess Is Back
description: The three-year attempt by major league baseball owners to undercut free agency is history. Here lies collusion, R.I.P. Farewell, adios, sayonara. Goodbye and good riddance.

title: Personal Christmas Greetings: The Art of the Few
description: LEAD: FOR many of Connecticut's artists, the message delivered by a Christmas card is too important to be left to strangers. They make their own.

title: Diva In Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CANDLELIGHT CONCERTS The Hartford Symphony Orchestra has returned to work following its 11-week strike, and 20 of its members will give three ''Christmas by Candlelight'' concerts this week at the Old Avon Farms School Refectory in Avon. At 8 P.M. Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the music of Handel, Vivaldi and Leopold Mozart, Mozart's father, will be performed. Excerpts from Howard Blake's ''Snowman'' will be sung by Karli Gilbertson, soprano, and readings from Dickens, Shakespeare, Churchill, Bob Hope and Erma Bombeck will be delivered by Ruth Lanzer, a Hartford Stage Company actress.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have improved the outside of my house by installing clear cedar shingles. Now I am confused as to how they should be finished. Should I use a paint or a stain, and what type (paint or stain) should I use?

title: ACADEMIC FREEDOM IS KEY ISSUE IN SUIT
description: Academic freedom and the autonomy of universities have emerged as key issues in the opening days of a Roman Catholic theologian's suit charging the Catholic University of America with breach of contract.

title:
DINING OUT;
Stove-Top Cooking in Larchmont
description: LEAD: EVEN though Harry no longer presides in the kitchen, procedures remain familiar at Harry's Sauteuse. Stove-top cooking - sauteing, as the name suggests - is still the order of the day as it has been since the restaurant's inception 11 years ago. Only the addition of a few seafood and pasta dishes has slightly altered the familiar menu.

title: Tina Victor and William McGrail 3d, Real-Estate Executive, Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Victor of Glen Cove, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martine Varick Victor to William P. McGrail 3d, a son of Mrs. Gaines Gwathmey Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., and Mr. McGrail Jr. of Remsenburg, L.I., and New York. The couple plan to marry in May. Ms. Victor, who is known as Tina, works in the consignment department at William Doyle Galleries in New York. She graduated from the Verde Valley School in Sedona, Ariz., and from Bennington College. Her father, now retired, was a vice president and the secretary and counsel of the Babcock & Wilcox Company. The future bride is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Royall Victor of New York and the late Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Peters Jr. of Glen Head. Mr. Victor was a partner in the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. Mr. Peters was a president of the Corn Exchange Bank in New York. The future bridegroom, a senior vice president of the Vector Real Estate Corporation in New York, graduated from the Fay and Lawrenceville Schools and from Boston University. His marriage ended in divorce. His father is a partner in Habitat Industries, a manufacturing concern in New York. Mr. McGrail is a grandson of the late William Larimer Jones, a president of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Company in Pittsburgh.

title: OHIO GETS DEADLINE ON POLLUTION PLAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has given Ohio officials two months to adopt a plan to inspect automobiles for pollution emissions in the Cleveland area or face a cutoff of $20 million in Federal highway funds.

title: Dress Code in Baltimore
description: A new public school dress code bars students from wearing gold jewelry, leather or fur coats and torn clothing at middle and senior high schools. The dress code, which takes effect in February, is is part of an effort to stem school violence by setting the standard ''for what is unacceptable,'' said Jacquelyn Hardy, spokeswoman for the schools. The code also bars sweat suits or jogging outfits, multiple rings or precious non-school rings, pajama-type hair rollers, slippers, shorts, halter tops, see-through tops and apparel bearing vulgar statements or statements related to the use of drugs, alcohol, sex or violence.

title: 1988 The Ups and Downs
description: No one who was there will ever quite forget the denouement of the pouf. A zany, delightful silhouette materializing from swags of fabric fluffed out over short, bouncy skirts, the pouf had swept international fashion in 1987 and catapulted its inventor, Paris couturier Christian Lacroix, to world fame. On this memorable April evening, 1988, it was still immensely popular - indeed, a highlight of the fashions worn at the gala opening performance of the American Ballet Theater at Lincoln Center. But for Lacroix, the moment was hardly victorious. The designer saw for perhaps the first time the real life his creation had assumed. He could barely mask an expression of glazed disbelief as he regarded multitudes of women, most, to put it politely, of a certain age, turning the pouf into a parody of style.

title: Bank Links Growth to L.I. Sound
description: A BANK in southeastern Connecticut has devised a plan to not only market itself, but also to help groups improve Long Island Sound, which is threatened by pollution.

title: Many Have Watched Climbing Monkeys
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MERELY PLAYERS. By Gregory Mcdonald. (Hill & Company, $16.95.) At the center of Gregory Mcdonald's 18th novel, ''Merely Players,'' is Janet Twombly, a perfect girl-next-door type from a little town in Maine who has left that world behind for reasons she cannot explain. Janet, as one admirer observes, ''has an idea of freedom, but she hasn't any idea what to do with it.

title: Recruiting Problems in New York Slowing U.S. Trials of AIDS Drug
description: The largest and perhaps the most important trial in the search for AIDS treatments is floundering in New York City, with few patients volunteering and many of those who do suspected of cheating.

title: Abrams Says Head of Foundation Lived Well on Charity's Millions
description: The president of a New York foundation was accused last week of looting more than $6.9 million from the charity to maintain a life style that included residences in New York and Florida, foreign travel, opening nights at the opera and theater and meals at fashionable restaurants.

title: Independent Publishers
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I thought at one time they were trying to use the rescue teams to say that no one was left alive and they could go in to begin demolishing and clearing. We let them know in very strong terms that they were wrong.'' - Norman F. Roundell, a British volunteer in Armenia, speaking of Soviet officials. [ 1:1 ]

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping Holiday Gifts Alive and Healthy
description: LEAD: THE increasing popularity of plants makes it certain that many will be given as holiday gifts again this year. Flowering poinsettia and amaryllis help brighten the season, and green plants are appreciated as gifts for both home and office. But often overlooked is the fact that plants are living entities and have requirements that must be met if they are to survive.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT THE WARREN COMMISSION
description: I was amused by David W. Belin's description of myself and G. Robert Blakey, chief counsel of the House Select Committee on Assassinations and now professor of law at Notre Dame, as ''assassination sensationalists'' (''The Warren Commission: Why We Still Don't Believe It,'' Nov. 20). Mr. Belin asserts that Jack Ruby's polygraph test cleared him of conspiracy. In fact, a panel of polygraph experts, commissioned by the House Assassinations Committee, found that Ruby's test ''was not validly conducted,'' and, thus, impossible to interpret. The committee determined, moreover, from independent conflicting testimony and records, that Ruby lied at least twice during the polygraph session.

title: THE SERIOUSLY ILL AND THE 'WORRIED WELL'
description: NOWHERE TO GO The Tragic Odyssey of the Homeless Mentally Ill. By E. Fuller Torrey. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: A Modern Woman's Secret Delight: The Hot Stove
description: I AM a liberated woman. I work. I have an I.R.A. And I can discuss the pros and cons of local Chinese takeout with the best of them.

title: Mass Transit Needed in the Suburbs
description: Russell Olwell's article (''Mass Transit: It's Still a Good Idea,'' Nov. 20) was a breath of fresh air, hard to find in the suburbs. I ride the bus to work each day, and I'm amazed that most of the cars I see contain just the driver. Meanwhile, buses are left to people too poor to afford a car and riding the bus is considered degrading.

title: SAFETY BARRIERS
description: Once, the fear of wrinkles was enough to send women racing for a jar of cream. Now, the threats to skin are, well, more threatening. The diminishing ozone layer, the multitude of pollutants, the swarm of free radicals - all are being flagged by cosmetics companies as hazards to skin. It figures that a new category of products would emerge to protect skin from the environment.

title: Beth Hunter Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Gayle Hunter to Patrick Joseph Smith, a son of Joan D. Smith of Hauppauge, L.I., and Raymond D. Smith of Midlothian, Va., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Morgan V. Hunter of Fairfield, Conn., and Wailea, Maui, Hawaii, the parents of the bride-to-be.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 18, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 20 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. 3 5 16 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. 4 4 9 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 2 2 7 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 3 3 6 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 4 5 35 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 8 14 2 CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An album of pictures taken by 100 photographers. 9 9 8 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 10 7 10 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 11 8 8 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 12 11 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 2 2 5 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 3 4 2 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 4 3 10 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 5 5 37 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' Choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE LETTERS OF JACK LONDON, edited by Earle Labor, Robert C. Leitz, 3d and I. Milo Shepard. (Stanford University, three volumes, $139.50.) More than 1,500 of London's letters following the supercharged life of the American writer who published 50 books and lived like a whilwind in the space of only 40 years.

title: The Camera Is Proving Its Case In the Courtroom
description: During the live television coverage of Hedda Nussbaum's testimony last week, a journalist friend of mine had a complaint. ''The show's interesting,'' he said, ''but it isn't like 'L. A. Law.' ''

title: Pretoria's White Tribe Is Split on Its Sacred Day
description: Danie Williams, dressed for the occasion in khaki with a pistol in his leather belt, considered what the Day of the Covenant meant to his Afrikaner forebears, who gunned down a far larger Zulu force at the Battle of Blood River 150 years ago today.

title: U.S. Jews' Muted Reaction Said to Reflect New Uncertainty
description: The muted reaction of American Jewish groups this week to the Reagan Administration's decision to enter talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization reflected a delicate balance of opinion between uneasiness with the status quo and worries that changes in it would threaten Israel.

title: The Great War Of the Raisins
description: IN a parallel to the old my-wash-is-whiter-than-your-wash TV commercials, the General Foods Corporation advertised its Post raisin bran cereal and suggested, in effect: ''Our raisins are better than their raisins.''

title: Warmth, From Prim To Puckish
description: AS far as cold-weather gear is concerned, the ultra-stylish segment of the small-person population seems split into two distinct camps. On one side are the traditionalists: those who prefer their winter coats in the precisely tailored shapes made popular way back in the 1930's by Britain's two little princesses, Elizabeth and Margaret. Not too surprisingly, these cover-ups are called princess coats, and among their distinguishing characteristics are velvet collars and cuffs, and a very correct little row of buttons - sometimes velvet - down the front.

title: Plan for Woodland Thwarted
description: PRESERVATIONISTS in this Bergen County seat have claimed a victory in a two-year battle to thwart construction on a 14-acre tract of virgin woodland, but city officials and the property's owner say the fight is only a delaying action.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Middle-Density Zoning; A Queens Project Tests 'Quality Housing'
description: A HIGH wooden fence surrounds a construction site in the Hillcrest section of Queens these days, leaving passers-by ignorant of the development experiment about to take place within. It is David E. Marx's Quality Housing apartment building.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Building-Restriction Plan Splits Greenwich
description: BUILDING or remodeling a house in Greenwich could be severely restricted if regulations under consideration by the Planning and Zoning Commission are adopted. A vote is expected in mid-January.

title: Correction
description: Because of computer entry errors, a letter on page 3 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the Lincoln Center Theater, gives an incorrect date for a telecast and misstates the organization's budgetary needs. The date, for ''Voices of Sarafina!,'' is Dec. 28. The amount required for next year's season is $5 million to $5.5 million.

title: Susan Gayle Kravet Weds Elliot R. Pecker on L.I.
description: The marriage of Susan Gayle Kravet, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Kravet of North Hills, L.I., and Elliot R. Pecker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon Pecker of Sands Point, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., took place last night at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I. Cantor Jacob Yaron performed the ceremony Susan Stern Kravet was matron of honor for her sister-in-law. Steven Pecker was his brother's best man.

title: Staining Furniture
description: FURNITURE stain is a finishing material used to color and enhance the grain pattern of wood. Because it is absorbed into wood and does not protect it, a surface-coating finish of shellac, lacquer, varnish or wax also must be applied.

title: A Busy Time Of Year
description: BE sure to use certified outdoor wiring when decorating trees and shrubs. Prune overgrown holly, yew, juniper, spruce and pine and use these trimmings for holiday decorations. Water pots of hardy bulbs stored in the basement or cool room to be sure they form strong roots so they can be forced into bloom during the winter months. Keep Busy

title:
TV VIEW;
Stopovers En Route to the Global Village
description: LEAD: Recently, I had a rare opportunity to test the temper of the international television audience in three vastly different societies. I began during the heat of the Presidential campaign in heartland America on an artist-and-writer's residency at the Bemis Foundation in Omaha, then moved on to the U.S.S.R., where I spent a month traveling and developing a collaborative video-art project with Gosteleradio, the Soviet state-run television network (for broadcast here on public TV next year), and ended last month in Tokyo, on a visiting journalist's grant from the Japanese

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: EVERYONE likes getting gifts, which does not mean that everyone likes the gifts they get. No indeed.

title: Post-Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Carson Is In, McMillan Is Out
description: The Giants activated Harry Carson, their defensive captain, yesterday for today's game against the Jets. Meanwhile, the Jets placed Erik McMillan, their starting free safety, on injured reserve.

title: Lawyers Redirect Lives As They Help Homeless
description: Elizabeth Bader had been representing Angel Quesada for months before the 63-year-old Cuban refugee confided that he missed appointments because he did not have bus fare or a place to bathe before he went to her office.

title: Safe Places for Runaways
description: Stores with such names as Video Kingdom, Gino's Deli, the Corner Store, Calabia Pizza, Cook's Restaurant and What a Bagel - all of them places to which many youngsters naturally gravitate - are now serving as temporary refuges for runaways.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Cruise Lines Limiting Stops In Antarctica

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO MR. X
description: GEORGE KENNAN AND THE DILEMMAS OF US FOREIGN POLICY By David Mayers. 402 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $32.50.

title:
GARDENING;
Keeping Holiday Gifts Alive and Healthy
description: LEAD: THE increasing popularity of plants makes it certain that many will be given as holiday gifts again this year. Flowering poinsettia and amaryllis help brighten the season, and green plants are appreciated as gifts for both home and office. But often overlooked is the fact that plants are living entities and have requirements that must be met if they are to survive.

title: Christmas Classics and a New 'Frosty'
description: THE children are out of school, and from now till year's end, there are plenty of family happenings around the county to keep them musically involved. Today at 1 and 3 P.M., for instance, ''The New Adventures of Frosty the Snowman'' (presumably he enters a literary time warp as the cast includes Snow White, Winnie the Pooh and Raggedy Ann) is on display at the Tarrytown Music Hall.

title: North Africa, More Relaxed, Gains in Trade
description: The lines of cars and the parade of pedestrians at the border here are the surest signs of the improved climate between Morocco and Algeria since they restored diplomatic relations in May.

title: Giants Go for the Title
description: When the Giants play the Jets at 1 P.M. today in Giants Stadium, it will be a big game, but not the Big Game.

title: Having Fun, Aiding Others Teen-Age Revelry
description: Dec. 18 - Teen-agers by the hundred - 10th graders through freshmen - from 50 private and public schools and colleges are expected at the 32d annual Gold and Silver Ball. The black-tie evening from 8:30 to 1 at the Palladium, 136 East 14th Street, will benefit the Youth Counseling League, which provides free and low-cost psychiatric and vocational counseling to teen-agers and young adults in New York City and Westchester County. Dancing, dinner and nonalcoholic drinks. Tickets, $175, at the door. Church Concert

title: But There Is No Shortage of Money
description: For a half-century, America's system of housing finance relied heavily on a highly regulated, specialized network of savings and loan institutions to finance owning a home. But the protective environment of rigid regulation was legislated away in the early 1980's. What is to become of our nation's home financing system? Will it survive?

title: Monkey King Under the Big Top
description: There once was an extraordinary monkey who could be found only in the opera until he came to America and scampered about in a circus, which is something he would never do back where he came from.

title: RESULTS
description: Skiing Victory for Girardelli: Marc Girardelli, the Austrian-born skier from Luxembourg, won his second World Cup slalom this season yesterday at Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia, and moved into first place in the overall standing. Armin Bittner of West Germany was second, and Alberto Tomba of Italy finished third. Girardelli's time was 1 minute 50.52 seconds.(AP) First of Season for Nykaenen: Matti Nykaenen of Finland soared to a final jump of 90 meters in near-perfect form yesterday to win the 70-meter World Cup jump at Sapporo, Japan, for his first victory of the season. Nykanaen, a triple gold medalist at Calgary last February, sailed 88.5 on his first jump for a total score of 219.7 points to beat Dieter Thoma of West Germany, who had the longest jump, 94.5. (AP) Soccer Norwich City Keeps Lead: Norwich City maintained its lead in the English League First Division standing with a 1-0 victory at the defending champion, Liverpool, yesterday. A second-half goal by Andy Townsend enabled Norwich to remain 2 points ahead of the runner-up, Arsenal, which edged Manchester United, 2-1.(AP) Horse Racing Traskwood Triumphs: Traskwood, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., surged ahead on the final turn, opened a clear advantage into the stretch and went on to a two-length victory in the $105,400 Nashua Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday. Doc's Leader finished second in the field of 10, two lengths ahead of the favorite, Triple Buck. Traskwood's victory was his third in four career starts. The son of Believe It and April Cloud went one and one-sixteenth miles on the fast track in 1:45 1/5, earned $63,240 for Loblolly Stable and returned $11, $5 and $3 across the board.(AP) Jockey Challenge to Shoemaker: Bill Shoemaker, 57 years old and the world's winningest jockey, defeated eight other top riders yesterday to win the Miller High Life Jockey Challenge at Balmoral Park in Crete, Ill. Shoemaker rode two winners and finished second for 26 points in the three races and edge the runner-up, Jacinto Vasquez, who had 22. Sandy Hawley was third, followed by Pat Day, Randy Romero, Jean Cruquet, Laffit Pincay Jr., Julie Krone and Ray Sibille. (AP) Golf 3-Shot Lead for Hill and Walker: Dave Hill and Colleen Walker combined for a 10-under-par 62 yesterday for a 122 total and a three-shot lead after two rounds of the $850,000 PGA Mazda Champions tournament at the Hyatt Dorado Beach complex in Puerto Rico. In the 12-team better-ball event, which pairs a member of the PGA Seniors Tour with an L.P.G.A. player, the leading team's 22-under-par score matched the tournament record set last year by Miller Barber and Nancy Lopez. Chi Chi Rodriguez and Jan Stephenson teamed for a 61 and a 125 total for second place.(AP) U.S. PGA Wins: The American PGA team beat the European PGA team by 4 points yesterday in the championship round to complete a sweep of the $1 million Kirin Cup World Championship in Kapalua, Hawaii. The United States beat the European PGA team in four of the six final-round matches. The United States players split the $360,000 first prize, with Joey Sindelar receiving a $4,000 bonus for the highest number of points, 8, during the four rounds.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 120, Hawks 94: Mark Price scored 17 first-half points as Cleveland, playing at home, built a 25-point halftime lead. The Cavaliers won for the eighth time in 10 games and improved their league-leading record to 15-5. Dominique Wilkins led the Hawks with 22 points.(AP) 76ers 119, Jazz 107: Charles Barkley and Mike Gminski each scored 24 points and Maurice Cheeks had 6 of his season-high 21 during a decisive Philadelphia spurt as Philadelphia handed Utah its third straight loss. Utah's Karl Malone had a career-high 44 points.(AP) Pistons 100, Hornets 91: Isiah Thomas scored 6 of his 25 points during an early 14-3 spurt that put Detroit in control. The Pistons, who broke a two-game losing streak, are 11-0 this season when they've held their opponent to less than 100 points. Kelly Tripucka led Charlotte with 18 points.(AP) Mavericks 104, Heat 87: Brad Davis celebrated his 33d birthday by scoring 9 of his 13 points during a 14-4 fourth-quarter run that spurred Dallas. Sam Perkins led the Mavericks with 16 points. Miami was led by Rory Sparrow with 16. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 2, Nordiques 2: Greg Hawgood scored the Boston goals and Peter Stastny the Quebec ones yesterday in Jean Perron's first game as coach of the Nordiques. Perron, the former Montreal coach, replaced Ron Lapointe on Friday after Lapointe stepped down because of a tumor on a kidney. Andy Moog, the Boston goaltender, had 24 saves, 16 in the first two periods, as his career record against the Nordiques went to 11-0-2.(AP) Penguins 3, Red Wings 2: Dan Frawley scored two goals, the second just 1:01 after Phil Bourque's tying score in the third period, to give Pittsburgh the victory. The Penguins, first in the Patrick Division, are 8-0-1 in their last nine home games and 9-1-2 over all in their last 12. Bourque tied the game when he deflected Mario Lemeiux's 50-foot shot past the Detroit goaltender Glen Hanlon at 11:51.(AP) Oilers 4, Whalers 2: Esa Tikkanen and Craig Muni scored three minutes apart early in the third period for Edmonton at Hartford. Tikkanen broke a 2-2 tie with his 21st goal of the season, beating the goaltender Peter Sidorkiewicz from the slot at 3:35. Muni ripped a 50-footer past Sidorkiewicz at 6:36 to give Edmonton an insurance goal.(AP)

title: THE NATION: The View From America's Stranded Public Schools; Lack of Interest: In New Orleans, Many Opt Out
description: WHEN Elizabeth Rack moved from Houston to New Orleans, she recalls, ''Everybody told me I could not send my children to public schools.'' That was 41 years ago. ''There was a stigma and continues to be a stigma about public school education in this city, a perception that the public schools were not good,'' said Mrs. Rack, a former member of the New Orleans school board.

title: Players Rebuffed
description: The chief negotiator for the National Football League owners has rejected the latest player plan for a new contract and has urged the union to stop submitting written proposals.

title: Polygamists' Murder Trial Is Ending
description: The polygamist leader John Singer was shot to death by law officers nine years ago, but he has been evoked constantly here at the murder trial of three young men who took up arms for his cause.

title: Seahawks Capture Their First Crown
description: The offenses were spectacular. The defenses were disasters. And after the final pass had been flung, the Seattle Seahawks were in the playoffs with the first division title in their 13-year history.

title: Review/Music; 'Letters From Colette' Stress Words Not Voice
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet hit upon a workable theme, invited a few guest musicians and produced an evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday that both demanded and held the attention of its good-sized audience.

title: Pro Bono
description: * New York Lung Association to Goldsmith/Jeffrey for a print campaign.

title: Race in Jersey Is Showdown On Gun Issue
description: A bill that would make New Jersey the only state to ban the sale of handguns to most citizens is emerging as a major issue in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination here.

title: Valspar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Devils Rally in 3d To Edge Chicago
description: John MacLean and Pat Conacher scored 19 seconds apart midway through the third period tonight to give the New Jersey Devils a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Reviews/Dance; With a Twist on Tradition, Tapping Out a Tribute
description: It's easy to see why Pat Cannon and her Foot and Fiddle Dance Company have audiences whooping in their seats. Miss Cannon has hit upon a dazzling blend of square-dancing, clogging and tap dance. She makes the traditional seem new and gives the popular a creative edge.

title: Steven V. White, 60, Who Headed Bechtel Affiliate, Dies of Cancer
description: Steven V. White, president of Bechtel Investments, a major affiliate of the Bechtel Group Inc., and a well-known Mormon Church leader, died of cancer Friday at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 60 years old and lived in Moraga, Calif.

title: Renaissance of Theater In Times Sq. Needs Help
description: To the Editor:

title: New President Is Named For Carter Organization
description: The Carter Organization, the proxy solicitation concern that Donald C. Carter built, has a new president, Arthur S. Ross. Mr. Carter discovered him a few years ago in Portland, Me., and brought him to New York.

title: Losses Cut At Campeau For 9 Months
description: The Campeau Corporation said Friday that its net loss for the nine months ended Oct. 31 was $14 million, compared with a net loss of $123 million a year earlier. The company attributed the improvement to cost cutting and the selling of assets, including Filene's, Foley's, I. Magnin and Brooks Brothers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Dec. 9 about the indictment of Robert A. Rough, a former official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, described his previous affiliation with the New Jersey Bankers Association incorrectly. He is a former chairman.

title: Mark Owens Is Wed To Debra H. Epstein
description: The wedding of Debra Holly Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Epstein of New York, to Mark H. Owens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Owens of New York, took place yesterday at the Rainbow Room in New York. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: In Break With Past, Daley of Chicago Courts Blacks
description: Breaking from the overtly racial politics this city has seen in recent years, Richard M. Daley brought his mayoral campaign to a black church today and repeated his vow not to run as ''the white candidate.''

title: 2 Women Are Slain In a Car in Queens As Children Watch
description: A young boy and girl riding in the back seat of a car witnessed the fatal shooting of their mother and an aunt by two men on a street in Flushing, Queens, early Sunday morning, the police said.

title: Martha Brody, Violinist,Marries Frederic Grevin
description: Martha Ann Brody, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan E. Brody of Bethesda, Md., and Frederic Jean Grevin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Grevin of Orinda, Calif., were married yesterday at the Key Spiritual Life Center of American University in Washington. Rabbi Alan D. Fuchs, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You go overboard to save a patient from trauma and there is no bed upstairs to put him in afterwards. There is something sickening about seeing conditions so bad in the richest city in the world.'' - Dr. Nabil Atweh of King's County Hospital. [ B4:6. ]

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $62,438 and $124,634 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: 2 Who Burned a Cross Must Repair a Church
description: Two white teen-agers who burned a cross on a black family's lawn have been ordered to help rebuild a 125-year-old black church that was destroyed by fire in an unrelated case.

title: Quebec Offers a Compromise in 'Poster War'
description: The government of predominantly French-speaking Quebec Province announced a new compromise today in its 10-year-old ''poster war.'' It will continue to outlaw signs not in French on the streets, but it will allow them inside buildings.

title: Cocaine Accounts for Much in Steinberg Case
description: To the Editor:

title: I-AA Crown To Furman
description: Jeff Blankenship of Furman lived with losses to Georgia Southern for three years. Now he's going home a winner.

title: Metro Datelines; 5 Officers Are Injured In 15-Mile Car Chase
description: Five police officers on Long Island were hospitalized yesterday afternoon with minor injuries after a 15-mile, high-speed car chase that unfolded along the commercial strips and neighborhood streets of western Suffolk County, officials there said.

title: Belgian Rates Up Again
description: Belgium's central bank announced Friday that it was raising the country's key interest rates for the second time in less than a week. The bank, the Belgian National Bank, said the discount and Lombard rates would be increased by a quarter of a percentage point each, to 7.75 percent and 8 percent, respectively. The bank also announced that it was increasing the three-month Treasury bill rate by a quarter-point, to 7.65 percent.

title: Errors Crucial In 27-21 Defeat
description: The Giants are out of the playoffs.

title: Ivory Coast Church to Tower Over St. Peter's
description: Rising from the red earth and green vegetation of a former coconut plantation, the Greco-Roman outlines are taking shape here of what will be the largest Christian church in the world.

title: Meet Mark for Schoolboy
description: Todd Orvis, a senior at Colonie High School in Albany, set a meet record yesterday, winning the mile in 4 minutes 16.7 seconds at the 35th annual Bishop Loughlin Games.

title: 'I'm Coming To You'
description: ON the scoreboard clocks, the seconds kept flashing away. At ''2:00,'' the referee blew his whistle. Two-minute warning.

title: Lakeland Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Carlsbad Journal; Aliens Have Amnesty but Little Else
description: A year ago Aleriberto Rosas was an illegal alien. Now, because of the immigration amnesty law, he has crossed the threshold into legality. But little else has changed for him.

title: Businessland Official Departs
description: Enzo N. Torresi, co-founder and vice chairman of Businessland Inc., will leave the computer retailer to become president and chief executive of Netframe Systems Inc., a new computer company.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Bus Stop Gains, Subway Claims; Overblown, Underground
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has exceeded acceptable limits of hyperbole in the way it hasheralded the opening of three subway stations in Queens and related and incidental route changes. ''The greatest number of service improvements since 1904,'' the M.T.A. bragged in posters and the papers. The changes are a mere freckle on 84 years of development and modernization.

title: Greek Premier's Government Wins Key Vote of Confidence
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou won a narrow majority in Parliament tonight on a budget measure that had become a vote of confidence in the Socialist Government. In a late-night vote after four days of debate, the budget was approved, with 156 deputies voting in favor, 138 against and 2 abstaining.

title: 15 Injured as Subway Train Derails in a Harlem Station
description: Fourteen passengers and a conductor were injured yesterday evening when a subway train derailed in Harlem, seriously disrupting IND subway service for much of Manhattan's West Side.

title: U.A.W. Making Peace With Japanese in U.S.
description: Using a strategy of ''compromise and organize,'' the United Auto Workers is coming to terms with Japanese car makers setting up shop in the United States. In doing so, the union is stemming a loss of members and bolstering its position as the intermediary between American auto workers and the industry.

title: Petroleum Helicopters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Los Angeles Weighs Change to Cut Smog
description: Home for 12 million people, 8 million vehicles and the worst smog in the country by far, the vast Los Angeles basin is near the reckoning point on its choking air.

description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $52,000 and $110,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $61,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the 9 months.

title: Browns Win, Earn Rematch
description: The National Football League playoffs and the trek to Super Bowl XXIII begin Saturday in Cleveland, where yesterday, in swirling wind and steady snow, the Browns earned post-season action for the fourth consecutive year.

title: Accounts
description: * Comerica Inc., Detroit, a bank holding company, to Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Detroit, with a budget in the $3 million to $4 million range.
