description: b-Net income Figures for the latest third quarter and 9 months included operating results of Florida Express Inc., which became a Braniff unit after April.

title: Washington Talk: Budget Committees; The Importance (and the Risk) of Being Chairman
description: ''You don't become the budget committee chairman if you want to become popular,'' said Stanley E. Collender, an expert on the budget.

title: Prime Rate Is Expected To Increase
description: A further increase in the prime lending rate, now at 10.5 percent, is likely before the end of the year, credit market analysts said, even if the Federal Reserve Board continues to put off a long-anticipated increase in its discount rate.

title: A Christmas Carol (For the 80's)
description: LEAD: Our indebtedness to Scrooge, It seems to me, is huge. What if every human heart were pure as Tiny Tim's, And all it took to bless us were a bit of goose and hymns? No extravaganzas, just inertia, No galloping commercia-Lization to deplore? Snore. Scrooge, you know, Was the one who was so Non-commercial Noel-wise he wouldn't spend tuppence, Till he got his comeuppance.

title: A Last-Place Team Gambles On a Billion-Dollar Contract
description: IS any baseball game worth $1 million an inning? ABC and NBC do not think so, but CBS does, and last week it won a $1.1 billion contract with Major League Baseball that shocked the competition.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Living Section on Nov. 30 described Lithuanian Jews who have tried to recapture their religious heritage through celebrations like Hanukkah. The article dealt in particular with a holiday meal planned by Karmella and Vladimir Raiz, a couple who for 15 years have been refused permission to emigrate.

title: Cocaine Accounts for Much in Steinberg Case; The Victim's Shame
description: To the Editor: in his cross-examination of Hedda Nussbaum, Joel B. Steinberg's lead defense lawyer, Ira D. London, is unwittingly highlighting and perpetuating the social myth that, tragically, often keeps women from escaping abusive relationships. While perhaps some of the victims of abuse are indeed masochists, most are not. If anything, the greatest psychological problem they may have in relation to accepting abuse is an inability to impose limits on the traditional view of femininity as being loyal, loving and all-accepting.

title: Winnebago Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net loss Revenue represents net revenue. The financial results for the quarter ended Nov. 28, 1987, have been retroactively restated to conform with new accounting standards, consolidation of all majority owned subsidiaries, which are required to be adopted by the company in fiscal 1989. The restatement had no effect on the net loss or the loss per common share previously reported.

title: From Boom Times to Bust: Connecticut's Fiscal Crisis
description: During most of this decade, state lawmakers here have grown comfortable with passing tax cuts, approving double-digit spending increases and boosting the size of their staffs. They even erected, and opened last spring, an opulent $54 million legislative office building to house the ever-expanding Connecticut government.

title: White House Disputes Warning on Budget for Arms Plants
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington warned the White House earlier this month in a letter that the Federal budget being developed for the next fiscal year proposes inadequate funds to operate the nation's nuclear weapons plants safely. But the White House chief of staff today denied that the Energy Department would be short of funds.

title: Broncos Dismiss Collier
description: The Denver Broncos dismissed Joe Collier, their defensive coordinator, and four other defensive assistants today.

title: Gandhi Heads Off to China for a State Visit
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi left India today for a five-day state visit to China, the first by an Indian head of government since 1954.

title: Public Education - Dump It
description: LEAD: Government-funded public education has been a miserable failure. It produces illiterate, spiritless and passive graduates who have neither the motivation nor the skills to find a good job or succeed. As a result, private sector schooling is growing by leaps and bounds. There is even a move toward privatization of the public school system in Massachusetts, where the city of Chelsea is about to give Boston University authority over its public school system.

title: Reviews/Music; Wayne Horvitz's America
description: The physical context of a performance is often overlooked as an influence on the reception of music. Wayne Horvitz's group, the President, which played the second half of his concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night, came on amid a nicely ascetic and spare light show and played art music using rock materials. At other shows, in rock clubs, the group has come across as a rock band using complicated formal materials.

title: Ski Insurance
description: This being the season when Santa Claus sometimes gets silly, it should come as no surprise that Max Colclasure has been up to his old entrepreneurial tricks, this time on the ski slope rather than the golf course.

title: Direct Action Marketing reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations for the quarter, and the 9 months included losses from discontinued operations of $510,627. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $15,935 for the quarter and $42,390 for the 9 months.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Pilobolus Sampler
description: Who would have thought that two guys from Dartmouth College with a limited but imaginative familiarity with modern dance would create a company that has survived for 17 years on a diet of athletic and irreverant dance created by madcap committee? But Pilobolus has flourished. And its history was suggested in a nicely varied program presented by the company on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), where Pilobolus performs through Jan. 8.

title: Zeus Components reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $607,000 from the extinguishment of debt, net of taxes. c-Net loss and included for the year a loss of $59,000 from the extinguishment of debt, net of taxes.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Best Addresses
description: When new members of Congress and Bush administration appointees start arriving in Washington, asking real estate brokers about apartments and searching the classified ads, some who believe lightning strikes twice might want to check the places where earlier newcomers lived before they were elected President.

title: ETHICS VIOLATIONS IN HOUSE SPUR CALL FOR TOUGHER RULES
description: Ten years after Congress bound itself to a strict code of fiscal conduct, frequent reports of ethical misdeeds by lawmakers are prompting new efforts to tighten the rules even more.

title: Ghana Acts To Rebuild Gold Industry
description: A new mine shaft that sinks a half-mile below the Ashanti hills here and incentives for foreign investors are part of this nation's drive to recapture its one-time glory as Africa's Gold Coast.

title: 'Bruised and Battered' Jewish Left Seeking a New Progressive Tradition
description: Declaring that established Jewish organizations are too politically conservative and too uncritical of Israel's policies, over 1,500 Jewish intellectuals and veterans of the civil rights, anti-war and feminist movements gathered in Manhattan yesterday to build a new network.

title: Torotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $56,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a $22,000 tax charge for the quarter.

title: Pico Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a $519,527 gain from an accounting change.

title: A Concert in London For Quake Survivors
description: The Soviet-born cellist Mstislav Rostropovich played in a benefit concert for Armenian earthquake victims Saturday night, after postponing a visit to India in order to participate in the event.

title: Pillsbury to Be Sold To British Company In $5.7 Billion Deal
description: After more than two months of struggling to remain independent, the Pillsbury Company agreed today to be acquired by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., a British conglomerate that had been equally relentless in its pursuit of the company.

title: Sarena Kaminer Wed To Dr. Martin Levin
description: The marriage of Sarena Kaminer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kaminer of Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. Martin Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Levin of Winnipeg, Manitoba, took place yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbis Yaakov Lerner and Dale Pollakoff officiated.

title: TV Notes
description: The Bob Hope Spirit

title: ARAFAT WILL PRESS DIPLOMATIC EFFORT
description: Yasir Arafat said today that the talks between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization were ''positive'' and indicated that he planned a continued diplomatic campaign for a Middle East peace conference.

title: Reviews/Music; Miles Davis's Own Brand of Funk
description: For an established star, a club performance can be a myth-making or a myth-destroying event. Without the automatic grandeur associated with a large hall, any weaknesses can become more obvious. But if the concert if special in some way, it can reaffirm greatness.

title: Tuscarora Plastics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Independents Pose Problem For Budapest
description: Hungary is facing difficult decisions over what to do about an explosion of independent political activity that has mushroomed in the recent relaxed political climate.

title: Qantel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago second quarter net and revenue figures included $1,251,000 from a fixed royalty that expired on April 30. Last year's second quarter net also included a reversal of $651,000 for a previously established reserve for estimated losses on disposition of certain operations. Last year's first half revenue included about $2.5 million in fixed royalties which expired April 30. Last year's first half included a credit of $651,000.

title: Ahmanson Officer to Head Bass's American Savings
description: Mario Antoci will become chairman and chief executive of the troubled American Savings and Loan Association after its acquisition by the Robert M. Bass Group is completed, a Bass spokesman said yesterday.

title: Werner Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT The 17 most indebted developing countries will pay out 50 percent more this year than in 1987, the World Bank estimates. Most developing countries are no better off than when the global debt crisis erupted in 1982, although the threat to the international banking system has abated, the bank said. The bank warned that the drain of money from impoverished countries ''of the speed and magnitude recorded in recent years represents a new and significant constraint on their expansion.'' [ Page A1. ] Czechoslovak farmers have made a blossoming business venture out of a thriving agricultural cooperative. In the process they have routinely defied party orthodoxy while vaulting into the front ranks of the nation's, and the East bloc's, producers of computers, machinery and biotechnology. [ D1. ] Ghana is working to recapture its pre-independence glory as Africa's Gold Coast. American, Australian, British and Canadian companies have responded to incentives it has offered. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Pillsbury agreed to be acquired by Grand Metropolitan for $66 a share in cash, or $5.68 billion, ending a two-month struggle. On Friday, a Delaware judge struck down Pillsbury's ''poison pill'' defense plan, immediately prompting it to begin negotiating. [ A1. ] American Savings and Loan will have a new chief executive after its acquisition by the Bass Group is completed. [ D1. ] Brunswick said it expected a 50 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings and a 10 percent drop in sales. [ D3. ] Campeau reported a lower net loss for the nine months ended Oct. 31. The company lost $14 million in the period, compared with a loss of $123 million a year earlier. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY A further increase in the prime lending rate is likely before the end of the year, even if the Fed continues to put off an increase in its discount rate, analysts said. Historically, the next two weeks are usually the slowest of the year for the credit markets. [ D1. ] Holiday business has stepped up sharply from the sluggish pace of the middle two weeks in the four-week season, reports from several cities show. To encourage shoppers, more stores have cut prices and followed the lead of Sears, Roebuck by increasing customers' credit lines and extending repayment periods. [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The British entrepreneur Eddie Shah is quitting newspapers. Mr. Shah, who helped revolutionize the British newspaper industry, shut down his five-week-old tabloid, The Post, after just 33 issues and losses estimated at more than $12 million. [ D1. ] Within ABC and NBC are grumblings that CBS overbid on its $1.1 billion television baseball contract. Executives at the other networks say that CBS stands to lose $75 million a year, but CBS says baseball could bring back long-lost viewers. Television. [ D12. ] Military and naval history has become a national fascination, say magazine publishers, book editors, authors and entrepreneurs who hope to turn a dollar on the phenomenon. [ D12. ] Dodd, Mead & Company is in liquidation. To help pay its debts, the 150-year-old publisher is offering to sell authors its rights in their books, as well as the books in its warehouse. [ D12. ] The Lemont Consulting Group is being expanded to include an agency-consulting function. Advertising. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Political promises of no new taxes are being dismissed by tax professionals, economists and business leaders, who think some consumption taxes are likely. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] AMRE Inc., a hot stock, is now attracting many short sellers, who are skeptical about the company's results and think its shares are overvalued. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Red Wings' Coach Sees Himself as Friend and Teacher
description: WHEN he was 16 years old, Jacques Demers quit school and drove a soft-drink truck in Montreal to earn rent and food money for his brothers and sisters.

title: Reality Time in Mideast; Israelis in Shock and Arabs in Jubilation Just Might Discard Old, Numbing Illusions
description: The decision by the United States to open a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization has jolted the Middle East, almost as much as a war, leaving elation and celebration in the Arab world, shock and numbness in Jerusalem.

title: Teaching Shops to Sell Themselves
description: BROWBEATEN and bedraggled, advertising leaders have weakly lashed out during the year at consultants like Alvin A. Achenbaum whose metier is instructing clients on reducing their agencies' compensation. Wanting to accomplish something tangible to tip the balance back in favor of the agencies, Fred Lemont is expanding his Lemont Consulting Group to include an agency-consulting function.

title: Oppenheimer Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
8 Miami Officers Suspended In Fatal Beating of a Suspect
description: A suspected drug dealer was beaten to death in a confrontation with police officers who believed he had arranged the murder of one of them, the police said today. Eight officers have been suspended with pay while the killing is being investigated.

title: Strollers Are Being Recalled To Repair Mechanical Faults
description: An Ohio company is recalling 14,000 collapsible baby strollers to correct mechanical problems, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says.

title: Central Illinois Public Service Co reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
WPP's Sorrell Assails 'One-Stop Shopping'
description: Martin Sorrell, chairman of the WPP Group, the marketing communications conglomerate, went on stage at Paine Webber's annual media conference on Friday and took a swipe at the idea of ''one-stop shopping'' for marketing services, a subject of some dispute lately.

title: Simms Is Stunned By Kickoff Return
description: The game was over. That was the happy thought that went through Phil Simms's mind as he stood in the shade of the visitor's sideline at Giants Stadium. The problems that the Jets had caused for the Giants, and those that the Giants had created for themselves, had been overcome.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In the Earthquake's Aftermath in Armenia, Soviet Press Barriers Tumble
description: Last Tuesday night three reporters from Moscow - an American, a Spaniard and an Englishman - arrived at the airport here and cadged a ride with a truck driver delivering volunteers from a Ukrainian mountain-climbing club to help rescue survivors in the earthquake zone.

title: Buyout Memo Sent to Banks
description: The agency regulating nationally chartered banks Thursday ordered its examiners to look for banks that have taken on too much of the risky, but lucrative, business of financing leveraged buyouts.

title: Lee Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Equion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $161,000 from reduction of income taxes arising from carryforward of prior years operating losses.

title: Director Draws Parallels Between 'Aida' and Life
description: Gary Hart, Jimmy Swaggart and Jim and Tammy Bakker were all deeply on the mind of Sonja Frisell as she was directing the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Aida,'' which opened last week to critical acclaim for both its spectacle and its sensitivity. The more Miss Frisell explored the Verdi masterwork, the more she became convinced of its power to speak to our time.

title: Elizabeth Baer Weds Mark R. Wilson
description: Elizabeth Jane Baer, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Harold Baer Jr. of New York and Fire Island Pines, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Roberts Wilson, a son of Anne Yates Wilson of Nantucket, Mass., and Peter Medlicott Wilson of Green Valley, Ariz. The bride's father, a justice of New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Why Primo Levi Need Not Have Died
description: LEAD: Why did the eminent Italian writer Primo Levi die in the shocking way he did?

title: Tab Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 11
Dr. Betty Rae Klein Weds Dr. Eric Brown in Jersey
description: Dr. Betty Rae Klein, a resident in ophthalmology, and Dr. Eric Brown, a fellow in nephrology, both at Yale-New Haven Hospital, were married yesterday at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., by Rabbi Barry Friedman.

title: Reviews/Music; Hakan Hagegard Sings Swedish Songs at the Y
description: Hakan Hagegard has an unusually fine baritone voice and he is one of the best vocal technicians before the public; the main rewards of his recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y were the reminders, sometimes spectacular, of those facts. Here, at a time when too many singers muddle through on natural endowment and half-digested ideas of craft, is a singer whose voice is truly an instrument at the disposal of the player.

title: Gun Cache Found at Airport
description: A Filipino native was arrested today at O'Hare International Airport after a search of his family's luggage, which was bound for the Philippines, disclosed nine automatic weapons and parts for several more, the police said. The arrest occurred as the man, identified as Lamberto Camacho, prepared to put his wife and two children on a Northwest Airlines jet for Manila. Sgt. John Fanning of the Chicago Police said Mr. Camacho, 44 years old, of Defiance, Ohio, works as a laboratory technician for the General Motors Corporation.

title: Islanders Finally End Slide
description: All season long, the once-feared Islanders have struggled to get their bearings on the ice. Like an awkward child trying to learn to ride a bicycle, they were at odds with their own coordination, and when they fell, they fell hard.

title: Emergency Rooms Overwhelmed As New York's Poor Get Sicker
description: Overwhelmed by patients suffering from AIDS, drug abuse and a poverty-related deterioration in health, New York City's emergency rooms are increasingly unable to provide acute care and are coming to resemble ill-staffed inpatient wards, health care experts say.

title: Bringing Gifts to the Coal Country Poor
description: Poverty covers the hills and hollows near here like the newly fallen snow.

title: Dataphaz Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: MONEY LOSS GROWS FOR POORER LANDS, WORLD BANK FINDS
description: Despite crushing debt loads and depressed living standards, poorer countries are transferring their wealth to richer nations in amounts that will reach record this year, 50 percent above 1987 levels, a World Bank report released today says.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bush's Secret Leaker
description: George Bush has let it be known he will tolerate no leaking in his administration. He is already fed up with the way the media has bruited about in advance the names of his appointments.

title: WITH VOTE TODAY, 23 DIE IN SRI LANKA
description: At least 23 people were killed over the weekend as leftists blockaded roads and terrorized communities to keep voters from going to the polls Monday to elect a president.

title: Japan Mausoleum Set on Fire
description: Fire broke out on the grounds housing the mausoleum of a former emperor on the outskirts of Tokyo early today and the police said they suspect leftist radicals were responsible. Fire fighters put out the blaze after 30 minutes and there were no injuries. The police said a timed incendiary device was used to set the fire. The mausoleum houses the remains of Emperor Taisho, the father of the present monarch, Hirohito, 87 years old. Taisho died in 1926.

title: 1 Killed in Indiana Hotel Fire
description: Fire swept through a residential hotel today, killing at least one person, injuring at least nine people and forcing the evacuation of 100 residents, the authorities said. Four people were unaccounted for. The blaze in the four-story Morningside Hotel apparently began on the third floor about 9:40 A.M.. The cause was under investigation. Robert Ziker, the owner of the 64-year-old hotel, identified the dead person as Julius Wood. His age was not immediately known.

title: The Lessons of War Sell in Peacetime
description: ''Read Sun Tzu,'' said the greedy financial manipulator portrayed by Michael Douglas in the movie ''Wall Street.'' He was referring to the Chinese author who wrote ''The Art of War'' in the fourth century B.C. A year later, his advice is being widely heeded. There are now three paperback editions of Sun Tzu's classic in print, including one just issued by Delta Books.

title: Farmers Deal Completed
description: Farmers Group Inc. and Batus Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British tobacco and retailing concern B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., said Friday that they had completed the merger announced in August. Stockholders of Farmers Group, a Los Angeles-based insurance and financial services company, approved the merger on Wednesday; Batus, based in Louisville, Ky., will acquire Farmers for $75 a share in cash, or a total of about $5.2 billion.

title: Outdoors: Warming Up to a Little Hunting Luxury
description: MY brother Dan has no hang-ups about striving to make waterfowling as comfortable as possible.

description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Consumer Price Index Nov. G.N.P. 3d qtr. Corporate Profits 3d qtr. Wednesday Personal Income Nov. Thursday Durable Goods Nov. Friday None

title: Gaby Levitt Wed To Peter Altman
description: Gaby Levitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Levitt of North Hills, L.I., and Peter James Altman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Altman of Bedford, N.Y., were married yesterday afternoon in the West Penthouse of the New York Hilton. Rabbi Mark Wiener performed the ceremony.

title: Going Courting
description: Given the amount of scandal it mongered, it's surprising that ''Steinbrenner's Yankees'' didn't create more of a stir when it came out in 1982. Anyone familiar with the book might suspect that George Steinbrenner bought up all the copies to keep people from reading, among other things, the suggestion that he once planted a vial of marijuana in Billy Martin's desk.

title: North American Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Barbara Schlansky Wed
description: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., Barbara Sue Schlansky, the daughter of Helen Schlansky of New York and the late Bernard Schlansky, was married last night to Lee Howell Schaffer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schaffer of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Robert Benjamin, Cantor Paul Offerkrantz and Cantor Joseph Rosenfeld, an uncle of the bride, officiated. The bride is the director of sales for the small-leather-goods division of Carlos Falchi in New York. Mr. Schaffer is an analysis consultant for A.T.&T. Technologies in Morristown, N.J.

title: Study Finds U.S. Sales of Timber In Federal Forests Are Profitable
description: Sales of timber from federally owned forests make money for the Federal Government but most forests lose money, a new study by the United States Forest Service reports.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sweden Wins One Match: Sweden salvaged one victory in its Davis Cup final against West Germany, as Stefan Edberg defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 8-6, yesterday in Goteborg, Sweden. West Germany clinched the title by winning two singles matches Friday and a doubles match Saturday, so the closing two singles were shortened to two-of-three-set matches. Edberg's victory was the only one for Sweden, the defending champion, in the three-of-five-match series. After the Edberg-Steeb match, the Swedes defaulted the final singles match against Patrick Kuhnen. (AP) SKI JUMPING Bokloev Jumps 115.5 Meters: Jan Bokloev of Sweden turned in the day's longest jump, 115.5 meters, on his first attempt yesterday and won the 90-meter event in Sapporo, Japan. The World Cup victory was his second of the season. Bokloev was awarded 222.0 points after soaring 110.0 meters in his second jump on the Ohkurayama Hill. Bokloev posted his first victory at Lake Placid, N.Y., Dec. 10. He is in second place in the World Cup ski jump overall standing with 78 points. Dieter Thoma of West Germany won his first jump at Thunder Bay, Canada, Dec. 3, and leads the overall standing with 81 points. Finishing second yesterday was Ari-Pekka Nikkola of Finland, who sailed 115.0 and 108.5 meters for 216 points. Matti Nykaenen of Finland jumped 110.0 and 108.0 meters for 212.5 points and placed third.(AP) SKIING Schneider Takes Giant Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland capitalized on a fall by her toughest challenger and won a women's World Cup giant slalom race yesterday. Schneider, a world and Olympic champion, won her third race of the season - her 16th World Cup triumph - edging Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia by one second after two runs in Val Zoldana, Italy. Schneider has 107 points after six races and a commanding lead in the overall standing. Ulrike Maier of Austria, who is in second place with 63 points, did not pick up any points after falling midway in the second run.(AP) AUTO RACING Shepherd Captures Christmas 500: Morgan Shepherd outdueled Sterling Marlin and won the $850,000 Nascar Christmas 500 yesterday at the Calder Park Thunderdome in Melbourne, Australia. Shepherd, of Conover, N.C., who drove a Pontiac, was treated for exhaustion and dehydration at the end of the 280-lap race, which was held in humid 100-degree weather. Marlin, from Columbia, Tenn., finished second in an Oldsmobile, with Harry Gant of Taylorsville, N.C., third in a Chevrolet. The 32-man field competed on the banked 1.125-mile tri-oval super-speedway. Shepherd collected $68,000, plus bonuses. Marlin earned $55,460 plus bonuses and Gant got $51,000. The race, only the second Nascar event held outside North America, attracted approximately 35,000 fans.(AP)

title: Lebanese Muslims Raid Israeli-Controlled Zone
description: Lebanese Muslim guerrillas struck today deep inside a strip of Lebanon controlled by Israel, attacking a radio station operated by the Israeli-sponsored militia. Two members of the Israeli-backed militia, the South Lebanon Army, were killed in the assault, on the outskirts of Merj 'Uyun, a town four miles north of the Israeli border.

description: b-Net loss

title: Slowing Is Seen in Britain
description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said today that the British economy is now slowing according to his plans after signs of overheating in the fall.

title: Books of The Times; A Minister of (Basketball) Defense Looks Back
description: Walt Frazier One Magic Season and a Basketball Life By Walt Frazier with Neil Offen. Illustrated. 259 pages. Times Books. $17.95.

title: Some Donors Increase Gifts To Neediest
description: Barbara and James Robbins of Manhattan have been loyal donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for more than 20 years, but this year they doubled their contribution because, they wrote, ''the problems seem so overwhelming.''

title: Tax Watch; The Likely Forms Of New Taxes
description: EVEN at Christmastime, few adults believe in Santa Claus. And in keeping with this cynical posture, tax professionals, academic economists and business leaders alike have greeted politicians' promises of no new taxes with a collective ''bah humbug.'' With the $155 billion Federal budget deficit, many contend that the real question is what form the new taxes will take.

title: Kirsten L. Schubauer Wed to Equity Trader
description: Kirsten Lee Schubauer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Schubauer of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Steven Donald Heinemann, a son of Mrs. Frank Jaeger of Arlington, Va., and Donald Heinemann of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Stanert L. Dransfield, a retired associate pastor at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York, performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: Please Enter Your PIN Now
description: At some hotels, guests get no keys, or even electronic cards. They open doors by dialing their credit card numbers on combination locks. It's a novelty that illustrates more than the pace of change in technology. That is paralleled by the revolutionary pace of change in social attitudes - in this case toward privacy and passwords.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which major league team has been victimized by no-hitters the most times?

title: The Baron and His Many Treasures
description: After years of negotiations, the Prado in Madrid and Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza are expected to sign an agreement before the end of the year apparently insuring that 700 of the Baron's most precious artworks will be lent to the museum for 10 years. Still, when it comes to the Baron and the future of his spectacular art collection, nothing is quite a sure thing.

title: Workers Returning to Weapons Plant After Strike
description: Nearly 400 workers at a Federal uranium processing plant will return to work Monday after voting to accept an agreement ending a 10-week strike, a plant spokesman said today.

description: IT looks very much like a small-business success story. Started from scratch in 1980, AMRE Inc. has grown rapidly, and its most enthusiastic follower on Wall Street sees more of the same ahead. The ''ultimate sales growth potential is nearly infinite,'' said Dean Witter's David L. Jarrett.

description: WHILE injuries to the knees, shins and feet are the most talked about and feared byproducts of heavy training, it is a pain in the backside that can cause the most frustrating setbacks for serious runners.

title: Body of Abused 5-Year-Old Girl Is Released
description: The body of Jessica Cortez, the 5-year-old Brooklyn girl who was found beaten to death last week in the home of her mother, was released yesterday from the office of the Medical Examiner and taken to a funeral home where her paternal grandmother was making arrangements for burial.

title: Metro Datelines; Arson Is Suspected In Bay Parkway Fire
description: Several stores and a doctor's office in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn suffered heavy damage early yesterday morning during a fire that burned for more than two hours before being brought under control, officials said.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Bus-Stop Gains, Subway Claims; Shelters, at Last
description: New Yorkers are finally getting what they were promised 13 years ago: a citywide system of clean, well-lighted bus-stop shelters. After an initial group went up mainly at choicer Manhattan sites, the program became bogged down in financial problems, performance failures, even charges of official favoritism. Things began to improve dramatically late last year, after the city awarded the shelter franchise to New York Shelter Media Inc., since acquired by the Gannett Company.

title: It's a March For Homeless In New York
description: Aiming to make housing a major issue in the 1989 mayoral election, thousands of homeless people and their supporters marched through midtown Manhattan yesterday, challenging New York City to adopt more humane housing policies for its poor and powerless.

description: The Pentagon plans to help finance research into the development of a high-resolution video display screen, in a move apparently aimed at reviving television manufacturing in the United States, an article in Monday's Washington Post said.

title: New York Is Ordered to Educate Retarded Man Past Age 21
description: Clifford Burr, who is retarded and blind, has received what his parents say is the best 21st birthday present possible: a chance for a complete education.

description: Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, told Texaco Inc. in a letter Friday that he was not acting in partnership with anyone in connection with his growing stock holdings in the big oil company.

description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has asked the Mexican Congress for approval to seek $6 billion in foreign credits next year.

title: 150-YEAR-OLD PUBLISHER ON THE ROPES
description: Two weeks shy of its 150th anniversary, Dodd, Mead & Company, one of the oldest privately held book publishers in the United States, is in liquidation. The once-distinguished house, which published George Bernard Shaw, Agatha Christie, Winston Churchill and Sigmund Freud, has closed its headquarters in Manhattan, where it has operated since 1839, and is selling its books to other publishers. It is also inviting its authors to buy back the rights to their own books.

title: Cause of Human Rights Takes a Step Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide in Brazil Said to Quit
description: The president of Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrobras resigned during the weekend, the country's major newspapers said today.

title: 4 Sentenced In Fraud Case
description: Two former executives of the Anheuser-Busch Companies and two advertising executives charged with trying to defraud the company and the Government were sentenced Friday to prison terms and fined in Federal court. The two former executives, Michael A. Orloff and Joseph E. Martino, each received a total of nine years in prison on counts of mail fraud, conspiracy and filing a false tax return. Each was also fined $10,000.

description: So you're one of the several hundred thousand people coming to the inauguration and you want to move around the capital in style? Shop around before you hire a limousine.

description: It used to be that the only way to get a custom fit in ski boots was to have them handmade. But today, off-the-shelf boots come with levers, knobs and micro tabs and getting the right fit is often no more than an adjustment away.

description: Directors of Sears, Roebuck & Company held a special board meeting on Saturday, a company spokesman confirmed today. The company may make an announcement this week.

description: A listing in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Thursday, about the First Financial Management Corporation, misidentified its merger partner in some editions. The partner is Appalachian Computer Services Inc., not Computer Services Inc.

Jim Jacoby of Richardson, Tex., a member of the winning American squad in the Venice Team Olympiad two months ago, teamed here with Morris Chang of Manhattan, Marty Bergen of Long Beach, L.I., and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J. Ms. Allen collects $269 every two weeks, plus food stamps. She pays $305-a-month rent for the one-bedroom apartment she shares with her daughter and 6-year-old son, Sharod.

description: It is 6 A.M., but the dozen men clustered on Ronald Reagan Avenue already have the weary look that usually comes at day's end. Many of them homeless, they were turned out of shelters an hour earlier and now wait for a van that will take them to a variety of menial jobs.

description: The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, yesterday assailed the president of the city's Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., saying that Mr. Wagner was ultimately responsible for any corruption that might be found in local school boards.

description: Kristina Schramm Doughty, a daughter of Dorothy D. Schramm of Burlington, Iowa, and the late James S. Schramm, was married yesterday to John Rust Chandler Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Chandler of Cleveland. Arthur W. White, a justice of the peace who is the headmaster of the Hotchkiss School, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home on the school campus in Lakeville, Conn. Mrs. Chandler is the director of development and her husband is the assistant headmaster at Hotchkiss. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did Mr. Chandler's first marriage. His second wife died.

title: After the Fall, Mixed Feelings for Giants
description: The Giants had expected to make the playoffs and celebrate. Instead, when the Los Angeles Rams upset the San Francisco 49ers last night, the Giants lost their last chance for a playoff berth. After that game, the Giants seemed stunned, and their words were muffled.

title: Schwartz Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle of $154,814. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect a change in the company's method of determining inventory cost.

title: Czechs Laud Shrewd Farm Co-op
description: Leaping from success to success, enterprising farmers here have turned a thriving agricultural cooperative into a blossoming business venture. In the process they have routinely defied party orthodoxy while vaulting into the front ranks of the nation's, and the East bloc's, producers of computers, machinery and biotechnology.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS (NYT COLUMN)GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Australian Government ministers said the nation's latest trade figures were alarming and far worse than anticipated. The country posted a November trade deficit of $1.55 billion Australian, or $1.3 billion American. The Government said the 3 percent rise in imports was mainly caused by increased demand for machinery. For the fiscal year that began July 1, Australia has a trade deficit of $7.3 billion Australian, or about $6.2 billion American, well above the Government's projections.

title: Developer Wins A Point in Fight On Landmarks
description: In a highly unusual action, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has said that three row houses on Central Park West may impose a financial hardship on their owner, a preliminary finding that could lead to demolition of the landmark buildings next year.

title: INSIDE
description: Cutting Los Angeles Smog Key decisions will probably impose unwelcome fetters on a way of life that has come to symbolize the ideal of American freedom. Page A14. Sri Lankans Vote Today At least 23 people were killed in attacks by opposition militants as Sri Lankans prepared for their first general elections in 11 years. Page A7. Calamity Speeds Glasnost Western reporters covering the Armenian earthquake have roamed free in what is still one of the world's more repressed societies. Page A3. Money for Reactor Found Contrary to warnings, the White House says it found enough money in the next budget to operate nuclear weapons plants safely. Page B11.

title: Zytec Systems reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $82,000.

title: Eagles Crush Cowboys and Win Title
description: The Philadelphia Eagles beat the Dallas Cowboys, 23-7, today to advance to the playoffs for the first time in seven years and win their first National Conference East title since 1980.

title: El Chico Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 14
description: b-After a gain from a cumulative effect of an accounting change of $440,000. c-Net income Sales represents system-wide sales.

title: Loan Expert to Lead Fidelity in Philadelphia
description: Leslie E. Goodman has taken on a sensitive job in the regional banking industry as chairman and chief executive of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Carmen' Cast Changes
description: Two singers have joined the Metropolitan Opera's ''Carmen'' cast and won from the Saturday-matinee audience an enthusiasm that had been elusive earlier in the opera's run. The reason was not far to seek: Mirella Freni as Micaela and Samuel Ramey as Escamillo could fill the Met with the handsome, juicy sounds that operagoers long, usually in vain these days, to hear.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 Poor nations are losing wealth to richer ones in amounts that will reach record levels this year, 50 percent above 1987, a World Bank report said. Page A1

title: Who's a Refugee?
description: Change in the Soviet Union and turmoil in Latin America now conjoin to torment the American conscience. Each year, this country generously admits thousands of persecuted foreigners. But there are many more refugees than this country can handle and the Government perpetually faces the vexing problem: Who are legitimate refugees, and which of them should be admitted?

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
Review/Television; Monday on the Ice With Brian Boitano, on ABC
description: Figure skating is not one of my favorite things. That much understood, I warmly recommend ''Brian Boitano: Canvas of Ice,'' an ABC Sports special being broadcast tonight at 8, just before the Chicago Bears tackle the Minnesota Vikings in Minneapolis. Like most other entertainments connected with ice skating, this one is larded with schmaltz, not to mention one of the more curious love-interest scenarios of the season, but Mr. Boitano, the gold medalist in men's figure skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, comes through not just winningly but spectacularly.

title: Child-Soldier Treaty Has Wide Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Tatham-Laird & Kudner Has Barclay Cigarette
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation has given creative responsibility for its Barclay cigarette brand to Tatham-Laird & Kudner in Chicago. Since April, the account had been at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi that continues to do creative work on Kool, Raleigh, Belair and Viceroy cigarettes.

title: Massachusetts Is Increasing Fees for Drivers and Vehicles
description: Motorists in Massachusetts will pay more for a driver's license and to register their vehicles next year under a state plan to raise $158 million to ease the state's $636 million budget deficit.

title: Product of 20 Minutes: A Million-Dollar Song
description: ''I've always said it took me 20 years to find out how to write a song in 20 minutes,'' Bart Howard, the composer of ''Fly Me to the Moon,'' recalled the other day. ''The song just fell out of me. One publisher wanted me to change the lyric to 'take me to the moon.' Had I done that I don't know where I'd be today.''

title: Celeste Lizio, Pizza Maker, 80
description: Celeste Lizio, an Italian immigrant whose likeness as ''Mama Celeste'' adorned millions of pizzas for the company she created, died Friday of complications from a heart ailment. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Lizio was born in San Angelo, Italy, in 1908 and came to the United States with her husband, Anthony, in the 1920's. They settled on Chicago's West Side, where they opened their first restaurant in 1937.

title: Racing to the Rescuce
description: One man can make a difference, and if that man happens to have connections in the motor sports business, he can make things accelerate at an astonishing pace.

title: N.C.A.A. Penalizing Oklahoma Football
description: Oklahoma athletic officials met privately today after a report Saturday night that the National Collegiate Athletic Association would place the school's football program on probation for three years.

title: 'Fed Up' Likud Hints Again at Deal With Rightists
description: Israel's political leaders continued to flounder today in their nearly seven-week effort to form a new government.

title: Commonwealth Edison reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: The company said earnings were primarily affected by an increase in depreciation and operation and maintenance expenses, as well as a substantial decrease in construction-related credits resulting from placing Byron unit 2 and Braidwood units 1 and 2 in service without their inclusion in rate base and commensurate increases in electric service rates.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; On the Calendar
description: The official 1989 calendar of the Commission of the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution is out, and guess who is pictured on the cover, front and off-center below a ''We the People'' banner?

title: Uniform Poll Closing Gives the Voter a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Nile Gives Abundantly As Doomsday Recedes
description: The old proverb says: the misfortune of one builds the fortune of another. They have discovered that wisdom here, in a village pressed between river and highway, nuzzled by the Nile.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; '101st Senator'
description: For the last 40 years, senators have ushered David Brody into Capitol elevators and subway cars marked ''Senators Only.'' Both Republicans and Democrats called him ''the 101st senator,'' and few have enjoyed greater access to the power wielders in the White House and on Capitol Hill. He has been the lobbying equivalent of a full-service gas station, introducing senators to constituents, fund-raisers and ''people I think they should meet.''

title: Rolls-Royce Order
description: The British airplane engine maker Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said it had won an order from America West Airlines Inc. of Phoenix, worth $:275 million, or about $500 million. Rolls-Royce said the United States carrier had ordered RB211-535E4 engines to power 10 Boeing 757 airliners it had bought and 15 others on which it had taken options. Deliveries of the aircraft are to begin in 1992. Rolls-Royce said the engine had been chosen for more than 120 B757's on firm order worldwide, giving it a market share of about 75 percent on this particular airliner.

title: Interco Is Selling Londontown Unit
description: Interco Inc. announced it was selling the Londontown Corporation for $178 million to a group led by senior managers of the division. The sale of Londontown, which manufactures London Fog rainwear, is part of a $2.8 billion restructuring that Interco undertook to fight a hostile takeover bid by Steven and Mitchell Rales of Washington.

title: Spending and Taxes in Westchester Are Going Up
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators approved a $930.36 million county budget for 1989 tonight, increasing spending by 9.2 percent over 1988 and taxes by 8 to 13 percent.

title: Sigfred L. Solem, Banker, 67
description: Sigfred L. Solem, a banker and former senior vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in East Williston, L.I. He was 67 years old.

title: Myerson Case Goes to Jury For a Verdict
description: A jury completed its first day of deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict in the criminal trial of Bess Myerson, a former Miss America who became the Cultural Affairs Commissioner of New York City.

title: When Shelters Are No Answer
description: With 30,000 homeless people in Chicago, and 3,000 beds in city shelters, the search for housing can have very personal solutions.

title: Is a Math Proof a Proof If No One Can Check It?
description: A PROBLEM that defied mathematicians for more than two centuries has finally yielded to a supercomputer, but experts say that no human mind could ever grasp all the details of the solution.

title: 'Tis a Gift to Be Simple
description: A WISE and popular book reminds readers that '' All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten.'' Don't hit people. Be nice. Put things back where you found them. For computer users, there are similar guidelines. These rules may sound obvious, but it is astonishing how often they are ignored.

title: 'Peace Now' Mission Divides Israelis
description: Two Israelis met at the gates of the Greek Orthodox church here today. The first, a soldier, climbed out of a jeep and ordered the second, a protester, to get out of town.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

title: Relatives Honor Crash Dead
description: Relatives of people who died in a Northwest Airlines crash two summers ago have decorated the crash site near Metropolitan Airport with holiday wreaths.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Golf for All
description: Vice President-elect Dan Quayle, widely considered the best golfer in Congress, is sensitive to the portrayal of golf as an elitist sport. At a recent holiday party, he rattled off statistics showing that millions of Americans enjoyed the game.

title: Legislative Leaders Doubt Passage of Campus Closings
description: The chairmen of the higher education committees of the New York State Legislature predicted yesterday that the Assembly and Senate would oppose the closings of any campuses in the State and City University systems.

title: Human Hunters and Pygmy Hippos
description: NEW archeological findings show that humans first occupied Cyprus as long ago as 8200 B.C., about 1,000 years earlier than had been thought. The discovery, scientists said, raises the possibility that human hunting, not climate change, brought about the extinction of the pygmy hippopotamus on the Mediterranean island.

title: J. G. Mecking, 57, An Antiques Dealer To Rich and Noted
description: J. Garvin Mecking, a New York antiques dealer for 30 years, died Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after suffering a stroke five days earlier. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Electoral College's Stately Landslide Sends Bush and Quayle Into History
description: The Electoral College made it anti-climactically official today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Coke's 3-D Commercial
description: The Coca-Cola Company will sponsor a halftime show during the Super Bowl on Jan. 22 that will include a three-dimensional commercial, executives of the company and NBC, which is broadcasting the game, said yesterday. The network said the show, which will be 12 minutes in length, will be the first live 3-D program in television history. To see it and the 45-second commercial for Diet Coke in all its lifelike glory, viewers will need special glasses, 20 million of which will be distributed by retailers beginning Jan. 9.

title: Winding Down the War Machine
description: LEAD: In his Dec. 7 speech to the United Nations, Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed that nations consider a policy to convert some of their defense production facilities into civilian production. President-elect Bush should treat this proposal gingerly, however. A national ''conversion'' policy could result in more than just a series of business failures.

title: Market Place; Why A.&P. Sees Value in Borman's
description: OFFERING to buy a company that is losing money, and to pay twice the market price while you are at it, does not sound like a brilliant tactic, but some analysts are warming rapidly to the attempt by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to do just that.

title: Blacks' Lifespan Falls For 2d Consecutive Year
description: Rising death rates from killings and accidents have cut the life expectancy of blacks in the United States for the second consecutive year, Federal health statistics show.

title: Developers Turn Aral Sea Into a Catastrophe
description: TWENTY years ago anglers might have stood on this spot, up to their hips in water, and fished for carp or pikeperch under the blazing sun of northwest Uzbekistan.

title: European Textile Pact
description: European Community foreign ministers approved a textile agreement with China today despite objections from Greece and Portugal that the terms of the pact were too generous. The agreement, negotiated by the community's executive commission, grants big increases in China's quotas for textile exports to the community. Theodore Pangalos, Greece's Minister for European Affairs who led the meeting, said his country and Portugal felt that the increases were inappropriate because of problems in the European Community textile industry.

title: NASA Offers Plans For Manned Missions
description: Humans can move out into the solar system soon after the turn of the century, perhaps with permanent lunar bases or even trips to Mars, if they make relatively modest investments in new technology and planning in the near future, space officials said today.

title: Fleetwood Offers $75 Million Issue
description: The Fleetwood Credit Corporation, a unit of Fleetwood Enterprises Inc., based in Riverside, Calif., is making the first domestic debt offering of securities backed by loans for recreational vehicles, according to the First Boston Corporation, lead underwriter for the financing.

title: Jets' Players Head Home With Winning Attitude
description: The way the Jets smiled today, the way Freeman McNeil said ''Cheerio and Merry Christmas, everyone,'' the way Coach Joe Walton told his players how much he enjoyed coaching them this season, why, it seemed very much like a playoff atmosphere around here.

title: Ahold NV reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 9
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; dollar equivalents are derived from the underlying figures in Dutch guilders at the exchange rate of $1 equals Dfl 2.0985 prevailing Oct. 7, 1988.

title: Japanese and Soviet Officials Discuss a Territorial Dispute
description: The Soviet and Japanese Foreign Ministers met today to discuss a territorial dispute that has disrupted their countries' relations for four decades.

title: How the U.S. Should Handle Arafat
description: LEAD: The opening of an official American dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization can break a longstanding deadlock between Arabs and Israelis. But if Washington forces the P.L.O. on Israel and ignores Jordanian interests, it can cause a disaster.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Labor and Likud agreed to share in a Israeli coalition headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The government's figures seem determined to deal firmly with the Palestinian uprising and have shown no interest in talks with the P.L.O. Page A1

title: Rate Plan Approved At Diablo Canyon Unit
description: Rate payers may have to absorb up to $4.5 billion of the $5.5 billion cost of building the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant under a plan that was approved today by the California Public Utilties Commission and immediately attacked by consumer groups.

title: IMMIGRANT HOSTEL BOMBED IN FRANCE
description: Two firebombs ripped through a hostel for immigrant workers in southern France early today, killing one resident and hurting 12, police officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Dec. 6 with an article about the jury that acquitted Larry Davis of attempting to murder nine police officers was published in error.

title: Computer Factory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
For Homeless Youths, Exposure to the Arts
description: A hundred homeless children in three Queens shelters will be given training in such subjects as music, the visual arts, theater and science in a pilot project announced by city officials yesterday.

title: By Design; Walking on Feathers
description: Let's face it, a walking shoe is not supposed to be an object of beauty. Its purpose is to cushion and protect the foot. And in order to do that, it does not end up looking especially pretty.

title: Thor Energy Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Strollers Are Being Recalled To Repair Mechanical Faults
description: An Ohio company is recalling 14,000 collapsible baby strollers to correct mechanical problems, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says.

title: COURT DID NOT GET REPORT OF NEGLECT
description: Family Court officials said yesterday that a Brooklyn mother accused in the beating death of her 5-year-old daughter had a documented history of child neglect and that a judge who later awarded her custody of the girl was never informed about it.

title: Manatron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A Charity's 1,000 Parties To Benefit AIDS Victims
description: Buddy Noro's first idea was to have a Night of 100 Dinners. ''Nah,'' he remembers thinking, ''some other charity already used that one.'' Next came Night of 100 Trees. ''Nah, they used that, too.'' This was during Mr. Noro's personal Night of 100 Headaches, when a fund-raising plan for a new and unknown cause eluded him. He gave up and went to bed. Inspiration struck the next morning on a grand scale: a Gift of 1,000 Parties - all for God's Love We Deliver, a charity that provides gourmet meals to housebound people with AIDS. ''They asked me to dream up something different,'' said Mr. Noro, the organization's special events coordinator.

title: Quake Relief Leaders Moving Back to Moscow as Rescues Dwindle
description: The Soviet Union's main earthquake relief commission is to relocate its activities from the stricken area to Moscow, indicating that the search for survivors has all but ended and that the focus has shifted to reconstruction.

title: The Anointing Of Arafat
description: It is just beginning. The pressure will now increase for Israel to risk its very existence.

title: Synercom Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring costs of $1,598,000 associated with implementing a reorganization of the company's management group and a writedown of its inventory, due to the phase-out of its hardware manufacturing operations.

title: Warning Of Drexel Indictment
description: The chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. told employees yesterday that talks with Federal prosecutors to avert criminal charges had not been progressing and that an indictment against the firm could be handed up soon.

title: Study for Congress Criticizes Slow AIDS Education Effort
description: The AIDS education program of the Federal Centers for Disease Control has been hampered by delays in mass mailings and by limited broadcasts of public service announcements, a Congressional report said today.

title: Diner Chain Has to Buy Locks for First Holiday Closing
description: In spite of signs that say ''Always Open,'' 1,221 Denny's restaurants around the United States will close their doors on Christmas so employees can have the day off.

title: Smithson Arbitration
description: Mike Smithson, a nine-game winner with the Boston Red Sox in 1988, yesterday accepted an offer of salary arbitration with the team. Smithson, who earned $395,000 last season, will now have his 1989 salary determined by an arbitrator. Nine players were eligible to accept salary arbitration from their 1988 teams, including Mike Flanagan with Toronto, Rick Honeycutt with Oakland and Jim Gantner with Milwakee. By the midnight deadine, only Honeycutt chose arbitration. The other players have until Jan. 8 to sign with their former teams.

title: Talking Business; with Haley of Budget Rent a Car; Turbulent Times In Car Rentals
description: These are turbulent times for car rental companies. Start-up concerns continue to crowd the industry, cutting prices and depressing profits. Higher interest rates, rising insurance premiums and increases in prices of new cars are also making it more difficult for rental companies. Last week the American Express Company said it would offer free collision insurance to holders of its green card; it has already offered the coverage to holders of gold cards.

title: Panel Backs Higher Pay For Scientists at N.I.H.
description: A review panel today recommended higher salaries and greater independence for top scientists at the National Institutes of Health, the Government's chief research arm in the fight against AIDS, cancer and other major diseases.

title: Corestates Financial Sets Up $750 Million Note Program
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation, a Philadelphia-based bank holding company, announced yesterday that it had established a $750 million continuously offered deposit note program for its subsidiary banks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Prices of Copper Rebound; Comex Margin Rises Again
description: Copper prices rebounded yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, which again doubled the margin requirement on the expiring December delivery.

title: N.C.A.A. Steps Up Effort to Clean Its Houses
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has moved uncharacteristically quickly in recent weeks to punish members who have broken its rules.

title: Valhi Ends Talks On Sugar Unit Sale
description: Valhi Inc., a diversified holding company controlled by the Texas millionaire Harold C. Simmons, said it had ended talks to sell its Amalgamated Sugar Company to the Bristar Acquisition Corporation of Britain. The Texas company said that it had been unable to reach final agreements needed to sell the wholly owned subsidiary by Dec. 30 for tax benefits available only through the end of the year.

title: Bridge
description: The Knockout Team Championship at the Winter Regionals ended Sunday at the New York Penta, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street, in a victory for a foursome led by Morris Chang, a New York businessman. He was teamed with three experts who are accustomed to the victor's laurels: Jim Jacoby of Richardson, Tex., who won the world team title in Venice two months ago, and Marty Bergen, Lawrence, L.I., and Larry Cohen, Little Falls, N.J., who won the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the Fall Nationals in Nashville last month. In the final, they defeated Joe Celebucki, Jersey City, and his team by 31 imps.

title: Baker Debt Plan Faces Review
description: President-elect Bush said a ''whole new look'' was needed for the nation's widely criticized policy on debtor nations. Page B10.

title: For Neediest, From People Who Perform
description: Paul Newman, the actor, philanthropist and businessman, has sent a gift of $50,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for the second consecutive year.

title: Laudner in Accord
description: Tim Laudner, who batted .251 with 13 home runs and 54 runs batted in for the Minnesota Twins in 1988, has agreed to a two-year contract. Laudner, who became a free agent after the season, made $307,500 in 1988.

title: Zeus Plans to Raise Stake in Whitman
description: The Whitman Corporation said Zeus Partners, a company based in Barbados, intends to raise its holdings in Whitman to more than $15 million. Lars Larsen, senior vice president of corporate affairs for Whitman, said: ''We really don't know what this means for Whitman. Several large shareholders have also filed for $15 million, but this is also one of the steps that would be taken by a potential acquirer.''

title: Arafat, Pressing Diplomacy, Meets With Austria Leaders
description: Yasir Arafat met with Chancellor Franz Vranitzky of Austria today as part of the P.L.O. chairman's effort to obtain European support for an international conference on the Middle East and a Palestinian state.

title: Concept Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: Year-ago first quarter share earnings is restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effective Feb. 22, 1988.

title: Joseph Moon, 76, Dies; Pianist and Arranger
description: Joseph Moon, a pianist and arranger, died of emphysema and heart disease on Friday at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ACC Corp., Rochester, said merger talks with Rochester Telephone Corp. had reached an impasse.

title: Review/Dance; A New Face for the Batsheva Troupe of Israel
description: The Batsheva Dance Company from Israel appeared Sunday afternoon at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College in a program dominated by American choreographers, but also featuring a bright new talent of its own.

title: Grand Met Vows to Fix Burger King
description: Buoyed by success after a two-month struggle to acquire the Pillsbury Company, the top United States executive of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that he would move swiftly to correct problems in Pillsbury's Burger King subsidiary and to make its huge foods operation more efficient.

title: Blue Chips Rally, Pushing Dow Up 21.97
description: LEAD: The stock market, particularly its blue-chip component, moved strongly higher yesterday on good volume.

title: Jennifer Convertibles Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Shell Loses Suit on Cleanup Cost
description: A jury ruled today that the Shell Oil Company is responsible for cleaning up three decades worth of pesticide pollution at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, a project that could cost up to $2 billion.

title: Washington Talk: The Transition; It's Business as Usual; Democrats Don't Mind
description: Ronald Reagan came to the capital as a stranger eight years ago, like Jimmy Carter before him. But George Bush is more like a neighbor to many Washingtonians, a familiar figure who has already chosen a batch of familiar advisers.

title: 2d Conviction At ZZZZ Best
description: An accountant for a carpet-cleaning company that bilked investors out of millions of dollars was convicted today after jurors determined that he had accepted a bribe from the company's founder, Barry J. Minkow. The accountant, Norman

title: Art in Miniature: Diverse Paths for Three Jewelers
description: Hoops and spirals and figure eights. Arrows, shields and daggers. Angels and devils, hands and feet.

title: U.S. CANNOT BEGIN DRUG TESTING PLAN
description: A Federal District judge today temporarily blocked a Reagan Administration plan to require random drug testing of 3 million interstate truck and bus drivers.

title: Leave Those Nose Tackles Alone, Lloyd
description: Maybe more than at any other time of the year, this is the season for the nose tackle, the guy in the literal middle of the belligerence that rages in the football game, where the collision of helmets and shoulder pads is a sound akin to bombs bursting in air.

title: Marcus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 10
description: The company said its latest 6-month, year-ago second quarter and 6-month revenue figures were restated to reflect certain reclassifications.

title: Nike Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a one-time credit of 21 cents a share from the settlement of customs litigation. The company said the year-ago first half results include second quarter credit of 21 cents a share.

title: Austrians Report Slur On a Times Columnist
description: Austrian Jews asserted today that anti-Semitic motives were behind an article in the country's most widely read newspaper that attacked a New York Times columnist.

title: South African Rock Fans Riot
description: A woman was killed and 31 people were injured when music fans, angered by lengthy delays at a rock concert, attacked motorists on a nearby road, the police and witnesses said today. The crowd at the Magalies Resort, 60 miles west of Pretoria, hurled rocks and other objects at passing cars Sunday afternoon after waiting two hours for the concert to begin, the witnesses said. A young woman was killed when she was hit by a car, the police said.

title: Court Backs Vance in a Fight To Block Housing Near Home
description: Former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance and his neighbors won a victory today when the Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that they had been improperly denied a hearing in their fight against an affordable-housing project in their Bernards Township neighborhood.

title: HRE Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of properties of $120,000 and $521,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes gains on the sale of properties of $584,000 for the quarter and $1,064,000 for the year.

title: MISSOURIAN ADMITS MURDERS OF 5 MEN
description: Robert A. Berdella, a 39-year-old shopkeeper already sentenced to life in prison for one murder, confessed guilt in five others today as part of a plea agreement that saved him from the threat of a death penalty.

title: Manor Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting adjustment of $5,696,000.

title: Mahwah Battles Its Own Over the Building Boom
description: A residential and commercial building boom in what was once a sleepy semirural community in northwest Bergen County has prompted a civil war of sorts among township officials.

title: First Round for Mancini-Camacho
description: It figured that Ray Mancini and Hector Camacho would wage a war of words at yesterday's news conference in Manhattan when they announced their March 6 bout in Reno.

title: Dangers Await Gray Whales on Return to Winter Home
description: WITH any luck, the two gray whales that won world sympathy in October when they were trapped in ice off Point Barrow, Alaska, will soon reach their winter home here. But when the giant mammals arrive, they and others of their species who spawn in Baja California each year will confront another set of potential dangers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Nestle Food Corp. to J. Walter Thompson, New York, for After Eight dinner mints and Turtle chocolate candy, both products of Rowntree Demet's, which Nestle acquired in August.

title: Ballesteros Is Best
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain, who won seven tournaments in seven countries, was named 1988 World Player of the Year by Golf Digest magazine.

title: San Francisco Journal; Suffering In Dignity And Exile
description: In the middle of the priest's homily on Sunday night, applause rang out at St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church, a rare defiant sound in an incense-scented space usually reserved for hushed worship.

title: Harry Heller, Taxi Fleet Owner, Dies at 72
description: Harry Heller, owner of a taxicab fleet, died of cancer Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Solitary for Quayle's Accuser
description: The Justice Department said today that four days before last month's election, its senior prison official ordered solitary confinement for an inmate who tried to call news conferences to assert that he once sold marijuana to Dan Quayle.

title: Material Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Duplex Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Elf Aquitaine Deal
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state oil giant, said it was about to spend 3.8 billion francs, or $633 million, to expand its stake in Britain's North Sea oilfields. The company said it would buy a 25.2 percent share in Enterprise Oil P.L.C. from London and Scottish Marine Oil P.L.C., or Lasmo. Enterprise Oil is the former oil division of British Gas P.L.C. and was sold off by the British Government as a prelude to the privatization of the gas company two years ago. Elf will pay Lasmo with interest-bearing loan notes listed on the Luxembourg stock exchange which means Lasmo will pay no tax on the transaction as long as it holds the notes. Lasmo put its stake in Enterprise up for sale in September.

title: Bush Backs U.S. Shift on World Debt
description: Citing ''enormous problems, particularly in our own hemisphere,'' President-elect Bush said today that American policy toward the world's debtor countries needed a ''whole new look.''

title: Leafs, With New Coach, Stop a 10-Game Slide
description: George Armstrong remembered the past as he described his first game as a head coach in the National Hockey League.

title: Media General to Buy Back Stake Held by Sugarman
description: In an unusual finish to an unsuccessful takeover fight, Media General Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy back the 10 percent stake of the Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman in the communications company for about $100 million. The deal involves the payment of $44 million in cash and a paper mill in Pomona, Calif., apparently valued at $56 million.

title: Panel Faults Pentagon on Overhaul of Purchasing
description: A committee of experts has concluded that the Defense Department has failed to make much improvement in the way it acquires costly new weapons, despite two years of effort.

title: A Holmesian Mystery
description: To the Editor:

title: Management Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings for the year-ago periods reflected number of shares adjusted to reflect 1-for-1 stock split.

title: Isabel Allende, the Novelist, Returns to Chile From Exile
description: Isabel Allende, the novelist, back home after 13 years of self-imposed exile, said today that she was convinced Chile was on the road back to democracy.

title: Help Wanted: Centers; N.B.A. Seeks a Few Big Men
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is retiring after the season. Mychal Thompson, the Los Angeles Lakers' backup center, is 33 years old. Robert Parish of the Boston Celtics is 35. Moses Malone is 33 and nine other National Basketball Association starting centers are 30 or older.

title: Fatal Ride for Caroler, 6
description: A 6-year-old boy died Saturday night after falling off a hay wagon filled with Christmas carolers and being struck by a wheel. ''Somehow he slipped getting onto the thing and fell back under the wheel, and it went over him,'' said David Watson, the father of the boy, Tommy Watson. ''The last minutes of his life were spent singing Christmas carols and praising Jesus - praising the Lord - and he spent the last few minutes of his life happy.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Corporate Friends
description: Since Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat, will become chairman of the Senate Budget Committee in the new Congress, a lot of people in Washington have decided that Mr. Sasser would be a good person to have as a friend in the years ahead. He will have a crucial role in trying to reduce the budget deficit, Thirteen major corporations are joining to sponsor a party on Jan. 3 to honor Mr. Sasser, who will be sworn into office for a third term that day. The list ranges from General Motors and International Paper to Federal Express and Tennessee Apparel.

title: Christmas Resolutions
description: Except for the one about losing 10 pounds, New Year's Resolutions have more to do with the spirit than with the flesh. That's why they're never kept. There is no creature on earth who can promise to keep the truth, his temper and his word on Jan. 1 and be found to have done so on Dec. 31.

title: Review/Television; Treating Mental Illness With Drugs
description: ''Mysteries of the Mind,'' on Channel 5 at 8 tonight, is a slightly schizoid show.

title: City Shelters Spurned, Shanty Serves as Home
description: The house that John built is a tumbledown shack standing in all its scrap-wood glory on the seedy side of Michigan Avenue. It has a patchwork of wall-to-wall carpeting, a roof of planks and plywood and a plastic flap over a peephole.

title: Forgetful Taxpayers Give New York State Financial Bonanza
description: The state has been reaping millions of dollars extra each year because some New Yorkers who make quarterly estimated tax payments to the state do not claim them on their subsequent tax returns, the State Comptroller said today.

title: U.S. Tries to Reduce U.N. Namibia Force
description: The Reagan Administration is trying to reduce the size of the United Nations peacekeeping force that is to oversee elections leading to independence in Namibia, diplomats here said today.

title: Uniform Poll Closing Gives the Voter a Break; Registration a Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Q. How do robins detect worms? A. ''All the studies point to their doing it entirely visually, not by hearing or smell,'' said Steven C. Sibley, an ornithologist with the bird population studies program of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology at Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Specialized Agency Opens Shop in Harlem
description: Harlem has been home to Austin and Denise Patrick for the last three years, and now the first two floors of their brownstone on 127th Street are also home to the Patrick Agency. The fledgling shop will primarily help clients market to black, Hispanic and Asian-American customers. So far, it has developed projects for local businesses and eight presentations to four national clients.

title: Study Links Intelligence And Myopia
description: IN general, people who are nearsighted do better on intelligence tests and achieve higher educational levels than those who are not, but the traditional explanation -that reading promotes nearsightedness in genetically susceptible people - may not be correct, Danish scientists say. Instead, they suggest, ''visual exploration of the near environment'' from birth may be associated with both higher intelligence and nearsightedness later in life.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arnold & Co. Advertising and Marketing, Boston, elected John C. Verret president.

title: New York School Decentralization Lost Its Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Disappointed Giants Hold Heads High as Season Comes to End
description: The Giants said goodbye today to a bittersweet season. They met with their coach for more than an hour, they heard words of farewell from the retiring Harry Carson and George Martin, they took physical examinations and they cleaned out their lockers.

title: Note and Bond Prices a Bit Higher
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched slightly higher in very thin trading yesterday, as market participants awaited the release this morning of potentially important inflation data.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Officer Gets More Titles At American Petrofina
