title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Burger King Ads: Which Way Now?
description: Like a tireless suitor, the Burger King Corporation keeps searching for a line that will work.

title: Moderate Rises Shown in Prices For Consumers
description: Despite widespread fears and scattered evidence of quickening inflation, retail price increases remain moderate, figures compiled by the Labor Department showed today.

title: New York City Needs Alternatives to Jail Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Looks To Its Future News Analysis
description: Fed by five years of prosperity and growth, New Jersey, like most of the metropolitan region, is choking on its success. Highways are jammed, water supplies are tainted and taxes continue climbing to pay for the new roads, sewers and services that reach ever farther into the countryside.

title: How to Put Better Principals Into the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: China in Loan to Soviets
description: The state-run Bank of China has joined in a syndicated $50 million loan to a Soviet bank, marking the first time China has provided such credit to the Soviet Union, the official China Daily said today. The daily said the bank was participating in a loan repayable over seven years to the Soviet Vneshekonom Bank. Other participants include two banks each from Finland and Denmark and a bank from the Netherlands. The report did not say how much the Bank of China was contributing to the loan package.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT'S time to bail out the procrastinators. Whatever else wine may be, it's a godsend to foot-dragging gift buyers. The big stores may run short of bathrobes and sweaters, but it's possible to wait until Christmas Eve to pick up a magnum of great Champagne or a case of Beaujolais nouveau.

title: Young Pupils And Others Aid Neediest
description: For the third year in a row, the fourth-grade boys at the Browning School decided to help ''the people less fortunate than us'' by sending a collective gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Fetisov Won't Join Devils Soon
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, captain of the Soviet national hockey team, will probably not play for the New Jersey Devils this season.

title: Wide Impact Expected In Shell Pollution Case
description: A finding by a California jury on Monday against the Shell Oil Company may influence similar suits involving pollution damage, parties in the case and in similar cases said yesterday.

title: Columbia Guard Slain in Journalism School
description: A Columbia University security guard was found fatally shot last night in the journalism building on the campus in Morningside Heights, the police said.

title: 10 Sullivan Finalists
description: Florence Griffith Joyner, who set world records in the women's 100- and 200-meter dashes and won three Olympic gold medals and one silver, is among 10 finalists for the Amateur Athletic Union's 1988 Sullivan Award.

title: Pact Is Reached On Repayments In Health Plan
description: Mayor Koch and the City Council, reaching a compromise, agreed yesterday to increase the city's reimbursement of health insurance premiums for its retirees starting next year. They did this without cutting $7 million from city cultural programs, as Mr. Koch had threatened.

title: America Is Going Sweet on White Chocolate
description: LIKE it or not, white chocolate seems to be on dessert carts and candy-store shelves to stay. The fad that announced itself with a profusion of elaborately decorated desserts, chips for cookies and brownies and products like white-chocolate-flavored toothpaste and white-chocolate tortellini, is settling in.

title: Export Aide Is Convicted
description: An employee of the United States Commerce Department was convicted Monday of bribery, extortion and lying to Federal officers.

title: THE WASHINGTON TALK: The Military; Panel on Closing of Bases Is Bracing for Uproar
description: For seven months a commission charged with drawing up a list of United States military bases to be closed or consolidated has done its work in strict secrecy, not to preserve national security but to shield itself from political interference.

title: Zap the Chestnuts; Tune In a Yle Log
description: Chestnuts roasting in the microwave, Nintendo blasting on the screen, Yuletide hymns being sung by a bear, And wreaths made of anything not green.

title: Giants Headed for More Changes
description: For the Giants, the season is over. For many of the Giants, their careers are over, at least with the Giants.

title: Leonard Fliedner, 88, High School Principal
description: Leonard J. Fliedner, an educator who was principal of Stuyvesant High School for 17 years until his retirement in 1973, died of complications from pneumonia Saturday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 88 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Russell Withdraws
description: Georgia Southern's football coach, Erk Russell, withdrew yesterday from the list of prospective successors to Vince Dooley at the University of Georgia.

title: Countrywide Credit Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $2,314,000 gain on the repurchase of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Massachusetts Bond Offering Has Maximum Yield of 7.5%
description: Massachusetts is offering $380 million of general-obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 7.50 percent for bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the sole senior manager for the sale.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
May Stores Announces Changes at Foley's Unit
description: LEAD: Michael Steinberg, a merchandising executive of the May Department Stores Company who joined its Foley's Department store division as president in 1985, was named chief executive of the 38-store division of May, while Jerome R. Rossi, a financial executive who has served as chairman of May's Hartford-based G.

title: At These Prices, Investment-Grade Caviar
description: CAVIAR prices are higher than ever this season, about double what they were two years ago. As usual, some dealers are suggesting that others are passing off lesser grades for more costly varieties - reports that, as usual, cannot be confirmed.

title: Review/Television; 20 Years After Kerner
description: If evidence is required of the difficulty of saying anything new about racial prejudice, ''The Deep North'' supplies it. Tonight's offering on Channel 2 at 9 o'clock sets out to discover whether things have changed since the 1968 Kerner Commission report warning that the nation was being split into two separate and unequal societies, one black, one white. The unstartling conclusion is that, as far as New York and its vicinity are concerned, the situation is pretty much the same.

title: U.S. RECONSIDERING 2D LAROUCHE TRIAL
description: After the conviction of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. in Virginia in a case involving defaults on $30 million in loans, the Government is reviewing whether to retry the political extremist on related charges here.

title: Growing Up in Denmark
description: ''Pelle the Conqueror'' was shown as part of the New York Film Festival this fall. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 30. The film, in Danish with English subtitles, opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinema, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Recipes to Summon the Holiday Spirit
description: NOSTALGIA for a home filled with the heavenly aromas of holiday cooking is as much a part of the seasonal spirit as last-minute shopping.. A number of new cookbooks can help turn savory memories into mouthwatering realities for the holiday cook or for someone on a gift list.

title: Japan's Contemptuous Whalers
description: Japan has dispatched its whaling fleet on what it calls a scientific research expedition. In fact, it's a hunting trip, and the quarry this year is 300 minke whales to provide meat for Japanese tables.

title: Lawyers Begin Defense's Case For Steinberg
description: The prosecution completed its case in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg yesterday when a medical expert testified that Lisa Steinberg was a battered child whose many injuries were consistent with her having been beaten to death.

title: 7 Indicted in Drug Deaths
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a chemist and six other people Monday in the distribution of the synthetic narcotic China White, which has been blamed for 13 deaths in the Pittsburgh area. The chemist, Thomas L. Schaefers, was charged in the 33-count indictment with manufacturing the drug. The others were indicted on distribution charges.

title: In Philippines, Progressives Are Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Judge Denied New Trial
description: A Federal judge Monday denied a new trial for Judge Walter Nixon Jr. of United States District Court in Mississippi, who was convicted in 1986 of perjury. He is serving a five-year sentence at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida.

title: Records of Gigante's Bronx Housing Group Are Subpoenaed
description: As part of a broad investigation into corruption in New York City's construction industry, a state grand jury has subpoenaed the financial records of a highly respected Bronx community organization.

title: Annette Daum, Educator, 62
description: Annette Daum, an educator and leader in interfaith programs, died of cancer Monday at her home in Syosset, L.I. She was 62 years old.

title: ALASKA CRASH LAID TO FAULTY LOADING
description: The National Transportation Safety Board ruled yesterday that improper loading that made the plane excessively tail-heavy probably caused a commuter airline crash in Alaska a year ago in which 18 of the 21 people aboard died.

title: Group in Bid For Fairchild
description: The Carlyle Group L.P., a Washington-based investment firm, has offered to buy all the shares of Fairchild Industries that it does not control for $15.50 in cash each, valuing all the company's shares at more than $220 million.

title: U.N. Votes to Send Angola Force
description: Beginning to carry out a 10-year-old plan for the independence of Namibia, the Security Council voted unanimously today to send a 70-member force to Angola to oversee the withdrawal of Cuban troops.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, said it had expanded the marketing of its disposable contact lenses into the Boston area.

title: Reagan Establishes a Board To Oversee Space Research
description: President Reagan has signed an executive order that establishes a National Microgravity Research Board to oversee scientific studies on the near-weightlessness of space.

title: No Headline
description: A bottlenose dolphin has become stranded in the chilly waters off Virginia Beach after failing to migrate south this fall, and the authorities are planning a rescue to try to reunite it with its brethren.

title: Library of 10,000 Rarities To Be Sold at Sotheby's
description: The 10,000-volume library of Henry Bradley Martin - embracing one of the world's finest collections of ornithological volumes, as well as major holdings in American, English and French literature and important American historical documents - is to be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York. The collection, part of Mr. Martin's estate, includes one of the last privately held copies of the first printing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: When the Sleigh's in the Shop
description: GIFT lugging is as much a part of Christmas as plum pudding and humbug. The larger the bundle, the nicer people are to the struggling pseudo-Santa, sometimes out of sympathy and often in memory of lugged gifts past.

title: Humana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $16,133,000 on the early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $16,214,000 from an accounting change.

title: End Timber Giveaway
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls 116, Lakers 103: John Paxson hit a 12-foot jumper with 3 minutes 28 seconds remaining and Michael Jordan then scored 6 straight points as Chicago dealt Los Angeles its fourth consecutive loss. It is the first time since March 1979 that the Lakers have lost four straight. Chicago scored 13 consecutive points in the final quarter as the Bulls built a 111-100 lead. Jordan had 13 of his 42 points in the final quarter. James Worthy scored 20 of his 24 points in the second half for the Lakers.(AP) Hawks 121, Sonics 118: Moses Malone scored 9 of his 30 points in the final 5:17 as Atlanta withstood a furious Seattle rally. Atlanta led by 99-84 after three quarters, but Dale Ellis scored 16 of his 30 points in the final period as the Sonics pulled within 3 points. Ellis scored 11 straight in a 13-2 run that pulled the Sonics within 108-100 with 5:17 remaining. Then Malone scored 8 consecutive points to put the Hawks up 116-105. But Seattle came back with 2 free throws by Ellis and a 3-pointer and a layup by Derrick McKey to pull within 116-112. The teams traded shots until Reggie Theus's layup made it 120-114. After McKey's layup, John Lucas stole the inbound pass and scored to make it 120-118 with 29 seconds left. Malone hit a free throw with 12 seconds left to make it 121-118. The Sonics attempted two 3-point shots, but both missed.(AP) Cavaliers 110, Jazz 94: Ron Harper scored 32 points and Cleveland's defense sparked a 32-6 third-quarter run. Mark Price scored 24 points and Brad Daugherty added 21 as the Cavaliers improved to 16-5, the best winning percentage in the National Basketball Association. Karl Malone led Utah with 30 points, Darrell Griffith scored 23 and Thurl Bailey added 22 as the Jazz lost their fourth straight game. Utah led by 58-52 after Griffith made a 3-point shot with 8:46 left in the third quarter. The Cavaliers went to a full-court press, which ignited the surge that put them ahead by 84-64 entering the fourth quarter. The Cavaliers, who lead the league in defense and are 14-1 when they hold an opponent under 100 points, forced 10 turnovers in the third quarter, leading to 14 points.(AP) Pistons 116, Heat 100: Adrian Dantley scored 9 of his 19 points in the first quarter as Detroit broke to a early lead at The Palace. A 3-pointer by Bill Laimbeer started a 22-10 run that gave the Pistons a 31-19 lead at the end of the first quarter. Detroit led 61-45 at halftime and 87-72 going into the final period.(AP) Mavericks 108, 76ers 102: Rolando Blackman scored 20 of his 24 points in the second half to give Dallas its fifth consecutive road game, equaling a club record. Sam Perkins had 25 points and Mark Aguirre 21 for the Mavericks, who are 6-1 on the road, the best in the league. Dallas led by 102-95 on a jumper by Derek Harper with 2:48 to play. But Charles Barkley hit a free throw, then connected on a 3-point shot as Philadelphia closed to 102-99. Harper scored on a driving layup with 56 seconds remaining before Barkley made a free throw and Ron Anderson a layup to cut the Maverick lead to 104-102 with 13 seconds left.(AP) Rockets 105, Kings 104: Buck Johnson's two free throws with 23 seconds left boosted Houston. The Rockets, playing without Akeem Olajuwon, who was ejected from the game with 2:12 remaining, then forced Ed Pinckney to take an off-balance, eight-foot shot from the lane that bounced off the rim as the game ended. With Sacramento leading by 97-96, Olajuwon was called for goaltending on a shot by Harold Pressley. Olajuwon disputed the call by Ed Rush and was ejected from the game after Rush called two technical fouls on him. Pressley hit both technical foul shots, and a free throw by Pinckney gave Sacramento a 102-96 lead with 1:54 left. Mike Woodson's 3-point shot cut the Kings lead to 102-99. After Pressley scored, Otis Thorpe and Woodson each hit two free throws to narrow the Kings lead to 104-103 with 41 seconds remaining, setting the stage for Johnson's game-winning free throws.(AP) Suns 128, Spurs 110: Eddie Johnson came off the bench to score 27 points, 11 during a decisive 29-5 third-quarter spurt as Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons his 600th victory. Fitzsimmons ranks ninth on the league's career victory list and fourth among active coaches - trailing only Gene Shue, John MacLeod and Lenny Wilkens. The Suns won their seventh straight home game and dealt San Antonio its eighth consecutive loss.(AP) Bucks 125, Hornets 115: Terry Cummings scored a season-high 37 points and Ricky Pierce had 17 fourth-quarter points for Milwaukee.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 6, Blues 3: Steve Yzerman scored his 32d goal midway through the final period to snap a 3-3 tie. Yzerman, who also had three assists, ran his point-scoring string to 22 games, tying the team record he set last season. After Paul MacLean's power-play goal tied the score 3-3 7:56 into the final period, Yzerman took a long pass from Joe Murphy, eluded two defenders and drove a wrist shot past the goaltender Greg Millen. Gallant scored his second power-play goal of the game with 1:45 left and Miroslav Frycer connected 53 seconds later.(AP) SKIING Tight Finish: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland edged Blanca Fernandez-Ochoa of Spain by one-hundredth of a second to win a women's World Cup slalom yesterday in Courmayeur, Italy. The victory was her fourth of the season and the 17th of her career. Schneider leads the women's overall World Cup standing by 58 points with 132 after 7 races. Schneider, 24 years old, an Olympic slalom and giant slalom champion, clocked a winning aggregate time of 1 minute 37.53 seconds after two heats down the Checrouit course at the foot of Mount Blanc, Europe's highest peak. Fernandez-Ochoa missed her first slalom victory since 1987 with a time of 1:37.54. Ingrid Salvenmoser of Austria, a third-group starter, rallied from 12th place in the first heat to finish third in 1:38.96. Anita Wachter and Ulrike Maier of Austria finished fourth and fifth, respectively. Maier is second in the standing with 74 points. Wachter is third with 62, 3 ahead of Michela Figini of Switzerland.(AP)

title: Hanover Corporation Names Vice Chairman
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday appointed Edward D. Miller a vice chairman as well as a director of both the holding company and its banking subsidiary, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Rates Up Again At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper rose yesterday for the third consecutive week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Cube, a new cooperative residence for the homeless on the Lower East Side, incorrectly reported the cost of apartments. In addition to monthly maintenance fees, residents pay a one-time purchase price of $477 for one-bedroom apartments; $614 for two-bedroom apartments, and $750 for three-bedroom apartments. The purchase-price money of all the residents represents the $12,684 that they put up as equity.

title: The Pop Life
description: Bette Midler Again

title: Lady Vols Rout U.C.L.A.
description: Bridgette Gordon scored 16 points, including 6 in an early decisive rally, to boost the No. 1 Tennessee Lady Vols to an 82-50 victory over U.C.L.A. last night.

title: What Added Up for the Playoff 10
description: The measuring stick for making the National Football League playoffs emphasizes two numbers: victories and losses. But for the 10 teams that qualified, there were other crucial figures.

title: John Duda Dies at 84; Part of a Farm Empire
description: John Duda, who helped his family build one of the nation's largest agricultural empires, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Now and Carlton Cigarettes Lowest in Tar, F.T.C. Reports
description: The Federal Trade Commission, in its first report on cigarette tar content in nearly four years, said today that a Carlton and a Now brand had the lowest tar, while Old Gold Straights and Philip Morris Commander had the highest.

title: Science Academy Proposes Changes in Budget Process
description: The National Academy of Sciences urged the White House and Congress today to adopt new budget procedures to improve the way priorities are set for research spending. The academy proposed that all Government-financed science and technology programs be considered together rather than being compartmentalized by agency.

title: Texas Air Stake
description: A group led by the New York investor Michael H. Steinhardt said today that it had purchased 5.5 percent of the Texas Air Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Steinhardt Partners L.P. said it had bought 2.18 million shares for $11.78 each. Texas Air's stock slipped 50 cents today, to $13 a share, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE vibrant and endlessly varied combinations of spices in Indian cuisine have fascinated me for years. Inspired by Indian curry dishes, I recently created a marinade for grilled shrimp.

title: Prime Computer Layoffs Are Seen
description: Prime Computer Inc. may lay off 200 to 1,000 employees within six months as it restructures its sales and marketing staffs after a recent acquisition, The Boston Herald and The Middlesex News reported. Speculation about layoffs has been fueled by a recent announcement that the company, which acquired the Computervision Corporation in February, intends to reorganize the operations.

title: Oakland Offering Of $209.7 Million
description: Oakland, Calif., is tentatively offering $209.7 million of special refunding revenue bonds (pension financing) with a maximum yield of about 7.641 percent for an issue due 2021 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: KEY RATES
FOOD NOTES
description: For Holiday Roasting

title: Knicks Sign Myers
description: The Knicks signed Pete Myers, a 6-foot-6-inch swingman, yesterday and requested waivers on Rick Carlisle, a guard who has been injured all season.

title: Cuomo Urged To Issue Order In AIDS Cases
description: New York State health officials have urged Governor Cuomo to issue an emergency executive order to overrule local opposition to homes for AIDS patients and drug-addiction treatment sites.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
A Different Direction In Forest Navigation
description: Part of the fun of poking about in the woods, whether hiking, backpacking, hunting or trying to find some remote trout pond, is learning to use topographic maps and a compass with a high degree of skill.

title: Books of The Times; Gloom Under the Gleam Of a Suburban Marriage
description: American Appetites By Joyce Carol Oates 340 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Guidry and Yankees Part, for the Moment
description: As expected, the Yankees did not tender a contract to Ron Guidry yesterday, essentially ending the 38-year-old pitcher's tenure with the team. But there was still hope in the Guidry camp that the left-hander could win an invitation to camp and a roster spot in the spring.

title: Oil Prices Surge on Report of a Saudi Curb
description: Crude oil prices soared yesterday on unconfirmed reports that Saudi Arabia had slashed by 40 percent an order from the Mitsubishi International Corporation as its contribution to the Organizaton of Petroleum Exporting Countries' latest agreement to reduce output.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Duckett Ineligible
description: Anthony Duckett, a center for the Rutgers basketball team who was arraigned Monday in connection with a theft from a New Brunswick store, was declared ineligible for competition by school officials yesterday after it was disclosed that a coach had posted his $1,000 bail.

title: In a Skeletal Armenian City, A Makeshift Hearth Appears
description: The mood in the Shaginyan household was not really festive today, but under the ghastly circumstances it seemed an oasis of comfort and joy.

title: YES. THEY INVITE A DOLLAR CRISIS - IF NOT WORSE
description: An inflationary recession with extensive financial disruption is quite possible unless George Bush and Congress promptly develop a credible program to reduce the Federal budget deficit. These risks stem mainly from the stubborn trade deficit and its financial implications.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Farmers' Costs Seen Rising
description: The Agriculture Department projects that farmers will face significantly higher crop production costs next year than they did in 1988. The department's Economic

title: Panel to Examine Remarks By Judge on Homosexuals
description: The Texas Civil Liberties Union, the Texas Human Rights Foundation, the National Lawyers Guild and the Lesbian/ Gay Rights Lobby of Texas have filed a complaint with the State Commission on Judicial Conduct against a judge whose comments about two slain homosexuals have stirred public outrage.

title: New Inquiry Is Ordered Into 3 Deaths in Ulster
description: The Court of Appeals ordered a new inquest today into the killing of three unarmed Irish Republican Army guerrillas at a police roadblock in 1982.

title: Subcommittee Favors A Longer School Year
description: The school year should be longer, and school buildings should be used for community purposes like alcohol and drug counseling, a Congressional subcommittee has recommended.

title: Liberty Hires Rutigliano
description: Sam Rutigliano, the former coach of the Cleveland Browns, was named football coach today at Liberty University, the school founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell.

title: Soviet Official Denies Plan to Devalue Ruble
description: The top trade official in the Soviet Government denied today that the ruble would be devalued by 50 percent in 1990 for trade purposes, as had been reported in the West based on Soviet news reports in the last two weeks.

title: LAW BARS ACCOUNT ABOUT SLAIN GIRL, AIDE TO KOCH SAYS
description: New York City's top child welfare official said yesterday that state law barred him from explaining why a Brooklyn woman with a documented history of child neglect won a 1986 battle for custody of her 5-year-old daughter, who was beaten to death last week.

title: Arens: Happy Engineer But Reluctant Politician
description: Moshe Arens, who will become Israel's Foreign Minister if the coalition agreement between the Likud and Labor parties is carried out, is an American-educated aeronautical engineer who says his heart is not in politics.

title: U.S. Has a Tariff Level Higher Than Japan's
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets to Get Surgery
description: Johnny Hector, the Jet running back, and two teammates, Reggie McElroy, an offensive tackle, and Billy Griggs, a tight end, will undergo surgery, the club said yesterday.

title: Moody's to Review Ratings Of Shearson and Salomon
description: Moody's Investor Services said yesterday that it was considering downgrading its ratings on the long-term debt and commercial paper issued by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and Salomon Inc. because of the firms' appetite for risky investments in merchant banking.

title: Sudan Confirms Coup Report And Arrest of 25 Suspects
description: The Government confirmed today that it thwarted an attempt to overthrow Prime Minister Sadek al-Mahdi last week and arrested 25 civilians and retired soldiers.

title: Michael Milken: Legendary Wall Street Outsider at Center of U.S. Inquiry
description: One of the few things the highly competitive and often contentious executives in the financial world can agree on is that the 1980's would have been a different era were it not for the energy and obsession for control of one person: Michael R. Milken.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Inch Up
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher after trading in a very narrow range yesterday. Activity slowed to a trickle, participants said, as the Christmas and New Year's holidays near.

title: Jetliner Carrying 258 Crashes in Scottish Town
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; D.C. Comics In New Push To Sell Space
description: IT'S been a traumatic year at D.C.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are responsible, we are guilty. Children do not just belong to their parents, they belong to all society. We must teach our children to love one another. Everything in this society teaches young people violence.'' - The Rev. Donald Kenna, at the funeral of Jessica Cortez. [ B6:4. ]

title: Berlin Ending Inquiry On 2 in Disco Bombing
description: A prosecutor said today that the authorities had dropped an investigation of two suspects in a nightclub bombing in 1986 that led to an American retaliatory strike against Libya.

title: Ex-Quebec Coach Has Surgery
description: Ron Lapointe, the former coach of the Quebec Nordiques, underwent surgery today to remove a kidney. Lapointe resigned last week after a cancerous tumor on the kidney was detected.

title: Washington Still Thinking About Pinstripes
description: The negotiations were expected to be swift and simple, but there is a snag. The prospect of Claudell Washington's return to the Yankees next season has slowly grown dimmer, reduced - at least in the player's mind - to no more than a 50-50 chance.

title: Dr. Isadore Gerber, 85, Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Isadore E. Gerber, a physician and clinical professor of medicine, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; All of Meat Line to Grey
description: Grey Advertising is the beneficiary of a decision by Swift/Eckrich, a meat and poultry processor, to consolidate its advertising in a single agency. After Swift and Eckrich merged in 1984, Grey continued doing creative work on Swift's Butterball turkeys, Brown 'n' Serve sausages and Sizzlean breakfast meat, and Leo Burnett maintained creative responsibility for the Eckrich line of cold cuts, frankfurters and smoked sausages and did all the media buying. The entire account has a budget of $15 million to $20 million.

title: Day Care in an Artistic Setting
description: KATHERINE awoke from a nap and demanded attention. Nathan painted more of the floor and himself than the paper. And Elena wanted her going-away party now, please. With some effort, the children were soon assembled around a small table for cake, candles and songs. So went a typical afternoon at Kathryn Kennedy's Little Darlings Child Care on St. Marks Place in Manhattan.

title: Armenia Opens To Show Capital Under Tight Lid
description: At Yerevan University and at the Polytechnical Institute, where passions have run high during this year of Armenian self-assertion, soldiers with automatic rifles take attendance each morning.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Tim Love Advertising will be moving its office to Katonah, N.Y., on Dec. 28, but will maintain a production operation in New York City.

title: Sherover-Marcuse, 49; Ran Group Encounters
description: Erica Sherover-Marcuse, an organizer of workshops aimed at the resolution of cultural conflicts, died of liver failure last Thursday at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 49 years old.

title: Trial Begins for GAF In Stock-Trading Case
description: The trial of the GAF Corporation began yesterday with a Federal prosecutor saying that Samuel J. Heyman, chairman of the company, set up the original contact between a senior executive and a brokerage firm that led to a conspiracy to manipulate stock prices.

title: Paine Webber Names Broker Unit President
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. announced yesterday that Paul B. Guenther had been named president of its broker-dealer subsidiary, Paine Webber Inc.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Robotic Vision Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Father and Son Have Team on Top
description: When the No. 1 high school basketball team in the country practices, the focus inevitably and rightfully sways to two individuals. One does the most talking; one does the most scoring. They have the same serious eyes and the same confident swagger. They even have the same name.

title: Rockwell Is Fined for Nuclear Plant Pollution
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and Rockwell International Corporation have settled a dispute over violations of Federal pollution laws at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver.

title: Drexel and U.S. Statements
description: Following are the statements released yesterday by the United States Attorney's office and by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. on the firm's agreement to plead guilty to six felony counts: U.S. Statement

title: Bonn Investigates 2 Companies' Nuclear Exports
description: West German prosecutors said today that two West German companies were being investigated for the suspected sale of nuclear equipment to Pakistan, India and South Africa.

title: Rockingham Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Reagan's Last Budget Calls for Deep Cut in Deficit
description: In the last budget of his Administration, President Reagan will propose reducing the Federal deficit to $92.5 billion, the lowest since 1982, without raising taxes.

title: Citizens Growth Properties Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After investment gains of $275,000 and $520,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes investment losses of $20,000 for the quarter and $110,000 for the 9 months.

title: Critics' Notebook  Charles Dickens: Eminently Adaptable but Quite Inimitable; Dostoyevsky to Disney, The Dickensian Legacy
description: ''Dickens,'' Fred Kaplan's informative new biography of Charles Dickens, opens with a scenef f the author burning all his correspondence, sending up, in a great bonfire, letters from the famous and the obscure, letters from Carlyle, Thackeray and Tennyson, letters from his family, admirers and friends. ''He had no belief in or commitment to the idea of a public record about private matters,'' writes Mr. Kaplan (William Morrow & Company, $24.95). ''His books would speak for him. All other voices should be silenced. His art, not his life, was public property.''

title: Paving Suspected as Road Becomes Deadly
description: Road crews were busy today tearing up and repaving specially treated pavement on two Essex County roads that was supposed to be extraordinarily safe but turned out to be deadly.

title: The Search for Grandmother's Tree
description: ''TINY white lights and red bows may be exquisite decorating,'' said Geva Alder of Nashville, ''but they do not fill the soul.'' What fills the soul? ''Screaming excess,'' she replied. Christmas at the Alders is celebrated with hot-pink 1950's bubble lights with pink cords and sockets. Their tree, a rotating green cellophane beauty, is draped with pink icicles and crowned with a star of pink, aqua and lime green. Among the cherished family Christmas ornaments are two whirly-spinners and a hot-pink Sputnik look-alike with projecting antennae.

title: U.N. Officer on Flight 103
description: Bernt Carlsson, who was a passenger on the Pan Am flight that crashed over Scotland, had served as chief administrative officer of the United Nations Council for Namibia since July 1987. He was on his way here for a ceremony on Thursday, at which accords providing for Namibia's independence are to be signed by Angola, Cuba and South Africa.

title: Inmate Hits Steinberg In Fistfight at Rikers I.
description: Joel B. Steinberg received a black eye and had a tooth knocked loose Tuesday in a fistfight with another inmate at Rikers Island, the Correction Department said yesterday.

title: Driver Jailed
description: Randy Lanier, the 1986 Indianapolis 500 rookie of the year, was sentenced yesterday in Benton, Ill., to life in prison without possibility of parole for his part in a multimillion-dollar drug-smuggling operation.

title: Relatives and Strangers Join to Mourn Young Abuse Victim
description: In life, Jessica Cortez was a quiet victim, a 5-year-old who was beaten and sexually assaulted. In death she attracted television lights and mourners who never knew her.

title: Ousted Panamanian Is Flown to U.S.
description: The ousted President of Panama arrived here today for consultations with President Reagan and President-elect Bush as the United States searched for new ways to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader.

title: Merryle S. Rukeyser, Financial Columnist And an Editor, 91
description: Merryle S. Rukeyser, a financial columnist and editor who lectured widely in the United States and abroad, died of heart failure yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Don Mitchum, president BDA/ BBDO, Atlanta, an operating unit of BBDO North America, has assumed the additional title of chief executive from F. Glenn Verrill, who will retire on Dec. 31.

title: Qume Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter results reflect the earnings of Data Technology alone which acquired Qume Corp. in June. Data Technology was renamed Qume in August.

title: Skyline Chili Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
AGENCY DEFENDED IN DEATH OF CHILD
description: New York City's top child-welfare official said yesterday that even if his agency had been aware that a Brooklyn mother had a history of child neglect, it still would have recommended that she retain custody of a 5-year-old girl who died in her care last week.

title: Books of The Times; A Mayor, a City and a Tangled Skein of Scandal
description: City for Sale By Jack Newfield and Wayne Barrett Illustrated. 466 pages. Harper & Row.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Coach Class Carol
description: The Partnership for Improved Air Travel, a group of industry and consumer groups seeking expansion of the air traffic system, has long argued that the Federal Government is too stingy with the tax revenue raised by surcharges on airline tickets. The group says the Government hoards the surplus to reduce the budget deficit instead of spending it on aviation needs, In a Christmas message this week, the group estimated that in the 17 days of peak Christmas travel, the ticket tax will raise $176 million.

title: National Service Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TWO NAMED TO FILL WHITE HOUSE JOBS
description: Gov. John H. Sununu, President-elect Bush's White House chief of staff, filled two senior staff positions today with the appointment of the chief Congressional lobbyist and the communications director.

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of assets of $12 million. c-Net income and includes a pretax gain of $17,473,000 for the sale of a subsidiary and a loss of $1,796,000 from early retirement of debt. Results for 1987 are restated to reflect an income tax accounting change.

title: One Korean Team Urged
description: North Korea proposed to South Korea today that the two send a joint team to the 1990 Asian Games in China.

title: Security Capital Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5.5 million and $1.9 million for the latest and prior years, respectively, on the disposal of the company's real estate advisory and broker-dealer segments. The company said its Benjamin Franklin Savings Association subsidiary incurred a net loss of about $125 million in the latest fiscal year, compared with a $28 million loss in the prior year. The company also said that at Sept. 30, Franklin's liabilities exceeded its assets by about $36 million.

title: Railroads That Carry Grown Men Away
description: THIS is the season that tries men's souls. Diesel or steam? Passenger or freight? The O-gauge trains you had as a child? Or the smaller HO trains your son wants?

title: Finding Beauty in the Commonplace
description: ''POTTERY BARN is too high-style,'' said Constantin Boym. ''I prefer Woolworth's and Lamston's.'' Mr. Boym is a 33-year-old Russian-born designer whose idiosyncratic interpretations of common objects, including detergent containers and miniature Scotch bottles, are on display at Gallery 91.

title: Texas Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,599,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Kevlin Microwave Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: N.F.L. Parity: All Teams Equally Dull
description: It is probably fantasy to expect Giants fans to have completely emerged from the depression brought about Sunday when their team's loss to the dastardly Jets cost the Giants the bragging rights to East Rutherford, N.J., and eventually, a playoff berth.

title: Bilzerian Is Indicted Over Deals
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who captured the Singer Company earlier this year in a takeover battle, was indicted yesterday on 12 counts of violating securities and tax laws, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government. None of the charges relate to the acquisition of Singer.

title: Taxi Meters Found Prone To Distortion
description: The almost 12,000 electronic meters that click off miles and fares in New York City taxicabs are so sensitive and vulnerable to distortion that even underinflated tires can cause overcharging, officials of the Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday.

title: Depression Among Elderly Patients Is Often Undetected, Study Finds
description: As many as one in seven elderly medical patients suffers from severe depression in addition to physical illness, a new study has found. And in many cases, or perhaps most, the depression goes undiagnosed and untreated, frequently worsening or complicating the physical disorder.

title: Trump Says He Won't Sell Manhattan Site
description: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had decided not to sell his 57-acre site on the Upper West Side, where he wants to build eight large apartment towers, shopping malls, offices and the world's tallest building, a 150-story tower.

title: L.I. Town Passes Housing for Homeless
description: The Brookhaven Town Board, which is being accused in a lawsuit of blocking the construction of apartments for poor people, has agreed to support a plan to build transitional housing for homeless women and children.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about New York City's decision to pay the full cost of health insurance premiums for its retirees next year misstated the amount of money that Mayor Koch had threatened to cut from city-sponsored cultural programs. He had proposed cutting $2.5 million from cultural groups, as part of a total plan to trim $7 million from 10 city programs.

title: Tournament With a Special Purpose
description: The Syracuse Invitational stands out among the Christmas college hockey tournaments. It is played to benefit terminally ill children and special attention is given to entertaining the players who have given up vacation time to participate.

title: Guard Is Slain On Campus At Columbia
description: A Columbia University guard was shot and killed Tuesday night in what university officials said was the first homicide on the Morningside Heights campus in 36 years. The police said they had no motive and no suspects.

title: Japanese Tax Bills Advance
description: Parliamentary debate on a tax-revision plan that would give Japan a sales tax turned into a raucous shouting match today when the governing party pushed the measures through a key committee session.

title: Crack in Fuel Pump Found in Space Shuttle
description: A tiny crack has been discovered in one of the high-pressure pumps that send liquid oxygen into the three main engines of the space shuttle Atlantis.

title: Barden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of about $840,000 for termination of a foreign distributor.

title: James J. Mannix Sr., Developer, 75
description: James J. Mannix Sr., a real-estate developer, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in the Prospect Park section of Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and also had a home in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Review/Operetta; A 'Pirates of Penzance' With Some Opulence
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players began modestly in 1974, when Albert Bergeret founded the group to perform operettas by their namesakes. Five years later Mr. Bergeret began staging homespun productions at Symphony Space, and in recent years these have become highlights of the holiday season.

title: Homeless Addicts in Oregon Find Aid in Restoring Lives
description: When city officials here proposed putting homeless drug addicts and alcoholics under one roof with nothing but peer pressure to keep them clean, a chorus of skepticism could be heard all the way up the Willamette River.

title: Amnesty From Seoul Releases 281 Jailed On Political Charges
description: The Government released 281 political prisoners today as part of a broad amnesty, and some of the freed prisoners vowed to topple President Roh Tae Woo and drive United States forces out of South Korea.

title: Mulroney Calls for Calm in Language Uproar
description: As passions continued to rise across Canada over Quebec's decision to entrench its ban on outdoor signs and billboards in English, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney appealed to Canadians today to weigh the question of minority language rights in an atmosphere of ''calm reason.''

title: House Panel's Buyout Inquiry
description: A House subcommittee has begun to investigate the leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco and the various offers made for the tobacco and food processing giant. In a letter to directors of

title: Syracuse's Coleman Pleads Not Guilty
description: Derrick Coleman, a junior forward averaging 18 points a game for the Syracuse basketball team, pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal mischief and harassment charges in connection with two incidents earlier this month. Judge James Tormey of Syracuse City Court released Coleman, 21 years old, on his own recognizance for a Jan. 31 hearing.

title: Nigel Olney, Transplant Patient, 44
description: Nigel Olney, Britain's longest surviving heart transplant patient, died today almost nine years after his surgery. He was 44 years old.

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the year-ago fourth quarter results were adversely affected by lowered production levels and decreased manufacturing efficiency.

title: Fuji Bank, Kleinwort Tie
description: The Federal Reserve Board Tuesday approved an application by Fuji Bank Ltd. of Tokyo to acquire 24.9 percent of the outstanding voting shares of Kleinwort Benson Government Securities Inc. of Chicago.

title: A Christmas Gift Gift
description: The world, it's been said, is divided between those who love salt and those who love sugar. It is also divided between those who can wrap packages and those who cannot. This division becomes dramatically clear each December.

title: Lincoln Center Shifts Plays
description: Lincoln Center Theater has moved its next production, Shakespeare's ''Measure for Measure,'' from the Lyceum on Broadway to its own Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

title: Howard B Wolf Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $50,000 and $82,500 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $5,147.

title: Acclaim Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter share earnings net is not available; the company went public in June 1988.

title: U.S. Indicts 3 in Killing of New York City Detective
description: Three men who have twice stood trial on charges of killing a New York City police detective in 1986 have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on racketeering charges that refer to the detective's slaying as ''part of the pattern of racketeering activity.''

title: Ford to Acquire Lending Unit of Meritor
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had agreed to acquire a consumer lending unit from the Meritor Financial Group for $1.3 billion - $150 million in cash and the rest in debt.

title: CANDIDATE FIGHTS SRI LANKAN RESULT
description: The leading opposition candidate defeated in Monday's presidential election said today that she would challenge the results of the voting in the Sri Lankan Supreme Court.

title: Town's Hall Used as Clinic, Then Morgue
description: Soon after the Pan Am Boeing 747 plowed into Lockerbie this evening, its council hall became a makeshift clinic. Within hours, it was a morgue.

title: Kenosha Looks Beyond Chrysler
description: The shutting of a car factory that was the backbone of the local economy for eight decades has become the occasion for some surprising expressions of relief and optimism in this industrial city on Lake Michigan.

title: Bridge
description: A Swedish form of contest that is gaining popularity in New York is the Barometer, in which all tables play a given deal at the same time. This adds to the excitement by permitting the matchpoint scores to be calculated round by round so that the players are aware of their standings.

title: Charming Music Boxes Recalling a Bygone Era
description: ''IT's just great that a whole piece of music comes out of a little box,'' said Adam Holland, a customer at Rita Ford Music Boxes in Manhattan, who was recently purchasing a music box for his collection. ''The timing is perfect; everything is perfect.'' It is easy to be charmed by these whimsical throwbacks to the days before stereos and compact disks. Flip a switch and ''Rhapsody in Blue'' spills out into the room. Hit the top of a jewelry box to find a ballerina that spins to ''The Emperor Waltz.'' Or watch the turning of a carousel of dinosaurs to ''Try to Remember.''

title: Faradyne Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New York Averts Cuts In Arts Budget, for Now
description: Many arts organizations in New York reacted joyfully yesterday to a City Hall compromise that averted a threatened $2.5 million cut in the city's cultural affairs budget. But some leaders of arts groups qualified their pleasure with concern about the possibility of still other city and state budget cuts.

title: Farm Credit Bank Posts Bond Yields
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering at a price of par a total of $2.46 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds with three-month, six-month, and one-year maturities through the corporation and various securities dealers and banks.

title: A Child's Death and a Law's Brick Wall of Silence
description: A 5-year-old girl died a horrible death last week in what New York City police call one of the worst cases of child abuse they have ever seen.

title: TV Notes
description: Ads and 'Questions'

title: From Levine Arrest to Drexel Settlement
description: MAY 12, 1986: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Dennis B. Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert of making $12.6 million in illegal trading on inside information since 1980. The next day Mr. Levine is arrested in New York and charged with obstructing justice and attempting to destroy records. JUNE 5: Mr. Levine pleads guilty to four felony charges and agrees to cooperate with the Government's investigation. He agrees to pay $11.6 million in penalties. Secretly, he implicates Ivan F. Boesky, a prominent stock market speculator who runs his own arbitrage firm. JULY 1: The S.E.C. charges Ira B. Sokolow and Robert M. Wilkis, former investment bankers at Shearson Lehman Brothers and Lazard Freres & Company, with exchanging confidential information with Mr. Levine. They settle with the S.E.C. SEPT. 4: Mr. Sokolow and David S. Brown, an investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company, plead guilty to criminal charges of passing stolen information to Mr. Levine. SEPT. 18: Mr. Boesky secretly signs a plea bargain with Government. He agrees to record telephone calls and, by wearing a concealed tape recorder, personal conversations with his alleged confederates. AUTUMN: The U.S. Attorney's office in Manhattan begins a criminal investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.. OCT. 9: Ilan K. Reich, a takeover lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, pleads guilty to two criminal counts for passing information to Mr. Levine. NOV. 14: Mr. Boesky agrees to plead guilty to one felony charge and to pay $100 million to settle S.E.C. charges that he used nonpublic information from Mr. Levine in 1985 and 1986 to play the market. Mr. Boesky announces he will cooperate with the S.E.C. DEC. 22: Mr. Wilkis pleads guilty to four felony charges, and Randall D. Cecola, a former junior financial analyst at Lazard Freres, pleads guilty to two criminal counts of filing false tax returns and settles S.E.C. charges on participating in the Levine scheme. JAN. 28, 1987 : Michael Davidoff, the former head trader for Mr. Boesky, pleads guilty to one count of securities fraud. FEB. 13: Martin A. Siegel resigns as a managing director of Drexel and pleads guilty to illegal stock trading and tax evasion. He surrenders $9 million to settle civil charges of insider trading concerning Mr. Boesky. FEB. 20: Mr. Levine is sentenced to two years in prison and fined $362,000 for securities fraud, tax evasion and perjury. MARCH 19: Boyd L. Jefferies, founder of Jefferies & Company, agrees to plead guilty to two criminal securities fraud charges, including an arrangement that enabled Mr. Boesky to falsify the extent of his stock holdings. APRIL 23: Mr. Boesky formally pleads guilty to one felony charge, conspiracy to make false statements to the S.E.C.. JUNE 4: Kidder Peabody agrees to pay $25.29 million to settle civil charges of insider trading and ''stock parking'' - secretly holding shares of stock to avoid S.E.C. limitations - with Mr. Boesky. DEC. 18: Mr. Boesky is sentenced to a three-year prison term. FEB. 18, 1988: John A. Mulheren, a prominent Wall Street trader implicated by Mr. Boesky, is arrested and accused of threatening to kill Mr. Boesky. MARCH 24: Mr. Boesky begins sentence at a minimum-security facility in Lompoc, Calif. JULY 5: Mr. Levine is released from a Lewisburg, Pa., prison camp to serve the rest of his term at a Manhattan halfway house. JULY 6: A federal grand jury indicts GAF; its vice chairman, James Sherwin, and two subsidiaries on charges they manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986 after trying to acquire the company. These are the first formal charges against a U.S. industrial company that stem indirectly from the Boesky scandal. JULY 14: GAF and Mr. Sherwin plead innocent. AUG. 4: A Federal grand jury indicts five partners of the investment firm Princeton-Newport Partners and a former Drexel official on charges of racketeering, conspiracy and mail and wire fraud. The case, growing out of the Boesky scandal, is the first time officials of a securities firm are accused of violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. All deny wrongdoing. SEPT. 7: The S.E.C. charges Drexel and its junk bond expert, Michael R. Milken, with securities fraud violations. DECEMBER: Discussions between Drexel and the U.S. attorney of a possible settlement of criminal charges, which would avoid an indictment, heat up. DEC. 6: A key Drexel equity trader, Cary J. Maultasch, who was named in the civil charges brought by the S.E.C., is said to agree to cooperate with the investigation. DEC. 21: Drexel agrees in principle to a settlement of criminal charges. The firm will plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million for fines and to set up a special trust fund.

title: Bid for Whittaker
description: The New Jersey investor Louis Caiola said he would continue his efforts to acquire the Whittaker Corporation, a technology and chemicals manufacturer, although the company has already rejected his offer of $47.50 a share.

title: Alphonse Ouimet, Broadcaster, 80
description: Alphonse Ouimet, a former president of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation who helped introduce television to Canada 40 years ago, died of heart failure on Tuesday. He was 80 years old.

title: Standard Microsystems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ex-Sanitation Leader Named to School Post
description: A former Sanitation Commissioner, Norman Steisel, has been named by Mayor Koch to be his representative on the three-member City School Construction Authority.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have noticed a musty odor in the room where there is a pull-down ladder leading to my attic. Although there is no odor in the attic, I discovered that the roof stringers and the ridge pole have mold on them. The attic has several vents and one window. What do you suggest I do?

title: Koreans Need to Know What Chun Did
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Offers Ties to Angola if It Ends Civil War
description: Saying there can be ''no military solution'' to the Angolan civil war, a senior Reagan Administration official indicated today that the United States will not agree to normal relations with Angola until the Government there makes peace with its guerrilla opponents.

title: U.N. Assembly Votes 'Reform' Budget
description: The General Assembly today unanimously approved spending plans for the next three years, the first time a budget has been voted by consensus since 1946, the year the organization was created.

title: Sunbelt Nursery Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Holmes a Court Christie's Stake
description: The Australian entrepreneur Robert Holmes a Court, whose business empire was badly hit in last year's stock market plunge, has taken a stake in the venerable auction house Christie's International P.L.C. Christie's said today that Mr. Holmes a Court had taken a 6.11 percent stake in the company, representing 2.09 million ordinary shares.

title: Metro Matters; Pleas for Heat: One Complaint That Got to Top
description: Darlene Jelicks was shivering in her uncle's one-bedroom apartment at 158 West 141st Street in Harlem one evening last week when she dialed the city's heat complaint number for the umpteenth time.

title: Duke Struggles, but Beats Wake Forest, 94-88
description: Danny Ferry scored 22 of his 33 points in the second half tonight night, lifting Duke past pesky Wake Forest, 94-88, in the opening Atlantic Coast Conference game of the season.

title: Yield Rises Continue
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds continued to rise in the week that ended yesterday. Assets of money market mutual funds have not gained much over the last month because seasonal factors have driven up money market rates to more attractive levels than those offered by the funds.

title: Aztec Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Piano; Brahms for Four Hands
description: In the Vienna of Brahms's day, chamber music was a leading pastime in educated families, and most of the composer's major instrumental compositions - like those of his predecessors - were quickly published in various arrangements for home consumption. The composer himself made four-hand piano arrangements of his three string quartets. Their purpose was hardly served, though, by the presentation of all three at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening by the Seiler Piano Duo.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Daiwa Securities America Inc., a brokerage and investment banking concern, announced that Takuro Isoda, chairman and chief executive, had been named to the added post of managing director of its parent company, Daiwa Securities Co. in Tokyo. Mr. Isoda will continue to be based in New York.

title: Probable Appointee Assures Lawmakers On Abortion Views
description: Leading Congressional opponents of abortion met with Dr. Louis W. Sullivan today and later termed him an acceptable candidate to be Secretary of Health and Human Services, a sign that President-elect Bush might be able to proceed with the selection of his first black Cabinet appointee.

title: 2 Disputed Atom Power Plants Move Nearer Operation
description: Against bitter local opposition and the finding of another Federal agency, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission took steps today to allow the operation of two nuclear power plants in New England.

title: KEY RATES
Probation for Doctor in Steinberg Case
description: The physician who pleaded guilty to helping Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum illegally adopt a baby boy in 1986 was sentenced yesterday to three years probation and 100 hours of community service and fined $1,000.

title: A Sanctuary for 1,000 or So Saints and Their Kin
description: SINCE 1973, when he began selling Art Deco furniture, Alan Moss has been known as one of New York's most prescient dealers. In 15 years, he has become an authority on 20th-century American decorative arts. One would expect his home, then, to be a showcase for fine furniture and great objects of the early 20th century.

title: Tokyo Journal; As Hirohito Sinks, Pall Falls on Japan's New Year
description: In more ordinary times, the ritual of sending out hundreds of New Year's cards to friends, relatives, schoolmates and business associates is meticulously executed by nearly everyone in Japan over the age of 10.

title: OEA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $304,100.

title: Drexel Concedes Guilt on Trading; To Pay $650 Million
description: In the largest settlement ever of Federal securities law violations, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street powerhouse, agreed in principle yesterday to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay $650 million.

title: More on the Drexel Case
description: The Decision to Settle - An indictment of the investment firm appeard imminent until late Tuesday afternoon, when U.S. Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani placed a call to Drexel's chief executive, Federick H. Joseph. Page D5.

title: Southmark Cites Possible Shortfall
description: The Southmark Corporation, a troubled real estate and financial services company, said in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company might not be able to meet its operating requirements and debt service obligations in 1989. The company said it expected to meet its substantial debt obligations by converting real estate and other assets into cash and by refinancing its debt obligations as they came due. But it is possible that the company will not have adequate liquidity to repay $125 million worth of public ''junk bonds'' due in November 1989, the filing said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING A Wink and a Nod Triumphs: A Wink and a Nod, ridden by Jean-Luc Samyn, set the pace and then drew away through the stretch for an easy five-length victory in the $25,000 feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. D'Or Etoile was runner-up in the field of six, 3 1/2 lengths ahead of the favorite, Gottagetitdone. A Wink and a Nod went a mile and a sixteenth on the good track in 1:45 4/5 to score her second victory in seven starts this year. She earned $15,000 for John L. Flynn and returned $6.60, $3.60 and $2.10 for $2 across the board. (AP) SKIING Bittner Wins Slalom: Armin Bittner of West Germany won a men's World Cup slalom yesterday after Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland had a poor second run in St. Anton, Austria. The slalom counts toward a combined, which will be decided by the downhill today. Bittner, third after the first run, had heat times of 49.02 and 54.84 seconds for a winning time of 1 minute 43.87 seconds. Bernhard Gstrein of Austria retained his second place from the first heat. His heat times of 48:93 and 55.22 gave him 1:44.15 over all. Zurbriggen, the winner of the first heat in 48.24 seconds, made a crucial mistake in the upper part in the second run and lost valuable time. He finished in a relatively slow 56.50 for an aggregate time of 1:44.74 and third place. Fourth was Ole Furuseth of Norway in 1:44.85, ahead of Felix McGrath of the Shelburne, Vt., whose overall time was 1:44.93.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women St. Joseph's 95, Northwestern 78: Dale Hodges scored a career-high 34 points and tied a school record with 21 rebounds to lead 20th-ranked St. Joseph's to victory over Northwestern last night in Philadelphia. Hodges shot 14 of 25 from the field and 6 of 7 from the foul line. She tied the school rebound record with Trish Brown, who had 21 against Rutgers in 1983. Jeanine Wasielewski scored 19 points 18 for Northwestern (4-4).(AP) N.C. State 80, Stanford 72: Andrea Stinson scored 34 points to lead North Carolina State (5-2) to the upset of sixth-ranked Stanford (6-2) at Raleigh last night. The score was tied at 72-all with 3:20 left, and Stanford was held scoreless the rest of the way. Rhonda Mapp hit a layup and the Wolfpack hit six of nine free throws down the stretch. (AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Fairchild Creates New Publishing Unit
description: Fairchild Publications has set up a new publishing unit, called the Fairchild Fashion Group, that will include 10 of its newspapers and magazines covering the domestic and international fashion industries. They are Children's Business, Daily News Record, DNR International, Footwear News, FN Europe, M magazine, Retail Technology and Operations, Sportstyle, W magazine and Women's Wear Daily.

title: In Bethlehem, Hope for Peace
description: This holiday season, in a silent witness to the need for peace, the bells in Bethlehem will not ring. No peace in Bethlehem - but, for the first time in many years, there is hope.

title: Washington Talk: Liberalism; A Liberal's Liberal Tells Just What Went Wrong
description: This is the season every four years in which liberals address the question of why they are losing ground. It is also the season when someone in their ranks risks being branded a heretic by stepping forward with some sharply self-critical words.

title: Miami Suspends Star
description: The University of Miami coach, Jimmy Johnson, announced yesterday the suspension of the starting wide receiver Andre Brown through the Hurricanes' Orange Bowl game against Nebraska on Jan. 2. Brown, a senior, had 47 catches for 746 yards and a team-high eight touchdown receptions.(AP)

title: Harold's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $119,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: University Science Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Special Price For Bosses' Stock
description: AT Integrated Resources Inc., a once highflying financial services company whose profits are down and whose founders are bailing out, the concept of ''greenmail'' has been expanded to what might be called ''bossmail.''

title: Gas Explosion Is Suspected In Indiana Fire That Killed 5
description: Neighbors said they heard an explosion shortly before a fire that killed a woman and four children in their home early this morning.

title: Customers Fault Bell Breakup
description: For the residential customer who does not make a lot of long-distance calls, the breakup of the Bell System has come to mean two things - confusion and higher rates.

title: Defense Becomes a Pressing Problem in N.B.A.
description: When is a trap an illegal defense?

title: Typefaces That Inspired Owners of a Small Press
description: THE Purgatory Pie Press, run by Esther and Dikko Smith, got its name when Mr. Smith spilled an entire case of 8-point Century Old Style type.

title: Loyalist Is Appointed New Argentine Army Chief
description: Still seeking to quiet military unrest, President Raul Alfonsin named a new Argentine Army Chief of Staff today, but he did not bend to the demands of rebellious officers by naming someone acceptable to them.

title: Reagan Confers With Allies on Libya Plant
description: President Reagan said tonight that the United States and its allies were discussing a Libyan chemical-weapons plant, and refused to rule out use of military force to destroy it.

title: Vernitron Rebuffed By Kollmorgen
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation, a maker of electromechanical components, said that it had rejected a takeover offer of $20 a share in cash, or about $206 million, from the Vernitron Corporation. The Kollmorgen board instituted a defensive purchase-rights plan on its preferred stock and said it had rejected the offer because it believed that the company's prospects were excellent.

title: Calendar: Varieties of Holiday Cheer
description: Variations on an Old Theme, the Arsenal Gallery, third floor, Central Park, Fifth Avenue at 64th Street; 212-360-3423.

title: Poland's Communist Party Shuffles Its Leadership
description: Poland's Communist Party shuffled its leadership tonight, in what appeared to be a move to bring in younger officials more amenable to change.

title: Delinquencies On Homes Cut
description: The number of Americans behind in their mortgage payments fell in the July-September quarter to the lowest level in a year, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said on Tuesday. It said that 4.73 percent of the payments on the 10.8 million mortgages surveyed in the third quarter were at least 30 days late.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, the troubled small-appliance maker, said it was weighing a new takeover offer - made by merchant bankers led by Paul Levy, Angus Littlejohn and Peter Joseph - while continuing to negotiate with a previous bidder, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

title: Commercial Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split declared last month.

title: I.R.S. Previews '88 Tax Forms
description: The Internal Revenue Service today previewed the new tax forms that 101 million Americans should begin receiving in the mail next week.

title: EIL Instruments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $189,900 and $214,300 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Shoney's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes recapitalization-related interest expense of $22,034,000 and $23,745,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes pretax recapitalization expenses of $1,965,000 (

title: Emanuel Fritz, Forestry Expert, 102
description: Emanuel Fritz, a forestry and conservation expert who helped to create California's state forest program, died last Thursday. He was 102 years old.

title: Jarred by Tragedy, Syracuse Students Grieve
description: The Chancellor of Syracuse University joined faculty and students here tonight in mourning the loss of at least 36 students killed in the Pan American jetliner crash in Scotland. He called the crash ''the greatest tragedy in the history of Syracuse University.''

title: Deng and Gandhi Pledge Amity
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India agreed today that their nations should put their quarrels behind them, but they did not appear to make any progress in solving their border dispute.

title: Cuomo and Bradley Back Jackson Aide To Lead Democrats
description: Governor Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, both potential Democratic Presidential candidates, yesterday endorsed Ron Brown, a former top campaign aide in the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 candidacy, to be the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer Chosen For Actifed
description: Right at the start of the winter cough-and-sniffle season, the Burroughs Wellcome Company of Research Triangle Park, N.C., has chosen Backer Spielvogel Bates from among nine agencies to create advertising for the Actifed line of cold remedies.

title: Trading Halts On Cummins
description: The Cummins Engine Company, the nation's leading diesel-engine manufacturer, suspended trading in its stock nearly an hour before the close today amid heavy speculation of a possible buyout attempt.

title: A New DCThree Alights At Santa Monica Airport
description: A NEW restaurant, DCThree, owned by Bruce Marder, the ever-au courant owner of Rebecca's and the West Beach Cafe in Venice, Calif., has alighted at the new Supermarine complex at the Santa Monica airport.

title: Selloff Continues as Dow Falls 1.43 Points
description: LEAD: A mild stock market selloff that began late on Tuesday continued yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.43 points to close at 2,164.64.

title: Robert Bernstein, 69; Founded Music Series
description: Robert Bernstein, the founder of the Island Concert Hall recital series on Long Island, died of heart failure Monday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 69 years old and lived in Upper Brookville, L.I..

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LEAD: REDUCING the amount of noise in a house, whether generated from within or from outside, can be challenging. Moderate success can often be achieved rather easily and without great expense. But complete soundproofing is difficult and usually requires costly remodeling.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: IN the evening I go home along an avenue that is in turn sordid, then desolate and, as the bus nears the end of its run, almost cozy in its small houses and small cars and sweet, if undistinguished, antiques shops. By that time the sky is usually dark and the street lamps are on and better even than staring at the other passengers, which I do a lot, is staring out the bus window into other windows.

title: Venezuela Seeks Loan
description: Venezuela's President-elect, Carlos Andres Perez, is seeking a $3 billion bridge loan, mainly from the United States, France and Spain, to bolster the country's sagging foreign reserves, the newspaper El Nacional said today. It said Mr. Perez suggested that the United States provide $1.5 billion, half the bridge financing needed, in a meeting in Washington last week with President-elect Bush.

title: The Perestroika in Our Public Schools Is Already Taking Place; Crucial Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Cavaliers End 11-Year Losing Streak
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers ended a 24-game Boston Garden losing streak tonight as they beat the Celtics, 115-114.

title: Who Really Ran the Oliver North Operation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pre-emptive Bids: A Growing Trend
description: THERE was a time when corporate raiders tried to buy companies on the cheap. And many would-be acquirers still try to pick up bargains with paltry initial bids. But the recently announced acquisition of the Pillsbury Company by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C of Britain confirms another approach to successful takeovers: offering an extraordinarily high initial price.

title: TO PAY $650 MILLION
description: In the largest settlement ever of Federal securities law violations, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street powerhouse, agreed in principle yesterday to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay $650 million.

title: That Every Dog May Have His Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson Journal; New Head of Police Allays Her Doubters
description: Not long ago the agents in one of Mississippi's law-enforcement agencies decided to get the chief a present - a camouflage-colored flak jacket with state-of-the-art accessories: an emergency teddy bear, pacifier, rattle and disposable diaper.

title: INSIDE
description: Labor Backs Israeli Pact After a stormy meeting, the Labor Party gave final approval to the new Israeli coalition government led by the Likud party. Page A14. Panamanian in U.S. Panama's ousted President arrived in Washington as the United States sought ways to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Page A3. Action on 2 Nuclear Plants The Nuclear Regulatory Commission took steps to allow the operation of the Seabrook and Pilgrim power plants in New England. Page A18.

title: 3 Centers Established to Help U.S. Business
description: The Federal Government on Tuesday named institutions in South Carolina, New York and Ohio to serve as the first three regional centers to help funnel scientific advancements to American businesses so they can better compete against Japanese and other trade rivals.

title: Review/Film; A Triangle, And a Dog Is One Leg
description: ''We Think the World of You'' is almost certainly the only film ever made about two men who fall in love with the same dog, a German shepherd named Evie. Evie is, needless to say, the beneficiary of emotions that her human admirers have difficulty expressing in other ways. Originally the prized pet of Johnny, a working-class fellow whose housebreaking has landed him in prison, Evie is sent to live with Johnny's mother, Millie, and stepfather, Tom, while her master is away. For Frank, the older and better-bred man who is desperately fixated on Johnny, this is simply too much to bear.

title: Spectre's Cookies, an Acquirable Taste
description: JAY SPECTRE, the bespectacled decorator and licenser extraordinaire, is fond of telling lecture audiences, ''Taste is acquired.'' A taste of Spectre can be acquired at Bloomingdale's and other places where Spectre cookies and coffees are on sale.

title: FICO Set to Price $700 Million Issue
description: The Financing Corporation, also known as FICO, a mixed-ownership Government corporation chartered by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, plans to price today through competitive bidding a $700 million competitive issue of 9.60 bonds with a maturity date of Dec. 27, 2018.

title: Personal Health
description: Millions of buyers of ultrasonic humidifiers who thought they had finally found a safe and effective way to add moisture to the home in the winter heating season have something new to worry about.

title: Giants Will Stay Put
description: Bob Lurie, the San Francisco Giants' owner, said yesterday he has shelved plans to seek a new home for the ball club outside the Bay area.

title: Vallen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Europe Fines 23 Concerns
description: The European Community's executive commission said today that it was fining 23 leading petrochemical companies a total of $70 million for taking part in two price-fixing and market-sharing cartels.

title: Esterline Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: c-Net loss and includes a pretax provision of $20,484,000 for business restructuring for both the quarter and year.

title: AEL Industries Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 25
description: b-Net income

title: Sighs of Relief From Some Clients, but Others Wait and See
description: Though it has agreed to pay a stiff price for its settlement of securities law violations, Drexel Burnham Lambert made some of its clients happy yesterday and left others with a tough decision about continuing the relationship.

title: Review/Theater; Jacobi as a Sympathetic Richard II in London
description: Derek Jacobi isn't the showiest of British classical stage actors, nor the best-looking, nor the one with the widest range. But he just may be the most popular, and the reasons for that popularity, both in England and in the United States, are spectacularly in evidence at the Phoenix Theater on Charing Cross Road, where Mr. Jacobi is starring in an engagement of Shakespeare's ''Richard II.''

title: Case Closed
