description: The University of Oklahoma said yesterday it would not appeal the N.C.A.A.'s decision to place the Sooner football program on three years' probation.

title: Pentagon Official Accuses 8 Concerns on Secret Data
description: The director of a Defense Department investigative agency said today that eight of the nation's leading arms makers face possible criminal prosecution for illegal possession of secret Government documents.

title: American Building Mainteance Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Devils Rally With 2 Late Goals to Tie Jets, 5-5
description: Jim Korn's goal with 13 seconds left in regulation capped a wild third period as the New Jersey Devils tied the Winnipeg Jets 5-5 tonight.

title: Review/Film; A Boy's Errant Mother
description: ''Burning Secret'' is a small, minutely observed emotional drama about the rude coming-of-age of a sheltered 12-year-old boy.

title: S & A Restaurant
description: The S & A Restaurant Corporation, the Pillsbury Company unit that operates the Steak and Ale and Bennigan's restaurant chains, is likely to be sold quickly by its prospective new owners, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. A spokesman for Grand Met's New Jersey-based United States operations said the company had already received several expressions of interest in the 379-restaurant company. Food industry analysts called the Dallas-based restaurant company ripe for a turnaround and estimated its worth to be greater than $300 million.

title: Jetborne International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Deficit Rose In November
description: The Federal Government ran up a $29 billion budget deficit in November, 7.4 percent higher than the shortfall a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: Numerex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Windsor Fund Manager Opens the Door Again
description: ''It seemed like the decent time to open the door a little bit more,'' said John B. Neff of the Vanguard Group, who announced yesterday that the Windsor Fund, the mutual fund that he has managed successfully, will be reopened to new accounts.

title: Theodore Zimmerman, Blood Researcher, 51
description: Dr. Theodore S. Zimmerman, director of the division of experimental hemostasis at the Research Institute of Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif., died of lung cancer Monday at Green Hospital of Scripps Clinic. He was 51 and lived in La Jolla.

title: Firecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Corrections
description: A list of organizations for volunteers accompanying the Personal Health column Dec. 1 gave an outdated telephone number for Vista (Volunteers in Service to America).

title: Pakistan No Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Settlement Master' Joining Lilco Talks
description: The Federal judge in the racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company raised the stakes yesterday in the settlement discussions by ''offering the assistance'' of a lawyer who had fashioned an accord in the complex Agent Orange case.

title: Giving Scrooge a Good Name
description: SHOP owners beware: this group could be hazardous to your sales. Calling itself Scrooge - the Society to Curtail Ridiculous, Outrageous and Ostentatious Gift Exchanges - it advocates sensible spending at Christmas.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: BEING rejected is an integral part of growing up. No child escapes the occasional brisk slap of exclusion from a group. For those children whose longstanding reputations proclaim that they do not fit in, the painful sting of rejection comes often. It can permeate their views of themselves and lead to problems during adolescence and adulthood.

title: Toledo Drops Charges Against 13
description: A judge today dismissed charges against 13 civil rights leaders arrested in a protest of the city's housing program. The ruling came after prosecutors reduced the charges and all 13 pleaded no contest.

title: American Greetings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said certain 1987 income statement amounts have been reclassified to conform with the 1988 presentation. The company recorded a $20.9 million pre-tax charge for restructuring costs ($11.9 million after taxes or 37 cents a share) during the third quarter of 1988 to reduce operating costs and to enhance future earnings prospects. The charge reflects the cost of relocating the Carlton Cards U.S. subsidiary from Dallas to Cleveland, consolidation of some Canadian operations, and the divestiture of several unprofitable greeting card businesses in Continental Europe. Excluding this restructuring charge, net income for the three months and 9 months ended November 30, 1988 would have been $24.0 million, or 74 cents a share and $41.9 million, or $1.30 a share, respectively.

title: Power Failure Slows Amtrak, N.J. Transit
description: Dozens of Amtrak and N.J. Transit commuter trains leaving Penn Station for New Jersey were delayed last night by a power failure at Amtrak's rail yard in Sunnyside, Queens, Amtrak officials said.

title: Welcome, Mr. Arens
description: A new face now appears on the world scene, and for Israel, not a moment too soon.

title: The Tick, Tick of Third World Debt
description: President-elect Bush says it's time to take ''a whole new look'' at the third world's $1.3 trillion debt. Indeed, and past time. Flexibility from the incoming administration is welcome. President Reagan's hands-off policy has hurt debtor nations and America's vital interests as well.

title: Engineered Support Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $500,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income The company said its results were negatively impacted by government initiated delays on selected projects and higher than anticipated costs on other programs.

title: Electronics, Missiles & Comunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $63,387 for the quarter and $269,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Army Technician and a Civilian Are Held as Spies for Soviet Bloc
description: An Army intelligence specialist and a Turkish-born civilian living in Florida were arrested today, breaking what American officials said was a major espionage operation that funneled information about the West's eavesdropping capacity to the Soviet Union and East Germany for six years.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hot Issue
description: A bipartisan array of Senators have sent the new administration a signal that the environment will be a significant issue in foreign policy.

title: Ross Cosmetics Distribution Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Secrecy, Safety and Jessica Cortez
description: Could New York City have prevented the death of Jessica Cortez, an apparent child-abuse victim? William Grinker, the Commissioner of Human Resources, says he wants to explain all, but the law requires confidentiality. Yet accountability is as important to the main goal, protecting children.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Patriotic Patents
description: One of the most singular exhibits in the capital is Patriotic Patents, in the rotunda of the National Archives. It is a manifestation of the extraordinary lengths to which inventors went to play to Americans' patriotic instincts in the 19th century.

title: Chicago Churches Make Pact Chicago Cardinal Has Pact With Lutherans
description: Leaders of Chicago's Roman Catholic and Lutheran churches joined Tuesday in a covenant aimed at building cooperation between two denominations divided by nearly 500 years of discord.

title: Curt Richter, Credited With Idea Of Biological Clock, Is Dead at 94
description: Curt Paul Richter, a retired professor of psychobiology at the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions who was a pioneer in the discovery and study of biorhythms, died yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 94 years old.

title: HEALTH: Nutrition; Help Wanted: Successful Dieters
description: Essentially all the information that has been gathered on obesity and how to treat it comes from studies of people who seek out medical researchers, often after years of fruitless attempts to control their weight. But researchers question whether these people are truly representative of the obese and ask whether there is a group of people who never volunteer for studies and are able to diet successfully.

title: Florafax International reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $312,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Edwards, A G & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter includes reserves for customer receivables of about 20 cents a share.

title: Lucille Ogle, 84, Dies; Creator of Book Series
description: Lucille Ogle, a creator of the Little Golden Books, a popular children's book series, died of heart failure Saturday in Lourdes Nursing Home in Pontiac, Mich. She was 84 years old.

title: Settlement Caps Days of Tension and Fear at Firm
description: The days leading up to the record $650 million agreement by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to settle pending charges of securities law violations were frustrating and bitter for the firm's leaders, who had undergone the uncertainty of two years of Government scrutiny.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Seeks Japan's Help on Nabisco
description: Searching for financing for the largest takeover in history, Henry Kravis sought help from Tokyo's banking establishment today, amid signs that big leveraged buyouts, like the one he engineered to take over RJR Nabisco, make Japan's Finance Ministry nervous.

title: Specialists See Oil Prices Moving Higher Next Month
description: A combination of smaller global inventories and tighter supplies will lead to higher oil prices in January, industry specialists said today.

title: Biggest Pension Fund Eases Regulations
description: The nation's largest pension fund, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, agreed today to allow policyholders to transfer their money to other investment vehicles.

title: Personal Income Declined By Slight 0.2% Last Month
description: Personal income in the United States declined a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.18 trillion, the Commerce Department said today. The decline followed a jump of 1.7 percent in October, the biggest in a year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Rise of the Humble Indian Dhurrie
description: DHURRIES and other rugs are piled high in a sprawling basement under a modern high-rise business center here. The rugs are the heart of a luminous collection that began with the sale of a single wool dhurrie to an American buyer nearly 20 years ago and turned into a multimillion-dollar business with showrooms here and in New York, London, Paris, Hong Kong and Sydney, Australia.

title: French Plan $163 Million Ulster Plant
description: A French automotive supplier announced today that it would make the largest investment ever by a foreign company in Northern Ireland, bringing the promise of a much needed lift to the area's depressed economy.

title: Koch Favors Measure to Protect Illegal Aliens
description: Seeking to protect what he called ''a very vulnerable population,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would support a bill amending the city's Human Rights Law to prohibit discrimination based on ''alienage or citizenship status.''

title: Second Fiddle Calls His Own Tune
description: Three months ago, Don Strock was a retired athlete approaching his 38th birthday, getting a tan, playing golf and glad-handing people at a country club outside of Miami.

title: Reds Sign 2
description: The Cincinnati Reds have signed two free agents, Joel Youngblood and Manny Trillo, giving each a one-year, $320,000 contract. Youngblood, 37 years old, an outfielder and pinch-hitter, hit .252 in 83 games with San Francisco last season. Trillo, also 37, an infielder, batted .250 in 76 games with the Cubs.

title: Catalina Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Television; A Cinemax Special on the Doors
description: When it comes to pop icons of the past half century, Jim Morrison surely ranks with Marilyn Monroe and James Dean. Morrison and Ray Manzarek, a keyboard player, formed the music group called the Doors back in 1965, when they were both students at the U.C.L.A. Graduate School of Film. A year later, they were joined by John Densmore, a drummer, and Robby Krieger, a guitarist. In 1967, they became stars with the debut album that contained the hit single ''Light My Fire.'' The next few years produced more hits and a number of notorious stage incidents, including one that involved charges of indecent exposure. Morrison died in Paris in 1971. He was 27 years old.

title: Head of Contractors' Group Arrested in Theft From Fund
description: The chief executive of a New York City building contractors' group was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing $600,000 from a fund set up to promote a special type of construction and jobs for union carpenters.

title: Rating Bush: So Far, Not Bad
description: During the Presidential campaign, Mike Dukakis insisted that ''competence'' rather than ''ideology'' should be the main issue, and that's precisely the word being applied here to George Bush's transition appointments.

title: The Limits of Law
description: It is a story that will not leave my mind: the case of Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, the 41-year-old plastic surgeon who has been in the District of Columbia Jail for nearly 16 months for contempt of court. Others, too, have reacted with astonishment and pain to the story.

title: Neediest Gain As Employers Forgo Parties
description: Concerned by the increasing evidence of poverty and despair in New York City, many employers and employees are forgoing greeting cards, holiday gifts and office parties this year and contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Editors' Note
description: A television review on Tuesday, about ''Mysteries of the Mind,'' on Channel 5, discussed mental illness and the progress of drug therapy in treating it. The review noted that the program belittled resistance to taking drugs for severe emotional problems. It added: ''The effect of such plugs for drugs is to draw the viewer's attention to the show's commercials. They are all for products of the Bristol-Myers Company, a major drug manufacturer.''

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 6.4% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered rose 6.4 percent on the Big Board in the four-week period that ended Dec. 15.

title: 36 Students at Syracuse Among the Passengers
description: Among those reported aboard Pan Am Flight 103 when it crashed yesterday were 38 students from Syracuse University and executives from several corporations.

title: 3Com Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes $3.2 million, or 11 cents a share, and $3.4 million, or 12 cents a share, of non-recurring expenses related to the company's merger with Bridge Communications Inc. in Sept. 1987.

title: Reco International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of marketable securities of $370,000 and $420,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: Judge Picks Jan. 31 To Start North Trial In Iran-Contra Case
description: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell today set Jan. 31 as the date for Oliver L. North to go on trial on conspiracy and theft charges in the Iran-contra case.

title: Kings Road Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rangers Fall Flat Against Sabres
description: Two nights after they had played one of their most inspiring games of the season in a victory over Washington, the Rangers' quality of play fell in a 5-2 loss to the Buffalo Sabres last night at the Garden.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF TRIES TO PLACATE UNIONS
description: A week after a general strike paralyzed Spain, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said today that his Government had failed to detect the depth of opposition to his economic policies, and he offered to negotiate with the unions.

title: Revenge Motive Seen in 2 Killings
description: Police detectives believe the killings of two women in front of six children in Queens last Sunday were retaliatory acts because the husband of one victim had cooperated with the police in a murder case, investigators said yesterday.

title: 2 Sundials Mark Time In Queens
description: BUILDINGS in the 1980's have been topped with oddities ranging from Chippendale curlicues to satellite dishes. But the most poetic top - certainly, the most retro - may be the new one in Jamaica, Queens: two vertical sundials atop the Social Security Administration's new Northeast service center.

title: Under Indictment: Not Just the Defendants, but a Way of Doing Business
description: On May 22, 1985, a 96-word, poorly typewritten letter from Caracas, Venezuela, arrived at Merrill Lynch & Company's headquarters in New York, charging that some brokers were trading with inside information. That anonymous message may have done more to alter the financial system than any legislation or stock market crash.

title: Review/Dance; Ailey Troupe in Its Last Novelty of the Season
description: Alvin Ailey's latest good-will effort toward developing young choreographers is ''From the Mountains of Taubalu,'' a solo by Rovan Deon that had its premiere with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Tuesday night.

title: JETLINER CARRYING 258 TO U.S. CRASHES IN SCOTTISH TOWN
description: A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

title: Europe Acts on Software
description: To encourage high-technology development, the European Community today proposed a communitywide copyright to protect computer programs. Legal protection for software varies widely among the community's 12 member states, the Executive Commission, the community's executive body, said in a statement. The proposal will need the approval of the community's ministers.

title: Morris Gives Nets Chance to Win in Overtime
description: For the second time this month, the Nets called on Chris Morris for a crucial long-distance shot. Once again, Morris answered. Morris made a 25-foot 3-point shot with 10 seconds left in regulation to tie tonight's game against the Dallas Mavericks. Then in overtime, Buck Williams made a driving scoop shot in the lane with 30 seconds left, giving New Jersey a 3-point lead on the way to a dramatic 122-120 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Paris Transport Strike Ends; Disruption Lasted 6 Weeks
description: Strikes that had paralyzed the Parisian train network for six weeks ended today when maintenance workers returned to work, the capital's transport authority said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Drexel Settlement

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Fruehauf Approves Recapitalization Plan
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, which has spent the last two years reducing its billion-dollar debt from a leveraged buyout, announced today that its board had approved a recapitalization to reduce debt and increase the company's cash flow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the National Collegiate Athletic Association's enforcement policies misidentified a university whose basketball program is expected to be placed on probation. It is West Texas State University, not North Texas State.

title: Chaparral Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,895,000 from an accounting change.

title: Daimler Stake Set In Messerschmitt
description: The board of the West German industrial giant Daimler-Benz A.G. decided to proceed with the purchase of a share in the aerospace concern Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. The deal, whereby Daimler will buy a stake in Messerschmitt from West German state holdings, promises to revamp the German aerospace industry and make it more efficient, Daimler-Benz's chairman, Alfred Herrhausen, said. Messerschmitt has a 37.9 percent share in the European Airbus consortium.

title: US Health Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,000,000 from an accounting change.

title: Electro Scientific Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Return With a 366-Day Record in Space
description: Two Soviet astronauts who set a record for endurance in space returned to Earth today, a year after they blasted off and three hours later than scheduled.

title: Jetliner Carrying 258 to U.S. Crashes in Scottish Town
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

title: William B. Volet, Government Official, 85
description: William B. Volet, a former government official and Democratic Party leader, died Tuesday when he was struck by a bus as he crossed 57th Street at Madison Avenue in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Critics' Notebooks  Charles Dickens: Eminently Adaptable but Quite Inimitable; Scrooge's Permutations Are Part of Popular Lore
description: On one recent night, television viewers could have seen Albert Finney in the 1970 movie musical ''Scrooge'' singing ''I hate people!'' interrupted by a fried-chicken commercial featuring Mr. Scrooge (chicken so cheap, even a miser likes it), followed by an ad for the new film ''Scrooged,'' with Bill Murray declaring in a most matter-of-fact tone, ''Bah, humbug.''

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the front page in some copies yesterday with an article about Israeli politics described some developments incorrectly. Although the Likud party gave final approval to a coalition accord early yesterday, the Labor Party had not done so as The Times went to press; it did so later yesterday. The later developments are reported today on page A14.

title: The Perestroika in Our Public Schools Is Already Taking Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Negro, Black and African-American
description: There's healthy archeology in the Rev. Jesse Jackson's belief that blacks now want to be called African-Americans. The term has ''cultural integrity,'' Mr. Jackson said after a meeting with other prominent African-Americans in Chicago on Monday. ''Every ethnic group in this country has a reference to some land base, some historical cultural base. African-Americans have hit that level of cultural maturity.''

title: Labor Party Gives Final Backing to Israeli Coalition Led by Likud
description: The Labor Party gave final approval today to a new coalition government led by the Likud party.

title: Ship Torn Up to Find Cocaine
description: Customs Service agents using blowtorches spent 30 hours ripping apart the belly of a Panamanian freighter before finding 4,792 pounds of cocaine in a secret compartment on Tuesday.

title: Test May Show Genetic Tie to Alcoholism
description: A chance discovery by cancer researchers at the University of Wisconsin has led to the development of a blood test that they said might detect a possible genetic predisposition to alcoholism.

title: Moog Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $197,000 loss on the sale of discontinued operations and a $2,740,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income and includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $3.1 million for the quarter; the year includes a $710,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $3,330,000 gain from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: 3 IN CLAN GUILTY IN OFFICER'S DEATH
description: Three members of a polygamist clan were convicted today on charges ranging from manslaughter to negligent homicide in the death of a law officer in a gunfight at the clan's compound.

title: Transmedia Network reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Head Coaches Never Know Of Cheating
description: Barry Switzer says he had no knowledge of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations in his football program at the University of Oklahoma, and there is no reason, certainly, to dispute the head coach. After all, aren't we as citizens led to believe that a football coach's primary job is to mold the character of his helmeted lads, and mold them in his upright image?

title: Southwest Bancorp
description: Southwest Bancorp said it had rejected acquisition offers from the Security Pacific Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company because each was inadequate. Southwest said it had received Security Pacific bid on Wednesday. The Wells Fargo offer was received on Dec. 8. Frank J. Mercardante, Southwest's president, declined to discuss either offer. The company said the proposals were rejected after being reviewed by Southwest's financial adviser, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Review/Art; Of the 50's, When Fortunes Shone
description: Perhaps no decade in the history of American art continues to generate quite so much debate as the 1950's, when the United States, and in particular New York City, supplanted Europe as the primary focus of international attention. The success of Abstract Expressionists like Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko and Franz Kline represented a kind of cultural coming of age in America at precisely the moment when the country's military and economic fortunes seemed brightest.

title: Miserable Wages, Miserable Leaders
description: The tidal wave of venom that threatens to sweep away the proposal to raise the salaries of Federal officials is flabbergasting. Who would have thought that so many Americans who love incumbent Congressmen so dearly as to award them something resembling life tenure simultaneously hate them so much that they would require them, along with Federal executives and judges, to serve at inadequate and steadily decreasing real compensation? Yet people are responding to the populists of the left and right who have exploded with fury at the Quadrennial Commission's proposal.

title: Agenbite of Inwit
description: Recently a baby boomer from fat city who'd made megabucks in junk bonds got a job in television. He assembled a panel of mediagenic talking heads, whose psychobabble left the couch potatoes cold. The baby boomer suffered forevermore from agenbite of inwit.

title: Texas Utilities Inc reports earnings for Year to Nov 30

THE LAW;
What Do Law Schools Teach? Almost Anything
description: LEAD: On page 28 of this year's Yale Law School catalogue is a sign of changing times in American legal education.

title: Man Accused of Smuggling Computers to the Soviet Bloc
description: A Dutch national who allegedly tried to ship a $1.1 million computer to a Soviet-bloc country has been arrested, breaking up a high-technology smuggling network spanning six American cities and eight foreign countries, the United States Customs Service said today.

title: Prosecutors of Corruption on Wall St. Have Yet to Face a Challenge in Court
description: From the time of the guilty plea of Dennis B. Levine to the settlement agreement announced Wednesday with Drexel Burham Lambert Inc., Government prosecutors have racked up an impressive string of victories in what amounted to a virtual war on Wall Street corruption.

title: The Crash of Flight 103; PAN AM WAS TOLD OF TERROR THREAT
description: Acting on an unsubstantiated threat received by its embassy in Finland, the United States Government notified airlines, airports and embassies in Europe two weeks ago of a possible bomb attack against a Pan Am flight from Frankfurt, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Fastcomm Communication reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Grist Mill Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Film; Going Nowhere, Slowly
description: Anne Tyler's fiction is as revealing of the tiny intimacies that bind people together as of the larger gaps that keep them apart. A key revelation of character, in one of Miss Tyler's novels, is more apt to occur while someone is driving a car or putting away groceries than during a more conventionally dramatic situation. Her writing is beautifully attuned to the minutiae of daily routines, to the seemingly trivial habits that both define and circumscribe her characters' lives. But in the film version of ''The Accidental Tourist,'' which opens today at Cinema 2, it's the broad strokes that stand out.

title: Review/Music; 15th Year of Avant-Garde
description: In December 1973, the composer and film maker Phill Niblock offered a series of concerts at his loft at 224 Centre Street. The Niblock loft concerts have continued as a branch of the Experimental Intermedia Foundation and have become a small but telling part of New York's musical avant-garde.

title: Review/Film; Their Lives Gone Straight to a Very Warm Place
description: You might find ''Hellbound: Hellraiser II'' provocative if, and only if, you badly want to know what people look like after they have been stripped of their skins by evil powers. As it turns out, they look very much like walking, talking candied apples, with a shiny red coating that covers their entire bodies. That effect looks even sillier than it sounds, though it's meant to carry a slight sadomasochistic erotic thrill.

title: Not Every Car Maker Opposes a Gas Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Myerson Wins Jury Acquittal On All Counts
description: Bess Myerson and her two co-defendants were acquitted of all the charges against them last night, ending their dramatic trial with a triumph for the defense.

title: Undefeated Seton Hall Tops Princeton, 64-46
description: Ramon Ramos scored 6 of his 9 points in a 13-3 run that spanned the first and second halves tonight as undefeated Seton Hall rolled to its 10th straight victory, defeating Princeton by 64-46.

title: Canal Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $858,000 from an accounting change. Prior year share net reduced by preferred dividend requirementes. The company said 1987 revenue figures have been restated. The company also said the latest quarter reflects $1,812,000 income from company's investment program as compared with a $6,443,000 loss in the year-ago quarter due to the Oct. 19 stock market crash.

title: West Texas Basketball on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed West Texas State's basketball program on three years' probation and barred the team from 1988-89 post-season play.

title: Gerges Attacks Refusal On Welfare Addresses
description: A Brooklyn City Councilman yesterday attacked the city's refusal to release the new addresses of about 140 children who were moved out of a midtown welfare hotel even to the doctor who treated them in the hotel.

title: Advanced TV's May Result From New Memory Chips
description: The research agreement announced today by Texas Instruments Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. is an attempt to regain ground lost after two other major chip companies, Motorola Inc. and Toshiba, forged a similar alliance two years ago, analysts said today.

title: Drexel's Plea Bargain Will Limit Exposure to Suits, Employees Say
description: The six felony counts that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. will admit involve circumstances in which the firm cheated a client, manipulated the marketplace and tricked a corporation into being taken over.

title: Transactions
description: Auto Racing TYRRELL RACING ORGANIZATION - Signed Michele Alboreto, driver. Baseball OAKLAND (AL) - Assigned Doug Jennings, outfielder, outright to Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. TORONTO (AL) - Sold the contract of Cecil Fielder, designated hitter-first baseman, to the Hanshin Tigers of the Japanese Central League for an undisclosed amount of cash. Football CLEVELAND (AFC) - Signed Edmund Nelson, defensive end. Placed Marlon Jones, defensive end, on injured reserve. DETROIT (NFC) - Appointed Wayne Fontes head coach and signed him to a three-year contract. Hockey NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended John Kordic, Toronto Maple Leafs forward, for 10 games for high-sticking Keith Acton of Edmonton in a game on Dec. 14. RANGERS (NHL) - Recalled Kevin Miller, right wing, from Denver of the International Hockey League. VANCOUVER (NHL) - Suspended Dave Saunders, left wing. Colleges NATIONAL COLLEGIATE ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION - Placed West Texas State's basketball program on probation for three years. BIG EAST CONFERENCE - Appointed Jack Lehane assistant supervisor of men's basketball officials. EAST-WEST SHRINE GAME - Appointed Bruce Snyder, California football coach, as West team assistant coach. GEORGIA TECH - Signed Jim Morris, baseball coach, to a three-year contract. JACKSONVILLE - Announced the resignation of Pat Schwab, men's golf coach. LIMESTONE - Appointed David Trudeau sports information director. MARIST - Signed Dave Magarity, men's basketball coach, to a multiyear contract extension.

title: Review/Music; Songs by Bart Howard, in His Own Words
description: After 40 years in the background, Bart Howard stepped into the spotlight as a headliner on Monday evening at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street.

title: Dow Closes Down 4.28, To 2,160.36
description: LEAD: The stock market drifted lower yesterday for the third consecutive session, and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 4.28 points to close at 2,160.36.

title: Accidental Clash in South Africa Sparks Debate on Army Role
description: An accidental shootout between South African soldiers and policemen in Soweto last week has prompted a new controversy over the routine assignment of army units to patrol black communities under South Africa's emergency regulations.

title: Divers Try to Rescue Dolphin
description: Divers and scientists failed again today to rescue a bottlenose dolphin that became stranded in the chilly waters here after neglecting to migrate south for the winter.

title: New Faces for 4 Cabinet Posts and the Top Environmental Job; William Kane Reilly, Environmental Protection Agency Administrator
description: With the selection of William K. Reilly to be Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, President-elect Bush has found a man likely to seek consensus and use negotiation to achieve tough environmental goals.

title: Clean Harbors reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Summagraphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are always going to be people - they make it their own choice for staying out there. There are shelters in virtually every city and shelters here and those people still prefer out there on the grates or the lawn to going into one of those shelters.'' - President Reagan. [ A26:1. ]

title: KEY RATES
Cybermedic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $93,795 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Review/Film; Eden for 3, In 'Genesis'
description: Rest easy. Despite the title, ''Genesis'' is not a biblical extravaganza. The Indian director Mrinal Sen's 1986 movie, now at the Public Theater, is a simply conceived, artfully rendered parable of love and jealousy, freedom and slavery. The tale is rudimentary, its themes a touch obvious, yet the telling, done with grave humanity, carries meanings of its own.

title: The Crash of Flight 103; JETLINER IN CRASH BLEW APART IN AIR, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: British and American authorities said today that the Pan Am jumbo jet that crashed in Scotland had exploded 31,000 feet in the air, scattering debris in a wide arc up to 80 miles from the area of the main impact.

title: Datametrics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,000 and $576,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $282,500 for the quarter and $632,000 for the year.

title: Yzerman Streak at 23
description: Steve Yzerman had two goals and two assists tonight, extending his scoring streak to 23 games, as the Detroit Red Wings rallied from a two-goal deficit to tie the St. Louis Blues, 4-4.

title: Remarks by Bush and 5 Designees at Capital News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of remarks by President-elect Bush, Representative Manuel Lujan Jr., Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Samuel K. Skinner, Ambassador Edwin Derwinski and William K. Reilly at a news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: OPENING STATEMENTS

title: Judge Hears Addict's Plea To Help Him
description: Two months ago, Alexis Vega, a 34-year-old self-described crack addict from the South Bronx, decided he wanted to get off drugs.

title: On Stage
description: Optimism Prevails

title: BUSH PICKS DOCTOR WHO WAS CHIDED ON ABORTION VIEWS
description: President-elect Bush, acting after days of fierce controversy over the abortion issue, today announced his selection of Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the president of the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta, to be Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: Clevetrust Realty Investors SBI reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Farm Exports To Spain Up
description: Spain is rapidly turning into one of the American farmer's richest overseas markets, the Agriculture Department said today. In the fiscal year that ended

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Four Staten Island Developers Build Midrise Condos
description: LEAD: Midrise condominiums are increasingly being built in the rapidly growing New Springville section of Staten Island.

title: For Many, The Agony Is to Persist
description: Bess Myerson's trial was not, in the end, a soap opera. But it was, despite the triumphant acquittal last night, a real-life drama that will leave lasting scars on the main figures who were drawn into it.

title: The Crash of Flight 103; At Syracuse, Remembrance And Prayers
description: It was a day of tears and prayers at Syracuse University today as the campus mourned its dead in the Pan Am jumbo-jet crash in Scotland.

title: Islander Goalies Are Outmatched by Flyers' Hextall in Loss
description: Al Arbour coached only half a team tonight, so it came as no surprise to him when his team scored just half as many goals as did the Flyers, who skated away with a 4-2 victory.

title: Long Way to the Stage For 'Song of Lawino'
description: It all started five years ago. Valeria Vasilevski, an experimentalist director searching for African writing to put onstage, was in a drugstore in Kenya and came across a dusty copy of ''Song of Lawino,'' written in 1966 by Okot p'Bitek, a Ugandan poet. It started, too, when Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, a modern dancer and choreographer, decided that the unpointed foot of her Afro-American heritage could be choreographed with the purpose of the classical pointed foot.

title: Takeovers Unfazed by Settlement
description: A day after Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s 11th-hour settlement of securities law violations, the effect on takeovers and restructurings in which the firm has been involved was not as striking as traders had expected.

title: Restaurants
description: For many people, the holiday season is a time to pull off the chaotic superhighway of everyday life and temporarily ramble along the reassuringly familiar backroads that lead home. It seemed appropriate, then, to revisit La Tulipe, a snug little Greenwich Village spot run by a husband-and-wife team, a place that seems frozen in time.

title: Alan Bond Says He Bought 'Irises'
description: The Australian billionaire Alan Bond said today that he was the mystery buyer of van Gogh's ''Irises'' in November 1987 for $53.9 million.

title: Churches Bask in Restored Brilliance of Windows
description: After decades of perilous neglect, several key works in New York City's most shimmering artistic legacy - the ecclesiastic stained glass of the 19th and early 20th centuries - are being restored to vibrancy.

title: Lions Keep Fontes As Head Coach
description: The spark Wayne Fontes put into the Detroit Lions in five weeks as interim coach apparently counted more than victories and losses. Fontes was given a three-year contract yesterday. Terms were undisclosed, but Fontes, an assistant coach for 13 seasons in the National Football League, is expected to earn about $250,000 a year.

title: Housing Crisis Called a Threat To the Economy
description: A panel named by Governor Cuomo in response to harsh criticism of his administration's housing record said today that the state faces a ''housing crisis'' that ''seriously threatens New York's long-term economic health.''

title: The Bull in 'Bull Durham'
description: LEAD: Is ''Bull Durham'' a movie, an advertisement, or both?

title: Cuomo Anti-Drug Unit to Focus on Education
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would create a council of top-level officials to oversee anti-drug programs in New York State.

title: Chicago Dock & Canal Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Collins Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $196,000 for the quarter and the year includes $1,768,000 for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $186,000 and $604,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $149,000 for the quarter and $489,000 for the year.

title: Employees at Drexel Begin Healing Process
description: Buttressed by the personal joys of the season, employees at Drexel Burnham Lambert began to put their professional lives back together again yesterday.

title: Three Companies Recall Toys Seen as Perilous to Children
description: Three distributors are voluntarily recalling several small toys because of the hazards they pose to young children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Calls Off Its Macmillan Deal
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York leveraged buyout firm, said yesterday that it was terminating its $400 million plan to buy three subsidiaries of Macmillan Inc. and one division of the Maxwell Communications Corporation.

title: Harding Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes $315,000 from an accounting change.

title: Duckett Eligible
description: Anthony Duckett, the Rutgers center who became ineligible to play basketball Tuesday because of an infraction of National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations, has had his eligibility restored. According to the director of athletics, Frederick E. Gruninger, the N.C.A.A. said ''all the necessary papers and procedures are in order.''

title: S.A.S. Orders 4 Big Boeing Planes
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System ordered four extended-range 767-300's from a unit of the Boeing Company in a deal worth about $300 million. S.A.S. has now ordered 13 of the twin-engine airplanes this year, worth about $1 billion. The airline holds options for 11 more jets, the Boeing Commercial Airplanes unit said. S.A.S. is to take delivery of its first 767-300 in March.

title: Review/Art; A Fashion Institute Exhibition Shows the History of Tartan
description: Kings, countries and fashion trends may come and go, but the tartan plaid, in one form or another, is here to stay. This is but one of the many lessons to be gleaned from ''Tartan,'' billed as a ''historical retrospective'' and currently on view at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Nurse Faces New Murder Charges
description: A Suffolk County grand jury today indicted a nurse, accused last year of murdering one patient and assaulting another with injections of deadly drugs, on three new counts of murder and two of assault.

title: POLISH CHIEF SEES WIDE CORRUPTION
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, has acknowledged that the Government's efforts to broaden the private sector have led to widespread corruption.

title: World Bank Loan to Nigeria
description: The World Bank said today that its board had approved a $500 million loan to help Nigeria reshape its economy and reduce its dependence on oil exports.

title: Hartford Insurers Feeling Strain of Layoffs
description: When John Blair was growing up near Hartford 25 years ago, a line of executives walked into his high school, preaching insurance as a way of life - a life of security and stability. ''You never heard about someone getting laid off back then,'' he said.

title: Orders for Durables Rose 0.1% in November
description: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods in November indicated continued strength in the economy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Television Ad For Cartoonist
description: It is rare that an underground cartoonist finds himself in demand for commercial work, but Matt Groening has made the leap.

title: Majerle Sidelined
description: Dan Majerle, the Phoenix Suns' rookie guard, has contracted mononucleosis and will be sidelined for the next two to four weeks. The 6-foot-6-inch Majerle, a first-round pick of the Suns last April and the No. 14 overall selection in the college draft, has played basketball almost without interruption since the fall of 1987 when his senior season at Central Michigan began. He also played on the United States Olympic team this year.(AP)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rockets 125, Clippers 109: Akeem Olajuwon scored 8 of his 20 points in the first two and a half minutes of the fourth quarter last night as Houston won its fourth consecutive game. The Rockets, at home, wasted a 19-point first-half lead and had to rally from behind to lead by 7 after three quarters. Olajuwon's 8 points then powered a 10-0 run that gave Houston a 98-81 lead. The Clippers, now 1-13 on the road, never got closer than 15 points the rest of the way. Buck Johnson had a career-high 24 points for the Rockets. Danny Manning led the Clippers with 21 points. (AP) Suns 126, Nuggets 118: Jeff Hornacek of Phoenix scored 10 of his 24 points in the decisive fourth quarter as the Suns won in Denver for the first time in 11 games. The Suns had not won at McNichols Arena since April 8, 1984. Phoenix, in registering only its third road victory this season, had a balanced offense: Eddie Johnson and Kevin Johnson each scored 23 points, and Tom Chambers and Armon Gilliam had 22 apiece. The Nuggets trailed most of the game, but rallied to tie it 97-97 at the end of three quarters. The Suns responeded with a 10-0 run to open the final period, with Hornacek scoring 6 of those points. Denver closed the deficit to 121-116 in the final minute after Alex English made one of two free throws. Eddie Johnson hit a jumper from the side, clinching the victory with 45 seconds remaining. English led Denver with 34 points. Michael Adams, who hit three 3-pointers in extending his long-range streak to 68 games, scored 20 points. Fat Lever added 19. Wayne Cooper of Denver had 19 rebounds and nine blocked shots,both of which tied career highs for the center, who is playing his 11th season. (AP) SKIING Hoeflehner Wins Downhilll: Helmut Hoeflehner of Austria conquered a dangerous downhill course in St. Anton, Austria, yesterday to capture his second World Cup victory of the season. Hoeflehner, who placed 69th last season in the World Cup standings, was timed in 2 minutes 02.03 seconds. Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland was second in 2:02.04. Third was Leonhard Stock of Austria in 2:03.14. The downhill counted toward the combined, along with the slalom Wednesday, in which Zurbriggen finished third, helping him win the combined. Hoeflehner was fourth in the combined, behind Zurbriggen, Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg and Armin Bittner of West Germany.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women Rutgers 71, Boston College 53: Missy Lender and Telicher Austin each scored 20 points, and Lender grabbed 13 rebounds last night to lead 10th-ranked Rutgers, at Piscataway, N.J. Rutgers, leading by 40-36 with 15 minutes 9 seconds left, scored 12 consecutive points to take a 52-36 advantage. Boston College (3-5) could pull no closer than 11 points in the final nine minutes. Austin had five assists, while Janet Malouf sank two 3-point shots, for the Lady Knights (5-1). Leslie Bjerstedt led the Eagles with 12 points. Boston led, 27-22, with 1:31 left in the first half. But Lender scored 8 points in a 10-2 Rutgers spurt, which put the Lady Knights ahead, 32-29, at the half. (AP) Iowa 90, Oregon State 45: Franthea Price score 22 points as seventh-ranked Iowa (7-2) took an early lead at home and coasted over Oregon State. Robin Christian added 18 points and Shanda Berry 17 points, six steals and 10 rebounds as the Hawkeyes took a 42-14 halftime lead. Chelle Flamoe had 21 points and six rebounds and Monica Raspberry 12 points for Oregon State (5-4).(AP) HORSE RACING Dancing Pretense Triumphs: Dancing Pretense took the lead in the stretch and went on to a 1 3/4-length victory in the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. The winner, carrying 114 pounds and ridden by Frank Lovato Jr., covered six furlongs in 1:09 2/5 over a fast track. Pok Ta Pok, ridden by Richard Migliore, who had battled for the lead throughout with favored Socially Informed, was runner-up in the field of eight. He finished a neck ahead of Socially Informed. For Dancing Pretense, the victory was the sixth in 15 starts this year. Dancing Pretense returned $16.20, $8 and $4.60 for $2 across the board. (AP)

title: U.S. Orders a Rollback Of Boston Airport Fees
description: The Department of Transportation ruled today that new landing fees imposed this summer at Logan International Airport in Boston illegally discriminate against private planes and small commercial carriers.

title: Margaret McInnis Wed To Frederic Coudert 3d
description: Margaret R. McInnis and Frederic R. Coudert 3d were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Israeli Cabinet Installed, With Warning on P.L.O.
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new coalition Government took office today with a call for national unity in the face of the ''serious dangers'' posed by the recent diplomatic successes of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Temporary Job Agencies Backed
description: The ethics committee of the American Bar Association has given its approval to a new phenomenon in the legal profession: temporary employment agencies for lawyers.

title: Boy Surrenders in Dog Attack
description: An 11-year-old boy surrendered to the police Wednesday for an attack a week ago Thursday in which two pit bulls were turned loose on 100 children. The police said the boy and another 11-year-old, who has not yet been arrested, had walked with the dogs into the schoolyard of St. Edwards Parochial School at recess and ordered them to attack.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Supports Questioned
description: Government assistance to the politically powerful dairy industry in the United States worked out to $1,139 per American cow in 1986, according to a recent study by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Perot Loses To E.D.S.
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation beat out its former chairman, H. Ross Perot, for a contract to operate the Medicaid program in Texas, state officials said. The National Heritage Insurance Company, an E.D.S. subsidiary that has operated the program since 1977, was competing against the Perot Systems Corporation. The system processes $1.1 billion a year in Medicaid claims.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The assets of the nation's 456 money market mutual funds decreased by $2.03 billion, to $278.64 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 135 institutional funds decreased by $1.20 billion, to $71.60 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were down by $328.40 million, to $89.68 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds decreased by $504.70 million, to $117.36 billion, the institute said.

title: Topics of The Times; 'You're Ruining Your Eyes!'
description: It's no news to connoisseurs of high school yearbooks that the myopic are apt to get more A's on their report cards than those who can spot a flea on a mouse.

title: 15 Savings Units to Be Merged
description: In another costly rescue of insolvent Texas savings institutions, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today pledged an estimated $1.85 billion over the next 10 years as part of a recapitalization that merged 15 savings units in the state.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, some passages in the Outdoors column in SportsMonday on Dec. 19 were out of sequence. Readers wishing copies of the corrected article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Carols From All Over
description: Christmas cards from Sweden, Germany, Italy, France and Puerto Rico are to be performed on a chamber-music program by Andrew Bolotowsky, a flutist; Beverly Thomson, a pianist; Helen Trezlie, a soprano, and Marianna Brodey, a soprano and guitarist, at the Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace, 28 East 20th Street, tomorrow at 1 P.M. The program also included Vivaldi's ''Winter'' Concerto, and seasonal works by Michel Corrette, Frank Martin, Alan Hovhaness and John La Montaine. Tickets are $1. Information: 260-1616.

title: Baker Held Likely to Join Drexel
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the former White House chief of staff and Senate majority leader, is leaning toward accepting the position of chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people close to him said yesterday.

title: Machine Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 4
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $48,000 and $14,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Review/Theater; 'Chu Chem,' a Musical
description: Hundreds and hundreds of years ago, Jews working their way along the silk route settled in the Chinese city of Kaifeng, and that's how ''Chu Chem,'' a new musical comedy, came to open this week at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: Alice Boney, Major Dealer of Art From China and Japan, Dies at 87
description: Alice Boney, a prominent dealer in Oriental art, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at her Manhattan apartment. She was 87 years old.

title: The Jurors Judge: How Sukhreet Gabel Hurt the Prosecution
description: By noon yesterday, the jury had crept within one vote of an acquittal for Bess Myerson and her two co-defendants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Dali Hospitalized
description: Salvador Dali was admitted to the emergency unit of Figueras Hospital at 1 A.M. today with a small hemorrhage in the stomach, the Spanish news agency EFE reported. Figueras is the 84-year-old Surrealist painter's hometown in northeastern Spain. The Spanish news agency provided no further details. Dali returned to his home Dec. 14 after 16 days in hospitals in Figueras and Barcelona, 60 miles to the south, where he was treated for a heart problem aggravated by blood clots in the lung.

title: Univation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; Sculpture, Private And Public
description: Melvin Edwards is one of the best American sculptors. He is also one of the least known. He made a barbed-wire-and-chain environmental installation for the lobby gallery of the Whitney Museum of American Art, but that was in 1970. His reliefs and freestanding sculptures have been presented at the Studio Museum in Harlem, but at the age of 51 he has never had a New York gallery show.

title: Penwest Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FRENCH ART

title: Chicago Council, in a Reversal, Passes a Gay Rights Measure
description: In a dramatic turnaround and over the opposition of Roman Catholic leaders, the City Council voted Wednesday to ban discrimination against homosexuals as part of a sweeping human rights law.

title: Kordic Suspended
description: John Kordic, a forward for the Toronto Maple Leafs, was suspended for 10 games by the National Hockey League yesterday as the result of a major penalty for high-sticking Keith Acton of Edmonton in a game Dec. 14.

title: Re-created: Phil Spector's Holiday Gift
description: ''The greatest rock-and-roll Christmas album ever recorded,'' blare the ads for ''A Christmas Gift for You,'' the Bottom Line's tribute to the ground-breaking record that wed genteel seasonal music with thundering rock-and-roll 25 years ago.

title: Christmas Songs
description: The pianist Monty Alexander and the trumpeter Harry (Sweets) Edison are performing Christmas songs in celebration of Nat (King) Cole at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) this weekend. Shows are tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 9 and 11:30 with additional 1:30 A.M. shows tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Reservations: 475-8592.

title: Arms Reactor to Remain Shut As Officials Search for Cracks
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington today said that the steel vessel containing a military nuclear reactor would be inspected for cracks before the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina was allowed to reopen.

title: Home Owners Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,837,000 from early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes a gain of $1,540,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter net did not cover preferred stock requirements. Share earnings for all periods are after preferred stock requirements.

title: 5 Members to Consider How to Improve System
description: Following are brief profiles of the members of the Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools, announced yesterday by Mayor Koch. James F. Gill

title: Just Ahead of Santa, Spain's Big Lottery Spreads Its Largesse
description: El Gordo, the Fat One, is as dependable as Santa Claus, and even brings his goodies two days earlier.

title: Rymer Company reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $10,314,000 and $11,041,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $8,529,000 and $8,704,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax benefit of $5,068,000 and $5,880,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: It's Christmas! Eat Deli! See Green Animals!
description: As if there weren't already enough to do this weekend, New York City has filled its holiday calendar with nearly every conceivable (and several nearly inconceivable) sorts of Christmas exhibitions, plays, tours and other festivities. While a cacophony of holiday music can be heard in churches and concert halls during the next few days, such bearers of the Christmas spirit as Ebenezer Scrooge and Tiny Tim will also be in town, and the traditions of Christmases past can be discovered at many historic Hudson River estates in Westchester County.

title: Ross, A J Logistics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MedChem Products reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest first-quarter results reflect the acquisition of the Avitene Product line in December 1987.

title: Teams N.C.A.A. Penalized in '88
description: Brooklyn College: One year in basketball.

title: 6 Publishers Cited for Unfair Tactics
description: The Federal Trade Commission issued complaints today against six of the nation's largest book publishers, accusing them of discriminating illegally against independent bookstores by selling books at discounted prices to major bookstore chains.

title: Fare-Stealing Curb: Pocketless Uniforms
description: City transit officials have decided that the answer to the problem of transit employees' pocketing fares is to get rid of the pockets.

title: Parins to Retire
description: Judge Robert Parins, the first full-time president in the 69-year history of the Green Bay Packers, said yesterday that he would retire in June.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Seals and Copeland

title: Ruder Sees No Crisis in Buyouts
description: Just one day after Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay $650 million for wrongdoing on Wall Street, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission said management ethics were matters of corporate governance that were best left to state law.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Carols and So Forth
description: For the third time in the last six years, the Supreme Court is trying to decide what kind of official Christmas celebration the Constitution permits the Government to sponsor. Daunting as that task may be, the Supreme Court's own Christmas party went off without a hitch last week in the shadow of the Court's very own Yule tree, a 22-foot spruce bedecked with colored lights that stands in the Great Hall just in front of the entrance to the courtroom.

title: Control Data Imposes Cuts
description: The Control Data Corporation, facing a break-even year in 1988, said it had told its 27,000 employees in the United States that they must take five days off without pay in the first quarter of 1989.

title: President to Become Guardian Life's Chief
description: After 30 years with the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, Arthur V. Ferrara, 58 years old, will become chief executive on Jan. 1. He will also serve as president, a post he has held since 1985.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Benefit for a Favorite
description: First Ladies often become involved in good works and single out particular projects. In the case of Barbara Bush, the favorite project has been and remains Reading Is Fundamental, on whose national board she serves.

title: 3 Reactors in Northeast Among 10 Worst-Managed
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has put three reactors in the Northeast on its list of the 10 worst-managed in the country.

title: Not Every Car Maker Opposes a Gas Tax; Slow on Alcohol Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo's Holiday Season Cruelty
description: LEAD: At this holiday time, when thoughts turn to family gatherings and giving gifts, New York State prisoners are thinking about Governor Cuomo and his clemency decisions, usually announced just before Christmas. If history holds, almost all will be disappointed - and many will not live long enough to seek the

title: INSIDE
description: Security Check Passed John W. Hall 3d passed a security check a year after the authorities suspect he began spying for the Eastern bloc, the Army said. Page A20. U.S. Rejects Logan Fees New landing fees imposed at Logan International Airport in Boston are discriminatory and must be rolled back, the Government said. Page A18. African Accords Signed Angola, Cuba and South Africa signed two accords on independence for Namibia and the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. Page A6. Reagan on Homelessness The President, in an interview, said his Administration bore no responsibility because many people choose to live on the streets. Page A26.

title: China and India Agree to More Border Talks
description: China and India will establish a group to tackle a border dispute that flared into a brief war in 1962 and has poisoned relations between the two nations ever since, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Fordham Hastening Move Into Colonial
description: Because Davidson College, one of the charter members, has dropped out of the Colonial League, Fordham's move to the Division I-AA level in football has been stepped up.

title: 'HUMAN RIGHTS NOW TOUR,' ON HBO
description: This Christmas we are getting, as usual, the standard fare of the season: religious services on Christmas Eve, including midnight Mass from St. Patrick's Cathedral (Channel 11) and, also at midnight, a Mass from St. Peter's in Rome (Channel 4). Series from ''Thirtysomething'' to ''China Beach'' have worked the holiday into their scripts. And, of course, there are the television classics - ''Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Reindeer'' and a slew of other low-cost reruns.

title: A Clear-Eyed Witness, Tyranny's Worst Enemy
description: My Century The Odyssey of a Polish Intellectual By Aleksander Wat Edited and translated by Richard Lourie. Foreword by Czeslaw Milosz. Illustrated. 407 pages. University of California Press. $35.

title: Soviet Military Wary of Arms Cuts
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to cut 500,000 from the Soviet armed forces has caused widespread apprehension in the military officer corps, Soviet military specialists acknowledged today.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The legal holiday for Christmas is Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Parking: Sunday rules, no street cleanings. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedule. Metro-North on holiday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule. Trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Court Overturns Death Penalty in Arizona Murder
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned the death sentence of John Adamson in the 1976 car bombing that killed Don Bolles, an Arizona newspaper reporter. It also ruled that Arizona's death penalty law was unconstitutional.

title: Reviews/Music; Hogwood Leads 'Messiah'
description: One of the tenacious myths in music is that there exists for all important works an authentic version, usually in the form of an original manuscript or a rewritten score reflecting the composer's final thoughts on the subject. This is musicology's way of tidying up the chaotic workroom of art before company comes. Unfortunately, until fairly recent times few composers worked with the tidy ideals of scholarship in mind.

title: Jackson, Rejecting Advice, Plans No Detours in His Political Career
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today rebuffed the advice of other leading Democrats that he should seek and serve in some lesser governmental office, like the Senate, before running again for President.

title: New Faces for 4 Cabinet Posts and the Top Environmental Job; Edward Joseph Derwinski, Secretary of Veterans Affairs
description: Edward J. Derwinski, the man chosen by President-elect Bush to head the new Department of Veterans Affairs, moved from the right wing toward the political center of the Republican Party in the course of a 24-year career in Congress representing a suburban Chicago district.

title: Kiki Kennedy Is Wed To J. R. Day, Librarian
description: The wedding of Katherine Kennedy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Kennedy of Highland Park, Ill., to James Ross Day, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Day of New York, took place in New York yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. The Rev. William Starr performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: The Importance of Dr. Sullivan
description: Why should it matter what Dr. Louis Sullivan, the President-elect's choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services, thinks about a woman's right to abortion? It's protected by the Constitution and the Supreme Court, isn't it? Besides, hasn't he got a lot else to think about?

title: Angola and Namibia Accords Signed
description: In a ceremony marred by angry exchanges, representatives of Angola, Cuba and South Africa signed two accords here today providing for independence for Namibia and the withdrawal of about 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Israeli Soldier Dies of Firebombing Wounds
description: An Israeli soldier who was severely wounded in a gasoline-bomb attack in the occupied West Bank two months ago died today in a London hospital, the army said.

title: The Crash of Flight 103; Vigils, Tears and Grief For Victims of Disaster
description: There were anguished sobs and vigils without hope and scenes of grief beyond telling in American homes, schools and offices yesterday as hundreds learned the fate of loved ones and friends aboard Pan Am's doomed Flight 103.

title: FOR NORTH KOREA, A HARSH PORTRAIT
description: In a rare glimpse into North Korea, two human-rights organizations have issued a report describing a society marred by extensive human-rights abuses and deadened by regimentation.

title: Checking (and Checking Off) The List of Holiday Movies
description: IF films had vintages the way wines do, 1988 would be remembered as a year that produced a lot of Kool-Aid. Luckily, much of the best has been saved for last, making Christmas a busy season for solidly interesting films if not for great ones. As usual, it's a time of mass moviegoing confusion, since the only thing Christmas films have in common is their strong claim on the ticket-buying budget of the potential patron. Built-in appeal, the quality that Hollywood thinks of as want-to-see, runs unusually high.

title: 9 Entities in Schools Investigation
description: At least nine entities are investigating or planning to investigate aspects of the New York City public school system. They are:

title: Texas Instruments, Hitachi in Chip Venture
description: Two of the world's largest semiconductor manufacturers, Texas Instruments and Hitachi Ltd., said today that they would jointly develop a next-generation computer memory chip.

title: U.S. Team Calls Scale Of Quake Unimaginable
description: American emergency relief workers, all of them seasoned in disaster assistance, said after returning from Soviet Armenia this week that nothing could have prepared them for the scale of human tragedy they encountered after the Dec. 7 earthquake.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN SUFFERS A SETBACK
description: A World Court decision favoring Nicaragua over Honduras in a case related to the contra war has prompted a new confrontation between the two countries, setting back regional peace efforts and endangering plans for a summit meeting next month.

title: Better Refund System For Cable TV Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; 'In' image in recruiting: snorkeling, wine-tasting, joggers who provide 'full-service'
description: One might expect the picture on the cover of the O'Melveny & Myers recruiting brochure to be of, well, Mr. O'Melveny and Mr. Myers. But the photograph is not of the two lawyers but of two rocks: ''Moon and Half Dome,'' Ansel Adams's famous shot of Yosemite National Park.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Drexel Case

title: Dish by Dish, The Top Tastes Of the Town
description: SOME people go to restaurants for a particular cuisine, some for a special ambiance, and others just because it is in the neighborhood and is fast and cheap. Occasionally, though, all of us get a craving for a particular dish: a blood-warming steak, lovingly roasted chicken with mashed potatoes, grilled vegetables or a great salad.

title: Novell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a pretax loss of $10,200,000 from the writedown of inventory.

title: At the Movies
description: A Players' Reunion

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Frederick Harold Joseph; Body Blow to a Fighter
description: Throughout his life, Frederick H. Joseph has modeled himself as a fighter, whether he was struggling to lift himself from his poor Boston roots, winning medals as a boxer at Harvard, or helping to turn Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a Wall Street weakling 15 years ago, into a powerhouse that took on the corporate establishment.

title: Suspect Passed '83 Review, After U.S. Asserts He Spied
description: James W. Hall 3d, the Army warrant officer who was arrested Wednesday on suspicion of espionage, passed an Army security check one year after the authorities say he began spying for East Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: Grenade Blast in Cape Town Hurts 13 Near Police Station
description: A grenade exploded near a group of people standing next to a police station near Cape Town, wounding 13, including 10 policemen, the authorities said.

title: For Any Other Coach, Rose Bowl Is Sweet
description: After 20 years as head coach of the University of Michigan's football team, Glenn E. (Bo) Schembechler finds himself exactly where he was after his first season with the Wolverines: preparing to meet the University of Southern California Trojans in the Rose Bowl.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Andover Bancorp, Andover, Mass., a bank holding company, and its subsidiary Andover Savings Bank promoted Robert M. Henderson to the new post of chairman and chief executive. Both concerns also promoted his son, Robert A. Henderson, to executive vice president. James E. McCobb Jr., chief financial officer of Andover Bancorp, added the posts of president and chief operating officer. Joseph F. Casey, controller of the bank, added the title of treasurer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creative Director Quits At HDM New York
description: Mike Drazen, the first creative director at HDM New York after it was formed in 1984 by Young & Rubicam and Paris-based Eurocom, and the creative director at HDM New York after HDM joined Dentsu last year, has resigned.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Treasury securities prices were mixed yesterday in light pre-holiday trading.

title: 'Cosby' Producers Strike It Rich
description: When Tom Werner and Marcy Carsey set up their television production company seven years ago, they did it the hard way.

title: New Faces for 4 Cabinet Posts and the Top Environmental Job; Samuel Knox Skinner, Secretary of Transportation
description: Samuel Knox Skinner, designated today as Secretary of Transportation in the Bush administration, will come to the job with a background in mass transportation and with close ties to the political organization of the President-elect.

title: Golden Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $1,025,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: War on Poverty: Bush's Approach
description: BENJAMIN DISRAELI, the great Conservative British Prime Minister, called 19th-century Britain ''two nations'' - the rich and the poor. And a quarter of a century ago, the American Socialist Michael Harrington published a book titled ''The Other America,'' which did much to inspire Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty, a war many consider to have been lost.

title: Joseph Ardleigh, 74; Led Research Institute
description: Joseph D. Ardleigh, former president of the Research Institute of America, died of spinal cancer at his home in Charlottesville, Va., on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and had been a resident of Greenwich, Conn., for many years.

title: Sunbelt Nursery reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Music; Clarinetist at Head of Trio
description: James Campbell, a Canadian clarinetist who is on the music faculty of Indiana University, presided over a satisfying chamber-music concert Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. His collaborators were Michael Tree, the Guarneri Quartet's violist (who also played violin here), and William Tritt, a pianist.
