description: b-Includes severance and outplacement costs of about $500,000 associated with the recent reorganization, and the write-down of $300,000 in costs associated with certain slow moving products. c-Net income

title: Last Defendant Settles In Bond Default Case
description: The final defendant in the securities fraud trial of the Washington Public Power Supply System has settled with class-action plaintiffs for $20 million, an attorney said today.

title: Knicks' Defense Is Tough Enough
description: When all else has failed this season, the Knicks have done it with defense.

title: Review/Film; A Fault Line Of His Own Making
description: The illegal substance of choice in ''The Boost'' is cocaine, but when first seen, Lenny Brown (James Woods) is so manic he seems to be headed for disaster long before he becomes hooked on drugs.

title: Team Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $734,000 and $554,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Jetliners Delayed in Europe By Threats of Bombs Aboard
description: A British Airways jetliner made an unscheduled landing at Rome's airport and an Air France flight from Turin to Paris was held up for more than an hour after bomb warnings, airport officials said.

title: Buyback Plan Set
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises said it would repurchase 5.3 million shares from the Coca-Cola Company for about $14.54 each, or about $77 million. Coca-Cola Enterprises, created in 1986 when Coca-Cola spun off its bottling interests into a separate unit, said it would start buying back the shares from public shareholders in the first quarter of 1989. It is to continue until Coca-Cola's stake was restored to 49 percent. At the spinoff, Coca-Cola sold the public 51 percent.

title: Official Faults New York City in Fatal Child Abuse
description: New York State's top child-welfare official said yesterday that the Koch Administration made numerous mistakes in its dealings with a Brooklyn mother who had a history of child neglect and is now accused in the beating death of her 5-year-old daughter.

title: Court Ruling Spurs Chase To Drop From Underwriting
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has withdrawn as co-manager of a $100.1 million underwriting of securities backed by bank assets after a Federal district court ruling supported the securities industry in its battle to keep banks out of the business.

title: Listen, Liberals, If You Can
description: Good for Barney Frank, the unquestionably liberal Congressman from Massachusetts, for reminding other liberals that they're not pariahs. On some of the most important issues facing the nation, they're actually in the mainstream.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Blossoming Ironies

title: U.S. Proposing To Lift Last Ban On Home Work
description: The Labor Department wants to lift the last of its prohibitions against the manufacture of clothing at home, officials said today.

title: Reagan on Homelessness: Many Choose to Live in the Streets
description: In an interview broadcast tonight, President Reagan dismissed the idea that his Administration bears any responsibility for the problem of homelessness and he said ''there are always going to be people'' who live in the streets by choice.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Proud of Being Liberal
description: According to Bethine Church, widow of the former Democratic Senator from Idaho, Frank Church, there are ''lots of great L-words'' in addition to ''liberal.'' So, in the wake of the election campaign in which the successful candidate made such a big thing out the dread ''L-word,'' she decided to incorporate some in her annual Christmas card.

title: Review/Opera; Fear And Frolic In 'Hansel'
description: The holiday season may not be the Metropolitan Opera's best excuse for reviving ''Hansel and Gretel,'' but in any form, at any time, it is nice to welcome Humperdinck's deceptively dark and beautiful opera back to New York. The Met's production was put together by Nathaniel Merrill and Robert O'Hearn in 1967, but its swooping scene changes, its towering forest and its series of storybook stage pictures are still appealing. ''Hansel and Gretel,'' in this English translation from the German, opened on Wednesday night and will have six more performances stretching into January.

title: Groups Urge Cuomo to Free Prisoners Dying of AIDS
description: At the time of year when governors customarily grant clemency to inmates, prisoner-advocate groups are urging Governor Cuomo to free prisoners dying of AIDS. The groups say the Governor has neglected such inmates in the past.

title: Eight Are Killed in Colombia As Rebels Attack Navy Boat
description: Leftist guerrillas ambushed a small navy vessel today, killing eight military men and wounding seven others, Colombian officials said.

Instead he continues to play ostrich about the alarming budget deficit. And his successor, Ralph Marino, seems more interested in raising senators' pay than balancing the books. Their obstructionism risks the state's financial health.

description: City officials have announced a three-year, $1.2 million advertising campaign to tackle one of Boston's most pressing problems: bad driving habits that worsen already snarled traffic.

title: Dining Out Guide: Cassoulet
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Ambassador Grill * (Oct. 3, 1986), 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) - Now that winter is here, robust fare is appropriate, and one of the most satisfying meals is cassoulet, the white-bean dish of southwest France that includes confit, pork or lamb and sausages. Half the menu of the Ambassador Grill is devoted to the foods of Gascony, the glorious region of ducks, geese, foie gras, confit, truffles - and cassoulet. The grill's version with duck meat may be less rich and complex than it could be, but it is flavorful nonetheless. An appealing starter, if you feel you have the room before the cassoulet, is the apple stuffed with fresh foie gras and served with a Sauternes sauce. For dessert, try crepes filled with chestnut cream, a fitting finale. Dinner prix fixe is $27, surely one of the better bargains in town. Open 7 to 11 A.M., noon to 2 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. on Friday; 7:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. on Saturday, and 7:30 to 10:30 A.M., 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. on Sunday. La Colombe d'Or *** (Sept. 16, 1988), 134 East 26th Street (689-0666) - A snug Provencal-style French establishment, this restaurant has a terra-cotta floor, colorful banquettes, whitewashed brick walls and gentle lighting. There is an impressive range of dishes that evoke the sunny and fragrant cuisine of southern France. The duck confit served here is outstanding: moist, full of flavor and crisply sauteed. It is among the ingredients in the cassoulet, which also includes beans, of course, along with confit of pork and two types of sausage. A good starter is escargots; a pleasing conclusion, ginger-spiked custard. Entrees are $16 to $25. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M. Friday and 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday. La Cote Basque *** (Aug. 22, 1986), 5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - The restaurant's dining room, after 30 years, still exudes a timeless glamour with its murals of coastal France, red leather banquettes, splendid flower clusters and a well-turned-out crowd. Habitues of this fortress of classic French cuisine look for comfort, cosseting and food they can really get their teeth into. The last includes a hearty cassoulet with roast pork, sausage, lamb stew and sauteed duck (fatback and garlic make the dish especially lusty). Light appetizers are available, like sparkling cold salads and vegetable combinations. For dessert, there is a silky, concentrated chocolate mousse. Dinner prix fixe at $52. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. Friday and 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday. Closed Sunday. Quatorze ** (Feb. 26, 1988), 240 West 14th Street (206-7006) - This is the sort of place you go to for sustenance, not surprises. Its modest setting is as guileless as the food; it has a long, pale-yellow-toned room with maroon wood trim, Art Deco sconces, French posters and neighborly banquettes. The cassoulet here has the requisite white beans, along with homemade pork and duck confits, lamb sausage and garlic sausage, all enlivened with a bit of tomato, fresh thyme and dried herbes de Provence. As a complimentary appetizer, there is a mildly livery terrine with green peppercorns. The dessert of choice is a thin, buttery apple tart the size of a Volkswagen hubcap. Entrees are $15.50 to $22.50. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11:30 P.M. Friday, 6 to 11:30 P.M. Saturday and 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sunday.

title: Report on Reserves Of Lincoln Savings
description: The American Continental Corporation said Federal regulators had found inadequate the capital reserves of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association unit. American executives said they disagreed. American said this week that it planned to sell Lincoln Savings, based in Irvine, Calif., to a California investment group led by Spencer Scott. The group would inject $50 million into the institution, bringing its net worth to $288.8 million.

title: Whose Butter Will Pay For All Those Guns?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sidney Spalding, 99, Retired Army General
description: Sidney P. Spalding, a retired Army major general who directed lend-lease shipments to the Soviet Union in World War II and later served as vice chairman of the Army-Navy Munitions Board, died of liver cancer Wednesday at the Reston Hospital Center in Virginia. He was 99 years old and lived at Patowmack Farm, Great Falls, Va.

title: Window Is Adjusted To Regulate Light
description: John Mecca, a home-improvement contractor in San Remo, L.I., has invented a window that can be adjusted to block out all or part of the light from outside.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge's Second Thoughts

title: Ivan Boldizsar, 76, Hungarian PEN Chief
description: Ivan Boldizsar, president of the Hungarian PEN Center and one of the first people from a Soviet bloc nation to receive an honorary degree in the United States, died Thursday in Budapest after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Niagara Rallies to Upset St. John's
description: Mike Rios's 3-point jumper with 1 minute 17 seconds left triggered a 7-point rally tonight as Niagara upset St. John's, 68-63.

title: CONFUSION MARKED ABUSE CASE REVIEW
description: A letter from New York City's top child welfare official explaining his agency's actions in the case of a 5-year-old girl who was beaten to death shows a pattern of repeated visits, confusion over the identity of children and failures to look up records that might have signaled a history of neglect.

title: Review/Concert; Chamber Music for Accordion and Strings
description: The Tregellas Quintet, which is led by Patricia Tregellas, an accomplished accordionist, offered an instructive look at the chamber literature for accordion and strings on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Of the seven works on the program, only two were transcriptions.

title: Grave Yields Psalms: World's Oldest?; Scholars See Problems
description: Scholars in New York and London said yesterday that the exact dating of the Book of Psalms found in Egypt may pose problems. One said it may be the oldest complete Book of Psalms on parchment, but questioned any claim that it is the oldest book in the world.

title: Albany Lawmakers Prepare For One More 1988 Session
description: Legislative leaders announced today that, contrary to what they said last week, they had not actually finished this year's legislative session and would reconvene the Legislature on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Executive Changes column in Business Day on Thursday about Daiwa Securities America Inc. misstated the new title of Takuro Isoda, its chairman and chief executive. He was named senior managing director of the parent company, the Daiwa Securities Company.

title: Ortega's Gifts: A Message?
description: If you work for the Government, what does it mean when the President sends you a bathroom scale for Christmas?

title: Flaw Not Ruled Out but Sabotage Is Still Suspected
description: Several aviation officials indicated today that it was far too early to dismiss mechanical or structural flaws as a cause of the midair disintegration of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet over Scotland.

title: Willie Kamm, Baseball Player, 88
description: Willie Kamm, who made baseball history when his minor league contract was purchased in 1922 by the Chicago White Sox for the record amount of $100,000, died of Parkinson's disease Wednesday at Belmont Convalescent Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Lockheed Stiffens Takeover Defenses
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that Harold C. Simmons, the Texas investor, recently acquired $15 million of its stock and that it had strengthened its anti-takeover measures to force any hostile bidder to acquire all of its shares.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are a number of potential causes for in-flight breakup. We are looking for evidence to try to point us in the right direction.'' - Mick Charles, a British investigator of the fall of Pan Am Flight 103. [ 1:3. ]

title: Jackson Interviewed
description: Doug Jackson, the Columbia assistant football coach whose allegations of drunkenness led Larry McElreavy to quit under fire as head coach last month, was interviewed Thursday for the Lions' job as McElreavy's replacement.

title: Anna Sierpinski Wed To K. S. Cavele-Clark
description: Anna Zofia Sierpinski, a daughter of Zofia Sierpinski of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mieczyslaw Sierpinski, was married yesterday to Keith Stewart Cavele-Clark, a the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Clark of Berwick near Polegate, East Sussex, England. Judge Sheldon Rand of Family Court performed the ceremony in his chambers in New York.

title: At Polish Store, the Cash Is Western
description: Some of the lines at the Junior department store along Marszalkowska Boulevard here are longer than usual these days, though not because of a shortage of goods.

title: Pregnant Women With Diabetes Cautioned on Blood Sugar Level
description: Pregnant women with diabetes can reduce the risk of miscarriage by keeping the body's blood sugar level under control, a study shows.

title: Crescott Gets 5.2% Of Dataproducts
description: Crescott Investment Associates, a New York general partnership, has acquired a 5.2 percent stake in the Dataproducts Corporation and said it had made a ''preliminary determination'' to seek control of the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Crescott group said that in October it proposed acquiring control of Dataproducts for $15 a share, or $294 million for all the shares, but received no response from the company.

title: Your Money; Bringing Up Baby Can Be Expensive
description: The cost of raising a baby can range from $10,000 to $60,000 in the first two years of a child's life, consumer specialists from the Chemical Bank say. And many of the costs occur during maternity leave, when a family is living on one income instead of two.

title: Mackovic Gets Job
description: John Mackovic, a former coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, was appointed athletic director at Illinois yesterday, after his first-year success in rejuvenating the football program earned him Big Ten coach of the year honors. Mackovic will remain as coach and will take up his new duties in about six weeks.

title: PRETORIA TO CUT POLICE IN NAMIBIA
description: South Africa has agreed to cut back the number of policemen in Namibia and disband a paramilitary police force there, diplomats said today.

title: The Core of the Myerson Case
description: The so-called ''Bess mess'' was a sad business well before Bess Myerson went on trial along with her companion, Carl Capasso, and former Justice Hortense Gabel. The onetime beauty queen had lost her job as New York City's Cultural Commissioner and the judge had left the bench during an ethics inquiry, her distinguished public career in ruins. Now their acquittal by a Manhattan jury re-ignites thoughts that the ordeal, besides being painful, was unnecessary.

title: Aged Inmates Pose Problem For Prisons
description: The nation's state and Federal prison systems, already straining as they handle more and more prisonerssentenced to longer and longer terms, are beginning to confront a complicated and costly new problem: elderly convicts.

title: Review/Dance; The Ailey Stages Works By Katherine Dunham
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater honored a pioneer of black dance on Thursday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, by presenting ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham,'' a program of works created between 1937 and 1950 by Katherine Dunham, the first black American choreographer to win international acclaim.

title: Hanging Mistletoe in Miami Beach?
description: LEAD: I had never been in a house with a Christmas tree until my freshman year at Mount Holyoke. Then, one snowy New England night a surprise phalanx of caroling students decked out in their Lanz flannel nightgowns urged us to grab our favorite teddy bear or childhood giraffe and join them to light the tree.

title: BRIDGE
description: Players from the Netherlands have always been strong competitors, but only one living Dutchman, Hans Kreyns, has ever won a world title. Two Dutch teams finished one-two in the De Looier tournament in Amsterdam Nov. 5 and 6, in a strong field of 64 teams from 10 countries. A British team was third. The prize money totaled $9,000, and some of the play was shown on Dutch television.

title: Richard A. Cawley, Investor, 43
description: Richard A. Cawley, founder and president of the Rain Hill Group, Inc., a multinational investment concern based in New York, died in the crash of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 on Wednesday. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kristallnacht Refers To Beveled Glass
description: To the Editor:

title: New Job for Bruce
description: Earle Bruce, former Ohio State coach, was hired yesterday as the football coach at Colorado State.

title: Hoax of the LSD Tattoos Has a Long History; Chemically Feasible
description: To the Editor:

title: Song of Christmas
description: What is it about Christmas music that draws in even nonbelievers? Is there a hamlet too provincial for Handel's ''Messiah'' or a metropolis too tone- deaf to stage it with the audience belting out the choruses? Carolers of all faiths, and no faith, raise their voices above the din of commercialism, carrying on one of the holiday's proudest traditions.

title: No Pact for McReynolds
description: For the third day in a row, the Mets conferred with the agent for Kevin McReynolds over a multiyear contract for their left fielder. But no deal was struck, and there will likely not be one until at least next week.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Antifreeze Checkup
description: Now is the time to check the antifreeze in your car, that magic substance that prevents the engine from freezing in winter and overheating in summer. It also lubricates the water pump. Not all antifreeze - ethylene glycol - contains the same ingredients; it is essential to read the label carefully. Most brands contain inhibitors for corrosion and rust. Antifreeze must always be mixed with water, although some brands come premixed. All brands should be able to prevent an engine from freezing in temperatures of 34 degrees below zero. Each brand has a different concentration of ethylene glycol. Avoid any brand with more than 50 percent water, which is too watered-down. Plastic testers, available for $3 to $5, can be inserted into mixed antifreeze and show, within 10 degrees, the mixture's anti-freezing ability.

title: Free-Flight Programs Shift Course
description: The number and variety of frequent-flier plans created by airlines since the concept was introduced about seven years ago are confusing enough for most passengers. But changes made this year and those coming in 1989 are making things even more complex.

title: Arkansas Suspends 2
description: Coach Kan Hatfield suspended two senior Arkansas players from his Cotton Bowl-bound team yesterday, saying they broke an unspecified team rule.

title: Leftist Rebels Bomb Salvador Ministry, Killing 3 and Wounding 35
description: Leftist rebels attacked the Defense Ministry with car bombs and catapult explosives today, killing at least 3 people and wounding at least 35, officials said.

title: Salvador Dali Is Hospitalized Again
description: The artist Salvador Dali was in stable condition today after being taken to a hospital suffering from complications from a small intestinal lesion, doctors said.

title: Almost-Instant Replay: Browns Take On Oilers Again Today
description: What are these guys doing in Cleveland again?

title: Bleaching Hair Quickly With Lasers
description: Clairol Inc., the manufacturer of shampoos, conditioners and dyes, has invented a way to bleach hair within minutes without chemicals. The secret: lasers.

title: Abortion Foes Hail Gains in Reagan Era
description: The anti-abortion movement has been so pleased with President Reagan's eight years in office that it seemed almost inevitable that President-elect Bush would somehow disappoint its leaders.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL Southern Mississippi 38, Texas-El Paso 18: James Henry, a senior cornerback, scored on punt returns of 65 and 45 yards to lead Southern Mississippi last night in the Independene Bowl. After U.T.E.P. (10-3) stalled on its first drive of the second half, Henry fielded the punt just inside the sideline, outracing the Texas-El Paso defenders for a 17-7 lead for Southern Mississippi (10-2). The 65-yard return broke the Independence Bowl mark of 60 yards, set by Leisville's Kevin Miller in 1977 against Louisiana Tech. (AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 119, Sonics 107: Larry Nance scored 27 points to lead six double-figure scorers and Cleveland outscored Seattle by 14-2 in overtime to earn their fifth consecutive victory last night. Seattle, which trailed by 17 points midway through the second quarter, forced the overtime by bouncing back from a 103-97 deficit with 1:10 remaining. (AP) Clippers 114, Spurs 108: Los Angeles recovered from a 15-point halftime deficit and defeated San Antonio behind 25 points from Reggie Williams, who came off the bench to score 21 points in the second half.(AP) Bucks 113, Mavericks 101: Terry Cummings had 30 points and Jay Humphries scored 7 in a late 13-2 run as Milwaukee rallied at home. The Bucks, who had watched a 13-point lead slip away in the second half, trailed by 89-84 when Jay Humphries sparked the decisive run. (AP) Hawks 131, Pacers 114: Dominique Wilkins had 13 of his 28 points in the decisive third quarter as Atlanta beat Indiana, which still has not won on the road this season. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres 5, Maple Leafs 2: Ray Sheppard, Christian Ruuttu and Mike Donnelly scored second-period goals as Buffalo defeated slumping Toronto last night in Buffalo. The victory extended Buffalo's longest unbeaten streak of the season to four games (2-0-2). The Leafs are now 1-11-1 in their last 13 games. (AP) Flyers 5, Whalers 4: Mike Bullard's goal with 29 seconds spoiled Hartford's comeback and gave Philadelphia, playing at home, its seventh straight victory. The Flyers' winning streak is their longest of the season. Hartford has lost four straight games and is 0-5-1 in its last six. (AP)

title: Letter: On Technology; Decline of American Inventiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Tons Of 'Snow' And Bliss
description: Shortly after 9 A.M. Thursday, a snowstorm of sorts hit the Stewards' house with fury, burying the green lawn and blooming rose bush and plastering the windows with white stuff.

title: L.I. Santa Pulls Gifts Of Bail From His Bag
description: Christmas came early for eight indigent inmates awaiting trial when a Long Island real-estate developer bailed them out of the Nassau County jail.

title: Devils and Penguins Battle to Tie
description: A wealth of penalties did not spoil some splendid hockey tonight as two goaltenders loomed larger than the rest of the players and the Devils and the Pittsburgh Penguins played to a 2-2 tie.

title: About New York; And Visions Of the City Clash Head to Head
description: Is there Christmas in New York City?

title: Review/Theater; Unlikely Mission in the American Backwoods
description: In ''Heathen Valley'' Romulus Linney fills a bare planked stage with passion, spiritual as well as sensual. This fascinating play is the story of a pragmatic idealist who, in defiance of the established church, restores a sense of faith in an abandoned people. At the same time, Mr. Linney illuminates a theological disputation and demonstrates civilization's instinct for inhumanity.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., an automotive parts company, completed the $204 million acquisition of the European exhaust systems business of TI Group P.L.C., Birmingham, England, a holding company.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up 14% In Period
description: Bolstered by sweetened buyer incentives, sales of new domestic cars and light trucks rose 14.4 percent in the Dec. 11-20 period from a year earlier.

title: Renew and Strengthen Apartheid Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Hamilton, 64, Electronics Executive
description: Anthony R. Hamilton, chairman of Avnet, Inc., died of liver cancer on Thursday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Harry M. Bainbridge, Lawyer, 34
description: Harry M. Bainbridge, international counsel with the law department of Pepsico Inc., was killed Wednesday in the crash of the Pan American World Airways plane in Scotland. He was 34 years old and lived in Montrose, N.Y.

title: Soviets Cleared To Buy Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has been authorized to begin a new round of subsidized wheat purchases from the United States, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: HIDDEN U.S. LOSSES IN LOAN PROGRAMS REACH HIGH LEVELS
description: The hidden losses embedded in the Government's huge portfolio of subsidized loans and loan guarantees have reached startlingly high levels, say budget experts, who add that losses from the programs will continue to cost taxpayers billions of dollars for years to come.

title: Chief Rescuer Now Fears Dolphin Will Die
description: The Federal Government has called off an effort to rescue a bottlenose dolphin trapped in Broad Bay, but the head of the rescue operation said today that he was still afraid the dolphin would die in the cold water.

title: Advisory Panel Raises Concerns About Continued Safety of Shuttle
description: The chairman of a scientific advisory group monitoring the redesign of the space shuttle's booster rockets said today that the panel was concerned about the space agency's efforts to assure continued flight safety.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Christmas Letdown
description: The prospect of a three-day Christmas weekend is enough to make even champion copers quiver. So much preparation has taken so much time, energy, organization and money, and then the rituals of consumption are observed so quickly: packages demolished in a flash; the first toys broken before the last are opened, and dinner over in a trice. In many households, especially those in which the holiday is primarily a secular event, the big problem is what to do next and, this year, what to do the following day.

title: Computer Suspect Called Part of Ring
description: A Dutch citizen arrested here on charges of smuggling computers to the Soviet bloc led one of the largest such operations known to Government officials, investigators said today.

title: 6 Killed as Propane Truck Explodes in Memphis
description: A 10,000-gallon propane truck exploded today on a highway in Memphis, killing six people, creating a fireball and sending pieces of the tanker crashing into a house 125 yards away, officials said.

title: Jan. 1 Closing Planned for 'Checkmates'
description: ''Checkmates,'' the Broadway play by Ron Milner, will close on Jan. 1, less than three weeks after it was disclosed that Michael Harris, a co-producer, is serving a 28-year-to-life sentence in San Quentin prison in California for attempted murder. He was also indicted by the United States Attorney's office in Los Angeles on drug charges.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 14 about President-elect Bush's visit to Gulf Stream, Fla., misstated the length of Jupiter Island and the size of its population. It is 15 miles long, not 9, and has a population of about 1,600, not 500.

title: Acupuncture for Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 of the Crash Victims Were From State Dept.
description: Three State Department employees and a Peace Corps volunteer were aboard the Pan American World Airways flight that crashed in Scotland.

title: Myerson Verdict Helps Koch (a Bit)
description: The acquittal of Bess Myerson disperses a cloud hanging over Mayor Koch's nascent and still unofficial quest for a fourth term, but it was only a small cloud, and others remain.

title: The Good, The Bad, The Tiresome
description: There were a number of success stories in sports during 1988, among them Orel Hershiser, Steffi Graf, Jose Canseco, Mark Jackson, Greg Louganis, Barry Sanders, Danny Manning and Kay Yow, the North Carolina State basketball coach who overcame cancer to lead the United States women's team to a gold medal in the Seoul Olympics.

title: Now, the Urban Sprawl Wonder Diet
description: Ask most residents of the world's largest metropolis what problem worries them most and the answer is likely to be pollution, crime or overcrowding. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari must contend not only with those issues but also with the growing political restiveness of the Mexican capital.

title: CSX to Sell Pipeline To Transco
description: The Transco Energy Company has agreed to buy the CSX Corporation's interstate natural gas pipeline subsidiary, the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, and two related units for $571 million.

title: Carols as Decreed by the King in 1453
description: They start lining up in the cold outside King's College Chapel the night before Christmas Eve. The attraction is a hallowed British tradition, the festival of lessons and carols at King's, held every Christmas Eve since 1918 and now broadcast live around the world over BBC radio.

title: A.&P. in Pact For Borman's
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of Montvale, N.J., said today that it had reached a definitive merger agreement to acquire Borman's Inc. of Detroit, operator of the Farmer Jack supermarket chain in the Detroit area, for $27 a share, or $76 million.

title: Woman Clear in Son's Killing
description: A judge today set aside the murder conviction of a 24-year-old woman who had argued that she was suffering from ''baby blues'' when she ran her automobile over her infant son and then left the body in a trash can.

title: P.L.O. and Muslim Militia Agree to End Lebanon Fight
description: Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Shiite Muslim militiamen announced an agreement today to end three years of fighting and begin a new relationship.

title: George A. Brooks, 88, Retired G.M. Executive
description: George A. Brooks, a retired executive of the General Motors Corporation, died of heart failure yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Nikolaas Tinbergen, 81, Zoologist And Nobel Winner for Medicine
description: Nikolaas Tinbergen, a Dutch-born British zoologist who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1973, died after suffering a stroke at his home here Wednesday. He was 81 years old.

title: A Personal Touch in High-Tech Invitations
description: One problem with parties - giving them, that is - is getting the invitations printed. Ordinarily it takes several weeks, longer around the holidays. But now, if you suddenly decide to celebrate the New Year or anything else with a party, and you will settle for something less than hand engraving, the Social Secretary will make life easy. It is a thing, not a person, a computerized laser printer to be exact.

title: Reagan Names New Director Of National Cancer Institute
description: President Reagan has named Samuel Broder to be the director of the National Cancer Institute to succeed Vincent T. DeVita Jr., the White House announced Thursday.

title: Coca-Cola Stock
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises said it would buy back 5.3 million of its shares by the end of the year. The Coca-Cola Company bottling subsidiary, which has already repurchased 2.5 million shares from the public in 1988, said in a statement Thursday that it intends to buy the 5.3 million shares from its parent company before the end of 1988. Stock of Coca-Cola Enterprises closed at $14.875 today, up 25 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the buyback would cost the company $78.8 million. The stock repurchase is part of a buyback of 25 million shares that Coca-Cola Enterprises plans to finish by the end of 1990.

title: The Holidays Inspire Many To Remember the Neediest
description: The Orich family of the Bronx has shared Christmas Eve with friends and their children for the last 30 years, exchanging many gifts.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed Monday for the Christmas holiday. Banks, government agencies and nearly all businesses will also be shut, as will most foreign stock exchanges.

title: Judges Turn to Ignition Locks To Ground Drunken Drivers
description: Nearly 40 percent of all fatal traffic accidents at this time of year involve drunken drivers. In an effort to find a solution to this problem, 11 states, including New York on Dec. 12, have passed legislation to promote the use of a breath-testing device that prevents automobiles from operating if drivers have had even one alcoholic drink.

title: Sidney Spalding, 99, Retired Army General
description: Sidney P. Spalding, a retired Army major general who directed lend-lease shipments to the Soviet Union in World War II and later served as vice chairman of the Army-Navy Munitions Board, died of liver cancer Wednesday at the Reston Hospital Center in Virginia. He was 99 years old and lived at Patowmack Farm, Great Falls, Va.

title: A South Bronx Church Draws Its Holiday 'Family' From Afar
description: When the sun comes up on the South Bronx tomorrow, Christmas Day, people who left the neighborhood years ago as it went into its spiral of decline will come home to North Church.

title: The Magical Root Beer
description: When I was a child we always had homemade root beer at Christmas. Making it required yeast, a lot of sugar, quantities of water and a bottle of root-beer extract, which was then easy to find in the neighborhood grocery.

title: Drexel Talks With S.E.C.
description: Talks between lawyers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and officials at the Securities and Exchange Com=mission continued yesterday in an effort to settle the complaint filed against the firm.

title: Evans Joins Braves As Minor Leaguer
description: Darrell Evans, the 41-year-old slugger who started his major league career in Atlanta 20 years ago, returned to the Braves as a free agent yesterday. Evans signed a minor league contract, with incentive bonuses if he makes the major league team. That strategy was needed because the 40-man big league roster is filled.

title: Cigarette Industry Financing Wide War on Smoking Bans
description: The $55 billion United States cigarette industry, facing a serious threat from a proliferation of city, county and state antismoking laws, is fighting back with a richly financed nationwide campaign to organize opposition to the legislation.

title: 'E.T.' Actress, 13 Years Old, Is Treated for Alcohol Abuse
description: Drew Barrymore, the 13-year-old actress who was a star of ''E.T.,'' has been released from a rehabilitation center after treatment for alcohol abuse, her publicist said Thursday.

title: String Orchestra
description: Alexander Schneider is to conduct the New York String Orchestra in its annual Christmas Eve concert at Carnegie Hall at midnight tonight. The program includes Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 3 and two works by Haydn - the Trumpet Concerto in E flat and the ''Farewell'' Symphony. Charles Lazarus is the trumpet soloist. Tickets are $7 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: Chadli Benjedid Re-elected To 3d Term to Head Algeria
description: Chadli Benjedid has been overwhelmingly re-elected President of Algeria for a third five-year term, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: Director of Kinsey Institute Is Urged to Resign
description: Indiana University has asked June Reinisch to resign as director of the Kinsey Institute, the internationally known sex research center, the institute says.

title: Reviews/Dance; Young Choreographers Explore Life's Perils
description: The world appeared to be a baffling place for the young choreographers who participated in Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks program on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Gabel Says 'It's Possible' Myerson Tried to Sway Her
description: Hortense W. Gabel conceded yesterday that ''it's possible'' Bess Myerson was trying to influence her handling of a divorce case when Ms. Myerson hired the former Supreme Court justice's daughter in 1983.

title: Three Are Slain And the Mother Leaves a Note
description: Hours after her first visit to a psychiatrist, a 31-year-old mother killed her husband and two young children early today and then apparently tried to commit suicide, the police said.

title: Hanson Discloses It Owns Big Cummins Engine Stake
description: Hanson P.L.C., the giant British-based conglomerate, has emerged as the buyer of a significant stake in the Cummins Engine Company.

title: How the F.B.I. Aids Academic Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Posts Trade Deficit
description: Britain said today that its balance-of-payments deficit in November reached $:1.61 billion, or about $2.9 billion, an improvement from October's revised record gap of $:2.53 billion, or about $4.55 billion.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Bookings Unaffected by Crash, Airlines Say
description: The crash of a Pan Am jetliner in Scotland appears to have had little effect on airline bookings to Europe, travel agents and spokesmen for air carriers say.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Flight 103: Threats and Warnings
description: All that's certain about the horrible air crash over Scotland is that everyone on board died, as well as people in the village of Lockerbie. The passenger list included Syracuse University students, U.S. servicemen and a senior United Nations official. The crash would have been tragic at any time. What makes it seem more awful are suspicions that the Pan American jet was sabotaged, and that someone - the airline or the State Department - didn't do enough to prevent it.

title: Brazilian Who Fought to Protect Amazon Is Killed
description: A Brazilian union leader who received repeated death threats during a campaign to protect the Amazon rain forest was shot and killed Thursday at his home in northwestern Brazil.

title: Army Copter Fleet Grounded
description: The Army said today that it had grounded its 234 CH-47D medium-lift Chinook helicopters to allow inspection of possibly faulty transmissions.

title: Reviews/Dance; Two Debuts at City Ballet As Cavalier in 'Nutcracker'
description: The role of the cavalier is traditionally a small one in ''The Nutcracker.'' Certainly George Balanchine doesn't allot much time to that princely character, who is mostly a partner or porteur in his production of the ballet. But like most movement, from a simple walk to sophisticated ballet choreography, the part does reveal a good deal about its performer. And two recent role debuts offered interesting portraits of their dancers.

title: Science Meets Vampire in Spain
description: Natural History By Joan Perucho Translated by David H. Rosenthal. 186 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Martin B.C. Simpson, Broker, 52
description: Martin B. C. Simpson, founder and president of the Martin Simpson & Company stock brokerage, was a victim of the Pan American World Airways crash in Scotland Wednesday. He was 52 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: TOWN PICKED FOR HUGE INCINERATOR FIGHTS IT
description: Much of this rural township seems a scene drawn from Currier & Ives. Wreathes decorate the doors of rambling homes on woodsy lots. Bearded, ruddy-faced men gather in the Clarksburg Inn for a nip against the winter chill. There are rolling horse farms, rows of greenhouses and fields lying fallow till spring.

title: Barge Leaks Oil in Pacific
description: A barge under tow collided with a tug boat Thursday and leaked fuel oil, which washed ashore today on beaches of the southwestern Washington coast. The barge trailed an oil slick that grew to 30 miles long and 100 feet wide. Authorities closed up to 2 miles of beach. Officials estimated that about 70,000 gallons of oil had leaked from a tank holding about 250,000 gallons of oil.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The legal holiday for Christmas is Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Parking: Sunday rules, no street cleanings. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedule. Metro-North on holiday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule. Trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Everyone Gains in Therapy Institute Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat's Aim: Turning a Foot in the Door Into Something More Permanent
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has unexpectedly achieved a long-standing goal: a dialogue with the United States. But the breakthrough has illuminated an equally long-standing challenge: to establish that Palestinian aspirations will not prove perilous, unwanted and unacceptable to Israelis and many Americans.

title: Faint Unknown Noise Is Detected At End of Crashed Jet's Recording
description: After the first playback of the cockpit and flight data recordings from the Pan Am Boeing 747 that crashed here, investigators said today that the cockpit voice recorder showed normal flight deck conversations until it cut off, and that an unidentified noise came at the end of the tape. The data recorder was also suddenly cut off, when the plane was at 31,000 feet.

title: 3 Suspended At Boston Co
description: The Boston Company, a unit of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said it had suspended three top officers while it investigated discrepancies in its 1988 financial report.

title: Kenya Reopens Israeli Ties
description: Kenya has re-established diplomatic relations with Israel in light of the Palestine Liberation Organization's decision to recognize Israel, the state-run Voice of Kenya radio said today. Kenya, with most other black African countries, broke off relations with Israel after the 1973 Middle East war.

title: What Scrooge Taught Me
description: LEAD: As a child growing up in my native Scotland, I was fascinated by Charles Dickens's classic ''A Christmas Carol.''

title: Armenia Quake Crews End Rescue Mission
description: No more survivors will be found from the Dec. 7 earthquake in Soviet Armenia, and crews will concentrate on clearing eight million tons of rubble in the crumbled cities, a Government official said today.

title: Review/Recital; 5 Composers For Cellist At Weill Hall
description: Richard Sher, a cellist who has been heard often locally as a soloist and chamber musician, and who has recently founded the Brooklyn Friends of Chamber Music, played a long and substantial program Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. To music of Debussy, Beethoven, Bach, Prokofiev and Tchaikovsky, he brought sound, thoughtful musicianship, technical capability and a subtler responsiveness to the character of each piece than is sometimes encountered in instrumental recitals.

title: Pratt & Whitney Jet Engine Orders
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft has received jet engine orders potentially worth $112 million, company officials announced. LTU International Airways, a West German airline specilizing in holiday travel, has ordered PW4000 engines for its three new McDonnell Douglas MD-11 trijet aircraft, officials said.

title: Hoax of the LSD Tattoos Has a Long History
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Braces for a Well-Equipped Passing Attack
description: Alabama's coach, Bill Curry, sent his backup quarterback home Wednesday for violation of team rules. The disciplinary action against Jeff Dunn will probably not have much bearing on the outcome of the Army-Alabama game in the John Hancock Sun Bowl on Saturday even if the Crimson Tide's starting quarterback, David Smith, is injured again.

title: 'Decompressing' Dukakis Tentatively Praises Bush
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has given President-elect Bush some early praise in his first interview since losing the election. He also said he was still ''decompressing'' from the campaign and would not want to replay it.

title: Belgium Cuts Interest Rates
description: The central bank lowered Belgium's most important interest rate today after increasing rates just last week. The Banque Nationale de

title: Sleeping Ranger Offense Awakens for Short Time
description: Three shots in one period and five in the next do not win games in the National Hockey League, but a quick spurt can earn a tie, as the Rangers discovered tonight at Capital Centre.

title: Teen-Ager Is Killed in Connecticut Crash
description: A high-school cheerleader was killed and a basketball player and another cheerleader were seriously injured today when their car bounced between guardrails, throwing them through the rear window, the state police said.

title: Advocate for Homeless Convicted in Protest
description: A woman active in causes on behalf of homeless people was found guilty today of trespassing for occupying a vacant, Federally owned house in August with a group of homeless women and children.

title: PENTAGON ASSERTS OFFICIAL MISSPOKE ON INQUIRY'S SCOPE
description: The Defense Department says that four major arms makers are under investigation for illicit possession of secret Government documents, not the eight that a top Pentagon investigator had identified on Wednesday.

title: Washburn Released
description: Chris Washburn, the Atlanta Hawks center, has been released from a California drug rehabilitation facility after an 87-day stay. ''They informed me that Chris was released and put on a plane to begin a period of readjustment to life in the community,'' said Stan Kasten, the Hawks' president.

title: Sale of Schlegel
description: The Schlegel Corporation, a privately held producer of weather seals for vehicles and buildings, said its board had approved the sale of the company to the London-based BTR P.L.C. for $200 million. The sale is expected to close in four or five weeks. The offer from BTR was one of several received by Schlegel, which has 4,000 employees. BTR owns British Tire and Rubber and a variety of other businesses.

title: A Device to Muffle The Cries of an Infant
description: A distressed father, who said he almost lost control when his infant son would not stop crying, has developed a ''baby cry muffler.''

title: Blakey and Messengers
description: Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers are playing at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street) through Jan. 2. Shows are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 cover charge and a $6 minimum. Reservations: 242-1785.

title: Hoax of the LSD Tattoos Has a Long History; Warning From F.B.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Countering Threat of Airline Bombs: Experts Say Security Isn't Foolproof
description: Even without specific evidence to show what brought down Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland on Wednesday, experts in aviation security said today that there was no foolproof protection against bombs. They noted that security officials had been paying particular attention to the possibility of bomb attacks against aircraft in recent months.

title: American Brands Surges on Talk of a Bid
description: The shares of American Brands Inc., a tobacco and consumer products company that is perennially rumored as a takeover target, ran up yesterday on speculation that an unsolicited bid was in the offing.

title: Trooper Held on Drug Charge
description: A New Jersey state trooper was arrested today on charges he planned to sell cocaine he confiscated from a drug courier who turned out to be an undercover detective, officials said. Trooper Jerome W. Johnson, 25 years old, of Newark, was arrested.

title: Bloomingdale's and Wall Street Journal in Dispute
description: Although it is not unusual for corporate executives to complain about news coverage of their companies, they rarely press their accusations in person. But the top executives of Bloomingdale's met Thursday with the managing editor and a reporter of The Wall Street Journal to complain that an article published in The Journal on Dec. 14 was inaccurate and had an unfavorable tone.

title: Star of the Nativity
description: LEAD: In the cold season, in a locality accustomed to heat more than to cold, to horizontality more than to a mountain, a child was born in a cave in order to save the world; it blew as only in deserts in winter it blows, athwart. To him, all things seemed enormous: his mother's breast, the steam out of the ox's nostrils, Caspar, Balthazar, Melchior - the team of Magi, their presents heaped by the door, ajar.

title: Leaders Seek To Blunt Rule On Campaigns
description: With politicians and potential candidates objecting to strict interpretations of New York City's new campaign-finance law, Mayor Koch and the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, chairman of the new Campaign Finance Board, met yesterday to begin softening the rules under which candidates will operate.

title: Decision Delayed
description: Syracuse University will not take any disciplinary action against Derrick Coleman until a court settles whether Coleman is guilty of criminal mischief and harassment. The decision means the 6-foot-9-inch junior forward can continue playing for Syracuse, said Robert Hill, the university's vice president of public relations.

title: MANY PENSIONERS GAIN IN I.R.S. RULING
description: The Internal Revenue Service has decided to order retroactive pension benefits for many people who have worked past the normal retirement age.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18.

title: Rumors Askitter of a Roach Retreat
description: It is too early to hang out the no vacancy sign on the Roach Motel, but there are bits of encouraging evidence that suggest the New York City cockroach population may be declining.

title: Sludge Found on Six Beaches
description: Fecal matter and sludge have washed up on six Ocean County beaches this week and health officials are trying to find the source. The waste may have come from a passing barge, said Tim Hilferty, health officer for the Long Beach Health Department. Mr. Hilferty said the material turned up several days ago after a high tide. The waste was reported to the police Thursday morning by John Vogt, a resident of Long Beach Island who noticed it while walking along the beach.

title: Choreography on a Stamping Line
description: The changing of huge metal-forming dies at the General Motors Corporation's stamping plant here has been transformed from routine maintenance to industrial choreography, with each move by a 21-man team as carefully planned as a ballet company's.

title: F.C.C. Reinstates Ban On Indecent Programs
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a new ruling, has reinstated a total ban on indecent broadcasts. A group of broadcasters and free-speech advocates say they plan to challenge the rule in the courts.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption Thursday about the sentencing of Dr. Peter J. Sarosi, who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from his role in the unlawful adoption of a baby boy by Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum, misidentified the lawyer at right. He was Wilfred T. Friedman, not Greg Baruch.

title: A Drug to Relieve Cerebral Vasospasms
description: Scientists at the Medical College of Wisconsin received patent approval this week for use of the drug nicorandil to relieve spasms in cerebral blood vessels. Such spasms cause thousands of deaths each year.

title: Bonds Stage Rally Led by Futures Trading
description: A brief but sharp rally yesterday in Chicago's Treasury bond futures market caused prices to move up in the cash market. Dealers in Chicago and New York said the advance reflected largely technical factors, and trading remained extremely thin in the pre-holiday atmosphere.

title: Officer Acquitted of Striking Photographer
description: The first New York City police officer to be tried for abuses against civilians during the melee in Tompkins Square Park last summer has been acquitted of departmental charges because of insufficient evidence.

title: Hearing on King Killer Blocked
description: Gov. Ned McWherter has blocked a Jan. 26 parole hearing for James Earl Ray, now 60 years old, who is serving 99 years in prison for shooting to death the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Memphis in 1968.

title: Melanie Kahane, 78, a Designer Known for Colorful Rooms, Dies
description: Melanie Kahane, an interior designer whose bold use of color created a new look for homes, died of lung cancer Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old. Miss Kahane, the widow of Ben Grauer, a broadcaster for NBC News, caught the public's eye in 1946, when she designed one of the first colored kitchen appliances, a shiny red stove. In 1949, her design for a black-and-white French provincial bedroom accented with pumpkin-colored furniture became one of the most photographed interiors in magazines and books.

title: Utility in Illinois Wins Rate Rise
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company, the nation's third-largest utility, said it had accepted a settlement proposed by the Illinois Commerce Commission giving it a rate increase of up to $480 million in the next two years, followed by a freeze on rates until 1994. The settlement gives Commonwealth Edison about $1 billion less than it had requested in a filing that sought to pass the costs of three new nuclear power plants on to customers.

title: Big Profits Seen if Rexene Is Sold
description: The stock of the Rexene Corporation soared yesterday to $24.50, up $6.25, after its management said it was negotiating to sell the chemical producer to a third party at a premium.

title: A Farewell to Santa Claus
description: LEAD: [The idea of this playlet grew gradually in the mind of the writer while he was quietly trying to read Chekhov's ''Notebooks'' at a cocktail party where the guests were discussing Hemingway, while one man in a lady's hat was imitating Ed Wynn.]

title: Grave Yields Psalms: World's Oldest?
description: A book bound in wood and leather and found in a child's grave south of Cairo is the oldest complete copy of the biblical Book of Psalms ever found and possibly the world's oldest book, scholars who have studied the volume say.

title: Dow Rises 8.57 in Sluggish Session
description: LEAD: The stock market edged higher in sluggish pre-holiday trading yesterday, spiced by real and rumored takeovers.

title: Computer System Lets TV Audience Join Show
description: F.D.R. Interactive Technologies, a Los Angeles start-up company in which the American Express Company is majority shareholder, won patent approval this week for a computer system that would let television audiences participate in game shows, polls and promotional events.

title: E. C. Finch, 77, Lawyer and Ex-Legislator
description: E. C. Kip Finch, a lawyer who served in the Connecticut House of Representatives and who held several posts with Time Inc., died on Thursday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Weicker Is in Running To Lead Trinity College
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who narrowly lost his campaign for re-election last month, is in the running to become president of Trinity College, a school offical said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 A recovered cockpit voice recorder from the Pan Am Boeing 747 that crashed in Scotland shows normal flight deck conversations until a cutoff and an unidentified noise at the end of the tape. Page 1 Airlines have no assured protection against bombs, experts in aviation security said, noting that officials had been paying particular attention to the possibility of bomb attacks in recent months. 5 A plane flaw should not be dismissed yet as a possible cause of the midair disintegration of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland, several aviation officials indicated. 5 A Brazilian union leader was killed Thursday night at his home in northwestern Brazil. He had received repeated death threats during a campaign to protect the Amazon rain forest. 1 The Pope received Yasir Arafat and told him that Israelis and Palestinians had ''an identical fundamental right to their own homelands,'' but that both must reject violence, including terrorism and reprisals. 3 New analysis: The P.L.O. has achieved a long-standing goal in starting a dialogue with Washington, but a long-standing challenge remains: to show that Palestinian aspirations will not prove perilous to Israel. 3 Lebanese Shiite Muslim militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas agreed to end three years of fighting in southern Lebanon. 2 South Africa has agreed to cut back the number of policemen in Namibia and to disband a police force in an attempt to show the United Nations that free elections there will not be subverted, diplomats said. 4 Holiday shoppers in Warsaw can buy from a great variety of luxury goods at a department store, and they can do so with any of 23 world currenices. The catch: The Polish zloty is not one of those currencies. 4 National 6-8, 28, 46 Hidden losses in Government loans to groups like farmers, students and small businesses have reached startlingly high levels and the losses will cost taxpayers billions of dollars for years to come, budget experts say. 1 The Pentagon retracted a statement that eight companies in the arms industry face possible criminal prosecution for possession of secret Goverment documents. Only four are being investigated, it said. 1 A new problem for prison systems has evolved as they handle more and more prisoners sentenced to longer and longer terms. The problem, complicated and costly, is elderly convicts. 1 Tobacco companies are fighting laws that restrict smoking in public with a richly financed campaign in areas as large as California and as small as Midwestern towns. 1 A Dutch man arrested in Miami on charges of exporting computers to the Soviet bloc has led one of the largest high-technology smuggling operations known to Government officials, investigators said. 6 The protest of anti-abortion groups over a move by President-elect Bush - the naming of Dr. Louis W. Sullivan to be Secretary of Health and Human Services - seemed almost inevitable given the movement's satisfaction with President Reagan. 8 Concern about the space shuttle's continued safety was voiced by the chairman of a scientific advisory set up by the National Research Council to monitor the redesign of the space shuttle's booster rockets. 6 The director of the Kinsey Institute was asked by Indiana University to resign from the prominent sex research center. The university cited concern about the quality of recent research and of managment. 7 Retroactive pension benefits for many people who worked past normal retirement age will be ordered by the Internal Revenue Service in cases where employers stopped contributing to their pensions when they reached normal retirement age. 8 Pregnant women with diabetes can reduce the risk of miscarriage by keeping the body's blood sugar level under control, said a study that found that their risk of miscarriage increases with blood sugar levels. 8 American Brands's stock ran up on speculation that a takeover bid was likely. The tobacco and consumer products company is perennially rumored as a takeover target. 35 An article upset Bloomingdale's so much when it appeared in The Wall Street Journal that executives met with the managing editor and the reporter. The Journal article said Bloomingdale's had begun to look like ''a bargain basement.'' 36 Six killed as propane truck explodes in Memphis 6 Dukakis offers early praise for Bush performance 8 Regional 29-31 Disarray at the child welfare agency in New York City that dealt with the family of a 5-year-old who was beaten to death is shown in a top official's letter explaining his agency's actions in the case. 1 'It's possible' that Bess Myerson was trying to influence Hortense Gabel's handling of a divorce case when Ms. Myerson hired her daughter, Sukhreet, the former justice said after her acquittal. 29 News analysis: Mayor Koch gained from the outcome in the trial of Bess Myerson, his former Cultural Affairs Commissioner and the woman with whom he strolled, arm-in-arm, to his improbable victory 11 years ago. 31 Mayor Koch sought to soften rulings of the new campaign finance board. The move was in response to politicians' complaints about the board's strict legal interpretations. 29 A town in New Jersey is protesting its selection as a site for a hazardous-waste incinerator that is to take an estimated 50,000 tons a year of toxic waste from across the state. 29 A mother killed her husband and two young children in Rockland County and then apparently tried to commit suicide, hours after her first visit to a psychiatrist, the police said. 30 Cockroaches may be on the decline in New York City - or at least officially recorded complaints about them are. Roach infestation ''is no longer the topic of cocktail party chitchat that it once was,'' a Health Department spokesman said. 31 New York legislators prepare for one more 1988 session 30 A South Bronx church draws its holiday family from afar 30 Neediest Cases 46

title: Rams Discover The Forward Pass; Offense Takes Off Behind Everett
description: If the Vikings are to beat the Los Angeles Rams on Monday in a National Football League wild-card game in Minneapolis, they must control the Rams' passing game.

title: POPE SEES ARAFAT AND BACKS TALKS
description: Pope John Paul II received Yasir Arafat today and told him that Israelis and Palestinians had ''an identical, fundamental right to their own homelands,'' but that both must reject violence, including terrorism and reprisals.

title: KEY RATES
Japan Proposal On Disclosure
description: The Ministry of Finance today detailed the kind of company news that must be disclosed to the public to reduce illegal insider trading. The ministry plans to announce the new regulations next month and institute them in April.

title: 1 Killed in Car Pileup in Fog
description: Heavy fog caused a pileup of 20 to 30 vehicles this morning on Interstate 40 about four miles west of here, killing one person and injuring a dozen, officials said.

title: Now, the Boss Helps House Everyone
description: BECAUSE some families are finding it more and more difficult to take a job in an area where there is an expensive housing market, a growing number of companies are beginning to extend a level of housing assistance to all employees that was once reserved for only the highest corporate ranks.

title: 'One Tough Cop'
description: To the Editor:

title: YELLOWSTONE IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: LEAD: The smoldering remnants of the wildfires that swept through the thick lodgepole pine forests and high mountain meadows of Yellowstone National Park have finally surrendered to winter, which comes early to the high plateau upon which Yellowstone lies, high even for the northern Rockies.

title: Running for Comptroller Is a Better Bet for Many
description: Convinced that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin will either challenge his frequent critic, Mayor Koch, in next year's primary election or return to private life, more and more Democrats are lining up to run for comptroller next year.

title: David Klein Engaged To Lauren M. Felsen
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morry Krantz of Randolph, N.J., of the engagement of Mrs. Krantz's daughter, Lauren Michele Felsen, to David Martin Klein, a son of Mr. and Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Klein of Secaucus, N.J. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Drug-Related Crime
description: Debate over the drug problem sometimes deteriorates into banal oversimplification. Hawks want tougher law enforcement; doves favor drug treatment. Wiser heads understand that both are needed. So do Alexis Vega and John Moore.

title: Reel of Film Found in John Lennon Car
description: Museum curators taking a ride in the 1960's Rolls-Royce limousine that belonged to John Lennon have found a canister of film under a passenger seat.

title: Fare of the Country; With Aquavit and a 'Skaal,' Denmark Greets the Season
description: When Horatio asks Hamlet if drinking is customary in Denmark, Hamlet replies: ''This heavy-headed revel east and west/ Makes us traduc'd and tax'd of other nations:/ They clepe us drunkards . . .'' With these words, the most famous Dane of all bemoans a custom ''more honour'd in the breach than the observance.''

title: Murder Record for New York
description: Homicides in New York City appeared to have reached a record level for a single year last night, the police said.

title:
GARDENING;
An Old-Fashioned Holiday Ritual
description: LEAD: A CHRISTMAS Eve ritual when I was young was my family's annual visit to cheap Sam's. Sam (I never met him, but I presume there was one) set up business around the middle of December by unloading a truckful of evergreen trees into an empty lot beside Route 59 in upstate New York.

title: The Unhappy Campers
description: In David Aaron's new spy novel ''Agent of Influence'' (Putnam, $18.95), a group of Wall Street M.&A. men are about to lose a leveraged buyout deal to a competitor with better inside information and deeper pockets. What figure of speech does the author (a former deputy national security adviser) choose to describe the infinite glumness on the greedy faces of his characters? Here it is, as >au courant as a ''poison put'' bond: ''Seldom had he seen such a group of >unhappy campers.''

title: How Is America? Social Science Plots Numerical Answers
description: ALTHOUGH man does not live by bread alone, it would be difficult to tell that from the indexes used to monitor the state of the nation. From the gross national product to the Dow Jones average, the numbers relied upon are all economic indicators.

title: IT BROUGHT OUT THE WORST IN EVERYONE
description: SAFARI A Chronicle of Adventure. By Bartle Bull. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Viking. $40. AFRICAN LIVES White Lies, Tropical Truth, Darkest Gossip, and Rumblings of Rumor - From Chinese Gordon to Beryl Markham, and Beyond. By Denis Boyles. Illustrated. 225 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Interfaith Union: Teach the Children
description: The Rev. Donna Schaper [ ''Weaving Symbols Into Interfaith Union,'' Opinion, Dec. 4 ] has a solution to the problem of intermarriage education. Providing the children with both backgrounds permits them, as adults or young adults, to make a choice based on knowledge and experience regarding the direction they wish to pursue.

title: Aging Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraud Charged in Program Giving Amnesty to Illegal Farm Workers
description: Government agents are investigating allegations of widespread fraud in a national amnesty program for farm workers in central and western New York, an immigration official said.

title: Amy Grenen Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Amy Sann Grenen to Donald Adam Levantin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen M. Levantin of Philadelphia and Snowmass, Colo., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Grenen of Radnor, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. A September wedding is planned.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Jack Connell; 'There's Not a Time I Didn't Have Fun'
description: EVEN when he is in his street clothes, Jack Connell of Willimantic, a jolly man with a bushy white beard, draws amazed stares from children. It is an image he has cultivated for decades, starting in the 1950's when he put on a red suit and stood in front of his Main Street gas station in his hometown of Willimantic.

title: Son of 12 Is a Ticket Back to Joy and Grief of Childhood
description: MY son is a voodoo doll in my image. When he is hurt, I am hurt. When he feels rejection, I am stabbed in the heart. I have no control in this matter. In fact, I have looked for witches to exorcise me from the terrible pain that can strike at any given moment. They (the witches) look me in the eye with carefully guarded understanding and ask, ''Why? Why do you feel all these things for him?'' I try to explain, ''It's not just that I feel for him, he makes me feel for me.'' He makes me remember, for the first time as an adult, what I really felt when I was 12.

title: Convenience of Automatic Flash
description: IT'S no wonder that photographers once made a cult of ''available light.'' Before automatic flash came along, using a flash of any sort was a complex and sometimes ill-fated enterprise. Sticking to light that was already there seemed the better part of valor.

title: In Rio, One Police Killing Refuses to Die
description: When the police make raids in the shantytowns of Rio de Janeiro, they often shoot first and ask questions later, apparently confident that the families of innocent victims are too poor to dare complain about police brutality.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Long-Awaited Guidebook Makes Its Debut
description: LEAD: A NEW coin guidebook, the most important in years, is ready for release. Called the ''Coin World Guide to U.S. Coins, Prices & Value Trends,'' it represents more than 18 months of preparation by the editors of Coin World, the largest-circulation newspaper in the field.

title: Eileen Brennan to Marry Daniel C. Oakley in July
description: The engagement of Eileen Mary Brennan to Daniel Charles Oakley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Oakley of Worcester, Mass., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Brennan of Old Brookville, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: Leila Metz to Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Andrew Metz Jr. of New York and Saddle River, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Metz's daughter Leila Fallon Metz to William Matthew Hewitt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Hewitt of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Andover, Vt.

title: Pottery Shard Bombarded in Reactor May Hold Clues to Ancient Trading
description: It is a safe bet that the maker of the coarse pottery bowl that researchers call sample 28 could not have conceived its use 4,500 years later and half a world away.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAYAT: On the Side of Life. By Mariapia Fanfani. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) There is a peculiar affection that the highly privileged sometimes feel for the severely deprived. Rarely has this emotion been given such unrestrained vent as in ''Hayat,'' a self-congratulatory account of a tour through famine-stricken Africa in 1985. Mariapia Fanfani, a vice president of the International Red Cross-Red Crescent and the wife of Amintore Fanfani, the former Prime Minister of Italy, raised funds to fill the hold of a ''Ship of Peace'' with relief supplies. For two months, Mrs. Fanfani was escorted by various officials to ports where the ship was unloading and to camps where goods were being distributed. Mrs. Fanfani's writing is as graceful and insightful as a press release from the United Nations. ''I believe that compassion has no geography and that a gesture, however small, is never useless,'' she writes. ''It is always a mark of friendship among people.'' Much of the book is taken up with maudlin and patronizing descriptions of Mrs. Fanfani's encounters with impoverished Africa. ''They were also beautiful, and their wretchedness had not managed to eradicate the signs of a fascination that is still there in the sad smile of the African water bearers before me now,'' she writes. ''They probably have only one change of clothing and will never have any wealth, only fatigue, hunger, and privation.'' Celebrities who raise money for charity deserve praise and maybe even an all-expenses-paid trip to Africa. Publishing their travel diaries is more difficult to justify.

title: Getting Off The Street And Into A Theater
description: LEAD: JUST before curtain time, 17-year-old Celiastine Ross helps actors take on their characters for each production of ''Forever My Darlin' '' at the Kean-Brown Center Stage here.

title: Susan Thomas to Wed John A. Glynn in July
description: Announcement has been made by Margaret Svensson Thomas of Dayton, Ohio, and Dr. Edward Robert Thomas of Kettering, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter Susan Anne Thomas to John Anthony Glynn, a son of Joseph Eugene Glynn of Scranton, Pa., and Mary Joan Glynn of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Report Warns of Maine Bay's Fouling
description: When Nini McManamy looks out her bedroom window each morning, she no longer notices the dark green forests of nearby islands in Casco Bay or the bright blue water. Instead, she sees a power plant and smokestacks and a sewage treatment plant.

title: Crime
description: To the Editor: A relative of mine, about to board a plane from a Midwest international airport for the West Coast, encountered a pair of thieves with a new-to-me wrinkle.

title: DATA UPDATE: December 25, 1988

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Scottsdale, Ariz.;
Grand Plans For Old Canal
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is expected to begin here next summer on a two-year, $120 million mixed-use complex along the Arizona Canal in this next-door neighbor to Phoenix.

title: ALL-WHITE PANEL LEADS TO BOYCOTT
description: A Federal commission recently created to fight poverty along the lower Mississippi River is already the focus of a black boycott over its racial makeup.

title: Satisfaction on Rise in U.S., Gallup Poll Finds
description: The American people are generally happier with the way the country is going than they were last year, and most of them like the way their own lives are going.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It looks like TV dinners for me again, but I'll probably still vote for her confirmation.'' - Senator Robert Dole. [ 23:2. ]

title: Q and A
description: Multiple Fees for Flats

title: The French in Africa: Old Ecole Ties
description: Staged in the throne room of a palace here, the family photo of the annual French-African summit meeting presented a vignette of modern Africa: President Francois Mitterrand surrounded by 21 African heads of state and government.

title: Grateful Inmate Aids Albany Hospital
description: When a $260 check arrived from Sullivan State Prison, fund-raisers at the Albany Medical Center were intrigued.

title: Radio Redux: Frequencies Are in Demand
description: MANY people think that a television station license is as good as a license to print money. On Long Island, licenses for radio stations are getting that reputation.

title: Mexico Police Storm Prison; 22 Found Dead After Assault
description: The police stormed a prison to crush an uprising by inmates who were denied Christmas pardons, officials said today. They said 22 people had died in the uprising and the assault, including the prison warden.

title: OFFICES THAT FLY AND MORE TELEPHONES IN THE SKY
description: Air travel problems, whether delayed or canceled flights, overbookings or missed connections, make it difficult to do business. To remedy this, airports, airlines and even airplane designers are devising ways to cash in on the businessman's demand for efficiency.

title: Raina B. Cassady To Wed a Priest
description: The engagement of Raina Brant Cassady to the Rev. William Steven Thomas, the son of William B. Thomas of Covington, Ky., and the late Jean Thomas, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cassady of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Down's Syndrome Study Ends Inconclusively
description: A state study says researchers cannot determine if a high rate of Down's syndrome births in Vernon Township during the late 1970's can be attributed to the concentration of satellite communications towers in the rural area of northwestern New Jersey.

title: Providing the Most Baserunners (and Reasons to Be Traded)
description: Shane Rawley, Jamie Moyer, Jimmy Jones and Kevin Gross are among the pitchers who have been traded in this off season. They gave their teams good reason to trade them.

title: A Year Just to Listen
description: Before the year lips away to wherever bygone time is kept, we should perhaps extend a parting look at 1988 into a summary overview.

title: One Family's Not Always Merry Christmas Stories
description: The oldest of the five Boda children, Steve, would grow up to be a sports historian, the N.C.A.A.'s associate director of statistics and a collector of Notre Dame memorabilia dating back more than a century. The middle child, Lou, would be a nationally respected sports announcer. The youngest, Bob, would be a Madison, Wis., engineer and heavy-duty equipment salesman. The only sister, Carolyn, would marry a milkman in South Bend, Ind.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SECOND SIGHT, by Mary Tannen. (Ivy, $3.95.) In the depths of urban New Jersey, a film director and a building developer become mixed up with a psychic named Destiny Ortega. In this first novel, Mary Tannen ''somehow makes it all work,'' Gary Krist said here earlier this year. ''She skillfully creates a fictional world spacious enough to house the highborn and the lowborn, the rational as well as the mystical.'' BY SILENCE BETRAYED: Sexual Abuse of Children in America, by John Crewdson. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) As they study the pictures of missing children on the sides of milk cartons and dutifully warn their offspring against taking candy from strangers, parents are offering themselves false comfort, John Crewdson writes. Most childhood sexual abuse is not rape and abduction by violent interlopers but skillful seduction by the child's own family, neighbors, teachers and other acquaintances.
