In February, our reviewer, Sherry Turkle, said this book was ''stunning in its statement of the facts and unrelenting in its attacks on our myths. . . . The illness is not just adults' sexual aggression toward children. It is also that we allow abuse to be an unspoken and invisible social fact.'' I LOOK DIVINE, by Christopher Coe. (Vintage, $5.95.) When Nicholas, a pathologically narcissistic homosexual, dies inexplicably at age 37, his older brother tries to figure out what went wrong. Last year, our reviewer, Richard Burgin, called the author of this novel ''an icy and acute observer.'' MY GURU AND HIS DISCIPLE, by Christopher Isherwood. (Noonday/Michael di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) In 1939, long before the mysteries of the East had become all the rage, the writer Christopher Isherwood began studying under a Hindu swami, tempering his sybaritic Hollywood existence with such worthy pursuits as translating the Bhagavad-Gita. ''What emerges is a record of a religious adventure that would have delighted Kierkegaard,'' Edmund White said here in 1980. ''Isherwood rejects conventional piety - all the humdrum apparatus of worship - in favor of a direct, even jaunty appreciation of how preposterous, certainly precarious, spirituality can be today.'' Noonday Press has also made three additions to its uniform set of Isherwood novels. In A MEETING BY THE RIVER ($7.95), the writer also explores the world's continuing war between spirit and flesh. This time the tension is between two brothers: Patrick, a homosexual publisher, and Oliver, who has decided to become a Hindu monk. The story is told with a ''natural charm that will make almost any literate reader, free of prejudice against its subject matter, want to read it to the end,'' Gerald Sykes said in The Book Review in 1967. THE WORLD IN THE EVENING ($8.95) tells of Stephen Monk, who flees Hollywood for loftier climes after he catches his wife committing adultery at a party. In 1954, our reviewer, Mark Schorer, called the book ''a brilliant enigma.'' First published in 1932 by Leonard and Virginia Woolf's Hogarth Press, THE MEMORIAL: Portrait of a Family ($8.95) uses the story of troubled siblings in London to document the decline of British society after the First World War. THE CARE OF THE SELF: Volume Three of The History of Sexuality, by Michel Foucault. Translated by Robert Hurley. (Vintage, $7.95.) The French archeologist of human consciousness traces the roots of our sexual anxiety to imperial Rome when, it appears, the first Me Generation was born. Through Michel Foucault's eyes, this ancient world is ''almost uncannily familiar,'' John Boswell said here last year. ''Its population . . . is obsessed with personal health and the care of the body. Pop medical authorities cater to this preoccupation by providing guides to diet, exercise, sex and regimen that seem surprisingly modern - down to such fine points as the recommendation to eat a lot of bran.'' Vintage has also published a new edition of MADNESS AND CIVILIZATION: A History of Insanity in the Age of Reason ($7.95), which is perhaps Foucault's best-known attempt to show how those in power shape the way we perceive reality. ''This is a difficult but rewarding book, beautifully written and subtle in its development,'' one reviewer said in 1965. THE SCREAMING MIMI, by Fredric Brown. (Carroll & Graf, $3.50.) In this classic pulp thriller, a hard-drinking newsman tracks down a serial murderer called the Ripper. In 1949 one reviewer called the book ''tough, funny, and plausible in a dreadful kind of way.'' DEEP BLACK: Space Espionage and National Security, by William E. Burrows. (Berkley, $4.95) The work of the National Reconnaissance Office, which designs and manages spy satellites, is considered so sensitive that, on the books, the agency doesn't exist. ''As described by Mr. Burrows, the routine activities of manned and unmanned systems deployed in space, the upper atmosphere, at sea and on earth seem more remarkable than exploits of human spies,'' John Newhouse said here in 1987. BOY, by Roald Dahl. (Penguin, $6.95). For almost a decade, Roald Dahl was held captive in English boys' schools, Dickensian places where children waged war against monstrous disciplinarians. ''These autobiographical stories are as frightening and funny as his fiction,'' Hazel Rochman said here in 1985. ''They have the intense drama and simplicity of the fairy tale, and its unequivocal extremes of good and evil.''

title: Carnegie Fund Honors 20 People for Heroism
description: William F. Kessler said he was worried about underwater stumps and the size of the foundering truck driver below him when he leaped 40 feet from a highway bridge into a Louisiana swamp to save the trucker.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our home-built kitchen cabinets are covered with Formica and this is separating from the particle board underneath. I would like to refurbish these cabinets. I can either reglue the existing laminate, then apply another on top of that, or remove the Formica, then apply a new laminate directly to the particle board. Which is best?

title: Dakar
description: Set on a peninsula that curls out into the Atlantic Ocean, Dakar, Senegal's capital, is the westernmost city on the African continent. Dakar offers all of the amenities of Western urban life including luxury hotels, computerized telecommunications, international banks and Continental cuisine. Here, one can witness a rich amalgam of African, French and Islamic culture without abandoning the comforts of home.

title: THE CONVENT AS PRISON AND SALON
description: SOR JUANA Or, The Traps of Faith. By Octavio Paz. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. Illustrated. 547 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $29.95. A SOR JUANA ANTHOLOGY Translated by Alan S. Trueblood. Foreword by Octavio Paz. 248 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press. $29.50.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The legal holiday for Christmas is tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Parking: Sunday rules, no street cleaning. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedules.

title: Synthetic Heroin Seen As Cause in 18 Deaths
description: China White, a powerful synthetic heroin that plagued California in the early 1980's, has surfaced in western Pennsylvania, killing 18 people, and the authorities suspect a drug ring they say is headed by a research chemist.

title: 3 Die as Plane Crashes In Westchester Woods
description: Three people were killed this morning when their single-engine airplane crashed in a wooded area just south of the Westchester County Airport, the police said.

title: Long Arms of Foreign Banks Prompt Debate and a Bill
description: LEAD: A BILL that would allow foreign banks to acquire banks in New Jersey is causing some banking experts to ask whether this is a natural progression for the state's growing economy or a conduit for giving it away.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CHATEAU ELLA. By Hilary Norman. (Delacorte, $19.95.) In the prologue of Hilary Norman's second novel, the plan of the whole book unfolds. There, Ella Bogarde, a distinguished woman surrounded by a pack of polite Irish wolfhounds, heaves closed the gates to her beloved hotel in the Hudson River Valley.

title: A Plant for the Holiday Season
description: TIME off for a Merry Christmas. Poinsettia

title: Ms. Pennington To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maier Pennington of Pennington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Pennington to Lieut. (j.g.) James Judson Cowie, U.S.N., a son of Michaelin Reamy-Stephenson of Dunwoody, Ga., and James Donald Cowie of Atlanta. A May wedding is planned.

title: Salvation Army Beats Drum for the Poor
description: Every morning, starting on Nov. 28 and continuing through yesterday, Christmas Eve day, Roger Rischway has transported 30 Salvation Army volunteers and their Christmas kettles to one of a dozen locations countywide. At night, Mr. Rischway, who is the director of the Salvation Army's Hudson Valley Service Extension bureau in Tarrytown, collects the workers, the kettles and the money.

title: THE REGION: A Forum on Governing New York City; Breaking the Cycle of Corruption and Incompetence
description: THE topic was the politics of New York City, and the proposition under discussion was this: Corruption breeds paralysis, and paralysis in turn breeds corruption.

title: A Walk Through the Snow and the Years
description: THE snow came like sleep, slow, steady and sounds muffled as if held under a blanket. Distinctions slowly fade into a oneness, the street light, the curves of my Volkswagen, the limbs of the dogwood. I walk looking for Milltown, looking for myself.

title: Wittgenstein's Labors
description: To the Editor:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
There Are No Great Teams Anymore . . .
description: LEAD: PETE ROZELLE and the National Football League owners should be gloating once again, slapping themselves on their collective backs.

title: Wreaths Carry Many Meanings And Messages Into Christmas
description: The Christmas wreath, so colorful and welcoming, is as packed as a snowball with tradition and symbolism.

title: Curbing Excess on Wall Street
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s dramatic decision to plead guilty to six felony counts of fraud last week and pay $650 million in fines for violating securities laws, comes at a critical juncture for the United States business community. It occurs as the nation is groping to find an appropriate balance between unbridled free enterprise and constricting regulation, between short-term gains and long-term prosperity, between papering over deep economic problems and devising substantial solutions to them.

title: CLEESE UP CLOSE
description: John Cleese, looking fit and chipper, is sitting on a sofa in a television studio in Bristol, England, not far from where he was born. He is on the 46th day of promotional interviews for his film ''A Fish Called Wanda.'' This interview will be, by his estimate, about the 150th he has given, but he shows no hint of the boredom or restlessness that this wearying process occasions. Instead, he wears a look of Buddha-like contentment - the sort of look you might expect to see on someone who has recently created something that is in the process of doing $80 million worth of business.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Cobble Hill
description: LEAD: ON a recent fall day of lingering warm weather, Cobble Hill, a 20-block mostly residential enclave just south of Brooklyn Heights, seemed far removed from the pressures of city life.

title: Our Man in Panama
description: Eric Arturo Delvalle left his hiding place back home last week for a visit to the United States, where he sought and received reassurance that, at least as far as Washington is concerned, he is still President of Panama. The Reagan Administration, which flew him here on an American military plane, has officially ignored the fact that Mr. Delvalle was ousted 10 months ago by Gen.

title: A Holiday Spent in Service to Others
description: FOR many, Christmas is a day to spend with friends and family, after weeks of marathon shopping and frenzied preparations. Many, though, spend time today, and in the days leading up to Christmas, with people they do not know.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Skowhegan, Me.; Scott Expansion Jogs Building
description: DEVELOPERS and owners of rental apartment houses are making plans to build new homes and apartments in response to an announcement that Scott Paper Company plans to expand its S.D. Warren mill in this town of 9,000 people that straddles the Kennebec River in central Maine. Scott pays 78 percent of the town's $7.5 million annual budget. Several subdivisions have been built and some apartments renovated since rumors of the expansion started about a year ago, said Patricia Dickey, the Town Manager. The company, based in Philadelphia, announced the project Nov. 16. The plant, which covers 60 acres and houses two machines for making high-quality coated paper, wil be enlarged to install another paper-making machine. The addition will cover 14 acres of the 2,200-acre site. The new machine, due to be operating by late 1990, will be 600 feet long and cost $250 million, said Mike Kilpatrick, the company's spokesman, and the building improvements will cost $125 million.

title: From Benign to Benighted
description: The parents of two small boys suddenly feel less conscientious. The boys have been plagued with head colds so the parents bought each an ultrasonic humidifier. These would, the parents thought, create a healthier atmosphere. The deluxe model, shaped like a flying saucer, includes a night light, plastic ducks and an electronic music box that plays ''It's a Small, Small World.''

title: Nebraska Inquiry Is Given File on Sex Abuse of Foster Children
description: A state file containing reports of physical and sexual abuse of foster children, based on interviews with some of the children and including one instance reminiscent of slave auctions, has been turned over to the Executive Board of the Nebraska Legislature.

title: Hope Is More Than Happiness
description: NOT long ago a child asked me, ''Why are your endings all so sad?'' The question threw me a bit. I know sad things happen in my books, but I certainly don't perceive them as all having sad endings. It forced me to take another look at my work, or at least at the endings of my novels, and I must confess that none of them have what might be conventionally called happy endings. But does that make them sad? Or, as one troubled mother complained to me about ''Gilly Hopkins,'' ''totally without hope''?

title: After New Year's Eve, for the Stomach
description: WHEN midnight has struck and you've rung in the new year it is nice to sit down to a festive snack with your champagne - something to line the stomach before you go to bed. One of my favorite dishes is blinis with caviar. You can make the batter in advance, and all you have to do at the last minute is saute the pancakes. If you have a couple of small frying pans this can be accomplished quickly and easily, particularly if you have someone to help you. Either black or salmon caviar, which is red and much cheaper, can be used on the blinis.

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: Good enough to win often and with style . . . to bring the game's smartest and loudest fans back to the Garden . . . to offer (and presumably sell) season tickets in the stratosphere . . . to help us forget the pathetic teams of the 80's . . . and to ease my pain over the Giants' loss to the Jets.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Meter's Off For the Holiday

title: Laura Rubenstein Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry G. Rubenstein of Gladwyn, Pa., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Meryl Rubenstein to Dr. Nir Barzilai, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Barzilai of Haifa, Israel.

title: Low Notes
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Barry Denies Interfering in an Inquiry
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry says it is purely coincidental that he visited a man at a hotel room while the police were checking allegations that the man had offered drugs to maids in exchange for sex.

title: THE MAKING OF PARADISE
description: HEAVEN A History. By Colleen McDannell and Bernhard Lang. Illustrated. 410 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BROTHERS IN ARMS. By Michael Carson. (Pantheon, $16.95.) This entertaining first novel is a young man's coming-of-age story with a twist. Our hero, Benson, is discovering his homosexuality. A 14-year-old English schoolboy in the years just after World War II, he is obsessed with sin, confession and guilt.

title: Marie McStocker to Wed Christopher J. P. Hulme
description: The engagement of Marie Ann McStocker to Christopher John Peers Hulme, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Peers Hulme of Dorchester, Dorset, England, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James McStocker of Southport, Conn.

title: When OPEC Prices Go to Yen per Barrel
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Critic's Choice: The Year's Best
description: LEAD: County diners have been lucky in that this area has managed to attract some excellent chefs to its unusually gracious restaurants. Although Manhattan may have a greater number of eating spots and a lion's share of top-notch waiting staff, nevertheless, county dining offers advantages that the city can never match.

title: Pervasive Protest by Palestinians Leaves Bethlehem a Joyless Place
description: None of the traditional lights or decorations were strung up around this hilltop Palestinian town this morning, the biblical birthplace of Jesus, as the Arab residents, most of them Christians, protested the continued Israeli rule and mourned the more than 300 dead of the yearlong uprising.

title: Drawings in Stamford, Herzl Emanuel in Westport
description: DRAWING used to be a means to an end and, for many artists, it still is. The product itself, however, has come up in the world. Connoisseurs of art take drawings as they come, valuing them for revealing aspects of an artist that can be obscured by painting or sculpture.

title: Some 'Facts' On South Africa
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A BOURGEOIS AMONG THE BOLSHEVIKS
description: TIME OF TROUBLES The Diary of Iurii Vladimirovich Got'e. Moscow: July 8, 1917 to July 23, 1922. Translated and edited by Terence Emmons. Illustrated. 513 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $39.50.

title: George Shiras Jr. to Wed Diana Morris
description: Announcement has been made by Charlotte B. Morris of Altoona, Pa., of the engagement of her daughter, Diana Lee Morris, to George P. Shiras Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Shiras of Lincoln, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Ultimate Elitist Event
description: To the Editor:

title: The Museum of Cartoon Art Spotlights The New Yorker
description: THE Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook is a serious place - perhaps a bit too serious. A guffaw from an adult visitor or squeals from frolicking children can sometimes be heard, but they aren't enough to disturb the ecclesiastical calm of an institution devoted to the preservation of jokes, old and new.

title: TALKING: Tax Relief; Many Eligible, Few Apply
description: THE end of an old year and the start of a new one is traditionally a time to reassess tax obligations. One area where savings may be achieved in 1989 is through programs for property-tax exemptions.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference With Elizabeth Dole
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of remarks by President-elect Bush and Elizabeth Hanford Dole at a news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: After 1, 2, 3 Kicks, Cleveland's Out
description: Every team has a collection of players who try to follow the bouncing ball on the onside kick.

title: Ancient Beasts Were Best in Shows
description: Antiquities - Greek, Roman, Etruscan and Chinese - enriched museum and gallery exhibitions, antiques fairs and auctions that were held throughout 1988. Mosaic floors from Carthage, frescoed walls from Pompeii, bronze vessels from China and Archaic period vases from Greece were the stars of some of the most innovative shows of ancient art seen hereabouts in decades.

title: 'Forever Plaid' Revisits the 50's
description: ''FOREVER PLAID,'' in which some 20 hit songs of the 1950's are tenuously strung together by a story line, operates under the delusion that it is a play.

title: POSTINGS: The Fingelly Award; Who, Me?
description: Each year the Fairfield Chamber of Commerce gives out something it calls the Nicholas H. Fingelly - remember him? - Award, honoring about 20 people for commendable construction and repairs. Anyone who spends lavishly on the restoration of an old building in the Connecticut town would probably be a candidate. But now the man doing exactly that, in the Village of Southport, is Nicholas H. Fingelly.

title: 'Singin' in the Rain' Performed in Darien
description: ONE expects a stage musical to entertain, but ''Singin' in the Rain'' has to do more. It has to justify its existence.

title: Christmas In the Making
description: AROUND HALLOWEEN, about the time the leaves burned at the curbside, my father set the clock ticking toward Christmas. Time changed, the temperature dropped and a pause settled on his workshop. From the basement, tobacco smoke curled up the stairs, bringing with it the sounds of pages turning in his old carpenters' magazines.

title: Ailing Man Helped by Neediest Cases
description: Ted Robinson plans to spend Christmas Day alone, listening to Nat (King) Cole on the radio or to Bing Crosby's ''White Christmas,'' or perhaps finding a rerun of ''I Love Lucy'' on television.

title: Now This Late Word on the Early Music Debate
description: The debate about the authentic performance of early music is shifting into a new gear. Previously the battle lines were drawn between those who espoused old instruments with their bright, plangent sounds, and those who preferred the greater sophistication of modern instruments; between those who believed in using the evidence of the past to arrive at original performance styles and those who believed in the continuity of modern performance techniques.

title: Out-of-Court Settlement Sought for Shoreham
description: LEAD: WREATHED in smiles, John D. Leonard Jr., the Long Island Lighting Company's vice president for nuclear operations, could not have looked more cheerful as he walked down a corridor in the company's Hicksville headquarters Dec. 2.

title: CULTURED CLUTTER IN A PARIS MUSEUM
description: When the Academy of Fine Arts flourished in France and painters treasured their links with the past, they often signaled their success by starting collections of their own. If they also married a rich woman, then they could buy enough to fill a small museum. That, in fact, is the story of Ernest Hebert, an artist of limited talent whose portraits were in great demand between 1840 and 1900. Today the house on the Left Bank of Paris in which his belongings are gathered is one of the city's least-visited museums.

title: Power of Presidency Is Still Power to Persuade; Look for Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Soup of Styles: The Specter of Pluralism Returns
description: Does anyone remember pluralism? That's what the art of the 1970's came to be called, largely by default. It consisted of a soup of styles, none of which dominated the rest, and which together seemed to add up to nothing in particular.

title: There's Nothing Like a Surprise or Two
description: PORT WaSHINGTON'S Cafe Le Monde presents more surprises than Christmas morning. Its name is French, its menu is eclectic, its owners are Iranian and its food is a crackling dose of the unexpected.

title: Paper Helps Reporters With a Boarding House
description: Hamilton and Helen Meserve have added a new dimension to the job description of a newspaper publisher -running a boarding house for reporters.

title: Elaine S. Gilde Plans to Marry
description: Elaine Sandra Gilde, a vice president in investment banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, and Richard Steven Green, a partner in the corporate department at the New York law firm of Myerson & Kuhn, plan to marry in April.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MINE ENEMY. By Amalia Barnea and Aharon Barnea. Translated by Chaya Amir. (Grove, $17.95.) At the end of ''Mine Enemy,'' Amalia and Aharon Barnea's account of how the Israeli couple come to respect and even love a Palestinian ''terrorist,'' the reader is left uncertain as to who the villains are in the Middle East. This is the measure of the success of the book, a best seller in Hebrew, now smoothly translated by Chaya Amir. ''Mine Enemy'' traces the Barneas' relationship with Lieut. Col. Salah Ta'mari, a commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization's forces who was captured during Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Mr. Barnea, the Arab affairs correspondent for Israel Radio, was offered the first interview; he arrived hot for the story but cold toward the colonel. He then had to reconcile his stereotype of a Palestinian with this student of T. S. Eliot who compares Zionists with Herod. If these are not complexities enough, Colonel Ta'mari is married to Dina Abd el-Hamid, the first wife of King Hussein of Jordan; some of the most disarming passages reflect the Barneas' gee-whiz attitude toward royalty. The journalists (she is a reporter for Yediot Aharonot, Israel's biggest newspaper) serve as go-betweens while Colonel Ta'mari is in jail, and win permission to take him on outings. Woven into the tale of unlikely friendship are biographies of the colonel and the queen, and eventually the Barneas' little girl is playing with Queen Dina's little grandson. This seems an obvious symbol for the brotherhood of man, but the Barneas serve it up without saccharine. Some of their analyses are simplistic: if the P.L.O. hides a military bunker under a hospital, can it protest the bombing of the hospital? But these do not detract from this readable description of the emotional morass of the Middle East.

title: Year After a Death, Town Is Still Split
description: To hear many white residents tell it, what happened here last Christmas is ancient history.

title: Couture Outfits For Chic Beagles
description: FASHION has gone to the dogs, all right. Snoopy, who wears only basic black and white in Charles M. Shultz's ''Peanuts'' comic strip, steps up to designer clothes in ''Snoopy in Fashion'' (Chronicle Books, $14.95).

title: Antismoking Law With Loose Teeth
description: WHEN it went into effect in January, it was called the most comprehensive ban in the nation against smoking in commercial transportation. A California law, it forbade smoking on airline flights that began and ended in the state and on all trains and buses operating in the state, regardless of their points of origin and destination.

title: Mara Mullen Engaged To Brenton R. Grant 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Rolf Mullen of South Egremont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mara Louise Mullen to Brenton Robinson Grant 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Jr. of Kennett Square, Pa. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Libya to Return a Body
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is willing to return the body of an American pilot killed in the 1986 air raid on Libya, the official Libyan press agency reported today. The body of Capt. Paul F. Lorence is to be given to his family ''through the Pope,'' said the agency.

title: THE RABBI, THE POET AND THE DROPOUT
description: BERNARD FOY'S THIRD CASTLING By Lars Gustafsson. Translated by Yvonne L. Sandstroem. 260 pp. New York: New Directions. $22.95.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE GM-TOYOTA TEAM;
Worker Harmony Makes Nummi Work
description: LEAD: The workers' revolution has finally come to the shop floor. The people who work on the assembly line have taken charge and have the power to make management do their jobs right.

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: Good enough to make me want to move back to New York. ALAN C. MILLER Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: Cutting to the Heart of the Way We Live Now
description: The theater year of 1988 opened with the falling of a chandelier and closed with the dropping of Robin Williams's pants.

title: Prospects; Deregulation Plus Five
description: Five years ago, a Federal District Court ordered the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's telephone monopoly. While some facets of the business have seen competition increase, critics contend that in others, costs have risen and service has deteriorated. The industry remains in flux, however, as companies move in and out of businesses. Four communications experts discuss what they see ahead for the next five years. William G. McGowan Chairman of MCI Communications Corporation.

title: The Sugar Plum Set Dresses Up
description: ONE of the few things more magical than watching the dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy at Christmas time is to go to a party onstage after ''The Nutcracker'' and actually meet her. It is also, of course, a rare opportunity to chat up Drosselmeier, who looks a little scary but is secretly a fun guy.

title: Washington Going Boating Again
description: AN icy wind whipped General Washington's cape as his boat crossed the Delaware to New Jersey. A ragtag assortment of oarsmen tried in vain to fight the current that swept them away from their intended landing site.

title: Slamming Doors + A Bright Idea - Farce
description: You don't declare farce in the same way that you might declare war, though I am very much afraid that is what Neil Simon is up to in ''Rumors.'' You will surely recall that, while Mr. Simon was churning out his long, long string of earlier successes, each new venture was announced in modestly sized type, like this:

title: Animal Rights Group Is Quiet in the Woods
description: Sometimes it is more difficult to get our points across to reporters than to hunters. Our anti-hunting actions in Connecticut's woodlands have never included ''making noise'' as we go (''Advocates of Animal Rights See Influence Grow in State,'' Nov. 27). To do so could, theoretically, frighten deer into the path of an unseen hunter, which, not surprisingly, is the last thing we want to do.

title: Real-Estate Market Bids Goodbye to Boom Times
description: WHETHER it is a house in Fairfield County or a condominium in Hartford, real estate in Connecticut is not selling as well it used to.

title: Psychiatrist Must Pay Woman $1.9 Million
description: A jury has ordered a psychiatrist to pay nearly $1.9 million to a patient with whom he had had sexual intercourse numerous times in 12 years, billing her for each visit.

title:
DINING OUT;
Delightful Fare Put Together With Flair
description: LEAD: LAST July 1, the husband and wife team of Wendy Farber and Brooks Niklas opened the doors of their first restaurant, called Park One Eleven, in Ridgewood. The name is due to the fact that the restaurant, which is on the main street in Ridgewood, is also opposite the local park.

title: BEST SELLERS: December 25, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 6 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 2 21 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 3 3 17 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride. 4 7 26 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 5 5 6 DEAR MILI, by Wilhelm Grimm. (di Capua/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) A recently discovered tale by the 19th-century folklorist, illustrated by Maurice Sendak. 6 6 8 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world. 7 4 10 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 8 9 10 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. 9 8 8 MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A writer's struggles with his heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai war. 10 * 11 14 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 11 10 11 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an ''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons. 12 12 45 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 13 1 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $18.95.) The agent Bernard Samson on the trail of a financial scam within the British secret service. 14 14 21 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to contemporary New York. 15 31 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 6 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 2 2 8 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 3 4 36 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 3 7 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 5 5 10 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 6 6 6 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 7 7 10 SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 8 8 3 CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An album of pictures taken by 100 photographers. 9 9 9 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 10 12 12 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 11 14 25 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 12 10 11 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 13 11 9 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 14 15 2 THE HOME PLANET, edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) How the earth looks from outer space, shown in 150 photographs. 15 8 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virginia roots. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 6 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 2 1 77 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 3 3 3 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 4 22 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 5 13 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) DANGER AND SURVIVAL: Choices About the Bomb in the First Fifty Years, by McGeorge Bundy. (Random House, $24.95.) A detailed, rigorously documented history and analysis of the political decisions in many countries that shaped the nuclear era. A SERIOUS CHARACTER: The Life of Ezra Pound, by Humphrey Carpenter. (Houghton Mifflin, $40.) Pound's latest biographer tells the life in its most extended detail, making skillful use of previous work, and especially of Pound's own writing and speech. THE QUESTION OF HU, by Jonathan D. Spence. (Knopf, $18.95.) Large issues of social control and the interpretation of alien cultures are raised in this scrupulous history of a Chinese man who came to Europe in 1722 and got shut up in a madhouse. JOAN MAKES HISTORY, by Kate Grenville. (British American, $17.95.) Joan, the first-person narrator of Ms. Grenville's brilliant third novel, acquaints us with several other Joans, all of whom, like herself, ''made history'' by confronting the destiny of being women in Australia, from 1770 to the present. THE RISK POOL, by Richard Russo. (Random House, $19.95.) Not just another novel about coming of age in a small town, ''The Risk Pool'' is an original and hilarious look at family, society and maturity that never collapses into nostalgia. TWO-PART INVENTION: The Story of a Marriage, by Madeleine L'Engle. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) The author's long marriage to the actor Hugh Franklin, who died in 1986, is described with a gravity and delicacy not often seen lately. THE LETTERS OF JACK LONDON, edited by Earle Labor, Robert C. Leitz 3d and I. Milo Shepard. (Stanford University, three volumes, $139.50.) More than 1,500 letters of the supercharged Californian who published 50 books in a life of only 40 years.

title: With Settlement by Drexel, Financier Now Stands Alone
description: The telephone call that Michael R. Milken had been dreading for more than two years came last Wednesday afternoon as he sat in his lawyer's office in midtown Manhattan.

title: When Leaving Brooklyn, Upstate Comes Quickly
description: TWELVE years ago I migrated from the bowels of Brooklyn into a pleasant, modern apartment just on the inner edge of the city of Peekskill. When I informed my city friends of my new home they invariably thought I had moved to Poughkeepsie.

title: A Better World
description: Recent years have seen an extraordinary development in world affairs, one largely unanticipated. That is the growth and acceptance of human rights as an international standard for the behavior of governments.

title: Rectory to be Home for Single Mothers
description: LEAD: THE rectory of St. Joseph's Church in Bridgeport will soon be converted into a transitional home for single mothers and their newborn babies, with the help of a $523,000 grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Vermont Water Department Is Cited for Lack of Testing
description: The North Bennington Water Department has been charged with failing to test water quality regularly since 1979.

title: NEW YORK, Etc.
description: MOST people, but not all, like Christmas a lot. They may forget the original purpose of the celebration, but somehow the goodwill that is supposed to permeate the air, does. Still, despite its almost universal popularity, it is not a holiday that generally remains fixed in the mind for anything other than sentimental reasons.

title: Beguiling Banditi
description: BIG DEAL ON MADONNA STREET Starring Marcello Mastroianni (at left in photo), Vittorio Gassman (at right) and Claudia Cardinale. Directed by Mario Monicelli. 1957 Connoisseur Video. $69.95. 91 minutes. In Italian, with English subtitles.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Friday's Games; Hornets Spoil Jordan's Return
description: Michael Jordan, who starred at the University of North Carolina before beginning his spectacular career in the National Basketball Association, received his expected welcome when the Chicago Bulls came to Charlotte.

title: For Sri Lanka, an Election With a Sense of Disintegration
description: MOST countries would consider it a triumph to have held an election with a 55 percent voter turnout while a guerrilla army roamed the land threatening to shoot anyone casting a ballot. Most Sri Lankans don't see it quite that way.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our home-built kitchen cabinets are covered with Formica and this is separating from the particle board underneath. I would like to refurbish these cabinets. I can either reglue the existing laminate, then apply another on top of that, or remove the Formica, then apply a new laminate directly to the particle board. Which is best?

title: When Addiction Strikes a Family
description: Having read your Nov. 13 Letters to the Long Island Editor in response to the article on the emancipation age of children, I want to relate what happened to my family when the disease of addiction entered our lives.

title: Lock-Gluer on Probation
description: Kamal hyder, 23 years old, has been placed on probation for five years and agreed to pay $9,800 for damages to seven campus buildings at the University of Massachusetts. Mr. Hyder, and Indian national, was given the terms by Judge Judge Clement Ferris in Northampton District Court Thursday. Mr. Hyder admitted that he used a liquid metal substance to glue the campus locks shut on Halloween 1987.

title: Fetal Sex Test Used as Step To Abortion
description: In a major change in medical attitudes and practice, many doctors are providing prenatal diagnoses to pregnant women who want to abort a fetus on the basis of sex alone.

title: 'NOBODY IS FREE IN LEBANON'
description: BEIRUT OUTTAKES A TV Correspondent's Portrait of America's Encounter With Terror. By Larry Pintak. 347 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books/D.C. Heath & Company. $18.95.

title: John M. Crawford Jr., 75, Dies; Eminent Collector of Chinese Art
description: John M. Crawford Jr., a prominent collector of Oriental art and a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Debra Fine Plans To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phil David Fine of Boston have made known the engagement of their daughter Debra Fine to Martin Ivar Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schneider of Manhasset, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: M. Elizabeth Pruett to Wed
description: The engagement of M. Elizabeth Pruett to John Kingston Herbert 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kingston Herbert Jr. of Milton, Mass., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Pruett of Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: Tide Edges Cadets in Sun Bowl
description: David Smith, Alabama's southpaw quarterback, set all kinds of passing records as the highly favored Crimson Tide rallied for a 29-28 victory today over a surprisingly strong Army team in the John Hancock Sun Bowl.

title: Lucky Day for the Ohio Valley's Jobless: New TV's and Work in Atlantic City
description: It was an unusual sight on a hot day in August when a convoy of 47 U-Haul trucks and trailers from the gritty coal and steel towns of the Ohio Valley pulled into the bright neon sprawl of Atlantic City.

title: New Calcutta; At Least Help the Homeless off the Street
description: Carols from a brass choir resound from the cavernous marble space. Shoppers cross beneath the star-pointed ceiling. Grandparents and college kids come and go on Amtrak. The giant color slide portrays an ''Old-Fashioned Holiday'' in a Colonial dining room. Grand Central Station bustles with holiday cheer.

title: Victoria
description: To the Editor: Had you not mentioned the Sooke Harbor House (''What's Doing in Victoria,'' Travel, Aug. 28) we would have missed a dining experience that was the highlight of our subsequent trip.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: The article by Barbara Cansino on ''Swiss Embroidery and Lace'' (Shopper's World, Nov. 20) was interesting but erroneously referred to ''16th-century St. Gallen in the canton of Appenzell.'' My 1982 Michelin guide to Switzerland states that ''The country of Appenzell and the great Alpine combe of the Toggenburg (Upper Thur Valley) are separated by an administrative borderline, for Appenzell has been a separate canton since 1513, while the Toggenburg is still under the control of St. Gallen as it was when the famous abbey was at the height of its power.''

title:
GARDENING;
Choosing the Right Hollies for Planting
description: LEAD: THE use of hollies at this time of year goes back to the Druids, who used evergreen leaves and red fruits in their rites for the winter solstice. Today, hollies contribute to the festive nature of the holiday season.

title: The Anatomy of A Swedish Victory
description: TWO strong contenders in the World Team Olympiad, which ended Oct. 22 in Venice, were Poland and Sweden. The Poles had won the title four years earlier in Seattle, but the Swedes were the reigning European champions. The round-robin qualifying match between the two teams was crucial, and thanks in part to the diagramed deal, the Swedes won the match and took the last qualifying position in their pool, just ahead of the Poles.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SLIGHTLY LIKE STRANGERS. By Emily Listfield. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) It takes a little while for Emily Listfield's third novel to move past the shadow of its immediate predecessor, ''Variations in the Night.'' But Sam Chapman and Amanda Easton, the hero and heroine of that novel, are rich characters, deserving of this sequel, and they remain intriguing and sharply drawn.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-16 Japan's most sweeping tax overhaul in 40 years passed its final legislative hurdle after a decade of failed efforts, months of maneuvering, and a 26-hour parliamentary session. Page 1 Bethlehem has seen few decorations and lights on this Christmas holiday, as the mostly Christian Arab residents protest against continued Israeli rule and mourn the more than 300 dead of the year-old uprising. 1 Jews are moving into the West Bank and living in new settlement houses just as fast as the houses can be built, despite the Palestinian uprising and the stones and firebombs that Arabs throw at Jewish settlers. 12 Bipartisanship in U.S. foreign policy appears to be returning after two decades of confrontation between Democrats and Republicans that began with the collapse of consensus over the war in Vietnam. 1 Armenia's earthquake children saw the shaking earth seal classmates in concrete. Many of them cannot sleep at night and often cry because they remember all too vividly what happened back home. 14 Final approval of the free-trade pact between Canada and the United States was voted by the House of Commons, effectively clearing the way for the agreement to go into operation as scheduled on Jan. 1. 6 The search for plane crash victims of Wednesday night's Pan Am disaster continued. The remains of 235 people have been found. 16 Britain, citing Ulster terrorism, keeps detention law 4 The economic decline in Nicaragua will continue as long as the Sandinistas pursue their current policies, a prominent economist predicted. Another economist said Washington bore primary responsibility for the problems. 8 Much of the open civil rights struggle in South Africa has fallen upon the Black Sash, an organization of middle-class white women who constitute one of the most effective protests against apartheid. 3 Soviets urge Afghan king to join talks on nation 3 NATIONAL/17-33 Elizabeth Hanford Dole was selected for Labor Secretary by President-elect Bush, who said she has the experience cope with a changing American work force. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. approved of the choice. 1 Woman in the news: Elizabeth Dole is a Washington veteran and a popular and respected figure withpoliticians of both parties, few of whom would be surprised if she someday sought elective office herself. 23 A feared moment for Michael Milken came when his firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert, decided to plead guilty to securities-related fraud, isolatating Mr. Milken as he prepares to face criminal charges. 1 Prenatal diagnoses are being given in increasing numbers to pregnant women who want to abort their fetuses on the basis of sex. The trend is a major change in medical attitudes and practice. 1 A year after a black man died of head injuries he suffered after being taken to the county jail in Hemphill, Tex., the incident and its aftermath remains a sore for many people. 18 Reports of physical and sexual abuse of foster children have been turned over to the Executive Board of the Nebraska Legislature for use by a recently formed investigative panel. 18 A farm workers union grape boycott has led to a tit-for-tat dispute in San Francisco: after the city endorsed the boycott, farm industry groups canceled convention bookings and a rural county urged residents to spend their money elsewhere. 19 There will never be enough tanks in Western Europe to offset the Soviet numerical superiority, military analysts say. So the Army is looking to technology to produce an array of antitank weapons to close the gap. 24 A commission to examine poverty along the lower Mississippi River is the focus of a black boycott over its racial makeup. All panelists of the Federal commission are white, while a third of the population to be studied is black. 30 Sale of the The Miami News to an out-of-state investor group was ''conceptually agreed'' to on Friday by Cox Enterprises. 29 Deaths from cold soar as homeless increase 26 Veterans of a U.S. spy ship look back with anger 33 Addicts get treatment at a clinic on wheels 43 Synthetic heroin seen as cause in 18 deaths 43 REGIONAL/34-39 New Jersey's first development plan for the entire state has been seriously weakened by concessions to farmers and builders in a revised draft announced last week, planning proponents said. 38 A Christmas Day baby with AIDS is remembered at Harlem Hospital Center, where he was born on Dec. 25, 1984, and died two months ago, becoming the hospital's longest surviving AIDS baby. 34 Suffolk County will buy 777 acres of wooded area in Montauk, L.I., for $17.1 million and make a watershed where a luxury-housing development had been proposed. 39 A judge has ordered Alton Maddox to pay New York State $1,000 in legal costs for filing a groundless complaint of racial discrimination last year against more than a dozen state judges and court administrators. 37 Running for comptroller is a better bet for many 34 The jobless children of Ohio Valley find new lives in a casino 34 A New Jersey barge company is charged with dumping sludge 49 Scientist warns of chemicals in sewage sludge 51

title: A Soft-Sell Convention For Performing Artists
description: Robert Gewald fielded questions dressed as Count Dracula. Thea Dispeker, another artist's representative, dispensed free fruit drops to the passing throngs. Dancers danced, actors acted, singers sang and musicians busily played their instruments on video screens perched every few feet. They were all part of the national convention of the Association of College, University and Community Arts Administrators - known to participants as Acucaa (a-koo-ka) -which met at the New York Hilton in Manhattan last week in all its frenetic glory.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BLOOD RUN. By Leah Ruth Robinson. (New American Library, $17.95.) Your fingers may itch to sneak a peak at the last pages of this ''medical suspense novel'' set in a fictional university hospital in New York, a huge institution that, thanks to Leah Ruth Robinson's quick and incisive descriptions, comes instantly alive.

title: Kim Dae Jung Asks Talks With North Korea
description: An opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, urged President Roh Tae Woo today to accept a North Korean call for political and military talks on easing tension on the peninsula.

title: Each Shout Does Count
description: There has always been talk of peace, probably since dim pre-history when people first organized to fight each other. Now, peace seems to be breaking out in many distant places, though in others people still insist on bloodshed and violence.

title: Nancy Oates Is Engaged
description: Nancy E. Oates, a probation officer with the United States District Court, Southern District of New York, and Peter H. Priest, a partner at the New York law firm of Davis Hoxie Faithfull & Hapgood, plan to marry in April. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Oates of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The future bridegroom is the son of Mary Priest of Skowhegan, Me., and the late William Priest.

title: Caren Osten to Wed in May
description: Caren Osten and Richard Gerszberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Gerszberg of Lakewood, N.J., plan to marry in May, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mrs. and Mrs. Bernard Osten of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced.

title: Sarah Polese Is to Marry
description: The engagement of Sarah Bradlee Polese to Joseph Vilsack Reineman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reineman of Tampa, Fla., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James K. Polese of Beverly Farms, Mass. The couple plan a June wedding.

title: Motor Skills
description: To the Editor:

title: The Meaning of Christmas
description: AS a child, I never believed in Santa Claus. No letter was sent off to the North Pole; cookies and milk were not left out for Santa.

title: Far-Flung World of Tea and Coffee Is at Home in Pleasantville
description: LEAD: Pull open the door against the dim December chill and enter a cozy, aromatic room. A handful of people inside bustle among chests of tea, sacks of coffee and blending equipment in a scene that evokes the turn of the century.

title: 2 Detroit Policemen Accused Of Making Dealer Eat Cocaine
description: Two police officers accused of forcing a drug dealer to eat 20 pieces of crack have been ordered tried on assault charges.

title: Credit Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Help for Indian Charities
description: He is a familiar sight to Mount Kisco residents, plodding slowly but purposefully down Main Street, through Leonard Park and along Grove Street, pushing the bright yellow wheelbarrow with Mount Kisco's Indian chief emblem painted on one side.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: WHEN he was certain that the shadows were only shadows, the fox stepped away from the pines and started across the cornfield. Walking, sometimes trotting, he navigated the long, empty rows, testing the world around him with eyes and ears and nose - which, as any red fox will tell you, are the finest in the world.

title: The Jingle of Holiday Spending
description: LEAD: Christmas is the season of giving and getting, a time when the jangling of coins is as loud as the jingling of bells. Americans are expected to spend about $37 billion this year on Christmas gifts, or about $325 per family, according to the Conference Board, a New York business research organization.

title: Whatever Became of Cereal?
description: THE other day, I was at the grocery store in the cereal aisle and it took me about 10 minutes to spot the cornflakes. They were not mis-stocked or pushed way in the back behind something else. It just took me that long to find the ''normal breakfast cereal'' section. You know, the area where the basic corn, oat, wheat and bran cereals are kept.

title: HOMELESS FAMILIES TO GET NEW LINEN
description: Thousands of New York City families who have been without housing may find their new homes a little warmer and a little cozier next year because of a multimillion-dollar pledge of corporate concern and charity.

title: Scientist Warns of Chemicals in Sewage Sludge
description: One of the organic pollutants in sewage sludge does not decompose when composted, a study has found. The finding could be important as Connecticut seeks ways to dispose of the 60,000 tons of sludge generated in the state annually.

title: 'Live From Lincoln Center': TV on a High Wire
description: It wasn't until 7:45 p.m. that the tenor Placido Domingo happened to notice the spectacularly unsightly crease in his white tuxedo vest. Ordinarily, a crease might not seem cause for alarm, but this time television close-ups were involved: in exactly 15 minutes he was to step out onto the stage of Avery Fisher Hall. There, before the New York City Opera orchestra, he would sing ''Amor ti vieta'' live before a national audience of several million viewers tuned to the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Miss Roggenburg To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Roggenburg Jr. of Todt Hill, S.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Mary Josephine Roggenburg to Franz Josef Balve, a son of Dr. Rudolf Balve of Krefeld, West Germany, and the late Countess Kristin von Wengersky Balve. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE NATION: Rise of 'Soft Money'; Even in Defeat, the Party Prospered
description: FORTY of the Democratic Party's biggest givers regrouped here one day this month to decide what to do.

title: Ex-Klansman Pleads Guilty To Disrupting Blacks' March
description: A former Ku Klux Klan leader has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor conspiracy charge involving a 1979 gunfight and brawl between Klansmen and black marchers.

title: Pension Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Veteran of 5 Administrations
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole has had a highly successful public career since arriving in Washington from Harvard. Woman in the News, page 23.

title: POSTINGS: Monmouth Square; New for Route 36
description: Beachgoers know Route 36 as a cursed stretch of road, cursed mostly by beachgoers. It is the only road that leads from the New Jersey Shore at Long Branch to the Garden State Parkway, the only road worth mentioning that leads to points north. So the end of a hot summer day usually provides drivers time to simmer over hot asphalt.

title: Cleaning and Protecting Metal
description: CLEANING metal and protecting it against rust or corrosion are important, whether the surface is to be painted or left uncoated.

title: C.I.A. Employee Is Reported To Have Been on Flight 103
description: A United States official said tonight that the victims of the crash of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 on Wednesday might have included an employee of the Central Intelligence Agency's station in Beirut, Lebanon.

title: 'Big Steel' Bets the Future on Its Indiana Mills
description: Along the shores of Lake Michigan, four sprawling mills produce nearly a quarter of the nation's raw steel - in a fraction of the time and with far fewer people than it took at the start of the decade.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bratenahl, Ohio; Lakeside Blend Of Old and New
description: A LOCAL developer has begun a $1 million renovation of a historic mansion in this suburb just east of Cleveland as the first phase of a $60 million, 75-acre residential development along the Lake Erie shore. The project, called Newport, promises to bring the community its the first major addition of housing in 20 years.

title: DATA BANK: December 25, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY

title: CART Export Plan Is Stalled
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams has hit a major trade barrier in the sanctioning body's efforts to export Indy car racing abroad.

title: Something New for New Year's Eve
description: LEAD: ON New Year's Eve, Montclair's central business district will be the site of an enormous celebration, featuring 47 performing ensembles in 18 locations.

title: Romney Marsh
description: To the Editor: The article about Romney Marsh (Travel, Aug. 28) by Benedict Nightingale has just come to my attention. One or two minor misconceptions about the Marsh hardly detract from a delightful and wide-ranging account of this lovely landscape. Your readers may be interested to know that the ''main road, cutting inland'' is not on the top of an ancient wall - straight as a die, it is the 13th-century canal cut to preserve the port of New Romney - unsuccessfully, as Mr. Nightingale also tells.

title: CHECK YOUR ANGST AT THE CLOAKROOM
description: LEAD: DISLOCATIONS By Janette Turner Hospital. 210 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $16.95.

title: Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon's Fraud-Hunters Called More Effective
description: The Pentagon's inspector general has reported that 596 companies were barred from doing business with the military in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

title: Rethinking the Arms Complex
description: TOP officials of the Energy Department have recently spoken candidly about how decades of mismanagement and sloppiness produced a record of pollution and disrepair in the nuclear weapons industry that almost defied comprehension. Their aim was to draw public and Congressional attention to the crippled industry -and the funds to repair it.

title: For a Little Girl in a Christmas Past, The Toys Were Almost Forgotten
description: ONE morning in the 1940's I awakened to an unexpected panorama of white. The season's first snowfall had made Christmas morning a winter wonderland, and with 7-year-old glee, I bounded from bed and alerted the household.

title: Is This Christmas Too Merry for the Economy to Take?
description: WITH retail sales having probably broken holiday-season records this year - though not by much - there are smiles all around.

title: Dr. Irving Sigal, Molecular Biologist, 35
description: Dr. Irving Sigal, senior director of molecular biology at the Merck Sharp & Dohme Research Laboratories in Rahway, N.J., was killed in the crash of Pan American World Airways Flight 103 on Wednesday. He was 35 years old and lived in Pennington, N.J.

title: Drexel Decides On a Guilty Plea
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert agreed to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay a $650 million fine to resolve a Federal investigation of securities- law violations. The largest-ever settlement came in a two-year-old case that centered on Drexel's dealings with the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky, who is serving a prison term for insider trading. Drexel's board voted 16 to 6 to accept the settlement. The firm's chief executive, Frederick H. Joseph, voted against the deal but then had to try to put the best face on it, both to the press and to Drexel employees, who were said to be bitterly divided. The strongest opposition reportedly came from associates of Michael R. Milken, the trader who created ''junk bond'' financing of big takeovers and made Drexel a Wall Street powerhouse. It is widely expected that Mr. Milken, who was not mentioned in the settlement and has denied any wrongdoing, will be indicted soon. Largely because of Mr. Milken, Drexel has been highly profitable in recent years and the big fine is not expected to pose a financial problem. The settlement also avoids a long trial on much more serious charges, including racketeering. Nevertheless, a guilty plea is expected to cost Drexel some customers and encourage lawsuits against the firm. The settlement still has to be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department. *

title: In Midst of Uprising, Jewish Settlers Keep Arriving
description: The brightly colored road sign on the highway to Nablus says: ''Come Visit Eli. We're Building!'' And up a dirt road, 20 Jewish families live in pleasant tract homes not much larger than trailers.

title: Winter Training
description: In a high-tech training facility, deep beneath the University of Massachusetts Medical Center, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd has begun throwing a baseball in hopes of getting back into the starting rotation of the Boston Red Sox.

title: The North Poles Of the Postal Service
description: THE geometer says there is one North Pole. The geologist says there are two. The United State Postal Service says there are three.

title: Slay Inflation With Rapid Growth
description: Interest rates and the supposed trade-off between faster growth and higher inflation will be a problem for President Bush in 1989. His ''flexible freeze'' program to reduce the budget deficit requires lower interest rates - which reduce the cost of the existing deficit - and faster growth, which increases revenue. But the decision makers at the Federal Reserve Board fear that faster growth will cause inflation. As a result, the Fed has pushed up short-term interest rates more than two percentage points since March in an effort to slow the economy.

title: POSTINGS: The Ritz Plaza; Off Broadway
description: Rising amid the cacophony of office and hotel construction in the Times Square area is a new place to live. But despite its East Side-hotel pretensions, the Ritz Plaza apartment house at 235 West 48th Street, west of Broadway, might not have been possible had its developer not made use of his theatrical setting and two government programs.

title: Hospital Treats Headache Sufferers
description: JACQUIE McCARY was curled up on the couch in the lounge of Greenwich Hospital watching television, when the flowers arrived. Her boss had sent them, along with a cheery note. And recalling all the times she had left work early, or had not made it in at all, Mrs. McCary smiled and shook her head in surprise.

title: Two Cheers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pound of Black Feathers
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD BOYS AND CORONETS
description: MASK OF TREACHERY By John Costello. 765 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Mexico Cruises Overbooked; Computer Cited
description: Admiral Cruises has overbooked its winter and spring Mexico sailings this season, leaving hundreds of passengers without berths despite having had reservations confirmed.

title: Indy Fisher to Wed Tyler Callaway; Susan Fisher Engaged to Paul Nannig
description: The engagement of Melinda Grace Fisher to Tyler Callaway and of her younger sister, Susan Elaine Fisher, to Paul Raymond Nannig has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Fisher of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New Suffolk, L.I., parents of the future brides. Summer weddings are planned.

title: Who Cares About Emma?
description: LEAD: Fifteen years ago, as a newly minted Columbia graduate student, I moved into an apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. At that time, long before it would find infamy as ''crack alley,'' the block was a quirky stretch of schoolyard, warehouses, tenements and a Roman Catholic nursing home whose courtyard was graced by a huge oak.

title: The Earthquake Children: Still Afraid but Resilient
description: The physical therapy room in Sanitarium No. 3 of this Armenian resort town is filled with dolls and crayons and dark-haired children who chatter and laugh during long play periods.

title: Julie A. Steinberg, Graduate Student, Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Steinberg of Merion, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie Ann Steinberg to Second Lieut. John Batterson Stetson 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stetson 4th of Haverford, Pa. The couple plan to wed in September.

title: THE WORLD: Lessons of the Quake; Through Shock After Shock, Gorbachev Keeps His Feet
description: IT is not hard to imagine Mikhail S. Gorbachev, an inveterate stock-taker, sitting down to calculate the effects of the past two weeks on his own standing as a leader, and concluding that on balance he had made the best of a dreadful situation.

title: Chicken Pox
description: You bring your sick child to an emergency room. The receptionist takes one look and hustles you away from other waiting patients. You are put into a special precaution room at the far end of the emergency ward separated from the corridor by double doors festooned with warning signs. The nurse warns you against letting the child leave the room under any circumstances. There will be a wait, she tells you; the one doctor who is available right now won't see your child.

title: Have Art, Will Travel
description: Given the record prices being paid for fine art these days, Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza might never be able to sell his huge collection as a unit. But he has found a way to rent out a big chunk of it. Baron Thyssen last week signed an agreement with the Spanish Government under which 862 paintings from his 1,400-work collection - regarded as the largest and most valuable in private hands - will go on display in Spain for 10 years and perhaps remain there permanently. The paintings are expected to be moved to Madrid in 1990 from the Baron's villa in Switzerland. The Baron will head a Spanish-financed foundation to oversee the collection and be paid $5 million a year for the life of the agreement.

title: Oilers Knock Off Browns in Rematch
description: The Houston Oilers survived the great outdoors, the road and three final onside kicks today to topple the Browns, 24-23, in the American Conference wild-card playoff game.

title: Passaic Basin Flood Plan Faces Opposition
description: AN $847 million plan developed by the Army Corps of Engineers to eliminate flooding in the Passaic River Basin has given rise to a dispute that threatens to doom the project before it has even begun.

title: USING CREDIT CARDS TO SAVE MONEY BY SPENDING
description: Business travelers may pay top dollar for service and convenience, but their companies aren't always happy about soaring costs. By last July, travel prices had risen by 4.4 percent, a point above the consumer price index, according to the U.S. Travel Data Center.

title: CHILDREN OF CHOICE
description: All of the reasons that Katha Pollitt and her friends give for having had an abortion add up to the same thing: me; me first. What does it say for our generation when we feel that our lives should not be interrupted by inconvenience? Are we being taught that we can respond to any problem by restructuring the environment to suit our needs? Part of being an adult is taking responsibility for one's actions. SHERRY MAILLIEZ New Providence, N.J.

title: Why Aren't You Sweating, Jane? Leave Me Alone!
description: I LOATHE Jane Fonda. It has nothing to do with her political opinions or competence as a film star. In fact, she used to be someone I admired.

title: Finding Gold in Overalls and Bibs
description: When Michael M. Searles needs ideas for his business, he observes the habits of his young children. Recently, for instance, his 4-year-old son came home from school with the velcro tabs crisscrossed on his sneakers. When Mr. Searles tried to tell his son that he had his sneakers on wrong, the boy replied that all the ''cool kids'' at school wore them that way.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Barnum Starring Burt Lancaster, Hanna Schygulla, the Royal Hanneford Circus. Directed by Lee Philips. 1986. Academy Home Entertainment. 100 minutes. $79.95. Not rated.

title: Good Things From Small Labels
description: Assembling best-records lists every year, one notices recurrent patterns. We are still in a period of massive reissues by the major classical companies of their long-playing-record catalogues onto compact disks. Thus any selection of the best new recordings of the year might seem tilted artificially toward smaller companies.

title: St. John's Upset by Niagara
description: Andy Walker, the Niagara coach, said he knew in practice this week that his team was not going to be routed when it took the court against St. John's.

title: Freshman Wins Two Events
description: Ian Jones, a New York State champion when he was a senior last year at Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, won the men's 600-yard run in 1 minute 11.95 seconds today at the Reebok Christmas Classic track meet in the Army field house. He returned later and anchored the Concord Track Club to victory in the 1,600-meter relay with a 48.5 seconds 400 split.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Reindeer and Rock-and-Roll
description: LEAD: Until man drew a border between Alaska and Siberia, humans and animals moved freely from continent to continent. In 1948 the Iron Curtain severed this ancient unity, and for the next 40 years only animals dared to cross the border. In 1988, with Moscow's blessing, a few Alaskan Eskimos visited again their Siberian kin.

title: Addicts Get Treatment At a Clinic on Wheels
description: At 6:30 A.M., with the city still blanketed by darkness, a 22-foot Winnebago motor home drives into its usual parking spot at the police station here to dispense methadone to heroin addicts.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our home-built kitchen cabinets are covered with Formica and this is separating from the particle board underneath. I would like to refurbish these cabinets. I can either reglue the existing laminate, then apply another on top of that, or remove the Formica, then apply a new laminate directly to the particle board. Which is best?

title: Lynne McGraw To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. McGraw of Bedminster, N.J., and Gulf Stream, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynne A. McGraw to Robert Lester Starkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Starkey of Downey and Pomona, Calif.

title: THE GOOD MOTHER LIZARD
description: DIGGING DINOSAURS By John R. Horner and James Gorman. Illustrated by Donna Braginetz and Kris Ellingsen. 210 pp. New York: Workman Publishing. $17.95. PREDATORY DINOSAURS OF THE WORLD A Complete Illustrated Guide. By Gregory S. Paul. 464 pp. New York: A New York Academy of Sciences Book/Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: BOYCOTT BACKLASH IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: The United Farm Workers' boycott of table grapes has led to a tit-for-tat dispute here: after politicians here endorsed Cesar Chavez's union, farm industry groups canceled convention bookings and a rural county in central California urged its residents to spend their money elsewhere.

title: Sheila M. Matthews to Wed in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Elmer M. Matthews of Bernardsville and Sea Girt, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Sheila Marie Matthews to John J. Goggins 3d, a son of Myra M. Goggins of the Bronx and Mr. Goggins Jr. of Dover, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth Ann Marciw To Marry R. H. Griffin
description: Announcement of the engagement of Elizabeth Ann Marciw to Robert H. Griffin has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Steve Marciw of Pocono Manor, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

title: Karel Littman to Wed Dr. R. L. Weinshank
description: Karel Joyce Littman and Dr. Richard L. Weinshank plan to be married in March, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Littman of Teaneck, N.J., have announced. Dr. Weinshank is a son of Zelda Weinshank of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Herman Weinshank.

title: Film to Tell of 3 Chinese Women in Manhattan
description: With the burning of incense to insure success, Hong Kong film makers have started making a movie on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Taxes Will Rise By Average of 9% For Homeowners
description: Property taxes will rise an average of 9 percent next year for Westchester homeowners as a result of the approval of a $930 million operating budget by the Board of Legislators last week. The Board approved the measure by a vote of 14 to 3 after cutting $1.79 million from County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed spending plan.

title: Suffolk County to Buy a 777-Acre Watershed
description: Suffolk County will pay $17.1 million to purchase and preserve as a watershed a 777-acre wooded area here where a luxury housing development had been proposed.

title: Music School Head Quits
description: Dr. Gideon Waldrop, president of the Manhattan School of Music since July 1986, announced his resignation Wednesday at a meeting of the school's board of directors. Until a successor is named, the school is to be directed by the board. A spokesman for the school said the resignation was the result of disagreements between Dr. Waldrop and members of the board. Dr. Waldrop has not been available for comment.

title: American Diva Italian Style
description: Onstage at the Metropolitan Opera house, her short, chunky figure is encased in the kind of trompe l'oeil drapery that opera couturiers use to flatter a soprano's waist while letting her big ribcage heave. Her red-brown hair is pinned back, hidden under a wig of pale yellow, intricately arranged curls. The Bette Midler-ish face is not plain, not beautiful, not young, not old; its mutable expressions shade from tragic nobility to haute glamour.

title: In the End, Plenty to Laugh About
description: While 1988 was pushing its way from January to December, it never seemed an especially funny year. It was a grind. There wasn't time to analyze what was happening since there were too many movies to be looked at: 419 this year compared to 388 in 1987. This sets a new record for the Reagan decade, one that will probably stick, since, according to trade observers, the production boom prompted by the home video market has peaked.

title: Getting to Heart of Christmas
description: CHRISTMAS should be more than a momentary carol-induced intoxication, or, although it's a start, a nebulous yearning for peace on Earth brought on by falling snow at twilight, or the shining face of a child.

title: Judge Bars Videotape as Evidence in Police Killing
description: A judge has barred the prosecution from using as evidence an incriminating videotaped statement obtained from one of four men charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer in Queens.

title: Maddox is Ordered to Pay $1,000 For Filing a False Bias Complaint
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr. has been ordered by a Federal judge in Manhattan to pay New York State $1,000 in legal costs for filing a groundless complaint of racial discrimination last year against more than a dozen state judges and court administrators.

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: I don't believe that there is another team in the N.B.A. that can stack up to the Knicks' lineup if you take into account the bench players. Mark Jackson and Rod Strickland form the best 1-2 punch in the point guard position in the league. At the shooting guard position they have two guys, Gerald Wilkins and Trent Tucker, who could start on a lot of N.B.A. teams.

title: Finding a Home For Poison Gas
description: FOR the last three years, Randall Kelley, president and founder of the Phoenix Research Corporation in La Mesa, Calif., has known how it feels to be an outcast.

title: Fraser Nelson to Wed C. D. Roberts in June
description: Jenifer Fraser Nelson and Christopher David Roberts plan to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Norman F. Nelson of Mahwah, N.J., and Brookhaven, L.I., have announced. Mr. Roberts is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Wilfred Roberts of Grand Haven, Mich.

title:
GARDENING;
Choosing the Right Hollies for Planting
description: LEAD: THE use of hollies at this time of year goes back to the Druids, who used evergreen leaves and red fruits in their rites for the winter solstice. Today, hollies contribute to the festive nature of the holiday season.

title: On Mass Transit And Judges
