description: The Nov. 20 Long Island section raised important issues confronting Long Island and especially Suffolk County.

title: Stocks That Have Nowhere to Go but Up
description: The stocks of computer-chip manufacturers have reached historic lows and have nowhere to go but up, a growing number of analysts say. ''They've hit bottom,'' said Thomas P. Kurlak, an influential analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. Mr. Kurlak, who was considered the biggest bear on the semiconductor stocks, turned positive about 10 days ago, helping move the stocks upward last week. Millard H. Phelps, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist Inc. in San Francisco, added: ''We have more positive times ahead.''

title: Search for Victims Continues at Scene of Air Crash
description: More than 600 police officers, soldiers and investigators today continued the search for victims of Wednesday night's crash of a Pan American World Airways jet.

title: Videocassettes Planned of 50's TV Variety Series
description: Performances remembered become better with time, the beneficiaries of a verdict of perfection that no one can disprove. Which makes it all the more fascinating to contemplate the testing of one's memory against performances from ''The Bell Telephone Hour,'' the celebrated television variety series of some 30 years ago, which are about to be released on videocassette.

title: FIZZY
description: My ironclad rule for New Year's Eve is to dine with just a few good friends. Although many of these evenings have been spent away from home, I usually find myself in one kitchen or another, preparing a meal to herald the New Year.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: KWANZAA CELEBRATION In Swahili, ''Kwanzaa'' means ''first fruits,'' signifying the celebration of a bountiful harvest. Adopted by American blacks, the festival has been adapted into a cultural affirmation.

title: Karen Fisher Engaged To Thomas M. Misisco
description: Announcement has been made by Lyn Schwartz and Arnold L. Fisher, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Fisher, to Thomas Mahon Misisco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Misisco of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY OPINIONBusiness-Arts Partnership CreatesA 'Quiet Revolution' in New Jersey
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S reputation as a ''cultural wasteland'' is clearly out of date, not that it was ever deserved anyway. Today, the state is considered a national model of arts development. In a pro-arts climate advanced by Governor Kean, there are tremendous opportunities for corporations to sponsor arts events - to engage in cultural and community needs.

title: Barton A. Lund, a Financial Analyst, To Marry Julie Marie Andre in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Pratt Johnson of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Johnson's daughter, Julie Marie Andre, to Barton Alexander Lund, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marquard H. Lund, also of Montclair. The wedding is planned for June 24.

title: DYNAMIC DUO: Kevin Eastman and Peter Laird; Turning Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Into a Monster
description: Here is Kevin Eastman, comic book artist and entrepreneur, describing the planning session with his partner, Peter Laird, that gave birth to a best-selling Christmas toy and a multimillion-dollar licensed-products business.

title: Slime? Don't Worry! The Ghostbusters Are Back
description: At the intersection of First Avenue and 77th Street, two men crouch on the pavement, scanning the area with their hand-held meters. ''I'm measuring 2.5 G.E.V.'s,'' one of them exclaims. ''I've got 1.18 on the P.K.E.,'' the other says breathlessly.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: December 25, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 6 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 8 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 4 4 SILVER ANGEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A kidnapped Englishwoman finds romance in a pasha's harem. 5 4 THE MASK, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.50.) The horrors that befall a couple after they adopt an attractive teen-ager. 6 8 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 7 14 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) (Bantam, $4.95.) The television star muses on life at 50. 3 5 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 4 28 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 5 31 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 6 270 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 2 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.) Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Warner, $5.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 2 13 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 1 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1989. (World Almanac/Pharos Books, $6.95.) Its 121st year. 4 4 SEPARATED AT BIRTH? by the editors of Spy. (Spy/Dolphin/Doubleday, $6.95.) Humorous juxtapositions of celebrities' pictures. 5 15 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: MIAMI NEWS'S SALE IS TENTATIVELY SET
description: Cox Enterprises ''conceptually agreed'' Friday to sell The Miami News to an out-of-state investor group, but no contract has been signed, the newspaper reported today.

title: Reborn Spirit of Downtown: A Second First Night
description: GREGG JABLONSKY has about 500 volunteers working for him, and he could have used another one to answer the phone that rang incessently in the cluttered headquarters of First Night Stamford Inc. at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza.

title: Barge Company Accused of Dumping Sewage
description: The State Attorney General has accused a Bayonne barge company of dumping tens of thousands of tons of raw sewage sludge into New York Harbor and surrounding waterways since at least mid-September.

title: Stephanie M. Kaplan, Teacher, Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David E. Kaplan of Longport, N.J., and Warren, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie M. Kaplan to Peter L. Goodkind, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Robert Goodkind of Rye, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: At Notre Dame, Losses Bred Leaders
description: Mark Green decided to go east to college. He could have gone most anywhere, and he chose Notre Dame. But when Green came home to Riverside, Calif., for the holidays four years ago, he felt much more than one year removed from being a consensus high school all-American. He had experienced a season of unexpected mediocrity.

title: POSTINGS: The Dinosaur Lives in Stamford; A Reprieve for the Corporate Campus
description: The two-building corporate campus that Gerald D. Hines Interests began building last week in Stamford will delay the end of an era in lower Fairfield County, says the project manager, Tommy Craig. When urban planning sentiment soured on the suburban office campus, community zoning decisions followed. And Stamford's campus design district, vintage 1950's, is, by now, practically out of room.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 11 about the increasing use of cellular telephones misstated the basic monthly service fee charged by Metro Mobile of Norwalk. The fee is $38, and there is a charge of 26 cents to 38 cents a minute for each call, depending on the time of day. There is an extra charge for calls placed out of state.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bedminster $141,500 42 Foxwood Court 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old condominium town house; fireplace, c/a, w/w carpeting, $150 monthly maintenance; taxes $1,458. East Windsor $234,900 33 Sheffield Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; patio, new kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $2,805. Hamilton Township $230,000 5 Lohli Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 9-year-old colonial; finished basement, separate in-law suite, hardwood floors; taxes $3,104. Manalapan $167,500 26 Pease Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, patio, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,500. Ringwood $279,000 51 Dewey Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; deck, new kitchen, basement; taxes $5,322. South Orange $175,000 356 Meadowbrook Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, enclosed porch, formal dining room; taxes $2,791. OTHER AREAS Bloomfield, Conn. $164,900 20 Clover Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; new deck, open-floor plan, 88- by 159-foot lot; taxes $1,885. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $450,000 Deertrack Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; den, solarium, 2.8 acres; taxes $7,926. Garden City, L.I. $405,000 4 Birch Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old center-hall colonial; fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,900.

title: INSIDE
description: Quake's Psychic Wounds Soviet psychologists have begun treating the tens of thousands of Armenian earthquake evacuees, including many children, and say the survivors will carry long-term psychological scars. Page 14. Canada Backs Trade Pact The House of Commons gave final approval to the Canada-United States free-trade agreement that is to go into effect Jan. 1. The vote was 141 to 111. The United States has already ratified the accord. Page 6. U.S. Priests and Morale A panel of Catholic bishops says many priests are overworked, lonely and sexually troubled. Page 18.

title: Motor Skills
description: To the Editor: The Nummi article raises questions that - in view of recent concern for business ethics - managers may now be willing to consider.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MISSIONARIES. By Norman Lewis. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.)The British travel writer Norman Lewis attempts in ''The Missionaries'' to chastise those fundamentalist Christians who, Mr. Lewis claims, justify destroying Latin American Indian cultures in the name of salvation. Mr. Lewis's anger derives from such facts as that in order to convert many tribes, including the Panare Indians of Venezuela, missionaries have found it necessary to introduce the foreign concepts of ''sin, guilt, punishment and redemption'' by ''re-editing the Scriptures in such a way as to implicate the Panare in

title: Holiday Shopping
description: The Dallas Cowboys are considering an offer from the Dallas Mavericks' owner, Donald Carter, to buy the football team for $130 million.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: A Concern for Pride; Despite New Efforts, Japan Avoids Making Peace With the War
description: IN the three months Emperor Hirohito has been gravely ill, there is one question few Japanese have asked or answered: How will his reign be remembered?

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Washington Township Going Commercial
description: LEAD: IN the last two decades, home buyers have flocked to Gloucester County's Washington Township for the new residential developments that have risen within its 24 square miles. Last year, it ranked first among the state's 567 municipalities in housing activity, with 1,140 permits issued for dwelling units; this year, by

title: Two Weddings Are Planned in the Jablons Family
description: Elissa Beatrice Sarah Jablons and Matthew Charles Bernstein are planning a March wedding, and the future bride's older brother, Joshua Samuel Jablons, is planning to marry Cynthia Rachel Green in May. The engagements have been announced by the parents of the future brides, Beverly Jablons of New York and Jordan Jablons of Milford, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Green of Greensboro, N.C.

title: Woman Bishop Has Episcopal Support
description: To the Editor:

title: PC and Mainframes, in Concert
description: Imagine Uncle Fud's face on Christmas morning when he opens the box and discovers OS/2 Extended Edition version 1.1 with Presentation Manager. ''G-g-golly, how nice,'' he stammers in the voice of someone who was expecting a puppy and got a 500-pound gorilla instead. ''It's what I've always needed. And my, it's so, well, big!''

title:
GARDENING;
Choosing the Right Hollies for Planting
description: LEAD: THE use of hollies at this time of year goes back to the Druids, who used evergreen leaves and red fruits in their rites for the winter solstice. Today, hollies contribute to the festive nature of the holiday season.

title: Students Get Taste Of a Doctor's Life
description: Robert Berg, a first-year medical student, watched as the weathered Tarrytown physician examined a newborn baby. Suddenly, the doctor placed the infant in the young man's arms.

title: White South African Women Step Off Their Pedestals to Fight Apartheid
description: Four mornings a week, the hard wooden benches at the Black Sash advice office here overflow with the bewildered, the desperate and the defeated.

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: The Knicks will definitely make the playoffs, but look for them to lose against Detroit. I can just see it now. Ewing gets into foul trouble and sits out half the game. Jackson starts taking wild shots. Oakley makes a couple of turnovers and is ejected for fighting with Laimbeer. Pitino uses all the Knicks timeouts just to calm the team down.

title: A Career in the Capital; Woman in the News: Elizabeth Hanford Dole
description: In naming Elizabeth Hanford Dole today as his Secretary of Labor, President-elect Bush was continuing what has become something of a Washington tradition. Presidents since Lyndon B. Johnson have bestowed titles on Mrs. Dole, a 52-year-old lawyer and former Democrat. Since arriving in

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Rehabilitation Funds Freed
description: LEAD: A FEDERALLY financed rental rehabilitation program has overcome early local administrative and marketing problems and will dole out nearly $1 million in redevelopment funds this year.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Plaza Theater; Is the Reel Running Out for a Converted Stable?
description: DEMOLITION work has begun on a handful of small buildings on the north side of 57th Street between Madison and Park Avenues in anticipation of a new commercial project that William Zeckendorf Jr. is developing.

title: Why Drug Arrests Are a Big Production
description: THE television cameras were rolling in Upper Manhattan last week as 150 heavily armed New York City police officers, Federal marshals and agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration descended on three apartment buildings.

title: Legal Gambling Sails to Texas Aboard a Ship
description: A 257-foot ship has brought legal casino gambling to Texas simply by sailing to a Mexican fishing village just south of the border.

title: An Era Ends: Gov. O'Neill Is Selling Family Tavern
description: THE East Hampton tavern that has been in Governor O'Neill's family for 52 years is closed today for Christmas and will reopen tomorrow to serve a few rounds on the house to regular customers. And when the bar closes Tuesday evening, that will be the end of O'Neill's Tap Room.

title: DOWN THE MOLE HOLE WITH BERNARD
description: SPY HOOK By Len Deighton. 292 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: PRESERVING BORNEO'S TRADITIONS
description: On the remote island of Borneo, farmers still appeal to the spirit of the rice paddy; communities continue to live in longhouses; people collect birds' nests from the roofs of caves; orangutans play in the rain forests, and orchids grow wild by the wayside.

title: A New Goal for The Peace Movement
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's dramatic announcement of arms cutbacks has left United States analysts grappling with Lenin's old question: ''What is to be done?'' Some argue that the West should simply stand pat and ask for even deeper cuts, while proceeding with planned ''modernization'' of its nuclear weapons in Europe. Others suggest that we should respond with comparable reductions.

title: Alla Pozniakov Wed To Eric Jay Raiten
description: Alla Pozniakov, who is studying for a master's degree in computer science at the University of California at Berkeley, and Eric Jay Raiten, a doctoral candidate in theoretical physics at the California Institute of Technology, were married last evening. Rabbi C. Nate Segal, assisted by Cantor Neil Ben-Isvy, performed the ceremony at the Marlboro (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title: WHO SKIS?
description: Jon Bowermaster's article ''Who Skis?'' (Nov. 27) might have been called ''Skiing in the Reagan Era.'' However, I did learn some very interesting things from reading it -among them, that the president of Vail Associates has been skiing for three years and thinks the lift operators should look as if they work at the Ritz-Carlton or Disneyland.

title: Wittgenstein's Labors
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, the Ontological Divorce Novel
description: IF you read contemporary fiction you will notice that we thrash out the ultimate terms of our divorces not in court or on the couches of therapy, but in novels. One can hardly imagine the novel now without divorce. The narrative of separation or divorce has become our Unbildungsroman. In the 19th century, fiction relied on love, but divorce is an even more baroque and pathetic subject. If the novel of love had passion, the novel of divorce has pity and terror.

title: The Envelope, Please
description: The tabloids called it ''the Bess mess'' and the trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan had vivid testimony about family strife and political intrigue. Bess Myerson, now 64 years old, a former Miss America who became New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner; her longtime companion, Carl A. Capasso, and a retired State Supreme Court Justice, Hortense W. Gabel, were accused of scheming to reduce alimony payments in Mr. Capasso's divorce case in 1983. In a dramatic ending last week, the jury acquitted all defendants of all charges.

title: LET US ADVERT, YOU AND I
description: ENGLAND, THEIR ENGLAND Commentaries on English Language and Literature. By Denis Donoghue. 365 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: THE RUMOR THAT WILL NOT DIE
description: THE MAN BEHIND THE IRON MASK By John Noone. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $35.

title: ELIZABETH DOLE CHOSEN BY BUSH FOR LABOR DEPT.
description: President-elect Bush today made Elizabeth Hanford Dole his choice for Labor Secretary, saying she had the experience and the skills to cope with a changing American work force.

title:
FOCUS: Equity Conversion;
Must Resort Residents Buy Into Their Country Club?
description: LEAD: Golf courses, tennis courts and other club facilities have been a major attraction at Boca West, a 16-year-old residential development here that has drawn thousands of home buyers. But they have also been the center of litigation since its residents were forced to buy equity stakes in the club or lose membership.

title: For My Grandchildren
description: I HOPE Santa brought you books for Christmas. And because you cannot yet read them yourselves, I hope your mother and father, and grandmother and grandfather, and aunts and uncles, and older cousins, and assorted baby sitters will read them to you. It is my sincere wish that, in this way, you will learn to love books, all kinds of books, and that they will become an important part of your life now and forever.

title: HOLDEN CAULFIELD OF THE BALKANS
description: SHADOW PARTISAN By Nadja Tesich. 214 pp. New York: A New Rivers Abroad Book. New Rivers Press/Talman Company. Paper, $9.95.

title: 2 Teen-Agers in Connecticut Are Shot While Viewing Show
description: Two teen-agers were shot and wounded while watching a talent show Friday night at Hamden Middle School. They were apparently the innocent victims of a dispute among other members of the audience, the police said yesterday.

title: THE NATION: The Committee Race; In Choosing a Leader, The Democrats Are Divided Once Again
description: THE five candidates are calling voters one by one, though they occasionally address small groups. The issues differ from group to group, sometimes from individual to individual. And while the campaigning goes on, the country is largely indifferent.

title: Q and A
description: France Question: Please suggest sources of information for accommodations in France equivalent to the paradors in Spain. I would also appreciate knowing where I could find a list of farmhouses and bed and breakfast lodgings. - S. E., Bellevue, Wash. Answer: France does not have a chain of government-owned inns like the 80 or so paradors, mostly in historic buildings, in Spain. What is generally perceived as similar in France is the Relais & Chateaux group of hotels, which are in chateaus, abbeys and manor houses converted into hotels and restaurants, and are managed by their owners. The Relais group began in France in 1954. Its American representative, David Mitchell & Company (200 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016; 212-696-1323 or, out of state, 800-372-1323), supplies a guide listing details of all the hotels and restaurants for $5. The 1989 issue is expected to be available in about two weeks. Mitchell makes reservations for the hotels.

title: Army Acts to Save Eroded Gilgo Beach in Babylon
description: LEAD: DESPITE 10 years of litigation, the Army Corps of Engineers has begun a stopgap, $7.4 million dredging operation to try to save Gilgo Beach and Ocean Parkway from being breached by the Atlantic.

title: An Elegant Setting in New Haven
description: IT is like stepping into the past. The former ballroom of the Taft Hotel in downtown New Haven, next door to the Shubert Theater, is neo-classical in style and embellished with champagne-colored wall panels, Queen Anne-style chairs and rose-colored draperies over long windows. Crystal chandeliers shimmer from high ceilings. This ornate setting is now an Italian restaurant called The Palms.

title: 'On Bended Knee'
description: To the Editor:

title: Treatment Facilities For Crack Abusers
description: The extensive article [ ''Crack Use on the Rise in Suburbs,'' Nov. 13 ] pointed out the shortage of beds for substance abusers in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: South Dakota Governor Hurt on Snowmobile
description: Gov. George S. Mickelson was injured today when his snowmobile dropped into a 10-foot-deep ravine, and he was hospitalized in serious condition.

title: Sugar Plum Dreams
description: LEAD: far back as she can remember, there always has been a ''Nutcracker'' in Deirdre Carberry's life. Even before she started taking dancing lessons in Manhasset at the age of 5, she had seen and fallen in love with the traditional holiday season ballet.

title: Sumner B. Miller Plans to Be Wed To Jane B. Lowry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Lowry Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Barkley Lowry, to Sumner Bardwell Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Miller of Greenwich, Conn., and Small Point, Me. An April wedding is planned.

title: TV: Under the Revival Tent
description: ON a vacant rock-strewn lot last summer in the heart of a troubled Central Ward neighborhood here, a revival tent rose and a minister faced an anxious crowd. For three weeks the Rev. Brian Jefferson Mosley preached the gospel and performed old-fashioned head-dunking baptisms, all captured on film and the subject of a New Jersey Network documentary scheduled to be broadcast tomorrow at 7 P.M.

title: Morris Stein, 83, Ex-New York Councilman
description: Morris J. Stein, a former New York City Councilman and Civil Court judge, died of cardiac arrest Friday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 83 years old. Mr. Stein, who kept homes in Pompano Beach, Fla., and Rockaway, N.J., served on the City Council from 1949 to 1969 and was the chairman of the General Welfare and Ethics Committees. He was elected to a judgeship on the New York City Civil Court in 1968 and held that position until his retirement in December 1978.

title: The True Official Tree
description: Millions of Americans have long believed that a 35-foot blue spruce on the Ellipse in Washington is America's official Christmas tree. In fact, the official tree stands 267 feet tall in California's Sierra Nevada Mountains. It is a giant sequoia named General Grant, designated by Federal law in 1926 as ''the nation's Christmas tree.''

title:
FOCUS: Equity Conversion;
Must Residents Buy Into the Country Club?
description: LEAD: GOLF courses, tennis courts and other club facilities have been a major attraction at Boca West, a 16-year-old residential development here that has drawn thousands of home buyers. But they have also been the center of litigation since its residents were forced to buy equity stakes in the club or lose membership.

title:
ART;
A Childlike Style That Isn't Childish
description: LEAD: OUTSIDE of that associated with Unicef, there is not much children's art as wholehearted as that made by Dusty Boynton, whose works are now being exhibited at Gallery Jupiter in Little Silver. But there is a surprise: the maker of these appealing paintings and ink drawings is a not a child, but a woman in middle age.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; Launching A Mini-Seaport
description: GROUND is expected to be broken in the spring along Wilmington's Christina River on a $25 million miniversion of New York's South Street Seaport or Baltimore's Harborplace.

title: WANDERERS ON THE EARTH
description: GYPSIES OF THE WORLD A Journey Into the Hidden World of Gypsy Life and Culture. Text by Nebojsa Bato Tomasevic and Rajko Djuric. Photographs by Dragoljub Zamurovic. 288 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $45. After Jan. 1, $50.

title: Trendlets, Revivals and a League of Women
description: In popular music, 1988 was a year without a consensus or a rallying point. It is likely to be one of the most lucrative years ever for the recording business, fueled in part by the growing popularity (and high price) of compact disks. Yet despite a few attempts, there was no pre-eminent performer who reached beyond the pop audience the way U2 did in 1987 or Michael Jackson in 1984. The most impressive event was the Amnesty International world tour to commemorate the United Nations Declaration for Human Rights, but perhaps because the United States audiences had already been treated to an Amnesty International tour in 1986, its effects were probably greater beyond our borders.

title: The Ombudsman And the 'Abused'
description: With a heavy heart did I read the letter from the Office of the Ombudsman to every nursing home administrator in the State of New Jersey. The Opinion page article of Nov. 13, written by three prestigious people in the field of law, medicine and medical ethics, ''Ombudsman and Elderly: Abuse Is in the Eye of the Beholder,'' served to lift my spirits, but just a little.

title: A Guide to Some of the Scariest Things on Earth
description: Here is a sampling of what environmentalists considered some of the worst problems in 1988. Canada

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAMPLIGHTER. By Maria Susanna Cummins. Edited by Nina Baym. (Rutgers University, Cloth, $45; Paper, $15.) What is it about the tale of little Gerty, rescued from the cold Boston streets by the kind old lamplighter Trueman Flint, that made this bulky novel, originally published in 1854, a runaway best seller and a favorite of women well into the 20th century?

title: Georgia Rejected
description: The North Carolina State football coach, Dick Sheridan, yesterday turned down an offer to become coach at the University of Georgia, leaving the Bulldogs still searching for a replacement for Vince Dooley.

title: Cecily Campbell Birmingham to Wed Oliver Call Colburn, a Lawyer, in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Merritt Folger of Washington have made known the engagement of Mrs. Folger's daughter, Cecily Campbell Birmingham, to Oliver Call Colburn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. I. W. Colburn of Manchester, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Foreign Films Shown In Niantic, Too
description: In Daniel Ort's article ''4 Movie Outposts Keep Off Beaten Path'' (Nov. 20), he mentions four theaters in Connecticut where one can see alternative films. There is another place that shows foreign films in Connecticut, much to our delight.

title: Art and Science Gained
description: Looking back is a good way to see where we are heading. That's one reason why history has such a hold on us. Granted, the field of video is too young to have much history, but at least we can do a fast replay of the old year to get our bearings and direction.

title: Doctor Kills Intruder With Unlicensed Gun
description: A 37-year-old doctor was charged with illegal possession of a gun yesterday after he shot and killed an intruder in his Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: On Dasher, On Dancer, On Fay
description: FAY RAY, THE 4-YEAR-OLD WEIMARANER/COMEDIENNE WHO IS THE COMPANION AND FREQUENT SUBJECT OF PHOTOGRAPHER WILLIAM WEGMAN, LIVES AMID GIANT POLAROIDS OF HERSELF IN WEGMAN'S APARTMENT IN MANHATTAN'S EAST VILLAGE. YOU WOULD THINK SHE'D HAVE AN ATTITUDE, SEEING HERSELF ALL OVER THE PLACE. BUT NO, NOT REALLY. ''I DON'T THINK SHE THINKS ABOUT IT MUCH,'' WEGMAN SAYS. STILL, IF FAY - NO RELATION TO GARY LARSON'S OVERCOLLARED DOG DAD ON OUR COVER - APPEARS UNMOVED BY HER OWN PROLIFERATE IMAGE, LIKE MANY OF OUR MEMORABLE AND FAMOUS FACES SHE'S COMMITTED TO THE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN ARTIST AND MODEL. AND SHE HAS HER OWN INSCRUTABLE STANDARDS. SHE'S PATIENT AND COOPERATIVE, WEGMAN SAYS, EVEN DOCILE AT TIMES. BUT AS MADE EVIDENT IN THIS PAIR OF PHOTOGRAPHS, THERE IS A VISION AT WORK, TOO, KEEN AND INVIOLABLE. DONNING HER GAY APPAREL FOR A CHRISTMAS PORTRAIT, FAY FOUND WEGMAN'S HOLIDAY IMAGERY A LITTLE, WELL, BUSY. ''I WANTED HER IN HER OUTFIT WITH HER FRONT LEG IN THE AIR,'' WEGMAN SAYS. ''BUT SHE WOULDN'T DO BOTH THINGS, LIFT HER LEG UP AND WEAR THE ANTLERS.''

title: Pueblo's Veterans Look Back on '68 in Anger
description: Twenty years after the crewmen of the American spy ship Pueblo crossed a bridge from North Korea to freedom in South Korea, they are still angry.

title:
FILM;
In the Land of This Oz, Character Is King
description: LEAD: ''People think Steve, doing wild comedy, is out of control,'' says Frank Oz about Steve Martin, who co-stars with Michael Caine in ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.''

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the article about baseball salaries on this page last week incorrectly used a phrase in French.

title: CANADA ENDORSES U.S. TRADE ACCORD
description: The House of Commons voted early today to give final approval to the Canada-United States free-trade agreement, effectively clearing the way for the agreement to go into operation as scheduled on Jan. 1.

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: Make no doubt about it, the Knicks are a good team. Just how good is a question only a full 82-game schedule can answer. A winning record and home-court advantage in the playoffs is probable, maybe even a first-place finish in the division. After that, tune in in April. MARK ROITHMAYR New York

title: Britain, Citing Ulster Terrorism, Keeps Detention
description: The Government has decided not to comply with last month's ruling by the European Court of Human Rights that British law permitting the police to detain suspected terrorists for up to seven days was a violation of the European Convention on Human Rights.

title: Death Toll at 9 in Memphis Tanker Explosion
description: The death toll has risen to nine in the explosion of a propane truck that blew up and burned after hitting a retaining wall on an Interstate highway here.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY;
History of a Popular Art Form
description: LEAD: NEXT month marks the 150th anniversary of Daguerre's announcement to the French Academy of Sciences that he had discovered a method of fixing projected imagery on a metal plate.

title: Closing the Tank Gap: NATO Looks to Robots
description: It is an old Army axiom that the best way to fight a tank is with another tank. But despite Mikhail Gorbachev's recent promise that the Soviet Union will unilaterally reduce its arsenal of tanks by 10,000, analysts at the Pentagon say the United States cannot hope to overcome the Soviet bloc's numerical advantage in tanks, and they doubt the Soviets would ever agree to such a thing in negotiations with the West.

title: Multiple Meanings
description: To the Editor:

title: Toys for the Needy From Prison 'Santa'
description: RICHARD J. ROWE, 47 years old, seems to be the antithesis of Santa Claus. He's thin, clean-shaven and certainly no saint. Yet he is the founder and director of the Ayuda Toy Drive Inc., one of the nation's largest Christmas charities, which distributes about a million free toys a year to needy and disabled children in 22 states.

title: A Witches' Brew
description: 'More than a thousand children continue to die each day in Africa as a consequence of the economic witches' brew that flows out of low primary commodity prices, poor borrowings, high interest rates, the remaining debt crisis.' - James P. Grant, Director of Unicef

title: Vikings Are Dangerous but They Can Be Erratic, Too
description: Jerry Burns looks at the Los Angeles Rams and sees stars.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LORDS OF VAUMARTIN. By Cecelia Holland. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) It is 14th-century Brittany. Plague is imminent; internecine warfare is on the rise. Against the backdrop of these events, Josseran de Vaumartin bows to the ambition of his beloved wife and takes Everard, his 14-year-old nephew and heir, into battle at Crecy.

title: Lillo Way, Choreographer, Weds Stephen Benjamin
description: The wedding of Lillo Way, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward U. Way of Havre de Grace, Md., to Stephen Benjamin, a son of Mrs. Robert M. Benjamin of New York and the late Mr. Benjamin, took place last evening at the bride's home in Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Linda Burry, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: CHILDREN OF CHOICE
description: ''Birth control being what it is . . .'' writes Katha Pollitt, in justification of the abortions for which her friends have opted. Please! When condoms aren't worn until ''too late,'' when diaphragms are replaced by calendars and when breast-feeding is relied on to prevent conception, we aren't talking about birth-control failures. These are examples of serious, even deliberate, negligence, which we might easily compare to the unsafe handling of a motor vehicle. Ignorant and thoughtless teen-agers can, perhaps, be excused for such negligence. Educated adults cannot. ANITA DERMER Toronto [

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LONG TIME GONE: The Autobiography of David Crosby. By David Crosby and Carl Gottlieb. (Doubleday, $18.95.) In 20 years the singer and songwriter David Crosby went from being one of rock-and-roll's shining stars to one of its biggest embarrassments. The man whose voice shimmered through two of America's seminal folk-rock bands - the Byrds and Crosby, Stills and Nash and occasionally Young - became addicted to free-base cocaine and heroin.

title: From a 'Singing Detective' to Violence Verite
description: Flip-flopping its way more pervasively than ever into our everyday lives, television in 1988 was, depending on where it grabbed you, appalling and astonishing. The medium turned the Presidential election into a depressing spectacle, more concerned with the selling of images than the clarification of issues. The prospect for the future, without dramatic changes in the ground rules, is glum: Whichever side has the most money and the cleverest social scientists -i.e., ad executives - presumably wins. But then, ABC's Ted Koppel and his ''Nightline'' crew went to Israel for a week to talk to Jews and Palestinians, and demonstrated that television could grapple quite effectively with complexities. Once again, the obvious lesson: The medium is neutral; the people or forces who can control and manipulate it are the culprits.

title: Power of Presidency Is Still Power to Persuade
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No More Goodbyes It's one of the ironies of contemporary life, according to the hero of this Shirley Hazzard novel, that lovers rarely part anymore: their tragedy is that they stay together in one way or another. This is from ''The Evening of the Holiday'' (Penguin).

title: Parties Gear Up for Important '89 Races
description: THE Presidential election barely history, Long Island politicians are already preparing for elections next year that are more important to them than the Presidential contest.

title: Joan Hauerstein to Wed
description: The engagement of Joan Karen Hauerstein to Craig James Inciardi, a son of Anne C. Inciardi of Brooklyn and Dr. James A. Inciardi Jr. of Newark, Del., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hauerstein of River Edge, N.J., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Rangers' New Arrival Quickly Leaves His Mark
description: Kevin Miller made his National Hockey League debut Friday night, and quickly proved his worth.

title: In Managua, 2 Economists Debate Crisis
description: Of all the troubled economies in Latin America, none is plagued by so dazzling an array of ills as Nicaragua's.

title: Deaths From Cold Soar as Homeless Increase
description: The number of deaths by freezing reported in the United States has more than doubled in a decade, possibly because there are more homeless people, the national Centers for Disease Control say.

title: Soviets Urge Afghan King to Join Talks on Nation
description: A senior Soviet official met here today with the exiled King of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, and later said he had asked him to take part in talks on forming a broad-based Afghan Government.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our home-built kitchen cabinets are covered with Formica and this is separating from the particle board underneath. I would like to refurbish these cabinets. I can either reglue the existing laminate, then apply another on top of that, or remove the Formica, then apply a new laminate directly to the particle board. Which is best?

title: Just How Good Are The Knicks This Year?
description: The Knicks are much improved and among the top five teams in the N.B.A., but a championship is unlikely. Despite their improvement, and the addition of Charles Oakley, the Lakers and the Pistons have All-Star lineups and will be too tough to beat in the playoffs. BRIAN LEVY West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Catherine Mark To Wed in April
description: Mrs. Peter Mark of Princeton, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Catherine Virginia Mark, to Charles H. Burdge Jr., the son of Mr. Burdge of Warren, R.I., and the late Lucille Barry Burdge. The couple plan to marry April 29. Miss Mark, the daughter also of the late Mr. Mark, is a nurse at Yale-New Haven Hospital and a clinical instructor at the Yale University School of Nursing. A graduate of the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart and Wellesley College, she received a master's from the Yale School of Nursing. Her father was a professor of electrical engineering and computer science at Princeton University and was internationally recognized for his experiments in the behavior of the surfaces of electronic and chemical substances.

title: Helping Out the Really Small Investor
description: With youngsters flush with holiday cash, parents may find that now is a good time to teach their children about money. And because ''kiddie'' finance is fast becoming big business, there are more tools than ever to help with the task.

title: Crash Survivors Urge Use of Belts
description: SIMON KLEBANOW said he reminds himself everyday of how lucky he is to be alive. ''I really am a miracle,'' said the 39-year-old Weston resident.

title: No Headline
description: TED SULLIVAN spends most of his spare time in his garage, preparing to take on such notables of automobile racing as Paul Newman.

title: Medical Center Cleared For Use as AIDS Center
description: LEAD: The County Medical Center has been given the green light to develop a regional AIDS-management center.

title: Children Broadcast For Others
description: LEAD: THE story was a new one: a one-inch man was eaten by a fish, then caught by Santa Claus and magically redeposited at his home on Christmas Eve. The movie ''Scrooged'' was reviewed and ''Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer'' was given a rousing rendition.

title: Pride Returns to a Housing Project, and She Leads the Way
description: TO everyone familiar with it, the Miller Homes housing project used to be considered beyond redemption. Drug dealers operated in the doorways and halls, selling to addicts who sometimes lined up 100 deep. Despite the shortage of public housing, Miller Homes always had vacancies. Only the desperate would agree to move in.

title: A Year of Musical Delights
description: As Santa arrives with presents for the children, perhaps we should ourselves look back with thanks to some of the bountiful musical pleasures enjoyed during a rapidly fading 1988. On such a list, might be the following:

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Melanie S. Griffin;
State's Equal-Rights Watchdog
description: LEAD: FOR 10 years the New Jersey Commission on Sex Discrimination in the Statutes has fought to end institutionalized discrimination. Piece by piece, it has dissected the state's legal statutes, searching for sexist references and inequities in laws that touch women's lives.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Michael has changed my life. We live off of his crumbs, but those are still more than you ever dreamed you'd have.'' a senior Drexel official, speaking of Michael Milken.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Studying the Star
description: LEAD: ''The most popular planetarium show in the world, ever,'' is the way Larry Brown, director of the Andrus Planetarium at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, describes ''The Star of Bethlehem.'' The show, which has been given at various planetariums over the years, offers a view of the constellations as they appeared at the time of the birth of

title: Elizabeth Journal; >Anticrime Plan:A 'Berlin Wall'
description: LIKE many aging residents in this Union County city, Iris Brown has a distrust of the streets. She has seen too many neighbors and friends fall victim to muggers and petty thieves, she says. Some have died. An air of desperation, she says, now pervades once-quiet neighborhoods where residents stare through venetian blinds at strangers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: CITIES, LIKE OLD FREINDS
description: EUROPEANS By Jane Kramer. 561 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Choosing the Right Hollies for Planting
description: LEAD: THE use of hollies at this time of year goes back to the Druids, who used evergreen leaves and red fruits in their rites for the winter solstice. Today, hollies contribute to the festive nature of the holiday season.

title: Goodbye, L.I.; It's Been Fun, but the Party's Over
description: THANK you, Long Island. We're leaving now and we were taught that you always say ''thank you'' when you leave a party. And it was a very nice party, thank you very much. But we have to leave before the ice cream cake goes all gooey and the balloons get small and withered. And we have another party to go to. It was good being born here, growing up in small-town Hempstead where the librarian knew my name and I knew all the shopkeepers and went to school with their children. Hempstead was the hub then, crowned by A & S and the brand-new Calderone Theater.

title:
WINE;
For Toasts, a Sparkling-Wine Sampler
description: LEAD: WITH local retail outlets currently stocking a wide variety of sparkling wines costing $3 to $99 a bottle, area consumers should find little difficulty in purchasing an acceptable product to use for toasting the New Year.

title: WHEN SHAME ENETERED THE GARDEN
description: LEAD: THE BODY AND SOCIETY Men, Women and Sexual Renunciation in Early Christianity. By Peter Brown. 504 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $45.

title: Fashions in Bricks and Mortar Make Room for Conscience
description: It looked, at the beginning of 1988, as if the architectural event of the year was going to be something called Deconstructivism, that trendy style of sharp, angular architecture that was ballyhooed by no less an authority than the Museum of Modern Art as the thinking person's alternative to the increasingly decorative and cliched style of post-Modernism. The museum mounted an exhibition of Deconstructivist architecture in June, organized by Philip Johnson, architecture's best bloodhound; it included work by the likes of Peter Eisenman, Zaha Hadid, Bernard Tschumi and the firm of Coop Himmelblau. With that kind of imprimatur, Deconstructivism seemed poised to take over the world.

title: Quick! Name That Relative!
description: I EXPERIENCED several uncomfortable moments at my sister's recent wedding, where most of the 200 guests were people I was supposed to know.

title: CONSUMER RATES
General Assuaged on Noise
description: Aircraft using this base outside Washington have changed their flight patterns after a general living at the base complained of the noise. Col. William Phillips, commander of the 1776th Air Base Wing, apologized in writing to Gen. Bernard Randolph, who heads the Air Force Systems Command, which has its headquarters at Andrews. The general's complaint resulted from a Sept. 12 incident in which an air traffic controller directed a C-141 to change its path for safety reasons because it was on a crash course with an approaching F-4 fighter jet.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Psychics' Christmas

title: Ohio Town's Power Restored After Leak of Radioactive Gas
description: Electric output at the Perry Nuclear Power Plant has been restored to 100 percent after a seven-hour decrease because of a leak of slightly radioactive gas into a building.

title: WINTER IN THE NATIONAL PARKS
description: During the winter, there is a sense that the national parks in the north take a holiday from visitors. To go to these parks in the winter - Acadia, Glacier, Grand Teton, Great Smoky Mountains, Mount Rainier, Olympic, Rocky Mountain, Sequoia and Yosemite - is to see them in their most forbidding form. Avalanches, sudden snowstorms and frostbite are the dangers; the reward is the exquisite solitude of raw wilderness.

title: The Computer That Hesitates Is About to Be Lost
description: JUST as impatience or nervousness cannot be expected of chess computers, so also hesitation or indecision would seem to be impossible. Still, there are times when the machines unaccountably seem to exhibit these human failings.

title: THE GUIDE
description: AMERICAN MUSIC The Whitney Museum in Stamford will play host to Alvin Lucier, an avant-garde composer, at 6 P.M. Wednesday, when Mr. Lucier will perform his work, ''I Am Sitting in a Room,'' and selections from the music of John Cage, Philip Glass and Steve Reich.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Herald Center; Revitalizing the Mall That Marcos's Millions Built
description: WHILE shoppers swarmed off 34th Street into Macy's during the final days before Christmas, an empty Santa's chair outside a vacant shop sharpened the look of desolation across the street at Herald Center, a vertical shopping mall that opened three years ago with great expectations of catering to wealthy shoppers.

title: Postal Santas Fulfill Disabled Boy's Wish
description: A letter to Santa Claus from a 10-year-old boy who wanted an electric wheelchair for his mother has brought Christmas greetings and gifts from around the world, including one brand-new wheelchair.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THEATER CELEBRATION The Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn will celebrate New Year's Eve with two performances of a gala musical comedy featuring selections from the theater's recent hit, ''La Cage aux Folles.''

title: Leave Shakespeare Out of It
description: To the Editor:

title: My Mother, My Past and Future
description: ''I AM lonely,'' she tells me, not really complaining. She is stating a fact, both specific and abstract. So am I, Mother, I think. ''When did I get sick? I don't remember ever being sick.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A RIVER FOR CHRISTMAS: And Other Stories. By Ernest Schwiebert. (Stephen Greene, $19.95.) Only a few fly fishing books published in recent years have transcended their natural audience to enter the literary mainstream. For all its marvelous descriptions of nature and of lands fished, ''A River for Christmas'' remains a book primarily for fishermen only.

title: CHILDREN OF CHOICE
description: Katha Pollitt's essay ''Children of Choice'' (Hers: Nov. 20) is one of the most discerning comments I have read on abortion in our present society.

title: Jersey Plan to Control Growth Said to Be Weakened
description: New Jersey's attempt to impose its first statewide comprehensive development plan has been seriously weakened, planning proponents say, by a revised draft announced this week.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on Dec. 18 on high-rise construction misidentified the construction manager of the Olympic Tower in Manhattan. It was the Tishman Realty & Construction Company.

title: A Bipartisan Foreign Policy? Hints of an Era of Consensus
description: A bipartisan spirit appears to be returning to American foreign policy after two decades of partisan confrontation that began with the collapse of consensus over the war in Vietnam.

title: When the Green-Eyed Monster Surfaces
description: Marcia Byalick's ''Green Eyes, Red Rage, Shameful Longings'' certainly hit a nerve. Whenever I have felt that ''green-eyed monster'' surface in myself, I have tried to hold it back. Jealousy is one of the most destructive emotions one can have.

title: When Charity Leaves A Sad Aftertaste
description: LAST year, I volunteered to help serve Christmas dinner at a local church from noon to 3 P.M. Driving over, I was nervous. I wondered how I would feel serving dinner to people who had nowhere to go or nothing to eat on this holiday. I wondered how they would feel receiving it.

title: The Weight of Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: BIRD-COUNTING TREK
description: Bird watchers, whether experienced or novice, may participate in the yearly Bronx-Westchester Christmas Bird Count from 1 to 4:30 P.M. tomorrow at Wave Hill, the environmental center at 675 West 252d Street in Riverdale. Reservations are not required and admission is free.

title: Gasoline
description: To the Editor: A comment about the letter on unleaded regular gasoline (bleifrei), which appeared on Nov. 13: My wife and I picked up a car in Munich last summer and were advised that either unleaded or regular gasoline could be used but that the bleifrei was recommended; the catalytic converter would be installed when our car was turned in for shipment to the United States.

title: Bravery of Armenians Is Hailed by Reagan
description: In his final Christmas message as President, Ronald Reagan praised the ''breathtaking bravery'' of the survivors of the Armenian earthquake today and asked Americans to join him in ''a time for prayer.''

title: A Year for Once-in-a-Lifetime Exhibitions
description: There is no doubt that in terms of the major museum exhibition -the show thought up, thought through, lodged deep in current scholarship and installed in a way that is a credit to the museum profession - 1988 will go down in history as an annus mirabilis. For years, we have heard from our constant companion, Gloomy Gus, that exhibitions of that kind were obsolete, frivolous, injurious to works of art, prohibitively expensive and destructive of the privacy, tranquillity and potential sublimity of the museum experience. But they keep coming, all the same, and when we come out of some of them we tread the air.

title: Town Helps Buoy Vermonter After Accident
description: Pat Paquin says she's been amazed by the outpouring of community support since her husband's accident three weeks ago.

title: Hope Rockwood Plans To Wed in September
description: Hope Shayna Rockwood and Matthew Adam Rosenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rosenbaum of Rochester, plan to marry in September, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William P. Rockwood of Albany, have announced.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; Launching A Mini-Seaport
description: GROUND is expected to be broken in the spring along Wilmington's Christina River on a $25 million miniversion of New York's South Street Seaport or Baltimore's Harborplace.

title: Army Acts to Save Eroded Gilgo Beach in Babylon
description: LEAD: DESPITE 10 years of litigation, the Army Corps of Engineers has begun a stopgap, $7.4 million dredging operation to try to save Gilgo Beach and Ocean Parkway from being breached by the Atlantic.

title: Some Sledding Slopes Lead to the Hospital
description: As many as 40,000 people may wind up in hospital emergency rooms each winter as a result of sledding mishaps, according to figures collected by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title:
The View From: The Arcadian Garden Center;
Elves, Carolers and Customers
description: LEAD: The day after Halloween, there appeared at Arcadian Gardens a sign reading ''Enchanted Forest Now Open: Free Admission.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Was The Best Performer In 1988?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Class Acts
description: Californian wine makers have always resisted the idea of a hierarchy or ranking resembling the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux. For one thing, California is too young. There are today almost 700 wineries where, 50 years ago, there were a couple of dozen. Who can say who will be the best 50 years from now?

title: 'A Great Joy'
description: Lyman Newlin, a reader in Lewiston, N.Y., liked The Times's 1983 Christmas editorial enough to save it. When he came across the clipping recently, he wrote to ''respectfully request'' that it be reprinted.

title: Forester Plays Public-Safety Role
description: LEAD: Trees mean beauty, wildlife habitats, oxygen, lumber, shade and recreation to Westchester County's Forester, Ted Kozlowski, who manages the county's woodlands.

title: Foreign Visitors, 'Lost' Ballets And Galas Galore
description: This was the year of the special event. It was hard to speak of business as usual in dance, what with birthday celebrations, anniversaries, galas, festivals galore and glasnost, which opened unprecedented floodgates for Soviet dancers to come to our shores.

title: Flanagan Signs
description: Mike Flanagan, the 37-year-old left-hander who led Toronto in starts and innings last season, agreed yesterday to a two-year contract with the Blue Jays worth $1.925 million.

title: On the Town With Comden and Green
description: NEW YORK -- They had been here before, of course, but somehow it all looked different.

title: Israelis Pull Together and Rightward
description: THE ''government of national paralysis'' is how the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, described the coalition that led Israel for the last four years. As late as two weeks ago, his party, which shared power equally during that time with the Likud party of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said it would not join another unity government. Now Mr. Peres, who has been

title: Don't Blame the Pilgrims for the Anti-Indian Sins of the Puritans
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Future
description: On the African Savanna, it is a strikingly foreign image. The Our Lady of Peace cathedral now being constructed by the government of the Ivory Coast at Yamoussoukro, the birthplace of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, seems symbolic of that nation's brash - some would say foolhardy - embrace of European culture. The cathedral, which if all goes well will be inaugurated next September during a visit by Pope John Paul II, is an imitation, in concrete, of St. Peter's Cathedral in Rome. Its cupola will rise nearly 400 feet. Its cost has been estimated at $200 million. Mr. Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled the Ivory Coast since it won independence from France in 1960, is Africa's longest-serving head of state and, at the age of 83, its oldest. Under his rule, the nation, located on the underside of West Africa's peninsular bulge, has emerged as black Africa's largest agricultural exporter, the world's leading producer of cocoa. Relative to most sub-Saharan republics, it is a prosperous place.

title: WHY THINGS TURNED VIOLENT
description: CONFRONTING THE THIRD WORLD United States Foreign Policy, 1945-1980. By Gabriel Kolko. 332 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $15.95.

title: Another Play in Semiconductors
description: With semiconductor stocks moving up, it might also be time to look at the companies that make the equipment used to manufacture computer chips. When the semiconductor business improves, the equipment business tends to improve six to nine months later. But the stocks of the two groups tend to move in lock step.

title: THE NATION: 37 Million Uninsured; Turning to the Biggest Gap In U.S. Health Coverage
description: THEY are mostly young, in worse health than the general population and, as often as not, poor.

title: Nicaragua Says Bush Sent Message of Peace
description: President-elect Bush has written to President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, saying that he wants to work toward strengthening world peace, the Sandinista Government said Friday.

title: This Time the Met Grabbed the Brass Ring
description: The premiere of ''Gotterdammerung,'' which forged the final link in the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring of the Nibelung,'' must go down in the record as 1988's most significant musical event in New York. Only the marathon celebration of Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday looms anywhere near as large in an over-the-shoulder glance at the fleeting year, but even to mark Mr. Bernstein's anniversary the Rhine did not overflow or Valhalla collapse. The Met takes the brass ring, if not the gold, this time.

title: There Are No Great Teams Anymore . . . and No Games to Rival the 'Greatest Ever'
description: I COULDN'T believe my eyes. I was on the way to New York, going over my last-minute notes before my broadcast of the 1958 Giants-Colts National Football League championship game, and there it was in the Baltimore News-Post: the play-by-play story written 24 hours before the game.

title: Catherine Shea, 68, Aide to a Times Editor
description: Catherine L. Shea, executive assistant to the managing editor of The New York Times, died of colon cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. She was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bronx Cheers and Tears
description: FIVE CORNERS Starring Jodie Foster (in photo), Tim Robbins, Todd Graff, John Turturro. Directed by Tony Bill. 1988. Cannon. 92 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: Denise Ann Scherer to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scherer of Mountainside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Ann Scherer, to Terence Sweeney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Sweeney of West Caldwell, N.J. A September wedding is planned. Miss Scherer, a graduate of Villanova University, expects to receive a master's degree in nursing in May from Columbia University. Mr. Sweeney, a graduate of Boston College and the Seton Hall Law School, is an assistant district attorney in the Bronx.

title: Hospital Remembers Its Christmas AIDS Baby
description: This is a special day of remembrance at Harlem Hospital Center for the child who came to be known as the Christmas AIDS baby.

title: Solving a Crisis In Insurance
description: LIABILITY insurance was hard to get and rates were vaulting to the sky when 12 Roman Catholic dioceses in three states decided to form their own insurance company in 1986.

title: SPEEDY CHECK-IN FOR FLIGHTS, HOTELS AND RENTAL CARS
description: Imagine strolling up to an airline ticket counter, handing over your baggage and, within seconds, receiving not only your boarding pass, but also your hotel and car rental keys. One-stop check-in is within technological grasp of the travel industry.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WHITE HOUSE TOURS

title: Suddenly, the World Itself Is a World Issue
description: AFTER decades of neglect, environmental issues are moving from the periphery of geopolitics toward center stage. Several recent events demonstrate that the superpowers and other nations are starting to address problems like the greenhouse effect, acid rain and the thinning of the ozone shield with some of the same seriousness once reserved for international security and economic affairs.

title: WRAPPED UP
description: The interior decorator Mark Hampton believes that bedrooms should be pretty, not tailored; romantic and dreamlike rather than cool and hard-edged. So does his wife, Duane, who has spent years collecting the antique linens and old taffeta and lace pillows that fill the bedroom of their Long Island retreat.

title: Mountains of Trash for Convenience' Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Decker To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Decker to Jean Marie Compagnon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michel Compagnon of Paris and Meaux, France, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Decker of Wilton, Conn., and Palm Desert, Calif., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: New Devices May Stop More Bombs At the Gate
description: WHILE investigators were still trying to determine what caused Pan American World Airways Flight 103 to explode over a Scottish village last week, killing at least 275 people, the suspicion of sabotage gave fresh impetus to the search for ways to keep terrorists from endangering the skies.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: SCHOOL BUS RULING After a fall season of many postponed and canceled field trips because New York State school districts were required to use only standard yellow school buses, instead of chartered buses, legislation reversing that decision has been signed into law by Governor Cuomo.

title: Specs Toporcer Turns 90
description: ''If a frail kid with a slight build, weak eyes and no high school or college training could jump directly from playing sandlot baseball to the big leagues - and stick for seven seasons! - then almost any young player with a passion for the game can do the same thing.

title: Practical Traveler; Visa Hurdles for Jews Headed for North Yemen
description: If you are an American and you want to visit the Yemen Arab Republic, to see what are described as its unspoiled wonders and its friendly people, there are at least six travel companies that will put it together for you, though it is not an inexpensive trip. If you are Jewish, however, things can be complicated, the experience of some travelers and travel agencies indicates.

title: THE REGION: In the Rockaways; A Queens Beachfront Is Ground for a Fight Over Housing Goals
description: THE street sign, which identifies the intersection as Beach 69th Street and Story Road, is perhaps the only indication that civilization still has designs on the forlorn stretch of sand and weeds in the Arverne section of Queens.

title: Tax Reform Slowing Historic Rehabilitation
description: IT was an arsonist, the police say, who ended the debate over the Patio Royale. The three-alarm fire that gutted the abandoned hotel - once a retreat for Hollywood stars - was probably set by one of the many homeless people who migrate to Phoenix every winter.

title: Correction
description: An article Dec. 18 on a Federally-sponsored AIDS drug study mischaracterized the advice that Dr. Nathaniel Pier of New York gives his patients. Dr. Pier said he tells his patients about participation in the Federal study and also about alternative experimental drugs, without advising them which to choose.

title: An Eye-Level View of Trains and a Model Community
description: THE model train layout that members of the Mohegan and Pequot Model Railroad Association have set up at the Avery Point campus of the University of Connecticut is big - 28 feet by 48 feet - and it can easily be seen by anyone walking past. But the model railroaders do not recommend just walking past. They urge people to take time and get close.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 11 about airport landing fees misstated the new fee structure at Logan International Airport in Boston. For commercial planes, the fee is $103.55 plus 55.12 cents per 1,000 pounds. Private planes pay a weight surcharge of 50.9 cents per 1,000 pounds.

title: HAVE YOURSELF A LITERARY CHRISTMAS
description: HOWEVER one stands, or kneels, theologically, it's not difficult to agree that Christmas is one of the great human fictions - in that all of us who celebrate it know exactly what role we've been assigned in this year's picture-book enactment of the holiday. Whether playing the ecstatic tissue-tearing child, the photographing parent, the maidenly aunt or avuncular uncle, we are never more ''literary'' than we are on Christmas morning. As the saying goes, we ''make a Christmas'' for one another, through our real-life behavior, creating a story along such formulaic lines that writing fiction about Christmas is somehow painting the lily, if you will, sugaring the sugarplum. Of course this redundancy hasn't stopped us from making the Yuletide tales of Dickens, O. Henry and Clement Moore some of the best-known stories of all time, but one would think we might be satisfied with documentary Christmases. Memoirs, diaries, letters and biographies are full of festive nonfiction ones, stories sometimes even richer than the more famous fictional tales, since character traits and circumstances other than the happiest but-once-a-year ones have a way of creeping into and complicating the narratives.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THAT RED WHEELBARROW: Selected Literary Essays. By Robert Coles. (University of Iowa, $24.95.) The 44 penetrating essays in this collection are a delight to read, revealing once again that Robert Coles is a clear-visioned thinker, a nonobfuscating critic of the social order and a delver into complex psychological realms of the human condition that plods ahead as best it can in what he refers to as ''this confused, tormented century.

title: No More Surly Clerks, an End to Long Lines
description: The right location used to be all a lodging company needed to attract business travelers. But that was before hotels began springing up like weeds around airports and revitalized urban centers. It was before air fare wars became standard fare and before companies began sending out swarms of executives in increasing numbers to do business.

title: ABROAD, AND BARELY BILINGUAL
description: One baking August afternoon on Rome's Via del Corso, I stopped at the elegant Europa for an ice cream. In front of me in the gelato line stood a middle-aged woman, her hands on the hips of her slacks as she read the list of flavors. On the back of her T-shirt was printed: ''If you can read this, you learned it from a teacher.'' An American tourist, I surmised. And, while I stood deciding what flavor I would order, I heard the woman say to her friend, ''Well, you'd think they'd at least print the signs so people could read them.''

title: MAJOR TAX BILLS PASSED IN JAPAN IN LONG SESSION
description: After a decade of failed efforts, months of intense maneuvering and a 26-hour parliamentary session, Japan's most sweeping tax overhaul in 40 years passed its final legislative hurdle this evening.

title: Mexico Opens Its Economy And the Imports Flood In
description: For decades, Mexicans knew the only easy way to obtain imported consumer goods here was to go to the barrio known as Tepito, where a flourishing black market offered everything from televisions to whisky. All that has now changed.

title: Hollywood Journal; Promise of Sunshine, Reality of Night
description: They are drawn here by the promise of sunshine and stardom, making Hollywood the nation's third-largest magnet for runaways after New York and Houston.

title: A Magazine Entrepreneur's Rescue Attempt
description: In 1970 Bernard Goldhirsh created Sail magazine because, as a sailor, he saw a need for ''how to sail'' information. His instinct was right. He sold the magazine for an estimated $10 million to $15 million.

title: American Indians: Swept Under the Rug
description: LEAD: This summer I worked in the field health nursing department on Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Rebuilding Schools, and Hope Wadleigh's New Lease On Dreaming
description: When Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch, Robert Wagner Jr., the Board of Education president, and Schools Chancellor Richard Green went to Harlem's Wadleigh Intermediate School three months ago, they found walls and desks in disrepair, dozens of broken windows and holes in the gymnasium ceiling.

title: Investment Bankers' Lofty Fees
description: After a merger or acquisition is completed on Wall Street these days, the gasping over the size of a deal is often followed by gasping over the investment bankers' fees, and a question: what did they do to earn that kind of money?

title: Northern Visitors Return to Boston Airport
description: Snowy owls from the frozen tundra far to the north are returning to their winter home near one of the nation's noisiest airports and one of its most polluted harbors.

title: Rome Journal; Quake of 1980 Rattles Italy's House of Politics
description: In this season when much of the world is sharing Armenia's agony, Italians have been distracted by the reverberations from an earthquake of their own.

title: Drug Found in Room Washington Mayor Visited
description: Traces of cocaine were reported to have been found in the hotel room of a former Washington city employee who received frequent visits from the city's Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr. The Washington Post today reported the results of the drug tests and quoted a narcotics officer as saying the results did not necessarily indicate that drugs were recently present in the room.

title: Blue-Gray Classic; Blue Wins, 22-21
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (AP) - Eric Wilhelm of Oregon State led an 82-yard drive in the final 1 minute 34 seconds and Aaron Jenkins of Washington ran for the 2-point conversion today, leading the Blue past the Gray, 22-21, in the Blue-Gray All-Star Classic.

title: A South African Town Won't Yield to Bitterness
description: As the working-class families packed the Anglican Church of St. Nicholas for the first Mass of this Sunday Christmas morning, the Rev. Demaraj Laban learned that a woman in the congregation had lost her husband and their home in a recent fire.

title: Dean Foods Sees Net Rise
description: Despite the summer's devastating drought and its impact on farm prices, the Dean Foods Company, a Midwest dairy and food processor, expects higher earnings for the second quarter, its president and chief executive, Howard Dean, said in an interview last week. Dean Foods, which includes

title: Netanyahu Wins Post
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the former Israeli representative at the United Nations, was appointed Deputy Foreign Minister today. Mr. Netanyahu, 39 years old, will work under Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, his ally in the hard-line Likud party.

description: b-Net income

title: Critic's Notebook; World Culture Conspicuous by Its Absence
description: Does Gloria Steinem occupy a more significant place in literary history than W. B. Yeats? In what sense is it more important to know about Bob Hope than about Tintoretto? These are questions most of us, left to ourselves, might never have puzzled our heads with. But a new book has put them firmly on the agenda.

title: I.R.S. to Join Cable Network in a Series on Tax Advice
description: The Internal Revenue Service is going on cable television in a new attempt to reduce the trauma of income taxes.

title: G.M. Opposes Gas Tax Rise
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, said Friday that an increase in the gasoline tax to 15 cents a gallon would mean the loss of 100,000 jobs in the auto industry.

description: State officials and criminologists are debating the operations of an unusual Maryland prison that emphasizes rehabilitation over retribution.

description: b-Net income

title: Passengers Need Runway Relief
description: The next time you're stuck in a cramped jetliner in a long flight line waiting with thousands of other travelers for a free runway, don't blame the airline. Don't blame the airport. Blame the Reagan Administration.

title: Poland Eases Business Rules
description: The Polish Parliament Friday approved two economic reform laws encouraging private enterprise and foreign business operations in Poland.

title: Some Checks for the Neediest Arrive With Christmas Cards
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund celebrates Christmas this year with an outpouring of holiday greetings and generosity.

title: Indian Industrial Parks Spreading
description: Nearly 30 years ago, this was a sleepy little township of 20,000 with only a couple of businesses.

title: Georgia Inmates Stage Protest
description: Inmates in the Hall County jail staged a disturbance to make sure officials knew how miserable they were, the sheriff said today.

title: Plant-Closing Law Is Being Felt
description: When the Grumman Corporation announced major employment cuts nine days before Christmas, it pointedly noted that the dismissals would take effect ''before the end of January.''

title: Bush Son and Grandson Visit Quake Victims
description: With tears in his eyes, President-elect George Bush's son presented gifts today to brighten the Christmas of children injured in Armenia's earthquake.

title: POPE URGES HELP FOR QUAKE VICTIMS
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a Christmas appeal today for more aid to Armenian earthquake victims and for intensified scientific research in the battle against AIDS.

title: Reading Anatoly's Mind
description: All my old friends in Washington are wondering why it was that I fell from power and then - just as suddenly - have been reinstated as foreign policy adviser to President (former Comrade) Gorbachev.

title: Tower Hints at Cut in Troops
description: John G. Tower, whom President-elect Bush has chosen as Defense Secretary, hinted today that military personnel rather than arms might be cut to meet budget restraints.

title: A Palestinian Is Killed, 16 Are Hurt by Israelis
description: Israeli troops shot dead a Palestinian youth and wounded 16 Palestinians in occupied areas today.

title: Noel Willman, Director, Was 70; Staged 'A Man for All Seasons'
description: Noel Willman, the British actor-turned-director, best known in the United States for staging the Robert Bolt drama ''A Man for All Seasons,'' died of a heart attack on Saturday. He was 70 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Outdoors: Tasty Game Tips
description: Eating what one has killed is an essential element of the hunt, but all too often precious wild game is ruined by improper care or cooking.

title: Tokyo Stocks Finish Up
description: The dollar inched down against the Japanese yen today, while share prices rose on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in slow trading. The dollar opened at 124.85 yen and was trading at 124.75 yen by late morning, down 0.20 yen from Friday's close of 124.95 yen. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks gained 135.29 points, or 46 hundredths of a percentage point, to finish at 29,821.65. Currency trading was slow because other markets around the world were closed for the Christmas holiday.

title: Review/Cabaret; Carrying The Torch Downtown
description: When Michele Bautier, a completely unknown pop-jazz singer from New Jersey, won a talent contest at Freddy's Supper Club three and a half years ago, it was immediately apparent that a major new cabaret talent had arrived. With her deep, penetrating alto and breathtaking emotional directness, Ms. Bautier lent time-honored torch songs an almost ominous personal immediacy.

title: Bridge; Sometimes, one board can mean a frustratingly small losing margin.
description: When a match is won and lost by a small margin, the losers go away grieving about many ifs: ''If I'd made a different lead on board 3,'' or ''If my partner had guessed right on board 7,'' or ''If the opponents hadn't made that lucky slam on board 23.''

title: Cognos Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOP, SKIP AND JUMP YOUR WAY TO STRONGER LEGS
description: The shoe looks like an upsidedown mortarboard attached to a sneaker sole, not anything you would want to wear downtown. But you may want to try it for a 40-yard dash, a sprint or for jumping rope.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
The Killing of Carlos Rosa, 19, The Death That Broke the Record
description: New York City's 1,842d homicide occurred at 11:05 Saturday night on a desolate corner in Staten Island in front of a burned-out, boarded-up house. The police believe the slaying was drug-related.

title: Babble Babble Babble Babble
description: LEAD: The assumption used to be that television news meant seeing something happening. But that was very early.

title: MUBARAK SUGGESTS THAT HE IS WILLING TO VISIT ISRAELIS
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said in an interview published today that he was willing to visit Israel if such a move could lead to negotiating an end to the Middle East conflict and a solution to the Palestinian problem.

title: The Two Baseball Gloves
description: Brooks Robinson was talking about his glove, and I, of course, was telling him about mine.

title: Oilers Quiet Critics By Beating Browns
description: The Houston Oilers emerged from their American Conference wild-card victory over the Browns as a confident team that believes it can handle the formidable Buffalo Bills in Round 2 of the playoffs next weekend.

title: Hinson Plays Role of Wherever-Whenever Starter
