description: It's anybody's guess where Roy Hinson will show up during a Nets game.

title: TV Notes
description: Spring Changes for NBC

title: Summary of Actions in New York Legislature's 1988 Session
description: The unusually drawn out 211th legislative session never quite managed to end this year. Although no major outstanding issues, such as how to close the state budget gap or whether to raise the minimum wage, are expected to be resolved before the end of the year, legislators are planning to return to Albany again on Wednesday to act on a handful of bills.

title: Pershing Didn't Say It
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIAN HELD IN COMPUTER CASE
description: A Southern California man accused of stealing computer programs from the Digital Equipment Corporation is being held without bail in a Los Angeles jail on the orders of a Federal magistrate, who said the man posed a threat to the community when armed with a computer.

title: MacLean Scoring Early and Often
description: Those who play with John MacLean are not surprised by the sudden eruption in his offense that has people taking their hats off and throwing them onto the ice. They say it was a matter of time before the feisty 24-year-old right wing of the Devils began scoring in droves, and this is as good a time as any.

title: Washington State Holds Off Houston
description: Timm Rosenbach passed for a touchdown and ran for another today, and Tuineau Alipate caused a fumble that preserved the victory as Washington State held off Houston, 24-22, in the seventh Aloha Bowl.

title: Schickele, Unrepentant, Unearths More of P.D.Q.
description: Can it be a quarter century? Surely it seems more. But tomorrow at Carnegie Hall, a bearded professor named Peter Schickele will begin his 25th season of confrontation with the sounds of P. D. Q. Bach.

title: In the Domain Of Larry Davis, 2 Tales of Hope
description: Woodycrest Avenue in the High Bridge section of the Bronx may be immortalized as the early stomping grounds of Larry Davis, who was indicted, but not convicted, of murder and attempted murder. His escape from the police earned him, in some quarters, the sobriquet ''the dude that elude.'' However, two virtually unheralded events last week offer hope for redemption.

title: FCS Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $94,000 from the writeoff of an investment in a patient-management system. The company said $334,000 of its latest year loss was attributable to ongoing carrying costs and certain non- recurring costs of a court-ordered reorganization of FCS's European operations. The company also said its latest year results were also adversely affected by a change in insurance reimbursement policies and increased competitive pressures.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is the legal holiday for Christmas. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Parking: Sunday rules, no street cleanings. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways, buses and Metro-North on holiday schedules; Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule. Trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: TEEN-AGE HOCKEY LEAGUE JUST KEEPS ROLLING
description: Rob Buhagiar took a pass from behind the rusted net, spun from a sliding defenseman and drove a low slap shot toward the goal. The puck trickled between the goaltender's pads, took a bounce and rolled into the net.

title: Mubarak Remarks on Israeli Visit Called 'a Very Good Sign' by U.S.
description: American officials today welcomed the statement by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that he was willing to go to Israel if such a visit helped achieve peace in the Middle East.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Investment Firm Sees Benefits in Small Size
description: LEAD: In reaction to the news that the Carlyle Group L.P. is offering to buy Fairchild Industries Inc. for $15.50 a share, or $220 million, some financial people are asking how a small, Washington-based investment firm with no Wall Street credentials can expect to make it in the rough-and-tumble world of leveraged buyouts?

title: G.M. Sees Plant Closings
description: The General Motors Corporation said last week it would temporarily close two assembly plants after the first of the year, idling 8,000 workers. The nation's largest auto maker will close its plants in Doraville, Ga., and Fairfax, Kan., for the week of Jan. 3 to reduce inventories. The shutdown will necessitate the layoffs of 4,000 workers at each plant, a G.M. spokeswoman said. The Doraville plant builds the Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme, while the Fairfax plant produces the Pontiac Grand Prix.

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
In Albany, Progress Despite A Year That Wouldn't End
description: The 211th session of the New York State Legislature will be remembered not so much for what it did, but for what it did not.

title: Warily, a Few Christians Stay in West Beirut
description: Christmas is celebrated in West Beirut, but only on one street.

title: Nuclear Arms Industry Eroded As Science Lost Leading Role
description: Forty-four years ago, when the first nuclear reactor at the Hanford Reservation here was started up to make plutonium for the bomb that destroyed Nagasaki, Enrico Fermi stood by with his slide rule to correct initial miscalculations.

title: Japan May End Car-Export Limits
description: Despite a large automotive trade surplus favoring Japan, there are signs of an end to the voluntary agreements that have restrained Japanese car exports to the United States for the last eight years.

title: Honeywell's New Chief Starts in a Tight Spot
description: Four quarters of unexpected write-offs and a possible loss of more than $400 million for the year have badly shaken Wall Street's confidence in Honeywell Inc. And James J. Renier, the company's newly elected chairman, may not have much time to restore it.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today for the Christmas holiday. Banks, government agencies and nearly all businesses will also be shut, as will most foreign stock exchanges.

title: Questions Raised on Prison Riot in Mexico
description: Five inmates taken alive on Friday after a prison riot were apparently later killed in custody, a news videotape indicates.

title: The Winners of Individual and Team Championships
description: Archery U.S. Target Champions Men - Jay Barrs, Tempe, Ariz. Women - Debra Ochs, Howell, Mich. World Crossbow Champions Men - K. Kesti, Sweden. Women - L. Moodie, New Zealand. Indoor Champions Men - Barrs. Women - Denise Parker, South Jordan, Utah. Auto Racing World Formula One - Ayrton Senna, Brazil. U.S.A.C. Silver Crown - Steve Butler, Kokomo, Ind. U.S.A.C. Sprint - Butler. U.S.A.C. Midget - Rich Vogle, Indianapolis. I.M.S.A. Camel - Geoff Brabham, Australia. CART - Danny Sullivan, Louisville, Ky. Daytona 500 - Bobby Allison, Hueytown, Alabama Indianapolis 500 - Rick Mears, Bakersfield, Calif. Miller High Lite 500 - Geoff Bodine, Chemung, N.Y. Michigan 500 - Sullivan. Trans-Am - Hurley Haywood, California, Calif. Nascar Winston Cup - Bill Elliott, Dawsonville, Ga. 24 Hours of Le Mans - Andy Wallace, Johnny Dumfries and Jan Lammers. Badminton U.S. Champions Singles - Chris Jogis, Redondo Beach, Calif. Women's Singles - Joy Kitzmiller, Manhattan Beach, Calif. Men's Doubles - Jogis and Benny Lee, Tempe, Ariz. Women's Doubles - Linda Safarik-Tong, Richmond, Calif. and Linda French, San Diego, Calif. Mixed Doubles - Jogis and French. Baseball World Series - Los Angeles Dodgers d.

title: Hidden Swiss Art Treasures in an Uneasy Jerusalem
description: ''Art is a way to enhance life, especially when you come out of the Holocaust.'' Jan Krugier, a Swiss collector and art dealer, was explaining why he had agreed to lend art from his collection to an exhibition that is drawing crowds to the Israel Museum here.

title: Bond-Default Negotiator Enjoys 'High-Risk' Role
description: Melvyn I. Weiss has emerged as the champion of 24,000 bondholders after recovering $750 million in settlements in the default on $2.25 billion worth of bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System. The settlements resulted in the termination of a complex trial that started last September over the municipal bond collapse, the nation's largest.

title: Washington Utility Plans New Bond Issue
description: Last week's end of the trial involving the nation's largest municipal bond default will clear the way for a bond offering in July by the Washington Public Power Supply System, an official for the power agency said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I invite everyone to take up the tragic burden of these brethren of ours, and, as I assure them of my deep affection, I exhort scientists and researchers to increase their efforts to find an effective treatment for this mysterious illness.'' - Pope John Paul II, speaking about AIDS. [ 6:2. ]

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: President-elect Bush was a varsity baseball player at Yale University. How many Presidents were varsity football players in college?

title: Shamir 'Happy to Receive' Egyptian
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight that he would be ''happy to receive'' the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, in Israel and that he would soon announce his own plan for Middle East peace.

title: CHURCH CRITICIZES BRAZIL ON INDIANS
description: Brazil's Roman Catholic Church has accused the Government of President Jose Sarney of adopting policies that could lead to the extinction of the Yanomami, one of the country's largest Indian tribes.

title: In Japan, a Growing Divide: The Rich, and Everyone Else
description: From the window of an anonymous apartment building in the eastern suburb of Funabashi, the Japan of Mercedes Benzes and $38 million Picassos seems far away.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; If 'Wheel' Is the Hit Single, Syndication Is a Gold Album
description: WHILE Geraldo Rivera earned the most attention among talk show hosts this year for being assaulted by his own guests, he did not earn the most money. That honor goes to King World Productions Inc., a company that distributes such fare as Oprah Winfrey's talk show and two game shows, ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy.''

title: V Band Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $12,848,000 gain on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Christmas Sales Surge At Finish
description: The Christmas shopping season ended brightly for retailers, with strong sales in the final days lifting results that had lagged and pointing to overall sales 6 percent or more higher than last year's.

title: What It Takes to Improve Care for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Apartment for Sale
description: How does a member of the Reagan Cabinet live?

title: Violent Year for Armored Car Guards in California
description: Southern California money messengers have had an especially deadly year, with 2 slayings, 13 armored car holdups, 3 bank robberies and the theft of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: 7 Are Killed as Car Hits Truck
description: A car carrying a family to a Christmas Eve celebration swerved into the path of a dump truck, killing seven people, the authorities said. Six members of the family and the girlfriend of one of the six were pronounced dead at the scene. The family's car veered into the path of the truck when the car's driver tried to avoid another vehicle that had slowed to make a turn. The driver of the truck received minor injuries.

title: Children Safe, She Dies in Fire
description: A 27-year-old woman died in a hospital here Saturday a few hours after she ran back into her burning home to save her three children. She was unaware that they had already escaped.

title: INSIDE
description: Record Year for Homicides With a week left in 1988, New York City has surpassed its record of 1,841 homicides, and officials point to drugs as a major cause. Page 33. Will Blacks Lose Power? Chicago black politicians say they fear they'll lose the Mayor's office, its power and its patronage. Page 12.

title: Heroes Prevailed, but Pedestals Shook
description: In a sweet-and-sour sports year, 1988's boldest headlines identified the villains or the vanquished as often as the victors.

title: Beyond Reading Lips; Courteous Minuet Replaces Bitter Jousting As Democrats Seek to Outmaneuver Bush
description: This is a season of passive aggression, political style, among Congressional Democrats.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; A HUFF AND A PUFF TO BETTER FITNESS?
description: Here we are, out for a run, laboring up a hill, our breath coming in shorter and shorter gasps. This is pain, and who says it's enjoyable?

title: Poland's Regime Sends in the Goons
description: A wave of police brutality in Poland is offering alarming evidence that the Government of Prime Minister Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski has no intention of fulfilling the promises of a new political accommodation that was offered in exchange for the ending of strikes last August.

title: Official Says Truck in Memphis Wreck Passed Test
description: A roadside inspection the day before a propane tanker truck exploded on an interstate highway, killing nine people, found the truck was free of defects, a Federal investigator said Saturday.

title: The Cold Hand in the Cradle
description: In poor countries, the debt crisis has a child's face. When income sinks, it's not usually defense spending that suffers, but health and education. A decade ago, a net $40 billion flowed from the richer north to the south; now the flow goes the other way to the tune of at least $20 billion.

title: Ark Restaurant reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $29,700 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary credit of $43,000 for both the quarter and year. Latest quarter and year losses from operations both include a pretax charge of $329,419 in connection with the closing of New Jersey restaurants, and the quarter also includes a pretax charge of $200,000 associated with the termination of a management agreement. Year-ago quarter loss from operations includes a pertax charge of $500,000 and the fiscal 1987 net from operations includes a charge of $783,000 both in connection with the closing of New Jersey restaurants.

title: Church Enfolds a Town That Lost 3 in Air Crash
description: The Church of St. Joseph in the Mendhams sits in the geographic heart of this Revolutionary era community, right off the corner of Main Street and Hilltop Road.

title: Cocoa Tie-Up in Ghana
description: Trucks carrying cocoa are congesting Ghana's main port of Tema, which could hinder shipments, P. V. Obeng, a member of the ruling Provisional National Defense Council, told the Ghana News Agency last week. Tema port officials said congestion had been aggravated by rehabilitation work on one of the cocoa storage sheds. The West African nation is vying with Malaysia to be the world's third-biggest producer of cocoa.

title: Dewey Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sanders May Miss Sugar Bowl Game
description: Deion Sanders, an all-America defensive back for Florida State, was arrested Saturday night in Fort Myers, Fla., on charges of battery on a police officer and disorderly conduct, the police said. He will find out Monday if he will play in the Sugar Bowl against Auburn on Jan. 2.

title: Removal of Michigan Judge Urged Over Sexual Charges
description: The State Supreme Court has been asked to remove a judge from office for making sexual advances to female defendants.

title: Election Panel Powerless on State Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Fires Strike 3 Abortion Clinics
description: Suspicious fires broke out at three abortion clinics in less than an hour early today, but the authorities said no one was injured and damage to the clinics was minor.

title: Review/Television; Fashion's Caprices Through the Ages
description: Fashion is a subject that makes experts of us all. Even people who are diffident about offering their opinions on art or food are eager to express themselves on the subject of clothes. They will shamelessly assert that green is poisonous, that designers hate women and that the fashion industry is interested only in separating people from their money. Well, yes and no.

title: Towle Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparable year-ago figures are not available. The company merged with Airport Road Corp., a unit of First Republic Corp. of America, in November 1987.

title: Review/Television; 'Quiet Victory,' on Beating the Odds
description: A couple of years ago, Melissa Goldsmith, a director of program development for the BBDO advertising agency in New York, saw a CBS News report about Charlie Wedemeyer, a football coach for Los Gatos (Calif.) High School. Mr. Wedemeyer had been stricken with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the degeneration of voluntary muscles known as Lou Gehrig's disease. There is no cure. Yet Mr. Wedemeyer, immobilized and not even able to speak, was leading his team in a bid for the state championship.

title: Kin of Abducted French Girls Told Arabs May Free Them
description: Relatives of two French girls held captive by Palestinian guerrillas for more than a year met with a representative of the kidnappers today and were told that the girls would soon be released.

title: Tool Orders Rebounded In November
description: Bolstered by strong foreign demand, orders for American-made machine tools rose 6.4 percent in November, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association. The increase follows two months of declining orders.

title: 1988: THE YEAR IN SPORTS
description: The Winners of Individual and Team Championships

title: New Yorkers Bask in Christmas Warmth
description: The children who received sleds for Christmas - presumably there still are children who get sleds instead of Nintendo games - must have been disappointed yesterday as fantasies of speeding down Dead Man's Hills dissolved in a 53-degree heatwave.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Scandal Over Heiress's Art Entangles a Louvre Curator
description: A scandal has captivated France and it has all the elements of a good detective novel: a nurse who is accused of taking advantage of a frail and aging heiress, a 17th-century painting that was supposedly stolen, a will that may be a forgery, lawyers accused of being criminal accomplices and the indictment of an internationally renowned museum curator on charges of having received stolen goods.

title: Homicides Hit a Record In New York
description: The record for homicides in a single year in New York City was broken in 1988, which began with the karate-kick killing of a young college graduate and saw the execution of a rookie police officer guarding a drug witness's house.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

title: Now in Season: 500-Page Guides to Those Simplified Tax Rules
description: Many books left over from the holidays will soon be taken off the shelves of bookstores and returned to their publishers for credit. But the selling season is just beginning for a record number of tax preparation guidebooks, some of them bigger and bulkier than ever.

title: Books of The Times; The Contentment of the Well-Sold Soul
description: Jack Gance By Ward Just 279 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: Benefits Seen in Japan Tax Law Overhaul
description: Japan's sweeping tax overhaul should stimulate sales of imported products, encourage consumption and buttress the nation's fiscal health, economists here said after the plan was approved Saturday by parliament.

title: Vikings Pit Their Reputation Against Rams' Recent Success
description: The Minnesota Vikings have the top-ranked defense in the National Football League and the top-ranked passer in their conference. The Los Angeles Rams have a newly found passing game and a newly found pass rush.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Constitutional Law; Keeping Government's 3 Arms Minding Their Own Business
description: In a city of lawyers that abounds with every legal specialty a creative profession can devise, Alan B. Morrison has carved out a singular niche. His specialty is the separation of powers, the constitutional relationship among the three branches of the Federal Government.

title: Review/Television; Koppel to Space: 'News From Earth'
description: Much is made on tonight's edition of ''The Koppel Report'' of the possibility that its contents might, in time and over distance, be received by an alien intelligence, since television signals never disintegrate but travel indefinitely through space. The prospect calls up an appalling image of unbiodegradable verbiage clogging the heavens. Anyhow, that is the small conceit behind ''News From Earth,'' Ted Koppel's year-end program, on ABC at 10 P.M.

title: Guilty Plea by Drexel Will Increase Pressure on Milken
description: Time is running out for Michael R. Milken of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to change his mind and try to settle pending charges of racketeering and securities fraud.

title: Syntrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Fiscal 1988 includes $1,538,726 loss on termination of proposed acquisition.

title: TeleVideo Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Overpopulation Strains Earth's Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Mainstream Tamil Party Returns in Sri Lanka
description: A major ethnic Tamil political party in Sri Lanka that has been out of politics for more than 5 years has decided to take part in national parliamentary elections scheduled Feb. 15.

title: Conservatives Likely to Conserve
description: George Bush insisted during the Presidential campaign that he was an environmentalist. Skeptics saw little proof in his record. But his word may be easier to accept now that he has nominated William Reilly to head the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Theodore S. Amussen, Book Editor, Dies at 73
description: Theodore S. Amussen, an editor with book publishers for many years and later an editor in chief for the National Gallery of Art, died of a brain tumor on Wednesday at the Collingwood Nursing Home in Rockville, Md. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Photos of black Chicago Mayoral candidates, Acting Mayor Eugene Sawyer and Alderman Timothy C. Evans (NYT/Steve Kagan) Blacks Fear Loss of Power in Chicago
description: After Harold Washington's solid re-election last year, many politicians here were quietly predicting that this city would never again have a white Mayor.

title: Students Choose Colleges for the Other Students Who Go There
description: To the Editor:

title: Scurry Arrested
description: Cocaine possession and use charges will be filed later this week against Rod Scurry, the major league pitcher, a Nevada prosecutor said during the weekend.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Natural Nickname They call her Christmas. She was born 27 years ago on Christmas Day in Bethlehem, Pa., and her name is Holly. But in all the years Holly Vaughn competed in sports, first in swimming and later in golf, no one thought of the nickname until she got to Southern Methodist University.

title: Save Scribner Bookstore
description: To the Editor:

title: Customs Overhaul
description: The Customs Service is getting a major overhaul with its new tariff schedule.

title: A Merry Christmas Redeemed
description: Susan and Shaun McMillin thought the loss of a purse with $1,250 in cash would mean a bleak Christmas, but a good Samaritan restored their cheer. The woman who found the purse in a street and returned it refused to give her name or to accept a reward. ''She even apologized for going through my purse to find some identification,'' said Mrs. McMillin, who had been taking money from her husband's business to a bank when she lost her purse.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-11

title: Revising Rules On Practice Sales
description: CALIFORNIA is poised to set a trend in legal circles with the adoption of rules that give lawyers a reason to retire early.

title: A Close (and Brief) Gorilla Encounter
description: On a steep incline 9,000 feet up in the Virunga Mountains, four tourists cling with hands and feet to a dense bed of nettles, vines and ferns, slowly nudging their bodies toward more than a score of gorillas just a few yards away.

title: Amid Namibia's White Opulence, Majority Rule Isn't So Scary Now
description: The white inhabitants of Namibia celebrated Christmas in this coastal resort with little of the fear and panic that the prospect of black-majority rule evoked in them a decade ago.

title: Review/Dance; James's 'Golden Bowl' According to Pilobolus
description: ''The Golden Bowl,'' as Pilobolus calls its latest premiere, is not the cartoon of Henry James's novel one might have feared. James, in fact, only rarely comes to mind.

title: MNC Acquires Savings Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has assisted in the acquisition of the insolvent Virginia Federal Savings and Loan Association of Richmond by the MNC Financial Corporation.

title: Suburbs Wrestle With Steep Rise In the Homeless
description: The counties around New York City are struggling to cope with a sharp increase in homelessness.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Murdered Environmentalist Buried in the Amazon Region
description: A prominent Brazilian enviromental advocate, Francisco Mendes Filho, murdered last week, was buried today as his colleagues began a campaign to block foreign loans until his killers are brought to justice.

title: Searchers for Crash Victims in Scotland Join Church Services
description: Soldiers and volunteers spent Christmas scouring the countryside for clues and victims from Pan American World Airways Flight 103, with some taking a break from the search to join saddened townspeople at somber church services.

title: Borman's Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 5
description: Year-ago periods' results are restated to reflect an accounting change connected with the purchase of SEG Stores Inc.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., a maker of portable electric tools, said William E. Stevens, executive vice president, planned to resign at the end of this month after assisting the company through its turnaround period, which is virtually completed. It added that he would pursue personal business interests.

title: Bodies of 2 Men Are Found At Yonkers Housing Project
description: Two men were found dead Saturday night in a public housing project, and the police today were investigating leads into the slayings.

title: Legal Battle Looms in San Diego Over Funds for Sewage Treatment
description: San Diego's bays and lagoons, a recreational paradise to boaters and surfers, are the subject of an growing battle between this city and the Federal environmental authorities.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
A WEEKEND AT CROSS-COUNTRY SKI CAMP
description: LEAD: Learning a new sports skill is a challenge. At a camp or clinic where you get intensive instruction, there is always a chance you won't be able to perform to your satisfaction or that you might look foolish to others in the group. It seems the older you get the less likely you might be to try.

title: American Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Algae Bloom Remains A Puzzle
description: Researchers at the University of Rhode Island say they cannot predict the next outbreak of a peculiar form of microscopic algae that wiped out Narragansett Bay's scallops three years ago and has been destroying scallop beds around Long Island.

title: Cold-Weather Dinosaur
description: AUSTRALIAN scientists have reported that certain breeds of small dinosaurs with big brains apparently flourished in a region where mean annual temperatures were lower than 41 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Critique of Reagan Years From Unlikely Source
description: Charles A. Bowsher says he did not really intend to be hard on President Reagan, the man who appointed him Comptroller General and, hence, head of the General Accounting Office, a research arm of Congress. Unfortunately, he said, such criticism is part of the job.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Nabisco Uses Three Shops In New Drive
description: NABISCO BRANDS, which many analysts expect to be spun off in whole or in parts by the new owners of its parent, RJR Nabisco Inc., will begin a corporate image campaign next Monday that was created by all three of its advertising agencies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Robin Leach to Narrate Spots on the Homeless
description: Robin Leach, who narrates ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,'' will lend his voice to decidedly more poignant tales of the poor and destitute in a 60-second pro bono spot for the National Coalition for the Homeless, which was filmed last week in New York by the director Bob Giraldi. Mr. Giraldi was aided by several agency volunteers and actors, and two restaurants, Positano and Brandywine, which supplied free meals to about 80 members of the crew and cast, a group that included numerous homeless people.

title: Shamir in New Tack on Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir may ask the United States and the Soviet Union to sponsor Middle East peace talks, an aide said today.

title: Colombo Journal; A Proud People, Scattered and Forgotten by Time
description: In Sri Lanka, a country torn by violence, the holiday season is perhaps most poignant for a small minority that has not been part of the ethnic strife at all.

title: Business and Health; Important Issues To Watch in 1989
description: WHAT will the year 1989 hold for the increasingly troublesome struggle to provide good health care and pay for it?

title: Preparing in Japan
description: William and Mary will play a Japanese all-star football team Jan. 8 -the first matchup between American and Japanese squads - and the host team is preparing just as an American opponent would, by watching films.

title: Pathologists Apply Modern Tools To Study of Ancient Disease Patterns
description: A NEW breed of scientist, combining expertise in pathology and archeology, is examining the dried remains of ancient peoples to unravel their patterns of disease and death.

title: Breaking Bad Habits: New Therapy Focuses on the Relapse
description: IN news that should hearten anyone whose New Year will bring resolutions to break bad habits, researchers say lapses do not necessarily mean that the effort is doomed. Rather, they say, learning to overcome lapses is emerging as one of the most important parts of such efforts, whether they are trying to eat less or to give up smoking.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASKETBALL Temple 50, Penn State 48: Mark Macon rebounded his own shot and connected on an 8-foot jumper with 1 minute 3 seconds left as Temple won the Atlantic 10 game in Philadelphia last night. Duane Causwell contributed 10 blocked shots to break Temple's record of 9, which he tied earlier this month. The victory was Temple's 11th straight over Penn State and the Owls' 27th in a row against Atlantic 10 opponents. Temple (3-4 over all and 3-0 in conference play) trailed by 45-42 after the Nittany Lions' Bruce Blake made a free throw with 2:47 to go. The Owls' Mike Vreeswyk then made 5 straight points to give Temple a 2-point edge, but Blake's two foul shots at 1:35 tied the score at 47-47. After Macon made his crucial jumper, Blake was fouled with two seconds to play. He missed his first shot and attempted to miss his second but the ball bounced off the backboard into the basket. Vreeswyk had 19 points and Macon 18 for the Owls. Tom Hovasse had 23 points for Penn State (4-3 and 0-1).(AP) HOCKEY Nordiques 5, Soviet Red Army 5: Joe Sakic scored a short-handed goal with less than two minutes remaining in the third period last night to give Quebec the tie with the Soviet Union's most powerful squad. Sakic, a rookie, outskated a Soviet defenseman for the length of the ice to beat the Soviet goalie, Sergei Mylnikov. The game, played in Quebec, was the first of a 14-game series between N.H.L. clubs and two Soviet teams, the Red Army and Dynamo Riga. The Red Army had taken the lead at 4:58 of the third period on a goal by Sergei Makarov. Vyatcheslav Fetisov, Vladimir Krutov, Valeri Kamensky and Yuri Khmylev also scored for the Soviet team. Mario Marois, Gaetan Duchesne, Iiro Jarvi and Jeff Brown scored for Quebec. (AP)

title: Calming Down With Classics
description: The masquerade is over. A sense of high seriousness pervades the new clothes that stores all over the nation have ordered for next spring. After last year's extravagant styles that puffed too much and bared too much, the watchwords now include ''wearable,'' ''practical'' and ''enduring.''

title: Jose Carreras Begins a European Tour
description: The tenor Jose Carreras, who is resuming his career with a European tour after a long struggle against leukemia, says his illness and treatment have brought him a new understanding of life.

title: French Girls Reported Freed, but Where Are They?
description: A radical Palestinian group said Monday that two French girls held hostage for 13 months with their mother and five Belgians had been released and would arrive in Paris within hours. But late into the night, there was no sign of the children, and the mystery continued about where they were.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 A major stock scandal in Japan has offered rare glimpses into how some deals there are done. It has also raised questions of whether Japan's drive toward internationalization has outpaced its internal reforms. Page A1

title: U.S. IS PESSIMISTIC ON REACTORS' ROLE IN ATOMIC ARSENAL
description: Three aging nuclear reactors at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina may never be able to produce enough of a crucial material for nuclear weapons even when the reactors are repaired, an Energy Department report for Congress says.

title: Honoring Serling, an Almost-Native Son
description: Rod Serling, the creator of the 1960's television series ''The Twilight Zone,'' has been honored with a plaque in the park where he set one of the show's most popular episodes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Creates Trade Publishing Unit
description: Family Media Inc., the publisher of Discover, Savvy Woman and other consumer magazines, is entering the trade publishing business. Robert E. Riordan, the company's chairman, and Paul F. McPherson, until recently the executive vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company, have announced the formation of FM Business Publications, which will acquire, start and publish business, trade, technical and industrial publications.

title: Review/Art; Rescuing 17th Century's Testa From Obscurity
description: The records of the registrar at the Roman parish of San Nicola in Arcione from March 3, 1650, note simply that ''Pietro Testa of Lucca, an excellent painter of about 36 years of age, was found dead in the Tiber.'' Friends, aware of how despondent the artist had become after repeatedly failing to secure reliable patrons and significant commissions, knew that Testa had thrown himself into the river.

title: 'Basketball' In the Viking Hothouse
description: Outside, in the flurries of what the local weather bureau described as a ''light snow'' of 4 to 6 inches in the 23-degree chill, the Metrodome resembled a huge igloo. But inside, the 69-degree temperature was accompanied near the corner of one end zone by a homemade banner that greeted the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Only Ideology Bars Bipartisan Foreign Policy; A Professional Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Inert System Let Shaky Principal Go On
description: Matthew Barnwell, the principal of Public School 53 in the Bronx for the last 16 years, had a history of drinking, absenteeism, lateness and serious lapses in professional performance, yet the city's mammoth educational system never acted to remove him.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday for the Christmas holiday. Banks, government agencies, many businesses and most foreign stock exchanges were also closed.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about homicides in New York City this year gave an erroneous account of the record number for a single year and of the current total, based on incorrect information supplied by the New York Police Department. Police officials said yesterday that the record, set in 1981, was 1,826 homicides. The number of homicides so far this year will not be known until early next year. A corrective article appears on page B3.

title: For the Guerrillas in Afghanistan, Getting to the Front Line Is Half the Battle
description: In the dim morning light in a guerrilla camp near here, 11 men stamped their feet against the cold and wrapped themselves more tightly in their all-purpose blankets, called patous.

title: Lessons Of Perm
description: One day, I am sure it will be possible to forget the prison camp in the Urals. So far, almost three weeks later, that has not been so for more than a few hours at a time.

title: If the Cold War Is Over, Then What?
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's bold appeal to reshape the world order requires the United States to review its foreign policy. For more than 40 years, America's international strategy has been subordinated to one overriding concern - deterring Soviet global designs against the West. But now the Soviet Union is declaring that the idea of an irreconcilable class conflict between capitalist and socialist nations is obsolete.

title: The Mysteries of the Familiar
description: Did you know that the dentist's drill is a direct descendant of the first windmill? Or that the principle behind the zipper governed the building of the pyramids? Come to think of it, how do you build a pyramid? Or a castle or cathedral?

title: Chess
description: Bent Larsen made it clear that he is not ready to concede his pre-eminent place in Danish chess. In a television exhibition match in Odense in October, Larsen defeated the new star Curt Hansen, 3 1/2-2 1/2.

title: Islanders Rally to Top Leafs
description: Reed Larson scored with 2 minutes 51 seconds left tonight to give the Islanders a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The victory was only the second on the road for the Islanders this season.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 26, 1988: TUESDAY Delmarva Pwr & Lt Nipsco Industries Inc WEDNESDAY National Svs Inds Inc Raytheon Inc FRIDAY Cascade Natl Gas Corp

title: Nets Come Unraveled At the End
description: The Nets had a rare opportunity tonight - a chance for their first three-game winning streak this season. But they played their ugliest final quarter of the season instead, and were beaten, 120-108, by the Washington Bullets.

title: Liquid Diet Should Be Handled With Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday New-Home Sales ... Nov. Leading Indicators ... Nov. Farm Prices ... Dec.

title: Sanders Will Play
description: Deion Sanders, the Florida State all-America cornerback, will play in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 2 against Auburn despite his arrest in a shopping-mall scuffle, his coach, Bobby Bowden, said last night.

title: Gene-Altered Animals Enter a Commercial Era
description: THE mice, light brown females of a common laboratory variety, look ordinary. But they carry a trait that sets them apart from all other mice on earth: they produce milk that contains a human blood substance valuable in treating heart attacks.

title: Where Eagles Dare to Nest: Seattle Park
description: Two bald eagles are nesting in a busy city park overlooking Puget Sound despite the species' usual intolerance for human activity. Biologists say the prospects of their raising a brood are good.

title: Man, 21, Held in Amazon Death
description: A cattle rancher's son surrendered to the police today and said he arranged the killing of a labor leader who was an internationally recognized Amazon ecologist, the police said.

title: Carlo Scorza, 91, Dies; Wartime Fascist Chief
description: Carlo Scorza, the last secretary of Italy's wartime Fascist Party, has died, family members said today. He was 91 years old.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: FRANK LORENZO - Texas Air; An Airline Emperor Under a State of Siege
description: In a year in which the airline industry recorded stunning gains in revenues and earnings, the leader of the Texas Air Corporation did little celebrating. Instead, Frank Lorenzo, whose career has been filled with turmoil, has faced persistent losses at his Eastern Airlines unit, bitter opposition from his workers and concerned attention by regulators.

title: Japan Science Activity Seen as Matching U.S.
description: JAPAN'S scientific enterprise has grown so vigorously that it has achieved ''relative parity'' with that of the United States, according to a report by the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency based in Washington.

title: Stocks Rise in Tokyo; Dollar Falls Against Yen
description: The dollar finished lower against the Japanese yen today, while share prices rose on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in slow trading as markets in other nations were closed for the Christmas holiday.

title: Cuba Expects Growth in '89
description: Cuba's economy will grow 1.5 to 2.5 percent in 1989, the head of the central planning board was quoted as saying today.

title: U.S. Pay Rise? Pass the Buck
description: Whether Congressmen and others in Government should get a raise next year, and how much of one, is a big issue in Washington right now. But to listen to people who are usually only too happy to say how much influence they wield, one would think none of them had anything to do with this decision. Article, page A12.

title: Guatemalan Priest's Daring Crusade
description: One by one, five members of the Rev. Andres Giron's family were killed here.

title: 3d Referee Draws a Favorable Call
description: The National Basketball Association has gone from two to three officials. With the season more than a quarter over, it appeared to be a good time to find out if the third official is worth $1.5 million the addition is costing the league.

title: Bureaucrats, Strangling an Airline
description: Ready for the Trump Shuttle? A Federal judge has now dismissed union objections and cleared the way for Eastern Airlines to sell its New York-Washington-Boston commuter air service to Donald Trump, the New York real estate figure.

title: Hostile Bids By Foreigners On the Rise
description: Foreign investors, who have generally trod softly in acquiring American companies, have become more aggressive, a General Accounting Office study shows.

title: Bush Takes Steps!
description: The Capitol Steps, a Washington singing group that specializes in poking fun at the great and powerful, has had cool relations with the Reagan family over the years, but the group has been given an appreciative reception by George and Barbara Bush.

title: 1988's Legacy to Evolution of PC's
description: WHEN the smoke clears from 1988, a handful of personal computing trends will stand out, trends that will have weight when it comes time to decide on your next PC purchase.

title: Patterns
description: What's Selling?

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: HAMISH MAXWELL - Philip Morris; Son of a Tobacco Clan Leads Diversification
description: Hamish Maxwell is a chain smoker and a fourth-generation member of a family that sold tobacco leaf, but the $13 billion acquisition of Kraft Inc. by the Philip Morris Companies was the latest in a series of moves to reduce the company's dependence on cigarette products.

title: Betrayed by a Faithful Servant and Murphy's Law
description: PERSONAL computers and their accessories are obedient servants. They uncomplainingly follow the rules laid down by Ohm, Boole and Turing, codifiers of laws of electricity, logic and computing, respectively.

title: Michael Jackson Silent On Ending His Tours
description: Michael Jackson whirled and twirled his way through a show today that was billed in the Japanese press as a farewell concert, but the pop singer did not mention retiring.

title: Wall St. Slowdown Brings Higher Costs for Investors
description: The past year was one of the worst in recent memory for retail stockbrokers, as market volume shriveled and individual investors became highly defensive. That means 1989, widely expected to be another tough year, could prove critical for the retail brokerage industry as it grasps for longer-term ways to deal with a leaner era.

title: Police Term Homicide Data Too Raw and Not Definitive
description: The New York City homicide record was almost certainly eclipsed this month, but no definitive statistics to substantiate that will be available until February or March, police spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Medicare Folly: Capping Doctors' Fees
description: LEAD: With health care the fastest growing part of the Federal budget, Congress will be under fierce pressure this spring to restrain health expenses. Whatever Congress ultimately decides to do, it should strongly resist proposals to cap Medicare payments to physicians. Such price controls would do nothing to eliminate the basic causes of rising prices and would threaten to reduce the quality - and ultimately the quantity - of medical care.

title: Ex-Chief Justice Has a Case Of 'Bicentennial Exhaustion'
description: Warren E. Burger, the former Chief Justice, has been hospitalized since Sunday suffering from dehydration, exhaustion and a ''mild touch of pneumonia,'' a Supreme Court spokeswoman said today.

title: Why Reports of Child Abuse Are 'Unfounded'
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes the pain of cancer? A. There are several ways that cancer can cause pain, according to the American Cancer Society. Many of them are related to the pressure of cancerous growths, although the society emphasizes that chemotherapy, radiation, surgery or pain-killing drugs can relieve much of it.

title: Israeli Army Kills 3 Guerrillas Yards From Lebanese Border
description: Israeli paratroopers killed three guerrillas today in a clash several yards north of the border with Lebanon, the army and armed forces radio said, adding that the troops suffered no casualties.

title: Africa Is Too Diverse for Easy Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Seismic Networks Aim to Take the Pulse of Earth
description: IN the wake of the devastating earthquake in Armenia, geologists hope to hasten the coverage of the globe with new networks of highly sensitive seismic stations that will monitor the earth's tremors with unprecedented accuracy.

title: Loving County Journal; Getting By in Nation's Richest Place
description: There are no Mercedes-Benzes here in the seat of the wealthiest county in the country, just some old pickup trucks. There are no jacuzzis, and drinking water has to be toted home from a communal well. There are no Gucci loafers, just mud-caked boots. Looking for haute cuisine? The only restaurant in town just closed.

title: A Death in Brazil
description: The shot that killed Francisco Mendes Filho last week in Brazil may not have been heard round the world, though it was reported on page 1 of The New York Times. But Mr. Mendes's violent death may at least further alert global authorities to the dangers of deforestation - an environmental abuse he fought so effectively that he probably was murdered by the land exploiters he opposed.

title: Campaign Donations Overwhelm Monitoring Agencies in the States
description: Political action committees are pouring money into campaigns for state legislatures as never before, overwhelming many of the small agencies charged with enforcing state election laws.

title: Allergies Transplanted Along With Bone Marrow
description: PEOPLE who receive transplants of bone marrow sometimes acquire the donor's allergies as well, researchers in Seattle have found.

title: The Regulatory Agenda in 1989
description: Key issues Congress and regulators will have to address in the coming year. THE SAVINGS CRISIS: More than 500 savings and loan associations are insolvent, with losses estimated at $50 billion to $100 billion. Losses are increasing at a rate of $1 billion a month. A taxpayer bailout is almost a certainty. DEPOSIT INSURANCE: The Government's blanket guarantee of deposit insurance contributed to the savings and loan crisis. Experts say some limits need to be placed on it. LEVERAGED BUYOUTS: The $24.88 billion RJR Nabisco buyout highlighted the issue of potential abuses by management of leveraged buyouts. Congress and the S.E.C. will consider requiring fuller disclosure, conflict-of-interest laws, and reducing the tax advantage of these transactions. GLASS-STEAGALL REFORM: While the Senate passed a bill in 1988 giving banks expanded underwriting powers, it languished in a divided House. The banking lobby plans to resurrect the question of whether to modify Glass-Steagall and let banks underwrite more securities. POST-CRASH MEASURES: Despite endless deliberations, Congress failed to pass any substantive legislation to deal with market structure problems highlighted by the October 1987 stock market crash. Proposals such as raising margin requirements on stock index futures and requiring detailed reporting of large program trades are likely to arise again, but may have the same fate.

title: Two Coloradans Are Rescued After 7 Hours Buried in Snow
description: Two men who were trapped in an avalanche that caught them as they were sliding on a snow embankment were rescued late Sunday after they spent nearly seven hours under six feet of snow.

title: Spotlight Swings Back To Washington's Mayor
description: A year ago, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington, long the subject of lively local controversy and investigations, promised that ''in 1988, I've resolved to lower my profile.''

title: A Case of Mistaken Identity Turns Into a Christmas Gift
description: Jack Wittman spent two days thinking his son had died in the Pan Am crash in Scotland and then, on Christmas Eve, found out he was still alive.

title: Calamity in the Aral Sea
description: When Alexander the Great set out to conquer the known world, his journey took him through the land bounded by the two great rivers of Central Asia, the Oxus and the Jaxartes. Now called the Amu Darya and the Sir Darya, they pour into a great inland lake known as the Aral Sea. The two rivers and the sea and the land surrounding them have now become the scene of an unparalleled ecological disaster.

title: Our Towns; A Gasoline Leak Changes Lives Of Homeowners
description: Robin Hood Lane is a quiet, residential neighborhood. Cardinals and quail dart among the oaks and dogwoods. Good schools are just a few blocks away. It's somewhere you'd want to raise your kids. Unless, of course, there were one million gallons of gasoline oozing underneath your backyard.

title: Escapism Returns to Prime Time
description: Michael and Louisa used to be married but not anymore. Still, they're fond enough of each other to work as co-hosts of a television travel show that sends them journeying to exotic European cities. Wherever they go, however, they become entangled in a preposterous larger-than-life adventure involving stolen treasure or spies or murder plots.

title: U.S. Urges Talks on Missiles in Mideast
description: Concerned by the spread of ballistic missiles in the Middle East, the United States is proposing talks with Israel and Egypt to explore what steps might be taken by Middle East nations to limit the use and development of those weapons in the region, Administration officials say.

title: No Detectable Health Risk Is Found Outside Chernobyl Vicinity
description: IF the 1986 nuclear accident at Chernobyl resulted in any increased health risk outside the immediate vicinity of the meltdown, the effect will forever be too small to be detected by statistical methods, a team of American experts has concluded.

title: Space Pollution Forces NASA To Change Plans For Key Projects
description: UPSET and angry, scientists are being forced to modify plans and equipment for space missions in a last-ditch attempt to protect billions of dollars worth of telescopes and spacecraft from the growing hazards of pollution in the heavens.

title: Giving to Neediest Supplants Cards and Gifts as a Tradition
description: It has become a holiday tradition at the Hooks Lane School in Fort Lee, N.J., to send a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of spending money on greeting cards and stamps. The directors of the nursery school-kindergarten, Toni and Gordon Fordyce, and their children sent wishes for ''a very happy holiday season and a safe and healthy 1989'' and $105.

title: 11 Youths Are Wounded In and Near 2 Nightspots
description: Eleven youths were wounded in unrelated attacks when violence broke out in and around two nightspots in Manhattan early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: By Design; Reviewing the Basics
description: Well, here it is, New Year's resolution time and the fashion resolves of yesteryear still hold true. Let us quickly review a few.

title: SPILLED OIL KILLING WEST COAST BIRDS
description: Volunteers here spent Christmas Day cleaning oil-soaked waterfowl in western Washington as a 70,000-gallon oil spill continued to kill birds.

title: A Big Push To Prop Up Platinum
description: The world's largest marketer and refiner of platinum is waging a vigorous campaign to assure investors and analysts that demand for the metal will outstrip supplies in the next few years.

title: TRADE RETALIATION READIED IF EUROPE BARS MEATS OF U.S.
description: The United States is preparing to impose 100 percent duties on $100 million of annual imports from the European Community, should the 12-nation group ring in the New Year with a ban on imports of American meat treated with growth hormones.

title: Flaws Are Discovered In Theory of 5th Force
description: JUST as physicists thought they had strong evidence indicating a possible fifth and sixth force in nature, causing apparent deviations in Newtonian gravity, they looked a little deeper and found a flaw that leaves the whole issue as perplexing and unsettled as ever.

title: Ax-Grinding Era
description: The death this year of Gwendolyn Cafritz, a premier capital hostess, signaled the fading of the era in Washington society when the wealthy set the social style with lavish parties in private homes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Raise Everyone Loves to Hate
description: One of the big issues in Washington is how big a pay increase the big people in Government should get. But to listen to those people who are usually only too happy to say how much influence they have, one would think none of them had anything to do with this decision.

title: CHINESE IN NANJING HOLD RACIST RALLY
description: Thousands of Chinese workers and students marched through the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing today, shouting an extraordinary combination of racist and democratic slogans, after two days of clashes with African students studying in the city.

title: Only Ideology Bars Bipartisan Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Speech: For Aliens, Too
description: In the early morning hours of Jan. 26, 1987, seven immigrants living in Los Angeles were arrested at gunpoint in their homes. The Immigration Service then treated the seven, and another immigrant arrested later, just as harshly in custody. They were detained under maximum security for two weeks in prison. They were even handcuffed during meetings with their lawyers.

title: Unusual Bacterium
description: Researchers at the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research in Ithaca, N.Y., have discovered a bacterium that not only derives energy from the sun through photosynthesis but also assimilates nitrogen from the air.

title: McReynolds Reaches Accord With Mets on 3-Year Contract
description: Overcoming problems with lockout language and method of payment, Kevin McReynolds and the Mets reached agreement yesterday on a three-year contract worth $5.5 million. The package computes to the highest annual average value the Mets have ever given a player in a multiyear contract. McReynolds also is the first player to have part of his payment linked to a duck club, the Double Deuce Duck Club, to be precise.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * New Jersey Transit to Poppe Tyson, with a budget in the $2 million to $3 million range.

title: TV and Saudis Open Remote Bit of Pakistan
description: A small village clings to a mountainside in the shadow of the Hindu Kush. Children run to school swinging wooden writing boards because there is no paper for copybooks. Miandam, with its 3,000 people, seems at first glance the picture of isolation.

title: Vandeweghe Update
description: The Portland Trail Blazers yesterday announced that Kiki Vandeweghe would be reactivated Jan. 3 when the Blazers play at home against the Miami Heat.

title: Louisiana Still Trying to Mix Races at Its Colleges
description: Nineteen years after the Federal Government began efforts to eliminate racial barriers at Louisiana's public colleges and universities, those in higher education here are debating how to desegregate.

title: Lewis Swyer, 70, Dies; Arts Center Chairman
description: Lewis A. Swyer, the chairman of Saratoga Performing Arts Center and owner of a construction company that built area landmarks, died after a long illness Sunday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 70 years old.

title: Intervention On the Dollar Faces Tests
description: In July, when the Federal Reserve was trying to cap a surprisingly strong rally in the dollar, many foreign exchange traders were ready, in the words of one dealer, John W. Baker, ''to take on the central banks.''

title: Christmas Gift to Dying Boy: Trip to Washington
description: A 16-year-old boy from Moore, Okla., was showered with gifts and attention last week from Washington dignitaries who were moved by his dying wish to visit the capital.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: Carlo De Benedetti - Olivetti; A Failed Raider Starts To Transform Europe
description: Until Carlo de Benedetti appeared on the scene in January, Societte Generale de Belgique was a European company case in the traditional mold - secreative, top-heavy with senior executives who had started as clerks, and producing steady but modest income for sharedholders.

title: Train's Riders Spend Christmas on Tracks
description: An 18-car passenger train jumped the tracks during a snowstorm Sunday night, stranding nearly 300 holiday travelers overnight but injuring no one.

title: Bertram Salwen, an N.Y.U. Professor, 68
description: Bertram B. Salwen, a professor of anthropology at New York University who specialized in urban and historical archaeology, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: Unpredictable Russians Boggle West's Brains
description: Dominique Moisi, the deputy director of the French Institute of International Relations, says he sometimes feels like ''a representative of an endangered species - those who are still fighting for the survival of the West.''

title: Rise in Short-Term Rates Is Seen
description: Short-term interest rates are likely to move erratically higher this week as credit market participants close their books on 1988.

title: A Point of Light
description: In the election campaign Vice President Bush envisioned ''a thousand points of light,'' Americans engaging in acts of voluntarism to help less fortunate Americans.

title: Review/Television; Foreigners' View of the Old West
description: This Evening at 9 o'clock on Channels 21 and 49 and at 10 on Channel 13, the public television series ''The American Experience'' explores a part of the nation's history that too often - and too sadly - is neglected. ''Views of a Vanishing Frontier'' focuses generally on the old West in the early 1830's and specifically on Native Americans. Made by Craig B. Fisher and Helen Ashton for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the documentary grew out of a 1985 exhibition of the work of the Swiss artist Karl Bodmer.

title: Reagan-Era Americans Make More Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadowlands Sells Itself to Win Big-Time Sports Events
description: After declining revenues in 1985 and 1986 and the loss last year of a public referendum to build a baseball stadium, the Meadowlands Sports Complex is again doing what it does best, attracting some of the sporting world's biggest events.

title: Books of The Times; Product of Early Ambition: Auden's Plays
description: Plays By W. H.Auden and Christopher Isherwood And other dramatic writings by W. H. Auden. 1928-38. Edited by Edward Mendelson. 680 pages. Princeton University Press. $39.50.

title: Careers; Management Participation By Workers
description: GENCORP AUTOMOTIVE needs 400 production workers for a new $65 million plant that makes reinforced plastics at Shelbyville, Ind., near Indianapolis, but it is choosy. It insists on aptitude and personal assessment tests to find highly skilled, trainable, ambitious production workers for an innovative program that eliminates layers of middle managers.

title: R.W. Dammann, 77, Lawyer and Executive
description: Richard Weil Dammann, a lawyer and former director of Philip Morris Inc., died of gastric cancer yesterday at his house in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: The Inside Dope on the Mayans' Fall
description: LEAD: A new book argues that the Mayan civilization may have disappeared because of unprecedentedly high levels of debt the Mayans were persuaded to take on by extraterrestrial leveraged-buyout specialists who visited what is now Yucatan in what was then A.D. 823.

title: The Financial Issues Awaiting Congress
description: When the 101st Congress convenes early next year, two financial issues will demand immediate attention - how to deal with $50 billion to $100 billion of losses in the savings and loan industry, and whether to curb the leveraged buyout frenzy exemplified by the $24.88 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: Rupert Murdoch - News Corporation; The Most Acquisitive Of the Media Giants
description: International media organizations were busy remaking the American publishing scene last year.

title: Market Place; Special Dividend And a Spinoff
description: THE name Chicago Milwaukee Corporation sounds as if the company should be a railroad, and once it was. But the railroad, having been through bankruptcy and sold off, is long gone. Now Chicago Milwaukee has a lot of cash, substantial real estate and some tax-loss benefits.

title: In the Mojave Desert, It's the Tortoise and the Raven
description: IN the western Mojave Desert in southern California, the desert tortoise is pitted against an opponent more sinister than the hare: the raven. This is a struggle for survival, and the reptile is severely overmatched.

title: Jerome Prince Is Dead; Former Dean Was 81
description: Jerome Prince, dean of the Brooklyn Law School from 1953 to 1971, died Saturday in his apartment in Greenwich Village. He was 81 years old.

title: Bond Issues Set For This Week
description: New-issue activity in the government securities market in this holiday-shortened week will center solely on Treasury financings, starting with the regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills today.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: ROBERT CAMPEAU - Campeau; Canadian Developer Scares U.S. Retailers
description: When 64-year-old Robert Campeau this year made his second major campaign of his invasion of American retailing from Canada, he not only routed his opponents but also left behind a new air of fear and defensiveness among even the mightiest retailers.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: Donald Trump - Trump Organization; The Artist of the Deal Turns Sour Into Sweet
description: The man who owns Trump Tower and Trump Parc in Manhattan and the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle in Atlantic City this year bought the Plaze Hotel. He agreed to buy the Eastern airlines shuttle. He planned a big Trump mall in Paramus, N.J. He acquired a huge yacht, Trump Princess. He staged the Spinks-Tyson heavyweight championship fight. HE rode the best-seller lists with ''Trump: the Art of the Deal.'' He scheduled a great bicycle race through several Northeastern states, the Tour de Trump, for next May.

title: Bridge
description: Very few experts deserve to be described as creative in the auction. This is the ability to produce an unusual bid like a rabbit from a hat, prompted by the circumstances of the moment rather than by experience or partnership methods.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * An Epilepsy Foundation campaign has been developed by Klemtner Advertising, which has created eight consecutive campaigns for the foundation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Effort by WQCD
description: Another dose of ''It's Cool to Be Cool,'' the campaign created by Dale Pon to promote the fledgling New York jazz radio station WQCD, began airing on local television stations yesterday. The budget for the expected 16-week effort is $2 million. That is four times the amount spent on the original three-week flight that began in mid-October.

title: Seven Acquisitive Executives Who Made Business News in 1988: F. Ross Johnson - RJR Nabisco; A Spectacular Defeat For a Corporate Titan
description: F. Ross Johnson charged into 1988 as a corporate titan, winning plaudits for shaking up RJR Nabisco Inc. A year later, the man is seen not as a new breed of management chieftain but as a symbol of what has gone wrong with the takeover craze.

title: INSIDE
description: 1989 Economy: Recession Is the Least of the Worries Expecting the nation's economy to grow for still another year, forecasters predict that the ''inevitable'' recession will be delayed until after 1989.

title: John U. Nef, Economic Historian At Chicago University, Dies at 89
description: Prof. John Ulric Nef, an economic historian associated with the University of Chicago for more than half a century and founder of an elite interdisciplinary graduate department died Sunday at his home in Washington after a long illness. He was 89 years old and had lived in Washington for more than 20 years.

title: As a Hotel Is Emptied, The Poor Move On
description: As a gentle rain washed the dusty marquee of the Martinique Hotel in Herald Square the other day, Madeline Ventura, her five children and two cats scampered up the back of a yellow moving van for a ride to their new home in Brooklyn.

title: Lakers Lose 6th in a Row on Road
description: Tyrone Corbin scored 21 points in his first career start for Phoenix and Eddie Johnson had 11 of his 21 points in the fourth period as the Suns beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 111-96, tonight.

title: Law Halting Conversions of S.R.O.'s Does Little to Help Poor
description: A New York City law intended to preserve single-room-occupancy hotels for single low-income people has largely failed to keep thousands of S.R.O. rooms available for poor adults, tenant lawyers and some city officials say.

title: Alleged Mosque Bias Has No Basis in Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway's Oil Cut
description: Norway's planned oil output in the first half of 1989 will be 115,000 barrels a day less than was projected earlier, the Government told Parliament Friday. The Ministry of Oil and Energy said daily production from January to June would average 1.44 million barrels.

title: OFFICIALS AT CRASH STUDYING SUITCASE
description: Officials said today that investigators had found a suitcase and several pieces of wreckage at the site of the Pan American World Airways crash that could show whether a bomb blew the plane apart at 31,000 feet.

title: Dali Released From Hospital
description: Salvador Dali returned home Sunday after being hospitalized for three days with an intestinal lesion, his doctors said.

title: Forecasters Put Off the Recession
description: Economic forecasters are a fatalistic lot. For more than a year, even the most optimistic of them have insisted that a recession is inevitable. But they keep postponing the starting date - and now, as they publish their predictions for 1989, they have once again delayed the recession.

title: Review/Book; Tale of a Fortunate Life
description: Kitty By Kitty Carlisle Hart 263 pages. Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Majerle Sidelined
description: Dan Majerle, the Phoenix Suns rookie guard hospitalized with abdominal pain stemming from mononucleosis, has an enlarged spleen and may be sidelined up to three months.

title: Fermi Prize Is Awarded To Physicists
description: Victor F. Weisskopf of Cambridge, Mass., and Richard B. Setlow of Upton, N.Y., are the 1988 recipients of the Enrico Fermi Award, the Energy Department has announced.

title: French Woman Sets Sights on a Sailing Legend
description: Anne Liardet belongs to a new breed of French sailors: they are racers and they are women.

title: Blackhawks Trade Vaive to the Sabres
description: The Chicago Blackhawks yesterday traded Rick Vaive, a right wing and the team's third-highest scorer last season, to the Buffalo Sabres for Adam Creighton, a center.

title: Browner's Interceptions Spark Viking Victory
description: By the time the first quarter was barely half over today, Joey Browner had intercepted two passes and the Minnesota Vikings turned them into touchdowns. That carried the Vikings to an impressive 28-17 victory over the Los Angeles Rams in the National Conference wild-card game in the National Football League playoffs.

title: AIDS and Cremation
description: People in New York City who die of AIDS are more than twice as likely to be cremated than people who succumb to other conditions, researchers at the Columbia University School of Public Health have found.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have not detected fundamental changes in positions here in Israel but there is a dynamic. People are talking about changes.'' - Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, on a possiblemeeting between Yitzhak Shamir and Hosni Mubarak. [ A8:2. ]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Video Series On Political Ads
description: For those wondering how political advertising compares with product advertising, Campaign Industry News, a newsletter for political professionals, has produced a three-videotape series of the best, worst, toughest and funniest domestic and foreign political ads of 1988.

title: Tenneco Sale Is Completed
description: Tenneco Inc. has closed the $590 million sale of its Chalmette, La., refinery to the Mobil Corporation, completing the sale of its Tenneco Oil Company holdings.

title: Review/Theater; 'Legs' Opens After 9-Week Preview
description: ''Legs Diamond,'' the Peter Allen floor show that held its official opening at the Mark Hellinger last night, wistfully bills itself as ''a big new Broadway musical.'' That it's not, since it isn't particularly big or new or musical. But was it too much to hope for the next best thing - a big new Broadway bomb along the demented lines of ''Kelly'' or ''Dude'' or ''Carrie''?

title: Private Gifts to Public Schools Bring Questions of Fairness
description: At the William A. Ray Elementary School on the city's South Side, students are studying Latin twice each week, taught by an instructor whose salary is paid by parents' donations.

title: Airliner Lands Safely After Its Fuselage Ruptures
description: A rupture in the fuselage of an Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 caused the jetliner to lose cabin pressure suddenly on a flight from Rochester, N.Y., to Atlanta yesterday. The crew made a safe, unscheduled landing in Charleston, W.Va.

title: Harvard Counting
description: It strains credulity, but in 1988 there are still people who keep count of things like the number of Harvard alumni elected to Congress.

title: Seamy Side of Business in Japan Is Uncovered in a Stock Scandal
description: Japan's reputation as an emerging financial and industrial superpower rests on hard work, technological wizardry and a remarkable ability to adapt to international ways. But just when the country's economic influence is being felt around the world, a major domestic scandal is exposing less flattering images of how the country's corporate and political elite sometimes do business.

title: Newcomer Wilson Plays Central Role for Rangers
description: The Rangers traded loyalty in Don Maloney and potential in Brian Lawton and Norm Maciver yesterday for what they hope will be the high-scoring center they desperately need.

title: Lessons
description: As an administrator at the University of Pennsylvania, Claire Gaudiani was once awakened in the middle of the night by a telephone call from a student who was spending a semester in Beijing. It seems that the young lady was upset because she could not make her hair dryer work.

title: Mohasco Chairman To Give Up Top Posts
description: Herbert J. Broner, 61 years old, the top officer of the Mohasco Corporation for the last five years, will step out of the three top jobs as chairman, president and chief executive, effective Dec. 31. He will continue as a consultant for the company.

title: Account Surplus Increases
description: Japan's surplus of current accounts grew in November from a year ago, the Finance Ministry announced today, but officials said they still expected the gap to decline for the year that ends on March 31.

title: Monthly Paper to Advise Nonprofit Groups
description: Charities and other nonprofit organizations have traditionally looked to corporations and foundations to offer guidance on how to solicit funds. But The Nonprofit Times, a monthly four-color newspaper, hopes to change all that.

title: IRAN FREES BRITON HELD FOR 2 YEARS
description: A 23-year-old Briton was freed and flown to Britain today after more than two years in an Iranian jail, and British officials said Iran's move was ''an important step'' toward improving relations.

title: U.C.L.A. Star Is Out
description: Coach Terry Donahue of U.C.L.A. announced the loss of his team's leading tackler yesterday, even before workouts began in a cold rain in Dallas for the Bruins' Cotton Bowl appearance against Arkansas Monday. The senior inside linebacker, Chance Johnson, who had 110 tackles, will miss the game because of a knee injury apparently suffered in a regular season-ending loss to Southern California. (AP)

title: JUSTICE DEPT. GETS REPORT ON MAYOR
description: The Justice Department has been given the results of a police investigation into the recent visits by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to a downtown hotel room where traces of cocaine were reportedly found, Federal and city officials said today.

title: 2 LTV Committees
description: The LTV Corporation's committee of unsecured creditors, assembled during its Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings, has split into two groups, the company said. One group will handle LTV's steel company creditors and the other will be responsible for the parent company's creditors. James F. Powers, LTV's chief financial officer, said the move could hasten the company's emergence from Chapter 11. The Dallas-based LTV filed for bankruptcy protection in July 1986.

title: When Military Left, One Town Saw Opportunity
description: By the week's end a Presidential panel is to recommend to the Pentagon how many and which military bases around the country should be closed to save money, a frightening prospect to any community dependent on the military for its economic welfare. Here is what happened to two communites after nearby bases were closed in the 1960's.

title: Drug Approved to Prevent Ulcers in Arthritis Sufferers
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a drug, misoprostol, to prevent the stomach ulcers that afflict thousands of patients who take large doses of anti-inflammatory drugs for arthritis.

title: Wilson Evens Score With All Concerned
description: Wade Wilson is the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback. He says so. Coach Jerry Burns says so. And after Wilson's performance here Monday against the Los Angeles Rams, no one seems to disagree.

title: Adults at Odds Over 9-Year-Old in a Florida Condominium
description: On school days, 9-year-old Jamie Swartz takes her lunch box and books and joins the world of children. But at the end of the day she returns to a world of adult rules where she is not welcome.

title: Carolina Gold: A Rare Harvest
description: In the South Carolina low country where rice was once king, a now-rare rice that used to be among the most famous in the world is making a comeback. Ten thousand pounds of Carolina Gold was harvested at Turnbridge Plantation in October, the first such harvest in 60 years. The rice is now making its way to the tables of those quick enough to order it.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: Chicago

title: Mets Make Changes
description: Gary Cohen, who has broadcast for Columbia's football team and for minor league baseball teams, was hired yesterday as a radio announcer for the Mets. He replaces Gary Thorne, who was let go by the Mets because he also announces Devils hockey games. Cohen, 30 years old, will join Bob Murphy, a Met announcer since the franchise was founded in 1962. The Mets also announced that Arthur Richman, their traveling secretary since 1980, is stepping down and will be replaced by Bob O'Hara, who has been in charge of the luxury boxes at Shea Stadium for two years. Richman will continue as a special assistant to General Manager Frank Cashen and director of special projects.

title: Release of French Girls Seen as Days Away
description: Contradicting an earlier statement, a spokesman for a radical Palestinian group said today that it might be a few more days before two French girls were released from captivity.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a chemical concern, has sold its remaining dyes business to the BASF Corp. unit of BASF A.G., West Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush Enjoys Outing in Texas
description: President-elect Bush managed to bag some quail on the first day of his vacation at the Lazy F ranch near here on Monday and even had some success today despite gusting winds and overcast skies, his spokesman said.
