title: U.S. Thinks Pro-Iran Group Was Probably Not Involved
description: A consensus is emerging among American intelligence officials that the pro-Iranian group that claimed responsibility for the Pan American World Airways crash last week probably had no involvement.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Inaugural Planners Pledge to Heed Curbs on Troops
description: A retiring Senator, angry that taxpayers paid out nearly $16 million for President Reagan's inauguration in 1985, is counting on one paragraph in a piece of military legislation to keep history from repeating itself.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''President Mubarak is prepared to visit Israel if it is ready to start a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization.'' - Boutros Ghali, Egyptian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. [ A1:4. ]

title: When It Comes to Football, I'll Pass
description: THE season of the bowl games is upon us; I'm not excited. I've never liked football. The language of the game confuses me, and always sounds vaguely off-color: split end, tight end, pass. Until recently, I thought a wingback was part of the holiday turkey you saved for the soup.

title: Big Board's Plan Curbs Use of New Stock Units
description: The New York Stock Exchange has issued a proposal that would allow companies listed on the Big Board to break their stock into new securities as part of a new type of corporate reorganization.

title: Parting Shot By President Of Four A's
description: IN his 10 years at the helm of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Leonard Sarver Matthews has rarely equivocated. He has called comparative advertising a ''wart,'' speculative creative work by agencies pitching an account a ''malignancy,'' a major consultant a ''quisling.'' The 756 member agencies of the Four A's have long known that the meat in his speeches at the organization's annual meetings was not minced.

title: Accounts
description: * Dayna Communications Inc., a Salt Lake City computer software company, and Personal Training Systems, a company in San Jose, Calif., that specializes in computer instruction, to Tycer Fultz Bellack, a BBDO affiliate, with a total budget for the two accounts of $1.2 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Ronald O. Perelman leads a group negotiating to acquire five deeply troubled savings institutions in Texas, with the help of $5 billion in Government aid over 10 years. It would be one of the costliest bailouts to date. [ Page A1. ] The Government should subject the insurance industry to antitrust laws, an A.B.A. panel said. It also called for an investigation of whether ''improper collusion'' had led to price increases and shortages in some lines of liability coverage. [ D1. ] Rules that would open up to four million acres of national parks and other protected Federal lands to coal mining were proposed by the Interior Department. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Public Service of New Hampshire filed a reorganization plan that would enable it to charge ratepayers for its stake in the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant. Public Service would establish a federally regulated holding company, circumventing a state law that bars utilities from charging ratepayers for the cost of a plant before it is operating. State officials said they would fight the plan. [ D1. ] A.T.& T. will pay $250 million for Paradyne, a data-communications equipment producer that is believed to be on the verge of a turnaround. Paradyne makes modems and multiplexers and has particularly strong operations abroad. [ D1. ] Sunshine Mining signed a letter of intent to buy Rexene for $28 a share in cash and securities, or $865 million. The announcement solved the mystery of who was buying Rexene's stock. [ D1. ] An investors' group offered to acquire Del E. Webb in a deal that values the Arizona developing company at $168 million. [ D4. ] Hughes Aircraft will buy Honeywell's flight-simulation unit for an undisclosed sum. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan's electronics industry grew at its fastest pace in more than four years, industry officials said this week, despite remarkable gains by South Korea. [ D1. ] The U.S. confirmed plans to impose sanctions against European foods in retaliation for a scheduled European Community ban on imports of American meat containing growth hormones. [ D2. ] MARKETS The Big Board issued a proposal that would allow companies to break their stock into new securities as part of a reorganization. But the proposal contains significant restrictions. [ D3. ] Stock prices drifted lower, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.25 points, to 2,162.68. [ D6. ] Nasdaq shares sold short and not yet covered rose 1.5 percent for the month ended Dec. 15. [ D15. ] Treasury bill rates climbed along with the yields on notes and bonds. The average discount rate on the 90-day issue rose to 8.22 percent, with the six-month issue rising to 8.33 percent. [ D12. ] Coffee futures prices fell sharply in thin trading on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. [ D13. ] The dollar was mostly higher in quiet trading after ending mixed overseas. [ D13. ] TECHNOLOGY An Australian engineer dreams of powering autos with an efficient and clean two-stroke engine. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Economic logic may be no match for the lobby defending the interests of general aviation. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Chase Medical's stock price has doubled in recent weeks, and the company's chairman is puzzled. Market Place. [ D6. ] Leonard Sarver Matthews has never couched his opinions in equivocations. Advertising. [ D15. ]

title: U.S. May Open Some Parklands To Coal Mining
description: The Interior Department today proposed rules that could open as many as four million acres of national parks and other protected Federal lands to coal mining.

title: Gold Stars for Teaching Nuggets
description: A third-grade teacher in Arizona put the multiplication tables to music. Fifth graders in an Idaho classroom can reel off the names of all 50 states in 30 seconds or less. And educators on an Indian reservation in Minnesota cut the dropout rate in half by adding Indian culture to the curriculum.

title: Eating Well
description: AS the year draws to a close, it's time to catch up on the mail. The Eating Well column attracts a variety of questions about health, whether the subject has appeared here or not.

title: In Pursuit of the Punctual Baby
description: The cost of caring for an infant born prematurely is rising rapidly, and many companies have started special prenatal care programs for employees or their wives to prevent premature births.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: San Francisco

title: Legislator Is Picked To Head Turnpike
description: Governor Kean said yesterday that he would nominate Assemblyman Ralph A. Loveys, Republican of Florham Park, to succeed Joseph A. Sullivan as head of the Turnpike Authority.

title: TRIAL IS ORDERED IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: A man arrested last week in a spy case involving a United States Army intelligence specialist was ordered held without bail today until he is transferred for trial on espionage charges.

title: Newark Struggles to Recreate Itself
description: In a show of civic pride, this unlucky city on the rebound has trained spotlights on prominent downtown buildings, including one that is a block long but half empty.

title: Swank to Sell Units
description: Swank Inc., a jewelry and leather goods manufacturer based in Attleboro, Mass., said it had agreed to sell its Prince Gardner and Wilshire divisions to a company formed by members of Prince Gardner's management and other investors. Terms were not disclosed, and the sale is expected to be completed by the end of January. Prince Gardner makes and distributes leather goods, travel accessories, umbrellas and belts under various brand names.

title: Massimo Mila Dead; Music Critic Was 78
description: Massimo Mila, a music critic and historian who fought against the rise of Fascism, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 78 years old.

title: Food Notes
description: Peanut Butter Glory Days

title: Don't Let Hormones Start a Trade War
description: The United States and the European Community are on the verge of poisoning relations with each other over the Community's plan to ban imports of meat treated with growth hormones. If neither backs down before the deadline, midnight Saturday, their best course would be to seek a neutral arbiter. The alternative is a damaging trade war that isn't worth it.

title: Mrs. Dole's Task at Labor
description: President-elect Bush's appointment of Elizabeth Dole as Labor Secretary gives him another high-profile woman in his cabinet and may improve his relations with her husband, Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader. These are short-term advantages; what will count in the long run is whether Mrs. Dole grasps the changing needs of a changing American work force, especially unorganized workers at the margin of the economy.

title: A Penchant for Older, if Not Better, Champagnes
description: THERE is a shop at 17 place de la Madeleine in Paris that specializes in caviar and smoked fish. If you know Paris, you probably know the place called Caviar Kaspia, just down the block from Hediard, the luxury grocer. Most people rush in, pick up some salmon or a precious ration of beluga and leave. A few, however, pass by the counters and head upstairs to the elegant little restaurant that, they say, still looks like St. Petersburg in the old days.

title: Dyson-Kissner To Get Fortune
description: The Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation appears to have outbid other investors seeking the Fortune Financial Group, a holding company on Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: U.S. Urged To Regulate Insurers
description: An American Bar Association panel said today that the Government should make the insurance industry subject to Federal antitrust laws and investigate whether ''improper collusion'' had led to price increases and shortages in some liability coverage.

title: A Seabrook Owner Sets Rate Plan
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire filed a reorganization plan in Federal bankruptcy court yesterday that would enable the utility to charge its ratepayers for its stake in the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Half Brothers' Big Gift Is Meeting Each Other
description: Two half brothers who had never seen each other got a surprise when they met by chance at a gift-wrapping counter.

title: India Sends Troops to Quell Riots in Southern State
description: Hundreds of paramilitary troops were flown to the southern state of Andhra Pradesh today after more than 25 people were killed in clashes set off by the slaying of a legislator from Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's party, a Government spokesman said.

title: Book Notes
description: Of a Penal Colony

title: Nicholas M. Pette, Judge, 97
description: Nicholas M. Pette, a former justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Second Department, died of a bleeding ulcer Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 97 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Surgery for Sampson
description: Ralph Sampson will undergo arthroscopic surgery on Friday to remove torn cartilage in his left knee and will be sidelined for at least four weeks, the Golden State Warriors announced yesterday. Sampson injured the knee during the first half of the Warriors' loss in Portland last Friday night. The 7-foot-4-inch center has been slowed by two previous arthropscopic surgeries on his knees, and is averaging a career-low 8.3 points and 7 rebounds in 24 minutes a game this season. (AP).

title: Jailer Said to Help in Escape
description: Two of three inmates who escaped from a county jail on Christmas with help from a sympathetic guard have been recaptured, and the guard has been dismissed, the sheriff said. Sheriff Philip Snedeker said Monday that the jailer, Chris Quintana, admitted helping the prisoners.

title: 202 Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included charges of $1,368,379 resulting from estimated cost of liquidation and asset revaluation. The company said comparable year-ago figures and fourth quarter results are not available because the company is in the process of liquidation, begun earlier this year.

title: Home Resale Rise Is 1.1%
description: Sales of existing homes rose 1.1 percent in November, the biggest increase since August, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Bogert Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $880,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Wilson Lends Assist to Rangers
description: The Rangers collected 4 points in two days at the expense of the Devils to stay close to the top of the Patrick Division.

title: Review/Film; Life Without Father, in 'A Hungarian Fairy Tale'
description: The title of Gyula Gazdag's haunting fable amounts to a slight redundancy, since the story of ''A Hungarian Fairy Tale'' could not take place anywhere else. It grows luxuriantly out of a unique peculiarity of Hungarian law, one that requires the birth certificate of an illegitimate child to bear some paternal name, any paternal name, once the child reaches 3 years of age. A name must be fabricated even if the real father's identity is unknown.

title: U.S. Document Provides Glimpse Into Air Force Fraud Investigation
description: An affidavit filed in court last June to justify a search warrant in the Pentagon procurement scandal was released today, providing details of the investigation of Victor D. Cohen, a civilian Air Force official.

title: Tokyo Predicts More Growth
description: Japan's economy, which has already been expanding for 25 months, will continue to grow in 1989, the Economic Planning Agency predicted Monday.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about Christmas shopping misstated the affiliation of Stephen Watson. He is chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Department Stores Company, a division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation.

title: EDUCATION;
description: The United Negro College Fund, the chief fund-raising arm for most of the nation's private black colleges, has surpassed its record for annual contributions, with results from several large urban areas still to be tallied, the organization's officials say.

title: Charting Culinary Currents
description: WATCHERS of culinary trends have always insisted that trends start in New York, Los Angeles or San Francisco. From there they move to large cities along the coasts, then to Chicago and Dallas and Houston, and thence out to smaller cities. By the time a trend reaches the frozen-food section of your supermarket you know it is dead.

title: EATING OUT: With New Yorker Cartoonists; Food as Fodder For Acerbic Wits
description: I THINK food is inherently funny,'' Mick Stevens said, scrutinizing a plate of eggs Benedict recently at a midtown Manhattan restaurant. ''I like the idea of surprise food, the mystery of food.''

title: Europe Sets Asian Duties
description: The European Community said today that it was placing special duties on videocassettes and videotape from Hong Kong and South Korea because they were being ''dumped'' at unfairly low prices in Europe.

title: Lewis Swyer, 70, Dies; Arts Center Chairman
description: Lewis A. Swyer, the chairman of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center and owner of a construction company that built some landmarks, died at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany on Sunday after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Addendum
description: * Davis, Johnson, Mogul & Colombatto Advertising has changed its name to Davis, Ball & Colombatto.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $671,000 for the quarter and $2,085,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter included a $900,000 gain from the sale of the company's Visalia, Calif., plant. The year-ago periods have been restated to reflect the discontinued operations of Aspen Leaf Inc. In the first quarter of 1988, the company changed its method of determining inventory costs from LIFO to FIFO. The prior use of the LIFO method resulted in the company reporting inventories at amounts substantially less than their current replacement costs.

title: Leon Freedman, Lawyer, 83
description: Leon Freedman, a lawyer who specialized in workers' compensation cases, died Saturday at his home in Maitland, Fla. He was 83 years old and had lived for many years in Nanuet and Nyack, N.Y.

title: China's Forgotten Wall
description: LEAD: It has been 10 years since the democracy wall and ''Beijing spring'' came into being, only to disappear the next year. In this decade, great changes have taken place in China and elsewhere. Detente has replaced the cold war. The opening trend in China has become irreversible.

title: Boy, 14, Is Wounded In Fight Over Jacket
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot and wounded Monday night in a confrontation on the campus of City College in Hamilton Heights, the police said.

title: First Federal Savings Arkanas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the losses were largely attributable to estimated provisions for losses on loans, real estate and letters of credit of $28.3 million and $106.1 million during the quarter and year ended Sept. 30, 1988, respectively.

title: A Purchase By Hughes
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it had agreed to buy the flight-simulation unit of Honeywell Inc. for an undisclosed sum.

title: Sometimes The 'Demon' Won't Let Go
description: On Christmas Day, it happened that a story came out of Nevada that said Rod Scurry would be charged this week by prosecutors for allegedly buying two ''rocks'' of crack cocaine in Reno. Scurry was arrested last Thursday, one day after he had become a free agent when the Seattle Mariners released him.

title: Election Echoes
description: In the middle of the fall election campaign there were news reports of a curious statement by Vice President Bush voicing personal concern about the situation of ''ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.'' The autonomous province of Kosovo is a region of Yugoslavia where there has been much strife between the dominant population of ethnic Albanians and the Slavic minority.

title: Investor Group Makes Offer for Del E. Webb
description: A group of investors has offered to acquire the Del E. Webb Corporation in a deal that values the Arizona development company at $168 million, the group said today in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Bridge
description: A player of 20 usually lacks experience and a player of 70 usually lacks stamina. So at what age is a tournament player at his best?

title: With Life Better, Cambodia Fears Worst After the Pullout
description: Ten years after arriving in the baggage train of the invading Vietnamese Army, the leaders of the Cambodian Government are proud of their accomplishments after the savagery of the Khmer Rouge, whom they replaced.

title: The Pop Life
description: Year of George Michael

title: Regan Opposes Thruway Exit at Sterling Forest
description: The New York State Comptroller recommended yesterday that a proposed Thruway exit in Orange County, which Governor Cuomo had promoted, be abandoned as economically and environmentally unsound.

title: Microwave Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: Roopville, Ga.

title: Dow Slips 6.25 Points on a Very Slow Day
description: Stock prices drifted lower yesterday in the opening of what is traditionally one of Wall Street's slowest weeks of the year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Capitals 4, Flyers 3: Mike Ridley's goal snapped a tie 3 minutes 27 seconds into the third period, ending Philadelphia's seven-game winning streak. The victory moved Washington a point ahead of the Flyers and into third place in the Patrick Division.(AP) Dynamo Riga 2, Flames 2: Dynamo Riga rallied, giving visiting Soviet clubs ties in their first two meetings with the N.H.L. Perry Berezan and Hakan Loob scored for the Flames, who played a 5-5 tie Monday night with the other touring team, the Red Army. Aleksandr Kerch and Aleksandr Belyavsky replied for Dynamo, which is making its North American debut.(AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Women Maryland 76, Long Beach State 72: Deanna Tate scored 8 of her 31 points in the final 1:51 last night to lead ninth-ranked Maryland past eighth-ranked Long Beach State. Long Beach's Angie Lee converted a 3-point play with 2:02 remaining to give the 49ers a 72-66 lead. But the Terrapins (6-1), sparked by Tate, scored the game's final 10 points. The Terps went ahead to stay at 73-72 on Vicky Bullett's short jump shot with 1:16 remaining. Tracy Waites led Long Beach (6-3) with 30 points and 7 assists. (AP) SOCCER Norwich Back on Top: Dale Gordon and Andy Townsend scored goals within seven minutes of each other midway through the second half to lift Norwich to a 2-1 victory over West Ham yesterday and back to the top of the First Division of English soccer. The victory gave Norwich 36 points for the season, 2 more than second-place Arsenal. (AP)

title: Sunshine Mining to Acquire Rexene in $865 Million Deal
description: The Sunshine Mining Company announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to buy the Rexene Corporation in a deal that it valued at $28 a share in cash and securities, or about $865 million.

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Attorneys for 2 Indians Ask For New York Investigation
description: Attorneys for two American Indians charged with kidnapping in the takeover of a newspaper office are urging Governor Cuomo of New York to order an investigation into their charges of corruption in a North Carolina county.

title: Betting on Bush
description: Government remains the main business of Washington, and probably always will be. But as the city grows it attracts other business interests, including real estate investors. These investors are displaying distinct caution about the incoming administration of George Bush, according to Douglas M. Firstenberg, a partner in K. S. Sweet Associates, an investment management and venture capital firm that opened a Washington office several years ago.

title: 11 Killed, 250 Missing, In Bangladesh Sinking
description: At least 11 people were killed today and 250 reported missing when a river ferry in Bangladesh capsized and sank after being rammed by a cargo ship, the police said.

title: EGYPT PLAYS DOWN WORD THAT LEADER MIGHT GO TO ISRAEL
description: Egypt today put a damper on speculation that President Hosni Mubarak might visit Israel by linking such a visit to Israel's willingness to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization, something Israel has said it will never do.

title: About Real Estate; New Project at the Brooklyn Army Terminal
description: Work is expected to begin early next year on New York City's $44.5 million plan to add a million square feet of industrial space to the Brooklyn Army Terminal, which the city acquired in 1981 as part of its campaign to retain manufacturing jobs.

title: New York Can Learn From U. of California; Cuts at Hunter
description: To the Editor:

title: Zenith to Increase Color TV Prices
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said it would institute a general price increase averaging 1 percent to 2 percent on its color television sets, effective on Jan. 1. The increases ''represent an important step toward improving Zenith's profit position and that of its distributors and dealers,'' the company's sales chief, Gerald M. McCarthy, said. ''There appears to be real opportunities for price increases to stick.''

title: EVIDENCE OF BLAST ON JET IS REPORTED
description: Investigators looking for the cause of the crash of a Pan American World Airways jet in Scotland said heat damage to the plastic lining of the plane's cargo bay was probably caused by an explosion among the luggage there, The Times of London reported today.

title: Algerian Oil Discovery
description: The Algerian state petroleum agency Sonatrach has struck oil in an area close to the Tunisia border, the agency said today. The find is near Negrine in Khenchela province, 250 miles southeast of Algiers, at depths of more than 9,000 feet, the agency said in a statement.

title: Extradition Set For Financier
description: A court in Italy has agreed to a Swiss request for the extradition of the Cuban-American financier Roberto Polo on charges of embezzlement and fraud, his lawyer said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Pakistan-Born Investor Has Traditional Formula
description: Munawar Hidayatallah owes some of his business success to political instability. But his latest endeavor, a $15-a-share, $297 million takeover bid for the Dataproducts Corporation, relies on a more traditional business formula.

title: Glenn McCarthy, Texas Oilman Who Inspired 'Giant,' Dies at 81
description: Glenn McCarthy, whose flamboyant career helped define the Texas oilman to the world, died Monday at a Houston nursing home. He had turned 81 on Sunday.

title: Nehlen Is Honored
description: The West Virginia football coach, Coach Don Nehlen, was named winner of the 13th annual Bobby Dodd Award in recognition of ''a higher and more noble aspect of college coaching'' and ''a belief that the game of football should be kept in perspective with college life in general.'' His Mountaineers, unbeaten this year, play Notre Dame in the Fiesta Bowl Monday. Nehlen, who is 52 years old, has a 69-35-1 record in nine seasons at West Virginia. (AP)

title: Expansive Welcome Propels an Expansion Team
description: What happens when a growing city in search of a national identity acquires a National Basketball Association franchise? In this community near the North Carolina-South Carolina border, the answer is a frenzied reaction that the hometown newspaper calls ''Hornets Mania.''

title: Fourth-Estate Vanity
description: Anyone who imagines that newswomen might incline more to vanity than newsmen had better listen to Norma A. Lee, who has directed a ''fresh-up lounge'' for members of the press on behalf of Clairol and Bristol Myers at Republican and Democratic national conventions and Presidential inaugurations for some years.

title: Peterson Outdoor Sold
description: Peterson Outdoor Advertising, acquired two years ago by Adler & Shaykin, a New York-based investment group, and several of Peterson's senior managers, was sold yesterday to Boston Ventures Limited Partnership II, a partnership specializing in communications companies. Terms were not disclosed. Peterson manages more than 6,200 billboards, primarily in the Southeastern United States.

title: Books of The Times; Arthurian Legend Wrapped in a Tale of Hoffmann
description: The Lyre of Orpheus By Robertson Davies 472 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: New Anti-Black Rally in China
description: Thousands of Chinese youths demonstrated today in Nanjing, calling on their Government to punish African students who battled Chinese over the weekend, an American witness said.

title: Syracuse Delays Rutgers's Plan With a 100-81 Romp
description: When Bob Wenzel assumed the head coaching position at Rutgers this season, he vowed to return the Scarlet Knights to national prominence and a Top-20 ranking.

title: What of the Prisoners Who Are Not Jean Harris?
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman W. Elson, Theater Manager, 81
description: Norman W. Elson, a manager of New York movie theaters for more than 50 years, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Indonesia's Human Rights Record Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Quiet Vermonter Who Makes His Words Count
description: Vermont's Republican Senator, Robert T. Stafford, may give the worst interview of any public official in the capital.

title: An Unlisted Telephone Means Self-Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Visits Future Office
description: President Reagan paid his first visit today to the penthouse office with a view of the Pacific Ocean that he will use after he leaves office Jan. 20.

title: Contributors To Neediest Cite Homeless
description: When the Sanders family of Bernardsville, N.J., sent a donation to aid the victims of the recent earthquake in Armenia, they also remembered The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''We realized that we should help our own needy and homeless in New York City, too,'' Jane Sanders wrote. They sent $50.

title: Domestic Violence Arrests Quadruple in New York City
description: Arrests in domestic violence cases have more than quadrupled in New York City in the last four years, and Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that was a result of more aggressive police response to reports of family disputes.

title: Letting a Year Go, and a Lot Else With It
description: This is it: the last fling, the last indulgence, one final round of frivolity for legions of New Yorkers before the New Year, when they will once more resolve to get their lives in order and, through hard work and will power, become better, more accomplished and, above all, thinner people.

title: Tass Poll Lists Griffith Joyner No. 1
description: Florence Griffith Joyner of the United States, who won three gold medals in track and field at the Seoul Summer Olympics, has been named athlete of the year in a poll conducted by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: INSIDE
description: A Proposal on Seabrook

title: Nancy R. Taylor, A Priest, Marries
description: The Rev. Nancy Roosevelt Taylor, the deputy for program for the Episcopal Diocese of Southwestern Virginia in Roanoke, was married yesterday to Dr. Lamar John Ryan Cecil Jr., the William R. Kenan Jr. Professor of History at Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Va. Bishop Arthur Heath Light of the southwestern Virginia diocese performed the ceremony at the R. E. Lee Memorial Episcopal Church in Lexington.

title: Pan Am Work For 2 Agencies
description: The Pan Am Corporation named Della Femina, McNamee WCRS as the agency for Pan American World Airways and Grey Advertising as the agency for the Pan Am Shuttle.

title: Uzbekistan Budget Rejected; Legislators Write Their Own
description: Legislators in Uzbekistan have rejected a budget plan from the republic's leadership and written their own, Tass said today.

title: National Environmental Conrols Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Metropolitan Diary
description: GRACE McQUEEN of Manhattan was shuffling through the crowd in front of Saks Fifth Avenue's Christmas windows. She was able to catch only occasional glimpses of the Velveteen Rabbit theme before the crowd merged with the even bigger crowd waiting to see the lighting of the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree. There was some shoving and pushing and a surge to gain a good vantage point. Going along with the flow, Ms. McQueen unexpectedly found herself inside Saks. Sanctuary, she thought. There was milling rather than shoving and the people were gentle, more concerned with shopping than viewing.

title: MaxPharma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $85,772 and $111,211 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $890,665 and $921,759 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Koch to Meet With Leaders Around City
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had begun holding invitation-only meetings with community leaders in 11 troubled New York City neighborhoods in an attempt to ease racial and ethnic tensions.

title: Pay in Japan Rises 4.4%
description: The average Japanese worker got a 4.4 percent pay increase in 1988, or about $75 more each month, the Labor Ministry said today.

title: Brazil Burns the Future
description: Brazilian governments commonly shrug off criticism of the cowboy strand in their society. That strand is evident in the environmental holocaust sweeping the Amazon rain forest and the cold-blooded murder of a trade unionist who dared to challenge slash-and-burn land developers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cityfed Financial Corp., Palm Beach, Fla., a holding company, named John W. Atherton Jr. president and chief executive, succeeding Alfred J. Hedden, who will retire Feb. 1.

title: Narrow Margin
description: In a close vote, John Stephens of the New England Patriots, who starred at Division I-AA Northwestern State in Louisiana, was named the N.F.L.'s offensive rookie of the year by The Associated Press. He received 30 votes, and the Philadelphia Eagles' tight end, Keith Jackson, from Oklahoma, got 29 votes. A Cincinnati running back, Ickey Woods, received 19 votes. Stephens rushed for 1,168 yards, fourth most in Patriot history and fifth in the N.F.L. this season. (AP)

title: Dean Foods Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
From Yale to the Ball Park, Good Conduct Is What Counts
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, one of the country's leading authorities on Dante, Spenser's ''Faerie Queene'' and the nuances of baseball's balk rule, is the author of a new book called ''A Free and Ordered Space: The Real World of the University.'' Its wide-ranging ideas prove that even after trading the campus for the diamond he's still a Renaissance man.

title: About New York; Black Is the Tie That Confers Stylish Glamour
description: Leaving his 18-room Park Avenue apartment, Joel S. Schreiber bids adieu to his live-in household staff of five. Since the chauffeur is using the Jaguar for an errand, he personally guides his gleaming new Rolls-Royce Silver Spur downtown. En route, he chats about his 51-foot yacht and how kind it is of the chef at the Waldorf regularly to send over his favorite dessert, raspberry creme brulee.

title: Generic Wines That Flourish
description: UNLIKE many producers of inexpensive blended wines, John S. Ransom is smiling all the way to the bank. So is Robert J. Palmer. Their small wineries are a universe apart from the goliaths in the generics industry: Gallo, Almaden, Paul Masson, Inglenook and Taylor California Cellars.

title: Hawkins Chemical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: People
description: * Christopher Rudge has been elected general counsel and secretary of the Interpublic Group of Companies, succeeding Edwin A. Kiernan, who is retiring.

title: Texas Creating Wetland Sites to Stem Cholera Among Birds
description: In an attempt to stem an unusual outbreak of avian cholera that has killed more than 7,500 birds, state agencies and volunteer groups have been pumping water into rice fields in southeast Texas for a week to create 1,500 clean wetlands for geese and ducks.

title: VSB Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax income of $741,000 for the quarter and $1,232,000 for the year from a joint venture real estate project. The per share earnings are not available; the company converted to stock form Oct. 27. The results for all periods reflected the operations of Valley Savings Bank as a mutual savings institution.

title: Rate Cut by Belgium
description: Belgium's central bank said today that it was cutting the interest rate on its four-month Treasury certificates to 7.55 percent from 7.65 percent. Last week, the National Bank cut the three-month Treasury certificate rate and the one- and two-month rates.

title: Japan Drug Maker To Buy Pharmavite
description: Otsuka Pharmaceutical Ltd., Japan's third-largest drug maker, has agreed to buy the Pharmavite Corporation of Arleta, Calif., one of the nation's largest makers of vitamins and mineral supplements. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pseudo-Scientific Hot Air
description: LEAD: Good science is often boring. Good science fiction is usually exciting.

title: Shipyard Bid Made in Belfast
description: Managers and workers at Belfast's Harland & Wolff shipyard have made a formal joint bid for control of the state-owned yard, its chairman, John Parker, said today.

title: Auto Makers Are Cheery
description: The top executives of the General Motors and Chrysler corporations today pointed to 1988 as a successful year during which their companies overcame large obstacles.

title: Israel's Shekel Devalued by 5%
description: Israel's central bank devalued the shekel by 5 percent today to stem a wave of panic buying of United States dollars and other foreign currencies. A Bank of Israel spokesman, Gideon Schurr, said the devaluation meant the dollar would now buy 1.68 shekels, compared with 1.599 at the previous rate fixed by the Government.

title: Tom William Scott, Air Force General, 86
description: Tom William Scott, a retired Air Force brigadier general who oversaw long-range bombing of Communist forces in the Korean War, died of natural causes Thursday at his home in La Jolla. He was 86 years old.

title: Schottenheimer and Browns Part Ways
description: Marty Schottenheimer, frequently criticized for assuming the role of offensive coordinator with the Cleveland Browns during the 1988 season, stepped down today as the team's head coach.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Promising Redesign For a Deficient Engine
description: LEAD: Ralph T. Sarich, an Australian engineer who has become one of his country's richest men through real estate deals, has a dream - a world with automobiles powered by the two-stroke engine.

title: Koch Finds Students' Speech Is Wanting
description: Mayor Koch, a man of strong likes and dislikes, doesn't like the way many students speak. ''New York-ese'' disturbs him. Fractured syntax irks him.

title: No Indictment
description: A St. Louis County grand jury decided yesterday not to indict a former St. Louis Blues player, Doug Gilmour, on charges related to sexual relations with a 14-year-old girl. Gilmour, who now plays for the Calgary Flames, testified for about two hours yesterday. His attorney, Gordon Ankney, said his client maintained his innocence in his second appearance before the grand jury. Gilmour, 25 years old, was traded from the Blues to the Flames in a seven-player deal Sept. 6, shortly after a $1 million civil suit was filed against him and his wife, Robyne, by the parents of the girl, who had been baby-sitting for the Gilmours. The accusation against Gilmour was not reported to authorities. He still faces charges filed in the civil suit.(AP)

title: Getting Tired of High-Culture Humility
description: I have long intended to become as knowledgeable about the arts as that critic who reviews them for wise-guy weekly publications issued from New York.

title: Avalanche Survivors Credit Staying Calm
description: Two men who were buried alive for nearly seven hours by an avalanche say they survived because they stayed calm and managed to pound air pockets in the 6-foot-deep snow.

title: President-Elect Martin Van Bush?
description: The morning following his victory, President-elect Bush gave thanks to Martin Van Buren, the last sitting Vice President elected to the Presidency - 152 years ago. Their careers, paths to the White House and the times in which they governed bear striking similarities. Their Presidencies must not. Like Bush, Van Buren had one of the best resumes in Washington, having held a long list of top Government positions before coming to the Presidency - Congressman, executive department head, ambassador, party chair and Vice President.

title: Accidental Shooting Leads To Suicide and Then Death
description: A man accidentally shot his friend in a debate over whether a gun could be knocked out of an assailant's hand before the weapon could be fired, and then killed himself, the police said. The wounded man died later in the hospital.

title: U.S. Lists Europe Goods That Face Retaliation
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would impose $100 million worth of trade sanctions against European food products in retaliation for a scheduled European Community ban on imports of American meat that contain growth hormones.

title: The Warmth of the Caribbean Comes Home for the Holidays
description: LEAD: FOR many Americans of Caribbean descent, removed from their past by time and geography, the most vivid recollections of the holiday season evolve around foods, a true link to the cultural past.

title: Courtroom Cameras, Still on Trial
description: Millions have watched Hedda Nussbaum's dramatic televised testimony in the Lisa Steinberg murder case, testimony that until recently could only have been seen by a few spectators in a Manhattan courtroom. Does the magnification serve the public interest? Perhaps, but the broadcasting of trials is still not a settled question. It's on trial in New York, an extended, interesting experiment that can help resolve the age-old debate over the effect of cameras in the court.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: John N. Thurber, 81, Labor Dept. Economist
description: John Newton Thurber, a labor economist, died of cardio-respiratory arrest December 18 at Providence Hospital in Washington. He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Boston Ready to Overhaul School Busing Policy
description: This city is on the verge of overhauling its school busing policy for the first time since 1974, when a Federal district judge ordered the public schools to desegregate, a decision that convulsed Boston and made it a national symbol of racial intolerance.

title: Will the French Now Wonder How to Spell 'Cause Celebre'?
description: When some schoolteachers called recently for simplifying the rules of French spelling, French writers and intellectuals quickly condemned the teachers as traitors out to sabotage the hallowed language of Voltaire, Balzac and Proust.

title: Review/Music; 'Brandenburgs' at the Y
description: In 1976, when the 92d Street Y was considering starting a chamber orchestra, it sent up a trial balloon in the form of two concerts devoted to Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concertos. The concerts proved there was an audience for such a venture, and the New York Chamber Symphony (then called the Y Chamber Symphony) was started the next season.

title: Revco DS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
OPEC Official to Egypt
description: Subroto, the OPEC Secretary General, and the oil minister of Oman, Said Bin Ahmed al-Shanfari, will visit Egypt for talks Jan. 9, an Egyptian minister was quoted as saying Monday. Egypt's Minister of Oil and Mineral Wealth, Abdel-Hadi Kandeel, was quoted in Al Ahram, a semiofficial newspaper, as saying the talks would focus on ways to stabilize world oil prices. Egypt and Oman are not members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but the talks appear to be aimed at coordinating the pricing policy of OPEC members and nonmembers.

title: Bulgaria Ends Its Ban On Radio Free Europe
description: Bulgaria has stopped jamming Radio Free Europe after more than three decades, and the station can now be heard in every country of the Eastern bloc, a station spokesman said today.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Up 1.5% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 1.5 percent monthly increase in the ''short interest'' for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Hassan of Morocco Agrees to Talk With Western Saharan Guerrillas
description: King Hassan II of Morocco has agreed to meet with guerrillas of the Polisario Front, who have fought his troops for 13 years over Western Sahara and whose existence he has refused to acknowledge until now.

title: Cavaliers Reach League-Best 19-5
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, with the best record in the National Basketball Association, won their sixth straight game tonight as Larry Nance scored 8 of his 18 points in the final 2 mintues 47 seconds in a 107-96 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Teresa Rosen Gordon, Teacher, 81
description: Teresa Rosen Gordon, a retired English teacher in New York City, died of stomach cancer Sunday at her son's home in San Francisco. She was 81 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Market Place; Chase Medical's Recent Gyrations
description: FEW stocks have done better late this year than Chase Medical Group Inc., a Miami-based chain of medical clinics that primarily serves Hispanic clients. In a move that the company's chairman called puzzling, the stock price more than doubled on huge volume in recent weeks despite a dearth of good news about the company's prospects.

title: Memories Of an Era Form Basis Of Lessons
description: Julian Bond, who had to fight to be seated in the Georgia General Assembly when he was 26 years old, is teaching about that and other incidents in civil rights history to students who were not alive when he was first elected.

title: JAPANESE LEADER SHUFFLES CABINET
description: Buoyed by his success in enacting a tax overhaul and undaunted by record low popularity ratings, Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita shuffled his Cabinet today, choosing politicians untainted by a stock trading scandal.

title: McMillan of Jets Earns Rookie Award
description: Erik McMillan of the Jets, who led the American Conference with eight interceptions, was named National Football League defensive rookie of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. McMillan, a free safety from Missouri drafted on the third round, was the only rookie defensive player named to the Pro Bowl. Although he missed three games with a foot injury, McMillan easily finished first in balloting by a panel of sportswriters covering all 28 teams. Chris Spielman, a linebacker for the Detroit Lions, was runner-up. (AP)

title: Detroit Journal; Its Food Is Not Enough To Sustain Chop House
description: The London Chop House, the clubby dowager of Detroit restaurants that is a favorite of visitors from Frank Sinatra to the New York Yankees, has fallen on hard times in recent months and is now the focus of a rescue effort by local businessmen who remember its glory days.

title: CUOMO URGES SHIFT ON LOCAL TAXATION
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would like to see local governments raise more of their own tax revenues and that he would seek expanded authority for them to do so.

title: Manila Seeks I.M.F. Loan
description: A new loan package from the International Monetary Fund is needed to help the Philippines sustain its economic recovery in 1989, Finance Minister Vicente Jayme said today.

title: CD's: Too Much of a Good Thing?
description: When the Compact Disk was introduced to the American market in April 1983, its inventors - the Sony and Philips corporations - predicted that it would render the long-playing record extinct within a decade. The LP may not take that long to die.

title: Wax Figures in Black Cut Chains of Stereotypes
description: When asked why he and his wife decided to start the nation's first wax museum dedicated to black historical figures, Elmer Martin said it was simply a matter of providing ''visual impact'' to history.

title: Researchers Establish Dangers of Steroids
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. in $250 Million Deal for Paradyne
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would pay about $250 million in cash for the Paradyne Corporation, a data-communications equipment producer thought to be on the verge of a turnaround.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: Boston

title: 3-Month Bill Rates Climb to 8.22%
description: Treasury bill rates climbed and prices fell in light trading yesterday. Yields on notes and bonds also rose. At the holiday-delayed weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate on the 90-day issue rose to 8.22 percent from 8.14 percent, with that on the six-month issue rising to 8.33 percent from 8.29 percent.

title: New York Can Learn From U. of California
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Electronics Thrive Despite Asian Competition
description: Japan's electronics industry grew at its fastest pace in more than four years in 1988, industry officials said this week, despite remarkable gains by South Korea in an area Japan once had all to itself: exports of videocassette recorders and other consumer electronics to the United States.

title: Daw Khin Kyi, Burmese Leader's Widow, 76
description: Daw Khin Kyi, widow of a Burmese independence leader and mother of an opposition leader, died today after a long illness, her family said. She was 76 years old.

title: Use of Polygraph in Hiring Is Curbed by U.S.
description: Many uses of the polygraph, or lie detector, by private employers became illegal today under a law that the American Civil Liberties Union calls a ''holiday gift to working people.''

title: As Fetisov Visits, He Wishes He Could Stay
description: He wants to leave the Soviet Union, where he has already garnered every hockey honor imaginable, to test his skills in the National Hockey League. But Vyacheslav Fetisov says he is bound by a 25-year military contract and a coach who isn't ready to staff a national team without him.

title: Harold Lax, Manufacturer, 64
description: Harold Lax, a Long Island manufacturer who was active in Zionist causes, died of chronic heart disease while awaiting a heart transplant Monday at the Texas Heart Institute in Houston. He was 64 years old and lived in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Chrysler to Raise Prices of Eagles
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would raise the price of its Eagle Premier mid-sized sedan effective next Monday because of the weakness of the American dollar against the French franc.

title: Ewing Gives Knicks A Momentary Scare
description: If Patrick Ewing is hurt, what will happen to the Knicks?

title: After a Year, Gentile's Era Is Near End
description: As the brief tenure of the 11th District Attorney in the Bronx comes to a close, some of the framed mementos on the wood-paneled walls of his office are taking on an ironic tone.

title: Quiksilver Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago shares outstanding and share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Nov. 19, 1987, to stockholders of record on Oct. 30, 1987.

title: Iran Ties Help to Hostages to Fate of Its Nationals
description: In July 1982, three Iranians were kidnapped in northern Lebanon. The case of the missing Iranians, whose disappearance is ascribed by Iran to Christian Phalangist militiamen, is connected to the fate of more than a dozen Westerners presumed kidnapped by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon.

title: Akagera Journal; Wildlife Park Seeks New Species: Tame Tourists
description: An early-morning light, the color of champagne flecked with violet, arched over vibrant green papyrus swamps, giving the first clues of the abandoned wildlife in this little-known habitat.

title: KEY RATES
60-Minute Gourmet
description: WHILE growing up in France, I developed a fondness for beef, veal and lamb's tongue, inexpensive and delicious cuts of meat. The flavor of tongue is mild, and it goes well with all sorts of tart and spicy sauces. So it is difficult to understand why some Americans have not warmed up to the idea of eating tongue when so many have learned to enjoy such other delicacies as sweetbreads, tripe and brain.

title: From the Soup to the Mousse, A Bubbly Accompaniment
description: LIKE parentheses around a meal, Champagne is frequently served as an aperitif and with dessert. There is no reason, however, why it cannot accompany the first course or the main course; why, indeed, it cannot be the only type of wine served with a meal.

title: U.N.'s Big 5 Seek Namibia-Force Cost Cuts
description: The United States, the Soviet Union and the other permanent members of the Security Council are seeking to reduce their share of the bill for the proposed Namibian peacekeeping operation and cut back its size and overall cost, diplomats say.

title: Lawyers Doubt U.S. Jet Liability
description: Lawyers said yesterday that the United States Government would not be legally liable for failing to notify passengers of a warning that a Pan Am flight from Europe might be bombed, even if such a warning proved relevant to the crash last week in Scotland.

title: Economic Scene; A No-Losers Deal For Busy Airports
description: WHAT does it cost to accommodate the landing of a Piper Cub at a big-city airport? A few dollars' wear and tear on the tarmac, say owners of private planes, plus a bit to cover the airport overhead.

title: Many Characters in Search of Tyson in His Chaotic Year
description: Back in September, as Mike Tyson was recuperating from an automobile accident, his wife, Robin Givens, was standing watch in his Manhattan hospital room, a forlorn expression on her face.

title: Snowstorm Snarls Holiday Air Traffic at Chicago
description: Hundreds of weary travelers who spent the night at O'Hare International Airport waited in long lines for flights today as the nation's busiest airport struggled to recover from its first major winter snowstorm of the season.

title: Interco Gets Offer For a Subsidiary
description: Interco Inc., which had resisted a prolonged takeover bid by the Rales brothers of Washington, said it had received an offer from the Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corporation to acquire its Londontown subsidiary for $190 million in cash. Interco, based in St. Louis, had agreed to sell the unit for $178 million to a company formed by Londontown's senior management. That transaction was scheduled to close tomorrow.

title: Social Security Said to Bridge Gap in Income
description: Social Security is the Federal Government's most effective weapon against poverty and reduces the inequality of Americans' income more than the tax system and more than recent social welfare programs, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Brennan Returns to His Job After Removal of Gallbladder
description: Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court, who underwent surgery to remove his gallbladder two weeks ago, returned to work today.

title: Pennwalt Spurns Bid By Centaur
description: The board of the Pennwalt Corporation today rejected a buyout proposal of $100 a share from Centaur Partners, calling the figure ''completely unacceptable.''

title: Anthony R. Gaeta Is Dead at 61; Ex-Staten Island Borough Leader
description: Anthony R. Gaeta, a former borough president of Staten Island, died of heart failure on Monday at Staten Island Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: ...But the Other, in South Dakota, Lost an Economic Lifeline
description: In the two decades since an Army ammunition depot closed and cost this town more than 500 jobs, Edgemont has tried to find another healthy payroll, even courting a string of potentially hazardous industries.

title: Citicorp Auction Rates Are Down
description: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. This week's decline is only the second time since Nov. 1 that rates have dropped.

title: St. John's Routs Fordham; Ohio State Gains
description: One day after receiving crushing news about a star player, St. John's put on a crushing performance against Fordham and coasted to an 84-59 victory last night in the second game of the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

title: Tranquilizer Stigma
description: To the Editor:

title: Hal Ashby, 59, an Oscar Winner Whose Films Included 'Shampoo'
description: Hal Ashby, who won an Academy Award for his film editing and whose critical and popular successes as a director included ''Harold and Maude,'' ''Shampoo'' and ''Coming Home,'' died of liver and colon cancer at his home in Malibu, Calif., yesterday. He was 59 years old.

title: Stalin's Victims: An Uneasy Enshrinement
description: Leaders of an independent group that has mounted a highly successful nationwide campaign to honor the victims of Stalin said today that they fear the Soviet authorities have set out to seize control of their effort and limit its scope.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry Links Four Bank Robberies
description: An F.B.I. investigation has tied four northern New Jersey bank robberies to one suspect, the agency said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; Mini-Series Investigates The Bible
description: On the Discovery cable channel at 9 tonight, a British archeologist, John Romer, begins a seven-part journey back into the sources of the Bible. Mr. Romer, the spirited narrator of ''Testament,'' remarks early that he does not go to church, so we understand that his approach to biblical history will not be literal. Yet he shows a respect amounting to reverence for the language and the power of the book that he traces to Mesopotamia some thousands of years before the Christian Era. And he has the additional charm of not speaking in the Oxbridge accent stamped on most productions from England.

title: L.I. Man Kills Estranged Wife; Commits Suicide
description: A man free on bail while facing charges that he had threatened his estranged wife with a shotgun broke into her home Monday, fatally shot her and then killed himself, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Detecting a Bomb's Debris Is Simple
description: If a bomb caused the Pan Am crash in Scotland last week, investigators stand a good chance of finding conclusive evidence of the explosion, American experts say. But they add that even the latest bomb-detection technology may not prevent similar tragedies.

title: Rachel Hosmer, Priest, 80
description: The Rev. Rachel Hosmer, one of the first women ordained to the priesthood of the Episcopal Church, died of cancer Friday at the Convent of St. Helena in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 80 years old.

title: Article 990588 -- No Title
description: In what would be one of the costliest bailouts of savings and loan associations to date, Government officials said tonight that they had worked out a plan for an investment group to take over five deeply troubled Texas institutions with the help of $5 billion in Government aid over 10 years.

title: Holtz Uncovers Reasons To Fear Bowl Opponent
description: For a coach whose team has trailed for just 29 minutes 25 seconds of a memorable 11-game season, Lou Holtz of Notre Dame sounded gloomy even by his own standards of pre-game pessimism.

title: Fetisov Expresses Anger As Devils Seem No Closer
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, who wants to be a New Jersey Devil but does not want to defect to do it, wore borrowed Islander pants as he practiced with his Red Army teammates this afternoon. He posed stonily for photographers and then, just as he had in a quiet hotel lobby upon his arrival Tuesday night, spoke candidly of his desire to leave the Soviet Union for the Devils.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Mayor Koch's proposal to ease racial tensions in New York City misidentified one area where he plans to meet with community leaders. It is the Belmont section of the Bronx, not Queens.

title: Michigan Upset in Tournament
description: Alaska-Anchorage, a Division II school, stunned Michigan, 70-66, tonight in the opening round of the Utah Classic behind Michael Johnson's 20 points and Todd Fisher's 18.

title: A.T.&T. Files A Complaint On 'Dumping'
description: Asserting that it had experienced ''heavy and growing financial injury,'' the American Telephone and Telegraph Company petitioned the Government today to investigate its complaint that companies in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan were selling small-business telephone equipment in the United States at unfair prices.

title: U.S. Lifts Fiji Aid Suspension
description: The United States is resuming economic aid to Fiji that was suspended last year after a coup attempt in the Pacific island nation, the State Department said Tuesday. A department statement said the decision to resume the aid, which totaled nearly $1.4 million, was made in view of recent steps taken by the Fijian Government to restore democracy.

title: Bridge
description: An enthusiast from England recently pointed out that dictionary definitions of bridge vary considerably but are uniformly dull. He asked for an improvement, and this department offered the following: ''A difficult game of chance for four players, one of whom, the dummy, is supposed to be dumb. Each deal is in two stages: bidding, involving a language that may be artificial, and play, a tricky mathematical exercise.''

title: Ditka-Ryan: Don't Sing 'My Buddy'
description: Buddy Ryan has never been Mike Ditka's buddy. And when the Philadelphia Eagles play the Bears in Chicago on Saturday in the Super Bowl XXIII tournament, the two head coaches will be on opposite sidelines. But unlike some opposites, these two don't attract.

title: Office Pool, 1980
description: Only three more weeks to go before Jack Kemp and Jeane Kirkpatrick are inaugurated as President and Vice President of the United States. That's what was predicted in this Office Pool last year, and I am not yet prepared to concede error.

title: Metro Matters; When Speaking To Mayor Koch, Ax No Questions
description: Mayor Koch once offered a historical example to hammer home his point about mispronounced words. A new President is delivering a stirring inaugural address. He is knocking at the threshold of oratorical greatness when he thunders: ''Axe not what your country can do for you, axe what you can do for your country.''

title: Stouffer Acquires Stanford Court
description: The Stouffer Hotel Company, which is based in Solon, Ohio, acquired the Stanford Court, one of the most luxurious hotels in San Francisco. The 402-room hotel was purchased from the Royal Stanford Hotel Company, a California limited partnership, for an undisclosed amount. It is Stouffer's first hotel in San Francisco and its second in California.

title: Surgery Is Performed On Cab Calloway
description: Cab Calloway, one of the last of the great swing-band entertainers, had surgery here early today after collapsing during a show in Tokyo and flying home.

title: Events: Making an All-Natural Calendar
description: Ringing in the New, Urban Park Rangers, Central Park; 212-397-3080.

title: KEY RATES
Ransburg May Get 2d Takeover Offer
description: Great American Management and Investment Inc. disclosed that it was interested in making an offer for the Ransburg Corporation that would be higher than the current tender offer of $16 a share, or $129 million, from the LFC Financial Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Great American said that it had purchased a 7.8 percent stake in Ransburg and was seeking clearance to acquire more than 50 percent of Ransburg shares outstanding. Great American is a Chicago-based manufacturing and financial services concern controlled by the investor Samuel Zell.

title: ASA Limited reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Assets represent net assets. The figures were based on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange closing prices. Net investment income for 1988 was $26,146,878, or $2.72 per share, and the year-earlier net investment income was $35,224,833, or $3.67 per share.

title: Wisconsin Toy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Leslie T. Steppel Is Wed To Dr. Stuart Weisbrod
description: Leslie Tonia Steppel and Dr. Stuart Terry Weisbrod, vice presidents at Prudential-Bache Securities, were married yesterday at the Box Tree Restaurant in New York by Rabbi Reuven Siegel.

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Ex-Army Mechanic Is Indicted on Spying Charges
description: A Federal grand jury here indicted a Florida man today on a charge that he conspired to deliver intelligence secrets to agents of the Eastern bloc.

title: F.D.R. Would Cry
description: Each new day brings a new post-mortem of the Democrats' fifth defeat in the past six Presidential campaigns and a corresponding proposal for change. If Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, Lyndon B. Johnson, John F. and Robert F. Kennedy or Hubert H. Humphrey were still with us, one suspects they would laugh, cry or, more likely, lose their tempers at the nonsense embodied in most of these notions.

title: High Winds Lash the East; Ship Capsizes
description: A damp balmy day in the New York metropolitan region turned suddenly cold and violent yesterday, as thunderstorms and gusting winds toppled trees, cut power lines and slowed traffic.

title: Risk Inherited at Finnish Concern
description: During his 11 years as chief executive, Kari Kairamo transformed Oy Nokia, Finland's largest private corporation, from a stodgy producer of pulp, paper, chemicals and rubber goods into an aggressive international leader in color televisions, mobile telephones and other electronics.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,925,000 for the latest 12 months and $14,984,000 for 1987. The year-ago period's results restated to reflect the writeoff of Connecticut Light and Power Co.'s disallowed portion of its Millstone 3 investment.

title: For Seahawks, Worse Is Better
description: The Seattle Seahawks, in their 13-year history, have had better players and better records than they have had this year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 A plastic explosive device blew apart the Pan Am jet that crashed in Scotland, British investigators said. They said two parts of the framework of a luggage rack showed evidence of a detonating high explosive. Page A1

title: Akira Kurosawa Film To Be Autobiographical
description: Akira Kurosawa has said he would begin shooting a film early next year as a series of nine stories based on his life.

title: Cavaliers Crush Hornets for Seventh Consecutive Victory
description: Ron Harper scored 19 points, leading seven Cleveland players in double figures tonight as the Cavaliers beat the Charlotte Hornets, 122-98, for their seventh straight victory.

title: Target Social Security on the Needy
description: A new study by the Census Bureau confirms that Social Security is the best anti-poverty program the nation has yet devised. Thanks to it, only 14 percent of elderly Americans fell below the poverty line in 1986; without it, nearly half would have been. Unfortunately, this evidence may add to Social Security's aura of untouchability in Congress and the White House as they grapple with solutions to the Federal budget deficit.

title: How to Stop Millions of Infant-Diarrhea Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Mountaineers' Life at Top Is Fight Against Putdowns
description: Renaldo Turnbull, a linebacker at West Virginia University from St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, had already been in Morgantown for several years when he heard that his sister, who had also come to the mainland, refer to his college home as western Virginia.

title: Critic's Notebook; Ever-Provocative Courbet Examined Anew
description: For much of his career during the middle of the 19th century, Gustave Courbet gladly played the bad boy of French painting, basking in the disdain that Parisian critics repeatedly tossed at his canvases. His work still engenders stormy debates among students of art, who over the years have constructed around his monumental images of the downtrodden and his heartily painted vistas of the French countryside myriad interpretative strategies. To trace the course of scholarship on Courbet is in a sense to sketch the history of art-history and its relation to politics during roughly the last century.

title:
Market Place;
Junk-Bond Funds Tempt Investors
description: LEAD: LURED by yields of 14 percent to 16 percent, many investors are buying ''junk bonds'' -the very speculative debt used to help finance some huge leveraged buyouts.

title: Mother Indicted For the Slaying Of Her Child, 5
description: The mother of Jessica Cortez, a 5-year-old child found dead with a broken neck in a Brooklyn apartment two weeks ago, has been indicted in the case despite her argument that she was physically and psychologically abused by the man with whom she lived.

title: It Was No Joke: The Coach Was Sick
description: One of the first things the Sacramento Kings' coach, Jerry Reynolds, requested after an ambulance took him to an emergency room Tuesday night was a bag of popcorn and a beer. That kind of joking is typical of the popular coach. In fact, Reynolds is so known for his jokes and courtside antics that most of the 16,517 fans who saw him collapse and lose consciousness during the Kings' victory over the Portland Trail Blazers in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday night thought it was a stunt. Even his players at first thought Reynolds was joking, and Referee Blaine Reichelt called a technical foul against the Kings, assuming that Reynolds had thrown himself onto the floor to mock an earlier call Reichelt made against the Kings. But the 44-year-old coach wasn't joking when he collapsed during the game. Although there were early fears that Reynolds had suffered a heart attack, the Kings' team physician, Dr. James Castles, said yesterday that Reynolds showed no evidence of a heart attack in tests conducted so far. The doctor also said Reynolds would be released from the hospital this afternoon if his final scheduled heart test, a treadmill study, showed normal results. Castles said that after a controversial foul call against the Kings, Reynolds ''leaped into the air and seemed to get dizzy.'' Reynolds fell face-first onto the arena floor and lost consciousness for about 30 seconds. The game was stopped 10 minutes with 5 minutes 56 seconds left while Castles and other doctors in the arena, including two cardiologists, examined him, attached a heart monitor to his chest and finally placed him on a stretcher. (AP)

title: Campaign Financing Pact Set
description: Leaders of the Legislature reached agreement today on a bill that would raise the legal limits on spending by gubernatorial candidates who accept public financing for their campaigns, Governor Kean announced.

title: China Venture In South Korea
description: In the first known investment by a Communist country in South Korea, a Chinese electronics company has agreed to form a joint venture here to make color television parts.

title: Chief Stepping Down At Farm Cooperative
description: Gold Kist Inc., one of the nation's largest farmers' cooperatives, said yesterday that William W. Gaston, 63 years old, will relinquish the title of chief executive on Sunday and retire on Sept. 1. He has served 10 years.

title: Banning the Bomb in India
description: LEAD: Until recently, I was one of those Indian defense specialists who supported India's refusal to sign the nuclear nonproliferation treaty. But eight years of President Reagan's laissez-faire policy on nuclear proliferation has changed my mind. India was better off under President Jimmy Carter's stringent policies.

title: Prime Computer Sets New Round of Layoffs
description: Prime Computer Inc. today announced a second round of layoffs, involving 1,200 employees in the next six months, as part of its realignment after the acquisition of the Computervision Corporation.

title: Sakharov Visits the Caucasus In the Quest for Ethnic Peace
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, reportedly acting at the personal request of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has joined the search for a settlement between the embattled republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Indiana Wins in Liberty Bowl: Dave Schnell passed for 378 yards and 2 touchdowns, including an 88-yard game-breaking toss to Rob Turner, leading Indiana to a Liberty Bowl victory over South Carolina last night. The victory capped an 8-3-1 season for Indiana. South Carolina ended the year 8-4. The Gamecocks never have won a bowl game, dropping to 0-8 with the loss. Collin Mackie had kicked a 43-yard field goal for South Carolina, making it 20-10. But Schnell then put the game away on the first play of the fourth quarter. He spotted Turner behind the secondary and Turner pulled in the pass at the Gamecocks' 40. He never was touched on the longest scoring pass in Liberty Bowl history.(AP) HOCKEY Nordiques 4, Whalers 4: Walt Poddubny scored a power-play goal with less than six minutes left in the third period as Nordiques rallied for the tie in Quebec last night. Poddubny took a drop pass from Peter Stastny just inside the Whalers' blue line, skated to edge of the left face-off circle and unleashed a hard wrist shot that eluded the goaltender, Peter Sidorkiewicz. (AP) Sabres 4, Red Wings 1: Rick Vaive, playing his first game with Buffalo after being acquired from Chicago, scored one goal and assisted on another to help lead the Sabres in Buffalo last night. Vaive, who came to the Sabres in exchange for Adam Creighton on Monday, scored the game-winner at 9:09 of the second period as the Sabres won their fourth straight game and extended their unbeaten streak to six. (AP) Jets 6, Blues 2: Dale Hawerchuk's second goal of the game capped a three-goal outburst in a 75-second span of the third period as Winnipeg ended a five-game winless streak last night. Hawerchuk, usually a center but playing left wing on a line with Thomas Steen and right winger Pat Elynuik, also collected an assist as the Jets snapped an 0-4-1 slide.(AP) Blackhawks 4, North Stars 3: Denis Savard scored a shorthanded goal and newly acquired Adam Creighton had the game-winner in a four-goal second period Wednesday, sparking Chicago to a 4-3 victory over Minnesota and giving coach Mike Keenan his 200th career triumph. Following a scoreless first period in which the two teams were a combined 0-for-8 on the power play, Steve Larmer's 18th goal of the season got the Blackhawks on the board at 9:50 of the second period. But Basil McRae countered at 12:47, beating Darren Pang on a wraparound.(AP) TENNIS Petrushenko Advances: Valdimir Petrushenko of the Soviet Union, last year's runner-up and seeded seventh this year, came back for a 6-7, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Travis Boyd of Castleton, N.Y., to advance to the quarterfinals yesterday of the boys 18-and-under division of the Port Washington (L.I.) International Championships. In the boys-16 quarterfinals, Nicholas Lorenzini of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was eliminated by John DeJager of South Africa, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Mandlikova Loses: Hana Mandlikova, playing her first match for Australia, lost to 17-year-old Sarah Loosemore of Britain, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the opening round of the Hopman Cup. Mandlikova, who became an Australian citizen last January, was playing for the first time since Wimbledon. The former Czechoslovak star has been sidelined by a hamstring injury. Mandlikova teamed with Pat Cash in the mixed doubles, beating Jeremy Bates and Loosemore, 6-4, 7-5. The Hopman Cup is being contested by teams of two players from eight nations. Each player has a singles and a mixed doubles match.(AP)

title: South Korean Debt Ending
description: Once one of the world's biggest borrowers, South Korea is expected to turn the tables next year and become a creditor nation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Recollections For Auld Lang Syne
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-EIGHT was a time of ironic turnabouts in the communications industry.

title: Metro Datelines; Harlem Hospital Is Cited on Waste
description: The Harlem Hospital Center was charged yesterday with two criminal violations of the state's new law for handling medical wastes.

title: Peter Critchell Is Wed To Yin Mei, a Dancer
description: Yin Mei, a dancer, choreographer, teaching fellow and Ph.D. candidate in dance and dance education at New York University, was married at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Peter Laurence Critchell, a second-year law student at Columbia University. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins and the Rev. Ichiro Matsuda, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Dance; Tapping Through an Evening in Honor of Mama Lu Parks
description: Mama Lu Parks was honored Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall by the Bronx Arts Council and a theater full of cheering fans. The performers onstage showed the same affection for Miss Parks, a longtime resident of the Bronx and the director of a noted company of Lindy Hop dancers. And the indomitable Miss Parks - who observed the Lindy Hop dancers of the 1930's and 40's at the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem while working there as a teen-ager - responded in kind.

title: Personal Health
description: Chances are that over the holidays you will go to a party where you will consume one or more alcoholic drinks, after which you will drive home or to another party. And chances are that even if you do not drink and then drive, several other guests at the party will.

title: Statement by Investigators
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Air Accidents Investigation Branch of the British Department of Transport on the crash of Pan Am Flight 103:

title: Deadline For Farmers
description: About 83,000 United States farmers with overdue debts to the Government will soon face a deadline for taking steps to avoid foreclosure, the head of the Farmers Home Administration said today.

title: Books of The Times; The Politics of the Philosopher
description: Bertrand Russell A Political Life By Alan Ryan 226 pages. Hill & Wang. $19.95.

title: Boston Revamps Busing Plan
description: After 15 years of court-ordered busing that touched off violent opposition and the departure of whites from the city, Boston has approved a school assignment plan of its own in hope of salvaging the troubled public school system.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Peace on Earth?
description: The year 1988, it is generally agreed, has been a pretty good one for peace, with the conclusion of a Soviet-American agreement to eliminate intermediate range nuclear weapons; cessation of the Iran-Iraq war, and the beginning of withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan. His followers say a lot of the credit is due Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, an advocate of transcendental meditation. While he is remaining in India, about 1,000 of his American followers are gathering in Washington today. The occasion at the Omni Shoreham Hotel, is being billed as ''Success! Peace Wave 1988 - 30 Years of TM Activities Culminate With Peace on Earth.''

title: Fertility Rate In Utah Is Off Amid Slump
description: For the first time in the history of Utah, a state dominated in nearly every aspect by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the fertility rate is declining.

title: Metro Datelines; Tollbooths Faulted On Garden State
description: Tollbooths on the Garden State Parkway contribute to pollution and accidents, a study released yesterday says.

title: Maltese Resigns As Party Chief To Enter Senate
description: Serphin R. Maltese, a leader of the New York State Conservative Party for 17 years, has stepped down as state chairman and has been succeeded by his second-in-command, Michael R. Long, the Brooklyn Conservative leader and a former City Councilman.

title: Newest Innovation at Police Headquarters Is Child's Play
description: The austere red-brick hallways of the nation's largest police headquarters will soon echo with the sounds of small children, if all goes according to plan.

title: Experts Say Bombing Showed Technical Skill and Resources
description: The bomb that destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland last week was so perfectly timed and so devastating that its makers must have had both technical skill and considerable resources, experts said yesterday.
