title: Short-Term Rates Keep Climbing
description: Short-term lending rates continued to soar yesterday, despite action by the Federal Reserve to add funds to the banking system. The central bank's efforts were thwarted by the strong demand for cash by banks and their customers.

title: Peru's Disappearing Democracy
description: Earlier this month, Carlos Escobar Pineda was honored in New York for his effective work as special prosecutor for disappearances in Peru's troubled Ayacucho region. Now he is in Lima, abruptly relieved of his position, and with reason to fear for his life. By what happens to him and to his work, much of the world will judge the Government of Peru. Today he is scheduled to appear before a senate committee that has opposed his efforts.

title: Burger Leaves Hospital
description: Warren E. Burger, the 81-year-old retired Chief Justice, was released from a Washington hospital today after three days of treatment for exhaustion and pneumonia, a spokeswoman said.

title: Applied Spectrum Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
U.S. Report Prods Allies on Military Outlays
description: The Secretaries of State and Defense told Congress today that the Western Europeans, the Japanese and the South Koreans can and should shoulder more of the military and financial burden for the common defense.

title: Adm. Alfred M. Pride, 91, Dies; Pioneer in U.S. Aircraft Carriers
description: Adm. Alfred M. Pride, a pioneer of aircraft carrier operations who led major strikes against the Japanese in World War II, died of a heart attack in his sleep on Saturday at the home of his daughter in Arnold, Md., where he was visiting. He was 91 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title:
CURRENTS;
Sculptured, In and Out
description: LEAD: A LUMINOUS, sparse, loftlike environment, Design Express's immense new retail store in Los Angeles was designed by Michele Saee and Max Massie of Building, a firm in that city. In the bare-bones steel, wood and concrete structure, 20th-century furniture and decorative objects are treated like sculpture: elegant chairs, tables and sofas by Hoffmann, Mackintosh, Mies and Starck; lighting from Artemide; tableware from

title: Bringing Down Budget Deficit: Some Big Targets Are in Sight
description: Congress and the White House will soon start spewing out proposals and counterproposals to reduce the Federal deficit. It will be months before the air clears, but already politicians and budget experts know where they can find most of the money to do the job.

title:
CURRENTS;
Toasting Arrival Of 1889
description: LEAD: ''IT is not easy to live in the past,'' David McDermott said. ''Actually, it is very expensive, even in a strictly middle-class manner.''

title: Values and Victories Flourish
description: When Pat Summitt, the 36-year-old head coach of the undefeated and top-ranked Tennessee women's basketball team, arrived in New York Tuesday, she might have thought it was more like a first than a hundredth trip away from home.

title: Custom Rubber Stamps For Business or Fun
description: ''THIS lady comes in at least twice a week,'' said Joan Santana of Klear Copy Design Rubber Stamps in Greenwich Village. ''She's crazy. I tell her she's crazy.'' The customer buys rubber stamps for every occasion: thank-you notes, get-well cards, dinner invitations (stamped, for example, with pigs and printed with the words ''Come pig out'').

title: Garden Return Special For Ohio State Coach
description: After he gets beyond the luster and tradition of Madison Square Garden, Gary Williams admits that he has a few bittersweet memories of the place.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A year ago we added a cedar porch, and the builder recommended that we apply three parts linseed oil and one part turpentine to retain the natural beauty of the cedar. The floor looks great at first, but after a while it starts looking dull. Any solution? A.Linseed oil is a poor choice for this purpose. It never completely dries, and the tacky finish holds dust and dirt. That is why your porch floor looks dull. Also, linseed oil eventually oxidizes and turns dark, and it is susceptible to mildew. For all these reasons, the oil should be washed off with a remover. The floor can then be treated with a clear wood preservative containing a water repellent. The color will change in time, but then you can apply a stain to restore the color. Q. I recently removed some cheap 20-year-old plywood panels from the painted dry wall in my house. But there remain large blotches and streaks of a hard tan adhesive that was used to paste the panels up. I tried various solvents - water, lighter fluid, etc. - but none worked. I also tried scraping, but this damaged the face of the dry wall. Power sanding works, but this is very slow and tedious. Do you know of a solvent I can use? A.Not knowing what kind of adhesive was used makes it impossible to recommend a solvent. I don't think a solvent is the answer. Any solvent that would work would probably be highly flammable and dangerous to use indoors, and it could soften the paper facing on the dry wall.

title: Eastern Shore Journal; Happy Is 'Mr. Goose' in a Sad Season for Hunters
description: All day long and into the night the skies here over Maryland's Eastern Shore are crisscrossed by great V-shaped flights of Canada geese, their honking and their beating wings beckoning an upward glance whose reward is always wonderment.

title: Dryness Hurts Wheat
description: Dry weather continues to be a problem for the 1989 winter wheat crop in much of the southern Great Plains, a Government report said today. ''Winter wheat fields in Kansas continued to show signs of moisture stress,'' the Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said. ''Greenbug infestation was a continuing problem.'' The farm weather facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments.

title:
CURRENTS;
Ringing In New Year On Mars
description: LEAD: FEW people who saw ''Blade Runner,'' Ridley Scott's 1982 movie that was set in the year 2019, can forget the director's vision of the city of the future: monstrous skyscrapers overshadowing littered, rain-soaked streets packed with people.

title: Birth-Control Test Developed
description: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc. said today that it had completed initial development of a home diagnostic test that women could use for birth control purposes. Designed as a simple, rapid urine test, the product would enable a woman to determine accurately certain days during her monthly cycle when she could have intercourse without using contraception and avoid conception.

title: Winter Gardening: Quiet Pleasures
description: ICY winds and frosty panes may tempt you to ignore the scene outside your window. But to neglect the winter garden is to lose a quarter of the year. With no summer blooms for distraction, experienced gardeners use this season for unfinished business and to consider color and pattern for next winter's scene.

title: Cuba Says Petition for Vote On Castro's Rule Is Absurd
description: President Fidel Castro's Government has rejected as ''absurd and inconceivable'' a petition by 100 writers, actors and scientists that he hold a plebiscite to see if the Cuban people want him to stay in power.

title: How to Stop Millions of Infant-Diarrhea Deaths; Challenge to the World
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brush Wellman Inc., Cleveland, a metal and ceramics maker, said Raymond A. Foos, president and chief executive, had been elected to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds Henry G. Piper, who is retiring.

title: Donors Forgo Gifts to Help The Neediest
description: Erica Crowley had already decided what she was going to buy her parents for Christmas and admits she felt ''a little disappointed'' when they asked her to donate the money instead to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Brazil Inflation Up 28.8%
description: Consumer prices rose a record 28.8 percent in Brazil in December, bringing 1988 inflation to a high of 933.6 percent, the Government said today. The December figure exceeded the 25 percent goal that had been agreed upon by businesses, the Government and labor unions in an accord signed on Nov. 4. The record figures added weight to warnings by economists and political analysts that Brazil was dangerously close to losing control over prices after anti-inflation efforts failed in 1986 and 1987.

title: Plastic Caning Provides Taut Durability
description: LEAD: IN response to an article written a while back about the care of caned furniture, a reader wrote asking if I were aware of a new development in caning: plastic. Actually, plastic caning has been around for about 30 years, but in the long history of caning, plastic can rightly be termed ''new.''

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Putting a Smooth Face on History's Rough Draft
description: As he enters his final weeks in office, President Reagan has been giving a series of farewell speeches and interviews that amount to his first draft of history, an attempt to defend his record and shape the views of future scholars as they evaluate the events that dominated Washington over the last eight years.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A House for Baker
description: The word on the Washington real estate circuit is that James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State-designate, is looking for a new home and has engaged Carolyn Deaver as his agent. Mrs. Deaver, the wife of the former White House deputy chief of staff, Michael K. Deaver, is associated with the Washington firm of Samuel P. Pardoe.

title: Bridgford Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to give retroactive effect to the 3-for-2 stock split to be distibuted Jan. 3, 1989.

title: Takeover Is Threatened Of Big Seabrook Owner
description: Govenor-elect Judd Gregg and legislative leaders said today that they would try to create a public power authority to take over the Public Service Company of New Hampshire should the utility try to have Federal regulators set its electricity rates.

title: New York Panel on Integrity Criticizes New Ethics Law
description: The New York State Government Integrity Commission has criticized the new state ethics law for overburdening executive and legislative officials and workers in one section and giving them special privileges in another.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the anti-ulcer drug misoprostol misstated the brand name of another drug, piroxicam. The name is Feldene.

title: Is Hirohito Free of War Guilt? The Risks of Defying a Taboo
description: People have been threatening to kill the Mayor of Nagasaki.

title: U.S. Files Plan to Test Nuclear Waste Site
description: The Energy Department today filed a plan to sink two 1,100-foot test shafts at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, about 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas, as part of the preparations for building a permanent burial place for the nation's highly radioactive waste.

title: Colombia Seeks New Loans
description: Colombia, the only important Latin American country to have avoided rescheduling its foreign debt, stands $150 million short on a $1.85 billion loan sought from commercial banks, Government officials said today.

title: How Many Nails Does a New House Take? Ten, Well Bitten
description: FEW undertakings are as fraught with tension as building a house, or remodeling an apartment, for that matter. For months, nearly every day brings decisions that will define daily life in your new household.

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Fine Du Pont $8.23 Million
description: The Federal Government sued E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company today, seeking a $8.23 million fine on charges that it had put too much lead in leaded gasoline.

title: V Band Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $12,848,000 on the sale of a subsidiary for the quarter and year. Corrected from Monday, Dec. 26, editions.

title: Sharing the Supercomputers
description: Computer scientists and Government officials are urging the creation of a nationwide ''data superhighway'' that they believe would have a dramatic economic impact, rivaling that of the nation's interstate highway system.

title: Ex-Corning Officer Sees Test in Small Company
description: Kirt C. Gardner, 54, recently moved from the senior vice presidency of a large company, Corning Glass Works, to become the president of a small company, Hunter Environmental Services Inc.

title: In the Baltic, Autonomy Has Only Been a Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up 3.75, to 2,166.43, Amid Listless Trading
description: LEAD: The stock market continued to limp toward the New Year yesterday, in directionless trading.

title: Europeans Criticize U.S. Over Sanctions
description: European trade officials were nearly unanimous today in their condemnation of the United States' decision to place 100 percent tariffs on certain European imports in retaliation for a ban on American beef from cattle treated with hormones.

title: Grant Tinker Pins Hopes to the Health Of an Ailing Series
description: Offering a visitor a bottle of Evian water, Grant Tinker said: ''I'm sorry, we have no glasses. It's been a rough year.'' He was only half joking. After 15 years as one of the most successful executives in television - first as head of MTM Enterprises and then as chairman of NBC - Mr. Tinker formed a new production firm, GTG Entertainment, backed by the Gannett Company.

title: J2 Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Car Rental Company Called Lax on Recalls
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had charged the Budget Rent-A-Car Corporation with not disclosing to prospective renters that it had failed to inspect cars subject that were to recall notices in a reasonable time. The agency said the company had also failed to make the necessary repairs.

title: Burlington Coat Spurned by Interco
description: Interco Inc. rejected a $190 million offer for its Londontown apparel unit, the maker of London Fog rainwear, from the Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corporation, opting instead for a lower bid from a management-led group. But Burlington said it would resubmit its offer in greater detail before the St. Louis-based company closes on the $178 million management offer Thursday.

title: Robertson Davies, a Novelist of the North
description: Robertson Davies was asked the other day if there was a particular quality that distinguished the Canadian novel from those written in England or the United States, where his books grow increasingly popular.

title: Record Japanese Largess
description: Japanese companies spent a record $33.5 billion in 1987 on entertainment and gifts, according to the National Tax Administration Agency. The agency, in a report released this week, said last year's spending of 4.19 trillion yen for entertainment represented an average daily expenditure of $91.8 million - a 6.1 percent increase over 1986. Japanese executives are often given carte blanche to entertain at exclusive nightclubs and inns, where an evening meal can cost $500 or more.

title: Article 235788 -- No Title
description: A Wisconsin family won a $39.6 million Lotto jackpot in the Illinois lottery Saturday night. The winners, John Evancho, 60 years old, of Waukesha, Wis., his wife, Maryanne, and their two daughters, Darlene, 36, and Cynthia, 28, have spent $5 apiece to buy $20 worth of Illinois tickets every week since 1974.

title: Billion-Dollar Bailouts
description: Major assistance packages worked out by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation in their bid to save the nation's ailing savings institutions. Estimates for the total cost of the transactions to the Government range from $45 billion to $100 billion. MAY 13, 1988: Coastal Banc Savings Association of Houston acquires four insolvent savings institutions. Coastal contributes new capital of $3.5 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $138.3 million. MAY 18: Southwest Savings Association, Dallas, acquires four insolvent savings institutions. Southwest provides $25 million in equity capital; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $2 billion. MAY 25: First Savings of Brenham, Tex., acquires Bluebonnet Savings Association of Texas, in Hempstead. First Savings provides $1.8 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $9.9 million. JUNE 22: Merabank, a Federal savings bank in Phoenix, acquires two savings institutions. Merabank contributes $8.8 million in new capital; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $83.9 million. AUG. 18: An investment group, Gibson Group/LSST Financial Services, acquires 12 insolvent savings and loan associations. Gibson contributes $48 million in cash; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $1.3 billion. AUG. 19: Eight insolvent Texas savings institutions are consolidated under the F.S.L.I.C. Initial F.S.L.I.C. cost is $2.5 billion; long-term cost could total $5.5 billion. AUG. 23: A holding company headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, agrees to pay $207.5 million to buy the insolvent Bell Savings of San Mateo, Calif., and the outstanding stock of the healthy Western Federal Savings of Marina del Ray, in a deal in which the F.S.L.I.C. will provide $565 million. AUG. 26: The bank board announces five transactions in which it will inject almost $1 billion into 10 savings units that will be merged into healthy institutions. Private investors will put up $20 million. AUG. 31: Fourteen of Oklahoma's most troubled savings institutions are consolidated into six larger institutions with $1.9 billion from the F.S.L.I.C. The bank board plans to sell the restored units. SEPT. 5: A group headed by the Fort Worth billionaire Robert M. Bass agrees to buy American Savings and Loan Association, then the nation's largest insolvent savings institution. The Bass group agrees to inject $550 million; the bank board will provide $2 billion. OCT. 14: A Texas cable entrepreneur, Don A. Adam, agrees to buy 11 Texas savings institutions that have been combined into a single unit. Mr. Adam agrees to pledge $80 million for the savings units; the F.S.L.I.C. will provide $1.3 billion over the next 10 years. DEC. 9: The bank board takes over the insolvent Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver with plans to inject $1.05 billion in Federal aid and then sell the rejuvenated unit. DEC. 22: The bank board pledges $1.85 billion over the next 10 years to recapitalize 15 savings units that have been merged into one entity. A private buyer for the new unit, James M. Fail, a Phoenix investor, agrees to invest $120 million. DEC. 28: An investment group headed by Mr. Bass agrees to buy American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., with Federal assistance of up to $1.7 billion. DEC. 28: Five large Texas savings institutions are taken over by an investment group headed by Ronald O. Perelman, a takeover specialist who heads Revlon Inc. The bank board agrees to provide $5.1 billion in aid over 10 years; the private investors will inject $315 million. Two of the savings institutions, Gibraltar Savings Association of Houston and First Texas Savings Association of Dallas, are among the largest in Texas.

title: HEALTH: Aging; Finally, Doctors Ask if Brutal Falls Need Be a Fact of Life for the Elderly
description: Scientists have embarked on major efforts to determine why so many elderly people suffer devastating falls and to identify medical and social measures that can curb the disastrous toll.

title: Soviet Team Stays Out of U.S. Reach
description: Call this one an almost. Victories come so rarely for the United States in hockey games against the Soviet Union that the Americans have virtually invented a new category.

title: Yields Post Rise in Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, with the yield rises in C.D.'s flattening.

title: What 'Iron Triangle' Means in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Agrees to North's Bid for Talks
description: South Korea today agreed to a North Korean proposal to hold high-level political and military talks to ease tension.

title: Minor Earthquake in Maine
description: A minor earthquake shook central Maine early today, prompting scores of calls to the police but causing no serious damage or reports of injuries. The tremor struck at 1:29 A.M. and registered about 2.5 to 3 on the Richter scale of ground motion and energy released, said Marvin Carlson, a geophysicist at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. ''The switchboard just lit up,'' said Sgt. Jeff Massey of the Waterville police.h ''Most people called and said they thought their furnace blew up. One lady said she thought her husband fell out of bed.''

title: State Panel Denies a Rate Increase for Lilco
description: The State Public Service Commission today denied the Long Island Lighting Company's request for an immediate 5.4 percent rate increase. At the same time, the commission outlined a path that it said could lead to an agreement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant without legislative approval.

title: 3 Held in Theft of Computers
description: Two Dutchmen were in custody in Boston and a third in custody in Rome as Customs agents continued their campaign against a network trying to smuggle computer technology to Bulgaria, a Customs official said today.

title: BUSH PICKS DEPUTY FOR SECURITY POST
description: President-elect Bush today named Robert M. Gates, a career intelligence officer who is now Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, as his deputy national security adviser.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The explosive's residues recovered from the debris have been positively identified and are consistent with the use of a high-performance plastic explosive.'' - The Air Accidents Investigation Branch of the British Department of Transport, on the crash of Pan American flight 103. [ A1:6. ]

title: POWERFUL BOMB DESTROYED PAN AM JET OVER SCOTLAND, BRITISH INVESTIGATION FINDS
description: A powerful plastic explosive device blew apart the Pan Am jumbo jet that crashed in Scotland last week, British investigators announced today.

title: Let's Not Minimize Dangers of Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Belfast Journal; For Ulster Catholics, Irish Spoken Here (Again)
description: The Irish language is alive and thriving in a former flax mill in West Belfast.

title: Ranger Wastes No Time Making Mark
description: After missing the target with Doug Wickenheiser and Brian Lawton, the Rangers may have hit the bull's-eye with Carey Wilson in their efforts to get the big center they desperately need.

title: 1988 VOTE: THE FINAL WORD
description: Here is the final vote for each candidate in the 1988 Presidential election, as compiled by The Associated PRess from the official returns from the 50 states and the District of Columbia. Most of the third-party candidates were on the ballot in only a few states.

title: Talking Deals; A Veil of Secrecy In Texas Rescues
description: THE struggle to rescue the Texas savings industry's deeply troubled institutions is a multibillion-dollar guessing game.

title: Help for Elderly Patients in Unusual Family Therapy
description: LEAD: AN elderly woman in Beth Israel Medical Center's geriatric psychiatric ward continued to get worse when her condition should have been improving. Finally, under an innovative program, the hospital's staff called in a team of family therapy consultants from Ackerman Institute to meet with the woman and her two sons.

title: In Egypt, the In-Laws Still Propose
description: Shereen Koraim had met her beau just twice, and they had not yet strolled outdoors alone together when his family proposed to her family that they marry. And marry they did - in style.

title: Many Students Fail Quiz on Basic Economics
description: More than half of all high school students in a national survey could not define basic economic terms like profit and inflation, an economics education group reported yesterday.

title: 'Twins,' for 3d Week, Is Top-Grossing Film
description: ''Twins,'' the comedy starring Danny DeVito and Arnold Schwarzenegger as brothers separated at birth, took in $9 million over the Christmas weekend to take first place at the box office for the third straight weekend.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Impregnable Fortress
description: This morning, when the long-awaited list of some two dozen military bases to be closed is announced, one of the usual suspects will almost certainly be missing.

title:
CURRENTS;
Pulling for an Old Boathouse
description: LEAD: NOT every square inch of New York's underused waterfront is in the hands of developers trying to build 80-story apartment towers. Consider a plan for the former fireboat station at the foot of East 90th Street, near the confluence of the East and Harlem Rivers. Two architects, John Keenen and Terence Riley, plan to double its size to add space for environmental studies and for meeting and storage rooms for the New York Rowing

title: Workers Buy Mill From Zellerbach
description: The much maligned leveraged buyout just won 635 new fans.

title: Tops in the N.F.L.
description: Roger Craig of the San Francisco 49ers, the National Football League co-leader in total yardage and a key performer on the league's second-ranked offense, was named offensive player of the year yesterday by The Associated Press. Craig rushed for 1,502 yards and 9 touchdowns and caught 76 passes for 534 yards and a score. Mike Singletary, the Chicago Bears' middle linebacker and inspirational leader, has been chosen the N.F.L. defensive player of the year. Singletary, who had 170 tackles, 89 of them unassisted. (AP)

title: Metro Datelines; Study Finds Students Ignorant on AIDS
description: Fifty-nine percent of the New Jersey high school students questioned in a survey mistakenly believe they can get AIDS from mosquito bites or are not sure, and 40 percent have the same unwarranted doubts about public toilets, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Perelman Trademark: An Ability to Act Fast
description: The day before Thanksgiving, Michael L. Tarnapol, an investment banker with Bear, Stearns & Company, placed a telephone call to Howard Gittis, a vice chairman of the Revlon Group and a longtime associate of Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's billionaire chairman.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A SMOKY fireplace is not only unpleasant; it can also be a fire hazard. Whether your fireplace is regularly smoky or only occasionally so, one or more of these procedures may remedy the situation.

title: Nets Win With Conner As the Spark
description: It was beginning to look like another dismal night for the Nets. They took a 17-point lead in the second quarter, then lost it because they stopped doing the things that got them ahead. They were on the verge of losing another home game, this time to the Indiana Pacers, a team that hasn't won a road game this season.

title: Sand and Clay Prove Treacherous Accomplices of Earthquakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Boggs Attacked
description: Wade Boggs, the Boston Red Sox third baseman, was cut in the neck and threatened by a man at knifepoint, police said yesterday. The inch-long cut was not serious enough to warrant medical attention, Boggs said. Police charged George Young Jr., 23, with armed burglary and two counts of aggravated battery. Edward Benjamin Cox, 31, was charged with aggravated assault and carrying a concealed weapon. Boggs, 30, said he was in his Jeep outside a Gainesville, Fla., bar showing a handgun to two friends when two men blocked them with their vehicle, according to a police spokeswoman, Lt. Sadie Darnell. Police said Young got out of the car carrying a knife, and Cox waved a revolver at Boggs and his friends. Young jumped into the back seat of the Jeep and held a knife to Boggs's throat, police said. Meanwhile, a friend of Boggs, Chuck Hollowell, ran to flag down police.(AP)

title: Killings Unsettle Gang-Ridden Area of Boston
description: Four months after an 11-year-old girl was killed in crossfire from rival drug gangs, residents of the Roxbury neighborhood have been shaken by three more fatal shootings in their area.

title: A Sudan Party Quits Cabinet After Strike Call and Protest
description: The second largest party in the Sudan's governing coalition quit the Government today as thousands of demonstrators took to the streets and a major union called for an indefinte strike to protest price increases.

title: Business Outlays Seen Rising in '89
description: The nation's businesses are planning to spend a record $451.64 billion on expansion and modernization next year, according to a Commerce Department survey.

title: KCS Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,425,000. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,185,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Gap Remains as Albany Votes Stipend Increase
description: Proving once again that it is quicker to spend money than to cut it, the New York State Legislature went into session today just long enough to increase stipends for some lawmakers and to raise the salaries of state commissioners. The legislators took no action to close the state's budget gap, which Governor Cuomo has said is more than $2.04 billion.

title: Knee Mishap Is Just a Scare for Ewing
description: Patrick Ewing did not participate in the Knick practice today. Instead, the 7-foot center spent the 90 minutes the rest of the team used to prepare for the game Thursday night against the Bulls in Chicago to ice his left knee, lift weights to keep the knee strong, ride a stationary bicyle and shoot free throws.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR the past four years, Jeanne has been concerned about how many of the things she has said about sex have gotten through to her son, a 19-year-old college student who is living at home. She knows he's been experimenting with sexual relationships. She's concerned about his happiness and his safety.

title: Gandhi Visit to Pakistan: Hopes for a New Era
description: After 40 years of almost unrelenting hostility punctuated by outbursts of armed conflict, India and Pakistan have a chance this week to open a new era in relations.

title: Mubarak/Shamir vs. Sadat/Begin
description: President Hosni Mubarak's prospective visit to Israel has disappeared in the desert sands, another victim of Arab shortsightedness and Israeli intransigence. The Egyptian leader seemed poised Sunday to go to Israel for the first time. Now he has put conditions on his trip that Israel cannot accept, and an important opportunity has been lost.

title: Bid Is Spurned By Champion
description: The board of directors of Champion Products Inc. announced today that it had rejected as inadequate the $220 million tender offer from an investment group led by the New York brokerage firm Walsh, Greenwood & Company.

title: U.S. Tariff Move Angers Food Importers
description: Specialty food shops and food-importing companies reacted with concern and anger yesterday to the prospect that they would be casualties in a trade war between the United States and the European Community.

title: Coach Is Released
description: The rumored house-cleaning of Los Angeles Raiders assistant coaches began Tuesday night and continued yesterday when Coach Mike Shanahan released Charlie Sumner, and Willie Brown. (AP)

title: Vietnam Devaluation
description: Vietnam has devalued its currency, the dong, for the third time since November, to 3,000 to the dollar, the state radio said Tuesday. Vietnam devalued its currency from 386 per dollar, to 2,600 per dollar, in November. It was devalued to 2,800 to the dollar on Dec. 12.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: WHEN I was in college, a women's college where evenings were whiled away in endless conversation, my friends and I had a shorthand method to describe ourselves and others. We were horses, kittens or muffins, or combinations thereof.

title: Gay Witch Hunt, Texas-Style
description: In colonial Massachusetts, by judicial order, 32 innocent persons were executed because, by the mores of the day, they were thought to be witches possessed of the devil. An obvious teaching is that common fears and biases make for poor justice.

title: S. Peter Dohanos, 57, Scenic Designer, Dies
description: S. Peter Dohanos, a scenic designer for film, television and theater, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 57 years old.

title: Bush Faces Test in Bomb Finding; 2 Anti-Arafat Groups Suspected
description: The finding that a bomb destroyed a Pan Am jet last week may pose serious foreign-policy questions for President-elect George Bush, who led a 1986 panel that urged harsh action against international terrorism.

title: F.A.A. to Toughen Check-In Security
description: Reacting to the British announcement that a bomb had destroyed the Pan Am jet that crashed in Scotland, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it was planning tougher security rules.

title: Brooklyn Soccer Ban
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association men's soccer committee, citing fighting and unsportsmanlike misconduct in a national tournament game in November, said today it has banned Brooklyn College from the tournament next year and reprimanded the coach, Len Roitman.

title: Unit's Head Is a Survivor in Texas Banking
description: Gerald J. Ford, a Texas banking entrepreneur who has managed to make money amid the state's financial woes, will become chairman and chief executive of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation's latest recapitalization, worth $5.1 billion.

title: Western Microwave Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Japanese Minister Is Tied to Stock Scandal
description: In an embarrassing blow to Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's efforts to distance his Government from a widening stock scandal, his newly-appointed Justice Minister confirmed news reports that he had received political donations from the company at the center of the scandal.

title: Quantum Announces $50 Payout
description: The Quantum Chemical Corporation yesterday announced a far-reaching restructuring plan that calls for paying a special $50-a-share dividend and selling its specialty chemical division.

title: In Amazon Rain Forest, a Vicious War Is Raging
description: The killing last week of a noted Brazilian environmentalist has focused attention on a turbulent struggle between rubber tappers trying to protect the Amazon rain forest and speculators and ranchers seeking fast fortunes by clearing the land.

title: Big California Air Base Called A Likely Target for Closing
description: A Southern California Congressman said today that the panel reviewing the nation's military bases for possible savings would recommend closing George Air Force Base and consolidating March and Norton Air Force Bases.

title: Albert S. Roe, Professor, 74
description: Albert S. Roe, a professor emeritus of art history at Cornell University, died of a brain hemorrhage on Dec. 19 at Tomkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: HEALTH: Pregnancy; New Method Allows Very Early Diagnosis of Fetal Problems
description: A new method of obtaining fetal tissue for testing should enable doctors to do prenatal diagnosis as early as the sixth week of pregnancy.

title:
CURRENTS;
Lunch Boxes Laden With Meaning
description: LEAD: IN ''The 50's and 60's Lunch Box'' (Chronicle Books, $14.95) Scott Bruce writes of the rise and demise of steel lunch boxes decorated with characters from television, movies and comic strips. He links the advent of the boxes to the postwar baby boom, the growth of the suburbs and the arrival of television.

title: Review/Music; Loony Tunes With P.D.Q. Bach
description: It is difficult for any comedian to keep his material fresh, and it has to be especially difficult for Prof. Peter Schickele, billed in the program as ''All Things to All Men'' in his current P. D. Q. Bach show at Carnegie Hall. Most of the purely musical components of his jokes - unconventional sounds and instruments and above all the use of pop harmonies in classical surroundings - have long since found their way into more or less serious avant-garde compositions.

title: Cuomo Plans to Acquire Adirondacks Tract
description: Averting an embarrassment, Governor Cuomo announced today the acquisition of 55,000 acres of Adirondack wilderness that the state unsuccessfully tried to buy three months ago.

title: Bronx Juries Are as Good as Any in the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN GROUNDS THREE AIRPLANES
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it had grounded three jets, two because of cracks in the fuselage and one for apparent corrosion.

title: Papandreou Scandals: First Casualty Is Popularity
description: According to a popular anecdote here, the Greek Socialist Government is afflicted by the same problem as the Acropolis: pollutants are eroding its structures, necessitating drastic restoration efforts to save them from total collapse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Israelis Kill Two Palestinians in West Bank
description: Israeli soldiers fatally shot two Palestinian teen-agers today in clashes with youths in the West Bank and killed three suspected guerrillas trying to sneak into Israel from Lebanon, the army said.

title: 2 SAVINGS BAILOUTS COSTING $7 BILLION CONFIRMED BY U.S.
description: In a year-end push to take advantage of tax breaks, the Government today announced two huge transactions to salvage the nation's largest insolvent savings institution and five Texas savings and loan associations. The cost to the Government will be almost $7 billion.

title: New Airport Fees Suspended
description: The Massachusetts Port Authority voted on Tuesday to suspend an increase in landing fees aimed at discouraging small aircraft from using the congested Logan International Airport. But it also voted to go to court to fight a ruling, issued last week by the United States Department of Transportation, holding the fee structure discriminatory and in violation of Federal laws.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TV Notes
description: Inside Washington

title: Nanjing Students Vow Nightly Protests
description: Thousands of students and workers held illegal demonstrations in the eastern city of Nanjing tonight, and the students said they planned to continue with nightly protests until the Government meets their demands to punish African students for their part in a brawl on Saturday.

title: Flamemaster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the share earnings results have been restated to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend effective July 1988.

title: Seymour Kleinman, 70; Lawyer Aided Charity
description: Seymour Kleinman, a senior partner at the Manhattan law firm of Golenbock & Barell and a noted philanthropist, died of pneumonia yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Whittaker Shares Increase by 8.3%
description: Shares of the Whittaker Corporation rose $3.875, or 8.3 percent, to $50.625, on the New York Stock Exchange today, the day's eighth-largest percentage gainer. The Los Angeles-based specialty chemical and technology concern said it was considering expressions of takeover interest from third parties as well as other unspecified alternatives.

title: Ragen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $319,000 for the quarter and $209,000 for the year, and gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $325,000 and $1,380,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,158,000 for the quarter and $1,745,000 for the year, and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,588,000 and $1,666,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Heine Discloses Acme Steel Talks
description: The Heine Securities Corporation, a Short Hills, N.J., investment advisory concern disclosed that it had held talks with the Acme Steel Company about a possible $24.75-a-share buyout offer. The proposal, made at a Dec. 20 meeting between the two parties, has a total value of just under $131 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Heine said it could give no assurance that any formal proposal would be submitted to Acme's board or even that any transaction would result from the talks. It also said it already held 9 percent of Acme's 5.2 million shares outstanding.

title: Santa Fe's 'Pill' Amendment
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it would amend its anti-takeover defenses to allow at least 80 percent of its shareholders to accept a cash bid over management's objections.

title: Gallo Trial Over Name Is Completed
description: A lawyer for Ernest and Julio Gallo contended today at the close of a monthlong trial in Federal District Court here that their younger brother took unfair and illegal advantage of their wine trademark by labeling his cheese with his name, ''Joseph Gallo.''

title: Quick Fix For City Campaigns
description: Peter Vallone, majority leader of the New York City Council, plans to postpone by a month the new campaign finance law's Jan. 3 filing deadline for the 1989 municipal elections. That will give the Council time to do some last-minute tinkering, good and bad, with the rules. The main change - to exclude certain fund-raising costs from the expenditure caps - may prove essential to the new system's success.

title: On the F Train, Violence Erupts Over a Song
description: A subway passenger's objection to a seatmate's rendition of a Billie Holiday song set off a bloody fracas aboard a crowded F train in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

title: One Stately Home in England Belongs to the U.S.
description: ''WE always try to leave a house better than we found it,'' Carol Price said, referring to summer places she and her husband rented when their children were younger. But since 1983 Mrs. Price's husband, Charles H. Price 2d, a banker from Kansas City, Mo., has been the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, and the house in which they have been tenants is Winfield House in Regent's Park, London, one of the premier ambassadorial residences in the world.

title: Reagan Extends Territorial Waters to 12 Miles
description: President Reagan today extended the territorial waters of the United States to 12 miles from 3 miles, a move Administration officials said was partly intended to hinder operations of Soviet spy trawlers that ply American coastlines.

title: What of the Present?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Review/Book; On Laos and Vietnam, Blame for All
description: The Key to Failure Laos and the Vietnam War By Norman B. Hannah Foreword by Col. Harry G. Summers Jr. 306 pages. Madison Books. $19.95.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Transtech, Jacksonville, Fla., a subsidiary of A.T.&T., reached an agreement to acquire Advanced Information Service Co. from U.S. Trust. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Metro Datelines; Rooming-House Fire Leaves 2 Men Dead
description: A late-night fire that apparently was caused by smoking in bed killed two men at a rooming house, including one who died when the roof collapsed as firefighters tried to reach him, officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; High-Fat Food Pressed on the Young
description: ''America's Kids: Diet of Danger'' takes a while to get to the meat on its menu, but when it does, it gives you something to chew on. The first half of the hour, at 10 tonight on ABC, is devoted largely to the well-known fact that Americans, especially young ones, are in the habit of eating junk food and fast food with more fat, sugar and salt than nutrients.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Under Fire as Hunter, Bush Finds Defenders
description: Animal rights groups are still steaming over President-elect Bush's reply to a reporter who asked how killing ''cute, cuddly animals'' like doves and quail jibed with his image of a kinder, gentler America.

title: J.W. Mays to Close Stores And Focus on Real Estate
description: J. W. Mays Inc., one of the original discount retailers in the New York area, said yesterday that it would cease business in its three remaining department stores.

title: Joseph Clark, 75, Dies; Editor at Daily Worker
description: Joseph Clark, an American Communist who resigned as foreign editor of The Daily Worker after crimes by Stalin were disclosed in 1956, died Tuesday after suffering a heart attack at his country house in South Egremont, Mass. He was 75 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: The Calm and the Storm

title: Anthony Hecht Wins $10,000 Poetry Award
description: Anthony Hecht, a poet and a professor of English at Georgetown University, has been named the third recipient of the Aiken Taylor Award for Modern Poetry. The $10,000 prize is awarded annually to a contemporary American poet for the substantial work of a distinguished career.

title: AIR FORCE WEIGHS ACTION ON OFFICIAL
description: The Air Force said today that it was considering whether to take new action against a procurement official who had been accused by Federal investigators of accepting illegal gratuities from a private military consultant and his clients.

title: USX Completes Subsidiaries' Sale
description: The USX Corporation completed the $600 million sale of its transportation subsidiaries to a new company controlled by Blackstone Partners, an investment group.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The legal holiday for New Year's Day is Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No street cleanings or collection. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; Metro-North on holiday schedule; Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed; local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule, trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Jess Oppenheimer, 75, a Creator And a Producer of 'I Love Lucy'
description: Jess Oppenheimer, a radio and television producer, director and writer who helped create one of television's most successful situation comedies, ''I Love Lucy,'' died of heart failure on Tuesday after intestinal surgery at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old.

title: Auctions
description: Mickey Mouse in Plastic Mickey Mouse in plastic is becoming as popular among collectors as earlier metal and wood ones. Eric Alberta, a collectibles specialist at Christie's East, said the 60-year-old Mickey was becoming newly important in the auction market now that plastic toys were selling for extraordinary prices. On Dec. 14, a rare Japanese celluloid toy Mickey from the 1940's or 50's was sold at the Christie's annex for $6,600, a record for a celluloid toy. The toy features Mickey riding Pluto, who is bridled and fitted with three wheels.

title: Ferry Helps Duke Rout Cornell
description: Danny Ferry scored 22 points and top-ranked Duke raced to a 17-0 lead tonight, leading the unbeaten Blue Devils past Cornell, 94-59.

title: Black Africa Leaves China In Quandary
description: Crowds chanting ''Down with blacks!'' in the eastern city of Nanjing this week have laid bare the gap in China between the official warmth extended to African countries and the suspicion that many Chinese seem to harbor toward African people.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's half-fare policy in New York misstated the age at which passengers become eligible. It is 65, not 64.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a play about a new adventure for the shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a funny zookeeper, written by Miranda McDermott and performed by child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. Saturdays at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations: 734-5195. ''THE CRICKET ON THE HEARTH,'' a musical about a cricket that brings comfort to two English families and a blind girl, adapted by Amie Brockway from the Charles Dickens story, and performed by young actors, 7:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth Theater, Henry Lindenbaum Center, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: $8 and $10. Reservations: 769-4143. ''THE NIGHTINGALE,'' an opera by Charles Strouse, suggested by Hans Christian Andersen's ''Emperor's Nightingale,'' performed by On Stage Productions, 3 and 8 P.M. tonight, tomorrow and Sunday; repeat shows Jan. 14 and 15. Tickets: children, students and the elderly, $7; others, $8. Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Reservations: 666-1716. ''ONCE A YEAR ON CHRISTMAS EVE,'' a musical about an enchanted forest where presents grow on trees at Christmas, performed by child actors, 7:30 P.M. Fridays, 2 and 4 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Tada! Theater, 120 West 28th Street. Tickets: children, $5; adults, $6. Information: 627-1732. ''PINOCCHIO,'' presented by Bil Baird Marionettes, with a book by Jerome Coopersmith, music by Mary Rodgers and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick, produced by Arthur Cantor. Peter Baird, the son of Bil and Cora Baird, supervised the production. Performances, 1 and 3:30 P.M. today, tomorrow and Sunday, at the Minetta Theater, 18 Minetta Lane. Tickets: $15. Reservations: 420-8000. ''A CHARLES DICKENS CHRISTMAS,'' a blending of fact and fantasy about the author's life as a young man, presented by the Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Reservations: 677-5959. ''IT'S TOUGH TO MAKE A NICKEL,'' a 40-minute living-history play about immigrant children living in tenements on the Lower East Side, 1 P.M. Sundays, at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street. Tickets: children, $5; students and the elderly, $6; others, $7. Reservations: 431-0233. ''WILBUR THE CHRISTMAS MOUSE,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, 1:30 P.M. Saturday, and ''Santa Claus and the Magic Bell,'' 3 P.M. Saturday, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 765-9540. ''IT'S NEWS TO ME,'' an exhibition about how news is communicated, with information about editing, transmitting and other activities, at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. The museum is open 1 to 4 P.M. Wednesdays through Fridays and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and most school holidays. Tickets: $2. Information: (718) 273-2060. ''POST CEREALS PRESENTS: FROM SEEDS TO CEREAL,'' an exhibition about plants and fruits, and how grains are grown and processed, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays, in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, the Bronx. Tickets: children and the elderly, $1.25; adults, $2.50. Information: 220-8779. ''THE BEAST,'' a musical by Tom Oliver with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677.

title: Scripps Forms Program Unit
description: The E. W. Scripps Company, the publishing concern that also owns a string of television stations, said today that it would begin to produce, develop and market programming for all segments of the television industry.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the appointment of Robert M. Gates as deputy adviser on national security misstated the current position of Richard J. Kerr, who succeeds Mr. Gates as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. Mr. Kerr has been Deputy Director for Intelligence at the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Courts Clear Way for Mississippi Vote on Judges
description: Two Federal courts cleared the way today for setting a date for the statewide election of trial judges, delayed for years by lawsuits charging racial discrimination.

title: Hamilton Sues Jets, Saying They Underpaid Him
description: Harry Hamilton, a former Jet defensive back, filed a lawsuit yesterday that says the team took advantage of him when he was a rookie and underpaid him by more than $300,000 over four seasons.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Li'l Queenie Sings

title: Skiing Is Seen as 'an Ideal Sport for the Disabled'
description: The freedom of movement, the feeling of accomplishment and the opportunity to participate with friends and family are all reasons for anyone to enjoy skiing. But for the physically handicapped person, they are particularly meaningful.

title: U.S. IS TIGHTENING SECURITY CHECKS ON FLIGHTS ABROAD
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday announced strict new security measures, including emptying and searching the luggage of more passengers, for flights of United States airlines from 103 airports in the Middle East and Western Europe.

title: G.E. Unit Acquires Stake in Tiffany
description: A unit of the General Electric Company disclosed that it had exercised a warrant to acquire a 15.2 percent stake in Tiffany & Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the General Electric Capital Corporation said it bought 1.12 million Tiffany shares on Dec. 19 for a total purchase price of $1.4 million. General Electric said it had also purchased 380,000 Tiffany shares on June 17 for $475,000.

title: Grieving Workers Brace for Mays's Closing
description: The sign in a front window at the Mays department store on Fulton Street in Brooklyn reads ''Nice to See You Again,'' but after 6 P.M. tomorrow, the message to shoppers will be moot.

title: Changes in Maintenance Sought To Keep Old Planes Flying Safely
description: Aviation safety experts and Federal regulators say better maintenance programs must be developed for the nation's aging airliner fleet if the planes are to remain safe.

title: Knowledge Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Plan for Cuts
description: CLOSINGS: The Defense Secretary's commission recommended that 86 bases be closed and 5 more partly closed and the operations transferred to 54 other bases. LAYOFFS: About 58,500 military and civillian employees would lose their jobs or be trensferred. But the panel said there would be 37,850 new jobs or assignments at other bases. SAVINGS: The panel estimated that $5.6 billion would be saved over 20 years. APPROVAL: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci is expected to approve the plan in January. Congress has 45 days after March 1 to block the plan; otherwise, it goes into effect and base closings begin in 1990.

title: Death, Despair and Valor: The Sinking of a Freighter
description: Three sailors riding gargantuan seas in life jackets were plucked to safety, but two shipmates were dead adrift and six others missing and presumed lost yesterday after a freighter capsized and sank in a howling Atlantic gale off the New Jersey coast.

title: For Costa Rica, Peace Makes Business Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Up, Dollar Down? Blame the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dollar Declines Slightly In Light Year-End Trading
description: The dollar declined slightly yesterday in light year-end trading as dealers began to wonder if the small December rally would carry into the new year.

title: Paris's Picasso Museum To Close for Repairs
description: The Picasso Museum, home for the past three years to nearly 3,500 works by Pablo Picasso, is closing for two months for repairs, a museum spokesman has said.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: The assets of the nation's 456 money market mutual funds decreased by $244.9 million, to $278.48 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. But assets of the 136 institutional funds rose by $142.6 million, to $71.82 billion. And assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up $13.3 million, to $89.70 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds, however, fell by $400.8 million, to $116.96 billion, the institute said.

title: 94 Federal Sites Are Chosen For Possible Aid to Homeless
description: Acting under court order, the Reagan Administration has designated 44 ''underutilized'' buildings and 50 land sites as suitable for sheltering or assisting the nation's homeless. But it was unclear whether any of the federally owned properties would be available for the homeless this winter.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Tennessee women's basketball team included one player incorrectly. Kris Durham transferred this year from Tennessee to Seton Hall.

title: William Exton Jr., 82, Consultant
description: William Exton Jr., a management consultant who wrote, lectured and taught widely on business subjects, died Monday at Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, Pa., after being injured in an automobile accident. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and Millbrook, N.Y., where he operated a dairy farm.

title: Laughing and Dancing Into 1989
description: New Year's Eve in New York may be the closest the city ever comes to having its own Mardi Gras. For one night of the year, the city's clubs offer more than the customary range of entertainment.

title: PLAN FOR FORT DIX SURPRISES JERSEY
description: A Presidential panel's recommendation yesterday to sharply curtail training activities at Fort Dix, N.J., which prepared soldiers for both World Wars, Korea and Vietnam, surprised New Jerseyans in and out of government.

title: Thanks, Whoever You Are
description: LEAD: ''Blood! We need blood fast!'' the doctor screamed. My blood pressure dropped to 60 over 30. I was in shock.

title: Honeywell Bull
description: Honeywell Inc. said it had completed the sale of a 22.6 percent stake in Honeywell Bull to Compagnie des Machines Bull, the French state-owned computer maker, for undisclosed terms. The sale reduces Honeywell's stake to 19.9 percent and increases the French concern's ownership to 65.1 percent. The sale was in line with a March 1987 agreement that formed the joint-venture computer company. At that time both Honeywell and Compagnie des Machines Bull held 42.5 percent stakes, while the NEC Corporation of Tokyo held a 15 percent interest.

title: Relaxed Approach Fails For Slumping Islanders
description: The Islanders approached this Super Series meeting with the Soviet Union's Red Army club as an exhibition game, and technically they were correct in doing so.

title: Kodak Price Rise
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced plans for price increases for nearly all consumer and professional films, as well as photographic papers and chemicals. The increases will be effective with orders beginning Jan. 26, 1989, and are publicized in catalogue inserts now in the mail to dealers. A company spokesman, Ron Roberts, said amateur films would rise 3.5 percent, with the exception of Kodachrome 25 film and Kodachrome 64 film, which will rise 7 percent. Price increases for professional film will range from 2 to 6 percent.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; Colleagues bid farewell to a Nazi-hunter, his quest ended by modern murderers.
description: A week after he went down with Pan American Flight 103, Michael Bernstein, or what they could collect of him, was still in Lockerbie, Scotland. His family had hoped to have his remains back in time for the funeral here this morning, but the bureaucratic maze was too formidable.

title: U.S. Shift Urged On Export Rules For Technology
description: The United States should narrow its efforts to restrict exports of computer hardware and software to Communist nations and concentrate on certain advanced technologies that have crucial military applications, according to a report to be released today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Reviews/Dance; Ailey Troupe Honors Its Graduates
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater paid homage to members of its sprawling family in ''Ailey and Graduates,'' presented on Wednesday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, where the company performs through Sunday.

title: Civil Rights, Burned
description: On June 21, 1964, three young civil rights workers - Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman - were shot to death on the back roads of Neshoba County, Mississippi, by a group of whites that included local police. When state law enforcement failed to indict those responsible, seven men were tried, convicted and imprisoned under the strongest Federal charge available - conspiring to violate the victims' civil rights. Almost perversely, a new movie, ''Mississippi Burning,'' recreates those events and the powerful emotions they evoke in a way that mocks civil rights.

title: Poignant Fallout to Holiday Season
description: As the Christmas carols fade, the telephones begin ringing at legal referral services.

title: L.I. Man Fatally Shoots Wife, Then Himself
description: A 34-year-old man being sought on charges of violating a court order to stay away from his estranged wife shot her to death and wounded his 2-year-old daughter here today before killing himself, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Ex-Midshipman Files Suit
description: A former midshipman at the Naval Academy who says he was forced to resign nearly two years ago after admitting his homosexuality filed suit in Federal District Court here today seeking reinstatement. Joseph Steffan, 24 years old, who now works for a computer software company in Fargo, N.D., charged that his resignation under the threat that he would otherwise be dismissed violated his constitutional rights to due process and equal protection of the law.

title: About Real Estate; An Abandoned School Yields Affordable Housing
description: In the first half of this century St. Clare Academy in Hastings-on-Hudson served as a boarding school in the country for New York City boys and girls. Starting in January, much of the wooded 53-acre hilltop campus will be a site for apartments and town houses marketed to families who cannot afford, or no longer need, the half-million-dollar-or-more homes that have characterized much of the recent residential development in lower Westchester County.

title: FNN Stock Up On Deal Report
description: Shares of Financial News Network climbed $1.625 yesterday, to $8.375, in very active over-the-counter trading after USA Today reported that Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, might seek the 45 percent stake in the cable television service that is held by Infotechnology Inc. of New York.

title: A Blueprint For Closings
description: The idea behind the complicated procedure for closing military bases was to take Congress out of the picture as much as possible, because of the reluctance on Capitol Hill to permit bases to be closed.

title: Angola Asks U.N. to Seek Funds For Cost of Cuban Troop Pullout
description: Angola has asked the Secretary General to begin an international appeal for aid to help pay the cost of pulling some 50,000 Cuban soldiers out of its territory, as required by last week's peace accords, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.

title: On Stage
description: Shakespeare's Yiddish

title: American Museum of Historial Documents reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Black Drops Out of Primary To Prevent Split in Chicago
description: Saying he feared that splitting black votes would insure the election of a white as Mayor, Alderman Timothy C. Evans, one of the two black candidates, dropped out of February's Democratic primary today, adding that he would run as an independent in the general election instead.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Hold the Mimosas Sunday brunch can be the most tranquil and pleasant meal of the week - or the most startling if you happen to wander into Adrienne, the restaurant at the Peninsula Hotel on Fifth Avenue at 55th Street, where a recent buffet brunch for two cost $115.83 before tip. The brunch selection was more than ample: a cold selection of smoked salmon, salad, shrimp, lobster, asparagus, marinated mushrooms and the like; chafing dishes holding chicken with tarragon, seafood stew, tortellini, roast turkey and roast tenderloin. The desserts were as splendid as they were copious.

title: Surgery for Jockey
description: Patrick Valenzuela, injured in a spill at Santa Anita Wednesday, will undergo surgery to repair broken bones in his left cheekbone today. ''He's doing fine, but he's still slightly dazed from a concussion,'' Dr. Jan Holwick said yesterday.

title: photo of cast of 'Pirates of Penzance' (Ken Howard); Staying Loyal to Gilbert and Sullivan
description: ''We believe in doing Gilbert and Sullivan straight,'' said Albert Bergeret, the founder, artistic director and principal conductor of the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players. ''That is, we try to keep the material faithful and true to the intent of the authors, but we also try to bring life, energy and contemporary wit to it, so that it remains alive and exciting to a modern audience.''

title: Dining Out Guide: New York Traditions
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. The Coach House

title: Belli Fined for False Lawsuit
description: Melvin Belli and a colleague have been fined $5,000 each by a Federal judge here for filing a damage suit on behalf of a dead man.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; A Museum for the Things Too Painful to Forget
description: ''After so much death, what forgiveness?'' asked Ly Sorsane, guiding a visitor through a museum devoted to the victims of the Khmer Rouge, driven from power by a Vietnamese invasion 10 years ago. ''Most of us simply want to get on with what's left of our lives.''

title: Their Economic Priority: A Job
description: For many of the 8,000 economists gathered in Manhattan this week, the law of supply and demand is more than an echo of Adam Smith. They are job-hunting, and the good news for them is that the demand for economists exceeds the supply.

title: Professional Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $395,000 for the quarter and $600,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,746,000 for the quarter and $4,019,000 for the year.

title: Slower Growth Is Expected In U.S. Industry Next Year
description: Industry should enjoy, at a slightly reduced pace, a seventh straight year of rising sales in 1989, according to the Government's annual assessment of American business.

title: Money Magazine Seeks New Kind of Advertiser
description: Money magazine, reeling from the loss of financial-services advertising in the aftermath of the October 1987 stock market plunge, introduces a trade campaign next week through John Emmerling Inc. that seeks to appeal to a different class of advertiser. The ads spotlight the Time Inc. publication's articles not dealing with financial services. One ad, with the headline ''Glasnosh,'' features a brief excerpt from a piece on Soviet cuisine and a picture of a beautiful table setting shadowed by a hammer and sickle. The ads, which will run concurrently with the five-year-old ''The Rewards of Money'' campaign, conclude with the slogan ''Money: as richly surprising as real life.''

title: San Francisco Deplores Plan To Cut Ship Base and Presidio
description: A Government recommendation that 6 of California's 104 military bases be shut disheartened many Californians because of the prospect of lost jobs and revenue from military payrolls.

title: Lessons and Carols
description: James Litton is to conduct the St. Bartholomew's Choir in a Christmas Festival of Lessons and Carols at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue an 50th Street, on New Year's Day at 3 P.M. Included on the program are works by Warlock, Cornelius, Poston and Rutter. Admission is free. Information: 751-1616.

title: Leslie Agency Creates A Talking Car Engine
description: As a talking car engine, the actor Dan Region has a lot to say about getting a tune-up, all of it good. Precision Tune, a Virginia-based automotive company with about 500 shops nationwide, has created ''Motorman'' to chronicle the fits and starts the average car engine is likely to face. Created by Leslie Advertising of Greenville, S.C., the $6 million national campaign will be shown during at least eight college bowl games.

title: Soviets Order Removal Of Ex-Leaders' Names
description: The Kremlin today ordered the names of the disgraced leaders Leonid I. Brezhnev and Konstantin U. Chernenko removed from the homes in which they once lived, as well as from every town, school and factory christened for them.

title: An Exhibition on Jewish Journalism
description: The idea that the American Jewish press - a hodgepodge of journalism with a history of dramatically divergent views from religious orthodoxy to political anarchism - could ever be brought under one roof might have boggled the imagination a few decades ago. But this feat of unification, if only for exhibition purposes, is in vivid evidence at the Jewish Museum.

title: Brazil Inflation Surges; Spending Cut Promised
description: Amid signs that a two-month-old anti-inflationary pact is already breaking down, a new surge of inflation this month has brought fresh pledges from President Jose Sarney to slash Government spending next year.

title: Surgical Appliance Seeking Lumex
description: Surgical Appliance Industries said it was prepared to buy all of the shares of Lumex Inc. for at least $13 a share in cash, or $52.9 million. But Lumex immediately rejected the offer. ''We are not interested in working with Surgical Appliance to arrange for the sale of our corporation,'' said Lawrence N. Cohen, the president of Lumex, a health care and rehabilitation equipment manufacturer based in Bay Shore, L.I.

title: Chilean's 'Life Is A Dream'
description: In ''Life Is a Dream,'' a 1986 film by Raul Ruiz, the expatriate Chilean film maker now living in France, a youngish revolutionary returns secretly to Chile for reasons that are never clear. Lying on the bed in his hotel room in Valparaiso, the man recalls that 10 years earlier he had memorized the names of 1,500 members of an anti-junta movement.

title: People
description: * Joseph Mackenna, Richard Stillman and Kathryn Woods have been promoted to senior vice presidents and, respectively, managing director for special markets, management supervisor and director of public relations at HDM, New York.

title: Reviews/Art; 2 Dynasties' Views of Landscape, in Met Paintings
description: When the department of Asian art at the Metropolitan Museum decided to mount an exhibition of Song and Yuan Dynasty paintings from its collection, it could not go too far wrong. The Song and Yuan periods are signposts of Chinese art. Between 960 and 1368, the Chinese debates about painting, poetry and calligraphy; about inspiration and method, and about working from the imagination and working from observation, reached a level of sophistication from which it will always be possible to learn.

title: Telecalc Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: New York Philharmonic To Be Featured on Radio
description: A new series of weekly programs featuring recordings of the New York Philharmonic is to begin Jan. 8 on the radio station of The New York Times, WQXR, 96.3 FM and 1560 AM. The programs are to be broadcast on Sundays from 3 to 5 P.M., the same time as the long-running series of live Philharmonic concerts, which recently concluded.

title: Congress's Acceptance Of Base Plan Expected
description: Federal lawmakers predicted today that Congress would go along with a plan to close dozens of military bases around the nation even though officials of some communities expressed anger and dismay over the potential loss of thousands of jobs.

title: Metro Datelines; Builder Admits Lying On Drinking Water
description: A developer pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he falsified documents to mask the fact that his company's homes had drinking water that could harm fetuses, children and the elderly. The developer, Bernard Mayerfeld, admitted to Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Federal District Court that he falsified documents certifying that water with unsafe nitrates was potable.

title: Turkey Reports Surplus
description: Turkey, helped by rising earnings from tourism, today reported a record surplus of current accounts of $408 million for the first 10 months of the year.

title: Israel Can Set Agenda for Palestinian Future; Important Leverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Air Force ultimately gave its cooperation. The Army begrudgingly gave its reluctant cooperation. The Navy stonewalled and got away with it.'' - Former Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, on the effort to close military bases. [ A16:3. ]

title: Avery in Talks on Sale Of Uniroyal Chemical
description: Avery Inc., a New York holding company, said yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of its Uniroyal Chemical Company subsidiary to a group led by management.

title: Base Closings: Necessary Pain
description: A Pentagon commission's list of military installations to be shut or pared down has produced predictable howls of protest from local politicians and genuine grief in communities where the military is a vital part of local life. But in the long run this streamlining will reduce waste, benefit national defense and allow communities to turn the Government properties to better use.

title: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve
description: Adderley at Birdland

title: Royal Palm Beach Colony LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings represent partnership units.

title: Esiason Is M.V.P.
description: Boomer Esiason of the Cincinnati Bengals, the key figure in Cincinnati's turnaround from a 4-11 record in 1987 to 12-4 this season, has been voted the N.F.L.'s most valuable player by The Associated Press. Esiason, who had the best rating among passers, completed 57 percent of his passes and threw for 3,572 yards and 28 touchdowns with only 14 interceptions. He won in a close three-way vote, getting 31 votes to 21 for the quarterback Randall Cunningham of Philadelphia and 17 for the running back Roger Craig of San Francisco. (AP)

title: Israelis Kill 3 Arabs in Negev Said to Be Infiltrators
description: The Israeli Army said today that it shot dead three suspected Arab infiltrators in the southern Negev on Wednesday, as concern grew here over an apparent increase in recent days in attempted Palestinian guerrilla raids.

title: Greenstone Offering
description: Greenstone Rabasca Roberts of Melville, L.I., has filed for an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency, which was established in 1972 and claims billings of $21 million, intends to sell four million shares at an aggregate price of $4 million, to be used for working capital and for acquisitions.

title: JAPANESE MINISTER QUITS IN SCANDAL
description: Japan's newly appointed Justice Minister reversed himself and resigned this morning because he had received political donations from a company at the heart of a widening stock scandal.

title: Reviews/Dance; 2 Role Debuts in 'The Nutcracker'
description: Musical tempos can seriously affect the impression dancers make. That was demonstrated at the New York State Theater Wednesday night, when there were several debuts in the New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A 'Gentleman's' Hunt
description: Few details of President-elect Bush's quail hunting trip have been made available, but a photograph released of the left-handed sportsman tells some things to the cognoscenti.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 126, Rockets 109: Jeff Malone scored 24 of his 31 points in the second half last night, leading the Bullets to their highest point production of the season. Houston (18-10) had won six games in a row, its longest streak since seven in a row in November 1985. Otis Thorpe led the Rockets with 26 points.(AP) Mavericks 131, Celtics 115: Derek Harper scored 11 points during a Dallas season-high 40-point first quarter. Dallas, which had dropped 15 of 16 previous meetings with Boston, hit 9 of its first 10 shots and 13 of 16 to build a 15-point lead in the quarter. (AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL Florida 14, Illinois 10: Emmitt Smith scored on e first play and then rallied Florida (7-5) to a late score last night in the All-American Bowl at Birmingham, Ala. Smith, the game's most valuable player, ran for 159 yards on 28 carries. His winning 2-yard run around right end came with 4:28 left, shortly after Doug Higgins had given Illinois (6-5-1) its only lead with a 44-yard field goal.(AP) Brigham Young 20, Colorado 17: Jason Chaffetz kicked a 35-yard field goal ath 2:33 to play, for the victory in the Freedom Bowl at Anaheim, Calif. Chaffetz, who tied the score with a 31-yarder with 4:11 to play, connected after Scott Peterson intercepted Darian Hagan's pass at the Colorado 45-yard line with 3:14 left. B.Y.U. finished 9-3, Colorado 8-4. (AP) TENNIS Czechoslovakia and Sweden Advance: Czechoslovakia and Sweden moved into the semifinals of the Hopman Cup team competition yesterday in Perth, Australia. Mikael Pernfors led Sweden to a 3-0 victory over Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia rallied to beat Japan, 2-1, in the international event, which features two-player teams from eight nations. Czechoslovakia started poorly when Miloslav Mecir was beaten, 6-2, 6-4, by Shuzo Matsuoka. But Mecir and Helena Sukova beat Matsuoka and Masako Yanagi, 7-5, 6-3, in mixed doubles, and Sukova clinched the series with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Yanagi. Pernfors beat Slobodan Zivojinovic, 6-4, 6-3, then joined Catarina Lindqvist to beat Zivojinovic and Carmen Skulj, 6-7, 6-3, 6-2, in mixed doubles. Lindqvist beat Skulj, 6-2, 6-3, in the final singles match. (AP) Upset in Championships: Unseeded Claes Ramel of Sweden upset the No. 1 seeded Jim Gurfein of Great Neck, L.I., 7-6, 6-4, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the New York State hardcourt championships in Blue Point, L.I. Third-seeded Phil Williamson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., rallied for a 5-7, 6-1, 6-4 victory over John Schmitt Jr. of Brookville, L.I.
