Randy Vigmostad of Washington eliminated Mickey Cook of Middletown, N.J., 6-2, 6-3, and Dan Montesdeca of Kew Gardens, Queens, beat Sven Salumaa of Huntington, L.I., 6-4, 6-1.(AP) HOCKEY Canada 9, Czechoslovakia 1: John Olsson scored two goals in a six-goal second period yesterday as Team Canada trounced Czechoslovakia's VSZ Kosice, 9-1, in the Spengler Cup tournament in Davos, Switzerland. Earlier, Kriliya Moscow defeated Davos Selects, 4-2. The USA Selects, the fifth team in the six-day tournament, had the day off. The Americans and Canadians are tied at 2-1 after three games in the round-robin part of the tournament. Kriliya Moscow is 2-2 and Davos and VSZ Kosice are 1-2. (AP)

title: A Time for Rhyme
description: Day after the Eve, are you feeling the blahs? Then here's a pickup, one that's laced with stars. Poets and singers and actors, famous all, Have answered the Poetry Project's urgent call. They'll join in its 15th annual marathon reading At St. Mark's Church; $10 you'll be needing. It's payable as you come through the door At 7 P.M. Sunday; you can't reserve before. The place is at 10th Street and Avenue Second, And each player will have two minutes, or four, it's reckoned. They'll recite, perform, dance or sing; In five to seven hours, you'll hear everything. Here's Allen Ginsberg, the poet; Spalding Gray of ''Our Town,'' And Gregory Corso, a rhymer who's Beat, but not down. Larry Rivers and the 13th Street Band will play up a storm, And the dancer Douglas Dunn should be in fine form. I. Dufresne, that's Ultra Violet, who now writes, And Rudy Burckhardt (the photographer) are some of the sights. Richard Foreman, plays are his thing, joins Jackson Mac Low, A man of letters, to recite Gertrude Stein. And so! Those are only a few from more than a hundred, People ahead of their time, who will have volleyed and thundered Before the end of this event, so colossal in scope. Information: 674-0910. That's right, I hope.

title: Move on Elephant Ivory
description: The United States announced a ban today on elephant ivory imports from countries that have not joined an international pact that regulates trade in endangered species. The move is the first step toward carrying out a 1988 act of Congress aimed at protecting the threatened African elephant, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said in a statement.

title: Unbeaten Seton Hall Flattens DePaul, 83-60
description: Andrew Gaze and Daryll Walker led 13th-ranked Seton Hall to a 35-point lead with 12 minutes left tonight and the unbeaten Pirates cruised past DePaul, 83-60, to win the Sugar Bowl tournament.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: The year-ago 12 months' results included an after-tax charge of $229 million to cover cost over-runs at the Vogtle Nuclear Plant.

title: PANEL ON MILITARY CALLS FOR CLOSING OF SCORES OF BASES
description: A Federal commission today proposed a sweeping plan to shut down 86 military bases and partly close five others to save $5.6 billion over 20 years.

title: Early Parole Is Proposed In Drug Plan
description: In an effort to deal with overcrowding in New York State prisons and the growing number of new inmates who are drug addicts, a state legislator is proposing that certain prisoners who complete intensive drug-treatment programs be considered for early parole.

title: A Marathon Reading Of 'Finnegans Wake'
description: James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake'' is a book that is always beginning and ending and beginning again. So New Year's Eve, the end of one year and the beginning of another, seems like a good time for a marathon public reading of this mysterious and funny novel.

title: Fight Over a Gasoline Tax Rise
description: Supporters and opponents of a stiff rise in the Federal gasoline tax have begun to square off in what is likely to be one of the biggest political battles of the new administration.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, a financial services concern, said it had completed the sale of its individual insurance products division to Standard Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of Intercontinental Life Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rooney Is Arrested
description: Kevin Rooney, former trainer for Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, pleaded not guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday to charges of drunken driving, resisting arrest and leaving the scene of an accident. The 32-year-old Rooney, who was dismissed from his job by Tyson earlier this month, was released on his own recognizance pending a hearing Feb. 3.

title: Heine Securities and S.E.C. in Settlement
description: The Heine Securities Corporation, an investment advisory firm controlled by Michael F. Price, Wednesday settled Federal disciplinary charges that it had failed to fully disclose Mr. Price's compensation arrangements to shareholders of its three affiliated mutual funds.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two rescues of savings and loan associations misidentified the previous position of Mario Antoci, the new head of the American Savings Bank. He was president and chief operating officer of Home Savings of America in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. to Study Copper Curbs
description: The United States began an investigation today into claims of unfair restrictions in Britain and the European Community on imports of American scrap copper and copper alloy.

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry of Police Hampered

title: 3 'Brandenburgs'
description: Bach's Fourth, Fifth and Sixth ''Brandenburg'' Concertos are to be performed at Bargemusic, at the Fulton Ferry Landing (Furman Street, at the foot of Cadman Plaza) in Brooklyn, on New Year's Eve at 7:30 P.M. Among the performers are Stephen Burns, a trumpeter; Laura Gilbert and Marya Martin, flutists; Ida Kavafian and Hamao Fujwara, violinists; Timothy Eddy, Fred Sherry and Peter Wiley, cellists, and Robert Wolinsky, a harpsichordist. Tickets are $60. Information: (718) 624-4061.

title: Officials in Natchez Reject Renaming Street for Dr. King
description: City officials have rejected a proposal to name a street for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., prompting complaints from a black alderman that the rejection was a step backward in race relations.

title: Pennwalt Files Suit
description: The Pennwalt Corporation, in an effort to avert a hostile takeover, filed a Federal lawsuit accusing Centaur Partners of violating securities laws in a recent tender offer. The suit seeks an injunction against Centaur's $765 million offer, which was filed Dec. 13 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A Pennwalt spokeswoman, Sue S. Kinard, said she had not read the suit and could not comment. On Tuesday, Pennwalt's board called Centaur's $100-a -share offer ''completely unacceptable.''

title: Metro Datelines; Homeless Are Barred From Train Station
description: The city has begun barring homeless people from the New Haven railroad station at night and directing them to shelters as a result of growing complaints by rail passengers and station personnel, city officials said yesterday.

title: Companies and Employees Give Generously to Neediest
description: The First Boston Foundation Trust sent its annual Christmas gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a check for $50,000.

title: Koch Plans Unity Parade
description: Mayor Koch, who pledged this week to be a ''kinder, gentler'' person in 1989, said yesterday that he plans to hold a parade this spring to celebrate the city's racial and ethnic diversity and that he would invite everyone but the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Economic Scene; A Common Goal: Fight Ignorance
description: ECONOMISTS by the thousands have been holding their annual meetings in New York this week. A population explosion has been going on in the field, and economists have been subdividing into a host of professional associations.

title: Dow's Close Is 2d Highest Since Crash
description: Stocks rallied to close moderately higher yesterday, led by strength in blue-chip issues, as the Dow Jones industrial average finished just short of its highest close in more than a year.

title: Restaurants
description: One is instinctively wary of a restaurant where the first category on the menu is labeled ''Let's Start With'' and where the waiter, a loose-limbed, unshaven Tom Hanks impersonator, begins his monologue about daily specials with ''Well, if you're into fish, my favorite is . . .'' Add to this a so-hip-it-hurts Neo-Classical design, complete with prechipped wall moldings and faux weathered columns, and you have all the trappings of yet another Upper West Side gastronomic Pompeii.

title: No Headline
description: Fate and the 'Tourist'

title: Citing Drexel Case, Judge Delays Takeover
description: Wall Street yesterday saw the first impact of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s $650 million proposed settlement of criminal charges on the firm's ability to do business, when a Federal judge used the settlement as a basis to delay a hostile takeover.

title: Redshirt Score: W. Va. 24, Irish 3
description: West Virginia dresses in blue and gold. Notre Dame wears gold and blue. The teams that will meet in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday to determine the winner of the national college football polls share certain strategic similarities.

title: Eagle Quarterback Has Opponents' Defenses on the Run
description: If the Bears can stop Randall Cunningham of the Philadelphia Eagles in tomorrow's National Football League playoff game in Chicago, they should win comfortably.

title: Bulls Beat Knicks on Pippen's Last-Second Basket
description: The floundering Chicago Bulls needed a change. Coach Doug Collins wanted more rebounding and more movement at the small-forward spot. Tuesday night, Scottie Pippen, who missed the first month of the season because of back surgery, replaced Brad Sellers for the Bulls' game against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Bid Planned For Utility
description: The New England Electric System, a public utility that serves customers in three states, said yesterday that it would proceed with its plan to submit a bid to acquire the operating assets of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, excluding the utility's stake in the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant. The announcement by New

title: Drexel: Hanged Without a Trial
description: You know that old saw about how, as a society, we can't afford to impinge on the constitutional rights of some obvious rat because it could eventually erode the rights of all of us?

title: V.A. TO OVERHAUL BENEFIT CRITERIA
description: Many disabled veterans may be missing out on hundreds of dollars' worth of benefits from the Veterans Administration because the agency's classification of disabilities is outdated, a Congressional study says.

title: Reynolds Released
description: Jerry Reynolds, the 44-year-old coach of the Sacramento Kings, was released from a hospital yesterday with a doctor's report that he was in good health after 48 hours of heart tests and observation.

title: Accounts
description: * Boating magazine to Muhlfeld & Wolff, a subsidiary of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss.

title: Flyers Surge in 2d Period and Halt Penguins' Unbeaten Streak at Eight, 3-2
description: Terry Carkner and Brian Propp scored second-period goals tonight to help the Philadelphia Flyers defeat Pittsburgh, 3-2, and end the Penguins' eight-game unbeaten streak.

title: No. 1 Lady Vols and Rutgers Gain Final
description: Daedra Charles and Tonya Edwards scored 13 points each to lead six Tennessee players in double figures as the top-ranked Lady Volunteers defeated Wake Forest, 82-61, tonight in a first-round game of the Bell-Atlantic Holiday Tournament.

title: Books of The Times; Updating the Minutiae of a Truly American Sound
description: The New Grove Dictionary of Jazz Edited by Barry Kernfeld Illustrated. Volume 1, 670 pages; Volume 2, 690 pages. Grove's Dictionaries of Music. $295.

title: Brazil Reduces Foreign Debt
description: Brazil, the largest debtor of the developing world, cut its foreign debt by 5.2 percent this year and should reduce it further in 1989, the country's central bank said today.

title: Review/Music; A Mature Voice of the Blues
description: Bobby Cole is a pianist and singer whose voice sounds as though it carries the distillate of a thousand nights in a smoky saloon. Mr. Cole may have long since passed that number and now, even in the relatively clear air of Elmer's, a spick-and-span steak and seafood restaurant on Second Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets, his vocal projection is little more than a gasping growl.

title: IDB to Buy Hughes TV
description: IDB Communications Group, which owns a network of satellite earth stations, said yesterday that it would buy the Hughes Television Network for about $35 million. Hughes, based in New York City, provides satellite transmission services for television coverage of entertainment and sporting events, including exclusive transmission of ''away'' games for major league baseball.

title: Brierley Has Stakes In 3 French Stores
description: Ron Brierley, the New Zealand corporate raider, has bought stakes in three French department stores, his first step into continental Europe. A representative, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., which is 69 percent controlled by Brierley Investments Ltd., has bought stakes of 5 percent in Bazar de l'Hotel de Ville and SA des Galeries Lafayette. A month ago another Brierley unit took 5 percent of a French regional department store group, Nouvelles Galeries.

title: Bain Acquires Apparel Chains
description: Bain Capital, a Boston investment firm, yesterday acquired for an undisclosed sum two Southwest apparel chains, Bealls and Palais Royal.

title: Biopharmaceutics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,310 for the quarter and $54,503 for the year. c-After losses of $2,054,333 and $1,295,144 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: TV Weekend; Kennedy Center Honors
description: Lovers of the performing arts would do well to grab a VCR this evening, the kind that lets you watch one program while recording another. It seems that CBS's ''Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts'' and PBS's ''John Gielgud: An Actor's Life'' are running against each other at 9 o'clock. Both shows are special. ''The Kennedy Center Honors'' has in the course of 11 years developed what is surely the classiest format in televised award ceremonies. The honorees are recognized not for any one particular achievement but for their life's work. With the President of the United States in attendance, they are praised by their peers and given standing ovations by a formally dressed audience of celebrities and power wielders. Short biographical films trace their careers. Entertainments of various sorts are offered as part of the tributes. The annual shows, produced by George Stevens Jr. and Nick Vanoff, have been honed into an unusually elegant and distinguished formula.

title: Robberies Rose In September, New York Says
description: More than 245 robberies a day were reported in New York City in September, 7.5 percent more than in the same month a year ago, according to Police Department crime figures made public yesterday.

title: Great Country Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Israel Can Set Agenda for Palestinian Future; Negotiations First
description: To the Editor:

title: Lights! Champagne! Music! 53 Ways to Welcome the New Year
description: AS the last of its 31,622,400 seconds tick into oblivion tomorrow night, 1988 promises to go out with a ball, a bang and a bonanza of festive celebrations in New York City.

title: U.S. Investigates Mayor of Capital; He Denies a Swirl of Drug Rumors
description: The Justice Department announced today that it would ''aggressively'' investigate to determine whether Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has committed a crime.

title: Heinz Workers Face Wage Freeze
description: Workers at the H. J. Heinz Company's Pittsburgh plant will vote next week on an agreement under which they will accept a three-year wage freeze while the company carries out a $90 million plant modernization program. Without such a program, workers could expect an ''extreme and rapid reduction in the work force'' as Heinz shifted products to factories with lower production costs, Michael Kedzuf, president of United Food and Commercial Workers Local 325, said.

title: Vader Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $1,972,480 and a tax credit of $815,000. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $1,191,613 and a tax credit of $570,000. The year-ago results are restated. The company said latest year results reflected gains from the sale in April of its artificial flower and plant business and interest income from the investment of cash proceeds of that sale.

title: Rates on Treasury Bills Tumble
description: Treasury bill discount rates plunged yesterday as the traditional year-end demand for the 90- and 180-day bills reached near feverish levels.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Burson and Ohio State End St. John's Streak in Festival
description: After watching Jay Burson pour in 37 points for Ohio State against Florida on Tuesday, Coach Lou Carnesecca decided that if Ohio State was going to beat St. John's, the Buckeyes would have to do it without their gangly, 6-foot senior point guard.

title: New Face: Uma Thurman; Prospects in 'Liaisons' Were Awesome at First
description: In the film ''Dangerous Liaisons,'' a convent-raised 15-year-old, played by Uma Thurman, confides a terrible secret to the Marquise (Glenn Close): that the Vicomte de Valmont (John Malkovich) entered her bedroom and forced her to submit to him.

title: Loral Negotiations
description: Turkey will negotiate with the Loral Corporation to supply electronic warfare equipment for its new fighter planes, Defense Ministry sources said. Turkey is seeking an electronic countermeasure system for the 160 United States-designed F-16 Falcon aircraft it will use to replace its aging United States-supplied F-104's. Loral is based in New York and manufactures military electronic systems.

title: Charles Mercer, Writer And Former Editor, 71
description: Charles Mercer, a novelist and former editor at G. P. Putnam's Sons, died Wednesday at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 71 years old. Mr. Mercer was the author of 17 novels, including ''Rachel Cade,'' a 1956 book about an American missionary in Africa, which sold more than three million copies, was translated into 14 languages and was made into a movie called ''The Sins of Rachel Cade.''

title: Interco Sells Londontown
description: Interco Inc. completed the sale of its Londontown Corporation subsidiary to the Eldersburg Acquisition Corporation today for $178 million in cash.

title: Egypt's Children: A Burden of Labor
description: Perched on a grimy sidewalk between mosque and highway, a small girl in blue school uniform hunched over a notebook, busying herself with homework in brief pauses offered by another pursuit: selling plastic shopping bags.

title: More of P. D. Q. Bach
description: Prof. Peter Schickele is to present ''The Preachers of Crimetheus,'' the latest of his discoveries among the works of P. D. Q. Bach, at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. Also on the program are P. D. Q. Bach's ''Minuet Militaire,'' ''Breakfast Antiphonies,'' ''La Pucelle de New Orleans'' and ''Bach Portrait.'' The works are to be performed by the New York Pickup Orchestra, with Jorge Mester conducting. The program is to be repeated on New Year's Day at 3 P.M. Tickets are $18 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Inaugural Bubbly Blend
description: The theme of the change from President Reagan to President Bush is continuity, and so it is to be with the sparkling wine that is served at the luncheons, dinners and balls attending the inauguration next month.

title: The March of Folly
description: Can it possibly be just less than a year - it seems an age - since I confidently declared in this space that ''the Democrats will know how to exploit'' George Bush's role in the Iran-contra scandal, and that it was ''difficult to imagine anything he might say to silence'' that issue?

title: Armed, Dangerous Life Of a Probatin Officer
description: One Tuesday morning, after 26 hours of chase and surveillance, a team of four Bronx probation officers had their man - a 41-year-old probation violator with a history of alcohol abuse and a record of holding women at gunpoint.

title: Our Towns; Cookie Sales 101, Or What to Do If 'Cute' Fails
description: School vacation has reached that critical point. The other morning, 6-year-old Erin Striebel watched ''Dirty Dancing'' on the VCR six straight times. She has now seen ''Grease'' more than 100 times. ''I love it,'' she said.

title: Soviets Halve Estimate Of Earthquake Deaths
description: Soviet officials today backed away from their estimate that 55,000 people died in the Armenian earthquake, saying that the recovery of bodies is nearly complete and that the final toll will be half that.

title: Corrections
description: The headline yesterday on an obituary of Joseph Clark described his position incorrectly. Mr. Clark was a former editor of The Daily Worker, the Communist Party newspaper in the United States. He resigned from that post, and from the party, in 1957 after Nikita S. Khrushchev denounced Stalin. He later worked for the American Cancer Society and for Dissent magazine.

title: Hermosa Beach Journal; Long After Summer Fades, Lifeguards Carry On
description: In the winter, from the beaches along Santa Monica Bay, snow is sometimes visible atop distant mountains. But for the lifeguards who patrol the ocean shores of Los Angeles County, the sun never sets on summer.

title: Young Team Brings On An Old Pro
description: THE entrepreneurial dream excites even jaded advertising executives. The new year rings in with the news that Donald D. Ashley is leaving his post as executive vice president and general manager of the Dallas office of Tracy-Locke, an agency with annual billings in the $400 million range, to become the third partner and chief operating officer of Mandelbaum, Mooney & Associates, a 10-month-old San Francisco shop with billings of $6.5 million.

title: Communication Cable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago fourth quarter results included the costs of acquisition and two months of operations of the Intercomp division, acquired in September 1987.

title: Doubts on Gasoline Tax Revenues
description: Doubling or tripling the gasoline tax, an idea recently embraced by some leading economists and members of Congress as a quick way to help reduce the budget deficit, may not raise nearly as much money as proponents hope, some experts contend.

title: Gould Investors LP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,027,000 on the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments. c-Net income and after a gain of $1,541,000 on the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments. The prior year results included a gain of $300,000, or 22 cents a limited partnership unit, from the settlement of condemnation proceedings. The year-ago share earnings represent a limited partneship unit.

title:
THE LAW;
Disabled Lawyers Join in Drive on Bias in Hiring
description: LEAD: As the legal profession opens its doors to many it once shunned, handicapped lawyers are presenting themselves for consideration. They are raising their voices against discrimination by law schools and law firms and pushing for special legislation and improved hiring.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY DEPRESSION ERA FILMS

title: Dr. Carl J. Johnson Is Dead at 58; Opposed Nuclear Weapons Tests
description: Dr. Carl J. Johnson, a public health official who attacked the Federal Government over the potentially dangerous effects of nuclear weapons testing, died of complications from heart surgery yesterday at Lutheran Memorial Hospital in Lakewood, Colo. He was 59 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: Melee Inquiry Is Stalled, Board Reports
description: A four-month investigation into allegations of police misconduct during a melee at Tompkins Square Park last summer has been severely hampered by a lack of voluntary cooperation by officers who were at the scene and by problems in identifying officers accused of abusing civilians, the head of the Civilian Complaint Review Board said yesterday.

title: Review/Art; Art of Opposites: New Haven Show Of Victor Pasmore
description: At the Yale Center for British Art here, there is a retrospective exhibition of paintings, collages, constructions and mixed-media works by Victor Pasmore, an English painter who turned 80 years old this month. It is not a show that I shall feign to have looked at with an objective eye. It was Mr. Pasmore, in 1948, who gave to me, and to many other people in London, a new idea of the potential of English art.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Holidays in History
description: Visitors at the Smithsonian Institution's American Museum of History this week found themselves in the middle of a demonstration of how Americans celebrate holidays.

title: Jackson's Promise Comes True
description: IT is such a ''long, long while from May til December'' (as Maxwell Anderson and Kurt Weill noted in their ''September Song'') that Mark Jackson's prediction last May 6 could easily have been invalidated by these last dark days of December.

title: 1 Killed, 40 Hurt, as Sudan Police Fire on Khartoum Demonstrators
description: The Sudanese police fired on a crowd of demonstrators in Khartoum today as rioting and widespread strikes continued in the Sudanese capital and other parts of the country.

title: Market Place; Baby Bells Leave A.T.&T. Behind
description: WHEN the Baby Bells were born half a decade ago, it was widely assumed on Wall Street that A.T.&T., the old Ma Bell who lost her nickname, would be the best of the family. A.T.&T. was expected to gain market share in the exciting area of computers while still reaping big profits in long-distance service.

title: Vote Ends Old Battle Over Name of Hamlet
description: When it comes to the pronunciation of the name of this Putnam County community, the official ruling is to hold the ''MAY-o.''

title: Ditka Is Voted Coach of the Year
description: Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears was voted the National Football League coach of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. ''It's a great honor; I appreciate it,'' said Ditka, whose Bears (12-4) won their fifth consecutive National Conference Central title. In winning the balloting by sportswriters covering the N.F.L., Ditka received 33 votes. Marv Levy of the Buffalo Bills was second with 23, and Sam Wyche of the Cincinnati Bengals third with 19. Ditka, 49 years old, suffered a mild heart attack on Nov. 2 but was back on the sideline two games later, promising to give up cigars and to try to control his temper.(AP)

title: Washington Talk: Federal Aviation Administration; Turf Battle Over an Agency's Future
description: The Federal Government and the aviation industry are girding for the renewal next year of a struggle over legislation that would detach the Federal Aviation Administration from the Department of Transportation, and make it independent again.

title: Talks on Deal for Lampoon
description: An investment group led by an actor who appeared in the motion picture ''Animal House'' has met with the senior management of National Lampoon Inc., the company that made the movie, to discuss the investors' ''interest in acquiring day-to-day managerial responsibility with respect to the operations of the company and board representation.''

title: Israel Can Set Agenda for Palestinian Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoechst Unit Sues G.E. on Patents
description: The Hoechst Celanese Corporation, a subsidiary of Hoechst A.G. of West Germany, filed patent infringement suits against the General Electric Company for manufacturing and selling certain polyester molding compounds. The lawsuits were filed in United States District Court in Delaware and in the Federal Court of Canada.

title: KEY RATES
A New Realism in Pretoria
description: LEAD: South Africa's signing of the Brazzaville Protocol, ending the long-running Namibian conflict, signals a major change in National Party thinking on regional foreign policy issues. Gone are such cliches as ''total onslaught'' and visions of a Communist conspiracy to enslave Southern Africa.

title: Cardiac Stress Test Is Far From Routine
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Executive From USX Elected Transtar Chief
description: LEAD: Donald H. Hoffman has been elected president and chief executive of Transtar Inc., a new holding company formed by the USX Corporation and the Blackstone Group to acquire the steel company's transportation division.

title: Eastern Defends Its Safety Record
description: Eastern Airlines defended its safety procedures today after two incidents involving cracks in the fuselage of its Boeing 727's. The airline said the problem was industrywide.

title: Bush Says 'We Cannot Rest' In Combating Terror Threat
description: President-elect George Bush said today that the United States should ''punish firmly, decisively'' those found responsible for the bombing that downed a Pan Am jetliner in Scotland last week.

title: Review/Theater; Fabulist 'Serpent Woman'
description: Andrei Serban has achieved directorial distinction with his versions of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Shakespeare and Chekhov, but it is with the 18th-century Italian playwright Carlo Gozzi that he seems to be having his most continuing relationship. Mr. Serban's creative collaboration with Gozzi is currently exemplified by his production of ''The Serpent Woman'' at the American Repertory Theater.

title: 'Shayna Maidel' to Close
description: ''A Shayna Maidel,'' a play by Barbara Lebow, which opened on Oct. 29, 1987, at the Westside Arts Theater, is to close Jan. 8 after 501 regular performances and 13 previews. Directed by Mary B. Robinson, the drama about the reunion of two sisters and their father after World War II stars Gordana Rashovich, Katherine Kamhi and Stephen Pearlman.

title: How to Defeat Plane Saboteurs
description: No one yet knows the identities or motives of whoever destroyed a planeload of people aboard Pan Am flight 103 and took the lives of many others in a Scottish village. But there can be little doubt about what must be done to combat such massacres: The threat of infiltrating bombs onto airliners needs to be taken seriously and eliminated relentlessly, just as the threat of airplane hijackings began to be countered a decade ago.

title: 5 Players Fined
description: Rod Thorn, vice president of operations for the National Basketball Association, has fined five players a total of $13,000 for fighting in three games Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about holiday celebrations of the Pro Arte Chorale, on Jan. 7 and Jan. 8, gave an incorrect telephone number for charging tickets. The correct number is (201) 445-9052.

title: 13 More Savings Bailouts Set
description: Amid rising criticism from Congress, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today continued its campaign to rescue troubled savings institutions before the end of the year, announcing three transactions that will require $1.18 billion in assistance.

title: General Public Utilities Corp reports earnings for 12mo to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents total revenue. The results for 1987 are restated for the effects of a change in accounting standards concerning computation of a loss on abandonment and disallowance of plant costs.

title: Comprehensive Care Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Photo of a section of the Pan Am jet being removed from a field (Reuters); Search in Scotland: Tedious and Slow
description: On a hillside overlooking this Scottish market town, a dozen blue-uniformed policemen, each dragging a big plastic bag, stooping like cotton pickers, scoured the terrain. For eight days, the ritual has been repeated from dawn until after dark by 600 police officers, mountain rescue workers and soldiers combing hills, woodland and lakes for clues to the crash of a Pan Am jetliner and bodies of the victims.

title: Metro Datelines; Jersey Increases Cost Of Hospital Stays
description: State health officials have decided to increase the average cost of a hospital stay in 1989 by about $150, to help shore up the $500 million Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, which reimburses hospitals for treating indigent and uninsured patients.

title: Open the Door to College as an Incentive for Would-Be Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike Halts Lisbon Subway
description: About 450,000 commuters had to find other transportation today when subway workers went on strike, union officials said. Workers said management was refusing to pay them overtime for 56-hour working weeks.

title: Metro Datelines; O'Neill Seeks Curbs As Deficit Increases
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said yesterday that Connecticut's anticipated 1988-89 budget deficit had grown by $20 million, to about $135 million, and he summoned agency heads to a meeting to drive home earlier orders to keep spending down.

title: Pauley Petroleum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $5.2 million from an adjustment to the depreciation, depletion and amortization accounts, for the quarter and year. Both latest periods also reflected the acquisition in January of Hondo Oil and Gas Co. for 10 million newly issued shares of stock.

title: Two French Girls Are Released in Libya
description: Two French girls, held hostage for more than a year, were freed today in Libya and flown home after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, reportedly intervened on their behalf.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Company Briefs column on Wednesday about R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company described its ownership incorrectly. It is not a unit of any other company.

title: Midwest Population Shows New Growth, Census Bureau Says
description: Population growth in the Midwest appears to be rebounding from a downturn earlier in this decade, but Americans continue to favor the West as the place to live, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: A Musical Comedy
description: The 18th annual Lincoln Center Community Holiday Festival, which continues through Thursday, is to present a free performance of ''The 1940's Radio Hour'' at Alice Tully Hall at 7:30 tonight. A behind-the-scenes musical comedy about a 1940's radio station, the show was written by Walton Jones and is to be performed by the Staten Island Civic Theater. The three-week festival features free programs presented by the cultural councils of the city's five boroughs and other performing-arts organizations from throughout the metropolitan area. It is sponsored by Consolidated Edison, and tickets are available only through local Con Ed offices. Information: 460-6917.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The U.S. should abandon its efforts to limit a wide range of computer exports to Communist nations and focus instead on restricting a narrower range of advanced technologies with military applications, the National Academy of Sciences says. The study contends the Soviet Union and its allies have gotten hold of many computer technologies despite the Reagan Administration's strict export controls. [ Page A1. ] Faced with a new surge of inflation, Brazil will slash Government spending next year. Inflation was 28.8 percent in December and 933.6 percent for the year. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY Three savings industry rescues involving 12 institutions in Texas and another in Illinois were announced by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, as Congressional criticism mounted. The deals include the first rescue in which a foreign company is a buyer. [ D1. ] Whether to raise the Federal gasoline tax is shaping up as a major battle likely to be fought in the Bush administration. President-elect Bush has pledged not to raise any taxes, but many politicians in both parties believe new revenues are needed. [ D1. ] Doubling or tripling the gasoline tax, may not raise nearly as much money as proponents hope, some experts contend. [ D3. ] The California Supreme Court sharply narrowed the right of fired employees to bring suit on the basis of wrongful dismissal. The 4-3 ruling was a major victory for employers. Legal experts said the ruling would close the door to a broad range of wrongful discharge suits that have proliferated in California since 1980. [ D1. ] Supply and demand was on the minds of many of the 8,000 economists who gathered in Manhattan this week: the annual convention of the American Economic Association is the scene of job-hunting by recent Ph.D.'s. [ D1. ] The population explosion among economists has forced them to subdivide into a host of professional associations. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] At a slightly reduced pace, industry should enjoy a seventh consecutive year of rising sales in 1989, the Commerce Department said in its annual assessment of American business. [ D3. ] COMPANIES A Federal judge delayed a hostile takeover because of concerns that Drexel Burnham Lambert's proposed settlement of securities fraud charges would harm the firm's finances. Drexel is participating in MAI Basic Four's hostile offer for Prime Computer. [ D1. ] Avery is negotiating a sale of Uniroyal Chemical to a group led by management. The New York holding company said it expected the sale to bring in $800 million to $810 million. [ D4. ] Interco completed the sale of Londontown to the Eldersburg Acquisition for $178 million in cash. [ D4. ] Shares of Financial News Network climbed $1.625, to $8.375, in very active trading on takeover speculation. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stocks rallied to close moderately higher, led by strength in blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones industrial average finished just short of its highest close in more than a year, gaining 16.25 points, to 2,182.68. [ D1. ] Treasury bill discount rates plunged, with the traditional year-end demand for the 90- and 180-day bills at a feverish pitch. The heavy buying of bills reflected year-end ''window dressing'' by portfolio managers. [ D12. ] The dollar declined slightly in light year-end trading as dealers wondered if the December rally would carry into January. [ D13. ] Coffee futures prices surged to their highest levels in more than two years amid strong demand for green unroasted beans. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Baby Bells, five years old, have gone to the head of the Wall Street class, outperforming A.T.& T. Market Place. [ D6. ] Donald D. Ashley is leaving Tracy-Locke/Dallas to become the third partner of Mandelbaum, Mooney. Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Shamir Hopes for Peace Talks in 2 Months
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he hoped to start peace talks within two months giving Egypt the role of broker in talks with Arab governments and Palestinians.

title: Israel Interest Rates Up
description: Interest rates soared today as skepticism grew over the Government's decision to devalue the shekel. The Bank of Israel, the central bank, raised its lending rate to banks and other large financial institutions to 48.25 percent a year, from 32.8 percent a week ago. The rate is high because of Israel's high inflation rate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, announced the election of Steven A. Miller, director of the Cleveland Foundation, to its board.

title: O'Reilly, Korn in Postgame Clash
description: The Bruins visited the Devils for the first time since last spring's Stanley Cup semifinal series, and again there was a confrontation in the hallway on the way to the dressing rooms that overshadowed Boston's 6-2 triumph.

title: Key Balfour Officer Heading Eyeglass Unit
description: To move from a commodity trading firm to an eyeglass company might seem to be an unusual switch. But for Thomas E. Hitselberger it was a logical move.

title: China Faults U.S. in Dispute On Diplomats' Travel Rights
description: China accused the United States today of ''discriminative restrictions'' on the travel of Chinese diplomats in the United States and blamed the American side for the dispute over diplomatic travel rights.

title: Ageless, and Dressed Like an Athlete
description: One day this week an elderly New Yorker was seen running for a bus. Running like a deer! How come this woman was so fleet of foot? Because said feet were encased in Nikes, or Adidases, or Reeboks. Or something just like them. Along with millions of other Americans old enough to remember Jesse Owens, she has discovered that wisdom lies in dressing like an athlete.

title: Robert Kingsley, Judge, 85
description: Robert Kingsley, a recently retired California appeals court judge and former dean of the University of Southern California law school who opposed capital punishment through most of his career, died here Sunday. He was 85 years old.

title: California Court Limits Suits By Dismissed Employees
description: In a major victory for employers, the California Supreme Court today sharply narrowed the right of dismissed employees to bring suit on the basis of wrongful dismissal.

title: Whalers Edge Red Wings With Late 3-Goal Rally
description: Ray Ferraro capped a third-period Hartford rally, scoring with 6 minutes 18 seconds left in the game to give the Whalers a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: Mercedes Fined $20.2 Million
description: Mercedes-Benz has paid a record $20.2 million fine because its 1986 cars failed to meet the minimum Federal standard for gas mileage, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: Hornets Expand Knicks' Losing Streak
description: No matter what happens to the Knicks for the remainder of the season, they can look back at tonight's 122-111 loss to the Charlotte Hornets as one of their most embarrassing defeats.

title: Parts of Koppers Sold by Beazer
description: Beazer P.L.C., the British homebuilding and building materials company, said it had sold the Koppers Company's tar, wood and coke business and the Pittsburgh headquarters building for $275 million.

title: More Drinkers Yield Wheel to Get Home
description: The person who refrains from drinking at a party to take his or her companions home safely is becoming an increasingly frequent guest at parties, the Gallup Poll suggests.

title: The Mayor Rains On His Parade
description: A day after he had it, Mayor Koch's vision of a big springtime melting-pot parade on Fifth Avenue to celebrate New York City's racial and ethnic diversity dissolved yesterday like one of those troublesome New Year's resolutions.

title: Wide Swings Posted in Fed Funds Rate
description: Short-term rates ended the year on a downward bias yesterday after a year-end scramble for money by some banks sent the basic lending rate soaring early in the session.

title: Team Is Different, But Mascot Is Same
description: In a move from one Owl program to another, Jerry Berndt, whose Rice Owl football teams have lost 18 games in a row, will return to Philadelphia as the head coach of Temple University to bring ''better things'' to that struggling Owl program, Temple officials said yesterday.

title: Israel Stops Trading In Currency to Halt Flight From Shekel
description: Israel's central bank stopped selling or buying foreign currency today in an effort to head off a panic over the efforts of Finance Minister Shimon Peres to shore up the country's battered economy.

title: My Favorite New Years Eve  So Far
description: When I was starting out in show business the thing I want most for New Year's Eve was a booking. If you were booked on New Year's Eve, it meant you were doing O.K.

title: Kabul Offers Truce, but Guerrillas Reject It
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan announced today that Government forces would cease firing on Muslim guerrillas next week and would refrain from attacks as long as the rebels did.

title: My Favorite New Year's Eve - So Far
description: LEAD: Growing up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, I always looked forward to New Year's, mainly because that was the only thing we could afford that was really new. And we always believed that things were going to get better during the new year; we believed it because we knew that they couldn't get any worse.

title: Strike Cancels 'Nutcracker' in Toronto
description: A walkout by stagehands forced the National Ballet of Canada to cancel the last five performances of ''The Nutcracker,'' the Christmas classic that draws hundreds of children.

title: Two Fords Flex Their Muscles
description: Young members of the Henry Ford clan are agitating to make sure there will always be a Ford at or near the top of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Large Equity Fund Drain
description: Investors took more money out of equity mutual funds in November than in any month since the 1987 stock market crash, figures reported by a trade group showed yesterday.

title: NETS LOSE TO SUNS, 116-109
description: The Nets rallied last night to take a 100-99 lead in the fourth quarter, but Phoenix, which had lost seven games in a row in New Jersey, scored 13 of the next 18 points and went on to win. Page 44.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Nobody has the answer. There is no proposal that I know of that, if you implement it with infinite sources of money, would eliminate child abuse.'' - Mayor Edward I. Koch. [ 27:3. ]

title: Lithuanian Bishop Is Invited To Resume Religious Duties
description: In a new sign of warming relations between church and state, a Roman Catholic Bishop in Lithuania has been invited to resume his official duties after almost 28 years in internal exile.

title: Court Orders Review of the Impact Of U.S. Offshore Lease Program
description: A Federal appeals court, ruling on environmental challenges to the Interior Department's five-year plan for leasing offshore oil and gas, today ordered a further review of the program's effects on wildlife but refused to void leases that had been made.

title: Broader Curbs Sought On Challenging Jurors
description: Two years after the Supreme Court sharply restricted the ability of prosecutors to create all-white juries by refusing to accept black jurors, an unusual coalition of state law-enforcement officials and civil rights groups is trying to persuade the Court to place similar limits on defense lawyers.

title: Two Tardy Irish Sophomores Learn About Punctuality Holtz's Way
description: Everything about their unplanned departure seemed so unreal, so many things had happened so quickly, that Tony Brooks and Ricky Watters figured there had to be some reprieve.

title: Trail of Bomb on Pan Am Jet Is Said to Lead to Frankfurt
description: Investigators have told the Scottish police that the bomb that destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 was put aboard in Frankfurt, West Germany, The Times of London reported in today's issue.

title: INSIDE
description: Drexel Sanctions by Koch

title: Elizabeth McGuire Dibble Is Wed to Stuart P. Milne
description: The wedding of Elizabeth McGuire Dibble, the daughter of Mrs. Harold White of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Willis A. Dibble, to Stuart Paterson Milne, a son of Pat Milne of East Horseley, Surrey, England, and Robert Milne of London, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove. The Rev. John J. McCann performed the ceremony.

title: Thomas Blaisdell Jr., Who Helped Frame Aid Plan, Dies at 93
description: Thomas C. Blaisdell Jr., a former Assistant Secretary of Commerce who helped design the Marshall Plan to help revive Europe after World War II, died Tuesday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 93 years old and lived in Berkeley.

title: Tokyo Picks Its 2d Justice Minister in a Week
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita named a career bureaucrat and former judge as Justice Minister today, replacing an official who resigned because he had received political donations from a company at the heart of a widening stock trading scandal.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic Brings Home a Fiery Work
description: Ellen Taaffe Zwilich is unusual among contemporary composers in that her music is played an awful lot. With a Pulitzer Prize in her possession and a mailbox seemingly bulging with new commissions, Miss Zwilich keeps turning out works of every conceivable size and shape and gets them performed. Perhaps the American myth of virtue and hard work rewarded is not quite dead.

title:
FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rebound in Crude Oil Prices Spurred by Short-Covering
description: LEAD: Crude oil prices rebounded yesterday, largely on technical factors, in a shortened pre-holiday session at the New York Mercantile Exchange. A major factor was the short-covering that usually precedes a long holiday weekend.

title: About New York; An I.R.S. Form? No, W44AI Is No-Frills TV
description: Two minutes to air time. Two minutes to the 6 o'clock news. In the studio on East 23d Street, the anchor, Lou Steele, clips the microphone to his tie. He peers into the Teleprompter. He tries out a line of his script. ''Slumping Islanders still a net profit for L.I.'' He blinks. ''Who the hell understands that?''

title: Don't Be So Quick to Make Park Slope a Symbol of Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: New-Home Sales Down 8% in Month
description: Sales of new homes, hurt by a big slump in activity in the Northeast, declined by 8 percent in November, the largest setback in 18 months.

title: A Spirited 'Holy War' In an Easygoing Land
description: More than 180,000 members of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God jammed a huge soccer stadium here one recent Sunday to hear Bishop Edir Macedo denounce the Devil and his supposed presence among powerful African-Brazilian spiritist cults.

title: Hearings Set on Lifting 1942 Homework Curb
description: The Labor Department will hold hearings in February and March on lifting a 1942 regulation that bars apparel manufacturers from employing seamstresses in their homes, officials said Thursday.

title: Cuomo Denies Clemency Plea By Jean Harris
description: Governor Cuomo granted clemency yesterday to two convicted drug dealers but denied the clemency request of one of the state's most celebrated inmates, Jean S. Harris.

title: Brezhnev Son-in-Law Gets 12-Year Term
description: A high military tribunal today sentenced the son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, to 12 years in a labor camp for accepting bribes, concluding a corruption trial that was widely read as an indictment of an era.

title: Recycling Christmas Trees
description: If you are holding on to your Christmas tree until after New Year's Day, get rid of it soon after - safely. If you are an apartment dweller, never push that dried-out tree, no matter how small, down the garbage chute, where it could easily become jammed and catch fire or cause a major removal problem.

title: Hitler Felt Gleeful At Viennese Acclaim
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Computer
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. said it had amassed 54.1 percent of Prime Computer Inc.'s shares as a result of its hostile $20-a-share tender offer. The computer maker, which began its $1.3 billion bid for Prime last month, has received 24.2 million shares of Prime - about 50 percent of the company -in its offer, adding to its 4 percent stake in the minicomputer maker. But a Federal judge Thursday delayed the takeover, saying he was not convinced that MAI's investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., could finance the transaction.

title: Free-Trade Accord Clears Its Final Hurdle in Canada
description: Canada's legislation to carry out the free-trade agreement with the United States passed its final parliamentary hurdle today, clearing the way for the agreement to go into effect as scheduled at midnight Saturday.

title: TEACHER CLEARED IN FLIGHT THREAT
description: A college teacher charged with making a bomb threat aboard an American Airlines flight was cleared Thursday after an 11-year-old boy admitted writing a note that led to the charges, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Review/Television; A Success Story's Unhappy Ending
description: In the early 1970's, the Carpenters - Karen and her older brother, Richard - began moving to the top of the pop-music charts with a series of easy-listening hits. Clean-cut and only in their 20's, they were the Ken and Barbie of pop music. Let Elvis and the Rolling Stones do their shake, rattle and roll. The Carpenters, on international tours and in television specials, were mining Pat Boone territory. But before the decade was out, Richard Carpenter was in drug detoxification programs, and his sister was collapsing onstage as she fought a losing battle with anorexia nervosa. The wholesome images melted. Karen Carpenter died in February 1983, at the age of 32.

title: Aspiring to Guinness Book
description: With 36.5 miles of shelves and more than 1.1 million different books, John Zubal's bookstore offers the largest collection of titles for sale in the world, the owner said.

title: Let's Try It Again: 'I'm From New Jersey . . .'
description: This New Year's Day will mark the start of Year 28 in the seemingly endless quest of Red Mascara, a man known as New Jersey's most persistent lobbyist and arguably its worst songwriter, a man who has plied the statehouse halls to achieve his vision of immortality, to have his composition ''I'm From New Jersey'' adopted as the official state song.

title: Canada Rejects Alien-Amnesty Plan
description: Canada has decided against an amnesty that would have conferred legal resident status on 85,000 people who assert that they are refugees and are living here on temporary permits.

title: Koch Suspends Drexel From a Bond Sale
description: In a symbolic gesture, Mayor Koch suspended Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday from co-managing a $500 million bond sale and recommended that the firm be suspended from a $250 million underwriting for New York City.

title: Museum Returning Antiquities to Egypt
description: The Musuem of Fine Arts here is returning nine fragments of 15th-century B.C. tomb paintings to Egypt because curators have concluded they were stolen from that country, the museum director said today.

title: Libya Offers to Allow Inspection Of Chemical Plant but U.S. Balks
description: Libya has offered to allow an international inspection of a plant that the United States says will be used to make chemical weapons, but Washington has rejected the offer, the State Department said today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Nov. 29 about the suicide of a West German prince, Ludwig Rudolf, identified his father incorrectly. He was Prince Ernst August of Hanover, the Duke of Braunschweig and Luneburg.

title: In Nicaragua, Contras Still Kill Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Fords Seek Power at Ford
description: Edsel B. Ford 2d said he and his cousin William Clay Ford Jr. are pressing Ford's chairman for appointments to two of the auto maker's most powerful committees. Page 31.

title: Broadway Is Reborn In Bombay
description: Two of the biggest hits of the Bombay theater season lately have been English-language revivals of ''Evita'' and ''Kabaret,'' as it is misspelled here on playbills. The success of reworked Broadway musicals with local audiences illustrates the changes that have been emerging in the cultural life of India.

title: Byrd Mass and Motets
description: Louise Basbas is to conduct performances of William Byrd's Mass for Four Voices and motets by Byrd and John Dunstable at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, during a High Mass at 11:15 A.M. tomorrow. Admission is free. Information: 666-9350.

title: Woman Slain by Husband Sought System's Protection
description: When Elizabeth Croff was fatally shot by her estranged husband who then killed himself on Thursday, she had used nearly all the protection the courts and the police in Suffolk County could offer a battered woman, investigators and county officials said today.

title: LEADING INDICATORS SLIP BY 0.2%
description: The Government's main gauge of future economic activity declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in November, continuing an up-and-down pattern that economists say signals a slower-growing economy in 1989 but not a recession.

title: A Writing Workshop
description: The director and lyricist Martin Charnin will teach a five-session workshop, From Page to Stage: Lyric Writing and Directing for the Musical Theater, starting Thursday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The fee is $85. Information: 996-1100.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Post Gains
description: The prices that farmers get for raw products averaged about 14 percent more in December than they did a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Coping: With Heating Bills
description: All homeowners will pay to heat their houses this winter, but some will pay more than they should.

title: For Lockerbie, Therapy of Self-Help
description: Heaped on the pavement in front of the Lockerbie town hall are dozens of floral wreaths and bouquets bearing expressions of sympathy.

title: Problem of Squirrel-Proof Feeder Solved
description: To the Editor:

title: Gertrude Cowan, Editor, 63
description: Gertrude Cowan, a newspaper editor and illustrator who was known professionally as Trudi Cowan, died of cancer yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 63 years old and lived in Merrick, L.I.

title: Bhutto-Gandhi Talks Cordial
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India, children of leaders who faced each other in war, met today in talks that were described as friendly and productive.

title: Plan to Build Huge Mall Under Attack In Rockland
description: To Thomas J. Valenti, a sponsoring partner of the Pyramid Corporation, the site is perfect. It is next to an exit of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and accessible to two heavily traveled highways.

title: Esiason and Bengals Ready for the First Step
description: When Boomer Esiason left the Cincinnati Bengals' practice field today, he was smiling confidently. Considering the way he has played this season, one could hardly blame him.

title: Bears and Eagles Cook Up An Intriguing Playoff Plot
description: The coaches are not exactly drinking buddies. The home team's quarterbacks are not exactly best friends, perhaps because no one seems sure from week to week which one will start. The visiting team knows which of its quarterbacks will start because its entire offense revolves around him.

title: Player Charged In Wife's Death
description: Lewis Bennett, a replacement wide receiver with the Giants during the National Football League players strike in the 1987 season, surrendered to Waterbury police today after his wife was stabbed to death in their Hamden apartment, the police said.

title: Two Texas Banks Close, but Not for Want of Cash
description: On New Year's Eve two more banks will close in Texas. But these two are different from the 113 others that closed in this state in 1988.

title: Dow Off 14.11 but Edns year up 11.8%
description: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday in slow end-of-the-year trading.

title: Spanish Officials Meet With Labor Leaders
description: It took a bitter one-day strike that paralyzed the country and a plea from King Juan Carlos before Government officials and leaders of the two largest labor organizations sat down and talked to each other.

title: Trail of Bomb on Pan Am Jet Is Said to Lead to Frankfurt; New Threat Received
description: An unidentified caller claiming to represent a pro-Iranian group today again took responsibility for the Pan Am bombing and threatened unspecified further action against the United States.

title: Capital Mayor Admits Errors
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry, under Federal investigation for visiting the hotel room of a former city employee who was suspected of drug dealing, said today, ''I'm guilty of poor judgment, no question about it.''

title: Governor Cuomo's New Budget Fantasy
description: As New York State's budget deficit worsens, so do Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed solutions.

title: Review/Dance; 'The Black Tradition' Inspires Ailey Concert
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater promised an evening of drama, ritual, humor and joy, as program notes put it, on Thursday at City Center. The company delivered it all, as well as some very fine dancing.

title: The Company That Makes It '89
description: From the white ball that will descend tonight to mark the start of the new year to the blinking Coca-Cola sign above 47th Street, the neon landscape of Times Square is almost entirely the handiwork of the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation.

title: MacLean, Burke Sit Out
description: The Devils, who have lost their last three games and are without a victory in their last five, will go against the division-leading Penguins in Pittsburgh this afternoon without their leading scorer and leading goaltender.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Pretoria Court Backs Blacks Resisting a Territorial Shift
description: A black rural community won a small but significant victory today in its battle to keep from being forcibly incorporated into a nominally independent black homeland nearby.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington misidentified a District of Columbia Council member. He is Jim Nathanson, not George Nathanson.

title: Insurance Suggested
description: Sean Elliott, Arizona's all-America forward, calls the N.C.A.A. too conservative in its policies toward student-athletes' welfare, and suggests they be afforded some sort of injury insurance coverage.

title: FORD MOTOR TO BUY WEAK SAVING UNITS WITH FEDERAL HELP
description: On the day before key tax breaks expire, Federal regulators today announced three more giant rescues of savings and loan institutions and promised to commit more than $3.7 billion in future aid.

title: Your Money; Finance Planning: Best Time Is Now
description: Unlike those New Year's pledges to shed 15 pounds or do an odd job around the house, resolutions to get one's finances under control actually have a first-of-the-year logic.

title: Raphael Self-Portrait Tested for Authenticity
description: A self-portrait thought to be by Raphael that sold for $10 million nearly 30 years ago is being tested for authenticity.

title: Records Show U.S. Attempt To Drop Gabel From Trial
description: Federal prosecutors secretly tried to sever former Justice Hortense W. Gabel from the Bess Myerson case, contending that the former judge was medically unfit for trial, according to court transcripts unsealed yesterday.

title: Theme for the 90's: A Rebirth of Faith
description: LEAD: Born in 1944 and just turned 44, I am part of a generation - the largest in our history - that is nearing life's halfway point. Ahead of us lie midlife transitions, divorce, depression, career successes and failures and the immense task of digesting changes wrought in part by our enthusiasms of the 1960's and 70's.

title: American Says Soviets Clear Last Hurdle for Him to Leave
description: Abe Stolar, an American who was brought to the Soviet Union as a teen-ager in 1931 and became stranded in a bureaucratic nightmare, said today that an emigration official had promised that his family would be given permission to leave.

title: Miami Is Accused of Chasing Homeless Out of Parade's Way
description: With the approach of the Orange Bowl parade this weekend in downtown Miami, homeless people say they are being harassed by the police and are being told to get out of the area under threat of arrest.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Brooklyn Schools Set Records: Two Brooklyn schools, Prospect Heights and Tilden, broke meet records yesterday at the Brown University interscholastic invitation meet in Providence, R.I. Prospect Heights won the boys' sprint medley relay in 3 minutes 33.8 seconds. Tilden captured the girls' sprint medley in 4:07.3.

title: Tyson Wins Holly Round
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the poultry giant, won a round today in its fight to acquire the Holly Farms Corporation for $1.1 billion when a judge blocked Holly from merging with the Conagra Corporation. The ruling by Judge Maurice

title: Italy's Inflation Rate Up
description: Italy's inflation accelerated to an annual rate of 5.5 percent in December, its highest in more than two years, the National Statistics Institute said today. A three-tenths of 1 percent increase in consumer prices, although lower than the eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in each of the previous two months, took the year-to-year rate to its highest since September 1986. The inflation rate was 5.1 percent at the end of last year. Italy's November trade figures, also released toiday, showed a widening of the deficit to 1.13 trillion lire ($870 million), from 786 billion lire ($604 million) in October. This took the cumulative deficit for the first 11 months of this year to 11.86 trillion lire ($9.1 billion), compared with 10.21 trillion ($7.9 billion) a year earlier.

title: Tompkins Square and Larry Davis
description: The New York City Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board, charged with investigating police violence in August in Tompkins Square Park, accuses virtually all police on the scene of obstructing the inquiry. The implications of that are deeply troubling for the whole city.

title: Review/Music; 2 Carnegie Concerts Mark 20th Year of Student Group
description: Alexander Schneider's New York String Orchestra, which celebrated its 20th anniversary with two Carnegie Hall concerts this week, is more of an educational project than a true ensemble. Its players are students - 60 of them between the ages of 15 and 22 - who have come to New York from conservatories around the country for Mr. Schneider's 11-day seminar in chamber and orchestral playing. The concerts are a kind of valedictory exercise.

title: BELGRADE CABINET QUITS IN A DISPUTE
description: Prime Minister Branko Mikulic and his Cabinet stepped down today in the first resignation by a Yugoslav government since the Communist Party took power after World War II.

title: Relaxing Takes Some Work As Weekends Come to Japan
description: Members of Japan's hard-driving work force will face a vexing problem in the new year: what to do with their Saturdays.

title: Sweating the Small Stuff Pays Off in a Big Way
description: When the San Francisco 49ers schedule a meeting, say, for 1 P.M., here at their sprawling, new $10 million training complex, Roger Craig might be found roaming the place at noon. Or he might be speaking softly into a tape recorder, reminding himself of his goals or setting new ones. He wears a tailor-made game jersey and each week he visits two chiropractors and a massage therapist to keep his body running smoothly.

title: First Fidelity Merger Halted
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation of Philadelphia and Newark and the Montclair Savings Bank of Montclair, N.J., have called off their $80 million merger, announced in July, citing the ''problem loans'' disclosed by First Fidelity earlier this month.

title: SANDERS SCORES 5 TIMES IN ROMP
description: Barry Sanders, the Heisman Trophy winner, ran for 5 touchdowns and 222 yards last night as Oklahoma State routed Wyoming, 62-14, in the Holiday Bowl. Page 45.

title: Champagne, a Magnum Opus
description: LEAD: Who can forget Leslie Caron, Louis Jourdan and Hermione Gingold and the song ''The Night They Invented Champagne'' in ''Gigi''? And what better time to recall that bubbly movie moment than New Year's Eve?

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Blocking Winter Sun
description: The winter sun is lower in the sky, but it still shines brightly, and eyes require just as much protection as they do in summer. Tinted prescription glasses or nonprescription sunglasses will block much of this uncomfortable light and shield eyes from the wind, dust and dirt. For winter sports, glasses should offer adequate protection against ultraviolet light, and the frames should be designed for the sport. If not, the lenses can pop out. The frames should be cushioned and sharp edges should be covered in case of a fall. Impact-resistant lenses, particularly those made of polycarbonates, increase safety. Any lens color that allows the wearer to distinguish between red and green and absorbs 70 percent to 85 percent of light is suitable. Here are some other tips on winter glasses. Lenses: Polycarbonate lenses offer the most protection against breakage, but they tend to scratch more easily. Coatings: Most plastic lenses incorporate material that blocks ultraviolet light. Additional coatings cannot hurt. Antireflective coatings make thick glasses look thinner and reduce glare. Never combine antireflective coatings with scratch-resistant coatings. Fittings: Make sure a licensed optician measures the optical center of the eye with a ruler or pupillometer so that the glasses are aligned properly. (Sources: Dr. Robert Rosenberg, chairman of the department of vision sciences, State University of New York College of Optometry, and the Ophthalmic Dispensing Program at New York City Technical College)

title: Patents; Celebrating The Artistic And Fanciful
description: Necessity is hardly the mother of all inventions. Just ask Donald Spector, inventor of the aromatic record player, swimsuits that change color and, most recently, the popcorn sculpture.

title: Faber Birren, 88, Expert on Color
description: Faber Birren, a color consultant who read and analyzed tastes in the hues deemed most suitable for one's surroundings, died yesterday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital, a week after suffering a stroke. He was 88 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: U.S. and Canada: Model Marriage?
description: For Americans, tonight may be just another New Year's Eve. For Canadians, it's the night they climb nervously into bed with their big, brash neighbor. At midnight, the United States and Canada will join to form a free-trade area that, in big ways and small, will touch the lives of practically everyone in both countries. On a still larger scale, it will also change the way the world trades - possibly for the better, possibly not.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 24 Washington rejected Libya's offer to allow an international inspection of a plant that American officials say is intended to make chemical weapons. Washington said the conditions of the offer are inadequate. Page 1 Trying to head off a panic in Israel over Finance Minister Shimon Peres's 5 percent devaluation of the shekel, the central bank stopped selling or buying foreign currency. 1 Mubarak criticizes Shamir for stance on U.N. Talks 3 No work on Saturdays in Japan, the government has told its financial industry as it seeks to persuade people to work less and spend more. The action takes effect over the next few weeks. 1 A new Japanese Justice Minister was named after scandal forced the previous minister to resign after only three days in office. The new official is Masami Takatsuji, a career bureaucrat and former judge. 24 Lockerbie, Scotland, is recovering from the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 last week. People there are moving beyond the initial shock of the disaster and beginning to rebuild their homes and their lives. 3

title: Florida Drops Inquiry Into Use of Donations
description: The state has dropped its criminal investigation into Maria DeSillers's handling of almost $700,000 donated for her late son's liver transplants, a state prosecutor said today.

title: Princeton Upsets South Carolina
description: Upsetting No. 16 South Carolina was a nice way to end a three-game losing streak, said Bob Scrabis of Princeton.

title: Guerrillas of Polisario Front Agree to Truce in the Sahara
description: Algerian-backed guerrillas fighting Morocco for control of the Western Sahara have declared a truce in the desert war pending talks with King Hassan II, the Algerian press agency said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AHSC Acquisition Corp. said that its $31-a-share tender offer for Alco Health Services Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., had been oversubscribed.

title: BRIDGE
description: For the second time, Italian bridge organizers have taken a big step toward displaying bridge to a large audience.

title: Few Joys in This World: Life in Criminal Court
description: New York was on vacation from itself this week, awash in tourists, tinsel and lights. But in some places, the spirit of the holidays did not reach.

title: 25 Vehicles Hit, Trucker Held
description: A truck driver was arrested today after he rammed his tractor-trailer into 25 cars, seriously injuring at least two people, in an 80-mile chase at speeds of up to 90 miles an hour during morning rush-hour, the authorities said. Stephen Odell Dillard, 41, of Coolidge, Ga., was charged with possession of cocaine and was held in the Medina County Jail in Hondo in lieu of $50,000 bond.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The legal holiday for New Year's Day is Monday. Below are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No street cleanings or collection. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; Metro-North on holiday schedule; Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Most closed; local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit buses on Saturday schedule, trains on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: 8 in a Row for Cavaliers
description: Ron Harper scored 22 points tonight and Brad Daugherty added 20 as the Cleveland Cavaliers tied a team record with their eighth consecutive victory, a 127-110 triumph over the Washington Bullets.

title: Businesses Near Illinois Base Fear for Survival
description: This military training base has anchored this part of central Illinois since 1917, which is why a Federal proposal to shut down the base has shaken nearby residents. They say they not only see dying businesses and empty schools but also fear a breaking up of families and friendships.

title: Ira Hertan, 58, Lawyer and Philanthropist
description: Ira J. Hertan, a lawyer who was active in the Long Island Jewish community, died of lung cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Reagan and Bush Get Subpoenas To Testify as Witnesses for North
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush were subpoenaed today to testify as defense witnesses for Oliver L. North at his trial on conspiracy charges stemming from the Iran-contra affair.

title: McGirt to Fight
description: James (Buddy) McGirt of Brentwood, L.I,, a former International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion, will fight Manuel DeLeon of the Dominican Republic in a 10-round bout on Jan. 12 at the Felt Forum. The fight will be McGirt's first since Sept. 3, when he lost the title to Meldrick Taylor. (AP)

title: Not a Vintage Year
description: It was the year of Geraldo Rivera pleading with America not to let the children watch this next segment.

title: Problem of Squirrel-Proof Feeder Solved; 'The Astronaut'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans for a day-care center at Police Headquarters in New York City misstated the estimated cost per child for the day-care service. It is $110 a week, not $110 a month.

title: Unisys Contract On Medical Data
description: The Government awarded a five-year, $15.9 million contract to the Unisys Corporation to operate a data bank on malpractice suits and disciplinary actions filed nationwide against doctors and dentists.

title: Southmark Report On Five Trusts
description: The Southmark Corporation said the five real estate investment trusts it advises are likely to post substantial write-downs and increase loss reserves because of declining real estate prices. The five trusts are Income Opportunity Realty, Johnstown/Consolidated Realty, Consolidated Capital Realty, Consolidated Capital Income and Consolidated Capital Special. In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Southmark also said the S.E.C. might take administrative action against Consolidated Capital Income and Consolidated Capital Special.

title: Wrong Place for Nehemiah
description: Why would a city in desperate need of affordable housing spurn another Nehemiah plan, the church-based project that contends it is the most efficient producer of such housing in New York? That's what backers of the group that would put a Nehemiah project in Far Rockaway are asking. The answer is clear: The city has reason to spurn even Nehemiah for housing in the wrong place.

title: Eugene M. Gervasi, 51, Author of Nonfiction
description: Eugene Michael Gervasi, an author and former public relations director, died yesterday at University Hospital in Richmond, after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Richmond.

title: Price Paid for Rolm May Reach $1.1 Billion
description: Siemens A.G., the West German electronics group, disclosed today that it would pay up to $1.15 billion for the Rolm telecommunications business that it agreed to buy from the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month.

title: The New-Fashioned Way To Steal Money: Fake Credit
description: The weapon of choice among bank robbers these days is the credit card: it provides them with millions of dollars in cash and products each year.

title: 15 Held in Cocaine Ring; One Is a Drug Counselor
description: A counselor at a Harlem drug clinic was arrested yesterday and charged with 14 others with being part of a cocaine- and crack-distribution ring on Long Island, Federal officials said.

title: All Night Long
description: The Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52d Street, is to feature ballroom dancing to the big-band sounds of the Tony Martell Orchestra and the Latin rhythms of the Emilio Reyes Orchestra tonight. Dancing is from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Admission: $25. The Roseland Disco will be open 1 A.M. to 6 A.M., and Judy Torres and Denise Lopez are to sing. Admission: $25. Information: 247-0200.

title: Surgery for Sampson
description: The Golden State Warriors announced yesterday that Ralph Sampson's arthroscopic knee surgery was successful and that they had found a player to fill in during Sampson's absence. The team said 6-foot-10-inch John Stroeder, who spent three weeks with the Warriors in the preseason, would sign a 10-day contract on Monday. Stroeder was averaging 15.3 points and 10.6 rebounds this season with the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association.
